column2: LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Sir John William Fortescue, historian, former librarian of Windsor Castle, died today at Cannes, France, on the eve of the publication of his "History of the British Army." This great work of thirteen volumes occupied him for thirty years.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Robert Randolph Meyer and Miss Kitty Barrett gave a buffet supper at their cottage tonight. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Dewey, Mrs. Graham Davis, Miss Natalie Davis and Raymond Verden of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw of Boston.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Investigation of the Lindbergh kidnapping, concentrated here today with the arraignment of John Gorch, 38, accused as a swindler, will shift to New York tomorrow when Federal authorities will investigate the contents of a safe deposit box held in Gorch's name in a New York bank.

Mr. and Mrs. Longstreet Hinton gave a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Wright 3d, Miss Patricia Coffin and William B. Shepard, Mrs. Wright is the former Miss Marie Beatrice Shepard.

Twenty shots were fired in the dark in the stableyard of the Sheffield Farms Dairy Company plant at 183 Williams Avenue, in the East New York district of Brooklyn, last night in a pistol battle between ten detectives and four alleged safe-crackers. One of the alleged safe-crackers was killed, one was wounded and another was injured in a twenty-foot jump.

HAVANA, Oct. 23 -- The Army-Student government, headed by Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, faced increasing difficulties today with additional strikes called and labor leaders consolidating their forces for bringing about a general strike to paralyze commerce and industry throughout the island.

Aside from sizable rallies in foreign loans, particularly those dollar issues on which the interest is being paid at the gold parity of exchange, the bond market on the Stock Exchange gave little response to the gold policy outlined by President Roosevelt.
PARIS, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- The French Cabinet headed by Premier Daladier resigned at 3:55 A.M. today, following upon its defeat by a vote of lack of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies.

Walter S. Franklin withdrew yesterday from the receiverships of the Wabash and Ann Arbor Railways to become vice president of traffic with the Pennsylvania Railroad, which controls the two former lines. Norman B. Pitcairn, president of the Detroit, Toledo Ironton, another Pennsylvania-controlled road, succeeds Mr. Franklin.

Railroad officials made no comment officially yesterday on the reduction in the price of rails from $40 to $37.75 a ton, announced on Saturday by the steel industry, but it was thought certain that substantial orders would result.

The New York University football squad began preparations for its intersectional battle with the University of Georgia at Athens on Saturday by engaging in a spirited drill at Ohio Field yesterday. The practice, which lasted for more than two hours, was confined to fundamentals and the correction of flaws.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Army plays figured in the defensive strategy on which Yale concentrated in the practice on Anthony Thompson Field today.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- The recent direct representations by Ambassador William E. Dodd and the constant pressure from the American Consulate General in Berlin regarding assaults upon Americana and other foreigners who did not salute the Nazi flag in Nazi fashion have resulted in the sending of a new circular on the subject to the authorities throughout Prussia.

The charge that "influential groups of industry" are engaged in "undercover efforts" to defeat the purposes of the National Recovery Act, a circumstance which has checked the progress of the recovery program, was made yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A decidedly bullish construction was placed today by the grain trade on President Roosevelt's remarks regarding advancing agricultural prices, and while there was no rush of outside buying to the Board of Trade prices there rose sharply with a noticeable lack of pressure except such as came from profit-taking longs.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The contention of Vice Chancellor John J. Fallon of Jersey City that the Chancellor of New Jersey did nothave the power to direct a public inquiry into the official acts or private conduct of Vice Chancellors was upheld here today in an opinion by the Court of Errors and Appeals.

Mayor O'Brien yesterday joined the ranks of the "unbossed" candidates for the Mayoralty. In a luncheon address before the City Club, and in a radio speech over WOR, he declared that "machine politics" had never governed his acts in the Mayor's office.

EAST VIEW, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Spot, a black and white dog of undetermined origin, began a 100day sentence in the county penitentiary here today with four youths who had pleaded guilty to shooting pheasants out of season at Somers, N.Y., yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The wedding of Miss Doris Warner, daughter of Harry M. Warner, president of the Warner Brothers-First National Pictures, and Mervyn Le Roy, one of the company's directors, will take place next month. Miss Warner, whose home is in New York, is visiting here.

The payment of approximately $900,000 of interest on first and second mortgage bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company by the receivers for the Interborough was ordered yesterday by Judge Julian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- Armament experts who drew up the tables of figures on possible German rearmament, published last Thursday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, stood by them today despite a semi-official denial of their correctness issued in Berlin yesterday.

Kansas does business as a State under the inspiring motto, in Latin, "Through Rough Sledding to the Stars." While the misguided farmers of some other States are going on strike, bucolic Kansas has the stars spread at her feet. Imperturbable, the State Board of Agriculture pursues its wonted way, amassing and emitting helpful information, reaching its glad and gladdening hand into every farmhouse.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The agricultural arm of the government was particularly gratified today by President Roosevelt's authorization to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to purchase newly mined gold in the United States, ostensibly to increase commodity prices, and by his pledge to increase the return to farmers for their products.

Harold Thurber, a veteran of the jockey ranks, scored a consecutive double in the third and fourth races at Empire City yesterday, riding two 3-year-olds with much of his old-time skill. The winners were Maxwell Howard's Orphean in the third and F.M. Taylor's Help Me in the Hudson Valley Purse.

The list of the Cunarder Berengaria, leaving tonight for the Channel ports, includes M. Foldi, managing director of Az Est, daily newspaper of Budapest, and Mrs. Foldi; Sidney B. Kent, president of the Fox Film Corporation, and the following:

Gertrude Stein's "The Making of Americans," which once was a book 925 pages long, is to be brought out in a "condensed" edition this Spring by Harcourt, Brace. Miss Stein worked on the book from 1906 through 1908, and in 1925 it was published by Contact Editions at Dijon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Attorney General Cummings tonight ruled that after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment the Volstead Act "will be in full force and effect in the District of Columbia, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and the Canal Zone."
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt's latest currency plan is receiving the widest editorial notice here.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- A challenge to churchmen everywhere to apply Catholicism as a "social gospel" for wiping out political, economic and social ills was heard tonight by 2,000 delegates to the sixth Catholic Congress of the Episcopal Church.

John H. McCooey, recently recovered from his illness, held a meeting of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee yesterday, discussed with twenty district leaders the Mayoralty campaign, arranged rally dates and conferred individually with several of his confidants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt today authorized extension until Nov. 30, 1933, of the time for the special review boards to complete the review of veterans' compensation cases, which, under existing regulations, were to have been completed on Oct. 31.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- The governing body of the League of Nations' International Labor Organization began here today its sixty-fourth session, with all present except the German members.

Headliners of the old days of variety attended the funeral service yesterday afternoon for Lome Haskell, known in the profession, as Loney, vaudeville actor and secretary of the Jewish Theatrical Guild of America, Inc.

Samuel Untermyer, who was one of the first to condemn Joseph V. McKee, independent candidate for Mayor, for his published criticism of some of the younger generation of Jews, replied yesterday to four distinguished Jews, who issued a statement Sunday, deprecating the introduction of any religious issue into the Mayoralty campaign.

Demountable finger nails and eye lashes, painted hair and other beauty aids that looked like passing fads a year ago are holding their own in the annual American Beauty and Styles Exposition which opened yesterday morning in the Grand Central Palace.

Holders of bonds of the Arizona Steam Generating Company and bonds and stocks of the Arizona Power Company have been notified by P.B. Lee, head of the readjustment committee, of the formulation of a plan contemplating the organization of a company to acquire the assets of the old ones and to issue new securities in exchange for theirs.

Interpreting President Roosevelt's new gold policy as inflationary, speculators bought stocks and commodities heavily yesterday, causing one of the sharpest rises in several months. This movement was accompanied by a rapid decline in the dollar in terms of foreign currencies.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, last night called as character witnesses four newspapers, The World-Telegram, THE NEW YORK TIMES, The Herald Tribune and The Evening Post, which are opposing his candidacy.
PHILADELPHIA, t. 23 (AP) -- Temple University announced tonight that five of the games on the 1934 football schedule have been arranged, four of them intersectional in nature.

Fordham's football team, still undefeated and untied, began vigorous preparations at Fordham Field yesterday for the invasion of one of its strongest 1933 opponents. The Maroon will clash with the powerful University of Alabama team at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Conversations between President Roosevelt and Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff of Russia are expected in official circles here to lead swiftly to a definite conclusion.

The successful medical specialist should maintain close contact with all fields of medicine as well as with his own specialty, Dr. Bernard Sachs, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, said last night.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The possibility that Moscow may seek some sort of understanding with Washington regarding Japan, if forthcoming conversations between President Roosevelt and Foreign Commissar Litvinoff bring the desired recognition, was seen in foreign circles here tonight.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA, made public yesterday a report submitted to him by the NRA credit committee, showing, according to Mr. Whalen, that there was no foundation for the charge that banks had failed to cooperate in the recovery program by withholding credit from business men legitimately entitled to it.

IT'S a long way from Portland, Ore., to the Strand, London. This is definite and nothing much can be done about it. But there is a loose connection somewhere. The football game that was played between Southern California and Oregon State, for instance.
The comment of leading newspapers throughout the country on the gold plan of President Roosevelt follows in part:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Farm Adjustment Administration today announced that rates of payment to growers of cigar leaf tobacco who reduced their acreage this year had been increased.

Alderman Joseph Kinsey of the Bronx announced last night that at the request of Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, he would introduce at today's meeting of the Board of Aldermen bills to repeal the 50 per cent increase in water rates and the five-cent tax on taxicab rides imposed recently by the O'Brien administration.

The Red Star liner Lapland, which has operated in the transatlantic service for twenty-five years, has been sold to shipbreakers and will be dismantled, it was announced yesterday by P.V.G. Mitchell, vice president of the Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company, owners of the line.

Statistics showing the relative growth of church membership in the United States divided among Evangelical, Liberal and Roman Catholic were presented yesterday by the Rev. Dr. G.L. Kieffer, statistician of the National Lutheran Council, before a meeting of Concordia, an organization of Lutheran ministers, in St. John's Lutheran Church House, 83 Christopher Street.
The text of the address by Joseph V. McKee over radio station WOR last night follows:

Mrs. Velda Tindall, 26-year-old cowgirl, was critically injured last night during the trick and fancy riding contest at the Rodeo in Madison Square Garden when a strap broke as she slipped out of the saddle and tried, with the horse at the gallop to crawl under the animal and regain her seat.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Sir Job Simon, Foreign Secretary, will not go to Geneva for either the meeting of the disarmament conference's bureau on Wednesday or the meeting of the disarmament commission Thursday. The Foreign Office will be represented at both sessions by Captain An the ay Eden, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. and his secretary. Miss Ada L. Burroughs, obtained a Supreme Court review today of the District of Columbia Appeals Court ruling that they must be tried on charges of violating the Corrupt Practices Act.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The text of the statement issued by General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, after President Roosevelt had signed the Retail Code, follows:

There is a special timeliness in Henry Varnum Poor's one-man show at the Rehn Gallery, since Mr. Poor has just drawn a prize at the Carnegie International in Pittsburgh with his figure subject, entitled "March Sun," discussed on the art page of THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 23 -- The strike of students of the University of Puerto Rico in protest against the appointment of Rafael Alonzo Torres, a Socialist, as trustee of the institution, spread today to the College of Agriculture at Mayaguez and to the San Juan High School.

Herbert Kluge of the German-American A.C. scored a one-round knockout victory over George Turner, unattached, in the heavyweight special bout, which featured the semi-monthly amateur boxing program at the New York Athletic Club last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The administration moved today to put into immediate operation its plan for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to purchase gold, as announced by President Roosevelt in a radio speech last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In an effort to arrive quickly at a figure for liquor taxes to be used as a basis for reconstruction of the whole taxation structure of the government, a Ways and Means subcommittee met here today to sift a collection of data already amassed by Treasury experts.

PARIS, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- Premier Edouard Daladier's government has been beaten. By 329 votes to 241 the Chamber of Deputies at nearly 3 o'clock this morning rejected an amended version of an article of the financial bill reducing the salaries of civil servants on which the Premier had asked a vote of confidence.
Covering the six-mile course in 32:33, Marvin Stern led the City, College cross-country team to a 25-to-30 triumph over Fordham at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The master code for more than 1,000,000 retailers prohibits selling below invoice cost plus an allowance for store wages, and exempts from Its provisions employers hiring fewer than five persons in towns of less than 2,500 population, it was revealed today with announcement that President Roosevelt signed the code last night.

Blase Mary Gets Up. From the women's colleges it is reported that the spirit of "blase indifference" which managed to hang on through the first three years of economic depression has now entirely disappeared.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Celebrating Irish Night at the World's Fair Horse Show, the Irish Free State Army's team wrested the lead from the United States Army representatives in the International Military Trophy jumping competition this evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Henry Ware Allen's letter he stated that "What the farmers really need and this is what they themselves repeatedly state, is to be relieved of the excessive taxes now put upon them and then be let alone by the government."

While the response of the speculative markets to President Roosevelt's Sunday night radio address was probably more cautious than might have been expected in the circumstances, there was an impressive advance in the general level of prices on the domestic exchanges.
The texts of the addresses by Major Gen. Harbord and F.H. LaGuardia over radio station WABC last night follow:

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- The Boerse began the week with cautious optimism. While the stock market was generally quiet, specialties were able to register gains up to 3 per cent. Bonds generally were firm, some municipal loans gaining up to 2 1/2 per cent.

Among economists yesterday President Roosevelt's reference in his Sunday night radio address to a dollar "which will not change its purchasing and debt-paying power during the succeeding generation" was interpreted as meaning a commodity, or compensating, dollar.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Organized railway labor extended its moral support tonight to the farmstrike movement.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- While heavy butcher hogs and packing sows sold today at steady prices, light weights dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds. The extreme top was off 15 cents at $4.50, while the day's average was 10 cents lower than yesterday at $4.15.

There was written into the civil service clause of the State Constitution in 1929 an unfortunate amendment granting an absolute preference, both in appointment and in promotion, "without regard to their standing on any list" of eligibles, to all veterans who were citizens and residents of New York both at the time of their enlistment and at the time of their application for such appointment or promotion.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 21 (By Air Mail) -- A research expedition has just been completed to the remote ruins of the Maya city of Palenque, in the heart of the jungle in the State of Chiapas, Mexico. The ruins represent the most interesting and beautiful group of the very ancient Maya-Quiche civilization, perhaps the most notable on the American Continent.

The city's financial collapse might well spell disaster to the national movement for economic recovery and possibly have an international effect, according to Henry Morgenthau Sr., former Ambassador to Turkey.

A chase through Central Park's west drive of four robbery suspects ended at fifty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue early today when their car skidded on the wet pavement and turned over. Three of the four extricated themselves and escaped on foot toward Ninth Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Cosgrave's comment on, Dr. Crile's theory is interesting, illuminating and puzzling. Certainly it must be a matter of enlightenment to many to know that "the Darwinian theory of evolution has been abandoned by advanced thinkers" and that "the theory; of special creation is coining back."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- To thirteen Yale sophomores today were awarded New York Yale Club prizes and charms at a meeting in Woodbridge Hall of the freshman faculty, on the basis of their work as freshmen. The prizes and charms were presented by President Angell.

Werner Josten's "Concerto Sacro No. 1," a composition of singular and exalted eloquence, was the novelty of the program given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- There were 428 licensed national banks in New York State on Oct. 16, with aggregate deposits of $3,679,091,000, Controller of the Currency J.F.T. O'Conner announced today.

The City Campaign. Joseph V. McKee charged that F.H. LaGuardia opposed the election of President Roosevelt and aligned his campaign closer with the administration with the slogan "A vote for McKee is a vote for Roosevelt."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) -- One of the "marrying Mdivanis," Georgian princes, was cast off in divorce court today.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- In the midst of a flood of protests that all Germany wants is peace, the German Government took still another step today in severance of its relations with the peace-making activities of Geneva by resigning also its membership in the International Labor Office, established there under the League of Nations.

MR. LOU LITTLE said he didn't feel well enough to talk -- poor chap, he was clawed 'orribly by a Tiger just a few days ago -- but Chick Meehan was in good voice. He took up a lot of points and set them in order.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- From the mass of gossip, guessing and rival propaganda that thus far constitutes the bulk of the evidence before the German Supreme Court in the Reichstag fire trial there emanated today what looked like a genuine clue to the real events of the night of Feb. 27.

Discussing the mistakes which happened in the officiating at two of the football games on Saturday, a former All-American player who has done his share of officiating in the past, though now retired, offered some pertinent comment yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- A government activity was lacking today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and while local professionals generally expressed bullish views they could not hold up prices after having caused an advance of about 2 1/2 cents a bushel from the early low, and the finish was at net losses of 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents.

NICE, France, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Two Riviera casinos, owned by Frank Jay Gould but operated by a French syndicate, have been crippled by a government order suspending twenty-four members of the gambling staff on charge of irregularities amounting to 15,000,000 francs [about $840,000].

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Buffeted about by gusty winds and rain squalls, the Graf Zeppelin, winner of many battles with the elements, cruised over the Akron air dock tonight, its landing postponed until morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Preliminary estimates of the value of retail sales of new automobiles, computed from number of cars sold as reported by the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, show an increase of 77 per cent for September over September, 1932, and a decrease of 14 per cent as compared with August of this year.

New York University's football squad participated in a lengthy outdoor drill at Ohio Field yesterday. Despite the steady rain, the workout lasted more than two hours and was featured by a scrimmage in which the varsity opposed the C team, the latter employing Georgia plays.

New York State borrowed $29,500,000 yesterday through the sale of long-term bonds at an interest cost of 3.43767 per cent. Although the rate was not so favorable as those of the last previous State bond sales, Controller Morris S. Tremaine expressed himself as satisfied that a fair price had been obtained consistent with present conditions.

"Let us clear our minds of cant." Better still, let the voters of this city clear their minds of all the irrelevancies, the personal animosities, the violent and unproved charges, the petty and provocative issues which have been threatening to dominate the municipal campaign.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, women's Eastern golf champion and former New Jersey titleholder, today denied a report from Mexico, D.F., that she would play in the Mexican championship.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Three stakes were completed today at the opening of the tenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association despite inclement weather conditions. The cover, unusually heavy this year, was sodden and in some places practically impenetrable.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The Irish Free State Army team took first and third places in the international military pair jumping competition at the World's Fair Horse Show tonight. The United States Army team from Fort Riley, Kan., was second and the Swedish team fourth.

The Australian thoroughbred, Winooka, will oppose four American racers of ability at Laurel this afternoon, but he will not meet C. V. Whitney's Equipoise on Nov. 7, regardless of whether he wins today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Large personal loans to former Presidents Machado and Menocal of Cuba by the Chase National Bank and to Carlos Miguel de Cespedes, Secretary of Public Works in the former's Cabinet, were bared today by the Senate Banking Committee in its investigation of the bank's Cuban financing.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24. -- There is some surprise in Moscow that Japan has failed to answer the Soviet publication of alleged secret Japanese official documents concerning a reported plan for seizure of the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 -- Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, today told the Associated Traffic Clubs of America, in convention here, that business recovery not only Had started, but was gaining momentum every day.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a broadcast from the White House, addressed a dinner given in honor of Miss M. Carey Thomas, president emeritus of Bryn Mawr College and founder of the Affiliated Schools for Workers, at the Park Lane Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Roosevelt, in an executive order issued today, established the procedure for administering provisions of the National Recovery Act designed to control imports which "are rendering ineffective and seriously endangering the maintenance of codes or agreements under the National Industrial Recovery Act."

At the close of the State's case late yesterday in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel on an indictment charging that he abetted in misapplication of $2,000,000 of funds of the defunct Bank of United States, Justice Taylor in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court took under advisement the defense counsel's motion for a directed acquittal.

The Mayoralty campaign claimed another casualty last night when Harry Polick, 38 years old, of 3,035 Ripple Street, Brighton Beach, was removed to the Coney Island Hospital suffering from multiple contusions of the face and body and possibly fractures of the left shoulder and wrist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the NRA, announced today the personnel of the Retail Trade Authority, which immediately begins administering the retail code approved yesterday by President Roosevelt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Because of the wet condition of Anthony Thompson Field today the Yale eleven spent another day in dummy scrimmage, largely centred around defensive tactics for the Army attack.

Despite the heavy downpour, Fordham's football squad worked for nearly three hours on Fordham Field yesterday, losing no time in preparing for the invasion of the sturdy University of Alabama eleven at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, who, though "no motion picture fan at all," accepted the presidency of the Motion Picture Research Council, today urged regulations in the "movie code" to prohibit such practices as block-booking and blind-buying and to bar salacious films.

Julius Hallheimer, as referee on an accounting of the American estate of Consuelo, Dowager Duchess of Manchester, by the United States Trust Company and Thomas B. Gilchrist, decided yesterday that the present wife of the Duke of Manchester and not his divorced wife was entitled to share in the income of the residuary estate.

Timothy J. Mara, sports promotor, and Patrick F. Kenny, plumbing contractor, won yesterday the suits against them for $50,000 and $20,000, respectively, by the County Trust Company on notes. The verdict was returned by a jury before Supreme Court Justice McCook after more than seven hours' deliberation.
Mrs. Baxter Jackson of 1,088 Park Avenue gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for her mother, Mrs. Thomas G. Ratcliffe of St. Louis, and her aunt, Mrs. George Leith of London.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 24 -- The need of keeping the distribution of cotton and flour away from governmental departments was stressed here today by Representative Robert Low Bacon, speaking at the annual regional conference of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A letter written by James Bruce, then a vice president of the Chase National Bank, to Joseph Rovensky another vice president of the bank as introduced at the Senate Banking Committee's inquiry today, revealed that former President Machado worried the State Department here by using $9,000,000 out of a $12,000,000 Cuban Government trust fund.

The news that the RFC would begin purchases of gold today at prices above the world market under President Roosevelt's new monetary policy caused a rapid depreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange yesterday. In the widest movement since April the dollar fell 3.47 cents to 66.74 per cent of parity, measured against the French franc.
A city-wide Inquiry among employers, designed to check up on what the NRA has accomplished in New York City in increasing employment and payrolls, will be started by the NRA organization today.

Stocks and commodities continued yesterday to advance in terms of a cheaper dollar. This merely conformed to the previous day's pattern and represented the market's response to the announcement that the United States Government was embarking upon a currency-depreciation policy of a scope that is yet to be defined.

The New York State Advisory Board of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works announced yesterday that it had forwarded to Washington applications for loans and grants of $6,435,950 for eighteen projects in various parts of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Nearly 10,000 persons, attending a high mass at the Municipal Conventin Hall today, heard the Right Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and also Bishop of the Diocese of Rhode Island, sound a call for religious unity.

Dr. Hermann Weyl, one of the leading mathematicians of the world, arrived last night with his wife and two sons on the Cunard liner Laconia to accept a professorship in the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton. Formerly Professor of Mathematics at the University of Goettingen, Dr. Weyl, as well as several colleagues, abandoned his post there as a protest against the Nazi removal of the Jewish faculty.

The season just closed witnessed the closest possible struggle for the championship of the newly organized Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association between the Brooklyn Cricket Club and the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club. An extra game was required to decide the tie between them in the regular series, with Brooklyn eventually victorious.

Trial of a suit in equity brought by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, against the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company and Henry E. Cooper, as conservator of the bank, to recover a large amount of securities was continued yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz.

Anticipating early repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment business leaders of the Broadway district, as represented by the Broadway Association, met yesterday to discuss possible means of restoring the prestige of the "Great White Way" of former days.

HAVANA, Oct. 24 -- Commercial firms in Havana were closed today owing to a twenty-four-hour strike of the clerks' union in sympathy with striking employes of Woolworth's. Only the cafes, restaurants and small grocery stores opened for business.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 24 -- The Georgia Bulldogs were sent through another arduous defensive practice today for Saturday's battle against New York University.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24. -- Owners of frozen credits here are keenly interested in the Spanish proposal to import 15,748,000 bushels of Argentine corn, to be purchased with Spanish frozen credits.

ATHENS, Oct. 24 -- Today's hearing in the extradition proceedings against Samuel Insull was occupied mainly by a long argument by Christos Ladas of the defense counsel. He attacked sharply the summary of the Federal dossier prepared by Herbert Huling of New York, asking why this professional accountant was employed, although there were no complaints from investors.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 24 -- D.O. (Tuss) McLaughry, head football coach at Brown University, today censured the decision on a blocked kick in the Brown-Yale game Saturday, which robbed Brown of a possible score, and denied he and the team "apparently accepted the ruling without protest."

Further covering of shorts, which improved the technical positions of the markets and renewed long buying on the weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange, resulted yesterday in further substantial advances in active commodities traded here.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Speaking at a meeting in the chapel of Drew University tonight, Dr. Friedrich Schoenemann, Professor of American Literature of the University of Berlin, declared that "the new Germany under Hitler is achieving a new dignity, solidarity and a sense of social jutsice that it has lacked since the World War."

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Germany's master spellbinder, came before the people of Berlin tonight and pleaded for that unanimous endorsement of the policy of his government in Geneva that he is almost certain to receive, together with a new Reichstag of his own choosing, when Germany goes to the polls three weeks hence.
Mayor O'Brien carried his reprisal campaign into another borough yesterday when he dismissed Alvert C. Benninger, Queens Park Commissioner, for his support of Joseph V. McKee's candidacy.

The order in which candidates for the five vacancies on the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District will be listed upon voting machines for the Nov. 7 election was decided upon yesterday by the Board of Elections. The board's action followed a decision of the Court of Appeals, handed down at Albany, denying an attempt to strike from the ballot the names of the Recovery party candidates for the judicial posts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The future of the petroleum industry depends upon the success of the government's control of crude oil production, but that control should not extend to governmental operation of the industry after the present emergency, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, told 1,000 oil producers and marketers attending the opening session of the annual meeting at the Stevens Hotel today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Harvard started its practice today in the baseball cage, where a long workout on defense against Dartmouth plays was held.

Nazi Mistakes Censured. Nazi storm troopers who may be tempted to assault foreigners for omitting to salute the Hitler insignia must please try to remember that such acts are a serious embarrassment to the German Foreign Office.

IN England, if you mention the name of Major C.H. Douglas in orthodox financial circles, very probably your listener will foam at the mouth. In America not so much is known of the man. A number of articles on his "social credit" proposals have appeared in magazines this side of the water, and the American Douglasites now have their own organ of expression called The New Democracy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Public works Advisory Board today allocated $22,974,900 for Federal projects upon which work will begin within a few days. For public buildings the board approved total awards of $14,208,400 for construgtion of eighty-six postal substations in seven large cities.
Following is the address made last night by Henry Morgenthau Sr. over Station WEAF: New York must permanently restore its shattered credit.
Mayor John P. O'Brien took himself back to "the old days at Holy Cross" in a brief appearance last night before the members of the Non-Partisan Academic League at the Hotel Biltmore.
BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- The upward movement in bonds continued on the Boerse today, gains ranging from 1 to 2 per cent. Stocks, on the other hand, turned soft, although changes remained only fractional.

The attempt to link John Gorch, under arrest in Boston on a swindling charge, with the Lindbergh kidnapping seemed yesterday to be another one of the hundreds of chimerical clues followed by Federal, State and local detectives.

Charging an "elaborate system of fraud and corruption" in workmen's compensation cases, Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, demanded last night that the city insure its employes in the State Insurance Fund as a matter of economy and justice.

Reports from Long Island, where the seasons on upland game birds, wild waterfowl and some species of animals begin on Nov. 1, indicate that good sport awaits the shooters. Quail, some snipe and rails in certain sections have been sighted.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Although the aid of the British Foreign Office was immediately sought, The Daily Telegraph late tonight had been unable to establish contact with Noel Panter, its correspondent, who was arrested in Munich on a charge of "suspected espionage."

The Columbia football team was out in full force yesterday at Baker Field preparing for its encounter with Penn State here on Saturday. The rain resulted in the outdoor session being limited to one hour, but Coach Lou Little and his assistants lectured to the players indoors for nearly an hour.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Robert Mantell Jr., 21-year-old son of the distinguished Shakespearean actor, faced a mirror in his home here early today and fired a pistol bullet into his head.

Mr. LAGUARDIA spoke yesterday of the low esteem in which, people from other parts of the country hold New York City. It would be easy to exaggerate this had character; it certainly has not prevented thousands from journeying to the metropolis to visit its galleries and museums, its shops and theatres, and even to seek their fortune here.

Although the relief situation in New York City was slightly improved during September as compared to other recent months, it is still far worse than during the corrosponding period last year, according to a summary of expenditures of relief agencies made public yesterday by the Welfare Council.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The French Cabinet's defeat early this morning by the combined votes of the larger part of the Socialist party and the Right has caused a political crisis that will be difficult to solve. President Albert Lebrun spent today consulting the leaders of all parties, but it is the general opinion that discussion of the situation will last some days before any one is invited to try to form a new government.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 24 -- The Dartmouth varsity again occupied a minor role in practice today as the C and D combinations scrimmaged for the second successive day. A blizzard of snow and sleet did not hamper the scrimmage, from, which, emerged several promising players who have no major game experience.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, in a speech in the Sportpalast, today pleaded with Germany to endorse his regime in its efforts to win equality for Germany abroad and domestic peace at home.
GALWAY, Irish Free State, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh were eager to continue their journey tonight because Mrs. Lindbergh is "terribly anxious to see my baby."

As time goes on Philip DeLaszlo's portrait manner looks more and more reminiscent of the chic of yesteryear. His exhibition at Knoedler's, remaining on through this week, contains several thoroughly representative examples of the sort of slick surface bravura that has for so long walked nonchalantly, arm in arm, with the term "fashionable."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- The cruiser Chicago, a new American fighting ship, was badly damaged, two members of her crew died of injuries, another was seriously hurt and a fourth was missing after a collision today with the British freighter Silver Palm.

Nothing but a strong sense of duty drives this column to press this morning. Daniel N. Rubin, who has written some good plays, and Al Woods, "who has produced some successful ones, have squired a considerable piece of hokum m "Move On, Sister," which was put on at the Playhouse last evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Proof that the Recovery Act has served to increase hourly earnings and spread employment was offered today by Secretary Perkins in a statement indicating that during September the codes have brought a substantial increase in average hourly earnings and a decrease in hours worked per week, attended by a rise in employment.

Although interest was centred yesterday in a comparatively large group of stocks which traders and investors seemed to be accumulating in some volume, the market did not advance uniformly, nor did it display firmness all day. There were occasional periods of weakness, and several prominent stocks moved lower at one time or another.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 21:

MONTREAL, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press) -- With three skating sessions behind them, the New York Rangers will enter the second phase of their training program when Lester Patrick lines them up for their first scrimmage tomorrow morning.

GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- The fall of the Daladier Cabinet in France accentuated today the trend toward having the bureau of the disarmament conference recommend tomorrow that the general commission adjourn for three or four weeks, leaving the bureau to carry on by drafting treaty texts.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Discovery that the composition of the sun's corona, one of the major mysteries of the universe, consists, in part at least, of oxygen in a high state of excitation, was announced here tonight by Processor Harlow Shapley, Director of the Harvard College Observatory.
The seventh annual drive of the New York City Cancer Committee was opened yesterday at a luncheon of the women's committee of the organization at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

In his address at the Chicago Exposition, Governor SMITH turned his face from the living present. It was natural that he should ascribe the past " century of progress " to those causes which the Democratic party, either from, faith in or lip-service to the old shibboleth, long championed.

The Fusion campaign was centred in the Bronx last night with F.H. LaGuardia, the candidate for Mayor, and Samuel Seabury jointly attacking Joseph V. McKee and Edward J. Flynn, the latter his political sponsor. The two Bronx politicians, they charged, had perpetuated in that borough a system as corrupt as Tammany's.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Margaret Lindner of 571 Manor Lane, Pelham Manor, who died Sept. 14, left $5,000 to St. Joseph's seminary at Yonkers for the training of Roman Catholic priests, according to her will filed here today. The residue of her estate was left to a niece, Helen M. Mehler of the same address, who was named executrix.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Maitre Marcel Willard of Paris and Maitre Stephan Detscheff of Sofia, two of the foreign lawyers who went to Leipzig and Berlin, representing the families of several of those accused of setting the Reichstag fire, protested today against their arrest in Berlin and their expulsion by the Nazi authorities.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- A decision by the Appellate Division recognizing Justice Frederic Kernochan as a Republican candidate for justice of the Court of Special Sessions in New York County was affirmed today by the Court of Appeals.

After prolonged bickering the Board of Aldermen amended yesterday the city ordinance placing a five-cent tax on taxicab rides to provide that failure to pay the tax shall incur an interest penalty of 5 per cent instead of loss of the cab license.

So that Bellevue Hospital's crippled and bedridden children can see the latest in bronco riding, steer wrestling, rope throwing and fancy and trick riding, the World's Series Rodeo at the Madison Square Garden will go to the hospital today.

An indictment accusing a grand jury witness of perjury was returned yesterday to Judge Cornelius F. Colling in General Sessions. The defendant was Robert Barbour of Great Neck, L.I., and Paterson, N. J., a brother of United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Twenty registration statements under the Securities Act for toe issuance of new securities were made public by the Federal Trade Commission today. The list represented issues of about $12,000,000.

Among the influences that make it difficult to cultivate the habit of good English is the modern novel, Police Commissioner James S, Bolan told 300 policemen of all ranks yesterday at the opening session of the new police course in written and spoken English at the Police Academy, 400 Broome Street.
The Greater New York Taxpayers Association, at a meeting last night in the Hotel Astor, adopted resolutions urging Mayor O'Brien and the Board of Aldermen to repeal the recent water tax increase.

The Republican party will be a minority party in this State for many years if Its scant majority in the Assembly is lost, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, warned yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Following close upon the settlement of the dye strike which sent almost 15,000 workers back to mills today, representatives of 3,000 striking Jacquard workers voted this afternoon to return to work tomorrow morning under terms recently approved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The government will launch its experiment in dollar devaluation tomorrow through the purchase of newly mined gold at a price above the world quotation.

At a preliminary hearing yesterday Mayor O'Brien informed a delegation representing the United German Societies that he would reconsider his prohibition of their German Day celebration at a final hearing in the City Hall at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon only if he changed his opinion of the chief speaker, Heinz Spanknoebel, as an "alien agitator."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- As a reward for his success in conducting the government's campaign against kidnapping and racketeering, Joseph B. Keenan of Cle eland today was appointed an Assistant Attorney General in charge of the criminal division of the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The object of appropriating nearly four billions for public works was not so much to improve America's physical plant as to provide employment and thereby increase purchasing power. It was early offered as a depression remedy by William Randolph Hearst.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration since 1931, was appointed yesterday to be chief of an enlarged Eastern area of the Immigration and Naturalization Bureau which will include Connecticut, nearly all of New York State and New Jersey cities as far south as Ocean County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- After endorsing President Roosevelt's "managed-currency" policy, a conference representing industrialists and farm leaders today recommended as a further step currency expansion and the remonetization of silver.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating rackets and kidnapping was told today by one who "ought to know" that only the Federal Government can stop kidnapping.

Elimination of tangled intercompany debt among the Southern Natural Gas Corporation, the Peoples Light and Power Corporation and certain subsidiaries, all in receivership, is proposed in a general settlement to be argued tomorrow before the United States District Court in Delaware.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The stock markets generally were firm today, being little affected by the fall of the French Cabinet. French bonds and francs weakened, then quickly recovered. Yesterday's rise in Wall Street did much to help sentiment in London and stimulate trading.

A resolution committing the city to approval of an agreement with, the I.R.T. and the B.M.T. for the installation of new equipment to permit the inauguration of subway express service on the jointly-operated rapid transit line from Times Square, Manhattan, to Flushing, Queens, was unanimously adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole.

In this day of Hitlers and Mussolinis, President Roosevelt never could be an American dictator because of his character and heritage, Professor Raymond Moley says in the first issue of Today, independent national weekly. The magazine will appear on the stands Friday.

Weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange created a demand for contracts on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices advanced a quarter cent or more. The market hung fire for several hours and fluctuated in a range of a few points, but a sharp rise in stocks in the last hour stimulated commission-house activity and left the list 20 to 27 points higher than on Monday.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24 -- Flabbergast, racing for the Wheatley Stable of New York, paid $116 for $2, the longest price of the meeting, to win the feature six-furlong test today at Laurel.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,434,500 barrels, compared with 2,419,650 barrels in the previous week, an increase of 14,850 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 12,550 and 6,700 barrels in the daily outputs of Oklahoma and Texas respectively were the most important changes.

The plan drafted by George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner, for disposal of Brooklyn's refuse by the city as opposed to having it done under private contract was reported favorably late yesterday afternoon by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The administration clamped down tighter today on oil production, and announced that objections to the price-fixing schedule which goes into effect Dec. 1 may be submitted as late as Nov. 15.

Quarterly reports issued yesterday by the Republic Steel Corporation, the Jones Laughlin Steel Company and the Otis Steel Company for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, indicate that the steel industry's operating results for the period were the best for any quarter in more than two years.

Cooperation of investment bankers and newspapers as one means of restoring the normal investment processes that are necessary to sustained business recovery will be discussed at a special forum at the convention of the Investment Bankers Association which will begin on Saturday at Hot Springs, Va.

PRINCEON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Three Princeton varsity teams and the scrubs went through a short scrimmage in a driving rain today. Only Bob Kopf and Chick Kaufman of the eleven that started against Columbia on Saturday were on hand for practice.

As French Premiers go, M. DALADIER has had a long term -- nearly nine months. Ever since M. POINCARE maintained himself so long as Premier without a party because he was regarded as indispensable, the succession to him has often seemed like fleeting phantoms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Germans are very truculent and will agree to nothing. They have already forgotten that they are a beaten nation. No wonder, therefore, the French are annoyed that we do not do something with them to restrain the ever-growing martial spirit of Germany.

Buyers' Arrivals Gained. The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the figures for the preceding week, but still remained well below the total listed for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The Centenary of the Oxford Movement, celebrated this week in Philadelphia, dates from the famous sermon by the ,Rev. JOHN KEBLE in July of 1833 on " National Apostasy." This then becomes also his centennial year, and it is fitting that here in America he should be remembered.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, and Mrs. William P. Wharton of Groton, Mass., were the guests in honor of whom Mrs. William Norton Bullard gave a luncheon today at Highwood, Lenox.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Francs are understood to have been bought heavily today not only by the British Equalization Fund but by Americans, perhaps acting under the mechanism newly set up by President Roosevelt. Therefore, despite internal weakness, the exchange rate of the franc was kept up by sales of dollars and pounds.

In cooperation with the New York State Bankers Association in its efforts to put into execution throughout the State the NRA bankers' code, Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the New York Clearing House committee, has appointed a bankers' NRA committee under the chairmanship of Merrel P. Calloway, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, yesterday branded as a lie the assertion of F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, that he and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, connived at graft and were responsible for the suicide of Louis H. Willard, a Hofstadter committee witness.
Shipping men will place their code problems before the NRA at a conference today with W.H. Davis, deputy administrator, at the offices of the Maritime Association, 80 Broad Street.

In a statement issued here yesterday, commenting upon the new monetary policy of President Roosevelt, Edwin Walter Kemmerer, noted authority on money, warns against the danger that "a highly managed currency will founder on the rocks of politics."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Evidence intended to show that J. E. Dockendorff, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, received salary and other benefits totaling more than a million dollars between 1919 and 1932 through that and other companies holding government contracts was brought out today by the special Senate committee investigating ocean mail contracts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 24. -- President Vargas today issued a decree doubling the duties on all French products imported into Brazil. The measure is in retaliation against the French decree, issued last July, increasing the duties on Brazilian coffee and other products.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The navy flies the church pennant above the national flag while church services are being held aboard its warships, Captain Sydney K. Evans of the Chaplain Corps said today. The question was brought to his attention as the result of a discussion surrounding a similar practice at the Queens Village Baptist Church in New York.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 -- The bestowal of a $100,000 annual pension on Albert H. Wiggin by directors of the Chase National Bank was declared "beyond all reason" by R. Walter Graham, Controller of the city of Baltimore and stockholder in the bank, in a letter to Winthrop G. Aldrich, president of the institution.

The will of Leopold Yesky, retired milliner, who died on Sept. 8, left $4,000 to his executors to distribute among institutions to be selected by them, it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where the document was filed. His widow, Valborg Yesky, of the Hotel Alamac, receives a life interest in the residue, and upon her death or remarriage the principal is to go to Mr. Yesky's brother and sisters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A processing tax of 28 cents a bushel on corn was fixed today by Secretary Wallace with the approval of President Roosevelt.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Edward J. O'Brien tonight admitted that he erred while officiating as referee in Saturday's Yale-Brown game at New Haven, but denied that his mistake robbed the defeated Bruins of any points.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Drilling for its game with Navy on Saturday, Pennsylvania's football squad got a taste today of the Rockne system, which is employed by the Annapolis eleven, in a dummy scrimmage with the La Salle College players.

Further sharp gains in foreign bonds, notably French loans; irregularly higher prices for domestic corporation isues and weaknesses in United States Government long-term obligations characterized active trading in bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- There was plenty of work for Army's football squad today as the cadets made further preparations for the game next Saturday with Yale at New Haven.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The first copy of Today, the magazine edited by Professor Raymond Moley, has been sent to President Roosevelt. Professor Moley and his assoicates in the magazine venture -- Vincent Astor, V.V. McNitt and Mrs. Mary H. Rumsey -- visited the art color printing plant today and dispatched the first copy to the President by air mail.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 -- The Los Angeles area was rocked by a vigorous earth movement at 11:01 o'clock tonight.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess Irbain-Kahn Kaplanoff will give a dinner dance Dec. 21 at the Pierre to introduce to society Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, daughter of the Princess.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- To refute charges made by newspapers and periodicals in Great Britain and other countries that the Schering-Kahlbaum Company of Berlin was "one of Germany's secret arsenals" manufacturing poison gas, the company, which is one of Germany's biggest chemical and pharmaceutical concerns, opened its laboratory and factory for inspection today by foreign press correspondents.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Sir Josiah Stamp, the British economist, declared himself today as puzzled by the United States' new monetary policy as revealed in President Roosevelt's radio address Sunday.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 -- The Bureau of National Statistics in its monthly report on the country's foreign trade today contains for the first time a classification of exports by countries, showing the United States purchased 7 per cent of Argentina's total exports for the past nine months, compared with Great Britain's 32 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Rhoda Tanner Doubleday, a divorcee well known in New York society, filed the praecipe of a suit for $1,500,000 against Harold F. McCormick today in the Circuit Court of Cook County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Representatives of the newsprint industry, speaking for American, Canadian and Europan interests, agreed tonight after an all-day conference under NRA auspices to have "an armistice on prices" for three weeks, in which a further general conference to consider all phases of their problems will be held.

Staging a strong stretch drive, Mrs. Paul Kelley's Le Miserable just managed to win by a nose from the B.B. Stable's Herowin in the featured Snowball Purse at Empire City yesterday. W.G. Merion's Happy Message saved the short end of the purse after leading almost all of the five and a half furlongs.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries report a deficit of $39,867 for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, after charges, taxes, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, in contrast with a net profit of $6,642,525 in the preceding year and with full dividend requirements of $5,131,638 on the $7 and $6 preferred stocks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- It now appears that to raise internal prices of commodities and keep them up, the President will be required to mix an ancient stand-pat Republican tariff doctrine with the assortment of Left Wing policies of the New Deal. Of all the interesting developments of the administration's economics, this is one of the most striking.

Summonses for the owners of the Irving Place and Republic Theatres, both burlesque houses, were issued last night by License Commissioner Sidney Levine in a move to revoke their licenses for exhibiting what he considers indecent performances.

Langdon W. Post, Fusion candidate, for President of the Borough of Manhattan, last night rebuked a Fusion speaker who had declared the sole issue of the campaign was not the candidates but the men be- hind them. With Mayor O'Brien and representatives of Tammany, and the Fusion.

VIENNA, Oct. 25 -- To discourage the Nazi practice of lighting fires on the surrounding hills in the shape of swastikas, the Kufstein District Council has announced that, for every such fire, a prominent member of the former Austrian Nazi party will be confined in a concentration camp.
A nation-wide campaign for education in inter-group relations has been formally approved by the executive board of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.
East is East and West is West, but it is the North and the South that will challenge the major interest of Father Knickerbocker's football followers on Saturday.

The establishment yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of a buying price for newly mined gold at $31.36 an ounce, slightly higher than the world price, had the paradoxical effect of increasing the value of the dollar in foreign exchange.

A spokesman for the Japanese Government politely puts aside all questions of a political motive on the part of President ROOSEVELT in preparing to recognize the Soviet Government, and intimates that his aims are purely "economic." The gain, or winning back, of a good customer is certainly not a thing to be despised by the United States.

Backers of Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor seemed greatly encouraged yesterday by the developments of the last few days. A week ago many of his supporters were doubtful of his election. Now, without exception, those managing his campaign seem confident that he had a better chance of election than either F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee, or Mayor John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for re-election.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 -- A stern warning was addressed by the High Commissioner for Palestine to members of the Palestine Arab Executive during an interview in which he cautioned them to avoid clashes with the police at Jaffa Friday, when they intend to demonstrate against alleged excessive Jewish immigration.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- American holders of Irish Sweepstakes tickets won today a total of L269,940 (about $1,286,264 at the current rate) on the Cambridgeshire Handicap.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Harold F. McCormick was served this afternoon with a summons in the $1,500,000 suit brought against him by Mrs. Rhoda Tanner Doubleday, a divorcee, long prominent in New York society.
A decision by the Port Washington Yacht Club to remain in commission this Winter caused the Manhasset Bay group of dinghy sailors to revise its schedule for the season, it was announced yesterday.
Plaintiffs bought in fifteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx at foreclosure auctions yesterday as follows:

The psychology of woman, always the most tremulous of subjects, came in for a beating last evening up on Forty-eighth Street. The occasion was the public unveiling of "Three and One," a work derived from the French of Denys Amiel.

Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot has enlisted the cooperation of many women of society as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons in making a financial success of the forthcoming performance of "Let 'Em Eat Cake" the night of Oct. 31 at the Imperial Theatre in behalf of the Travelers Aid Society.

The largest crowd in the history of Police Department auction sales turned out yesterday to bid on 274 lots of automobiles, motorcycles, bicycles, tires, baby carriages, sleds and other unclaimed add condemned property placed on the block at the property clerk's garage, foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

Consumers having anticipated their requirements for some time to come, the steel industry is operatins on a "hand-to-mouth" basis, according to the review of The Iron Age. The operating rate for the country at large is fixed at 31.8 per cent. compared with an estimate of 39 per cent for the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Secretary Parking suggested today that supporters of unemployment reserves or insurance hold State conferences soon to lay the groundwork for early submission of bills to legislators.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The long expected reorganization of the National Recovery Administration was announced tonight by General Johnson.

After an ancestral (folk art) curtain-raiser, the Downtown Gallery has begun its regular series of exhibitions for the new season with a group show containing work by various "regulars." it is slated to remain until Nov. 11.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The touring United States women's field hockey team today was defeated by East Scotland, 5 goals to 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Since July, 1929, more than $2,000,000,000 has been advanced to farmers by the government through various agricultural credit agencies and a total of $2,370,000,000 is still outstanding in loans by such agencies, some of which began operating some years earlier.

The urgent need for approval of Proposition I, which is the $60,000,000 relief bond issue to be voted on by the people of the State at the election next month, was emphasized by the State temporary emergency relief administration in its monthly bulletin published yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last night I attended a Tammany meeting at the corner of Broadway and 110th Street. I was struck with the popularity of the speakers. Every time anything that might be termed aggressive was said there was a thunderous round of applause.

The Board of Education approved yesterday a request to the Board of Estimate for inclusion in its application for Federal funds $11,075,000 for the construction of new school buildings. Four weeks ago the board requested $16,496,808 through the same channels for new buildings and equipment.

A Very Small Omar. The smallest printed book in the world has just been completed in Worcester, Mass., after seven years of labor. It consists of twenty-six pages with forty-six verses of the Rubaiyat -- about half of the FitzGerald version.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In almost every one of our basic industries the NRA contemplates reducing the output next year that we may not be confronted with a great surplus of products, thus lowering the prices of so many essentials of life below the cost of production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Intervention by President Roosevelt was expected tonight if a prompt settlement is not made soon in the "captive" mine controversy involving the steel corporations and their soft coal mine employes.
Mayor O'Brien campaigned last night in Yorkville, the heart of the German population of the city, but all was quiet and peaceful.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- More than 2,000 telegrams received at the White House, responsive to the gold announcement in President Roosevelt's radio speech Sunday night, and said to have been perused personally by him, were declared today to have included only two sounding a critical note.

Mayor O'Brien paid a surprise visit to Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon during a rodeo performance by the Madison Square Garden company and stole the show. When ha stepped before the microphone to utter a word of praise "for the valiant men and women from the Western land, who stand for sunshine, open spaces and health," the limelight belonged to him.
The address of F.H. LaGuardia last night at St. Bartholomew Community House follows:

The obscurity surrounding the President's s announcement that the Government was about "to take firmly in its "own hands the control of the gold "value of our dollar," and that this was to be done through setting up "a "Government market for gold in the "United States," was not dispelled by yesterday's initial fixing of the price for gold in American current funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Oscar B. Ryder, chief of the newly created imports division of the National Recovery Administration, was instructed today to give constant study to all import statistics, for the purpose of assisting General Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, in determining whether data on any import, "which is substantial or increasing in ratio to domestic production," should be referred to the President for Executive action.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- Old and bent, shoulders stooped and his hair a snowy white, Joseph Weaver obtained an award of $12,000 compensation today by a vote of the county commissioners for the twenty-two months he spent in the Ohio penitentiary "death row" before he won freedom on a murder charge.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 -- Russian recognition by the United States was opposed in a long debate which upset the Kew Jersey Baptist Convention today.

A special meeting of Congregation Emanu-El will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, at 8 o'clock next Monday evening to elect a rabbi and to consider recommendations of the board of trustees regarding the rabbinate. Official notice of the meeting has been sent to members of the congregation by Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals, who is president of the board of trustees.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Pointing to improvement in the oil industry since it began operations under the NRA, Secretary Ickes warned the American Petroleum Institute today that more drastic regulatory powers would be used unless cheating was stopped and production held down to figures prescribed by the government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt today put into effect his plan for controlling the gold value of the dollar in an effort to laics commodity prices when $31.36 an ounce was set as the figure at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was prepared to buy gold newly mined in the United States and its Territories.

Edwina Booth, film actress, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the Metro-GoldwynMayer Corporation for 1,000,000 damages on the ground that her health had been ruined through the alleged negligence of agents of the company in the production of the film "Trader Horn," in which she was starred.
In an answer to a petition in bankruptcy filed against it on Oct. 13, the New York Investors, Inc., asserted yesterday it was a solvent and going concern.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Walter Johnson, chief postal inspector, declared tonight that $500,000 worth of bonds and securities taken in three mail robberies had been recovered, most of it in Chicago.

Millions of cattail seeds, which nature has equipped with filmy parachutes, were swept from the New Jersey salt marshes yesterday by the westerly gale. They descended upon the city and entire metropolitan area like a flurry of early Fall snow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Mr. Pecora developed today that the prospectus issued to the public offering the $40,000,000 of Cuban bonds did not include a statement of Cuba's $7,000,000 governmental deficit for the previous year.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday Tuesday. For the best names...... 1 1/4 % 1 1/4 % The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 25 -- In the sweepstakes today only one Canadian, Ira N. Kirk of Crandall, Man., had a ticket on Raymond, the winner -- worth $143,000 -- and he had sold half his share for about $4,000.

Asserting that the approval of the retail code Toy the President has now shifted the battle for recovery to the retail front, Ward Melville, president of the National Council of Shoe Retailers, in a letter sent yesterday to the presidents of all national, sectional and State retailers' associations urged these executives to emphasize in personal messages to their memberships the "great responsibility which now rests upon the retailers of the country."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Evelyn Briggs Baldwin, Polar explorer, died here tonight of a fractured skull after having been struck by an automobile while he was crossing one of the capital's busiest thoroughfares.

Daniel F. Cohalan, member of the Tammany war board, hinted last night in a speech at Odd Fellows Hall, in 106th Street, that President Roosevelt and Postmaster General James A. Farley were seeking to overthrow the leadership of John F. Curry, Tammany leader, through the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee in revenge for Tammany's opposition to Mr. Roosevelt at the Democratic National Convention.

PALMA, Maporca, Oct. 25 -- Five Americans locked up for six weeks in the Palma military prison as a consequence of a row with members of Spain's Civil Guards last June appeared cheerful on the eve of their trial before a military court set for 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.
Several Manhattan leasehold deals wore announced yesterday. These included a theatre, a hotel and several dwellings, as well as some business structures.
LAUREL Md., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Sheltlon H. Fairbanks, arriving from New York today, said he discovered yesterday a sponge in the nostrils of his horse, playing On, at Empire City.
LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Red Roamer, 10-to-1 shot and owned by F. and C. Le Bus, galloped off with the Fernbank Purse, feature event today at Latonia.

After hearing for almost three hours yesterday how Heinz Spanknoebel had taken control of the United German Societies here in the interests of "The New Germany" in the last month, and after considering what he had heard for three hours more, Mayor O'Brien finally decided last night he would not rescind his prohibition of the annual German Day celebration.

NEWMARKET, Eng., Oct. 25 -- Thousands of persons, including King George, expressed disappointment today when Sir Abe Bailey's Raymond, an extreme outsider, paying 33 to 1, won the historic Cambridgeshire on Newmarket Heath. The King's colt, Limelight, finished out of the money in fourth place.

Representatives of the Federal Government joined with representatives of retail beverage dealers of the metropolitan area yesterday in urging establishment of a system of dispensing liquors to meet new conditions after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Calm, and revealing an ease of memory for figures and the intricate affairs of the defunct Bank of United States, of which he was counsel, Isidor J. Kresel was the first defense witness yesterday at his trial on a charge of abetting the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of its funds.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial produced its star witnesses today to erect a bridge between Marinus van der Lubber, the self-confessed incendiary, and the Communist party of Germany. But these witnesses saw their testimony thoroughly discredited -- at least according to all Anglo-Saxon legal standards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Warren of Cornell University, whose plan is thought to be the basis of the President's monetary plan, is quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES as saying: "The dollar has to be rubber either as to weight or value. It cannot have a fixed weight [of gold] and also a fixed value.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Harvard did not let up a moment today during its two and one-half hour drill for the Dartmouth game. There were all sorts of scrimmages.
HAVANA, Oct. 25 -- Bomb explosions linked with growing labor troubles kept Cubans disturbed and uneasy today while American officials watched events with increasing anxiety.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Robert Crawford of Greenwich, baritone, who is soloist of St. Thomas Church, New York, gave a song recital at the Round Hill Club this evening before a large audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- General Johnson, NRA Administrator, announced today that, pending the election of members, the National Retail Trade Council and the National Retail Drug Council will be named by the boards of directors of the trade associations which sponsored the retail and drug codes.

Fordham's football squad yesterday was sent through the hardest and longest workout it has had this season. More than four hours were utilized in rehearsing plays, developing back-field deception and adding a new formation. The Rams spent three, hours on Fordham Field and then drilled in the college gymnasium for more than sixty minutes.

Work on the new $3,674,837 city building that will house the Health, Sanitation and Hospitals Departments will begin at noon Monday, when Mayor O'Brien and Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan attend the cornerstone laying, Mr. Levy announced yesterday.

Raids in two uptown hotels and a private dwelling by headquarters detectives last night netted seven prisoners, three loaded pistols, opium and opium-cooking layouts and some counterfeit banknotes. Two of the prisoners were women.

A list of 10,000 names of NRA workers throughout the State was forwarded to Washington yesterday by the office of W. Averell Harriman, State NRA chairman, to serve as the nucleus of consumer councils in nearly 1,200 up-State communities.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $33,341,618, which was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 72 cents a share on the average number of common shares outstanding. This was in contrast with a loss of $4,464,229 reported for the corresponding quarter of last year.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- In fixing the price of gold at $31.36 an ounce, President Roosevelt almost exactly fulfilled predictions in Paris financial circles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The high price announced for gold today by the RFC was a factor in the grain and commodity markets on the Board of Trade here, and a rush of professional buying lifted grains sharply. Wheat at the top was up as much as 4 cents a bushel and corn 3 1/4 cents above yesterday's finish, recovering virtually all the loss sustained in the liquidation movement that started early this month.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The British Challenge Cup was captured today by the white and liver puppy dog Trex of Chance-field, owned by Mr. and Mrs. J. Squires of Norwood, Mass. The winner was handled by Mr. Squires, one of the leading amateur handlers of spaniels in this country.

Apprentice, star of James Butler's string, raced to the easiest kind of a victory through heavy going at the Yonkers course yesterday. Played down from even money to 7 to 10 the homebred son of Vulcain and Teacher's Pet scored by eight lengths. It was his first start since the Empire City Summer meeting.

The trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have chosen three new curators and other administrative changes have been, made by Herbert E. Winlock, director of the museum, according to an announcement yesterday.
General Sessions Judges and not city magistrates, as in past years, are to hear the cases of illegal registrants arrested in Manhattan for voting on election day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt set a new mode in White House press conferences this morning by receiving a small dele- gation of correspondents in his bed- room when a slight indisposition kept him from his desk in the executive offices for a second day.
