WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- In the age-old ceremony of "laying on at hand," in which by the traditions of the Roman Catholic Church he received the command of Christ to "go forth and teach ye all nations whatsoever I have given unto you," the Most Rev. James Hugh Ryan, rector of the Catholic University, was consecrated Bishop of the See of Modra today.

THE esteemed D.O. (Tuss) McLaughry, football coach at Brown University, was simply simmering until a well-meant phrase uttered by W.R. Okeson was brought to his attention. Then he boiled over. It was apropos of Dr. Eddie O'Brien's mistake on a blocked punt play in the Yale-Brown game.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 25 -- Alabama's squad completed its local practice today with shouts of "on to Fordham!" As the team boarded a train at 9 o'clock cheers of hundreds of students rang out. There was a parade from the campus to the train.

Fifty men, the guests of Richard B. Scandrett Jr. at a dinner at the University Club last night, pledged their support to the Crusade for Children and formed themselves into the nucleus of a men's division for the crusade, a joint effort of seven child welfare organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- None of the $10,000,000 recently allotted for army motorization will be spent with firms which have not signed the NRA automobile manufacturing code, the War Department stated today.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- An emphatic disclaimer was made today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, that Heinz Spanknoebel, alleged in America to be in charge of Nazi activities in New York, holds any mandate whatever either from the Hitler government or from the National Socialist party.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25 -- Denmark's fears of Nazi aggression are believed to be the reason behind the visit of Per Albin Hansson, the Social Democratic Premier of Sweden, to Copenhagen. Premier Hansson left here for the Danish capital tonight.
Joseph V. McKee's record on prohibition and on woman's suffrage was attacked last night by Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll, vice chairman of the women's division of the Fusion campaign committee.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The financial community was relieved today because President Roosevelt went no higher than $31.36 in fixing the price of newly mined gold.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25--Although Yale's only scrimmage of the week for the Army game was devoted chiefly today to a defense for the cadets' attack, the first varsity players swarmed through the Grays for one touchdown. Then, with half a dozen changes in the line-up, they continued their advance for another during the twenty minutes of offensive tactics.

The trend of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was largely a repetition of the drift of the previous day. Domestic corporation bonds moved irregularly higher, foreign loans showed exceptional strength, while United States Government long-term obligations finished generally weaker. Trading was less active than on Tuesday.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The Boerse was decidedly firm today. Both bonds and stocks registered gains up to 4 per cent. The firmness was attributed in the main to the overwhelming response which Chancellor Hitler received yesterday on opening his election campaign, which is taken as a symbol of political stabilization at home.

With the wind howling out of the north, the weather last evening was well suited to a melodrama set in the Antarctic. George F. Hummel's lurid lithograph, "The World Waits," was accordingly staged at the Little Theatre to the sound accompaniment of most of the wind machines in that neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The names of former President Hoover and several of his Cabinet members were brought into testimony again today before the special Senate committee investigating mail contracts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Oct. 18 was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 8,605,580 running bales, exclusive of linters, counting 326.475 round bales as half bales and including 1,183 bales of American-Egyptian cotton.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo issued an order yesterday requiring Mayor O'Brien and the other members of the Board of Estimate to show cause why they should not be restrained from voting twenty-five-year bus franchises in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Madison Avenue Coach Company and the Comprehensive Bus Corporation.

The City Campaign. Samuel Seabury, who was counsel for the Hofstadter Committee, last night absolved Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn from blame in connection with the suicide of Louis H. Willard, an aftermath of the Hofstadter investigation.

In a speech delivered in Washington and broadcast from Radio Station WOR, Ferdinand Pecora, Recovery party nominee for District Attorney of New York County, declared last night that he had been refused the nomination for that office by "Curry Co." because he had stepped on the toes of persons the political bosses would have spared prosecution and punishment.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Albert Sarraut, Minister of Colonies and later, on the death of George Leygues, Minister of the Navy in the Daladier Cabinet, has been asked by President Lebrun to form a new Ministry. He ill give his reply tomorrow after he has concluded the necessary consultations with his own party members and neighboring groups.

Although the markets were in some confusion yesterday as a result of the uncertainties surrounding the government's gold-buying policy, prices advanced on all the Exchanges. Stocks, bonds and commodities moved upward at the same time that the dollar was seeking nervously to find its proper relation in the international market.

According to an eminent authority, the English-speaking world is divided into (1) those who neither know nor care what a split infinitive is; (2) those who do not know but care very much; (3) those who know and condemn; (4) those who know and approve; (5) those who know and distinguish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Preliminary reports for the first half of October indicate some decrease in employment following an increase of employment among factory workers between mid-August and mid-September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly business and financial review.

MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States would be a serious matter to Japan, Toshio Shiratori, newly appointed Japanese Ambassador to Sweden, stated here today. Mr. Shiratori is on his way to Sweden to take up his new post.

An order directing Mayor O'Brien and Commissioner of Accounts James A. Higgins to show cause on Nov. 1 why they should not permit an inspection of "suppressed" reports of the Commissioner of Accounts was obtained yesterday by Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, from Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

John T. Trimble, head of a squad of twelve agents who gathered evidence in the election fraud inquiry being conducted by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, has been dismissed from the government service by J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Division of Investigation of the Department of Justice, it was revealed yesterday.

Senator William G. McAdoo of California is due to arrive today on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia from a vacation in Europe, including a visit to Russia. Colonel A.A. Graziani, aide de camp to the King of Italy, and Marquis Aurelio Paterar Pescara also are on board.

The current exhibition at the Roerich Museum, held under the patronage of the Argentinian Ambassador, Dr. Felipe A. Espil, presents the work of about twenty Argentine artists -- woodcuts, etchings, lithographs, dry points and aquatints.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Joseph M. Schenck, president of United Artists, and Samuel Goldwyn, film producer of that company, who on Monday announced their resignation from the Association of Motion Picture Producers, Inc., last night said that they also would resign from Motion Picture Producers and Distributors, Inc., headed by Will H. Hays in New York, if necessary, in their battle against provisions of the proposed NRA film code.

An average pulmonary tuberculosis death rate of 56.3 for each 100,000 population, the lowest figure on record, was achieved by fiftynine American cities in 1932, Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman, consulting statistician, writes in today's issue of The Spectator, business insurance paper.

Sweeping aside technical objections on behalf of the Fusionists and Democrats by Judge SEABURY and the Board of Elections, the Court of Appeals has ordered the latter to list, on the various tickets for which they have been nominated, all the accredited candidates for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District.

The freshman class of Columbia College, voting yesterday in the traditional questionnaire conducted by The Spectator, student daily newspaper, declared a liking for 3.2 beer and a preference for a Phi Beta Kappa key rather than a varsity letter.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The stock markets had a big expansion of business today, with heavy buying and dollar shares all buoyant. The entry of the United States today into the gold market, a rise in the price of gold here to 130s 1d a fine ounce and good Johannesburg advices, were all favorable factors.

Profit taking retarded the pace of the advance in the principal commodity exchanges yesterday, but substantial gains in futures were recorded for the third successive day in response to the government's entering a bid for gold somewhat above the London price.

Operations on the Stock Exchange yesterday were quieter than they might have been ordinarily for the reason that speculators took no chance on the possibility of a great upset in the government's gold-adjustment policy. As the plan worked out, gold was worth less in the international market than had been predicted.

It took thousands of years for man to discover that in every rainbow the sun does its best to reveal its composition and physical state. In the last century came the man-made rainbows of the laboratory, the spectra of prisms. Physicists naw not only colors but lines -- more than 20,000 of them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 25 -- The action of the New Jersey House Commission in selling $200,000 of Union County and other bonds to enable the Sinking Fund Commission to purchase more than $1,000,000 of Jersey City 6 per cent bonds is condemned in resolutions adopted by the directors of the Union County Taxpayers Association.

WARSAW, Oct. 25 -- The Polish Foreign Minister, Joseph Beck, and Ambassador Antonov-Ovseenko of the Soviet Union agreed today to regard as closed the correspondence between the two governments following the killing of a Soviet consular clerk at Lwow Saturday by a Ukrainian nationalist.

Dr. John J. Moorhead, Professor of Traumatic Surgery at the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, charged in the Supreme Court yesterday that his wife, Mrs. Helen Howell Moorhead, had treated their 13-year-oId adopted son David so cruelly that he has an inferiority complex which has hindered his progress in school.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- In a new effort to disarm the underworld the Department of Justice had under consideration today a plan for the registration of all machine guns.

From the first, the McKee candidacy has intimated that it had the approval of the President. On Tuesday, Mr. McKEE himself went further than ever before and said in a public speech: "A "vote for McKEE is a vote for ROOSE"VELT." But the latter's name will not appear on the voting machines in the column set apart for Mr. McKEE's Recovery party, or any other.

Painting a word portrait of F. H. LaGuardia in brilliant crimson, Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, charged last night that his Fusion opponent favored a revolution to destroy the capitalistic system and eliminate production for profit and charged that he represented a menace to the fundamental principles of American government.
Lou Little, head coach at Columbia, suggested yesterday that there was a simple solution to the fuss over bad decisions by football officials on kicks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Albert H. Wiggin today asked the Chase National Bank to discontinue his salary of $100,000 a year for life, voted previous to his retirement last January as chairman of its board. The bank complied.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Soaring majestically upward, the veteran sky voyager Graf Zeppelin took off at 11:35 o'clock tonight for a hop to the Chicago world's fair after a night and day stopover here on the journey from Friedrichshafen, Germany.

Fishermen still are finding many species in good quantity. This applies mainly to salt-water varieties. The fresh-water anglers are getting in some good bass fishing these cool days when the lowered temperature of the water seems to make the bass bite better than ever.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the recommendations of the committee on stock list pertaining to the auditing of accounts by listed corporations and authorized the committee on stock list to bring its suggestions to the attention of those concerned.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, spent the greater part of yesterday on the witness stand in the Federal Court in Brooklyn, where he is suing in equity to recover a large amount in securities from the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Spokesmen for 1,500,000 unionized building mechanics and helpers agreed today upon a substitute code that will be presented to Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, in place of the master code for the construction industry that is now in the hands of NRA deputies.

TRENTON, Oct. 25 -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, said late today that nothing has been developed of interest to his department by the questioning in Boston of John Gorch in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Subscriptions of over $650,000,000 in Fourth Liberty bonds have been tendered to the Federal Reserve Banks and to the Treasury in exchange for Treasury bonds of 1943-45, Acting Secretary Acheson announced today.

W.H. Davis, Deputy Administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Administration in charge of shipping, conferred here yesterday with representatives of three branches of the industry and helped clear the way for a speeding-up of code negotiations which have been under way for two months.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- The church was challenged tonight by the Rev. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., to impart Christianity to a world "emancipated and unhappy," which had turned its back upon religion in virtually every sphere of activity.

GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- The disarmament conference bureau unanimously decided today to recommond to the general commission tomorrow to continue the conference's work in the immediate future through the bureau and to resume its own sessions not later than Dec. 4.

A team of six players will sall from New York on Jan. 19 to represent the United States in the second international women's squash racquets match for the Wolfe-Noel cup, according to plans announced yesterday.
An Arctic gale whipped the Northern United States and Canada yesterday, bringing them the first severe snowstorm of the season.
For the first time since Coach Lou Little came to Columbia three years ago he made wholesale changes in his starting line-up yesterday at Baker Field for a midseason contest.

The rugged life of pioneer times is contrasted with the hysteria of present-day existence in "The World Changes," a picture presented by the Warner Brothers at the Hollywood last night. It is a panorama of seven decades, depicting the ambition and disappointments of a family, chiefly of Orin Nordholm, who is acted by the talented Paul Muni.

The Prudence Realty Co. was the broker in the recent sale of the six-story apartment at the southwest corner of 7th Av. and 111th St. to Edward W. Browning, who also bought through the same brokers the adjoining nine-story house at the northwest corner of Cathedral Parkway and 7th Av. and now control the entire blockfront on the west side of 7th Av.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Federal Surplus Relief Corporation called for bids today, returnable Nov. 6, for the purchase of 15,000,000 pounds of domestic beef that will be added to the larder of the nation's destitute unemployed.

Ed Wynn, comedian, announced yesterday that he had resigned as president and director of the Amalgamated Broadcasting System, which was organized last Spring and went on the air Sept. 25 with its official inaugural broadcast. The reason given for the resignation, according to a spokesman for Mr. Wynn at the Amalgamated headquarters, 501 Madison Avenue, was that the comedian had discovered he was a showman and not a "radio technical executive."

A precedent in the case of picketing injunctions was established in Kings County Court yesterday when Judge George W. Martin ruled in favor of granting a trial by jury to Robert Minor, Communist candidate for Mayor, and Jack Rosenberg, a young, striker, who were arrested on Sept. 6 for picketing near the plant of the Progressive Table Company at 9,506 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn.

The three candidates for Mayor appeared last night before the Yale Club. F.H. LaGuardia carried away with him the honors of having been the most vociferously received and most loudly applauded as he went.

New York University's football team practically brought to a close its preparations for the University of Georgia game on Saturday by engaging in a spirited two-hour session at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet party of thirty-two players and others will board two private cars on the regular train leaving for Athens, Ga., this morning.

Morris Hillquit, Socialist leader, lawyer and author, who died at his home, 40 East Sixty-sixth Street, on Oct. 7, left most of his estate to his family, it became known yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. The value of the estate was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration replied today to demands of Corn Belt farmers with a statement by George N. Peek, chief administrator, that the Commodity Credit Corporation would lend 50 cents a bushel on corn in States having Farm Warehouse Acts.

A copy of the rare first edition of Eugene Field's "Tribune Primer," presented by the author to his wife, brought $1,100 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, at the first session of the auction of the library of the late Charles P. Senter of St. Louis, Mo. The purchaser was Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 25 -- Governor Robert H. Gore revealed this afternoon that he had been advised the Governor's Summer home at Jajome Alto had been bombed Sunday night, and also told of a warning he had received of a plot to poison himself and his family.

DES MOINES, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Governors of North and South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri, Indiana, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Illinois were invited tonight by Governor Herring of Iowa to attend on Monday a conference here for the discussion of farm problems.
NEW YORK. The New York Bradford Club, composed of alumnae of Bradford Academy, Haverhill, Mass., will give a tea next Wednesday afternoon at 290 Park Avenue.

Copper in the domestic market sold yesterday at 8 1/2 cents a pound, up 1/2 cent from Tuesday. Some copper, however, was available at 8 1/4 cents and the market was described as being 8 1/4 to 8 1/2 cents a pound for delivery to the end of the year.
J.P. McEvoy writes from Hollywood that he is finishing a novel he calls "Plastered Paradise." It is about "the underdogs in the movies."
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Sweetheart on Parade tonight carried off the $500 championship stake for fivegaited mares, her victory featuring the evening program at the World's Fair Horse Show.
Cotton shared yesterday in the upward movement of speculative markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange making net gains of 14 to 18 points, although they had started the day higher.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Lucier, 6-year-old gelding which races in the colors of Ward A. Wickwire of Buffalo, captured the eighth running of the Whippany River Club Plate today. The race featured the opening session of the eighteenth annual two-day meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds, held on the estate of E.B. Schley.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- It was revealed today that the Red Star liner Lapland, which had been reported as sold to wreckers, had been bought by a Japanese concern for demolition.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26. -- Only by buying for export to the United States Argentine products which hitherto have had no market there, can Americans thaw any portion of their frozen credits in Argentina, except through a loan of the Argentine Government. Even then they will not be permitted to take, out more than 60 per cent of their funds by this method.

Yesterday the United German Societies determined to abandon their plans for a celebration of " German Day" next Sunday. Under the circumstances, their action seems well advised. The whole affair had got into a sad tangle, as was fully shown at the long hearing before Mayor O'BRIEN.

"Give Us This Day," by Howard Koch, will have its premiere this evening at the Booth Theatre and a revised version of "The Family Upstairs," a comedy by Harry Delf which was first produced on Broadway in 1925, will open at the Biltmore Theatre.

Plans for the $9,289,708 model housing operation which the Board of Estimate authorized the firm of Sloan Robertson, architects, to build on the vacant $5,000,000 Chrystie-Forsyth area of three blocks, have been rejected by the State Board of Housing, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Boerse opened today with a continuation of the upward movement of the last few days, but considerable liquidation in I.G. Farben and Siemens Halske, attributed to foreign sources, brough about a reversal of the trend and the close was soft.

Robert Barbour, head of large textile enterprises in New Jersey and a brother of W. Warren Barbour, United States Senator from that State, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment charging him with perjury in testifying before a grand jury.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The text of the Executive Order of President Roosevelt relating to gold recovered from natural deposits was as follows:
Down went Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn's gavel.

Returns to date indicate that earnings of the railroads in September did not show the same ratio of improvement on an annual basis as was shown in August, but this was in part explained by the fact that earnings in September, 1932, showed an upturn compared with the preceding month of that year.

A copy of the rare first edition of James Whitcomb Riley's first book, "The Old Swimmin'-Hole," which he presented to his life-long friend, Eugene Field, while the two were on a joint lecture tour, came under the hammer yesterday afternoon in the auction sale of the library of the late Charles P. Senter of St. Louis, at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- A declaration that the true object of the Catholic movement in the Protestant Episcopal Church was not to create a party in the church nor to promote a party spirit "but to arouse us all to realization of our spiritual heritage as members of the one, catholic and apostolic church" was made tonight by Bishop William T. Manning of New York.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Finishing with a belated rush, Open Hearth, seasoned campaigner racing in the colors of H.G. Schoemaker, beat Agincourt by two lengths in the featured Glendale Purse today. The event, an allowance affair at six furlongs, was turned in the good time of 1:12 4-5, with Foxy Artist, an outsider, finishing third.

A switch in marketing emphasis from the producer to the consumer, from what our machinery can produce to what the public desires and requires, was urged yesterday by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, in an address before the Sales Executive Club of New York at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Representatives of retail industries of this city, which, comprise 134,000 individual retailers employing some 700,000 persons and doing an annual business of $500,000,000, met yesterday at the office of the local NRA, 45 Broadway, and announced that they were ready to abide by the retail code signed by the President and scheduled to go into effect on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The news of Maxim Litvinoff's departure from Moscow, en route to Washington to begin the Russian recognition discussions with President Roosevelt, made Secretary Hull decide this afternoon to postpone his own sailing for Montevideo, so that he could participate in the beginning of the negotiations here.

The persecution of Jews in Germany was condemned last night by leading Protestant churchmen, including a German theologian, at a dinner of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America at the Riverside Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Myron Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and a committee representing steel operators owning "captive" soft coal mines, were asked today to confer with President Roosevelt on Monday in an effort to settle the controversy involving the 30,000 striking employes of these mines in Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The following Coast Guard changes were announced for the week ended Oct. 25:

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Hogs weighing more than 200 pounds were in brisk demand here today and 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, while lighter kinds were steady to 10 cents higher. Colder weather and firmness in fresh and cured products were again factors in stimulating the demand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- So varied and many are government activities in Washington these days that it is difficult for chroniclers, interpreters and their readers to mark and follow trends as well as to record actions. The actions march in daily phalanxes, and few people, after intensive study of each day's newspaper, could possibly list most of them from memory.

The latest phase of the Government's continuously expanding farm plan is designed to aid producers of corn and hogs. These commodities, as the Farm Administration points out, are of more importance in dollars and cents than the " headline commodities," wheat and cotton.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener sailed his Graf Zeppelin through Chicago's overcast skies this morning to visit the Century of Progress Exposition, and encountered a storm of dissension raging among the anti-Hitler and pro-Hitler groups of the city's 600,000 German-Americans.

ALL California must be seething by this time. The Giants are going to train at Miami Beach. There's gratitude for you! As soon as they get around to it, the Chambers of Commerce in California will have William Harold Terry listed as Public Enemy No. 1 from the Golden Gate down to the inlet at San Diego.

The victory streak of the 10-year-old gelding Euclid was snapped in the feature at Empire City yesterday when the son of the Finn and Mrs. Sewall finished out of the money in a field of five which saw him the favorite at 2 to 5. P.A. Mahony's Foreword, a 12-to-1 shot, was the winner by three lengths.

Peter Augustus Jay, a descendant of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States, who died on Oct. 18, left his estate to his widow and daughter, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of his will. The New York estate was valued at "more than $10,000."

The eastern section of the football world tomorrow will receive its first taste this year of a show which is part of no other sport played in the country -- the parades of the corps of cadets of West Point and of the regiment of midshipmen from Annapolis.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa, arriving today from Bremen and Channel ports, has on board Fritz Kreisler, violinist, with Mrs. Kreisler; Sergel Rachmaninoff, pianist; Katharine Cornell, actress; Allen W. Dulles, special legal adviser to the American Disarmament Conference at Geneva, and Basil Rathbone, actor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Senate mail investigating committee promised today to go fully into the disposition of $53,000 paid by J.E. Dockendorff, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, to James B. Reynolds after learning that the latter, a former Republican National Committee official, only recently wrote to the Internal Revenue Bureau conceding the taxability of the amount.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The members of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association fared better than did members of other women's golf organizations in picking their closing days this year.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- Four points in the New York State law which would prevent the return of "the old-fashioned" saloon were outlined today by Attorney General Bennett in a letter to Frank M. Parrish, acting head of the criminal branch of the Federal Attorney General's office.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY is beginning to make Frank E. Campbell look pretty unenterprising in a mortuary way. This latest collection of Hemingway short stories, "Winner Take Nothing" (Scribner's, $2) is one of the grisliest books ever published. Statistical method, applied to the subject matter, would result in a table very like that kept in the recording room of Bellevue Hospital.

The new Walgreen Drug Store on the ground floor of The Times Building, Broadway and Fortysecond Street, will open its doors for business tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock as the 471st link in the Walgreen chain.

In the peak of condition for its battle with, the University of Alabama at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, Fordham's football squad was sent through its final heavy workout before the encounter at Fordham Field yesterday.

By all the tokens of well-informed comment upon and criticism of the Federal Securities Act, effective as a mandate July 27, 1933, the practical workability of the act in respect to certain classes of corporations is generally regarded with, serious apprehension; this refers particularly to established corporate enterprises with extensive interests in affiliates and subsidiaries.

The North American Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $12,930,818 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, equal after preferred dividends to $1.43 a share earned on the average number of common shares outstanding for the period. It compares with $18,992,252, or $2.42 a share, earned on the average number of common shares in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 25, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,518,000,000, an increase of $21,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $299,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- In the fear that publication might cause trouble in Cuba, part of a letter from the files of the Chase National Bank, containing a confidential report on the financial embarrassment of President Machado's regime in the Fall of 1932, was suppressed today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee investigating banking practices.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn reserved decision yesterday on the application by Mrs. Sadye Greenberg, as a taxpayer, to restrain the Board of Estimate from granting twenty-five-year bus franchises for a half dozen cross-town and two longitudinal lines in Manhattan at a hearing announced for today.
Sales and leases of several business structures in downtown Manhattan were negotiated yesterday.

Mrs. Jay Madden gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for her debutante daughter, Miss Audrey Madden, who will be formally introduced to society on Jan. 1 at a teadance in Greenwich, Conn.
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Under the heading "The Riddle of the Dollar," the financial editor of The London Times writes:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- Throughout the Far West today famed football coaches took sides on the suggestion to modify the present rule which prevents a defensive team from running with the ball after recovering a fumble.

In an oral decision in the Federal court in Brooklyn Judge Grover M. Moscowitz declared yesterday that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was entitled to $302,000 in securities now in the hands of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Gardner Prouty, quarterback on the Harvard freshman team last year, was brought up to the varsity squad today by Coach Eddie Casey. He was placed in charge of the second-string substitutes, who did what little scrimmaging was allowed in the final drill in preparation for the Dartmouth game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Negotiations for a rearrangement of the wartime debt of Great Britain to the United States were resumed at the Treasury Department today. A recess then was taken until early next week, when another effort will be made to narrow down the differences in the way of some arrangement.
PARIS, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Count Paul de Pourtales, head of the famous longchamps racetrack, died today in Chateau Cangey, near Tours.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26. -- Historic La. Fortaleza, for 400 years the residence of Puerto Rico's Governors, tonight is flooded with lights, giving it a fiesta appearance, but the illumination is to guard against bombs and other possible attacks on Governor Robert Gore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his recent radio speech the President stated that farm prices had risen 33 per cent over their low point; that the farmer was now getting $400 instead of $300 for the same amount of produce.

The advance in foreign loans, and to a lesser extent in domestic corporation issues, and the weakness in United States Government obligations, were halted yesterday when the Government issues moved irregularly higher and all other groups of the listed bond market were inclined to be lower.

Advancing 0.8 point, in the week, the Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices stood at 103.9 on Tuesday, compared with 103.1 (revised) on the Tuesday previous. Sharp increases in grain and flour prices, aided by cotton, largely accounted for the rise in the face of lower prices for cattle, hogs and beef.
Columbia's football squad concluded its heavy practice yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Penn State here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 24:

Once upon a time Vicki Baum's "Divine Drudge," which was acted at the Royale last evening, was a novel entitled "And Life Goes On." Perhaps it was coherent and forceful as a full-gauged story between covers, although this column cannot verify that supposition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The price offered by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for newly mined gold was raised by the government this morning to $31.54 an ounce, 48 cents above the world market today and 18 cents above the government bid yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Sweden's army team celebrated Swedish Day at the World's Fair Horse Show by advancing to first place in the International Military Trophy jumping competition tonight. The test was the third in the series.

Victor over Fordham Prep and St. Paul's School of Garden City, Brooklyn Prep will seek to register its third straight triumnh today when it meets Poly Prep at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium in the twelfth edition of their football rivalry.

Isidor J. Kresel continued his testimony yesterday at his trial on the charge of abetting in the misapplication of $2,000,000 of the funds of the Bank of United States, of which he was the counsel and a director.
PARIS, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- An unexpected slump in imports plus an unusual increase in exports translated the nation's August unfavorable trade balance of $23,000,000 into a September favorable balance of $13,000,000, the largest favorable balance since April.

Although the disappearance of Heinz Spanknoebel remained a public mystery yesterday, it was admitted definitely by several of his associates in private that he had been recalled to Germany to explain to Nazi headquarters the situation that led Mayor O'Brien to prohibit the annual celebration of German Day in the 165th Regiment Armory next Sunday.

With Le Corbusier's name we naturally associate architecture. Still energetically functioning in the most energetically functional division of that vast field, Corbusier was one of the first, as he remains one of the most famous, of the "moderns."

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- New York City companies which distribute milk varied from a profit of .35 cent on a quart of the fluid to a loss of 1.28 cents, Dr. Leland Spencer stated today in a report of his preliminary investigation of milk distributers costs and profits, ordered by the Legislature.

BALTIMORE, Friday, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Euel Lee, 60-year-old Eastern Shore Negro farm hand was hanged at the Maryland Penitentiary just after midnight for the murder of his former employer, Green K. Davis, more than two years ago. During the last day Chief Justice Hughes and President Roosevelt had refused final pleas to intervene.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, left Moscow tonight for Washington, where he will confer with President Roosevelt regarding American recognition of Soviet Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- As a result of many weeks of discussion among members of President Roosevelt's Cabinet recovery board, new machinery has been set up to handle the tremendous number of alleged code violations that have been pouring into the NRA offices, it was announced today.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Argument was heard and decision reserved today by the Court of Errors on the appeal of two judgment creditors of North, Bergen Township from the refusal of the Supreme Court to compel the municipality to include in its current tax levy their claim for $443,600 on defaulted sewer notes.

The girls' field hockey team from Beaver College, Jenkintown, Pa., defeated N.Y.U.'s eleven, 7 to 0, on the field at Prospect Park yesterday. It was the visitors' first victory in four games and the Violet's first defeat.

The trustees of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, comparing with dividends of 85 cents each paid in the two preceding quarters and with $1 quarterly paid prior to those declarations.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following Changes in pounds sterling:

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, last night presented a twenty-one point program to be put into effect if he is elected. Mr. McKee, who spoke at an enthusiastic meeting at Morris High School, the Bronx, asserted his independence and declared that he and he alone would be Mayor.

"Meet the Baron," with Jack Pearl and Jimmy Durante, will open at the Capitol today. Mr. Pearl is expected to attend the first showing this morning and will be introduced by Rudy Vallee, who is featured on the stage program.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26. -- Affairs of the money-losing last-place St. Louis Browns of the American League are to continue, at least temporarily, under the direction of L.C. McEvoy, vice president, and Rogers Hornsby, newly acquired manager.

DES MOINES, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Thirty Iowa National Guardsmen were used as Deputy Sheriffs tonight as growing opposition to the strike of the Farmers National Holiday Association developed in Western Iowa.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Oct. 26. -- Playing today at the Orangeburg County Fair before 5,000 spectators, the University of South Carolina defeated Citadel, 12 to 6. It was the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the elevens.

GENEVA, Oct. 26. -- James G. McDonald, chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, was named high commissioner for German refugees today by Dr. Raoul A. Amador of Panama, president of the League of Nations Council, in consultation with the British, French, Italian, Czechoslovak, Dutch, Spanish and Portuguese Governments.

The short symphony of Mozart in C major, numbered 200 in the Kochel catalogue, and Bruckner's immense Eighth symphony in C minor, were the works performed by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.
After a lapse of seven years the New York Giants will return to Florida next Spring to prepare themselves for the 1934 National League pennant race.

The New York University football squad of thirty-two players, accompanied by Chancellor and Mrs. Harry Woodburn Chase, departed yesterday for Athens, Ga., where the Violet eleven will meet the University of Georgia at the Sanford Stadium tomorrow.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Frank B. Noyes, president of The Associated Press and publisher of The Washington Star, told managing editors of Associated Press member newspapers today of the elementary principles and growth of the press association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- "Pain and shame" have been suffered by Mrs. Rhoda Tanner Doubleday, New York divorcee, through failure of Harold F. McCormick, Chicago capitalist, to marry her, according to the declaration of her $1,500,000 breach of promise suit filed today in the Circuit Court.

The twelfth celebration of Navy Day finds the United States undertaking a large building program. Its purpose is not only to strengthen the fleet in aircraft carriers, cruisers, destroyers and submarines, but to give employment to thousands. With the $238,000,000 allocated from funds of the National Industrial Recovery Act, there is also to be work on seventeen warships now building and five authorized.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the suspension for two years of George M.L. LaBranche on charges that he had violated rules governing the conduct of specialists. Mr. LaBranche is a partner in LaBranche Co., who act as specialists in several prominent issues.
Following the return of former Governor Alfred E. Smith to the city, it was declared definitely yesterday that "Al Smith is out of the campaign."

Reporting on the Park Department's plan for rehabilitating Bryant Park, the landscape architects' committee of the advisory board of the Park Association suggested yesterday that more emphasis be placed on the mall-like treatment on the main axis centring on the library fountain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- On the eve of Navy Day President Roosevelt sent a letter today to the Acting Secretary of the Navy, Henry L. Roosevelt, congratulating the service on its efficiency and devotion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The United States accepted today the invitation of the League of Nations to name a representative on the governing board that will deal with German refugees who have fled political persecution in their native country.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Yesterday the grain trade talked of little but the price of gold, but today that subject was scarcely mentioned on the Board of Trade, and the advance of 18 cents an ounce for the metal, announced by the RFC, fell flat as a market influence for grains.

HAVANA, Oct. 26. -- A general strike was voted early this morning by about 600 labor delegates representing all sections of the island, but the date for the beginning of the walkout was not fixed, owing to an attempt of the government to prevent the strike by arresting labor leaders.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- One development of President Roosevelt's gold policy which is becoming increasingly evident in France is a strengthening of the conviction already felt in many quarters here that among other things he is seeking to force the franc off the gold standard.

The twelfth annual observance of Navy Day today will be featured by two broadcasts from the Macon while the dirigible is in flight on the West Coast, according to a program of events made public yesterday at Third Naval District headquarters here.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- While every resource of propaganda and showmanship is being utilized to insure that unanimous endorsement of the Nazi Government's policy toward the disarmament conference needed to give it a free hand in dealing with the skeptical world, it comes out that the number of prisoners in the concentration camps is increasing.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- Awards of fifty-one athletic insignia, twenty-seven of them major letters, were announced today by the Yale Athletic Association.

The Real Meaning. As the city campaign swung into the homestretch it became clearer every day that voting for any man on the ticket meant much more than voting for him. Broader horizons were ever opening up. Thus:
Twelve paintings by Claude Monet (1840-1927), the great French impressionist, brought $45,700 last night at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Attorney General Cummings passed over to Postmaster General Farley today that part of the new liquor problem growing out of the advertising of wet goods in dry States by use of the mails.

Cora Jarrett and her publishers, Houghton Mifflin, report that they are troubled and amazed because certain critics here have written about Mrs. Jarrett's "Night Over Fitch's Pond" as a mystery story rather than as a psychological novel of married life, as it was intended to be considered.

Joseph V. McKee's political and economic viewpoint dates back to the early eighteenth century, and no one in the campaign is as far removed as Mr. McKee from the philosophy and outlook" of President Roosevelt, Louis Waldman, State chairman of the Socialist Party, declared last night.

A jury in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions yesterday, after four hours' deliberation, returned a verdict of guilty of kidnapping against Gong Goo, 49 years old, a Chinese waiter, on the complaint of Miss Betty Chun, 24, also a Chinese.

Awaited eagerly, the first number of Professor MOLEY'S "independent national weekly" greets the public this morning. In appearance, in make-up, in the variety and substance of its articles, it promises to meet even the most generous expectations. General JOHNSON writes of "Common Sense and the NRA."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Funeral services -were held in St. Patrick's Catholic Church here today for Mrs. John Egan, mother of Colonel Raphael Egan, former commander of the 156th Field Artillery, and of James Egan, public administrator in New York and former secretary of the Tammany Society.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- Yale's starting line-up for the game against the Army in the Bowl Saturday was announced tonight by Head Coach Reg Root as follows:

An emergency crew from the Liberty Avenue police station raided and demolished last night a "pirates' den" in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. The "pirates," ranging in age from 10 to 15 years, fled as the police approached. Not more than a dozen of them, lurking in the distant shadows, witnessed the work of destruction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A bid made by a local Ford dealer on light trucks for the Civilian Conservation Corps brought a test today which may help decide the status of the Ford Motor Company as a potential government contractor.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Attorney General William A. Schnader of Pennsylvania served formal notice today on Attorney General Hal L. Norwood of Arkansas that he would institute proceedings in the United States Supreme Court on Nov. 6 looking toward requiring Arkansas to fulfill its State highway bond obligations.

Samuel Untermyer, in his capacity as financial adviser to the city, was described yesterday as "Public Enemy No. 1" by George V. McLaughlin, former State Banking Commissioner and former Police Commissioner.

Aside from the gold price adjustment, to which Wall Street has been unable to adapt itself, one incident yesterday which may have interfered in some degree with the progress of the share market was the reduction in dividend rate of Consolidated Gas of New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Princeton University has operated without a deficit during the depression and has balanced its budget for next year, according to the first annual report of the president of the university, Harold Willis Dodds.

The sharp improvement in operations of the steel industry during the third quarter of this year was reflected yesterday in the report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which showed a net loss of only $283,097 for the period ended on Sept. 30, compared with a net loss of $3,312,846 in the second quarter, and a net loss of $5,425,724 in the third quarter of last year.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 27. -- Premier Albert Sarraut has formed his Cabinet. At 8 o'clock last evening he announced to President Albert Lebrun that he would undertake the mission that had been confided to him and at 1 o'clock this morning announced who his colleagues in the Cabinet would be.

The annual fund-raising campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association began last night with a rally and entertainment in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The campaign will continue until Nov. 15, or later, and will attempt to raise $220,000 for the association's 1934 budget requirements.
In addition to the usual dwelling turnover, New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday included a taxpayer, a factory and an acreage tract.

Speculative operations on the Stock Exchange as well as in the commodity markets were conducted more cautiously yesterday and, except for a rather sharp decline in wheat, there were no price movements of consequence. Realizing sales must have been largely responsible for the weakness in both securities and commodities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 25, unless otherwise specified:
The Arctic gale that swept across Canada and the Northern United States Tuesday passed far out to sea yesterday, leaving in its wake snow and frigid temperatures.
A bronze bust of Dr. John H. Finley, who celebrated his seventieth birthday last week, was unveiled yesterday in the Great Hall of City College, of which he was president from 1903 until 1913.
With the arrival of eight carloads of pork from the Federal Government today the city's needy will prepare to go on a diet of salt pork through the Winter.
NEW YORK. Mrs. K. Stone Hoyt will give a supper-dance for her debutante daughter, Miss Virginia Hoyt, at the Court House, 205 East Sixty-fourth Street, Dec. 29.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday in sympathy with those in other markets and closed with losses of 10 to 15 points.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

A cross-section of the everyday lives of the nearly 10,000,000 gainfully occupied women in the United States was pictured yesterday at a conference of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Associations.

A "hands-off" policy in the problems of distant foreign countries was advocated for the United States yesterday by Senator William G. McAdoo of California, who returned from a trip to Europe on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Mr. McAdoo was accompanied by his wife, who joined him in Europe after he had made an inspection tour of Russia.

The Sophie Irene Loeb Playground at Henry and Market Streets was dedicated yesterday afternoon by officials of the Park Department and others interested in the city's playground development. The ceremony, under the auspices of the department's Bureau of Recreation.

When Miss PERKINS entered upon her duties as Secretary of Labor she found that the department was largely preoccupied with matters concerning immigration. This service alone absorbed 3,659 of the 5,113 employes and nearly $10,000,000 of the $13,500,000 appropriated for the entire department.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 27. -- For about six hours during the night concern had been felt here for the safety of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who had taken off from Inverness, Scotland, at 1:30 yesterday afternoon for a secret destination.

While the Federal Reserve System further reduced its open-market operations to $25,000,000 in the purchases of government securities in the last week, seasonal influences continued to swell member bank reserves so that the excess reserves rose to a high record of $850,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Hollywood forgot its class distinctions among actors today when the Screen Actors Guild announced that extra and bit players would be taken into the organization in its fight against "salary control" features of the proposed picture industrial code.

Formal organization of the Family Welfare Committee of New York City, which will seek to "rehabilitate and rebuild American family life'' was affected yesterday at a meeting of its executive committee at the State Chamber of Commerce Building, 65 Liberty Street.

"Oh what a tangled web we weave when first we practice to" -- raise prices by government fiat! Of the national and even international aspects of the problem it is not intended here to speak. Consider only New York State's difficulties with a single commodity -- milk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Official, diplomatic and resident society was represented in the capacity audience which greeted in Constitution Hall tonight the National Symphony Orchestra, directed by Hans Kindler, at the first of its Thursday evening concerts.

It would take an agile thief to dodge the bullets of the night and day guards of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who showed steady aim at their fifth annual pistol competition yesterday afternoon at the museum.

Bank clearings showed further improvement in the last week, and are again better than for most of the earlier weeks since the unusual spurt in July, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which records a total of $4,674,939,000 in the week ended on Wednesday for twenty-one leading cities in the United States, a gain of 10.4 per cent over last year.

The Swedish Government is planning to offer to American holders of its $30,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1954, at the option of the holders, internal 3 1/2 per cent perpetual kroner bonds. This is in line with the government's policy of refunding its high interest-bearing debt.

The Board of Estimate, despite Its avowed opposition to any general pay cut for city employes, voted yesterday to consider this economy as well as others amounting to $15,000,000 which were submitted by Samuel Untermyer, financial adviser to the city, at a budget hearing in City Hall.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Oct. 26. -- The Boys Club of 161 Avenue A, Manhattan, receives $50,000 under the will of Charles H. Sabin of Manhattan and Southampton, chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company, which was filed here today.

GENEVA, Oct. 26. -- The Disarmament Conference's general commission unanimously adopted today the proposal of the bureau or steering committee that it adjourn until Dec. 4 and leave the bureau to prepare meanwhile a revised convention text for its second reading then.

The Tidewater Building Co. has obtained the contract for the erection of a six-story salesroom building at the southeast corner of Jamaica Av. and 166th St., Jamaica, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. The building will be erected from plans by De Young Moscowitz, architects, for the Felberose Holding Corp. at a cost of $210, 000. The building Has been leased to Spear Co.

A program providing for the placing of an additional 40,359 unemployed now on home relief in emergency jobs was announced yesterday by the City Emergency Work, and Relief Administration, of which Commissioner Frank J. Taylor of the Department of Welfare is chairman.

Severe storms in Canada and in our Northern States within the last forty-eight hours can be depended upon to hasten the movement of great flocks of flight ducks toward this general region. While thousands of ducks already have reached the warmer climate afforded by Long Island Sound, the majority now here are native blacks.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Three more stakes were completed today at the tenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association. The Open All-age Stake, the leading event for the cocker spaniels, was won by H.E. Mellenthine of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., with his noted champion, My Own High Time, which repeated his victory of a year ago in this competition.

The $50,000,000 bank loans of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., due yesterday, were extended for one year, with interest at 5 3/4 per cent. The Electric Bond and Share Company, which controls American and Foreign Power, in turn purchased $10,000,000 of the renewed loans from the banks.

Prices on local commodity exchanges yesterday, after three consecutive days of gains, underwent the first sharp reaction since President Roosevelt announced on Sunday his latest policy with respect to raising price levels. All active staples except coffee and sugar lost an important part of their upturns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A statement that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration had been studying a general plan for fixing the price of wheat at its pre-war level through marketing agreements with millers was made today by George N. Peek, Farm Administrator.

No one objects to a hard-hitting campaign. But the blows must be fair. This is a rule which both leading candidates for the Mayoralty have not always observed. Major LAGUARDIA maintains that he was careful not to mix up the two FLYNNS of the Bronx, though many thought he did.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: THE TIMES editorial "Bench Candidates" admirably sets forth the problems which face the independent voter. You point out that this year the independent voter "has an unusual opporunity to discriminate," and recommend five names to fill the five places on the Supreme Court bench.

Juan Reyes, the Chilean pianist, who made his New York debut last night in Town Hall, played the Chromatic Fantasie and Fugue of Bach in Emil Sauer's edition, Beethoven's rondo in G major, Chopin's sonata in B minor, a group of shorter pieces, including Albeniz's "Malaguena," one of the dances from de Falla's "La Vida Breve," Schumann's "Aria" and Sauer's "Etude Caprice" and "Espenloub" and the Wagner-Liszt "Tannhauser Overture."

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- A 12-year-old boy's plea to President Roosevelt, made without his parents' knowledge, resulted today in the first New Jersey loan by the Home Owners Loan Corporation being received by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Schmidt of 118 Dayton Street, this city.

Members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, at their convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday, were urged not to vote for any of "the three men running for Mayor" unless they included in their platform specific provision for the care of unemployed single women, including "permanent" housing for them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 21 totaled 650,482 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 13,576 cars, or 2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 8,497 cars, or 1.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 119,191 cars, or 15.5 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged the city government last night with, "ruthless exploitation of labor" in opposition to the principles of the NRA. He spoke at three Brooklyn meetings, at Grand Paradise Hall, 318 Grand Street, in Williamsburg; at Socialist party headquarters, 844 Utica Avenue, and at Casa d'Amor, Mermaid Avenue and West Thirty-fifth Street, Coney Island.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 27. -- The annual meeting of the Lenox Horse Show Association was held today at the Lenox Club. R. Jay Flick was re-elected president. The other officers chosen were honorary president, Miss Kate Gary; vice president, a newly created office, Harris Fahnestock; secretary and treasurer, Charles Astor Bristed.

The recently organized regional labor mediation board, of which George W. Alger is chairman, will begin work on Monday, when it will attempt to settle the strike of 3,500 shipyard workers employed in this area. The board was named by Senator Robert F. Wagner to handle local labor problems.

Prices were generally lower yesterday in all groups of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The declines were not severe, even in individual issues. Not often of late have foreign loans and United States Government obligations moved lower in unison, but yesterday the Washington issues fell 1-32 to 5-32 point as several leading foreign loans receded a point or more.

Discussion of the America's Cup challenge from the Royal Yacht Squadron featured a dinner following the annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound last night at the Yale Club.

Representatives of nine retail trade associations and the city's leading department stores were pushing their preparations yesterday for setting up the New York City Retail Code Authority in cooperation with Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local NRA organization.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 27 (AP). -- J.N. Darling, Des Moines cartoonist, known as Ding, told this story tonight after his return from a fishing trip with former President Herbert Hoover:

Is it good news or bad that Mr. HUGH WALPOLE brings from Oxford? He finds the university city congested, packed, jammed with novel writers. This is good news, say we. One grand sweet song of typewriters comes to the ear from all directions. Every place has the Oxonian habit.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Reverberations of student strikes and protests against Governor Robert H. Gore of Puerto Rico reached Washington today.

Old Man Constitution walked into the Board of Estimate during the budget hearings this week. It was his first visit in many months. As he ranks every member of the board, including the Mayor himself, and is in fact the penultimate authority on all matters of civic government, being subject only to the popular will, deliberately expressed, his words always command respect.

DETROIT, Oct. 27. -- The Ford Motor Company broke today the silence it has long maintained in relation to the NRA automobile code, which it has refused to sign. In a statement issued today the company attacked the Recovery Administrator, General Johnson, as "assuming the airs of a dictator," and asserted it was being singled out for unfair treatment.

While the markets for agricultural staples continued yesterday to advance rather excitedly, stocks refused again to show enthusiasm for the government's new gold-buying policy. The modest rise in prices on the Stock Exchange was not comparable to that in grains.

How the tomb of an Egyptian high priest of about 2000 B.C. was discovered and a little more light was thrown on ancient life along the Nile is disclosed in the report just issued by the Metropolitan Museum of Art of the work of its Egyptian and Persian expeditions during the 1932-33 season.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 20 (By Mail). -- Atom smashing has revealed new secrets about the hidden energy of the building blocks of matter which may some day serve as power in a super-machine-age civilization.

ATHENS, Oct. 27. -- The trial of the United States Government's application for the extradition from Greece of Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities chief, closed at 8:50 o'clock tonight, after a three-hour rebuttal by State Prosecutor Riganakos had been replied to briefly by Mr. Insull's counsel.

LONDON, Oct. 37. -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's radio speech last Sunday, in which Mr. Roosevelt proclaimed the new American gold policy. The London Week-End Review will say tomorrow that the "American election of a year ago represented not merely a change of government but a revolution, in which the initiative and administration passed from the hands of creditors to the hands of debtors."

To the Editor of the Times: European advocates of a managed currency, which appears to be President Roosevelt's latest experiment, have not advocated its use, as far as I am aware, as a means to force up the prices of commodities of which there is a great surplus constantly pressing on the markets, and yet this is just what the President apparently intends to do.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27. -- Winooka, reputed Australian sprint champion, failed in his attempt to vindicate himself for his defeat in the special international sweepstakes last Wednesday when he finished a hard-driven third in the featured six-furlong Westover Handicap today.

Foreign trade in September reversed its record of the previous month. In August a substantial increase of imports and a sharp decline of exports gave us the largest "unfavorable" balance for any month in seven years. September showed enough improvement in our export trade, and a sufficient decline in the value of our imports, for the balance to shift to the "favorable" side by a margin of $13,000,000.
Little happened in the money market to distinguish it from trading in early week. Business was small and quotations for all classes unchanged from Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The index number of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor showed a continued weakening of prices during the week ending Oct. 21 and receded almost to the level of the week ending Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- An allowance for "actual wages," probably on a 10 per cent basis, involving all branches of the trade covered by the retail code will be announced in a few days and will be mandatory on all retail units, Hugh S. Johnson, NRA administrator, said this afternoon.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 27. -- Among those who had luncheon at the Casino today were Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed, Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph R. Loening and Mrs. John Gilbert.

The Greek Byzantine Vocal Ensemble, which sang last night in the Town Hall, has previously distinguished itself for a moving exposition of music rarely heard in the concert hall -- traditional Byzantine liturgy, fragments of classic Greek music traceable, perhaps, to the golden age of Pindar, and modern Greek folk-song.
DENVER, Oct. 27. -- Days as of Fifty-nine, when gold first lured men to the banks of Cherry Creek and the bed of Russell Gulch, are here again.

If the new monetary policy of the United States results in seriously altering the relation between sterling and the dollar, Great Britain will be compelled to take defensive measures, Sir Robert Home, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, asserted yesterday in an address before the Bond Club of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The obvious halting in the progress of the recovery program is causing considerable apprehension in many quarters. The slowing up was to be expected as an inevitable feature of any operation requiring the coordination of a number of human activities.
Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, returned yesterday with Mrs. Kreisler on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for his Fall and Winter tour.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 27. -- John D. Fackler of Cleveland is organizing a fox hunt to take place tomorrow in Kates Mountain. Among the many joining the chase will be Charles H. Thieriot of New York, Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw and Russell H. Johnson of Boston, G.R. Leonard of Chicago and Mrs. Albert B. Dewey.

The railroads east of the Mississippi River and north of the Potomac voted almost unanimously yesterday to institute proceedings before the Interstate Commerce Commission to prevent the Pennsylvania Railroad from providing door delivery and collection throughout its system on Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The circular of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation describing the notes which it will exchange for newly mined gold and the procedure to be followed in making applications follows:
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 27. -- Bronze medals for acts of heroism were awarded by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today, three of them posthumously, to men and boys of New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Securities in the United Kingdom experienced only a temporary reaction to the strengthening of the American dollar, according to the weekly report today of the Department of Commerce on foreign business conditions, based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

Pending further study of the Manhattan approaches to the proposed midtown tunnel under the Hudson River to New Jersey, the Board of Estimate deferred action yesterday for two weeks on the plans for the project submitted by the Port Authority.

BATH, S.C., Oct. 27 (AP). -- National Guard troops moved late today into the troubled Horse Creek Valley textile manufacturing area, scene this morning of a clash between State highway patrolmen and strikers during which the officers released tear gas and the strikers hurled stones.

WARSAW, Oct. 27. -- By an order today from the Minister of Education the University of Warsaw was closed indefinitely. Thus the Minister confirmed the decision of the university senate that work should be suspended following the tumultuous riots which culminated in the shooting and serious injury of five students.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 27. -- The first New York University football team to cross the Mason and Dixon Line is quartered here tonight awaiting tomorrow's intersectional clash with the University of Georgia at Sanford Stadium.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- G. Frank Shanley, manager of the Federal Home Loan Owners Corporation, announced today the appointment of James Gerity of Woodbridge as Assistant State Appraiser at $3,500 a year.
PARIS, Oct. 27. -- A Belgian company has threatened to withdraw from the International Steel Cartel, but this is not expected to lead to withdrawal of the entire Belgian group.

HELSINGFORS, Oct. 27. -- A month after Lieutenant Vilho Pentikainen, photographer of the Finnish General Staff, mysteriously fled to Russia the political police, after a strenuous investigation, report the discovery of a spy organization of much larger dimensions than had been expected and showing that Pentikainen was a member of an international force.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Led by President Green, of the American Federation of Labor, spokesmen for about 1,500,000 building trades workers called upon General Johnson today to protest provisions in the master code for the construction industry proposed by the Construction League.

ONCE Owen Wister was sitting in the White House talking government with Theodore Roosevelt. Alice Roosevelt rushed in, said how d'ye do, and rushed out. The talk went on. Alice suddenly reappeared and vanished. The talk again started. Alice came in again. Her father said:

In an effort to get producers and custom smelters of copper to agree on provisions to be included in a code for the industry, H.O. King, NRA representative in charge of the copper code, will meet on Monday morning with representatives of the custom smelters and in the aftenoon with the producers.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27. -- With many delegates to the Seventh Pan-American Conference already en route to Montevideo, the preconference atmosphere daily is becoming more sombre. Fresh outbreaks of political violence were reported today in the Uruguayan capital.

We think we know fairly well the French artists of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, only to discover, upon occasion, traits we had not glimpsed before or to which we had not given much thought.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Published rumors, said to have originated in diplomatic circles, that the mission sent here to discuss a rearrangement of the British wartime debt to the United States might soon return to London without a conclusion having been reached could not be verified here today.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The Soviet Foreign Commissar, Maxim Litvinoff, arrived late tonight from Moscow en route to the United States and departed an hour later for Berlin without revealing what ship he would take.

A ragged start, in which Wedding Ring was away winging, decided the issue in the featured Hollyhock Purse at Empire City yesterday. The 11-to-5 favorite, Zorana, was caught napping at the break and General A., heavily backed second choice at 12 to 5, also was slow to begin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would be ready within a week to announce the policies that will guide the government in its new approach to the liquor problem.

A first-half attack netting three touchdowns featured the Manhattan freshman football team's triumph over the Dean Academy eleven, 25-6, at Manhattan Field yesterday. The victory was the third in as many games for the Jasper cubs.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upheld yesterday a decision by Justice Albert Cohn, striking the name of Alfred E. Herz from the ballot as candidate on the Fusion ticket for Municipal Court Justice in the Sixth District. His nominating petition was opposed by Justice Samuel Ecker, on the ground that it had not contained sufficient legal signatures.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Political gossip columns purporting to tell the story behind the news was a topic under consideration by the managing editors of Associated Press newspapers at their annual meeting here today.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Federal Judge Philip Forman today continued indefinitely a hearing on a motion by a group of stockholders of the closed Broad Street National Bank of Red Bank for an order restraining L.K. Roberts, chief national bank examiner in the New York Federal Reserve District, from levying a 100 per cent assessment against stockholders of the bank.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The Princeton varsity and freshman cross-country teams defeated the rival Columbia harriers today over the Princeton course. The varsity won by 17 -- 38, while the freshmen triumphed by 22 -- 33.

The Board of Estimate received a request yesterday from Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor for a revolving relief fund of $15,000,000 and referred the matter to its committee of the whole for action next Tuesday.
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, who put forth a twenty-one point platform in a speech Thursday night, added twelve points to it last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The motion picture code, still containing provisions designed to curb the payment of excessively high salaries, was delivered late today by Deputy Recovery Administrator Sol A. Rosenblatt to his chief, Hugh S. Johnson, for the latter's approval.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, sent a telegram last night to General Hugh S. Johnson complaining that the Recovery party had adopted the NRA symbols in a campaign folder. He also sent a telegram to Colonel Louis McH. Howe, chief of the White House secretarial staff and close friend and adviser of President Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- Noel Panter, correspondent in Germany of The London Daily Telegraph, who has been arrested in Munich and who for two days was held incomunicado, is to be tried before the Supreme Court in Leipzig on a charge of treason to the State.

Eight haggard years ago Harry Delf wrote a comedy called "The Family Upstairs." Its disappearance from Broadway, while not meteoric, was rapid enough to give rise to the speculation that what Broadway didn't want was family life on the East Side.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 27. -- The Jews here are becoming increasingly perturbed by anonymous anti-Jewish propaganda that has been spread in growing volume during the last few weeks. It is presumed that the propaganda emanates from Nazi sources.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- The German Government today notified the World Court at The Hague that "in conformity with Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations," it would also cease to appear as plaintiff before The Hague tribunal.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Fleet of Falcon Hill, white-and-liver English springer spaniel puppy dog owned by Henry L. Ferguson of Fishers Island and handled in all his stakes by William Sinclair, was named the winner of the William Rauch Memorial Challenge Trophy today.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor still leads in the latest tabulation of the poll of the Literary Digest published today, but Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate, is revealed as having made considerable gaine.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Six schoolboys of the Riverdale Country Scheol were injured here today when a bus in which they were being driven to their homes was in a crash with a truck at the point where Park Avenue turns into Ashburton Avenue.

Retail trade responded to the first touch of wintry weather, which gave a sudden spurt to the movement of seasonal merchandise, although department stores depended heavily on profit-sharing sales to move stocks, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Five Naval Reserve planes from Floyd Bennett Field took the air yesterday afternoon, flew east and circled the grave of Theodore Roosevelt at Oyster Bay, where they dropped cascades of flowers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The Yale and Army elevens today held their final practice in adjacent fields before their thirty-third annual meeting tomorrow in the Bowl before an estimated attendance of 50,000.

Dry Goods Jobbers Cautious. Although sentiment in the various primary dry goods markets showed distinct improvement during the week, jobbers held down their orders. In the last two weeks, it was said, sales to their retail accounts have fallen off, in line with the decline seasonal at this time of the year.

The Constitution of the United States was the only charter of the first rate powers of the world which remained intact after the troublous times of the last decade, said Dr. Charles Jacob Smith, president of Roanoke College, at the annual dinner of the Southern Society at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The importance of maintaining educational facilities in a changing social world and of revising curricula to meet the needs of a collective society was impressed upon 9,000 teachers in convention here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Government officials have undertaken a broad study in an effort to determine the extent that speculative trading on the stock and grain exchanges contributes to free markets.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Premier Albert Sarraut and all of France's most famous air aces tonight honored Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh at a private dinner at the home of the famous flier, Captain Dieudonne Coste.
Major Gen. and Mrs. A.W. Brewster and Senator Giovanni Agnelli are sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia. Other passengers include:

Recent discovery of a portrait or copy of a portrait of HENRY VIII by HOLBEIN, the so-called Castle Howard Holbein, has led Dr. IVO GEIKIE COBB, author of "Glands of Destiny," to a more momentous discovery. After long perusal of the features of Brother Bluebeard, he is convinced that the old boy suffered from deficiency of the thyroid gland:

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES Berlin correspondent reports Dr. Henseling as propounding "the startling theory that civilization was not cradled in the Old World but in the Americas."
