In all justice, however, and without depreciating the findings of the German astronomer, it should be added that his conclusions no more than augment with astronomical evidence the similar findings of other modern investigators, such as Niven, Le Plongeon and Dr. Spinden.

Several influences operated to steady prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, the most important being a sharp falling off in the marketing movement, as the amount brought into sight ran nearly 100,000 bales under the total of last week and 50,000 under that a year ago.

The seventy-fifth birthday anniversary of the late Theodore Roosevelt was commemorated by the Roosevelt Memorial Association last night by award of the Roosevelt Medal to Stephen Vincent Benet, author of the narrative poem, "John Brown's Body."

ROME, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Fascism is ''the hope of the world," Premier Mussolini says in a message to the Black Shirts which is to be read in every town in Italy tomorrow on the eleventh anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome. The message reads:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been spending a few days in New York. I am at a loss to know under just what caption to write. Shall I make it "The New York That is Glamour" or, more cynically, "The Glamour That Is New York"? The truth is, of course, that my view of the metropolis is kaleidoscopic rather than panoramic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The National Recovery Act and the codes and agreements established under it have created a "series of new rights and obligations between employer and employe," according to Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, who outlined today the work and scope of the regional labor boards now being established.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 27. -- Unterrified by recent bombing attempts and the warning of a poison plot, Governor Gore said this afternoon his belief still was that the bombs had not been intended to kill him or any member of his family, but only to frighten him.

New Jersey shortly will embark upon a new game experiment which should attract the attention of State conservation officials and sportsmen the country over. Both will have a vital interest in the successful culmination of the project.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Harry F. Cowan, manufacturer of silk neckwear, his wife Fanny, a woman guest and the Cowan maid were trussed with rope in the Cowan home on the Parl way here tonight by five men, all armed with automatic pistols.

Only $6,415,027 of new municipal bond issues will come up for award pejct week, compared with this waek's revised total of $39,514,559 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $13,900,214. This respite in financing will come at a time when many municipal bankers are attending the convention of the Investment Bankers Association at Hot Springs, Va.
Flashing a high-grade defense When pressed and staging an alert attack, the Poly Prep football team defeated Brooklyn Prep, 6 to 0, yesterday before 2,500 at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium.

Alfred E. Smith and Nathan L. Miller, former Governors of the State, appeared as character witnesses yesterday in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court for Isidor J. Kresel, on trial on charges that he abetted in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh lost another round last night in his long fight for anonymity when he and Mrs. Lindbergh arrived in Paris. Every arrangement had been made for the utmost secrecy. The Hotel Crillon, where rooms had been reserved by the Air Ministry, was under strict orders to reveal to no one the return to Paris of the man whom Paris made famous.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Eight thousand Illinois farmers, embittered over the price and the government loan limit on corn, swarmed into Peoria today for a protest meeting, but left, pledging support to Washington.

When ex-Governor SMITH was asked at Chicago what he thought about the New York City Mayoralty election, he replied: "The lid is on." Apparently he means to keep it on. Though the campaign is drawing to an end, he has not yet openly said a word regarding his political position or personal choice.

Being disillusioned over the divinity of money, Howard Koch has libeled it in an earnest play, "Give Us This Day," which was acted at the Booth last evening. It is the saga of the Strong family, who wait like buzzards for the death of the matriarch who controls the family fortune.
With both teams In top form and enjoying undefeated records for the season, Fordham's eleven and the sturdy University of Alabama team will clash at the Polo Grounds starting at 2:30 o'clock today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Harvard and Dartmouth will draw a crowd of 50,000 for their annual football game in the stadium tomorrow if the day is fair. There was a rush of ticket-seekers today.

Too Far Back. Digging up Mr. McKEE'S antisuffrage views as of the year 1915 is really too much. Digging up any person's views of eighteen years ago on any subject is absurd; and they have been such eighteen years!

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Attorneys for Harold F. McCormick were preparing his answer today to the $1,500,000 breach of promise suit brought by Mrs. Rhoda Tanner Doubleday of New York. It will contain a flat denial of the allegations, it was said, and set at rest rumors that the defendant will not permit the case to come to trial.

Into the legal or social aspects of the controversy between HENRY FORD and General JOHNSON we have no intention to go. But one cannot withhold a certain admiration of the statement in its own behalf made by the Ford Company. It points to its well-known record for thirty years.

Traditional games, which will mark the renewals of rivalries started many years ago, top today's widespread program of prep school football contests in the East. The outstanding attractions include the Lawrenceville-Hill and Choate-Loomis encounters at Pottstown, Pa., and Windsor, Conn., respectively.

In the North, South, East and West a good many of the major football teams of the country stand at something of a crossroads today. On this last Saturday of Octobei the trails of unbeaten teams are beginning to cross and the preliminary barrage of football's first month is ended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, repudiated today the policy of the Wiggin regime under which millions of shares of the bank's stock were bought and sold in so-called "pools" operated by its investment affiliates.
SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The Westminster and Hopkins Grammar School football teams played a scoreless tie today.

The Paramount-Publix Corporation transactions with banks, prior to its bankruptcy earlier this year, were taken up yesterday in the course of an examination of Adolph Zukor, president of the company, at a hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at 140 Nassau Street.

Minneapolis, Minn. Salomon Bros. Hutzler won yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 city of Minneapolis relief bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1935 to 1944. The price paid was 100.755 for the bonds as 4 1/2s. The WellsDickey Company and Fhelps, Fenn Co. jointly bid 100.75.

Acting on the recommendation of Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly, the Board of Estimate deferred yesterday for one week its vote on the proposed twenty-five-year Manhattan bus franchise contracts with the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Madison Avenue Coach Company and the Comprehensive Bus Corporation.

JAFFA, Palestine, Oct. 27. -- More than twenty persons were killed and about 130 were wounded here today in a clash between police and Arabs when the latter attempted to hold a demonstration of protest against Jewish immigration into Palestine.

A book-review contest, with professional reviewers barred, is announced by Abraham Straus as a forerunner to its book fair next month. Contestants may select what they consider the most important novel of this year and write 400 words about it.

NEW YORK. Many New York debutantes will go to Boston for the dinner dance which Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lyman are giving Nov. 1 at their home to introduce their daughter, Miss Lydia Lyman, and Miss Margot Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Langdon Warner of Cambridge, Mass. Miss Warner is a granddaughter of Mrs. J. West Roosevelt of New York and Oyster Bay.

The firm of Jackson Bros., Boesel Co. announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement, effective on Nov. 1, whereby virtually all of its Western offices, as well as certain Western correspondent connections, will be acquired by Winthrop, Mitchell Co., whose wire services duplicate those of Jackson Bros., Boesel Co. at several points.

A Jump of 25 per cent in attendance during the New York racing season was one of the most interesting developments of an analysis made yesterday by officials. This increase, while encouraging from the standpoint of greater interest on the part of the public, means little so far as total income is concerned, since the admission prices were approximately 331-3 per cent lower than last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Speaking at a meeting of the New Jersey Joint Committee on Economic Food Distribution here today, William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co., declared that "most of the NRA codes have come to mean nothing more than a new form of profiteering."

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- Warning from Dr. Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, against speculative excesses produced some liquidation by professional traders on the Boerse today. Despite this, the market was comparatively steady. Some specialties even registered minor gains.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Plans of the automobile industry's leaders to have virtually every 1933 model out of dealers' hands by the end of the year appear to be well on the way to fulfillment with current production dropping behind retail distribution.

A Federal warrant for the arrest of Heinz Spanknoebel was issued here yesterday on the ground that he was acting, or purporting to act, as an agent of the German Government in the United States without notifying the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The government today advanced the quotation at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy gold newly mined in the United States to $31.76 an ounce, an increase of 80 cents over the London world market price in dollars.

Wall Street showed an increasingly skeptical attitude yesterday toward the government's gold and currency management plan. This was reflected most strikingly in the share market, where transactions were slow and price movements narrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The entire United States delegation to the Pan American Conference at Montevideo will sail from New York on the steamship American Legion on Nov. 11, Secretary Hull announced today. Mr. Hull has definitely given up his previous intention of leaving a week earlier to hold consultations en route with the governments of Peru, Chile and Argentina.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Reorganization of local governments to eliminate waste and overlapping in thousands of offices was advocated by Postmaster General Farley at a luncheon meeting with 300 Democrats of the six counties of the Fifth Judicial District here this afternoon.
AMHERST vs. Wesleyan -- Douglas round him drew his cloak, folded his arms, and thus he spoke (this just by way of Scott-ish joke): one vote for Amherst.

Sales of wholesale firms in the New York Federal Reserve district were 15 1/2 per cent higher in September than a year before, representing the fifth consecutive monthly increase, according to the Nov. 1 review of credit and business conditions reported to the Federal Reserve agent in New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- A sharp difference of opinion within President Roosevelt's own official family as to the results of the recovery program arose today as a result of references in the monthly Federal Reserve bulletin to the slowing down of activity in industries "in which processing taxes or codes have become effective recently."
PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Estimates here of the probable life of the Cabinet of Albert Sarraut range up to three months, but no more.

A United Foreign Missionary Conference will open in this city tomorrow evening and close Friday afternoon. Similar conferences are to be held simultaneously in twenty-nine-cities in sixteen States. Never before have virtually all the Protestant foreign mission boards combined in such a united effort.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- The prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial scored a technical advantage today that, however illusory to neutral eyes, fully revealed the jeopardy of the defendants should the court permit political passion to sway its judgment.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- There was opened at the United States Embassy today a unique exhibition of portraits of five Lords Baltimore of the famous Calvert family which colonized and governed Maryland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Those who have known the depth of the hidden conflict in the administration over policies and methods of recovery have been awaiting some such open dispute as that represented in the divergence of opinion tonight between General Hugh Johnson and the Federal Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today authorized the purchase of $25,000,000 of capital notes of the Manufacturers Trust Company, the first of the big New York City banks to participate in the administration's program to strengthen the capital structure of banks throughout the country, enhance their loaning facilities and enable their joining in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Announcement of the award of fifteen Harvard prize scholarships to entering freshmen was made by the committee on scholarships at Harvard College.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- A three-wheeled automobile upset here today while speeding down the outer drive near the World's Fair grounds, resulting in the death of its American driver and serious injuries to two foreign visitors who had arrived on the Graf Zeppelin.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The Irish Free State army team came close to a clean sweep in. the feature jumping event at tonight's session of the World's Fair Horse Show. The Irish riders took first, second and fourth places in an international military test over the "figure eight" course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- President Roosevelt and his advisers are considering asking Congress to increase the huge fund set aside for public works construction in an effort to stimulate employment.

Advances in commodity futures were resumed yesterday among the principal staples, activity increasing in numerous instances on the various exchanges. Cash prices also went higher. Regarded as a whole, however, the volume of trading decreased as a result of the completion of short covering and of profit-taking operations.

BOSTON, Oct. 27. -- Two men were arrested as gold hoarders here today. One, a clerk in the city Welfare Department, was charged with withdrawing $10,000; the other, a lawyer engaged in attempting to win nearly $1,000,000 from a group of bankers, was charged with withdrawing $2,000 in violation of the President's order against hoarding.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Wheat resumed its upward course today on the Board of Trade after early hesitation. Reports that the government was buying cash wheat in carlots here and in other leading markets started the reinstatement of lines by operators who had sold out yesterday, and prices ran up rapidly to a new high mark on the current movement.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27. -- Fighting in the Chaco has been renewed, the Paraguayan War Minister announcing a six-mile advance and the occupation of five miles of Bolivian lines.

Czechoslovakia enters today upon the fourth quinquennial of her independent existence as a nation. We of America should have special pride in marking the day in our calendar, for it was here, in the very city in which our own independence was declared, that MASARYK, her blacksmith, schoolmaster leader, issued his Declaration of Independence for Czechoslovakia.

Operating details of the new transatlantic service created by the merger of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American lines have been completed in the past week after a series of conferences of representatives of the two groups.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, business agent of Local 594 of the United Sea Food Workers Union in Fulton Market, and two other union men were acquitted in Special Sessions yesterday on a charge of conspiring to coerce a fish dealer to recognize the union.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's terminal and yards in this city are to be reconstructed at a cost of at least $900,000 for use of the unified seashore lines of the Pennsylvania and Reading companies, it was announced today by James O. Hackenberg, general manager of the joint lines.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press) . -- Twenty-five persons, passengers and crews of two lake boats, are missing following violent squalls on the northern end of Lake Winnipeg. The boats are five days overdue and grave fears are entertained for the safety of the missing men.

Appropriately enough, the first play to be presented here dealing realistically with Nazi anti-Semitism was produced in Yiddish last night at the Second Avenue Theatre. It is called "Germany Aflame" and is the work of Ossip Dymow, last represented in the theatre by his "Bronx Express."

The City Campaign. Samuel Seabury accused Joseph V. McKee, the Recovery party candidate, of "hushing up," in violation of a solemn promise, charges contained in an affidavit made by Francis T. McEneny.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27. -- After days of bickering the House of Deputies today referred to committee further consideration of Finance Minister Gustavo Ross's bill creating a new sales corporation to replace the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, which is in process of dissolution.

PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 28. -- Pertinax in this morning's Echo de Paris sharply assails United States Ambasador-at-Large Norman H. Davis for his insistence that the disarmament bureau meet as soon as possible.

A suit for $2,000,000 for libel was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Princess Irina Youssoupoff, wife of Prince Felix Youssoupoff and cousin of King George V of England, against the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Corporation, producer of the film "Rasputin and the Empress."

Hendrik Willem Van Loon returned yesterday from a three months' visit to Germany, Holland and France on the Cunarder Aquitania. He plans to write another book before he makes his first voyage round the world on the Franconia next January.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Oct. 28. -- Further sharp recessions in Chinese Government bonds during a turnover exceeding $20,000,000 accompanied virtual confirmation today of T.V. Soong's resignation of the finance portfolio. Chinese banks were the largest sellers of the bonds.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold to an investing client of Louis Lustig, a broker, the fivestory brownstone house, on a lot 19.6 by 100 feet, at 123 East Thirtieth Street. The building was recently altered for a rooming house.

B. Coles Neidecker, an American banker in Paris, sailed last night for France on the Majestic to prepare in definite form plans for large-scale purchases of American cotton by French interests. He is understood to have had a favorable reception in Washington, where the plans he presented were said to be in line with government policy.

Columbia will attempt to rejoin the ranks of victors today when it encounters Penn State at Baker Field at 2:30 P.M. It will be the first football meeting between the institutions and is expected to attract a crowd of 10,000 persons.

Members of the New York Yacht Club will meet next Thursday to consider the challenge for the America's Cup issued by the British Royal Yacht Squadron on behalf of Thomas Octave Murdoch Sopwith, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Mr. Pecora read into the Senate committee's record today a list of stocks and bonds in which the Chase Securities Corporation had dealt through pools from February, 1928, to March, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- President Roosevelt and his advisers have agreed that, barring a contrary decision by the Attorney General or the Controller General, Henry Ford is ineligible to receive government contracts.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Miss Grace Fryer, 35 years old, the twenty-second victim of radium poisoning in the old Orange plant of the United States Radium Corporation, died this morning in Homeopathic Hospital here. Her home was at 32 Carnegie Avenue, East Orange.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press) . -- Twenty-five persons, passengers and crews of two lake boats, are missing following violent squalls on the northern end of Lake Winnipeg. The boats are five days overdue and grave fears are entertained for the safety of the missing men.

Appropriately enough, the first play to be presented here dealing realistically with Nazi anti-Semitism was produced in Yiddish last night at the Second Avenue Theatre. It is called "Germany Aflame" and is the work of Ossip Dymow, last represented in the theatre by his "Bronx Express."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The "six basic principles" which in the view of the National Recovery Administration "cover practically any case of unfair practice in industry or trade" were approved today and the NRA has recommended that they be included in pending codes of fair competition.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- A smart-thinking, superbly conditioned Army eleven that exploited the quick kick and the forward pass to the bafflement of the enemy, tumbled Yale from its high place among the East's unbeaten coterie today with the most decisive victory scored by the Cadets over the Blue since 1926.

MOST of the stories in this latest collection of the inimitable Dorothy Parker -- certainly those which turn out to be the most uproariously funny -- are concerned with the regrettable but undeniable tendency of most of us to sentimentalize our emotions -- emotions which, if we were really as well-balanced as we hope we are ought to be accepted quite simply as a matter of course.

With the superb performance of Curtis High of Staten Island marking the day's program, four new individual titleholders were crowned as the Public Schools Athletic League's annual borough cross-country championship runs were held over the Van Cortlandt Park course of two and three-eighths miles yesterday.

THE American farmer is again showing signs of unrest. While the government is taking steps designed to improve his lot, he is not at all satisfied that the efforts in his direction have compared favorably with those exerted in behalf of industry and labor.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 28. -- Ohio State, beaten last week by Michigan, accomplished something no other Buckeye team has been able to do -- defeat Northwestern in the local stadium when it won, 12 to 0, today. A homecoming day crowd of 35,000 saw the victory.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Hun School suffered its first defeat since early in the 1931 season today, losing to Peddie of Hightstown, N. J., in a thrilling game. The score was 10 to 7.
PARNASSU, published by the College Art Association, has resumed for the season after Its customary Summer recess. The October number appeared last week.
DUBLIN, Oct. 27. -- The government's policy for industrial development was outlined this week by Sean Lemass, the Minister of Industry and Commerce, before the Dublin Chamber of Commerce.

NOT least among American poets of today is Robert Hillyer, who modestly calls this assemblage of his works not collected poems but "Collected Verse." On the whole, we are inclined to resent this modesty, for Mr. Hillyer's output has many just claims to the superior designation.

Two points away from a perfect score, the New York University cross-country team yesterday defeated Lafayette in their dual race over the six-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. N.Y.U. finished with the low score of 17. The harriers from Easton, Pa., had 38 points.

A defense of the "boss" system in politics featured an address by Daniel F. Cohalan, member of the Tammany war board, delivered last night at an Irish-American gathering at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Tammany's campaign headquarters.

PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The policies of former Premier Daladier, whose defeat last Tuesday was followed by the formation of the Sarraut Cabinet, will be followed almost to the letter by the new government, it was said today, particularly regarding the gold franc, armanent vigilance, strict protectionist quotas and commerce."

In the November American Mercury Mr. JONATHAN NORTON LEONARD describes a curious and charming anachronism. On Cape Cod people mind their own business. Descended from children of the sea, the natives "all possess a "peculiar combination of fractiousness "and toleration which makes them "very hard to influence and little inclined "to influence others."

The Crimson Tide of Alabama was stemmed by a tidal wave of surging Fordham linemen at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and by the margin of a safety resulting from a blocked kick the Maroon defeated the Southerners, 2 to 0.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Running back a punt fifty yards in the first five minutes of play and running back an intercepted pass 45 yards in the last five minutes of the game. Bud Sawyer scored R.P. L's two touchdowns today to defeat Union College.

OTTAWA, Oct. 26. -- The theory of State medicine, so often debated as an academic proposition, is being given a practical test, if a voluntary one, in the little Alberta town of Cardston, which has a population of 2,000. Cardston is the centre of the Mormon settlement in Southern Alberta, and it is dominated by the beautiful temple which is a shrine of the Mormon faith to which most of its citizens adhere.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 28. -- British methods of securities distribution, which involve a minimum of personal solicitation on the part of the bankers, are not generally applicable to investment banking procedure in the United States. This was the sentiment expressed at the initial forum of the twenty-second annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which opened here today.

THE committee on photoplay appreciation of the National Council of Teachers of English recommends "that units of instruction be introduced into the nation's schools, with a view to improving popular standards oftaste" in movies.
LONDON. THE reputation Burton J. Hendrick had already gained here by his Walter Hines Page books has been enhanced by his life of Andrew Carnegie, just issued by Heinemann in an English edition.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Andrew Salata, 38 years old, of Great Meadows, N.J., was killed by a hit-and-run driver early this morning on Route 29. Mr. Salata was struck as he got out of his machine to cut a piece of loose fabric that was flapping on a front tire of his truck. His son, Walter, 12, who was on the truck, said that the car was a yellow roadster.

In the October number of The Quarterly Review the Rev. CLEMENT F. ROGERS, who has been teaching Pastoral Theology for many years, makes a plea for a better understanding of social science by the clergy. He speaks with emphasis of the need of clearer ideas of "scientific sociology," but fortunately does not demand that every clergyman should devote years to its study.

Accused of purchasing a murder for $500, of an accidental killing in connection with it, and of killing the hired gunman when he demanded his fee, four Brooklyn men were held without bail by Magistrate Haubert in Brooklyn Homicide Court yesterday for further hearing Wednesday.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 28. -- The University of Georgia successfully stopped the first invasion of the South by a New York University football team in a highly impressive manner today. Playing on a Summer-like afternoon, before a homecoming day gathering of more than 25,000 spectators, the Bulldogs repulsed the Violet, 25 to 0.

All types of retailers, with the exception of those specializing in foodstuffs and tobacco, hastened the completion of plans during the week for functioning under the master retail code, which goes into effect tomorrow.
GREENCASTLE, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Henry P. Fletcher, former Ambassador to Belgium, Mexico and Italy, lined up with Henry Ford today in his differences with the National Recovery Administration.

Over the heads of producers of raw materials in all parts of the world there have hung for several years excess stocks of goods, helping to depress prices. Many devices have been resorted to in efforts to reduce these surpluses or to prevent them from piling higher still.

The Ballets Jooss, which has achieved a notable success in Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels and London with the dance drama "The Green Table," arrived from Havre yesterday on the French liner de Grasse and will make its American debut at the Forrest Theatre, in West Forty-ninth Street, on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- When Congress reluctantly departed from the capital last June, seven days later than the President wanted it to remain, there was rejoicing in Washington and elsewhere in the nation. The press was happy; business was relieved; from the general public came expressions of satisfaction; and the administration was beaming.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Arturo Toscanini's appearances here with the Straram Orchestra at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees have been, these days, social as well as musical events. For the second Wagner festival concert, which had to be repeated owing to the imperative demand, James Roosevelt, the President's son, and his wife and her sister, Mary Cushing, were guests of Countess Costantini.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- Iowa saw its Big Ten title aspirations plowed under today by Minnesota's powerful eleven, which harvested three touchdowns to give the boys from the Corn State their first football setback this year, 19 to 7.

VVith the tenth annual springer spaniel field trials at Fishers Island now a matter for the record books the followers of the cocker spaniel are looking forward to the concluding events of the Autumn field-trial calendar for their own breed.

Another performance of "Let 'Em Eat Cake" in behalf of philanthropy is scheduled for Tuesday night at the Imperial Theatre for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society. Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot, who heads the benefit committee, has enlisted the aid of many prominent women of society as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- With less than two minutes left to play and with the score 7 -- 0 against them, the Indians of Dartmouth opened the way for Bill Clark to run 55 yards for a touchdown. They then held stanchly while Donald Hagerman kicked the extra point which enabled them to tie a rugged Harvard eleven today, 7 -- 7.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Standings of the leaders in the first division of the English Soccer League remained unchanged after today's battles. Tottenham Hotspurs defeated Middlesbrough, 2 -- 0, in London to hold their lead over the Arsenal, the league champions getting a 3-2 victory at Aston Villa.

With the national recovery program well under way and rapidly changing industrial and social conditions, the marketing of goods in this country is entering a new era and practices must be revised materially, L.D.H. Weld, president of the American Marketing Society and a staff member of General Marketing Counselors, Inc., told THE TIMES yesterday.

OUT of thirty years of experience in the salvaging of human wrecks Mrs. Menken has written this eminently sane, well-reasoned, deeply felt survey of the achievements, methods and aims of modern ways of dealing with delinquency and the earlier stages of criminality in men, women and children.

KINGSTON, Ont., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Queen's University at a special convocation this morning conferred honorary degrees on Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company; Major W.D. Herridge, Canadian Minister to the United States, and W.D. Robbins, Minister to Canada.

PARIS. FRANCE has always been a hospitable country. Her people may seem perhaps less so than Americans. Their social life is different. They entertain less in their homes. They do not receive foreigners so easily into their lives as Americans do, except, of course, in the artistic and cosmopolitan sections of society.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- Governor Ely announced last night that he would call a special session of the General Court for Nov. 8, two weeks from today, to deal with a proposed code for liquor control. The final report of a special legislative commission which has been struggling with the problems created by the prospective end of prohibition will be in the Governor's hands in a few days.

THE sub-title, "Statesman of the Lost Cause," is not flamboyant. The Southern Confederacy had no other statesman worthy of the name, from President Jefferson Davis down through the Cabinet to the least-known member of Congress. Alexander H. Stephens, the Vice President, occupied an office which, by immemorial custom, is largely ornamental, and though he was active it could only be as a critic, and most notably as a hostile critic, of the administration.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28. -- Rigid suppression of anti-government activities was ordered today by Minister of the Interior Alfredo Piwonka in a letter addressed to the Governors of all Chilean Provinces.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, is exhibiting a portrait in oil of Count Pulaski, the Polish patriot, who lost his life while serving in the Continental Army during the American Revolution. It was presented to the society by the Pulaski Military Club and was painted by John Ward Dunsmore.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Interest in the American experiment has given rise to the publication of a new crop of books about the United States, among which that entitled "The Crisis of American Capitalism," by Bertrand de Jouvenel, is attracting wide attention.

JUDGING by the standard of education, there are four kinds of government. There are the ignorant leading the ignorant. This is tyranny. There are the ignorant leading the wise. This is a prelude to revolution.There are the wise leading the ignorant.

Mrs. Lillian Smith, 30 years old, of 6 Church Street, Bordentown, N.J., wife of Milton T. Smith, a retired master sergeant of the United States Army, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon suffering from a bullet wound in the calf of the left leg.

Furniture and decorations, the property of Dr. and Mrs. T. Morris Murray, Boston, will be offered at auction next Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. Inc. Among the lots included is a royal Aubusson tapestry by Dumonteil, about 1735, with peacocks and animals in the foreground and in the distance a fortified town and river.

THE twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of Rimsky-Korsakoff, which, to be exact, was the 21st of last June, was observed last Wednesday night at the Roerich Museum by a program which announced the opera, or dramatic duologue, "Mozart and Salieri," after the text of Pushkin.

Representatives of thirty-seven universities and collegese in the United States and Canada will convene at the Hotel Pennsylvania Thursday and Friday for the annual meeting of the Association of Urban Universities, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Paul Linehan, director of the evening session at City College and president of the association.

BOSTON. IN the late Eighteen Sixties, when higher vocational education was rare for men and too profane to be mentioned for women, a wealthy Boston merchant decided that it was needed and endowed a "female college for the purpose of teaching medicine, music, drawing, designing, telegraphy and other branches of art, science and industry best calculated to enable the scholars to acquire an independent livelihood."

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- A report was received here last night saying that the British were seriously considering a gold plan similar to that of President Roosevelt, and this is another important cause of anxiety for the French regarding the franc. Were such a move adopted there is little doubt it would contribute greatly toward weakening the franc and, perhaps, ultimately forcing France off the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- A series of interpretations of the provisions of the retail code and the retail drug code prepared for the guidance of retailers throughout the country was made public late this afternoon by the National Recovery Administration.

Seventy-six students of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance have been appointed to the managing and associate board of the Violet, Commerce year-book, Dean G. Rowland Collins announced yesterday.

THE author of this ominously titled volume, Nicholas Alexandrovich Berdyaev, formerly a Professor of Philosophy at the University of Moscow, expelled by the Bolsheviki in 1922 as an upholder of religion and now an emigre in Paris, where he directs the Academy of the Philosophy of Religion, is admittedly the leading Russian religious thinker of the day, in the direct line of Solovyov and Dostoyevsky.

NEXT to the, fog hazard, that of ice formation on wings, tail surfaces and propellers presents one of the major risks of airplane operation and an important impediment to regularity of scheduled operation on airlines during the colder months.

Faced with the prospect of Federal regulation of the security and commodity markets of the country within six months, a group of influential members of the New York Stock Exchange believes the Exchange should cooperate with the administration to ensure the drafting of legislation which it regards as sound.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 24. -- Resigning themselves to the fact that Denver is not, and never can be, a city of national importance, Denver business men are bending their efforts toward making the city a provincial capital. A Rocky Mountain League of States is envisaged knit about Denver as closely as New England is about Boston.
PARIS. MODISTS lately seem to have cast aside all inhibitions and let their imagination run riot as to the shape, fabric and trimming of hats. Smart women are playing right along with them.

PARTLY, no doubt, because it simplifies matters and provides a convenient date, we have got rather into the way of referring to the illustrious Armory Show of 1913 as America's first taste of "modernism." But initiation really began before that.

Even those who have magisterially condemned the capitalistic system, for its complete break-down in the depression are calling upon capitalists to rescue the world. This is perhaps more pronounced in Europe than here. As Europeans have not resorted to artificial stimulants with the enthusiasm of Americans, it is natural for them to demand that capitalism now show what it can do to bring about recovery.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 28. -- The Navy Relief Society for Rhode Is land, of which Mrs. Cocke, wife of Captain Herbert C. Cocke. commanding officer of the Newport Naval Training Station, is president, was considerably benefite tonight as the result of a large attendance at the navy relief ball in the training station auditorium.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Factors which tended to make Westchester County an outstanding community were outlined tonight at the annual dinner of the "Westchester County Historical Society in the Hotel Gramatan. The dinner was held on the anniversary of the Battle of White Plains, but the 250th anniversary of the founding of Westchester was the principal subject.
GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The Hobart eleven dropped a hard-fought homecoming game to Hamilton today, 19 -- 12.

Samuel Untermyer, financial adviser of the city administration, called upon Joseph V. McKee in a statement yesterday "promptly and publicly to repudiate and denounce" a recent declaration by his campaign manager, George V. McLaughlin, prominent banker, calling Mr. Untermyer "Public Enemy Number 1."

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Attacking the NRA in an address here today, former State Senator Clayton C. Lusk of Cortland declared that "if we are to go from a republican form of goverment to State capitalism it should not be done under measures which are held out to the public as simply intended to stimulate industry and relieve unemployment."

The American Metal Company, through its wholly owned subsidiary, the American Metal Company of Canada, has sold to the International Nickel Company of Canada 25,790 shares of the Ontario Refining Company for $3,000,021, including dividends accrued to Oct. 11.
Tammany abandoned its defensive tactics and launched an offensive drive against the newspapers and rival parties.

IF before reading it you glance in a cursory way through Dr. Clendening's book and then look at it as a whole but in perspective from start to finish, you will perceive that the progress of medicine, as he recounts its story, is very like the growth of a tree.

A BIOGRAPHY of Sherlock Holmes must of necessity be largely conjectural. Dr. Watson, who recorded the adventures of the great detective, has very little to say about the man's private life, nor is he always reliable. He frequently contradicts himself, particularly where the dates of the various adventures are concerned.

DETROIT. AUTOMOBILE manufacturing is experiencing the annual between-season period of makeover and factory equipment change for new models. As a result, the assembly lines of eight makers are reported closed, and the production of others is being tapered off in preparation for the new models of 1934.

Ghosts and goblins and witches and whatnot of that world where the Stygian River flows and the cauldron boils the peppery prophecy of magic will emerge once again. 'Twill be the night of Halloween on Tuesday, and one must not be surprised if he sees a headless horseman galloping past and hears the swish of a witch's broom in the clouds.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Edmund Clarence Stedman, American poet and critic, on Nov. 8 and 9.

WILL the next Mayor of New York City be chosen under the sign of the eagle, star, key or fourleaf clover? These are some of the party symbols in the campaign. Airplanes, hammers, torches and sickles also are guides for the voters; there are parties old and new.

The annual Christmas sale and tea for the benefit of Hope Farm, a model community school for boys and girls in Verbank, Dutchess County, N.Y., will be held Nov. 15 and 16 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- F.A. Silcox, director of industrial relations for the New York Employing Printers' Association, was appointed Chief Forester of the Forest Service to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Major R.Y. Stuart last Monday.

FRANK SULLIVAN once wrote some hilarious reminiscences about the pleasures of Paris, without ever having been there at all. That was easy. All people who have heard of Paris can do that. Before they get there they know what glories lie in store and just where they are going to find those sights and that so-marvelous onion soup.

THERE is no mystery about the economics of the New Deal. For several generations, governments ran their affairs on the theory that natural economic forces balance themselves out. The law of supply and demand would regulate prices.

Appropriations granted during 1932 by the Rockefeller Foundation for projects in medical, social and natural sciences, the humanities and public health, amounted to $11,577,064, according to a report made public by the foundation yesterday.

WASHINGTON. TWO thousand, six hundred and ninety-four segments of the huge network that is the nation's highway system already are destined for improvemen under the aegis of the Public Work Administration, with less than half of its $400,000,000 highway appropriation applied. The figure represents the total number of projects approved by the United States Bureau of Public Roads and the administration to date.

TOKYO. JAPAN is soon to have a change of government. It may come in three months or in six, and even a longer delay is not impossible. The date of the event is less important than its nature. Is Japan to be the next country to scrap Parliament and join the dictatorships?

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 28. -- More than 2,000 persons from all parts of Nassau County attended the Republican rally and tea this afternoon at "Charlton Hall, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. David Dows. The rally was held outdoors near the paddock and the crowds huddled around big blazing bonfires while Mrs. Dows introduced the speakers, candidates on county and township tickets.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A trail of deaths, originally ascribed to heart ailments, was under investigation by the District Attorney's office today in the case of Alfred L. Cline, insurance man of Glendale.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 28. -- More than 2,000 persons from all parts of Nassau County attended the Republican rally and tea this afternoon at "Charlton Hall, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. David Dows. The rally was held outdoors near the paddock and the crowds huddled around big blazing bonfires while Mrs. Dows introduced the speakers, candidates on county and township tickets.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A trail of deaths, originally ascribed to heart ailments, was under investigation by the District Attorney's office today in the case of Alfred L. Cline, insurance man of Glendale.

Dr, Jacob Hoschander, Professor of Biblical Literature at the Jewish. Theological Seminary and widely known authority on biblical archaeology and Assyriology, died last night at his home, 515 West 110th Street, after a, long illness. He was in his sixtieth year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Charges that they had broken faith with President Roosevelt by "prior consultation and collusion" to fix the price of steel rails to be purchased for the railroads through the Public Works Administration were leveled at the four large steel companies today by Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Carleton H. Palmer, noted Long Island sportsman, watched his black and white silks flash to an exciting victory today in the sixteenth running of the New Jersey Hunt Cup.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The British National Government is now in the position of an American President, warned in mid-term by new Congressional election returns that his popular support is waning.

Scoring all Its points In the opening quarter, the Flushing High School eleven remained undefeated yesterday by downing John Adams, 13 to 7, before 6,000 persons at Dexter Park, Woodhaven. The setback was the first of the season for the losers.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The Rev. Augustus A. Walker, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church here and for years a prominent clergyman, died suddenly in the parsonage this morning. He was 69 years old.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Arrests for drunkenness were 10 per cent more numerous in New York State during the first six months of legalized beer than during a corresponding period in 1932, Frank A. Leonard, statistician for the State Department of Correction, said today.

FEW countries have been as successful as Poland in creating a unity between the age-old arts of weaving, embroidery, woodwork and pottery and the modern school-taught decorative design This is evident to the observer at the current exhibition of Polish art at the Brooklyn Museum.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, in speeches before Brooklyn audiences last night, called upon the voters to support the Fusion ticket as the only way of assuring the defeat of Tammany.

HAVANA, Oct. 28. -- A general Strike to begin, at midnight Monday was voted by the central committee of the Cuban unions at a secret meeting which lasted until an early hour of this morning. The action is in protest against "the repressive methods" being employed by the government against labor.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Williams College sprang a surprise on the Tufts Oval today, conquering the previously unbeaten home eleven, 6 to 0, in the first game between these rivals since 1922.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- H. Richard Segoine, 08, of Highland Park, was re-elected chairman of the Rutgers Alumni Council at the semi-annual meeting of the group here today. Dr. Carl R. Woodward '14, and Ernest E. McManon. 30, both of Highland Park, were chosen vice chairman and secretary respectively.

The NRA code for automobile dealers, the trade and marketing provisions of which will go into effect next Thursday, is expected to bring about far-reaching changes in car retailing. Motor dealers in New York City, said to number about 1,600, will be affected.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- Two noted Frenchmen, Paul Painleve, former Premier and a well-known mathematician, and Professor Albert Calmette, Assistant Director of the Pasteur Institute, were reported seriously ill tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 20. MR. COCHRAN'S new production, "Nymph Errant," at the Adelphi Theatre, and a version of Lady Eleanor Smith's novel, "Ballerina," at the Gaiety, both musical pieces, are what Northcliffe would have called the "talking points" of the week.

OF all the European attractions scheduled to appear in this country this season, the Jooss Ballet, which opens a limited engagement at the Forrest Theatre on Tuesday evening, is in many respects the most significant. For one thing, its technical method is a reconciliation (at least in intent) of the classical ballet and the modern dance.

Yesterday was the most exciting day in the Isabella Home for the Aged, and Sick since it was established forty-four years ago. Romance had entered the lives of four of the comparative youngsters among the inmates and they were married with much ado.

It is no exaggeration to say that last Sunday's broadcast about the Administration's price and currency policies left the public mind increasingly uncertain what to expect. For this there were two main causes -- one, that no clue was given to the precise policies contemplated; the other, that some of the objectives, stated in very general terms, were inconsistent with others.

MOST theatregoers are profoundly uninterested in the sponsorship of the plays they see. Sometimes a producer with a distinctive style overcomes their indifference; they know what characteristics a Belasco, a Ziegfeld or a Theatre Guild production may be expected to have.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 28. -- A Trojan "will o' the wisp" known as Irvin Warburton popped out of a tangle of arms and legs today to dash 60 yards to the goal and bring a 6-to-3 victory to Southern California over California's Bears.
LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 28. -- Eased up at the finish, Marta Hari, the Dixiana filly, continued her brilliant come-back today, winning the $10,000-added Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes handily.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Crown of Gold, six-year-old chestnut gelding owned by J.G. Holcombe of Kingston, N.Y., captured the saddle horse championship as the Fall horse show conducted by the service battery of the 156th Field Artillery came to a close tonight.

Slight price advances were registered last week on bunched carrots. Iceberg type lettuce and green peppers, George G. Royce announced yesterday in his consumers' weekly review of local wholesale markets. Mr. Royce is director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

All utility reports are consolidated returns, including subsidiaries, unless otherwise specified. Commonwealth Edison. The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and its subsidiaries report a net profit of $946,846 after taxes, charges and depreciation for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, equal to 58 cents a share earned on 1,623,459 shares, comparing with a revised net income of $1,212,086, or 75 cents a share on 1,600,692 shares, in the third .quarter last year.

IT is almost impossible to present a fair comparison between air transport and other modes of travel in relation to safety. There are enthusiasts -- with little in the way of figures to back their statements -- who declare that aviation today offers the safest method of mechanical transport.

WILLIAM MORROW CO. announce that they have signed a contract for the American rights to the "Memoirs of General Caulaincourt, Duke of Vicence, Grand Equerry of the Emperor Napoleon," recently published by Flon in Paris.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28. -- With the first snowfall in the Ural Mountains the Soviet Union is making a desperate drive to keep transportation from falling to the usual low Winter level. Last Winter many industrial units were unable to maintain their schedules because of the lack of transportation of raw materials and the construction of new plants was delayed.

Enrique Ortega, Superintendent of Public Works in the Puerto Rican Department of the Interior, who was here last week discussing a "new deal" public works program for his country with the United States Army engineers, gave an interview explaining the background of the recent political turmoil in the island.

Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion campaign committee, told a large audience at a Fusion rally in Kismet Temple, Brooklyn, last night that an affidavit served upon Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, in proceedings begun by Francis T. McEneny, whom Mr. McKee had removed as his chief examiner, had been with-held from the public files.
CHICAGO, Oct. 38. -- In the feature event of the World's Fair Horse Show tonight, Lieutenant Sachs of the Swedish Army team won the individual military championship. His mount was Orcilla.

Three young men were arrested yesterday by detectives charged with sending threatening letters through the mail to Dr. Williard P. Beach, 75 years old, of 1,789 Patterson Avenue, the Bronx. Three letters are said to have informed Dr. Beach that unless he left $500 at a fruit stand at 2,306 Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, he would be killed or his 4-year-old grandson kidnapped.

FOR the first appearance of Jean Harlow and Lee Tracy as a team, Metro-GoldwynMayer selected an excellent vehicle in "Bombshell," a picture which kept audiences in a high state of glee at the Capitol last week.

The Casino Theatre, at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street, one of the largest and most modern in the Times Square theatrical district, has been sold to Haring Blumenthal and Jack Shapiro in a deal representing an investment of about $2,000,000, it became known yesterday.

THE concert season may be said to be in full swing again when such artists as Kreisler and Tibbett are represented in the current week's recitals. The National Orchestral Association will be heard for the first time this season, and from Philadelphia this week comes the Curtis String Quartet.

COLDER weather brought the long-awaited upturn in retail trade last week. Possibly the address of President Roosevelt and advances in the speculative markets also helped. Demand centred, however, upon seasonal apparel, and, if prospective inflation was an influence, it was not felt in larger sales of higher priced goods.

Shown to England. COMFORT and convenience seem to have been chief considerations in the minds of the designers of the motor cars displayed at this year's Olympia Show, Great Britain's annual automobile exhibition, which was held earlier this month.

The body of Doc Lucas, young "bronco buster" and rider of wild steers, was put on a train at the Grand Central Station yesterday to be taken to his home in Belden, Texas. Lucas was 20 years old. He died Thursday night at the Polyclinic Hospital, forty-eight hours after he jumped from a bucking steer and fractured his skull at the Rodeo in Madison Square Garden.

Schoolboy cross-country fans will flock to Van Cortlandt Park again on Saturday morning to get another glimpse of Steven Szumachowski and the other Schenectady stars who registered such impressive performances in the Manhattan College interscholastic run over the course a week ago yesterday.

Many corporations and Individuals holding contracts for foreign wines and liquors to be imported after repeal are unduly concerned over the "embargo" order issued recently in Washington, James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., Inc., customs brokers, told THE TIMES yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- American and British conferees on the war debt, who have been holding fruitless meetings for several weeks in Washington, will see President Roosevelt in a few days. It is expected in administration circles that the result of that conference will be the shelving of the debt discussions for an indefinite period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Federal Trade Commission has issued a stop order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act by the Shamrock Gold Mining Company of Downievilie, Calif., for a proposed issue of $200,000 in stock.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Ossip Gabrilowitsch, noted pianist, will appear at the Greenwich High School auditorium on Nov. 7 in the second of the series of concerts sponsored by the Wednesday Singing Club. Many homes will be open to dinner parties before the concert.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was amused at the storm of indignation aroused by Henry W. Taft's plea for good English. If he had championed some form of crime or vice in a letter to THE TIMES, there could not be more passionate resentment.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 28. -- The Puerto Rican students' "cultural" strike, now marked by a twelve-day university recess, is but a part of a larger political struggle.

The architectural development of Columbia University, "as it may look a generation hence," has been envisioned by the students of the Columbia University School of Architecture in connection with a study of the possible development of the Morningside Heights area.
ISTANBUL, Oct. 28. -- Ten years have been sufficient for Turkish women to run the gauntlet of a newly acquired freedom and settle down soberly to education and work.

Interest in the markets was at the lowest ebb of the week yesterday, with stocks almost motionless and most agricultural commodities only slightly more active. The price movement was downward in all the domestic markets, but the pressure generally was gentle.

THE new Autumn styles in radio receivers are designed to cover a wide tuning band. Many of the new outfits are not restricted to the 200 to 550 meter band, but also cover the police, aircraft, amateur and commercial short-wave channels.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28. -- Bucknell extended its home winning streak to seventeen games today by defeating Pop Warner's Temple University Owls, 20 to 7, before a home-coming day crowd of 13,000.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Oct. 28. -- West Virginia, and Davis and Elkins battled to a 7-7 deadlock in one of the most brilliantly played games here this season. The Mountaineers had three scoring chances and the Senators two.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Oct. 24. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. never has influenced Kansas thought to an appreciable degree, but the Rockefeller Foundation survey has projected sober thinking on a question that now is uppermost in the minds of Kansans -- the control of liquor after repeal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Incorporation of a Public Works Emergency Housing Corporation to build low-cost apartment houses as slum clearance projects throughout the country was announced today by Secretary Ickes.

The twenty-ninth annual national motor boat show will be held in the Grand Central Palace from Jan. 19 to 27. In announcing the dates of the Winter's leading event in motor boating hereabouts, Henry R. Sutphen, president of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, said that the show would occupy at least three floors of the palace.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The most serious possibilities affecting Anglo-German relations are contained in the case of Noel Panter, British correspondent arrested in Munich, whom the German Government now threatens to try before the Supreme Court on a charge of "treason to the State."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal to establish a Federal prison at Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay has raised a heated discussion. Certain facts remain to be brought out. First, Alcatraz has long been used for army prisoners with no comment; second, commentators seem to have forgotten the army prison on Governors Island and the new Riker's Island prison in the East River.

SOMEWHERE or other in the back alleys of literature unexplored by Bartlett there must be a wise saw to the effect that an article acquires no real dignity until a cult of collection grows up around it. The point need not be labored.

Celebrated Broadway extertainers will share the honors with a quaint county fair at the Halloween Carnival to be given tomorrow night at the Plaza for the benefit of the Humane Service Bureau, an organization for humane treatment of animals.

THE Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra under Bruno Walter will give the first New York performance of Randall Thompson's Symphony No. 2 in E minor next Thursday evening. It will be repeated Friday afternoon.
George Washington High School's football team downed Stuyvesant, 6 to 0, yesterday before 4,000 at the George Washington High School Stadium.

Today will bena Sunday of many different celebrations. It will mark the opening of the United Missionary Conference of the United Boards of Foreign Missions in America, with missionaries speaking from many pulpits. It will be the annual Girl Scout Sunday, when girls in Scout uniform will attend churches in troops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The Red Cross reported tonight that need among families of disabled veterans and peace-time service men arising from economic conditions and altered veterans' laws was taxing the organization's facilities "to the limit."
NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 28. -- Auburn's plainsmen surprised Tulane for the second successive year by downing the Green Wave today, 13 -- 7, before a homecoming crowd of 20,000.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 25. -- With the third trial of the Scottsboro Negroes scheduled for Nov. 27 at Decatur, and with Judge W.W. Callahan assigned to preside in place of Judge James E. Horton, who conducted the second trials last April, Alabama approaches with profound misgivings a probable resurrection of the antagonism and dispute attendant upon this now famous case.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25. -- Virginia is aware that the entire country will be watching when George Crawford, Negro accused of murdering two white women near Middleburg early in 1931, is brought back from Boston and placed on trial in the Loudoun County Circuit Court.

BERLIN. WHEN a nation is passing through a period of crisis and violent upheaval its thinkers occupy themselves predominantly with studies of the intellectual and spiritual make-up of great men, particularly of such as are their compatriots.

IT is a matter of regret that Professor Kitchel should have thought fit to emblazon on her title page that her clear-eyed depiction of George Lewes and George Eliot is a review of records. Not that it is unimportant that readers should be apprised of the fact that the study is everywhere supported by authorities; but using the title page for this purpose places the emphasis wrongly.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- A new tin control scheme was approved here today by the International Tin Committee, and an agreement was signed by representatives of Bolivia, the Malay States, the Dutch East Indies, Nigeria and Siam for continuance of control over production and exports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Ina Claire, actress and former wife of John Gilbert, motion picture star, was found to owe $8,561 in income taxes for 1929 in a stipulation judgment today by the Board of Tax Appeals.

THE most imposing-looking sheaf of notes for what should be a nice Fall morning concerns the activities of the Shuberts. This would be both present and future. Since there appears to be more than one item, the easier method is merely to list them -- and in no order whatsoever. Therefore:

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Beginning tomorrow and for two days following hundreds of thousands of Turks will stage a strenuous three-day show, observing the tenth anniversary of the Turkish Republic.

The increasing number of important contests on municipal ownership of utilities has aroused the managements of the large utility systems, which have adopted the policy of treating each case as a local issue. In this the companies are restricted, in many States, by laws preventing them from advertising or otherwise circulating their views.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 28. -- A sophomore halfback named Kurt Warmbein led Michigan State to a 27-to-3 victory over Syracuse's hitherto undefeated eleven before a large homecoming crowd today. Michigan State came back strong in the third and fourth periods after being held in check in the first half.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Tariffs in connection with the Pennsylvania Railroad's plan for establishing throughout its system on Dec. 1 the store-door collection and delivery of less-than-carload freight were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission and the State Commissions today.

HARTFORD, Oct. 26. -- Connecticut, one of the two States never to ratify the Eighteenth Amendment, awaits the repeal of the "constitutional warrant for prohibition with considerable calm, believing the liquor control act adopted last Spring after the bitterest legislative contest in a generation is adequate for the situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The trend of industrial activity continued downward during the week ended on Oct. 21, but the rate of activity remained above that of last year, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Anchor liner Transylvania returned yesterday afternoon from a twelve-day cruise to the West Indies with six East Side youths ranging from 17 to 22 years, who had stowed away on the ship when she left New York on Oct. 15.

THE New Jersey State Highway Commission last week awarded to William Eisenberg Sons of Camden the contract for construction of a bridge to carry Route 10 over Route 5-N at Morris Plains, Morris County. The bid, $47,811, was the lowest of twenty submitted.

Quel Jeu from the Arden Farm Stable captured the Keystone Purse, feature of the closing day of the New York racing season at Empire City yesterday. The winner was saddled by George M. Odom, who Sent out his own racer, Irene's Bob, in the same race.

The local NRA administration will start an investigation tomorrow of profiteering by theatre ticket brokers, it was learned yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, city administrator, notified officials of "an important Broadway theatre ticket agency" to appear at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT announced last week a new monetary policy for the United States. The American Government will buy gold mined in this country at prices to be determined by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, after consultation with the President himself and the Secretary of the Treasury -- the initial price being set at $31.36 an ounce, slightly above the prevailing world figure.

Puffy, a 3-year-old cat, who had protected a stray robin with a broken wing and now lives in harmony with the bird as its playmate, shared honors yesterday with more than a dozen dog heroes at the semi-annual "Animal Hero Day" at the Hotel Astor.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Referring to Postmaster General Farley's recent statement that he would not interfere in local political campaigns, Senator George R. Fearon, Republican minority leader, said last night that "Mr. Farley has already given up the fight and knows he has no chance of electing an Assembly this Fall."

Moscow. THE year 1933 will go down in history as the year that marked the resumption by the U.S.S.R. of the place as a great world power which "Russia" lost in 1917. Force of circumstance, no less than the Soviet's own effort and progress, has brought this result, which finds its most striking expression in the message of President Roosevelt to Mikhail Kalinin, raising the question of recognition.

"Come, come!" said the visitor sharply, "That story about Lou Little and the broken blackboard, the overturned furniture and all that in his daily meetings with his assistants! A trifle exaggerated; what? Coaches don't get wrought up that much. Impossible!"
NEW HAVEN. Conn., Oct. 28. -- Gifts to the Yale gallery of fine arts dating from the time of Xerxes to the early fourteenth century were announced today.

THE Annual Fall Exhibition, at New Hope, by the artists of the Delaware Valley, finds in the Old Phillips Mill a most sympathetic setting. The big gallery hangs about fifty pictures and the small gallery as many prints, drawings and water-colors; a spacious, well-lighted basement overlooking "a stream," offers a display of arts and crafts, and, at the visitor's bidding, tea.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 28. -- A strong New Hampshire freshman eleven scored an 18-7 victory over Andover today. Captain Joe Nathanson of the visitors scored two touchdowns and booted a field goal in the last quarter.
Tony Canzoneri, former world's lightweight titleholder, received the decision over Frankie Klick of San Francisco in the feature ten-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night.

More than 7,000 high school boys thronged the aprons at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon in celebration of High School Aviation Day. Some 400 of them took flying models and entered them in contests. Commander Frank M. Hawks and the Army and Navy put on an air show for the boys in demonstration of the various tactical manoeuvres and precision flying they are being taught in the specialty classes of high school.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- Norman H. Davis, American Ambassador-at-Large, called on Ambassador Naotake Sato of Japan today to return his call and, it is understood, to express the hope that M. Sato's statement to the bureau of the conference yesterday did not mean Japan was withdrawing from the Disarmament Conference.
Exports and imports into and from the United States by classifications during September, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and a year ago (000 omitted):

SIX persons are traveling in the same compartment of a railway train speeding through France. During the night two of these persons, an Englishman and a Frenchman, are murdered. One of the other occupants of the compartment is Ludovic Travers, an amateur detective of some reputation who has appeared in other books by Christopher Bush.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Government support was necessary today to prevent the grain markets on the Board of Trade from dropping to the limits allowed by the rules of the Exchange, and pit brokers estimated that houses presumably acting for the emergency relief organization bought around 3,000,000 bushels of wheat in the last fifteen minutes of trading, of which about 1,500,000 bushels were said to have been taken in the final five minutes.

Professor George Warren's theories concerning the intimate relation between gold and prices have provoked interesting debate since President Roosevelt's address of last Sunday night. The commodity-minded section of Wall Street has been discussing index numbers in and out of trading hours. The Warren and Pearson price tables run back about 150 years and show at a glance the strikingly similar trends of prices just prior to and succeeding the Napoleonic, Civil and World wars.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 25. -- The boys all thought when Jim Farley came to Texas that now was the time for the party to coma to the aid of all good men. So they hopped on the merry-go-round early and they're still riding and grabbing for the brass ring.
Federal and State authorities began separate investigations yesterday into Nazi activities in this city.
C.C.N.Y.'s eleven put on the best exhibition of football it has given this season yesterday afternoon and played a, 0-0 tie with a strong Lowell Textile team at Lewisohn Stadium.

Twenty-two passengers were injured, one seriously, and about fifty others shaken up when two trolley cars on the Ralph Avenue line were in a collision in the underground loop near the Manhattan end of the Williamsburgh Bridge at 9:30 last night.

The protest of F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, against use by the Recovery party of the Blue Eagle insignia of the National Recovery Administration had effect yesterday when General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, telegraphed Joseph V. McKee, candidate for Mayor, that the use of such insignia was in violation of the NRA regulations.

Debutantes will distribute programs and sell various handicraft articles made by unemployed seamen during the performance of "A Divine Drudge" on Wednesday night at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York on behalf of that organization.

Josef Lhevinne's piano recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall brought forth the following allChopin program: The G minor and F major ballades; the F major and A minor etudes of op. 25; the entire series of 24 preludes, op. 28; and a final group including the fantasie impromptu, C sharp minor, the B major mazurka, op. 56, No. 1; the A flat major "Valse" and the A flat major "Polonaise."
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert T. Wade will give a dinner-dance Dec. 1 at the St. Regis before the first Junior Assembly to introduce Mrs. Wade's daughter, Miss Beatrice Jacquelin Stout.

FOR reasons which are readily apparent, a particular interest is attached to this new book by Irina Skariatina. She believes herself to be "the first member of the titled Russian aristocracy, who is not a Communist, to be allowed to 'go back' home to Russia, legally with a passport visaed by Moscow."

Support of the proposed $60,000,000 State bond issue for relief was urged yesterday by representatives of the State and of private organizations. The bond issue is listed as Proposition No. 1 on the Nov. 7 ballots.

Navy Day, 1933, found the United States Navy still below its treaty quota in combatant ships and hand icapped in its efforts to achieve parity and to maintain and operate a navy second to none by market deficiencies in other elements of sea power, naval officers declare.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- Among the fabrics prominently featured in Worth's midseason collection are dotted monotone woolens and taffetas; faconne ottomans are also important. Square openwork Chinese motifs made in gold and set in the centre front of velvet ribbon choker collars, which tie in a bow at the nape of the neck, offer a novel means of enlivening Spring afternoon frocks.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 28. -- Before a home-coming crowd of 12,000 North Carolina lost one of the most thrilling games played here in years to the Georgia Tech Tornado today, 10 to 6. Governor Ehringhaus and former Governor Max Gardner were among those present.

GREAT designers of clothes must indulge their fancy for extravagant fabrics with much the same relish that a bon viveur does his appetite for terrapin. Can you not imagine how they pick up some unusual fabric, feel it, dream over it, drape it and then, finally, turn it into a breathtaking garment?

ISTANBUL. THE Kemalist revolution, though born in violence, has evolved into a peaceful and constructive regime. During the past decade, while other nations have had internal political crises, republican Turkey has escaped domestic wrangles.
PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The Mohammedan Mosque in Paris, on the fringe of the Latin Quarter, is the first religious edifice in Paris to put into effect a "no tipping" regulation.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 26. -- The California Institute of Technology at Pasadena is the peephole of science. The institution, plus the Mount Wilson Observatory, whence the antics of the universe are lamped, have placed Southern California in the world's king row from the standpoint of original research and finished product.

AT the Samuel Goldwyn factory the new Eddie Cantor comedy, "Roman Scandals," has been finished. "Nana," that other Goldwyn enterprise which will mark the long overdue debut of Anna Sten in American pictures, is still before the cameras.

Manhattan's football hopes were buried under an avalanche of Villanova touchdowns, as a smoothly functioning Wildcat machine rode roughshod over the Jaspers to score a 47-to-0 triumph before 20,000 persons at Rbbets Field yesterday.

OMAHA, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Forgery of Omaha City bonds, which Controller Charles Stenicka believes may total $400,000, a $42,000 block of which was sold to a Chicago bank, was announced in official quarters today.
BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 28 (AP). -- South Carolina's eleven defeated Virginia Poly, 12 to 0, today.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Arthur Garfield Hays, American attorney, who has observed the Reichstag fire trial since its beginning, issued a statement today in which he summarized the evidence in the case and on this basis passed a verdict of not guilty on all the defendants except Marinus van der Lubbe, selfconfessed pyromaniac and anarchist.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The "Colgate plan" of education, based on a large use of survey courses and the preceptorial method of guiding freshmen, was recognized today with the announcement by President Cutten that the Carnegie Corporation of New York had given the university $120,000 to put the plan into full operation.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- It is not for us to judge the motives of President Roosevelt in opening official relations with the Soviet Government. This is an internal affair, which concerns Americans only. What interests us in London is the repercussion which this sensational event is certain to have upon the international situation.

GEORGE BARBIER (he is a party to "Love, Honor and Oh, Baby!" at the Roxy) was being prepared for the ministry at Crozer Theological Seminary when the stage bug's deadly virus entered his blood. The direct stimulus was a small part in the institution's pageant "Joseph and His Coat of Many Colors."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The index of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today showed farm prices and costs of goods to farmers as a whole retained the same relationship on Oct. 15 as on Sept. 15.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- The Road Horse Association of New Jersey held its final matinee of the season at Weequahic Park today as Hollyrood Onward, owned by J. I. Lyle of Plainfield, won the featured event, the free-for-all trot.

Cold weather brought considerably increased activity in the women's coat market, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Prices which have been weakening recently are firmer, the report adds, and manufacturers were able to dispose of a good portion of their stocks.
VIENNA, Oct. 28. -- Seven professors and students of a State school were sentenced to prison terms of from two months to two years today for participating in Nazi bombings in Baden, Austria.

PERHAPS no one in the audience at the opening of the Joe Cook show, "Hold Your Horses," watched the proceedings with more interest than a slight, modest figure of a man who, disdaining a conspicuous place, viewed the performance from a secluded seat on the aisle in the fourth row centre.
