BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Radiating smiles and showing considerable pleasure over the outlook for his trip to Washington, Maxim Litvinoff, Soivet Foreign Commissar, with his official staff reached Berlin this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- Two thousand armed men, National Guardsmen, State police and volunteers from American Legion posts, were mobilized today to police all roads in this State's fight on organized crime. They will search for the desperadoes who have been terrorizing Indiana and surrounding States for more than a month.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 26. -- Clouded since its inception by wrangling, petty politics and ill-advised schemes, the Colorado relief program has finally gone into complete eclipse. The crisis, expected for months, was precipitated by the State Supreme Court's action in declaring invalid the special excise tax on automobiles passed by last Summer's special session of the Legislature to care for the needy during the coming Winter.

VIENNA, Oct. 28. -- While Germany is preparing for a plebiscite intended to demonstrate to the world her determination to obtain "equal" rights on arms, attempts continue to be made to organize the States of Southeastern Europe into what some Berlin newspapers have interpreted as an anti-German bloc.

SARAH BERNHARDT cast a magic spell upon her generation. To the next generation that knew her as an old woman of world-wide fame, invincible energy and unquenchable spirit, she became a legend. The spell was not dissolved.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 28. -- Gold mines of Ontario during September produced bullion worth $3,366,898, the lowest total for any month this year and $349,497 under the $3,716,395 reported for August. Production was down in all areas, Kirkland Lake declining $169,384 to $1,558,684, Porcupine falling off $152,722 to $1,733,824, but maintaining the lead in total output, while Northwestern Ontario at $74,410 was down from $101,801 in the preceding month.

DETROIT SEVEN years ago a rather disconsolate-looking Irish priest walked into the office of radio station WJR in Detroit, explained that he had been thinking "about broadcasting a sermon," and poured the story of his troubles into the sympathetic ear of the man in charge.

MANILA, Sept. 26. -- Governor General Frank Murphy has turned his attention to the troublesome problem of the Moro population of the Philippines. He is undertaking to work out a more satisfactory policy by which peace may be maintained and constructive improvement made in the Moro provinces.

Two unbeaten elevens crossed paths in the feature game of a scholastic football double-header at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and it was Theodore Roosevelt High School which fell by the wayside, bowing to a strong Curtis outfit, 9 -- 6.
St. Cecilia High of Englewood, N.J., experienced little difficulty defeating Emerson High of Union City at Fairview, N.J., yesterday, 25 to 0. Frank Eckles led the attack with two touchdowns.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Chicago proved to be just an old-fashioned Maroon team against the mighty Michigan eleven today, with the Wolverines registering an overwhelming 28-to-0 triumph in their march toward a fourth Western Conference gridiron championship.

Long Island and Pennsylvania will usher in their general hunting seasons on Wednesday. The Keystone State sportsmen have been duck hunting since Oct. 16, but Long Islanders have had to sit by and await Nov. 1 for the time to unlimber their duck guns and get down to business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Disregarding a drop in world gold quotations, the administration again, today pushed upward its fixed price for the domestically mined metal.

MADISON. Wis., Oct. 28. -- Sweeping aside Wisconsin's threat to score an upset in the first period, Purdue's backs made two lightning thrusts today to topple the Badgers, 14 to 0, before a home-coming crowd of 30,000 at Camp Randall Stadium.

AKRON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Aboard the Graf Zeppelin when it left here this morning were twenty-five passengers in addition to Dr. Hugo Eckener and his veteran crew.

Pressure from the consumers' advisory board of the NRA and the policies of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration are two of the main factors in the growing development of standards in industry, P.G. Agnew, secretary of the American Standards Association, said here yesterday.

HAMMONDSPORT, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- In the musty wine cellars of this Lake Keuka region a million or more bottles of rare champagne of pre-Volstead vintage are waiting to add the right touch to the nation-wide celebration that undoubtedly will mark prohibition repeal.

WRITING of democracy in the United States, de Tocqueville paid this country a compliment. Such is the compliment that a later Frenchman is paying to Great Britain. In biography M. Maurois has recaptured the romantic triumphs of Benjamin Disraeli.

Those who are predicting a continuance for an indefinite time of Princeton's rise in football have been pointing to the strength of this year's freshman football team, as evidenced in its games to date.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Colgate's Red Raiders were held to a scoreless tie today by a sturdy Lafayette eleven, before an alumni and dad's day crowd.

MR. ORTON as he confesses about half way through this discussion of the prospects for American culture, admits that those who seek that flower among the cogs and springs and acres of cement and empty tin cans of our present civilization are engaged on a desperate venture.

THE "Markie" to whom these letters were written by General Robert E. Lee was Miss Martha Custis Williams, first cousin of Mrs. Lee and a more distant cousin of the General. The two families were intimately bound together by these close relationships, especially strong among Virginians, and by ties of mutual affection.

AGAIN the interesting question of coordination of control for all forms of transportation was raised last week by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads. Speaking before officials of seventeen States who were in session at Harrisburg, Pa., to discuss uniform truck and bus laws, the former Interstate Commerce Commissioner outlined the ideal of a transportation system which would be devoid of overlapping services.

IN a booklet made public today, the National Council on Freedom From Censorship, organized two years ago by the American Civil Liberties Union, publishes a record of the cuts made by the New York State censors from January, 1932, to March, 1933, under the licensing law which forbids dialogue and scenes that are "obscene, indecent, immoral, sacrilegious" or that tend "to corrupt the morals or incite to crime."
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- A crowd of 10,000 in Palmer Stadium watched a fighting Washington and Lee team hold Princeton's undefeated eleven to a 6-0 score today.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The carpet war is on in Paris. This is no trifling matter, but goes, back to fundamentals of Parisian household economy. The Prefect of Police, Jean Chiappe, who successfully decreed the silence of automobile horns during the dead of night, has gone one step further and has forbidden the beating of carpets in the late or early morning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Rutgers defeated Lehigh, 27 to 0, before a Homecoming Day crowd of 6,000 today. The Scarlet counted twice in the second period and twice in the final quarter, and held the upper hand at all times. Rutgers completed three forward passes for a total of 109 yards and made fifteen first downs to the Engineers' three.

COMEDIANS now on the air are to be reinforced with Will Rogers, Ed Wynn and Eddie Cantor. The broadcasters believe that this season's bumper crop of comics is evidence that they will continue to enliven the ether throughout the Winter.

Ocean mail contracts axe improperly termed and should be designated to include other services performed for the government by the ship lines, according to Roger D. Lapham, president of the American Hawaiian Steamship Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- A 90-yard run for a touchdown in the final period by Halfback Junie Smith gave William and Mary's Indians a 12-to-6 victory over Georgetown in a thrilling football game in Griffith Stadium today.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 28. -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers retained the Big Six conference football leadership today, beating Oklahoma, 16 to 7.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Six thousand persons lined the banks of the Raritan River late today while Rutgers and Columbia broke even in two races which marked the resumption of intercollegiate rowing at the local university after an interval of thirty years.

HAVING written and illustrated several general books about the birds, beasts and fishes. Eric Pitch Daglish now tries his hand at a specific study of dogs. His volume follows the same plan utilized by numerous authors who have preceded him in the field: advice for beginners, choosing a dog, short sketches of the various breeds and a few chapters on the care, breeding and training of dogs.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Boston College piled up four touchdowns in the first half and won the intercollegiate football championship of Boston by defeating Boston University, 25 to 0, for the tenth successive time at Alumni Field today.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, former medical professor of the University of Havana, now Provisional President of Cuba, urges recognition by the United States for his government in a statement just received by air mail in response to a questionnaire prepared by this writer while in Havana recently.

Fine Tool Slanderd. The first number of Professor MOLEY'S new weekly paper, Today, stresses the point that the hand which wields the chisel rocks the boat. The lesson is driven home in picture and text.

The results of the first four days of operation of the monetary policy enunciated by President Roosevelt a week ago supported the contention of bankers that the mere announcement by the RFC of a buying price for newly mined gold would not serve to control the course of the dollar in foreign exchange nor to affect materially the movement of domestic prices.

THE working girl who decided not to give her friend a book because she already had one, was not after all, it appears, typical of America. As a matter of statistical fact, it now turns out, our working girls would rather read than eat.

DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 28. -- William S. Culbertson, former Ambassador to Chile, asserted in a speech here today that permanent inter-American relations depended upon the exclusion of European intervention in the affairs of American republics and upon Pan-Americanism.

POTTSTOWN, Fa., Oct. 28. -- Checking a spirited rally in the closing period, the Hill School eleven held Lawrenceville to a scoreless tie in the twenty-eighth game of their football rivalry today. Two thousand persons witnessed the encounter.

ONE aim of the New Deal, it becomes plainer, is to question high salaries and high bonuses of Big Business. Since last May the Federal Reserve Board has inquired into possibly excessive compensation paid to officers of member banks.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28. -- Revolt in Sao Paulo and other southern Brazilian States has been delayed until early November to give President Vargas an opportunity to choose whether to accept a bloodless coup d'etat or to plunge the country into a civil war, according to private advices reaching this correspondent today from high military sources in Sao Paulo engaged in preparing for a revolution.

In a letter, copies of which were sent yesterday to all candidates for Mayor, candidates for the Borough Presidencies and to nominees for President of the Board of Aldermen, Electus J. Litchfield, president of the Municipal Art Society, said:

Charging that the National Association of Manufacturers failed to cite proof of its contention that imports are menacing the success of the NRA program, Charles T. Riotte, secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., in a statement yesterday challenged the producers' group to show one month this year in which imports of manufactured articles actually exceeded those for the corresponding month in 1932.

Not having witnessed a match for the chess championship of the United States for ten years, followers of the game in this country are stirred by the developments of the past week which have served to pave the way for an encounter between Frank J. Marshall and Isaac Irving Kashdan, both of this city, within a few months.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Mamaroneck High School's football team defeated Gorton High of Yonkers, 20 to 0. in a W.I.A.A. game. Al Luceno's runs featured the contest.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 28. -- State police were scored by Judge Eugene O'Dunne today as he issued an injunction forbidding interference with the burial by the State prison warden of Euel Lee, the Negro murdered who was hanged early Friday morning after a two-year legal contest by attorneys of the Communistic International Labor Defense.

MUNICH, Oct. 28. -- Consul General Mainer of Great Britain continues to watch the case of Noel Panter, British newspaper man who was arrested Tuesday, with the greatest care. Further visits to Mr. Panter will be allowed, but each time the Consul General must apply for a permit, which involves complicated formalities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The publication on Oct. 21 of the President's letter to Mikhail Kalinin and the more recent announcement that negotiations are on foot for a loan of $500,000,000 of the American taxpayers' money to the Soviet Government are two matters which deserve the most earnest attention of the American people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Public Works Administration today approved allocation of $8,869,309 for Federal and non-Federal projects as the Advisory Board started on the distribution of the final third of the $3,300,000,000 fund, which it hopes to allocate by the end of December.

ONLY in very recent years has our modern civilization begun to appreciate the immensity of the debt it owes to Egypt. Even today only those specially interested in the ancient world realize how many of our ideas, of our philosophy and ethics had their origin on the banks of the Nile.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Massachusetts State College had little trouble in defeating Worcester Tech in their annual game today, 20 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Foreclosure of 2,589 mortgages totaling $9,903,920 on homes of city dwellers was averted by the Home Owners' Loan Corporation in the week ending Oct. 20, it was announced today. The government corporation has now fended off in all 22,832 mortgages with a total value of $65,271,957.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Government control over the manufacture and distribution of distilled spirits through licenses required by the Secretary of Agriculture is provided in a marketing agreement for the distilling industry completed today and filed with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Many Halloween dances were given tonight at the clubs in Westchester County. One of the largest, a costume dance, took place at the Ardsley Club here and was preceded by a dinner. The committee in charge included:

PARIS, Oct. 15. WHETHER you like Steve Passeur's conception of dramatic art or not, there is no denying its influence upon his fellow-dramatists. One after another they try to adapt themselves to a method of playwriting in which the characters spend their time in blurting out what in real life they might think but would refrain from saying.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, assailed last night the "nonpartisan" and "good housekeeping" conceptions of city government which he attributed to F.H. LaGuardia and Joseph V. McKee, and attacked the contentions of both these Mayoralty candidates that economy alone would solve the city's financial problems.
ROME, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini said today that he wished to "give the Italian nation a hard but magnificent task, that of obtaining primacy on earth and in the skies."

The Merchants Association of New York has sent a letter to Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, protesting the ratio of funds that the government would spend on American labor and materials and on Canadian labor and materials in connection with the St. Lawrence Canal project.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27. -- If the United States establishes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, the action will bring into play important new factors to Russia's advantage, despite oft-repeated statements here that the Soviet Government no longer needs to beg for recognition and is now economically and politically independent.

VIENNA, Oct. 28. -- The Austrian Association of Gendarmes was dissolved today by a government order. Affiliated with a nationwide federation of labor, the organization published for members a weekly information sheet which, a communique said, recently included matter "likely to endanger discipline in the gendarmie."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The Veterans Administration sent formal notice today of acceptance of a low bid for one truck to the Ford dealer whose low figure on 1,000 trucks for the Civilian Conservation Corps may be rejected because officials do not deem the maker of the cars a compliant with the NRA code for automobiles.

WORTH REMEMBERING" is a newcomer that deserves a place on the shelf with the few classics of childhood. It is not perfect; but it is extraordinary. And, like each of its fellows on that hypothetical shelf, it is unique.

ONE hundred American cities are now protected by police radio and more than twenty other municipalities have applied for construction permits, according to the new call letter list issued by the Federal Radio Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Navy's football team came through an extremely hard-fought engagement on Franklin Field today to turn back Pennsylvania, 13 to 0.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Jose Iturbi on the night of Nov. 13 at Carnegie Hall in behalf of the Women's Trade Union League of New York. Prominent women including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, who long have seen interested in the welfare of the organization, have subscribed to the benefit.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 28. -- Eight singles and six doubles matches were played tonight in the Nassau Country Club's annual invitation handicap squash racquets tournament for the J.L. Luckenbach Trophy.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 28. -- The game but seemingly shellshocked forces of one of football's long-time powers, Notre Dame's burly Green Shirts, fell a victim today to the Pittsburgh Panthers for the second successive year, chiefly through the exploits of shifty Mike Sebastian of Sharon, Pa. The score was 14 to 0.
Columbia's football hopes were revived yesterday when the Lions defeated Penn State, 33 -- 0, before 10,000 spectators at Baker Field.

A slight fire, believed to have been caused by a short circuit, halted a Long Island Railroad train, inbound from Long Beach to the Atlantic Avenue Station, Brooklyn, at Atlantic Avenue and Chestnut Street, about 6 o'clock last night.

Trade reports issued last week testified with remarkable unanimity to a moderate expansion in retail trade, reflecting the arrival of cold weather, and to a moderate decline in wholesale trade, which also is normal at this time.

The swimming team of Seward Park High rated one of the strongest candidates for interborough laurels this season, met surprising defeat in the third series of weekly P.S.A.L. dual meets for senior high schools in the George Washington pool yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Warnings that the freedom of the American press is still threatened, even though it is guaranteed in the Constitution, dominated the celebration today of the two hundredth anniversary of the establishment of a free press on this continent, in the yard of ancient St. Paul's Church, East Chester.

HOLLYWOOD. WHERE once this place felt flattered when its main thoroughfare was referred to as a miniature Broadway, the influx from Gotham has been so great in recent months that local residents now drop the qualifying "miniature."

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 28. -- A smashing ground attack led by Peter Slifkus and Ulysses Lupien enabled Loomis School's eleven to trounce its formidable rival, Choate School 26-7, today and account for one of the major upsets of the prep school season.

WASHINGTON, (AP). -- Another mystery of the sea -- what becomes of millions of shrimp which disappear annually from the fishing grounds off the South Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States -- is puzzling experts of the Bureau of Fisheries.

THE first two or three chapters of "The Old Man Dies" will prove rather hard going. Elizabeth Sprigge drops us without preamble squarely into the centre of the complicated story she has chosen to tell, and leaves us, for the moment at least, floundering.
Hunter College students have elected thirty-four class officers for the current term. Of these, twenty are student council representatives. The names of the officers follow:

In anticipation of the official opening of the Winter trapshooting season next Saturday, thirty gunners of the New York Athletic Club reported at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday and shot a full program. The High Scratch Cup went to Tracy H. Lewis, who broke 98 out of a possible 100 targets.

THOOSE who read Miss Parton's "Melissa Ann: A Little Girl of the 182O's" found in it a pleasing quality that came from the well-suggested atmosphere of a past day and the picture of an interesting child. In Tabitha Mary there is much more.

Convinced that existing difficulties threaten success of the seventh Pan-American Conference in Montevideo in December, export executives last week were outspoken in their demands that the gathering be postponed until the meeting can be held under more propitious circumstances.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- The meetings here this week of the Disarmament Conference's Bureau (steering committee) and general commission have shown that Europe's chancellories are absorbing more rapidly than had been expected the shock of Germany's double withdrawal.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The annual Tuxedo Autumn ball, official opening of the debutante season in the metropolitan district, was held tonight in the Tuxedo Club, which was brilliantly decorated for the event. The ball, which served as the formal introduction to society of several young women, was preceded by many dinners.

AS a centrist, Mr. Hazlitt has only to look right and left to see the errors of extremism perpetuating our critical chaos, and he continues with businesslike dispatch to expose these errors of isolation and exaggeration, so abhorrent to his reasonable view of things.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Meeting today in this little silk city where silk unions were unknown until last Spring, a hundred delegates of the national strike committee voted to continue the strike against the silk code minimum wages of $12 and $13 a week.

The meaning and the effects of the national recovery program and the prospects it holds out for the future will be discussed at the annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor, Nov. 8. More than 1,000 members and guests of the academy are expected to be present.

TODAY. FIRST 'CELLIST of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Alfred Wallenstein, will broadcast as guest soloist when, Bruno Walter directs the musicians for the Tartini 'Cello Concerto in D major, comprising the first half of this Carnegie Hall concert.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounted to 376,000 shares, compared with 1,260,000 on the previous Saturday. This represented the slowest trading since the second week in September. The share market, aside from the fact that it was moving with unusual caution in all its operations, indicated that speculators were "off the reservation" for the time being.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was quiet and produced no important price changes. United States Government securities were moderately soft, except for the Treasury 3 3/8 s of 1941-43 which advanced 2-32 point.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- White Plains High School's football team defeated A.B. Davis High (formerly Mount Vernon High), 12 to 6, today before 10,000 at Howard Field in a Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association game.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- The Swarthmore soccer team defeated Princeton, 2 -- 1, today. It was the Tigers' third straight setback.
PARIS. AMBROISE VOLLARD, whose name is already a legend in the history of modern French art, leaned over the dining room table in his house on the Rue Martignac, glooming, as Gertrude Stein puts it.

DETROIT, Oct. 28. -- Federal receivers of the closed First National Bank of Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce asserted that the holding companies for the two institutions were organized unlawfully and "were hopelessly and irretrievably insolvent from their very inception."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 26. -- Not for a long time has Palestine Jewry felt so keenly disappointed and despondent as in the past week when the government here announced that only 5,500 Jewish labor immigrant certificates would be issued for the coming six months.
PARIS, Oct. 28. -- Monday night's upset of the Daladier Cabinet in the Chamber of Deputies has lent further appearance of complexity to the French political and parliamentary system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Following are the letters from steel concern executives on which Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, based his charges of collusion on prices:

ALL planetaria are so much alike that the articles which have been published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the planetarium of Chicago serve very well to describe the one to be opened this week in the Benjamin Franklin Memorial and Franklin Institute at Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Retail trade rose sharply with the advent of colder weather. The larger department stores saw the best buying crowds since the abnormally heavy purchases of August and early September. Underwear, blankets, and women's wear and children's apparel sold particularly well.

In the October Geographical Review is an article by JULIAN E. ROTHERY on "the newest map of the oldest British colony," of which he says that surveys of the forest resources of a large paper mill led to the compilation of the map. Of this work he observes that until it was completed "little indeed was known of most of the interior."

The construction of tonnage for the naval, lighterage, fishery and other government departments in privately-owned shipyards is urged in resolutions adopted by the Propeller Club of the United States, it was announced yesterday. This policy would mean a lower cost to the government while aiding the advance of information as to naval architecture and construction among the shipyards of the country, says the club.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Holy Cross turned back Brown today, 19 to 7, and continued along its undefeated football path.

AT the Roerich Museum prints by a score of Argentine artists are now to be seen. While certain medieval, religious and Spanish influences may be traced, the work is for the most part individual and strong. It is a group that possesses surprising variety.

A pledge to check crime, gambling and racketeering, which he declared had not been checked by the Tammany city administration, was made last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor.

At its students' series concert last night in Carnegie Hall the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Bruno Walter repeated Mozart's symphony 28 in C major from its previous concerts this week, and introduced the Lalo concerto in D minor for 'cello and Tchaikovsky's fourth symphony. Alfred Wallenstein, first 'cellist of the orchestra, was the soloist.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28. -- Facing defeat for the third successive Saturday, the University of Tennessee football team came to life in the final period today, scored two touchdowns on line drives and beat its Southeastern Conference opponent, Florida, 13 to 6.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 28. -- The Holy Land was in a ferment today as a result of Arab agitation against an increase in Jewish immigration and unrest spread rapidly not only through Palestine but to Transjordania and Syria.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 28. -- Wholesale arrests of Arab leaders and agitators, extensive military precautions and the appearance over Palestine's leading cities of two squadrons of Royal Air Force planes from Cairo served to overawe the Arabs today after yesterday's clash with the police in Jaffa, in which more than twenty were killed in an attempt to stage a demonstration of protest against Jewish immigration.

THE administration's policy of purchasing newly mined gold at higher than world prices is expected to stimulate further an industry that is already intensely active in this and other countries -- gold mining.

At the picturesque field of Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, Conn., where the national tourney was staged last year, the New York Field Hockey Association team will oppose the Fairchester representatives this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- William L. Ward, Republican leader of Westchester County, who died on June 16, left a gross estate of $867,130, according to the report today of James J. Fleming, Westchester transfer tax appraiser. With the necessary deductions his net estate was estimated at $655,077, of which his four children receive equal shares under his will.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28. -- Dark Secret, stout-hearted 4-year-old from the Wheatley Stable, charged from behind to a smashing triumph in the twentieth running of the $7,500 Washington Handicap, mile and a quarter feature of the closing card at Laurel today.

Displaying a powerful running attack, Erasmus Hall High School subdued the previously undefeated New Utrecht eleven, 27 -- 0, before 6,500 spectators at Erasmus Field yesterday. The victory was the fourth in four starts for Erasmus.

RADIO CITY is a beehive of activity; one of the busiest new places in New York. It is no easy task to complete the monumental job by Nov. 11, the date marked on the calendar when the thirty-five magnificent studios will be dedicated as a temple of modern broadcasting -- but the engineers promise to be "on the air" when the clock strikes 8 on the fifteenth anniversary of Armistice night.

Fifteen vessels of 18,800 tons were under construction in American shipyards on Oct. 1, according to the American Bureau of Shipping. Only three of these ships of 12,300 tons were of the ocean-going or Great Lakes types of 500 tons or more.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 28. -- The Wesleyan football team sprang a surprise on the favored Amherst eleven in the opening game of the Little Three championship on Pratt Field today when it held the Lord Jeffs to a scoreless tie.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The stock market thus far has benefited by America's new monetary policy. Sterling commodity prices to some extent followed the rise in American prices and this caused fresh speculative buying of industrial securities.

On the basis of replies to an inquiry sent to American manufacturers, shipping concerns and banks interested in foreign trade, the Committee on Reciprocal Trade Agreements concludes that there is a definite desire that such agreements be entered into as early as possible, particularly with LatinAmerican nations.

NEVER mind; this coming Saturday will be worse. But they should put an end to those scoreless ties. With economy being preached in all directions, a scoreless tie is a dreadful waste of energy. Maybe they were using a dead ball.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged both F.H. LaGuardia, the Fusion candidate, and Joseph V. McKee, the Recovery candidate, yesterday with a misconception of municipal government and urged a comprehensive plan of social insurance.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 30. -- President Roosevelt's decision to buy gold in foreign markets has caused considerable anxiety among financial interests here and this second step in his new monetary program is looked upon as "another factor of uncertainty."

AMARILLO, Tex., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Three air circus troupe fliers were killed and a fourth was injured in the crash today of two planes after a collision. They were diving at paper streamers dropped by another craft above the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Study of the one-eighth inch of ozone gas which is all that stands between the human race and destruction by "death rays" from the sun is described by Dr. Charles G. Abbot in the annual report of the Smithsonian Institution.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 (AP).-- Turkey's tenth anniversary as a republic was made the occasion of a demonstration of Germany's friendship today by the mounting of a guard of honor over the Turkish Embassy. The guard was composed of Nazi storm troopers who are veterans of the Turkish theatre of the World War.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- True to the boast of Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, that the Nazis know how to celebrate, Nazified Germany again engaged in a series of festivities over the weekend that fitted well into the election campaign and for which the living and the dead and a foreign country as well were made to furnish the occasion.

NANKING, China, Monday, Oct. 30. -- Apparently apprehensive over disorders or possible violent attempts against himself and other government leaders, as a result of the acceptance of the resignation of Dr. T.V. Soong as Finance Minister, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek threw an immense cordon of troops around the base of the Purple Mountain yesterday and closed all roads and paths to traffic.

To provide emergency work for unemployed men and women who are not now being aided by public and private relief agencies, the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor will resume immediately operation of its Work Relief Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Cornelius N. Bliss, president of the A.I.C.P.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Professor Albert Calmette, assistant director of the Pasteur Institute and a noted leader in the fight against tuberculosis, died this morning of a liver ailment in his almost monastic room in the institute. His death came about twenty-eight years after that of his great master and friend, Pasteur.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 29. -- Trading was active all week in the new clip of wools, with interest especially keen for fine wools and fine crossbreds. One lot of 150,000 pounds of fine Australian wool in Buenos Aires Province brought 14 pesos for ten kilos, equivalent to 23% cents a pound.

The ninetieth anniversary of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, was commemorated yesterday. The Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector, in his morning sermon, discussed the spiritual changes in New York City since the founding of the church.

One hundred years after the failure of Sir JOHN ROSS to discover a Northwest Passage its centenary is being celebrated in England. He came home on the Victory to report that he had found land where he expected water, and had cleared up a mystery that had baffled the scientific and geographical world for 200 years.

A definite pledge for repeal of the increase in water rates and the five-cent tax on taxicab rides, imposed recently by the O'Brien administration, was made last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, in a speech broadcast from station WOR.
The beginning of national Girl Scout week was observed at services at St. Patrick's Cathedral and other houses of worship throughout the city yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- In a sermon preached at Christ Church here today on a text, "Landmarks Erected By Men of Old," the Rev. Dr. Alexander G. Cummins, the rector, and editor of The Chronicle, monthly magazine of the Protestant Episcopal Church, sharply criticized recent activities of the Anglo-Catholic party.

WITH Shavian aplomb, G.D.H. Cole and his wife, Margaret, two of the most indefatigable economists in England, offer us "The Intelligent Man's Review of Europe Today" (Knopf, $3). The book is encyclopedic. Very few people will care to read every word in it, but virtually every one will need it for special information about certain selected aspects of the European troubles.

The colder weather last week spurred retail sales and brought a larger volume of orders on seasonal goods into the local ready-to-wear markets. Women's coats were particularly stimulated and substantial purchases of the dress types strengthened the market.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 29. -- The novel spectacle of newspaper men advising bankers on their public relations was presented at the investment bankers' convention here today.

The world spinning of American cotton in September is estimated at 1,193,000 bales by the New York Cotton Exchange Service. This compares with 1,262,000 bales in August and 1,168,000 in September last year. Consumption in August and September, the first two months of the season, aggregated 2,455,000 bales, compared with 2,235,000 a year before, and 1,960,000 two seasons ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The administration at Washington is very properly exerting itself to free the frozen deposits of closed banks. It is difficult, however, to reconcile this action with what every governmental agency, Federal, State and municipal, is doing to impair the capital of savings banks and insurance companies, by forcing a serious decline in the asset value of their public utility security holdings.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Illinois has assumed the role of dark horse in the Western Conference football championship race, now that Iowa's title hopes have been blasted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Differences as to hours and wages for men and women in eight recently adopted NRA codes and others now under consideration were protested today by the National Woman's Party, which called upon General Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator, to establish a general policy of equal pay for equal work and of regulations based on the nature of the work and not on the sex of the worker.

New York City's three-cornered race for the Mayoralty seemed to have tightened last week. The indications were that Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee, and Mayor John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for re-election, each had gained somewhat on F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate, and that although Mr. LaGuardia apparently retained the lead, it was not by so great a margin as at the end of the preceding week.

Pheasant hunters can get busy today in New York State-except on Long Island. The season will not be an extensive one, terminating on next Saturday, but from all accounts it promises to be a fruitful one. Pheasants have been found in wide areas, liberated by the Conservation Department in large numbers and raised by private clubs from eggs supplied by thousands by the State.

The United German Societies will meet this evening in the New York Turn Hall, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, to decide what answer to make to Mayor O'Brien and what action to take in view of his prohibition of their annual celebration of German Day which was to have taken place yesterday.

Two Cardinals participated in a solemn pontifical mass yesterday morning in the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. The services were in celebration of the golden jubilee of the parish and of the diamond jubilee of the Fathers of the Blessed Sacrament, the French-Canadian order of priests in charge of the church.

In spite of the glaring evils present in our world today, we must not lose our idealism, said Dr. Edmund Davlson Soper, president of Ohio Wesleyan University, in his sermon yesterday morning at the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church at 44 John Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn today defeated the Philadelphia Cricket Club at soccer by 4 to 1.

Last week's more or less erratic movement of the markets indicated little but speculation -- which, concerned itself, first, as to what was the meaning of the government's latest utterance or action, and, second, as to what the government was likely to do next.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- As regards both the practicability and advisability of President Roosevelt's plan to stabilize commodity prices by manipulating the value of gold, there is skepticism among German experts.

QUEBEC, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press). -- The New York Rangers came here from their Montreal training camp today to defeat the Boston Bruins, 6 -- 3, in an exhibition hockey match. More than 3,500 fans gathered at the arena to watch the world's champions beat last year's American section leaders in a fast pre-season match.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It looks as if our President, whom we love for his cheerful courage and high purpose, were definitely courting trouble for us. His broadcast of Oct. 22 declares his aim to be "a dollar which will not change its purchasing and debt-paying power."

Real estate transactions announced in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn over the week-end indicate a demand for a wide variety of property including dwellings, home sites in the Bronx and commercial buildings. Many leasehold deals were reported.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial entitled "To Test the Law Against Owning Gold" appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 8. Paragraph 2, Sentence 2, reads:

JERUSALEM, Oct. 29. -- Jerusalem today became the scene of the bloodshed that has been going on in Palestine since Friday in connection with Arab protests against Jewish immigration, three Arabs being killed and about seventy wounded, fifteen of them seriously, in clashes with the police.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- General Araki's move for a Far Eastern peace conference was interpreted here tonight as a prelude to requesting naval parity in 1935. While officials would make no comment, the presumption is that both the United States and Great Britain would oppose such a decision.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Unofficial intimations from Germany that Noel Panter, imprisoned correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, may not be tried for treason as threatened after all, but expelled instead leave Britons cold. They are waiting to see what will happen.

In the current Dow Service Dally Building Reports, Myron L. Matthews declares that some apprehension is being felt in building circles over the ultimate result of predetermined group pricing of Federal works as shown in bids recently submitted presumably by codified contractors.

WESTBORO, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Trapped in a monoplane streaking earthward at 200 miles an hour with the wing fabric ripping off, three men and a woman met instant death when the craft crashed on the Fairbanks farm opposite the Westboro Airport this noon.

Seventeen years ago the SOTHERNS announced their permanent withdrawal from the stage. Mrs. SOTHERN'S health precluded her going on, and he "could "not play with an actress inferior to "her." What was then said by those who could speak with authority for America should be repeated today, now that he has taken his last curtain call.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes assured residents of the Northwest Oklahoma drought area today that he had no intention of trying to force them to move.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The American army team from Fort Riley, Kan., won the International Milltary Trophy in the feature event of tonight's closing program at the World's Fair Horse Show in the 124th Field Artillery Armory be fore a crowd of 13,000.
VALENCIA, Spain, Oct. 29. -- The ashes of Vicente Blasco Ibanez, novelist, were returned his birthplace here today with elaborate ceremonies.

Displaying a marked superiority in every department of the game, the Brooklyn Dodgers turned back the Chicago Cardinals, 7 to 0, at Ebbets Field yesterday to gain their second victory in the National Football League before a crowd of 18,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The Chicago Bears' fourth-quarter rally worked again today when the defending champions of the National Professional League scored a touchdown in the last five minutes of play to beat the New York Giants, 14 to 40.
E.H. Sothern, dean of the romantic drama in this country and long considered its foremost Shakespearean actor, died Saturday evening in his suite at the Plaza Hotel.

Turning further from his policy of purely defensive tactics, Mayor O'Brien last night rebuked the Recovery party by denouncing its attempt to get into office "on the coattails" of Federal and State executives.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- A charge that some newspapers which are members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association are not living up either to the letter or the spirit of the NRA was made by Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, in an address here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- A charge that some newspapers which are members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association are not living up either to the letter or the spirit of the NRA was made by Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, in an address here today.

Mickey Walker, former world's welterweight and middleweight champion, yesterday was within one pound of the required 175 pounds specified as the weight for his fifteen-round championship battle with Maxie Rosenbloom, world's light-heavyweight titleholder, in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Buster, a handsome bay gelding owned by Miss Becky Lanier, was named the champion of the Ox Ridge hunter trials today, marking the second year in a row that he has gained this distinction.
The Brooklyn soccer team added two American League points by defeating the Brookhattan eleven, 2-1, at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,500 persons.

A crew of five oarsmen, representing the Twenty-fifth Fleet Division of the Seventh Naval Reserve Battalion of Jersey City, yesterday won a silver trophy in the first annual series of whaleboat races to be sponsored by the Third District Chapter of the Naval Reserve Officers Association.

Lutheran churches of the Bronx and Westchester, with the cooperation of others throughout the city, sponsored yesterday a special service commemorating the 450th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther. The service was held in the New York University Chapel on University Heights, the Bronx.

F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, who protested to General Hugh S. Johnson against use of the NRA insignia on a pamphlet for James J. Hoey, Recovery party nominee for Borough President, should have made certain that none of his supporters was doing the same thing before making a complaint.

Helen Teschner Tas, violinist, who played last night in the Town Hall, presented Tartini's sonata in G minor, Respighi's B minor sonata, the Bach partita in D minor for violin alone and a group of short pieces including works of Szymanowsky, Paganlni, Prokofieff, Samazeuilh and de Falla.

The Hill and Hotchkiss elevens are still unbeaten, but that cannot be said for many other Eastern major prep school football teams. The past week-end's contests brought the downfall of several previously undefeated squads as surprises were recorded.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- The general public here and speculators as well have failed quite to understand the exact purport of President Roosevelt's recent declarations. But it would seem, according to cable dispatches from New York, that Wall Street and the general public, and even the American press, did not agree in their interpretation.

In every theatre of the United States where the spoken voice of the dramatic stage is still heard there will be a pause on the night of Nov. 13 for the leading man or woman of the company to step before the curtain and pay a tribute to the memory of Edwin Booth on the centenary of his birth.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 29. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.6, which compares with 71.5 a week ago, 72.2 two weeks ago, 71.1 three weeks ago and 71.4 four weeks ago. The average of two weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- President Roosevelt's announcement that he will enter the world market to buy gold confirms the expectations and fears of Paris. Every authority here since the President's gold policy went into effect four days ago has been presenting arguments, intended to prove that it would be Impossible to affect foreign quotations of the dollar until the United States bought gold abroad.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 29 (AP). -- The Green Bay Packers put on the pressure in the final period of their National Professional Football League game with the Philadelphia Eagles today and won, 35 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Taking inventory of the work the $3,300,000,000 public works fund has already started, Secretary Ickes said today that "a higher and better standard of living for the people of the United States will be one of the achievements of the administration" as a direct result of Federal expenditures in the huge relief program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Did the President offend the propriety of purists by applying the word "chiselers" to a class of petty cheaters? In one form or another the word "chisel," a cutting tool, is found in many members of the Aryan family of languages. Probably we get it in English speech directly from the Low Latin "cisellus."

Bishop William T. Manning of the Episcopal Diocese of New York delivered the sermon yesterday at the first of a series of services to commemorate the 225th anniversary of the founding of the parish of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Richmond, S. J.

Mistaken Marine Parents. A local woman ichthyologist maintains that many species of fish have intelligence. This is measured by successful adaptation to changing environment. The most intelligent fish are the chiclids:

These "almost chaotic times" may be regarded with equanimity by true Christians, the Right Rev. Arthur S. Lloyd declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James, Jerome Avenue and East 190th Street.
The local political campaign was discussed in pulpits throughout the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Opinions among public men tonight as to the effectiveness of the second step in the President's new monetary policy varied greatly. Republicans were skeptical of its accomplishing any benefit for home markets, while Democrats said that it was a step in the right direction.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The Athletic Council of Cornell University today announced awards of seventy-six varsity insignia and freshman numerals.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Oct. 30. -- Dispatches from Peiping report that Mongol Princes in Inner Mongolia have already perfected an organization for an autonomous government and that 170 leaders have subscribed to the budget and adopted plans for the erection of administration buildings at Tientchih, 160 miles northward of Kweihua.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Jap Doud led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 16 -- 14 victory over the Boston Redskins at Fenway Park today before 7,500, the smallest crowd of the local National Professional Football League season.
Twenty canvases by the modern French artist, Georges Rouault, go on exhibition today at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, where they may be seen until Nov. 24.

Coordination of all Federal health activities under a single head in one department, formulation of a national public health plan and appropriation of Federal funds to supplement State and local funds are advocated in a report made public today by the Milbank Memorial Fund.
F.C. Lloyd, president of the Wine Institute of Europe, will arrive today on the White Star motor ship Georgic. Others coming on the liner from Liverpool via Queenstown are:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Many of the Berkshire colonists motored to Salisbury, Conn., this afternoon and attended a concert in the Scoville Memorial Library by the Morgan Trio, sponsored by Mrs. George Griswold Haven. The Morgans are sisters, Virginia, harpist; Frances, violinist, and Marguerite, pianist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- President Roosevelt, after consulting with a group of his fiscal advisers, announced late today that the goveminent would Boon enter that world markets to buy gold through machinery to be set up by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Bids on construction of the third section of the West Side Highway Express, extending from Thirty-eighth to Forty-sixth Streets, will be opened on Friday, Borough President Samuel Levy announced yesterday.

Last Spring the Republican Assembly grudgingly accepted charter revision for New York City. The Democratic Senate defeated it, scorning Governor LEHMAN'S advice. As usual, Tammany was prepared with an alibi. At the last minute Mayor O'BRIEN had introduced in the municipal assembly a revision bill of his own, subsequently adopted, which provides for a popular referendum next week on a local law creating a commission of seventeen to draft a new charter.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 29. -- While trading in the cotton contract market here had periods of activity last week, traders generally were hesitant. Speculative interest was only moderate, but there were at times some trade buying and price fixing, offset by considerable hedge selling.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Bankers expect that the new Reichsbank law legalizing an open-market policy will cause a fresh advance In domestic bonds. It is believed it will involve also a change In the liquidity policy of commercial banks In the sense that the centre of gravity of their investments will tend to move from bills to fixed-interest securities.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 30. -- General Sadao Araki, Minister of War, proposes that Japan summon a Far Eastern peace conference in Tokyo before 1935, inviting the United States, Great Britain, China, India, Russia, France, Holland and Manchukuo.

Department of Justice agents, the police revealed yesterday, joined them Saturday in arresting three young men accused of sending threatening letters through the mail to Dr. Willard P. Beach, a 75-year-old physician who lives at 1,789 Patterson Avenue, the Bronx.

The Chicago Opera Company performed -- or attempted to perform -- Wagner's "Die Walkuire" yesterday afternoon, at the New York Hippodrome. The principal roles were cast as follows: Siegmund, George Fassnacht; Hunding, Sigurd Nilssen; Wotan, Bennett Challis; Sieglinde, Rachel Morton; Brunnhilde, Erna Steinway; Fricka, Norma France, Harry Ladek conducted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Consumers' Advisory Board today requested the Department of Commerce to consider the advisability of developing "over the counter" standards within the Bureau of Standards. The request followed a report to the board by Dr. Robert S. Lynd that quality standards were essential to the successful operation of the industrial codes.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- The early disappearance of State frontiers from the political make-up of the Reich was officially forecast today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Interior Minister, who is in charge of the technical preparations for the elections and referendum on Nov. 12.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- It must be confessed that even now, after nearly a week's consideration, a certain amount of perplexity, misunderstanding and bewilderment exists concerning President Roosevelt's new monetary policy.

A brief, outlining the objections of retail organizations to ten trade practice provisions contained in manufacturers' codes of fair competition has been submitted to A.D. Whiteside, NRA deputy administrator, by Walter N. Rothschild, chairman of the executive board of the retailers' protective committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George Monroe Moffett, who passed the Summer and early Autumn at Les Bois, their place in Glen Cove, are expected today at the Pierre, where they will be for the season.

The Pro Arte Quartet of Brussels provided, at Its first New York recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday, an afternoon of admirable chamber-music playing. The ensemble, which consists of Alphonse Onnou, Laurent Halleux, Germain Prevost and Robert Maas, was generous to a fault in its program: Brahms's Quartet in C minor, Op. 51, No. 1; Bartok's Quartet, Op. 7, No. 1, and Beethoven's C sharp minor Quartet, Op. 131.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 29. -- Alleged speculation by Guggenheim Brothers in their holdings in the Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Company and the Lautaro Nitrate Company, later incorporated as the Cosach Nitrate Corporation of Chile, was emphatically denied today by Medley G.B. Whelpley, a partner in Guggenheim Brothers, and former president of Cosach.

Though two months will pass before Congress reconvenes, a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee is already at work in Washington on a tax program for the next session. Its first problem is to decide what to recommend with respect to liquor taxes.
The Portsmouth Spartans defeated the Stapleton football team in an exhibition game at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, yesterday, 14 to 7, before a crowd of 6,000.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Expansion of the port of Pittsburgh is being discussed by rivermen, who point to a possibility of shipping Western grain to the city via water routes and re-shipping it East by rail.

Somewhere in the doldrums the full-rigged ship "Combermere" is stubbornly becalmed, impatiently rolling and creaking in the ground swell. You can hear the bulkheads and the rigging creaking at the Hudson Theatre, where "Eight Bells" opened on Saturday evening, for the stage effects and Cleon Throckmorton's setting of the captain's saloon are calculated to disturb a land-locked theatregoer's peace of mind.

Recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States was advocated by two out of every three daily newspapers which responded to a recent questionnaire of the Committee on Russian-American Relations of the American Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Another step in the rebuilding of the Boston Red Sox, the gigantic task that Tom Yawkey and Eddie Collins assumed last February when they took over that American League club, was taken today when they announced that Stanley (Bucky) Harris had accepted a one-year managerial contract.

The wage controversy between steamship operators and the 30,000 longshoremen employed at the North Atlantic ports was practically settled yesterday when an offer of the New York Shipping Association to adjust differences was approved by a majority of the local branches of the International Longshoremen's Association.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Demands that Great Britain repudiate the Locarno treaty and free herself from possible entanglement in a European war were registered tonight at two crowded public meetings.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 29. -- Skippers of dinghies who like their sailing in rough water, and cold weather gathered at the Larchmont Yacht Club today for the first of a series of Fall regattas. Throughout the day the Class B dinghies competed in seven races, while the skippers of Class A craft had five events.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 29 (AP). -- A shining flood of gold was headed to the markets of the United States today from Uncle Sam's last rich diggings, where miners expected the new yellow metal to restore prosperity in Alaska.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I found in THE TIMES a statement by the city landscape architect that in redesigning the smaller parks and squares consideration must be given to ease and comfort in crossing these areas.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29. -- Sales offices of the steel companies find as much reluctance as ever on the part of their customers to make purchases. Engagements are made only in case of necessity.

Addressing an East Side audience of 500 at the Neighborhood Playhouse of the Henry Street Settlement, Grand and Pitt Streets, last night, F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged that civil service employes were forced to buy promotion.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Army's football team, victorious over Yale yesterday, made its second triumphal return in a week to the military academy today to receive the acclaim of the entire corps of cadets. The latter assembled at the railroad station at noon for a noisy homecoming celebration.

Only through education can the New Deal be prevented from degenerating into tyranny and despotism, it is declared by Dean William P. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report, made public today. He asserts that a new government of men, not of laws, has been established in the United States and characterizes the Roosevelt administration's recovery program as the sharpest break with the past in the history of the country.

Three Davis and Elkins players dominate the race for Eastern scoring honors this week. Halfback Winter is at the top of the list with 67 points, the result of eleven touchdowns and one conversion. Right behind him are two of his team-mates, Tinney, the other halfback of the West Virginians, with 57 points, and Fluharty, Winter's substitute, with 56.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Par short of its goal, the strike of the National Farmers Holiday Association entered today upon, its second week.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In his statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Dr Edwin W. Kemmerer says: "All currencies in recent years have been more or less managed." And in his conclusion he makes the statement, "The great danger is that a highly managed currency will founder on the rocks of politics."

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Farmers and packers are endeavoring to get the most out of the hogs that they handle, but they are uncertain of the effects of the processing tax and other factors, although they hope things will be clearer by Nov. 5, when the new deal is effective.

Governors Island gained its second leg on the Colyer Trophy yesterday by turning back the First Division polo team, 9 -- 7, before 4,000 persons at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. It was the final of the season's five-game series and developed into one of the most exciting battles of the year.
Tammany resorted to logic yesterday in an effort to prove that neither Joseph V. McKee nor F. H. LaGuardia, anti-Tammany candidates for Mayor, were fit to hold that office.
Tammany resorted to logic yesterday in an effort to prove that neither Joseph V. McKee nor F. H. LaGuardia, anti-Tammany candidates for Mayor, were fit to hold that office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Basing the decision on a ruling of the Department of Justice, the Postoffice Department announced today that it would enforce the law forbidding the circulation of liquor advertisements in dry States. This is regardless of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

The Girl Scouts' "Little House," erected by the Bronx Park Department on the old Huntington estate in Pelham Bay Park, was turned over to the Bronx Girl Scouts yesterday and dedicated by them with appropriate exercises.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Creation of special machinery for a nation-wide campaign to aid State tanks not members of the Federal Reserve System to expand their lending facilities and become eligible for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was announced today by Harvey Couch, RFC director who is in charge of the task.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,321,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

As a result of the government's latest policy with respect to improving price levels announced by President Roosevelt a week ago, commodities recovered last week a moderate part of the losses incurred since the high levels reached in mid-July.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, told an audience at the Chicago Forum today that moderated retail prices, coupled with higher wages and farm incomes, would be necessary to smooth out maladjustments.
The four major candidates for Mayor of New York endorsed in a statement yesterday the proposed $60,000,000 State bond Issue for unemployment relief to go before the voters on election day.

Operations of steel plants last week declined to 30 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The publication believes that only a combination of public works, railroad and automotive requirements can induce a vigorous rebound in operations.
One man was killed and ten persons were injured early yesterday in a collision between two automobiles at Seventy-fourth Street and Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers, bound toward a third straight Big Six football title, knocked the Oklahoma Sooners out of the running yesterday and will take the championship if they can get by Missouri at Columbia next Saturday and the Kansas Jayhawks in Lincoln the following week-end.

The Board of Estimate will hold today the first of two executive sessions on its proposed city budget of about $556,000,000 for 1934. The meeting, it is understood, will be marked by a determined drive, headed by Samuel Untermyer, to force substantial and drastic reductions before the budget is passed on to the Board of Aldermen.
As the administration's decision of yesterday to invade the world gold market was interpreted by financial interests, it marks the second and most delicate phase of the new monetary policy.
Several flats were included In the New Jersey realty turnover reported over the week-end.

In September Lord BEAVERBROOK desisted from his noble but expensive enterprise of promoting the knowledge of DICKENS among his readers. The almost free gift of the novelist's works cost The Daily Express some $90,000 and did no lasting good to its circulation.
By this stage of a topsy-turvy season, the football form follower has become too inured to the unexpected to be shocked by anything that happens on the gridiron.

Active participation in the boycott of German goods, which is being carried on by Jews in this country in retaliation for the antiSemitic activities of the Nazi government, was voted yesterday by delegates from the junior leagues of fifty synagogues throughout New York City.

Herman Lindner of Cardston, Alberta, all-round champion cowboy of Canada, won the championship at the eighth annual rodeo which closed at Madison Square Garden last night. Lindner has won the same title at Calgary for the past three years.

Last week's campaign in this city worked up to a grand climax of personal vituperation. Though razors were not flying through the air, sharpedged epithets fairly filled it. Again the public heard of the " hypocrites," "fakers" and "deliberate falsifiers" who are candidates for office.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Forty-five Jewish organizations from both sides of the Atlantic were represented today at the beginning of a four-day conference on the relief of German Jews.

Mayor O'Brien unveiled a bronze tablet in memory of Lieutenant Edwin Francis Conway, U.S.N., former commanding officer of the Naval Reserve Aviation Base at Floyd Bennett Field, at exercises yesterday afternoon at the field.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Led by Miss Jean Nolan, forward of the Northeast team who tallied four goals, the Fairchester Field Hockey Association eleven conquered the New York Field Hockey Association, 8 to 0, in a challenge match at the Rosemary Hall field today.
The December choice of the Literary Guild will be "Vincent Van Gogh," by Julius Meier-Graefe, published by Harcourt-Brace.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The Chicago Clearing House Association adopted a resolution today approving in principle the program of the national administration for the strengthening of the banking structure through the issuance of preferred stock or debentures.

The two New York County grand juries voted eleven indictments yesterday charging twenty-nine persons in the First, Second and Fifth Assembly Districts in the lower part of Manhattan with falsely registering at the polls to vote in the general elections on Nov. 7.

The most constructive step that could be taken to encourage a further upward movement of industry and trade would be to give immediate assurance that a sound-money policy would be pursued, in the opinion of the Guaranty Trust Company, as set forth in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.
DES MOINES, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Leaders of a dozen agricultural organizations offered remedies for the farmers' economic troubles today at a ten-State Governors' conference.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 30. -- Although no serious incidents occurred in Palestine today following upon the riots of the last few days, the High Commissioner, Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, proclaimed the so-called "Palestine (Defense) Order in Council of 1931," which gives him military and dictatorial powers.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Another foreign artist was added today to the lengthening list of musicians who have declined to appear in Nazi Germany when the American composer Werner Janssen canceled his engagement to conduct the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra in December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A picture of twenty-four-hour air service to Europe from the United States was painted today by sponsors of the Seadrome Ocean Dock Corporation, who urged the technical board of review of the Public Works Administration to advance $30,000,000 for construction of a series of five floating landing fields across the Atlantic.

A crowd of 10,000 wrestling fans in Madison Square Garden last night saw Jim Browning, Missouri giant, retain his world's heavyweight catch-as-catch-can title by throwing Sandor Szabo, husky Hungarian grappler, in 50 minutes 56 seconds of their finish struggle.

Cancer Week, designated by Mayor O'Brien for the annual appeal for funds by the New York City Cancer Committee to carry on its campaign to "fight cancer with knowledge," was opened yesterday with a radio address by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, over Station WABC.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- President Roosevelt's decision to purchase gold abroad resulted in renewed demand for gold-mining shares on the Stock Exchange today. Kaffirs were the most active, with Australian, Indian and West African stocks sharing in the advance.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The chief immediate effect of President Roosevelt's new gold policy was in foreign exchanges, where it caused a sharp fall in the value of the dollar, New York exchange rising to 4.82 1/2 in early dealings and closing at 4.78 3/4.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The return of legal beer was heralded as the harbinger of a return of good cooking and the appreciation thereof.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries report for the year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $2,495,099 after all taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest equal, after preferred dividends, to 9 cents a share on the common stock.

Maxie Rosenbloom and Mickey Walker, who are to battle fifteen rounds or less for the former's world's light-heavyweight championship Friday night in Madison Square Garden, yesterday were pronounced physicially fit by Dr. William H. Walker, State Athletic Commission physician.

DETROIT, Oct. 30. -- A mob of 2,500, sweeping through the manufacturing district in 300 automobiles, attacked seven factories here today and did thousands of dollars in damage. The mob was made up, it was said, of persons sympathizing with tool and die makers, but strike leaders said none of their men was involved and laid the rioting to hoodlums who, they held, had seized on the strike as an excuse for vandalism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Company are attempting through a code approved by the government to "freeze their long-continued monopolistic and anti-union policies," according to a statement by Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, at a hearing today on the proposed code for the structural steel and iron fabricating industry.

Preliminary plans for policing the polls on election day to guard against violence and illegal balloting were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Bolan. Coincidentally, Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, chairman of the watchers' committee of the Honest Ballot Association and a leading Fusion supporter, was sworn in, at his own request, as a Special Deputy Attorney General.

The Brotherhood of Edison Employes, an independent labor organization, obtained a temporary injunction yesterday from Judge Robert P. Patterson in the United States District Court upholding its right to organize the 33,000 employes of the New York Edison Company without interference by the company and restraining the activities of the Association of Employes of the New York Edison Company, characterized as a company union.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Four men, one critically wounded by machine-gun fire, were brought to New London today after a lively skirmish that sent an alleged rum-runner to the bottom of Long Island Sound and badly damaged a Coast Guard patrol boat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The text of the code of fair competition for the anthracite industry as submitted to the NRA by the coal operators follows:

Dishwashing, he-man jobs in ocean freighter stokeholes and other glamourous prospects faded last night for Phelps Newberry Jr. and Henry Wetter Jr. when the police caught up with them in the Bradley House at 101 West Forty-third Street.
BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- The round-by-round description of the Lou Brouillard-Vince Dundee fight follows:
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30. -- The management of the Colon Theatre has announced that Lily Pons has accepted a contract to sing here next season.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Vice Chancellor John J. Fallen today enjoined the American Federation of Silk Workers from interfering with the operation of the Bayonne Textile Corporation in Bayonne. The decision emphasized that the Bayonne factory was operating under an NRA code with provisions to end strikes, and, therefore, courts of equity should not recognize picketing as a means of bringing about a settlement.
Several business structures and flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The division of loyalty between church and State as evidenced in Germany was pictured yesterday as one of the causes of international discord by the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn. He spoke at a luncheon of the Congregational and Christian Ministers' Federation of the Metropolitan Area in the Hotel George Washington, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
Misuse of the NRA insignia for campaign purposes was charged in two boroughs yesterday.

Countess D'Zarnekau gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for the Grand Duke Dimitri and his sister, the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Thomas and Frank Adair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Oct. 25 shows decreases far the week of $100,000,000 in loans, $25,000,000 in investments, $15,000,000 in net demand deposits and $55,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $47,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Private funeral services for E.H. Sothern, veteran actor and leading Shakespearean player of this country, were held yesterday afternoon at the Fresh Pond Crematory in Maspeth, Queens, only a few intimate and lifelong friends being present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Developments today gave every indication that the administration is seeking to avoid bringing on international monetary warfare when it puts into effect its program of gold-purchasing by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the world markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- When the President's fiscal council observed last week that domestic gold purchase by the government was not having the effect desired, the authors and supporters of the plan voted to move at once into the foreign field. It then once more became the unhappy duty of the loyal councilors who did not favor the idea in the first place to point out the prospects of French and British retaliation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Gratified that only four nations have withdrawn from the tariff truce proposed by the United States before the London Economic Conference, officials today said that no intimations had been received that any others intended to withdraw.
The reputation for power which is sometimes attributed to a team on the strength of an impressive game is not always accepted in the same degree of enthusiasm by those close to the team.

The series of public lectures inaugurated last year at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America will continue this Fall, Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the seminary, announced yesterday. The purpose of the lectures is to give the general public a popular as well as an authoritative presentation of various aspects of Jewish history and literature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- More rum boats along the coasts and mounting liquor supplies at their home stations were interpreted today by Coast Guard officials as spelling trouble with smugglers if prohibition is repealed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The administration found itself confronted today with direct challenges to the legality of its policy in attempting to force compliance with the NRA by denying government contracts to non-conformists.

The scheme for paying coupons of German bonds, 50 per cent in cash and 50 per cent scrip, redeemable at one-half its face value, may be put in operation in this country by about the middle of December, according to an announcement yesterday by Ralph Crane of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., who is chairman of a committee of firms and institutions which issued German securities.

GENE FOWLER used to be the managing editor of The New York Morning Telegraph. Before that he worked for a variety of newspapers of the more sensational variety, usually with his tongue thrust impudently into his cheek. As reporter, managing editor or special writer, Mr. Fowler never forgot his will to enjoyment and laughter.

Hoodlums invaded F.H. La-Guardia's stronghold in Harlem's Little Italy early yesterday morning and smashed about 100 plateglass store windows in which his campaign placards were displayed. Hundreds of tenement windows, almost exclusively displaying the placards, were not touched, however.

The Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., made public yesterday a resolution condemning the boycott of German goods in this country. The resolution was adopted by the executive committee of the organization a week ago and copies were sent to President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Hull, Secretary of Commerce Roper and Recovery Administrator Johnson.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance tonight of "Let 'Em Eat Cake" at the Imperial Theatre which has been taken over by the directors of the Travelers Aid Society to raise funds for carrying on its work. Several young women of society will distribute programs and sell flowers at the benefit.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30. -- The names of sixteen Newark lawyers on an alleged "preferred list" at the State Labor Department's compensation bureau was read into the record today at a continued hearing of the legislative commission's investigation of the administration of the Compensation Law.
