NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson will sail on Nov. 9 for a visit with Lord and Lady Astor in London.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 (AP). -- The infant daughter of John and Florence Trumbull Coolidge became Cynthia Coolidge today, thus perpetuating the initials "C.C." borne by her distinguished grandfather, the former President.
Six team matches were played last night at as many clubs to open the squash tennis league season in the Class C division.

The local NRA organization, of which Graver A. Whalen is chairman, may take a plebiscite this week of the 1,500 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company to determine whether the men want to join the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway Employes, an A.F. of L. organization, or whether they prefer to remain members of the company union maintained by the line.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Judge Samuel West in Federal Court today approved the reorganization plan for the Empire Steel Company and sale of a majority of the properties to the Empire Steel Tinplate Company, organized by the committee headed by John A. Hadden, Cleveland attorney.

Vince Dundee, the new middleweight champion of the world, is 29 years old and has been boxing professionally since 1927. Prior to annexing the title he had been a strong contender for the crown, although he was outpointed in his last two starts before defeating Lou Brouillard.
Mayor O'Brien and Controller George McAneny signed the city's agreement with its bankers, providing for financing over the next four years, at 1 o'clock this morning.
BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Nikolai Soenka, landlord of Wassil Taneff, a defendant in the Reichstag fire case, was arrested in court today on charges of perjury.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30. -- Finance Minister Aranha has instructed Brazil's London bankers, N.M. Rothschild Sons, to withhold the payment due tomorrow of 9,419,187 gold francs on the nation's debt to France. It is understood it is proposed to make no further payments on the debt until France rescinds the increases decreed on July 8 in tariffs on imports from this country.

Mayor O'Brien and Borough President Samuel Levy, assisted by the heads of the Departments of Health, Hospitals and Sanitation, officiated yesterday noon at the laying of "the largest cornerstone ever to be laid for any public building." The ceremonies marked resumption of work on the structure at Worth and Centre Streets, which is to house the three departments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A group representing the country's mutual savings banks conferred with President Roosevelt today in the Glass-Steagall Banking Act as applied to such institutions.

Thieves who had worked for three weeks finally got into the thick concrete vault of Benjamin Kroll Brothers, Inc., furriers, of 788 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, and escaped Sunday night or early yesterday morning with fur coats valued at $100,000 to $125,000.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30. -- Fascists here are rushing Argentina toward a serious class conflict, according to unanimous editorial comment in leading newspapers today, condemning the firing on a Socialist meeting Sunday, resulting in the death of a workman and the wounding of a political orator.

The New York Joint Stock Land Bank announced yesterday a plan for conserving its assets pending ultimate liquidation as necessitated under the Farm Relief Act. The bank has asked holders of its bonds to accept a reduction in interest for the next five years from the rate of 5 per cent to a rate of 2 1/2 per cent annually.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Copain, racing for the St. Louis stable and ridden by Jockey R. Tilden, made it three straight when the 2-year-old son of Sin Paleau Di Nil won the Stickney Handicap at Sportsman's Park before more than 9,000 spectators today.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 30. -- A bill of indictment was signed this evening by the military Attorney General in connection with the sedition charges against Second Captain Salvador Tirado Salido and eight alleged accomplices, who are held in the military prison here.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., Oct. 30. -- Scoring 170 points on the first cast of the thirteenth chase futurity, Gene Parrish, by Napoleon K. out of Pebbles Parrish, was high-score hound among fifty-three contestants as the National Fox Hunters Association began its annual meeting today.

Isidor J. Kresel continued yesterday to give testimony in his defense in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court at his trial on the charge of abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States.

Archer Milton Huntington, author and art collector, son of the late Collis P. Huntington, builder of the Southern Pacific Railroad, has purchased for occupancy the Rockland County estate near Haverstraw, of Sam Katz, formerly vice president of the Paramount Publix Corporation and president of the Publix Theatres.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 30. -- During a short pitched battle today 300 shoe factory workers prevented the removal of machinery from the factory of Paisner Batchelder, Inc., to an interstate truck bound for Berwick, Me.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 30 -- There is no crepe on the golden dome of Notre Dame that reflects the rays of an Indian Summer sun above the colorful Autumn foliage of the university campus.

The New York organization of the American Legion protested yesterday to the steamship lines against persons who have been soliciting funds from passengers and visitors on ships and piers on the pretense that they represent the Legion and that donations will be turned over to it.

Told that there had been a terrific battle in the beer gardent of Thomas Cox at 610 Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Patrolman John Morahan investigated last night and by a thorough search uncovered what would have been a mystery, the police said.

The five Canadian officers who will compete in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 8 to 14 are due to arrive in New York with their ten mounts on Friday, it was announced yesterday. The horses will be further schooled here and four officers and eight mounts will make up Canada's official entry for the military team events.

The American Bartenders Institute, at 352 Fourth Avenue, yesterday began its first Fall semester. The institute will be run on the "co-ed" plan, will maintain a 100-foot bar for laboratory work and will embrace in its curriculum every drink from the elementary Manhattan cocktail to the advanced horse's neck.

A petition for a special session of the Board of Aldermen at 10 o'clock Saturday morning to vote on the question of repealing the 50 per cent increase in water rates was being circulated among the city's Aldermen yesterday.

MANAGER POTSY CLARK of the Portsmouth Spartans had the table covered with little blocks of sugar. He was demonstrating various formations and talking fluently of the Warner system, the Notre Dame system, the Haughton system and half a dozen more systems. He was not enthusiastic about the Notre Dame system, which was no surprise to his listeners, because Mr. Clark was once a star quarterback at Illinois for the esteemed Herr Zuppke.

The City Campaign. Samuel Seabury, chairman of Fusion campaign committee, charged Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, as a member of the Board of Estimate voted favorably on a petition of a McKee client for street changes in Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP). -- D. Harvey Sykes, his six-day portrayal of the alleged Delaware County "protection" organization completed, underwent cross-examination today by counsel for the seventy-five defendants.

Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in Richmond reserved decision yesterday on the application of Charles Pallister for an injunction to prevent the regular Democratic organization in Richmond from supporting Anning S. Prall for the Borough Presidency.
BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Graf Zeppelin, homeward bound from Chicago, reported shortly before midnight that she was about 1,000 miles at sea and making satisfactory progress.

CRISTOBAL, Oct. 30. -- The Jacob Ruppert, with Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and his Antarctic expedition party, arrived here at 2:45 P.M. today, finishing the first leg of its voyage to the South Polar regions. The vessel immediately began to discharge a supply of coal for the second Byrd ship, the Bear, which is expected Nov. 11.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30. -- Asserting that a reservoir of money that could be translated into jobs for millions of people was being held back by the need for clarification of the liability sections of the Federal Securities Act, Frank M. Gordon, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, characterized the act today as a serious hindrance to national recovery.

The three principal candidates for Mayor have expressed themselves as favoring five planks of the platform put forward by the New York City League of Women Voters, it was made known yesterday by release of their answers to a questionnaire sent from the league offices, 155 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Rockefeller Foundation aided in the refinancing of two railroads and a utility in which it had invested by depositing its bonds under refunding plans, the report for 1932 discloses. The foundation bought railroad and oil securities in 1932.

Anti-Semitism in Germany and lynchings in this country were condemned alike at a seminar sponsored by the National Conference of Jews and Christians yesterday in Horace Mann Auditorium, Broadway and 120th Street.

The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $3,236,296 for the three months ended Sept. 30, equivalent to 62 cents a share on 5,251,468 shares of no-par common stock. This compares with a net profit of $3,238,168, or 62 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, and with a net profit of $2,450,047, or 47 cents a share on 5,251,493 shares in the corresponding period of last year.

Eleven Manhattan properties and five Bronx parcels were put on the auction block yesterday in foreclosure actions. All the holdings were bid in by the plaintiffs, except one Manhattan parcel which was withdrawn. The results were as follows:

Pointing for its traditional game with City College at Ebbets Field on Saturday, the Manhattan eleven worked for two hours on Manhattan Field yesterday. In an effort to strengthen the team's defense, Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan moved Jack Connell from guard to right end.

Romantic Revival Arrives E.H. SOTHERN was generally accepted as the leading romantic actor of his day. Had his death occurred only a year ago it would have been hard to challenge the statement that he was also, with the exception of WALTER HAMPDEN, the last of the romantic actors.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Federal approval has been given to the application for funds for work at the Newark Airport, construction of a water supply in Bernardsville and for the Princeton incineration plant, according to Dr. Jacob G. Lipman, member of the State advisory committee, in a report to Governor A. Harry Moore today.

Chaotic conditions developed yesterday on the commodity markets, with trading small except in silver, which showed a more consistent trend than other staples and retained a part of its gains to close substantially higher than on Saturday. Other commodities backed and filled and were irregular in their net changes.

Columbia began preparation yesterday at Baker Field for its traditional contest with Cornell at Ithaca on Saturday. It was a comparatively easy session, as Coach Lou Little and his assistants have scheduled the heavy drills to get under way today.
ROME, Oct. 30. -- Rome, which has seen many curious processions in its day has witnessed few more curious than one that wound its way through the principal streets this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Vast savings in operating costs, sufficient to have given the nation's railroads nearly a half billion dollars' profit in 1932 instead of a quarter-billion deficit, are claimed by sponsors of the Prince plan for railroad coordination, now being studied by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

Settlement of the dyers' strike and buying confidence inspired by the new gold policy brought material improvement in the silk gray goods market last week, according to Woodhouse, Nickel, Barrett Quinn, textile brokers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP). -- George W. Wickersham, chairman of the Hoover Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement, said here tonight that he "made a mistake" in reading the public mind regarding prohibition when the commission's report was submitted.

An improvement of 15 points or more occurred yesterday in early prices on the Cotton Exchange following a sharp advance in both sterling and gold quotations in London. The list maintained a slight gain for several hours, but selling pressure increased during the afternoon break in security prices and a 30-point decline left net changes ranging from a loss of 6 points to a gain of 3 points.

Popular-Price Goods Stressed. The improvement in retail sales last week, resulting from the cooler weather, was reflected in reorders coming into the wholesale market yesterday. The increase in volume however, over that of last week was only fair and confined to popular price goods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, who as a delegate to the World Economic Conference was a member of the monetary committee, expressed approval today of the President's program to buy gold in the world markets.

After falling heavily at first on the news of the government's decision to buy gold abroad, the dollar rallied yesterday to close with minor losses against the principal foreign exchanges. In terms of the French franc the dollar dropped to 65.57 per cent of parity, rallied to 67.29 cents and closed at 66.80 cents, down .29 of a cent.

HAVANA, Oct. 30. -- The Havana University General Assembly in a special meeting tonight split over a proposal to give the Student Directorate, now in control of the government, a vote of confidence until Saturday, Nov. 4.

A report to be presented to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on Thursday by its executive committee opposes the plan of the Federal Government to engage in housing construction in slum areas, it was announced yesterday.

Fordham's football eleven, still undefeated and untied, launched a week of vigorous practice yesterday in preparation for the intersectional battle with the powerful St. Mary's team of Oakland, Calif., at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Rodeph Sholom, Pittsburgh, was elected the rabbi of Temple Emanu-El by more than 200 members of the congregation, who unanimously adopted last night the recommendations of the Board of Trustees.

The fire of "bitterness and resentment" is sweeping the masses of Germany's workers against the Hitler regime and a growing underground movement aiming at its overthrow is making itself increasingly manifest -- this was the report brought yesterday by Martin Pletti, former head of the German Clothing Workers Federation, who arrived here yesterday from Holland on the steamship Vollendam.

Criticizing Joseph V. McKee for his speech promising to free the Police Department from political domination, Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, took up yesterday the issue of racketeering and corruption. He called for public ownership and operation of utilities as the only means of eliminating graft due to the seeking of favors from government by private business.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 30. -- Professor Bertil Ohlin, the Swedish economist, explained today the method used by Sweden in carrying out its gold-buying policy, as compared with that of the United States, and recounted its effect upon the country's commodity price level and general economic condition during the past year.

Announcement over the week-end that the administration had determined to extend its gold-buying operations into the European market had only a temporarily beneficial effect yesterday upon stocks and commodities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Nelson Morris, member of the packing house family, who divorced his French wife in May because she wouldn't leave the stage for a domestic career, today married another French comedienne, Mile. Blanche Bilboa.

Reports from this State and others in the East indicate a greater abundance of grouse this year than in several seasons. Though this condition may strike the fancy of the sportsmen who have found great pleasure in gunning for this fine game bird, the mere fact that grouse have increased to such an extent also should carry a warning.
The International Paper Company sent yesterday to its newsprint customers a letter in which it said in part:

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Sir Eric Geddes, discussing the establishment of transatlantic air lines today before stockholders of the Imperial Airways, said that Canada was likely, by force of circumstance, to be the last great Dominion with which Britain would be in contact by a regular air service.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- The entire board in charge of Chicago's vast park system was sentenced to jail today for contempt of court in connection with the discharge of a civil service employe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is much confusion with respect to the monetary policy now in process of development at Washington. As an adherent of the principle of the compensated dollar, it seems to me worth while to state what I conceive to be the probable results of the present course of action and to point out that the compensated dollar is not really involved in the present program.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Favored by his light impost and alertly handled by Jockey L. Ruder, E. Trotter's Judge Leer produced a distinct surprise when he accounted for the Wyoming purse, an all-age allowance dash of six furlongs which featured today's program.

HAVANA, Oct. 30. -- A turbulent meeting of 1,000 Havana University students tonight was regarded with anxiety by political leaders, who believed it might mean the breaking or the making of the Ramon Grau San Martin government.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 30. -- Making one of his few public appearances since he captured the national amateur championship at Kenwood, George T. Dunlap Jr. annexed the first amateur prize today in the weekly amateur-professional tournament sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association at the Garden City Country Club.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30. -- Rlgan McKinney, leading amateur steeple-chase rider in the country, added another victory to his string when he was first today with Thomas Hitchcock's Escapade on a charity program given over to claiming events.

So just enough ozone to make a layer one-eighth, of an inch thick is all that separates us from death. Dr. ABBOTT might easily have elaborated the theme. Life is the manifestation of a mechanism of almost incredible subtlety, delicacy and intricacy.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Boerse opened the week with a dull and sagging trend. Both stocks and bonds showed losses, but most of these were merely fractional. Reichsbank shares opened with a drop of 2 per cent, but were able to recover.
John B. Bass of the Conoco Golf Club, Ponca City, Okla., yesterday was declared winner of the first annual national handicap championship, conducted by the Handicap Golfers Association of America.

BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- Vince Dundee Baltimore veteran, tonight stripped Lou Brouillard of his newly won middleweight title by side-stepping most of his savage rushes and driving him back with a light but effective right to the head in their fifteen-round engagement.

In presenting a series of carefully planned, thoroughly representative, one-man shows of work by American artists, the Museum of Modern Art has undertaken a service of the utmost value. Last season the artist thus brought forward was Maurice Sterne.

Associates who said last Thursday that Heinz Spanknoebel had sailed for Germany on the Deutschland the previous night changed their story yesterday when they were summoned to the office of George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- While the American Government's decision to purchase gold abroad was greeted with cheers today by inflationists in France, which include commercial interests and many industrialists, the United States is denounced in strong language by newspaper editorial writers.

Miss Kathleen Hogan will give a luncheon Thursday in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis to celebrate the third anniversary of the Lots for Little Shop, which is maintained at 902 Third Avenue to aid various charitable organizations. The guests of honor will be Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes, founder and president of the shop, and members of the board of managers.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was based upon the prospect that, as a result of the government's decision to go into the world market for gold in a large way, share prices would have to be moved higher. It did not work out exactly that way yesterday, but the slow business was carried on in the morning to the accompaniment of a moderate advance in stock and commodity prices.

The Alimony Club, comprising men who have been committed to the County Jail for default in payments under court orders in marital suits, was incorporated yesterday with the approval of Supreme Court Justice Cotillo. The members' purpose is to try to obtain legal and financial aid for themselves and others in the same predicament.

United States Government bonds shared yesterday in the general weakness of domestic issues. Trading in the Federal securities was the heaviest of the month, the volume of $3,866,000 comparing with $1,974,500 on Friday, or nearly double the last full day's turnover.

All the candidates in this city election seem to picture New York as an anxious lady singing plaintively: " Oh, Promise Me." Never have so many pledges been made by those seeking office. The list of promises is so long and bewildering that no one can possibly remember them all.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -- With the exception of Stanton Whitney, who started Harvard's game with Dartmouth as quarterback, Shaun Kelly, who played for a short time at one of the ends, and Allan Sherman, a halfback, all of the Cambridge varsity men who participated in the tie contest on Saturday were excused from practice today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Any processing tax on hogs must either be passed on to the consumers by the packers or taken out of the price paid to farmers, because the processors are unable to absorb it, the Farm Adjustment Administration was told today.

BELIN, Oct. 30. -- The case of Noel Panter, the English newspaperman who is held at Munich on a double charge of espionage and treason, has been transferred from the hands of the Bavarian police to the public prosecutor of the Reich Supreme Court at Leipzig.

Among all who are closely observing the Government's experiment with gold purchases, none are more interested or vigilant than members of Congress who are committed to currency inflation. A depreciated dollar, when measured by gold, will not in the least satisfy them. They demand vast new issues of paper money.

A memorial absolving Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, from racial or religious prejudice was presented, to him yesterday by eighty-six leading Jewish residents of the Bronx, his home borough.

Let us not take up much of each other's time this morning. "Under Glass," which opened at the Ambassador last-evening, is not a subject worth dawdling over. It carries itself with a self-conscious air of smart and cosmopolitan sophistication.

Mrs. John Sloane, president of the Maternity Centre Association, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for the board of directors of the organization and for Miss Elsa Maxwell who has arranged a novel hunt to feature a large entertainment for the benefit of the association tomorrow night.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, recovering from an operation for appendicitis, has developed pleurisy, it was announced yesterday. His physicians, however, indicated by their bulletins that the Governor was still making satisfactory progress.

The efforts of steamship operators to draft a code for the shipping industry was complicated further yesterday when a group of American-flag lines operating in the foreign trade agreed to meet with the foreign-flag lines serving American ports to prepare a code of their own, apart from the general code sponsored by the American Steamship Owners Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Under the leadership of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt "key women" from many widely separated cities conferred today over the problem of bridging the gap between temporary government relief measures and permanent local welfare service.

The three leading candidates for Mayor and the candidates of the Socialist and Communist parties will speak tonight at a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Citizens Budget Commission, it was announced yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of the commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A code fixing a forty-eight-hour week for the anthracite industry was filed today with the National Recovery Administration.
The New York Retail Code Authority was set up yesterday to adminster the NRA retail code for New York City. Between 50,000 and 75,000 retailers will come under the Authority's jurdiction.

Returns to date indicate that the upward trend of railroad earnings continued in September, with gross revenue and net operating income above the levels of September, 1932. The indicated results for September follow:
BUCHAREST, Oct. 30. -- King Boris of Bulgaria spent seven hours with King Carol of Rumania today.

In quest of prize money aggregating upward of $60,000, America's professional golfing forces soon will set forth on their annual competitive campaign through the South and Far West, according to The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- President Roosevelt at a conference with steel men today brought about an agreement which is expected to end the strike in the captive coal mines owned by the steel companies.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Oct. 30. -- Finnish police believe that the espionage organization discovered here last week has wide ramifications in other countries of Europe and in America.

More than 600,000 homeless and dependent children will need the care of welfare agencies in this country during the coming Winter, it was asserted yesterday by J. Prentice Murphy, president of the Child Welfare League, at its annual conference at the Hotel Biltmore.

Virginia La Rae, a young soprano from Seattle, whence she came 3,000 miles to New York for what was declared to be her second appearance in a performance of opera, although her first here, sang the cadenzas and topnotes of Donizetti's "Lucia" to shouting galleries at the Hippodrome last night.

The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency sent yesterday to all member firms and individual members of the New York Stock Exchange questionnaires covering their commissions, profits and pool operations since 1929. It is the most exhaustive inquiry ever made of Stock Exchange brokers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Yale's football practice today consisted of a thirty-minute signal rehearsal for a picked varsity eleven and a twenty-minute scrimmage session by the reserves against the scrubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The effectiveness of a statement filed by the Van Cortlandt Recreation Corporation of Brooklyn for registration under the Securities Act of an issue of $300,000 of 6 per cent participating stock was suspended today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery nominee for Mayor, asked the voters of New York City last night to elect a Mayor on a business basis and to compare his qualifications with those of F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, for running a corporation that spends more than $2,000,000 a day.

Michael Laura, former leader of the Brooklyn Italian-American Democratic groups, is slated for appointment as assistant to Aldermanic President Denis J. Mahon, it became known yesterday. The position pays $9,140 yearly.

RENO, Nev. Oct. 30. -- A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Mary Marshall Foster from Cannon Foster of New York on the grounds of cruelty. An agreement was reached as to the custody and support of their two children.

The alternative to a free press is irresponsible and often scandalous rumor, Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, told students of the School of Journalism in an informal address at Columbia University yesterday.

A book explaining the technique of newspaper copyediting, how to prepare news stories for publication and write the headlines, has been written by Robert E. Garst and Theodore M. Bernstein, and will be published tomorrow by the Columbia University Press.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30. -- Gordon W. Scott, trustee in bankruptcy of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., and inspectors of the company decided today to reject a proposal of Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., of London, for purchase of the company's assets in a reorganization plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Subordinating all other considerations to "the interest of getting people to work," President Roosevelt offered today a compromise price of $36.375 a ton for the 845,000 tons of steel rails to be purchased for railroads with government assistance, and the proposal was accepted by four steel operators.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Eddie Sauers of Oakland, Calif., and William Mosconi of Philadelphia won their matches in the national pocket billiard tournament which opened tonight.

Sigmund Berkowitz, 55 years old, was shot and wounded seriously last night while remonstrating with a robber for ill-treating Mrs. Berkowitz. The shooting occurred during the hold-up of a haberdashery shop at 53-22 Eighth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.
Maintenance of the five-cent fare was injected into the Mayoralty campaign as an issue yesterday as Tammany continued its drive for the re-election of Mayor John P. O'Brien.

HENRY HESTERBERG was in San Francisco on April 18, 1906. So he ought to know something about earthquakes. At any rate, he is all set to ride one next Tuesday. Let the leaders desert McCOOEY, let even his fellow-candidates come out for MCKEE, they cannot cause him to quail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Representative Cochran demanded information today on whether the Civil Service Commission had barred persons over 45 years of age from entering government service. He wrote to Harry B. Mitchell, president of the commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Industry is revolting against paying salaries of government representatives on code authorities, it was learned today.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The German Government has surrendered in the conflict with Soviet Russia on newspaper reporting. A communique issued tonight states that Foreign Minister von Neurath and the Soviet Ambassador have reached these common conclusions:

The city and its principal banking connections signed yesterday the formal contract embodying the four-year financing and unemployment relief plan worked out last September at conferences among city officials, Governor Lehman and spokesmen for the bankers.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Cornie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, stood in Shibe Park today and emphatically said: "No, I haven't sold any ball players."

Secretary HULL, valiantly working at his plans for reciprocity agreements, has made a painful discovery. It is that the United States has no fixed " commercial policy." How could it have one? American tariffs have long been made for sectional reasons, not for national.

Exports of gold fell Off sharply in October, with virtually no outgoing consignments late in the month. The shipment totaled $27,589,300, compared with $53,972,800 in September and contrasted with imports of $10,922,700 and exports of $35,000 in October, 1932.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated, Oct. 28:

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, who is supporting the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee for Mayor, issued a statement yesterday in which he said that F. H. LaGuardia had written a criticism of Jewish youth in 1919. Mr. Gerard issued his statement to the press at his home, 1,014 Fifth Avenue.

Recognition of the cultural contributions of various races as a means of promoting tolerance was suggested yesterday at a seminar course on intergroup programs, sponsored by the National Conference of Jews and Christians in Teachers College, Columbia University.

Use of increased relief appropriations by Tammany as a campaign fund to re-elect Mayor O'Brien was charged yesterday by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor. To support the charge, Mr. Solomon cited reports of Socialist investigators who, he said, found that O'Brien buttons were being given out to applicants for work relief jobs.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- France today trebled her duties on all imports from Brazil, from whom she buys 90 per cent of her coffee.
Approval of an application for a loan of $29,134,500 from the Federal Government to build and equip schools was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which met in Committee of the Whole.

Della Samoiloff, and not Anna Fioramonte, sang in "Cavalleria Rustlcana" to a gala Halloween throng at the Hippodrome last evening. The soprano from La Scala, a Russian newcomer with an Italian name, was suffering from acute indigestion and unable to make her debut as Santuzza in Mascagni's one-act opera.

Eleven more prominent men, nine of them lawyers, some of whom have been international figures, testified as character witnesses yesterday for Isidor J. Kresel in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court at his trial for allegedly abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the Bank of United States in 1930.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Seventeen registration statements under the Securities Act, involving more than $6,500,000 in prospective issues, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- During a scrimmage, in which Harvard's substitutes scored three touchdowns against a scrub team today, Freddy Moseley, a 163-pound halfback from last year's freshmen, fractured a bone in his ankle and will be out of football for the remainder of the year.
The text of Joseph V. McKee's address at Carnegie Hall last night follows:

A railroad in receivership will soon offer to retire some of its bonds before maturity as a result of an order issued by the Federal court in Mobile, Ala., releasing $540,000 held by the City Bank and Farmers Trust Company to be used in redeeming Mobile Ohio Railroad general mortgage 4 per cent bonds of 1938.

More than 200 student delegates, representing virtually all the schools of Columbia University, attended the first meeting of the Columbia Conference Against War last night in John Jay Hall. The conference, t which is heing held under the auspices of the Columbia College Board of Student Representatives, will continue today.

Henri Morin de Linclays, newly appointed resident director general of the French Line in the United States and Canada, arrived yesterday from Paris on the Ile de France to take up his duties at the offices of the company at 19 State Street.

Fordham University's basketball quintet will face fourteen opponents in its 1933-34 campaign, which will be launched on Dec. 2, when the Rams face the Alumni, it was announced by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey yesterday.

Independent refiners and distributers of unbranded oil products have organized associations in various States in an effort to block the price-fixing program of Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator, which is scheduled to go into effect on Dec. 1 after hearings that are to start today and end around Nov. 15, it was revealed at a meeting of these groups here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and his associates here were gratified on learning today that the miners of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company had decided to affiliate with the union by a vote of 877 to 273.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 31. -- For the second successive day the Dart- mouth coaches ordered a long scrimmage and today the varsity had a taste of work against Yale formations.

Quaker City Brewing Corporation. The Quaker City Brewing Corporation of Philadelphia will offer today through Disbrow, Dixon Potts 41,000 shares of capital stock at $6.25 a share as a speculation. Registration papers, it is stated, have been filed with the Federal Trade Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Standard Oil Company of California declared today the usual quarterly dividend on the reduced basis of 25 cents a share and issued a statement showing a profit of $4,674,102 for the third quarter, or 35.7 cents a share.

Overshadowed by the New York City Mayoralty campaign, a fierce battle for control of the Legislature is being waged from one end of the State to the other. The Democrats already control the Senate, by a single vote; a new batch of Senators will not be elected for another year.

Despite the increase made by the Department of Sanitation in the number of litter receptacles on the streets, the condition of the streets and parks of the city is "almost as bad as it ever was," the Committee of Twenty of Street and Outdoor Cleanliness reported yesterday at a meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Albert H. Wiggin admitted before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that he began to "sell short" in stock of the Chase National Bank a month before the market crash of 1929.

Charges that Tammany was responsible for the abuse in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Laws were made last night by Nathan Straus, Recovery party nominee for President of the Board of Aldermen. He declared that the city administration, instead of insisting on a reorganization in the administration of that work reluctantly dispensed with the services of a few doctors who had received too much publicity.

The nominating straws which show which way the voting winds are blowing indicated yesterday that either Glenn Cunningham or Bill Bonthron will be acclaimed the outstanding American amateur athlete for 1933 and awarded the James E. Sullivan Memorial Medal.
Following is the text of the four-year financial agreement between the city and its bankers:

The existence of a difficult and serious farm problem cannot be dismissed merely because farm organizations seem often to be crying for the moon. On whatever basis the test is made -- by comparison with the boom year 1929, the war years or the pre-war period 1909-14 -- farm prices have fallen further than those of non-agricultural products.

Manhattan College's varsity football squad worked out two hours at Manhattan Field yesterday in preparation for next Saturday's game against C.C.N.Y. at Ebbets Field. Half of the drill was devoted to a lengthy scrimmage against the Jasper freshman eleven, which employed C.C.N.Y. plays.

The Federal grand jury inquiring into the activities of Heinz Spanknoebel in admittedly organizing support for the Hitler government among Germans in this country began to examine witnesses here yesterday on the help that Mr. Spanknoebel's associates may have given him in evading arrest since last Friday.

The Assembly campaigns up-State were discussed yesterday at a conference between W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, and Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly, who is head of a committee composed of legislators in charge of the Republican fight to retain control of the lower house of the Legislature.

Louis Eugene Boudin, an exhibition of whose paintings has just opened at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, is sometimes spoken of as occupying a traditional sphere between the Barbizon men and the Impressionists. He was born at Honfleur in 1825, and as a child must have had some contact with the art of the Barbizon school.

Commemorations come too fast. Captain MAYNE REID died on Oct. 22, 1883. Only a correspondent of The London Times took notice. Millions of boys have thought, one hopes a lot of them think still, that REID was the greatest writer that ever lived. CONAN DOYLE and THEODORE ROOSEVELT doted on him.

Seventy-four members of the Police Department will be promoted today, it was understood last night when Chief Inspector John O'Brien issued an order directing the men to appear in uniform at headquarters this morning.

Universities have no responsibility to any political party or platform but they have a responsibility toward "that scheme of values which makes up the great American experiment of democracy," Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase said last night at a dinner given by the New York University Alumni Federation at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Instead of one International Night at the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden one week from today, the program has been so arranged that it will be International Week.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- The Boerse today was largely under the influence of President Roosevelt's gold policy, but contradictory interpretations of its import produced an attitude of watchful waiting which led almost to complete stagnation of trading.

At this time of the year the opening of a game-hunting season does not provoke extraordinary interest, since the sportsmen have been in the field looking for some sort of game for quite a while in this State. It follows that the first thrilling edges of anticipation no doubt have been rubbed a little blunt.
Two thousand women attended yesterday a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria opening the drive of the New York Chapter of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization, for $50,000 for medical work in Palestine.
Alfred E. Smith questions the constitutionality of certain State laws passed in conjunction with the NRA program in an editorial in the November issue of New Outlook.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- Use of the county airport was denied today to an armada of autogiros which is campaigning over the State against the proposed $50,000,000 bond issue to pay a soldiers' bonus.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The Chicago Board of Trade today won a victory in its fight with the Grain Futures Commission when the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals handed down a decision setting aside an order of the commission suspending the Chicago board for a period of sixty days as a grain "contract market."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Probably the warders of industrial peace, headed by Senator Wagner of New York and known collectively as the National Labor Board, have not gone far enough with their task to have reached any fixed conclusions about the effect of NRA on the future relations of employers and employes.

Present fear of a national policy of uncontrolled inflation is "in large part groundless," since repeal will bring into the Treasury of the United States more than $1,000,000,000 in revenue and wipe out the national deficit, "the real urge toward inflation."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. -- A new movement to transfer the 1936 Olympic Games from Berlin because of anti-Jewish feeling in Germany was started today by Albert F. Whelte, president of the South Atlantic Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.
HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- The Grau San Martin government began an energetic campaign to suppress all criticism today.

No Room for Argument. The political use of NRA in the city election seems to have been wider than was at first suspected. Nothing so offensive and unblushing as the circular issued from the Hoey headquarters -- which Mr. McKEE, the head of the ticket, promptly disavowed and repudiated -- has appeared elsewhere.
The text of the speech prepared by F.H. LaGuardia for delivery at Carnegie Hall last night follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The projected reciprocal trade treaty with Colombia was discussed at a long conference today in the office of Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State. It is understood that the Colombian mission commented on a memorandum of United States suggestions, which was furnished to its members a day or two ago.

"The time has come to extend the 'New Deal' to the wild waterfowl of America," Dr. T. Gilbert Pear son told members of the Nations Association of Audubon Societes a the annual meeting at the Museum of Natural History yesterday. Dr. Pearson, president of the association, in his report of activities said that the depression had been doubly hard on wild life.

Representatives of the American ship lines operating in the foreign trade, and foreign-flag lines serving American ports drafted a code of business ethics at a meeting yesterday afternoon which they will submit today to W.H. Davis, Deputy Administrator of the National Recovery Administration in charge of shipping.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 31 -- A petition on behalf of 1,500 striking workers of the Ford Motor Company plant at Edgewater, citing twelve grievances, including a charge that average pay has been $800 a year, was sent to President Roosevelt today by J. Glenn Anderson, their counsel.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- An international conference for seeking means to keep wild animals in Africa from extinction at the hands of big-game hunters, as well as from marauders, began its sessions here today.

MONTREAL, Qua., Oct. 31 -- Rejection by the trustee in bankruptcy of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., of the Bowater offer to creditors and shareholders of the Price company will not deter the bondholders' protective committee from proceeding with its efforts to make effective the agreement it arranged with the Bowater interests.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Advances authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in September fell to $95,009,511.29, as compared with $111,485,630.87 in July, according to the monthly report made public today. Later accounting's, however, are expected to show a sharp upward trend as a result of expanded activities in the campaign to aid reopening or liquidation of closed banks and other steps in the administration's recovery program.

Despite Lord RUTHERFORD'S recent dictum that speculation on the possibility of utilizing atomic energy "is mere moonshine," even physicists and engineers persist in dreaming of the day when a thimbleful of water will carry an airplane across the ocean or light a small community.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 31. -- The art of the sloganeer plays a major part in Coach D.X. Bible's successful campaigns for football championships at the University of Nebraska.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The business barometer of the Prudential Insurance Company has shown a decided upturn throughout the last four months, Edward D. Duffield, president, said today. Cancellations of policies have dropped sharply and loans nave lessened materially.

After weeks of prolonged public hearings, strenuous executive sessions and midnight meetings, the Board of Estimate adopted a 1934 budget of $554,678,511.85 yesterday, a reduction of $1,298,484.50 from the $555,976,996.35 tentative budget.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- German and Italian circles here today interpreted the announcement of Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, that he was leaving to consult officials in Washington as meaning that the United States was disinteresting itself, like Japan, in disarmament as now a purely European question, and that this marked the break-up of the world conference.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told an assemblage of 8,000 women at the Century of Progress today that the government's great social experiment would succeed, not through the government itself or its leadership, but through the cooperation of every one, particularly the women.

The body of a woman killed by an automobile Saturday night a Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street was identified at the morgue yesterday as that of Mrs. Minnie Hoover Linton, 59 years old, a literary agent. Mrs. Linton, who was distantly related to former President Hoover, lived at the Hotel Roger Williams, 28 East Thirty-first Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The will of John B. Anderson of Madison, N.J., leaving $900,000 in securities to Princeton University after the death of three sisters, was offered for probate in Prerogative Court here today. The Bank of New York and Trust Company was named executor.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 31. -- Today, the fifth day since disturbances began in Palestine, passed off without bloodshed, but demonstrations still continue and tension is running high throughout the country.

A festive atmosphere created by jack-o'-lanterns, ebony-hued felines, high-flying witches and other manifestations of Halloween prevailed last night at the Central Park Casino, where many dinner and supper parties were given.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was amazed on my return from a month's vacation beyond the reach of newspapers, to find the campaign directed against Joseph V. McKee by nearly all the newspapers and persons who, when I had left the city, had been mournfully regretting that he was not then available as a candidate.

FRANK FRISCH, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, came out of the Giant offices and started shouldering his way down Sixth Avenue. What had he been doing in the Giant headquarters -- trying to make a trade for a pitcher named Hubbell?
Corporation Counsel Hilly dismissed three Assistant Corporation Counsels yesterday for their support of Joseph V. McKee and intimated that others would go for the same reason.

Contributions of $176,000 to the fund sought by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies was announced yesterday following a dinner meeting of thirty-four leaders in Jewish philanthropy at the Plaza Hotel on Monday.
The opening of "It Pays to Sin," which was scheduled for this evening at the Morosco Theatre, has been postponed until Friday evening at the same house.
Election-day Instructions to the polled were issued yesterday by Commissioner Bolan.
Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens' Budget Commission, presented the following eleven-point program for remedying the city's financial troubles at the mass meeting last night in Carnegie Hall:
Coach Lou Little had his Columbia football squad out on Baker Field yesterday for a three-hour session in preparation for its annual encounter with Cornell on Saturday at Ithaca.

HOW much of "The Journey of the Flame," by Antonio de Fierro Blanco (Houghton Mifflin, $3), is true to fact and how much is true to legend we have no means of knowing. Certainly Don Juan Obrigon (the Hispanization of the Irish John O'Brien) out-Marlowes Joseph Conrad's most voluble character in this "historical novel, in which certain deviations from the truth are essential."

The American Bankers Association Journal has canvassed the heads of faculties of the schools of economics and business administration in the leading universities to inquire whether, under the New Deal the United States has been "placed on a new and permanent economic basis."

Vince Dundee's acquisition of the world's middleweight title from Lou Brouillard is expected to stimulate interest in the class over which such ring immortals as Bob Fitzsimmons and Stanley Ketchel once reigned.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Representatives of 500 ribbon workers met at the headquarters of the Associated Silk Workers tonight to formulate new demands which will probably be presented to the manufacturers some time this week with a request for a conference.

The compliance board of the local NRA, representing employers, labor and the public, took up for the first time yesterday problems of business men who consider themselves hard-pressed under the President's re-employment agreement and have petitioned the compliance board for modifications as affecting their respective situations.

Dividends declared in October Showed a continuance of the improvement in payments which set in several months ago. The aggregate, however, was still below that for the same month in 1932, although the disparity in the figures and the number of corporations was the smallest for any month this year.
ATHENS, Oct. 31. -- The second application of the United States Government for the extradition of Samuel Insull was, like the first, rejected by the Greek Supreme Court today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley decided today that Fred Schickler, Peekskill hospital employe, cannot be legally separated from his wife, Helen May Schickler, 21-year-old tuberculosis victim.

Buyers' Total Off Slightly. Registration of visiting buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday showed a slight drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Further evidence was given here today that the administration expected collaboration by the British Government in carrying out the President's program to buy gold in the world markets and thus seek control of the gold value of the dollar.

There was a slow, easy drift of prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with no indication of interest on the part of traders. The turnover was 1,128,000 shares, compared with 1,465,000 the day before. The combined averages fell about 1/4 point and the industrial averages less than 1/2 point.

Fordham's football team spent three hours on Fordham Field yesterday in one of its most thorough practice sessions of the season, as preparation continued for the battle with the powerful St. Mary's eleven of California on Saturday at the Polo Grounds.

Interest charges for both call and time loans in October were virtually the same as in September. Rates for call money have been unchanged since Aug. 30; for sixty and ninety-day loans, since Sept. 19, and for half-yearly loans, since Oct. 9, when a fractional reduction from the previous month's quotations was made.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United states last week was 2,358,150 barrels, compared with 2,434,500 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 76,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 48,750 barrels in Oklahoma and 30,000 barerls in Texas were the most important changes.

VIENNA, Oct. 31 -- Minor Nazi outrages were committed in Austria today. One was the hoisting, despite the daily vigilance of policemen and firemen, of a swastika banner on the flagstaff of the Vienna City Hall, citadel of Austrian socialism. Another was the overthrowing of several gravestones in a Jewish cemetery at Hohenau and the placing of swastikas on others.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- "Captive" mines of the H.C. Frick Coke Company will be reopened as soon as the miners are protected on their way to and from work, Thomas Moses, president of the company, stated today.

An issue of $5,000,000 State of New Jersey 4 1/4 per cent Emergency Relief bonds dated Nov. 1, 1933, and maturing on Nov. 1, 1934 to 1941, was awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers on a bid of 100.097. The bonds will be offered to the public today at prices to yield from 2.25 to 4.10 per cent.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- The Atlantis, ship of science, a floating laboratory for the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and the only vessel of its kind in the United States, came into port here this morning after completing its twenty-third cruise in the exploration of the mysteries of the sea.

BUENOS A1RES, Oct. 31 -- The Brazilian, Chilean and Peruvian Ambassadors conferred separately and at considerable length with Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas today at his invitation. As they represent the countries which, with Argentina, formed the ABC-Pan group for conciliation of the Chaco dispute the conferences caused widespread conjectures that they were concerned with Bolivia's refusal to recognize the League of Nations commission now en route to Montevideo.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Charging Samuel Seabury, leader of the Fusion forces with unfairness, Joseph V, McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, denied yesterday that he had acted with impropriety in voting for the application of the Hart Place Realty Corporation for a change in street grade while a member of the Board of Estimate after his law firm had prepared the firm's incorporation papers.

DENVER, Oct. 31 -- The Colorado Fuel Iron Company, a Rockefeller concern now in receivership, will recognize the United Mine Workers of American in the near future, abandoning the "Rockefeller working plan" which was put in effect at all C.F. I. mines after the serious labor troubles about twenty years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Steel rail orders of nearly 850,000 tons were foreseen today by Secretary Ickes as he contemplated a plan for direct loans to the rail carriers from the public works fund to finance the purchases.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Unless a catastrophe smites the world -- and there seems no reason at the moment why it should -- the coming Winter and Spring should see a large number of capital issues made in England for sound financial enterprises.
The bond market was lower in all departments yesterday, with transactions totaling $10,111,600, compared with $12,486,000 on Monday.

The Independent Theatre Owners Association named at a meeting in the Astor Hotel yesterday a committee to examine the current film product of the First Division and other independent exchanges as an element in their war on what they consider the excessive film rentals charged by the major companies.

Excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose in October to $850,000,000, by far the largest amount ever reached, while indebtedness of the member banks to the Reserve Banks fell to the smallest figure since 1917, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states in its monthly review.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- There is nothing to be alarmed about in the strikes now in progress, said Secretary Perkins today. She said the record showed that for the six months ending with September industrial disputes were fewer and less severe than in a comparable period following the 1921 depression.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- The zeal of the Nazi authorities to convict the Communists, of the Reichstag fire turned against them today.
NEW YORK. The Hon. and Mrs. Alastair Erskine of England are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The will of Mrs. Mary E. Wickham, widow of Delos O. Wickham, pioneer oil man and capitalist, which was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court, leaves $200,000 to Pikeville College at Pikeville, Ky., and $100,000 for the establishment of a home for incurables in Cleveland, Ohio.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Cash resources of Chicago's national banks were increased in October, but total deposits and outstanding credit contracted moderately, according to figures made public today in response to the call for their condition on Oct. 25 issued today by the Controller of the Currency.

When a literary fantasy like Christopher Morley's "Thunder On the Left" hobbles into the theatre, the stage looks like an ungainly medium. The stage of Maxine Elliott's had that hobbledehoy look last evening when Jean Ferguson Black's play appeared there.

The Kurt Jooss Ballet, which stepped forth from its modest home theatre in Essen a little more than a year ago into the limelight of world prominence by winning an international competition in Paris with its ballet, "The Green Table," made its American debut last night at the Forrest Theatre, and apparently added another country to its list of triumphs.

Indecision was shown, by the various markets yesterday and this reflected not only doubt as to how extensively the government expects to engage in the buying of gold abroad, but also as to how effective these operations will be.
It might seem a bit incongruous that rival football coaches who were brought up in the same system and teach the same general style of play should want to know anything about each other's teams.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the slowest for any month since last March. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 39,379,082 shares, compared with 43,319,334 in September and 29,187,659 shares in October a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Norman H. Davis will remain in this country only a short time on his forthcoming visit, Secretary Hull said today in response to a question. He confirmed previous indications that Mr. Davis would return to Geneva in time for the resumption of plenary sessions Dec. 4.

Mayor O'Brlen charged last night that a "whispering campaign" was being conducted against him. He declared that he would see to it that the perpetrators of the "outrageous fraud" would be prosecuted if they continued their activities.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 -- Only two of the seven favorites won as the Laurel meeting came to an end today with another program of races for charity. In the Chestertown Purse, the featured event, E.K. Bryson's Pharatime was the winner by a half length under a hustling ride from Dominick Bellizzi.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net loss for the quarter ended on Sept., 30, after all charges, was $2,717,014, the best showing for any quarter in more than two years. In the preceding quarter the net loss was $8,627,367 and in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, 1932, it was $20,871,709.

GEORGE OTIS SMITH, whose appointment as Chairman of the Federal Power Commission occasioned a spirited controversy between President HOOVER and the Senate -- the latter trying to remove him after it had confirmed his appointment -- yesterday retired at the request of the President.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 -- Winooka, the Australian race horse, will go to the post for the third time in the East when he faces the barrier in the Baltimore Handicap, six furlong opening-day feature at Pimlico tomorrow. The Australian sprinter, in his two Eastern appearances, has disappointed his followers, finishing fifth and third, respectively.
HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- A change in Cuba's Government was said in reliable and well-informed quarters tonight to be only a matter of hours, some believing there will be a showdown before dawn.

New York's second orchestra to open the new season was greeted by a crowded house at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The 130 young men and women of the National Orchestral Association reassembled with at least ten new members replacing those who had won professional place in orchestras afield since last year.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed yesterday to Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the United States District Court an indictment charging Eugene E. Merrell, former deputy prohibition administrator, and seven others with conspiracy to smuggle liquor into this country and with conspiracy to transport liquor.

Woman writers won all three of the O. Henry Memorial Prize Awards this year. The first prize of $500 has been awarded to Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings of Hawthorn, Fla., for "Gal Young Un," published in Harper's Magazine, June and July, 1932.

The City Campaign. Four Mayoralty candidates, F.H. LaGuardia, Joseph V. McKee, Charles Solomon and Robert Minor, speaking at Carnegie Hall, told how they would meet the city's financial problems. Mayor O'Brien was represented by Corporation Counsel Hilly.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Yale, in its drive to prepare for the Dartmouth invasion Saturday, sent the first and second varsity teams Through more than an hour's scrimmage today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 31 -- Halloween was celebrated with a dinner dance in the garden terrace of the Greenbrier, which was decorated in harvest fashion with Autumn boughs and the fruit and grain of the season, jack o' lanterns and appropriate favors.

Offerings of new State and municipal bonds, the only senior issues marketed, and of industrial stocks in October were smaller in amount than in September, aggregating $51,909,500, of which $49,807,000 was in bonds and $2,102,500 in stocks. This compared with $54,499,000 of offerings in September, when $52,995,000 was in bonds and $1,504,000 in stocks.

Replying to protests by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., against the movement to boycott German goods, Samuel Untermyer declared yasterday that the Board of Trade showed "a sad lack of consistency and of familiarity with the true state of affairs, particularly in regard to American investments in the Reich."

Seventy-five physicians voted to form a Physicians Mutual Cooperative Association at a meeting last night in the Sherman Square Hotel. Dr. Harold M. Hays, president of the boards of directors of the Park East and the Park West Hospitals, who had called the meeting and who presided, was elected chairman of a committee on organization.

Grand juries in Manhattan and the Bronx voted more indictments yesterday in the drive on fraudulent registration for the general elections next Tuesday. The investigation before the New York County grand jury is being conducted by twenty deputies of State Attorney General Bennett, while District Attorney Foley is presenting the evidence in the Bronx cases.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Henry Ford definitely made known today his intention to submit a report on the wage scales and hours of labor prevailing in his plants, in compliance with the NRA code for the automobile industry.

George H. Townsend, president of the American Power Boat Association, arrived in New York yesterday on the Ile de France of the French Line. He was very enthusiastic about the successful negotiations he had conducted abroad for the international motor-boat races in Florida next March.

Where three years ago four candidates, Enterprise, Weetamoe, Whirlwind and Yankee were built and raced in an elimination series for the honor of defending the America's Cup, only two syndicates definitely are being formed thus far for the 1934 match.

The election in New York City will determine whether the control of the liquor business is to be taken from the hands of racketeers, Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County, warned last night in an address before about 500 members of the University Alumni Fusion Committee at a dinner at the Hotel Astor.

The public will have an opportunity to see the art collection of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan for several days beginning on Nov. 18, according to announcement by the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., which will disperse the many notable objects at auction on the afternoons of Nov. 23, 24 and 25.

DES MOINES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Governors of five mid-Western States and representatives of four others tonight signed a report to President Roosevelt urging an NRA code for agriculture, minimum prices for basic farm products and inflation of the currency.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31 -- The urgent need for Federal legislation to enable defaulting States and municipalities to compose their differences with their bondholders, relieving the holders of some $1,500,000,000 of municipal bonds, was outlined today in the report of the municipal committee of the Investment Bankers Association at the convention of that body.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Confidence in the possibility of an early settlement of the strike of 30,000 silk workers in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Massachusetts was voiced tonight by Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board.

Non-recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States has produced "anomalous" situations and has restricted Russian-American trade, according to a report published yesterday by the committee on Russian-American relations of the American Foundation.

Charged with roller-skating with her little niece around the Central Park Casino a week ago last Sun- day, Mrs. Townsend Burt of 124 East Fortieth Street received a suspended sentence yesterday in West Side Court. She had pleaded guilty.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- While reports were received here from America to the effect that a "secret Anglo-American currency truce has been reached at Washington, including an agreement to stabilize the pound and dollar," they were definitely denied today in British Treasury circles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Beginning tomorrow, the Industrial Advisory Board of the NRA will inaugurate a system of rotating members. Four members who have temporarily stepped aside will be succeeded by four other industrial leaders.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31. -- "The simple fact that there has been a lack of diplomatic relations between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. has allowed every adventurer of the West and the East to rely upon American assistance in the event of aggression against the U.S. S.R," Karl Radek comments in the Molot, a newspaper published at Rostov-on-Don.

The Railway Express Agency, which is owned by the principal railroads, announced yesterday that it was preparing for substantially increased shipping in the belief that President Roosevelt's efforts to stimulate business recovery would be successful.

This year's American turkey supply is conservatively estimated at more than 20,000,000 birds, a production record which assures plenty of turkeys for Thanksgiving Day feasts, according to P.Q. Foy, market expert and food economist. Not only is the United States assured of the largest production ever, but it will have the best-developed table grade of turkeys, Mr. Foy said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Huge losses in the Richfield Oil Company of California, running $250,000 a month before receivership, have been checked by Receiver William C. McDuffie to the extent that in the past three months he has been able to show a net profit of $562,000, it was testified here today.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Finishing with a burst of speed in the stretch run, C.V. Whitney's 3-year-old Chicle-Eden colt Contraband proved best of a band of five overnighters in the Halloween Purse, fifth and feature event of today's racing card.

Moderate weakness was shown yesterday in all the principal commodity futures traded here except silver, which rallied strongly after a weak opening. All the markets proved to be thin, and trading was generally slack owing to widespread uncertainty over monetary and other conditions.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The Cabinet at Thursday's meeting will consider all the possible political implications there may be in the case of Noel Panter, English correspondent under arrest in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 30, unless specified:

C.B. Ames, chairman of the board of the Texas Corporation, announced yesterday the appointment of A.L. Humes, an attorney in New York, to act as chairman of a stockholders committee to investigate the charges made against the management by R.C. Holmes, a director and former president, who has been soliciting proxies for the calling of a special meeting in order to increase the number of directors to twenty-five.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not very cheerful news to the small home owner in Westchester County to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES a statement by the regional director of the Home Owners Loan Corporation at White Plains that the corporation had finally completed its first loan to a distressed home owner under the new Home Loan Act.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- A sharp attack on the policies of the Roosevelt administration is contained in a pamphlet entitled "Let's Look at the Record," issued by the Republican National Committee.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Official circles expect a decisive turn this week in negotiations of the British war debts mission at Washington.

The reduction in the price of rails brought about by President Roosevelt's intervention was followed promptly yesterday by the announcement of pending orders for an aggregate of upward of 200,000 tons. The price fixed by President Roosevelt was $36.375, which compared with a former price of $40 a ton.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Gait Bro., 131-year-old jewelry firm of which Mrs. Woodrow Wilson is sole owner, will start a "going out of business" sale tomorrow -- a depression liquidation.

The dollar declined further in foreign exchange yesterday, but continued substantially above the theoretical value indicated for it by the price at which the RFC offered to buy newly mined gold. The RFC set a price of $32.12, up 16 cents an ounce from Monday's figure, which indicated a value of 64.32 cents in gold for the dollar.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated within narrow limits in light trading yesterday, but there was an undertone of resistance and net changes at the end of the day ranged from a gain of 3 points to a loss of 4.

PRAGUE, Oct. 31 -- The transformation of the Little Entente within the next few years into a single economic unit was announced by Dr. Eduard Benes, the Foreign Minister, in a parliamentary speech today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The grain markets slipped today, and despite one strong upturn the finish was weak, with a nervous distrustful feeling permeating the pit. All grains closed within a fraction of the bottom, wheat showing net losses of 1 5/8 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel, corn 2 1/2 to 2 7/8 cents, oats 7/8 to 1 7/8 cents, rye 3 1/2 to 4 cents and barley 4 cents.

Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion campaign committee, declared in an address yesterday from Station WFAB that the voters had already determined to get rid of both Mayor O'Brien and Joseph V. McKee. He called Mr. McKee the representative of a "sinister group" of Tammany leaders.

Establishment of a $15,000,000 revolving fund to finance unemployment and home relief moved forward yesterday when the Board of Estimate approved it in Committee of the Whole and referred it to the board for action on Friday.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Washington's decision to set up machinery to buy gold in the foreign markets through the RFC is not expected by French observers to disturb the franc. It is admitted that if order is not brought into French finance, France may some day be compelled to abandon the gold standard.

Pig iron production, according to The Iron Age, declined 14 per cent in October, according to estimates obtained by The Iron Age on the last day of the month. The October daily rate was 43,320 tons, compared with a September average of 50,742 tons a day.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- The German Supreme Court, which is trying the Communists on charges of revolutionary terrorism in connection with the Reichstag fire, was asked today to obtain from the Nazi authorities safe conduct for German citizens who are needed as witnesses but who are guilty of differing politically with the Nazi regime.
Columbia had one of its longest and most thorough practice sessions of the year yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the encounter with Cornell at Ithaca on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Unemployment relief grants of $6,723,292 to seven States, including $3,664,903 to New York, were approved today by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration. The administration also agreed to allotments amounting to $472,000 to finance for one month the care of destitute transients in twenty-four States and the District of Columbia.

Statements of condition of national banks, which have been called for by the Controller of the Currency, are expected to show a moderate decline in deposits, compared with last June and a year ago, on the basis of the results shown by those banks which published reports for Sept. 30, before the Controller's call was issued.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Philadelphia formally received today a planetarium, the second "indoor universe" in the country, presented with the hope that many residents would "begin to know as much about stars as they do of traffic lights."

Net income of $1,575,007 was reported yesterday by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the third quarter of 1933, after taxes, charges, depreciation and underlying dividends, equal to 18 cents a share earned on 8,738,007 common shares.
The dollar cheapened further in foreign exchange yesterday, approaching more nearly to the gold value put upon it by the RFC than at any time since the government's new monetary policy was adopted.

Recognizing their right to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing, but declining to commit itself definitely to the establishment of minimum wage scales, the Ford Motor Company yesterday replied to the demands of 1,500 strikers at the Edgewater assembly plant, according to The Associated Press.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Al Simmons, the $100,000 baseball star of the White Sox, doesn't like the $2,000,000 Comiskey Park set-up so owner J. Louis Comiskey is going to change it.

The fifteen-round light-heavy-weight title fight between Champion Maxie Rosenbloom and Mickey Walker in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night will be one of several attractions in which ring champions will appear at the Eighth Avenue arena, according to James J. Johnston, the Garden's boxing director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Protocol experts of the State Department have decided that Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, should receive all diplomatic honors accorded to visiting foreigner of Ministerial rank. Secretary Hull said today.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- It was semi-officially announced today that Noel Panter, correspondent of The Daily Telegraph of London, arrested in Munich last week on a charge of "espionage and treason," would not be brought to trial, but would be presently released.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The twin subjects of peace and disarmament, having come to a standstill at Geneva, will now do temporary service as an issue in British domestic politics. A full-dress debate on the matter is on the calendar of the House of Commons for the opening of Parliament next Tuesday.

Arnold Schonberg, one of the world's foremost composers and teachers, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Ansonia that he had high hopes of encountering fine musical talents in this country. He looked forward not only to the opportunity to guide some of America's young composers to a fuller expression of themselves but to the learning of new and enriching things from the contact with them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 30:
Arrangements were made yesterday to have the New York Giants-Boston Redskins football game at the Polo Grounds on Nov. 12 serve as a memorial to the late Major Frank Cavanaugh.

A temporary injunction restraining the New York Edison Company and its so-called company union, the Association of Employes of the New York Edison Company, from interfering with attempts by the Brotherhood of Edison Employes to organize the company's 33,000 workers, was vacated yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 -- The will of Mrs. Sidney Gurnee Dyer of Baltimore, who died Friday at her Newport home, was probated here today in Orphans Court and leaves the bulk of her more than $1,000,000 estate to her granddaughter, Lauretta Patterson Robeson.

A request that the city seek $25,775,000 in Federal funds, in addition to the amount already asked, to complete the Wards Island sewage treatment works and the system of Manhattan and Bronx intercepting sewers connecting with it, was made to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Ernest P. Goodrich, Acting Sanitation Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Ten registration statements for issuance of securities totaling more than $11,500,000, as filed under the Securities Act, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.
