They included four from New York and covered financing of such businesses as beer and wine, investment trust, personal loans, foreign bond investments, motor cars and amusements.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway allowed judgment for the plaintiff here today in the action brought by Mrs. Leda Van Der Vorst of Hempstead against Jacob Ruppert, brewer and baseball team owner.

August Heckscher, philanthropist, entered the theatrical field yesterday with the announcement that the Heckscher Theatre at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street is to be turned into a tryout house, the proceeds to go to the support of the Heckscher Foundation.

The City Campaign. Joseph V. McKee declared that, if elected Mayor, he would be independent not only of Edward J. Flynn but of James A. Farley. Mrs. Ruth B. Pratt, Republican, endorsed him as he began his final campaign tour of the city.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 1 -- The Australian thoroughbred Winooka, owned by MacDonald and Matthews, won his first race in three starts in the East when he captured the Baltimore Handicap in a driving finish before 10,000 persons today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a steady reader of Mr. "White's South American articles, which are most interesting and accurate. Not only I, but the Brazilian and other South American colonies enjoy his "comunicados."
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The Labor party scored considerable success in today's municipal elections, judging from preliminary returns, but nothing in the nature of a political landslide.

The executive committee of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York acted yesterday to keep freight rates free from interference by codes adopted by the shipping industry as a whole or by any branch of the industry.

Announcement of the formation of an advisory committee of the National Industrial Council of the National Association of Manufacturers, consisting of officers of twenty-six of the leading national trade associations, was made here yesterday by the association.

Presentation of a four-point program for city charter reform by Charles Solomon, candidate for Mayor, and the charge by Julius Gerber, campaign manager, that F. H. LaGuardia was attempting to create a false impression of support by needle trades unions, marked the Socialist municipal campaign yesterday.

MALTA, Nov. 1 -- Political tension over the British Government's attitude toward the Italianized educational policy followed by Sir Ugo Mifsud's Nationalist Ministry since it took office in June, 1932, is still acute. The people are anxiously awaiting a statement by the Premier or the British Governor General, Sir David Campbell, concerning what happened at yesterday's meeting of the Executive Council, sumoned by the Governor, and at the extraordinary Cabinet meeting that followed.

Amends were made yesterday by a spokesman for the Fusion campaign committee to representatives of the National Broadcasting Company, who on Tuesday evening had received some harsh words from F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, at the N.B.C studio, 711 Fifth Avenue.

Isidor J. Kresel denied on the witness stand yesterday in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court any part in the arrangements which resulted in the defunct Bank of United States, on Jan. 13, 1930, lending $8,000,000 to three of its safe deposit company affiliates.
Leasehold deals played a major part in real estate transactions announced in Manhattan yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A summons was granted today for the appearance in Bow Street Police Court on Nov. 10 for the Duke of Atholl on a charge of violation of the Lotteries Act. The summons created a sensation in England.

If Mayor O'BRIEN was ever charged with want of energy, his present resistless activity may be his plea in mitigation. It seems as if a forty-eight-hour day would hardly suffice to fill his program. From morning till far into the night he circulates, giving the glad word and hand.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 1 -- Industry of the nation might as well resign itself to further Federal regulation after the present emergency is over, but must prepare to insist on certain rights of action, the Investment Bankers Association was told here today by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- The Boerse continued its waiting attitude today. Trade in stocks was very dull, and although quotations continued to sag, the changes were generally slight. Heavy industrials were mixed; electric shares lost up to 2 per cent, textiles gained up to 2 per cent and the rest of the list was steady.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Albert H. Wiggin, members of his family and their personal corporations paid $4,624,905,28 in taxes for the five years 1928 to 1932, despite the market crash, he revealed today to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Five of the nation's leading industrialists were selected today to serve four months on the Industrial Advisory Board, replacing five others who are retiring under the "rotation plan" announced yesterday.

After an hour's dummy scrimmage against the Theodore Roosevelt High School team at Lewisohn Stadium, the City College varsity football team engaged in a two-hour secret drill yesterday in the college gymnasium.
A new attempt to celebrate German Day, which was prohibited last week by Mayor O'Brien, was announced yesterday by the Steuben Society of America.

The registration in the regular day public schools in the city is now 1,128,697. The enrolment shows an increase of 12,224 over that of a year ago and an increase of 36,360 over the figure for last June 30.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reports for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $4,536,631 after charges, taxes and depletion and depreciation reserves, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 30 cents a share on the 13,070,625 shares of common stock.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Oct. 1 shows the following principal changes in September. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:

The greatest jumping show in history is anticipated next week during the Golden Jubilee of the National Horse Show Association, which opens Wednesday at Madison Square Garden. Officers of four of the international military teams arrived yesterday from Chicago and the fifth, from Canada, is expected tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Secretary Hull was unanimously re-elected today chairman of the governing board of the Pan American Union. The Secretary of State of the United States has always held this post.

There is no doubt but that the preponderance of opinion among economists is adverse to the managed currency idea, says the National City Bank in its current monthly bulletin, in discussing the monetary policy announced by President Roosevelt on Oct. 22.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 1 -- A plea to voters to support two referenda provided by the Legislature for the transfer of a $7,000,000 bond issue to school relief was made by speakers here today at the opening session of the thirty-third annual convention of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Declaring that the city administration under the guise of economy steadily had been breaking down the school system, Nathan Straus Jr., Recovery party candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, presented a twelve-point program for the rehabilitation of the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Purchase and sale of about 750,000 bushels of wheat for export have been concluded by the North Pacific Emergency Export Association, formed under a marketing agreement to stimulate exports of surplus wheat from Oregon, Washington and Idaho.

Walter Kleinert, 35 years old, an insurance claim adjuster, was found dead in his apartment on the fifth floor of 27 Jones Street yesterday morning. He had been strangled. Detectives had failed, up to last night, to establish a motive for the crime.
Two hundred student delegates representing every branch of Columbia University went on record last night against any cooperation with the United States War Department in the event of war.

Silver futures resumed their brisk advance on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., yesterday, after a mixed opening, while the remainder of the commodities traded here moved around in quiet trading, with mixed results and uncertain undertone.

Under the auspices of the Society of Kentucky Women of New York a bridge party to further the charitable enterprises of that organization will take place this afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. In conjunction with the party there will be a sale of useful articles made in Kentucky.
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, began last night his series of final borough meetings, his main speech being at Hunts Point Palace in his home borough, the Bronx.

NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. William Smith Gregory and Mr. and Mrs. R. Randolph Hicks will give a tea dance Dec. 23 at the Pierre to introduce to society Dr. and Mrs. Gregory's daughter, Miss Margaret Ungrich Gregory, and Mr. and Mrs. Hicks's niece, Miss Jane Hall.

Three little pigs went to Flatbush Court yesterday and did a little squealing for Magistrate John J. Walsh. By showing cuts and bruises on their noses and tails, they were able to substantiate a charge of cruelty to animals against Martin Block, assistant manager of the Flatbush Theatre at 2,207 Church Avenue, by Ray Mulligan, special agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published this morning a letter from William C. Chanler, who expressed the view that the Fusion forces cannot reform Tammany; that Mr. McKee will not attempt to do so, but "intends to destroy that entire organization root and branch so that it can never be put together again."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The annual Princeton Fall handicap track meet in the Palmer Stadium today was featured by Warren Rainear's performance in the 600-yard run. Rainaer, a veteran member of the varsity squad, showed the way home in the fast time of 1:15.5.

The duck hunting season opened on Long Island yesterday, but it was not quite as auspicious as that of several years past, due chiefly to the warm weather which prevailed in all sectors where ducks had gathered. The army of sportsmen which invaded Great South Bay was doomed to disappointment, for the bay was as flat and calm as a mill pond and few birds moved all afternoon after the official opening at noon.

The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 496,450 shares of new $5 par stock of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company, issued in accordance with the company's plan of recapitalization.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Tommy Curtin, Kim Whitehead and Webb Davis, reserves all season, were assigned to places in the Yale first-team line-up today as Yale scrimmaged in preparation for Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- United States exports in September, valued at $160,089,996, were larger to all the so-called grand divisions except Oceania, and exceeded those of the preceding month to thirty-two of the forty principal foreign markets, according to detailed foreign trade figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A decision in the strike of employes of the Art Metal Construction Company of Jamestown, N.Y., was The decision is that the dispute be adjusted upon the following terms:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Jack Tidball of the University of California at Los Angeles, intercollegiate champion, has been assigned the honor position in the 1933 rankings by the intercollegiate tennis committee, it was announced today.

Arthur J. Morris, President of the Morris Plan Company of New York, in an address before the Bronx Board of Trade yesterday in the Concourse Plaza Hotel advocated the formation, under government sponsorship, of what he suggested should be called the First Industrial National Bank of the United States, with a capital of $1,000,000,000.

Professor von Zahn, president of the International Statistical Congress, will sail for Bremen today on the North German Lloyd liner General von Steuben after attending the session of the organization held recently in Mexico City. He will be accompanied by Mrs. von Zahn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Speaker Rainey denied today that there was any formidable economic unrest in the West and denounced as "ghouls" the Republican National Committee and Senator Dickinson of Iowa, who are now attacking the administration's policies.

The hilarious pastime of "scavenger-hunting," lately become a favored diversion of cosmopolitan society in Europe, had its New York premiere on a vast scale last night when several hundred members of society and the artistic world -- young and old alike -- surged forth in couples from the Waldorf-Astoria on a chase that led them through the highways and byways of Manhattan Island and into a mirth-provoking labyrinth of preordained difficulties.

Al Rosen, who filed suit in Los Angeles last week for $1,022,000 against the Association of Motion Picture Producers and Distributers, announced here yesterday that he would proceed with his film on the Hitler regime in spite of the opposition of the Hays organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

When Dartmouth enters the Yale Bowl on Saturday it will be in pursuit of the one thing denied so far to Hanover elevens -- a victory over Yale. Great Dartmouth teams, indifferent ones and poor ones all have met with the same fate.

THE cynics should have been there. It was a gathering of football folk at the New York Athletic Club yesterday to make definite plans for the Cavanaugh memorial game at the Polo Grounds a week from this coming Sunday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Liquidation was on again today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, wheat breaking as much as 4 3/8 cents a bushel and corn 3 1/8 from yesterday's finish. Local and Eastern interests went out of long lines on the way down.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- Slogans to be used this month in the sixteenth anniversary celebrations of the Bolshevist revolution, and the "line" to be followed in the coming year, were published in the newspapers here today.
Dwelling deals comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 1 -- A project for reconditioning the United States Fleet, running into many millions of dollars, has been submitted to the Public Works Administration, it was announced today by Admiral Standley, chief of naval operations.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 1 -- The Official Gazette, which ordinarily is published in the three official lan- guages -- English, Hebrew and Arabic -- giving the latest government ordinances, will now be published daily in Arabic, reporting news happenings in Palestine.

Temperature Rise Slows Trade. The rise in temperature has again exerted a hampering influence on retain turnover of heavier apparel, reports on trade thus far this week indicated yesterday. The general gains noted last week in the sale of women's coats are missing and the woolen dress call is running below expectations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The address of Gerard Swope, chairman, in opening the meeting of the Business Advisory and Planning Council, was as follows:

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Principles congenial to controlled economics but new to international trade are being worked out by the Indo-Japanese textile conference in Delhi, but their application leaves so much room for dispute that the conference's success is still doubtful.

Money market continued easy. Demand for funds was light and with the street rate going to 1/2 from 5/8, which had prevailed earlier. The official rate remained at 3/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were quiet.

Stags and NRA. Society in the Federal capital refuses to follow the lead of New York in seeking to bring back the dance program as a substitute for the stag line. One Washington authority insists that debutantes love the stag line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Representatives of dairymen of five States which ship milk to the Greater New York market will meet in New York City tomorrow, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration said today, to study a proposed production and price control code.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's arrived in New York last night from Oakland, Calif., bent upon avenging the 14-0 defeat which Fordham administered to them a year ago. The two powerful elevens clash in an intersectional battle at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Representatives of many old Staten Island families played a leading part in the celebration of the 250th anniversary of the organization of the County of Richmond held yesterday at the old court house at Richmond. The exercises were directed by Cornelius Kolff and were attended by more than 800 persons.

Endorsement of the O'Brien-Prial-Solomon ticket by the Allied Civil Service Conference, which asserts it has behind it a block of 600,000 potential votes, was announced yesterday by James F. Chambers, secretary of the conference, who also is secretary of the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

Plans of four two-story dwellings to be built at 533-39 West 217th Street, a block south of Columbia University's Baker Field on the Harlem River, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings. The total cost is estimated at $26,000 by Benjamin F.V. Driesler, the architect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Presi- dent Roosevelt, at a long conference today with Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, and Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, head of the British war debt mission, averted an immediate break in the negotiations which have been carried on here during the past month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- All things considered, the attitude of the NRA toward the permanent code for American newspapers is one of the mysteries of 1933. Up to this hour that attitude has been a stubborn unwillingness to permit the insertion in the licensing code of a sentence reiterating the freedom of the press as guaranteed by the Constitution.

Joseph V. McKee issued a statement last night reviewing the record of his seven years as President of the Board of Aldermen and asserting that he had consistently opposed waste and extravagance by Tammany officials.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 1 -- Jockey Jack Westrope pressed closer to his goal of 300 winning mounts this year by scoring in three races at Arlington Downs today. The triple increased his total number of victories for 1933 to 255.

Each successive move in Washington's tinkering with the dollar seems to add a touch of the extraordinary. The Government enters the market to purchase newly mined domestic gold. At once is disclosed a purpose to raise the bid each day. No gold appears to have been tendered.

Stock prices in October, after a short-lived rally early in the month, resumed their downward trend and reached new low levels in their second consecutive month of decline, being approximately where they were in the first week in May. Selling was not aggressive, however, trading being the smallest in six months.
After quiet trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply in the last hour yesterday and ended unchanged to 4 points higher than on Tuesday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is the author of "It's Up to the Women," published today by Frederick A. Stokes. The book contains general answers to some of the thousands of questions that women have written to Mrs. Roosevelt. Among the subjects discussed are budgets, family health, recreation, "when your children marry," women and jobs, grandmothers, women and the vote, women and peace, women in business training and women and the NRA.

Bronx housing properties taken over by savings banks as the result of defaults in mortgage and tax payments are rapidly finding their way into investment channels. Two such holdings were bought by investors yesterday.

With almost every one of the 1,553 automobile dealers in New York City reported to have pledged to operate under the code of fair campetition for the motor vehicle retailing trade, the sale of cars, beginning today, will be governed by NRA rules.

Adolph Zukor, head of Paramount Productions and one of the best known figures in the moving picture world, appeared as a witness yesterday at an examination before Referee Theodore Stitt in Brooklyn into the affairs of the bankrupt Allied Owners, Inc. Mr. Zukor appeared in court in the Federal Building in answer to a summons issued by Archibald Palmer, attorney for a group of creditors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Verne C. Miller, who is alleged to have operated the machine-gun with which five men were slain in the Union Station at Kansas City on June 17, shot his way out of a trap closely drawn about him tonight by Federal agents.

The extraordinary grand jury investigation ordered by Governor Lehman into the Brooklyn laundry racket was started in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Pierce H. Russell of Troy, who was designated by the Governor to preside over the extraordinary term of the Supreme Court, convened court after the special jury of twenty-three had been selected from a panel of forty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Unofficial forces were set in motion today to supplant the administrative functions with an industrial self-government to be administered through a National Chamber of Commerce and Industry, built around the organization of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

A "concerted move to bring 'floaters' into the Gowanus section" of Brooklyn admittedly overtaxed the prosecuting agencies investigating registration frauds in that borough yesterday. The New York County authorities were pressing their in- quiries, meanwhile, to complete pre-election phases today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 -- After engaging in a long scrimmage, in which blocking and tackling again were stressed, Tulane's Green Wave, thiry strong, entrained tonight for New York and the inter- sectional clash with Colgate. More than 100 fans accompanied the team.

The very first hours of a child's life are it is likely, of great importance in their results not only on its later habits of learning but on its general disposition, according to Dr. James J. Ganders, who addressed one of the sessions of the twelfth annual convention of the Eastern Homeopathic Medical Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- For the first time since the Nazi revolution a united Jewish effort was launched tonight for the relief and reconstruction of German Jewry.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Oct. 10 (AP) (by Mail) -- While Japan is endeavoring to purchase the 1,100-mile Chinese Eastern Railway from Soviet Russia on behalf of the Manchukuo Government, the Japanese authorities are building thousands of miles of new railroad in Manchuria at a cost of millions of dollars.

Paintings, drawings and designs from the Serge Lifar collection, illustrating "Twenty-five Years of the Russian Ballet," constitute an exhibition that opens to the public today at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue. It will be on until Nov. 18, and is being held for the benefit of the Architect's Emergency Committee.

ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Decision was reserved today by the Court of Appeals in a case to test the validity of the Fusion party nominating Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican, for re-election and Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for Alderman in the Tenth Assembly and Aldermanic Districts of New York City.

The President's Re-employment Agreement under the National Recovery Act was upheld in a New York court yesterday as a contract binding upon an employer. It marked the first instance in this area and the second in the United States in which a court took such action.

Abraham Kaplan, Tammany's campaign manager, made public yesterday figures which he said were the final tabulation of the Literary Digest poll on the Mayoralty election. He denounced them at the same time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission repealed today its rule of July 27 regarding exemptions from registration under the Securities Act of certain classes of real estate mortgages and substituted a new rule as follows:
GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Norman H. Davis, the United States Ambassador at Large, left tonight for Paris on his way home. He will sail Saturday on the liner President Roosevelt.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- With only one more day of real work before he sends his Red Raiders out to face Tulane on Saturday, Coach Andy Kerr of Colgate staged an extended scrimmage today. The undefeated freshman eleven opposed the varsity, which stressed the plays which will be used against the Green Wave in the Yankee Stadium.

An incendiary fire was discovered yesterday in the Recovery party headquarters of the Eleventh Assembly District at 263 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn. Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy reported that three separate blazes had been started in the place, over which three families were sleeping.

Mayor O'Brien avoided the necessity of calling a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen before election to abolish the 50 per cent water rate increase yesterday by out-manoeuvring the fifteen Aldermen sponsoring that move.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- The great Ullstein Verlag -- the house of Ullstein -- the largest publishing concern in Germany and one of the largest, richest and most enterprising in all the world, if not superlatively all these, threw up the sponge today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three Middle Western Governors arrived here late today to ask for inflation and immediate price-fixing for farm products in a bold program aimed at bringing quick relief to farmers.

The possibility of a shortage of fine wines following repeal, and the need of education of the American public on the subject of "nature's most magnificent works of art" -- fine wines -- were discussed yesterday by F.C. Lloyd, retiring president of the Wine Trades Club of Great Britain.

Default in interest on sixteen foreign bond issues was announced yesterday, of which fourteen were of German bonds and two of Uruguayan obligations. The New York Stock Exchange ruled that seven German and the two Uruguayan bonds shall be dealt in flat, while the New York Curb Exchange ruling affected the seven other German bonds.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 1 -- Noel Panter was accused of misrepresenting a recent Nazi gathering at which Chancellor Hitler spoke.

An altar and reredos in All Souls Chapel of All Souls' Bay of the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine were consecrated yesterday morning by Bishop William T. Manning. It was a feature of the celebration of All Saints' Day. The altar and reredos are the gifts of F. Saxham E. Drury in memory of his wife, Mabel Gerry, daughter of the late Elbridge T. Gerry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A voluminous document compiled by all government departments and agencies concerned with the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was before President Roosevelt today for his study.

The discovery of an old Turkish map, believed by geographers to have been copied directly from the lost original which was Columbus's guide on the voyage which ended in the discovery of America, is announced in the new issue of The Geographical Review, official organ of the American Geographical Society.
HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- Four policemen, a soldier and a civilian were gravely injured this afternoon when a bomb exploded at the central police station. One of the policemen died later.

An attempt to enlist the support of school officials throughout the city for the emergency defense fund of the American Jewish Congress failed last night when, after speeches by associate superintendents warning against retaliatory methods in the fight against Hitlerism, the scheduled apppeal for funds was not made.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 1 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Cantonese Headquarters announce two victories over Communists in Kiangsi province and report that between 7,000 and 9,000 Communists were slain in battles that resulted in advances by the Nanking armies along the Kiangsi-Fukien borders and by the Cantonese along the southerly lines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Reconstruction finance Corporation today set in motion its machinery to begin buying foreign gold tomorrow.

TORONTO, Nov. 1 -- Thousands of lives will be saved and mining costs will be greatly reduced by the development of a means of preventing silicosis credited to Dr. F.G. Banting, the discoverer of insulin, according to a cablegram today to The Toronto Evening Telegram from its correspondent, W.T. Cranfield, in London.

The attempt of James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, to attribute an anti-Semitic attitude to F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, brought Samuel Untermyer to the latter's defense yesterday. Earlier in the campaign Mr. Untermyer had attacked Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party Mayoralty candidate, whom Mr. Gerard is supporting, for anti-Semitism.

With the Fusion campaign approaching its climax -- the Madison Square Garden rally scheduled for this evening -- F.H. LaGuardia and his running-mates carried their campaign into the Borough of Queens last night for the third time.

Dr. William Hallock Park, director of the Bureau of Public Laboratories of the New York City Health Department, will celebrate his seventieth birthday on Dec. 30 next. Under the requirements of the city's pension fund system, he is subject to retirement on that date.

The adjudication of differences regarding conditions of labor in the theatre was passed on to the National Recovery Administration in Washington through a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday at the weekly meeting here of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Three Paris newspapers today renew the accusation that America is seeking to drive France off the gold standard, while a number of others reproduce private news services from Washington headed "France must abandon gold."

Whether or not it is in the public interest for reports of investigations by the Commissioner of Accounts to be thrown open for inspection was argued before Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn yesterday. Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, is suing to compel Mayor O'Brien and Commissioner James A. Higgins to permit him to see "suppressed reports" of inquiries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Definite and partially official movements looking to fundamental changes in the methods of reaching the goals originally set for the NRA took form here today as administration leaders frankly faced their growing task.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and its subsidiaries sustained a net operating loss of $3,356,552 in the eight months ended last Aug. 31, according to the second report of the Irving Trust Company as equity receiver, filed yesterday in Federal Court.

Representatives of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the Newspaper Editorial Association, and the Newspaper Guilds agreed yesterday upon a procedure for determining classified wage minimums for editorial workers throughout the United States.

Mayor O'Brien was touched by sorrow last night when he visited 10-year-old Reba Garson in the Harbor Hospital in Brooklyn, where she is suffering from a bullet wound in the stomach inflicted during a Democratic rally in Brooklyn last Tuesday night.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior in the Democratic administration, today had the honor of having a Republican officeholder dedicate a book to him. The author is none other than his wife, Anna Wilmarth Ickes, Republican member of the Illinois Legislature.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and its subsidiaries sustained a net operating loss of $3,356,552 in the eight months ended last Aug. 31, according to the second report of the Irving Trust Company as equity receiver, filed yesterday in Federal Court.

Representatives of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the Newspaper Editorial Association, and the Newspaper Guilds agreed yesterday upon a procedure for determining classified wage minimums for editorial workers throughout the United States.

Although the government's buying price for domestic gold was advanced again yesterday and the dollar had a further setback in the international market, stocks and commodities moved at times in opposite directions and apparently with little consideration for the inflationary possibilities involved.
Another season in women's squash racquets was officially inaugurated yesterday with the playing of the first interclub series.

With the market for United States Government bonds steadied after several days of weakness, foreign bonds resumed their advance yesterday while domestic issues declined anew, but generally to a lesser extent than in the earlier days of this week.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1 -- One and a half million gallons of gasoline exploded at the New England Terminal Company's North Tiverton plant this afternoon, follow- ing a blast at 9 A.M. that killed three men, injured a half dozen others and started a conflagration that defied scores of firemen.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Samuel Untermyer, New York attorney, in a speech here today, charged that Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, was "masquerading as the German Ambassador" and was "one of the most destructive of propagandists."
Formation of Foreign Bond Associates, Inc., organized to trade in and invest in foreign bonds, was announced yesterday by Distributors Group, Inc., the company's fiscal agent.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Covedale Purse, an allowance affair for 2-year-olds, and the Walnut Hills Purse, designed for horses of all ages, co-featured today's card. Both events were at six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Some of the Chase National Bank stock sold short by a personal company of Mr. Wiggin, then its head, for a $4,000,000 profit was traced into a market pool participated in by a bank affiliate.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP). -- Assemblyman Richard L. Saunders charged in a statement today that he had been ruled off the air by the management of Station WHAM because of criticism of Postmaster General James A. Farley in a speech prepared for delivery last night in answer to an address Monday night by the Democratic leader.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The sterling group of countries is leading the world in recovery at the present time, according to an authoritative survey of economic conditions in the current Midland Bank Review.

Holders of Dutch East Indies twenty-five-year external 6 per cent bonds due on Jan. 1, 1947, have been notified by the Guaranty Trust Company that $2,480,000 of the issue has been drawn for redemption on Jan, 1 next, in terms of the gold dollar.
Supporters of Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, expressed satisfaction yesterday at the progress of his campaign in the last few days and made definite predictions of his election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Nine registration statements for the issue of securities totaling more than $3,000,000 filed under the Securities Act, were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission. They included one from New York and covered mining, research, investment trusts and other businesses.

Mrs. Therese Schiff, widow of Jacob H. Schiff, philanthropist and financier, left an estate appraised yesterday at $5,524,278 gross and $4,689,587 net, of which $4,533,119 was in securities. Mrs. Schiff died on Feb. 26 at her home, 965 Fifth Avenue, where she lived alone after the death of her husband in 1920.

Sharp declines in United States Government bonds, ranging from 2-32 to 11-32 point, contrasted yesterday with generally higher prices for domestic corporation issues and leading foreign loans on the Stock Exchange. The dealings in bonds reached $11,275,000, of which trading in government issues accounted for $3,025,000.

A card party and sale of articles made in Kentucky was held yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the relief work of the Society of Kentucky Women of New York. The proceeds will help to provide for the education of the children of Kentucky mountaineers and the relief of their needy families.

The First National Bank of the City of New York announced a proposal to liquidate and dissolve the First Security Company, its securities affiliate, in a letter to stockholders of the bank late on Tuesday.

Mayor O'Brien carried his campaign, into the Bronx last night, addressing a rally at the Hunt's Point Palace. While the Mayor has spoken previously in the Bronx his appearance last night at the Hunt's Point meeting and at other places in that borough marked the culmination of Tammany's effort to carry that borough, the strong-hold of Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate.

The captain and ten members of the crew of the seagoing tug Salutation were rescued in the East River near the foot of Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday after the craft had been in a collision with Delivery Boat 5 of the Standard Oil Company of New York.
GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- The United States warned and protected with unusual vigor here today against the opium "menace" to it and to the world created by Manchukuo.

A final polishing of its offense and defense completed the intensive preparations of the Manhattan College eleven for its traditional contest with City College at Ebbets Field tomorrow. Speed and aggressiveness were emphasized, in a two-hour drill on Manhattan Field yesterday.

Not since old man BRUTUS has there been a public character more nobly Roman than Mr. McKEE. He walks the chalk-line of duty. The sweet ties of old association, friendship, tutelage are nothing to him. There will be no room in the City Hall "for ED FLYNN "and JOE McKEE, and he will exert no "influence over me when I become "Mayor of the city."

The largest and what was considered by many, the most colorful annual exhibit of the Horticultural Society of New York opened last night at the American Museum of Natural History. Three flowers never before shown publicly in the United States were in prize winning groups judged during the afternoon by fifty or more experts.

A first Book-length attack on the Roosevelt administration policies is published today. The book is called "America Swings to the Left," and the author is Alva Lee, former army Colonel, described by his publishers as a "publicist," who lives in Salt Lake City.

Returning from Washington last night to speak with other candidates of the Recovery party over WEVD, Ferdinand Pecora, candidate for District Attorney, denounced the conduct of that office under Thomas C.T. Crain, although he did not name Mr. Grain.
Several changes in memberships on the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Senators heard testimony today that a syndicate dealing in common stock of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation had made net profits of $11,702,056.68, and two participants, Harry F. Sinclair, oil operator, and Arthur W. Cutten, Chicago market operator, were quickly subpoenaed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Liquidation by holders of grain futures on the Board of Trade apparently ran its course yesterday, as the markets advanced readily today, with relatively little pressure. A leading local professional was credited with buying wheat.

UPPERVILLE, Va., Nov. 2. -- Four difficult tests, including the Llangollen National Steeplechase, comprise the program for the third annual hunts meeting, to be held Saturday on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney.

A further reduction in the rate of purchases of government securities to $20,000,000 a week was shown in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. The system, having bought government securities at the rate of $35,000,000 a week for eight weeks, began to reduce the intensity of its open-market operations three weeks ago under cover of a reduction in the rediscount rate from 2 1/2 to 2 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- About 250 delegates attended the annual Fall meeting of the Central Jersey Scholastic Press Association this afternoon at Princeton High School. Wilbur Forrest, executive secretary of The New York Herald Tribune, spoke on "The Tie-Up of Secondary School Journalism With a Life Profession."
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 2. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Russian diplomat, was recommended today for the Nobel Prize for doing most to promote peace.

The first organized attack on President Roosevelt's new monetary policies, particularly the recent gold purchases, will be made this morning at a special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The call for the session was voted at the regular meeting yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Yale's final scrimmage before the Dartmouth game was held today behind closed gates on Anthony Thompson Field. Instead of proving to be a let-down from yesterday's hard session, the workout practically duplicated it.

The final returns in The Literary Digest's city-wide poll, made public yesterday, show F.H. LaGuardia leading in all five boroughs with 47.98 per cent of 545,024. On the repoll of the 100,000 voters who were polled before Joseph V. McKee entered the Mayoralty race, Mr. LaGuardia's percentage was 7.06 better than in the main poll.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The polo field of the Westchester Country Club, with a strange dress of football goal posts stuck in the middle, today felt the cleat marks of one of the biggest football teams of the country as St. Mary's of California worked out both morning and afternoon for the Fordham game Saturday.

SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 2 (AP). -- The question "Who took the names of Huey P. Long and O.K. Allen off the Red River Bridge?" today took its place beside the mystery of "Who hit the Senator on Long Island?"

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 2. -- The undefeated Chase Me, owned by Mrs. John Bosley Jr., and bred by Mr. Bosley and Rigan McKinney, made it four in a row today when he captured the main event on the Pimlico program, the Carroll Purse. Coming from far back, he closed with a whirlwind charge to win by a length.

The interior of the clubhouse of the South Brooklyn Democratic Club, which is supporting the Fusion ticket, was wrecked early yesterday morning by unidentified vandals. Arthur C. Agoglia, executive member, estimated the damage at $5,000.
Madison Square Garden became last night for Fusionists a veritable Rome to which all roads led.

Plans of the United German Societies to celebrate a postponed "German Day" in December are obviously intended to meet some of the Mayor's objections to the meeting that he forbade. Instead of gathering in an armory, they will make use of Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Although Noel Panter has been released, the British Foreign Office has not yet decided to let the matter drop as a closed incident.

Addressing the real-estate owners of the city over the radio from Station WJZ last night, Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., urged them to find out the attitude of each candidate for whom they were asked to vote.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Winter schedules in four sports, announced today at Yale, include a series of annual events only slightly curtailed from last season.

Loans on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange fell $120,413,498 in October to $776,182,033, the lowest level since the end of May. It was the second decline in a month since last March, loans having dropped $20,619,743 in September.

Following is the text of Samuel Seabury's address at Madison Square Garden last night: This campaign presents to the people of New York City the greatest opportunity that has been presented to them in many decades. This city has been ground beneath the heel of brutal political bosses for all too long a time.

To the accompaniment of reports that government purchases of gold abroad had begun and that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was buying sterling here preparatory to further gold buying abroad, the dollar cheapened rapidly in foreign exchange yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a rule our citizens leave politics to politicians. What naturally results is that government gets worse and worse. When it becomes too rotten the citizens awake. This is the year of awakening!
Two district associations of the A.A.U. have opened fire on the metric system, adopted a year ago by the amateur sports governing body, and propose a return to the yardage system of measurement.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The end of control by the Ullstein family over the great publishing house it founded and built into an outstanding monument of German enterprise and organization took place today as scheduled and on the lines set forth yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The United States will take to the forthcoming Pan American Conference at Montevideo President Roosevelt's "good neighbor" declaration, contained in his inaugural address, as its underlying policy, Secretary Hull told representatives of the twenty republics of the Western Hemisphere yesterday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Chief Two-Moon Meridas, originally Chico Colon Meridas, the colorful little brown man in the big, white sombrero, who made and spent a fortune as a healer and manufacturer of patent medicines, died in his home here this morning at the age of 43.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 2. -- Dartmouth ended its preparations today for the Yale game by rehearsing its entire list of plays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The National Labor Board formulated a decision today which is expected to end the nine weeks silk strike affecting 40,000 to 50,000 workers. At the same time the board announced its rulings in cases involving 2,000 boot and shoe strikers in New York and Brockton, Mass.

A committee with power to act on the America's Cup challenge was appointed at a meeting of members of the New York Yacht Club at the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse last night as the challenge was formally received.

AVALON, Catalina Island, Calif., Nov. 2. -- E. McFarlane Moore, former naval air officer and son-in-law of the late Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, and George Baker, airline pilot, were killed today when a ten-passenger amphibian plane of the Wilmington-Catalina Airways, Ltd., capsized in taking off a half mile from shore.

Loew's, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $4,034,289 for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31. After payment of preferred dividends the net profit was equivalent to $2.15 a share on 1,464,205 shares of common stock. This compares with a net profit of $7,961,314 in the year ended on Aug. 31, 1932, equivalent to $4.80 a share on the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A fund of $135,000,000 was set aside today by the Public Works Administration for financing purchases of railroad equipment under the administration's program to stimulate activity and re-employment in the heavy industries.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, presided yesterday afternoon at the first meeting of a public relations committee recently formed to assist in seeking support of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, preceding the drive for an emergency fund of $300,000 to be opened Nov. 27.

It is exceptional to find new American music on Philharmonic-Symphony programs. But last night Bruno Walter, conducting the admirable orchestra in Carnegie Hall, gave the New York premiere of Randall Thompson's Second Symphony.

Mickey Walker will try to annex his third boxing championship tonight when he opposes Maxie Rosenbloom, holder of the world's light-heavyweight title, in a fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden. The Rumson fighter, who has been campaigning regularly for the past fifteen years, has trained four weeks, for the struggle, and maintains that he is in the best of shape.

New York's hitherto inexhaustible public for popular grand opera, the discovery of which has for some months now been the Hippodrome's unique and significant achievement, was again in evidence last evening at the performance of a century-old classic for the first time at that house.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The German Institute for Business Research published an analysis of Germany's foreign trade today which furnishes a clue to the mystery of how German exports are able to hold their own in the face of the world-wide boycott against German goods.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 2. -- Because Leo Nebbia, a grocer, gave away a loaf of bread with a bottle of milk, the Supreme Court of the United States will pass upon a State's right to fix the price of milk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- By all the standards government officials have set up, it appeared tonight that Henry Ford had qualified for government contracts, and that no basis existed for rejection of any bids submitted by his dealers.

As a result of the overnight announcement that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had authorized the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to purchase gold in Europe, the foreign exchange markets made the conventional response yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2. -- The United States Department of State finally hag taken cognizance of the frozen credit situation in Argentina. The embassy here began this week the collecting and transmitting to Washington of charges of anti-American discrimination by the Exchange Control Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- In a decision revising the processing tax application, the Treasury Department today ruled that the tax attaches to all goods in the first stage of domestic processing of cotton on Aug. 1. The floor stock tax attaches to goods in the second stage of domestic processing on Aug. 1.

Residential construction with the uae of pre-fabricated units of steel, permitting quick assemblage, is helping to revive the home-building industry of France, according to Colonel Louis Icre of Paris, director of l'Office, Technique pour l'Utilization de l'Acier.

Frau Maria Griebl, wife of Dr. Ignaz T. Griebl, Nazi leader here, refused yesterday to be questioned before a grand jury by United States Attorney George Z. Medalie, on the ground that he was a Jew. Her husband approved her course, although he himself had just put in his third uncomfortable day with Mr. Medalie before the grand jury.
The improved demand for investment properties noticeable in realty trading in recent weeks was felt yesterday in Brooklyn, where some large flats changed hands.

TORONTO, Nov. 2. -- The great recovery experiment in the United States is sociological as well as economic, and it is as a social enterprise that it should be "weighed and finally judged, Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here today in an address before the Empire Club.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Oct. 31 shows the following changes in reichs-marks:
Mrs. George Whigham gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Grace, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shearson and Robert Sweeney.

In July the Duke of ATHOLL, made a public appeal to a powerful English class in which many classes are represented. He asked that a million sportsmen and sportswomen send him ten shillings each to be spent at his absolute discretion. There were nearly 340,000 replies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Chief William Byrne of the Westchester park police had to call out his reserves at noon today to protect the $1,000,000 County Centre here from a stampede of 7,000 school children who descended unexpectedly, and all at the same time, upon the exhibition of Westchester historical objects opened last night by the Westchester County Historical Society.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Air authorities in Great Britain and Canada are understood to favor the New-foundland-Ireland Atlantic air route in preference to the Greenland route, which Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh believes to be the more practicable of the two.

A merchant marine subsidized by the Federal Government and manned by officers trained at government expense was urged by Rear Admiral Yates Stirling, newly appointed commandant of the Third Naval District, at a luncheon of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York in the Downtown Athletic Club Building yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Experience with the new Securities Act has convinced the Federal Trade Commission that its rule of July 27 relating to notes and bonds secured by real estate mortgages Is unnecessarily strict and has led it to modify the regulations regarding exemptions from registration of some classes of real estate mortgages.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 2. -- George Coleman, 4 months old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Coleman of 93 Laurel Avenue here, Negroes, died yesterday at his home of intestinal stoppage. An operation that might have saved his life was not performed because the baby had whooping cough and none of the three hospitals in Nassau County, all private institutions is permitted by law to admit patients with contaerious diseases.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- German automobile owners were "coordinated" today when all German automobile clubs were merged into a new "German Auto Club" and placed under the command of former Major Adolf Huehnlein, leader of the National Socialist Motor Corpa and chief of the motor division of the Hitler storm troops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The National Association of Manufacturers is unwilling to lose its identity and merge with other trade and industry groups to form a national Chamber of Commerce and Industry, as outlined in the Gerard Swope plan, Robert L. Lund, its president, said today.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. Wednesday. For the best names.. 1 1/4% 1 1/4% The quotations are for three-four months paper.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Despite the announcement that American gold purchases would start today, no American Government bid was received in the London market. Gold rose sharply to 133s 3d an ounce, but there was no sign of any American bidding for u400,000 up for sale.

Norman Thomas returned yesterday from a three weeks' tour to the Pacific Coast, eager to "get into the fight for Charlie Solomon." He will make a score of speeches for the Socialist candidate for Mayor and his ticket between now and election.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Inaugurating play in the women's Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, the Greenwich Country Club today captured its opening interclub match of the season by 5 to 0.
FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, Nov. 2. -- In a pouring rain at 5 o'clock this morning the Graf Zeppelin arrived here on its return trip from Chicago via Spain.

With Manhattan College entering strong teams in both varsity and freshman events in an attempt to retain its double honors of a year ago, the complete entry lists for the twenty-fifth annual varsity and fourteenth annual freshman cross-country championships were released by the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. yesterday.

Social control of educational practices and standards by voluntary organizations of educators, rather than by State and other agencies, was favored by Dr. George F. Zook, United States Commissioner of Education, at a conference yesterday in the Hotel St. Regis.

A proposal for Federal aid to education through national tuition scholarships was discussed yesterday at the twentieth annual meeting of the Association of Urban Universities at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Delegates weighed the question of appealing to the government to help institutions by scholarships, direct grants or other means, and the matter was referred to the resolutions committee, which will report back to a business meeting this afternoon.

The new Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital at First Avenue and Thirtieth Street, which is now equipped to house 375 patients, was formally dedicated last night at a meeting of the New York Society for Clinical Psychiatry, held in the auditorium of the institution.

Nathan Straus Jr., nominee for President of the Board of Aldermen on the Recovery party ticket, said last night that the present city budget could be cut by more than $100,000,000 without affecting "one necessary service" or "reducing the pay of one employe who is doing an honest day's work."

A letter from Alice B. Toklas is now on exhibition in the Cleveland book store of Halle Brothers. It was sent to a Cleveland reader of Gertrude Stein's "The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," who wrote asking for an explanation of one sentence.
The two student papers representing the Washington Square centre of New York University are at odds over the football situation at that institution.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- More than half of the original directors of the Federal Home Loan Banks appointed by the Home Loan Bank Board have been re-elected.

The trial of Isidor J. Kresel, which has been going on for six weeks in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, neared its close yesterday. Questioning of the defendant was completed and several State witnesses were recalled for additional cross-examination by John W. Davis, chief defense counsel.

Ignace Jan Paderewski has canceled his scheduled American tour for this season because of acute and persistent neuritis, which prevents him from practicing or playing, it was announced yesterday by George Engles, his manager. The pianist had planned to begin a short concert tour in this country in January.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- According to The Daily Herald, a move will be made tomorrow to form a new company to complete the unfinished giant Cunard liner, known as the 534, and afterward to operate it. The new company, the newspaper says, will comprise representatives of the Cunard and White Star lines, who will meet in London tomorrow to discuss the details, after which a government nominee may be appointed to the management board.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- The second volume of the New York State Manufacturers Directory has just been completed, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today, and is ready for distribution. It covers the metropolitan area, including New York, Long Island, Rockland and Westchester Counties.

The American Water Color Society opened its sixty-seventh annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building last evening with a private view. Beginning today, the work may be seen by the public until Nov. 19.
Several store structures were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Marking time pending further developments in the currency situation, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices stood at 103.8 on Tuesday, unchanged from the revised figure of the week before. The dollar declined during the same time to 65.9 cents from 66.7, and the index on a gold basis therefore dropped to 68.4, a new low except for Oct. 3, when it touched 68.0.

NEW YORK. Mrs. William Blanchard Rand and Mrs. G. Grenville Hunter will give a reception for Miss Penelope Grenville Hunter, Dec. 8, at 320 East Fifty-seventh Street. Miss Hunter, a debutante of this season, is the daughter of Mrs. Hunter and the late G. Grenville Hunter and a niece of Mrs. Rand.

Contracts for the construction of highways amounting to $13,816,000 were let during the week ended Oct. 30, The Engineering News-Record reports, describing the total as a renewal in full force of highway lettings, which showed a let-up the previous week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 31:

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Nov. 2 (By Wireless). -- After five weeks of lonesomeness, distant lighthouse beams are flashing across the bow of the Wyatt Earp, the Lincoln Ellsworth Trans-Antarctic-Flight Expedition ship which is carrying his polar plane to the Ross Sea.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- The first purchase of gold for the account of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York took place here today, forcing the dollar finally to give ground on the Paris exchange market after resisting pressure for many days.
PARIS, Nov. 2. -- Bad weather caused Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh to delay their take-off for Amsterdam this morning from the French hydroplane base in the Seine at Les Mureaux.

KINGSTON, Ont., Nov. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Staging a scoring bee in the last period, the New York Rangers, world's professional hockey champions, defeated the Montreal Canadiens tonight in an exhibition game, 3 to 0. A crowd of over 3,000 fans attended.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Consolidation of American cable companies' branch offices in Great Britain and some Continental countries is being discussed here this week and may be agreed upon within a few days.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Business stagnation on the Boerse continued today. Transactions mostly were concentrated on the bond market, where prices were irregular but generally steady, with government and industrial securities even fractionally higher.
The Mayoralty candidacy of Joseph V. McKee is endorsed in the current issue of Today in an editorial written by Raymond Moley, editor, and long an associate of President Roosevelt.
Columbia probably will rely on its aerial attack to penetrate Cornell's defense in their annual game tomorrow at Ithaca.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,549,000,000, an increase of $31,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $321,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The Princeton varsity crew will meet seven Eastern rivals in four regattas next Spring, it was announced today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 2. -- Dr. Aaron Levin, widely known physician here, died of a heart attack in his office today at the age of 39. Dr. Levin was graduated from Coe College, Iowa City, Iowa, and Emery Medical College, Atlanta. He was a brother of the late Rabbi J.M. Levin.

Edward A. Hayes, national commander of the American Legion, at a rally last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania reiterated the organization's stand of uncompromising opposition to the recognition of Soviet Russia and asserted the Legion disagreed with President Roosevelt's views on hospitalization of veterans, expressed in his address before the service men in Chicago.

Columbia brought its Fall rowing campaign to a close yesterday when it held the annual Bangs Cup Regatta on the Harlem River. The varsity heavyweight crew, composed mostly of last season's freshman eight, won the cup by defeating a lightweight outfit by slightly less than a length in a one-mile race.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- America cannot afford to let down its standards on higher education, and "skip a generation," simply because present economic conditions have made support of colleges "inconvenient," Walter Lippmann, New York publicist, declared tonight at an alumnae dinner here for presidents of several Eastern colleges for women.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 2. -- While M.E. Comerford, State NRA Chairman, strove to prevent the calling of a general strike tomorrow when the convention of anthracite miners resumes, feeling ran high here tonight in the wake of two outbreaks at operations of the Hudson Coal Company, where a walkout was authorized by the insurgent union.

The Regional Labor Board, of which George W. Alger is chairman, intervened actively yesterday against the maintenance by the New York Edison Company of a so-called company union, whose right to organize the 33,000 employes of the company is being challenged under the National Recovery Act by the Brotherhood of Edison Employes, an independent organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Postmaster General Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said late today that as a voter in New York City he would vote for Joseph V. McKee for Mayor because he believed that "the best interests of the city would be served by his election."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes reported tonight that his campaign for reduction of oil production was bringing fairly satisfactory results, with last week's stocks of crude petroleum dropping 725,000 barrels from the previous week.
Fordham'a football squad spent three hours on Fordham Field yesterday, adding the finishing touches to its offensive and defensive tactics for the battle with the Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved slightly again yesterday and closed 1 to 4 points higher than on Wednesday.

HAVANA, Nov. 2. -- A bomb exploded this morning at the offices of La Semana, a comic weekly owned by Sergio Carbo, a radical journalist and supporter of the government of President Ramon Grau San Martin. The entrance of the building was badly damaged and the windows shattered.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A distinguished audience welcomed John Charles Thomas, who was the guest artist at the concert this afternoon in Constitution Hall by the National Symphony Orchestra.

No one can charge that Mr. PRIAL is boss-ridden. When the Democratic leaders refused to nominate him for Controller, he ran against the organization candidate in the primaries and beat him. After this unusual demonstration of political power he strode into Tammany Hall and denounced the leaders to their face for their "political arrogance."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The decline in commodity prices which had been in progress for two weeks was halted during the week ending Oct. 28, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Isador Lubin, announced today. The index number of the general commodity level rose by more than seven-tenths of 1 per cent over the previous week.

The campaign in New Jersey has an importance larger than the contest for members of the Assembly and seven vacancies in the Senate. Not since 1929 has there been an election in which no State-wide office was to be contended for. This year only control of the Legislature is at stake.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Dorey, Brig. Gen. H., U.S.A., appointed Major General.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Visitors to A Century of Progress Exposition during the regular period of the fair, which came to a close yesterday, spent about $35,000,000 in gate admissions and in concessions and exhibitions within the grounds. The figures were made public today by M.M. Tveter, controller of the exposition.

Lawrence Tibbett is an artist who knows how to adapt his style and program to his surroundings. In the more modest reaches of the Town Hall, where he sang last night in the first concert of the hall's endowment fund series, his approach was intimate and his selection of songs wisely calculated to avoid conceptions too big for the auditorium.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- An enthusiastic crowd sent the Colgate squad and Coach Andy Kerr off to New York tonight after a long but light workout on Whitnall Field this afternoon. Kerr is taking thirty-three players to the Yankee Stadium as he attempts to maintain Colgate's record of being undefeated since Oct. 24, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The National Recovery Administration rejected today a proposed code for the music publishing business, which had been approved by publishers' representatives as a means of curbing unethical "song plugging" and similar practices.
The statement of condition of the National City Bank of New York on Oct. 25 shows deposits amounting to $1,113,760,296, comparing with $1,134,750,257 on June 30 and $1,023,319,821 on March 31, 1933.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- No official intervention by America in the London bullion market could be traced today.

Only three of the five scheduled team matches of the opening Class A program of the season in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League were played last night. The University Club, the Harvard Club No. 1 team and the Downtown A. C. were the winners.

"It Pays to Sin," a comedy adapted from the German of Johann Vaszary, will be presented this evening at the Morosco Theatre. Jane Starr, Leon Waycoff, Martin Burton and Frances Woodbury are included in the cast.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The finding of a bullet-riddled automobile on a farm near Downington, Pa., today started a search for the bodies of two women who are believed to have been slain in a feud between rival gangsters.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 2. -- The beginning of a new cycle of spots of the sun was announced at the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory today. It promises:

The Association of Railway Executives and its advisory committee will hold their Fall meeting in Chicago on Nov. 9. It is expected that consideration will be given to suggestions for permanent railroad legislation made by members of the committee appointed by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The administration today set in motion its program of buying gold in the world markets, coupling the first steps with assurances that it was not the purpose unduly to disturb the finances of any country.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The Labor party's success in the municipal elections yesterday are now revealed as the most substantial it has achieved since the party first began to contest in local government' elections on a wide front.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A shortage of $27,215.48 in the accounts of Hugh J. Arthur, formerly an investigator in the Workmen's Compensation Division of the State Department of Labor, was reported to Governor Moore today by State Auditor Walter R. Darby.

Virtually the entire personnel of the city Police Department, with the exception of clerical men, patrol-wagon operators, turnkeys and gasoline dispensers, will be concentrated on Election Day duty next Wednesday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2. -- Following meetings of executives of the Canadian newsprint companies held yesterday and today, the formation is announced of the Newsprint Export Manufacturers Association of Canada, with headquarters in Montreal.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, was cheered by a crowd estimated at 10,000 yesterday when he addressed an open-air midday rally at Broad and Wall Streets.

The removal of the top of the skull as an apparently successful treatment of epilepsy of hitherto undetermined origin was demonstrated publicly for the first time yesterday by Dr. K.W. Ney, Professor of Neuro-Surgery in the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital, before members of the Eastern Homeopathic Medical Association and Clinical Congress holding its annual convention in the hospital.

The achievements of the National Recovery program in increasing business activity, particularly in the chemical industry, were stressed yesterday by Francis P. Garvan, president of the United States Institute for Textile Research, at a luncheon meeting of the institute at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Waste, greed, corruption, crime, inhumanity, demagogy and confusion were named last night by Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, as the "seven deadly, vicious enemies of good government."
THE fellow from California didn't want to hear anything about the Rosenbloom-Walker fight. He turned up his nose as soon as the weights of the gladiators were mentioned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Opposition to pending monetary proposals of the Roosevelt administration looking to a managed currency was expressed today in a joint statement by twelve outstanding economists attached to the faculties of Middle West universities.

Speeches by Mr. LaGuardia and Mr. Seabury, Page 2. F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor; Samuel Seabury, his principal backer, and a dozen other Fusion leaders demanded the permanent destruction of Tammany Hall last night at a large rally in Madison Square Garden.

The application made by F.W. Charske, chairman of the Union Pacific Railroad's executive board, for the authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to become a director of the New York Central Railroad has been withdrawn. The withdrawal was without prejudice to resubmission.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Shandon Farm Stable's Naval Cadet, which only last week earned brackets after eleven starts in the maiden ranks, made it two in a row by winning the Hinata Purse, feature of today's Latonia card.

The Literary Digest itself is not moved by the figures of its own questionnaire to put on the robes of an infallible political prophet. It admits that something might happen before Nov. 7 to change the trend which the 545,000 votes it has received and tabulated seem to reveal.

MUNICH, Nov. 2. -- Noel Panter, correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, was released from jail here at noon today after nine days in prison. He has agreed to leave Germany within forty-eight hours and will depart for England tomorrow with his brother, who is a London physician.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- Premier Albert Sarraut will present his Cabinet before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow and outline at least briefly in his Ministerial declaration the financial policy he intends to follow and the means by which he hopes to obtain a balanced budget.

The plight of the sportsman who sets forth with dog and gun for a day's shooting and, after walking many miles, discovers nothing but signs reading "This land posted; no trespassing" is indeed an unhappy one.

We grown-ups have made a rather bad business of running this world, and ought not to "take it out" on the children. The best we can do to repair the damage done by the wreckage of war and the greed of peace is to see that children are not denied a fair chance to lead decent, happy, useful lives.

Keeping a watchful eye upon the foreign exchanges in their possible relation to the government's plan to buy gold in the European market, the stock market continued yesterday to mark time. There was no active display of spaculative interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Secretary Hull today expressed to Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, "his concern that an Ambassador accredited to the Government of the United States should be subjected to a public attack" such as that made yesterday on Dr. Luther by Samuel Untermyer in Cleveland.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Collective bargaining stood tonight as an accepted provision by Henry Ford, both in administration headquarters at Washington and at the manufacturer's Dearborn office.

All Read Alike. Aryanization has overtaken the Ullstein publishing house. This is the greatest enterprise of its kind in Germany and probably in the world, exercising control over numerous widely circulated newspapers and periodicals and a highly successful book-publishing business.

The return of 400,000 unemployed to jobs in New York City since the beginning of the recovery program is indicated in incomplete returns on a questionnaire being circulated among 200,000 employers of the city by the local NRA, according to a statement last night by Grover A. Whalen, local NRA chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Continued substantial gains in miscellaneous internal revenue receipts brought total collections from that source in October to $169,776,114, the highest since the special depression taxes were put into effect, said the Treasury today.

Most commodities joined yesterday in the upward trend established by silver futures earlier in the week, but trading was limited and the gains were not extensive. The gains in general were ascribed to the withdrawal of offerings, while the demand met steadily rising quotations.

Charges against Mayor O'Brien will be filed with Governor Lehman unless the Mayor acts soon in calling a special session of the Board of Aldermen to repeal the 50 per cent increase in water rates, Aldermen Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Holding that the statute creating the Home Owners Loan Corporation should be construed liberally to facilitate its purpose of extending the greatest measure of relief, Attorney General Cummings, in a ruling made public today, said that "the government will not be entitled to payment from the corporation on account of interest claims until the bondholders have been paid in full."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Governors of five Western States worked out with President Roosevelt today a tentative plan for price-fixing on wheat, corn, rye and other products to improve the situation among the farmers.

Surrogate James A. Foley, approved yesterday an agreement that settled the disputes among claimants to the $4,000,000 estate of Edward Albert Ridley, eccentric East Side real estate dealer, who last May was found murdered with his secretary, Lee Weinstein.

Henry C. Steneck, president of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, testified yesterday at his trial before Judge O'Regan in Quarter Sessions Court, Jersey City, that he was told by John Milton, his former lawyer, that he had been indicted in connection with the bank crash before the indictments Were handed up by the grand jury to a judge.

Though the city government is increasing its monthly expenditure for unemployment relief by $4,000,000 "in a desperate attempt to get votes," the sum to be spent is still $5,000,000 short of the actual requirement, Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 1 unless specified:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The administration moved swiftly today to reassure its followers that it intends, for the present at least, to forge straight ahead on the recovery road as originally laid out, despite strong suggestions that it modify some of the control it has assumed over industry.

The additional New York County grand jury voted nineteen new indictments yesterday, accusing forty persons of fraudulently registering in seven Assembly districts in Manhattan. At the same time a total of seventy indictments, involving 181 persons in other fraudulent registration cases, which previously had been voted by the two October grand juries, were handed up to Judge Nott in General Sessions.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Henry D. Sharpe, president of the New England Council, today advised President Roosevelt that New England business leaders were strongly opposed to any currency inflation.

The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court upheld yesterday a ruling that the word "as" in a lease relieved General James G. Harbord from liability in a suit of Eleven West Forty-second Street, Inc., for $1,500 for rent of quarters in the Salmon Tower taken by the New York Republican Advisory Committee in May, 1930.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Jack Dempsey, the former heavyweight champion, informally came out of retirement last night to score a knockout in what started as a wrestling match and ended in a slugging bee.

Bank clearings at twenty-one cities for the week ended on "Wednesday were 10.9 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of 1932, as reported by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was due to an increase of 16.6 per cent here, as the other centres showed a decline of 0.3 per cent.

KAY BOYLE is one of the writers for Eugene Jolas's experimental magazine, transition, who has managed to shed the skin of self-consciousness and adopted, preciosity that are necessarily attendant upon experiment. From her first book, the short stories in "Wedding Day and Other Stories," she has grown. Her new novel, "Gentlemen, I Address You Privately" (Smith Haas, $2.50), is, perhaps, the best thing she has done.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- For the second time in four years the Constitution of Malta has been suspended and the island, which is a powerful Mediterranean naval base, has been put under crown colony government, which means direct control from London.
