The Karmiol Co., brokerage, has moved to 261 E. Fordham Rd. from 2,488 Grand Concourse.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- German Kultur, all the external manifestations of the so-called higher mental life of Germany, has been governmentally organized in a Reich "Kulturkammer," that is, a "Chamber of Culture" -- much like a Chamber of Commerce.

Some enthusiasts still speak of the possibility of "destroying" Tammany in next Tuesday's election. But it is better to limit our ambitions to inflicting upon it a sound defeat. Tammany can stand a lot of destroying, as its past history shows." If the Red Slayer thinks he slays "he had better look the second time.

The Street and Outdoor Cleanliness Committee of the Academy of Medicine finds little or no improvement in the condition of parks and streets. Hopes were raised that when receptacles were conveniently placed at street corners much of the littering would end. It was said that until these were provided outdoor cleanliness would always remain in the realm of theoretical discussion.

Nine Negroes, six of them children, lost their lives early yesterday in a fire that swept through an old frame tenement building at 361 Britsol Street, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. Three others were burned severely and are in the hospital in a serious condition.

The Curtis String Quartet, consisting of Jascha Brodsky, Benjamin Sharlip, Max Aronoff and Orlando Cole, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. The program, consisted of Haydn's quartet in C, Op. 54, No. 2; Schubert's quartet in G, Op. 161, and Schumann's quartet in A, Op. 41, No. 3.
The City Campaign. Mayor O'Brien made a plea to the voters of Brooklyn to carry the city for the regular Democratic ticket at a rally of 4,000 persons. Senator Copeland praised the Mayor's stand.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn reserved decision yesterday on applications to restrain bands of city departments from playing at non-official functions on the ground that the city's money is wasted when employes devote time to work having no connection with their official duties.

When "Jurgen" was being made popular James Branch Cabell sent out word to the "rabble" that the way to pronounce his name was to make it rhyme with his name for them. Not all authors have been so up and coming about pronunciations, however, and to solve such problems-and a great many others -- C.O. Sester Mawson has compiled an "International Book of Names."

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- A confused all-day fight today in the League of Nations advisory committee on opium, partly public and partly private, followed the protest of Stuart Fuller of the Washington State Department yesterday against a narcotic menace which he charged to Manchukuo.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Local dogs carried off first honors today in the opening stakes of the ninth annual field trials of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America held on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club. In the open all-age stake for springer spaniels, the winner was the black and white dog, Speed of Falcon Hill, owned and handled by Elias C. Vail of Poughkeepsie.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's will trot out a powerful football eleven against the unbeaten Fordham team at the Polo Grounds at 2 o'clock today in New York's first East-West battle of the current season.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Bill Bonthron of Princeton, the 408.7 miler of several months ago, collapsed forty yards from the finish line in the Yale-Harvard-Princeton cross-country race today when he had individual honors and a course record in his grasp.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The National Progressive Republican Organization appealed today for the nation to support its Democratic President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and demanded that attacks on his administration cease.

Stores Push Apparel Sales. With the weather proving a marked handicap in the turnover of heavier apparel, retailers have resorted to increased promotional pressure to move stocks on hand. The number of close-price sales showed an increase over last week, reflecting primarily the featuring of merchandise recently bought at offprice in the wholesale markets, but also some concessions from recent retail levels.

The statement of combined earnings of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, excluding the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, for the third quarter of 1933 shows a balance of $6,944,355 available for common shares of the parent company, equal to 29.87 cents a share on the number of shares outstanding, compared with $6,858,567, or 29.50 cents a share, in the same period in 1932.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- After an absence of more than three years, the United States fleet will return to the Atlantic Coast next Spring.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 4 -- The ordered transfer of the United States Fleet from the Pacific to the Atlantic came as a welcome surprise today to the Japanese people.

Real estate and general business are "definitely on the road to recovery" after having passed the low point in one of the most trying periods in the city's business history, realty experts yesterday told the campaign workers of the Young Women's Christian Association's drive for $220,000 to balance its budget for 1934.

The wages of longshoremen employed at the piers of the coastwise steamship lines were increased yesterday, following the decision of the deep-sea lines to increase the wages of their men. A notice was posted on the coastwise piers saying that wages had been fixed at 75 cents an hour for the forty-four-hour week and $1.10 an hour for overtime, instead of the current rate of 67 cents and $1.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- The Princeton 150-pound football team scored its second straight victory today, defeating the Manhattan lightweights on University Field, 27-0.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- A Catholic priest, a Protestant pastor and two Christian attorneys who are partly Jewish challenged the Hitler government's extreme anti-Semitism tonight on behalf of millions of fellow-Germans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Stock Market Investigating Committee, said today he was studying means to prevent directors of corporations from using "inside information" in their personal stock transactions to the disadvantage of their companies and the public.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 1:

Four new officers were elected at the annual meeting of the Indoor Polo Association, held last night at the Metropolitan Club, Sixtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, at which Robert A. Granniss and Winston F.C. Guest were renamed president and vice president, respectively.

The Brotherhood of Edison Employes failed yesterday in the United States district court to obtain a temporary order enjoining the New York Edison Company from circulating or permitting to be circulated petitions by its employes seeking to bar the brotherhood, an independent organization, or the American Federation of Labor from attempting to organize the company's 33,000 workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Ten new registration statements for securities to be issued under the Securities Act were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- New York City was accused of contempt of the Supreme Court in a brief filed with the court today by New Jersey.

Members of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York at a meeting here yesterday took steps to participate in the temporary Federal deposit insurance plan, but reaffirmed their intention to seek changes in the Banking Act in the interests of their depositors according to an announcement after the session.

The question of amending the State Sanitary Code to eliminate Grade B milk and stop the sale of raw milk other than "certified," was taken under advisement yesterday by the Public Health Council, State Department of Health, after a lengthy hearing attended by more than 300 persons.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday broke a technical corner which had existed for more than a month in the Class A stock of the Fierce-Arrow Motor Car Company.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 3 -- Assailing a group of unnamed persons for crying loudly for the banishment of public high schools to reduce governmental costs, Dr.. Arvie Eldred of Albany, executive secretary of the New York State Teachers Association, today urged teachers to "fight to the last ditch" against such a move.

The top of a sound truck, parked at Wall and Nassau Streets, was utilized yesterday noon as a courtroom and an inquiry into racketeering was conducted by the Fusion party. The witness was William Fellowes Morgan Jr., president of the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company, who described himself as "the fellow foolish enough to think he could lick single handed an organized racket controlled by Tammany."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- State Department officials expressed their satisfaction today at the extradition order granted by the Supreme Court in Italy for Giuseppe Spinelli, wanted in Pittsburgh on a charge of murder. They said extradition proceedings had been in progress for about a year.

The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for the sale of $70,000,000 in relief bonds on Nov. 15 to provide city funds for helping the needy in the next ten months, and meantime delayed action on approving the $15,000,000 revolving fund for relief suggested by Frank J. Taylor, Welfare Commissioner.

In disciplinary proceedings against lawyers, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court disbarred yesterday Sigmund Horkimer, Paul Kahan, David H. Lehman, Aaron Zanger and Nathan Schwartz. The court suspended Demerald H. Williams for a year and Salvatore Freda and John C. Cunningham for six months each.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Public Works Administration allocated $17,578,855 today to Federal and non-Federal projects, including several in New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The British debt negotiations apparently moved into a new phase today when Dean Acheson, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, held a long conference with Secretary of State Hull on the subject. The debt discussions have taken place at the Treasury, although Frederick Livesy, assistant economic "adviser of the State Department, has sat in at the conversations with the British negotiators.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 3 (AP) --Art Mondt, wrestler and promoter, testified today that he was told, "to the victor belong the spoils," and was asked to contribute to the expense of electing Governor Miriam A. Ferguson, when he sought a wrestling and boxing permit in Texas.

Frank C. Wright, vice president of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad, who has been invited to assist the Public Works Administration in its purchasing plan for the railroads, went yesterday to Washington. At his office it was said he had not disclosed whether he would accept the offer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade turned upward today as a result of the announcement that the administration was inclined to regard price-fixing as a panacea for the maladjustment between agricultural products and what the farmer buys. Other influences counted for naught.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3 -- Canandaigua scored easily in the Harford Steeplechase, feature at Pimlico today, giving Owner Thomas Hitchcock and Rider Rigan McKinney a triumph to add to those gained during the Maryland Fall season. Carrying top weight of 158 pounds, the 6-year-old Rocksavage gelding won by four lengths at even money.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Premier Sarraut's new Cabinet survived tonight its first encounter with the Chamber of Deputies, but the manner of its survival confirmed its transitional character and indicated clearly it would be but a temporary expedient.

The public had its first opportunity yesterday to visit the twentysixth annual exhibit of the Horticultural Society of New York at the American Museum of Natural History. The exhibit opened Thursday night with a private showing and will close tomorrow afternoon.

Richard Aldrich and Alfred de Liagre Jr., announced yesterday that they had started rehearsals on a new comedy, "Haywire," by Kennon Jewett. Tom Powers and Harold Vermilyea will appear in it and Mr. de Liagre will direct. The opening is scheduled for Nov. 28.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- A slight increase in business, owing to repurchases by professionals, produced an improvement on the Boerse today. Prices still were irregular, but public utilities, lignites and electricals were able to register gains up to 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The administration is striving to complete a "common-sense" formula for dealing with the changed liquor situation in the expectation that the prohibition era will come to a practical end on Tuesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Most of the questions raised by the present industrial crisis are so complex that only an expert in economics can argue them sensibly. But some concern such basic principles that every citizen should have an opinion about them. One of these is the proposal of Gerard Swope printed in THE TIMES of Nov. 2.
Football heads into the second half of the season today under favorable circumstances generally for the unbeaten array.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- With the Home Owners Loan Corporation operating "successfully" in the refunding of home mortgages, W. F. Stevenson today started a system of rotating the chairmanship of the Home Loan Bank Board by resigning that position.

Samuel Levy, Tammany candidate for re-election as Borough President, dedicated two playgrounds on the lower East Side yesterday. The playgrounds, which have been in use since the beginning of the school year, are at Public School 15, East Fourth Street between Avenues C and D, and in the area bounded by Sheriff, Broome, Delancey and Columbia Streets.

The country is "on the way out of the depression, and make no mistake about it," but a great responsibility in the relief of suffering and distress still remains to be fulfilled, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A ruling opposing the lease and agency practice whereby large oil companies control retail outlets was sent to the NRA administrator today by the Federal Trade Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- With L200,000 of gold in the market reportedly taken by the usual Continental sources at 133s 2d an ounce, the American gold policy remained as much of a mystery as ever today. Bullion brokers failed to observe any indication that America was inquiring into this market, but the market was inclined to accept reports that the United States is buying secretly.

MADRID, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Sidney Franklin, Brooklyn bull fighter, sailed from Gibraltar today for New York aboard the liner Rex. He is convalescing from wounds suffered in the bullring and subsequent operations.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Secret negotiations between the Cunard and the White Star Lines made progress today toward formation of a holding company to take over operations of the North Atlantic passenger liners of both concerns.

UPPERVILLE, Va., Nov. 3 -- The third annual hunts meeting at Llangollen, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney, will be held tomorrow, with forty-one entries lor the four events which comprise the program. Hunt club followers throughout the East are expected for the races, the first of which will start at 1:30 P. M.

Mrs. Madeleine Force Astor Dick, former widow of the late John Jacob Astor and divorced wife of William K. Dick, returned from Bermuda yesterday on the Monarch of Bermuda, and was carried from the ship in a stretcher. She was taken in an ambulance to the Doctors Hospital.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The principal reason for the present visit of General Maxime Weygand, the Chief of Staff, to North Africa, is to study the question of reinforcing the army in France by colonial forces, Le Matin declares.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Charging that the reply of the Ford Motor Company, given Wednesday in Edgewater to the demands of the striking workers, was evasive and failed to meet them "at any point," the strikers today announced that they would "prosecute vigorously" the charges filed against the company with the NRA in Washington.

Responding to public agitation against the enforced retirement of Dr. William H. Park from the Health Department, Mayor O'Brien wrote to Dr. Park yesterday assuring him that he would be continued in service after he reached the retirement age of 70 on Dec. 30.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Professor Emile Roux, one of the most Illustrious scientists of France and successor to Louis Pasteur as director of the Pasteur Institute, died here tonight after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The upward business trend continued in Austria during the third quarter of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of foreign business. In Germany, on the other hand, there was "a lack of spontaneous improvement in September, despite a certain increase in industry and employment stimulated by the government public works and work-sharing schemes."

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Premier of Prussia, will appear before the German Supreme Court tomorrow to deny under oath charges made abroad that he ordered the burning of the Reichstag building to bring about the establishment of the Nazi dictatorship.

An attack upon F.H. LaGuardia as the "Janus-faced candidate of the 1933 campaign" and a "political weather vane" was made last night by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, as the Socialist party prepared to wind up its campaign with a city-wide rally at Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon.

James G. McDonald, recently appointed High Commissioner for German Refugees by the League of Nations Council, is sailing today for Europe on the French liner He de France. Others leaving on the ship for Havre via Plymouth include Emil Ludwig, German biographer; Count Ghislain de Maigret, Paul Lukas, screen actor, and:

The new Chemical Industry Medal of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry, which takes the place of the Grasselli Medal now discontinued, was presented last night to James G. Vail, vice president and chemical director of the Philadelphia Quartz Company, at a meetng at the Chemists' Club, 52 East Forty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States Government will move cautiously, if at all, in the question of frozen Argentine exchange at the present time, Secretary Hull indicated today.

Miss Leila Jones, daughter of Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones of Morristown, N. J., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for her debutante sister, Miss Ann B. Jones.

Manhattan and City College, traditional metropolitan rivals, will meet in the eighth renewal of their football series at Ebbets Field this afternoon starting at 2 o'clock. Three contests have resulted in ties, three have been won by the Jaspers and two by the Lavender in an unbroken succession of games since 1925.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 -- Although the police feared further anti-Jewish outbreaks by Arabs today, as on Fridays crowds of Moslems assemble at the Mosques after midday prayers, the day passed peacefully. All persons entering the Old City in Jersualem were searched by police.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The wholesale trade submitted its code of fair competition to the National Recovery Administration today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Pennsylvania's junior varsity football team romped to an easy victory over the Villanova jayvees on Franklin Field today, 31 to 0. Ralph Ferdinand starred with three touchdowns, while Baker and Beck also crossed the goal line.

Samuel Untermyer declared yesterday that Secretary of State Cordell Hull was "most precipitous and unjudicial" in publicly expressing regret for Mr. Untermyer's attack on Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Leaders of 40,000 miners employed in the "captive" pits of the Pennsylvania steel corporations agreed to order their men back to work at once after conferring with President Roosevelt today and receiving his personal assurance that the power of the government would be used to guarantee them a fair election of their spokesmen for collective bargaining with their employers.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- In a long article under the caption "Gold Delusions" the London Economist will say tomorrow that if the Americans are seriously determined to depreciate their own currency Great Britain should not put unnecessary obstacles in their way, but should do what is necessary to prevent the pound and gold currencies from falling in pursuit of the dollar.
COSHOCTON, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- The Swope plan for a permanent business supervision and administration of the National Recovery Act as published in the press is unacceptable to labor.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 3 -- Two hundred women attended today the Nassau County conference of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs held in the Garden City Casino. Mrs. Walter JR. Hood of Rockville Centre, chairman of the day, called the roll, which was responded to by sixtynine affiliated clubs.

For the third successive session, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday and under a steady withdrawal of contracts the list closed at the top at gains of 6 to 8 points. Strength in stocks and grains, a further sharp falling off in marketing and light hedging helped to advance prices.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 -- An American girl and an Indian Moslem were found slain today in an olive grove near the Garden of Gethsemane at the foot of the Mount of Olives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The reported plan for establishing an airfield on Saipan Island aroused some interest in naval circles here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES Palestine correspondent, Joseph M. Levy, in his dispatch from Jerusalem published Oct. 29, makes statements which we, who form the American Section of the world-wide Labor Zionist movement, and who stand in close relations with the General Jewish Federation of Labor in Pales tine, cannot permit to go unchallenged.

George W. Rogers, former official of the Manufacturers Trust Company, who had been ought for more than a year on a charge of grand larceny from the bank, turned up yesterday as the bank's witness in a $70,000 suit brought against it in Brooklyn.

For the nine months ended Sept. 30, the Bendix Aviation Corporation reported a net profit after taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges of $1,096,367, equal to 52 cents a share on 2,097,663 shares of $5 par capital stock. This contrasted with a net loss of $367,307 in the corresponding period last year.

The 450th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther, which is next Friday, will be celebrated tomorrow afternoon by a mass meeting in the Hippodrome under the auspices of a Committee of One Hundred, representing every branch of the Lutheran Church in the metropolitan area.

The inquiry by the two New York County grand juries into illegal registration resulted yesterday in the voting of thirty-one more indictments and the filing of sixtynine others with Judge Nott in General Sessions. The new indictments named forty-two persons, making a total of 223 since the opening of the investigation last Monday by prosecutors of Attorney General Bennett's staff.
ALBRIGHT vs. Villanova -- Still staggering from last week's shocks, one shuddering vote for Villanova.

MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Nov. 3 -- Two army aviators were killed tonight when their observation plane crashed in flames, after an explosion in mid-air. The bodies were found after a ninety-minute search on a heavily wooded hill on the south side of the Susquehanna River.

A resolution demanding a return to a gold standard and disapproval of the commodity dollar or managed dollar was adopted yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The passage was accompanied by rather perfunctory debate and the leading bankers, insurance representatives and industrialists whom James Brown, president of the chamber, had announced would be present were not in evidence.

Although the government continued yesterday to manipulate the price of gold in the world market, and possibly with some effect upon commodities, stocks seemed to be influenced mainly by domestic developments such as the proposal that the National Recovery Administration may be revamped to insure a greater degree of independence on the part of individual industries.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Ludwig Mueller, new Bishop of the Reich Evangelical Church, pleaded today for the united support of German Protestantism for the Hitler government in the forthcoming election.

In order to permit Borough President Hesterbergr of Brooklyn to "study further" the Brooklyn refuse disposal problem, which has been before the Board of Estimate awaiting solution for more than seven months, the board put off yesterday for two weeks action on Controller McAneny's plan for city operation of Brooklyn refuse disposal.

With real estate brokers reporting an increase in the number of inquiries for residential properties throughout the city, the fashionable Button Place section yesterday provided one of the largest outright sales of a private house in some time.
Mickey Walker's bid for ring immortality fell short last night at Madison Square Garden.

An American opera, Deems Taylor's "Peter Ibbetson," will open a season of the Metropolitan Opera House this year for the first time in the fifty years' history of the house, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Giulio GattiCasazza at his annual pre-season interview.
One of the greatest treasures of the Hermitage, the Russian national museum in Leningrad, has come to New York as a result of the exigencies of the Five-Year Plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- With President Roosevelt represented as having informed the Governors of five farm States here that he was willing to accept a price-fixing plan if they prepared for him one that was "feasible and workable," the Executives labored today over a new program, as a substitute for the one which they took to the White House yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Despite the effort to force the dollar down, it improved on the Paris exchange market today, closing at 16.54 francs against 16.51 yesterday. At its lowest it hit 16.38, but a short covering boom drove it upward. The theoretical parity at yesterday's price of gold in Washington was 16.35 francs; at today's price, 16.26.

Next Saturday afternoon will be an official holiday in the Borough of the Bronx. This is the day when Fordham and N.T.U. meet at the Yankee Stadium in their annual battle, which, among other things, regularly settles the collegiate football supremacy of the borough.
Moderate advances were scored yesterday by the principal commodities in dull futures trading here, with the exception of silk and metals, which declined after fairly large gains earlier in the week.
ALBANY, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The largest "off year" number of registrants in the history of New York State, 5,210,430, are eligible to vote in Tuesday's election.

Wall Street was pleased with the performance of all the markets yesterday. The action of the share market indicated that, while the speculative element was still moving with the greatest caution, it was taking a more cheerful view of the situation.

The large attendance at the Fusion mass meeting at Madison Square Garden on Thursday evening, as well as the temper of the gathering, has convinced the leaders of the anti-Tammany movement that victory for F.H. LaGuardia is firmly within their grasp.

Colgate and Tulane will clash in an intersectional battle at the Yankee Stadium today, starting at 2 P.M. They await their battle at two different points, the New Orleans combination in New York and the Red Raiders at Travers Island.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The price at which gold newly mined in the United States will be bought by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was advanced again today.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The football squads of Columbia and Cornell were twenty-two miles apart tonight, but tomorrow they will stage their twenty-first football engagement.

STEPHEN BENET'S tribute to THEODORE ROOSEVELT as " the ideal reader " was deserved. ROOSEVELT read " not as a task nor as a duty " but for the love of it and as " an integral part of life." He made his range as wide as human interests. He read voraciously and remembered veraciously.
With the challenge for the America's Cup officially in the hands of the committee appointed at Thursday's meeting at the New York Yacht Club, speculation on the situation increased yesterday.

MADRID, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Juan March, Spanish millionaire, escaped from prison last night because a prison guard chief was "sorry for him," and he slipped past the customs today into Gibraltar, where he intended to spend the night.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 3 -- A plot to extort $10,000 from R. J. (Dick) Reynolds under threat to kidnap his young wife was revealed here today through the arrest of John Lanier, an unemployed textile worker. A decoy package led to the arrest after Mr. Reynolds had turned two threatening letters over to the police.

A plan for closer coordination between the States and the Federal Government in the adoption and administration of their various revenue programs was proposed yesterday in a resolution submitted to the State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws by G. William Magley, a member of the commission.

The Government's allotment of $135,000,000 to finance the purchase of railroad equipment has the distinct advantage of being much more than a mere make-work plan. The railways are demonstrably in need of new equipment -- not to increase capacity, which is ample for present needs, but to make up deferred maintenance, to effect economies in operation and to meet competition under new conditions.

There will be football activity today on various fronts for the East's leading prep school elevens and most of the major teams will see action for the last time prior to next week's imposing list of traditional season-closing contests.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov.3 -- Salaries paid to executives of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company were listed in answers filed with the Public Utility Commission by the company today in compliance with the commission's ruling that it must furnish information sought by petitioners seeking a reduction in electric rates.
A large exhibition composed of work by prominent American illustrators occupies several of the exhibition rooms at the Grand Central Galleries, where it will remain on view until Nov. 11.

William J. McDermott, Special Assistant Attorney General of the State Election Frauds Bureau, began an inquiry yesterday to determine if Jay T. Fox, assistant secretary to Mayor O'Brien, had a legal right to register from the apartment house at 124 East Ninety-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The plan drafted today at the conference of mid-Western Governors represents a modification of the one they drafted earlier in the week at Des Moines and provides for fixing prices of beef cattle, hogs, corn, wheat, milk and butterfat at parity and the fixing of quotas for each farmer, limiting definitely the amount he may produce and sell.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- More adequate provision in relief programs for unemployed women and girls was predicted today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at her press conference. She said plans were under consideration concerning which she would be able to speak more definitely Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The bank-closing order of March 6 has been sustained as legal in a decision in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. So far as was known by the Controller, that was the first case of a ruling on the legality of President Roosevelt's proclamation.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 3 -- The positron and the electron, two parts of the atom, are about the same mass or weight, it has been determined by experiments conducted by Dr. Carl D. Anderson of the California Institute of Technology, who is credited as the discoverer of the positron.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Nov. 3 -- Stroked by Guy Richdale, the Rutgers University crew won the special Fall triangular regatta with Manhattan and Pennsylvania on the Schuylkill River late today.

Two more witnesses had testified yesterday in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court when it was adjourned by Justice Taylor until Wednesday because of the pending election. Mr Kresel is accused of abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the Bank of United States before its crash in December, 1930.

The dollar again developed resistance to the government's efforts to cheapen it yesterday. Although the RFC fixed a new high rate of $32.57 an ounce for newly mined gold, indicating a theoretical gold value for the dollar of 63.46 cents, the currency rose in foreign exchange to 64.97 cents and closed up .16 of a cent at 64.54 cents.

The Association of Urban Universities voted yesterday to appeal to President Roosevelt to put into effect a plan for Federal aid to education. The resolution, as adopted at the closing sessions of its two-day annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania, made no suggestion as to the form this plan should take, although at Thursday's session a proposal had been made for national tuition scholarships.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- A prediction that great social reforms would grow out of the economic changes wrought by the National Recovery Administration was voiced by Secretary Ickes in an address tonight at the centenary anniversary banquet of the Philadelphia Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Allocations of the Oct. 15 cash offering of 4 1/4-3 1/4 per cent Treasury bonds of 1943-45 were about $500,000,000, it was made known at the Treasury today.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National and State chairman, who announced on Thursday in Washington that he would vote for Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, made arrangements yesterday through his office here for a radio speech Monday evening at 9 o'clock from Station WABC.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A new draft of the Grain Exchange code, containing several important changes as compared with that previously submitted to the Washington authorities, was adopted unanimously today by the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade.

Expressing their conviction that the city administration in adopting a $554,000,000 budget with virtually no reduction had been influenced by political motives rather than the will to save, five members of the Municipal Economy Committee handed in their resignations last night.
DES MOINES, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Farm strikers tightened their grip on farm-to-market highways in five Midwest States tonight.
Business and Sun Spots The beginning of a new Business sun- spot is announced by the Mount Wilson Observatory scientists, one of whom thereupon proceeds to sneer a little at us poor-laymen.
The Columbia freshman football team and Roxbury School of Cheshire, Conn., battled to a 0-0 deadlock yesterday at Baker Field in their annual game.

With only $2,965,637 of new municipal bond issues up for award next week, the total will be the smallest for any week since March, when the banking holiday operated to shut off new financing. The revised total for this week was $6,415,027, making the weekly average for the year to date $13,730,096.

Mr. and Mrs. Warner Dare Huntington of this city and New Orleans gave a dinner dance last night at their home, 20 West Tenth Street, for Miss Mary Louise Stillman, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Stillman of 1,155 Park Avenue, who will be introduced to society at an afternoon reception on Dec. 31.

Cardinal Hayes has appointed Mgr. William E. Cashin as the chaplain of the Catholic Club. Mgr. Cashin was for many years chaplain at Sing Sing Prison, and for the last few years he has been pastor of old St. Andrew's Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Place.

It may be hoped that yesterday's unanimous resolutions of the Chamber of Commerce, upholding the gold standard and denouncing dangerous experiments with the standard of value, will mark a turn in an intolerable situation.
The six-day pheasant hunting season in this State comes to a close at sunset today, except on Long Island, where the sportsmen may continue to seek this game bird until Dec. 31.

Weather conditions were not conducive to much activity in such lines as dry goods, men's and women's apparel, shoes and hardware supplies, resulting in volume falling below that of the preceding week in most sections, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion campaign, committee, in addresses delivered last night on Staten Island and in the Bronx, predicted a sweeping victory for the Fusion ticket. At a meeting in Staten Island he placed the plurality at 300,000 or more.

Samuel Seabury, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, in an open letter addressed "To the Voters of the Tenth Assembly District" and made public last night, urged the re-election of Herbert Brownell Jr. to the Assembly and the election of Thomas J. Curran to the Board of Aldermen.

A plan to end the strain and fear of "professionalized" school and college examinations and to make of them "an important amateur sport" was presented to a group of educators yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis.

Yielding his place as first speaker to F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, at a luncheon of the American Criterion Society at the Hotel Plaza yesterday. Mayor O'Brien, with broad smiles and blue eyes beaming, listened to Mr. LaGuardia's attack on Tammany, bad government, "bossism" and the city's growing financial burden.
Maxie Rosenbloom weighed 173 3/4 pounds for his bout in Madison Square Garden last night with Mickey Walker. The latter scaled 173 1/2.

The Interborough, Rapid Transit Company's report for September shows a loss of $186,929 before deducting the dividend rental of 5 per cent on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee stock, which, is payable only if earned. The result compared with a loss of $97,796 in the corresponding month last year.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Yale and Dartmouth will play their seventeenth football game in the Bowl tomorrow.

In a statement attacking the speech made here on Thursday night by Edward A. Hayes, national commander of the American Legion, the American Veterans Association denounced yesterday the Legion policy as detracting from Federal care of those actually wounded in the war.

A lone co-ed was found yesterday among the more than 3,000 men students registered at the New York University uptown centre. Miss Isabel C. Ebel, graduate student at the university's College of Engineering, holds that distinction.

T.G. Townsend Phillips was a host at the Henry Miller Theatre last night for the performance of "Spring in Autumn," and for supper after the play in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. In the party were Princess Maria de Bourboa, Miss Nina de Belmonte, Miss Leta Clews, Jose de Belmonte, Richard Hale and Pepe Boneti.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 -- Following yesterday's hard scrimmage, Harvard had only light work today, merely running through signals and drilling on kick-offs for tomorrow's game with Lehigh.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES'S greeting to the new publication Today, the inspiring spirit in which is a former Assistant Secretary of State whose presence in his official family the President found embarrassing, is, of course, the felicitous greeting of a veteran to a fledgling in the field of journalism.

In a message broadcast to the New York State electorate by his wife, Governor Lehman appealed last night for support on Nov. 7 for the $60,000,000 State bond issue for unemployment relief. He described its ratification as "a plain and simple duty to humanity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The administration is determined to give the NRA a full opportunity to prove itself before turning to any other plan such as that proposed by Gerard Swope, it was said at the White House today.

ROME, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Giuseppe "Big Mike" Spinelli was no longer an Italian citizen and that therefore he must return to Pittsburgh for trial in connection, with the gangland murder of the three Volpe brothers.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Nov. 3 -- T. Darrnigton Sample, Treasurer of Westchester County, requested the Board of Supervisors in a letter today to ask the State to assume the $63,126,000 bonded debt on county parkways to assist the county out of its financial predicament.
DEVONPORT, England, Nov. 3 -- By courtesy of the Admiralty I have been privileged to inspect what is probably the last remaining "hushhush" ship in the British Navy.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Rip Van Winkle, from the barn of W. L. Johnson, upset the talent at odds of 10 to 1 In the feature today. The test was styled the Eastern Avenue Purse, an allowance affair for older horses at a mile and seventy yards. Evergold, well fancied, was runner up, with Cathop third.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The New York Retail Code Authority announced last night through Grover A. Whalen, the chairman, that every store operating under the retail code must post by Monday the schedule of store hours and employe hours under which it has elected to operate.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Former Premier Paul Painleve, who was an exceptionally simple and modest man with the habit of receiving visitors in a purple dressing gown, will be buried tomorrow in the Pantheon with full national honors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Hogs of the best grades today were strong to 15 cents a hundredweight higher in price than yesterday, while other kinds were steady, and packing sows steady to 10 cents lower, but demand fell off toward the close. Cold weather was a factor in strengthening the market.
NEW YORK. Lord Dudley, who is sailing for England next week, will give a fare-well dinner Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, last night put four questions to F.H. LaGuardia, his Fusion opponent, in a speech to an enthusiastic audience of about 2,500 at Bay Ridge High School, Brooklyn. Addressing Mr. LaGuardia, Mr. McKee said:

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 4. -- The convention of the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania today issued a call for a general strike to begin in the northern field Monday morning to force recognition of the new union and adjust working conditions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Before the seasonal need for production credit develops next Spring there will be many hundreds of new organizations formed throughout the rural districts of the United States to assist in the financing of agricultural production.

In February, 1841, HENEY J. RAYMOND, a few days over 21, was working on The New Yorker, a literary weekly founded by HORACE GREELEY in 1834. New York History for October reprints a letter written by him in that month to ROBERT S. WAIE, an up-Stater who subsequently went to Vermont, where he was a Representative in Congress.

Six referenda will be submitted to the voters for their action on Tuesday, including four proposed amendments to the State Constitution one proposition and an expression of opinion on a local New York city law.

France's Now Forts. The great system of subterranean fortifications now approaching completion along 125 miles of the French northeastern frontier is vividly described with word and picture in today's Magazine Section.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- Two touchdowns by Paul Sweeney during the first half gave Taft School's eleven a 13-0 victory over Kent today. It was Tafts sixth triumph in the series, which commenced in 1911. A large crowd, including the fathers of Taft students who had returned for their annual reunion, was present at Rockefeller Field to witness the Red and Blue's fourth conquest of the season.

AIR transport, particularly passenger air transport, may have a chance in competition with the railroads on long hauls in regions where the climate and weather conditions are wellnigh perfect. Elsewhere we have nothing to worry us.

Brooklyn College scored its initial victory of the season yesterday, defeating Upsala, 34 to 0, before a crowd of 5,000. This was Brooklyn's second victory over the New Jersey rivals in three encounters.

ALL those who dearly love a lord will feel comfortably at home with Mrs. Belloc Lowndes's latest novel, in which the further adventures of Laura, Duchess of Richborough, are carried on in a milieu and atmosphere that only just fall short of those enjoyed, or not enjoyed, by royalty itself.

PITY can be the most uncomfortable in all the assortment of human emotions -- many of them uncomfortable -- both to give and to receive. Pity for something or some one weaker or littler than you are is not so bad -- you can Usually do something to help.

THE most startling items from the London front concern Talbot Jennings's "This Side Idolatry." It closed a week ago last night after only ten days run. (See the London letter northeast of this. -- Ed.) The reception was mixed and business was improving, but Mr. Miller decided to take it off anyhow.

THE type of weather associated with the name Indian Summer is familiar through personal experience to all dwellers in the Northern United States and Southern Canada and by repute to the rest of the world. Its praises have been sung by poets and essayists, by travelers and by staid men of science.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 6. -- China's proposed new Constitution, published in tentative form in order to draw public criticism, provides for a President and a Vice President, each to be elected for six-year terms and to be ineligible for reelection.

Southern women in New York who are interested in the restoration of Stratford, the home of the Lee family of Virginia, have reserved tables for the bridge party to be given Thursday afternoon in the roof garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation.

AN attractively planned little volume with delightful drawings that exactly suit the text. The tales, which are gathered from old journals and collections of French folkiore and tradition, have a fine authentic flavor of peasant life and a homely wisdom.

Tammany Hall reached the climax of its campaign last night at a rally at Carnegie Hall, at which the Hall's best orators presented the plea that the organization, under Mayor John P. O'Brien, had given the city the best possible government.

Larurent J. Tonnelle, one-time president of the North Jersey District Water Commission, who was deprived of property valued at $2,000,000 before he was born, as the result of one of New York's strangest court cases, died yesterday of heart disease in his home at 870 West 181st Street.

Although there are signs pointing to some modification of NRA policies, these policies stand as a corrective to the paradox of adjacent plenty and famine, C. T. Revere, economist for Munds, Winslow Potter, says in a report on fiscal, economic and commercial trends.

There was little change in general business conditions last week, retail trade declining moderately, partly due to unseasonally warm weather, and wholesale trade lagging in normal intra-seasonal manner.

THIS satire is not for children though Mr. van Loon originally intended it for them. They wouldn't be amused by the scene where "Sir John, an elephant of great charm," swings two gangsters around his head and dashes their brains out against a stone wall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- Displaying its best offense this year, Ohio State University swept Indiana off its feet in the first half of their annual game today and then coasted to a 21 to 0 victory. The game was played before 23,700 persons, including the Governors of both States.

DES MOINES, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Leaders of the agricultural strike of the National Farmers Holiday Association ordered a major offensive tonight after the Federal Administration rejected what they regarded as their own demands for price fixing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every now and then I report to your readers on the condition of my uncle, who has been sick for more than four years. His new doctor, who took charge last March 4, after performing a desperate operation is devoting practically his entire time to the old man's case; and I believe uncle is making headway, although the recovery is painfully slow.

VIENNA, Nov. 3. -- The past week was marked in Southeastern Europe by an official exchange of visits between King Boris of Bulgaria and King Carol of Rumania and the announcement by Foreign Minister Eduard Benes that the Little Entente would be welded into an economic unit with Czechoslovakia, establishing a system of planned national economy to make possible her participation in it.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 1. -- The controversy within the AAA as to whether landlords who join in the cotton reduction plan next year should be bound to keep the number of tenant families they have this year is being followed with interest in the South. Opinion is divided.
SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 4. -- In a game that was hard fought all the way Western Maryland today defeated the Bucknell eleven, 14 to 13.

The final chapter in the history of Joint Stock Land Banks is being written as a result of the "orderly liquidation" of the system prescribed by Congress in the emergency Farm Mortgage Act of 1933, according to James B. Madison of Madison Co., Inc., former member of the Federal Farm Loan Board and former president of the Virginian Joint Stock Land Bank.

PANAMA, R. P., Oct. 31. -- The ousting of President Juan de Dies Martinez Mera makes the fourth Chief Executive forced out of power by the Congress of Ecuador, and leaves the country facing the prospect of electing another President, who may suffer a similar fate.

Further development of the technique of international conference, rather than insistence on immediate disarmament coupled with "emotional" protest against war, was advocated yesterday by Dr. James T. Shotwell, Professor of History at Columbia University, as offering the greatest promise of ultimate world peace.

Twenty-seven gunners took part in the first regular shoot of the season over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the feature, a scratch event at 100 targets, C. J. Winninger and Z. G. Slmrnons each had 97.

Joseph V. McKee told 4,200 men and women at the Metropolitan Opera House last night that Tammany Hall was unfit to rule the city and that F. H. LaGuardia, the Fusion mayoralty candidate, was too dangerously radical.

For the golden jubilee exhibition of the National Horse Show Association of America, which will open on Wednesday afternoon in Madison Square Garden to continue through Tuesday, Nov. 14, a total of 1,359 entries has been received. Three hundred and ten horses, representing 158 individual owners, will compete in 110 classes during the thirteen sessions.
Mayor O'Brien went through the ceremony yesterday of conferring the widely known Verdun medal on fifteen veterans of the Fourth Division who brought their medals to City Halt for the purpose.
THE programs for the five subscription performances of the New York Orchestra, which Nikolai Sokoloff will conduct at Carnegie Hall beginning Nov. 28, are at hand.

THROUGH the street-car window I read a sign -- "Zu den Anil Konigen" -- painted with the Three Kings mounted on age-stained camels. It swung over the door of a bulging, squatty brick house in a little town of Southern Germany.

THE most striking thing about Mrs. Buck's translation of this rich and vigorous Chinese novel is its contemporary quality. It is a more convincing revelation of the "real" China than any Chinese tract or foreign analysis of the last few years.

THE dancing dervishes of the Mulawiyah, whirling madly in the dust of an Iraqi village, may not know it -- and it's not very likely that they do -- but Broadway has a peculiar branch of that fraternal order. The bonds of kinship may be intangible and there are certainly no formal ties, but nightly the local brothers betake themselves to the open streets and perform their ritualistic rhythms in the full sight of men.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 4. -- Revision of the regulations of the Rutgers University faculty and the appointment of about ninety professors to new advisory boards was announced today. Each college of the university will have its separate faculty under the changed regulations, and a graduate faculty, composed of all professors offering courses for graduate credit, is created.

Subscriptions amounting to $1,226,346 to aid the 600,000 victims of the anti-Semitic Hitler regime were announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the German Relief Fund. The funds are being raised under the auspices of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

Bond prices continued to fluctuate erratically during the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but within much narrower limits than was the case on the days immediately previous. The actively dealt in United States Government long-term issues finished 3-32 up to the same fraction lower, with several issues holding unchanged on the day.

WHILE plans for the limitation of air armaments are being matured by European nations in preparation for the putative resumption of the disarmament conference at Geneva, preparation for air defense and for building up personnel trained in the ground work of aviation goes on apace in Germany and in Russia.
MANLIUS, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- A powerful Hun School eleven from Princeton, N. J., defeated Manlius School today, 25 to 0. The game featured the Fall reunion of the Manlius old boys.

Speculators love a world in which nobody knows what is going to happen next. The more extreme the fluctuations in prices and values the happier they are. They make money out of the variations and imperceptibles of trade and finance. When prices are fairly steady, currencies stabilized and rates of foreign exchange shifting only by fractions, their profits are small.

A TOUR-PAGE newspaper with a vocabulary of only 900 words makes its appearance in New York City. The American News -- "News of the Week for New Americans" -- is put forth to aid foreign-born adults in learning English and in adjusting themselves to the American environment.

HEMINGWAY has had so many imitators and his manner has become so familiar in other men's writing that until we get back to his own work we half forget what Hemingway himself is like. He has created a fashion, almost a tradition, but it by no means completely expresses the man in one respect.
DURHAM, N.H., Nov. 4. -- Tufts rallied to score a 6-3 victory over New Hampshire before a Home-coming Day crowd today.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- All fears for the franc's stability have suddenly evaporated, as well as charges in the French press that the real object of America's purchases of gold abroad was to deprive France of most of her great gold reserves.

Held to one touchdown for three periods by the stubborn resistance of the City College football team Manhattan crossed the goal line thrice in the fourth quarter to gain a 24-0 triumph over the Lavendeir yesterday before 8,000 at Ebbets Field.
ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Andover won from the Harvard second freshmen today, 28 to 6. Andover counted twice in the first period, Off running 45 yards through left tackle for the first tally.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- The first week of the midseason showings maintained the siren line for dressy wear. Outstanding examples are Schiaparelli's high-necked evening gowns, encasing the figure in an unbroken sheath from shoulders to ankles.

The appearance of considerable numbers of green-wing teal along the North Atlantic coast this season has caused some sportsmen no end of trouble, since teal are among those species which enjoy greater protection this year than usual.

PEARY LODGE, THULE, Greenland, Oct. 14 (By Wireless to Copenhagen). -- Early on the morning of July 3, with the wind hissing across the frozen white plain of Camp Watkins, inland ice weather station of the University of Michigan-Pan American Airways Expedition, located seventy-five miles west of the Continental Divide between East and West Greenland, Max Demorest, navigator, with a lightly loaded sledge, disappeared from sight in the driving snow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The United States Government today peremptorily denounced its extradition treaty with Greece as proved ineffectual in the two attempts to extradite Samuel Insull, the Chicago utilities operator, to stand trial on Illinois and Federal charges.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 4. -- A strong running attack which refused to be bogged down by a water-logged gridiron gave the Nebraska Cornhuskers a 26-0 decision over the Missouri Tigers today and sent them over the semifinal hurdle in their quest for a third straight Big Six Conference football title.
DETROIT, Nov. 4. -- The hitherto-unbeaten Holy Cross eleven was the victim of an upset today when it lost to the University of Detroit, 24 to 0, before 20,000 spectators.

CONCLUSIONS of the fact-finding committee which it appointed to take testimony in the controversy between the principal airlines of the country -- which are also the air mail contractors -- and the Airline Pilots Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, over questions of pay and bases for pay are now before the National Labor Board.

KALGAN, Chahar Province, China, Oct. 8. -- On the broad, windswept plateau of Inner Mongolia there are no newspapers, but word travels fast. News of the changed status of the Mongols in Manchuria as a result of the establishment of Manchukuo has spread rapidly from one end of Mogolia to the other.

F. H. LaGuardia, Joseph V. McKee and Mayor John P. O'Brien have promised to work for the creation of a permanent shelter for "lone women," Mrs. Walter Nelson Sedgwick, president of the City Federation Hotel, announced yesterday. Mrs. Sedgwick made public statements from the three Mayoralty candidates.

Reform in the methods of workmen's compensation insurance as affecting city employes was promised yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., Recovery party nominee for President of the Board of Aldermen, in a speech at the Insurance League luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel.

Government financing of rail buying was approved in a report of the railroad securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association presented at the association's annual meeting last week, but the document raised the question how much rolling stock should be bought in the present circumstances.
BARCELONA, Nov. 4. -- Emergency measures were taken by the Governor General and other authorities tonight to cope with an impending strike affecting gas and electrical workers.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., Nov. 4. -- Harry Dering Sleight, newspaper writer and author of a number of books on Long Island history, died at his home here early today in his fifty-eighth year, after a long illness. He had continued writing by dictating to his secretary until a few weeks ago.

An unusual tax situation is brought about by a recent ruling of the Treasury Department holding that certain corporations will be permitted to deduct in their 1933 income tax returns the capital stock tax for two taxable periods: for the fiscal year ended June 80, 1933, and for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1934.

KURT JOOSS, who first became known outside of Germany a little over a year ago by winning an important international competition in Paris, has succeeded in this short time in establishing himself as one of the most vital forces in the development of the contemporary dance.

Looking toward the improvement of conditions under which employes in the real estate management field are compelled to work, Grover A. Whalen, local NRA Administrator, has appointed a committee to investigate conditions and report to the compliance board here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Henry Ford is in the fold. It could hardly have been as much of a surprise to the country generally as it was to Recovery Administrator Johnson, but Thursday, when the long-distance shooting between Washington and Dearborn had ceased and the smoke of a somewhat useless battle had subsided, there sat Henry among the other conformists to the NRA.

THE recent disturbances in Palestine, resulting in death and injury to civilian Arabs and police, were the third outbreak of mass violence in that country since the Jewish post-war colonization began. In 1920-21 there were demonstrations in Jerusalem and bloodshed in Jaffa; in 1929 Jews were massacred in Hebron and Safed and attacked in Jeru salem and in many settlements throughout the country; this time the chief disorders were again in Jaffa.

MAXIM LITVINOFF, Soviet Commissar of foreign Relations, who comes here to discuss terms for American recognition, is the first diplomatic envoy from the Russian people to the United States in sixteen years. No other European diplomat was ever entitled to go to Washington with a greater sense of personal triumph; for Litvinoff the trip is the dramatic culmination of a successful career.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Ten new securities registration statements were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. They involved more than $2,500,000 in securities and were listed as follows:

WASHINGTON. AN Executive order establishing an imports division in the National Recovery Administration gives to the American manufacturer operating under the recovery codes a court of first resort before which he can lodge complaints against harmful foreign competition.

UPPERVILLE, Va., Nov. 4. -- Surviving the hazards which brought down more than half the field at one time or another during the three miles, Mrs. Frank M. Gould's Daniel Soot won the third running of the Llangollen national steeplechase at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Football history was made at the Baltimore Stadium today as an inspired Navy team scored its first victory over Notre Dame, beating the South Bend eleven by 7 -- 0 before 40,000 spectators.

If I am asked why prohibition failed I can best answer not categorically but by pointing first to outstanding difficulties encountered in enforcing the law. Since most of our trouble was in the East, with New York City and New Jersey the glaring examples, it was natural for that section to provide notable reasons for our failure there as well as elsewhere.

WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 4. -- A superior Loomis School football team, defeated Tabor today, 37 to 8. A touchdown by Brooks in the first ninety seconds of play and two clean end runs for touchdowns by Gildersleeve featured the game.

FIFTY years ago, when the horse was the motive power of the pleasure vehicle, of short-haul transport and of agriculture -- when field work and field sport, road work and road sport, were equally his province -- the first National Horse Show was staged in the first Madison Square Garden at the northeast corner of Madison Square.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 4. -- Action on five public questions and the election of sixty-seven members of the Legislature will feature Tuesday's balloting in New Jersey. Polls will be open from 7 A. M. to 8 P. M.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- Miss Nancy Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Putnam of Overtheway, Rye, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the Apawamis Club here.

INDUSTRY and labor today face momentous decisions. The choices they make will determine whether our progress toward industrial self-government and a planned economy is to be Orderly and rapid or halting and marked with bitterness, needless misery and possible chaos.

THE recent announcement that engineers from New York's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were treating the water in Ashokan Reservoir for turbidity draws attention to the methods of safeguarding the city's water supply.

A the age of 100, so runs the argument of "The Journey of the Flame." Senor Don Juan Obrigon told the guests who had come to his birthday celebration, at his home near Rosario, in Lower California, this narrative of his adventures in the year 1810.

Special elections in six States on Tuesday are expected to fix the date, a month from today or tomorrow, for the end of the thirteen-year-old "experiment, noble in motive," the nation-wide prohibition of the use of intoxicating beverages by the American people.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 4. -- After a series of misplays seldom duplicated in college football, Northwestern's Wildcats battled today to a scoreless tie with the vaunted Gophers from Minnesota.
ROME, Nov. 3. -- When the German Nazis took office seven months ago the general impression was that an era of the most intimate Italo-German collaboration was about to be inaugurated.

Lincoln, Washington and Franklin items appear in a collection of furniture and decorations from the estate of the late Hiram Burlingham of this city and Newport which will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- There is much elation in Chicago over the extraordinary public interest displayed in the special World's Fair exhibit of paintings at the Art Institute. It closed last Wednesday night after breaking all records of attendance, American or European, for an exhibition of similar nature.

THERE is a picture in a recent number of Punch which New Yorkers may well take to heart. The scene is lower Broadway and occasion one of the city's characteristic receptions to distinguished guests. A blizzard of ticker-tape, torn pages from telephone books and other small paper fills the air, and the occupants of the skyscrapers are hard at work pouring more litter out of the windows.

EXPANSION is the order of the day among the trawler owners of Hull, England. Orders for twenty large craft of more than 400 tons and with a length of 150 feet have already been placed this year. The boats are to have a speed of twelve knots and to be fitted with such modern apparatus as echo-sounding gear, directional wireless and wireless telephone.

WHEN the microphone Legan to handle spoken words and music the warning was heard that broadcasting lurked in the sky as a menace to the theatre. Some said it would destroy the stage, because listening-in would keep people at home.

Two brilliantly colored posters designed to justify Germany's armament demands were prominently displayed in the foyer of the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin when the ship arrived yesterday after a day's delay because of foggy weather.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Milk went to 11 cents a quart here last Friday. That jump of one cent a quart is not being accepted by the consumer without protest, and in his objection to the arbitrary increase in his milk bill he is getting aid and comfort from the Mayor and the City Council.

PETER FREUCHEN came out of Hollywood last week, six feet six of him. His hearty arrival in New York was an unintentional rebuke to rock-bound metropolitans. The wooden left leg clumped cleanly on the floor of his suite at the Warwick and the thick brown beard nodded gently in corroboration of what he was saying.
ELSA ALSEN and Paul Althouse will be the soloists in this afternoon's all-Wagner program given by the Philharmonic-Symphony. They will be heard in excerpts from Tannhauser" and "Siegfried."

NEW ORLEANS. RECENT events have contributed to the belief, held in many quarters, that Senator Huey Pierce Long is threatened with loss of the political czardom of Louisiana. As observers describe his plight, he finds himself with his back to the wall in the most desperate fight of his career.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 (AP). -- New York State's alimony-paying husbands stand united today in a newly incorporated organization for a common cause-promotion of reforms in the law relating to domestic relations and aid for the incorcerated.

NOT often do artists achieve in words clear utterance of the inward compulsion that makes their work What it is. Because in this regard Edward Hopper must "be called an exception, it will be well, first of all, to study his terse, revealing credo that appears in the catalogue of the one-man show at the Museum of Modern Art.
James Monroe High School's football team scored in every period in vanquishing Morris High, 32 to 0, yesterday at James Monroe High School field. The Bronx rivals played before 2,000 spectators.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- The Australian racer, Winooka, accounted his second victory in the East before a crowd at 15,000 at Pimlico today when he ran six furlongs in 1:11, one-fifth of a second off the track record. He won by a length from Gold Step in a special $2,500 added invitation race.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The diplomatic corps has lost its oldest member in point of service.

IN the tract occupied by Rockefeller Center, gardens are reappearing. Some on roofs or terraces can already be seen from other buildings to the south. In what is called the Center's Central Plaza workmen are laying out a garden larger than Gramercy Park, in formal Italian style, including a sunken feature.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- The Boerse closed the week with profit-taking by professionals which depressed stocks up to 3 per cent. Heavy industrials, potashes and electricals were the chief sufferers. Individual issues were able to register fractional gains among the textiles, lignites and a few public utilities, while Reichsbank shares rose 1 1/2 per cent.

THE tireless statisticians at Fox have assembled some figures on "Cavalcade" as an example of how the cinema girdles the globe. About 40,000,000 persons already have seen the Noel Coward film. The estimate is that by next June the figure will have risen to 75,000,000, which is approximately the world audience of "The Birth of a Nation."
EXETER, N.H., Nov. 4. -- Exeter defeated Hebron Academy, 32 to 0, today. The Maine eleven had not been defeated previously this season.

Football -- Before 60,000 at the Polo Grounds Fordham met its first defeat of the season, losing to St. Mary's, while at the Yankee Stadium Tulane beat Colgate. Columbia defeated Cornell at Ithaca. Yale won by one point from Dartmouth, Princeton overwhelmed Brown and Harvard vanquished Lehigh. Notre Dame again was beaten, Navy winning.

AFTER a week more of concert appearances hereabouts Lawrence Tibbett goes to San Francisco for the opera sea son there. One of his roles, inevitably and as a matter of course, wil be that of Brutus Jones in the opera by Louis Gruenberg, after the drama of Eugene O'Neill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Socialists were never noted for the modesty of their demands on the resources of the Treasury. Their well-intended reforms usually outrun all sense of proportion to values in their anxiety to give in full measure, and more, of public property.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Syracuse defeated Perm State, 12-6, in a hard-fought game before 10,000 fans at Archbold Stadium today.

HAVANA, Nov. 4. -- All possibility of a change in the present Cuban administration through agreement between the government and opposing factions was dissipated this morning when the Students Directorate gave President Grau San Martin a vote of confidence.

THE great difficulty with a novel covering, as does this one, the lives of four generations, is that it can show only one or two aspects of those lives; at least, within the compass of a single volume. "The Tumult and the Shouting" is confined almost exclusively to the love affairs of its different characters.

DENVER, Nov. 2. -- Faced with the necessity of cutting the budget by an additional 13 per cent, raising the school tax rate or asking the taxpayers to authorize an issue of $859,000 of refunding bonds to care for obligations maturing in 1934 and 1935, the Denver School Board has chosen a combination of the first and last alternatives.

TOKYO, Oct. 12. -- Shipping depression and currency depreciation have reduced the price of round-the-world travel to round-the-city rates. It is now possible to go around the world, traveling comfortably by express train and liner, for approximately 2 cents a mile.
Led by Bill Kessler, who scored three touchdowns, the unbeaten Flushing High School eleven crushed Far Rockaway High, a Queens County rival, 25 -- 0, yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field.

Moderate gains were made yesterday by the principal commodities traded in on local markets, with the exception of cocoa. Trading was quiet in all staples and the advances were due rather to limited offerings than to active buying operations.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 4 Cy Grant and Homer Key, a fine pair of sprinters, sliced through Florida's defense today on two quick and brilliant thrusts that brought Georgia a 14-0 victory and undisputed leadership of the Southeastern Conference football race as Alabama eliminated Kentucky.
POTTSTOWN. Pa., Nov. 4. -- The Hill School football team continued its unbeaten streak by defeating the Princeton freshman seconds today, 19 to 0.

Swimming teams holding or sharing the lead in each of the three divisions of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament for senior high schools lost first place in the weekly series of dual meets yesterday.

THIS is Valentine Kataev's first novel since he wrote his gay travesty of the petty bureaucracy of Moscow in "The Embezziers." In the meantime he has written plays, he has extended his experience of the Russian worker, come in direct contact with an audience and lost most of his humor in the pragmatism of propaganda of the Soviet scene.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The administration today set up a new, organization within the Public Works Administration to facilitate loans to railroads for the purchase of equipment.

FLORAL, PARK, L. I., Nov. 4. -- Outstanding Bible Class leaders addressed the fifth convention of the State Federation of Men's Bible Classes today in the Methodist Episcopal Church. The convention closed with an evening program in the Sewanahaka High School.

ZURICH, Oct. 18. ALEXANDER VON ZEMLINSKY is one of the Austrian composers who has had great personal success as conductor in many parts of Europe. He is now 61 years old and has published many operas which have been performed in various German towns.

As indicated by the title page, this study has principally to do with Longfellow's interest in German literature, especially poetry, and not with his own poetry in general, or with his ranking as a poet. For this reason there is much that is fresh in the volume, and not a little which sheds something of a new light.

SOFIA, Oct. 15. -- Bulgarian churchmen have been surprised by the action of the ecclesiastical court in granting an absolute divorce to a retired army officer only forty-eight hours after the petition had been filed. Legal proceedings in Bulgaria commonly take months and even years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Pepper Gerhard of Overbrook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emilie Campau Gerhard, to Brooke Dolan 2d, son of Mrs. Thomas J. Dolan of Villanova. The wedding will take place in March.

VERBANK, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- With the running of three stakes today the ninth annual field trials of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America were completed on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club. Conditions again were almost ideal.

THE revolution in learning in Turkey has begun." So ran the headline in the Milliyet, the semi-official daily newspaper of Istanbul (the former Constantinople), announcing the recent opening of the reorganized national university.
THIS week seems to hold several items regarding the office of Arch Selwyn. Some of them may appear just a bit obscure, being, as they are, Reports and Rumors. But, anyway, here they are:

Blood on the moon is the prediction for Election Day. Old heads foresee a revival of wholesale fraud, violence and skullduggery, a return to the ungentle tactics of the plug-hat, brickbat and hob-nail period of city politics.

Several traditional football games and three championship cross-country runs will attract the chief attention of school sports fans this week, which will be one of the most and important and busiest of the Fall campaign for scholastic athletes.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 4. -- All Bermuda is awaiting with keen anticipation the staging here next week of the famous Freiburg Passion Play, rated second only to that produced periodically at Oberammergau. The leading roles will be taken by the Freiburg Players, while some fifty or sixty local amateurs have been recruited for the lesser parts.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 (AP). -- A new element of mystery developed tonight in the slaying of Joan Winters, American dancer, and an Indian government worker, with reports to authorities that the two had been traveling with another Indian Moslem, who left this morning for Egypt.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: In your issue of Sept. 3 Miss Edith H. Walton in reviewing "The Gold Falcon" writes that the publishers say that its authorship has been accredited to me among others The publishers know very well that it is not by me, and I resent their suggesting that it possibly may be Sophisticated reviewers should in any case be above snapping up publishers groundbait.

Although business on the Stock Exchange was about twice as heavy yesterday as on the previous Saturday, the price movements did not indicate any positive conviction on the part of speculators as to the direction in which the market should move.

Women interested in the completion of the new clubhouse for girls, which will adjoin the Convent of Marie Reparatrix, 14 East Twentyninth Street, will give a bazaar Wednesday and Thursday at the Plaza to raise money for the building fund.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- As a result of the establishment of industrial codes under the NRA, and the procedure of the National Labor Board, the conflict between the company or plant union and the independent union has become accentuated.

IN 1731 Voltaire dropped for a time the compilation of his "Dictionnaire philosophique" and began to assemble the documents which were to serve him in his "Siecle de Louis XTV" -- the "Great Century," which had closed sixteen years before.

IN the panorama of more than seven decades in "The World Changes," the Warner Brothers' production which is at the Hollywood, conspicuously fine performances are delivered by Paul Muni and Aline MacMahon. The sterling work of these players atones to some extent for the extravagant and at times ludicrous characterizations given by several other performers in the latter episodes.

THE beautiful, declares Mr. Gill, is that which is pleasing when seen, and art is the skill to make well what needs making. "Look after goodness and truth," he adds, "and beauty will take care of herself."

F. H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, set forth an eleven-point program embracing his policies and proposals for immediate action as Chief Executive of the city at a crowded rally of Fusion supporters at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.
To the Music Editor: May I ask the indulgence of your columns to forward an inquiry among your readers?

FOR some reason a paragrap or two about ozone in the report that Dr. C. G. Abbot prepares annually of the Smithsonian Institution's scientific activities received far more prominence last week than it deserved as a piece of news.
