Recalling that Tammany nearly forced the Stock Exchange to move to New Jersey, Albert Ottinger, former Attorney General and chairman of the Republican committee for the election of Joseph V. McKee, declared last night that F. H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, had proposed in Congress such an excessive stock transfer tax that the Exchange had threatened to move to Canada.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- All Germany is slated for another Sunday of self-denial and short rations tomorrow. The proceeds will again go to the government's fund for the relief of the unemployed and destitute, and this time the Nazi officials directing the Winter relief campaign are confident of their ability to achieve a more patriotic indulgence in the "single dish menu" than was observed at the first attempt.

The complaint of the Seatrain Lines, Inc., that Eastern and Southwestern railroads have refused to cooperate in the transportation of freight from its terminal in Hoboken to points beyond New Orleans will be considered by the Shippers Conference at its November meeting at the offices of the Merchants Association.

The fifteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice will be marked here by several large dances which for several years have become known internationally for their aid to disabled war veterans and for the lists of patrons including men and women distinguished in diplomatic, governmental, military, civic and society circles.

Today has been designated as "NRA Sunday" and many pastors will reach on the duty of all the religious forces to cooperate with the program laid down by President Roosevelt "in order that the churches through their interest and instruction may contribute to the common weal."
WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 4. -- Displaying a powerful running attack and a strong aerial game, Duquesne defeated W. and J., 21 to 6, today before a homecoming crowd of 12,000.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 1 -- Henry Ford, who has been so many things to Detroit, now has become the bright and shining knight of the motor capital, which watches with approval and some hopefulness his latest tilt with generally accepted standards, in his defiance of NRA.

ALICE ROOSEVELT was born into a great clan. At Oyster Bay alone there were sixteen Roosevelt cousins. On the distaff as on the sword side she had accomplished and charming aunts. In Massachusetts she had grandparents and other relatives who "spoiled" her a little, she thinks, and yet left ner unspoiled.
COMMACK, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Miss Judy Johnson's Mediaeval won the feature event at the third annual racing meeting sponsored by Sound Shore Aerie, F.O.E., today on the John Carll track.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4. -- The Lehigh football team put up a plucky battle against Harvard today but lost 27 to 0. About 8,000 saw the game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The text of the White House statement rejecting the farm price fixing plan is as follows:

Mayor O'Brien laid the last cornerstone yesterday afternoon in the new women's pavilion of Harlem Hospital, 136th Street at Lenox Avenue. More than 1,000 persons, white and Negro, attended and applauded the Mayor as he forecast the further development of the hospital into the greatest medical centre in the world.

The Lawyers County Trust Company, of which Alfred E. Smith is chairman, issued yesterday a statement of its condition as of Oct. 31, three months after the date of the merger of the Lawyers Trust Company and the County Trust Company into the present institution.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 4 (AP) -- The government apparently eased up on its foreign gold buying today, but advanced the price of the newly mined domestic metal from $32.57 to $32.67, a new high figure. At the same time the London price of gold decreased from $32.26 to $32.08.

PARIS, Nov. 3. -- Bankers and economists in America generally believe that the gold purchases abroad by the United States are intended to depreciate the dollar externally without inflating its buying power at home to any great extent, because that can only be accomplished through printing more paper money, according to Bertram Coles Neidecker, American head of the Travelers Bank of Paris.

Putting on a brilliant exhibition of running, Steven Szumachowski of Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady carried off the individual laurels for the second straight year in the twenty-first annual Columbia University A. A. invitation interscholastic cross country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times : If Stephen G. Rich will read the item, "What Is Expanding the Postoffice Costs?" as it appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, under my name, he will note nothing therein about Congressional speeches, in the manner of his comment in THE TIMES of Oct. 22.

THE leaders of the Soviet Union always have been America-conscious. While their propagandist campaign for world revolution included the entire capitalist geography, America was cited more often as the horrible example than any other nation.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Kanam mandible and Kanjera skulls discovered recently by an East African archaeological expedition were displayed by Dr. L. S. B. Leakey at a meeting of the Royal Anthropological Institute under the chairmanship of Professor G. Elliot Smith.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Mr. MacDonald has spoken. At last the Prime Minister hag broken a long silence to speak about the German attitude in the matter of disarmament.

A unanimous recommendation in favor of the hourly basis for the pay of pilots in air transport has been made by the fact-finding committee appointed by the National Labor Board to investigate matters in dispute between pilots and operators, it was ascertained here yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- Scoring two touchdowns in the final period, Yonkers High defeated Gorton High, 12 to 6, before 3,500 at Gorton High's field today. A 35-yard pass from McNally to Drohan gave Gorton its touchdown in the second period.

Whitfield W. Smith, president of the First National Bank of Paterson, N. J., and a director of several corporations, died Friday of a complication of ailments in his home at 293 Mountain Avenue, Ridgewood, N. J. He was 59 years old. Mr. Smith had been under the care of a physician for several months, but became seriously ill a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- General Johnson, as Recovery Administrator, gave the Ford Motor Company an opportunity today to avoid laying off 9,000 men a week, which action was asserted by the company to be necessary in order to comply with the thirty-five-hour average week provided in the Automobile Code.
KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Although East Side High was first to score, Kearny had little difficulty beating the Newark eleven, 15 to 6, today.

FIFTEEN years ago long-wave wireless flashed the news across the sea that the World War had ended. Since broadcasting began, each year the ether on Nov. 11 has pulsated with tribute to the heroes. This year a number of special programs honoring those who took part in the conflict are planned, while many of the regularly scheduled broadcasts will reflect the spirit of Armistice Day in word and song.

The 300 words of this list have been found, after long test, to be the first words needed by the foreign-born adult as he begins his life in America. It is said that they will carry him through all situations that he is most likely to meet in his contact with the new world. The list is issued by the Language Research Committee, affiliated with New York University.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Politics is the major industry in this city in this final week of the campaign for Mayor. Not in many years have we had a campaign so bizarre. Never has the outcome been more uncertain. Enthusiasm does not run high, but interest is intense.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- Yale swept Dartmouth from the list of undefeated teams today, turning back the Green by the slim margin of a point after touchdown.

A slight increase in hedging operations caused losses of 5 to 7 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, leaving the December at 9.57 cents a pound, compared with 9.56 on the previous Saturday.

A STATUE of Marshal Foch is to be erected at the place in the Forest of Compiegne where the armistice was signed fifteen years ago next Saturday. The place has been expanded into a circular clearing devoted until now to the glories of two immortal spurs of railway track.
WHILE none of our Presidents has ever played intercollegiate football, a number of the recent occupants of the White House have been much interested in the game.

PARIS. WHEN the couture season has run about half its course the natural selection of important style leaders begins to make its influence felt in clothes, and their choice generally turns to models that are more restrained and simple than the big show pieces that necessarily usher in any new mode. The smart silhouette tends to relax slightly and lines become less rigid.
PAWLING, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Two touchdowns in the last period gave Westminster School a victory over Pawling, 20 -- 6, today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4. -- The University of California and the University of California at Los Angeles fought to a scoreless tie before 45,000 spectators today, opening a series between the two divisions of the State school.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A further recession in the rate of productive activity occurred during the week ended on Oct. 28 after allowance for usual seasonal changes, according to the weekly survey of domestic business made public today by the Department of Commerce.
The text of the address of F. H. LaGuardia at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last night follows:

GENOA. IN November, 1931, we wrote on this page: "Campanile does not dare to collect and publish in one volume the series of sketches he wrote years ago, 'The Italian Street,' which is undoubtedly the best thing he has done."

A forty-hour week, with exceptions, and minimum wages ranging from $14 to $15 a week, depending on the population of cities, are fixed by the code of fair competition just completed for submission to the Recovery Administration by the trade book publishing industry.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- It will not be surprising if one of the ideas Norman H. Davis carries back to President Roosevelt is that Great Britain is the crux of the present disarmament problem. To understand that one need re-examine the problem from a different angle than most people do now and to deflate some of the current arguments whose soundness few seem to question.

More than 35,000 persons, including many school children, visited the twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. This total more than doubled that of the closing day last year. The exhibit will close today.
TORONTO, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The Amateur Athletic Union of Canada, at its forthcoming Winnipeg meeting, may oppose holding the next Olympic Games in Germany, says Lou Marsh in The Star today.

EIGHT years ago, two committees of the Colgate faculty, one consisting of younger men and the other of older men, were appointed to study the curriculum and to suggest any changes. They met independently, the president being the only member of both committees.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 4. -- The Amherst Varsity football team defeated Massachusetts State today by the score of 14 -- 0. Showing a steady attack led by Eddie Brehm, Jack Kehoe and Walt Murphy, Amherst scored in the second and third periods.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. AT the moment and as the New England saying has it, the Bostonian theatre is "between hay and grass." The good, and also the successful, plays, like Miss Le Gallienne's two pieces and Pauline Lord's "Christopher Bean," have departed.

St. Mary's of California beads home today with a victory over hitherto unbeaten Fordham, 13 to 5. And the Westerners carry with them, the memory of one of the hardest-fought, tightest struggles ever waged on any football field.

Patsy Valentino, 14 years old, of 74 President Street, Brooklyn, received serious injuries to his eyes yesterday when flames shot from a manhole of the New York Edison Company after an explosion beneath Eighth Avenue at Forty-second Street.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 4. -- Scoring twice in rapid succession in the second quarter, Muhlenberg today defeated Franklin and Marshall, 14 -- 3, in their annual meeting.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Last night's Chamber of Deputies' vote of confidence in the Sarraut Cabinet has settled nothing. Exactly half of the Chamber voted for it and nearly half voted against or abstained from voting. Those whose places are vacant because of death or illness made up the rest.

A NEW streamlined twenty-two-foot motor car capable of traveling sixty-five miles an hour is equipped with the National Broadcasting Company's new shortwave transmitter, three times more powerful than the old mobile outfit used for field events.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The agricultural price-fixing program presented by five Midwestern Governors was rejected by President Roosevelt today on the ground that it was impractical and would be unacceptable to most farmers.

When the voters go to the polls on Tuesday they should reduce their tax burdens by defeating unnecessary expenditures and by selecting capable officials, Louis S. Lebenthal of Lebenthal Co., dealers in odd lots of municipal bonds, said yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes, who has refrained from taking any part in politics, has broken his rule for the election of Tuesday to endorse proposition 1, the referendum which would authorize New York State to issue $60,000,000 in bonds for unemployment relief.

An overwhelming victory for F. K. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, by a plurality of 650,000 over Mayor John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for reelection, and by a 788,209 plurality over Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee, was predicted last night by William M. Chadbourne, Fusion campaign manager.

SHAVIANS, take notice! From now on the Irish dramatist desires to be known as Bernard Shaw, without any first name or initial. He has requested his American publishers, Dodd, Mead Co., to see that his name shall so appear on all title pages and notices.

LONDON, Oct. 20. TO re-create the creator of Hamlet, to draw from the fragmentary story of Stratford and London the sort of man Shakespeare's contemporaries might be supposed to recognize and yet a man not unfitted to wear the glorious garments woven for him by posterity -- this is the very ecstasy of ambition in a dramatist.

IN real life there may be something like an NRA code for detectives, but in fiction then is none. Let a detective seek out some secluded, peaceful spot for his vacation, and a crime wave is sure to break out and make him work when he should be resting.

Racketeers and Taxi Drivers. IT is more or less commonly believed by the anxiously taxi-cabbing public that, if there is any gypping to be done between driver and passenger, the driver can be depended upon to play the role of gypper with his passenger as a helpless gyppee.

MANILA, Nov. 4. -- Senator ManBel Quezon departed today on a new independence mission to Washington, thus writing a conclusion to the campaign for and against the Hawes Law, in which Senor Quezon was completely victorious, as the law has been definitely rejected.

VIENNA, Nov. 4. -- Austrian Nazis blew up the cables supplying the current for the two electric light systems of Klagenfurt, the capital of Carinthla, tonight and thereby interrupted Chancellor Dollfuss in the middle of a speech to members of the Heimwehr.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Below the Rue de la Vrilliere in Paris lies one of the biggest gold mines in the world. It contains more than 81,000,000,000 francs' worth of gold -- that is to say, more than $5,000,000,000 calculated at the present value of the dollar. But just how much it is worth to anybody nobody knows.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- With four minutes left to play and the game tied at 6 -- 6, Newt Wilder kicked a field goal from the 15-yard line today to give Columbia its first victory over Cornell scored on Schoellkopf Field.
The New York City electorate will express its choice for Mayor on a total of 4,114 voting machines, it was announced yesterday by the Board of Elections.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- On the day New York is balloting for its next Mayor the British Government will take up in Parliament all the challenges thrown it in recent elections to justify its foreign policy.

LILIAN HARVEY, who is trilingual, diminutive and blond, makes her second American film appearance this week at the Roxy in "My Lips Betray." Her Mayfair accent may be explained by the place of her origin, which was London.

NO matter who is elected Mayor of New Tork next Tuesday, the teachers of the city have his pledge that he will uphold the present protective laws in regard to education and the present salary schedules.

PROFESSOR OSBORN has taken "the greatest pleasure" in endorsing a book which, whatever its historical or scientific merits, is about the most uncompromising and aggressive plea for the maintenance of a Nordic and Protestant America, racially and nationally pure and undefiled, that has ever found its way into print.

ABOARD THE S. S. BERENGARIA, at Sea, Nov. 4. -- Maxim Litvinoff maintains aboard the Berengaria the rule announced at the Moscow Foreign Office that no Soviet official is to comment on the negotiations with the United States until M. Litvinoff reaches the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I may be soft and tender and practical business men will not agree with me. But I would like to know whether it is necessary to train babies in the use of deadly weapons just for the enrichment of toymakers.
A FEW sad weeks ago it was Pop Hart who left us. Now the art world mourns the passing of George Luks.
Mayor O'Brien's address at Canegie Hall last night follows:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 4. -- That Costa Rica will recognize the government of President Martinez of El Salvador in January, when the period of a year after its denouncement of the Central American treaties expires, now appears certain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The State Department was chosen today as the scene for preliminaries in next week's significant conversations between Maxim Litvinoff of Russia and United States officials.

Many prominent women interested in the welfare of the Public Education Association are working for the success of the exhibition of modern paintings which will open tomorrow afternoon with a tea at the Knoedler Art Gallery, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The New York Retail Code Authority, through its chairman, Grover A. Whalen, made public yesterday a summary of the retail code, seeking to clarify the many questions bearing on the code's operation and its meaning to retailers, consumers and employes.

BERLIN. THE German film season has opened with a picture that reminds us of our beloved "Zwei Herzen im Dreivierteltakt." It is in that bewitching three-fourth measure, the waltz, which Ludwig Berger has set into sound and motion in "Walzerkrieg" at the Ufa Palast.
PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Nov. 4. -- John D. Hamilton, gentleman rider, narrowly escaped injury in a spill during the Pickering Hunt Club's Fall meeting, held at Williams Corners, ne..r here, today.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Oct. 6. -- Decreases in exchange value of the American dollar are causing hardship to American residents in Manchuria, American consular officials, who have recently taken severe salary cuts, are particularly affected.

The Commodity Exchange, which was organized on May 1 as a consolidation of four exchanges with facilities for trading in six commodities, reported yesterday that trading in several of the staples had been of record proportions during the first six months of its existence.

A WEEK ago yesterday brought probably the best retail business of the season in many centres as a result of the first real cold spell. The spurt ended abruptly, however, when the weather turned warm and, in fact, made same new records for high temperatures at this time of the year.
DURHAM, N. c., NOV. 4. -- Duke University's powerful Blue Devils kept their undefeated record unmarred today by defeating Auburn's Plainsmen, 13 to 7, before a crowd of 12,000.

Peter S. Duryee, vice president of the Chase National Bank and general chairman of the annual membership roll-call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, announced yesterday the completion of a volunteer organization to start the campaign.

DUBLIN, Nov. 3. -- Official trade returns for the Free State for the year ending in September, just issued, show that by comparison with 1932 the country suffered a very considerable economic loss during the period.

The American dollar is intrinsically sound and, if left alone, would, within a reasonable length of time, return to par in the opinion of Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University. It is however. Dr. Nadler believes, highly doubtful whether the government will permit an appreciation of the dollar in the future.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Founding back by land to match Drake's marvelous overhead attack, Temple University tumbled the Missouri Valley Conference leaders in the Temple Stadium today, 20 to 14, before 12,000 persons. Temple tallied twice in the second period and once in the third.

Of the 300,000 young men and war veterans originally enrolled in President ROOSEVELT'S Civilian Conservation Corps, about 200,000 have "re-enlisted" for the extra six months recently authorized. The Administration anticipated little difficulty in filling their places, even with the cold weather in the offing, and the corps should now he at about its maximum strength.
A bitterly fought battle between Republicans and Democrats for control of the Assembly will be decided by the voters of the State on election day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Pennsylvania's football machine, which has been missing fire nearly all season, finally got all cylinders working smoothly today on Franklin Field and the Red and Blue romped away with its traditional game against Lafayette, 16 to 7.

THE Leningrad State Philharmonic will be the central musical organization in Leningrad during the current concert season, writes V. Bogdanof-Berezovsky from Leningrad. Close association with the Union of Soviet composers, the State Academy of Arts, the conservatories and independent groups is planned.

DOROTHEA WIECK, whom only tolerably fair memory will be sufficient to recall as the school teacher of "Maedchen in Uniform," will walk the screen of the Paramount on Friday, as the star of "Cradle Song." Mae West and her "I'm No Angel" (now in a fourth and positively final week at that theatre) have prevented Fraulein Wieck from reaching Broadway earlier in this, her first American picture.
NEW YORK. Mrs. William L. Harkness will give a dinner-dance on Dec. 20 at the Colony Club for her niece, Miss Eleanor Mullally, debutante daughter of Mr and Mrs. Mandeville Mullally.

PARIS, Oct. 26. AT last Paris has had Toscanini for a whole week, in which he directed three concerts. Since the war we have only seen him for twenty-four hours on tour with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4. -- A game but outclassed Centre College eleven lost to the University of Pittsburgh, 37 to 0, at Pitt Stadium today.
ITHACA, N. Y , Nov. 4. -- The dedication on Nov. 11 of two new fraternity houses on the Cornell University campus will mark a new epoch in the social organization of the university.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The lucid and unusually full account in THE TIMES of the conclusions of Dr. Robert Henseling of the University of Berlin that the Mayan culture is, on astronomical grounds, unquestionably old must have arrested wide attention.
Manhattanville College opened its field hockey campaign in successful fashion by vanquishing the New York Field Hockey Association, 5 to 1, in a challenge match at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

PARIS. ONCE more the grim old French convict ship La Martiniere has steamed slowly out of the harbor of the lie du Re with a full cargo of 673 prisoners bound for St. Laurent de Maroni in French Guiana.
MADRID, Nov. 4. -- El Debat, a conservative Catholic daily with a reputation for accuracy, is publishing a sensational article tomorrow concerning the Balearic Islands off the East Coast of Spain.

Speaking last night from Station WEAF, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, defended the plan which he presented last Wednesday in an address before the National Business Advisory and Planning Council.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Four men accused of having kidnapped on Aug. 18 Herman Miller, 18 years old, a messenger for the Lachsimkins Dental Labratories, were convicted today and immediately sentenced to State's prison for from thirty years to life. It was alleged they mistook Miller for a bank messenger.

The recent experience of stores or all sizes with leased departments suggests that chains of department stores based on chains of departnents "seem unlikely to succeed," according to a study issued yesterday of department leasing in department stores made by the Graduate School of Business Administration of Harvard University.

THE saxophone is still permitted in Germany, according to a recent official ruling, although the music which it chiefly adorns, American jazz, is forbidden. One of the reasons given for the decision was that the inventor was a German.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Corn became the market leader today as the result of an export sale of 25,000 bushels of No. 2 white grain to the United Kingdom, the first business of consequence in the domestic cereal with Europe in many weeks. The announcement was followed by heavy buying of December corn, headed by brokers who usually act for the Farmers National Grain Corporation, which had sold the cash grain.

FOR 1934 Nash presents three new lines of cars, each comprising five different body types. The new series, put on display throughout the country last week, are the Big Six, on 116-inch wheelbase; Advanced Eight, on 121-inch wheelbase, and Ambassador Eight, on wheelbases of 133 and 142 inches.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Nazi Premier of Prussia, told the court at the Reichstag fire trial today that "irrespective of how the trial may end, I will find the guilty ones and deliver them up for punishment."

HOLLYWOOD. THE first motion picture made by the Technicolor new three-color process will reach the screen early next year with the filming in January of Ann Harding in "The World Outside." Differing almost as greatly from the color films with which the public is familiar as those films did from black and white, the new process is being carefully guarded and its use restricted.

In this drifting world it is a comfort to find something solid you can stand on. A law faculty was inaugurated at Bristol University the other day. The Lord Chancellor got an LL. D. In return he showed to doubters and despairers the one citadel of stability and security:

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 4. -- "The Mining Laws of Ontario and the Department of Mines" is the title of a volume just issued by the Ontario Department of Mines. The author is Thomas W. Gibson, veteran Deputy Minister, who spent more than a year in research and writing.

THE voters of New York City, more than 2,000,000 strong, will elect a Mayor and a new municipal government next Tuesday. Hundreds of meetings have been held and thousands of words have been spoken in a campaign which ranks as one of the bitterest ever fought in New York.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 4. -- Alabama today unleashed its finest display of offensive power this season to turn back Kentucky's Wildcats by 20 to 0.

SHELLEY alone among the romantic poets undertook to reconcile an intellectual awareness of the real and suffering world of humanity with a faith in an ideal social order. His problems are similar, therefore, to those confronting every modern poet.

WITH the football season now well under way, the regular weekly games are attracting motorists in increasing numbers. The principal fields in New York City, where contests will be staged on the coming and following Saturdays, are indicated on the accompanying map, with the routes advised for their approach.

Decisions which will prevent many persons who have registered from voting on Tuesday were handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. The ruling affects all student nurses in hospitals and other public and private institutions.

LONDON. SOMETHING more than conventional respect for the memory of the recently departed has inspired the friendly, almost affectionate, tone of the press notices of John Galsworthy's posthumous work, "Over the River," called "One More River" in America.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2. -- For the first time in twenty-seven years Pittsburgh's Democracy feels seriously that on next Tuesday it is going to elect a Mayor and also some members of Council. Its Mayoralty candidate is Attorney William N. McNair, who in the bare and forlorn years of the party accepted nominations simply in a perfunctory manner, to help make up the ticket, for offices all the way from District Attorney to United States Senator.

CHAMBER MUSIC in its own right, as well as in that of its practitioners, came in for a "new deal" in the citation read by Dr. Herbert Putnam, Librarian of Congress, at the annual Founder's Day concert recently in Washington.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- The Pelham Charity League will sponsor an entertainment next Friday evening at the Manor Club. The artists will include Mrs. Frederick Reynolds, soprano, Mrs. Frederick Brophy, lyric soprano, and Mlle. Madeleine Le Fortier, violinist.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- There are now twenty-eight Republicans and fourteen Democrats on the Westchester board of supervisors, a comfortable majority for the Republicans. What the political alignment of members will be after the voting on Tuesday is the major subject of speculation throughout the county as campaigns draw to a close.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3. -- The Young Communist organization celebrated its fifteenth anniversary this week. With a membership of 4,547,186 boys and girls between the ages of 16 and 24 (68 per cent boys and 32 per cent girls), the organization has more than doubled its size since 1928.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 4. --0 Unleashing a speedy running attack in the third quarter, with Abe Mickal, brilliant sophomore, as the spearhead, Louisiana State University crushed South Carolina, 30 to 7, today before 8,000.

WHEN we speak of the classic in art, we think of simplicity of line, of elimination of all but essential form and of decoration that attracts attention to itself only as a part of the whole. With this in mind one feels justified in calling Augustabernard -- really Mademoiselle Augusta Bernard -- a classic modern.

LONDON. NEXT Thursday is the day when the annual bit of pageantry known as the Lord Mayor's Show winds slowly through the streets of Inner London with the beaver-hatted and ermine-robed Lord Mayor bowing from the windows of his massive gilded State coach.

A DISCRIMINATING eye, appreciation inspired by sympathy and understanding and sensitiveness to values characterize this study of our South-west by Mrs. Ickes, member of Congress from Illinois and wife of the Secretary of the Interior.

The need for a strong organization of parents and "right-thinking citizens" to protect the school budget and seek further financial aid for public education was impressed upon 600 parents yesterday at a luncheon of the United Parents Associations in the Hotel Astor.

Flying squadrons of patrolmen will be assigned to the Fusion and Recovery party headquarters on Tuesday for emergency action on reports of illegal voting or intimidation of voters at polling places, particularly in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 4.-- A smashing third-period attack dotted with spectacular long runs by Jim Carter and Duane Purvis carried Purdue to a 17-to-7 victory over Carnegie Tech before a home-coming crowd of 18,000 today.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- Recent social events in Paris of a charity and musical cast, as well as at the races at Longchamp, have seen, many New Yorkers in evidence. For the outstanding Autumn turf event, the Prix du Consell Municipal, which yields 210,000 francs to the winner, many of our well-known compatriots were in the brilliant throng to see an American-owned horse, Joseph E. Widener's Magnus, take second money.

The interest of exporters in possibilities of trade with Soviet Russia has been aroused to the highest pitch in sixteen years by the scheduled arrival here Tuesday of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, for conversations with President Roosevelt upon recognition of Russia by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Negotiations on the British debt to the United States in effect came to an end without tangible results today, according to a report in authoritative quarters following a conference between negotiators in the presence of President Roosevelt at the White House.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, turned his guns upon Mayor John P. O'Brien yesterday, declaring that the Mayor had demonstrated utter incapacity for civic leadership and asserting that many of the "economies" boasted of by the Mayor were things he should be "heartily ashamed of."

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Europe, and the world, is still demon-haunted by the fear of war. For the past nine months, advancing in intensity, this fear hag dominated the press and private conversation. When Germany broke off from the disarmament conference and abandoned the League of Nations a shudder passed through the soul of the world.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4. -- Lynn Hunt triumphed in the registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. H. W. Watts defeated N. E. Sprague in a shoot-off for the handicap cup, 23 -- 22.

Speaking of Shylock. Professor Tugwell's remarks at the Chicago Forum disclose, in the use of the term "Shylock," an unfortunate tendency toward oratory instead of the 'precise diction to be expected of an, economist. Shakespeare did an ill turn to lenders when he created this tragedy.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 1. -- The collapse of the Midwestern farm revolt so far as it embodied forcible interference with orderly markeding, was emphasized by the widely publicized conference of Governors at Des Moines, which ended Tuesday.
BLACKSBURG, Va., Nov. 4. -- Virginia Tech and Washington and Lee, two evenly matched elevens, struggled today to a 7-to-7 deadlock.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 14. -- The people who live in the area in Szechuen Province, which is under control of General Yang Sen, consider themselves lucky because the land tax in that area has been collected in advance only up to 1962. In an adjoining area the 1970 land tax has just been levied, and in more remote parts of the province farmers hold tax receipts dated clear ahead to 1992.

TWO exhibitions of more than passing interest are on at the Macbeth. One is made up of drawings by Robert Henri -- water-color, charcoal, sepia, ink and pastel. Within the individualism of the artist's vision there is striking variety in the thirty studies shown, and an easy comparison is afforded by the fact that they are all figure studies.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 4. -- Princeton's team of opportunists, supplementing its alertness with a power-house attack, crushed Brown, 33 to 0, at Brown Field today before a near-capacity crowd of 20,000.

PROPOSED diversion of $5,000,000 worth, of highway bonds to emergency relief, which the New Jersey voters will be asked to ratify at the coming general election, has resulted in the formation in renton of an organization to be known as the "State Highway Users Conference."

THE most serious objection which the radical progressives raise against existing tests and -- if I understand them correctly -- against any conceivable tests, is that any testing program inevitably becomes itself the goal of instruction and hence dominates, standardizes, stifles and devitalizes the whole of the teaching process subjected to it.

WRITING to Charles Francis Adams in 1903, John Hay said that his short experience in collecting through personal memories material for the Life of Lincoln had taught him that no confidence whatever could be placed in the memories of even the most intelligent and most honorable men when it came to narrating their relations with Lincoln.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 1. -- More than a year ago there was serious rioting in the federal penitentiary at Kingston, Ont., and repercussions of the affair still are being heard. Meanwhile vast quantities of good white paper have gone to the discussion of convicts, their rights and privileges; to their grievances, if any; and in a broader way to the general intent and purpose of this country's penal system.

The statements of oil companies, so far issued for the third quarter of the year, are generally considered satisfactory and show for the first time in several years that virtually the entire industry is operating on a reasonably profitable basis.
A good deal of the preparatory work that will make possible the enjoyment of many weeks of golf during the Summer months is now being carried on by the various district associations.

Applications by New York City, for Federal loans and grants totaling $35,020,000, of which $25,500,000 would be for rapid transit purposes, have been acted on by the New York State Advisory Board of the Federal Emergency Administration and will be forwarded to Washington early in the week, according to an announcement yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Miss Virginia Tucker Kent was introduced yesterday at a tea given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, at their home in Ardmore. The debutante was presented at the Court of St. James last May after attending school in Paris for a year.

Robert M. Harriss, Queens campaign manager for Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, made public last night a letter from former Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills, soliciting a subscription for the Fusion campaign fund.

IN many homes modest-sized rooms call for furniture which is compact and an arrangement which combines greatest convenence with happy decorative effect. Meeting the requirements often sixtes both the art and the ingenuity of the decorator.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tenor of the anti-inflationists' view is that business stagnation and the dearth of credit are due to the fear on the part of capital that the value of the monetary dollar may be curtailed and thus check its flow into natural channels.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2. -- An example of how projects of far-reaching importance may be held back for years through errors or "jokers" in legislation is furnished by the fact that the metropolitan Pittsburgh movement is now at precisely the point it was in 1928.

WHAT an opportunity we have been having this year, during what we call "the artless season," to take stock of American art; to observe ourselves against our former selves and against the art of foreign nations!
The address of Joseph V. McKee at the Metropolitan Opera House last night follows:

RICHARD STRAUSS'S "Macbeth," which was heard here last on Dec. 13, 1921, when the composer himself conducted the work with the Philadelphia Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House, will be revived this week by Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Prospects of early reorganization of millions of dollars' worth of real estate properties against which mortgage bonds are outstanding in this and other cities have practically vanished as a result of the application of the Securities Act of 1933 to the activities of reorganization committees, several committees have been informed by their legal advisers.

The Fusion campaign managers have arranged for a radio talk from Station WABC tomorrow evening, immediately following a broadcast by James A. Farley, Chairman of the Democratic National and State Committees, on behalf of Joseph V. McKee and his running mates on the ticket of the Recovery party.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 4. -- A smoothly functioning Rutgers team defeated Springfield today, 33 to 6. The Scarlet attack ran roughshod over the visitors and accounted for five touchdowns on uninterrupted advances of 51, 53, 60, 73 and 80 yards.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Army defeated Coe College of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, today by a score of 34 to 0 in a fast and interesting game. A crowd of 10,000 witnessed the contest played in Michie Stadium in perfect football weather.

Rounding out the week without any enthusiasm and showing more restraint than usual, the share market did not trouble itself yesterday to appraise the colorless week-end developments. There were no price changes of consequence on any of the Exchanges.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3. -- Wholesale and retail business was quiet during the past week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The University of Tennessee football team, with the redoubtable Feathers, clashed today with the hitherto unbeaten George Washington University eleven. Tennessee won, 13 to 0.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The booked Nazi cross is being blazoned on the armorial bearings of the feudal nobility of Germany. The Junkers and the other possessors of old and aristocratic names have discovered that Adolf Hitler is their natural leader.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2. -- Loss of three by-elections this week in widely separated parts of the country is a disconcerting incident in the experience of the Bennett government and correspondingly a source of much satisfaction to the Liberals, who see in it a clear indication that their term in opposition will come to and end when the Dominion at large has a chance to vote in a year or two.

Lester W. Paterson, judicial candidate on the McKee ticket, and James W. Brown, Flynn supporter in the Bronx, were character witnesses for Richard Nash, narcotic agent who received a five-year term and a $13,000 fine in a bribery plot, F. H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged last night.

The question of whether there should be a sale at this time of the assets of the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company will be considered at a meeting held at 10 A. M., Nov. 18, in the Federal Building.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2. -- Referendum petitions which have resulted in submitting the new Water and Power Act to the voters at a special election to be held Dec. 19 bid fair to bring water to Senator Hiram Johnson's mill and to give power to his somewhat wabbly candidacy for re-election to the Senate.

ACCORDING to the critic's credo, it is unethical to denounce a playwright for something he never intended doing. That may seem like Spartan ethics for one of the freebooting professions. Politicians have more supple standards: they can denounce at random, and they do.

The possibility of recognition of Russia by the United States has caused steamship lines to study the prospects for traffic. Estimates based on surveys of steamship statisticians range as high as $1.000,000,000 a year if Russia can be developed internally.

Successful functioning of the retail code will depend more upon the quality of the local enforcement of its provisions in each trading community throughout the country than upon any other single factor, according to a well-known retail authority here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Wisconsin and Chicago battled up and down Stagg Field all afternoon today, each in quest of its first Western Conference football victory of the season, but had to settle for a scoreless tie.

"A BROKER," said the brutal Dr. Johnson, "is a low in wretch given to dealing in shares." It was not a kind phrase, but in its eighteenth-century way it was no more censorious than the things which are said about brokers nowadays in places much more public than a coffee house.

An immediate speeding up in administration approval of NRA codes and a more interested attitude by the government were regarded as necessary here yesterday to stem the growing tide of resentment among business men. The fact that only sixty-four of the 1,500 national and 2,900 local codes submitted have been approved has left innumerable industries wide open to trade abuses, which have been intensified since the recent let-down in business, it was said.

IS there any one who is likely to be a better friend of the League -- a better child the League -- than he or she who is the bearer of its international passport?" It was with those words that Mrs. Swanwick, the British delegate, presented her report on refugee questions to a League Assembly.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 4. -- W. R. Coe won his second Latonia Championship Stakes today, Pomposity beating the leaders in the stretch to win by almost a length in the fifteenth and last running of a $25,000 added stake famous on the turf for many years.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4. -- It is learned authoritatively that Finance Minister Pinedo delivered a virtual ultimatum to the local subcommittee representing American holders of frozen credits at his first meeting with them. He gave them until Monday to agree to convert their blocked funds into a 4 per cent twenty-year loan, similar to the recent British loan.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- Yale received its first setback in the Intercollegiate Soccer League today when Pennsylvania captured a closely fought contest, 2 to 1.

Members of the Seventh Regiment of the National Guard gave their Autumn military ball last night in the armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The event, designated "A Siamese Fantasy," drew more than 2,000 guests, including many members of society, veterans of the regiment and men prominent in military circles.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2. -- Loss of three by-elections this week in widely separated parts of the country is a disconcerting incident in the experience of the Bennett government and correspondingly a source of much satisfaction to the Liberals, who see in it a clear indication that their term in opposition will come to and end when the Dominion at large has a chance to vote in a year or two.

Lester W. Paterson, judicial candidate on the McKee ticket, and James W. Brown, Flynn supporter in the Bronx, were character witnesses for Richard Nash, narcotic agent who received a five-year term and a $13,000 fine in a bribery plot, F. H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged last night.

The question of whether there should be a sale at this time of the assets of the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company will be considered at a meeting held at 10 A. M., Nov. 18, in the Federal Building.

Erling Olsen, 38 years old, so-called Mayor of "Hoover City," the collection of makeshift shacks of unemployed men and women at the foot of Columbia Street, Brooklyn, died early yesterday in Long Island College Hospital a few hours after be had been struck by a hit-and-run automobile driver at Dwight and Delevan Streets, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Nov. 4. -- The Republicans will "retain all the seats in the Assembly that we now hold and will gain four or five in addition," according to a prediction made tonight in a joint statement by Majority Leader George R. Fearon of the Senate and Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- Trinity came from behind in the fourth period today, scoring twice, and defeating Wesleyan, 14 to 6. Wesleyan's tally came in the second period when Burton, who replaced Huntress, threw a clever forward pass to Johnson, who carried the ball 35 yards for a touchdown.
Sixty-eight students of the New York University College of Engineering have been placed on the honor roll of that division, Dean Collins P. Bliss announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- National banks to a total of 133 were licensed, chartered or liquidated during October, according to a summary issued today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

NYACK, N. Y., Nov. 4. -- Rockland County, looked upon as one of the pivotal points in the figrht for control of the State Assembly, is expected to have an unusual turn-out of voters at Tuesday's election. Few halls in the county have been able to accommodate the crowds at Democratic and Republican meetings during the campaign.

The North Atlantic Union, recently created by the merger of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American steamship lines, will be directed in the United States jointly by Christian J. Beck and John Schroeder, it was announced yesterday. Both men have assumed their new duties with title as managing directors.

With the most hotly contested Mayoralty campaign in many years concluded, more than 2,000,000 voters are expected to throng to the polls on Tuesday to exercise their franchise in New York City. Through the State the close fight of the Republicans and Democrats for control of the Assembly, together with mayoralty battles in many other municipalities will bring out large numbers of additional voters.

ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 1. -- Although the Florida Constitution specifically prohibits a State debt, Governor Dave Sholtz and his Cabinet are back at home speaking enthusiastically over their Washington visit, which had as its objective the borrowing of some $2,600,000 from the Federal Government.

The five members of the Municipal Economy Committee who resigned last Friday in protest against the city administration's failure to cut the 1934 budget reconsidered their decision yesterday and rejoined the committee in the hope of making further budget cuts.

Great interest is feeing shown by women prominent in the worlds of society and politics in next Tuesday night's performance of "Champagne Sec" at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Goddard Neighborhood Centre. Already there has been a large subscription.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Regular North Atlantic air service is confidently expected by authoritative aviation circles here to be inaugurated within the next two years.

SEATTLE, Nov. 1. -- When Washington repealed its bone-dry law last year it also erased from its statute books all laws for the control of the liquor traffic and is now looking forward to the ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment with considerable anxiety.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. THE German theatre is making a feverish search for the play of the people for the people -- the play that is rooted in the soil, that draws its strength from the theme of manual labor, that can contact the masses and that they can be made to understand.

PARIS. THREE years ago I tried to describe the business cycle as a drama in five acts. Act I was joyfuL Factories had large orders. Raw materials, which were eagerly sought after by every country in the world, were increasing in quantity.

While there has been a definite slowing down of collections in the last month and the number of past due accounts has increased, credit executives interviewed yesterday declared that the underlying situation is still strong and that no immediate basis for fear exists.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 4. -- With the brilliant ball carrying of Bill Ingram spurring the attack, Lawrenceville conquered Choate, I 18 to 0, before an enthusiastic gathering today.

Meeting for the first time since its appointment by Commodore Junius S. Morgan, the America's Cup Committee chose W.A.W. Stewart as chairman and George A. Cormack as secretary, it was announced yesterday at the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- William G. Shepherd of Locust, N. J., staff writer for Collier's Magazine and former newspaper man, died of bronchial pneumonia today at George Washington University Hospital. He became ill here on Monday and was transferred to the hospital from his hotel on Thursday.
Retail sales are not measuring up to earlier expectations and heavy inventories still retard reorders, according to the market report prepared especially for the THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

IF there's anything in the saying that the theatre claims its own, it has taken a long time to do so in the case of George F. Hummel, For the author of "The World Waits," the play of the Antarctic now at the Little Theatre, is the same Fred Hummel who has played round the fringes of the theatre all his life without ever before yielding to the temptation to throw his hat into it.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 4. -- The undefeated Panzer College soccer team registered its fourth victory of the season in defeating Long Island University today, 6 to 1. Belaniz's four goals increased his season's total to ten.

The joint committees representing investors in certificates and bonds of the Fidelity Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Ridgewood, N.J., announce that J. J. Newberry and J. Blauvelt Hopper of Ridgewood and Daniel Van Winkle of Paterson are the proposed voting trustees who will act if and when the plan of liquidation proposed by the committees is approved and declared effective.

The city-wide campaign for $4,000,000 of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee of New York, of which James G. Blaine is chairman, will be begun at a dinner which will take the form of a "town meeting dinner in welfare city" at the Hotel Astor on Nov. 16, it was announced yesterday.

Colgate's long reign among the nation's undefeated football teams came to a dramatic termination yesterday. Tulane's Green Wave, assuming tidal force, conquered the fighting Red Raiders, 7 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium in an intersectional battle before a crowd of more than 18,000.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 12. ALREADY at the very outset of this year's theatre season Hungarian playwrights have taken a leading place. Budapest producers seem to realize that dramatic art is a field in which this country excels and one of Hungary's products in constant demand abroad.

I REMEMBER my secret misgivings one night in the Spring of 1928 when Miss Leona Hogarth called me up to say that a friend of hers had written a dramatization of "Thunder on the Left" and would I read it? I thought perhaps I had misunderstood.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 1. -- With the prospect of work ahead for 100,000 heads of families between now and Jan. 1 on a wide variety of public works and emergency relief projects, Governor Robert H. Gore, recently returned from Washington, believes that "prosperity has turned the corner for Puerto Rico."

NEW HAVEN, Cohn., Nov. 4. -- Only college graduates or candidates who have equivalent training will be admitted to the Yale School of Nursing beginning next year. Yale will thus be the first school of nursing in the world to make completion of the college course an entrance requirement, it is believed here.

THE first thirteen years of broadcasting read like a Horatio Alger yarn of science. The opening chapter is set against the background of a garage from which the pioneer KDKA raised its feeble voice to the winds. Three days ago Pittsburgh celebrated this anniversary, humble indeed, compared to Radio City, which goes on the air for the first time on Saturday night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 4. -- Miss Becky Lanier of Greenwich today captured the Bedford Challenge Cup and with it the hunter trial championship of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds. The title test climaxed the annual trials staged over the estate of the late John W. Sterling on Quaker Ridge Road.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 4. -- The undefeated Panzer College soccer team registered its fourth victory of the season in defeating Long Island University today, 6 to 1. Belaniz's four goals increased his season's total to ten.

The joint committees representing investors in certificates and bonds of the Fidelity Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Ridgewood, N.J., announce that J. J. Newberry and J. Blauvelt Hopper of Ridgewood and Daniel Van Winkle of Paterson are the proposed voting trustees who will act if and when the plan of liquidation proposed by the committees is approved and declared effective.

The city-wide campaign for $4,000,000 of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee of New York, of which James G. Blaine is chairman, will be begun at a dinner which will take the form of a "town meeting dinner in welfare city" at the Hotel Astor on Nov. 16, it was announced yesterday.

Colgate's long reign among the nation's undefeated football teams came to a dramatic termination yesterday. Tulane's Green Wave, assuming tidal force, conquered the fighting Red Raiders, 7 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium in an intersectional battle before a crowd of more than 18,000.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 12. ALREADY at the very outset of this year's theatre season Hungarian playwrights have taken a leading place. Budapest producers seem to realize that dramatic art is a field in which this country excels and one of Hungary's products in constant demand abroad.

I REMEMBER my secret misgivings one night in the Spring of 1928 when Miss Leona Hogarth called me up to say that a friend of hers had written a dramatization of "Thunder on the Left" and would I read it? I thought perhaps I had misunderstood.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- It is officially reported that industrial production in September rose to 72 per cent of the output in September, 1928, which was a boom year. But the consuming industries are mostly stagnant, retailers complaining that business is poor and getting worse.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- The St. Bonaventure football team defeated Canisius College, 15 -- 6, today before a crowd of 10,000 in the outstanding gridiron upset of the season in Western New York.

A senior fours double-blade crew representing the Pendleton Canoe Club triumphed over a junior eight-oared shell from the Union Boat Club in a special handicap race over the three-quarter-mile course on the Harlem River yesterday.
The text of the address by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, at the Socialist rally in Madison Square Garden yesterday follows:

Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, assisted by Elsa Alsen and Paul Althouse, presented yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall two major examples of Richard Wagner's concern with love and its ramifications, These were the duet of Venus and Tannhauser, preceded by the overture and bacchanale, all in the Paris version of the opera, and the closing scene from "Siegfried."

It is understood in shipping circles here that if the Cunard and White Star lines are merged there will be an amalgamation of offices throughout the country and the piers in this city for economy and efficiency which are now being carried out by the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American lines.

A protective committee for holders of Imperial Russian Government obligations, originally sold in this country in the amount of $75,000,000, announced yesterday that it would seek a voice in the negotiations between President Roosevelt and the emissaries of the Soviet Government which will explore all questions now standing in the way of American recognition of the Stalin government.

While many leading Eastern prep school football elevens were winning their semi-final games of the campaign, Lawrenceville brought its season to a successful close on Saturday with a well-earned and brilliant three-touchdown triumph over Choate.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 5 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.8, which compared with 71.6 a week ago, 71.5 two weeks ago, 72.2 three weeks ago and 71.1 four weeks ago. The average of three weeks ago was the highest price of the year to date; the highest July figure was 70.4.

Affirming their party's pledge to better conditions for the working masses, and attacking the three principal Mayoralty candidates as "tools of the bankers," the Socialist candidates yesterday staged a rally in Madison Square Garden which was attended by about 15,000 enthusiastic followers.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The propaganda campaign preceding next Sunday's German election and referendum is now in its most intensive stage. Chancellor Hitler and his chief lieutenants are touring the country in fast airplanes and fast motorcars and by train and addressing huge meetings nightly.

Lutherans from all parts of the metropolitan area crowded the Hippodrome yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting in celebration of the 450th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther, which will be on Friday. The hall seats 6,500. Latecomers stood about the walls of the two galleries.

Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, denied yesterday that he ever had speculated in the company's stocks or "unloaded" any of them in anticipation of the suspension of dividends.

Speaking last night in the third of a series of five programs arranged by the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, which was broadcast over the Columbia radio network and the Red and Blue networks of the National Broadcasting Company, Walter Lippmann, editorial writer, urged support for the agencies being mobilized for the campaign of the Winter of 1933-34.

CHEMNITZ, Germany, Nov. 5 -- There is much excitement in this centre of the German cotton glove industry, half of whose product goes to the United States, about reports of increased customs levies on their goods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Main- taining that under code control and the President's re-employment agreement 4,00,000 have been put back to work, the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business, made public today, gave optimistic interpretation to developments under the administration's recovery program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Estimating the 1933 gross income of farmers at $6,360,000,000, or 24 per cent over that of 1932, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today predicted further improvement in agricultural conditions in 1934 on the basis of progress already made in the administration's recovery program.

Multitudes of adults, as well as adolescents, are at present out of touch with life because they have remained moral infants, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, minister of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, said in his sermon yesterday.

Mayor O'Brien, F.H. LaGuardia and Charles Solomon, rivals for the mayoralty, were heard over radio Station WOR yesterday afternoon in a political symposium. Joseph V. McKee was invited but did not attend. "The time did not fit in with his schedule," his representative said.

The danger that some of the voluntary hospitals in New York City may be forced by economic conditions to discontinue their services is discussed by Henry J. Fisher, president of the United Hospital Fund, in Better Times, organ of the Welfare Council, out today.

Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor, made public at his Hotel Biltmore headquarters late last night a statement "of facts that have come to my attention," concerning the connection between F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee, and Richard Nash, former Federal narcotic agent.

In The Nation Mr. HENRY L. MENCKEN as one of the contributors to a symposium called somewhat inaccurately "Books I Have Never Read" apologizes for "having read too much." Some of the confessions will enrage other elders of the intelligentsia. He has read " Paradise Lost " and "Paradise Regained."
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The old familiar battle cry "Beat Michigan" resounded tonight from the camp of Iowa's Hawkeyes.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Sir Herber Samuel, former Secretary of State for Home Affairs and Liberal leader, has just returned from the United States, where he observed the workings of the National Recovery Administration. He has written two articles on his conclusions, of which this is the first.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Here's How Again, owned by Donald W. Evans of Philadelphia, tonight was judged best in show at the first annual specialty exhibition of the Boston Terrier Club of Connecticut, staged at Moose Auditorium.
A program of expansion which will provide fourteen posts for former German scholars was announced yesterday by Dr. Judah L. Magnes, chancellor of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

Discussing friendship as a fine art, the Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, that there were conditions and an "if" in friendship that must be met if people were to remain friends.

FEIPING, Monday, Nov. 6 -- Although the Princes of Inner Mongolia and representatives of the Nanking Government have not yet reached a basis of understanding on Mongol autonomy, the go-betweens are gradually working closer, according to an adviser to the Panchen Lama, exiled Tibetan spiritual dignitary, who has arrived in Peiping from Failingmiao after interviewing Prince Teh Wang, the autonomy leader, and General Huang Shao-hsiung, Nanking's goodwill delegate.

JOHN MASEFIELD recently quit his Oxford home on Boar's Hill because he couldn't stand the noise of the airplanes. Shortly afterward, during a visit to America, he complained that the pace of modern life was entirely too swift. Yet his new novel of the tea clipper races of the China trade, "The Bird of Dawning" (Macmillan, $2.50), moves with all the headlong pace of a story by W.C. Burnett about Chicago gangsters.

Serge Lifar made his long-expected American debut last night before a brilliant audience at the Forrest Theatre, and proved how unreliable advance reclame can be. Although it is claimed for him that upon his bronzed shoulders has fallen "the mantle of Nijinsky," the resemblances between this last protege of Diaghileff and the great star of the Russian Imperial Ballet are so elusive as to be quite undiscernible.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The New York Carroll Club girls' field hockey team lost to the Germantown Cricket Club at Manheim today, 7 to 1. The Philadelphia girls led at half-time, 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The upshot of the White House conference yesterday on the British war debt is that on the next instalment day, Dec. 15, Great Britain will in all likelihood once more tender a "token payment," and it will again be "received" by the President.
QUEBEC, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Boston Bruins, though lacking their mainspring, Eddie Shore, today had enough power to take a rough, tough exhibition game from the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of New Jersey, announced yesterday that Governor A. Harry Moore would be the party nominee for the United States Senate next year, and that former State Motor Vehicle Commissioner William L. Dill would be the Democratic candidate for Governor.

Winooka, the Australian race horse, arrived at Belmont Park yesterday from Baltimore ready for his appearance in the International Speed Test, one of the events listed for the United Hunts meet tomorrow. The invader, fresh from a brilliant six-furlong triumph at Pimlico, was shipped here with Good Advice, Curacao and Blue For Boys.

In a hair-raising finish that had the crowd of 15,000 spectators in an uproar, the New York Giants professional football team staged one of the season's great last-ditch comebacks yesterday at the Polo Grounds to defeat the Portsmouth Spartans, 13 -- 10, for the first time in four games.

The Hugo Stinnes Corporation and its principal and wholly-owned subsidiary, the Hugo Stinnes Industries, Inc., both of which were incorporated in 1926 in Maryland as holding companies for the varied interests of the estate of Hugo Stinnes, announced yesterday a plan to pay interest at the rate of 4 per cent on their dollar obligations despite the German Government's scrip payment plan of June 9.

As football moved into its climactic month, the opening games of November proceeded to make it more evident that there is no single team among the major elevens -- unless it be Princeton -- that stands forth vividly above the pack.

New York State has placed privately a new issue of $20,000,000 eight months' 1 per cent notes, it was learned yesterday. The notes, which will mature on June 8, 1934, were sold at par to the Bank of the Manhattan Company and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., each taking $10,000,000.

A total of 2,730,300,000 passengers used the rapid transit, street surface, Hudson Tube and bus lines of the city during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1933, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. The total included figures for the city's Independent System, but excluded bus companies not reporting to the commission and certain bus lines which obtained certificates during the fiscal period.

The difficulties encountered in enforcing the provisions of the National Recovery Act are discussed from the builder's point of view by Myron L. Matthews in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. Leaders in the building construction industry who recognize the compelling force of public opinion in the ultimate success of the NRA are now suggesting the dissemination of official data on controversial points to correct misinterpretations of the law, the Dow Service writer declares.

The pouring of more than 120 tons of refuse a day into the Harlem and East Rivers within two miles of Ward's Island constitutes a standing menace to health and property values in the vicinity, Dr. George A. Soper, consulting engineer for the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

Three women and a 16-year-old girl were injured yesterday afternoon when a water-jacket used for providing hot water exploded in the kitchen of an apartment on the second floor of a two-family dwelling at 88-27 Fifty-fourth Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, AT SEA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- At noon today Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's antarctic expedition aboard this flagship was approximately 200 miles south of Balboa, C.Z., preparing to cross the Equator tomorrow night.

Five hundred Italian Fascists, who gathered last night in Public School 3, Fifth and Adams Streets, Hoboken, heard William A. Meyer, Heinz Spanknoebel's successor as leader of the Friends-of-New-Germany movement to this country, declare that he and his associates were determined to plant that organization firmly in the United States "regardless of the obstacles placed in our path."

Prince Alexis Mdivani and his wife, the former Miss Barbara Woolworth Hutton, are among the passengers arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others coming on the ship from the Channel ports are Jose Iturbi, the pianist, accompanied by his daughter; Joseph Szi geti, Hungarian violinist; Mme Vera de Villiers, British contralto; Gifford Cochran, theatrical producer, and:

A group of young women headed by Miss Charlotte Morgan, who are aiding in the arrangements for the forthcoming dinner dance Dec. 16 at the St. Regis in behalf of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children, will meet today at a luncheon in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis to complete plans for the benefit.

The horse show already has taken over Madison Square Garden. Although the Golden Jubilee exhibition of the National Horse Show Association will not start until Wednesday, the advance guard of attendants invaded the arena last night and set about making preparations for the annual exhibition, which will run until a week from tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes The Omaha World-Herald as saying, "It [agriculture] is falling to receive the bare cost of producing what it sells," and that "it is impossible to get along without the farmer."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Hugh S. Johnson set out for the West tonight in an endeavor to clear away opposition and discontent that have massed in the farm belt against NRA and the rest of the recovery program.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- Japan has transferred its wool buying from Australia to Argentina and Uruguay as part of its campaign of reprisals against Great Britain for restricting Japan's textile imports. The resultant active buying of fine crossbreds for Japanese mills was largely responsible for the sharp increase in prices in the last fortnight which makes the wool market the only bright spot in the Argentine economic picture.

DELHI, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Representative John Davenport Clarke of Fraser, member of Congress for the Thirty-fourth New York District since 1921, was killed near here tonight in an automobile accident. He was 60 year old.

Pre-election statements were issued yesterday by John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and Abraham Kaplan, Tammany campaign manager, predicting the re-election of Mayor O'Brien; by Postmaster General James A. Farley, and Harry M. Durning, Recovery party campaign manager, on behalf of Joseph V. McKee, and by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, and William M. Chadbourne, Fusion campaign manager, predicting the election of F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor.

Attendance figures of every flower show held at the American Museum of Natural History in the last eighteen years were exceeded yesterday. Whether the new record will excel the figures of even remoter epochs will be determined as soon as museum officials get a chance to thumb back through the files.

Appealing to the six States that vote tomorrow on repeal to end "the wet-dry debate of the past decade" within "forty-eight hours," Postmaster General Farley declared last night that the return of the "open saloon" would be barred under new liquor-control systems.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr. were among the dinner hosts at the Greenbrier last night. They entertained in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stevenson, who departed for New York tonight after a week's stay.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Announcement of the dean's list of Yale University undergraduates who have a scholarship average of 80, and are therefore free from classroom attendance requirements, today disclosed that more than 27.9 per cent of the students in the academic department, the Sheffield Scientific School and the School of Engineering have attained that rank.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 5 -- A convention of the Kappa Alpha fraternity, commemorating the one hundredth anniversary of its founding as the first on the Williams College campus, was ended here today with a reception at which the organization was host to its friends in the college, the town and the neighborhood.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Gangdom and the law will come to grips again this week in the government's second big legal battle involving the kidnapping of a man of wealth.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 4 -- The American experiments are judged here with great mistrust. It is not doubted that the continued purchase of gold abroad will depreciate the dollar further, but the effect of the depreciation itself is questioned.

Abraham Chait, 34 years old, a truckman of 1,240 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, and Herman Borenstein, 21 years old, of 439 Manida Street, the Bronx, one of Chait's employes, were arrested yesterday by Department of Justice agents charged with conspiracy to harbor and conceal a criminal.
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, will close his campaign tonight by a tour through Queens and a speech at 11 o'clock in the New National Hall in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- General Johnson, Recovery Administrator, in a statement today, defined the status of code authorities in relation to the enforcement of codes. He declared that they had power to settle labor disputes when labor was adequately represented on the committee.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- The Italian Chamber of Deputies will come to the end of its allotted five-year span of life early next year and Rome is full of reports regarding constitutional changes which will be introduced before the next Legislature assembles.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Norman Ebbutt, Berlin correspondent of The London Times and new president of the Association of Foreign Correspondents in Berlin, is the latest foreign journalist to incur the displeasure of the Nazis.

Bert Godfrey, prosperous Brooklyn marine engineer, father of Carol Godfrey, the blonde dancer who, with an East Indian civil service employe, was found slain in an olive grove near the Garden of Gethsemane outside Jerusalem on Friday night, said last night he would ask the State Department to investigate and report on the circumstances leading to the death of the young woman.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- An efficient forward passing defense, that clicked to perfection when its goal was threatened, enabled the Boston Redskins to gain a 10 -- 0 victory today over the hitherto undefeated Chicago Bears, the National Professional League champions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The administration will carry the case for its recovery program to the farmers and others in the West who are protesting against the NRA. The decision was reached coincident with President Roosevelt's refusal to accept price-fixing measures suggested by five mid-Western Governors, who reported to him that there would be a formidable uprising of agriculture unless quick relief came from the Federal Government.

Declaring that the civic duty of every Catholic was as important in the eyes of the church as his religious duty, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday exhorted the congregation to "consider carefully the issues of the coming election, fraught with greatest importance and significance for God and nation alike."

VIENNA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A sweeping shake-up of Austria's governmental machinery under the supervision of a federal commissar, authorized to ferret out and eliminate officials and government employes of Nazi sympathies, was announced by Chancellor Dollfuss in a speech today.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Naotake Sato has been appointed Japanese Ambassador to Paris and Hachiro Arita has been named to succeed him at Brussels. Coming simultaneously with the visit to Washington of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, this development directed attention here today to what is described as a new orientation of Japanese policy.

Seeing JOHN J. CHAPMAN in life, many must have remarked his Jovian appearance, as AMELIUS PAULUS, seeing the statue of Jupiter, exclaimed that " the Jupiter of PHIDIAS was the Jupiter of HOMER." CHAPMAN was also Jovian in his Olympian attitude. He represented the "old perfection of the earth" and spoke with all the assurance of a god about mortal things.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Taber Sears will give the first in a series of Sunday afternoon receptions for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tyson Scully, whose marriage took place recently, next Sunday at their home, 1,060 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A demand for the resignation of the committee of Senators investigating the primary election in Louisiana was made today by Mrs. Hilda Phelps Hammond, chairman of the Louisiana Woman's Committee which is working to unseat Senators Long and Overton.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 5 -- The Fall series of dinghy sailing was started today on the Long Island side of the Sound under the auspices of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Only four races were held, three divided into classes. The breeze failed in the afternoon.

VIENNA, Nov. 5 -- In a baroque room in the Ballhausplatz where Metternich once worked to make a new Europe, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss revealed for the first time in an interview last night the details of a maturing plan for a venture more modest but possibly not less significant -- the constitution of the new Austria.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The world's legal fraternity was invited today by Dr. Hans Frank, Nazi Reich Commissar for Judiciary, to pass on the legality of Germany's claim to equality in status with other nations.
