His appeal came in the course of an address at the inaugural session of the German Academy for Law in Berlin Town Hall.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- With or without the consent of the Allies, Germany is preparing for a defensive war, Colonel Alexander Powell, war correspondent and author, told 1,000 members and guests of the Boston Chapter of the Foreign Policy Association here yesterday.

Commodity prices backed and filled last week with virtually no results except in silver, cocoa and rubber, in which the futures markets made substantial gains. The rallies were attributed to the decline of the dollar day by day. Trading was light in staples, and the markets appeared to have no definite trend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The State Department's sharp note denouncing our extradition treaty with Greece, which the American Minister was instructed today to deliver to the Minister of Foreign Affairs of that country, has been made public here.

Formation of a group of physicians to assist fellow-doctors who have suffered hardships as a result of the Hitler regime in Germany was announced here yesterday. Headed by Dr. Bernard Sachs, who is president of the Academy of Medicine, the committee has opened offices at 2 West Forty-fifth Street and is seeking funds.

The Sutton Place Playground at Sutton Place and Fifty-fifth Street was dedicated yesterday by the Community Councils of New York in honor of August Heckscher, philanthropist. More than 300 fathers, mothers and children witnessed the ceremony.
HAVANA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Grau San Martin administration tonight began preparing stern measures to restore public order.

Civilization was defined by the Rev. Demetrius B. Zema, S.J., head of the History Department at Fordham University, in the first of a series of Sunday conferences in the university chapel yesterday afternoon.

By scoring a touchdown and four extra points against Geneva on Saturday, Halfback Tinney of the Davis and Elkins eleven moved into a tie for the lead in the race for Eastern individual scoring honors with his team-mate, Winter. Each now has registered a total or 67 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Receipts of hogs at eleven leading markets last week were 18 per cent larger than in the preceding week and 22 per cent more than in the same time last year, yet the top price of $4.30 a hundredweight on Friday was 5 cents higher than on the preceding Friday and only 5 cents under the high point at the opening of the week.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The departure of 754,000,000 francs of gold as shown by the Bank of France statement for Oct. 27 has no connection with American gold purchases and was caused solely by withdrawals of foreign capital as a result of the fit of pessimism concerning France's financial position which arose from the fall of the Cabinet.

Nina Gordani, an animated and picturesque performer, grave a costume song recital at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening, by way of a return to the local stage. She was cordially greeted in the varied song's and imitations of a lyric diseuse.

In what was announced as his only New York piano recital of the season last night in the Town Hall, Ossip Gabrilowitsch assembled a splendid Chopin and Schumann program to the obvious delight of an audience which filled all the available seats in the hall and occupied much of the balcony's standing room.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The advocacy of the so-called "child-labor amendment" to the Constitution by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, is a plain case of fishing in troubled waters. We are living in a time of great distress, and the agencies relieving that distress, particularly so far as destitute children are concerned, are worthy of all support.

The persistent report that Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, was supporting F.H. LaGuardia for Mayor in return for the promised aid of Mr. LaGuardia if Mr. Mills should run on the Republican ticket for President in 1936 brought no comment from Mr. Mills yesterday when he was reached by telephone at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 5 -- Responsibility for the initiative in the mutiny last February on the battleship De Zeven Provincien in the Dutch East Indies is placed on four East Indian marines by the committee of investigation, which has just finished its task.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Seven persons were killed late this afternoon in one of the most unusual airplane accidents on record when an airplane crashed into a house near Red Bank Airport, exploded and set fire to the house.

Two plays will have their premieres this evening. They are "Thoroughbred," the work of Doty Hobart, which stars Florence Reed, and "Doctor Monica," a translation from the Polish, with Alla Nazimova. The first is at the Vanderbilt Theatre, the second at the Playhouse.

Professor Werner Hegemann, an international authority on town planning and architecture, arrived Saturday aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines to spend a year lecturing at the New School for Social Research and elsewhere in America.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 5 -- Confidence in President Roosevelt and his administration is growing steadily throughout the country, Postmaster General Farley said here this evening in an informal address at a Democratic rally in the Garden City Hotel.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Award of 141 additional scholarships and aids to freshmen in Harvard College, aggregating $41,735, was announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Many encouraging reports of business in this territory which were issued last week were tempered with statements of restricted buying. This was attributed to the NRA and other conditions, including unseasonably warm weather, which affected sales of heavy goods.
At enthusiastic mass meetings and over the radio F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion candidate for Mayor, continued his campaign yesterday, confident of victory tomorrow.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The Cosmopolitan Club of the New York Field Hockey Association suffered its first setback of the season today, losing to the North Jersey Field Hockey Association Reserves, 3 to 1, at Branch Brook Park.
With the most hotly contested city campaign since the McClellan-Hearst battle in 1905 ending tonight, four possible results of tomorrow's election were indicated yesterday:

Opposition to Russia because of the past actions of its government, or even because of its atheistic activities, is Unjustified and should be replaced by recognition, the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, said in a sermon there yesterday.

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Middle Atlantic Baseball League "is in the best shape in its history," Elmer Daily, president, told a meeting of club owners and executives today. He added that the eight-city circuit probably will remain intact for the 1934 season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Cash disbursements aggregating $138,070,389 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during October increased the total of actual loans by that agency since its establishment to $3,234,762,178, according to a monthly summary of its operations made public today.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- An unofficial Jewish boycott of Germany in the British Empire was proclaimed tonight by a conference of 400 Jewish organizations representing about half of the 300,000 Jews in Great Britain and Ireland.
F.H. LaGuardia went to Harlem's "heaven" last night and found out that "Father" Divine -- not the Fusion ticket -- is the evangelist who will lead the City of New York out of its wilderness of sin.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 5 -- The volume of trading in cotton contracts on the Cotton Exchange here last week was moderate mainly because of the absence of speculative activity, of the limited amount of hedge selling for this time of the year and of the cautious attitude of traders in view of their uncertainty as to the government's policy in regard to further support of commodities.

As most of the officers and men of the fleet come from States east of a line drawn from Chicago to New Orleans, the announcement of Assistant Secretary ROOSEVELT that " the Presi"dent has authorized a cruise of the "United States fleet into the Atlantic "in 1934" must have been received by them with satisfaction.

Big State Registration. All of New York State is excited about tomorrow's election. The registration figures show this plainly. Here in the city the registered voters are within one-half of 1 per cent of the registration last year, a Presidential year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Trade Commission, in another ruling on the operation of the Securities Act, made public today, held that underwriters may distribute information concerning an offering during the twenty days from the time of filing to the effective date of the application, if the data furnished conforms to that contained in the regulation statement.

Torn and tattered banners that once flew above battlefield and trench were carried proudly up Fifth Avenue yesterday as veterans' and patriotic organizations paraded to the Church of the Heavenly Rest for the annual massing of the colors service.

John Charles Thomas, baritone, admirably accomplished in the art of diction as well as song, gave his second Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Mr. Thomas, in this program, covered a very wide range of song literature, and did so in the most finished style.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers defeated Chicago's hapless Cardinals, 14 to 6, before less than 5,000 fans today.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- On the quay commanding the approach to the Chamber of Deputies has just been built a reinforced concrete structure resembling a blockhouse.

Part of the rather evident halt in trade recovery results from last Summer's abnormally rapid speeding-up of production, whereby any increase of consumers' Autumn requisitions was anticipated. Part of it must be put down to honest perplexity as to how the new "recovery codes" would work.

More than 400 members of the Supreme Anchor Clubs of America received communion at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross yesterday, and afterward heard Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel, declare the necessity for "a return to symbolism in everyday life."
Henry Ford was criticized yesterday for his stand against the NRA by the Rev. Lyman R. Hartley, pastor of the Fort George Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and 186th Street.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 -- Fifteen Arab prisoners, who were held in the Acre jail in connection with the Jaffa disturbances on Oct. 27, were released on bail today by order of High Commissioner Wauchope. All were members of the Arab Executive or leaders of the Arab Youth organization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Farmers in a large part of the grain belt are dissatisfied with prices, asserting that the returns for their products are too small, compared with what they have to "buy. However, there have been few years of recognized equilibrium between farm and commodity prices.

In connection both with the monetary policy of the Roosevelt Administration and with the operation of the new Securities Act, reference is frequently made to the failure of capital to seek long-term investment. Without considering the influence of either of these factors in relation to others which may have been operative, a brief summary will explain what is meant by the "drying-up" of capital for new investment.

Aside from a flurry or activity in the coat market early in the week, the wholesale markets here generally were quiet last week. Retailers held orders down to immediate requirements, owing to comparatively large stocks on their own shelves.

PEIPING, Nov. 5 -- After a relentless all-night battle, Chinese special police armed with heavy artillery recaptured the city of Funing, held by bandits for five weeks. Their merciless fire killed 800 bandits and forced the survivors to flee to the hills.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- America's decision to buy gold abroad was unfavorably received at first. In England and other countries and even in France a portion of the press expressed the fear that such purchases might become large enough to constitute a serious menace to countries still on the gold standard, particularly France.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Violence in the farm strike -- halt ing of a market bound freight trail near Lawton, Iowa, and the release of eight carloads of livestock by pickets -- tonight brought a statement from Governor Clyde L. Herring that unless peace officers could maintain order the State "would step in."

Report's on the deer hunting season which now is in full swing in this State have not yet been made, so that no official count of the kill is known. Unofficially it is said that hunters have had more than usual success.
The Brooklyn Celtics scored an upset in the American Soccer League competition yesterday by toppling the New York Americans, 2 -- 1, at Starlight Park.

ELBING, Germany, Nov. 5 -- Chancellor Hitler told thousands, gathered here in East Prussia to- day, that the policy practiced by Germany in regard to other na- tions' domestic affairs entitled Germany to the same consideration from foreign powers.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Financial experts are predominantly skeptical as to the effectiveness of President Roosevelt's latest measures. The press mostly confines itself to asking what is really happening in America, professing to be unable to discern a homogeneous Washington plan.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The spectre of empty dinner plates will be met this coming Winter by the forces of thirty-eight State Governments which have assumed the role of purveyor of relief to unfortunate and unemployed.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The wind-up of the war-debt negotiations in Washington leaves British opinion unmoved. The public is beginning to feel that, so long as the United States is unwilling to settle on a

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,405,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Etablissements Violette, a French firm making Vouvray wines, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The local representative is Roger Grillon, a member of the 50-year-old company. The firm has not had an agency in this country previously.

Mayor O'Brien continued his campaign with appearances in various parts of the city yesterday, and he will end it late tonight without any slackening in the pace that he has kept up for more than three weeks.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The new monetary policy of the United States is occupying financial London's attention to the exclusion of almost everything else. The first feeling of alarm which was aroused here and on the Continent has subsided and given place to a calmer view.
AFTER what St. Mary's did at the Polo Grounds and Tulane did at the Yankee Stadium, this area can be considered devastated territory. It's a clear case for the Near East Relief Committee.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 5 (AP) -- An amateur crew, composed of men and women from widely scattered communities, set sail today in a 92-foot, two-masted schooner on a voyage intended to carry them around the world. The cook is the only "professional" aboard.

The opinion that "chiselers" who seek free publicity in the newspapers rarely get far is expressed by Raymond C. Mayer, sales promotion expert, in a book, "How to Do Publicity," published today by Harper Brothers.

Fusion leaders made a concerted effort yesterday to answer the cry of radicalism raised against their Mayoralty candidate, F.H. LaGuardia, by Joseph V. McKee, his opponent on the Recovery party ticket.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Nov. 1 at 64, against 64.3 a fortnight before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before Great Britain abandoned the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Excavations on the site of what is believed to have been one of the principal shrines of Hou T'u, earth goddess of the ancient Chinese, set up about 113 B.C. by the Emperor Han Wu Ti, have brought to light valuable material evidence of prehistoric religious practices, according to report of archaeologists associated with the Freer Gallery of Art of the Smithsonian Institution.

An experimental series of circulating exhibitions in settlement houses, which may be the forerunners of neighborhood branch museums, will be started tomorrow by the Metropolitan Museum of Art with the public opening of a show of Chinese and Japanese art at the University Settlement, Rivington and Eldridge Streets.

Ferdinand Pecora, Recovery party candidate for District Attorney of New York County, asserted in an address broadcast last night at 6 o'clock over WJZ, that he had information that "mobsters and gangsters" would be active at the polls tomorrow. He appealed for support on the strength of his record of twelve years in the District Attorney's office.
A plea for Christian devotion to peace was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Allen Clay Lambert, pastor, in his sermon at the St. Thomas Lutheran Church, Topping Avenue and East 175th Street.

ATHENS, Nov. 5 -- The Insull case's not wholly unexpected leap into the diplomatic category remains half complete tonight, with the decoded and translated denunciation of the barely a year old extradition treaty awaiting delivery by Minister Lincoln MacVeagh to the Foreign Office.

The New York Public Library has just placed on exhibition a little group of early drawings by George Luks, who died Oct. 29. These drawings, thirteen in number, are swift little pencil sketches, done con amore, and for that reason peculiarly revealing.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Mary Louise Martin, arrested here in connection with the international espionage activities uncovered by the disappearance of Lieutenant Pentikainen of the Finnish general staff, is now believed to be identical with the mysterious woman spy, "Marie Louise," whose name figured last Spring in the London court martial of the Highlanders officer Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart, prisoner in the Tower.

Z.G. Simmons won the high scratch cup in the first Sunday shoot of the season over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He triumphed by breaking 96 out of 100 targets. Simmons also captured the distance prize with a string of 25 straight from the 22-yard line.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Charles Seaback of Astoria, N.Y., increased his lead in the national pocket billiard championship today, defeating Walter Franklin, Kansas City, 125 to 61 in fifteen innings for his fourth victory. It was the only game played.

MOSCOW, Nov 5. -- The Donetz Basin, the Soviet Union's "Pennsylvania" coal fields, has been requested to bring production up to schedule as a sixteenth anniversary gift to the nation. The mines have been operating for the past month between 95 and 99 per cent of the schedule, and it is hoped to push the volume to more than 100 per cent -- 125,000 tons daily -- this week.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles outwitted the Cincinnati Reds in the final minutes of play and won a National Professional League football game today, 6 to 0, after a see-saw battle.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- The Women's National Committee for Education Against Alcohol in a statement issued tonight through its chairman, Mrs. William Tilton, said that "time alone can tell whether the words 'tragic failure' best fit the Democratic administration" or prohibition.

No one can blame the members of the Municipal Economy Committee for offering to resign. As they say in their letter to Mr. GRIMM, they had accepted this call to duty on the understanding that their suggestions would be welcome and that Mayor O'BRIEN really meant what he said about reducing appropriations.
BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 5 -- Declaring that the NRA's "Buy Now" campaign, because of "monopolistic prices," was receding instead of progressing, Senator Borah called today for revival of anti-trust laws.

An almost audible sigh of relief has gone up from the whole city at the fact that the municipal campaign is over. It has been kept for weeks at a high pitch not only of excitement but of clamor and confusion. Never were the ears of the public so bethumped with personalities, charges and counter-charges, great swelling words of vanity and endless promises.

That the question of immortality is beginning to recapture the attention of men and women was the belief expressed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Gustav A. Carstensen, pastor emeritus of Holyrood Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue at 179th Street.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, at Sea, Nov. 5 -- News that Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, will begin direct conversations with President Roosevelt as originally proposed without any preliminary stage undoubtedly brightens the prospect of a successful issue in the forthcoming negotiations.

A drive to bring new collectors into the art field by volume selling methods, a general campaign for reasonable prices, instalment selling and rental of pictures will be made this Winter by art dealers throughout the country. The plan, which is under the direction of the American Art Dealers Association, national organization of art galleries, was announced by F. Newlin Price, chairman of its committee on new collectors.
Sales of dwellings formed the bulk of realty trading in New Jersey over the weed-end:

Mr. ROOSEVELT was quite right to confer with the embattled Governors of the Western States. Even in the stress and pull of other more important duties, he could not refuse to listen to them or to express sympathy with the hardships of many of their constituents. But it was his duty also, after discussing with them their demands and their plans, frankly to tell them that their whole scheme was both fantastic and futile.

John L. Kohler, 23 years old, and John Bills, 21, both members of the New York University football team, were injured yesterday when an automobile in which they were riding was in collision with another car at the intersection of Roosevelt Avenue and Fifty-second Street, Woodside, Queens.

The General Motors Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on its common stock, in addition to regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share. It was the first extra dividend paid by the corporation since 1930.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically today, but developments were not of a kind to stimulate outside buying. While wheat advanced at one time on local buying, it broke about 2 1/2 cents a bushel from tire early top when buyers on the bulge attempted to sell out.

THOSE football followers who like to juggle statistics should look at the record of Gonzaga University on the Coast. Here's a team that has played five games, hasn't won any of them and hasn't scored a single point so far this season. Yet it must be a good team on the face of that same record.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler heard argument yesterday and reserved decision in a suit to test the constitutionality of the emergency law for the rehabilitation of mortgage-guarantee companies in which it was contended by a guaranteed mortgageholder and in behalf of the fourteen mortgage companies now in rehabilitation that the law is invalid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- It will not be many days before final hearings are held in Washington on the permanent NRA code for newspaper workers. In the meantime the last touches are being put on a wages-and-hours arrangement for certain types of employes.

Many dinners will be given in advance of the performance of "Champagne, Sec" tonight at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The American Federation of Labor granted a charter of affiliation to the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America today in accordance with the decision of the Executive Council at the recent convention of the federation.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The British Cabinet, with a full report before it of the futile efforts of Ambassador Sir Ronald Lindsay and Sir Frederick Leigh-Ross to negotiate an agreement in Washington on the war debt, decided today on the nature of the pronouncement on the debt question which Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will make in the House of Commons tomorrow.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Governor A. Harry Moore reiterated today that despite announcement to the contrary by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, he will not be a candidate for nomination for United States Senator next Spring.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- The builders ''put the bouquet" on the great new palace of the League of Nations today. The phrase translates the name for a European festival in which the architects, contractors and workmen celebrate the laying of the final stone -- symbolic of the completion of all the rough workby putting above the finished roof a large bouquet of evergreen branches.

This week the British Government is to defend itself in the House of Commons against charges particularly in relation to its foreign policy. As a sort of preliminary practice, Mr. BALDWIN, Lord President of the Council, made a speech yesterday at a political luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Reports that monetary purchases of gold have been made in London and Paris were confirmed today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. "Substantial amounts" have been acquired through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he said, but it was emphasized that there had been no change of policy and no intent seriously to disturb the finances of other nations.

In one of the largest anti-trust actions ever undertaken in this district, the Federal grand jury yesterday handed up three indictments, naming as defendants five labor organizations, eighty individuals and sixty-eight corporations in the fur industry.

Our Local Loyalties. All the party forecasts for today's poll implicitly credit New York City with a virtue it is commonly accused of lacking. It is the spirit of neighborliness. All the headquarters assume that borough loyalty will count.

Nathan Straus Jr., Recovery party candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, closed his campaign in Brooklyn last night with a plea for a business administration to meet a business crisis in the city's affairs.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP). -- A warning to investors to investigate thoroughly the standing of any stock salesmen seeking their business was issued today by Attorney General Bennett.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- "Upon the basis of a competitive, unregulated selfishness, a stable, satisfying prosperity cannot be built, as we thought," said Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, today in opening" the annual lecture course in Woolsey Hall of the New Haven Church Union.

DETROIT, Nov 6 (AP). -- Henry Ford's "layoff plan" to bring average Ford working hours within the NRA auto code went into effect today in the huge River Rouge motor plant, and with it came indications that the Ford-NRA controversy has moved into another phase of silence.
Several business buildings and flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
Besides the Mayoralty election in New York City, the attention of the country is centred today upon several other elections of more than ordinary importance in various sections.

The vogue of the seven-man line with the box secondary appears to have seen its day and the coaches who continue to employ it, regard-- less of the forward passing strength of the opposition, have been subjected to a considerable amount of criticism.

Whatever "benefit" may subsequently accrue to the ensemble training and scholarships organization of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society from last night's chamber music concert in the Town Hall, the first beneficiary was undoubtedly the audience.

Heralded as "the most important art event of this and many seasons," the group of paintings from the Ambroise Vollard collection went on view yesterday at Kneedler's, to remain until Dec. 3. This week and next, admission will be charged ($2 yesterday and 50 cents thereafter), proceeds going to the Public Education Association.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The Soviet Government today formally protested against statements made by General Herman Goering, a member of the Reich Government and Premier of Prussia, in connection with his testimony at the Reichstag fire trial last Saturday.

The address of James A. Farley declaring he would vote for Joseph V. McKee and the Recovery party candidates, while advertised as the "big bertha" of the Mayoralty campaign, turned out to be just "a popgun," F.H. LaGuardia said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The hearing on the code of fair competition for investment bankers was terminated today by Deputy Administrator A.D. Whiteside because the NRA was not satisfied with the compact.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The weather today came to the assistance of the Democrats in their struggle to overturn the Assembly at tomorrow's election and gain control of the Legislature. They have not controlled it since 1913.

Proton, electron, neutron, alpha particle or helium core, deuton or heavy hydrogen nucleus, positron -- six supposedly fundamental "bricks" of which some have been violently blasted out of stable atoms and others ejected from unstable, radioactive ones by spontaneous explosions -- can matter be so complex?

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 -- Luckite, the Stefan the Great gelding, owned by J.W.Y. Martin, was an easy winner of the featured Glenmore Steeplechase Handicap at Pimlico today. Luckite won by five lengths from High Kilted, with Aries another three lengths away in third position.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. G. Beekman Hoppin are at the Pierre.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6. -- Harvard's football forces have suffered two losses, It was made known today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Following is the text of General Hugh S. Johnson's address on the NRA before the Chicago Association of Commerce and the Illinois Manufacturers Association today:

Police Commissioner Bolan, the Attorney General's office and officials of the Honest Ballot Association concurred yesterday in the opinion that there probably would be less disorder and violence at the polls today than is generally anticipated.

ROME, Nov. 6. -- The unification of the ministries of War, the Navy and Aviation, which has been among Premier Mussolini's intentions since he took over the Ministry of War last July, became, to all intents, an accomplished fact today.

Urges Retailers Buy Under NRA. While it is not specifically provided for in the retail code, recommendation has been made by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association that retailers adopt the policy of patronizing manufacturers, wholesalers and jobbers who are enrolled under the NRA, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Already confronted with the first direct challenge of the constitutionality of the NRA code governing the oil industry, the Federal Petroleum Administrative Board today faced another vital decision on whether to prohibit the lease and agency system by which big companies control the retail outlets for oil products.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A great stretch run by Swiftsport, 2-year-old son of Swift and SureLady Sportsman, gave the form players their fifth successive setback in the running of the Mount Airy Forest Purse today. The oddson favorite, Mr. James, succumbed in the closing strides to Swiftsport, losing the decision by a nose.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6 -- In a statement read from the bench at the opening of court this morning, Federal Judge Guy L. Fake decried the filing of involuntary bankruptcy petitions against concerns which are in equity receiverships and are being "wisely administered."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 6 -- The trouble with Notre Dame's faltering football team, as Edgar E. (Rip) Miller, Navy coach, sees it, is altogether psychological.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Yale started preparations for the Georgia game today by clearing the Bowl and Anthony Thompson Field gridirons of the first snow of the season.
Tammany continued its campaign far into the night in its effort to re-elect Mayor O'Brien and elect his runnings mates on the citywide ticket.
Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party nominee for Mayor, charged last night that Tammany would attempt to steal today's election.
The market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $2,612,105,000 last month, it was announced yesterday.

Close examination of "Thoroughbred," which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening, fails to disclose the kitchen sink. But Doty Hobart, who is down as the author, has managed to include nearly every other useful article, including Florence Reed, who roars her way through the leading part as a racetrack virago.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP). -- The whirr of straining hoists and the thud of miners' boots told the story in sound tonight of the break in a prolonged strike at the Western Pennsylvania "captive" coal mines operated by steel companies.
These orders were issued yesterday: Transfers and Assignments. SERGEANT -- Fred G. Norman, from 30th Precinct to 18th Division.

A cursory grlance at "Doctor Monica" suggests that three women and a telephone can have a devilish time, if they are long left alone. To all members of the cast in the Playhouse's latest tenant come crosses of love and ethical theories.

A demand for the more expensive wines and whiskies rather than the cheaper brands is indicated in orders received by Park Tilford in reply to its newspaper advertisements, it was reported yesterday by Gordon Stewart, president of the company.

Although the government's objective of a cheaper dollar was realized yesterday -- at least in teems of sterling -- the stock and commodity market gave a contrary response. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the slowest for a full five-hour day in seven months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorial on Hesterberg of Brooklyn has caused me to reflect upon the present methods of election. I write as a psychologist and chairman of the Long Island University faculty committee, sponsoring the election of Mr. Baker for Borough President.

TIME plays tricks with perspectives, as every one knows. And Ursula Parrott, author of "Ex-Wife" and other novels of what happened during the big F. Scott Fitzgerald party years, has long since been convinced that there may have been something to the steadfastness of Puritan and Victorian alike. In the "Tumult and the Shouting" (Longmans, Green, $2.50) she makes a valiant effort to ram the thesis home.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Mrs. Bessie Wakefield, principal in one of the most notorious murder cases in the history of Connecticut, was pardoned tonight in her seventeenth appearance before the State Board of Pardons.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Arthur Church of New York City slipped another notch in the standings of the national pocket billiard tournament today when he was defeated by Harry Wood of Duluth, 125 to 31, in twenty-seven innings.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- "There will be complete destruction of the enemy and complete victory for the Red Army in case of an attack," declared Vyacheloff Molotoff, President of the Council of Cornmissors, in an address tonight before a convocation at the Opera House celebrating the sixteenth anniversary of the October Revolution (Nov. 7, Gregorian Calendar).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The administration was outwardly calm tonight in the face of reports from the Middle West of growing disorder and picketing among adherents of the farm holiday movement, and there appeared no change in preconceived plans to counsel patience and give the present recovery machinery a chance to prove itself.

A letter from Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland to Robert Minor, Communist candidate for Mayor of New York in the election today, was made public yesterday by the Communist Election Campaign Committee, which has offices at 799 Broadway.

Silver, tin and cocoa resumed yesterday their advances of last week in the commodity markets, but silk and rubber broke sharply, while other staples backed and filled. The turnover was larger than, recently in the commodities that showed the principal advances or declines, but trading in the other staples was rather sluggish.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- In spite of a snow-covered gridiron, Army went through a hard drill today. The regular Monday lecture was followed by a forty-minute blocking and tackling drill.

To aid the scholarship fund of the Child Education Foundation, the first in a series of literary and artistic receptions will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 22 in the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria. Some of the writers and artists who will appear are Dorothy Parker, June Walker, Margaret Bourke-White, James Thurber and Carveth Wells.

Georg Schmitt arrived here yesterday on the Bremen with full authority from Berlin to perfect the organization of the German Stahlhelm in this country and to coordinate it with other Nazi bodies in support of the Hitler government.

Daniel F. Cohalan, speaking for Tammany Hall from WOR last night, declared that Postmaster General Farley, in fomenting rebellion in the party ranks here, had sacrificed his right to remain as Democratic National and State Chairman.

The Vanderbilt Cup tournament, the blue ribbon event in contract bridge, will open tomorrow at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Twenty teams of four, including virtually every prominent player in the East, have entered the event to date. After the qualifying session tomorrow the teams will meet in knockout rounds during the week, with the semi-final rounds being held next Monday and Tuesday.

Negotiations going on between the Argentine Government and representatives of companies in the United States with the object of freeing about 100,000,000 "frozen" pesos are complicated because of a previous agreement with British firms on their frozen pesos which provided that other nationals should receive no more favorable terms than the British.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General and Democratic chairman in the State and nation, delivered an address last night from Station WABC appealing for the election of a Democratic Assembly to assure the reform of local government.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Both Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, publicly referred to the United States today as a country in which democracy has broken down. They made these criticisms at a political luncheon at which they and Prime Minister MacDonald were guests of the National Labor party executive committee.

CHESTERTON speaks of the name Smith, being so poetical that it must be an arduous and heroic matter to live up to it. It is older than the nations and its sign is the hammer of Thor. When to this surname is added the "given " name Theobald, the difficulty of living up to it is increased, for this name when first applied to a man meant that he was "bold for the people."

The New York University football team began Its second week of preparation for its traditional battle with Fordham on Saturday by engaging in a spirited two-hour workout at Ohio Field yesterday. The return to action of Vie Barber, regular guard, cheered the coaches.

VIENNA, Nov. 6. -- A police investigation into the blasting Saturday night of the cables supplying electricity to Klagenfurt indicates this was no mere isolated demonstration against Chancellor Dollfuss's speech in the Carinthian capital but part of a widespread action meant to paralyze the life of half the province.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 (London Times Dispatch) -- It is pleasant to be able to record that Fritz Ebert, son of the first German President, is now in apparent good health at the concentration camp at Lichtenberg.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 6. -- Relief and business activities are included with official and personal hospitalities in the program for the week outlined today by Mrs. Roosevelt at her press conference.

Washington dispatches spoke last week of charts which confirm the President's belief that the economic and financial situation is much improved by comparison with the Autumn of last year. A detailed description was not given, but an amateur craftsman would have no difficulty in constructing a set of graphs from material readily available.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The British Ambassador and Lady Lindsay gave a dinner party tonight for Vice Admiral, the Hon. R.A. R. Plunkett-Ernle-Erle-Drax, commander-in-chief of the AmericaWest Indies Station, and Mrs. Drax, who arrived today and will be guests at the embassy during the week's visit here of the British cruisers H.M.S. Danae and Norfolk.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- William Curtis Demorest, member of a prominent New York family, died this evening of heart disease at his residence here. Mr. Demorest was in his seventy-fifth year and had been in poor health for the last two and a half years.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 6. -- The Board of Supervisors delayed today making application for Federal funds to build a county airport pending a determination as to whether the project could be made self-sustaining. Meanwhile residents of Greenburgh, in the vicinity of one of the two proposed tracts added their protests to others already received.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation has been called for Dec. 14 to obtain their consent to the sale of the corporation's properties in the Far East to the StandardVacuum Oil Company, a company recently organized by Socony-Vacuum and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The Supreme Court today took under advisement a motion by Pennsylvania for permission to proceed with its case against Arkansas seeking repeal of acts of the Arkansas Legislature which the petitioner claimed impaired securities behind $200,000 in Arkansas State bonds held by Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- A White House conference late today, participated in by President Roosevelt and his principal aides studying the question of Russian recognition, completed the preparations for the forthcoming conference with Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs.

Wet-dry contests ended last night in six States which hold special elections today on ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, repealing the Eighteenth, or prohibition amendment.
LEAD, S.D., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Search for gold in the Black Hills of South Dakota, scene nearly sixty years ago of one of the maddest rushes for wealth in history, is not what it used to be.

Efforts of the North German Lioyd and Hamburg American steamship lines to avoid payment of the fines which they were assessed in October by Emil Lederer, arbiter of the Atlantic Passenger Conference, for selling passage in exchange for "blocked" marks, have failed, it was learned yesterday.

A clash of campaigns, in which a Fusion speaker sought, by means of a list of six questions, to link Joseph V. McKee, Recovery candidate for Mayor, with the much discussed Equitable bus franchise, was witnessed yesterday by crowds in the financial district.

HAVANA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- An incident involving the United States flag has aroused comment here. It was said authoritatively that the incident was immediately reported to the State Department at Washington.

The second set of six matches among the Class C teams of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League, played last night, sent the Columbia University Club, City A.C. and New York A.C. into a triple tie for first place. Each team has won two matches and lost none.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange declined yesterday about 20 points, or a dollar a bale, and ended the lowest since operations under the new gold policy were started.

Dr. George Frederick Kunz, mineralogist, gem expert and vice president of Tiffany Co., who died June 29, 1932, left an estate appraised yesterday at $148,613 gross and $114,109 net, of which $59,387 was in securities. His interest in Tiffany Co. consisted of seventythree shares of stock valued at $58,400.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Nov. 6. -- The bellicose attitude of farm strikers, the burning of a railway bridge and the shooting at a freight train brought an urgent appeal for National Guard troops tonight.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP). -- Thousands of hard-coal miners in Northeastern Pennsylvania stayed away from work today while other thousands of their comrades of the soft-coal mines were trudging back to the pits at the other end of the State.

With Dark Secret, Blot and Winooka among the featured racers, the United Hunts Racing Association this afternoon will offer at Belmont Park what many consider its most interesting program in years. Dark Secret is the conqueror of the champion Equipoise in the Jockey Club Gold Cup and he is scheduled to go to the post in the featured Whitney Gold Trophy race, at a mile and a half.

A contest which has as its purpose the discovery of new compositions in the modern American idiom was announced yesterday by Paul Whiteman. The winner each year will receive a gold medal, to be known as the Whiteman Medal, together with a scholarship to one of five important musical conservatories and sufficient money to finance him or her for a minimum period of a year.

Erasmus Hall and Manual Training High, annual football rivals since 1909, will meet at Ebbets Field in the feature event of seven schoolboy games scheduled for fields within New York City today. More than 20,000 fans are expected to see the twenty-fifth annual contest between two teams that are undefeated this Fall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Few people realize it, but during this depression the medical profession has been so jeopardized by lack of sympathetic understanding that if drastic measures are not taken soon it may be so paralyzed that it cannot properly function.

Disregarding hundreds of passersby and a traffic policeman less than twenty feet away, thieves cut a glass panel of a jewelry store showcase in the vestibule of the Sax Furniture Store, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, and escaped yesterday with jewelry valued at $8,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The constitutionality of the NRA is simply a question of "the capacity of the Constitution to absorb a revolution," declared Professor Edward S. Corwin, chairman of the Department of Politics of Princeton University, in a speech here tonight.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The proceeds accruing to the Winter relief fund from last Sunday's "one-dish" dinner is expected to be three times as great as from the first of these monthly "self-denial Sundays."

Hotel and night-club proprietors, because the city election this year coincides with the action at the polls of the remaining States necessary to repeal prohibition, look forward to unusually widespread celebrations tonight.
Hidden away in the long list or American records that will be submitted to the Amateur Athletic Union for approval at its convention in Pittsburgh this month is the greatest mile that man has run.

The undertone of the market continued easy. Offerings were in good volume in all sections, but demand was small. Routine requirements made up the bulk of the day's business. Quotations for call loans, time money and business paper were all unchanged.

All the markets as well as the banks will be closed today because of the election. As a result business will be at a standstill in Wall Street. Some of the less important outside Exchanges will be open and banking business will be carried on in some sections outside of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The National Labor Board has rejected the finding of the committee it designated to examine the airplane pilots' dispute, and thus referred the matter back to the committee with instructions to present data for the board to make its own finding on the issues.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The application of Mrs. Eleanor M. Kohn of New York for an order to sequester the business and assets of her former husband, Lorin M. Kohn of 2 West Eighty-sixth Street, New York, was granted by Justice Bleakley in the Supreme Court here today.

DENVER, Nov. 6 (AP) -- "That's great news," Major Charles A. Shepard almost shouted when he was informed at Fitzsimons Hospital of the decision of the United States Supreme Court in setting aside his conviction of the slaying of his wife.

Voting machines will be used in all districts in New York City today. The polls are open from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M. All persons in line waiting to vote at closing time will have an opportunity to cast their ballots. A patrolman will take his place on the end of the line and prevent any persons from joining the queue after 6 o'clock.

With the most turbulent municipal campaign in two generations ended last night, the largest number of voters ever to record their choice in a general city election will go to the polls today to decide which of three candidates, F. H. LaGuardia, Fusion; Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party, or John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for re-election, will be Mayor of New York City for the next four years.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Stanley Baldwin asserted during a rally today that the "ordinary Constitution" had broken down in the United States.

Reminiscences of past decades were called forth last night at a hurdy-gurdy costume dance given by a committee of prominent men and women in the interests of a Summer camp for poor children. Those in charge of arrangements had "hired a hall," literally, at 254 West Fifty-fourth Street for the occasion and embellished the interior with relics of the years surrounding the turn of the century.

The average age of inmates of the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn is 24 years, it was pointed out yesterday by the Kings County October grand jury, which urged that stronger attempts be made toward the prevention of crime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- While there are eight vacancies in the House membership, only one will be filled in the elections tomorrow, that in the Ninth Pennsylvania District. The Democrats will gain a seat, as the Republicans declined to make a nomination for the uncompleted term of the late Henry W. Watson, Republican.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Legal steps toward searching for a reported hidden hoard of gold and currency in a rambling old suburban mansion where John M. Hoffman, famous writer of dime novel thrillers, died in 1928, at 82, were taken today by relatives.

Extreme weaknesses in United States Government long-term issues and generally lower prices for foreign loans and domestic corporation issues characterized dealings in the listed bond market yesterday. Issues of the United States Government were marked down 8-32 to 19-32 point despite the fact that the dollar was stronger in terms of some foreign currencies.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Konstantin von Neurath charged tonight that the former allied nations had used the League of Nations as a tool to perpetuate the Versailles treaty.
The Columbia football squad was out in full force yesterday at Baker Field as it commenced preparation for its game with the Naval Academy here on Saturday.

The Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries report a consolidated net loss of $525,159 after all deductions for the third quarter of 1933, comparing with a loss of $812,128 a year ago. In the preceding quarter the loss was $790,048 and in the first quarter of 1933 it was $478,164.

Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Mayor, and the other Socialist candidates and party leaders concluded their campaign last night with an appeal for votes on the ground that no matter which of the three major tickets won the great masses of the city's population lose.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The second visit of Reichsminister Hermann Wilhelm Goering to Rome in recent weeks was said in informed circles today to be connected with difficulties between the Vatican and the Prussian Government concerning the appointment of a Bishop in Berlin to succeed the late Bishop Schreiber.

The twenty officers making up the five teams which will take part in the international jumping contests at the National Horse Show, starting in Madison Square Garden tomorrow, will be the guests of the United Hunts at Belmont Park this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Connie Mack today began to build up the Philadelphia Athletics for the 1934 campaign, announcing that Raymond Radcliffe, outfielder and left-handed batter of the St. Paul club of the American Association, will be with his team next year.

Lieut. Col. Julian L. Schley, Governor of the Canal Zone, who arrived yesterday from Colon on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania, said there had been a decided improvement in canal traffic since last March.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6 -- After many months of work, members of the commission which has been drafting a new Constitution signed the project this afternoon and forwarded it to President Vargas for his signature. President Vargas will lay it before a constitutional assembly on Nov. 15 accompanied by a special message reviewing government activities during his three years in office.
PARIS, Nov. 6. -- The rise of the pound, which not only crossed its...

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The heads of three British steamship companies flew to Paris today for tomorrow's resumption there of the North Atlantic Conference, which is considering fares on Atlantic liners. They are B.J. Lister of the Cunard Line, A.B. Cauty of the White Star and Sir George McLaren Frown of the Canadian Pacific.
F.H. LaGuardia, Fusion nominee for Mayor, made his last talk to the voters in an impromptu address, delivered to an outdoor audience estimated by the police at 5,000, virtually on his own doorstep.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Harold N. Guilfoyle, Hartford veterinary surgeon serving a life sentence for second-degree murder, committed suicide today in the presence of guards by leaping fifty feet from the top tier of the main cell block at the State's prison at Wethersfield.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Mayor Moore in an open letter today accused Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, with playing "politics" in criticizing this city and the Mayor for failing to take advantage of the works program.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The dollar "crossed the line" today, tumbling through its old parity of $4.86 2-3 to its lowest value in terms of sterling since 1914.

S.S. BERENGARIA, Approaching New York, Nov. 6 -- The Berengaria is due at Quarantine at 10 A.M. tomorrow, and Maxim Litvinoff will leave the vessel immediately for Jersey City to entrain for Washington. There he will be met by Secretary of State Hull and will go directly to the White House to pay his respects to President Roosevelt.

Herbert Kluge, German-American A.C. battler, knocked out Andy Zupkusky of Philadelphia in, the third round of the heavyweight special which featured the semimonthly amateur boxing program at the New York A.C. last night.

LONDON Oct. 29. -- From a beautiful eleventh-century silver salver, just brought to London from Persia, art experts here have established their first definite link with Alp Arslan, the great Persian monarch who made himself the first patron of Omar Khayyam.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 6 (AP). -- The New York cartoonist, Peter Arno, was knocked "cold" in an Embassy Club fist fight early today while celebrities looked on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to punish New York City by a fine or some other measure for failure to comply with the highest court's order to cease dumping its garbage into the sea.

LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Decision on a motion to quash an indictment charging George Crawford, Negro, with the slaying of two women at Middleburg, Va., was deferred until tomorrow after counsel for the defense and State had completed argument today.

The compliance board of the local NRA organization issued a ruling yesterday setting the hours of work at forty-eight a week for maintenance staffs of office buildings and at sixty for higher class apartment houses. The ruling, according to Grover A. Whalen, NRA chairman, will affect 3,529 office buildings and apartment houses in the city and will add 2,575 new employes to their operating staffs at wages totaling nearly $2,500,000 annually.

Mr. McCOOEY is a man of strong domestic affections. He showed it by giving his son a Supreme Court justiceship. But his great heart is true to a larger household, to the Whole machine establishment as it was before the days of division. He looks mournfully at every borough.

RED BANK, N. J., Nov. 6. -- Four separate investigating bodies, the findings of one of which will be presented to a grand jury, attempted today to ascertain the cause of the airplane crash that resulted in the death of seven persons near here late yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The Boerse remained in the doldrums today. Financial circles as well as the public are waiting for the result of the election and its consequences, and trading has become almost at a standstill. General steadiness of quotations, however, was considered a good sign of stability.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- This is the second of two articles by Sir Herbert Samuel, former Secretary of State for Home Affairs and Liberal leader, on his conclusions regarding the recovery program in the United States, from which he has just returned.

According to a report submitted yesterday to George C. Warren Jr., president of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission, game has not been so plentiful in that State in a decade as at the present time.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 6. -- After four years of unsuccessful endeavor to give Cincinnati a winning team, Sidney Weil today stepped down as president of the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The purchase of $232,000,000 of preferred stock and capital notes has been authorized in the government's campaign to strengthen the capital structure of the nation's banks, and bring more of them into the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Chairman Jones, of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Major Charles A. Shepard, 62-yearold army surgeon, convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment on a charge of murdering his wife, Zenana, on the military reservation at Fort Riley, Kansas, was in effect granted a new trial today by the Supreme Court.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A generally listless election campaign, marked by enthusiasm in only scattered localities where local interests surpass those of Statewide importance, ended today and New Jersey voters prepared to express their preferences tomorrow on multifarious candidates and issues.

A program for systematic dental care for the 1,600,000 school and pre-school children in New York City, to be carried out by the Department of Health, was advocated last night by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, before a neeting of the First District Dental Society at the New York Academy of Medicine.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- About $2,250,000 in county securities were brought across Main Street from the County Trust Company to the offices of T. Darrington Semple, County Treasurer, under a guard of armed deputy sheriffs at noon today.

An "atmospheric sewer" created by invisible solids and noxious gases from a million small and large chimneys hangs in the air over New York City and threatens the health and life of its population, the Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine was told last night by H. B. Meller, head of the Air Pollution Investigation of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, Pittsburgh.
"Father" Divine announced his political platform yesterday. He declaimed it over the telephone in rounded, throbbing syllables, but despite his eloquence he was far from definite.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger Endeavour will be launched toward the end of April. She has been entered in the coastwise fixtures for big yachts racing in British waters from the opening regatta at Harwich to the Torbay meeting in July, after which she will be sailed to the United States.

Joe Savoldi of Three Oaks, Mich., the famous Jumping Joe of Notre Dame football, made short work of Eli Fischer, former Rutgers athlete, last night in their finish wrestling match at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- Premier Herman Wilhelm Goering of Prussia arrived unexpectedly by air from Munich early this morning. The ostensible reason for his visit is that he wishes to inspect German cultural institutions in Rome -- the German Archaeological Institute and the Prussian Historical Institute.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) -- For the first time since Great Britain went off the gold standard, the Canadian dollar was at par in New York today. In fact there were two or three sales at a premium of 1-16 of a cent, according to information wired to the Finance Department here.

Eight more indictments naming twenty-seven persons were handed up yesterday by the two New York County grand juries which for the past eight days have sifted 2,800 complaints of illegal registration. Indictments to date total 117 and involve 312 persons.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 shows consolidated net income of $7,430,516, equal after preferred dividends to $1.05 a share earned on the common stock, comparing with $9,111,210, or $1.36 a share, in the preceding year.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 6. -- The Long Island Golf Association's tournament activities for this year came to a close today when a small field gathered at the Lakeville Club, despite the rain and cold, to compete in an amateur-pro competition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- After weeks of indecision, hingeing upon the Cuban situation, Secretary Hull recommended to President Roosevelt today that Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Latin-American affairs, be sent as a delegate to the forthcoming Pan American conference at Montevideo.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 6. -- Jack Cannell sent his second and third Dartmouth teams through an hour's scrimmage today as most of the regulars received a rest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The final chapter in the current effort to arrange a readjustment of the British war debt to the United States will be written tomorrow, when a joint communique will be issued here and in London. This is expected to provide for another token payment by Great Britain Dec. 15 and continued recognition of its debt by Great Britain, and to express the hope that future conversations may reach a successful conclusion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Assailing "witch doctors who are setting up hobgoblins about the President's re-employment program," General Hugh S. Johnson, chief administrator of the NRA, declared here today that "Franklin Roosevelt has pulled this country about one-quarter of the way out of the March depths in six months."

The sale of beer will not be permitted from 6 o'clock this morning until 6 o'clock in the evening, as the result of an order promulgated yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, based on a section of the State law.

Jose Iturbi, the Spanish pianist, said yesterday that there was no question in his mind that the future of music lay in America and that the promise of the future was great. He arrived from Europe with his daughter Maria on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Movements of vessels follow: All dates are Nov. 6 unless otherwise specified:

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies formally organized last night an industrial division through which it will make its first appeal to office and factory workers throughout the city.
A large apartment house on upper Broadway and a multi-family building in the Bronx figured among the real estate transactions reported by brokers yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes made his first visit yesterday afternoon to the headquarters of the Catholic Medical Mission Board, Inc., at 8 and 10 West Seventeenth Street. He bestowed benediction of the blessed sacrament and delivered an address in the small chapel. It was crowded with priests, sisters and lay friends of the work.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 6. -- With their little cabin cruiser sinking under them, A.J. Goldner and his wife of New Bedford were snatched from death yesterday by the crew of Cobb's Island Coast Guard Station. The rescue was reported today.

The National Hockey League season will get under way this week, when all nine of the teams will see action. New York, however, will not have an opportunity to observe its teams for another week, for both the Rangers and the Americans open on the road.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Nov. 1 shows increases for the week of $50,000,000 in loans, $208,000,000 in United States Government securities and $287,000,000 in government deposits, and decreases of $32,000,000 in net demand deposits and $91,000,000 in reserve balances with federal Reserve Banks.

TOKYO, Nov. 6. -- Foreign Minister Hirota's effort to find a diplomatic solution of Russo-Japanese problems was commenced today in a three-hour discussion with Ambassador Yureneff of the Soviet Union of various irritants that have been injected into Russo-Japanese relations.

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) -- At this moment when rumors of wars and revolutions have become an impediment to the recovery of confidence in economic matters, governments of the world must realize that economic recovery has made further headway than is popularly appreciated, the Royal Bank of Canada says in its monthly letter.

New "repeal" and "tavern" dresses were added to collections shown yesterday by members of the Dress Creators League of 'America, whose lines wholesale at from $10.75 to $16.75. Offerings were of the formal afternoon, and dinner types.

For the first time in twenty years, Fusion yesterday wrested control of the city government from Tammany and elected former Representative F.H. LaGuardia Mayor and a majority of the Board of Estimate. The last Fusion victory was in 1913 when the late John Purroy Mitchel was elected Mayor.
Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. GRANITE FALLS, Minn., Nov. 7 -- To Andrew Volstead, attorney-at-law, Nov. 7, 1933, was just another Tuesday.

The Salt Lake City (Utah) Tribune announced early this morning that on the basis of more than three-eighths of the total vote in that State, Utah had voted for the Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, repealing the Eighteenth or prohibition amendment, by a safe majority of more than five to three.
John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, took the defeat of his ticket philosophically, and joked about it with John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, in a telephone conversation last night.

The Simms Petroleum Company reports a net income of $50,126 for the third quarter of 1933 after depreciation, depletion, rentals, uncapitalized drilling costs and taxes, equal to 10.9 cents a share earned on 461,000 shares of stock, contrasting with a deficit of $44,654 in the 1932 period.

An invitation to 750 leading citizens of New York to attend a meeting at the New York Chamber of Commerce to discuss the welfare situation tomorrow afternoon has been issued jointly by Harvey D. Gibson, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the finance committee and the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation; Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Cornelius N. Bliss.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- There is no reason why the retail price of bituminous coal need rise more than 20 per cent to cover the greater mine charges resulting from the coal code, according to a statement made today by the Consumers Board of the NRA.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field of Lloyds Neck won the Mrs. Percy Chubb memorial prize for twenty-five indoor roses in the first day's judging of the twenty-eighth annual chrysanthemum show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which opened this afternoon in the Pratt oval on the Pratt estate.

TAKING time out from football, a grave situation in another sport is herewith exposed to view. Word comes from across the sea that the grave and reverend seniors of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews have completed their revision of the rules of golf.
Blackjacks, brass knuckles, lead pipe, bricks, stones and hob-nailed boots played an important part in the elections yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 -- The cotton market here was comparatively quiet today, with price fluctuations narrow and showing no definite trend. As the New York stock and cotton markets were closed and as the government crop report is due tomorrow, traders were cautious about making new commitments.

Buyers' Total Above Year Ago. A slight drop in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total, however, was well above the number listed for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Although the season up to the present has contained the most complete assortment of surprises that almost any in recent years has provided, there is a strong likelihood that from now on upsets may come in an increasing degree.

Tommy Loughran, veteran Philadelphia heavyweight, who formerly held the world's light-heavyweight title, yesterday accepted terms for a ten-round bout against Ray Impelletiere, giant Italian boxer, to be held in the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, Nov. 22.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Chapman, estranged wife of Ben Chapman, the Yankee outfielder, testified today before Judge William Walker in Jefferson Chancery Court that her husband had left her in Birmingham last March with only $2.87, and refused to give her more money.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The United States apparently is now going through another of those periodical doldrums, in British political opinion.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, asserted today that if his interpretation was correct, "the closed shop is prohibited by the Recovery Act."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The official silence which has separated the United States and Russia for more than fifteen years was ended at the White House this afternoon when President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, clasped hands cordially and extended greetings on behalf of their respective governments.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7 -- The Republican party, despite a determined opposition on the part of the Democrats, still rules supreme in Nassau County. I even increased the majority on the board of supervisors, the administrative body of the county.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The House of Commons, crowded on the first day of the session, heard without excitement or much interest the announcement by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that Britain would pay the United States $7,500,000 on the Dec. 15 war debt instalment.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The dollar today for the first time responded on the Paris exchange market to Washington's effort to depress the rate, falling from 16.50 francs yesterday to 16.38. When the RFC's unchanged gold figures of $32.84 was announced, however, the dollar rose to 16.43 in unofficial trading.

William Faulkner has just bought an airplane and flown it here from Mississippi with the man who sold it to him. He will be here for a few days' vacationing, and expects to leave the end of this week to fly back to his home. He is at work on a novel tentatively called, "Requiem for a Nun."

F.H. LaGuardia, so dier and political leader, has been a dynamic figure in the life of the city and the nation for almost two decades. Known as a pugnacious and effective fighter, he has been in the forefront of movements for action at first assailed as extremely radical and within a few years written into the law of the land.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Tea registration statements filed under the Securities Act for securities issues totaling more than $5,000,000 were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. They included one from New York. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Negotiations for a final adjustment of the British war debt to the United States were adjourned indefinitely today by an arrangement under which a "token" payment of $7,500,000 in American currency will be made Dec. 15.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- An early Italian step to ascertain what would be the reaction of Great Britain and France if Germany were to propose a meeting of the signatories of the Four-Power Pact to consider the general European situation, with particular reference to disarmament, is expected as a result of a two-hour conversation General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Minister of Aviation, had with Premier Mussolini this morning.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 -- Speaking tonight at the gateway to the agricultural Northwest, General Hugh S. Johnson declared the American farmer "must look more directly to other parts of the President's program than to the NRA for immediate relief."
Columbia's football squad went through its longest and most strenuous drill of the season yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Navy here on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Victory for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was hailed tonight by Jouett Shouse, president of the Associatio Against the Prohibition Amendment, in a radio address.
The nature of the funeral obsequies of prohibition to be observed by New York City when repeal becomes effective remained something of a mystery yesterday.

New York voted early and rapidly yesterday. Enlivened by the bitterly contested campaign of recent weeks, encouraged by suitable weather and aided by the smooth functioning of voting machines, citizens lined up early at the polls and began piling up a total of ballots regarded as unusual for a local election.

General JOHNSON'S nervous, racy, idiomatic, hammer-and-tongs language makes any speech of his a delight, not unmingled with a shade of terror. He says what he thinks in a devil-may-care way. To associations of business men, too familiar with platitudinous drone, such a speaker must take on something of the character of a powerful revivalist, preaching the new awakening -- a doctrine not without its mysteries as well as its threats of punishment.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- E.H. Harris, a Richmond (Ind.) publisher, who is secretary of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that if General Johnson, the National Recovery Administrator, "is sincere in his desire to preserve a free press," he would permit inclusion in the newspaper code of the section "preserving the freedom of the press."
CITY TICKET Mayor. . . . . . . .F.H. LaGuardia, R.-F. Controller. . . . . .W.A. Cunningham, R.-F. Pres. of Aldermen B.S. Deutsch, R.-F.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The upward price swing for newly mined domestic gold was halted at least temporarily today when an RFC price of $32.84 an ounce was set for the metal, representing no change from the previous quotation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Democrats of Westchester, who pinned their hopes on the Republican organization's loss of the personal leadership of the late William L. Ward, were startled to-night to see the old organization carry the county in customary fashion, adding one vote to its majority in the Board of Supervisors and taking two of the county's four cities, which had been Democratic.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- In the great hall of the University of Berlin Professor David Prescott Barrows of the University of California was introduced today as the new Theodore Roosevelt guest professor by Eugen Fischer, the rector of the university.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Frank J. Stackhouse, 70-year-old proprietor of the Chadds Ford Inn, testified in Federal court today that he had paid more than $8,000 to the alleged Delaware County "protection" organization so that he might sell "high-powered" beer.

With business entirely suspended in Wall Street as a result of the election, whatever interest may have been yesterday was centred in the outside markets. But the New York holiday had the effect of curtailing activity not only on the Chicago Board of Trade and the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, the two most important domestic markets that remained open, but on the European exchanges as well.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- In a city-wide political revolution without parallel here for more than two decades, a surprisingly strong coalition of Democrats and Republicans today swept to defeat the powerful Republican machine of William S. Vare, long dictator of Philadelphia politics.

The writer of this article, Elias Tobenkin, was born in Russia and educated, in the United States. As correspondent for American and European newspapers, specialising in Russian affairs, he has repeatedly met and interviewed Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in Moscow and other European capitals in the last fifteen years.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- A 101-gun salute opened the celebration today of the sixteenth anniversary of the October revolution (Nov. 7 on the Gregorian Calendar) in Moscow's Red Square.

The next Assembly will be composed of eighty-five Republicans and sixty-five Democrats, a net gain of eight seats for the Republicans, who in the present Assembly have seventy-seven seats while the Democrats have seventy-three.

SCARSDALE, N.Y.,Nov. 7 -- This village, dry as long as its oldest residents can remember, voted in a special referendum today in favor of the sale of bottled beer, but against the sale of beer or other liquors over the bar except in hotels.
A chronology of the chief events in the history of national prohibition follow:

In Washington and in London yesterday spokesmen of the American and British Governments acknowledged the breakdown of the latest war-debt negotiations. They were undertaken at the request of Great Britain and at least provided opportunity "for a full and frank discussion."
Repeal will have a beneficial effect on real estate in New York City, according to Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc.

Agriculture and industry probably will benefit chiefly during the first few months after repeal becomes effective, while the tax yield from alcoholic beverages will aid in balancing Federal and State budgets, and, in time, may lead to reduction in certain other forms of taxation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Great Britain's withdrawal from the tariff truce has been expected here for some time. It was interpreted in official circles as meaning only that Great Britain wished to preserve liberty of action in future economic upsets.

After being out of politics for seventeen years, Samuel Seabury returned to the platform and the soap box in this campaign in the belief that only by the election of F.H. LaGuardia could the city take advantage of the lessons taught by his latest and greatest work, the city investigation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Heavy voting and outbreaks of violence that caused seven men to be killed and four wounded marked a chill, gray election day in Kentucky. The vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and on State issues served to bring out a large number of voters in most counties.
