Fordham's football squad yesterday was sent through one of the longest and most vigorous practice sessions it has had in more than a month. The Rams worked for five hours at Fordham Field in preparation for the battle with its traditional metropolitan foe, New York University, at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment means the end of one of the most far-reaching social experiments in the history of the world. It has lasted nearly fourteen years. Never before had there been such an attempt to regulate the habits and customs of a nation of 120,000,000 persons of such varied racial strains by sumptuary legislation.
Incomplete returns on the proposition that would permit Mayor O'Brien to name a charter revision commission indicated last night that the proposal would be defeated.

For the first time since 1930 an Alexander Hamilton High School football team is able to boast of a victory over its traditional rival, Boys High. Meeting for the twenty-seventh time since the Inception of the series of 1906, the former turned back the Red and Black, 20 -- 13, yesterday in an exciting struggle.
Following is the text of the statement made by Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, on his arrival here yesterday:
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Repeal forces trailed by a narrow margin in late returns from today's referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment in this State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- An issue which Congress itself may be called on to settle was raised between radio broadcastrs and daily newspapers today when the standing committee of correspondents of the Congressional press gallieries rejected applications for admission to the galleries on behalf of three members of the Columbia Broad-casting System's news service.
DUISBURG, Germany, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mary Wigman, dancer, was in a hospital today with a broken arm, suffered when she slipped on a staircase as she was leaving a stage where she had been performing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today the appointment of Wilfred M. Hall of New York City as engineer in charge of the construction of the $20,000,000 General Joe Wheeler Dam on the Tennessee River, sixteen miles above Muscle Shoals.

A favorable report has been filed. Secretary Joseph F. Higgins of the Board of Estimate announced yesterday, by Chief Engineer H.H. Smith on a map prepared by Borough President Harvey for changing the lines and grades of the street system within the Queens territory bounded by Ninth Avenue, College Place, Eleventh Avenue, 122d Street, Twenty-fifth Road, 119th Street, Twenty-third Avenue, 120th Street, Eighteenth Avenue, 117th Street, Fifteenth Avenue, 120th Street, Twelfth Avenue and 119th Street.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, shot a volley of verbal barbs at foreign correspondents tonight in a campaign address, and speaking directly to the world denied that Nazis were spreading propaganda in the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Pennsylvania voted emphatically today to take the Eighteenth Amendment out of the Constitution.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 7 -- This city, industrial capital of Connecticut, elected a Socialist Mayor today, and an entire Socialist city government for the first time in its history or that of the State.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- The Boerse continued dull but steady today. Due to uncertainties in the world economic situation, especially in the United States, speculative interest dropped to a minimum. Trading was concentrated on fixed-interest securities and stocks with assured dividends, which were rather buoyant.

Before the election, Major LAGUARDIA showed that he had a full and keen perception of the difficulties which he will have to face as Mayor of New York. Confident of winning, he spoke of the need of calling upon all citizens of goodwill, irrespective of party, to aid him in the great and trying work that he will soon have to take up.

A.F. MacNichol won the Election Day Handicap over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the trophy by breaking 99 out of a possible 100 targets. In the Handicap Cup shoot the first trophy went to J.R. Murphy, with E.J. McGrath winning the second prize.

Heroes Shun Laurels. Why do the victors in cabaret fist-fights and similar affrays shrink from the laurel? The hero of the battle of Sands Point, in which Senator LONG was the casualty, leaves unclaimed the medal that awaits him.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 7 -- A theory that the explosion that followed the crash of a National Guard plane near here Sunday, resulting in the death of seven persons, may have been caused by scattered burning coals, was advanced today by Harry Crook, chief county detective.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- President von Hindenburg, breaking his habitual silence, will speak to the German people Saturday evening, the night before the election, on a nationwide hook-up. He has done this only on a very few occasions that he considered of the utmost moment.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 7 -- The Dartmouth regulars, with the exception of Elbert Camp, who scored a touchdown against Yale, returned to action today as intensive work for Princeton began.

With the certainty that a sufficient number of States was added yesterday to the list voting for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, we have only to await its formal abolition a month from now. By that time the necessary conventions will have put in legal form the expressed will of the people.
Election of officers for the academic year in societies of the School of Commerce of St. John's University, Brooklyn, have been announced by the administrative office of the college.

Dr. Johannes Borchers, German Consul General, received Captain Georg Schmitt here yesterday and examined the credentials he brought from Berlin on Monday authorizing him to perfect the organization of the German Stahlhelm in this country and to coordinate it with other Nazi bodies in support of the New Germany.

The voters of the entire State piled up a huge majority for the $60,000,000 relief bond issue, and approved at least three of four proposed amendments to the Constitution. In the city the Tammany plan for charter reform apparently was defeated.
The texts of the Eighteenth, or prohibition amendment, and of the Twenty-first, or repeal amendment, follow:

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Highly discordant atmosphere prevailed at the opening today of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference here. The reclassification of liners to bring the rates charged on the luxurious new cabin, ships closer to those on the older first-class vessels is the principal business before the conference.

Tempering art, which its regular patrons don't seem to care about so much, with mercy, which is something the most simple-minded playgoer can understand, the Second Avenue Theatre last night presented "Three in Love," a good old-fashioned musical play of the "Ol, weh, mameh!" school, by L. Freiman and Al Olshanetsky.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Republicans made heavy gains today in Rockland County, electing Laurens Morgan Hamilton, nephew of J.P. Morgan, to the Assembly by 911 votes. Hamilton defeated Fred R. Horn, Democrat, serving his third term.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Before the statue of Rochambeau, which was unveiled here today, words were spoken between the peoples of France and the United States which Americans here and Frenchmen who knew America recognized as more apt than any spoken for a long time to cement that mutual respect which is more desirable than all protestations of affection.

A tax revenue of about $12,000,000 to this State in the first year liquor is sold is expected by Marie Graves, president of the State Tax Commission. The proposed tax on liquors is $1 a gallon for spirituous liquors, 40 cents a gallon for spirituous wines and 10 cents a gallon for distilled wines.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- In a keen competition today among the new Class B sailing dinghies, Harry Hall took five out of eight races in his boat, Ice Pick.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am convinced that most critics of the Swope plan have failed to read it carefully. Mr. Swope has very little to say of the relation of industry to the NRA, and that little is strictly in keeping with the act and its present administration. What he does discuss is the organization of industry and commerce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Secretary Wallace today tentatively approved a marketing agreement covering oranges and grapefruit produced in California and Arizona and forwarded it to shippers for their signature.
Lawrence Tibbett and James Wallington have received the gold medals of the American Academy of Arts and Letters for good diction on the stage and on the radio, the academy announced yesterday.
Three of the four amendments to the State Constitution voted upon yesterday were passed by large majorities, on the face of incomplete but representative returns from all parts of the State.

An alarming increase of nervous stomach ailments resulting from the depression and the rigors of political uncertainty is reported by physicians and diagnosticians of the metropolitan area, who say that nervous indigestion, which may have grave consequences, has become almost epidemic throughout the city in the last few weeks.

New York City candidates and their politically powerful backers and associates voted early for the most part yesterday, and with a few exceptions managed to enliven the serious business of the franchise with pleasantries addressed to those in the polling places.

Representatives of various branches of the liquor industry and allied groups, including distillers, rectifiers, wholesalers and buyers, formed an organization to meet the problems of their respective groups in the event of repeal at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

Business will be resumed in Wall Street this morning after having been suspended yesterday on account of the election. All the local exchanges as well as the banks were closed for the holiday, but the Chicago Board of Trade and the New Orleans Cotton Exchange remained open.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Yale turned to an hour's defensive drill today in opening scrimmaging in preparing for the Georgia game. Head Coach Reg Root installed an innovation by using the second varsity, drilled in Georgia plays, against the regulars.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- Displaying a marked partiality for the heavy going, Mrs. Elmer Trueman's good mudder, Ilchester, led practically all the way to win the fourth race, featured attraction at Pimlico today. Ilchester defeated the favorite, the B.B. Stable's Waterway, by three lengths.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rockhill will give a reception Dec. 2 at 4OO Park Avenue to introduce their daughter, Miss Katharine Louise Rockhill, for whom they will give a tea dance Dec. 27 at Sherry's.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,300,750 barrels, comparing with 2,358,150 barrels the week before, a decline of 57,400 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 37,750 barrels below the Federal allowance of 2,338,500 barrels daily.

Setting the pace for nearly all of the race, Joseph Moclair, 16-year-old Manhattan Prep junior, retained his championship at the annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 7 -- The lightly regarded Kievex, capably ridden by "Wayne Wright, sprang a surprise by leading a field of seven 2-year-olds over the Waggoner course in the feature at Arlington Downs today. The 8-to-1 shot was trailed by two stanchly supported juveniles, Kieva and Ytfin, which finished second and third, respectively.

BALDWIN, L. I., Nov. 7 -- The Baldwin High School eleven gained undivided possession of the leadership in Class A of the South Shore League of Nassau County by conquering Freeport High, the defending champion, 12 -- 0, today. A crowd of 7,000 saw the contest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Some of the political and social aspects of the national prohibition movement in the United States may be worth recalling to readers of a newspaper which will on another page be recording the last coma or death of the experiment. There will be columns of statistical information, of statements by dry and wet leaders, of historical data.

Frederic Kernochan, who trailed Owen W. Bohan, Tammany district leader, by a very slender margin in yesterday's election for Judge of General Sessions, had been generally regarded as having an excellent chance of winning.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Harvard's scrub team today demonstarted plays which the Army eleven is expected to use in the Stadium on Saturday.

A housing development representing an investment of about $10,000,000 will be undertaken in the Pelham Parkway section of the East Bronx, according to plans announced yesterday at the office of Joseph F. Dusenbury, architect. Erection of the house is contingent upon a Federal loan, application for which is being filed with the Public Works Administration.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- A long scrimmage against Dartmouth's offensive and defensive formations as used by the third team featured the practice of the first two Princeton varsity elevens today.
Many Tammany district leaders holding city and borough jobs are probably slated for severance from the payroll as a result of yesterday's election.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 7 -- Repeal of the State amendment would make effective on Jan. 1 an act of the last Legislature legalizing the manufacture and sale of 3.2 beer, but otherwise would leave in effect the State's prohibition law, passed before the adoption of the State prohibition amendment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The persistent report that the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board intends to announce stringent regulations to follow repeal is exceedingly disquieting. It is circumstantially stated that the board means to prohibit the sale of hard liquors for consumption on the premises except with meals.
Statements made last night on the result of the election follow:

Bullet Joe Simpson, after one season in the trying job of managing the New York Americans, has proved his courage at least by asserting that if his star-spangled team doesn't get into the National Hockey League play-offs this year he will quit the job.

LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 7 (AP) -- George Crawford, Negro, will go to trial in the Loudoun County Circuit Court Dec. 12 for the alleged slaying of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley at Middleburg, Va., Jan. 13, 1932.

HAVANA, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- Revolt flared up anew in Havana this morning when the ABC uprising, which was reported to have been scheduled for midnight, began just two hours and thirty minutes behind schedule.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Government officials planned no action today on the case of Georg Schmitt, Nazi organizer who has arrived in New York, presumably to replace Heinz Spanknoebel. In the absence of official information about him, the State Department assumed that Mr. Schmitt was admitted to the country as a private individual, without any official connection with the German Government.

Municipal ownership of electric distributing systems was defeated in six cities in yesterday's balloting and scored a lone victory in Camden, N.J. The plans submitted to the voters of San Francisco, Salt Lake City, Cincinnati, Youngstown, Akron and Portsmouth, Ohio, requiring expenditures of from $500,000 to $18,000,000 for city owned and manager utility plants, were rejected.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- After litigation spreading over seven years, the Lexington (Ky.) natural gas case involving about $1,000,000 in impounded money was argued today in the Supreme Court.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7 -- All Democratic candidates in today's State election have apparently won over their Republican opponents by three to one on the basis of partial returns from 931 of 1,690 precincts in the State.

The only sustained attack it unfolded during the game gave De Witt Clinton a 7-to-0 victory over Stuyvesant in the twenty-fifth meeting between these two old rivals which featured the scholastic football triple-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Saying that he anticipated repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. James K. Shields, superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New Jersey, declared here tonight that the tide would turn back toward prohibition within a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A further explanation of the cotton processing and flour taxes imposed by the Agricultural Adjustment Act was issued today by Commissioner of Internal Revenue Guy T. Helvering.

When Rabbi Nathan Wolf, who lives upstairs above his Temple at 240 West Thirty-eighth Street, awoke yesterday morning he was in a monarchal mood. Slowly, with a mellow, Louis Quatorze dignity, he arose, completed a leisurely toilet and calmly bethought himself of the day's duties.

Samuel Lamport, cotton exporter, returned yesterday on the Berengaria from a two-month tour of Europe during which he made a survey in the interest of the textile industry of this country and found the prospects for trade abroad were good, especially in Russia, Jugoslavia, Poland, Latvia and Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- An entirely new revenue structure, based upon an annual return of at least $500,000,000 in liquor taxes, will be guaranteed to the American people by repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Opponents of the NRA were likened to the Tories of 1776 in a radio address made here tonight by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant.

The Research Division of the National Education Association has put forth under the title "What Are Taxes For?" an analysis of what the people buy with their taxes. The figures do not include executive reorganizations and reflect only a part of the recent increases in relief and social welfare work with the decreases in cost of schools, but they suggest broadly and approximately the apportionment of the expenditures of Federal, State and local governments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The text of the statement issued by President Roosevelt today on the Anglo-American debt conversations follows:

The defeat of Tammany Hall marks the end of another resurgence in the history of that famous, and at times infamous political organization. Founded as a social body, it has become the synonym of political boss rule and corruption, but its phases have been almost as orderly and recurrent as those of the moon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is written that some 200 years ago, at the end of the reign of Louis XIV, the financial affairs of France were in a deplorable condition. At this moment a young man, who was known as being rather too skillful at faro, appeared with a new deal which promised to create unlimited sources of national wealth.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 7 -- Ohio, the Anti-Saloon League's home State, where national prohibition had its inception, today joined the roll of States voting for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Holding on grimly in a furious drive, John Simonetti's 2-year-old Sgt. Byrne yesterday won the sixfurlong International Speed Test at Belmont Park, with the Australian thoroughbred Winooka, fourth and last. The event was one of the features of the United Hunts one-day meeting.
Approval by an overwhelming majority of Proposition No. 1, the $60,000,000 relief bond issue, was indicated in incomplete returns from New York City and up-State counties in the voting yesterday.

Organization of the Brooklyn Division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee is proceeding rapidly and the appointment of a borough chairman and executive associates is expected within the next few days, it was announced yesterday at Brooklyn headquarters of the committee at 215 Montague Street.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who is recovering at Mount Sinai Hospital from an operation for appendicitis, continued yesterday to maintain the improvement he has shown recently, his secretary, Joseph J. Canavan, made known in a bulletin issued at 6 P.M. over the signatures of the attending physicians.

The National Horse Show will get under way in Madison Square Garden this afternoon. The inaugural day of the Golden Jubilee exhibition, which promises to prove the greatest in the show's fifty-year history, will include the colorful and inspiring ceremony of the salute to the flags, included on tonght's program.

The Earl of Dudley, who sails tonight on the Bremen for England, gave a farewell dinner last nignt at the Waldorf-Astorla. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Dewees W. Dilworth, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Waterbury, Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Phipps, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Blackwell, Mrs. J. de Kay Sloan and Colonel William Donovan.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7 -- More than 1,000 persons attended the concert given by Ossip Gabrilo-witsch, pianist and conductor, at the Greenwich High School tonight. The program of Chopin and Schumann compositions was presented under the auspices of the Wednesday Singing Club of Greenwich.

SHANGHAI, China -- Further tightening of censorship of the Chinese press, and if possible of censorship over the foreign-language newspapers and magazines published in China, is foreshadowed by the action of the Central Party Headquarters of the Kuomintang at Nanking.

Several young women, headed by Miss Ruth Baldwin, will assist in the varied program of entertainments at the bazaar which will open this morning at the Plaza and continue throughout tomorrow for the benefit of the building fund of the new clubhouse for girls adjoining the Convent of Marie Reparatrix, 14 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Organizations of employes of the shipping industry will file separate recommendations with the National Recovery Administration tomorrow in Washington when hearings on a shipping code are started. Several conferences of labor representatives have failed to bring them into agreement, it was said yesterday.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 7 -- The general strike of the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, the insurgent union, spread here today with reports of violence over a widespread front.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Police authorities here are baffled by the discovery of an unidentified body of a boy about 5 or 6 years old on a dumping ground near Princeton yesterday afternoon. An autopsy today indicated there was no foul play and revealed that the boy was a victim of pneumonia, congestion being found in one lung.
HEWLETT, L.I., Nov. 7 --Scoring a touchdown in both the first and third quarters, the Woodmere High School eleven vanquished Roslyn High, a Nassau County rival, today. The score was 12 -- 7.

Cases of illegal voting, alleged illegal registration and interference with voters piled up during the balloting yesterday, keeping the courts busy up to the time the polls closed. It was estimated that the number of cases presented this year was at least three times as great as in other years.

Wild but triumphant disorder reigned last night on the roof of the Hotel Astor, emergency election night headquarters of the Fusion party, where 2,300 active supporters of F. H. LaGuardia celebrated his victory. It was a scene which the famous hotel will long remember.

A collection of theatrical souvenirs of Sir Henry Irving and Ellen Terry, accumlated over thirty or forty years, is to be sold in London. One of the principal exhibits is a pay-book of the Royal Princess's Theatre, Marble Arch, for the year 1655, when it was under the management of Charles Kean.
Although the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board will not make public its rules for liquor control for several days, it is known that the board has under consideration several plans.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A swastika banner unfurled from the university was removed with difficulty today by police wearing gas masks. Nazi students, after hanging out the flag, released tear gas in the rooms through which it could be reached.
GARY, Ind., Nov. 7 (AP) -- There were six Blue Eagles plastered about Theodore Rahutis's dining and dancing place tonight. "Oh, boy, I'm glad to have em," he said.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 7 -- The Democratic party in Suffolk County, long a Republican stronghold, today captured control of the county's Board of Supervisors for the first time in many years. The Democrats won six of the ten seats to break a two-year deadlock of 5 -- 5 in the board.

The ratification of the Twenty-first or Repeal Amendment by the thirty-sixth State means the end of the Eighteenth Amendment and national prohibition. Ratification will not be complete, and liquor cannot legally be sold in the wet States, however, until action is taken by the State convention of the thirty-sixth State.
"Eight Bells," the English melodrama of the sea, will be withdrawn on Saturday night from the Hudson Theatre, where it opened on Oct. 28.

The American people spent more than $36,000,000,000 in ten prohibition years for bootleg and smuggled liquor, according to an estimate made by Clark Warburton in "The Economic Results of Prohibition," one of the Columbia studies in economics, history and public law.

Tammany Hall salvaged from the wreck left by yesterday's election the offices in the Borough of Manhattan that it prizes the most. It retains control of the offices of the Borough President and the District Attorney, and the county offices of the Sheriff, Register and County Clerk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The national leaders of the prohibition forces declared tonight that they will immediately concentrate on a program the aim of which will be the retention of existing prohibition laws and the enactment of similar laws in States where there are no restrictions.

Both Delacroix and Courbet were rebels. They were not, however, rebels warring side by side in a common cause. Delacroix entered violently into revolt against the reigning French classicists, and Courbet, breaking as violently away from the romanticism of Delacroix and his friends, established realism upon the basis of solid earth itself.

Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, arrived here yesterday on the Berengaria and proceeded immediately to Washington for the conversations with President Roosevelt which are expected to institute diplomatic relations between the United States and the Moscow government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet-American conversations got off to a flying start if one may judge by the first impressions produced on visitors. It is no exaggeration to say that M. Litvinoff was delighted by the style and cordiality of his reception.

Arthur Garfield Hays, American lawyer, who has followed the Reichstag fire trial in Berlin and Leipzig and was a member of the unofficial commission of inquiry in London, returned yesterday on the Cunard liner Berengaria. He expressed the belief that the defendants, except Marihus van der Lubbe, who confessed setting fire to the building, would be acquitted.

Quail hunters on Long Island have been having some great sport in the heavily covered sector adjacent to the Belmont Lake State Park near Wyandanch and also further east as far as Brentwood, according to the latest reports.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 7 -- The Election Day Purse, best event at the Latonia track today, was captured by Vitamin B., running in the colors of A.L. Ferguson. The Ferguson entry, a strong favorite in a field of twelve juveniles, triumphed impressively by six lengths over a muddy track.

A youth and a 16-year-old girl, roller-skating about 8:30 o'clock last night in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, were killed by a hit-and-run driver who, according to the story of a witness, must have been fully aware of the damage he had done.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The British Government unexpectedly announced today its withdrawal from the tariff truce, to take effect Dec. 7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Unemployment relief in Kentucky was taken over today by the Federal Government, President Roosevelt, at the request of Governor Ruby Laffoon, authorizing Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator, to assume complete control.

CROWN POINT, Ind., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Virtually every charge on which he could be named was made today against James (Fur) Sammons, "public enemy" of Chicago, in order to hold the gunman and robber for two States eager for his custody.
The city Democratic organization retained a large majority of the members of the Board of Aldermen in yesterday's election.

In an "off year" election marked by shootings and numerous arrests for alleged illegal voting in hotly contested local fights in which the balloting was heavy. New Jersey Democrats, on the basis of incomplete returns, failed to capture control of the House of Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The popular vote today of the last of the thirty-six States required for ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was the final signal for the Federal Government to abandon prohibition enforcement on a national scale.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Nov. 7 (AP) -- There is probably no more democratic or friendlier ruler in the world than Henry Pu-yi, former Emperor of China and now Chief Executive of the new State of Manchukuo.

Unsuccessful in a spectacular scoring attempt in the closing minutes, Erasmus Hall High School's eleven played to a scoreless tie with Manual Training yesterday at Ebbets Field in their twenty-fifth annual football meeting.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were under pressure early today. Wheat broke about a cent a bushel and corn nearly 2 cents, with small longs liquidating because of uncertainty regarding developments in Washington.

Speed was emphasized at yesterday's two-hour workout for the New York University football team at Ohio Field. The Violet squad, idle last week-end, hopes to reach top form Saturday when it opposes Fordham in a traditional battle at the Yankee Stadium.

For more than a year, Tammany leadership has been not only sordid but stupid. Drunk with power and plunder, it moved on-fatuously disregarding the political signs of the times, and blindly inviting the resounding defeat that has now overtaken it. It could command neither the respect of the public nor the obedience of its followers.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The House of Commons roared with laughter today at the official German statement that no order of expulsion had ever been issued against Noel Panter, The London Daily Telegraph correspondent recently released from a German prison, and that he was free to return to Germany whenever he wished.
DES MOINES, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Governor Herring suggested today that Iowa Sheriffs deputize citizens to clear highways of striking farmers.

Chief Inspector O'Brien disclosed at Police Headquarters late last night that to prevent tampering with the voting machines before they are turned over to the Board of Elections one patrolman had been assigned to guard each of the 3,842 machines in the city on each eight-hour tour.

A flash-back into the only blood-tainted history in the discovery and early development of Yellowstone National Park was re-enacted there recently when an expedition was made to the crest of Mary Mountain to obtain data from an old abandoned camp-site once Used as a pow-wow ground for renegade chiefs of a band of Nez Perce Indians, says a bulletin from National Park Service.

THE signature of Spain's dominion is written all over the coast of California. Along the Camino Real, the highway that leads from San Diego to the Golden Gate, the Franciscan missions stand, weathered ruins that have been fortunately arrested in the process of decay. At San Gabriel, to the east of Los Angeles, tourists visit the mission play in memory of the time when Alta California was part of a Catholic empire.

Victor Johnson, 32 years old, employed by the city as chauffeur for Natban Mandel, Deputy Superintendent of Hospitals, was arrested last night on a technical charge of homicide, after the body of a 17-year-old boy, said to have been killed by the automobile Johnson was driving, was found in a vacant lot near Sheepshead Bay Road and Avenue Z, Brooklyn.

A plea to more than 300 members of the Junior League of New York City to apprise themselves of the conditions under which many persons less fortunate than they were living was made yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Questionnaires were submitted today to all Class I railroads asking data on the number, condition and potential capacity of their steam locomotives with a view to replacements to be financed by the Public Works Administration.
The challenge of the Royal Yacht Squadron for the America's Cup was accepted yesterday by the New York Yacht Club. The announcement was made by George A. Cormack, secretary of the club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Andrew F. Mahoney, one of the best known shipping men and lumber magnates in the West and former San Francisco Police Commissioner, died here today.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here this afternoon from Amsterdam in their seaplane on a sight-seeing tour and a visit to the League of Nations.

The Socialist party in the country faces its greatest opportunity, Leo Krzycki, newly elected national chairman of the party, declared yesterday. Despite the party's poor showing in the New York election, Mr. Krzycki saw in the "disillusionment" with the efforts of the Roosevelt administration, in the Socialist victory in Bridgeport, Conn., and in the increasing radicalism of farmers in his own State of Wisconsin, evidences of the Socialist opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Impatient at the delay of employers and employes in reaching an agreement on a code for the graphic arts industry, Dr. Lindsay Rogers, Deputy Administrator, today made a new wages and hours proposal in an effort to bring the dispute to an early termination.

New York gave an old-fashioned welcome to the horse in Madison Square Garden last night, it was the opening day of the golden jubilee exhibition of the National Horse Show and seldom has so much enthusiasm been seen at a first night.

TOKYO, Nov. 8. -- Japanese suspect that after Maxim Litvinoff has negotiated recognition of Russia by the United States, which they expect will cause little difficulty, he will endeavor to reach some understanding which might serve to restrain Japanese ambitions on the mainland.

Tammany district leaders and district captains may have to account in court for the skull-thump- ing and shin-booting tactics that enlivened the election, particularly on the East Side and in Harlem, according to a statement yesterday by George Abrams, chief investigator for the Honest Ballot Association.

MADRID, Nov. 8 -- A touch of humor was added today to the second International Press Conference, meeting here under the auspices of the League of Nations, when Mr. Rosenberg, a Russian delegate, proposed that correspondents of any newspapers or news services receiving money from armament firms be forbidden to operate in foreign countries.

The engagement of two singers, Carlo Pel Corso, Italian dramatic tenor, and Virgilio Lazzari, basso, was announced yesterday for the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera by General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza. The addition to the company of ten singers was announced last Spring, making a total of twelve for the season which opens on Dec. 26.
Thousands of congratulatory messages, it was said yesterday, had been received by Mayor-Elect F.H. LaGuardia. The following was received from Mayor O'Brien, his Tammany rival:

Exchange on London ran up yesterday, in terms of dollars, to $4.98. This invited on the market the comment that so high a price had never been reached in our times, except for the three months after the European war broke out. The reason for the higrh rate in 1914 was that London was drawing heavily on New York and that no gold could be shipped because of the risk of capture by German warships.

War to the hilt between the Roosevelt Democratic faction headed by Postmaster General James A. Farley and Secretary of State Edward J. Plynn, Bronx leader, and Tammany was indicated yesterday. The leadership of John F. Curry, Tammany chieftain, and that of John H. McCooey, his Brooklyn ally, may depend on the result of this struggle, of which the independent Mayoralty candidacy of Joseph V. McKee, backed by Messrs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Of the nineteen States which it is now known will be wet when repeal of national prohibition becomes effective, ten have already adopted State liquor control laws.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Labor members of the parliamentary opposition voted unanimously in a private meeting today under the chairmanship of George Lansbury to offer motion Monday censuring the government on its foreign policy.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The final blow to prohibition in the United States was greeted here today with restrained satisfaction.

Fordham's football squad was occupied for more than three hours at Fordham Field yesterday in a complete rehearsal of its plays and climaxed the lengthy session with a hard scrimmage against the Maroom freshman eleven. The contact work was the first that the Rams have had in practice for a month.

As the government-sponsored depreciation of the dollar carried the currency yesterday to the lowest value in more than sixty years, financial markets responded with a sharp rise in stock and commodity prices and a resounding fall in government and other high-grade bonds.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess de Caraman Chimay of Paris are at the Pierre.

OMAHA, Nov. 8 -- Invading the heart of the Midwest farm strike area to answer "disturbing" criticism of the National Recovery Administration, General Hugh S. Johnson predicted today that the concentration of all the powerful influences of the Roosevelt recovery program would be felt throughout the agricultural belt in the next three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 6:
Earnings of the Timken Roller Bearing Company and subsidiaries for the nine months and the quarter ended on Sept. 30 showed a marked improvement over those of the corresponding periods a year Ago.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 8 -- All scrimmage sessions were called off by Coach MeCracken today as a precautionary measure for the Lafayette squad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read THE TIMES daily and listen to many addresses over the radio boosting the NRA, but I believe that not one of you gets down to the real cause of the depression.

ROME, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A fundamental reshaping of the corporative structure of the Fascist State was undertaken at a National Council of Corporations meeting today over which Premier Mussolini presided.

MR. JOHN HEYDLER, president of the National League, sat in his office yesterday talking about small matters, and finally reached the point where be was discussing with great seriousness just one strand of thread.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Fluctuations today on the Boerse in both stocks and bonds were exceedingly narrow, being chiefly fractional. There were a few notable exceptions, such as Julius Berger, which rose 3 points, and Bremen Wool, which lost 6 points.

With a victory won, substantial enough to give to Mayor-elect LaGuardia a Fusion Board of Estimate to back him in his program for the rehabilitation of the city government, the first thing to which he will give thought is charter revision involving abolition of the Aldermanic Board and many other fundamental changes.
Fifteen families were made homeless last night when a two-alarm fire, fanned by a high wind, spread through lour attached frame houses on Fifty-sixth Road at Sixty-first Street, Maspeth, Queens.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- The Democratic party made important gains at the polls in New Jersey yesterday, but failed to seize control of the Legislature.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 8. -- Abdullah ibn Hussein, Emir of Transjordan, has invited the representatives of all the Arab parties in Palestine for a conference to discuss the situation in Palestine.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- A new national system of unemployment relief and an overhauling of the existing system of unemployment insurance are proposed in a bill which Sir Henry Betterton, Minister of Labor, introduced in the House of Commons today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 9. -- None of the band of young naval officers charged, with the assassination of Premier Ki Inukai, or with complicity in the act, which was committed on May 15, 1932, will suffer the death penalty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Dlscussions looking toward Russian recognition appeared to be proceeding smoothly here today, and some observers were predicting that President Roosevelt would conclude the conferences with Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, by Saturday.

The University of Edinburgh has celebrated her 350th anniversary, with Sir JAMES BARRIE as Chancellor presiding. It would be inferred that his address was not of the solemn, conventional sort. He even became so familiar as to apostrophize the University as " Grandmamma."
LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Kuvera, Mrs. K. Ramsey's sturdy 4-year-old son of Fair-Miss Cynthia, proved best of the field which contested in the Florence Purse at Latonia today.
The New York Junior League squash racquets team triumphed yesterday for the second consecutive week in the interclub championship tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Bondholders yesterday bid in the Manhattan Towers at 2,162-68 Broadway, the feature item of a busy day in the auction marts. Eight other Manhattan parcels and five Bronx properties, also under the hammer in foreclosure proceedings, went to the respective plaintiffs.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Paul Bonhoure, hairdresser of Tarascon, whose National Lottery ticket H-18,414 yesterday won him 5,000,000 francs ($307,000 at the current rate), was asleep when he made his fortune.

WESTMOUNT, Que., Nov. 8 (Canadian Press) -- John Alexandre Beall, scion of prominent Maryland family, a participant in the Civil War and a former Assistant Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, died at his home here today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Heavy votes in municipalities tabulated tonight swept Kentucky steadily toward ratification of the prohibition repeal amendment. The ballots were counted after a violent election day, which saw sixteen men shot to death, but some of these killings were not traceable to ballot disorders.

Charles Franklin, George A. Ellis and John F. Russell Jr. were elected yesterday directors of the Manhattan Railway Company to succeed the late M.S. Burrill, Herman Baruch, who resigned, and Lionel Straus, who was not renominated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP). -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve $1,818,750 of notes to be given to the Public Works Administration for a loan to buy 50,000 tons of steel rails.

Wet leaders in the long fight against national prohibition expressed their delight at the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment in statements yesterday, while outstanding drys declared war anew on alcohol.

Unkind, not to say malicious, people are gloating over the political setback of a great and good man. The city election is described as having dealt a terrible blow to the prestige of the myriad-officed if not myriad-minded JAMES FARLEY. But consider how that willing horse has been overworked.

After being robbed of money and jewelry totaling about $3,000 by seven hold-up men in the lodge rooms at 119 Powell Street, Brooklyn, sixteen members of the board of governors of the Conquerors Club were forced to disrobe to their underwear shortly before last midnight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Prices of hogs were steady to strong here early today, but the demand was less aggressive and some late sales showed a decline of 5 to 10 cents on some medium grades at the last. Further gains in the price of fresh pork helped the market for a time, but it is believed the recent upturn in hogs will result in swelling the movement in the immediate future.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The closest election race in WestChester was in the town of North Castle, where it was found after a canvass of the votes today that Hannibal Fiore, White Plains attorney and Democratic leader of North Castle, had been elected Justitce of the Peace with a margin of six votes, defeating the incumbent police justice, Arthur S. Pietschker, who has held the position for about twenty-five years.

Metals, rubber, cocoa, hides and cottonseed oil futures registered sharp gairis yesterday on the commodity exchanges here. Other staples remained irregular and quiet. Sharp weakness in the dollar was described as the principal reason for the gains.

The opening of the Class A play in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night brought about one decided upset when the City Athletic Club team, playing on its own courts, defeated the Columbia University Club players, 3 to 2.

MUNICH, Nov. 8 -- This city, with tens of thousands of German visitors and several thousand more Nazi storm troopers, is celebrating today and tomorrow a political miracle. The miracle is the resurrection of the National Socialist party of Adolf Hitler and its marvelous endurance and growth until at length it has swept over all Germany, and within Germany its power is limitless.

United States Government bonds were the centre of attention yesterday in the listed bond market, with the group displaying pronounced weakness early in the day, when at one time six of the fourteen longterm issues sold below par. Weakness of the dollar in the foreign-exchange market caused heavy selling of the government issues, but with the subsequent rally the close was steady.

HAVANA, Nov. 8 -- After many hours' fighting, the government had failed tonight to crush the revolt of the ABC revolutionary organization. The revolt began at 2:30 A. M. in an effort to restore Dr. Carlos Manual de Cespedes to the Presidency.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters paid tribute last night to the memory of Edmund Clarence Stedman, American poet, critic and essayist, who was born 100 years ago yesterday and died on Jan. 18, 1908.

Geopge H. Charls has resigned as secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, it was announced yesterday. He went to the institute soon after Robert P. Lamont, former Secretary of Commerce, assumed its presidency in August, 1932.

Pasquale Amato is to celebrate on Nov. 20 at the Hippodrome the twenty-fifth anniversary of his American debut, which took place at the Metropolitan in 1908, Gatti-Casazza's first season. The baritone made his bow here in "Traviata" with Marcella Sembrich and the late Enrico Caruso.

An application for the listing of 743,734 shares of $5 par value common stock of the Marancha Corporation, which will be issued and distributed pro rata as a dividend to holders of the common stock of the South Porto Rico Sugar Company of record as of yesterday, was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Federal Trade Commission is making a careful study of the operation of the Federal Securities Act and will be prepared to present its viewpoint to Congress as to the desirability of amendments or additional paragraphs to clarify sections, such as that imposing civil liability, over which there has been lively dispute.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8. -- An American offer to take Argentine Treasury notes, instead of twenty-year bonds, to thraw frozen credits was presented to Finance Minister Pinedo this week by the local subcommittee, as intermediary for the New York committee, which drew up suggestions and cabled them here.

Resale of a Brooklyn apartment house by an operator and an investment purchase and several leasehold transactions in Manhattan were reported yesterday. The six-Charles Walzer, who recently accommodates sixty families, is at 354 Ocean Avenue.

New Yorkers listened to the death knell of prohibition yesterday without missing a swallow. News of the deciding vote for repeal caused no halt in speakeasy drinking, nor did it evoke joy and celebration though business at the bars picked up perceptibly.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, which was assured by the result of Tuesday's vote, was viewed yesterday in shipping circles as a boon to the American merchant marine operating in the foreign trade.

The first piano recital Artur Schnable has given in this city this season, which took place last night in Carnegie Hall, was devoted entirely to the sonatas of Beethoven and was a demonstration of extraordinary mastery and understanding.

New York University's football team engaged in a lengthy scrimmage against the reserves at Ohio Field yesterday. The workout lasted more than two hours, half of which was devoted to the contact session. The Violet squad is working hard for the battle with Fordham.

Considering the activity, interest and strength shown on the various markets yesterday, Wall Street felt that perhaps the stalemate might have been broken. There was a lively advance on all the domestic exchanges, coinciding with the further depreciation of the dollar in relation to foreign currencies.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- George D. Widener's Chicstraw, winner of the Walden Handicap last Saturday, scored in the Pimlico Handicap at Pimlico today, returning 5 to 2 to those who backed him in the totalisator.

Samuel Skoblow, who was once described by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy as one of the most dangerous firebugs in the country, pleaded guilty in the Kings County Court yesterday to a charge of first-degree arson.
ISTRES, France, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A great French armada of twenty-seven planes, manned by fifty-four picked aviators, started a mass flight to Africa early today.

Nick Holde, formerly general manager of A.C. Blumenthal's theatrical activities, will depart on the President Lincoln today on a world cruise, accompanied by Mrs. Holde. He hopes to acquire on his trip a foreign play, to be produced under his own management.
PARIS, Nov. 8. -- The dollar touched an all-time low record of 16.20 francs on the Paris exchange today, demonstrating that the American policy was now working smoothly.
There has been a certain amount of agitation of late for the rules makers to give the attack in football more of a "break."

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Buying of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade was of a better class than had appeared in some time. Houses With Eastern connections were much more active on the bull side and many local operators who had been inclined to do little of late were more disposed to trade freely.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Complete returns from New York City piled up big majorities of affirmative votes for the $60,000,000 unemployment relief bond issue and three of the proposed amendments to the state constitution, but left amendment 2 with the negative votes far ahead.

Trade Gain Encourages Stores. Support for their contention that weather has been the chief stumbling block to trade expansion was seen here in the good trade yesterday following the heavy increases made on Election Day. Executives reported their increases on Tuesday as ranging up to 25 per cent over the same day a year ago for the store generally and in excess of this figure for some individual departments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Cotton ginned from the current crop up to Nov. 1 was placed by the Census

Washington will be the centre of unusual activities among conservationists and sportsmen in January and succeeding months if the plans already formulated in many quarters are not changed by the time the next Congress meets.

James Roosevelt, son of the President of the United States, is returning today from a brief visit to Europe on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt. Others arriving on the ship front Mediterranean ports include:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Frank German, vica president of the United Textile Workers, and a committee of silk workers from Scranton, Pa., will go before the National Labor Board tomorrow and request action in the case of silk employers who allegedly refused to comply with a decision of the board last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Although an effort will be made to legalize the sale and consumption of light wines and beers on the ships of the navy, the opinion is general in naval circles that the Josephus Daniels order, which made the American sea service the only "bone dry navy," will continue in force.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The United States has notified the League of Nations that it concurs, except in a few particulars, in the conclusions and recommended procedure of the League's Manchurian Advisory Committee for practical application of the principle of non-recognition of Manchukuo.

In skirmishing for position in 1934 the New Jersey Democrats failed on Tuesday to win the Essex delegation of twelve members and thus obtain control of the Assembly. They did, however, gain five seats in other counties. They carried Newark by 8,000, but this advantage was easily overcome by Republican majorities in the outlying towns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Until yesterday James A. Farley had a perfect score in politics. It seemed that he couldn't lose. Now the national politi- cal community, which was inclined to think him invulnerable, has concluded that he, too, is human and subject to the consequences of the mistakes it was presumed he could make with impunity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The statement issued by the White House concerning the new civil works program was as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Appraisal committees appointed by the district chairmen of the Federal eposit Liquidation Division to survey the assets of banks in New Jersey to make possible the granting of loans by the Federal Government were announced today by Colonel William H. Kelly, commissioner of banking and insurance.

Three games tonight will usher in the National Hockey League's seventeenth season. There will be contests at Montreal, Toronto and Chicago. Another trio of games is booked for Saturday, but New York fans will not see a league encounter until next Thursday.

The Skin and Cancer Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital receive $5,000 and $2,500, respectively, in the will of Raymond Blackwood, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. They also share equally in the residuary estate. Mr. Blackwood, who died Sept. 23, lived at 581 Hudson Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- In the only contact scrimmage for the Georgia game, the Yale varsity today battled the freshmen and scored three touchdowns. Andy Callan, regular fullback, who replaced Earl Nikkel after some twenty minutes of play, took two across and Dick Cummins, second-stringer, who was used at both left halfback and right halfback, the other.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- The German Supreme Court, which for seven weeks has been sitting in judgment on the Reichstag fire, was today turned into an international forum for debate on the rival revolutionary theories and practices of National Socialism and communism.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Great Britain today enthusiastically hailed the doom of prohibition in America. The action of the American people is welcomed for two reasons. First, as a boon to Scottish and Irish distilleries and English breweries, and second as a moral vindication of the principle of personal liberty.

Sonia Essin, who had a song recital last night in the Town Hall, possesses a true contralto of rich, dark and beautiful timbre; a voice whose lower register especially inevitably summons to the memory the utterance of Erda, though it was concerned last night with things quite different -- Cherubini, Brahms, Strauss and Wolff among them.

The protest of the Eastern railroads against the door service planned by the Pennsylvania, the Erie and the Grand Trunk railways was filed with the I.C.C. yesterday by D.T. Lawrence, chairman of the Trunk Line Association. The petition held that the proposed charges for the service would not cover the cost and that they were therefore tantamount to a reduction in rates.

One of the first moves the Fusion administration which assumes office on Jan. 1, it was predicted yesterday in financial and political circles, will be to seek legislative permission to reopen the 1934 budget to pave the way for numerous municipal economies.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, will announce the regulations for the control of the sale of liquor here for publication in tomorrow morning's newspapers, under the authority of the New State Liquor Control Law.

Of more than $400,000,000 of new bonds up for authorization by voters in many communities throughout the country on Tuesday, including financing for unemployment relief, soldiers' bonus and public improvements, as well as municipal light and power projects, available returns yesterday indicated that about $300,000,000 were approved.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 8 -- Three explanations are given here for the heavy vote which North Carolina gave yesterday against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Harvard continued its hard work for the annual football game with West Point in the stadium Saturday, staging a long workout today in which the coaches stressed the necessity for more speed on offense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Vice Admiral R.A.R. Plunkett Ernle-Erle-Drax and the officers of the visiting British ships Danae and Norfolk were guests of honor at a luncheon given today by Secretary of the Navy Swanson. This afternoon the visitors held a reception on board the Danae.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt moved today for determination of the administration's new liquor policy, as it relates to the abandonment of national prohibition on Dec. 5 and to maintaining a semblance of Federal control until that date.

Charging that "certain widespread criticisms" of the NRA emanated either from "misunderstanding or misrepresentation of both the means employed and their objectives," Donald R. Richberg, general counsel for the National Recovery Administration, replied yesterday to opponents of the recovery program.
The task of perfecting a defense against Navy's highly regarded running and aerial attacks occupied most of the attention of Columbia's football squad yesterday at Baker Field.

The Whitney Museum of American Art opened, with a private view yesterday afternoon, its exhibition called "Twentieth Century New York in Paintings and Prints." The show opens to the public this afternoon at 2 o'clock and will he current until Nov. 30.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- Fritz Leiber, portrayer of Shakespearean and other characters, who is one of the outstanding members of the cast of "Mary of Scotland," playing at Ford's Theatre here, said today he would sever his connection with the Theatre Guild, Inc., producers of "Mary of Scotland," at the close of the show Saturday night.

Samuel Seabury took the stand yesterday at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel as a character, witness for the defendant. After his testimony the trial was adjourned until today, owing to the illness of James G. Wallace, Assistant District Attorney.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The Rev. Dr. Nehemiah Boynton, prominent Congregational clergyman, formerly of Brooklyn, died suddenly this afternoon at his home in Medford, Mass., according to word received here by his son, Edward Chadbourne Boynton.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- If Germany should refuse to accept any control of armaments, League of Nations members would apply the sanctions provided in the covenant, Joseph Paul-Boncour, Foreign Minister, said in reply to a question in the Chamber's Foreign Affairs Committee today.

New york Origins. It may very well have happened to the Communist candidate for Mayor in the late campaign that some one in the audience indignantly told him if he did not like the way things are run in this country he should go back where he or his immediate ancestors came from.

Heartened by a net grain of seven seats in the Assembly, Republican leaders made plans yesterday to consolidate their advances in the hope that by intensive work in the coming year they might make Tuesday's increase of strength serve as a prelude to victory in the Gubernatorial election next year.

Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador at Washington, expressed his conviction yesterday that if this country abandoned its rigid policy of a single tariff in favor of reciprocal concessions, a "most beneficial" agreement could be negotiated between France and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A "fundamental change" in the Federal relief program, providing governmental employment for 4,000,000 unemployed men this Winter on a civil works program, was announced today by the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The election reaction among political observers here today was that the chief factors entering into the contests were a popular wish to continue liberal political thought in government, and a revolt against political bosses.

The stake programs of the Belmont Spring and Fall meetings, which for years have been the richest and greatest in the country, are being held in abeyance by Joseph E. Widener, president of the WestChester Racing Association, according to an announcement yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Indications were today that a man outside the department would be picked to fill the place vacated by the appointment of Joseph C. O'Mahoney as Senator.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Seven members of the Touhy gang were indicted today for the kidnapping of John (Jake the Barber) Factor, wealtlhy stock operator, who is fighting extradition to England to stand trial for swindling investors. Four of the indicted men are on trial now at St. Paul for the abduction of William Hamm Jr., two are fugitives and one is in custody here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Soviet-American parley looks like it will break all rules of international conferences -- that is, instead of being long-winded, laborious and inconclusive, there seems reasonable probability that it will be brief and decisive.

The favorable action taken on the Sunday Sports Bill by the voters in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh in Tuesday's election, which now will make it possible for the Phillies and Pirates in the National League and the Athletics in the American to play home games on the Sabbath, was hailed with satisfaction yesterday by baseball men.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Reorganization of the principal settlement agency of the Bureau of Internal Revenue was announced today by Commissioner Guy T. Helering.

Although the government's crop reporting board yesterday raised its estimate of this year's cotton crop 215,000 bales to a total larger by 98,000 bales than the crop grown last year, the increase was less than many operators had feared, and prices on the Cotton Exchange here improved about $1.50 a bale net.

Raymond Philippe, the French banker who is credited with having devised the measures by which France stabilized the franc in 1928 and who has been visiting in this country, discussed the United States monetary policy yesterday before he sailed for home on the Bremen.

Tuesday was a bad day for the Ins. The voters were on their " kickingest toes." The New York recipients of dispossession notices ought to be able to bear their sufferings better, knowing that so many other patriots are about to be subjected to the cruelties of eviction.

All the domestic speculative markets recovered vigorously yesterday as the dollar, manipulated by government authority, sank to a new low level in terms of foreign currencies. There was a spirited advance late in the day on the Stock Exchange after the commodity markets had pointed sharply upward.

Repeal of national prohibition will become effective soon after 2 o'clock on the afternoon of Tuesday, Dec. 5, according to yesterday's indications. The Eighteenth Amendment, the Volstead Act and the 3.2 Beer Law all will expire simultaneously and the sale of all liquors, wines and beers will become legalized in New York and other wet States.

For the third consecutive month, production of steel in the United States declined in October, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. The reduction, however, was much smaller than in the two preceding months and the rate of operations was higher than the average for first ten months of the year and approximately twice the average for 1932.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that sales of its cars to consumers in the United States last month totaled 63,518, or more than twice the sales in October, 1932, when 26,941 units were sold. Sales in September this year were 71,458 cars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A forecast that farmer's cash income for the period from August to December would show an increase of 20 per cent over the same period of last year was issued today with Secretary Wallace's approval.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Mass production of small airplanes to sell for about $700 was proposed today by Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics of the Department of Commerce.

A movement to help national recovery by emphasis on economic self-sufficiency and reciprocity in foreign trade was started yesterday by James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, at a luncheon in India House.

J. Thomas McNerny, who ran for Alderman in the Fifth district of Queens as an independent, was carrying a rifle last night and executing martial manoeuvres with grim determination, his fiery shock of red hair virtually exuding sparks.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 8. -- The city of Long Beach proved to be the only haven of refuge for the Nassau County Democrats, a retabulation of the vote revealed today. There the entire Democratic ticket, headed by Charles Gold for Mayor, was swept into office.

Captain Georg Schmitt, who arrived here on Monday with authority from Berlin to perfect the organization of the German Stahlhelm in this country and to coordinate it with other Nazi bodies in support of the New Germany, was subpoenaed yesterday by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

Because newspapers, in reporting games played by the football team of Cooper Union, used the name "Cooper Union team," instead of "Cooper Union Students team," the members of the squad -- about fourteen in number -- have been suspended until after the Christmas holidays.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- King Nadir shah of Afghanistan was assassinated today in his capital, Kabul. His 19-year-old son, Mohammed Zahir Khan, was proclaimed King, taking the title King Zahir Shah.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- In the first final decision made under the NRA code for legitimate theatres. Sol A. Rosenblatt, Deputy Administrator, today ruled that the Broadway Theatre Ticket Company of New York shall be barred for one week from receiving tickets for attractions by code producers and that Courtney Burr, producer of "Sailor, Beware!" was guiltless of violations of the code.

Objections to the will and codicil of William W. McLaughlin, former Chief Inspector of Police, who died at Mount Kisco, N.Y., Oct. 12, were filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by four of his children. The documents were offered for probate Oct. 23.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Delegates of nine countries signed a convention here today to protect the wild life in Africa. Creation of national parks in every country or colony in Africa was recommended to prevent indiscriminate slaughter of animals.

An urgent plea to every person engaged in any phase of the building industry to support the code now awaiting final adoption in Washington was made to the members of the New York Building Congress by Colonel Willard T. Chevalier, editor of The Engineering News Record and a member of the code committee of the Construction League of the United States, at a luncheon of the congress yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Harrison Williams of Bayville was awarded the George Dupont Pratt Medal for the most meritorious exhibit in the twenty-eighth annual chrysanthemum show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the Pratt oval on the Pratt estate.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 8. -- Jasper McLevy, Socialist, who was elected Mayor by a plurality of 6,070 votes in the heaviest municipal election vote ever recorded here, sought refuge today from newspaper men and crowds of admirers by climbing atop a house in Southport, where he worked at his trade, repairing the roof.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Alfred E. Smith, John J. Raskob and otber participants in a syndicate account obtained a loan of $336,000, subsequently enlarged, from the Chase National Bank soon after the stock market decline of 1929, according to information submitted by the bank to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

A new "choreographic burlesque," entitled "The Seven Heroes," was added last night to the program of the Jooss Ballet at the Forrest Theatre, and revealed both the choreographer and the company in their most obstreperous humors. In extremely bright peasant costumes against amusing decors that looked as if a child might have conceived them in a mad moment, Mr. Jooss tells a rollicking folk tale with great gusto.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Army overwhelmed Syracuse at soccer today, 5 to 0. The cadets scored two goals in the first quarter and added two more in the second to lead, 4 to 0, at half-time.

The Royal Canoe Club of London, England, has accepted the challenge issued by the American Canoe Association on behalf of William A. Bartholomae Jr. of Los Angeles for an International Challenge Cup decked-canoe sailing series in 1934, it was announced yesterday.

Salaries of the administrative officials of the Staten Island Edison Company were increased as a result of their compliance "with the NRA code during the last two months, it was revealed yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8. -- Rear Admiral Pedro S. Casal has resigned as Minister of Marine as a result of a conflict with high commanding navy officers over disciplinary measures against warrant officers and sailors accused of fomenting discontent in the ranks.

MUNICH, Nov. 9 -- The Nations Socialists' celebration of their first "putsch" of ten years ago -- the abortive "putsch" of the very same party that now holds Germany in the hollow of its hand -- reached its culmination here today in a great semi-military memorial demonstration in which 10,000 uniformed and disciplined men took part.

Attorneys for the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case have in their possession evidence indicating that their own lives as well as those of their clients will be in danger if they are forced to retry the case in Decatur, Ala., it became known yesterday.

Excited speculation in the foreign exchanges, accompanied by a further sharp depreciation in the value of the dollar, overshadowed all other market developments yesterday. Stocks and commodities continued to advance in unusually active trading.

Jobs Won and Lost. Enthusiasts say that the end of prohibition means 500,000 new jobs. For the moment it is interesting to speculate on the jobs which, will disappear with prohibition. Some of the doomed occupations, trades and skills would be:
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Asked in an interview tonight if he was willing to have written into the newspaper code his recent interpretation assuring freedom of the press, General Johnson replied:

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the tenth period of their fiscal year showed the best increase over the previous year since December, 1929, the gain being 20.9 per cent. In the ninth period sales were 8 per cent above last year. In the eighth period, they were 18 per cent higher, the best increase up to that time since 1929.

Chairman MULROONEY and his colleagues on the State Commission announce this morning the terms on which legal liquor will return to New York on the afternoon of Dec. 5. Their regulations cover the period between that date and April 1 of next year. Authority to prescribe temporary rules was given them by the Legislature, which intends to establish later a more permanent system of control.
ROCKPORT, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Fifty troopers, drawn from all over the State, tonight were housed in emergency quarters in this town after starting an intensive search for a murderer here.

In a daring hold-up in the busy Grand Central Terminal area last night, four men stole watches, rings, brooches and other jewelry, valued by the police at between $3,000 and $4,000, last night and walked away, seemingly unobserved, after having bound the manager and two clerks and left them imprisoned in a washroom.

Two line changes were made by Coach Chick Meehan yesterday as Manhattan continued its preparations for the battle with Holy Cross at Ebbets Field tomorrow. Vin Liberton, a 170-pound guard, was moved into the forward wall in place of the heavier Matt Murray and Andy Dorn went to left end in place of the injured Tip Kaye.

The money market felt the first impact of the government-propelled fall of the dollar yesterday. As prices of government bonds melted away, giving rise to higher and higher yields, bill dealers took steps to protect themselves against possible offerings of paper by advancing discount rates one-eighth of 1 per cent.

A cabinet of men of commanding ability and familiarity with the affairs of their city, of unquestioned integrity and proved devotion to the city's interests, was pledged by Mayor-elect LaGuardia yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne gave a dinner last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Max Shoop, who have just arrived from Paris; Mrs. Richmond Temple, Mrs. M. Dangrerfield Holmes, Miss Antonie Straussman, Inzer B. Wyatt, Carter M. Braxton and Edward Seawell.
New York City, the rest of the country and a large part of the civilized world will celebrate tonight and tomorrow the fifteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice which ended the World War.

James Roosevelt, son of the President, returned with Mrs. Roosevelt yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after a six-week trip abroad. Their travels in England, France and Italy included meetings with Prime Minister MacDonald, President Lebrun of France, Premier Mussolini and the Pope.

EVERY once in so often Sven Hedin, the pertinacious Swedish explorer, comes out of the wastes of Inner Asia with a batch of news to stir the blood. The latest bulletin from the desert front, in which Dr. Hedin gathers together the reports, meteorological, geological and archaeological, of his collaborators in the 1927 expedition through the dunes of Gobi, is called "Riddles of the Gobi Desert" (Dutton, $5).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The dally average volume of Federal Reserve credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,564,000,000, an increase of $15,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $341,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Nov. were announced today:

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 9 -- Following the advice of his physicians. Governor Gore sailed this afternoon for New York en route to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, where he will undergo a kidney examination and possibly an operation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Evidence against two gangs which have taken between $800,000 and $1,000,000 through, kidnappings in various parts of the country was made public today by investigators who now have the principals under arrest.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- There was further sharp depreciation in the dollar today, with the rate of exchange, for the first time since 1914, over $5 to the pound sterling, against last night's closing at $4.94 3/4, the dollar opened at $4.98 1/2, quickly fell to $5.04 and continued downward to close at $5.06 1/4.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 9 -- Delegates from all parts of Brazil were negotiating in numerous groups today in preparation for the opening of the Constituent Assembly tomorrow afternoon.
BERLIN, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 7 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

Health conditions among residents of the United States and Canada for the nine-month period from January to September this year were characterized yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's statistical bulletin as having been "exceptionally good."
Sale of a Kearny business parcel and a Hoboken lease featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- What the grain trade regards as a flight of the dollar into commodities became more pronounced today on the Board of Trade, buying being stimulated materially by the soaring rates for sterling and other foreign exchanges.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 8, unless specified:
BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- A romance of Georgi Dimitroff was described in the Reichstag fire trial today when Frau Ammy Kruger was forced to testify that her relations with him bad led to her divorce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Postmaster General Farley, Democratic National Chairman, asserted in a formal statement today that the recent elections showed a strong Democratic tide and no diminution in the popularity of the Democratic Administration.

That the domestic security and commodity markets should have been influenced so completely yesterday by the action of the dollar could have been no surprise after what has been happening in the last few days. Stocks moved actively at times, and in the last hour there was an extremely lively advance.

Dry Goods Jobbers Optimistic. While dry goods wholesalers reported yesterday that they made few purchases in the primary markets during the week, they expressed the opinion that the business outlook was much brighter. Any stiffening in prices would bring a sizable volume of buying into the market, not for spot but for Spring needs, they said.

Opposition to the second proposal to celebrate German day in this city was abandoned yesterday by Major Julius Hochfelder, counsel for the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, who were instrumental in inducing Mayor O'Brien to prohibit the first celebration two weeks ago.

The pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, which was issued yesterday, showed that the corporation's holdings of cash and United States Government securities increased sharply in the three months.

John W. Davis, summing up yesterday as chief defense counsel in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, insisted his client had been innocent in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States, as charged in the indictment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The Rutgers football practice was devoted entirely to an intensive drill against forward passes today. The varsity line worked for more than an hour against the reserves, while third-string backfield men tossed many forwards.

Flashing an efficient ground attack that combined power and precision, Poly Prep of Brooklyn registered a 14-to-7 football triumph over its traditional rival, St. Paul's School of Garden City, yesterday at Ebbets Field. A crowd of 3,000 saw the game, the proceeds of which went to the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities for the benefit of crippled children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- Speeding eastward today on special trains were 1,280,000 quarts of California's finest old wines. No interference with the great wine shipments was expected in dry States through which liquor trains must pass en route to Eastern distributing centres, as all such shipments have been dispatched under government permit labeled for medicinal, sacramental and other legal purposes.
