WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 7:

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- The establishment of a, German air-mail line across the South Atlantic early next year was assured today when news reached Berlin that the flying boat Monsoon of the Lufthansa. Lines had completed a flight from Africa to South America after alighting beside and then being taken aboard the "swimming island" in mid ocean exactly on schedule time.

Rameses V. the austere, roundhorned ram which has been Fordham's mascot for the last three years, was kidnapped early yesterday morning and a near riot on the New York University campus late last night failed to solve the mystery.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Under the heading "Italian Victory," II Progresso Italo-Americano, the leading Italian-language morning newspaper in New York, hailed the LaGuardia victory yesterday in an article on its front page signed by Generoso Pope, the publisher.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- A project to auction the import licenses on agricultural products has been prepared and signed by the Minister of Agriculture, it was learned today. It is now going the rounds of the other Ministries and probably will take the form of a decree within the next few weeks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Professor Albert Einstein and a few friends had a musical evening tonight at the house at 2 Library Place here, which the German physicist and Mrs. Einstein are occupying while the scientist is filling his instructorship in the Institute for Advanced Study.

NEW YORK. Miss Beatrice de Bavier Greeff will give a reception on Sunday afternoon at her home, 1,212 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Martha Lee Sims and Theodore E. Greeff, whose marriage will take place next Tuesday noon at the home of Miss Sims, 1,165 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Soviet-American discussions might in a sense be compared to a legal case which is being prepared for the President's consideration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- The Yale University A.A. today announced rowing and baseball schedules for 1934. Three varsity races and a number of tests for the other crews have been listed, while the baseball players will engage in twenty-four games, fourteen at Yale Field and ten out of town.
Appleton-Century Company says that it has an advance sale of 36,000 copies on the new edition of Andrew Dickson White's "Fiat Money Inflation in France," which will be published next Monday.

Foreclosure auctions again contributed most activity to the local realty field yesterday. Twenty-one parcels went to plaintiffs, against fourteen in the preceding day. Yesterday's list showed fifteen offerings of properties in Manhattan and six in the Bronx.

A STORY bobbed up from somewhere that Coach Rip Miller of the Navy, for various nautical reasons, was going to send his second-stringers against Columbia at Baker Field tomorrow. This drew no comment from the Columbia players or from Coach Lou Little of the Lions. Possibly they thought the news was too good to be true.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Seated around a cake weighing 500 pounds, eight feet tall and six feet in diameter, 700 persons tonight paid tribute to Marie Dressier on the sixty-second birthday anniversary of the actress.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries report for the year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated deficit of $390,684 after all charges, reserves, taxes, underlying dividends and minority interest, contrasting with a net income of $6,160,502 for the preceding year.
Mayor O'Brien will retire on a pension of $14,933.12 on Dec. 31. He said yesterday that he would return to the private practice of law.

Wasn't it HENRY GEORGE who said, Out of his Own unhappy experience, that the surest way to make a political doctrine ineffective is to "organize" it? There is already talk of making the Fusion party in this city a permanent organization. Asked his opinion about this yesterday, Mr. LAGUARDIA said that it might be attempted, and might be a good thing, but that he would have no part in it.

Lennox Robinson has a cleansing sense of humor which is likewise a sense of proportion. In "Is Life Worth Living?" which he staged at the Masque last evening, he has some droll things to say about the pernicious influence serious drama may have upon the people of a provincial Irish town.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Guns leveled at their backs, four members of Roger Touhy's Chicago gang watched today the selection of a jury in Federal court to try them on charges of kidnapping William Hamm, wealthy brewer, for $100,000 ransom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- American exporters massed opposition today to rate fixing provisions of a proposed code of competition for the shipping industry, while within the industry several groups offered resistance to the plan for a general code embracing all forms of water transportation.

The revival of elegance in fashions and the display of jewels added to the brilliance of the social scene at the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. The boxes and arena seats were filled with representatives of metropolitan society.

The principles of business conduct promulgated in the National Recovery Act will govern the building industry even after the emergency which inspired it has passed, in the opinion of Stephen F. Voorhees, chairman of the code committee of the Construction League of the United States.

Allotment of $135,000,000 of public funds to facilitate equipment purchases by the railroads and plans under way for the enlargement of the public works program are encouraging steel producers but are "not likely to affect steel mill operations materially until late in the year," according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

Samuel Skoblow, self-confessed "torch" for an alleged Brooklyn arson ring, admitted in the Kings County Court yesterday that he had set about fifty fires in Brooklyn, and said that he started thirty-six of them for Shields Wurzberg, Brooklyn fire adjusters, witn offices at 66 Court Street.
HAVANA, Nov. 9. -- Loyalist troops quelled a rebellion here today in a six-hour battle of machine guns and artillery in which more than 100 persons were killed and 175 or more were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The earmarking of $150,000,000 of Federal funds for loans on corn stored on farms was announced today by both the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the Commodity Credit Corporation on the eve of Secretary Wallace's departure for the Middlewest to preach the merits of the recovery program.

The only event of Interest in the day's money market was the advance in bill rates, 30 to 90 day maturities being marked up 1/3 in yield. Other dates were unchanged. This was the first variation since Aug. 30, when all bills were cut 1/3. The advance was not unexpected in view of the higher yields now obtaining on short-term government securities.
Following are the regulations of the New York State Alcoholic Bevarage Control Board governing sale of liquor and wine from the date of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The smooth-running schedule of conferences on Russian recognition was disrupted this afternoon by postponement of a meeting of President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, which had been scheduled for 5 P.M. A new engagement was made for noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Capital notes and debentures issued to State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System will be recognized as eligible capital if such banks apply for membership, according to a ruling just made by the Federal Reserve Board and announced today by Harvey C. Couch, head of the Non-Member Preferred Stock Board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
In excellent physical condition, Fordham's football squad spent three hours on Fordham Field yesterday in a final heavy workout in preparation for the battle with New York University tomorrow.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- Professor Erwin Schroedinger is an Austrian, and he was educated in his native country. In 1927 he succeeded Max Planck as Professor of Physics at Berlin University. Before the current semester opened he gave up that chair to accept a call to Oxford.

MANILA, P.I., Friday, Nov. 10 -- Acting Speaker Quintin Parades forced an abrupt adjournment of the Philippine Legislature last midnight amid scenes of the wildest confusion. This legal but previously unobserved action of adjourning a session precisely at the appointed time was totally unexpected.

Commodity prices rose briskly yesterday in fairly active trading, all staples advancing excepting sugar, adversely affected by the news of Cuban troubles. The advances were attributed almost entirely to the weakness of the dollar.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Investments made by the State Sinking Fund Commission in the last two years have caused a loss to New Jersey of $400,164, it was testified today before the Legislature's joint Committee on Economy and Reorganization.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Reports that Communists held a secret meeting at which lots were drawn to select a man to bomb Governor Ely's automobile as lie traveled from Westfield to Boston Tuesday has caused extraordinary precautions by the State police to guard the Governor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the intricately coordinated chain, both human and mechanical, extending between an event in current world history and the vast public to which news of it must be brought, reporter, communication facility, editor, typesetter, paper supplier, roaring press, distribution, the last named may achieve efficiency not inferior to the preceding links.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Now that the currency, under Administration management, has bit a sixty-year bottom, stock and commodity prices have spurted, and government and other high-grade bonds have had an equally sharp fall, interest here is centring more closely upon the related subjects of the greenback issue and the Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Economic discussions appear to be virtually barred by the United States from consideration at the Pan-American conference at Montevideo in December in the light of a White House statement, including the list of official delegates, issued here tonight.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- The government made a totally new departure in Italian finance today by inviting the public to subscribe to a State-guaranteed loan, the proceeds of which will be used for relief of private companies which find themselves in difficulties because of the depression.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The Boerse opened with a sagging trend today, attributed, in the main, to continued weakness in the dollar, which touched 2.65 marks, and to a decision by the courts that German dollar bonds are payable only in paper dollars.

Sparks from a machine in the basement of the Waterbury Rope Company plant at 101 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, started a fire yesterday morning that, destroyed the five-story factory building at an estimated loss of more than $100,000. Two hundred employes escaped unhurt.

More hunters will take the field for the opening of the New Jersey upland game bird season today than a year ago, according to official estimates made yesterday. A lower fee, the promise of more game and a wider area over which sportsmen may enjoy free shooting account for the large army of hunters.

Six first-round matches were played yesterday as competition began in the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club. H.A. Haines of the Yale Club and D.K. Clifford, Harvard Club representative, waged the most keenly fought of the opening clashes, with Haines winning, 12 -- 15, 18 -- 17, 15 -- 8.

A plea for wholehearted support of the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, on the ground that it is "vital to the mental welfare of our people" was made yesterday by Dr. C.M. Hincks, general director of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, at the annual meeting of that organization in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The old-type saloon and drinking at bars prohibited. Liquors or wines must be served at tables for consumption on premises, only in bona fide hotels, restaurants, clubs, vessels, or railroad cars.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The campaign launched yesterday to get 4,000,000 men off relief rolls and into employment on public works projects moved forward today on all fronts.

The protective committee for holders of United Post Offices Corporation first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1935, announced yesterday that more than a majority of the $4,345,000 bonds of the issue outstanding had been deposited with it.
Master chefs of New York's leading hotels were looking forward with keen anticipation yesterday to the wild fowl and game dishes that will be restored to the menu with the repeal of prohibition.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Shandon Farm Stable's Naval Cadet extended his recent winning streak, making it three in a row, when he romped in ahead of his field in the Autumn Handicap, feature event today at Latonia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Public Works Administration has rejected offers of several large New York banking houses to act as corporate trustee under equipment trusts to be set up in connection with loans to railroads for financing purchases of rolling stock and other equipment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Dummy scrimmaging on the defensive, with the scrubs ramming Georgia plays against the regulars for an hour today, comprised Yale's final hard practice before 'Saturday's game. Only signal rehearsals are scheduled for tomorrow.

Scoring one of the most brilliant upsets in the history or contract bridge competition, a dark horse team of four from Atlanta, Ga., defeated the defending champions in the first elimination round of the Vanderbilt Cup tournament, held last night in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

TORONTO, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, last year's National Hockey League champions, opened the 1933-34 National League season tonight by overwhelming the Boston Bruins, 6 to 1. The Bruins, rivals for the leagu title, carried the Leafs to five games and the longest overtime play-off game on record last Spring.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9. -- The 7-year-old Man o' War horse, Annapolis, captured the Masters of Foxhounds Steeplechase, feature event at Pimlico today. Over a track that was only good, the big brown juniper carried the colors of Mrs. T.H. Somerville to a length and a half victory over Drapeau.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Dr. Charles A. Eaton, Representative in Congress from the Fifth New Jersey District, filed today a petition in bankruptcy in the Federal court here. He listed liabilities at $160,925 and assets at $26,499.

One of the oldest business indices in this country, the monthly figures of the unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation, has been discontinued, it was announced yesterday by Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the corporation's board of directors and finance committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of last Saturday regarding the unanimous resolution of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York upholding the gold standard and sound currency was very timely when many widely divergent views are heard.

Asserting that the "prestige of amateur sport" has been damaged by the loose and conflicting character of existing regulations, Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Association, took the initiative yesterday in a movement to bring about uniformity in the amateur code for all branches of American athletics.
Following is the text of the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms, approved by the President and effective on Nov. 18.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- In London's ancient Guildhall where historic declarations of policy have been made for hundreds of years Prime Minister MacDonald appealed tonight to the rulers of Germany to re-enter the disarmament negotiations.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 9 (AP). -- The battleship Wyoming, anchored off Egmont Bar, thirty-seven miles from here, since Saturday, departed tonight to sail to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, issued a statement today relative to filing returns concerning the tax on floor stocks of articles processed wholly or in chief value from hogs and field corn.

An unusually large increase in bank clearings at leading centre in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday was partly due to the payment on Nov. 1 for such of the United States Treasury bonds of 1943-45 as were purchased for cash.
MONTREAL, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The veteran cast of the Montreal Canadiens started a new National Hockey League season with a victory tonight, downing the Detroit Red Wings, 2 to 1, before a big crowd.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Wholesale commodity prices today were shown to have remained virtually unchanged during the week ended Nov. 4.

Copies or the code of fair competition under which Stock Exchanges throughout the country will operate in accordance with the National Recovery Act will be mailed today by the United States Government Printing Office to the individual brokers.

Relief for 28,000 restaurants of the city from the minimum wage provision of the President's Reemployment Agreement, which restaurant keepers have declared to be too burdensome and even ruinous to many of them, was officially granted yesterday by the compliance board of the local NRA organization.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Awards of eighty-five honorary scholarships to Harvard undergraduates were announced today.

You get the quintessence of John Carroll's style in simpler subjects such, as "Georgia with a Flower" and that utterly charming little portrait called "Roses." These, however, do not tell the whole story. And it is the stranger, the more "radical," chapters that scare people off.
Columbia reached the peak of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the game with Navy here tomorrow.
MANILA, Nov. 9 -- Suffrage was granted to the women of the Philippines today, marking the first extension of the right to vote to the women of an Oriental country.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- A picture of Germany being capable of mobilizing forty-five divisions in five days, with ultra-modern war material and ultra-modern munition and gas factories, twice the number of airmen France has and a capacity for turning out 2,300 airplanes a month, was presented to the French people today by Georges Mandel in the Chamber of Deputies when he took part in the debate on foreign affairs.

GRASSE, France, Nov. 9. -- Ivan Bunin, exiled Russian writer of novels and stories of Russian peasantry, expressed the greatest pleasure tonight on receiving a cable message from Stockholm announcing that the Nobel Prize for literature had been awarded to him.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- While the dollar was tumbling today to $5.07, its lowest value in twenty years, Neville Chamberlain declared in the House of Commons that the pound would continue to be independent of the dollar or gold currencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Issuance of bonds by some of the Federal Home Loan Banks to obtain capital with which to aid needy homeowners was indicated today by an announcement of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board that a $3,000,000, loan, required for expansion of its activities, had been made available to the Home Loan Bank of Cincinnati by other regional home loan banks.

Because Russian book and play royalties are paid in a rind of hotel due-bill system, the National Association of Book Publishers, acting with information gathered by the staff of The Publishers' Weekly, has approached the State Department, asking some kind of copyright protection.

JACKS NVILLE, Fla., Nov. 9. -- Lieut. Gov. Albert B. Chandler of Kentucky came here to find his mother's grave, but discovered that she lived and had watched him from afar since the night, thirty-one years ago, she told his father "good-bye."

The regulations under which liquor and wine may be sold in this State when repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment goes into effect were made public this morning by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

To one of its begetters and most distinguished members the National Institute of Arts and Letters has given pious commemoration this week, in which came the centennial of his birth. Old friends and associates of EDMUND CLARENCE STEDMAN have recounted his brilliant and solid qualities and his services to American literature as editor, poet, critic.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 9 -- Not more than 1 per cent of the American people have any idea of opposing President Roosevelt's recovery program, General Johnson told an audience of 5,000 here tonight.

The buying movement which started on the Cotton Exchange immediately following Wednesday's government crop estimate broadened yesterday and prices rose a quarter cent a pound, making a gain of $3 a bale from Monday. As December approached the 10-cent level, the market met more contracts, and a setback in the last hour left quotations with gains of 14 to 17 points.

PRAGUE, Nov. 9 -- "While treaties are being made Czechoslovakia will make treaties. If machine guns are fired it will be ready to fire machine grins, and if cannons it will be ready to fire cannons also," said Foreign Minister Benes in Parliament last night.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 9 -- Dartmouth wound up its practice today for the Princeton game as snow fell all afternoon. This week saw no scrimmages held, the coaches preferring to avoid contact work. Passing was stressed, with four backs throwing the ball.

The regular grand jury yesterday heard five witnesses in an impromptu investigation of the charge against Pasquale Caffre, Tammany chairman of election inspectors at a polling place at Bayard and Elizabeth Streets on election day, that he had violated the Election Law by attempting to enter a polling booth when it was occupied by a voter.

The open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System were curtailed further in the week ended on Wednesday, yesterday's report of the system showed. The rate of weekly purchases of government securities was reduced to $10,000,000 from $20,000,000 bought in the preceding week, $25,000,000 two weeks before, $31,000,000 three weeks before and $35,000,000 a week for eight weeks before that.

Miss Elinor Smith, aviatrix, and Assemblyman Patrick H. Sullivan Jr. of the Eleventh Distrist, Manhattan, were married quietly last July 30 in St. Ignatius's Roman Catholic Church, Hicksville, L.I., the bridegroom admitted last night at the couple's new home, 501 West 113th Street.

Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York and Upperville, Va., and her famed gray hunter. The Grey Knight, will have their names engraved on the John R. Townsend Memorial Challenge Cup for the first time. They scored a notable victory in the competition for this highly prized trophy last night at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

Charles F. Murphy, former State Senator and Republican leader of the Tenth Assembly District in Brooklyn, was arrested Monday on a charge of misapplying the funds of a concern for which he was receiver in equity, it was learned yesterday.

In issuing its first general appeal for funds for its fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor reported yesterday that during the twelve months ended Sept. 30, it had aided 17,273 families, 6,778 of which were given continuous care.

The close personal relationship involved in care of the sick and the afflicted cannot be delegated to government, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared in an address yesterday afternoon before several hundred men and women prominent in social and economic work here.
To discourage littering of the streets the Sanitation Department will hold a street-sweeping demonstration on East Seventh Street between Avenues A and B at 10:45 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A committee of business men, public officials and miners from the anthracite areas of Pennsylvania called on President Roosevelt today and proposed that the Federal Relief Administration buy 10,000,000 tons of anthracite for relief purposes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- New York's rebuilt Americans lost a two-goal lead, but held the Chicago Black Hawks to a 2 -- 2 overtime tie before 13,000 spectators in the opening game of the National Hockey League season at the Chicago Stadium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today:

MOSCOW, Nov. 9. -- A vigorous protest against the reported flight of nine Japanese military planes over the Amur River -- the Siberian-Manchurian frontier -- on Nov. 3 was made to the Japanese Government today by Ambassador Yureneff in Tokyo. He said:

The report of the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, made public yesterday, sets forth the license fees covering "only the interim period." expiring April 1. The report explains that the license fees for that period have been apportioned pro rata and the fees are to be paid in advance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Socalled agreements of "purchase and resale" entered into between banks and their customers constitute loans by the banks, E. Barrett Prettyman, counsel for the Internal Revenue Bureau, said today, and in making income tax returns the banks should report as gross income the entire amount of interest charged customers in these transactions.

The Director of Aeronautics, EUGENE L. VIDAL, wants to find out how many of the holders of pilots', student pilots' and mechanics' licenses, in all some 33,500 persons, would buy and operate a plane if its cost and upkeep were brought into the class of the low-priced automobile.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From time to time the State Government or the Federal Government, or both, offer rewards to citizens for making certain types of investments or impose penalties for certain other types of investments. When citizens elect to conduct their affairs in such fashion as to avoid the penalties and claim the rewards, public officials commonly try to attach some kind of obloquy to this procedure.

Heavy selling of United States Government bonds with resultant Josses of a full point or more for half the list eclipsed the action of other bond groups on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Foreign loans were strong as the dollar and the United States Government bonds were weak, and domestic corporation issues averaged slightly lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A purchasing syndicate which operated in 1,130,000 shares of Sinclair Consolidated Oil stock in 1928-29 reaped a net profit of $12,002,109.41 without putting up any "real" money, Arthur W. Cutten, Chicago stock and grain operator, disclosed today before the Senate market inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Controller General McCarl today held that the Treasury could legally make payments to the George F. Driscoll Company, of Brooklyn, to which a contract for a New York postoffice building had been denied because it had not signed the President's re-employment agreement when its bid was submitted.

This week has been designated and widely observed as Education Week and Open School Week. A special effort is made to arouse the interest of parents, particularly those whose children would profit most by closer cooperation between the home and the school.

Again the voters of this city and State have shown intelligence and discrimination in passing on constitutional amendments and other proposals referred to the electorate for final decision. By an enormous majority they approved the $60,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Because of a peculiar oversight on the part of some one in the British Admiralty, the government tonight had to order an eleventh-hour change in the manoeuvres of the Home Fleet.

Three of the four Class A matches played last night in the Metropolitan Squash. Racquets League resulted in clean sweeps, the Harvard Club No. 1 team, the University Club and the Montclair Athletic Club scoring 5 -- 0 shutouts. In the other contest the Princeton Club No. 1 team, playing its first match of the season, defeated the Harvard Club No. 2 outfit, 3 -- 2, on the winner's courts.

The President was urged to withhold Federal liquor revenues from States that had not voted to repeal the prohibition amendment or had not repealed their own prohibition laws in a resolution adopted yesterday by the executive council of the National Retail Beer and Liquor Dealers Association.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters elected four new members yesterday, observed the centenary of the birth of the American poet and critic, Edmund Clarence Stedman, and presented medals for good diction on the stage and radio. The National Institute of Arts and Letters also presented its gold medal for fiction.

The importance of continued private aid for unemployed musicians was emphasized yesterday by speakers at a luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., at the Hotel St. Regis. Support of the concerts to be conducted at Madison Square Garden by Dr. Walter Damrosch for the fund's benefit was asked by Dr. Damrosch and other speakers.
The closing date for the more important stakes of the Saratoga Association has been postponed until 1934, it was announced yesterday by George H. Bull, president of the association.

RUSTON, La., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Likening, himself to a "rooster with a broken wing," and saying he was proud of his enemies, Senator Huey P. Long spoke here today for new State taxes and redistribution of wealth, and replied to some of his critics by calling them "liars."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 -- City management and finance experts here today at the opening session of the National Conference on Government heard a bitter attack on "tax slackers" as wreckers of their communities and a plea for radical revision of the whole American public school system.

Lindsey E. Bird of Brookline, Mass., owner of $10,000 of bonds of the Associated Gas and Electric Company of 61 Broadway, filed a petition yesterday in United States District Court asking that an equity receiver be appointed for the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Immediate withdrawal of the general ban on importations of liquor for medicinal purposes was ordered by President Roosevelt today in the first of a series of steps he purposes to take in adjusting the country to repeal of prohibition.

Sweeping charges of "shocking" irregularities in the business practices of some of the fourteen title and mortgage companies he took over for rehabilitation, last Spring and Summer were made public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Andrew Kerr, head coach of football at Colgate University, has signed a new contract for a three-year term, Graduate Manager of Athletics William A. Reid announced tonight after a conference with Kerr.

Society was well represented at the Horse Show last night despite the social exodus from the city for the usual week-end in the country. The large number of strollers on the promenade, interested in close-ups of the society notables in the boxes, was reminiscent of the show in the Nineties in the old Garden on Madison Square.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Pleasantville High School football team vanquished Hendrick Hudson High, 18 to 0, today. Bob Berringer scored two touchdowns. Mareno made the other when he ran back a punt 75 yards in the second period.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Each Armistice Day much is said and written in tribute to the Unknown Soldier, but less recognition is given to the "Unknown Sailor," who, in the perils of war and the glory of peace, has carried on, ever an unsung hero. And yet it was Admiral Sims who referred to the men of the merchant marine as "an indispensable national asset."

Police Commissioner Bolan disclosed yesterday that he had already made arrangements to retire on pension. At the same time he made public a telegram of congratulation to Mayor-elect LaGuardia. Mr. Bolan indicated his belief that his replacement as head of the Police Department was only a matter of weeks.

Upsets appeared to have become the rule rather than the exception at the end of last night's play in the Vanderbilt Cup tournament, the second of two sessions held yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The impression gained ground here today that President Roosevelt may be succeeding in his currency experiments after all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The price at which the RFC will buy newly mined gold was raised only 5 cents today, the quotation of $33.20 being lower than the best offers in the world markets. This was interpreted by some experts as an effort to check a too rapid decline in the value of the dollar, and to punish speculators who may have played an important part in bringing on the recent violent fluctuations.

HAVANA, Nov. 10. -- With the revolutionary movement in Havana under control following the capture of Atares fortress yesterday afternoon, the government of President Ramon Grau San Martin strove today to stamp out the last vestiges of rebellion white hundreds of ABC members and other revolutionists went into hiding.

In response to an invitation from Harry L. Hopkins, Civil Works Administrator, to attend a work relief conference in Washington Wednesday, Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia yesterday designated Robert Moses and Professor A.A. Berle Jr. to represent him at the conference.

The choir of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, will appear in new vestments at the services tomorrow. The colors for the adults are red with purple trimmings and the colors are reversed for the boys' choir.

One hundred and fifty couples are expected to attend the Columbia University Players quadrille to be held tonight in John Jay Hall on the Morning-side Heights campus. The dance, which will be under the auspices of the Columbia Players Club, will be for the benefit of the Columbia Varsity Show.

For nearly five hours the jury in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel listened yesterday to James Garrett Wallace, Assistant District Attorney. He denounced the defendant for his alleged part in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States in 1930.

HAVANA, Nov. 10. -- Shortly after it had convened this evening a summary council of war decided to postpone until tomorrow morning at 7 o'clock the trial of three leaders of the Camp Columbia outbreak early Wednesday morning.

As hundreds of applicants appeared yesterday at the offices of the State and City Alcoholic Beverage Control Boards to qualify as liquor dealers, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State board, clarified some of the regulations governing the sale of liquor and wine when repeal goes into effect.

Before leaving the city last night for a brief vacation "not very far away," Mayor O Brien signed an application for a $700,000 Federal loan to rebuild the Health Department research laboratories near Willard Parker Hospital, Sixteenth Street and the East River.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Merry Fahrney Parker-Fickering, who wanted to marry a Chilean last Sunday, obtained a second h--hand nearer home today, but her early morning elopement ended in an automobile crash and the death of her new brother-in-law.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Consecrated to the perpetuation of international amity, a shrine symboliced of those who served and sacrificed in the World War will be dedicated in the Indiana World War Memorial here tomorrow.

The Federal grand jury which has been investigating the admitted propaganda activities of Heinz Spanknoebel since he disappeared two weeks ago, found yesterday that at least one of his operations here in behalf of the New Germany of Adolf Hitler warranted his indictment.

Reports of trade progress were more encouraging this week, as some of the somberness of the business atmosphere of the last thirty days has been cleared by the belated arrival of cold weather, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
VIENNA, Nov. 10. -- Martial law was proclaimed throughout Austria tonight because of activities planned by the Nazis and Socialists for Sunday, the fifteenth anniversary of the republic.

The powerful Holy Cross eleven, triumphant over Harvard and Brown season, comes to Ebbets Field today to oppose Manhattan, which held the Crusaders to a scoreless tie in 1932. A season's record attendance of 25,000 is indicated by the most active advance sale in history at Manhattan.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Restoration of a fixed gold standard was urged upon President Roosevelt in a resolution adopted today by the board of directors of the Illinois Manufacturers Association.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Wise Miller will give a reception the afternoon of Nov. 22 at 450 East Fifty-second Street for the Misses Katherine and Joan Blake, debutantes of the season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Allotment of $16,678,675 from the funds of the Public Works Administration for building 237 new postoffices all over the country was announced by President Roosevelt today.

ATLANTA, Nov. 10. -- Calling for an "electrification of America" which would serve the average man, David E. Lilienthal, director in charge of power development for the Tennessee Valley authority, declared tonight that use of power must increase or the electric industry would be in a "blind alley."

The period long set apart for the annual Red Cross enrolment -- beginning on Armistice Day and ending on Thanksgiving Day -- is already partly occupied by the local campaigns of welfare agencies. But whatever is done to meet the exceptional needs due to unemployment, it is important that this "first-aid" national organization should be kept first in the concern of all communities.

SUGAR and spice is what the new book by Margaret Ayer Barnes is made of. It is almost certain that no male reviewer is quite capable of doing it justice, for it is as exclusively a creation for women as is a hat with a veil. In plan and detail, in characterization, material, background and point of view, "Within This Present" (Houghton, Mifflin, $2.50) is meant for women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A writeup of more than $26,000,000 in 1,000, -- 000 shares of stock taken over in the formation of the General Theatres Equipment Company was bared today by the Senate market inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The case of an enlisted man found guilty of communicating military secrets to Communists was before the board of review of the army today, the first such case in the board's history.

Today is Armistice Day, the fifteenth anniversary of the ending of hostilities in the World War. Many celebrations will mark the day in New York City. The traditional two minutes of silence, beginning at 11 A.M., will be observed widely.

Copies of the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms, which will become effective on Monday, were sent yesterday by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms to firms which are members of the New York Stock Exchange.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 10. -- Great interest has been aroused here as a result of renewed revelations by Senator Dordolot concerning the final report on German armaments by the Interallied Control Commission in 1927.

Hoisting of Red Cross flags from hundreds of New York's prominent buildings will open this morning the annual roll-call activities of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, in connection with the beginning of the seventeenth annual membership roll-call of the national organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 8:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- To make government control of the liquor industry effective the Farm Administration arranged today for a hearing on a code for the distillers, who were said to have reached "an advanced stage" in their discussions of measures to be laid low down in such a compact.

Isidor Achron, who terminated recently an association of about a decade as Jascha Heifetz's accompanist, appeared last night at Carnegie Hall as solo pianist. His program encompassed three Bach transcriptions: that of the chaconne by Busoni, the prelude and fugue in A minor by Liszt and the overture from Cantata No. 28 by Saint-Saens, Haydn's andante with variations, a Chopin group and a concluding section by Borodin, Scriabin and Liszt.

Need Xmas Trade This Month. Stores which are dilatory in pushing for holiday business early this year will find themselves behind in meeting last year's figures for the latter part of this month, according to views in retail circles here yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Southern California's vaunted defense, successful in the last twentyseven starts, will be given the test of Stanford's speed at the Coliseum tomorrow.
Dwelling deals made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (AP). -- A crop report issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics estimated Canada's wheat crop at 271,821,000 bushels.

The financial operations of the Paramount Publix Corporation before it was placed in receivership in January of this year were recounted yesterday by John Hertz, who was chairman of its finance committee during that period, at a hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at 120 Nassau Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Cold, clear weather is promised Harvard and West Point for their annual football game in the stadium tomorrow. All except a few thousand of the 57,000 tickets have been sold and good weather will mean a complete sell-out.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Princeton's varsity 150-pound team easily defeated the Penn lightweights on Franklin Field today, 28 to 0.
RICHMOND, Nov. 10. -- The one important duty before the nation is to see that children have enough food, recreation, schooling and character building, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Despite the efforts of twenty veterinarians, nurses and other pachyderm experts, Pierre A. Bernard's Mom, said to have been one of the largest female elephants in the Western Hemisphere, succumbed today in her ninety-second year.

ROME, Nov. 10. -- The great volume of comment and speculation on the visit of Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Aviation Minister, to Premier Mussolini early this week caused the Italian Government today to issue a communique on the conversations.

New issues of State and municipal bonds to be awarded next week through competitive bidding total $12,617,896, compared with this week's aggregate of $2,965,637. As some of the communities that will offer bonds are not ranked as high as others in credit ratings, it is expected that not much more than half of the bonds on the calendar will attract bids.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- The dollar pursued its downward course in Paris today, closing at 15.84 francs, against 16.11, far under any previous low record, and 10 centimes below the theoretical gold parity set by the RFC in Washington.
BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- According to reports of the labor exchanges the number of unemployed in Germany decreased by another 103,000 last month, reducing the remaining total to 3,746,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Nov 9 unless specified:

The Naval Academy football team, which has improved during the past few weeks to the extent of being regarded as one of the strongest elevens in the East, will oppose Columbia, starting at 2 o'clock today. A crowd of 25,000, the largest of the season at Baker Field, is expected to attend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 4 amounted to 607,785 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 28,889 cars, or 4.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 20,483 cars, or 3.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 109,263 ears, or 15.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Sale of a large apartment house in the Bronx, and leasing of a warehouse property in Brooklyn for a possible site of a liquor manufacturing plant were included in the scattered real estate deals reported by brokers yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I. Nov. 10. -- Princeton University, the Peddle School, Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass.; Trinity Church of Hewlett, L. I.; the First Presbyterian Church of Hights Hill, N. J., and several other institutions and clubs will divide upward of $100,000 in conditional bequests provided in the will of Tracy Hyde Harris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- It was a case of "no news is good news" today in Soviet-American negotiations, which did, however, enter the final phase of conference between President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff.

Fordham and New York University will clash on the gridiron beginning at 2 o'clock today at the Yankee Stadium in their fourteenth meeting since the traditional series was begun in 1904. Both teams are in prime condition for the metropolitan football classic.
PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Louis Lepine, one-time Prefect of Police here, who had become an almost legendary figure to Parisians, died this morning at the age of 87.

Discussing the situation that resulted in the suspension of the captain and the manager of a football team organized among students of Cooper Union, Pwafessor R. C. Brumfield, chairman of the faculty committee on extra-curricular activities, made known yesterday that all athletic activities might be dropped by the institution.

Emma Cecilia Thursby, internationally famous as a concert singer fifty years ago and teacher of Geraldine Farrar, was honored yesterday when a memorial to her was unveiled in the Brooklyn Museum of Art on Eastern Parkway. Old friends, pupils and fellow-artists of Miss Thursby came to the borough where she was born eighty-eight years ago.

All the markets recovered their composure yesterday after the great agitation of the day before. The dollar was comparatively steady in the foreign exchange market, stocks reacted moderately, agricultural commodities declined rather sharply and United States Government bonds, after extending their losses of Thursday, engaged in a mild rally, although they failed to recover all of their ground.

Heavy selling of United States Government bonds was again the feature of a generally weak bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Although dealings in the government's long-term issues were heavier than on the previous day, amounting to $7,764,800, against $7,421,500 then, the declines were not so severe as on Thursday.

All market operations yesterday were based on the possibility that anything might happen in a day of upsets. As it turned out, the various markets got nowhere; indeed, they showed a strange inclination to fall backward. Commission houses complained that their customers were taking less than the usual interest in the markets.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 10 (AP). -- The 2-year-old Brown Toney, owned by R.L. Woodard and a 9-to-1 shot, captured the Buddy Rogers Purse, all-age allowance test at a mile and seventy yards, today at Latonia.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 10 (AP). -- George Kelly and William Mosconi, both of Philadelphia, and Charles Seaback, Astoria, N.Y., will represent the United States in the world's pocket billiard tourney at Chicago next month, it was definitely decided today in the national championship tourney.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Yale and Georgia today finished preparations for tomorrow's football game in the Yale Bowl, which is expected to attract 45,000 onlookers.

Nineteen more of the 312 persons who were indicted last week by the two New York County grand juries in investigations of fraudulent registrations were arraigned yesterday before Judge Koenig in General Sessions. Fifteen of the accused were freed and the indictments quashed, the cases of two others were put off for further investigation and the remaining two were held in $1,000 bail each for trial.

Decipherment of ancient tablets in archaic Hebrew, dating to 1,4001,350 B.C., about 600 years older than the earliest Hebrew writings so far known, is furnishing a wealth of startling material relating to early Biblical history, it was stated here yesterday in an interview by Sir Charles Marston, British archaeologist, now on a visit to the United States.

Most of the trading done yesterday on the Cotton Exchange was at a slight advance in prices, and high levels of the week were reached at one time, but contracts appeared on rallies and the final quotations were a point higher to two points lower than on Thursday.

Officers of the Irish Free State won the high-score international team competition last night at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. Their total score was 12 faults for the three nights of competition.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press). -- "How are you getting along with our Labor Government," some one asked King George in 1924, according to Lord Riddell's "Diary of the Peace Conference and Afterward," published today.

Mrs. Charles A. Childs gave a luncheon yesterday at the SavoyPlaza for Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, Mrs. James Russell Soley, Mrs. Alexander W. Biddle, Mrs. Alllen M. Thomas, Mrs. "Walter B. fames, Mrs. Wlnfield Scott and Mrs. Herman D. Kountze.

Recent paintings and water-colors by Henry E. Schnakenberg have been placed on view at the Kraushaar Gallery, where they will remain until Nov. 25. This artist's development is consistent, each show revealing the steps he has taken toward a realization of his own painting aims.

AMHERST vs. Trinity -- After consulting Blackstone, Coke, Kent and Brightly (Court of Nisi Prius, Penn.), it appears that there is no law compelling a man to guess the outcome of football games in advance. This, then, must remain just a demonstration of Free Will or an exhibition of brazen hardihood. With the permission of the Honest Ballot Association, one vote for Amherst.

In Its first monthly report on shipments of steel the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its shipments of finished steel in October amounted to 572,897 tons, compared with 575,161 in September, a decrease of 2,264 tons.

One result of the election is to reveal the glaring need for legislative reapportionment, now many years overdue. No one can have run his eye down the table of the votes cast in the different Assembly districts in the five counties that comprise this city without observing the startling discrepancy between their voting strength.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Iowa draws tomorrow's assignment from the "stop Michigan" league.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The seasonal increase in department store sales from September to October was somewhat less than the estimated amount, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The total cost of the New Deal, including contingent liabilities of the Federal Government, may amount to $11,735,000,000, according to estimates given out yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. This figure does not include most of the loans being made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the conference board pointed out.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The Boerse staged an upward movement for a while today, quotations rising as much as 2 per cent for some specialities, but the advance ended quickly and the closing was soft. The largest gains were registered among heavy industrials and electricals, but most of the list made at least fractional increases.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10. -- Hotchkiss brought Hill's two-year reign among the unbeaten prep school football teams to an end today, scoring 7 points in the final period to triumph by 14 to 13.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The wheels of industry and business were stopped for a full hour throughout Germany today and rail and street-car traffic everywhere halted for a minute -- a "minute of silence" -- ordained to put Germany's millions of workers of "the brow and the fist" into an appropriately solemn and receptive mood for hearing Chancellor Adolf Hitler's concluding election appeal.

Renewals of several old-time rivalries, topped by the Andover-Exeter game at Exeter, N.H., are the feature attractions on today's program as the 1933 Eastern prep school football season reaches its climax. Most of the major prep elevens will conclude their campaigns this afternoon by meeting traditional foes.

A request that religious books purchased by the Brooklyn Public Library "should be predominantly Catholic until such time as a proportionate representation for Catholic books is attained" was made to the library trustees yesterday by the Brooklyn Catholic Action Council.
To the Editor of The New York Times : The following suggestions for a reorganized school system, based on Mayor elect LaGuardia's seventeen-point program, may be of Interest.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10. -- Katsuji Debuchi, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, was host to fifteen members of the Princeton University faculty at a dinner in the Princeton Inn tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- The market for hogs was in a deadlock today for the second successive day, a situation regarded as without precedent in the trade. Packers continued their efforts to obtain lower prices, bidding 20 to 25 cents lower than on Wednesday, while sellers were again firm in their views and asked steady prices.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- The Riggs Handicap heads the program on the closing day of the Maryland Jockey Club's meeting at Pimlico tomorrow with A.C. Bostwick's Mate installed as the overnight favorite at 5 to 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos letters regarding darkened windows, may I call attention to the fact that shades at half-mast are only a minor consideration in this idea of shutting out light?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Lawrence Tibbett, noted baritone, sang to an audience of more than 4,000 persons in the Westchester County Centre here tonight at the second concert of the season given by Mrs. Julian Olney.

Acting as if they were staging a hold-up, four masked men last night invaded a poolroom at 239 Jefferson Street, Brooklyn, threatened eleven customers and the proprietor, Salvatora Binda, with pistols and shot to death Joseph Pellino, 35 years old, of 243 Jefferson Street.

As a result of protests from restaurant keepers of the city against one provision of the ruling by the local NRA compliance board affecting payment of wages to waiters under the President's Re-employment Agreement, Grover A. Whalen, city NRA Administrator, called a meeting yesterday of the entire compliance board for next Tuesday to consider a modification of the provision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Colonel John P. Hogan of the Construction League of the United States in a statement today charged that the building unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor were obstructing efforts to obtain one code for the building and heavy construction industry in order to create an impasse in the negotiations which have been proceeding for several months.

Great South Bay fishermen are experiencing difficult times these days trying to locate the Fall run of flounders. In other years this was the season when boat captains could count on good passenger lists of sportsmen in quest of flounders.

Addressing 500 public health nurses and other welfare workers at the Regional Institute on Child Health yesterday, Dr. Alfred F. Hess, authority on pediatrics, recommended irradiation of the city's milk supply as a strategic move in the war on rickets in young children.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 10. -- Ransom of $40,000 is demanded of Alexander J. Hart, wealthy merchant, for the return of his 22-yearold son, Brooke Hart, the object of a State-wide bunt as a kidnapping victim.

Construction continues to forge ahead under the effects of the Federal public works program, although, most other Industries have failed to show more than a seasonal recovery in recent weeks, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- On the eve of his departure to attend the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, Secretary Hull told newspaper men tonight that he hoped to pursue an exhaustive study of South American countries and their problems which would assist in establishing a new era of cooperation for solving the problems of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Capture of the next House and continuance of a campaign against administration policies are on the immediate program of the Republican National Committee, Everett Sanders, chairman, declared today after a conference with George F. Getz of Chicago, new treasurer of the committee.

The Chesapeake Corporation's control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway has dropped from the ratio of 52 per cent at which it stood at the end of 1932 to 48 per cent, according to the statement of condition on Sept. 30. Conversions and liquidation of holdings to meet bank loan requirements caused the decline.

Heavy profit-taking brought moderate recessions yesterday in most of the commodities traded on local markets, but the offerings were apparently easily absorbed and the price levels at the close remained considerably higher than at the beginning of the week.

WILKES BARRE, Pa., Nov. 10. -- Peace was restored to the northern anthracite field tonight after two months of terrorism climaxed by a call Saturday for a general strike of the 60,000 workers in district No. 1, issued in defiance of the United Mine Workers of America.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- Persons employed in October in factories in this State remained at about the same number as September, according to the monthly report of Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, issued today.
MUNICH, Nov. 10. -- The Augsburg police have taken ten prominent local members of the now dissolved Social Democratic party into "preventive custody."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Until this country becomes a member OF the League of Nations and the World Court "no real effort can be made to secure world peace," Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan of New York declared here tonight at a dinner of the International Goodwill Congress of the World Alliance for International Friendship.

MADRID, Nov. 10. -- The International Press Conference being held here under the auspices of the League of Nations has set up some very useful machinery for furthering the dissemination of accurate news. It also brought into the open some unpleasant facts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Executive repeal next month of four "recovery" taxes enacted to produce $227,000,000 annually to finance the $3,300,000,000 public-works program was deemed a certainty today when President Roosevelt let it be known that he would proclaim repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as soon as the State Department had been notified of ratification by the thirty-sixth State.
Segregation of the round-lot and odd-lot brokerage business under rules approved by the Stock Exchange on Oct. 10, which was to have become effective next Wednesday, has been deferred until Jan. 1.

On the eve of the sailing of Secretary HULL and the American delegation for the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, the President cut down the possible agenda to a very small minimum. He announced that the United States would have to "forego" discussions of currency stabilization and also of tariffs.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler told a dinner meeting of the Pilgrims of the United States at the Hotel Plaza last night that the Englishspeaking peoples must stand together to conserve their traditional principles of liberty, as embodied in the Bill of Rights in the United States Constitution, against antidemocratic doctrines.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Bringing the ashes of her actor husband, E.H. Sothern, Julia Marlowe arrived in England today on the liner Ile de France.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 10 (AP). -- The bodies of four men, one of them an internationally known surgeon, were removed today from the twisted flame-swept wreckage of a transport plane which crashed on a hillside in a heavy fog near here last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not so very many months ago the forgotten man was the topic of news stories, speeches and magazine articles. Just who he really was did not appear though at the time each man thought himself a member of the elect. We know now, however, who the "remembered man" is-the one who is always remembered when the looting begins.

VIENNA, Nov. 10. -- A communique, issued tonight for compulsory printing in all newspapers, said the government was yielding to popular demands for the restoration of the death penalty and was doing this in the only way possible under the Constitution, by the declaration of martial law.

Two important organizations of Democrats who participated in the Fusion movement made it clear yesterday that they intended to carry their fight on Tammany to a finish. They are the Knickerbocker Democrats, who sponsored the campaign of Langdon W. Post for Borough President of Manhattan on the Fusion ticket, and the Society of Young Democrats, with organiaztions in sixteen Assembly districts in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 10. -- Calling the General Assembly into special session on Monday to enact liquor-control legislation, Governor Pinchot today recommended the establishment of State liquor stores but left the way open for the adoption of alternate methods of sale.

A throng of nearly 2,000 persons, including many persons prominent in New York society and guests representative of diplomatic, military and official circles, attended the annual Victory Ball last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The George Washington University eleven defeated Washington and Jefferson tonight, 13 to 6. George Washington did all of its scoring in the first period.

The incoming Fusion administration will be firmly committed to a program tending to break up or prevent any criminal connection between the police and the illicit liquor traffic, Mayor-elect LaGuardia declared yesterday.

A denial of any intention to spread propaganda for socialism or any other "ism" in any of his presentations was expressed yesterday by Kurt Jooss, whose ballet at the Forrest Theatre has brought a new type of theatrical entertainment to Broadway.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The dollar again broke post-war records in London today. Against last night's closing rate of $5.06 1/4 to the pound sterling, it opened at $5.11 and fell to $5.16 1/2, a new low since September, 1914. Later, fluctuating wildly, it recovered to $5.12 1/2, closing at $5.13.

The State rules for liquor control were approved generally by men in the liquor trade yesterday, but it seemed to be their belief that the code would serve merely as a foundation for the law of the future.
Football crosses the halfway mark of its season today and heads down the home stretch with some of the most interesting games of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Farm Administration has decided to pay $17.50 an acre rental plus 12 1/2 per cent of the net amount received by the grower for his reduced crop, in an effort to cut next year's flue-cured tobacco acreage 30 per cent.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 10. -- A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Hester Gibson Huntington Davisson against Oscar Fulton Davisson of New York. The charge was cruelty.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The drop of a referee's hand, a blast from his whistle, will set two football teams in motion Sunday -- nothing unusual in itself, perhaps, but it will be the first legal Sabbath sporting event in Philadelphia since 1794.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon tried to assure a distinguished deputation that visited them today that supervision of armaments was intended to be world-wide and not applicable solely to Germany.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 10. -- Mrs. Luella Gear Heckscher, who played in 'Gay Divorce" with Fred Astaire, has arrived here to acquire residence preparatory to filing suit for divorce against G. Maurice Heckscher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, announced today further action to complete the settlement of the strike of silk workers in Allentown, Pa.; Paterson, N.J., and New England.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Miss Alice A. Dodsworth's red Cocker spaniel My Own Brokers Tip went to the top of a large class of solid-color dogs at the twelfth annual specialty show of the New England Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club today. Next to him was Mrs. Arthur Vogel's Freelands By Request.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- A genera profit-taking movement started today at the opening of the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Confronted with a double holiday while the Exchanges in New York will be open tomorrow, operators began to lighten their lines, and the selling movement continued until near the end of trading, when there was a fair rally.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- Earl Porter, leading rider at several of the metropolitan meetings this year, scored a triple at Pimlico today, including in his sweep the victory in the featured Caswell Purse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- President Roosevelt began tonight a discussion of possible Russian recognition in the man-to-man manner he originally planned when he and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, sat down by themselves in a conference at the White House.

WARSAW, Nov. 10. -- Reports in foreign newspapers of a German proposal for a treaty of non-aggression with Czechoslovakia have revived comment in the Polish press on Germany's plans to make a similar offer to Poland. The newly appointed Polish envoy to Berlin, Joseph Litsky, reported to Marshal Pilsudski personally -- an unusual thing for a Polish diplomat to do -- on a hurried visit to Warsaw over the week-end.

If any one asks what has caused the enormous difference in the emotions with which the nations of the world approach Armistice Day this year, compared with last, the answer is plain. The Hitler regime at Berlin has altered everything. It has caused a sharp reversal of the sentiment toward Germany which had been becoming more and more cordial and hopeful year by year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Chancellor Hitler was quoted in an address at Yale University by Dr. Arnold Wolfers of the University of Berlin today as favoring Germany's return to the league of Nations, if she regained her equality, putting an end to discrimination against her as a vanquished nation, and a new policy of international cooperation and Franco-German rapprochement.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Directors of the Empire Sheet and Tinplate Company, successor to the Empire Steel Corporation, were announced today by C.H. Henkel, head of the reorganization commit- j tee and president of the new concern.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 10 (AP). -- Frances Meany Scofield, one of the Meany sisters, aquatic stars, obtained a divorce today in Superior Court from Edmond H. Scofield of Port Chester, N. Y.

Insurgent city Democrats, headed by Postmaster General James A. Farley, national and State chairman, served notice yesterday or Tammany Hall and its leader, John F. Curry, that they have just begun to fight.

When word came on Thursday that Ivan Bunin had won the Nobel Prize for Literature no book publishers were prepared to do much about it. At the offices of Henry Holt Co., records were searched before it could be said definitely that M. Bunin's book, "Mitya's Love" was published by Holt in 1926.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Nov. 10 (AP). -- A barrage of eggs, constant heckling and enthusiastic applause punctuated Senator Huey P. Long's tax-reform address from the square in front of the City Hall here tonight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (AP). -- How a celebration in Siberia last Tuesday of the sixteenth anniversary of the October Revolution took the form of a militant demonstration against any would-be aggressors was told tonight in a Tass (Russian) News Agency dispatch.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A code designed to end racketeering and ruinous competition in the cleaning and dyeing industry was approved today by President Roosevelt. The code adds 20,000 workers to the trade.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that he had filed suit in the Kings County Supreme Court to recover $80,650 from Oscar Jacobs, president of the Long Island Title Guarantee Company of Jamaica, which Mr. Van Schaick contends was converted by Mr. Jacobs for his own use.

The third day of District Attorney Geoghan's clean-up of a Brooklyn arson ring resulted yesterday in the conviction of a third man, and developed further testimony by Samuel Skoblow, the self-confessed "torch," as to how he operated his lucrative business.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10. -- Importers of goods into Argentina must hereafter either obtain government licenses for each shipment or risk a long delay and probable failure to get exchange permits for remittances.

Russian Nobel Prizeman The Swedish Academy of Literature is apparently not in a mood to recognize Soviet Russia. It has just given the Nobel Prize in Literature -- the first time the coveted honor has been won by a Russian -- to an emigre poet and short-story writer, IVAN BUNIN, whom critics chiefly esteem for his faultlessly chiseled style.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Corn production this year was announced today by the Department of Agriculture in its preliminary estimate at 2,289,544,000 bushels. A month ago 2,291,000,000 bushels were forecast. Last year's crop was 2,876,000,000 bushels.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Instead of speaking before the German plebiscite and setting forth the position of France, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour postponed a speech he had been expected to make in the Chamber of Deputies today until next Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Disclosures by a Belgian Senator regarding the Interallied Control Commission's secret report on German armaments caused a stir here tonight, although its contents as reported came as no surprise to anyone.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10. -- The annual dance given by the combined boards of The Daily Princetonian and The Princeton Tiger, undergraduate publications, was held in the Frinceton University gymnasium tonight.

The Merchants Association of New York protested yesterday to Secretary Ickes as Federal Administrator of Public Works against the proposal to finance by a government loan the construction of an $11,000,000 produce terminal in Bayonne which is sponsored by the Central District Corporation of Bayonne.
Twelve first-round matches were scheduled in the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the Columbia University Club last night, but only seven were contested. The five others went by default.

TUSLA, Okla., Nov. 10. -- Oklahoma, America's petroleum producing centre, tonight loudly proclaimed its faith in the Roosevelt recovery program. Leaders of the oil industry, Federal and State officials and the populace paid tribute to the National Recovery Administration and General Hugh S. Johnson, its administrator, as factors behind a better economic outlook in the Southwestern oil fields.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace boarded a plane for the Corn Belt late today to make what his aides described as "the most important speech of his career" at Des Moines tomorrow night.

Four men believed by the police to have sold a number of forged bonds purporting to be issued by the City of Nevr York were arrested last night on charges of forgery and possession of forged documents. Detectives who arrested the four said they were unable to tell how many of the bogus bonds had been sold to innocent purchasers.

MUNICH, Nov. 10. -- A new and serious religious clash is looming in Germany, now that the Protestant Church has been coordinated by the National Socialist Government. The new difficulty is with the Catholics. The Concordat recently concluded with the Vatican is not working well.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- After five years of research the Inter-American Commission of Women has finished a report on laws governing the legal status of women in countries of the Western Hemisphere.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 10 (AP). -- William Hamm Jr., in a tense Federal court room today, testified that Eddie McFadden, a Chicago gangster, resembled one of the men who forced him into an automobile when he was kidnapped here on June 35.

The five-cent levy on taxicab fares, recently imposed by the Board of Aldermen as part of Mayor O'Brien's new revenue program, was declared illegal and void yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn of the Bronx. He granted a temporary injunction against its further collection by the city.

EDUCATION'S way out of the present emergency is more and more generally felt to be through the door of Federal aid. And teachers and administrators in various parts of the country are looking hopefully to see whether the $3,300,000,000 public-works fund may not be partially diverted to school programs instead of being wholly devoted to building projects.

Fourteen Soviet engineers are being trained in the production of Wright aircraft motors under a licensing agreement between the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and the Soviet Government by which the American engines will he manufactured in Russia under American supervision, it became known yesterday.

HIS name was Emilius Evensen, though he was better known as "Umullus," a pun on the Norwegian word "umulig" which, the translators tell us, means "impossible." But this Evensen was not at all an impossible creature. The world around, there are probably far too many human animals lot pretty much his stripe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Sixtyfour committees of bankers and business men to speed the liquidation of more than $3,000,000,000 of assets of closed national and State banks throughout the Federal Reserve districts were appointed today by the Deposit Liquidation Board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

THE latest of the new cinema faces is Margaret Sullavan, who went to Hollywood last Spring and has now filtered through the cameras and microphones as the star of "Only Yesterday" at the Radio City Music Hall. Miss Sullavan (the "a" is no typo-graphical error) is a Virginian, born in Norfolk, May 16, 1911.

With the announced intention of clearing up the confusion existing in the minds of many Germans and foreigners regarding the status of the various organizations of German musicians under the Nazi regime, the Vossische Zeitung of Sept. 23 printed an explanation reading as follows:

BOSTON, Nov. 11. -- The Great My Own, Leonard J. Buck's sterling black cocker spaniel, bred by Herman Melanthin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., tonight defeated one of the best collections of cocker spaniels ever gathered under one roof to gain the best in show award.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11. -- Those few members of the LatinAmerican group of the diplomatic corps who could be interviewed today expressed disappointment at President Roosevelt's refusal to discuss tariffs or currency stabilization at the Pan-American conference.

A powerful finishing drive enabled Johnny Wilson of Jamaica High School of Queens to win the individual title in the annual city Public Schools Athletic League championship cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning.

Ringtail, the young raccoon, begins life in the family den in the hollow of a great old tree. At first he was conscious only of mysterious noises that came to him through the darkness, then there was the first excursion along a big branch, where he could watch the outside world.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11. -- On the day dedicated to the suspension of hostilities, Army's all-conquering football forces resumed operations where they left off on Soldiers Field in 1932 to score their second most decisive victory in history over Harvard today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 11. -- Herman Everhardus, the Flying Dutchman from Kalamazoo, unleashed a toe as true as a navy siege gun and Bill Renner displayed uncanny passing aim today as Michigan's powerful football team, playing in snow and ice, swept toward a fourth consecutive Big Ten championship with a hard-earned 10-6 victory over Iowa.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- One minute after midnight on Nov. 3 the New England Milk Marketing Agreement went into effect for the regulation of this basic industry by the Federal Government through the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Britain, stirred by an undercurrent of war rumblings, honored today the memory of her 1,000,000 war dead with deeper feelings than at any other time since the Armistice.

THERE is much that is stimulating about the step taken last Wednesday by Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics, Department of Commerce, to encourage private flying. His questionnaire to the 34,000 trained potential owners of small planes should elicit a wealth of important information.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11. -- After seeing an inspired Mississippi team drive for a touchdown in the first few minutes of play today, the Tennessee volunteers rallied to win overwhelmingly, 35 to 6.

ON the first day of June of last year a company of forty-two adventurers rode out of Hollywood with fifty tons of food and general equipment and reached Seattle in time to embark on the steamer Victoria for Nome, Alaska. There they transferred their belongings to the whaling schooner Nanuk and set out for Teller, a point chosen as most advantageous for central operations.

Appointment of a citizens' committee of 178 members to support the Citizens Family Welfare Committee in its drive for $4,000,000 to help the local private family welfare agencies carry the extra burden of relief through the Winter was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the welfare committee.
On Nov. 13, 1833, in a little log house shaded by a great sycamore, Edwin Booth was born at Belair, Md.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- As the result of an allotment of $25,000 of public works funds the Statue of Liberty on Bedloe's Island, New York Harbor, will be repaired, visitors there will be made more comfortable, and 2,500 man-days of work, or about five months' work for twenty-five men, will be provided.
MADRID, Nov. 11. -- Probably for the first time since he became a world figure in 1927 Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh found today some one who did not know of him.

EVERY so often there manifests itself some unexpected development in the theatre which attracts the interested attention of those who make it a business to keep in touch. Not so long ago showmen were looking with amazement -- mingled with a certain amount of scorn -- upon the comparative success of a plethora of revivals or "second engagements" which came sweeping down upon Broadway with a snowstorm of ambiguous coupons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- A decision by the United States that Russia must give substantial assurances on major differences prior to recognition was reported today as the reason for prolongation of the negotiations that brought Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- For the seventh time in their history, the twenty-one republics of the Western Hemisphere are soon to meet in conference on their common problems. The United States, always a hearty supporter of Pan-Americanism, has sent its Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, to head its delegation to the gathering at Montevideo on Dec. 3, and the other republics are sending their Foreign Ministers or high functionaries.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will hold its annual meeting on Dec. 7 at the Hotel Biltmore, at which time the election of officers will take place.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Lord Boatwright are at the Pierre.
