WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Ely E. Palmer of Providence, R.I., Consul General at Vancouver, B.C., has been assigned as Consul General at Jerusalem. Other changes in the foreign service were an- nounced by the State Department today as follows:

Great Britain's withdrawal from the international tariff truce is largely sentimental in significance. At no time since it was first proposed by the American Government, on the eve of the London conference, has the truce been genuinely effective. Sixty-one nations agreed to it, pledging themselves not to adopt "any new initiatives" which would create further obstacles to trade.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 11. -- Ontario's gold mines, taking advantage of the high price that is being paid for their product, are handling ore of lower grade this year, it is shown by the report of the Ontario Department of Mines.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- As the midseason showings progressed they confirmed the supremacy of the molded line. However, higher skirt fullness is conceded by Mainbocher and Augustabernard. Bolero suits are being revived by Leloag and Mainbocher, and many bolero effects are being shown by other houses.

IT seems a pity that factory and distribution routine made it impossible for the general release of Victor Album M-156 to be as well timed as the arrival of the review copies. These reached us on Oct. 9 so that they were ready to be put on immediately after Schnabel's first appearance of the season, at which he played this Beethoven Concerto, in G (No. 4), with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

PARIS, Nov. 11. -- Armistice Day -- fifteen years after! And Sunday will begin a new chapter. For Germany will declare herself free from the armament restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles, and offer peace or the beginning of a new race toward war.
IT is fifteen years since the Cease-Fire was sounded at the end of a World War which had caused a great death of youth, a sum of human agony beyond reckoning, and enormous ruin.

THERE is not much in Mr. Fowler's book to suggest the austere purity of the timber line, and there are long stretches which do not even suggest the two gentlemen who made such a noise with The Denver Post. Otherwise the title is a perfect indication of what the reader may expect to find in the plumpish volume here presented.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- War in Siberia is regarded in the best-informed quarters in Washington as now well within the range of possibility.

AN all-Tchaikovsky program, with Grete Stuckgold, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, as soloist, will commemorate the fortieth anniversary of the composer's death it the Philharmonic-Symphony concert this afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
With an underlying plea for continued peace audible in most of the ceremonies, New York joined with the nation yesterday in observance of Armistice Day.

A purported plot by Tammany to regain some of its power at City Hall after January was scotched yesterday by Bernard S. Deutsch, President-elect of the Board of Aldermen, at a Fusion victory luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

FOR many years lovers of American poetry have treasured the verses of Lizette Woodworth Reese, and have eagerly awaited future poems from her lilting pen. Miss Reese loves all the homely things of life (we use the word "homely" in its original and dignified meaning); and particularly of life in her own land.

WHEN Helen Hayes returned from her first joust with the talking film several years ago, she complained of an ambition to play in Barrle's "What Every Woman Knows" for the cinema. Now, having traveled the road of sin, suffering and sainted motherhood which the studios prescribe for their heroines, Hiss Hayes is to have her chance in the role she acted so well on Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.-- Ohio State's football team successfully maintained an impressive record of victories over Eastern foes today. The Buckeyes triumphed over the University of Pennsylvania, 20 to 7, at Franklin Field, but only after receiving the most stubborn oppo- sition.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 11. -- Complete understanding of common dangers on the part of the United States and Great Britain is one safeguard against becoming involved in the next war, Walter Lippmann said today in an address to Amherst College Alumni Council.
RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 11. -- The Constituent Assembly will hold a preliminary meeting tomorrow to elect its president. The Minas Geraes leader, Antonio Carlos, is regarded as the strongest candidate.

The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission a proposed tariff which would leave the East and New England as the only sections in the country in which the post-war rate of 3.6 cents a mile for railway travel, plus surcharge for Pullman accommodations, survives.

Charging that many codes prepared by domestic industries have gone so far as to describe the purchase or sale of competing foreign merchandise as an "unfair trade practice," the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., yesterday appealed to the Recovery Administration in Washington to prevent American producers from effecting boycotts through codes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Syndicate loans totaling $208,933,876.34 were approved by the board of directors of the Chase National Bank between Jan. 4, 1928, and Aug. 17, 1933, a ccording to disclosures made today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which is inestigating stock market operations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Princeton's powerful eleven, undefeated, untied and unscored upon, maintained its proud record before 35,000 spectators in the Palmer Stadium today, but only after a close call.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (AP). -- If the millennium of peace is ever found it must originate in the heartfelt understanding of peoples, Major General Hugh A. Drum declared here today at the dedication of a Shrine Room of the Indiana World War Memorial.

Somebody on The Manchester Guardian found GEORGE WILLIAM RUSSELL "in a flat not far from the Marble Arch." He will work no more in Ireland unless he goes to Donegal to paint. He may -- and should -- come here next Spring. He won't go back to Ireland unless the political secret societies break up.

WHEN it was announced in 1930 that a Radio City would be built on Manhattan Island the enterprise was heralded as a vast sociological experiment -- a city that must rest on a firm economic foundation as well as on a sound scientific and esthetic base.

Moving with the relentless power of a war tank, Columbia's football team drove through to a 14-7 victory over Navy at Baker Field yesterday. Behind this balanced, controlled power and forming its driving force was a fire and dash, and all of it was needed, for the Navy eleven refused to believe it was beaten until the exact last play of the game.

PRECIOUS, very precious indeed, must be this sheaf of twenty-two poems, the last to come from the pen of Sara Teasdale, whose tragic death robs America of a truly fine lyrist. A note by the publisher informs one that these are all of her poems in manuscript which Miss Teasdale wished preserved; in a notebook was found the title she has devised for them, "Strange Victory."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Representative Hamilton Fish of New York issued a statement today charging the administration with interfering with the freedom of the press.

HAVANA, Nov. 11. -- Interior Minister Guiteras said today that the state of siege invoked at the climax of the rebellion would shortly be lifted in Havana, but that the state of war would continue everywhere except in the capital.

Six months ago today President ROOSEVELT signed the ambitious measure known as the Agricultural Adjustment Act. Its administrator, Mr. PEEK, reviews in the Feature Section of THE TIMES this morning the more important plans initiated under its authority.

THE Winter has started off with a bang. In spite of what the pessimists may say, there is laughter in the air. There are good plays and smart crowds to see them; the ballet season (New York seems to have one!) is putting its best foot forward, with Jooss and Lifar leading it; the Horse Show, celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, hurdled into the social whirl last Monday, and the opera is on its way.

DISTINCTIVE value is given to this interpretation of the United States Constitution by the fact that its two authors combine the legal and non-legal viewpoints, Mr. Magruder being Professor of Political Science in Oregon State College and Mr. Claire assistant Professor of Law in the University of Oregon.

WARSAW. PLACE PILSUDSKI, in the very centre of Warsaw, is a huge, empty square surrounded by official buildings and the tomb of the Unknown Soldier. It is grassless and treeless; a Russian church once stood there.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP). -- An airplane dash from San Francisco and an exhaustive search of an ocean liner here proved futile today in the search by police and Federal agents for the kidnappers of Brooke L. Hart of San Jose.

ROOMS containing early American furnishings may take on an added charm when the wall decoration -- handpainted murals, wallpaper or fabric coverings -- depicts events or scenes of the same period. Accurate data for creating such decoration are becoming increasingly available through researches connected with the restoration of historic buildings and even towns, such as Williamsburg in Virginia.

Calling attention to the trade possibilities expected as a result of the conversations between President Roosevelt and Maxim Ldtvinoff, Soviet Commissar, looking toward the recognition of Soviet Russia, the National Association of Manufacturers circularized its members yesterday with data showing that America's post-war trade with the unrecognized Soviet was far greater than the pre-war trade with Russia.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 11. -- Scoring one touchdown in the initial period and three in rapid succession near the end of the game, Wisconsin routed West Virginia, 25 to 6, in an intersectional football clash today.

Women attorneys are too modest and should appear in court more often, Justice Edward R. Finch, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, declared in an address to members of the Phi Delta Delta Legal Fraternity.

Estimates of the nation's fire losses during the first nine months of 1933 show a decided improvement over the preceding year, according to Curtis W. Pierce, vice president of the Continental Insurance Company.

A mounting volume of retail trade and steadiness in wholesale trade but lessened activity in industry in general were reported yesterday from Federal Reserve centres for last week. These developments permit the belief that a more satisfactory adjustment between production and consumption has been effected and that further progress along these lines is in store, with manufacturing following rather than leading consumption.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, predicted the success of the national recovery program this afternoon in an address before the convention of the New Jersey State Teachers Association. She characterized it as "a going concern."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Miss Judy Johnson of Farmingdale, L.I., was the outstanding performer in the racing meeting held under the auspices of the New Rochelle Post, No. 8, American Legion at Ward Acres today. It was the second meeting held here this season, and will be concluded tomorrow when four more events will be run.

Arnold Schonberg, for a quarter of a century a storm centre in Austria, Germany and other portions of Europe, had the probably unique experience, last night in the Town Hall, of being present at performances of his music when it was not hissed.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- For their Christmas and New Year's cheer, Americans must expect to get any French wines, cognacs and liqueurs only from St. Pierre and Miquelon, France's tiny islands off Nova Scotia, it is already apparent.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 7. -- Wyoming citizens have a great deal of thinking and discussing to do in the scant four weeks before Dec. 4, the date set by Governor Leslie A. Miller for a special session of the Legislature to consider emergency and other legislation, if their legislative representatives are to represent them intelligently.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- New Rochelle High School's football team hurdled one of the biggest obstacles in its defense of the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association championships by defeating White Plains High, 7 -- 0. today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- North winds and snow flurries ended the unseasonably mild November weather this week and brought a sharp upturn in retail store sales. Demand was most active for men's and women's coats, gloves, dress accessories and underwear.
DOES the defeat of Tammany last Tuesday portend its doom? Or is it only one more in the list of reverses which that organization has encountered in its long career?

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- A 40-yard forward pass from Meyer to McKinley in the last quarter gave Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute a 6-to-0 football victory over Worcester Tech totday. The Troy engineers stopped the visitors on the 15yard line in the first quarter, but were not threatened thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- A report by a committee on Latin American policy in connection with the Pan-American conference at Montevideo was presented to Secretary Hull and members of the American delegation before they sailed from New York today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11. -- Tulane unloosed its speedy halfbacks in the second half of today's contest with the Mississippi State Maroons and the Green Wave speed merchants galloped to five touchdowns and a 33 to 0 victory.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 11. -- Kentucky defeated a smart, hardfighting Virginia Military Institute eleven today by 21 to 6.

Cold weather stimulated excellent retail trade in women's coats during the week and resulted in a good many open orders for Quick delivery of this merchandise reaching the wholesale markets, according to the market reports prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Fred Cauchois topped a field of thirty-one gunners in the first registered shoot of the season at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the high-over-all cup by breaking 96 out of 100 targets.

Rumors in theatrical circles that S.L. Rothafel might return to the leadership of the Seventh Avenue Roxy Theatre were denied in a statement issued yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, receiver for the theatre. The statement said:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- William R. Coe's Pomposity gained his second stake victory in eight days when he raced home the winner by half a length over C.V. Whitney's Mad Frump in the eighth running of the $5,000 added Riggs Handicap, closing-day feature at Pimlico today.

Speculative enthusiasm having waned after the excitement in the earlier part of the week, the share market was unusually quiet yesterday. Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to only 472,000 shares, compared with 703,000 shares on the previous Saturday.

BERTRAND RUSSELL once remarked that a mathematician does not have to know what he is talking about. In honoring Professors DIRAC, SCHROEDINGER and HEISENBERG the committee that awards the Nobel prizes in physics have recognized what has been achieved by men who care not what their X's and Y's stand for.

DUBLIN, Nov. 10. -- Steadily increasing numbers of young persons who are coming to the labor market in search of employment are presenting a difficult problem to the government. With the population increasing and emigration to the United States and other countries negligible, President de Valera's Ministers are giving much attention these days to evolving schemes to provide some outlet for youth.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9. -- After bogging down badly because of apparently insuperable objections on the part of counties, cities and towns to pay the required minimum of 45 cents an hour to common labor, the Federal public works program in Virginia is well under way.

STRACHEY, who could not write badly and never wrote idly, deserved a collection of his shorter reviews. They are put together here by his brother, James Strachey, and there are thirty-eight papers of one sort and another, to compare with the fifteen elaborate articles of the earlier "Books and Characters."
MELBOURNE, Nov. 10. -- When hard times overtook Australia, commercial aviation came almost to a standstill.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Professor Yandell Henderson of Yale, chemical authority, told the National Conference on Government today that State liquor control laws should compel whisky and other hard liquors to be sold at different places from those selling light wines and beer.

This country is going to "rediscover the impracticability of attempting to repeal by fiat laws of economics and of human relations," Dr. C.F. Hirshfeld predicted yesterday. Dr. Hirshfeld is chairman of the Engineers Council for Professional Development, an organization of representatives of seven national engineering groups, and is chief of the research department of the Detroit Edison Company.
An attempt is being made by British authorities to lift another worry from the golfer's mind.

THE schooner Morrissey with the Norcross-Bartlett Expedition has returned home after four months spent in the Arctic. We have brought back no tales of great discoveries, yet the voyage has significance because of its connection with the Fury and Hecla expedition more than 100 years ago.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 11. -- Duke remained unbeaten and untied today by routing Maryland.

HAVANA, Nov. 11. -- Despite their defeats in the past four days rebels in Havana intensified their sniping campaign today. Reports from the interior indicate the revolutionary movement is getting under way there.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The American dollar finished a delirious week, in which it dived to $5.16% in relation to the British pound, by returning to a more sober course today when it rapidly recovered to close at $5.02%.
The unbeaten and untied St. Peter's Prep eleven registered its eighth victory at the Jersey City baseball park yesterday, conquering Xavier of New York, 20 to 0.

Trading was mixed in the commodities markets yesterday as profit-taking and speculative buying occurred with more or less prominence in the various staples. Silver and cocoa were the strong features of the trading, while coffee and sugar, in the first Saturday's trading since June, declined in active dealings.
With the passes of Carrol Gould and the end runs of Omer Landry prevailing, the City College football team closed its season by losing to Providence College, 39 to 6, yesterday at Lewishon stadium.

Signs of significant shifts in the general distribution picture, due to forces generated by the retail code, are receiving careful attention in retail circles. So far, however, the basic competitive situation as between department stores, chains and the independent or smaller merchant has remained virtually unchanged, according to views in authoritative retail quarters.

The new quarters of the Nation al Broadcasting Company in Radio City were formally dedicated last night in a one-hour program from 8 to 9 o'clock. It was broadcast on every NBC station in the United States, Canada and Hawaii and was sent by short waves to all parts of the world.
THERE isn't one born every minute -- not any more. Take it from B.C. (Doc) McKay, who has contacted millions of suckers since 1880 and once made a fortune by pulling their ears.

PARIS. THERE are a few million peopie in France for whom the morning and the evening are made considerably more cheerful just now by the lively hope that very soon the National Lottery will promote them, or some near relative, into the ranks of franc millionaires.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- By the margin of a point after touchdown, Princeton's freshman football team turned back the Yale yearlings today, 14 to 13.
Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday that New York University has received gifts and bequests amounting to $621,671.75 since the May meeting of the council of the university.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP PENNSYLVANIA, Nov. 11. -- F.H. LaGuardia, Mayor-elect of New York City, slipped quietly away from the worries of city government this morning for a two-week vacation to rest from the rigors of his winning campaign, bound for the Canal Zone.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read this statement made by President Roosevelt on Sept. 21, 1932, at Portland, Ore.: "I state to you categorically that as a broad general rule the development of utilities should remain, with certain exceptions, a function for private initiative and private capital."

Today's Reichstag election is avowedly designed to prove to the outside world that the German nation is a unit behind the Hitler Government. Yet it is conducted in a manner fatal to the Nazi purpose. If it is to be demonstrated beyond any doubt that the German people have freely given their hearts to HITLER, it must be shown in the first place that the Germans are free; and the election today is not free.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- German banking, even in the years preceding the war, was developing in a direction that at times gave rise to some apprehension. The war and its consequences, the many post-war meddlings and blunders in the domain of banking as well as in industry, therefore brought about a condition that, when Germany came to face the economic crisis, its banks were unable to rise superior to their task.

Announcement that Captain F.X. A. Eble, former Commissioner of Customs in the Hoover administration and more recently a customs investigator abroad, has resigned from government service and will join the recently organized American Match Institute as its manager was made here yesterday at the institute offices in the Graybar Building.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11. -- Three American corporations having 50,000,000 pesos [about $20,500,000] in frozen credits here made an offer today to accept Argentine Treasury notes for the equivalent of their blocked funds, according to a statement given out tonight by Finance Minister Federico Pinedo.

THREE artists, each endowed with unusual personal force, originality and talent, have died recently. They are George Benjamin Luks, George Hart and Gari Melchers, all belonging to the rapidly passing generation that grew up during the latter half of the nineteenth century.
Texas Guinan came back yesterday to Broadway.

A sharp expansion in the demand for services of industrial and management engineers after the first of next year was predicted here yesterday by executives of important organizations, who reported that since NRA codes went into effect they have experienced a slightly better demand from industry.

VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- The thumpthump of hammers resounded in the gloomy courtyard of old Vienna's district jail today as carpenters built a gallows for offenders against Chancellor Dollfuss's new martial law decree.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- London, Rome, Paris, Prague and Warsaw have now pooled their information about the situation in Berlin in regard to arms, and the powers interested have fixed on exactly what they expect from the excited nation.

LONDON. POPULAR authors are seldom loath to speak for publication, but we rarely get from them such an interesting talk as an interview with Somerset Maugham recently published in John o' London's Weekly.

TORONTO, Nov. 11. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight made it two straight over their National Hockey League play-off rivals of last Spring when they added a 4-3 victory over the world's champion New York Rangers to the 6-1 opening game triumph over Boston on Thursday.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- Unrest and discontent in the French South Sea capital of Tahiti have become serious, according to Deputy Lionel de Tastes, who says he is the first member of the French Parliament to visit the island since Tahiti came under French rule.
SIMSBURY, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Scoring early in the third and fourth quarters, the Taft School eleven turned back the Westminster team, 14 -- 7, today. The game closed the season for both schools.

After four days of bitterly contested play, the only one of the four seeded contract bridge teams left in the Vanderbilt Cup tournament emerged from the semi-finals last night a decided favorite in the race for the trophy.

EARLY American sculpture, painting and miscellanea, from the extensive collection of Isabel Carleton Wilde, are being shown at the John Becker Gallery, furnishing a treat not only for the lover of Americana, but for sophisticated gallery-goers in general.

IMPORTANT documents which are intended to have a life measuraable in centuries rather than in years can now be recorded, proof against all decay, impermeable to insects and bacterial infection, and capable of withstanding neglect or burial in earth, swamp or water.
Doug Pooley gave St. Francis Prep's eleven victory over the Samuel J. Tilden High team yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium with a touchdown in the final period. The score was 6 to 0.

Fighting desperately throughout the encounter, the Manhattan football team went down to defeat at the hands of the powerful Holy Cross eleven yeserday at Ebbets Field. Coming back strongly after the Crusaders had scored two touchdowns in the first period, the Jaspers kept the issue in doubt until the final minutes, when the visitors tallied two more touchdowns to triumph, 27 to 6.

With the Chicago Board of Trade and the Canadian grain exchanges closed in observance of Armistice Day, speculative interest, such as it was, centred in the American security markets and in the foreign exchanges. Trading was slow and price movements narrow as a rule.

THE little magazine from which this collection was culled was one of those obscure ventures with a romantic history that gradually won itself a reputation and some measure of success. It was first modestly mimeographed in Vienna by its editors, Whit Burnett and Martha Foley, who were newspaper correspondents there.
Superior speed and aggressiveness enabled the Manhattanville College eleven to turn back the North Jersey Field Hockey Association team, 2 -- 1, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

DRYVILLE, U.S. THE vote of this village, in a middle border State, on the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was: Wet 1,128, Dry 476. It had voted extra dry the last time the issue was up, and was considered dry in sentiment even two years ago.

W. Arthur Cunningham, Controller-elect, sailed yesterday for Italy on the Italian liner Rex. He had booked passage privately with Mrs. Cunningham several days ago, and the Italian Line has not included his name in the advance list of passengers made public on Friday.

Mrs. ROOSEVELT'S book is the expression of a mellow, experienced woman who lets neither the past confuse her nor the future confound her. She has great respect for the wisdom and good sense of her grandmother, but this does not prevent her from understanding that the grandchildren of today can and do teach her a great deal about life and its adjustments.

UNFORTUNATE in its title, whose implications are in no wise applicable to the contents, spirit or purpose of the book, Mr. Untereiner's small volume offers to the general reader a valuable survey and study of taxation in this country.

GENEVA, Nov. 10. -- The League of Nations was notified by its commission governing the Saar Basin Territory in its quarterly report yesterday that the commission felt "obliged to adopt exceptional measures" to protect the territory's residents against the Nazi "policy of intimidation" and assure the independence necessary for the plebiscite in 1935.

BUFFALO, Nov. 9. -- If any claims are set up that the election in New York rebuked the Roosevelt administration, Buffalo offers one offset at least. Tie election of George J. Zimmermann as Mayor was distinctly a vote of approval on the NRA and the Federal leaders responsible for the recovery policy.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Ed Berlinski, leading point scorer in New Jersey High School football ranks, starred in Bloomfield's 19to-0 rout of Irvington today when he ran 94 yards for a touchdown in the final period.
BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- President van Hindenburg, in his broadcast address today for solid support of the Hitler government in tomorrow's German elections, said:

British Columbia Gold. From reading the local papers and listening to the talk of a great many local and Eastern "financiers" and so-called "mining experts," one would think that this Province is one immense gold mine. Gold was first discovered in paying quantities, in this Province, about 1860, and millions of dollars' worth has been taken out by probably the very best mining men that this continent has produced.

MADRID, Nov. 11. -- On Nov. 19, the men and woman of Spain who are more than twenty-three years of age will march to the polls to register their opinion of this Spanish republic for the first time since the early flash of enthusiasm over former King Alfonso's departure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many informed persons believe that if the facts concerning the basis upon which our mission schools operate in China were known in America, a radical revision of policy in soliciting and distributing Chinese mission funds would follow.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra makes its first appearance of the season here, giving two performances in New York and one in Brooklyn. The orchestra will play, for the first time in New York, Nicolai Tcherepnin's Three Pieces for Orchestra, after a tale of Edgar Allan Poe.

VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- Ten thousand of Austria's soldiers and all her police, augmented by 5,000 auxiliaries, are being held in readiness tonight to prevent demonstrations by the Socialists tomorrow on the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the republic and by the Nazis over Chancellor Hitler's expected electoral triumph in Germany.

As this is written it is just fifteen years since the guns ceased their hoarse roar along the battle line of mud and blood which stretched from Belfort to the sea. After four years of carnage the deadly rattle of the machine gun was stilled and the crack of the rifle was silenced. On the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month Germany quit.

The British Great War Veterans of America celebrated Armistice Day by giving their annual Armistice Ball last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of their relief work among disabled, ill and needy British war veterans.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 9. -- Another romantic legend of history has been shattered. Jefferson Davis and Sarah Knox Taylor did not elope in 1835. Young Davis and his bride's uncle went to the court house here in Louisville and got a license for the couple to wed.

Richard Washburn Child, chairman of the Bondholders Committes for Republic of Colombia dollar bonds, announced yesterday that his committee had warned Dr. Enrique Olaya Herrera, president of Colombia, that if Colombia wished to continue to sell 90 per cent of the coffee to the United States, cognizance should be taken of the growing sentiment here to "buy from those who pay on their bonds."

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Lafayette's goal posts late today were re- duced to splinters by a joyous throng of 800 Rutgers undergraduates who thus celebrated the first Rutgers football victory over Lafayette on the home field of the Maroon in the last sixteen years.

TWO of the largest and most attractive national parks in Canada -- Jasper National Park and Banff National Park, both in the Province of Alberta, the former in Northern Alberta with an area of 4,200 square miles, the latter on the east slope of the Rocky Mountains with an area of 2,585 square miles -- will soon be linked by a 150-mile highway.

BERLIN, Oct. 15, 1933 WE are navigating the first shallows of a sterile music season. Not even the most optimistic pretend that Berlin has much to look forward to this coming Winter of anxious uncertainty and sinister forebodement.

EDUCATORS are increasingly debating the relation of the schools to society, the responsibility of the schools in connection with the present national emergency. Exhortations are many that the schools should influence the social order, that they should use controversial issues as curriculum material and even that the whole weight of organized public education should be thrown behind the present administration at Washington and its recovery program.

VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- The Dollfuss government is now fighting on three fronts. As though the National Socialists and the Socialists were not enough, the "Little Chancellor" seems to have added the Peasant party to the list of his opponents.

Official delegates of eighteen nations will participate in the third international convention for the Roerich Pact and Banner of Peace in Washington next Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday. The pact was promulgated and the banner created by Nichcia Roerich in 1929.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP). -- A petition in bankruptcy has been filed for Angela Morgan, poet, but she says she is "not at all unhappy." Inspired by the sight of homeless men sleeping on sidewalk gratings, she is already at work on a new poem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. ,11. -- Henry Ford was held today by the Controller General to be eligible for government contracts, although not a signer of the automobile industry's NRA code.

When Faith is 8 years old her father is forced out of his Senatorship by the varying fortune of political life, and he is about to leave Washington and retire to his farm in New England. His city-loving wife refuses to be banished to the country, however, and she takes Faith to live in Europe.

After an early recession that carried prices on the Cotton Exchange off $1 a bale from top figures of the week, a 12-point recovery left the list a point higher to a point lower than on Friday. Fluctuations during the greater part of the short session held within a 5-point limit in the lightest trading in several weeks.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Milo Reno, National Farm Holiday Association president, said tonight that the address of Secretary Wallace here would have "absolutely no effect" on the farm strike.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11. -- Stanford's fighting football team outplayed and outscored Southern California before a crowd of 90,000 persons today, to win by 13 to 7 and administer the first defeat the Trojans have suffered in twentyeight games.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11. -- Two mighty touchdown drives, each for better than 70 yards gave the University of Oregon a victory over Oregon State College, 13 to 3, in their Pacific Coast Conference football clash today. It marked the ninth consecutive victory for the undefeated and untied Webfoots.

The Shipping Board has announced its approval of five contracts of the Dollar Steamship Company which designate New York as either the transfer or terminal port in freight shipments in the intercoastal and Far Eastern trade and the European passenger traffic.

EDWARD M. HOUSE, in a brief introduction to Mr. Looker's book, praises its perspective, its spirit of non-partisanship and its wealth of biographic detail. Colonel House's commendation is well-deserved. This does not mean that we have here a study of Franklin Roosevelt embodying the alleged scholarly virtues of coolness and neutrality.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Wesleyan won a Little Three football contest from Williams today, 6 to 0, and remained in the running for the championship.

MADRID, Nov. 11. -- Although some European delegates in the International Press Conference opposed the Pell resolution for a study to prevent false news reports, on the ground it would reveal "international journalistic secrets," the measure was finally approved unanimously.

The United States Navigation Company, operating ships in the foreign trade, has filed objection with the National Recovery Administration to the shipping code proposed by the American Steamship Owners Association on the ground that it endangers American export trade and the operations of ship lines which function on irregular schedules.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report in THE TIMES of Oct. 22 on the annual conference of the Public Ownership League of America, in Chicago, makes specific reference to numerous municipalities which own and operate electric systems, alleging conspicuous success in each instance.

A brisk recovery in United States Government bonds featured an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The rallies in the government issues carried prices 2-32 to 29-32 point above the previous close, but did not save these issues from finishing substantially lower on the week.

THE phrase chosen to characterize this year's celebration of Children's Book Week lends itself to a personal interpretation. "Growing Up With Books" suggests, no doubt, something slightly different to each one of us; its meaning is colored by our own book background and childhood experience.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 9. -- Despite depression, the cultural interests of the Southwest have continued to grow. Education, music, art -- all have gone forward. In one instance, hard times even worked to the advantage of an outstanding example of cultural progress, the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art, in Kansas City, which will be opened formally in December.

WASHINGTON. THEY are building new vaults in the Treasury Building. All day long the line of concrete mixers stands outside, all day long muddy men trundle barrows of thick gray soup in through the breach in the Treasury wails. Eight feet thick they will be with metal plates that no tool can pierce, so that even the screw holes must be cast in them.

New York and Brooklyn department store advertising showed a gain for the third successive month in October, the total of 3,754,829 lines registering an increase of 10 per cent over the 3,411,160 lines for the same month a year ago, according to Media Records.

The rustic influence of the county fair will pervade the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of Dec. 9, when a "County Fair Ball" will be given to further the social service work of the New York Hospital. The ballroom will be gayly bedecked, with booths of carnival games and sideshows surrounding the floor.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 27. WITH "Desire Under the Elms," the Royal Dramatic Theatre now offers the Stockholm public its third production of a Eugene O'Neill tragedy. This earlier play has received the same outstanding recognition from the critics who noted the dynamic dramatic power in "Strange Interlude" and "Mourning Becomes Electra."

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- While the German Supreme Court continued to hear witnesses in the Reichstag fire trial today, a special court in Berlin established something of a precedent by rendering the first verdict in a political arson case under the retroactive so-called "Lex van der Lubbe," decreed by the Hitler government to make the swift execution of incendiaries.

ABOUT the best business of the season was done by retailers last week as colder weather brought out an active call for seasonal apparel. Some stores here on election day ran 10 to 15 per cent ahead of last year's figures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from J. Gresham Machem printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES, opposing the Federal Child Labor Amendment, builds up its case around the statement that the Federal amendment would give to Congress power no State Legislature now possesses.

TO be on the air planning a pro gram and directing an ethereal troupe for eleven years is quite a record in broadcasting, for the art is not many years older than that. Roxy, however, has that distinction, for he has been at the microphone weekly since 1922, when he introduced his "gang" to listeners.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Melville J. Gideon, American composer and entertainer and one of the original "Co-Optimists," died here today at the age of 49. He underwent an operation for appendicitis a week ago.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 11. -- Emphasis was put on Latin-Americanism, in preference to Pan-Americanism, in a discussion of the program of the coming Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, by Jose M. Puig Casauranc, Foreign Minister of Mexico, who was here today en route to Montevideo as chief of his country's delegation.

ELKINS, W. Va., Nov. 9. -- Through a decision of the West Virginia Supreme Court interpreting the new constitutional amendment limiting levies on various classes of property to mean that all debt requirements, bonded and otherwise, must be met before such levies can be applied on current expenses, local units of government are confronted with the difficulty of raising sufficient funds to carry on their functions.

A NORMAL boy by the time he is 16 or 17 years of age has given some indication of his individual intellectual bent. During four years of secondary school experience he has shown himself proficient in some field of study.

Sixteen eighteenth-century British portraits from the collection of Sir Albert James Bennett, Bart., of Kirklington Hall, Nottinghamshire, England; of William Dawson, 14 Gledhow Gardens, London, and Ralph L. Christie, Durie, Leven, Fife, Scotland, will be offered at motion at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening.

Through the air N.Y.U. struck with lightning swiftness for two touchdowns early in the second period at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and Fordham's vaunted eleven found itself hovering on the brink of defeat for the greater part of the fourteenth annual battle between the two traditional foes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Possibilities of a sharp rise of prices in the wheat market here next week were indicated today. One of the largest grain companies reported that Chicago had only 5,500,000 bushels of that grain in public and private elevators, and that in no other market, except perhaps Duluth, were prices low enough to permit shipments to replenish stocks here this season.

ROME, Nov. 11. -- In January of this year Premier Mussolini created the Institute for Industrial Reconstruction for the purpose of aiding those industrial enterprises which, although fundamentally sound, found themselves in a critical position owing to the depression.

ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Boston skippers outscored Western Long Island Sound sailors today on the opening day of the North American Dinghy Association's regatta held under the auspices of the new Essex Yacht Club on the Connecticut River.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 11. -- A.C. Webb captured the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today by breaking 48 out of 50 targets. T.B. Pettit Jr. scored in a shoot-off for the handicap prize.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 9. -- In a little more than a decade the Holy Land has suffered four serious disturbances -- in 1920, 1921, 1929 and 1933. In three of these Jews were victims and the disturbances were aimed directly at them. In the fourth the Arabs themselves and the police were those who suffered, and the disturbances were directed entirely against the Palestine government, although the reasons were anti-Jewish.

The loss of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was reduced sharply from that of the corresponding period a year before. Net loss after depreciation, interest, taxes and other charges, was $272,650, compared with $1,706,748 loss in the first nine months of 1932.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 1 (AP) -- (By Mail). -- Talk of a gold surplus is a myth, since there is a marked shortage of gold in the world. Professor Gustav Cassel, Swedish economist, says in commenting on the present gold standard problem in the quarterly review issued by the Scandinavian Credit Company, Ltd.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 11. -- Georgia Tech wasted a lot of power during the course of the battle with Florida today, but had enough to spare to defeat a courageous invading eleven by 19 to 7. More than 10,000 saw the game.

THE rare distinction of having written a book a long way out of the ordinary must be accorded Miss Helen Simpson. Symbolical, fantastic, sometimes even bizarre, but always thoughtful and always interesting, "The Woman on the Beast," is of, though by no means altogether in, the romantic tradition.
DETROIT. DURING recent weeks the executive personnel of General Motors Corporation has undergone far-reaching reorganization. A new "Who's Who" of officialdom has been written.

A group characterizing itself as "a delegation of intellectuals, writers and editors" found little sympathy yesterday in a call at the German Consulate to "protest against the imminent execution of Torgler, Dmitroff, Popoff and Taneff on false charges of instigating the Reichstag fire."

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 11. -- Alabama, using thirty-two players, overpowered Virginia Tech, 27 to 0, today, scoring four touchdowns and a safety. The second team started and played the entire first and fourth quarters, scoring once. Dixie Howell's great punting and openfield running featured the Tide attack.

TWO months ago, at the request of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I described the first steps we had taken to carry out the terms of the Agricultural Adjustment Act. Now, responding to a second request, I shall try to bring the story up to date.

IF George Bates, the Sussex bookseller, does not watch out, he will be in danger of becoming a collected author. The pungent introductions to his rare-book catalogues have already attracted widespread attention and comment. The tendency is to read and chuckle over the prefaces and neglect the enticing selection of books offered in the following pages.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 9. -- Opposition to closing the Hiawatha Asylum for Insane Indians at Canton, springing at first from the commercial aspects of the case alone, has been strengthened by the sudden dismissal of Dr. H.R. Hummer, for twenty-five years superintendent of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Further contraction in productive activity occurred in the week ended on Nov. 4, but output remained above that of the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A CHECK on "tax raids" on the country's car owners is seen in a recent decision of the Supreme Court of Colorado, holding unconstitutional the levying by the State of a special car registration fee for relief purposes. Speaking for the American Automobile Association, Thomas P. Henry, its president, believes that the ruling will discourage imposition of special motor taxes or the diversion of motor tax revenues for unemployment aid.

TWENTY, years ago every ship headed for New York carried a crowded steerage. Immigrants passed through Ellis Island at the rate sometimes of 5,000 a day. Late each afternoon ferries left the island crowded with prospective American citizens.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 9. -- The demand of railroads for lower operating costs and greater speed has brought the development here of an engine designed to derive its power from compressed air to be replenished as it runs and to attain a speed of 125 miles an hour.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Gaining at will through the opposing line and completing forward passes for long gains, the Penn State football team had little trouble in defeating Johns Hopkins, 40 to 6, today.
At no time in the history of this country has the question of game preservation been as uppermost in the minds of conservationists and sportsmen alike as now.

A new gold rush was on yesterday as hundreds of would-be vendors of liquor pushed and scrambled and fought at the offices of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, to stake out their claims before others beat them to it.

Two men were arrested yesterday on charges of attempted extortion after they had demanded $2,500 for the return of a diamond ring valued at $27,000, which Mrs. Carlyle Blackwell, wife of the film actor, had reported missing in September. The men did not have the ring in their possession, the police said.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 11. -- For the third year in succession Exeter turned back the Andover eleven in their traditional game today. On a windswept gridiron and in bitter cold, Exeter triumphed by 7 to 6 in the fifty-fourth game of the series.

DESPITE the fact that Ernest Bloch's recently completed setting for the service of the Reformed Synagogue is the work of an American, it seems that its first performance is to take place Jan. 12 in Turin, Italy. The same concert, to be given by the radio orchestra of Turin, will bring forth the composer's "Schelomo," rhapsody for 'cello and orchestra, and his setting of the Twenty-second Psalm for orchestra and baritone.

ENCOURAGED by the late Lord Rosebery, that versatile statesman and litterateur, Mr. Churchill has devoted the leisure of many years to the pious and worthy task of writing what has never yet been written in such fashion, a monumental biography of his illustrious ancestor, the first Duke of Marlborough.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The investments of the State Sinking Fund Commission were defended today by Albert C. Middleton, State Treasurer, and one of the three members of the body. The other members are Governor Moore and Controller John McCutcheon.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Several parties were given in Greenwich today. Mrs. Charles R. Sherlock was a dinner hostess at her home in honor of Colonel Robert D. Baker of New York.

One of the important benefit theatre parties in prospect is the performance of "Her Master's Voice" at the Plymouth Theatre on the night of Nov. 21, which has been taken over to aid the support of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, a nonsectarian, home school for neglected boys.

THE revolt of children against the leading-strings of parents is a well-worn but essentially interesting theme. Jane Miller's childhood is set in the particularly confining period of toe 1890s. Her mother is an ultra-Victorian of the most efficient and blackest type.

ONE of Mr. Freeman's favorite stunts is to start off with two or more mysteries, apparently unrelated to each other, and then to show that they are either parts of one crime or that there is an intimate, even though accidental connection of one with the other.

UP to three weeks ago last Friday, when Jed Harris presented "The Green Bay Tree" at the Cort Theatre for the first time in this country, Mordaunt Shairp was little more than a dimly familiar name to most theatre-goers here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- America was called upon today by the World Alliance for International Friendship to propose an amendment to the Treaty of Paris "through which all the signatory nations will pledge themselves in the event of hostilities in violation of the pact, or the threat of such hostilities, promptly to consult together to determine upon such joint measures as will help to maintain peace."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11. -- A 50yard touchdown drive late in the third period gave the Pitt Panthers a 7-to-0 victory over Duquesne on a sleet-sloshed field today. It was the Dukes' first loss in nine starts this season. A crowd of 60,000 attended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Armistice Day ceremonies at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington Cemetery were marked today by addresses by Secretary Dern, who declared that "everybody lost" the World War, and Edward A. Hayes, National Commander of the American Legion, who asserted that if the Unknown Soldier could speak he would protest the "official recognition of strange tenets," which, "through violence and revolution," would destroy the American Government.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 11. -- Carnegie Tech and Michigan State fought a bitter intersectional football battle today that ended in a scoreless deadlock. The game was marked by brilliant defensive play on the 1-yard line, both teams failing to score by inches.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- A touchdown early in the first period enabled Georgia to preserve its string of consecutive victories today. The undefeated Southern Bulldogs, encountering unexpectedly strong resistance from Yale, capitalized on their early scoring thrust to turn back the Blue, 7 -- 0.

IT is difficult now to re-create the mood in which the American experiment with national prohibition began in 1920, but certainly there was no lack of confidence on the part of its chief sponsors. This was to be the end of the saloon, of the distillers' lobby, of crime bred by the liquor traffic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The Food Industries Advisory Board, created in June as an adjunct of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration has been dissolved, the administration revealed today. Varying explanations, official and otherwise, were given as reasons for its discontinuance.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9. -- With prohibition repeal an accomplished fact except for the final obsequies, Los Angeles and other Southern California cities engaged in appropriate celebration of the event. While the Eighteenth Amendment is still technically in effect, enforcing machinery ceased to function, and in the interim before Dec. 6, when the Twenty-first Amendment becomes the law of the land, California is without jurisdictional powers, for its new enforcing laws are inoperative until then.

EBRLIN. WITH the entrenchment of the National Socialist government and the division into departmental duties of what had previously been theories, the Nazis find themselves facing facts which sometimes prove a surprise.

BERLIN. RICARDA HUCH, who has such love for heroic figures, hitherto has gone abroad for the subjects of her books. She also has written a history of the dreadful Thirty Years' War, revealing an extraordinary sense of historic values.

TIENTSIN, Nov. 10. -- On his arrival here today from Sinkiang Province, in the Northwest, Foreign Minister Lo Wen-kan, while taking full cognizance of the grave plight of Sinkiang's polyglot population, said he believed there was no immediate danger that the province would become detached from China, provided Nanking promptly rectified maladministration there.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 9. -- Though known far and wide as a distinctly rural State, Mississippi can take one and one-half million acres of cotton out of production, plant the entire acreage in food and feed crops and still reach only the half-way mark in meeting its deficiency in the production of such commodities.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 8. -- Texans are being alternately amused and shocked these days as a legislative investigating committee blows hot and cold in a petty job-selling inquiry that seems to have come in with the administration of Mrs. Governor Ferguson.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 11. -- After running two brilliant races, Happy, a black and white setter today scored a well-merited triumph in the Derby Stake, the feature of the opening session of the two-day field trial of the North Shore Game Protective Association, staged at Kilsyth, the estate of Gerald H. Livingston near here.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 11. -- Before a colorful home coming day crowd of 31,000 Nebraska's scarlet-jerseyed Comhuskers staged a spirited offensive in the second and fourth quarters to defeat the University of Kansas today, 12 to 0.

FOR the first time in some years the O. Henry Memorial Prize has been given to a story which confers real honor upon the award. Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings's long-short story "Gal Young Un" has a vigor of conception and an appropriateness of style which would have assured it a prominent place in the fiction of any season.

The Metropolitan Trap. THE Automobile Club of New York is having another attack of optimism. It shows symptoms of believing that markers designating routes through the city will actually be erected before the dawn of the post-historic future.

TIME is the "essence of the contract" where radio writing is concerned, according to Montague Glass, creator of "Potash and Perlmutter," who for the past five months has been devoting his talents to the production of script for his comedy characters to "speak" three times a week on WJZ's network.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9. -- Argentina will not import from the United States and other countries more than they buy from Argentina. This is the aim of the new exchange control policy to be instituted soon by Finance Minister Pinedo, this correspondent learned tonight from an authoritative source close to the Finance Ministry.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 11. -- Yesterday marked the twenty-second anniversary of the formal opening of the Chinese revolution, the overthrow of the Manchu dynasty and "the founding of the republic."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 9. -- At the end of six weeks -- covering a period preliminary to a general students' strike at the University of Puerto Rico, the strike itself and the final removal of its cause through the resignation of the Socialist representative, Rafael Alonso Torres, from the board of trustees -- two rather fine things stand out.
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 11. -- A fighting Boston College eleven scored an upset at Alumni Field today by outplaying Villanova, 9 to 0.

ABOUT fifty years ago Sir Oliver Lodge began a series of experiments on the precipitation of dust, fumes, smoke and fog. Near a stove or on the ceiling above a gas-jet or even above an electric light bulb he, like many others, had noticed that there was usually a black patch.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The trade relations figuring in the Russo-American conversations embrace a wide field and have many ramifications.

IN a series of biographical ballads this book presents a rhymed review of American history. It is a very uneven performance. At its best it reaches a high level. At its worst it sounds like the relentless trickling of Milne-and-water. The dedication, "To Stephanie, Thomas and Rachel, our other works in collaboration," urbanely indicates that the collection is mainly meant for children.
The Republican organizations of New York City will play a minor role in patronage dispensing under the administration of F.H. LaGuardia, it was asserted yesterday.

In two and one-half weeks or operation of the governments' new monetary policy, the dollar has declined rapidly in relation to gold and foreign currencies, but there has been no proportionate rise in domestic prices.

The swimming team of George Washington High School, only unbeaten team of the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond group in the senior high school race for Public Schools Athletic League honors, faced its first strong rival of the season in the home pool yesterday and came through successfully.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- An Armistice Day dinner dance took place tonight at the Bonnie Briar Country Club here. The hosts included:

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Colgate romped to a 72-0 victory over Ohio Northern's football team today in a game played during a snowstorm. The Red Raiders' entire squad, except the first team, was used before the final whistle blew.

BUFFALO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Thomas Penney Sr., the prosecutor of Leon Czolgosz, who assassinated President McKinley here in 1901, died at his Buffalo home today. He had appeared last night to be in excellent health. His age was 74.

Four hundred members of the American Civil Liberties Union, at luncheon at the Astor yesterday, voted unanimously to send a protest to Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador at Washington, over the conduct of the Reichstag fire trial.

Although prices of stocks now are more than 80 per cent higher than they were at the year's lowest level in March, memberships in the New York Stock Exchange were sold last week at $95,000, which was only $5,000 above the lowest quotation this year and $155,000 below the year's high mark of $250,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- It was a year ago this week that Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected President of the United States. Nine months of this period he has been in office. What have been the changes in his outlook, his policies, his associates and in himself?

PARIS. PARIS feels, cinematically speaking, as if it has come into its own as the Winter season is getting under way. For not only are the films of its own production coming out in goodly numbers, but the best of foreign pictures are finding their way here, so much so that September brought two world premieres of important films in English.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Election of Neville Miller, Democrat, as Mayor of Louisville, was conceded today by Chesley H. Searcy, a member of the Republican campaign committee. Colonel Dan M. Carrell, the Republican candidate, made no statement.
IN the Summer of 1912 Lawrence was in Bavaria and the Tyrol with his wife, Frieda. It was one of the happiest times in his life.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Wheat futures, after a dull opening, advanced 1/4d a bushel on unfavorable Australian crop reports. Lack of moisture in Argentina where temperatures were reported high; better demand for cash wheat and nervousness over the monetary situation also contributed to the advance.

A message from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, stressing the peace message of Anntstice Day, was read yesterday afternoon at an open-air peace meeting held in Washington Square under the auspices of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, and of World Peaceways.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Behind the facade of public debates and national plebiscites on foreign policy, there is being fought out just now one of the keenest diplomatic struggles in which France ever took part.

THE New York records for twelve and one-half years of prohibition are here arranged by Stanley Walker, close to the closing-hour deadline, for their bum's rush into history. The gaudier figures of the night club era are already tarnished.

IT would be pleasanter not to discuss any further than has already been done the American debut of Serge Lifar, but Mr. Lifar's international reputation demands more attention for the event than one's kindly, instincts would dictate.

Two undefeated teams, Cosmopolitan and the Carroll Club, met in a tournament game of the New York Field Hockey Association at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, and when the whistle ended the contest Cosmopolitan remained the only unbeaten team in the association.
PARIS, Nov. 11. -- Past the tomb of the Unknown Soldier beneath Napoleon's great triumphal arch people have been filing all day in processions, in groups and singly.

PARIS. THE -- Chinese silhouette will be fairly conspicuous among early Spring fashions. (Mme. Schiaparelli started the ball rolling in her Winter collection). Notice that the word silhouette is used, so do not get the idea of just draping yourself in an antique mandarin coat or celestial embroideries and calling it a day, or a night.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 8. -- Of chief interest in the Farm Belt during the past week has been the attack by the administration, through General Hugh S. Johnson, upon those who have been fighting the recovery program.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 9. -- For the fourth time in five years the North Carolina electorate has amazed all of the State's political prognosti- cators -- this time by returning a majority of 150,000 against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. As on each of the former occasions the unexpected is so readily explainable in retrospect that surprise at the event is mingled with surprise that it was not anticipated.

With her after bridge dotted by bullet marks, the Ward liner Morro Castle arrived here yesterday and landed thirty-one passengers who were still talking over the thrilling experience of being under fire last Wednesday afternoon as the ship was leaving Havana.

Revision of the State's mortgage foreclosure moratorium and deficiency judgment statutes, is essential to an equitable solution of many realty problems which have arisen in the past three years, in the opinion of Robert H. Armstrong of-the-real estate firm of Armstrong Armstrong.

THOMAS ROURKE, whose "Thunder Below," a tale of Yankee engineers and one woman isolated in Central American jungles, received wide acclaim, once more finds his inspiration in the Caribbean scene. This time a dictator-ruled republic on the north coast of South America serves for background.

Problems of ship construction and operation will be discussed by naval officers and commercial shipping experts at the forty-first annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers on Thursday and Friday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) . -- A suggestion that the government collect all liquor levies and allocate shares of the money to the States was added today to the lengthening list of after-repeal proposals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Impressive ceremonies in memory of Woodrow Wilson attended by surviving members of the Wilson Cabinet, members of the Roosevelt Cabinet and men and women prominent in public and private life were held this afternoon in Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral before the tomb of Mr. Wilson.

"Zeke the Raccoon" is the story of a pet. To be sure, like most young raccoons, he started life in a hollow tree. But while still a baby he falls out of the tree and into the hands of a small boy who carries him home and at once Zeke becomes an important member of the household.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 11. -- Notre Dame's football fortunes rose to new hopes today and then crashed to the lowest depths in five years as Purdue's Boilermakers took to the air to seal a 19-to-0 triumph over the Ramblers before 35,000 spectators.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. , 11. -- A crowd of 40,000 shivering spectators saw Illinois triumph over Northwestern, 3 to 0, today, scoring a victory over the Wildcats for the first time in five years.

Sales of the first twenty store chains reporting for October show a gain of 4.8 per cent over sales for October, last year, according to a compilation made by Lehman Brothers. As to groups, the mailorder chains led with an increase of 18.7 per cent over October, 1932.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said before sailing on the Munson liner American Legion yesterday that he believed the coming Pan-American Conference at Montevideo would result in the most substantial step toward Pan-American unity of the last twenty years.

GENEVA. SINCE Babylon, three things in the world have been said to attract women and fill the greater part of their lives: chatting, shopping and dressing. In these last few years one thing could cave been added in the case ot some women -- international conferences.

JASCHA HEIFETZ will return to his native Russia next April for the first time in seventeen years. On June 27, 1917, be left Russia and has not been there since. In April he will return for a six weeks' concert tour. He will play with the Moscow and Leningrad orchestras under Albert Coates, as well as give a series of concerts in the various Soviet cities.

IT is only recently that we have had much fiction in English whose predominating note is that of sensibility. Our older novelists flirted with the same note; but Meredith, Jane Austen, Henry James impress us, in the long run, as really psychologists or novelists of manners.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP). -- American Legion officials expressed indignation today because seventy-five Wellesley College girls carried anti-war placards at the annual Armistice Day services on Wellesley Green.
Rameses V, the indignant Fordham mascot which was kidnapped early Thursday morning from his stable on the university campus, reappeared at the Fordham-N.Y.U. football game yesterday.

THE repeal of prohibition, like Rip Van Winkle's awakening from his long sleep, brings back into a changed world something that has itself greatly changed. The boldest prophet may hesitate to say precisely what will happen when the modern American again has his legal jug of wine beside him in his wilderness.

As today is the annual Red Cross Sunday, launching the seventeenth annual roll-call of the organization, pastors will appeal to parishioners to enroll for 1934. Representatives of the American Red Cross will be stationed in the vestibules of the churches after the services to receive donations and to inscribe names in the membership drive.

MOSS HART yesterday went about what he called "doing a Noel Coward." He caught a freighter (the name escaped him last Wednesday when all this came up) and started on a three weeks' cruise. Route: To Honduras, South America and way stations.

The use of the name of James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, in letters soliciting advertising for The Jeffersonian, a Democratic publication, was unauthorized, Robert R. Livingstop, chairman of the Democratic Union, which directs the magazine, said last night.

THIS long and, one feels, heavily documented family history revolves around the old theme of "shirt-sleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations." It tells briefly through the reminiscences of Grandmother Sewall of the rise of the Sewall family to great eminence in the banking world; and, in detail and at greater length, of their years on the heights and of their recent fall.

TWO orchestral events of recent date have been auspicious for American compositions and American music. The first of these was the performance by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra of the "Concerto sacro," by Werner Josten, German by birth, American by citizenship and long residence here.

Beginning yesterday with the enrolment of public officials and a ceremony at the Eternal Light in Madison Square the annual roll-call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will continue today with the observance of Red Cross Sunday in the city's churches.

Society's interest in the Horse Show at Madison Square Garden was shown last night by crowded boxes and arena seats. Many of the boxholders canceled their weekend trips to the country in order to stay over for the Saturday sessions and the gala performance tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 27. IN the last few years the historians' Elizabeth has become a favorite target of dramatic marksmanship. It is not an easy one, and the core of that complex and dazzling character has so far gone untouched.

Two 16-year-old schoolboys appeared in Harlem Court yesterday on a charge of extortion. The complainant was a frail 13-year-old classmate of one of them, who said he had paid them $12.50 in the past two weeks to avoid being beaten. The prisoners, Rocco La Morrocco of 420 East 115th Street and Ralph Tutino of 412 East 115th Street, were held by Magistrate Burke in bail of $100 each for a hearing Wednesday.

SCHEDULED to meet Yale at New Haven this year on Dec. 2, Princeton has two remaining games at Palmer Stadium, its home field -- with the Navy next Saturday and Rutgers on Nov. 25. Both contests are expected to draw many motorists.
DISCONTENT again hangs over the tall-grass country. The hope of the farmer that the prices of things he sells would overtake the prices of things he buys from the cities has been disappointed.

Rudolf Friml, composer, returned last week after an extended stay in Europe and the Orient, bringing back nearly 1,000 new compositions and a desire to increase the understanding of Oriental music in this country.

There is no better story-teller than Mrs. Bianco, for she enters thoroughly into the events she describes, and her characters, whether they are a "Velveteen Rabbit," a "Skin Horse" or a broken wooden doll, are conceived with so much imagination that they continue to have a real existence for us even after the book is closed.

THIS book is not so much a sequel to Sven Hedin's "Across the Gobi Desert" as it is an amplification of that illuminating and stirring volume. Perhaps it would be even more accurately described as the complement of the first narrative.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 11. -- The last step in the Farm Administration's program, the method by which the corn-hog farmers of Iowa are to be lifted from their slough of despond, was outlined here today to 10,000 farmers and business men of Des Moines by Secretary Wallace, who before he became a member of the Cabinet was editor here of Wallace's Farmer.

DENVER, Nov. 9. -- Called for Dec. 4, the special session of the Legislature is likely to continue indefinitely. Ostensibly to untangle the relief problem, it seems likely that the session will find it necessary to revise the work of all recent Legislatures, which have followed the policy of doing nothing so that nobody would be offended.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9. -- Eddie Morse, a Negro who keeps a store near the University of Richmond, is minus $960 in banknotes as a result of his gullibility in allowing the roll to be "blessed" by a mysterious woman who said she was an Indian.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 12. -- Ever since Premier Inukai's murder stories of a plan for a Fascist drive have been news in Japan, apt to revive in the newspapers with every political ripple.

PEARY LODGE, Thule, Greenland, Oct. 21 (By Wireless to Copenhagen). -- In the morning Demorest started alone for Camp Watkins to recover the supplies I had left, most important of which were pemmican and dog food. Schmeling and I remained in camp to rest the other dog team.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 11. -- St. Michael's capitalized on two dazzling 50-yard runs by Emil Bozek and Earl Peavy to register an astonishing upset and defeat the University of Vermont today, 13 to 0.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- President von Hindenburg and Premier Goering of Prussia closed tonight the campaign of the Hitler government for unanimous approval of its policy by the German people at the polls tomorrow and the election of an all-Nazi Reichstag.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- A pan card of 70, scored in an icy wind, today put Paul Runyan, 28-yearold pro of White Plains, N.Y., in the lead for the National Capital open golf championship over the Kenwood Country Club course.

Almost coincidently with celebration of the release of 5,000,000 Americans from armed warfare fifteen years ago, our Government is enlisting 4,000,000 men to defend themselves and their families against want. It is an undertaking of greater difficulty and complexity than mobilization for war.

ALL-WAVE radios are the vogue this season. They tune in the regular broadcasts and in addition the short waves from foreign lands; from police headquarters, airplanes and amateurs. A small switch shifts the listener from the 200 to 550 meter broadcast band into the short wave spectrum.

EMPORIA, Kan., Nov. 10. -- These lines are written by one who for forty years and more has worked in politics to promote prohibition. Prohibition is dead. Peace to its ashes! It is too early to write its history intelligently. But it was significant that the day before the final voting repealed the Eighteenth Amendment, the Kansas House of Representatives unanimously voted for a referendum on the State prohibition amendment.

The local NRA Compliance Board will hear on Tuesday the protests of the Federated Restaurant and Hotel Guilds against the exceptions now being granted to restaurant owners, who say it is unduly burdensome for them to comply with the minimum wage requirements of the President's Agreement.

PRAGUE. SIX hours south of Berlin by train, the towers of Prague rise in magnificent symmetry, unknown to the mass of travelers. While the German capital to the north provides political food for an anxious world, the ancient Czech city offers only the inspiration of beautiful views.

HOLLYWOOD. PURCHASE of several important European stories, the importation of additional Continental players and a more comprehensive schedule for Movietone City were announced this week by Winfield Sheehan upon his resumption of the Fox reins after three months abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- In his message to President Kalinin of the Soviet Union, President Roosevelt used the phrase "to explore" the possibilities of American-Soviet relationship. That is exactly what is happening now -- America is "discovering" Russia.

WHIFFY McMANN," by Berta and Elmer Hader, is an unpretentious but attractive little picture book. Whiffy, the kitten, is droll and engaging and children will enjoy the drawings and also the simple text that describes his exploits and adventures.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The British Government now hopes it has devised a law which will make its unemployment insurance actuarially solvent for a generation to come.

IT is four years now since the first definite moves were made by leaders in the aeronautic field, both here and abroad, toward the establishment of round-the-world airline, using both airships and planes.

PARIS. THE story of the A.E.F. has now been inscribed in stone on the gnarled and hollow hilltops of the old battlefields. Crumbling, weed-grown trenches still seam the slopes of Montfaucon, Montsec, Blanc Mont, Beltean Wood and Hill 204 below Chateau Thierry.

The question of municipal ownership of public utilities was answered by several cities on last Tuesday, but plans for municipally owned electric plants will be submitted to the voters of Knoxville on Nov. 25 and of Memphis on Dec. 11, while other important Southern cities are considering the matter and many towns and villages are to ballot on such issues in coming months.

ON the traffic-crowded waters of New York Harbor it is necessary to maintain a considerable fleet of municipally operated vessels of various sorts and sizes. There are fireboats to answer waterfront alarms, police boats to aid in various emergencies, ferryboats to carry thousands of passengers across bay and river, scows to be towed to seat for the dumping of garbage.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11. -- The interest with which Maxim Litvinoff's reception in Washington is being followed in the Soviet press recalls that probably in no other country are the activities of a representative in foreign lands so interesting to the public.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The Montclair High football team defeated Morristown today by 21 -- 6.

The annual Grand National Show of the Empire Cage Bird Association opened yesterday in the Salle Moderne, on the roof of the Hotel Pennsylvania. Down in Seventh Avenue it was Winter, but in the Salle Moderne, so far as the ears could tell, it was the most idyllic of Spring days.
Football will pay its tribute to the late Major Frank W. Cavanaugh at the Polo Grounds today when the New York Giants clash with the Boston Redskins in the Cavanaugh memorial game.

A LATE addition to the Fall list of Little, Brown Co. is Bernard Fay's "Roosevelt and His America," which will be published on Nov. 24. This is the book that was commented on by Andre Maurois in his Paris letter in our issue of Sept. 24.

PARIS, Oct. 28. AFTER the two plays of Jacques Deval and Alfred Savoir -- essays in the brutal insolence and misanthropy of the Steve Passeur manner by authors who fall to convince, as Passeur does, that this is really their outlook upon life -- we have had an essay by Passeur himself in the light and airy manner of his friend Marcel Achard.

The Guaranteed Mortgage Certificate Holders Protective Association issued a statement yesterday demanding a Federal or State investigation of title and mortgage companies operating in this State and asking also for an inquiry into methods used by the State Department of Insurance in supervising these companies.

Away From Parliaments. What is the real grievance which people have against the parliamentary system? Is it that parliaments are political bodies instead of being economic organizations, as they ought to be?
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The deadlocked hog market was no nearer a solution of its troubles tonight than three days ago when the "sellers' strike" started.
