Except for deviations from heretofore generally recognized principles of income taxation, the New York State emergency tax imposed upon personal incomes, for which regulations were released by the State Tax Commission on Oct. 16, might have been regarded merely as a 1 per cent addition to the present normal income tax rates.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Bucknell scored its eighteenth consecutive home victory today by defeating the hitherto unbeaten Furman University eleven, 12 to 0. The game was played in sub-freezing weather.

In a recent speech over the radio Lord CECIL rather unguardedly asserted that the chief international difficulties with which the world is confronted today are due to secret diplomacy. He admitted, to be sure, that, in negotiations between one country and another, "a great deal must be done by per"sonal conversations between one man "and another."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Municipalities able to finance their programs either partly or wholly will not be allowed to take advantage of the benefits of the newly created $400,000,000 program for civil works, it was stated this afternoon after officials discussed the new plan.

Since the passage of the National Industrial Recovery Act by Congress, the question, of price-fixing has been a cause of much discussion among industrial executives as well as high government officialsFew codes under the NRA have been submitted to Washington without the question of price-fixing having been discussed at one time or another in the course of their preparation.

A series of public hearings to discuss the implications of increased leisure time accruing to millions of workers under the NRA as a result of economic recovery will be held by the National Recovery Administration's New York committee on the use of leisure time, it was announced yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick, chairman.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 11. -- A fighting Brown team today staved off a last-minute passing attack by Syracuse to win, 10 -- 7, before 4,000 at Brown Stadium.

Unemployed architects and their needy families will be aided by several events in the near future arranged in their behalf by prominent women. One of these will be the private showing of drawings of eighteenth-century American houses by talented young unemployed draftsmen tomorrow afternoon at the English Bookshop Gallery, 55 East Fifty-fifth street.
Supremacy in cross country racing among the metropolitan colleges rests for another year with the green-clad Harriers of Manhattan College.
Frank Goodell scored all points as Curtis High School's undefeated football team downed Far Rockaway High, 7 to 0, before 2,000 yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons celebrated the opening of their 1933-34 National Hockey League season tonight by coming from behind to defeat the Boston Bruins, 3 to 2, in a hardchecking game before a crowd of 7,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The University of Detroit defeated the strong Catholic University team today, 26 to 0.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- With the popular verdict in and official sentence about to be pronounced on prohibition, governmental authorities in Illinois, Wisconsin and Indiana -- as in many other States -- are wrestling with the problem of how to avoid too jubilant a wake after the noble experiment has been adjudged legally dead.

A nerve-tingling duel in the final stages saw Joseph Moclair of Manhattan Prep triumph over Herbert Cornell of Poly Prep, Brooklyn, and retain his Athletic Association of Private Schools' championship in the association's eleventh annual cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning.

The scene of the major interscholastic cross-country runs will shift from Van Cortlandt Park to Long Island this week. On La Salle Military Academy's picturesque course bordering on the Great South Bay at Oakdale the annual La Salle invitation interscholastic race will be contested on Saturday.

Decentralization of industry through the location of factories in small towns and cities away from large centres of population will be one of the outstanding results of the NRA program, industrialists and engineers agreed here yesterday.

THIS is the fourth of Maurice Hindus's periodical reports on the state of affairs in the Soviet Union. For several years now his position has been established as one of the more dependable observers of the course of the Russian experiment.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 11. -- General Hugh S. Johnson came here today to "sell" President Roosevelt's recovery program to the people of this vast Southwestern cotton region and discovered that the "sale" had already been made.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The Union College football team defeated Rochester 13 -- 0 today, to score its first victory in six games. Union literally passed its way to victory, Dain throwing 15 yards to Milano and a touchdown in the first period, and tossing from the 11-yard line over the goal line to Waldron in the third.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- Adolf Hitler will this Sunday summon the German people to the polls in a national rally such as the world probably never before has witnessed. In name it is to be an election; in fact it will be a monster demonstration by more than 40,000,000 eligible voters for "the honor, peace and equality" of Germany.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- The Boerse began to anticipate Hitler's assured victory in tomorrow's election with a mild upward movement today which produced gains up to 3 per cent. The turnover, however, remained small. Heavy industrials rose about one per cent and lignite, electrical and potash shares up to 3 per cent.

VIENNA. THE airplane from Nuremberg, skirting the mountains hemming in the wide valley, circled over Salzburg, swooped to a halt on the green flying-field and the few passengers for points east trooped out to the tiny frontier control office.

A preview of the motion picture "The Mystery of Hamlet" will be given under the auspices of the New York branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance in connection with a reception and a musicale on the night of Dec. 1.

Lieutenant C.W. Raguse of the United States Army team won the Bowman Challenge Cup at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. He defeated thirty-four other officers in the international military jumping competition open to all nations, the closing event on a brilliant program which was witnessed by 10,000 en- thusiastic-spectators.

KENT, Conn., Nov. 11. -- The traditional rivalry between the Kent and Choate School football teams was resumed on Alumni Field today. After a tense struggle, Choate gained a 7-to-0 victory. The encounter brought the season to a close for both teams.

Advertising prospects for 1934 are very much clouded by uncertainty over impending Federal legislation, particularly in the drug, cosmetic and food industries, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by leading national advertisers and agencies.

Among the large number of codes submitted to the NRA authorities in Washington, one of the most importance to both workers and employes, points out Myron L. Matthews in the current Daw Service Daily Building Report, is that drawn up by the Construction League of the United States.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Robert White, 21-year-old son of Governor George White of Ohio and a senior at Princeton University, was killed in an automobile accident near here last night.
Dr. Burton James Lee, surgeon and cancer specialist, died yesterday morning at his residence, 155 East Seventy-second Street, of coronary thrombosis. He was 59 years old.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 Police today were working on the theory that Jay F. Towner 3d of Perryman, Md., found dead last night on the Princeton University campus, was crashed to death in the crowd leaving Palmer Stadium yesterday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that our city has once more been freed from the misrule of Tammany, which this time has put us "in hock," it is of greatest importance that we make provision in the new charter to keep Tammany out and not go through the experience we have had in the past of seeing it back on the job again in a few years.

D.L. Taylor and Z.G. Simmons each broke 99 out of 100 targets in the contest for high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The former gunner triumphed in the shoot-off, 24-23. E.B. Horwath took the first handicap prize and H. Thoens the second.

Ten persons were injured, none seriously, yesterday when an automobile in the funeral procession following the body of Texas Guinan to the Gate of Heaven Cemetery at White Plains was struck by another car coming out of a side road.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Muskogee Frank's Princess, a black and white pointer, today triumphed in both stakes at the final session of the two-day field trial of the North Shore Game Protective Association, held on the estate of Gerald Livingston.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Chicago's Cardinals today were relegated to the National Professional Football League cellar as the Cincinnati Reds beat them, 12 to 9. About 6,000 spectators, half of them "ladies day" guests, witnessed the contest.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- For the first time in fourteen years the annual Rose Tournament football classic took on the emerald hue of Oregon today, at least temporarily, as the Webfoots alone pursued the unbeaten path on the Western seaboard's gridirons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: General Hugh S. Johnson at Chicago on Nov. 6 characterized the critics of NRA as "witch doctors" or "chiselers." Edward A. Filene of Boston on Nov. 7 characterized all the critics of NRA as "Tories." Has there even been a largescale social experiment without its honest critics?

Certainty in a second coming of Christ was voiced by the Rev. Dr. Will H. Rogers, pastor of the Hinson Memorial Baptist Church, Portland, Ore., yesterday morning in the First Baptist Church, Broadway at Seventy-ninth. Street, where he is preaching a series of sermons.

Capitalizing every opportunity that presented itself, a fast and aggressive Philadelphia Country Club eleven blanked the Carroll Club of New York, 3 to 0, in a women's field hockey match at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BERLIN, Monday, Nov. 13 -- At 2 A.M., out of an eligible German electorate of 44,400,000, the votes of more than 43,400,000, or 97 per cent, in yesterday's plebiscite have been counted and all but 6.6 per cent of them support the attitude of the National Socialist Government in quitting the disarmament conference and the League of Nations.

Endorsement of the work of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee was expressed in a letter from President Roosevelt to James G. Blaine, its chairman, made public yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 120 Broadway.

Several thrilling games marked the climax of the 1933 Eastern prep school football season during the past week-end as a majority of the leading elevens concluded their campaigns. In the five outstanding traditional contests there were many tense and exciting moments.
By the narrow margin of one-fifth of a second, Lieutentant E.F. Thomson of the United States Army team won the $1,000 International Military Sweepstake at the National Horse Show last night.

In round numbers the national debt of the United States is twenty-three billion dollars. The National Industrial Conference Board estimates that the total cost of the various measures comprising the "New Deal" may amount to more than half the indebtedness now outstanding.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- The plant of The Mansfield News-Journal was bombed early today, eight hours after the editor of the newspaper received a racketeer warning to "lay off or you'll get yours." The bomb exploded in the mailing room at 4:06 A.M.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- While the American price of gold rose last week from $32.67 an ounce to $33.20, the London price fell from 132s 4d to 129s 8d.

Forty-seven educators, social workers and clergymen have joined in a petition to the State Temporary Relief Administration protesting against a proposed reduction in the pay of teachers in the emergency adult education project, a relief plan conducted by the State Department of Education and financed by the relief administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Farm officials have decided to make loans on the cotton on which options were given to farmers as part of their benefit payments for plowing up more than 10,000,000 acres of their growing crop last Summer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Development of better transportation facilities between the Americas was termed the most important method of developing a closer understanding between nations in the Western Hemisphere by Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to the President, in a radio address tonight.

LIMA, Nov. 12. -- A new political group to be known as the National party is being organized by the majority in the Constituent Assembly. The prime mover is Dr. Clement J. Revilla, president of the Assembly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not long ago I read in your column with sinking spirits that you had severed association with "that stout medieval monarch," Gilbert Keith Chesterton. So distasteful an occurrence was caused by some little thing he had written chiding Miss Gertrude Stein and her coterie of modernists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A minimum of 1,500,000 needy persons will be benefited directly this Winter through the payment of cash allotments by members of the Civilian Conservation Corps to their dependents, according to Robert Fechner, Director of Emergency Conservation work. Such cash allotments, he said, are expected to aggregate more than $35,000,000 during the five months from November to March.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12.-The body ot a young man, his skull fractured and his features disfigured, was found early today sprawled across trolley trades In Westchester. Pike, in a lonely, unlighted section at the edge of suburban Broomall, Pockets of his expensive clothing had been turned inside out, indicating robbery.

Holders of $7,990,000 Hotel St. George first mortgage bonds now in default, have been notified of the formation of an independent bond-holders' committee which purposes to "compel restoration of diverted income and to effect a speedy and economical reorganization."
Three men were killed, and a fourth, the pilot, was badly injured yesterday when the plane in which they were joy-riding crashed into a Brooklyn apartment house.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- From widely scattered districts of the State, club women thronged to Elmira today for the opening tomorrow of the annual meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A strong defense of Federal regulation of petroleum prices was made today by the oil industry's planning and coordination committee at the same time as reports were heard that prices due to become effective Dec. 1 might be postponed or revised sharply.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- Stricken by the death of their son and brother, Governor White and his eldest daughter, Miss Mary White, First Lady of Ohio, were comforted at the Executive Mansion here tonight by two old friends, Mr. and Mrs. John H. McCoy of Marietta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, has tendered his resignation to Attorney General Cummings, to become effective on Nov. 21, and will return to the private practice of law in New York.

Spiritual rehabilitation of Judaism in America was decided upon yesterday at the National Recovery Assembly of the United Synagogue of America, at the Hotel Commodore. Delegates representing more than 750 Jewish religious organizations in the United States and Canada attended morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Dr. John Emmons deMund, retired physician and sportsman, died last night at his home here. Dr. deMund was 67 years old and had been in failing health for almost a year. His death, however, was caused by a heart attack.
In the house in which he died forty years ago, Edwin Booth was honored last night on the eve of the 100th anniversity of his birth.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Luneau Tonnele will give a reception the afternoon of Dec. 16 at the clubhouse of the Junior League of New York, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Reva Marie Tonnele.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Jay Franklin Towner 3d,, whose body was found last night on the campus of Frinceton University, was the only child of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Franklin Towner Jr. of Ferryman, near Havre de Grace, Md. The young man was a graduate of Friends School, Baltimore, and had attended Johns Hopkins University.

CADIZ, Spain, Nov. 12 -- A spectacular attempt by a gunman to assassinate Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, leader of Spanish Fascists and son of Spain's late dictator, brought death to one man and serious injury to four others in the neighboring town of San Fernando today.

Two persons were killed and two others were injured seriously yesterday when an automobile in which they were riding, overturned and ignited after crashing into a pile of paving stones on Cross Bay Boulevard near Ninth Road, Broad Channel, Queens.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.6, which compares with. 71.8 a week ago, 71.6 two weeks ago, 71.5 three weeks ago and 72.2 four weeks ago. The average of four weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Lanky Johnny Sorrell, forward for the Detroit Red Wings, registered four goals tonight to furnish the scoring power that defeated the New York Americans, 5 to 2, in the season's opening National Hookey League game at Olympia Arena before 8,500 spectators.

The course of the markets is just now giving little indication as to the real financial situation. Last week their action was for the most part governed by speculation on the meaning and probable results of the government's program to depress the dollar's foreign value.

The construction of merchant tonnage dropped to the lowest level on record in the fiscal year 1932-33, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday. A total of 449,751 tons was built and classified by the society, as compared with 920,902 tons the previous year and 1,758,610 tons in 1930-31.

ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 12 -- In bitter cold sailing today out on the Connecticut River, Waldo Howland of Boston captured the early Winter championship of Class B dinghies. He took the Everett E. Dickinson Cup in the North American Dinghy Association regatta, running up a total score of 55 points in his boat Plover II.

Metropolitan subscribers are this week receiving the fifty-first annual statement of New York's leading opera season, long a social and musical fixture, and now for the first time made possible by a popular guarantee fund of $300,000 obtained through stage and radio appeals last Spring.

Despite the decline in steel operations from about 51 per cent of capacity to 24 per cent in the ninety-day trial period for the steel industry's code, which will end in a few days, steel makers are convinced that real progress has been made and that the groundwork has been laid for a rapid rise when sea-sonal influences have run their course, according to the weekly survey of the magazine Steel.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP). -- A warning by the Far Eastern section of the Communist party that Soviet planes would bomb Japanese centres of population from the air if Japan attempted aggression against the Soviet Union is regarded here as the most outspoken yet voiced against the possible violation of the country's Far Eastern frontier.

The tramp, tramp of the unbeaten and untied brigade of football sounded firm on Armistice Day as seven of the eight major powers in this category continued steadfastly on down the homestretch of the race for national acclaim.

Fred G. Clark, Commander-in-Chief of The Crusaders, whose membership, said to number 1,600,000, took an active part in the fight to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment, announced yesterday that the organization, "while vigorously continuing its fight to keep selfish groups from preventing sane and practical liquor legislation in the various States," also will carry on a nation-wide campaign against the "growing menace of greenback inflation."

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- Immediate establishment of a central bank and an organization for the extension of intermediate and short-time agricultural credit are the chief recommendations in the report of the Royal Commission on Banking and Currency in Canada.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- The Stock Exchange here experienced the greatest boom in its history last Thursday and Friday on rumors of the government's impending conversion operation. Internal credit bonds, which were quoted at around 85 a month ago, were carried to within a few cents of par during the excited scramble to obtain possession of issues which, according to the reports, were to be called in at par.

IT'S the same story again in the East. Princeton and Army are still leading the parade. Duke goes rolling along through the Southland and Michigan is still on top in Big Ten territory. Will some soothsayer kinidly call off the names of the teams that are going to stop these fellows?

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12. -- Legal Sunday sports competition, finally was introduced to Pittsburgh today with, a National Football League contest in which Shipwreck Kelly and his Brooklyn Dodgers put the Pirates to rout. The score of the game, the first since the blue law was voted out, was 32-0.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A combination of gold and silver inflation with what grain traders regard as the best supply and demand situation that the grain trade has seen in a long time, is expected to bring about a general revival of business and speculation at higher prices.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- The first comments on today's election by the "coordinated" German press are one continuous paean, of victory in which, however, the world is called upon to establish "a true peace" that meets Germany's desires.

SIOUX CITY, Ia., Nov. 12. -- Western Iowa, Eastern Nebraska, Eastern South Dakota and Southwestern Minnesota, from Omaha north to Watertown, S.D., today were in the grip of a severe wind and dust storm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Insistence on immediate adoption of a master code for the construction industry was recommended today by the executive cabinet of the Construction League, which will open a week of war councils" here tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 12. -- Although trading in the cotton market here was rather quiet early last week, because of the impending government crop estimate, it became active after the estimate had been issued on Wednesday morning and remained so until the end of the week.
Brookhattan and the Scots-Americans played a 2-2 tie in a return American League soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,500 persons.
Prominent Liquor Dealer Chairman MULROONEY believes that the new liquor regulations will be productive of desirable social changes, as well as economic.
Overtures for a truce, if not peace, have been made by Tammany to representatives of Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, it was learned yesterday.

The necessity of working unceasingly for the cause of peace was emphasized yesterday in Armistice Day sermons delivered in many pulpits throughout the city. Clergymen united in urging that war be outlawed.

Next Thursday will mark the opening of the duck-hunting season in New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and a number of other States in the Southern, Southeastern and Southwestern sectors of the country.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- On the stroke of midnight tonight the Century of Progress came to an end. The giant gates were shut with an official greeting and the presentation of a medal to the last visitor.

Because of an article in the November issue of the B'nai B'rith Magazine opposing the boycott as a weapon of retaliation against Hitlerism, Samuel Untermyer declined to attend the ninetieth anniversary dinner of B'nai B'rith last night at the Hotel Roosevelt, at which he was to have been the principal speaker.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- One hundred ferry passengers, including women and children, were rescued from the ferryboat City of Reading today as it was sinking in the Hudson River shortly after leaving the slip here for a trip across the river to Nyack.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- While the increasing momentum in the fall of the United States dollar is beginning to excite grave concern here, there is little prospect that the British exchange control fund will be used to hinder the movement. The prospects of success for such a venture would be small and the risks great.

After Granville Holmes, 40 years old, had been sentenced to six months in the workhouse by Magistrate Jonah. J. Goldstein yesterday on charges of impersonating Mayor elect F.H. LaGuardia and soliciting funds, George Brokaw Compton, chairman of the Fusion speakers' bureau, disclosed that impersonators had developed that kind of racket to the point where it was embarrassing to the Fusion organization.

Westchester residents reported yesterday that they had begun to get results in their desperate fight against a return invasion of the cankerworm that stripped their trees and shrubs of foliage over a wide area in the county last Spring.

The fifteenth annual observance of Children's Book Week begins today in schools, public libraries and bookshops. Marjorie Griesser, executive secretary of the National Association of Book Publishers, says that 10,000 requests for posters and publicity material have been received.

The Installation of water meters in every building in the city, together with frequent house-to-house inspection of pipes and faucets, is recommended in a report submitted to Mayor O'Brien by the special committee"which he named last March to investigate the problem of additional water supply.

Men and women should be "conscious of the presence of God" not only on Sunday at formal divine worship in church but all through the week in their homes, their stores and their offices, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson declared yesterday morning in the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street, just East of Broadway.

Substantial gains were made by commodity futures on local Exchanges last week, principally due to the decline in the dollar to a new low mark for the movement originated early last Spring. The volume of trading increased as speculative buying gained headway, and prices were only moderately affected by profit-taking at the end of the week.

Red Cross Sunday was observed in many of the city's churches yesterday as the New York Chapter of the organization, now conducting its annual membership roll-call, gained many new members in church congregations.

HAVANA, Nov. 12. -- In an attempt to bring about peace in Cuba, representatives of many organizations met today in response to a call from the Masonic Lodge. The Rotary Club, Engineers Society, Medical Federation, Architectural Society, Lawyers College and Knights of Columbus were among those who hope to bring about a settlement between the government and the opposing factions and prevent further bloodshed.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,413,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
UNION, N.J., Nov. 12. -- Defeating the newly, admitted Hispano eleven by 4 to 1, the Newark Germans today added two points in the competition of the American Soccer League.

The expansion in retail sales last 'week, because of colder weather, was not fully reflected in the wholesale markets, as store stocks continue heavy. Another ten days to two weeks of activity in stores are regarded as necessary to bring any appreciable volume of orders into the markets.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Renewed speculative buying of oats futures came with the advance in other grains last week, and carried prices up sharply, creating a greater capacity for absorption and profit-taking on the bulges. The market acted well, according to oats specialists, with cash interests the best buyers on breaks.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Philadelphia celebrated the legalizing of Sunday sports today when the Eagles held the Chicago Bears, 1932 National Football League champions, to a 3-3 tie at the Phillies' ball park.

Many evidences of better times for real estate and a higher income return for good properties have been apparent during the last few weeks, and now that the repeal of the prohibition amendment is assured a very substantial improvement in the realty, situation for the near future is the unanimous opinion of leading real estate brokers.

Roosevelt Son took from John C. Gabler a mortgage for $4,000, payable four years hence, at 6 per cent, on a twenty-one-year leasehold of the two-story building at 517 W. 28th St., which Mr. Gabler holds from Marie M.I. de Courval at a yearly rental of $700, plus additional specified rent, with renewal privileges.

Secretary WALLACE bore to the Iowa farmers both assurances and warnings. If they would only be patient, they would yet see the agricultural miracle wrought. Farm prices would go up, and other prices would go down. If the moderate inflation which we have already had does not do the trick, the magic will be used in larger doses.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 12 (AP). -- The sixty-three members of Betty Compson's "Highlights of 1934", road show, found themselves "at liberty" after last night's performance here. Sparse attendance and high expenses drove the troupers back to New York after ten weeks on the road.

Organization of a third major radio chain, to compete with the existing National and Columbia systems, was announced yesterday by George F. McClelland, former vice president of the National Broadcasting Company.

Prompted by increases in pneumonia cases and deaths and in influenza cases in the last four weeks as compared with the same period last year, Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, made public yesterday a "code" for the avoidance of colds.

CHILDREN like doggerel. Sometimes it is the superior doggerel of William Allingham's "Up the airy mountain, down the rushy glen, we daren't go a-hunting, for fear of little men." Generally, however, children seem to have a preference for such unlovely lyrics as the one that begins "Smarty, smarty, thought you'd have a party."

Speaking last night in the last of a series of five national broadcasts staged by the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, Marie Dressler and Mrs. August Belmont, who was known on the stage as Eleanor Robson, urged the women of the nation to rally to the support of welfare programs.

The Chicago Opera Company rushed in where many an angel has feared to tread and gave yesterday afternoon at the Hippodrome a performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde." The cast, as printed, was as follows: Harry Ladek, conductor; Isolde, Rachel Morton; Brangaena, Norma France; Tristan, Arthur Gerry; Kurvenal, Pasquale Amato; King Mark, Sigurd Nilssen; Melot, Alexis Tcherkassky; shepherd, Karl Schubach; steersman and sailor, Costante Sorvino.

Twice the usual number on holiday rum boats rode the waters outside the twelve-mile limit yesterday, apparently set for a dash with the last big load of contraband. At the same time the Merchants Association of New York warned the government that an excessive tax on legal liquor would encourage bootlegging.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12. -- Extension of theatrical activities by the Yale School of Drama has brought at least one annual play into a large number of dramatic clubs, schools, colleges and churches in New Haven. Nearly every one of the 125 members of the department is connected with some local organization.
A Hillside factory and dwellings in various towns were among the New Jersey realty tournover reported yesterday.

You can't keep good men down. The Farley-Flynn politico-moral movement for the elimination of bosses and the purification of municipal politics in this city was but halted for a moment last week. It is to go on majestically until it has redeemed every borough and made it as spotless as the lily.

A forward pass, batted by an opponent who had broken up the play on his goal line, bounced into the arms of Tex Irvin, Giant tackle, and brought victory to the New York Football Giants over the Boston Redskins at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Farmers who market live stock are endeavoring, with the aid of commission men at the stock yards, to obtain higher prices for their hogs, cattle and sheep, particularly their hogs, and are on strike for an increase of 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds for hogs of the class that is particularly suitable for packers' requirements.

Entertainers representing every branch of the amusement field were on hand last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the National Variety Artists held its seventeenth annual benefit performance. Eliminating the customary intermission, the program was still in progress long after 11 o'clock.
PARIS, Nov. 12. -- French pessimism over American monetary policies was typically summed up tonight by Frederic Jenny, financial editor of the Temps, in his weekly article.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Only six complaints by manufacturers, located chiefly in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, have been filed with the NRA against importations under conditions said to render ineffective the maintenance of codes and agreements under the Recovery Act.
"I Was Waiting for You," an adaptation from the French, will have its postponed premiere tonight at the Booth Theatre.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Financial experts analyzing Great Britain's trade figures for the past ten months, which show an increase of nearly u1,000,000 over 1932, have discovered that a revival of her export trade started in the same month.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- In a spectacular game before a crowd of 13,000, the Chicago Black Hawks handed the New York Rangers their second straight defeat tonight, 1 to 0.

The cry of an ancient prophet was that those in places of responsibility had "healed the hurt of the people lightly." They kept saying "peace, peace, when there is no peace." A like rebuke President BUTLER uttered in his review of the fifteen years since the Armistice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Governors of ten States have been requested by Secretary Ickes, as administrator of public works, to expedite their lagging road-building programs under the Federal aid plan and to absorb more of the unemployed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 12. -- Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchison, president of Washington and Jefferson College, addressing 3,500 delegates to the annual convention of the New Jersey Teachers Association, said today "education in high schools, colleges and universities has become the great American racket."

Rummaging around among the remains of our supercilious forebears, Darothy Sands has recovered some amusing gewgaws. She bills them as "Our Stage and Stars," and last evening she displayed them before a responsive audience at the Little Theatre.

DETROIT, Nov. 12. -- A railplane type of coach, by means of which the railroads hope to regain some of the passenger traffic lost to motor transport, was tested today in a 154-mile run between Detroit and Delta, Ohio.

PRAGUE, Nov. 12. -- Despite his reluctance to talk, Walter Tschuppik, a Czechoslovak newspaperman, who has just been released by the Nazis at Munich, tonight told the correspondent of his experiences during eight months' imprisonment in Germany.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- The financial press continues to criticize Washington's currency policy. The Frankfurter Zeitung attributes thereto an increase in American anxiety and discontent, while asserting that President Roosevelt may temporarily purchase the farmers' confidence by means of still more depreciation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The American home is threatened with an additional tax burden. If the program of the Department of Agriculture to place a compensatory tax on cane and beet sugar is approved and made effective, an annual levy of from $60,000,000 to $120,000,000 will fall upon the housewives of the nation.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The decline in the gold holdings of the Bank of France is ascribed here to the flight of capital and not to purchases for United States account. Withdrawals for this account have been small.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- Production of steel ingots underwent so mild a decrease this week, after three or four weeks of sharp cuts, that a tendency to level off is seen, and forecasts of the average rate for the remainder of the year have undergone a slight upward revision, at about halfway between 20 and 25 per cent of capacity.

MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, Nov. 12. -- The farmers of Harrison County flocked today into this town on the fringe of the corn-hog belt to hear Milo Reno, head of the Farmers Holiday Association, challenge Secretary Wallace, who spoke last night at Des Moines.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reports for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 26 a net loss of $6,291,748 after all charges, including interest, amortization and depreciation. This compared with a net loss of $14,095,054 for the previous year after similar charges.

The leaders in the race for Eastern individual football scoring honors remained unchanged over the past week-end although none of the first five tallied a point. Davis and Elkins was idle on Saturday and Villanova was blanked by Boston College.

The new Gallery of American Indian Art has opened at 850 Madison Avenue, with a miscellaneous exhibition that contains, among other items, paintings, blankets and small objects of craftwork. Mrs. John Sloan, the director, announces that through the season a series of special exhibitions will be held, the next one bringing forward examples of Indian artists' skill in basket making.
Opera better than ever this coming Winter was promised by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, in a short address yesterday afternoon from Station WEAF.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Although Chancellor Hitler's double referendum produced "the intended, almost inevitable" result, as The London Times puts it, the heaviness of the vote whereby the German public reaffirmed the policy of withdrawal from the League of Nations and the Disarmament Conference comes to some British newspapers as something of a surprise.

GORHAM, N.H., Nov. 12 -- Rupert A. Marden, aged 22, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Marden of 33 Harvard Avenue, Brookline, Mass., died today at the Hermit Lake hut from, overexertion in climbing Mount Washington.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 32 (AP). -- While members of the family of Brooke Hart, missing 22-year-old son of a wealthy store owner, persisted in their denial that they had received further word from the supposed kidnappers of the youth, Chief of Police J.N. Black today was busily checking new clues in the case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Asserting that there has been considerable complaint tbat the administration was "verging toward State socialism," Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican, of New York, contended today that the proposal of Secretary Ickes "to own, manage and control apartment houses is a concrete example of the socialistic tendencies of the New Deal."

God as a father to whom one can go as to a home and shut out all the distressing things of life was the conception of God urged on his congregation by the Rev. James J. Henry, pastor of the Park Avenue Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday.

ABOARD S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Nov. 12 -- F.H. LaGuardia, Mayor-elect of New York City, revealed today that he planned to curtail, if not to eliminate entirely, the appearances at public dinners that have in previous administrations formed a considerable part of the duties of the Mayor.

NAVY BASE, SAN PEDRO, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Grim old Point Arguello, headstone of the "grave-yard of ships in the Pacific," will be the pivotal point off which some hundred ships of the Navy will engage in manoeuvres this week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Twenty-six Chicago business and industrial leaders today expressed opposition to "the present trend in our monetary policy." At the same time they announced that a permanent organization, a committee on monetary policy, has been formed, with headquarters here.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The two-day race meeting under the auspices of the New Rochelle Post 8, American Legion, was concluded today over the halfmile track at Ward Acres.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A three-hour discussion of monetary and financial policies took place at the White House today between President Roosevelt and a large group of his financial advisers.

It may have been that Jascha Heifetz, for his second program of the season, given last night in Carnegie Hall, had decided to give the public a few more virtuoso exhibitions than the earlier program afforded. But as a matter of fact Mr. Heifetz, whatever he undertook, has always been more than the incredible virtuoso.

BOGOTA, Nov. 12. -- The Senate has approved the 1934 budget, providing for the issue of 240,000 pesos in 4 per cent scrip for service on the bonded foreign debt, according to El Tiempo. [The peso is currently worth about 69.5 cents.]

BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP). -- On direct intervention by the Reich Government the suspension yesterday of two popular pastors, the Rev. Martin Niemaeller and the Rev. E.F. von Rabernau, who dissented in certain matters from the Reichsbishop's policies, was rescinded at midnight.

Gunfire flashed vividly early yesterday in the dimly lit Rhumba Restaurant, a cabaret at 2,728 Broadway, near 105th Street. When brighter lights dissipated the artificial twilight of the place, two diners lay wounded and about fifty others were crouched in fear under their tables.

The ultimate folly of worldly fame as compared with the greater and more fruitful benefits of "heavenly fame" was pictured yesterday by the Rev. John J. Nestor, preaching at the 11 o'clock high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- Police, gendarmerie, troops and Heimwehr were standing by throughout Austria tonight to prevent attempts by the Nazis to mark the day's German election by violence and sabotage in this country.
Accused of having held up and robbed more than 150 men and women at two armistice night parties in Brooklyn social clubs, four young men were arrested early yesterday by two radio patrolmen.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A survey of business conditions throughout the Middle West for last week shows considerable improvement in various lines. The advent of colder weather prompted a vigorous revival in retail buying, chiefly for immediate requirements, although advance buying for Christmas, before prices are raised on Dec. 1, is a factor in retail activity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- In a further effort to refute the charge of a wholesale patronage turnover in the Federal service, the Civil Service Qominigslon, after an investigation, showed today that two-thirds of recent changes in personnel were due to the hiring and dismissal of temporary employes.

The world looks to the United States for leadership, the Rev. Dr. George P.T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, declared yesterday in a sermon in which he expressed disapproval of American recognition of Soviet Russia.
The code of fair competition for the dress industry, signed by President Roosevelt on Oct. 31, will go into effect today throughout the country.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 12 (AP). -- A memorial to the courage and heroism of Alabama troops in the battle of Gettysburg was presented to the nation today by women of the Alabama Division, United Daughters of the Confederacy.

Time was when Americans would have been irritated, or even angry, at seeing the dollar kicked around in foreign countries like a Missouri houn' dog. Here is the Canadian Government directing all the postmasters in the Dominion not to accept United States currency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Nudging par with a snappy 211 for fifty-four holes around the Kenwood Country Club course, Paul Runyan, White Plains (N.Y.) pro, today captured the third annual $2,000 national capital open golf championship.

Adolf Hitler's National Socialist German Labor party-Nazi party -- was first represented in the Reichstag after the elections of May, 1928. Twelve Nazis, including Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, now Minister of Propaganda, and Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Prime Minister of Prussia, were in that Reichstag, in which the Social Democrats, with 152 members, had the largest group.

Settlement of 130 strikes, involving more than 250,000 workers and affecting the livelihood of between 600,000 and 700,000 persons, was the achievement of the local NRA organization during August, September and October, according to a report sent yesterday to General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, by Grover A. Whalen, NRA Administrator for New York City.

Teresina, the "authentic" Spanish dancer who made her reappearance in New York at the Town Hall last night, proved beyond doubt that she was wise in her determination to show herself to American audiences under more favorable conditions than those which surrounded her debut here three seasons ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Conversations between President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff over the recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States were resumed late this evening. The Russian Foreign Commissar hurried to the White House from a dinner given in his honor by Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration, to confer with the President.

STEAMSHIP AMEFICAN LEGION, bound for Montevideo, Nov. 12. -- Definite progress along the lines of commercial policy, peace machinery and cultural relations is to be expected at the Pan-American conference at Montevideo, Secretary of State Hull indicated today.

The Holland Tunnel completed yesterday its sixth year of operation, having been used by more than 66,500,000 motor vehicles of all types. In the last twelve months traffic totaled 10,954,173 vehicles, which, although nearly 6 per cent less than that of the previous year, marked a distinct reduction of the rate of decrease from 1931 to 1932.
Columbia's football regulars, who brought great pleasure to Morning-side students and alumni last Saturday by their victory over Navy, rested yesterday.

For the last two years clergymen have been preaching "a sort of vestibule religion," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in an address before the Presbytery of New York yesterday afternoon in the French Evangelical Presbyterian Church, 128 West Six-teenth Street.

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 13 -- In cold, windy weather, making many seasick, 320 Baltic Hitlerite Germans cast their votes yesterday on board the German freighter Danzig at sea on the Gulf of Finland. They had been picked up at Reval.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- Dr. David Prescott Barrows of the University of California, for this academic year Roosevelt Professor at Berlin University, lecturing before the German Society for the Study of Eastern Europe, scouted the possibility of a quickening of Communist sentiments in the United States as a consequence of closer relations with Soviet Russia.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP) .-- Crane Wilbur, actor and playwright, obtained a divorce today from Beatrice Blinn Wilbur, stage actress. He testified she refused to live with him because she wanted to pursue her own career.

Aroused by what they termed the "undignified interference with business and unfavorable impression on visitors resulting from the recent use of amplifieds and other noisemaking instruments by political parties, spectacular advertisers and theatrical promoters," Broadway business interests started a movement yesterday to prohibit such devices on the streets of New York.

A little girl of 8 with a big name, Miss Ruth Slenczynski, made what was unsmilingly billed as her American debut at the Town Hall last night and left no doubt that she is a pianist of phenomenal gifts. The only occasion of recent memory to equal it was the first appearance of Yehudi Menuhin.

In a Reichstag election designed to show that the Germans are as one man behind HITLER there were cast 40,000,000 votes for his electoral list and about 3,500,000 votes against. Knowing the conditions under which the election was held, it is for the reader himself to determine by what number it is necessary to multiply the 3,500,000 opposition votes in order to get a true estimate of the opposition to HITLER.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt will address the first Civil Works Conference of State, county and city Officials, who will meet here Wednesday at the call of Harry L. Hopkins, administrator of the new agency and of Federal Emergency Relief.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 13 -- Forty thousand members of the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania returned to work today on assurances that the National Labor Board would investigate conditions in the strike zone.

A showdown between W. Kingsland Macy, Republican. State Chairman, and Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies on the party's policy in organizing the Assembly and directing its work was expected yesterday when it was revealed that Mr. Macy had written to Mr. McGinnies at his home in Ripley, Chautauqua County, suggesting that he come to New York for a conference.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- After its week-end recovery, the dollar again weakened today to 5.14% to the pound sterling, around which rate it fluctuated narrowly, closing at $5.15. Francs and other gold currencies also depreciated. The price of gold was lower at 129s 1 1/2d an ounce.

Eddie Cantor, president of the Screen Actors Guild, announced yesterday that he had been invited by President Roosevelt to Warm Springs, Ga., to confer with him there on Nov. 21 regarding details of the pending motion-picture code, as they will affect actors.

Early reports from volunteer Workers indicate a greater response to the annual Red Cross membership roll-call than last year, it was announced yesterday by Peter S. Duryee, roll-call chairman of the New York Chapter, and Mrs. L.M. Fish, roll-call director.
Mrs. Harvey Ridabock of Woodway was re-elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fair-field Golf Association at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Aborns and Savoyards. MILTON ABORN'S revivals of GILBERT and SULLIVAN over a period of nearly thirty-five years made him the carrier of one of the two living traditions of the English stage, the other being SHAKE-SPEARE.
New York University's football team started preparations yesterday at Ohio Field for the meeting with Rutgers act the Yankee Stadium this Saturday.

James Garrett Wallace, Assistant District Attorney, late yesterday afternoon finished more than ten hours of summing up in the trial of Isidor J. Kresel on a charge of abetting in the misapplication of about $2,000,000 of the funds of the defunct Bank of United States.

CAMERON BAY, N.W.T., Nov. 13 (Canadian Press).-- An airplane pilot stood by today at this isolated outpost while Dr. T.O. Byrne was deciding whether it would be possible for Vie Ingraham, captain'of the ill-fated schooner Speed, to be flown to Aklavik, tiny settlement at the mouth of the Mackenzie River, on the Arctic Ocean, for an emergency operation.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Chancellor Hitler's 40,000,000 votes have changed France's relation to Germany. It is admitted that henceforth Nazi Germany can no longer be treated like the defeated Germany of 1918, that she must be conquered again or treated on a basis different from that imposed by the treaty of Versailles.

Most of the domestic markets were in some suspense yesterday as the government's monetary policy was re-examined, not only in the light of week-end developments but also in that of the conflicting opinion as to the ultimate effect of the policy upon the national economy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade again today and despite profit-taking the close was well toward the top. Wheat gained 1 3/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel; corn, 7/8 cent; oats, 5/8 to 7/8 cent; rye, 1 to 1 1/8 cents, and barley, 1/4 to 3/4 cent.
Opposition to the use of serums in medical practice was expressed yesterday by the delegates to the International Conference for the Investigation of Vivisection held at the Hotel Ambassador.

The drive to end the arson menace in Brooklyn, continued yesterday with the imposition of an unusually severe sentence on a first offender convicted of second-degree arson. He was Frank Scaringi, 45 years old, of 25-17 Forty-sixth Street.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 13 -- Another step in the refusal of the military authorities to accept the jurisdiction of the civil courts in the Panama Canal Zone was taken today in an appeal from a decision of Magistrate Tatelman of Cristobal, which may lead to the United States Supreme Court.

Carl J. Austrian, counsel for Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, in the liquidation of the Bank of United States, probably will be appointed United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to succeed George Z. Medalie, it was learned last night.

Paintings by two artists -- Edward Biberman, American, and Maurice Utrillo, French -- were placed on view yesterday at the Reinhardt Gallery, where they may be seen until Dec. 2. Each of these artists has a room to himself, which is fortunate considering the fact that their work has nothing more than pigment and frames in common.

Jose Iturbi gave his first New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. The recital was given for the benefit of the educational department of the New York Women's Trade Union League, of which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, who was present, is honorary chairman.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Heat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

A reorganization plan has been proposed for the Eitingon-Schild Company which would permit the exchange of new no-par common stock for the present preferred and common stock, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday.

The estate of Michael George Herbert of London, member of the banking firm of Morgan, Grenfell Co., who died Sept. 26, 1932, was appraised yesterday at $2,287,835 gross and $2,176,154 net, of which $1,497,157 was in securities. Of this sum $1,131,194 was the value of English stocks and bonds.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- The announcement that legislation affecting economic matters would be entrusted to the National Council of Corporations under a new and powerful guild system was made by Premier Mussolini tonight at the end of the Council meeting.

BUCHAREST, Nov. 13 -- Efforts of Dr. Ion G. Duca to form a Cabinet in accordance with King Carol's instructions, which would include his bitterest enemy, George Bratiano, leader of the dissident Liberals, have failed.

Out of a mass of useful information contained in the report of Mayor O'BRIEN's Committee on Additional Water Supply, headed by PETER GRIMM, a few vital facts reveal the relation between supply and demand. The dependable yield of existing sources of supply, including the private companies, is 1,039 "m.g.d.," or millions of gallons daily.

Sales of useful articles will be held this week to raise funds for Philanthropic purposes. The Helpers, who maintain a settlement louse at 113 East Eighty-fifth Street, will hold a bazaar at the Plaza on Thursday. Young waflaen who have long been identified with the organization will serve luncheon and tea at the benefit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Hope was expressed at the White House today that the conferences on Russian recognition would be concluded by Friday, when President Roosevelt is scheduled to leave for Warm Springs, Ga.

Overcoming an 810-point lead which had been scored by the "dark horse" contract-bridge team led by Frank Rendon, the favored four of Louis H. Watson, A. M. Barnes; Richard L. Frey and Sam Fry Jr. came through early this morning to gain a 400-point advantage in the next-to-final session of the Vanderbilt Cup matches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- No President since Woodrow Wilson, and very few others in our history, have needed public support to the extent that President Roosevelt needs it. His program, like Mr. Wilson's conduct of the World War, cannot be successful unless the public stands by it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Secretary Wallace envisioned today the complete control, acre by acre, of all America's farm land, with only rich soil used for farming and the remainder devoted to forests, recreation, residence and the like.

TOKYO, Nov. 13 -- The calmness of the public under the government's lead and Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's appeal to Russia to help create a better atmosphere by demilitarizing the Siberian-Manchurian frontier are seen as evidence that Japan seeks no quarrel with Russia.

An advance of nearly 20 points, or $1 a bale on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried all months to 10 cents a pound or more, for the first time since the latter part of September. Further depreciation in dollar exchange, a rise in silver to the highest figure, of the year and a tentative agreement to advance to holders of option cotton $37,000,000 furnished by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation stimulated demand for contracts.

Judging from the large subscription for the performance of "Let 'Em Eat Cake" tonight at the Imperial Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Boys Club of New York, the funds for carrying on the work of the club will be greatly augmented.

Substantial progress is being made in the rehabilitation of the fourteen title and mortgage guarantee companies taken over by the State Insurance Department, according to an interim report made yesterday to Governor Lehman by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The turbulent scenes of the early days of the beer license rush were re-enacted yesterday at the City Beverage Control Board office at 2 Lafayette Street by applicants for licenses to sell wines and distilled spirits.

A large and notable gathering of society viewed the events at the Horse Show last night with enthusiastic interest. The scene was a brilliant one, with the comeback of the oldtime elegance in fashion in the boxes -- the flash of jeweled tiaras, diamond necklaces and the satiny sheen of ermine and sables.

The recently signed Retail Drug code was criticized as unsatisfactory last night by speakers at a meeting of the New York Branch of the American Pharmaceutical Association at the Columbia University College of Pharmacy, 115 West Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Coincident with the return to work of 40,000 anthracite miners today, Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, announced the personnel of the fact-finding committee that will make an investigation and report to the board.

The Harriman Realty Corporation of 527 Fifth Avenue filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court through its attorneys, Rushmore, Bisbee Stern. F. Revere, secretary, signed the petition.

ROME, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The problem imposed on Europe by the break-up of the Austro-Hungarian Empire seemed today to be moving toward a solution on the basis of the Mussolini memorandum on the Danbubian States.

For several months a royal commission, with Lord MACMILLAN as chairman has been studying Canada's Banking Act with a view to recommending changes. The question has not been how to strengthen a weak system, for Canada -- with the record of not a single bank failure during the depression-already possesses a strong system.

The Horse Show Ball, the final entertainment arranged in connection with the National Horse Show Golden Jubilee at Madison Square Garden, was held last night in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. The event, which climaxed a series of luncheons, dinners and suppers, had the officers of the international military teams competing at the Garden as the guests of honor.
Captain Frederick A. Ahern of the Irish Free State Army team won the international individual military championship challenge trophy at the National Horse Show last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today completed all details incident to the purchase of $50,000,000 of the capital notes of the Savings Banks Trust Company of New York, which has been organized for the purpose of assisting the mutual savings banks of New York State to grant extensions, continue a generous attitude toward their borrowers on mortgages, and to lift or ease restrictions in withdrawals.

I WAS WAITING FOR YOU. a play in three acts, adapted by Melville Baker from the French of Jacques Natanson. Settings by Jo Mielziner; staged by Arthur J. Beckhard; produced by Edward Choate, in association with Lee Shubert. At the Booth Theatre.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Secretary Wallace took issue today with the attitude of city folk as expressed in Chicago newspapers, which he said carried "far more peril than the outbreaks in Iowa," and if pursued would eventually "reduce Chicago to an ash heap."

A stowaway, who characterized himself as a "world traveler," was turned over to immigration authorities yesterday after the Colombian liner Colombia docked from Portau-Prince and West Indian ports. A return visit to the United States, which he had planned for five years, went awry when he accidentally pressed a button which summoned a ship's hell-hop for room service.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will have a chat today with President Roosevelt in Washington on his first visit to the White House since Mr. Roosevelt's inauguration. Mr. Smith will be accompanied by John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Dr. Raymond P. Sullivan of St. Vincent's Hospital, Mr. Smith's family physician.
GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 13 -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, believes there is nothing wrong with, the game except "depression."

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Elmira College for Women, whose destinies in the last eighty years have been closely linked to the progress of women, figured in the opening of the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs here today.

The Pan American Association of Composers presented a program of contemporary music by North Americans last night at the New School. The New World String Quartet, Mary Bell, soprano; Mrs. Richard Donovan, soprano; Erno Ballogh, pianist, and Mabel Schneider, pianist, took part.

Bill rates, four to six months, were advanced 1/8 in yield. The upward revision in these maturities followed the fractional advance in the short dates last Thursday and brings them more in line with the yield on government issues. Stock Exchange call money remained at 3/4, outside money at 1/2.

"The Drums Begin," the Howard Irving Young play in which Judith Anderson is starred, will open at the Shubert Theatre on Friday of next week. "Champagne Sec," the current occupant of the Shubert, will be transferred next Monday to the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES today has a heading "Municipal Experts Score 'Tax Slackers.' " The article following also speaks of the waste in education.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- King Nadir Shah of Afghanistan was assassinated last week by a man he had pardoned for intrigue, it became known today in the first official account of the crime to reach London.

OAKLAND, Cal., Nov. 13 (AP). -- Two mysterious telephone calls to the police and a note indicating he might have some connection with a gang suspected of possibly playing a part in the kidnapping of Brooke Hart, 22-year-old son of a San Jose department store owner, resulted in the arrest of Burr W. Poole, an Oakland printer, here today.

SHELTON, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Development after twenty-five years of research of a technique for the breeding of a special type of bacteria that destroy the bacillus of tuberculosis, human, bovine and avian, was described here tonight by Dr. Stephen J. Maher, international authority on tuberculosis, before a gathering to which 1,800 physicians had been invited, at the Laurel Heights Tuberculosis Sanatorium.

While most of the city's department stores were not prepared yesterday to tell of their plans to meet the liquor demand after repeal, glassware dealers announced that their business had soared since the end of prohibition was assured.

What was going to done done about the eighty-third birthday anniversary of Robert Louis Stevenson was a problem that agitated virtually every lover of sad, memorial occasions in the five boroughs yesterday. What could be done, with. Mrs. Annie Ide Cockran out of town, was even more pressingly problematical.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The British Government has made "representations" to Germany against alleged discriminatory treatment of British holders of German bonds, it was announced in the House of Commons today.

Approval of the machinery set up by New York merchants and trade associations for a Retail Code Authority to administer the retail code in the New York area was received yesterday from the National Retail Council in Washington. The council is part of the national machinery created under the retail code and has supervision over the formation of retail code authorities or councils in the various communities.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 13 -- The 200 oil men meeting here today reelected Wirt Franklin president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America and urged the national administration to go through with its announced policy of price-fixing.

In the cold, huge, former power house at 216th Street and the Harlem River, George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, made final preparations yesterday for the public showing Thursday of the full-size model of his rainbow arch war memorial, begun on Armistice Day fifteen years ago.

In a few days a strange thing will be seen in the old part of Williamsburg, Va. -- the tearing up of modern streets in order to replace their surfaces with flag and cobblestones. Already many of the buildings of the Colonial period have been reconstructed and tourists will soon have the opportunity of seeing the Williamsburg of pre-Revolutionary times.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- Marinus Van der Lubbe, the sphinx of the Reichstag fire trial, began to talk today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The Labor minority in the House of Commons once more went through the formality today of offering a motion of censure of the British Government for the sake of precipitating another debate on disarmament. The motion lost, of course, by the usual government majority, 409 to 54.

After its 20-12 triumph over New York University on Saturday, Fordham's football squad received a day of rest yesterday. Except for a brief lecture by Coach Jim Crowley, the players had a complete holiday from the sport.

United States Government bonds continued yesterday the recovery which began on Saturday. Yesterday's rally lifted prices 7-32 to 24-32 point, net, with the exception of the called Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s and the first Liberty 4 1/4s which were down 1-32 and 8-32 point, respectively.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 13 -- Harry and Jack Warner have resigned from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, according to Howard Green, vice president of the academy.

The twelve member lines of the United States Intercoastal Conference, representing the most powerful steamship lines operating between the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, resigned from the conference yesterday, effective Dec. 31.
Two hundred and twenty-five years ago Dr. WILLIAM KING in his "Art of Cookery " wrote these affecting lines:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Westchester County authorities began negotiations today for a loan to meet current indebtedness. At the same time the Park Commission aggravated matters by requesting for the first time in its history, an appropriation from the county to meet expenses ordinarily met from park revenues.
Duck hunting in Great South Bay has shown a big improvement in the past week. Hundreds of sportsmen have been getting limit bags over a stretch of ten or twelve miles between Amityville and Babylon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the current issue of The Architectural Record there appears a statement by Robert D. Kohn, Chief of the Government Housing Division, that plans are under consideration by the Public Works Administration for the construction of low-rent and slum-clearance projects in large cities at Federal expense.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Premier Sarraut's Cabinet is having difficulties with financial proposals.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The British-American Cup Committee has forwarded a challenge for another contest between six-meter yachts representing Britain and the United States in American waters next September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- In another effort to speed the recovery program, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that the interest rates on loans to railroads, including those outstanding, would be reduced from 5 to 4 per cent for one year from Nov. 1.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Jasper McLevy, 52 years old, a roofer who fop nearly thirty years has campaigned for municipal government reform from soap boxes and at factory gates, was sworn into office as Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport at Central High School this noon before a crowd of more than 2,500 persons, the largest ever assembled here to see a Mayor take office.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- The Harvard College Observatory will train a battery of twenty-four telescopes and cameras upon the sky Wednesday and Thursday nights in an effort to gain as much information as possible from the Leonid shower of meteors which then is due for its annual display.

Neither dictatorship nor regimentation, but a balanced national economy as a basis for a higher form of individualism, with service as its ideal, is the purpose of the National Recovery program of the Roosevelt Administration, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the members council of the Merchants Association of New York at the Hotel Astor.

ABOARD S. S. PENNSYLVANIA, Nov. 13 -- Between now and Jan. 1 Mayor-elect F. H. La-Guardia and his advisers will, in the course of working out an economy and charter revision program, draft plans for an attack on whatever patronage remains in Tammany's hands.

The New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company announced yesterday that 15,000 employes of all departments of the two companies will vote in a referendum on Nov. 22 on a plan of organization for collective bargaining as to wages, hours and conditions of employment.

Mme. Maria Jeritza will be the guest artist in a Richard and Johann Strauss program at the second Musicians Emergency Fund concert at Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening,. Nov. 24, Walter Damrosch announced yesterday. This program had been scheduled previously for the third concert of the series on Dec. 9.

Speculators were on their guard yesterday against possible news from Washington that might alter the course of the government's monetary program. But their cautiousness was based upon week-end dispatches which told of inconclusive negotiations in the capital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today made public a report detailing its operations for the third quarter, ending Sept. 30, and since its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been asked by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to give particulars on RFC loans to the Midland Mortgage Company and the Bankers Mortgage Company, both of Houston, with a view to ascertaining whether he had a personal interest in either of these companies.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13 -- Winding up a 3,000-mile speaking tour in defense of the Roosevelt recovery program, General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, tonight told an audience of more than 12,000 Kentuckians that what ha observed of "actual operation of the law in the field" had "exceeded all expectations."
By scoring triumphs last night the New York A.C. and City A.C. teams now share first place in the Class C Metropolitan Squash Tennis League race with three victories each.

The Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company and subsidiaries reported for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $67,194 after taxes and other charges, which was equal to 23 cents a share on 290,285 shares of $1 par Class A. stock. This contrasts with a net loss of $653,414 in the third quarter of 1932.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Suit for dissolution of her three marriages to Walter A. Burke was filed here today by Dorothy B. Andrus Burke, New York society matron.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 13 -- After facing six severe tests, five on land and one in the water, Garscube Meg, a black Labrador, owned by Charles L. Lawrance, today captured the open all-age stake, outstanding event on the program of the third annual field trials of the Labrador Retriever Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Setting a record high run of 125, George Kelly of Philadelphia, defeated Charles Seaback of Astoria, L.I., tonight in the final scheduled game of the national pocket billiard championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board's statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading, cities on Nov. 8 shows decreases for the week of $30,000,000 in investments, $122,000,000 in net demand deposits and $33,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and an increase of $25,000,000 in time deposits.

Governor Robert H. Gore of Puerto Rico arrived yesterday on the steamship Borenquin to consult diagnosticians of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore about a kidney ailment with which he is suffering. He said he might enter the Walter Reed Memorial Hospital in Washington for an operation if his physicians thought it necessary.

The New York City News Association received yesterday a radiogram from Mayor-elect LaGuardia denying stories in the evening newspapers relative to the appointment of a police commissioner. The message follows:

HAVANA, Nov. 13 -- Twenty-seven rebels under 18 years of age, who were captured during last week's rebellion, were liberated today by the Cuban Government. Senorita Marina Garcia y Gonzalez, one of four women captured after the fall of Atares Fortress, also was released and the three others will be freed shortly, according to officials.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Abraham "John" Knoebel, 55 years old, of 20 Linden Street, Dumont, a well-known wallpaper designer, was found dead today, apparently murdered, in a vacant lot at the rear of 253 Merritt Avenue, Bergenfield.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- While the full scope of the administration's program of gold purchases remained in doubt today, the atmosphere was cleared of much of the uncertainty that has existed when Secretary Woodin declared that he was in full accord with the President's policies and that published reports of a rift were not justified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- If silence and caution and secrecy and discretion make for a successful conference, this Soviet-American parley is 100 per cent perfect, because no one will say a word.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Secretary Ickes brought his fist down hard today in repudiating any suggestion that municipalities seeking loans from the Public Works Administration will not be forced to repay them. In a sharp telegram he "terminated" the services of Harry S. Berry, Public Works engineer in Tennessee, who had expressed this supposition in a circular letter.

GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- High Commissioner James G. McDonald agreed today to invite eight Jewish organizations to be represented in the League of Nations' autonomous governing body for German refugees, in accordance with the decision of the London conference for the relief of German Jews.

Bargains in foreign currencies have been available to purchasers of postoffice money orders, as a result of the lag of forty-eight hours or more between the decline of the dollar on the world markets and the establishing of new postoffice exchange rates for money orders payable in foreign countries.

It will take a "big stick" and not merely persuasion and "beautiful language" to enforce the NRA provisions against Unfair trade practices in a city like New York, shoe retailers were told last night by Grover Whalen, local NRA chairman, at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania called by the Shoe Merchants Council.

Members of the labor committee of the League of New York Theatres and the National Association of the Legitimate Theatre will confer today with representatives of the stagehands' and musicians' unions in the office of Deputy Administrator Sol A. Rosenblatt in Washington.

Trade Gain Swells Reorders. The sharp spurt in retail trade last week was reflected to a considerable degree in the substantial volume of mail orders reaching this market yesterday. Much of the business was on holiday items, including lingerie, gift specialties and toys.

Individual drinks in sealed two-ounce bottles, cocktails concocted in full view of patrons to prevent bootleg substitution and the elimination of liquor sale by bulk were among the recommendations made by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to the New Jersey State Beverage Commission yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 13 -- The hope expressed at the White House that the Russian recognition conferences might be concluded within four days was the first that seemed to set any time limit for a decision since M. Litvinoff arrived last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates Nov. 12, unless specified:

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Heavy losses by the Royal Mall Steam Packet Company were revealed tonight in the company's 1932 report, which gives an incomplete estimate of the gross deficiency at L11,710,867 and the net at L9,011,362.

The first public demonstration of the astrophane, or miniature planetarium, was given last night before seventy leaders of the Manhattan Council, Girl Scouts of America, on the Rockefeller Center Observation Roof, where the device will be located permanently.

Monetary inflation, contrary to the general impression, does not operate in the long run to reduce debt and does not boom industry or invariably benefit common stocks, Dr. W.S. Landis, a vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, asserted yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 13 (AP). -- An offer to help him if he "ever got into a jam" was extended to William Hamm Jr. by his kidnappers when he was held hostage for $100,000 last June, the St. Paul brewer testified in Federal court today.

VIGO, Spain, Nov. 13 -- In spite of strong north winds and threats of rain, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took off with Mrs. Lindbergh in their seaplane from the little fishing port of Santona at 11 o'clock this morning for Lisbon.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 13 -- State liquor stores would be established in Pennsylvania under a bill sponsored by Governor Pinchot and offered today at the opening of the special session of the Legislature. The stores would be operated by a Liquor Control Board and would have the sole right to sell liquor for consumption off the premises.
