A sycamore sapling was planted yesterday beside the statue of Edwin Booth in Gramercy Park. Members of The Players, whose clubhouse across the street from the park had been the tragedian's dwelling, joined members of Mr. Booth's family in honoring the one hundredth anniversary of his birth.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Acting vigorously along four fronts, John H. Fahey, new chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, sought today to revitalize the corporation's activities.
The code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms, which was signed by President Roosevelt, became effective yesterday in Wall Street and on out-of-town security exchanges.

The Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan, Moderator of the Presbytery of New York, will, it is expected, be called to the pastorate of the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich, Conn., at a special meeting of that congregation to be held this evening to elect a new pastor, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Ways and Means subcommittee which has been studying the liquor tax problem halted its efforts today at the request of President Roosevelt until his special interdepartmental committee has made its report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Ways and Means subcommittee which has been studying the liquor tax problem halted its efforts today at the request of President Roosevelt until his special interdepartmental committee has made its report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Thirteen national banks completed reorganization plans and obtained licenses to resume business or charters for new banks in the first ten days of November, the Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor, announced today.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- The entire Italian press announced today under headlines of large type spread across front pages the result of the German election, which it considers a most important event in the international situation.
THE huddle was larger and louder than usual this Saturday evening just past. An incomplete and grossly inaccurate stenographic report of the proceedings is herewith offered for inspection.

Opening gains in local commodity markets were substantially reduced yesterday in later trading in most staples, but at the close prices were generally higher on the day. Trading was in good volume. Cash prices were also higher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent statement of Miss Amelia Earhart is subject to challenge. If ever American, women measured up to the highest possible standard, it was during the World War.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 13 (Canadian Press).-- Six men from the ice-bound motor boat Mabel, marooned in the ice of Athabasca River, told, on arrival at Edmonton today, of a grim fight against Canadian weather.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- Germany after yesterday's election apparently is in a waiting mood.

Hope of a settlement of the six-weeks-old strike of 3,500 workers in shipyards and dockyards in the New York area was seen yesterday with the announcement by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, vice chairman of the New York Regional Labor Board, that a conference of representatives of the employers and workers has been called for Saturday at 10 A.M. at NRA headquarters, 43 Broadway.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Preparations by the city and bankers here for a comprehensive financial plan which would cover the city's needs for the next two years were disclosed at the City Commission conference today by Mayor Ellenstein.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann and family are at 4 East Eightieth Street for the Winter.

College football scoring, on the basis of performances thus far this season by teams representative of the entire country, has set a new low record, according to figures compiled yesterday. This adds weight to the arguments of coaches that the defense has gained the upper hand and, in effect, has pretty well throttled the offense.

Continuance of activity in the Manhattan and Bronx realty fields was reported yesterday. A motion picture theatre is to occupy former banking quarters as the result of a Manhattan conveyance; in the Bronx the feature deals were investment purchases of apartment houses.
Sixteen players, including seven of the eight that were seeded, will go into the third round of the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club tonight.
who was brought up as a Catholic, must leave her maternal aunt who has cared for her since she was a few weeks old and go to live with her father, who says he wants her to be reared as a Protestant.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A denunciation of the special United States Senate committee investigating the election of Senator John H. Overton, Democrat, of Louisiana, was shouted in open hearing here today by the committee's own investigator, John G. Holland, who charged Chairman Connally with being "yellow" and the whole committee with "covering up for the rat from Louisiana.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Pennsylvania came out of the Ohio State game in good physical condition and started light practice today for the renewal of football relations with Penn State on Saturday. Dorran Brown, sophomore halfback, who played well against the Buckeyes, may get a chance to start this week.

Joyful over the imminent passing of prohibition, with its promise of a new prosperity, hundreds of hotel men and women wandered yesterday afternoon through the aisles of the National Hotel Exposition at its opening at the Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Twenty-seven wholesale tradegroups today presented to the NRA a master wholesale code which Immediately drew fire for proposing means of establishing price levels for direct sales from manufacturers to retailers and consumers.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 13 (AP). -- Cornered in a barber shop, Russell Hughes was shot and killed today by police who sought to question him about bank robberies, counterfeiting and the $400,000 kidnapping syndicate headed by Handsome Jack Klutas.

Continuance of activity in the Manhattan and Bronx realty fields was reported yesterday. A motion picture theatre is to occupy former banking quarters as the result of a Manhattan conveyance; in the Bronx the feature deals were investment purchases of apartment houses.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 14 -- There is no more revolution in Iowa than there is in New York or any other State in the East. There are a lot of farmers who are desperate, unhappy and fearful for the future. Some of them see hope in the Wallace corn-hog program; some of them do not.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Charges and countercharges involving the "master code" of the construction industry, sponsored by the Construction League and its affiliated organizations, were made today by partisans on both sides.

Buyers' Registrations Ahead. A gain in the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Germany formally put American and her other foreign bond creditors on notice yesterday that payments, in full of interest and sinking funds on her bonds, now suspended under the moratorium decree of June, are not likely to be resumed "when the moratorium ends on Dec. 31.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,273,300 barrels, compared with 2,300,750 barrels in the previous week, a decline of 27,450 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 96,700 barrels in the daily output of Texas and a gain of 68,950 barrels in Oklahoma were the most important changes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 3 -- The draft of a new Constitution for Brazil, details of which have just been revealed, contains several controversial points, one of which would affect foreign investments here.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Senator Thomas D. Schall was booed by a University of Minnesota audience today as he gave an address attacking the National Recovery pragram.
Columbia took up its heavy work yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Lafayette here on Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- In the House of Commons today, Morgan Jones, a Laborite, retracted with an apology the charge he had made yesterday that Sir Austen Chamberlain had, by his speeches, encouraged a high-handed policy by Japan in Manchuria.

The jury that will decide whether or not Isidor J. Kresel, former counsel and director of the defunct Bank of United States, had abetted the misapplication of funds of the bank, listened yesterday afternoon and last night to the longest charge ever made by a judge in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court.

Efforts to perfect the New York University football team's aerial attack were the highlight of yesterday's three-hour workout at Ohio Field. The N.Y.U. eleven is preparing for Saturday's battle with Rutgers at the Yankee Stadium.

While the local NRA organization intervened yesterday in an effort to stop the tobacco war which has been going on for several days in several retail stores in lower Manhattan, hostilities among the stores became more bitter, with large crowds of cigarette and tobacco purchasers rushing to the establishments to take advantage of the cut prices of the competitors.

Sale of an Eighth Avenue site for improvement with a small new business building and the leasing of several commercial and residential structures in various parts of Manhattan featured the realty activity as reported by brokers in the metropolitan district yesterday.
THE youthful guardian of the outer portal came in flushed with excitement and said:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet-American conversations are, one hears, proceeding "according to plan." And that, it may be said, is all one does hear.

MUNCIE, Ind., Nov. 14. -- Secretary Wallace tonight asked that America take a position for reducing tariffs or curbing production, or decide on a compromise between the two, and be prepared to stick to its decision for ten to fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Two old personal and political friends, President Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith, whom Mr. Roosevelt dubbed "the Happy Warrior" when he nominated him for President, met in the spirit of olden days at a White House tea this afternoon.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Wesleyan will play its closing football game on Saturday at Rochester against the University of Rochester. The growing rivalry between the institutions is due largely to the fact that their directors of physical education are twin brothers.

Four youths were indicted by the Kings County grand jury yesterday on charges of first-degree murder in the shooting of Sigmund Berko -- witz on Oct. 30 in the hold-up of a haberdashery store at 5,322 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The difficulties blocking are Anglo-Soviet trade agreement are understood to have been narrowed down to a few points of principle, upon which both sides are still immovable. It is expected that the Cabinet will review them soon.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Indictments accusing three men, now in custody, of being the kidnappers of James Hackett, a Blue Island gambler, were voted today by the grand jury.

The Department of Taxes and Assessments announced yesterday that today is the last day on which property owners may file protests against assessed valuations on their holdings for tax purposes next year.

Ralph D. Blumenfeld, chairman of the board of The London Daily Express, and who was its editor-in-chief for many years, arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic to give a series of lectures. He was met at the pier by Edward G. Broenninan, his boyhood companion in Watertown, Wis., where a reception has been arranged for him on his way West.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For reasons which are fairly obvious, both THE TIMES's correspondents, Herbert Mahler and Albert Bernard, manifest notable ingenuity in misinterpreting my reference to the Russian organization known as MOPR.

Captain Thomas C. Evans, master of the steamer Borinquen of the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company, received yesterday a gold medal for having directed the rescue of a woman passenger who fell from his ship May 5 when it was on its way to Puerto Rico.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All the good rules, and they are many, laid down by the Liquor Control Board are likely to be outweighed by the pro- hibition of bars. So flagrant a defiance of local habits will only perpetuate the prosperity of the speakeasy, and Mr. Mulrooney's explanation of the reasons are singularly unconvincing.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 -- George H. Earle 3d, the United States Minister to Vienna, delivered a warning against anti-Semitism to the Austrian people today in an interview with American and Austrian newspaper men.

Representative of about one hundred American export firms which hold approximately 30,000,000 pesos of blocked balances in Argentina have decided to accept the Argentine Government's offer of Argentine Treasury bills in exchange, according to announcement made yesterday by the committee which has been negotiating the matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Secretary Woodin's spirited denial that he is out of step with the administration's fiscal program, and that there is a "Treasury clique" which is resisting it, was a measured stroke of policy. From the President down, the government has been first annoyed and then, in view of the delicate nature of affairs, concerned over reiterated stories of dissension.

Frank J. Price Jr., an executive of the Prudential Insurance Company, has written a book of mystery stories in which an insurance detective is featured. The book is called "Mind Wreckers, Limited," and will be published tomorrow by the Spectator Company of Philadelphia, which specializes in books about insurance.

Weakness in United States Government bonds, in line with the decline of the dollar in the foreign exchange market, contrasted with the sharp advance in leading foreign loans on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The government's issues lost 2-32 to 20-32 point on the day, except the called Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s and the Treasury 3 3/8 s due in 1947 and callable in 1943, which held unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A greater share for the farmer was recorded in the rising prices of foodstuffs during October, according to Dr. Fred C. Howe, consumers' counsel for the AAA.

The formation of Chinese Boy Scout Troop 197, composed of young Chinese boys living in Chinatown, was announced yesterday by Bert V. Eutemey, organizer of the troop. Mr. Eutemey recalled that about twenty years ago Chinese Boy Scout Troop 150 was formed and its members grew up to be dentists, pharmacists, insurance brokers and other professional men.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 14 -- The regular annual late Autumn politicomilitary shifts and realignments are developing alarmingly and filling the Chinese newspapers with apprehensive conjectures as to the possibilities of new civil warfare.

ABOARD S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Nov. 14 -- After a day of indecision, Mayor-elect LaGuardia decided this afternoon to continue his vacation trip to the Canal Zone. The ship docked at Havana this morning, and from then until sailing time at 4 P.M. it was uncertain whether he would continue his voyage.

There are many forms of illegal shooting and there are many forms of shooting which, though not actually unlawful, are considered unethical among sportsmen. The campaign now going on in Connecticut against deer jacking calls attention to one form of illegal shooting which has caused so much trouble to State game officials.

The limitations on ruthless price competition in the NRA retail code are a necessary part of the economics of the new period we are entering, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and chairman of the National Retail Council, said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Sir Bolton Meredith Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today that the British naval construction program for 1933 had been changed by substituting for the four small cruisers originally planned two larger ones of 9,000 tons each and one small one of about 5,200 tons of the Arethusa type.

Further support of the Red Cross membership roll-call drive by professional and business groups was announced yesterday by Peter S. Duryee, roll-call chairman of the New York chapter. Musicians, stock brokers, college women and other women's organizations gave evidence of their interest in the annual campaign.

Advances in prices continued yesterday in all commodity markets except sugar, cocoa and hides. Most openings were higher and the gains were augmented until late in the day, when a recession followed the partial recovery of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- The Reichstag fire trial, staged at the beginning as a show trial to demonstrate to the German masses the menace of communism and the rescue work of Adolf Hitler and greeted as such by both the press and the government radio system, after Sunday's election has been suddenly reduced to a perfunctory place in the newspapers and silence on the radio.

Current assets of the General Foods Corporation on Sept. 30 totaled $36,835,076, against current liabilities of $5,701,345, a ratio of 6.4 to 1, according to the company's pamphlet report. On Sept. 30, 1932, the ratio was 5.6 to 1.

Walter T. Fitzsimmons, Deputy Commissioner of Records in the New York County Surrogates' Court and Tammany leader of the upper half of the Tenth Assembly District, died late last night in Post-Graduate Hospital after a lingering illness.

The campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $4,000,000 to be devoted to relief of the unemployed through accredited family welfare agencies will open tomorrow evening with a dinner at the Hotel Astor. More than 1,000 men and women prominent in business, industry, finance, social work and philanthropy will attend.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan said yesterday that he approved the proposal to erect a monument at Broadway and Forty-sixth Street in memory of the late Father Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Infantry.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Interest on the Boerse centred today on fixed-interest securities, which were lively and firm, while stocks were rather neglected and irregular. The upward movement in the bond market was attributed to the consolidation of the domestic political situation and the open market policy of the Reichsbank, while stocks suffered from a new slump in the dollar, which reached a new low record of 2.59 marks.

Plans for the appointment of a committee on railroad recovery were announced by Pierre S. du Pont, a director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, following a meeting held under the auspices of the Security Owners Association in the Metropolitan Club yesterday.

The annual armistice ball and reunion of the First Division, Lieutenant Jeff Feigl Post, took place last night in the new ballroom of the Hotel Astor and drew an attendance of several hundred persons prominent in military, civic and social life.

James J. Hoey, Recovery party nominee for Borough President of Manhattan at the recent election, was appointed yesterday by President Roosevelt to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District to succeed William Duggan, Republican.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Another violent slump in the dollar to $5.28 1/2 caused less agitation in London to- day than the persistent, ominous weakness of the French franc.
Herbert Jaques, member of The Country Club of Brookline, Mass., has been renominated for the presidency of the United States Golf Association.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Hitler youth is running ahead of the national government in obliterating State lines from the new Reich. Hundreds of boundary monuments between the States of Prussia and Hesse have been removed by enthusiastic members of this organization.

Approximately 8,000,000 members of the Christmas Club throughout the country will receive $350,000,000 within the next two weeks from banks and other organizations sponsoring the club. It is estimated that 42 per cent of this, or $147,000,000, will be spent directly for Christmas purchases.
Tammany Drinks Horizontally. People are excited about bar drinking and table drinking, liquor on the premises and liquor off the premises, wine with meals and meals with wine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A cryptic allusion to "the Rockefellers" in connection with payment of $300,- 052.73 to William S. Fitzpatrick from the profits of $12,002,109.41 by participants in a Sinclair Consolidated common stock syndicate was made by Harry F. Sinclair today, puzzling Senate stock market investigators.

Production of new life insurance in this country in October ran close to that in the same month last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents has reported to the United States Department of Commerce. The total was 1.9 per cent below the figures of a year before, with industrial insurance gaining for the third consecutive month.

John Isola, 34 years old, an aviator, of 2,246 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in the Federal court in Brooklyn of violation of the socalled Lindbergh law in sending an extortion letter through the mails. Judge Clarence G. Galston sentenced Isola to serve ten years in a Federal penitentiary.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The outstanding feature of the last four years has been the excessive fall of prices, which has gone to a greater extreme in America than anywhere else. It would be next to impossible to restore prosperity in America on the low level to which prices have fallen except after long years of depression and of industrial and agricultural adjustment.
Freddie Miller, Cincinnati featherweight, made a triumphant return to New York in a bout last night at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press). -- After a conference aboard the yacht owned by Lady Houston, millionaire sportswoman and publisher, it has been decided to remove offending paragraphs from an article by Lady Houston printed in The Saturday Review, which she owns.

In the soup that was sizzling in a pot on the kitchen stove in the apartment of Abraham Matler, a credit jeweler, at 815 First Avenue, three hold-up men found a weapon that vanquished their shiny, fully loaded revolver last night.

Although the dollar was again sharply depressed yesterday in the foreign exchange market, there was no large-scale buying of stocks or commodities. Business on the Stock Exchange was slow, and prices, after a session of nervous irregularity, closed slightly lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Assurance that the special recovery levies, enacted to produce $227,000,000 annually for the $3,300,000,000 public works program, would be repealed next month was given in an informal ruling by the Treasury today.

The question of whether to renew for another twelve months the oneyear bus franchises now held by the operators of twenty-six routes in Queens was referred yesterday for investigation to Controller George McAneny at a meeting of the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate.

An action to compel seventeen officers and directors of the Hamilton Mutual Auto Casualty Corporation to account for acts alleged to have resulted in $350,000 damage to the company was begun yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, liquidator of the corporation.

Authorities on tuberculosis, speaking through the New York Academy of Medicine and the National Tuberculosis Association, as well as individual research workers in the field, expressed themselves yesterday as being skeptical regarding the announcement Monday night by Dr. Stephen J. Maher, Connecticut tuberculosis expert, that he had developed a technique for breeding a type of bacteria, known as cocci and diplococci, from tuberculosis germs, which in turn, de- stroy the bacillus of the "white plague."

Many junior and senior high school students lack knowledge of the fundamental principles of courtesy and social usage. Dr. Ruth Strang, Assistant Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columhia University, declared in a survey, made public yesterday.

NANKING, Nov. 14 -- A foreign military observer, arriving here from Nanchang, is pessimistic concerning General Chiang Kai-shek's chances of complete success in the anti-Communist campaign in Kiangsi.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- That the spokesmen for simon-pure Germanic Protestantism at last night's meeting of Nazi GGerman Christians at the Sportpalast over-reached themselves was shown today by the condemnation that overwhelmed them from the highest church authorities.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The speedy Detroit Red Wings scored a 4-2 victory tonight over the Bruins in the Boston opening of the National Hockey League season. The victory enabled the visitors to take first place in the American Division.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 14 -- Willie Macfarlane, bespectacled veteran of the links and a former open champion, paired with Paul Runyan of White Plains today to win the annual mid-South best-hall title. The event was the curtain-raiser to the individual championship tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The dollar fell to a new post-war low record today. From the overnight rate of $5.15 to the pound sterling, it weakened to $5.28 1/4. The previous lowest point since 1914 was $5.17% on last Friday.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Two solid votes of confidence ended a debate on foreign affairs today in the Chamber of Deputies in which Premier Albert Sarraut firmly declared that France "does not know fear and now possesses a material and military force that prevents any one from dictating to her."
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Another "marrying Mdivani," Prince Serge of the Soviet Province of Georgia, was divorced today.

CALDELAS DE TUY, Spain, Nov. 14. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh said today he was considering flying across the Middle Atlantic by stages as a continuation of his aerial survey of the North Atlantic.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 -- Protests by Palestine Arabs, carried on with great fervor in the past two months and still continuing, against Jewish immigration here are beginning to have effect. The Palestine Government has decided to enforce stringent measures against illicit Jewish settlement in the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A determined effort will be made in the next session of Congress to overhaul the Wiley Pure Food and Drugs Act of 1906 so as to bring within the purview of the law cosmetics, mechanical devices for curative purposes, and advertising in publications, by radio and by other means.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- In what was called the funeral oration of capitalism and liberal institutions, Premier Mussolini today forecast the eventual abolition of the Italian Chamber of Deputies. Speaking before the National Council of Corporations, he also advanced a program by which other nations could acquire corporative States.

Alfred M. Cohen, president of B'nai B'rith and a former State Senator in Ohio, returned on the French liner Paris yesterday from London, where he had attended the conference of international Jewish organizations for the relief of German Jews.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 -- The Charter ticket for the City Council was victorious in winning five of the nine seats in the council and retaining control of the city government.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 14 -- H. Mason Brent, 47, owner of the King School for Boys, was found dead in the schoolyard this morning. He had plunged from a second-story window of the building.

The hotels and restaurants operated by charitable and benevolent organizations on property partly or wholly tax exempt came under fire at the annual convention of the New York State Hotel Association at the Hotel Commodore yesterday. The convention session was in connection with the National Hotel Exposition being held through Friday under the auspices of the State group and the Hotel Association of New York City at Grand Central Palace.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- Arthur Henderson's threat to resign as president of the disarmament conference took all delegations by surprise. Its result will depend on Mr. Henderson's success in swinging British public opinion away from ideas of secret big-power negotiations and forcing the Cabinet to take disarmament decisions it has been postponing for months.

A total of 1,399 horses and 195 riders, both flat and steeplechase, took part in the recently concluded Jockey Club racing season of 151 days, according to the official report of Albert Burlen, clerk of the scales, as annnounced yesterday.

The Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York announced yesterday that it had filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission for the suspension of tariffs of the Pennsylvania, Grand Trunk and Erie railroads which were recently published, providing for store-door delivery and collection of freight.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Playing a consistently steady game, George Kelly of Philadelphia tonight won the national pocket-billiard championship. He defeated his fellow-townsman, 18-year-old William Mosconi, 125 to 98, in twenty-nine innings, in the third game of the title play-off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Security and freedom of religious worship for American citizens in Russia were reported authoritatively today to be outstanding points in the deliberations on recognition of Russia by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors was asked today to uphold the report of the division engineer recommending a survey of the Shrewsbury and Shark Rivers in New Jersey for dredging and improvement.

The spirit of cooperation displayed in the shipping industry in the depression of the last three years was praised last night by Kermit Roosevelt, vice president of the United States Lines, at a meeting of members of the Seamen's Bouse branch of the Y.M.C.A.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The government proceeded slowly today with its program of gold purchases abroad, as the price at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy newly mined domestic gold was fixed at $33.56, an increase of 11 cents over yesterday's quotation.
Residential properties made up the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
Seven of the eight favored players in the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the Columbia University Club emerged victorious from "the third round of play last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and the American Stores Company, large food store chains, were cited by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today to show cause why their licenses to distribute milk in the Philadelphia area should not be suspended or revoked.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14 -- A four-point program establishing a comprehensive policy dealing with fraternities at Rutgers University has been presented by President Robert C. Clothier.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14 -- With large fields entered for all seven events on the opening program, the fourteen-day race meeting of the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association promises to get off to a successful start tomorrow. The feature will be the Capitol City Purse, a six-furlong sprint which has attracted eight speedy juveniles.

An unusual entertainment will be given tomorrow by the International Institute of the Y.W.C.A. at its headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue, consisting of a reception, concert, bazaar and tea. There also will be an exhibition of art, craft, needlework and handiwork, representative of various countries, including Greece, Poland, Italy, Hungary, Mexico, Armenia, Estonia, China and Ukrainia.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Making the Olde Egremont Tavern, South Egremont, their headquarters, twenty members of the Connecticut Chapter, Appalachian Mountain Club, have been spending a few days hiking over the snow-covered trails of Mount Washington and Mount Everett.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- A team selected from the second and third varsity elevens at Harvard played a 6-6 tie with the Crimson junior varsity in a thirty-minute scrimmage on the practice field today.

Somebody on La Nouvelle Revue Francaise seems to have had the curious notion of proving, in a world of overproduction, that the poetry crop wasn't failing. So the magazine addressed itself to amateur makers, not bothering about the professionals, of whom there is always sure to be a constant supply.

Miss Fanny Washington of Warrenton, Va., and New York, descendant of John Washington, uncle of George Washington, presented a set of original drawings of Mount Vernon to Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Pepper of Philadelphia and Miss Annie Burr Jennings of Fairfield, Conn., representing the Ladies' Mount Vernon Association, yesterday afternoon at the English Bookshop.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The New Jersey Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform disbanded at a meeting here this afternoon and the New Jersey Committee of Women for Honest Liquor Laws was created to operate in the approaching post-prohibition era.

The American college, with which the word "racket" was associated a few days ago by a college president, does not deserve that opprobrium, despite all that he said of some of its graduates. It is true, as another college president said last week when inaugurated as head of an institution that has for a century been giving education on a high level to those qualified to receive it:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Lonny Goodyear will probably start at centre for Yale in the clashes with Princeton and Harvard, remaining games on the schedule, according to conclusions reached today. He replaced Joe Johnson, veteran snap-back, who was sent to the reserve squad today.

Herbert Nolan, former prison guard charged with murdering his wife, sat unmoved in the Kings County Court yesterday as his white-haired mother took the stand in his defense. The mother, Mrs. Helen Nolan of 332 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, told the jury that her son had been driven almost frantic for fear that he would be "made the goat" for the fatal shooting in the Brooklyn city prison last November.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 15 -- "Either complete independence, with the Philippines maintaining their own defenses and responsible to themselves for national survival, or, if a probationary period is necessary, then maintenance of the present economic ties with the United States during that period."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Forced to mark time by the inability of the Alcoholic Beverage Commission to have a report ready, the Legislature adjourned today until Nov. 22. Thomas N. McCarter, chairman of the beverage commission, notified Governor Moore that the report might be ready next Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, delivered a grave warning to the Irish Free State of the danger of losing her place in the British Commonwealth in a statement in the House of Commons today.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- When the dollar dropped sharply today to 15.72 francs, against 15.89 yesterday, it was 10 centimes below the theoretical gold parity set at Washington. The official market closes before the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's daily gold price becomes known in Paris, so comparison must be made with the previous day's figure.

The Barium Steel Corporation has been organized under the laws of Ohio to produce stainless steel in open hearth furnaces from scrap by the use of barium, it was announced yesterday by Lawrence K. Diffenderfer, president. Stainless steel can be made at a low cost by the process, Mr. Diffenderfer said.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I consider your editorial "The Lowly Dollar" one of the finest outlines of the situation that I have so far read. I find that there is another situation which the American public as a whole do not realize, and that is what the actual purchasing value of our American dollar is in the foreign markets.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- In the 28,000,000 American homes there are 20,000,000 American women running their households without scientific training in nutritional values, according to a paper by Mrs. Charles E. Gregory which was read at the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs today.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Germany having by an overwhelming majority officially standardized itself according to the Nazi model, there is now arising from the suppressed liberal elements within it a plea for a new generosity toward the vanquished, a suggestion of relenting toward liberalism.

Ex-Governor SMITH scorned the idea that his call at the White House had any political significance. It was to be merely a delightful meeting of two old friends. But the President, with the gracious tact so characteristic of him, made sure in advance that it would he an agreeable "social" affair.

A fascinating exhibition called "The Second Empire," which commemorates the centenary of Nicephore Niepce, inventor of photography, has just opened at Knoedler's, in the galleries on the third floor. It is composed of daguerreo-types by Louis-Jacques Daguerre and his school, from the collection of Miss M. Therese Bonney, supplemented by a large group or American loans.

The dollar went to a new low yesterday, and at the same time Government bonds dropped again in the market. One of the Administration's financial advisers was quoted on Monday as being "indifferent" to the weakness of Government securities and holding the opinion that a "slump" in them for the time being "does not matter much."

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 14 -- The Shaughnessy plan, of post-season play-offs among the four first division clubs, last season's innovation in determining league championships, will be tried again next year by the Texas League.

The Princess Alexis Mdivani reached the age of 21 yesterday and received a one-third share of the $60,000,000 estate left in 1919 by her grandfather, F.W. Woolworth, pioneer of the five-and-ten-cent stores.

The setting up of a code authority for the dress industry under the dress code signed last month by President Roosevelt was begun yesterday at a meeting of representatives of employers' associations and the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, all parties to the code, at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Supreme Court of the United States "is probably in for a very unhappy and soul-searching experience" in its interpretation of the constitutional problems arising from the present emergency legislation. This assertion is made by Dr. Howard Lee McBain, Ruggles Professor of Constitutional Law and Dean of the Graduate Faculties of Columbia University, in today's issue of The Independent Journal of the Columbia School of Journalism.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The next Congressional elections may herald the beginning of a political realignment of the American people, Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, said today at the convention of Land Grant Colleges and Universities.

The final night of the horse show brought an outpouring of society that probably has not been equaled since the national association began to stage its annual exhibition in the new Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The Federal Relief Commission resumed buying of hogs today and paid $4.60 a hundredweight and under for the supply of around 10,000 which had been carried over from yesterday, meeting sellers' views as to price. Federal holdings to be slaughtered for relief purposes are now around 28,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Professor Arthur Wold Meyer, 48 years old, chief surgeon of the West End Hospital, shot his wife and himself dead at their home in Charlottenburg today. No explanation was offered for his act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, oil administrator, told the oil industry tonight that he had no intention of relaxing his control over Federal efforts to re-establish an industry that had failed to govern itself.

Although the turnover on the Stock Exchange yesterday was about twice as large as on Monday, the price changes did not keep pace with the increase in trading activity. Wall Street watched uncertainly the wide variations in the foreign exchange market and tempered its enthusiasm accordingly.

With Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia laying plans for a thorough elimination of Tammany's patronage in the city departments, the Board of Estimate, sitting in Committee of the Whole yesterday approved two-year extensions for 568 city employes who will reach the retirement age of 70 before the end of this year.

The provisions of the legitimate theatre code respecting the minimum wages for actors are applicable to all contracts as of Aug. 27, the date on which the code went into effect, whether or not the contracts were drawn before that date, according to a ruling made by Sol A. Kosenblatt, Deputy Administrator of the NRA, on Nov. 8, and made public yesterday.

Repeal will bring employment to approximately 100,000 persons in New York City, according to an estimate made yesterday by Frank A. Ludwig, head of the employment unit of the Federation of Hotel and Restaurant Guilds.

After a day of rest, Fordham's football squad returned to action yesterday and spent about two hours on Fordham Field in a long signal drill and a complete rehearsal of its plays. The Hams will clash with the strong Oregon State eleven at the Polo Grounds on Saturday in the finale for the Maroon this season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The gyrations in foreign exchange were largely responsible for a sharp upward movement in the grain markets early today, but liberal profit-taking occurred on the bulges. Toward the last a somewhat overbought condition developed, causing a loss of most of the upturn.

Schenectady, N.Y. The first offering of a new issue of municipal bonds in nearly two weeks will be made today when Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., will place on the market an issue of $410,000 city of Schenectady (N.Y.) 4 3/4 per cent bonds dated Nov. 15, 1933, and due serially on Nov. 35, 1935 to 1943.

Studies in the psychology of bird behavior were presented yesterday at the semi-centennial meeting of the American Ornithologists Union at the American Museum of Natural History. Ornithologists read papers describing observations of the home life of birds, the qualities of song by various species and the reaction of birds to the sight of their images in mirrors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Medical men eagerly discussed tonight the possibilities of a specific cure for tuberculosis offered by experiments in which Dr. Stephen J. Maher changed germs responsible for the disease into harmless bacteria.

By a magnificent display of horsemanship the team of the Swedish Army last night won the International Military Trophy as the National Horse Show came to a close in Madison Square Garden. The Swedish riders thrilled the crowd of 15,000 by turning in a perfect score.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14 -- South Orange and Montclair scored 5-0 shutouts in Class B matches of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League today.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Miss Katharine Ten Eyck Lansing, sister of the late Robert Lansing, Secretary of State in the Wilson administration, died today at the age of 58 after a long illness.

At least two 6-meter racing yachts will be built in this country for the British-American Cup match next Summer. The challenge, announced on Monday in London, was accepted yesterday by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, which will hold the races on Long Island Sound.

Reversing its earlier ruling, which provoked protests from organizations representing 150,000 waiters employed in New York's 28,000 restaurants and hotels, the local NRA compliance board announced yesterday that waiters' tips must not be included as part of wages and that the minimum wage scales prescribed under the President's re-employment agreement remain in force.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The informal investigation of alleged Nazi propaganda in the United States was opened today by three members of the House Immigration and Naturalization Committee in a spectacular setting.

WHEN Dorothy Thompson is chosen for one of the sundry halls of fame, the identification line should contain three items, first, that she is the wife of Sinclair Lewis; second, that she is an accomplished journalist in her own right, and, third (but not least), that she is the American discoverer of "Karl and the Twentieth Century," a remarkable first novel by Rudolf Brunngraber, published by Morrow for $2.50.
The Vanderbilt Cup, classic trophy of the world of contract bridge, was won yesterday by a team against whom the odds were strong at the start of the week's play in the Ritz Carlton Hotel.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Albert Knapp will give a dance on Saturday at the Rumson Country Club to introduce their three daughters, the Misses Christine, Elizabeth and Honora Knapp.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 -- Amid gusts of boos and hisses, volleys of "falsehoods" and thunderings of "contempt" the subcommittee of the United States Senate inquiring into the fitness of Senator John H. Overton ran into a typical Louisiana hurricane of political hate today.

The National Musical Benefit Society, which offers its hall at 21 Gramercy Park to qualifed musicians of the neighborhood, presented there last night a chamber music program by the Lavotta String Quartet. The players, Emery Pillitz, Paul Bekkar, Benjamin Pellman and Francis Tonhazy, were heard in quartets of Schubert in D minor and Dvorak in F major, a presto by Kodaly, a Hungarian air by J. Bloch and Coleridge-Taylor's "Deep River."

ROME, Nov. 14 -- During a long speech with which he closed the Fall session of the National Council of Corporations Premier Mussolini appeared today in his most scintillating moods. He flitted from subject to subject, touching on economic, political, internal and international topics as the mood seized him.

With emphasis on defensive play, kicking and passing, the Manhattan College football team started preparations yesterday for the game with Catholic University at Ebbets Field on Saturday. Following their day of rest on Monday, the Jaspers were sent through a ninety-minute workout by Coach Chick Meehan.
The 1934 budget of $554,678,511.85 was referred to the finance committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday after that board had formally acknowledged its transmission from the Board of Estimate.

A proposal to extend the Fusion movement to the State as part of the fight to check political machines and bring about "good government" has been under discussion since the sweeping Fusion victory in the city election last Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The first Soviet comment on the recognition negotiations in Washington were published in today's newspapers in the form of a telegram from New York carrying the opinions of the correspondents of prominent United States newspapers regarding reasons for the delay in recognition.

Mrs. Madeleine McLean Ward, widow of John Seely Ward, who died at her home, at 350 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Nov. 4, divided her residuary estate, of undetermined value, in equal shares between the New York Exchange for Women's Work, 541 Madison Avenue, of which she was president, and the Trudeau Sanitarium, Trudeau, N.Y.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Penn's first heavyweight crew won the annual St. Paul's Cup race on the Schuylkill River this evening, the mile and a Quarter being rowed in the dark.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the heaviest for a day in several weeks, while prices rose more than 20 points, or $1 a bale, to the highest quotations recorded since the advance in September. All months sold and closed above 10 cents a pound, or a gain of 12 to 16 points on the day.

The distribution of applications for liquor licenses proceeded with comparative quiet yesterday in the offices of the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, at 2 Lafayette Street, until three State Senators, headed by Majority Leader John J. Dunnigan, came in to obtain blanks for their constituents.

After the pains he took to place his researches in tuberculosis before his medical colleagues and the public in a conservative light, Dr. MAHER is probably astonished to find himself enjoying more publicity than he courted. A paper of 10,000 words on the subject of the proper line of investigation to be pursued in discovering a specific cure for tuberculosis is bound to arouse hopes.
When Charles Hammel sold to Gertrude Guldemond the five-story building at 239 E. 73d St. for about $9,000 he took back a purchase-money mortgage for $7,750, payable five years hence, at 5 per cent.

More than 1,000 unfair trade practices which American business seeks to have eliminated as detrimental to the nation's economic life are listed in the codes so far submitted to the National Recovery Administration, Malcolm Muir, divisional NRA administrator, in charge of some 800 codes, revealed yesterday.

An evening of Russian music given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was an evening of music which had lost none of its fantasy, freshness and rich orchestral color, and also an evening of superb orchestral performance.

It begins to appear rather strongly now that the two games which round out the season for the Big Three this year, Yale-Harvard at Cambridge on Nov. 25 and Yale-Princeton at New Haven Dec. 2, will be games well worthy or their tradition.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 14 -- Rembrandt's "Jeremiah Mourning for the Destruction of Jerusalem," valued at 400,000 kronor [about $100,000], was stolen last night from the home of M. Herman Rasch, art collector.

LISBON, Nov. 15. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here early this afternoon from Valencia on the Spanish Portuguese border. Fog had delayed their take-off from the Minho River. They brought their plane down at the hydroplane base in the Tagus River here after an hour and forty minutes in the air.

The Lawyers County Trust Co., Thorwald Stallkennter, vice president, has released to the Meenan Coal Company, Inc., the inner 160 feet of the north side of Pier 75, North River, foot of W. 35th St., with 4,000 square feet of pier area adjacent thereto, from the lien of a mortgage for $450,000 given in trust to the County Trust Co. on April 1, 1931.

The Red Cross membership rollcall drive received aid yesterday from employes of the Federal Government in New York City and from the New York Real Estate Board. The appeal in the annual campaign conducted by the New York Chapter will be carried forward today by Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chapter chairman, in a radio speech.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- A. new struggle between American and British holders of German bonds and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, is scheduled to take place Dec. 5 at a conference of Germany's foreign creditors in Berlin. The meeting was called by the Reichsbank for discussion of a prolongation of the German transfer moratorium.

RIDGELAND, S.C., Nov. 15. -- William K. Vanderbilt Jr., fatally injured in the crash of his automobile here today, had not fully recovered from effects of a previous automobile wreck. Only yesterday a bird flew through his windshield at Bunnell, Fla., and flying glass inflicted wounds which required medical attention.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn signed yesterday an order requiring the Board of Education to show cause why it should not fill 1,576 vacancies in the city's high schools with new teachers from the eligible list.

The price war in which a group of tobacconists in lower Manhattan have been engaged for several weeks and which had threatened to develop into a city-wide contest was ended last night after a conference of tobacco dealers at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15. -- An uproar that nearly became a riot marked today's session by the Senate subcommittee investigating the Overton-Broussard election. It followed a statement by Chairman Connally, which ended with the words: "You cowards in Louisiana."
As a result of last night's matches among the Class A teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League there now is a triple tie for the lead.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15. -- A dispute has arisen between German companies and the Soviet Government over the payment of notes. A "number of German companies," it is revealed, is demanding the honoring of Soviet notes in dollars or pounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- President Roosevelt declared today that neither politics nor graft would be allowed to interfere with the new civil works program by which the administration plans to put 4,000,000 to work in self-sustaining employment on local projects before Dec. 15.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15. -- The turf on Harvard's football field was frozen solid today, causing the coaches to hold the two and a half hour session in the baseball cage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- While no question of international relations is involved in the first seadrome tests, pending their outcome the administration probably will hold in abeyance any development of policy concerning their use.

George E. Coughlin, former assistant counsel to the Board of Transportation, died yesterday at his home at 454 Riverside Drive. He was 40 years old. His heart became affected, it was said, after a sinus operation three weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 13:

The directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share, completing the twelfth full year of dividend payments at $9 a share. The new dividend will be paid on Jan. 15 to stockholders of record of Dec. 15.

Secretary WALLACE believes that the United States has "blundered along" for fifteen years, refusing to recognise the consequences of its creditor position. He means that we tried to eat our cake and have it too. The World War transformed us from a debtor nation, on foreign account, into a large creditor.

PRINCETON, N.J., NOV. 15. -- Information received by the police today established definitely that Jay F. Towner 3d of Perryman, Md., whose crushed body was found on the Princeton campus Saturday night, did not suffer his fatal injuries at the hands of crowds during the Princeton-Dartmouth football game in the afternoon.

ST. JOHNS, N.F., Nov. 15. -- The British steamer Saxilby left Bell Island, N.F., on Nov. 7 with 6,000 tons of iron ore for England, part of a barter trade between the Newfoundland Government railway and English smelters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Two hours after a conference with President Roosevelt, Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, announced tonight that complaints of profiteering under the codes and Blue Eagle agreements would be aired at public hearings starting Dec. 12.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The American Federation of Labor's press release attacking a dispatch by Walter Duranty, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday, read as follows:

Indications that the steel industry has "struck at least a temporary resistance level" are seen by The Iron Age, which, in its mid-weak review, draws attention to the fact that more steel is being bought for public works and automobile manufacturers.

For the second consecutive month, the railroads increased their passenger revenues in September, according to figures issued yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission. These two monthly gains were the first to be reported since the depression began.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yester- Tuesday. day. For the best names..........1 1/4% 1 1/4% Quotations are for three to four months' paper. * * * To Study Fair Practice Results. W.H. Hager, president of the Pennsylvania Retailers Association, was appointed chairman of a special committee of retailers to study the effects of the fair trade practice provisions of the retail code at a special meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Warning every sportsman in America of the possibility that the shooting of wild fowl may cease as a result of tremendous decreases in flocks, the More Game Birds Foundation yesterday issued a two-volume report of its investigations into the duck situation, in the United States and Canada.

In the offices of the City Alcoholic Beverages Control Board Tuesday three Tammany State Senators, unswerving foes of "privilege" save to the organization, maintained triumphantly the rights of their order. Ordinary citizens seeking application blanks for liquor licenses had to wait their turn.

LEMARS, Iowa, Nov. 15. -- Iowa is a State of contradictions. Finding one's way through the conflicting opinions of farmers, business men and commission men is a confusing process. When a packing agent in Sioux City is discovered talking like a semi-revolutionary farmer in Lemars, and at the same time cussing the farmer, the conscientious inquirer feels as if he were wandering in the land behind the looking glass.

Six high school boys who were willing to learn got the opportunity last night. In a two-by-four kitchen in the basement of the Labor Temple, Fourteenth Street and Second Avenue, they cooked a meal and ate it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- In an effort to foil both the bootlegger and the profiteer by assuring low price legitimate liquor on the first day of prohibition repeal, the administration is now allowing the withdrawal of old bonded whiskies from warehouses for blending and shipment to all parts of the country.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- The breach in the German Protestant Church broadened tonight as the capital teemed with bishops, church, superintendents and preachers rallying to the support of the Rev. Dr. Martin Niemaeller and his ousted colleagues, suspended for their opposition to the Nazi German Christians' anti-Semitic doctrines.
PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 15. -- For the second successive year the mid-South open golf championship ended today in a triple tie for first place.

The residence of the late Miss Elisabeth Marbury at 13 Sutton Place will be opened at noon on Sunday to any one who may be interested in seeing its furnishings prior to their sale at auction on the afternoons of Nov. 24 and 25 at the Plaza Art Auction Rooms, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Urging "immediate reflation of our currency and credits," Louis J. Taber, National Master of the Grange, declared today agriculture bad failed to receive the full benefit of the Federal recovery program.
SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 15. -- Over a frozen gridiron, the Groton School eleven converted a brilliant rally into a victory to defeat St. Mark's in their forty-fifth annual game, 7 to 6, today.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Oscar M. Hartzell, promoter of a claim to the Sir Francis Drake estate, was found guilty today on twelve Federal charges of using the mails to defraud in collection of funds for his enterprise. Judge George C. Scott in Federal court sentenced him to ten years in the Federal penitentiary and fined him $2,000.

Great Britain has decided to make a change in her navy-building program for 1933 by substituting for the four small cruisers of the Arethusa type two ships of 9,000 tons each and one of 5,200 tons. The obvious comment is that, temporarily at least, she has abandoned the small-cruiser policy which had been recommended to the United States.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15. -- The convention assembled here to adopt a new constitution and select a new President for Brazil was formally opened today with a message from President Getulio Vargas which was construed as granting amnesty to political exiles.

Onlookers had their full measure of entertainment yesterday if they watched the foreign exchanges and some of the commodity markets. But they may have been disappointed by the action of the share market which, pursuing its erratic course of the recent past, dwindled to a volume that was only about three-fifths of the turnover on Tuesday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- With Westchester facing payless paydays and the default Dec. 1 on obligations totaling about $3,500,000, heads of county departments have asked salary increases totaling about $60,000 for the 1934 county budget, it was disclosed today.

Injunctions in labor disputes and as a means of breaking strikes were attacked yesterday at a meeting at the Bar Association Building by representatives of the Civil Liberties Union and others. The meeting was held as a hearing by the State Commission on the Administration of Justice of which Senator John L. Buckley is chairman, with a view toward the recommendation of possible legislation on the subject.

Scientific control of future employment through a study of occupational distribution is the subject of a survey announced yesterday by Charles S. Slocombe, associate director of the Personnel Research Federation. The Slocombe plan, recently was presented as a possible guide to the labor administration in Washington.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 15. -- Minor league baseball magnates today heard William G. Bramham, president of the National Association at Professional Baseball Leagues, assail the Shaughnessy pennant play-off plan, chain store deals and "shoestring operators."

Price movements in local commodity markets were sharply irregular yesterday. For the most part, opening transactions were at higher levels, with an upward trend prevailing until noon, with sharp breaks from that point, in many cases wiping out the gains.

GENEVA, Nov. 15. -- Arthur Henderson, as president of the disarmament conference, increased today the pressure he has been bringing on the delegations of the great powers, especially the British and Italians, to fulfill their promises to return here and push on with their task.

Continuation of the steel industry's code for an indefinite period in substantially its present form was forecast yesterday by steal executives, following a meeting here of the directors of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Empire State Building.

Assurance that the government will participate in no "squeezing" or "surprise parties" in its handling of actual cotton and cotton futures was given yesterday to members of the New York Cotton Exchange by Oscar Johnston, director of finance of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

The "President's Concert" for the benefit of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, which is devoted to the care of infantile paralysis sufferers, will be given in Carnegie Hall the evening of Dec. 8, it was announced yesterday. President Roosevelt is personally interested in the institution.
DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A 35-year-old housewife today shot and killed a young widow whom she accused of "stepping out" with her husband.

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Disregarding the gold price fixed at Washington, the dollar accelerated its drop today closing at 15.34 francs, against 15.72 yesterday. The theoretical parity with gold at $33.56 an ounce should be 15.76 francs; hence there was a premium on the dollar in New York over Paris.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The 10,000-ton cruiser Tuscaloosa, fifteenth of the eighteen ships of its type allotted to this country under terms of the London naval treaty, slid smoothly into the Delaware River here today.

Sharp criticism of the price theories of Professor George F. Warren of Cornell, who has frequently been consulted by President Roosevelt on monetary questions, was expressed last night by Dr. Walter E. Spahr, chairman of the Department of Economics at the New York University School of Commerce.

BUCHAREST, Nov. 15. -- The resignation of the National Peasant Cabinet was due to the impossibility of working with King Carol, former Premier Vaida-Voevod admitted at a meeting of party leaders today. He assumed the entire responsibility and resigned the party leadership.

An attempt to extort $1,000, under threat of blackmail and bodily injury, from Charles B. Halsey, real estate broker, and Mrs. Halsey, was frustrated yesterday when a detective, posing as a taxi driver and acting with Department of Justice agents, fired a shot through a cab window and seriously wounded one of the alleged extortionists.

The process of organizing the Newspaper Guild of New York among the news gatherers and writers of this city was completed last night. The organization committee, which steered it during the last three months while a constitution was elaborated and members were enrolled, handed over authority to officers elected by the members in a mail ballot.

Mrs. Thomas Crimmins will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 176 East Seventy-second Street, for a group of women who are aiding in the forthcoming campaign for Christmas donations of articles to Everybody's Thrift Shop. The shop, which is maintained at 112 East Fifty-ninth Street for the benefit of charitable organizations, is seeking various useful articles, including household furnishings, clothing and trinkets that may be purchased as gifts.

William P. Farnsworth, assistant to Deputy Administrator Sol A. Rosenblatt and a former theatrical producer, has been named as the third representative of the NRA on the National Legitimate Theatre Committee. He attended his first meeting of that committee yesterday afternoon.

The activities of "so-called scientists and collectors," through which many species of birds are rapidly becoming extinct, were decried yesterday by Dr. James Bond of the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. Dr. Bond spoke at the morning session of the American Ornithologists Union, in the American Museum of Natural History.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- A violent collapse of the dollar to $5.41 to the pound today combined with Treasury shifts in Washington gave London a day of the worst financial shocks it has had since the new American monetary policy was undertaken.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Interest on the Boerse continued today to centre on the market for fixed-interest securities, where a large number of small buying orders from the investing public produced price increases up to 2 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Martin Coles Harman, uncrowned "King" of Lundy Island and a picturesque figure in the London financial world, was sentenced today to eighteen months' imprisonment for conspiracy to defraud.

A memorial show of drawings and rare prints by Pop Hart, who died Sept. 9, is being held at the Downtown Gallery. A comprehensive memorial exhibition is to be arranged later, perhaps in January; meanwhile, this group of drawings is offered, by way of reminding gallery-goers that in Pop Hart we have lost a draftsman of peculiar distinction and a penetrating, shrewd and always warmly sympathetic commentator on the human pageant.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP). -- In their deal with the Cardinals, the Phillies took another step in their reconstruction work for 1934. Meanwhile, rumors persist that Chuck Klein, slugging Philadelphia outfielder, will be involved in the next transaction.

Dates were set yesterday afternoon for the international motor boat racing in Florida this Winter. Races will be held at New Smyrna on March 3 and 4, at Palm Beach on March 10 and 11 and at Miami Beach on March 16 and 17.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- "All is quiet on the Potomac" as far as the Soviet-American conversations are concerned. Or might not one call them negotiations by now? -- a word which today has been given high authority.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The prosperity of 1927 and 1928 was condemned by an overwhelming majority of Princeton students who recently answered a questionnaire submitted in a sophomore course in public speaking.

To football's roster of famous "Reds" add the name of Norman (Red) Franklin. He's in town from Corvallis, Ore., where men grow like redwood trees, and from what they say about him in his native habitat, Red Grange and Red Cagle were just two other backs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The bull movement in grains on the Board of Trade came to a halt today, and instead of increased buying resulting from the soaring sterling exchange, scattered liquidation developed owing to uncertainty regarding the future, and prices dropped rapidly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The text of the correspondence with President Roosevelt which led to the granting of an indefinite leave of absence to Secretary Woodin was made public at the White House today as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: The whirr of the motor has subsided and we realize that we have been taken for a ride since March 1 by a group of impractical theorists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Employes of the National Recovery Administration, believing it is now their turn to bargain collectively, have formed a local union of the American Federation of Government Employes, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Further sagging of domestic bonds occurred yesterday in trading much less active than recently. Most issues in the foreign loan group on the Stock Exchange were bid up briskly as the dollar weakened, several scoring new high marks since issuance.

After serving four hours of a sentence of five months imposed upon him for violating the Federal lottery law, Conrad H. Mann, Republican politician of Kansas City and a friend of Herbert Hoover, was pardoned yesterday by President Roosevelt.

Eleven properties, including the ten-story Warwick Arms apartment house at the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue and West Eightieth Street, were sold at foreclosure auctions in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. The four Manhattan parcels were bid in by plaintiffs, as were six of the Bronx holdings.

WARSAW, Nov. 15. -- The Polish capital had a foretaste today of future war. A sham gas and airplane attack made this city of 1,250,000 inhabitants a "dead" place, with only a few Red Cross detachments dressed in costumes not unlike those of sea divers, solitary policemen in gas masks, and firemen in the otherwise empty streets.

Bruno Walter, attentive to the cause of American composers, gave a hearing at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall to David Stanley Smith's "1929 -- A Satire, op. 66."

James J. Hoey, newly appointed Internal Revenue Collector, demanded a complete reorganization of the leadership of Tammany Hall yesterday, as it was learned that John F. Curry had been turned down flatly at the White House on demands for Federal patronage.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 15 (AP). -- Identification of three of the four Chicago defendants as occupants of an automobile he saw near the scene of the release of William Hamm the day $100,000 ransom was paid to his kidnappers, was made today by a farm hand.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- A number of trial races for the British challenger for the America's Cup will be sailed on the Solent between June 11 and 23, it was decided at a conference of the Yacht Racing Association today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address today before the Civil Works Conference delegates was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Definite progress in the negotiation looking toward Soviet recognition by the United States was reported at the White House today as the President held two conferences with Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15. -- United States firms whose funds are blocked here by refusal of the exchange control commission to permit remittance abroad have received the choice of lending these funds to the Argentine Government for fifteen years at 2 per cent interest or for twenty years at 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Secretary Wallace, predicting that the Farm Administration's $500,000,000 corn-hog production control program would be a "big success," returned today from the Middle West, where he made three addresses to explain the aims of the Roosevelt program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The changes in the personnel of the Treasury which the President announced today have with one notable exception been foreshadowed.

DUNEDIN, N.Z., Nov. 15 (by wireless). -- Released from its wooden bed where for four months it had tossed more violently than it ever will in the air, the Northrop Gamma monoplane in which Lincoln Ellsworth and Bernt Balchen, his pilot, hope to span the Antarctic Continent was placed ashore on a Dunedin wharf today.

A lengthy dummy scrimmage featured yesterday's three-hour drill of the New York University football team at Ohio Field, where the Violet continued preparations for Saturday's battle with Rutgers at the Yankee Stadium.

Herbert Nolan, former prison guard, was found guilty of manslaughter of the first degree in the killing of his 28-year-old wife. The verdict was returned last night by a jury before County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn that had deliberated for six and one-half hours.

The fast-skating Detroit Red Wings will furnish the opposition for the New York Rangers tonight at Madison Square Garden to inaugurate a new National Hockey League season in this city. Interest in the battle is at a high point, and indications are that a near capacity crowd of 15,000 will attend.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 15. -- Cold weather today forced the Brown football squad to hold a dummy scrimmage in the gymnasium. A long forward-passing session was followed by a half-hour signal drill under floodlights outdoors.

IT'S just as well that the Rangers have returned to do some skating on their home rink. In two efforts on alien ice they were held for downs and no gain. On the part of Stanley Cup guardians, this was rather undignified, to say the least. It is to be hoped that they have been sitting up nights sharpening their skates for the opening festival in the Garden this evening.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- As this city today paid its municipal and school employes their Nov. 1 salaries, totaling $1,200,000, it faced the need of paying $2,800,000 on Dec. 1 on tax notes held by New York banks.
Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, the French Consul General, won the admiration yesterday of eminent chefs at the National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace.
Tammany added another victim to its list of reprisals yesterday when Michael J. Sheehan, a McKee supporter, was dismissed as an investigator in the Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- A definite decision by the government to finance experiments with floating landing fields for airplanes with a view to the early establishment of a commercial airway across the Atlantic Ocean was announced today by Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce.

Both the New York Junior League and the Heights Casino teams scored victories yesterday to remain in a first place tie in the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association interclub team league. New York group.
A division of "spoils" among a group of East Side children has resulted in the loss of nearly $3,000 to a butcher and yesterday caused the arrest of the 49-year-old mother of one of the children.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Navigation facilities for guiding planes from one to another of the seadromes to whose establishment the government has decided to extend aid, as well as from land stations, have been the subject of long and scientific study.

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- At the end of last night's debate in the Chamber of Deputies a witty Frenchman exclaimed, "Well, we are out of the trenches now." He meant that the long warfare for peace, which had been carried on for fifteen years within the defense lines of the Treaty of Versailles and the League of Nations, was over.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Eight registration statements for the issuance of securities totaling about $5,000,000 were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission as follows:

Cuts in governmental costs more drastic in some respects than those in the $25,000,000 economy program put forward last September by the Municipal Economy Commission are recommended in a report sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, its financial adviser.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Employes of the Weirton Steel Company of Weirton, W. Va., in affidavits filed with the National Labor Board today, alleged that they were being coerced into voting for a company union rather than for one affiliated with the American Federation of Labor at the forthcoming election of spokesmen for collective bargaining Dec. 11.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York voted yesterday to support the Seatrain Lines, Inc., in its petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an order obliging the railroads of New England and the Southwest to cooperate in its rail-water freight service between Hoboken, Havana and New Orleans.

Suitable books are as necessary to the growing child as good food, according to Miss Anne Carroll Moore, superintendent of work with children. New York Public Library. Miss Moore was one of four speakers at a symposium yesterday on children's books of 1933 at the Woodward School, 321 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.
Several flats and an industrial plot were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Eight of Britain's most eminent artists agreed last night that the "long-lost Holbein portrait" of Henry VIII found recently at Castle Howard was not painted by Holbein at all.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Snow and a driving wind hampered the Princeton football squad today in its preparation for the Navy game. A long passing drill and signal practice featured the session.

The official version of what happened on Tuesday in the offices of the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board during the visit of three State Senators in search of application blanks was released yesterday in the absence of Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State board.

The Recovery party, which vainly attempted to elect Joseph V. McKee as Mayor, finds itself with a deficit of approximately $80,000, it was learned yesterday. The resources of the organization total between $20,000 and $30,OOO, while its debts amount to about $109,000.

An alleged deficiency in the income tax return of United States Attorney George Z. Medalie for 1928, before he assumed the Federal post here, was examined yesterday by the United States Board of Tax Appeals, sitting in the Hotel New Yorker.

The city set up two barriers blocking the rails of the viaduct at the entrance to the municipal ferry house at St. George, S.I., yesterday in an effort to substitute buses for trolley cars. The Richmond Railways Company, however, defeated the attempt, first by crashing through the barriers and then by destroying a more formidable substitute.

RIDGELAND, S.C., Nov. 15. -- William K. Vanderbilt Jr., 26, was fatally injured today when the automobile he was driving at a high speed struck a fruit truck parked at the side of the national highway in this town, about thirty miles north of Savannah, Ga.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- President Roosevelt reluctantly granted to Secretary of the Treasury Woodin today an indefinite leave of absence to recuperate from a serious illness. The President declined to accept a resignation proffered by Mr. Woodin on Oct. 31.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 15. -- John J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, sharply criticized the government tonight for regulating railroads and making them try to be self-sustaining while such tests were not applied to rival forms of transportation.

William M. Chadbourne, Fusion campaign manager, president of the Honest Ballot Association, Harvard graduate, member of leading clubs in New York, Washington, Paris and London, and wearer of the Legion of Honor, among other distinctions, appeared yesterday as a defendant on a charge of disorderly conduct in the Tombs magistrate's court.
