BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Germany intends to remain a sideline spectator it of the disarmament manoeuvres it discerns going on in London, Paris and Geneva until these "feelers" have crystallized into something tangible. She has not been notified that the broken pieces of the Geneva negotiations have been fixed again.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Yale resumed football practice today under weather conditions so chilly that Head Coach Root ordered the first and second elevens indoors for the early part of the drill.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday that its net profit for the third quarter of the year was more than twice as large as that for the second quarter. For the three months ended on Sept. 30, the net profit was $3,773,130, which was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 23 cents a share on the common stock.
The Columbia football team held one of its longest and most strenuous sessions of the year yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions reached their peak in preparation for their contest with Lafayette.

The American Securities Investing Corporation, the so-called bond pool organized in June, 1932, by the twenty largest banks and banking houses in this city to purchase sound bonds for the "long pull," is being liquidated, it was indicated yesterday in an announcement by Thomas W. Lament of J.P. Morgan Co., president of the corporation.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- An assertion that the only women's club which would survive was the one which was definitely serving its community was made today by Mrs. Charles J. Reeder of Carthage, a former president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

A sharp decline in dollar exchange caused an upturn in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the market met contracts, resulting in reactions that left the list 1 to 3 points higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The War Department disapproved today plans for the construction of a bridge across the Hudson at Fifty-seventh Street, New York, mainly for the reason that, in the opinion of the department, the bridge would come into "direct and powerful competition" with the new Hudson River vehicular tunnel at Thirty-eighth Street, toward the construction of which the Public Works Administration advanced on Aug. 29 $37,500,000.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- There is so much more than routine to worry the British Government at the present moment that after today's regular Cabinet meeting an emergency session was held tonight to consider the European situation. The pressure of public opinion against letting the disarmament conference die in its tracks is becoming too strong for the government to ignore it.
NEW YORK. Lady Cunliffe-Owen, wife of Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen, Bart, of London, is at the Waldorf-Astoria accompanied by Mrs. Winifred Rossell.

The first of a series of four public hearings sponsored by the National Recovery Administration's New York Committee on the use of leisure time, of which Raymond B. Fosdick is chairman, will be held this afternoon at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

A sale of unusual interest and importance was closed yesterday in the high-class apartment section adjacent to the East River, when an investor paid all cash for a group of old tenements which will be rebuilt into a five-story elevator apartment house with a spacious inner court and garden.

MANITOWOC, Wis., Nov. 15. -- George Vits, president of the Aluminum Goods Manufacturing Company, this city's largest industry, and Republican National Committeeman, died at his home tonight after an illness of more than two years.

The dollar fell to more than 40 per cent discount in the foreign exchange market yesterday. Ignoring the mildly "bullish" implications in the action of the RFC of posting the same price for newly mined gold as on Tuesday, $33.56, the world markets fastened upon the news of Secretary Woodin's long leave of absence and Under-Secretary Dean Acheson's resignation as the day's outstanding guides to administration monetary policy.

VALENTIA, Ireland, Nov. 15. -- The fate of the little British freighter Saxilby, whose crew of twenty-seven was reported to be abandoning ship in a raging North Atlantic storm, was hidden tonight as ships raced to her rescue.

New Uses for Wealth. A granddaughter of the late F.W. WOOLWORTH came of age yesterday and into full possession of one-third of a fortune estimated at $60,000,000. The young woman frankly states that she and her husband, whom she recently married, expect to devote the respectable sum of $20,000,000 to having a good time in each other's company.

The northwest gale, freighted with snow, that descended from Canada upon the Great Lakes region Monday continued with unabated violence yesterday, causing a total of seven deaths in various sections. Zero and subzero weather followed in its wake.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Nov. 16. -- In an effort to checkmate the Fukien Province independent movement, Premier Wang Ching-wel announced today an invitation had been sent to Hu Han-min, a leader of the disaffected element, to return to Nanking and rejoin the government, assuming some important post.

BOWEE, Md., Nov. 15. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Brown Witch captured the Capitol City Purse, feature today as the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association's meeting, which is the last of the Eastern season, got away to a successful start despite cold weather.

Japan is a commercial client of the United States, eager to develop the trade of both nations, Kensuke Horinouchi, Consul General of Japan, told the Foreign Commerce Club of New York last night at the Hotel Astor. Charges that the Japanese were "dumping" goods in the markets of the United States and Europe were denied by Mr. Horinouchi, who cited commodity price indices and exchange rates to support his stand.

At a meeting yesterday of the International Racing Committee of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., it was announced that a challenge for the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup had been received from the Royal Northern Yacht Club of Glasgow, Scotland, and that it had been accepted.

Mr. UNTERMYER'S report to the Board of Estimate is in some respects a surprising document. No Fusion orator could have done a better job exposing the waste and extravagance of Tammany government. In his detailed description of sinecures and "sacred cows" he spares neither individuals nor institutions, and he certainly is not sparing of adjectives.

Mrs. Clara Wridgway, who brought about the capture of a nest of German spies during the World War, was found yesterday to be destitute and living in dread of eviction. With her, but unable to help, was her son, Walter, a war veteran, who had a nervous breakdown soon after his enlistment in the army and whose mentality is impaired.

NEWCASTLE, England, Nov. 15. -- A smart Welsh eleven today defeated England, 2 to 1, and thereby clinched the international professional soccer championship. There is one international match yet to be played, England against Scotland at Wembley next April, but it cannot affect the Welshmen's lead.

Directors of the New York Travelers Aid Society drafted a "questionnaire" for philanthropists yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Percy S. Straus, 875 Park Avenue. Acting as individuals rather than as officials of the society, they prepared questions to assist contributors to welfare agencies in determining which appeals to heed and which to ignore.

The National Recovery Act was escribed yesterday as having paralyzing effect upon industry and business generally in this country by Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board of 247 Park Avenue.

Money market was dormant. Renewals of expiring obligations made up all of the day's business, little new money being taken in any section. Quotations for call loans, maturity money and business paper were all steady and unchanged from the previous day.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- The General Electric Company has received a radiogram from Admiral Richard E. Byrd, stating that the first radio program sent to him and his expedition over W2XAF had been received and was much enjoyed.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- Alexander Steinert, one of the country's leading patrons of art and music and for many years head of M. Steinert Sons, piano manufacturers, 162 Boylston Street, died suddenly at his home, 401 Commonwealth Avenue, today, after a brief illness.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Crashing her way through mountainous seas the giant liner Berengaria was rushing through darkness tonight to rescue twenty-nine seamen of the British 3,630-ton vessel Saxilby adrift in tiny lifeboats.

Close upon Armistice Day comes the like quinquennial anniversary of the Republic of Latvia. The independence of the three little Baltic republics and the "restitution" of Poland all came in the same year, 1918. Estonia celebrates its birthday in February, Lithuania in May, though it declared the dissolving of its bonds" in February, and Latvia and Poland in November.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 15. -- Chancery Court Judge W.A. Moncure granted today a permanent injunction to Alfred Levinger of New York, a director of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation, ruling that the election of eight directors of the company on Oct. 11 was unlawful because of the lack of a quorum of all classes of stock.
The East River Savings Bank has made a $700,000 first mortgage loan on the fifteen-story Havemeyer Building, on the east side of Church Street from Cortlandt to Dey Streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Today's hearing of the informal investigation by three members of the House Immigration Committee into the alleged circulation in the United States of German Nazi propaganda ended abruptly with Chairman Dickstein rapping for order and commanding police to clear the room.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A basis for alloting the $400,000,000 civil works fund was announced tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator. Asserting that "unemployment follows population," he said the administration proposed to allot the jobs to be created 75 per cent according to population and 25 per cent unemployment or relief needs.
The growing importance of corporation history was stressed last night at a dinner conference on industrial history at the Faculty Club of Columbia University.

Dr. and Mrs. John A. Vietor gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home at 1,107 Fifth Avenue to introduce their daughter, Miss Eleanore T. Vietor. The debutante wore a frock of red velvet and carried a bouquet of gardenias, and her mother also was gowned in red velvet and carried a bouquet of or-chids.

The Actors Equity Association will resume its course of lectures in an effort to acquaint newly elected members with their responsibilities and impart historical information of a theatrical nature. Classes will be held at Equity headquarters, 45 West Forty-seventh Street, starting next Monday at 3 o'clock.

Slow selling pressure unsettled most of the security and commodity markets yesterday. This fresh weakness coincided with another violent dislocation in foreign exchanges, in the course of which the dollar, groping for a landing place, reached a new low mark.

HAVANA, Nov. 15 (AP) . -- A verdict recommending the death penalty for two aviators convicted of being leaders in a rebellion, last week which cost 150 lives was in the hands of President Ramon Grau San Martin tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The action of the Federal Relief Organization yesterday in buying the Monday carry-over of hogs failed today to change the attitude of packers toward the market, and the deadlock on the chioce kinds showed no signs of being broken.
BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Renewed efforts to smooth over the difficulties between the Reich and the Papacy arising from conflicting interpretations of the concordat concluded last July are in preparation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Bertram Cutler, financial adviser for thirty-two years to the Rockefellers, completely contradicted testimony by Willim S. Fitzpatrick today that he and the Rockefellers had arranged payment of $300,000 to Mr. Fitzpatrick from profits reaped in a Sinclair oil stock purchasing pool in 1929.

The Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, 49 West Twentieth Street, receives a bequest of $10,000 under the will of Mrs. Margaret B. Gilbert, who died at Beverly Hills, Calif., on Nov. 4. Her will was filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court.
A powerful Oregon State team arrived in New York yesterday, completing its transcontinental journey which began last Saturday night.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Three men, two of whom were here during the early stages of the O'Connell kidnapping investigation, were sought today as suspected participants in the abduction of the young member of the political family.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- President Roosevelt today signed the air transport code under the NRA, without the minimum-wage and maximum-hour provisions for pilots, which had been strenuously opposed by the fliers. The code goes into effect Nov. 27.

Hampered by ill health from the Very beginning of his term of office, Secretary WOODIN has heeded the warning of his physician and taken an indefinite leave of absence. He naturally thought it proper to offer his resignation, but the President, with expressions of the warmest personal friendship, refused to accept it.

Allen Deutch, formerly employed by the Square Deal Laundry of Brooklyn, testified yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, that Philip Schlanger, a State's witness in the recent laundry racket trial, had threatened him with violence in the event of his refusal to quit the Square Deal employ.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press). -- The Lamaque Gold Mines Company's property in Quebec, optioned by Teck-Huges Gold Mines, Ltd., has good prospect of developing into a paying producer, officials of the latter company announced today at its annual meeting here.

When the offices of the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board closed last night on the six-day rush for applications for licenses to sell liquors and wines for "off-the-premises" consumption the board had distributed well over 5,000 sets of blanks and had received for filing 1,568 applications.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Representative Dickstein, chairman of the House Immigration and Naturalization Committee wrote today to the managers of the George Washington Hotel in New York City asking them to appear here before his informal committee group on Dec. 5 with a complete record of hotel guests and scheduled meetings for two weeks prior to and including Oct. 7.

NANKING, Nov. 16. -- General Tsai Ting-kai, Field Commander of the famous Nineteenth Route Army, and other South China commanders are reported to be not sympathetic with the Fukien Province independence movement.

WARSAW, Nov. 16. -- The declaration of non-aggression that Chancellor Hitler of Germany made last night to Joseph Lipsky, the Polish Minister to Germany, is regarded here as "a most important European event."

Calling for support of the American Red Cross "in order that this splendid relief and educational organization may continue its wonderful work," Major Gen. James G. Harbord broadcast a plea last night for enrolment in the annual rollcall now being conducted.

Isidor J. Kresel, former counsel for the defunct Bank of United States, was reported yesterday to be ill In bed at his apartment in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue. The illness, according to Theodore Kiendl, counsel for Mr. Kresel, had resulted from the shock of his conviction Wednesday on a charge of abetting the misapplication of about $2,000,000 in funds of the closed bank.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were alternately strong and weak today. An early bulge was followed by a break, while a strong rally toward the close carried prices to a new high level for the day. The finish was well toward the top.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Sir Herbert Samuel, in a radio broadcast tonight, made the long-expected announcement that his thirty-three Liberals would "cross the floor" to join the opposition when Parliament reassembles Tuesday.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Agreement has been reached for amalgamation of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Standard Stock and Mining Exchange, Harold Franks, president of the Toronto exchange, announced today.

In a final heavy drive for its concluding contest of the season, Fordham's football squad was sent through a long and fast workout at Fordham Field yesterday. The Rams will clash with the strong Oregon State eleven at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

As if to emphasize their repudiation of a once popular inflationary theory, the stock and commodity markets engaged yesterday in a broad recovery simultaneously with a sharp increase in the dollar's exchange value. Whatever the real explanation may have been, there were widely circulated reports that government agencies were seeking to make it more difficult to transfer capital to foreign countries.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The dollar plunged to a new post-war low level today. From the overnight rate of $5.40 to the pound sterling it fell to $5.49, thereafter fluctuating to $5.42 and closing at $5.50. The price of gold here was lower at 128s 6d an ounce.
BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- German official ears are close to the ground tonight in an endeavor to pick up everberations of developments abroad that may put a new face on the disarmament impasse.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Nov. 16. -- By pulling a lever twice, the pilot of a transport-type airplane ejected three men and a woman today through doors in the sides of the fuselage and, sitting calmly in the chairs in which they had been riding, they floated down to the field in safety.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 17. -- A less panicky feeling about the currency situation was noticeable in London today, although the dollar continued to plunge downward toward the 50-cent level. Dealings closed at $5.50 to the pound before news of the spectacular afternoon rally in New York could make itself felt here.

ELMIRA, N.T., Nov. 16. -- The State Federation of Women's Clubs voted today to follow the Tugwell Bill to Washington to try to obtain the passage of a substitute for the present Pure Food and Drugs Law, provided the federation's constituents make no serious objection.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Nov. 14:

Commodities traded in local market followed the general trend yesterday in ignoring the recovery of the dollar and all closed with good gains on the day. Trading continued active on all exchanges. In the cash markets, prices were generally higher.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- A new British effort to revive the disarmament conference will be begun tomorrow when Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, and Captain Anthony Eden, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, start for Geneva.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 16. -- Student riots today in the cities of Guadalajara and Durango were reported over the telephone by students tonight. No other source of information was available because local censorships had been established, government officials here admitting there had been riots, but refusing details.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Hope was abandoned today for the twenty-seven seamen of the British freighter Saxilby who were forced to take to lifeboats in a terrific North Atlantic gale yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The first protests against proposed oil prices were placed on the record today after Secretary Ickes, the Oil Administrator, had advised the oil industry that, to give both sides an opportunity to present their views, prices probably would not be fixed as scheduled on Dec. 1.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- A crowd of thousands of political factionists today stormed the Scottish Rite Cathedral, where the special United States Senate committee has been conducting investigations into the election of Senator John H. Overton, and Senators Connally and Overton were forced to enter the building by a fire escape and through the ladies' washroom.

Inefficient methods of handling cargoes and lack of suitable means for detecting and preventing fire at sea were criticized yesterday in papers read at the opening of the annual two-day meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Norman B. Mackie of Princeton will give a dance tomorrow evening at their home to present to society their daughter, Miss Marian Mackie.

PARIS, Nov, 16. -- Simultaneously with the announcement of an agreement between Poland and Germany to begin direct negotiations, which was prefaced by an oral declaration of non-aggression, the Petit Pariaien this morning published a document purporting to bo secret instructions from the central bureau of propaganda in Berlin, headed by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, to agents abroad.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Senator Norris of Nebraska said tonight that selfish ambition to accumulate money must be curbed by law if civilization is to stand.

Day's Gold Developments. The dollar again declined in foreign exchange yesterday, then rallied sharply on reports that restrictions had been placed by exchange control on the flight of capital, rather than on an apparent endeavor on the part of Washington to apply the brakes by leaving the RFC quotation for gold unchanged for the second successive day.

At the annual dinner of The Evening Post Alumni Association, made up of men and women who formerly worked on The New York Evening Post, a medal was awarded last night to Charles A. Selden, London correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, under the terms of the annual award made by the association.

John F. Galvin has resigned as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority and will Join its executive staff next week as director of port development at an annual salary of $12,000, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Galvin's resignation has been accepted by Governor Lehman, but the acceptance was not announced formally by the Governor because of his illness.

It was predicted that Chancellor HITLER would, directly after the election of Nov. 12, issue a resounding proclamation about Germany's international policy. It might be to declare the Versailles treaty no longer binding. Short of that, it might announce the intention of the German Government to create and equip an army of any size it desired.

After holding within a narrow range for several hours yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 20 points, or a dollar a bale, under the heaviest buying since the upward movement started, and ended at the top at gains of 11 to 15 points.

Continuing yesterday through the third successive day, the cold wave reached its lowest point at 5:50 A. M., when the Weather Bureau thermometer atop the Whitehall Building registered 16.7 degrees above zero.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Mary McCormic, opera singer, told today how and why she slapped the woman biographer of the three "marrying Mdivanis" in a newspaper office last night.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Economies amounting to 2,361,000,000 francs were proposed in a financial reconstruction project that the French Government submitted to the Chamber of Deputies today. [The franc was quoted yesterday at 6.42 1/2 cents.]

The stockholder in industrial companies will have to foot the larger part of the bill for national recovery In the form of decreased dividends, Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of State, told Columbia University's Institute of Arts and Sciences in a lecture last night.

October Store Collections Up. Retail collections increased 2.21 per cent during October, according to the index based on twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The gain compares with a drop of 0.74 per cent in October a year ago and of 2.52 per cent last September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The administration's long-range policy for control of the supply of hard liquor and for protection of dry territory from invasion following probibtion repeal was reported today to be virtually complete.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Ruth Potter, a sophomore at Greenburgh High School, wrote Governor Lehman a week ago asking his aid in getting $250 by Nov. 24 so her family, which includes her parents and seven sisters, will not lose their one-story frame home at 26 Dobbs Ferry Road, Greenburgh.

The first Federal Indictment for violation of an NRA code to be found in the United States, according to United States Attorney Howard W. Ameli in Brooklyn, was handed up to Judge Clarence G. Galston in the United States District Court in that borough yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- There were indications today of a temporary moderation in the administration's gold purchase policy, when the price at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will accept newly mined domestic gold again was fixed at $33.56, the same figure quoted yesterday and Tuesday, and intimations were given in at least one official quarter that purchases abroad in the last twenty-four hours, if any, had been of little consequence.

Senator Eimer Thomas of Oklahoma, inflationist leader, defended the present gold buying operations of the administration in a speech here last night in which he said there was no danger of a repetition of the German and Russian systems of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Soviet-American negotiations have illustrated something which perhaps is not generally appreciated by people who live here, hut which strikes a visitor most pentratingly, to with the development of realism in this city of Washington which is the seat of the government of the United States.

A reduction of $20,000,000 in railway rates charged for the movement of relief supplies was ratified yesterday at a meeting of the Eastern presidents' conference. It was understood that like action was taken in the Southwest and West.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The disturbance from Alaska has moved rapidly southeastward to Manitoba and the Dakotas, and another disturbance is now moving eastward over Alaska. Pressure remains low over Hudson Strait and Greenland.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The American plan for an airline across the North Atlantic, with floating decks as intermediary landing places, has aroused considerable interest In Germany, which proposes to start a similar line across the South Atlantic early next year.

The statement of net Income by the Pennsylvania Railroad for the first nine months of this year showed that the company earned $1 a share on its capital stock in that period. The company paid in March a dividend of 50 cents on its stock, which is of $50 par value.
PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The Bank of France's statement for the week ending Nov. 9 shows a loss of 730,000,000 francs in gold.

Emil E. Shauer, vice president of the Paramount International Corporation, who had been an important executive in the motion picture industry for twenty years, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 241 Central Park West.

Heavyweight boxers will provide the feature attraction In Madison Square Garden tonight, when Steve Hamas, former athletic star at Penn State, opposes Lee Ramage of California in a ten-round bout. The battle, originally listed as the semi-final to the Ben Jeby-Young Terry encounter, was moved to the main spot when Terry withdrew because of illness.

Greatly concerned over the unseasonably cold weather and the frozen state of the field, Lon Stiner, the youthful coach of the Oregon State football team, sent his squad of young huskies through a short, brisk workout at the Polo Grounds yesterday in preparation for the game with Fordham tomorrow in the Giants' baseball park.

Twenty paintings, sixteen of them eighteenth-century British portraits, brought $125,000 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The prices were among the highest realized at auction here during the depression.

Twenty paintings, sixteen of them eighteenth-century British portraits, brought $125,000 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The prices were among the highest realized at auction here during the depression.

At the meeting yesterday of the American Power Boat Association, motor boating's largest organization in this country, Horace E. Dodge of Detroit voiced an insistent demand for superchargers next year on Gold Cup boats, a class in which he individually has been among the most active participants with his series of craft named Delphine.

Some sales figures on "Life Begins at Forty," by Walter B. Pitkin, are submitted by McGraw-Hill, publishers of the book. In its first year of publication, which ended last month, the book sold 64,000 copies. Since Oct. 23, 13,400 more copies have been sold, and 30,000 more are now on the presses.
NEW YORK. Miss Elizabeth Chew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Chew, will give a luncheon Nov. 23 at the Plaza, for Miss Mary I. Brown, debutante daughter of Mrs. Harold McC. Brown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- President Roosevelt chatted over tea cups this evening with J.P. Morgan, the New York financier, and Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation.

Criss-Cross Trades. A barber, truly observed, does not belong entirely to the Personal Service trades. To some extent he may be said to be engaged in manufacturing and mining. A college professor is not exclusively in the Professional group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Unprecedented regulation of trading in grains, including the policing of individual contracts by an independent agent or "supervisor," is provided in a proposed code of fair competition for all grain exchanges, which was laid before Secretary Wallace today and assigned for public hearing on Nov. 27.

DUNEDIN, N.Z., Nov. 16 (By Wireless). -- Busy inspecting and sorting his polar equipment now being aired in the long sheds on Dunedin's wharves, Lincoln Ellsworth, leader of the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition, must also find time to answer the numerous requests to render service which he receives from day to day.

The advance in tank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday over the preceding week was substantially less than in the corresponding period last year, "with the result that the gain in the total oyer last year was somewhat reduced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A difference of opinion within the administration over government financing of transatlantic seadrome experiments developed today in the denial by Secretary Ickes that $1,500,000 had been allocated by the Public Works Administration for the first test of the project originated by Edward K. Armstrong.

Several hundred priests, including Bishop Thomas E. Malloy, and many public officials attended a requiem mass yesterday for Mgr. William T. McGuirl, rector of St. Joseph'a Roman Catholic Church, 856 Pacific Street, Brookly, who died on Monday of bronchial pneumonia.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, as the leader of German Protestantism, agreed tonight to promulgate a law rescinding all church laws adopted by the States or the nation in recent months, including the so-called "Aryan" statute.

With a sharp advance of 1.9 points, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 104.9 on Tuesday, from 103 on Monday, Nov. 6. The advance was, however, much more than offset by a fresh decline of the dollar to a new low of 60.7 cents from 64.4, and the index on a gold basis consequently fell to 63.7 from 66.3.

The daily reports of commercial leases in Manhattan are giving constant evidence of increasing activity in store and office rentals by wine and liquor merchants and manufacturers. Several such contracts were included in lists announced by brokers yesterday.

In the first court decision concerning President Roosevelt's policies on gold hoarding, the United States District Court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the Anti-Hoarding Act passed on March 9.

Katharine Hepburn vill arrive today by airplane from Hollywood to begin rehearsals of "The Lake," which Jed Harris intends to present at the Martin Beck Theatre on Dec. 26. The play will begin an out-of-town tour at the National Theatre in Washington on Dec. 11, and play the following week at the Garrick Theatre in Philadelphia.

The problem of affording opportunities for the use of leisure time is primarily one for consideration by local governments rather than by the Federal administration, Newton D. Baker and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said yesterday.

Tomorrow at the stadium In the New Hampshire hills at Dartmouth one of the always interesting clashes of the season will develop when Cornell invades the tepee of the Dartmouth Indian. Judging by the weather of the past few days throughout the East, it will be a frozen, contest, for the Green is famed as the home of Winter sports and rugged, old-fashioned Winters.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Activity on the Boerse, which recently had been confined mainly to fixed-interest securities, gained breadth and momentum today and led to price advances among active stocks ranging up to 5 per cent. Heavy industrial, metal, automobile, electrical, public utility, chemical, textile and some construction issues participated in the upswing, while potash, brewery and shipping stocks remained rather soft.

Alfred E. Smith, Ogden L. Mills and Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow joined last night in an urgent plea for support for the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $4,000,000 for relief to be administered through accredited welfare agencies. The form
HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- Sergeant Basilio Gonzalez and Private Homobono Rodriguez have been sentenced to face firing squads as leaders of the revolutionary movement of Nov. 8, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Presidents of more than forty of the largest banks in the United States are being subpoenaed by stock market Investigators seeking to learn to what extent bank loans were used for stock speculation from 1929 to 1933.
PARIS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Sportsmen of Putnam and Westchester Counties are taking the lead in a drive which promises to extend to many other congested areas of the State. The drive has as its objective the enactment of new and restrictive hunting laws and the clarification of existing regulations contained in the fish and game code of New York State.

THROUGH four successive volumes of his "Our Times" Mark Sullivan has brought an "Open, Sesame" to an American reading public that is nostalgic for the good old days before the World War, when life ran along in a groove. Looking back to the early century, many have caught brief, tantalizing, half-remembered glimpses of a Golden Age.

The policies and some of the personnel of the Federal administration were hotly attacked by three speakers last night at the annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Injuries will keep two of Columbia's outstanding linemen out of action when the Lions meet Lafayette tomorrow at Baker Field.

Mr. JAMES J. HOEY, who is about to collect internal revenue taxes, has been good enough to favor the world with a collection of his thoughts. These are not only valuable in themselves, but because they are shared by two other deep students of polity and friends of reform, Mr. FARLEY of Washington and Mr. FLYNN of the Bronx.
"Cradle Song," Dorothea Wieck's first American film, will be presented at the Paramount this morning.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh began today a series of studies of weather conditions and meteorological data looking toward the establishment of a transatlantic air route.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16. -- Tambour, frequently referred to as one of the best racing mares in Maryland, today won the W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap, feature at the Bowie course where another charity program was held. It was an appropriate victory since the horse was bred and is owned and trained by Preston M. Burch, son of the man for whom the race is a memorial.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 16. -- The mystery of the kidnapping of Brooke Hart, 22 years old and son of a wealthy merchant here, ended in a tragic solution today with the arrest of two men and the announcement by the authorities that the pair had confessed to murdering the youth, hurling his body into San Francisco Bay an hour after he disappeared and then demanding $40,000 for returning him "alive."

Samuel Untermyer's report recommending budget cuts of $35,000,000 will be considered next Tuesday afternoon, when Controller George McAneny convenes the Mayor's committee on balancing the budget for its first session in his office.

The Retail Code Authority of New York City denied last night the petition of a retailer employing about 1,500 persons for an exception of the code's provisions to permit him to pay a minimum of $12 a week instead of $14.
The New York Rangers opened their eighth home season in the National Hockey League last night, when, they clashed with the Detroit Red Wings in Madison Square Garden.

The body of William K. Vanderbilt Jr., who was killed in an automobile accident on Wednesday at Ridgeland, S.C., while driving from Miami, Fla., to New York, arrived at the Pennsylvania Station at 5:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in a private car.

Vera de Villiers, British contralto, made her American debut last night in the Town Hall with a program largely composed of beautiful songs that singers do not often use. The first group comprised works of Monteverde, Scarlatti, Martini, Dowland, Carey and an old French song her second, Brahms's "Gestillte Sehnsucht" and "Geistliches Wiegenlied," with viola accompaniment played by Egon Kornstein.

Open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System, which had been undergoing rapid curtailment for five weeks, reached the vanishing point in the week ended on Wednesday, when only $1,500,000 of United States Government securities was bought.

A "code" for roller skaters designed to decrease the mounting list of accidents was offered yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters. Because of the rapid spread of the fad, mishaps are from two to five times more frequent than a year ago, it was said by Albert W. Whitney, associate general manager of the bureau, who made public the results of a roller skating survey in twenty American cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil at the close of the week ended on Nov. 11 amounted to 343,395,000 barrels, a decrease of 776,000 barrels from the total of 344,171,000 barrels reported for the preceding week, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and administrator of the code of fair competition for the petroleum industry, announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Keren Osborne Warner of Pleasantville, widow of Dr. Lucien C. Warner, New York chemist and manufacturer, left the bulk of an estate of $260,000 to her four children, one of whom is Mrs. Agnes Warner Mastick, wife of State Senator Seabury C. Mastick of Fleasantville, according to her will filed today. Mrs. Warner died Oct. 23.

Success of the Crusade for Children is a vital necessity to the city, Owen B. Lovejoy, chairman of the steering committee, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore. The Crusade is a drive by six child-welfare agencies to raise $400,000 to help homeless children.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 17. -- The Cabinet begins today consideration of the draft budget which, though 221,000,000 yen ($70,432,000 at the current rate) less than last year's, is the second largest in Japan's history during peace.

WHITES PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Abraham Borsun, 48 years old, of 249 West Eightieth Street, New York, secretary for Local 302 of Cafeteria and Countermen's Union, died this afternoon at the Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, of bullet wounds inflicted when he was taken for a "ride" last Saturday night.

A line of steel and cement floating islands across the Atlantic to serve as landing stations for airplanes carrying a heavier paying load than is now possible -- it is a dull imagination that fails to kindle at the suggestion. For sixteen years EDWARD R. ARMSTRONG has been urging this method of correcting Nature's forgetfulness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- An effort to shift the 1936 Olympics from Berlin to some country other than Germany because of the activities of the Hitler government against Jews will be made at the quadrennial meeting here next week of the American Olympic Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: T.L. Fitch in a letter to THE TIMES quotes Secretary Ickes as saying: "If a municipality makes a survey and wants to build its own plant, it is not our business whether they have made up their minds wisely or not. They come here with their plans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Investigation of fabricated steel imports from France, Germany and the Saar Basin has failed to disclose evidence of unfair competition with American steel, Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, indicated today.

The Nazi investigation undertaken by Representative Samuel Dickstein by virtue of his position as chairman of the House Committee on Immigration and without waiting for the return of Congress, was pronounced "unofficial and irresponsible" yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, president of the World Jewish Federation and of the Nonsectarian League for the Defense of Jewish Rights, who are conducting the world boycott of German goods and services.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, gave its first New York program of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, with a finale, in the form of Sibelius's Second symphony, which drew shouts and cheers from the audience.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Syracuse University football squad engaged in its first outdoor practice of the week in snow-covered Archbold Stadium today. Saturday the Orange meets Colgate for the thirty-fifth time.

Trade unionism will become entrenched throughout American industry as a result of the impetus given it by the NRA, Sumner H. Slichter, Professor of Business Economics at the Harvard Graduate School of Business, declared yesterday at the twelfth annual Autumn conference of the Personnel Research Federation in the Hotel Astor.

Scoring its third straight triumph in as many starts, the Harvard Club team No. 1 last night took undisputed possession of first place in the Class A tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. The Harvard players conquered the Union League Squash Club, 5 to 0, taking every match in straight games.

MADRID, Nov. 16. -- Twenty-four Socialists were killed today when a truck carrying twenty-five home to Huescar from a politcal meeting at Castrial, near Granada, plunged off a bridge 250 feet down into a river.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- When the President first announced that William H. Woodin, a business man, was to be Secretary of the Treasury, the prevailing comment was that clearly Mr. Roosevelt intended to be "his own Secretary of the Treasury." The same reflections appeared when Senator Hull of Tennessee, noted as an economist rather than as an expert in diplomatic matters, was chosen Secretary of State.

The American Hebrew Medal for the Promotion of Better Understanding between Christians and Jews In America will be awarded this year to Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, noted feminist, says an announcement in the issue of The American Hebrew out today.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Hubert ScottPaine established a new unofficial world's record for a single-engined motor boat today, driving Miss Britain III over a mile course on Southampton Water at 102.105 miles an hour against wind and tide.
BERLIN, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The new Nazi criminal code, containing some of the most drastic penal measures of modern court history, was made public tonight in detail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Cities and States will be asked, and expected, to contribute to the financing of new civil works projects on which it is designed to have 4,000,000 unemployed at work by Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Dr. W. I. Myers was named by President Roosevelt today to be governor of the Farm Credit Administration, succeeding Henry Morgenthau Jr., who will become Acting Secretary of the Treasury tomorrow.
JUST a moment while the party of the first part dons a couple of sets of shoulder harness and four or five headguards. There are a few kicks to run back.

Liberal liquor laws are essential if the bootlegging industry is to be stamped out, speaker after speaker declared last night at a dinner at the Commodore given by the New York State Hotel Association in honor of Arthur L. Race, chairman of the American Hotel Association's committee on prohibition repeal.

A movement to bring about the repeal of the tax on capital gains and the allowance for capital losses in both the Federal and State taxation programs will be initiated in the forthcoming sessions of Congress and the New York State legislature. The step was decided on yesterday by the board of directors of the Merchants' Association of New York after considering a report from its committee on taxation, headed by Laurence A. Tanzer.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 16 (AP), -- Injuries received today in an automobile accident resulted in the death of Harry Irving Clarkson, 35 years old, a Tulsa singer, and amputation of the right foot of Carlo Edwards, 43, assistant director of the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ending Nov. 15 were announced today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Recovery Administrator Johnson today issued a statement concerning working conditions of NRA office employes in connection with the announcement yesterday of the unionization of these employes.

Coty, Inc., and domeatic subsidiaries -- Nine months ended Sept. 30: Net income after Federal taxes, depreciation and other charges, $384,874, equal to 25 cents a share on 1,537,435 no-par capital shares, against $481,139, or 31 cents a share, in corresponding period of 1932.

For the second day in a row, the New York University football squad engaged in a dummy scrimmage at Ohio Field yesterday. The workout lasted for more than two hours and practically brought to a close preparations for tomorrow's battle with Rutgers at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- State officials estimated today that New York would receive $25,740,000 a month for unemployment relief' under the Federal civil works plan as long as the Federal civil works funds of $400,000,000 lasts.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 16. -- There is little doubt that the prospect of getting money from the government on corn loans is weakening the hold in Iowa of Milo Reno, president of the Farm Holiday Union. In Lemars, the centre of militancy in this State, farmers are being urged by their leaders to accept the cash and take a chance on the corn-hog program being a success.

ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 16. -- Irwin R. Silvers, an optometrist and a well-known business man of Orange, was held today in $10,000 bail by Federal authorities on a charge of conspiracy to harbor Verne C. Miller, a fugitive from justice.

At the New York office of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, 285 Madison Avenue, it was stated yesterday that the questionnaire on the relationship of banks and brokers was sent on Nov. 1 to fifty leading banks, including ten in New York.

The progress of the Sunday school movement in foreign countries was outlined yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the North American administrative committee of the World's Sunday School Association held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The consolidated balance sheet of the North American Company and subsidiaries on Sept. 30 showed current assets of $54,885,896, including $17,566,707 cash, $7,865,218 United States Government securities and $4,812,491 short-term investments. This compared with $46,173,418 current assets a year earlier, which included $18,059,507 cash, $6,068,359 government securities and no shortterm investments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The way was cleared for an announcement on Russian recognition tomorrow by a two-hour review tonight of subjects involved between President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Normania" is sweeping the country. We are trying to fit everything into patterns. We are being squeezed into inflexible molds in the hope that we will jell into one uniform, consistent mass. The norm has become the ideal. A man who invests his own money in a business is not allowed to conduct his own enterprise as he sees fit.

The Long Island Railroad will add seventy-one trains to its passenger schedule on Dec. 3, according to an announcement yesterday by George Le Boutillier, vice president. The experimental excursion fares established last May, which were to expire on Dec. 31, will be extended into 1934, he said.

Percy Crosby's first exhibition was in 1928, at the old Anderson Galleries. He exhibited again in 1931. According to Walter M. Grant, in a foreword to the third and current showing at Macbeth's, the artist's studies "have gone on unceasingly during the last two years and so he comes to the present exhibition partly retrospective, partly new, to greet an old audience and to create new friends."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Rutgers football team reported at full strength today for the first time since the Lafayette game. Heenan, veteran end, and Dan Van Mater, substitute fullback, were back in uniform.

The New York Stock Exchange was more closely linked with the Association of Stock Exchange Firms yesterday, when the latter organization, at the invitation of Richard Whitney, president of the Stock Exchange, elected five representatives who will meet regularly with the law committee of the Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the first state dinner of the season and of their administration, entertaining in honor of members of the Cabinet and their wives.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 16. -- A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Roma H. Wehrhane from Henry H. Wehrhane of New York on grounds of cruelty. In her suit she asked permission to assume the name of "Ware," though her maiden name was Connor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Since March more than 2,800,000 workers have returned to employment in a large group of manufacturing industries and sixteen non-manufacturing industries, and this represents more than three billion dollars put into payrolls in the seven months' period, according to Secretary of Labor Perkins, who announced the Labor Department's monthly payroll and employment figures today.
Two Jewish youths and a Catholic youth felt the sting of a judicial rebuke yesterday when County Judge Algernon I. Nova in Brooklyn told each that he was unworthy of the traditions of his religion.

Civil service reform scored another notable victory over the spoils system when the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court handed down a decision this week placing all the forty-eight assistant clerks in the municipal court here, hitherto exempt, in the competitive service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.-- Wholesale prices increased almost half of 1 per cent during the week ending Nov. 11, according to today's report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department. The index number for the week, based on the 1926 level as 100, was 71.2.
Roy Chapman Andrews, explorer, awoke in his penthouse apartment yesterday morning to find a burglar gazing down at him.

A hearing on the report and petition of the trustees of the Film Securities Corporation scheduled for yesterday was adjourned to Dec. 7 at the request of the General Theatres Equipment Corporation. The reason for the request was the possibility that General Theatres Equipment might work out a plan in the next three weeks for preserving an equity in the stock, it owns in Film Securities.

The twenty-six-story business building at 245 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Twenty-eighth Street, was bid in at a foreclosure auction yesterday by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, in an action against the Fifth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street Realty Company.

Robert L. Bellick, codefendant with William M. Chadbourne, Fusion campaign manager, on charges of disorderly conduct in an election day controversy, testified yesterday at the second day of the hearing before Magistrate Stern in Tombs court.

Announcement that the so-called "bond pool," formed more than a year ago to invest in fixed-revenue securities, was winding up its operations has occasioned some strained inferences. A suggestion promptly followed that this action must mean distrust of the whole investment situation.

MONTREAL, Nov. 16. -- The New York Americans played an overtime 2-2 tie with the Montreal Maroons before a crowd of 2,500 fans tonight. The result left the visitors still at the bottom of the international division standing of the National Hockey League, with the Maroons one point above them.

It is generally agreed that the Federal public works program has moved more slowly than its sponsors hoped would be the case. "We might as well be perfectly frank," President ROOSEVELT told a conference of relief officials on Wednesday. It has been "exceed"ingly difficult honestly to allot the "entire sum of $3,300,000,000 to worth"while projects," every one of which must be approved by local authorities, State authorities and, finally, by the Federal Government.

The bond market on the StocK Exchange took a downward course yesterday, foreign loans dipping as well as domestic corporation issues and United States Government bonds. Trading in bonds on the Exchange reached $20,395,900, against $16,690,000 on the previous day, with dealings in United States Government issues accounting for $5,615,900 of yesterday's total.

Manager Bill Terry of the Giants made a move to improve the reserve hitting strength of his team yesterday when he obtained George Grantham from the Reds in exchange for Glenn Spencer, one of his second-string pitchers. The deal was announced at the Giants office by Assistant Secretary Edward T. Brannick as a straight player-for-player transaction, with no cash involved.

The results of experiments indicating that convalescents from epidemic encephalitis develop in their blood a specific protective substance against the disease, are announced today in Science, official organ of the American Association for the 'Advancement of Science, by research workers of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

The local debt of counties in New York State on Jan. 1 ranged from $27.50 for each $1,000 of valuation in Sullivan County to $149.40 in Westchester County, according to an analysis completed by Meech, Harmon, Lytle Blackmore, auditors and municipal and industrial surveyors.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 16. -- The Field Club of Greenwich and the Racquet and Swimming Club of Ardsley-on-Hudson were victors In the women's Westchester Interclub Squash Racquets League matches today.

Formal organization of the American Foreign bondholders Protective Committee, consisting of eighteen men who met in Washington on Oct. 20 at the behest of the State and Treasury Departments, will be accomplished in a few days. When the preliminaries of incorporating and electing a chairman are accomplished, a statement is to be issued outlining the plans of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,577,000,000 an Increase of $13,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $372,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

A proposal whereby a private charitable organization, working through the municipal government, could share In the benefits of the Federal loans now being made under the public works provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act was made to the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Madison Square Boys Club, 312 East Thirtieth Street.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 16. -- Minor league club owners today reelected officers of their association, adopted a resolution designed to curb "shoestring operators" and then set about strengthening their teams for the campaign of 1934.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- A Century of Progress Exposition, which cost $38,699,476.77 to erect and administer, made a profit of $6,861,888.22, according to an estimate of the final audit today by M.N. Tveter, controller.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Western Maryland -- The football charts have been thrown away as just a set of forged papers giving a wide variety of misinformation. Taking the nearest reference book to hand, the first phrase is: "Absit omen!" Very ominous. In, fear and trembling, on thin vote for B.C.

Sportsmen of New York State are preparing to seek many changes in the present fish and game laws, judging from the numerous resolutions which the various associations have adopted and the proposed regulations which they advocate.

District Attorney Crain, through his secretary, Joseph A. Durkin, issued a statement yesterday in which he denied he had demanded the resignation of three of his prosecuting staff in the last two days because they supported the McKee Recovery party ticket.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A new administration policy of restricting interpretations of recovery statistics to one central agency under the direct control of the President's own Executive Council was reflected for the first time today in the publication of the November Federal Reserve Board's bulletin.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 17 -- The, Uruguayan Government and the Secretariat General of the PanAmerican Conference do not share the pessimism which has arisen in some Latin-American capitals as a result of President Roosevelt's banning of discussion of tariffs and currency stabilization.

J. Ebb Weir, hard-working chairman of the tournament committee of the Long Island Golf Association, will head that organization in 1934, according to an announcement made yesterday following the annual executive meeting held at the Cherry Valley Club.

Frank J. Prial, defeated candidate on the Tammany ticket for Controller, was retired by the Board of Estimate yesterday on an annual pension of $5,010.52, with a service allowance of slightly more than twenty-six years.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 17 -- Inquiry among the farmers of lows in the more conservative sections -- and the only radical belt is along the Missouri and in Southern counties -- brings out several varying points of view.

Mr. BRUCE BLIVEN, editor of The New Republic, offers in its latest number" a few funeral flowers for the Chicago Fair." He went out to the show, which he sternly calls "A Century of Treadmill." Nothing pleased him much. Most things made him growl. It was a Middle West affair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Nov. 5 there appeared an article written by former Governor Alien of Kansas under the caption "The Meaning of Recognition for Russia and for the United States."

With a substantial increase in net income reported for September, the Baltimore Ohio turned its net loss for the first eight months of the year into a net income for the first nine months. This contrasted with a net loss in the first nine months of 1932. The figures follow:

With at least four of the seven remaining major powers that have been neither beaten nor tied in real jeopardy and important sectional and intersectional contests studding the program, football offers one of its most inviting set-ups of the waning season today.

The plan drafted by George McAneny when he was Sanitation Commissioner for the city to take over the work of disposing of Brooklyn's ashes and refuse, was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The Department of Sanitation, it is expected, will be ready to take over the work shortly after Jan. 1.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Both the French Foreign Minister, Joseph Paul-Boncour, and the British Foreign Secretary, Sir John Simon, were on the way to Geneva tonight, but whether in agreement or with different intentions was far from clear. At least they had agreed that they would both go.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Mary McCormic, opera singer, arrived at the Newark Airport this evening in a United airliner from Chicago. The plane was scheduled to land at 6:25, but arrived at 5:55. The singer went on to New York in the airline's car. Miriam Hopkins, actress, arrived in the same plane.

The Appellate Division, ruled yesterday, in a 4 to 1 decision, that the city no longer has any right to use tax funds to pay interest and amortization on bonds issued to finance construction of the Eighth Avenue subway. Reversing a ruling made in June by Supreme Court Justice John J. Walsh, the court granted a taxpayers' application for a temporary injunction against such payments.
The sudden, rise in dollar exchange yesterday unsettled prices on the Cotton Exchange, bringing liquidation that caused a break of 30 points and net losses of 20 to 24 points at the close.

The Board of Estimate's practice of laying over items on its calendar for months was attacked yesterday by Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, who picked out a layover on a $2,750 tombstone to illustrate his argument.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read that Secretary Dern on Armistice Day "bitterly denounced the futility of the sacrifices in the 'war to end wars' and declared that the dreams of Woodrow Wilson, 'the great Idealist,' were not realized and that he 'overrated human nature.' "

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Lewis M. Nuttman, now in command of the New York Port of Embarkation at Brooklyn, was ordered today to Honolulu, where he will have command of the Twenty-second Brigade at Schofield Barracks. He will sail Jan. 18.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17 -- With a rearranged team, Harvard tomorrow will play its thirty-fifth football game with Brown. Having been beaten five times in the last seven starts against Tuss McLaughry's eleven, the Cambridge forces have made extensive preparations.

Samuel Skoblow, who recently admitted to setting fifty fires in Brooklyn, and three other men, including a Brooklyn fire adjuster, were arraigned in the Kings County Court yesterday on charges of second degree arson. It was the third arson charge to be made against Skoblow in the last two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The administration continued along moderate lines in its gold policy today as Henry Morgenthau Jr. took over the reins at the Treasury Department as Acting Secretary.

A legal consignment of French liqueurs valued by its importers at $17,600 was hijacked yesterday afternoon by four gunmen on West Street near Christopher Street. The shipment, newly arrived on the liner Paris, was being trucked from the French Line pier to the bonded Independent Warehouse on Hubert Street.

The assistance of city employes in the annual Red Cross roll-call now in progress was urged yesterday in an appeal sent out by Borough President Samuel Levy as chairman of the city government group of the New York chapter's roll-call volunteers.

Seventeen games, four of them involving undefeated public high school football elevens, are listed for New York City field today. The program is one of the largest Saturday schedules of the scholastic seaeon and the day will also be a busy one for schoolboy elevens in Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Here are the events leading to recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States:

The establishment of recreational "service stations" and other new recreational facilities, a large expansion of existing facilities, and a program integrated to the individual rather than a mass program were advocated by speakers yesterday at a hearing before the New York Committee on the Use of Leisure Time.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 -- If any attempt is made to arrest the nine persons named by Attorney General William Preston Lane of Maryland as having participated in the lynching Oct. 18 of George Armwood, a Negro, in the town of Princess Anne, Somerset County, serious mob violence probably would arise, State's Attorney John B. Robins of that county advised Mr. Lane in a long letter today.
Comments of the press of the country on the recognition of Russia generally accepted the step as inevitable.

Flooded with complaints that many "clearance" and "liquidation" sales were not bona fide, the local Retail Code Authority has begun an extensive investigation, it was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen, NBA Administrator for the City of New York.
HAVANA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Cuban Army took extraordinary precautions tonight to guard against a reportedly imminent outbreak against the Grau San Martin government.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- The New Haven Lawn Club was the scene of a debutante ball given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Charlton D. Cooksey and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Seymour for their daughters, Miss Barbara Cooksey and Miss Betsy Seymour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Defini- tive bonds of the eighteen-year 4 per cent issue of the Home Owners Loan Corporation are ready for exchange for interim receipts outstanding, the corporation announced today. All holders of interim receipts may obtain bonds by forwarding their receipts to the Treasury Department, Division of Loans and Currency, Washington, D.C.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The body of Edward N. Hurley, financier and manufacturer, was laid to rest in Calvary Cemetery this afternoon after services in Holy Name Cathedral. Business, industrial and political leaders of the country attended the rites.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Foreign Commissar Litvinoff disclosed in a statement before the National Press Club tonight that the first commitment sought by President Roosevelt as a requisite to a recognition of Russia was an assurance of the Soviet policy toward nationals of other countries.

Columbia and Lafayette, who last met on the gridiron in 1889, will encounter each other today at Baker Field, starting at 2 o'clock. In their first contest the teams battled to a 10-10 deadlock and several of the members of Lion and Lafayette teams of 1889 will be on the sidelines today.

More than 75,000 persons in the hotel, restaurant, steamship, railroad, club, hospital and catering businesses were registered at the National Hotel Exposition, which closed, last night in Grand Central Palace after a week's display. The exposition was held under the auspices of the New York State Hotel Association and the Hotel Association of New York City.

When is a railroad not a railroad? When it is a part of the Independent System of city subways, according to Chairman DELANEY and the lower courts, which agreed with him that his "road" was not legally in operation until not only the Eighth Avenue line but the rest of the system was completed.

Two issues of Russian Government dollar bonds were sold in the United States in 1916, comprising $50,000,000 of a 3-year 6 1/2 per cent credit, on which principal was defaulted on June 18, 1919, and $25,000,000 of 5-year 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, on which interest was defaulted on Dec. 1, 1919.

With the government assigning to newly produced domestic gold the arbitrary value of $33.56 an ounce for the fourth consecutive day, stocks and commodities fell back yesterday into their old irregular habits. Prices were generally lower on the Stock Exchange as well as in the markets for agricultural staples and other products.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 17 -- The basic policies of the incoming New York City administration on transit and charter revision were outlined by Mayor-elect LaGuardia in an interview today on his arrival in the Canal Zone.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- British golf's reaction today to the suggestion of the United States Professional Golfers Association that profanity be forbidden during tournaments, summed up was "Tut tut and dearie me; those Americans are trying to reform the game again."

MADRID, Nov. 17 -- Spanish nobles are hurrying back to Spain in planes, automobiles and buses from London, Paris, Berlin, the French Riviera, Biarritz and smart St. Jean de Luz, just across the French border, in a rush to Madrid to vote the Catholic Reactionary ticket in Sunday's election.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The undefeated Princeton eleven meets Navy in Palmer Stadium tomorrow and will attempt to score its first victory over the midshipmen since 1924. The game starts at 2 P.M.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 -- A nose finish, with Morton L. Schwartz's Clarify in front, thrilled racegoers in the featured Wildwood Handicap at Bowie today. Driving to the line with the son of Chatterton and Maharanee was Deduce, which gained the place by six lengths over Don Pedro the favorite.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- Reports of the recognition of the Soviet by the United States were spreadeagled in German newspapers appearing late enough to carry the news, but editorial comments were scanty on account of the lateness of the hour.
In response to requests from THE NEW YORK TIMES, comment as follows has been received from United States Senators on the recognition of Russia by President Roosevelt:
BERLIN, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 15 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Spokesmen for the Socialist party in the United States praised President Roosevelt's action in recognizing Soviet Russia, chiefly because of its promise to the permanence of international peace. The selection of William C. Bullitt as the first American Ambassador to the Soviet Union likewise was approved heartily.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The communications between President Roosevelt and Commissar Litvinoff of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which preceded the resumption of normal diplomatic relations were as follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Unless charges are filed in the United States Senate against Senator John H. Overton on behalf of the people of Louisiana, Senator M. M. Logan, member of the committee investigating the Overton election, said tonight all of the testimony taken in New Orleans last February and this week might be thrown out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read your editorial "The Lowly Dollar." I wish I had a Canadian dollar to send you so that you could go to your nearest postoffice and buy some stamps. You could not buy one stamp with it. The postmaster would laugh at you for trying.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Armour Co., meat packers, have started to prepare another plan for revamping their present top-heavy capital structure, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 11 amounted to 577,676 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 30,109 cars, or 5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 40,989 cars, or 7.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 112,284 cars, or 16.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Fordham and Oregon State will clash on the gridiron at the Polo Grounds today in the final encounter of the 1933 season for both elevens. The opening kick-off in this East-West battle will be at 2 o'clock.

The estate of Albert N. Hallgarten, member of a family of bankers, who died at Nice, France, on Jan. 18, 1931, was appraised yesterday at $2,968,194 gross and $2,745,278 net, of which $2,822,915 was in securities. He gave $170,000 in nine public gifts, of which $50,000 was left to establish a fund under his name to provide free musical education for needy persons and to award prizes for proficiency in musical composition and attainments.

President Roosevelt, from the beginning of the negotiations looking to recognition of Russia, was more concerned for world peace than interested in economic considerations, Colonel Hugh L. Cooper, president of the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce, declared in a statement last night.

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher, who is here from her home in Paris, grave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. W. Curzon Taylor, Dr. and Mrs. Robert Emery Brennan, Mr. and Mrs. Joel E. Fisher Jr., the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert Darlington, Mrs. Banks Taylor, Mrs. Thomas E. Satterthwaite, James Lenox Banks, Charles Stuart-Linton, the Rev. Elliott Darlington, Lawrence Atterbury and James L. Banks Jr.

Rumors of impending "stabilization" of the dollar, feeding and multiplying upon themselves, spread rapidly through the financial markets yesterday, adding new strength to the recovery of the currency in foreign exchange and lending aid and comfort to the dejected market for United States Government bonds.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow: "There is a better demand for wool in the Boston market; induced, apparently, by the statistically strong position of the raw material, rising prices abroad and the strong upward surge in sterling exchange, which tends to prevent the importation of foreign wool.

VIENNA, Nov. 17 -- Dr. Richard Steidle, Tyrolean Heimwehr leader, who has just been appointed National Commissar for Propaganda, indicated to foreign correspondents at his first official reception today that the Austrian press was to be censored.

The average of wholesale prices reported yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics was within a fraction of the highest of the year. The bureau's "index number" for the week of Nov. 11 stands at 71.2, with 71.5 the top mark reached in any week this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In a ceremony marked by a Presidential tribute to Secretary Woodin's services. Henry Morgenthau Jr. took the oath of office as Under-Secretary of the Treasury at the White House this morning.
Many of the candidates in the last election who filed individual expense accounts with the Board of Elections yesterday reported that they spent nothing on their campaigns.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 17 -- The football teams of Dartmouth and Cornell are ready to resume their traditional football rivalry tomorrow in a game which will have a Winter carnival setting.

New York University and Rutgers will meet today at the Yankee Stadium for the thirty-first game in a football series which began in 1890. N.Y.U. has won fifteen of the games, Rutgers fourteen and one ended in a scoreless tie.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt was urged today to continue his "gold and monetary policy until the 1926 level of commodities, salaries, wages, conditions of employment and the solvency of the people of the United States are restored."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt left Washington late this afternoon for Warm Springs. Ga., where he plans to spend the Thanksgiving holidays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- William Christian Bullitt, first American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has been an advocate of Russian recognition since March, 1919, when he was sent on a secret mission with Lincoln Steffens and Walter Weyl of the New Republic to deal with Nikolai Lenin.

The relative merits of diesel and steam-propelled ships as cargo carriers were debated anew yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers. The need for cargo ships, the construction of which has lagged seriously in American yards in recent years, was emphasized by several speakers who stressed the fact that the larger passenger ships were no longer able, for economic reasons, to handle general cargoes.

The Appellate Division handed down a decision yesterday which was hailed by advocates of strict enforcement of the civil service laws as a blow against preferences to so-called "disabled" veterans when doubt exists as to the extent of the disability.

A program of special services beginning tomorrow morning and continuing through Sunday, Nov. 26, will mark the opening of the newly erected $3,000,000 Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, at the north-west corner of Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Stimulated by success in polling 418,000 votes for Mayors-elect F.H. LaGuardia under its four-leaf clover emblem, the City Fusion party will continue permanently, Maurice P. Davidson, its city chairman, announced yesterday. Headquarters have been opened on the twentyfifth floor of the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord Privy Seal, repeated tonight more strongly than before his assertion that in the United States democracy had broken down and that President Roosevelt was a fullfledged dictator.
GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- Efforts are being made to hold a meeting of the Disarmament Conference Bureau (steering committee) or its officers with great power delegates in Rome.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Weakness in stocks and commodities in general counted heavily today, against the prices of grains on the Board of Trade, but there was no material pressure other than from some of yesterday's buyers. The net result of operations was largely to wipe out the gains made yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A tangible estimate in a reliable quarter of American capital which has "flown" to Great Britain in the last three months is only L75,000,000 roughly $375,000,000.

President Clifford D. Mallory and the other officers of the North American Yacht Racing Union, ruling body of yacht racing in this country and Canada, were re-elected yesterday at the annual meeting held at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The steel industry, whose code of fair competition was one of NRA's knottiest problems of the past Summer, petitioned President Roosevelt today for an extension of the ninety-day test period granted by legislative order when the code was signed in August, and the request was approved.

Faulty distribution of employment rather than a surplus of college-trained men and women is responsible for the discrepancy between opportunities and available trained workers, in the opinion of Colonel Walter V. Bingham, director of the Personnel Research Federation.

Milton Baron, Fraternity Club star, and Edward McLaughlin, representing the Columbia University Club, will meet in the final round of the Fall scratch invitation squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club on Monday evening as the result of winning their semi-finals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The National Labor Board has been urged, it was learned today, to postpone the elections of spokesmen for collective bargaining in captive mines. Former Governor Nathan L. Miller of New York and Hoyt Moore, counsel to the United States Steel Corporation and the American Iron and Steel Institute, who made the request, have also sought to change the method of selection.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In notes and telegrams written in the most formal diplomatic language, the United States Government today solemnly terminated all diplomatic relations with the remnants of the Czaristic and Kerensky regimes which preceded Soviet control of Russia.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- Berlin's interest in the attempts of the Western powers to, resuscitate the disarmament conference, while alert, is not overeager in view of its feeling that the next move is up to those powers.
