John Ringling, the circus man, related yesterday before Theodore Stitt, referee in bankruptcy, in Federal Building, Brooklyn, how he had turned over all his assets, including a collection of paintings, valued by him at $1,000,000, to New York Investors, Inc., to cover $16,000 to $18,000 in defaulted interest due Allied Owners, Inc., a subsidiary.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The prospect was seen tonight that Bishop Albert Augustus David of the Anglican Diocese of Liverpool might be brought to trial before the Archbishop of York on a charge of having "caused a grave scandal to Christian people" because of his reported intention of permitting a member of a Unitarian body to preach in Liverpool Cathedral.

Some Christmas Buying Noted. A surprisingly good response to the few promotions of gift and toy promotions was noted by retail executives here during the week. While it was still too early to predict that Christmas buying has definitely started, the volume done was held to indicate that retailers may well meet considerable success in their promotions before Thanksgiving.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A hearing on a code of fair competition for anthracite mining today revealed a wide divergence of opinion on the problem of how to stabilize the industry.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 -- The football teams of the University of Pittsburgh and the University of Nebraska are ready for the kick- off in tomorrow's intersectional battle at the Pitt Stadium, a game that will go far toward deciding the ultimate ranking of both out- fits in the national standing.

Fire Lieutenant Wesley Williams and seven firemen had a narrow escape yesterday when trapped on the fourth floor of a blazing loft building at 109 Greene Street. Choked by the fumes and blinded by smoke from burning cotton waste and fiber, the men had to abandon their hoselines and retreat to the roof.

Edward Doro, a young Western poet, whose first book was published only last month, has won a $1,000 award by the National Institute of Arts and Letters, administering the Russell Loines Memorial Fund. The book was called "The Boar and the Shibboleth," and was published by Alfred A. Knopf in an edition limited to 500 copies.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 17 -- In an interview with The Chicago Tribune correspondent tonight, President Ramon Grau San Martin confirmed reports that he had written to President Roosevelt asking that Ambassador Sumner Welles be replaced immediately.

The cold wave, with its chilling, snow-flecked blasts which have lashed the North Atlantic seaboard and the Middle West for several days, abated yesterday, but only after the record low temperature for the date had been equaled in New York.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday adopted amendments to its rules and regulations designed to eliminate the possibility of conflict between judges and referees in the designation of fouls in boxing bouts. At the same time it is expected the changes will improve boxing from a competitive stand-point.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Ten registration statements under the Securities Act calling for the issuance of securities totaling nearly $31,000,000 were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

The first for this season of the Friday assemblies, a series of dances for young married couples and debutantes of a few years ago, took place last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Several dinners preceded it.

Charles T. Hindley gave a mortgage for $6,000, due Sept. 30, 1936, at 5 per cent, to the trustee of the will of John H. Hindley on 11 E. 20th St., a three-story building, in which the mortgagor owns a hall interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Commissar Maxim Litvinoff held a tenminute radio conversation over the transatlantic radio telephone from the White House this morning with his wife, Mme. Ivy Litvinoff, and his son, Mischa, in Moscow, the conversation, in English, being purely of a personal nature.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Tulsa University eleven defeated the George Washington Colonials tonight, 13 -- 6, to keep its record intact.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- An official disclaimer of the article in The London Saturday Review attributed to Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, was issued here tonight, emphatically denying its genuineness. It stated that Dr. Goebbels had never written the article.

The trade picture has been Changed almost completely by the momentum gained in retail distribution, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. As the cold weather extended to nearly all parts of the country, and was accompanied in many sections by heavy snowfall, the largest sales for the season were recorded in a majority of the cities reporting.

NEW YORK. Prince Ludovico Potenziani, former Governor of Rome; his daughter, Princess Myriam Potenziani, and Colonel Carl Graziani di Sansepolero, aide de camp to King Victor Emmanuel of Italy, have returned from Chicago to the Ritz-Carlton.
The fistic series between Steve Hamas, Passaic (N.J.) heavy weight, and Lee Ramage of California now favors the New Jersey, fighter.

The incoming Hamburg American liner Deutschland, with 300 passengers, rammed the steamship Munargo of the Munson Line off the Statue of Liberty at 5:35 P.M. yesterday. The Munargo, with a hole fifteen feet wide on the port side amidships, was beached on the mud flats 300 feet north of Bedloe's Island. No one was hurt.

While workers in the Citizens Family Welfare Committee's drive for 14,000,000 prepared to begin today intensive solicitation, James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee, asked the canvassers yesterday to bear in mind the preventive aspect of the work.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Word of the recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States reached Paris tonight too late for any extensive comment, but it was prominently displayed in the news columns.

Protracted efforts to rehabilitate the Municipal Service System, formerly controlled by Insull interests, collapsed yesterday when a group of creditors of the Ohio operating companies in the system failed to renew a standstill agreement that had been in effect several months.

CANBERRA, Nov. 17 -- A response unprecedented in Australian financial history has been made to the Commonwealth internal loan of L10,000,000 [currently about $42,260,000]. Within forty-eight hours of the opening of the lists the applications exceeded the amount required.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 17 -- Gilman defeated Tome School today, 6 to 0, in the seventeenth annual football game between the two institutions.

Sir Gilbert Eliott is sailing today for Glasgow on the Anchor liner Cameronia. Others sailing for Scotland and Ireland on the ship are: F.D. Harris Mrs. C.A. Black Mrs. Mary K. Kemp Mrs. James Ross Miss Catherine Daniel McFarlana Crawford Miss Evelyn Raye New Yorkers sailing for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Roma include:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Russian orders for American goods worth $520,000,000 are immediately available to the United States if the government will extend the credit necessary for financing such exports, it was stated today by Smith W. Brookhart, special adviser to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Countries that have not recognized Soviet Russia are:
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- Hopes for the recovery of the body of Brooke L. Hart were revived tonight as a block of cement tied with wire was pulled from San Francisco Bay.

Domestic bonds on the Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday under the leadership of United States Government bonds, abruptly reversing the trend of the previous day. The government's long-term issues were bid up from 2-32 point to a full point, and corporation bonds made fair gains.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 18 -- The recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States had been expected here so long that its actual announcement today caused only a ripple of interest.

With an eye to the possibility of another upset in the foreign exchange market, the Wall Street trading element proceeded yesterday with more than usual caution. The perplexity as to what the government's monetary policies may bring about was again a restraining influence, but generally it was felt that the dollar was gradually working itself into a more favorable position.

Scoring in every period, the Horace Mann School for Boys football team concluded its campaign with an impressive 40-to-0 triumph over Morristown School yesterday at Horace Mann field. By winning the sixth gridiron meeting between the two schools, Horace Mann deadlocked the series at three victories apiece.

Edward Sonnenschein of Chicago, of counsel for the S.W. Straus Co. interests, described yesterday at a hearing before John E. Joyce, referee in bankruptcy, at 70 Pine Street, how he had communicated with Benjamin M. Kaye, attorney, regarding the bankruptcy petition against Straus Co., filed by Mr. Kaye in Federal court last March.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A receivership has been set up for the United Hotels Company of America, a Delaware corporation with executive offices in this city, Frank A. Dudley, president, announced today. The corporation is a holding company, owning stocks and securities of United hotel companies in the United States and Canada.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 18 -- Word of the recognition of the Soviet by the United States came to Moscow in the dead of night because of the difference in time, but not too late for a communique to appear in every morning newspaper.

DUNEDIN, N.Z., Nov. 17 (By Wireless) -- In reply to Rear Admiral Byrd's request, in which he asks for my assistance in furnishing weather reports and help to get his Huge twin-engined monoplane on the Ross Sea Barrier after it has been landed on the water, I have said: "I will always go fifty-fifty with you."

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 17 -- Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was taken to task today by Professor Albert Levitt of Redding, Conn., a Republican, for the former's recent attack upon the policies of the Roosevelt administration.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Confidence that President Roosevelt would increase the price of agricultural commodities was expressed here tonight by Senator Borah, but he declared the President "will never do it until he does two things-increases the volume of currency in circulation and puts the combines and trusts of this country under control."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why all the tumult about a bigger and better Tammany? New York has announced, by way of the vote, that it is not afraid of the big, bad tiger, so why should the populace in general have any interest in the reorganization of a society that is only a drop in the bucket when it comes to the Democratic party in toto?

The policy of the United States toward Soviet Russia, first laid down by Bainbridge Colby as Secretary of State under President Wilson and followed rigidly by the succeeding Republican administrations, was sharply reversed by the resumption of diplomatic relations yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Reacting to reports that the export of American capital had been restricted, the dollar, for the first time in two weeks, showed strength today. Opening at 15.55 francs, it fluctuated violently, touching 15.30 francs at its lowest point, but closed at 15.55 francs, against 15.05 yesterday.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Control Board, announced yesterday that after Dec. 5, the day repeal goes into effect, brewers would not be required to state the alcoholic content of their brew on beer bottle labels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Regulation of Stock Exchanges of the country by a governmental board was proposed to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Henry Goldman Jr., a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Waters of San Francisco's lower bay still held the body tonight of Brooke L. Hart, but authorities moved swiftly in perfecting a case against his confessed kidnappers and slayers, John Holmes and Thomas H. Thurmond.

Fifteen years ago a President of the United States went a long way toward recognizing the Soviet Government. On March 14, 1918, President WILSON sent a letter to the Soviet Congress assembled at Moscow, in the course of which he assured the Russian people of the most cordial sympathy of the United States in their aspiration to liberate themselves forever from "absolutism" and to "become the master of their own destinies."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Latest estimates put the total of claims by the United States Government and its nationals against Russia, based on the repudiation of obligations and the confiscation of property by the Soviet, at roughly $800,000,000.
Plans for the Manhattan approach of the $37,500,000 midtown Hudson tunnel were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate after they had been submitted by the Port Authority.
The All Hallows football team continued unbeaten by turning back McBurney School, 19 -- 6, yesterday at Macomb's Dam Park. The victory was the seventh in a row.

Details of the plan for the establishment of a central comparison department by the New York Stock Exchange for the purpose of reducing overtime work in brokers' offices were announced yesterday by the Stock Clearing Corporation, which will have charge of the new system.

VIENNA, Nov. 17 -- Franz Lehar, the father of Austrian light opera, made an appeal to American theatre managers today in a speech at a luncheon of the Anglo-American Press Association, of which he was the guest of honor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- An attack upon Postmaster General James A. Farley for his part in the recent municipal election campaign in New York and an admonition against any Federal "interference" in local campaigns in the future were delivered here tonight by Samuel Seabury.
Purchase of a farm for a country estate and various housing deals made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty trading reported yester day.

The Japanese are radio fans with an enthusiasm unsurpassed in any other country, but a paternal government takes care that broadcasting is employed to build up a "national ideology." This is, declares SIEGFRIED LINDSTROM, in an article in Asia for December, "an exceedingly official proposition."
The purchase of three paintings by the Henry W. Ranger Fund has been announced by the National Academy of Design, whose council administers the fund. These canvases, all by American artists, are:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As reported in THE TIMES, Senator Thomas of Oklahoma states that "doubling the price of gold, if carried through by all the nations, would be equivalent to new discoveries of gold, which would double the total monetary stocks of the world."

BERLIN, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The audience at the Reichstag fire trial today heard a former Communist directly, accuse Ernst Torgler, one-time Communist whip in the Reichstag, of having been the leader of an arson gang that set the blaze on the night of Feb. 27.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- United States purchases of gold in France have virtually ceased and have not been large enough materially to affect the Bank of France gold reserves, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet told the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Quotations in Canada on United States manufactures continue firm, not-withstanding the exchange trend, according to the weekly survey of foreign business conditions issued by the Department of Commerce today on the basis of advices from commercial attaches abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics of the Department of Commerce, said today that the plan of the department to stimulate mass production of low-wing monoplanes to sell at about $700 each, provided that there was a guarantee of a market for at least 10,000 of the craft, was receiving an enthusiastic response.

The greatest opportunity for good in railroad coordination lies not in physical changes but in the integration of carrier organizations, methods and practices, J.R. Turney, director of transportation service for Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, told the New York Railroad Club at a meeting in the Engineering Societies' Auditorium last night.

In outlining the plan under which about $25,000,000 monthly is to be made available to nearly 400,000 men and women in New York to be employed on Federal civil works projects, Charles D. Osborne, member of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, told a conference of 200 Mayors at the Hotel Commodore yesterday that there would be no politics in this program.

East side deals involving change in ownership for two properties were included in the realty transactions reported yesterday. Frederick Brown, operator, continued his activities by purchasing from the Manhattan Savings Institution the fivestory business building at 1,495 Third Avenue, near Eighty-fourth Street. Hardy Brauners acted an brokers. Negotiations are reported pending for leasing the structure to a furniture firm.

William M. Chadbourne, Fusion campaign manager and president of the Honest Ballot Association, was found not guilty of disorderly conduct in connection with an election day row by Magistrate Adolph Stern in Tombs Court last night. His co-defendant, Robert L. Bellick, a Fusion watcher, also was acquitted.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Movements of vessels follow: all dates are Nov. 16 unless otherwise specified:

Time itself will have a birthday today. The date will not, of course, mark the anniversary of the beginning of time as such -- that still belongs to the realms of metaphysics -- but the beginning of standard time. Today marks the fiftieth anniversary of its adoption in the United States, a standardization which has since spread to most countries of the world.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- In the King's speech, today, proroguing Parliament, there was a hint that the World Economic Conference had not passed permanently out of existence.

Mr. OGDEN MILLS presented a powerful argument in support of the appeal for the $4,000,000 needed for family relief in addition to what is done by the Government, Federal, State and local, in meeting the continued unemployment emergency and by the welfare societies in normal times:

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., is in a favorable position to supply the United States market with its products when the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed, W.J. Hume, president and general manager of the company, told the directors here today at their annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Wholesale commodity prices continued to rise during October, it was announced today by Isador Lubin, commissioner of labor statistics of the Labor Department, the index number of the general level showing an advance of one-half of 1 per cent.

APPARENTLY when Kenneth Roberts plans a book his major effort is to find a "rental plot," a worried entanglement of love interest and melodrama. Then he starts writing and cuts away from all that. He plays down the melodrama that his plot reaches and strains for, becomes super-selective when dealing with the soft excitements of love, and tries his best to write what seems to him to be true.

Including the $70,000,000 of New York City 4 per cent relief bonds which are to be taken by a citywide group of banks, pursuant to the four-year plan to rehabilitate the city's finances, new issues of State and municipal bonds up for award next week will amount to $75,190,328.

A sharp reaction, which in many cases wiped out the gains of the preceding day, took place in nearly all commodities traded on local futures markets yesterday. The break in silver futures was particularly pronounced. Trading was in fair volume.

Morley's Debated Play. The quarrel goes on merrily around "Thunder on the Left," the play made out of CHRISTOPHER MORLEY'S novel. It has no trouble at all in eliciting strong words from those who dislike it and also from those who find in it many rich moments of a magic all too rare in the theatre.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 18 -- The appointment of William C. Bullitt as American Ambassador to the Soviet Union is regarded as certain to meet favor here because of his efforts to persuade President Wilson to recognize Russia.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 17 -- The Southern Association startled the baseball world today by adopting an amazing rule designed to curb intentional passes with two men out by permitting base runners to advance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- William M. Wherry, New York attorney and authority on public utilities, today attacked the new Federal Securities Act and predicted that public demand will bring about its early amendment.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The Nazis are going into new uniforms, and not brown ones. Whether the change is in any degree inspired by a desire to escape from the unsavory memories attaching to the mustard and chocolate dress of the Storm Troops it is difficult to determine.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The forty-foot cabin cruiser of Captain Brooks Van Norden, deep-sea angrler and skipper, was towed into port here tonight by the Coast Guard with her skipper dead and the other member of the crew unconscious.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 17 -- One of the strangest accidents in the history of the navy took the life of one seaman and critically injured another today.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Plans to move durum wheat out of the State were set in motion today as Governor William Langer partly lifted his wheat embargo to permit shipments for the next six days. Then the lid will be clamped down again.

The incoming Fusion administration, headed by Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia, will not be able to avert a fare rise on all subway and elevated lines even if it should bring about early unification of all rapidtransit facilities, it was predicted yesterday by transit and financial experts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Roosevelt administration was charged today by Chairman Sanders of the Republican National Committee with "censoring" government statistics.

The thirty-first annual concert for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen will take place on the morning of Dec. 5 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists will be Albert Spalding, violinist, and Rose Bampton, contralto.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 18 -- Illinois needed all its traditional fight today to earn a 7-to-0 football victory over an inspired University of Chicago team.

J.H. Wantling and T.H. Lewis tied for the scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each had 97 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off at twenty-five targets, Wantling prevailed, 24 -- 23. G.N. Hersey and E.J. McGrath deadlocked in the handicap competition, and each was awarded a prize.

BARCELONA, Nov. 18 -- Government authority over the Civil Guards, Spain's best-disciplined semi-military police force was shaken in this region today when the Guard as a body refused to obey orders to do strike-breaking duty in connection with the revolutionary transportation strike which began at 2 o'clock this morning.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 18 -- The big Red team from Cornell, using only a single substitute, rolled over Dartmouth today by virtue of one sustained march to gain a 7-0 victory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Further downward adjustment in gasoline to a low level of 18 cents per gallon for the season and a reduction in natural gas rates in Northern California were among business changes of the past week in the Twelfth district.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In 1918 thousands or men and women bought United States Government Liberty bonds as a patriotic duty to help win the World War. The great majority of these investors are people of moderate means who love their country and had faith in the integrity of our government.

Four gunmen who entered a poolroom at 387 Grand Street last night intending to rob the twenty or more men in the place were greeted by a burst of pistol shots by a policeman who happened to be in the room. The policeman's bullets felled the robbers' leader and caused his three accomplices to take to their heels.

PUGILISTIC champions have invariably taken advantage of their popularity to appear on the stage and a few have tried their luck in motion pictures. Boston's pride, John L. Sullivan, toured the country in "Honest Hearts and Willing Hands" and other melodramas; Bob Fitzsimmons appeared before the footlights in "Peck and His Mother-in-Law" and "The Honest Blacksmith."

STANDARD time is half a century old. "At 9 o'clock yesterday morning," said THE TIMES of fifty years ago today, "the pendulum of the standard clock in Room 48 of the Western Union Telegraph Building * * * was set at rest for 3 minutes and 58.38 seconds."

Opening of swim suit lines for 1934 during the week brought forth the largest volume of advance business in several years from wholesalers and chain stores, selling agents reported yesterday. The most favorable feature, agents said, was the comparative lack of price resistance from buyers, in the face of a 70 to 80 per cent rise above last year's opening levels.

Recognition of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics by the government in Washington failed to do more on the Cotton Exchange yesterday than to steady prices in early trading, and a decline later left the list 2 points lower to 3 points higher than on Friday.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Familiar by this time with having a rather unusual government, the German public finds nothing exciting in a German Cabinet Minister's addressing an editor of a London weekly with a request for the suppression of an article.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Steven Szumachowski, 18-year-old harrier from Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady, N.Y., gained additional laurels as the outstanding school cross-country runner by winning the La Salle Military Academy invitation run today in impressive fashion.

THE negotiations looking toward recognition of the U. S.S.R. by the United States lend ironical flavor to a story buried in the Revolutionary correspondence of the young Republic. It concerns the difficulty this country experienced in gaining the recognition of Russia under imperial rule.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- Temple warmed the hearts of its alumni in the anual home-coming game by gaining a second-half victory over Washington and Jefferson at the Temple Stadium today, winning 13 to 0.
TWENTY-FIVE years ago, during the intermission of a burlesque show playing at the Academy of Music in Pittsburgh, a youth of 17 walked before the curtain, raised his hand for silence, and began:

The Roosevelt administration is moving forward week by week to new positions from which a simple retreat to the starting point is absolutely out of the question, declares William A. Orton, historian and economist, in December Current History.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 21 -- General Chiang Kai-shek's armies surrounding the area in Southern Kiangsi Province, which is held by Chinese Communist forces, are taking elaborate precautions to maintain an effective blockade of what is now called the Red area.

Three leading Socialists here joined yesterday in expressing satisfaction at the Russian recognition and hailing it as a step forward in international relations. Norman Thomas, as co-chairman of the public affairs committee of the Socialist party, said that President Roosevelt and the country were to be congratulated.

Another in the series of recitals for the benefit of the Music School of Christodora House will be held on the night of Nov. 26 at the home of William Matheus Sullivan, 322 East Fifty-seventh Street. The artists will be Marie Montana, soprano, and Harold Berkley, violinist.

TOKYO, Nov. 18 -- One of the first comments on the recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States published here appeared in the form of a communique in English from the Russian Embassy to the Japanese newspapers.

The funeral service for William K. Vanderbilt Jr., who died after an automobile accident on Wednesday at Ridgeland, S.C., took place yesterday in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the pastor, officiated.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- As returns from the French vineyards come in, they confirm the forecast that owing to the exceptionally dry, sunny weather this season, 1933 will be a great wine year. This holds true for Champagne, Bordeaux and Burgundy as well as for the lesser-known districts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Yale and Harvard today inaugurated an annual series between the champion football teams of their college or house leagues, the battle ending in a scoreless tie. Saybrook represented Yale, while the Winthrop team wore the Crimson.

Prominent women are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Roberta" Thursday night at the New Amsterdam Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the New York City Committee of Mothers Health Centres to raise funds for furthering the work of that organization.

MILLIONS of dollars' worth of pure gold, wrung from the earth by the labor of countless men, has disappeared from regular trading channels and passed into the hands of people who guard it against profitable use.

OMAHA, Nov. 16 -- Whether it is mere coincidence or a definite example of cause and effect, a sunnier feeling has pervaded the corn belt since the recent Wallace and Johnson speeches. The madness that beclouded the atmosphere like the great dust storm of last Sunday seems to have expended its violence.

BOSTON EARLY implements and products of American industry have their museums and there is at least one museum of commerce, but up to recent years the records of business generally had not been assembled.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Wesleyan's football team toyed with the University of Rochester today, winning by 15 -- 0. The game was played on a heavy field, well checkered with patches of ice.

Value of Dollar on Exchange Market The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Freddy Stork scored two goals to give Harvard a 3 to 1 victory over Army on a snow-covered field at the Harvard Business School today.

AMONG Compton Mackenzie's most entertaining works of fiction are two books of espionage tales, the harvest of war years in the British Secret Service. Once again he returns to that fertile field, but this time his gleanings result in a hilarious burlesque of military and political intelligence units as they function in peace times.

Increasing optimism based on steadily improving retail sales totals during the last two weeks is expressed by leading local department-store executives in a survey issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Receiving word from Moscow that the Soviet Government approved the selection of William C. Bullitt as Ambassador from the United States to the U.S.S.R., Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, entertained at luncheon today Cabinet officers and others who may play a part in the new relations established between Washington and the Soviet.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The Frenchman who has traveled in Russia cannot fail to recognize the desire of the Russians for understanding with foreign countries, says Edouard Herriot in an article in this evening's L'Information. The former Premier recently returned from a visit to the Soviet Union.

PARIS. JUST about this time of year the early print perennials begin to bud in those sartorial "hothouses," the Paris couturiers' workrooms; they are being cultivated for the Palm Beach and Riviera season.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 14 -- Efforts to devise a system of liquor control for Oregon, one of the major problems confronting the special session of the Legislature, convening next Monday, have created a situation in which the municipality of Klamath Falls has challenged the authority of the State to establish a State-owned chain of liquor dispensaries within the confines of any incorporated city.

IN a recent article, Edouard Herriot exclaimed: "We will fight relentlessly against this snobbish idea of dictatorship which is becoming today's fashion. There is no greater danger: internally, for our political liberties: externally, for peace."

The United States of the future cannot escape a policy of "collective control," Dr. Howard Lee McBain, dean of the graduate faculties, declares in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, made public yesterday.

A NEW producing firm is about to set foot into the Broadway arena. Its members are Sidney Phillips, who produced "Blessed Event" and "Girls in Uniform," and Bertram Bloch, the latter being a playwright and head of the local story department at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 19 -- "The laboring masses of the Soviet Union, warmly greet this new victory for the cause of peace," the Pravda said today in the first official Soviet comment on the recognition of Russia by the United States.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16 -- The status of Missouri public schools is the worst since 1903, when the State ranked thirtieth in education, and unless emergency funds are made available immediately the free system will be abandoned in many communities and some sort of tuition program substituted for those who can afford to pay.

IT is disappointing to find a young writer as intelligent and sensitive as Mr. Granville Hicks accepting hook, line and sinker the economic evaluation of literature. His economic convictions are his own business, but when he permits them to become so entangled with his literary judgments as to vitiate almost completely the value of his book, one can only shrug one's shoulders and trust that time will correct the myopia.
PANAMA, Nov. 18 -- A pledge to restore the city both financially and artistically was made today by Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia of New York in an interview.

The new supply of crude oil in September averaged 2,668,000 barrels daily, the largest for that month since 1929, and 18.7 per cent more than the 2,247,000 barrels in September, 1932, according to data of the Bureau of Mines compiled by William J. Kemnitzer.

MICROPHONE fright or-lack of training -- that is the way Nino Martini, new Metropolitan tenor, diagnoses the nervous terror that grips performers, especially newcomers, when they are about to go on the air.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs regained undisputed lead in the International Division of the National Hockey League tonight with a 4-to-1 victory over the Ottawa Senators. It was Toronto's third straight victory and broke a triple tie with Ottawa and the Montreal Canadiens.

Apart from a moderate rise in stocks of companies which may benefit from the resumption of normal diplomatic relations between the United States and Russia, there was no market reaction yesterday to the news of the recognition of the Soviet Government.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- A spirited offensive in the final period enabled the Princeton football team to repulse Navy today, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 40,000.

The foreign exchange market relapsed into a week-end truce yesterday, with the dollar reacting moderately from its recovery of the past two business days. The movement of the foreign currencies, while uniformly against the dollar, was small compared with the explosive fluctuations of earlier in the week.

COMMERCIAL "movies" apparently are the modern adolescent's textbook of life and love. No conclusion drawn from the vast investigations of the Payne Fund for the Motion Picture Research Council seems surer than this.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- While President Roosevelt in a speech at Savannah was attacking "Tories" who criticized his "experimentation," the Chamber of Commerce of the United States was aiming a blow today at administration policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Two important business indexes, steel production and electric power output, have recently turned upward after an uninterrupted decline of many weeks, but the trend of most production statistics continues downward, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

IT is twenty years since Edward K. Armstrong, du Pont engineer, first set to work on his scheme for a string of floating airports across the Atlantic. He has worked carefully and painstakingly, has checked his own figures against those of the best naval architects and construction experts in this country and abroad and has never wavered in his belief in the practicability of the seadrome project.

Licenses permitting the sale of wines and liquor in retail and wholesale stores will be ready for distribution the latter part of this week, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. The hotel, restaurant and club licenses, permitting consumption of liquor and wines on the premises will be given out beginning next week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Carnegie Tech defeated the Georgetown University eleven today, 19 to 0.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Princeton alumni in Connecticut and Westchester have been invited to attend a reception, buffet supper and dance in honor of Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, and Mrs. Dodds, at the Greenwich Country Club, Friday evening, Dec. 1.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 18 -- A touchdown scored on a 55-yard run by Jack Smith in the opening minutes of play gave Ohio State a 6-0 victory over a fighting Wisconsin eleven today.

An inspired Rutgers football team that would not be beaten could not be beaten yesterday and held a favored New York University eleven to a 6-to-6 tie at the Yankee Stadium. Both of the scores were made in a stormy second period, the Scarlet coming from behind to deadlock the count.

IN the colorful days of the Old West when outlaws rode the ranges, there were many, Mr. James would have us believe, who stole not for profit but adventure. Particularly, he thinks, was this true of those engaged in cattle rustling and horse stealing.

A plea to the public for early mailing in the coming Christmas season was made yesterday by the Postoffice Department. Coupled with this request was an announcement of the latest mailing dates for delivery in foreign countries before Christmas.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 18 -- General Ismael Montes, president of the Central Bank and twice President of Bolivia, died this afternoon, after a short illness, at the age of 72.

VIENNA, Nov. 18 -- A thousand soldiers, 5,000 auxiliaries and the country's whole force of gendarmerie and police saw to it this week that the fifteenth anniversary of the foundation of the Austrian Republic was not celebrated.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 -- Two more weeks will be devoted to taking evidence on the Overton-Broussard primary of 1932, it was decided today by the Senate subcommittee inquiring into fraud charges.

The flight of capital from this country, reported as heavy since the decline in the dollar began, has not been materially accelerated through the operations of general management investment trust companies, although several have somewhat larger holdings of bonds payable in pounds sterling than they might have had if the dollar had remained stable.

Seventy years ago today a tall, gaunt man rose from his place on the rude grand stand at the dedication of a national cemetery at Gettysburg, Pa., and delivered a short oration, untitled then, but subsequently known throughout the world as "Lincoln's Gettysburg Address."

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 16 -- Although the next primary election is still eleven months away, the State political campaign has already started. The opening gun was the announcement of Secretary of State Frank D. Fitzgerald that he was definitely in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Wall Street was disappointed yesterday that the overnight announcement from Washington of the recognition of Russia did not cause more of a stir in the domestic speculative markets. So far as the New York Stock Exchange was concerned, the volume of business was only about 100,000 shares greater than on the previous Saturday, when business was virtually at a standstill.

THIS is the fourth volume in the very excellent series of "Pioneer Histories," edited by V. T. Harlow and J.A. Williamson, whose purpose is to provide broad surveys of the great migrations, for whatever purpose, of European peoples into non-European countries, thus describing a racial expansion, say its editors, which has created the complex world of today, so nationalistic in its instincts, so internationalized in its relationships."

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 18 -- A home-coming day crowd saw the William and Mary Indians bow before a slashing attack of the Davidson Wildcats by the score of 12 to 7 today. Davidson's fleet back, Wingfield, crossed the W. and M. goal line twice.
The Columbia football juggernaut struck with speed and deception yesterday at Baker Field to defeat Lafayette, 46 -- 6, before 10,000 spectators.

The American Iron and Steel Institute, which applied Wednesday for the extension of the steel industry's code of fair competition to May 31, 1934, announced yesterday that it had received a telegram from Administrator Hugh S. Johnson expressing his own and President Roosevelt's gratification with the operation of the code.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Liquidation of wheat by local and Eastern longs developed today on the Board of Trade, and while there was a fair class of buying early, the support apparently was withdrawn. Uncovering of stop-loss orders dropped prices sharply and the market closed around the lowest levels of the day and week.

THE taxicab rider may now tune in on his favorite radio program as he is whisked about city streets. The first few hundred taxicabs of an order of 1,750 placed by Radio Fleet Owners, Inc., with the General Motors cab division, have been on the streets for several days, all equipped for radio reception.

PIERRE, S.D., Nov. 16 -- America's semi-arid West is scanning the doctrine of overproduction. More accurately the deluge of conservation news that has flooded the countryside the last few months, the granting of costly new reclamation projects in many States, is at last having its effect and the West is asking, "Are these projects justifiable?"

HAVANA, Nov. 18 (AP) -- As rumors of a new revolutionary movement continued ramant and bombthrowers renewed their activities, War Minister Antonio Guiteras revealed today that martial law would be enforced strictly and plans for liberating political prisoners would be abandoned.

HERE is a lively and engrossing Western that differs from most in that it is based upon historic facts and, like Eugene Manlove Rhodes's other stories of the old rough life of New Mexico, while presented in the form of fiction, is written with painstaking regard for authenticity even in details.

FLORENCE, Oct. 31. IT is now almost three years since Broadway first-nighters, in convention assembled at the Empire Theatre, first saw Elizabeth Barrett and Robert Browning take leave in the last act for Florence, and their freedom from the ogreish tyrannies of Barrett pere.

The National Association of Manufacturers pointed out yesterday that employers' contracts guaranteeing exclusive employment of members of any one organization violated three provisions of the National Recovery Act whether the "closed shop" applied to a company, employer representative or to an outside labor union.

ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 16 -- While most States are digging in for the Winter, Florida is putting its house in order this month to resume its annual Winter role as host to the nation. Throughout South Florida and along the East Coast all agree to the prediction that there will be a definite revival of Winter tourist travel.

One of the most interesting sports events of the Fall season will be staged tomorrow when runners of twenty colleges race through the open stretches of Van Cortlandt Park in the anpual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A., cross, country meet.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 18 -- Despite reported threats of mob violence, seven of the nine defend its in the Scottsboro case are to be brought here Monday from the jail in Birmingham without a military guard.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 16 -- A dozen trade and professional organizations have joined with the Chamber of Commerce of Puerto Rico in making a direct appeal to President Roosevelt for the extension to the island of all national emergency relief and recovery measures.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 18 -- With the varsity playing less than half of the game, the Duke University Bluedevils triumphed over North Carolina today, 21 to 0. A crowd of 32,000 persons, the largest number ever to witness an athletic contest in the State, saw the game.

A MAGNETIC storm, blamed on the sun spots, and a low-pressure area along the eastern seaboard during the early part of the week scattered static into the short-wave realm, but during the clear periods foreign stations found their way into America's November air.

LONDON. ROGER PIPPETT, whose critical articles in The Daily Herald always deserve attention, has been discussing the chances of the individual book amid the vast output of new novels. He believes we shall never see again the colossal sales that a popular novel attained before the World War.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., Oct. 21 -- Dissatisfied with the results of its policy of State relief of the unemployed, New Zealand is attempting to impose a system of piecework on the jobless who hotly resent the effort.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- In its final home game of the season Army defeated Pennsylvania Military College today, 12 to 0, in a stubbornly fought contest. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the game.

THIS account of a dazzling episode in the drab monotony of a Paris bank clerk's life begins with a scene so often described by French novelists as 19 lack any trace of novelty. The young bank clerk picks an acquaintance with a beautiful girl sitting opposite him in an Opera-Passy bus; as one might have guessed, she is dressed in red from top to toe.

HERE is an excellent sequel to a really fine historical novel. "Arundel," the story of Steven Nason's adventures as a scout under Benedict Arnold, and of his participation in the terrible and gallant march on Quebec, is certainly one of the best historical novels yet produced in America.

A DISTINCTIVE viewpoint and original thinking mark this book on a subject that has not yet received adequate attention from medical investigators and writers. Dr. Tucker, who is professor of nervous and mental diseases in the Medical College of Virginia, speaks of its study as being still "pioneer work," and says that its problems have been "largely overlooked," although it is he believes, "in many respects the most important period of life."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of Nov. 14 under "Topics of the Times" seriously misrepresents a proposal for the control of liquor that I offered at the meeting of the National Municipal League. It is represented that I have suggested that whisky after dilution should cost more than undiluted whisky.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 18 -- The University of Maryland defeated Johns Hopkins University, 27 to 7, before 4,000 spectators in their annual game today. It was the thirty-first meeting of the two State universities.

A notice went out to golf clubs in the metropolitan district yesterday stating that the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Golf Association, the governing body, would be held at the Hotel Commodore on Monday, Dec. 18, at 8 P.M.

OVER one hundred years after his death. General James Wilkinson. United States Army, is the subject of a first biography, the text for which is the partisan judgment of his bitterest and most relentless critic -- John Randolph of Virginia -- a master of cutting sarcasm and invective.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 14 -- Whatever other troubles they may have had, the people of Colorado, New Mexico and Wyoming have been relatively free from concern regarding their banks through the entire period of the depression. There have been closings, mismanagement and chicanery here, as everywhere else, but such cases have been widely scattered and the losses suffered by depositors have been slight.

ANN AXTELL MORRIS was richly favored by the gods, who enabled her to know her own mind even at the early age of 6, when, though she knew not the word, she chose the science of archaeology for her lifelong work and joy.

LONDON, Nov. 3 THE audience at the Palace Theatre last night was concerned less with the play than with the players. Fred Astaire had not been seen on the London stage since the marriage of Adele Astaire ended this famous partnership, and interest obviously centred on his new partnership with Claire Luce.

DENVER, Nov. 18 -- The University of Utah football dynasty was swept out of power in the Rocky Mountain. Conference today by an alert, defensively brilliant hand of Denver Pioneers. The score was 13 to 0. It marked the first Conference defeat of the Redskins since 1927.

In behalf of the Prosperity Shop a fashion show will take place Friday afternoon at Sherry's to raise funds for the shop. Packages of useful articles suitable for resale later in the shop will be accepted as part payment for admission, a charge of 25 cents being asked for those with packages and one dollar for those without packages.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Yale took the lead in the Big Three soccer league today by defeating Princeton, 3 to 0. The game was played on a field heavy with snow and mud.

PARIS. THE season for the reopening and renewal of publishing is much later in France than in the United States; in this year of crisis particularly, August and September were almost completely dead months.

SAVANNAH, Nov. 18 -- Carrying into the heart of the old South his fight for the right to experiment and to change government, President Roosevelt today assailed "doubting Thomases" who wanted to let things alone.
BARCELONA, Nov. 17 -- On how Catalonia votes Sunday in her first elections for the National Cortes may turn the future of Spain.

THE title for this new collection of poems by William Rose Benet is from William Blake, that half-mad genius who energized with equal audacity and equal power both in the realm of poetry and in the realm of pictorial art. Wrote Blake:

Seeking to bring about a Federal receivership for all the properties against which S.W. Straus Co. have sold $350,000,000 in bonds, Samuel L. Chess, attorney representing bondholders of the company, filed a bill of equity yesterday in Federal court.
MADRID, Nov. 18 -- Amid tremendous excitement men and women of Spain will get to the polls tomorrow to cast what is expected to be the biggest vote ever registered.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I wonder whether the directors of radio station? WABC and WJZ would consider it good manners, supposing they had been invited to the Lord Mayor's dinner in London, to have arisen and walked out in the middle of the Prime Minister's speech?

BELGRADE, Nov. 4 -- Thirteen peasants appeared recently in court at Cetinje, the capital of Montenegro, charged with the murder of a peasant who had offended their racial traditions by the use of "a devilish instrument" -- to wit, a toothbrush.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- This last week has seen the biggest change in the European situation that there has been in many years. How big, it is not yet quite easy to grasp.

Fordham's season ended in defeat yesterday, but it required the combination of two of the most spectacular scoring plays witnessed on any gridiron this season for Oregon State to encompass the downfall of as game an eleven as ever wore the Maroon. The score was 9 to 6.

AT first glance the title which Professor Chloard has chosen for his biography of John Adams may seem to savor of oversimplification of his subject. Was Adams distinguished chiefly for honesty in the majestic company of the patriotic Americans, whose standards in public life were elevated much beyond those of many of their successors?

The contract between the city of Tupelo, Miss., and the Tennessee Valley Authority, announced last week, is officially described as the standard for all contracts that will be entered into with towns of corresponding size by the government agency.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Director of Public Security today decreed a 7 o'clock curfew and prohibited all automobile and bicycle traffic between 6 P.M. and 5 A.M. The regulations were aimed at suppressing possible Nazi activities.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the performance by well-known Negro entertainers to be held next Saturday night at the Town Hall in behalf of the New York Urban League. Some of those who have volunteered their services are the Hall Johnson Singers, Rose McClendon, Eva Taylor, Clarence Williams, Juano Henandez, Horton's African Dancers, William Bowers, and Ada Ward and the members of the Cotton Club Revue.

IT was an ingenious idea to compile a "history of music" by piecing together essays on different aspects of the art and especially biographical studies of the great composers, by different authorities. Of course, such a compilation is not a history of music.
Distinguished alumni were honered for post-graduate accomplishments at the fifty-third annual dinner of the associate alumni of City College at the Hotel Commodore last night.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 18 -- Captain Roberts for the third straight week led the Tulane team to victory, the Greenies running up a 34-0 score on the Kentucky Wildcats today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Securities issues totaling about $4,000,000 are contemplated in ten registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. They include flotations for mining, distilleries, breweries, real estate, theatre and apartment house activities.

Officers and members of the New York Stock Exchange are subjecting its trading machinery and regulations to the most intensive examination in its history with a view to uncovering for themselves any flaws before Congress meets in January.

The New York Society of the Order of Founders and Patriots of America sent a letter to Mayor O'Brien yesterday asking his aid in keeping children dressed as vagabonds off the streets on Thanksgiving Day.

MILAN, Nov. 6, 1933 WITH the publication today of the official Scala bill, confirming the advance information already published, and on the basis of trustworthy reports on the plans of the other major lyric stages, a sufficiently complete picture of the coming Italian opera season is now possible.

Leading educators and school authorities from Connecticut, New York and New Jersey will participate in the annual regional conference of the Progressive Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania next Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Frederick L. Redefer executive secretary of the association.

The Jockey Club, governing body of racing in this State, again will give its approval to a bill similar to the Wallace-Crawford Bill at the next session of the Legislature, according to an announcement yesterday from William Woodward, chairman.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 18 -- Franklin and Marshall defeated its ancient rival. Dickinson, in their thirty-sixth annual football meeting, on Williamson Field today, 13 to 0. The Blue and White scored early in the first period, when Sielski carried the ball over on an end run.

One of the most important art auctions in recent years will be held here this week when the collection of the late Thomas F. Ryan, financier, will be sold at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John C. Manning of 14 Washington Place gave a dinner party last evening at the St. Regis for Miss Constance Kimpton of Boston.

IT was a cold day, even for the erstwhile Wheaton Iceman. Harold (Red) Grange, once the so-called Galloping Ghost of Big Ten territory, had his hat pulled down and his coat collar turned up. But he soon thawed out and it wasn't long, before he was chatting warmly on old days with Illinois and newer days with the Chicago Bears.

THERE appeared at the door of the Girls Service League recently two girls of about 17, dressed in shirt and knickers, each wearing a sign with the words, "Please Give Us a Lift." They had hitch-hiked from Indiana in quest of adventure in the great city.

Captain George Fried, master of the Washington of the United States Lines, which arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with 619 passengers, said the ship was seven hours late because of the "miserable November weather" that had been encountered all the way across.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- "Bowery night" was celebrated at the Apawamis Club here with a dinner dance tonight. Members and their guests were attired in costumes of the "gay nineties."

Murray Prusmak's touchdown in the third period on a brilliant 65-yard sweep around right end enabled the John Adams High School football team to top Grover Cleveland High, 7 to 0, before 2,500 fans at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

It was the truly magnificent music of George Frederick Handel (Concerto Grosso No. 5) and the emotional drive and the superlative performance of Tchaikovsky's Fourth symphony, and Handel, too, which gave distinction to the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

OCCASIONALLY there comes the opportunity to see a collection of rare pieces of antique decorative art gathered by a man of taste and discrimination and with wealth enough to use museum pieces as furnishings for his home.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Ten above zero temperatures much of the week brought a sharp pick-up in cold-weather items sold at retail. One store reported sales about one-third greater than for the like period of 1932, but the improvement elsewhere was not as pronounced.

THERE are eight articles in the current number of The Colophon, seven of which deal with books and authors. This is as it should be for The Colophon is a magazine for book collectors. The last essay is concerned not with books but with stamps.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Two priceless medieval stained-glass windows that were sold to a wealthy American had been stolen from the Abbey Church of the Trinity in Fecamp, Normandy, the police charged today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is interesting to observe the difference between the reasons that we shall have for a Thanksgiving Day this year and those given a century or more ago, particularly the assignment of Thursday, Nov. 26, 1789, by proclamation of President George Washington as the Day of National Thanksgiving.
The tournament activities of those who play squash racquets in this vicinity during the Winter months are divided into the New Jersey, Westchester and New York sectors.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 18 -- A strong Williams football team, led by a sophomore back, Nick Holmes, upset a favored Amherst eleven in the fiftieth annual contest between the two colleges today on Weston Field. The score was 14 -- 0.

THE earlier volumes of Mark Sullivan's monumental history of the first quarter of the twentieth century in America had a nostalgic flavor, arising from the fact that tremendous changes had swept over the nation they described.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Harvard's freshman football team staged a spirited drive in the last half to trounce the Yale freshmen, 31 -- 6, on the Harvard Junior varsity gridiron today. The teams were tied at 6 -- 6 going into the third period.

IF as has sometimes been stated, the primary function of the historian is to describe the economic and social pattern of a period rather than its battles and politics, then we have here a book which amounts almost to a history of England in the middle of the last century.

ATHENS, Nov. 6 -- In a miniature fortress, high enough above the Gulf of Corinth to see across to where Byron met death in the swampy lowlands of Missolonghi, winemakers are rushing that they may not be tardy when the prohibition amendment is repealed in the United States.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the organization of its committee and engineering staffs that will direct the construction of the New Hudson River Tunnel which will link Manhattan and New Jersey at West Thirty-eighth Street and Weehawken.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. IT is not simple for the German operetta stage to explain why in this day of self-sufficiency it still goes on poaching across Austrian and Hungarian borders for its provender. The now quite customary apologies in the theatre programs are just so much smoke screen.

A CERTAIN amount of happiness in primitive and isolated surroundings falls to the lot of the 200 members of the leper colony of Orafara on the South Sea island of Tahiti, according to a mission from the French Government which recently passed through New York after investigating the colony.

SUGAR is everything in Cuba. When the price is up and the crop is good, everybody is happy. When the price is down and the crop is restricted, hunger and poverty stalk and the political, economic and social life of the country become progressively demoralized.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 -- The football wizardry of a great little quarterback, Irvlne (Cotton) Warburton, today enabled Southern California to blast the University of Oregon out of the undefeated class. About 60,000 spectators saw the home team get away fast, slow down for a time and then come back with a rush to roll up a 26-0 score.

WASHINGTON. WITH the inauguration of the Civil Works Administration, designed to give jobs at living wages to 4,000,000 of the unemployed, half of them now on the relief rolls, the Federal Government last week attacked the depression from an unprecedented angle.

IN his contribution to the Appleton Biographies Series, Mr. Linklater has undertaken a task which called for no little agility and discretion. Under the most favorable circumstance. Mary, Queen of Scots is a difficult subject for a biographer to approach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Liberia was informed indirectly today by the State Department that the United States expected it to cooperate with the League of Nations in re-forming its governing and its finances.

DES MOINES. MILO RENO, the colorful leader of the present farm revolt, stems, oddly enough, from a Renault who was a courtier in the resplendent entourage of Louis XIV -- an intimate of royalty who put away his stately satins and went forth to map the sprawling, half-mythical French province called Louisiana in the late Sixteen Hundreds.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 18 -- Eighteen students and a policeman were injured and more than 100 students arrested in the city of Guadalajara last night in rioting at Guadalajara University. The students demand the right to govern themselves in the university and a government subsidy.

FOOTBALL has rounded out an eventful double victory this year -- victory over the depression and victory over evils that grew up in the period of former prosperity. Again the great American collegiate game is flourishing as the apex of the 1933 season draws near.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Amazed Philadelphians who said it could not be done are still marveling at the rout of the Vare Republican organization in last week's election. While William S. Vare, the boss, sits for a few days under the Florida sun, deciding whether to take the advice of friends and critics and retire from politics, the Democrats at home are enjoying a rare Quaker City experience as the majority party.

WOODMERE, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Two touchdowns by John Vogel, one of which came in the final two minutes of play, enabled the Woodmere Academy football team to come from behind and gain a 13-all tie with Fieldston School of Manhattan today.

ROME, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Folks in Premier Mussolini's home town have looked for 2,700 years upon the famous statue of the Capitollne Wolf that suckled Remus and Romulus, but folks who live far from the Tiber, at the confluence of the Etowah and the Ostanaula, couldn't stand it for nearly so long.

THE story of Beowulf is here told for young people in a fashion that ranks this volume at once among the very best retellings of epic stories. A reader of any age can enjoy this fine and stirring book and for the boy or girl who is ready for heroic legends it will promptly place Beowulf beside Siegfried, Arthur, Roland and the Viking warriors.

HOLLYWOOD. REHEARSALS for "The House of Rothschild," regarded by the town as one of the more important pictures of the year and by George Arliss, its star, as the most lavish film in which he has appeared, are scheduled to begin during the coming week on the Joseph M. Schenck-Darryl Zanuck Twentieth Century stages.

BEING now within hailing distance of his seventieth birthday. Dr. Chapman, curator of birds at the American Museum of Natural History, has set down the testament of a fortunate life. In a world crowded with people who wear their lives away over tasks that do not interest them.

This collection, taking its name from one of the songs included, was intended by the compiler. Lady Bell, who died before the work was completed, to be a family songbook for children and grown-ups alike. The selection of songs is excellent for this purpose.

To the Music Editor: Some years ago you did me the honor of publishing a letter of mine la which I commented upon the remarkable habit conductors have fallen into of "cutting" the last movement of Tchaikovsky's Fifth symphony.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- Topping off the enthusiastic acclaim with which Russia greeted the news of United States recognition, the Pravda will say editorially tomorrow that "it should now be clear to every one that the Soviet Union has overthrown all obstacles to its peaceful construction.''
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Two touchdowns in the first half enabled the Princeton 150-pound football team to defeat the Yale lightweights on University Field today, 20-12.

A legal solution of what is to be done with about $500,000 collected by taxicab operators at 5 cents each from riders between Oct. 1 and Nov. 10, when the taxicab collection was declared to be an illegal tax, is sought in a suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday in behalf of all persons who had paid.

MR. PHILIP HALE, the very distinguished music critic of The Boston Herald, has relinquished his task, at least for a season, to take a muchneeded rest from his arduous and modest labors. His readers and colleagues of two continents will sorely miss his writings, however ably his department of The Herald may be represented.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Nov. 18 -- The West Virginia University eleven ran, smashed and passed to a 26-13 triumph over West Virginia Wesleyan today. They amassed twenty-four first downs on a muddy field while holding the Bobcats to three.

Civil works projects soon to be launched in New York City and State with a monthly allocation of approximately $25,000,000, which will give employment to about 400,000 men and women, will not benefit destitute families for whose relief the Citizens Family Welfare Committee is raising $4,000,000, it was pointed out yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, vice chairman of the committee.
LONDON. DUNVEGAN CASTLE in the Isle of Skye, whose owner, The Macleod of Macleod, recently entertained the Duke and Duchess of York, has a romantic legend which extends back centuries.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10 -- After three years of provisional government, or benign dictatorship as it has also been called. Brazil re-enters the realm of constitutional government on Nov. 15; that is, on that date the delegates elected last May by the people of Brazil to the Constituent Assembly will meet and officially open the Assembly.

APARTMENT-HOUSE dwellers and others whose shelf space is limited may be interested in the publication of what is said to be the smallest complete book ever printed by the letterpress process -- a twenty-eight page, leather-bound volume of forty-six quatrains of "The Rose Garden of Omar Khayyam," issued by the Commonwealth Press of Worcester, Mass.
LONDON. CHIMNEYS will be smoking in the Scottish glens this Winter. Already the pungent smell of burning peat is drifting through the lonely villages which are the fountain-head of whisky.

FIVE years ago newspaper readers were startled with the account of an unusual sporting event. A seeming anachronism in the twentieth century was the steamboat race on the Ohio between the Chris Greene and the Betsy Ann.

ATER months of hard thinking concerning hard liquor, New York State has announced the plan it will follow in dealing with the liquor problem after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The whole State rings with discussion of the regulations put forth by the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board for the sale of liquors and wines.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested in the article, "The Road Out of Devil's Island," by Herbert L. Matthews in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine. It deals with a subject that the Salvation Army has very much at heart at the present moment, although I am afraid the writer confuses the operations of the Howard Association with those of the Salvation Army.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10 -- Feminist leaders of Rio de Janeiro have commenced an "anti" campaign.

MANILA, Oct. 14 -- There is a growing protest in the Philippines against the recent pension order which cuts pensions by 50 per cent, so long as the recipients reside in the Philippines. Governor General Frank Murphy has informed the Veterans Administration that he considers the order inequitable and its basis mistaken, but he has been advised to tell the veterans to be patient and loyal.

There is little economic future for the refugees from Germany who are trying to establish themselves in France, Holland, Belgium and in other European countries, Dr. Jacob Billikopf, president of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service, said yesterday in a statement based on an investigation of the German Jewish situation in various countries.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- In a speech before the National Council of Corporations "Wednesday, Premier Mussolini announced that the reform of the Italian parliamentary system would not be introduced yet awhile.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Syracuse led Colgate for more than three-quarters of the thirty-fifth annual football game between the schools before 15,000 shivering fans at Archbold Stadium today. But a blocked kick and a forward pass on fourth down from Ike Kern to Captain Winnie Anderson and a 70-yard run by Marty McDonough gave Colgate two touchdowns in the closing moments of the game for a 13-3 victory.

SOME three years ago a mound of earth at Ras Shamra on the coast of Asia Minor, opposite the Island of Cyprus, attracted the attention of M. Virolleaud, the French Director of Antiquities for Syria. Excavations brought to light the ruins of a small temple; and in the vaults of this ancient building a library of clay tablets was found.

LONDON. THE turnover in the London foreign exchange market in recent months has been larger than on any other market in the world. If we are to believe some authorities, half the world has abandoned legitimate and sound trading and has entered the dangerous field of speculation in exchange.

OSLO, Nov. 6 -- If the victory of the Labor party in the Storting elections last month results in a Labor Cabinet, as it almost inevitably will, Norway will have a government which, theoretically at least, will be more radical than any other except that of Soviet Russia.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Mary Hall Taft, widow of Charles Ellis Taft and the daughter of the late Benjamin Frank Hall, who was one of the founders of the Republican party, died yesterday at her home here, 425 Central Avenue. Mrs. Taft, who was in her eighty-seventh year, was a church worker and took a prominent part in the activities of many organizations.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 18 -- Iowa's Hawkeyes rose to the heights today to crush mighty Purdue, 14 to 6, and wreck the Boilermakers' chances for the 1933 Western Conference gridiron championship.

"ONCE by the River Moskva there stood only the goodly hamlet of the noble, the worthy Stephen Kutchek. son of Ivan," a medieval Russian chronicle says. Today, on the same spot by the River Moskva stands the fastest-growing city in the world -- a city which has new interest today for the United States because of the discussions over Russian recognition.
WARSAW, Nov. 17 -- The Polish Government and press have displayed remarkable restraint in commenting on the German elections.

ATLANTA, Nov. 16 -- Of the report made to the Georgia Baptist Convention in Augusta this week by its Social Service Commission, nearly one-half was devoted to prohibition and the causes of repeal. This report is of unusual interest since it is one of the first official statements made by a Southern State-wide meeting of churchmen.

The Smithsonian Institution's " Physical Tables " for 1933 is the last place where one would seek romance. Yet it prints figures to make the eyes of treasure-hunters open wide. They are figures of gold -- gold in sea water, gold enough to make every one of the 2,000,000,000 people on earth rich to the extent of $24,000 at prevailing prices.

MILAN, Oct. 31, 1933. THE baptism recently at the Palazzo dell' Arte of Alessandro Cicognini's two-act melodrama "Donna Lombarda" before the awarding jury and a mixed public marked the end of the hearings in oratorio form of the four prize-winning operas of the Milan Triennial Fair contest.

Discussions relating to the wild waterfowl situation will take up a full day of the twentieth session of the American Game Conference, which is to be held in this city on Jan. 22, 23 and 24. From these discussions it is likely a program of legislative action will arise, for there is no gainsaying that a crisis in the wild waterfowl situation in North America is at hand.
MUNICH, Nov. 18 -- Colonel Ernst Roehm, chief of staff of the Nazi storm troops, in an edict today frowns upon their making levies on the public and forbids them to do so in uniform.

THIS novel deals with a future phase of aerial communication that may soon be an accomplished fact. F.P. 1 (Floating Platform No. 1) was a proposed mid-Atlantic landing for passenger planes, designed by young Bernard Droste for the Lennartz shipyards.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 18 -- A strong Muhlenberg offense, with Albert (Red) Weiner the main cog in the attack, defeated Lehigh today in the twenty-third renewal of the series, 10 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Both sides to the Soviet-American bargain are well pleased with it, it may be stated "on high authority," which, in this case, is no empty phrase.

THERE is a certain American consul, somewhere in Europe, whose wife is selling cakes to her neighbors in order to eke out what remains of her husband's consular salary after the Economy Act and the exchange rate have done their worst with it.

THIS red-and-gold Autumn both Yale and Harvard are being run as it were, in sections -- and for the same reason that trains are run in sections, for convenience in handling crowds. Call them "colleges" or call them "houses," they are parts of Yale and of Harvard which carry along the individual Harvard or Yale undergraduate and they are not all of Harvard and Yale till you take them together.

THIS is the story of a glorious failure told by an American woman who accompanied the German-American Himalaya expedition organized to climb Nanga Parbat, the Naked Mountain, so called because its rock cliffs often wear no mantle of snow.
RUTH SLENCZYNSKI, the 8-year-old pianist who scored an exceptional success in her American debut concert at Town Hall last week, will make her final appearance of the season Saturday afternoon.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 18 -- Turning on the power in the second lalf. Captain Biff Jones's Louisiana State eleven kept its undefeated record clean by running and passing to a 31-to-0 victory over University of Mississippi today.

With stimulation afforded by cold weather, retail trade quite generally showed gains during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The consumer's ability to absorb merchandise, however, has not materially improved, and in order to obtain additional business merchants rind it necessary to feature goods at less than replacement basis, the buying office notes.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Considered to have little chance for victory, the football men of Xavier University played their most brilliant game of the year today, romped around massive Indiana, and defeated by 6 to 0 a team that had been figured to beat them.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 16 -- The ribald Bronx cheer attained the dignity of a court-room demonstration at the first-degree murder trial of Serafino Sinatra, better known as Joseph (Wop) English, in the Common Pleas Court of Judge Roy K. Stuart here this week.

IMPROVING on the grains dating from election day, retail trade last week ran at a level here which it was estimated would bring an increase for the half month of about 5 per cent over the corresponding period last year. Cold weather, a readjustment of prices to lower and more acceptable figures and lively promotion have proved the winning combination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A.A. Berle's opening statement in his article, "The Social Economics of the New Deal," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, "there is no mystery about the economics of the 'New Deal'," is reassuring to those whose understanding of the subject fails to equal his.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- American recognition of the Soviet Union is by far the best thing President Roosevelt has achieved, The London Observer says editorially.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Harvard came back to victory today in its last game before the climax battle with Yale next Saturday. Two touchdowns gave the Crimson the edge over Brown, 12 to 6, in a hard-fought, bruising struggle in the Harvard Stadium.

MR. and Mrs. Cole are thoroughgoing Socialists. Not only do they believe in socialism, but they are convinced that socialism offers the only cure for the multiple and grave evils that now distress the European world.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 18 -- Auburn's football team toppled the University of Georgia's national championship contenders from the ranks of the unbeaten in Memorial Stadium today, 14 to 6. The Georgia football machine was outplayed by a fighting Tiger eleven that upset the dopesters.
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 18 -- In one of the most exciting battles played on Alumni Field this season Boston College overcame a hard-fighting Western Maryland eleven by a 12-to-9 score today.

Charitable organizations will be aided by two performances of "Her Master's Voice" at the Plymouth Theatre during the Coming week. The one tomorrow night has been taken over by members of the Junior Auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital Social Service and that on Tuesday night for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm.

WASHINGTON. MR. ROOSEVELT knows his publicity as no President ever has. That may not sound like a Sensational observation to those who watch the workings of Washington from a fireside chair at home, but its tremendous importance will be apparent to all who have seen administrations rise and fall on the basis of their ability to maintain popular public relations.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 18 -- To combat persistent bootlegging and rum running, which has continued in Finland despite the repeal of prohibition, the government obtained today a new weapon.
