Frank Stuart of Sparkill, N.Y., has been named chairman of the nominating committee by the directors of the American Kennel Club. The other members are Thomas Carruthers, Cincinnati; Benjamin Phillips, Philadelphia; T. Dixon Smith, Boston, and Charles P. Scott, New York City.

Hampering the Utilities. Surely the time has arrived when the threats of unfavorable legislation, still more stringent regulation and costly investigation which have been held over the heads of the managements of our public utilities should be renewed.
A calendar of boxing that recalls pre-depression days confronts the fistic fan during the coming week.
CANNES. THE ideal distance between any given author and a play of his that is suffering the pangs of production is 4,561.8 miles.

PITTSBURQH, Nov. 18 -- Another of the football titans was driven from the ranks of the unbeaten today when the puissant Pitt Panthers vanquished Nebraska, 6 -- 0, on the snow-fringed gridiron at Pitt Stadium.

Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor that he hoped that soon New York City would excuse the pupils in its public schools certain hours a week to go to the church or synagogue designated by their parents for religious instruction.

HOW far may an artist go without appearing to have gone, in the vernacular, haywire? Modern art, of whatever age, swarms with invitations to debate this highly debatable though perhaps insoluble problem. Everything depends upon your point of view.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The centennial of the founding of Psi Upsilon fraternity will be observed by a three-day celebration at Union College next week.

AN exhibit of examples of keyboard instruments from the eighteenth century to the present time will open tomorrow in the Museum Room of Knabe Hall, 584 Fifth Avenue. The collection will be open to the public.

THE waters of Davis Strait and Baffin Bay, of Jones and Lancaster Sounds, bear magic names to the traveler who has sufficiently read his Arctic romances. They conjure crushing ice and dim, mysterious bergs drifting in the storm; gales and driving sleet, danger and death.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Informed government circles expressed opinion today that the administration would not extend government credit to Soviet Russia through export guarantees to American manufacturers unless Congress were favorable to the project.

THE Cleveland Orchestra began its sixteenth season at Severance Hall in its home city on Oct. 26, in what the veteran Archie Bell of The Cleveland News described as a "brilliant manner." The big auditorium was jammed to capacity, with all the extra chairs allowed by fire rules filled and such a turn-away as seldom happens at any musical event nowadays.

A three-cornered trading treaty between the United States, Argentina and another country, as yet undetermined, was reported here yesterday to be the objective toward which Secretary of State Hull and other government officials are working.

News that the United States Government had resumed diplomatic relations with Russia after a severance of sixteen years gave no impetus to the domestic speculative markets yesterday. What was expected to be a powerful market influence aroused no speculative enthusiasm at all, no doubt for the reason, as Wall Street was prompt in pointing out, that the possible effect upon America's foreign trade already had been discounted.

KATHARINE HEPBURN, the Jo of "Little Women," at the Radio City Music Hall -- described herself in a hasty vignette last year before she went to Hollywood. "Hartford," she said, "was my home. Went to Bryn Mawr. Not intellectual, though.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Steel, the first major industry to submit a detailed report of operations under an NRA code, has increased its payroll more than $9,000,000 and added more than 92,000 workers under the code, the report of the American Iron and Steel Institute, made public today, revealed.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. FOR once the event was an event. The most notable audience that Boston has assembled since the disappointing first night of "Too True to Be Good" sat before "Mary of Scotland" at the Colonial.

IN one of the early chapters of this book several of the characters are discussing a proposed code for writers of detective stories. The consensus of opinion is that detective stories should have plenty of blood, chills and humor; all clues should be plainly stated; all the murders should be committed by one character, and that character should have an established place in the story.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The fact that the army was able to lend 3,000 officers to the Civilian Conservation Corps is the basis for a movement reported now under way to reduce the officer personnel of the army from 12,000 to 10,000. The argument is that if these officers can be spared from their regular duties, they can be considered surplus and should be eliminated.

Plans for a "Red Cross Sale" for the benefit of the New York chapter, with well-known women behind the counters and authors and stars of stage and screen greeting the customers, were announced yesterday at chapter headquarters by Mrs. L.M. Fish, roll-call director.

Many pastors will in their sermons today refer to the recognition of Russia by the United States, particularly with reference to the religious situation in Russia. In the Methodist Episcopal churches of this area it will be "Foreign Missions Field Day" and several Bishops will preach.

Because of the lateness of Thanksgiving Day, which will leave only twenty shopping days before Christmas, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Retail Code Authority of New York City, issued an appeal yesterday to every shopper to begin buying before the holiday.

TOKYO, Nov. 18 -- The Indo-Japanese effort now proceeding at Delhi to eliminate the tariff and dumping problems by accepting the principle of barter has now progressed to a point where only narrow differences divide the two sides.

THIS week's cable burns with the news that rehearsals for Mr. Shaw's "On the Rocks" have started. The cast includes Lewis Casson, Nicholas Hannen, Lawrence Henry and Ellen Pollock. The play is in two acts, is set at 10 Downing Street, and most of its characters are Cabinet Ministers.

Some of the ground lost in Friday's general break in commodity prices was regained yesterday in trading in futures on Exchanges here. Operations generally were moderately quiet. Cash prices were irregular.

Business activity in October and the early part of this month again failed to respond to seasonal influences and to monetary measures employed to stimulate production and trade, according to the report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry of the National Industrial Conference Board.

MENDHAM, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Sessions of the thirty-seventh Training School for Professional Leaders of the Boy Scouts of America were opened here today at the new Mortimer L. Schiff Boy Scout Reservation, following a dinner and fireside meeting last-night.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- Maine is having two special sessions of its Legislature within three weeks of each other. One met on Tuesday and completed its work in four hours, a record for brevity. It dealt with tha banking situation. The other session will assemble on Dec. 4 to grapple with the dilemma created by Federal repeal in a State which retains a prohibition amendment in its own Constitution.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- British tramp shipping is threatened with extinction, and heroic measures may be necessary to save it, according to men associated with the trade. A committee of thirty, representing owners in all parts of the country, has been appointed by the Council of the Chamber of Shipping to consider the problem.

A CAREFUL selection of oils, temperas and water colors by Josef Foshko makes up the current exhibition at Gallery 144 West Thirteenth Street. The work is modern, while avoiding any sharp break with the traditional. Finished and sensitive, this painting does not go sweet nor does it lack strength.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Maintenance of the spurt in retail sales of last week, and increasing optimism among New York's retailers were reported to General Johnson today by officials of the National Dry Goods Association.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- Though Italy finds nothing remarkable or unexpected in America's recognition of the Soviet, for one of Premier Mussolini's first acts on his accession to power was to re-establish normal diplomatic relations with Russia, nevertheless the negotiations between President Roosevelt and Commissar Litvinoff have been closely followed here and their consummation is hailed today as an epoch-making event.

PEIPING, Sunday, Nov. 19 -- Following a month-long series of conversations with North China governmental leaders which Japan openly hoped would result in formal treaty agreements, the Japnese Minister Akira Ariyoshi is departing for Shanghai today with nothing more than a verbal understanding, which leaves the North China situation continuingly dangerous.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The highly favored Pennsylvania eleven was held to a 6-to-6 tie by Penn State on Franklin Field today. A fourth period pass for a touchdown saved Penn when it looked as if the State College team would score an upset.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The King and Queen of England, wearing their crowns and royal robes, will ascend their thrones in the House of Lords Tuesday, opening in person the new session of Parliament, thereby givthe United Kingdom its most resplendent annual pageant with ancient traditions, linked with prosaic legislation for the solution of present-day problems.

Additional comment from United States Senators on the recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States was received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES in response to its requests. It was as follows:

IT is a humoie and unpretentious science that now faces the world, for all its startling discoveries about stars and atoms. Most of the cocksure laws that once served to explain everything, from the wheeling of the planets to the constitution of matter, have been swept away.

SOFIA, Oct. 29 -- Though Vasilka Gregoreva strangled her lover with his necktie while he lay in a drunken stupor and was sent to jail for two years for the crime, she has found another man bold enough to marry her. His name is Konstantin Tolinoff, an expert housebreaker known as "the King of the Villas" on account of his activities in the suburbs.

PEACE is a fleeting quantity in the theatre. Just as we were congratulating ourselves on the theatre's extraordinary recovery this Autumn along comes Lennox Robinson to complain that the plays are not indigenously American.

MR. HOLCOMBE, who is Professor of Government in Harvard University, foresees in the near future, as many others are beginning to do, a new alignment of political parties in this country, a new attitude of the electorate toward those parties and a new content and arrangement of political programs.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Upsala College closed its football season with a victory over the New York Aggies at Upsala Field today, 24 -- 0. The Vikings scored twice in the first period and duplicated the feat in the final.

CAIRO. CAIRO has been feasting. All Egypt has been celebrating. Once again the Nile has risen to its full height, and for yet another year it has given assurance, as it has done from time immemorial, that it will faithfully perform its task of making the land fruitful and the water supply plentiful.

Important revisions of merchandising practices of both manufacturers and retailers are developing in the wholesale markets as the number of codes approved by the President has grown. So far 117 codes have been approved by President Roosevelt and of these 44 had regulations of specific importance to retailers in their buying operations.

SIR JOHN REITH was in New York a few days ago. As director of British broadcasting he was curious to find out whether Radio City had any novel ideas and devices that might be used on the European edge of the Atlantic.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- What next? This is what British diplomacy asks itself after the failure of the Disarmament Conference at Geneva.

TURNING the great telescope of Mount Wilson upon the sun last month. Dr. Seth B. Nicholson saw a little spot. At the beginning of the present month there was another. The cyclic procession had begun, to last for about eleven years and to raise the old questions that have puzzled astronomers, meteorologists, agricultural experts, economists, geologists, authorities on terrestrial magnetism, physicists and biologists. What are the sunspots?

Stanley Rose of Far Rockaway High School yesterday placed to his credit one of the most brilliant feats achieved this Fall in the Public School Athletic League dual meets for senior high school swimmers.

ON Dec. 1 a new system, designed to place the purchase and sale of used cars on a fairer and more equitable basis both for the dealer and the public, will go into effect. This system is the result of cooperation between representatives of the public and of the retailers, each interested in restoring order to this chaotic phase of the automobile business.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 -- The suspicion that a bucketful of whitewash instead of a tubful of mud was being prepared for their senior Senator and Kingfish was what really raised all the rumpus at the current sitting here of the Senatorial committee investigating the Overton-Broussard primary.

Five persons were injured and nine arrested in street disturbances that lasted for two hours yesterday morning, when 500 Communists attempted to break up a parade of 8,000 Ukrainians from Washington Square to the Central Opera House at Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue.

DAVID BOEHM -- he was a coauthor of the late "Sing High, Sing Low" -- has now written a play by himself. It is called "Gardenia," and as may or may not be suggested by the title, it is a sophisticated comedy of some sort.
A touchdown by George Hutchinson in the second period grave James Monroe High School's football team a 6-to-0 triumph over Central High of Paterson, N.J., yesterday at Monroe field.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- President Roosevelt's nomination of two men for vacancies on the bench of the United States District Court in the Chicago district has sharpened the edge of a situation which is far from pleasing to the chieftains of Illinois Democracy.

THE storm that last week swept from Iowa to New York impaired visibility, gagged pedestrians in cities, obscured the sun in some States, shattered plate-glass windows in others, blew automobiles off the road in Nebraska and made it necessary to turn on lights in the early afternoon was remarkable not so much for its velocity of sixty miles an hour as for its load of dust.

NEGOTIATIONS are in progress for the construction under license in England of the Rohrbach type of paddle airplane, which would derive both lift and thrust from the operation of rotating wings set on either side of the fuselage after the fashion of paddle wheels in a steamboat.

DANVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 -- Lacking the defensive power which enabled it to hold Princeton earlier this season to one touchdown, Washington and Lee bowed before an effective Centre aerial attack this afternoon, 12 to 0.
Scoring in the closing minutes, Curtis High School's undefeated football team vanquished De Witt Clinton High of the Bronx, 6 to 0, yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, before 4,000.

STRASBOURG. AT the French end of the bridge which spans the Rhine at Strasbourg are three miniature concrete fortresses, one or them in the centre of the roadway, from which machine guns could be trained upon traffic crossing from the German side.

"Journalism as a Guild," a subject which is at present greatly interesting the British newspaper world, was discussed recently by the well-known Anglo-American editor Ralph D. Blumenfeld at the annual conference of the Institute of Journalists at Eastbourne, England.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Lanvin's square-necked princess evening gowns that ignore the waistline hint at a new silhouette. Smart women like her black wool all-day frocks with contrasting satin sleeves and turndown collars for Spring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Home Owners' Loan Corporation had completed 6,942 loans with a dollar volume of $20,275,125 up to the close of business Nov. 10. Loans tentatively approved numbered 125,631, amounting to $357,074,376.

GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament' Conference, kept today the lead he had taken. In succession there came to confer lengthily with him Sir John Simon and Anthony Eden of Britain, Joseph Paul-Boncour and Rene Massigli of France and Marquis di Soragna of Italy, whom Premier Mussolini had recalled to Italy in order to mark his unwillingness to confer in Geneva on disarmament.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Nov. 16 -- The independent Kansas banker, the banker in the small town, believes his days are numbered unless he demonstrates that he can do a good job of running his bank. The Glass-Steagall law, which becomes effective next year and permits central or branch banking, is the shadow that grows blacker and blacker.

MAN has tried to make amends to the bee, it would seem, for systematically and continuously exploiting its industry and looting the results of its toil by writing about it with admiration, scientific and practical knowledge, imagination and fantasy.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Holy Cross closed its home season by defeating Springfield College, 19 to 6, in a stubbornly fought game today. With the score tied going into the final quarter, the Crusaders pushed over two touchdowns, chiefly with the aid of their aerial attack.

Recognition or Russia was described yesterday by Max Bedacht, member of the central executive committee of the American Communist party, as a mere consummation of something that could no longer be avoided and no indication of a change of attitude or policy toward the Soviet Union.

The National Bank of Detroit, organized on March 24 last with half of its capital supplied by the RFC and half by leading industries in that city to restore banking facilities in that municipality, has issued for publication today a statement of its condition as of Oct. 25, indicating rapid strides.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- The treasure-seekers who a year ago were raising millions of golden rubles are sunken Russian warships containing millions of golden rubles, are now engaging the attention of the police.

DURING my stay in America a year ago I put the following question to myself: "Is it feasible, in the light of prevailing conditions, to launch a campaign for the spread of the cooperative movement in America?"

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins scored their first victory of the National Hockey League season tonight after three straight defeats, beating the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 7,500. The defeat dropped the Canadiens from a first-place tie into a deadlock with Ottawa for second place in the International Division.

Moscow. THE first All-Union Conference for the Thematic Plan of Soviet Motion Pictures for 1934, composed of representatives from producing units of different nationalities within its borders, recently met in Moscow for a stock-taking of ideas.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- From all parts of the United States delegates were arriving today for the forty-fifth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union which will open at the William Penn Hotel tomorrow and continue until Tuesday.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The German Supreme Court, which for two months has been trying to solve the riddle of the Reichstag fire, concluded today its search for evidence on the arson part of the indictment against Marinus Van der Lubbe and his four co-defendants.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 18 -- While Nanking officials persist in declarations of confidence in their ability to settle the Fukien Province secessionist project politically, Shanghai representatives of the Fukien leaders insist that a full-fledged government will soon be established at the provincial capital, Foochow.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Four stakes were completed today and two more will be run tomorrow in the fifth annual field trials of the American Spaniel Club. The meeting opened this morning on the Ivor estate in the Dix Hills and a large gallery of spaniel enthusiasts followed the work of the cockers and springers in the heavy covers.

IN 1921 the Commonwealth Fund commissioned the Institute of Educational Research at Teachers College to evaluate for vocational prediction certain items of school record as well as of psychological measurements. Under Dr. E.L. Thorndlke's direction the institute attempted to ascertain the significance of school records of "scholarship," "conduct" and attendance, and of teats of intellect, clerical ability and mechanical adroitness for vocational success.

Mr. and Mrs. Grattan T. Stanford of 1,060 Fifth Avenue gave a dinner dance last night in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Mrs. Stanford is the former Miss Effa Dunn of Milwaukee, Wis.

MANILA, Oct. 18 -- The perplexing problem of a rainy-season sport in the Philippines has apparently been solved; Manila has gone wild over badminton. The game has been played here on the well-kept lawns of a few members of the British community for a number of years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The employment bureau at Rutgers has aided 175 students who are working their way through college by obtaining positions for them since the opening of the Fall semester, Edward H. Heyd, assistant dean of men and director of the bureau, announced today.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- After a race over a trying snowcrested course, Oronoke Paul, a liver and white pointer, owned by Dr. C.H. Beere of Waterbury, Conn., today captured the annual Derby Stake, which marked the opening session of the field trials of the Verbank Fishing and Hunting Club's two-day meeting.

In a recent address in this city, Professor TUGWELL turned epigrammatic and said: "Hell hath no fury like a "professor whose theories are dis"turbed." He was referring to the group of financial authorities whom he described as "orthodox economists," and who have had and expressed doubts about the monetary experiments of the Government.
Miss Edith Voehl, president of the Pan-Hellenic Association of Hunter College, announced yesterday that twenty-three Hunter sororities had pledged 106 students.

IN cold-test laboratories, where the worst conditions of Winter weather are not merely reproduced but exaggerated, automobile engines start easily and perform efficiently. Yet millions of motorists have trouble starting their engines in cold weather.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Colonel Arthur W. Brown, on detached duty in connection with the administration of the territory of Leticia, S.A., where he represents the League of Nations Commission, was named today by President Roosevelt to be Judge Advocate General of the Army to succeed Major Gen. Blanton Winship, who retires under the age limit, Nov. 30.

IN that most human and delightful of all London's showplaces. the Wallace Collection, we are greeted by the portrait of a lady by Sir Thomas Lawrence. It is a portrait that is as familiar to us, whatever its artistic merits, as the Mona Lisa herself.

IN "The Forest of Adventure Raymond Ditmars tells in the form of a romance the exciting experiences of a scientific expedition to the American tropics in search of rare specimens. The story represents, as Dr. Ditmars says in his preface, "composite adventures of the author and the experiences of scientific friends."

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 16 -- The announcement, earlier in the week, from Washington, that $18,000,000 had been voted for work on the projected Midnight Sun Highway has revived interest in this scheme, which already has been approved by the governments of Canada and the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By executive order, the President has directed that $25,000,000 from the great public works appropriation be used to set up "subsistence homesteads" as a means of stimulating a back-to-the-land movement from unduly crowded industrial centres.
LEBANON, Pa., Nov. 18 -- Lebanon Valley defeated Drexel today, 16 to 6, Lebanon Valley scored in the opening period on a safety when Smith broke through and downed Potter behind the goal line.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- As a result of the recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States, Michigan is thought likely to reap a financial harvest because of the expected demand for products, especially automobiles.

Bond prices on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly in the two-hour trading period yesterday. In general, United States Government bonds worked irregularly lower and domestic corporation bonds and leading foreign loans irregularly higher.

GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- Norman H. Davis, the United States Ambassador at Large, will arrive home in circumstances' his European colleagues will envy. The Americans are a people who seem convinced not only that one of their soldiers can beat ten foreigners, but that it takes ten of their diplomats to equal one alien in a bloodless struggle.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 -- The powerful University of Minnesota eleven, led by Pug Lund, blasted Michigan's hopes for national gridiron honors today. More than 65,000 spectators watched the Gophers and Wolverines battle to a scoreless deadlock.

Last week's changes in the Treasury's personnel -- especially the resignation, of Under-Secretary ACHESON -- occasioned inevitable comment and conjecture. That the position of the Treasury during the past eight months has in many respects not been of the traditional character, every one was aware.

THE purpose of this series is to rescue history from being a captive subject of dullness, of mere dates and facts, and to make great occasions live again by dramatic treatment. Mr. Johnson is capable of writing in such a vein, and Secession is a topic worthy of the first American volume.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The text of General Johnson's report to President Roosevelt concerning the operations of the steel industry's code during the ninety-day trial period is as follows:

THE protest by the Broadway Association against the use of amplifiers and other noisemaking instruments by political parties, spectacular advertisers and theatrical promoters directs attention to the city's campaign against noise.

TOKYO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Ninety million loyal Japanese prayed today that the child to be born soon to the Empress will be a boy, an heir to carry on the "dynasty for ages eternal." Physicians in the imperial household announced that the child might be born late in December or early in January.

IT is with pardonable elation that RKO-Radio Pictures announces the acquisition of screen rights to George Bernard Shaw's satiric comedy, "The Devil's Disciple." The transatlantic cables started humming with the impudent project seven months ago and continued to hum in the teeth of the Shavian scorn.

Marked gains in retail trade occurred in all Federal Reserve districts excepting St. Louis and Kansas City during the last week. The increases were due in part to the cold spell, which brought larger movements of Winter goods and in part to early Christmas buying.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Oct. 27 -- Manchukuo launched its initial venture in aircraft construction recently when two locally built planes took the air. They were built and will be used by the Manchukuo Air Transport Company.

DESIGNS for the Metropolitan's new production of Richard Strauss's "Salome" are to be prepared by Donald Mitchell Oenslager, graduate in 1923 of Professor George Pierce Baker's Harvard Workshop 47, and since 1925 instructor and Assistant Professor of Scenic Design under his former chief at Yale.

IT is with pardonable elation that RKO-Radio Pictures announces the acquisition of screen rights to George Bernard Shaw's satiric comedy, "The Devil's Disciple." The transatlantic cables started humming with the impudent project seven months ago and continued to hum in the teeth of the Shavian scorn.

Marked gains in retail trade occurred in all Federal Reserve districts excepting St. Louis and Kansas City during the last week. The increases were due in part to the cold spell, which brought larger movements of Winter goods and in part to early Christmas buying.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Oct. 27 -- Manchukuo launched its initial venture in aircraft construction recently when two locally built planes took the air. They were built and will be used by the Manchukuo Air Transport Company.

DESIGNS for the Metropolitan's new production of Richard Strauss's "Salome" are to be prepared by Donald Mitchell Oenslager, graduate in 1923 of Professor George Pierce Baker's Harvard Workshop 47, and since 1925 instructor and Assistant Professor of Scenic Design under his former chief at Yale.

Unbeaten on their home gridiron this season, the New York football Giants will face a stern test this afternoon when they oppose the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds. The game will bring together the sectional leaders in the National Football League, and the Giants will make a strong bid against their Western adversaries.

A SMALL group of professors representing educational institutions on and near Morningside Heights, in association with representatives of various religious and philanthropic institutions of the neighborhood, are making a study of the community about them with a view to discovering the needs of its population and improving the general conditions of living.

Branch Brook Park in Newark will be the scene of two big schoolboy cross-country runs during the next two weeks. Of major importance is the eighth annual national interscholastic race, to be contested there on Thanksgiving Day morning at 10 o'clock.

English furniture, tapestries, silver and art objects from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Talmage of New York and Mendham, N.J., brought $43,615 yesterday afternoon at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., making the total for the two-day sale $76,947.50.

President ROOSEVELT'S note to Mr. LITVINOFF, extending recognition to the Soviet Government, expresses a wish from which very few will dissent. " I trust," wrote Mr. ROOSEVELT, "that "the relations now established between "our peoples may forever remain nor"mal and friendly, and that our na"tions henceforth may cooperate for "their mutual benefit and the preserva" tion of the peace of the world."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 -- Led by their crack halfback, Beattle Feathers, Tennessee today scored the most decisive victory ever registered over a McGugin-coached Vanderbilt team by the Volunteers. The final count was 33 to 6.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 18 -- Andy Pilney, sophomore back from Chicago's West Side, led Notre Dame out of football's wilderness today as the Ramblers defeated Northwestern, 7-0.
BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The Reich "Chamber of Culture," which is to shelter all the so-called external manifestations of higher mental life in the new Germany, was solemnly dedicated this week.

Led by Robert Mitchell and Captain Sid Luckman, the unbeaten Erasmus Hall High School football team crushed Boys High School, 36 to 0, before 4,000 spectators at the Boys High Stadium yesterday. The triumph was the fifth in six starts for Erasmus, the other resulting in a tie.

GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- After seeking in a long conference with British representatives for a way to resuscitate the Disarmament Conference, Foreign Minister Joseph, Paul-Boncour of France said tonight the two governments no longer were agreed on how to handle the problem of German arms demands.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- An advertisement in small type in the "Agony Column" of The Times recently revealed that John Fothergill, one of the few really individual innkeepers left, would be glad to receive offers of small hotels or proposals for cooperation in bigger enterprises.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Guarded closely against lynching, Thomas H. Thurmond was taken today from the city prison to San Mateo Bridge to point out the place where he and John M. Holmes threw into San Francisco Bay the trussed and unconscious Brooke Hart, whom they confessed they Kidnapped for ransom.

Young women headed by Miss Mary King-Smith are aiding in the arrangements for a fashion show which will be held in conjunction with a luncheon Wednesday at Sherry's for the benefit of the Riverside Day Nursery. The proceeds will further the work of the nursery, which maintains headquarters at 149 West Sixty-third Street for the purpose of caring for infants and small children whose mothers are employed during the day.

HARTFORD, Nov. 16 -- Bridge port, self-styled Industrial Capital of Connecticut and third larges city of the State, has become the second city of more than 100,000 population in the United States to elect a Socialist Mayor, but Bridgeport does not seem to be at all concerned about it.

EUREKA, Nev., Nov. 16 -- Those high in the councils of Nevada Democracy are learning anew the adage, that with roses comes thorns -- even when watered by the welcome showers of patronage. During his last two terms Senator Key Pittman was of the minority party, and had no worries over appointments.

The first of the series of Festival Concerts to be given this season in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Aid took place last night before an audience estimated at between ten and twelve thousand. Walter Damrosch, who inaugurated the series last year arranged the concerts of the present season, conducted.

Displaying the same powerful offensive that has characterized its play all season, the undefeated Flushing High School eleven crushed Jamaica in the thirteenth renewal of their annual rivalry yesterday. A capacity crowd of 6,000 at the Jamaica Stadium saw Flushing come through with a 43-0 triumph.

A suit for $100,000 damage brought by Mrs. Josephine Bingham, a widow, of Whitestone, L.I., against William H. (Big Bill) Edwards, former Princeton football star and former Collector of the Port of New York, was disclose yesterday.
MADRID. THE Spain of literature and legend is disappearing fast. Who wants to see flounced senoritas in high comb and mantilla will soon have to look for them on the stage or at masquerades.

THIS title is not a salutation but the name of a Chinese boy who served Mr. Maugham for a year in the East while he was "inventing'' (his own word) these six long tales about English men and women, exiles of empire living in far-flung outposts of progress.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 18 -- Alabama's Crimson tide swept to victory over Georgia Tech today, 12 to 9.

It appeared, so described, on Jan. 21, 1789. Mrs. ROWSON'S "Charlotte Temple," still remembered, came out the next year. Writing of its predecessor in The American Review, Mr. TREMAINE McDoWELL calls" The Power of Sympathy: or The Triumph of Nature" a "harmless little tale."

Confidence that the price differential provision in the master code for the wholesale trades would prove acceptable to the NRA administration was expressed here yesterday by officials of various wholesale organizations who attended the hearings in Washington during the week.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 6 -- As a direct consequence of the increasing political tension in Central Europe and persistent reports of Nazi activity along the southern border of Denmark for the alleged recapture of North Schleswig, said to be one of the goals of the "third empire," Scandinavianism has once again become a clear-cut issue here in the North.

Identification of the Egyptian Queen who rescued the child MOSES from the bulrushes and determination of the date of the fall of Jericho have had a fitting sequel in the recent discoveries reported by Sir CHARLES MARSTON. A whole library of clay tablets was found three years ago in the course of excavations on the coast of Syria north of Beirut.

FINGERPRINTS of kidnappers, extortionists and gangsters are being handled under a new plan at the United States Bureau of Investigation -- a plan designed to simplify the process of identification and increase the bureau's effectiveness.

NOVELTY has been called "the great parent of pleasure." But real novelty is as seldom encountered as a century plant in bloom. And so it was a welcome relief to jaded listeners whose vicarious dial wanderings last Sunday night put them in tune with Will Rogers's diverting allegory on world politics.

Manhattan, playing its last game of the season, conquered a favored Catholic University eleven in a bitterly contested battle at Ebbets Field yesterday, 7 to 0. The victory was Manhattan's foremost achievement of the year, and it was gained before 8,000 thrilled spectators.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 -- William Woodward's Dominus just lasted to win by a nose and lead home a field of seven fast 3-year-olds in the mile and a sixteenth of the Prince George Autumn Handicap before 10,000 persons today.

America's greatest auction sale of postage stamps, comprising the United States collection of the late Arthur Hind, will begin tomorrow afternoon at 1:30 o'clock in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The sale will be continued every afternoon during the week through Friday.

MANY persons answering the questionnaire recently addressed to licensed pilots, student pilots and mechanics by Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics, Department of Commerce, have apparently misunderstood the purpose of that memorandum, it was ascertained last week.

Church and Nazis. German Protestants, It now seems fairly certain, will not be called upon to abandon the Old Testament in favor of the Nibelungenlied. This is a goal for which super-Nazis in the Evangelical churches appeared to be headed.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 18 -- The Coast Guard Academy defeated Norwich University of Northfield, Vt., 8 to 7, at Jones Field today. This was the last football game of the season for the local cadets and was attended by about 2,000.

The higher income given by the NRA to low wage groups, which form the bulk of customers in the smaller stores and the smaller towns, and the better competitive position due to the manufacturers' codes, are among the major benefits thus far noted by owners of small stores doing up to $350,000 annually, it was reported here yesterday by an executive in close touch with small store developments.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Dr. William A. Wakeley, who practiced medicine here for forty-two years and whose interest in the treatment of cancer was largely responsible for the establishment of the Metcalf Memorial Foundation, died last night after a stroke at his home in Main Street.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Dr. William A. Wakeley, who practiced medicine here for forty-two years and whose interest in the treatment of cancer was largely responsible for the establishment of the Metcalf Memorial Foundation, died last night after a stroke at his home in Main Street.

The New York Americans will make a belated appearance on their home ice when they oppose the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although the season is almost two weeks old, the spangled skaters have not appeared in this city yet, and a large crowd is expected to welcome them against the Maroons.

VIENNA, Nov. 18 -- After a hearing significant for the absence of any attempt to prove he had been inspired to commit his deed by the Nazi party, Rudolf Dertil was sentenced by the Vienna penal court today to five years' imprisonment for shooting and slightly wounding Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss.
Victor Kosow, a ctothing salesman, has brought suit against his daughter, Sylvia Sidney, the screen star, to set aside her adoption by Dr. Sigmund Sidney, a dentist.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 10 -- One of the last few requisites necessary to set this country off on an unparalleled era of prosperity is now taking shape in the Eastern Prov- ince of Cape Colony, the principal outlets of which are East London and Port Elizabeth.
SAVANNAS, Ga., Nov. 18 -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows:

AN old, old woman, scheming, ruthless, indomitable, is the outstanding character of Marguerite Steen's new novel, "Spider," in whose intricate, cleverly woven web every other person in the book is more or less closely enmeshed.

Retirement of John H. McCooey as Democratic leader of Brooklyn, either in the near future or some time after Jan. 1, was reported yesterday to be a probability. A majority of the Brooklyn Assembly district leaders were said to have expressed a willingness to go along with the Roosevelt wing of the party, headed by Postmaster General James A. Parley, and to be ready to pick a leader to succeed Mr. McCooey.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The "Hitler confidence boom" continued on the Boerse today. Despite week-end profit-taking, both stocks and bonds advanced. Heavy industrials and chemicals gained up to 2 per cent, and lignites, cables and electricals, up to 4, while the rest of the list made minor advances.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 18 -- A Miami detective and a gunman died in a pistol duel here tonight at the entrance to a downtown hotel.

Replying to the arguments of opponents that its proposed systemwide door service would be provided at les than cost, the Pennsylvania Railroad joined other companics in filing yesterday a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission in which it was argued that free collection and delivery were designed to meet a popular demand for lower rates.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, Count and Countess Mercati (the former Mrs. Newbold Leroy Edgar) were among many notables of the American colony, and of Parisian and cosmopolitan society, who attended the opening of Prince Henry XXXIII of Reuss' exhibition of paintings the other day at the Jean Charpentier Galleries in the Faubourg St. Honore.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, Count and Countess Mercati (the former Mrs. Newbold Leroy Edgar) were among many notables of the American colony, and of Parisian and cosmopolitan society, who attended the opening of Prince Henry XXXIII of Reuss' exhibition of paintings the other day at the Jean Charpentier Galleries in the Faubourg St. Honore.

LUM AND ABNER are in town. The two boys from Arkansas who play the ethereal rustics are seeing the sights of New York before snuffling off to Boston and Chicago. Their nightly broadcasts usually emanate from Cleveland and they are due back home in ten days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Marcus Schussheim, of New York, six times national champion, won the men's singles title in the American zone tryouts for the world's table tennis championship last night by defeating Max Rushakoff, Chicago, 21 -- 14, 21 -- 14, 21 -- 19.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19. -- The opponents of the metric system for track and field measurement in the United States are fighting a losing battle. This became evident today as the various committees of the Amateur Athletic Union concluded their deliberations at the William Penn Hotel prior to the opening of he forty-fifth annual convention tomorrow.
ROME, Nov. 19. -- A strong suggestion that Italy might quit the League of Nations was published today in three Italian newspapers, one of them Premier Mussolini's Popolo d'Italia.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- At a mass demonstration against war by the Women's Peace Crusade, joined in by seventeen British organizations cooperating with similar women's groups in the United States, last night, Great Britain, was urged to more forcible efforts to halt rearmament and save the Disarmament Conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19. Bishop William T. Manning, addressing 5,000 persons in the West Chester County Centre this afternoon at the second annual Bishops' mass meeting for Westchester and vicinity, said that a great movement was on foot for spiritual recovery.

The National Export Trade Committee announced yesterday that more than sixty industries of the United States largely engaged in exporting had approved the conditions worked out by the National Recovery Administration under which exporting industries shall be exempt from the NRA code provisions.

The deadlock for first place in the Eastern individual scoring race, which had existed since Nov. 4, was broken on Saturday when Winter, of Davis and Elkins, tallied four touchdowns against Albright. Tinney, his team-mate, who had been tied with Winter, at 67 points each, registered one touchdown and five points after.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- A more healthy situation is developing in corn with speculative interests well divided. Several of the largest and most successful corn traders take a constructive view of the situation, and buy futures on every sharp price decline.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- President Roosevelt's decision to enter diplomatic relations with Soviet Russia has "removed an anomaly which long ceased to serve any useful purpose and which indeed had become extremely inconvenient to both countries," in the opinion of The London Times.

HAVANA, Nov. 19. -- Apparently fearing another revolutionary movement, the student-army government carried out many defense preparations last night and today to prevent a surprise attack. Guards at strategic points in the city were doubled; machine gun nests were constructed in various places and a large number of soldiers were again stationed in the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- "Capacity to pay" is a phrase that may be heard somewhat frequently in Soviet-American conversations during the coming week. And what is more, heard no less from Russian lips than from American.

BOSTON, Nov. 19. -- Trinity Church in Copley Square, founded more than twoscore - -ars before the nation, and the leading Episcopal church in New England, began today a week's observance of the bicentennial.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Nelson Macy was host at his home here this evening to about 100 persons at a concert given by the Perole String Quartet.
BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The wholesale German price index on Nov. 8 was 95.9, against 96.1 on Nov. 1. The index has risen every month since April, but the pace of the rise lately has slackened.
The New York Americans soccer team ended its recent slump by downing the Newark Germans, 3 to 1, at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,500 spectators.

Richard Bartscheidt, 2 years old, was burned to death while sleeping in his crib yesterday when fire destroyed the home of his parents at 12 Ocean Avenue, Bast Hamilton Beach, Queens. The father and mother, Gustave, 33, a laborer, and Anna, 28, were visiting neighbors at 10 Ocean Avenue at the time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Preliminary approval has been given to the organization of eighty-six Federal Savings and Loan Associations in twenty-six States and charters have been granted to twenty such associations in seven States, according to an annoucement made today by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

It was inevitable, after four weeks of confusion under dollar-manipulation and with last week's sudden halting of the experiment, that financial interest should have converged almost exclusively on developments in that direction. The fact that this Autumn's reaction in production, trade and prices (primarily a result of overdone midsummer recovery) had been arrested, and that considerably more cheerful indications had begun to appear ia various industries, attracted little interest.

S.B. Hasten. J.H. Wantling and C.J. Winninger tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished with a card of 95 out of 100 targets. Masten broke 25 straight in the shoot-off to carry off the honors.

BOSTON, Nov. 19. -- Curtis Henderson Glover, 25 years old, who left Dartmouth College in his junior year to "lead the life described by Thoreau" in the Northern woods, was found dead this morning in the kitchen of his home in Melrose Highlands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Organization of an Inspection Division "as a safeguard against graft, waste and slipshod work" to check up on all non-Federal projects and "see that every Public Works dollar is spent as intended" was announced today by Secretary Ickes.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Victorious in two of the qualifying classes. Miss Elizabeth Hyland of Greenwich, Conn., concluded a successful afternoon by carrying off the championship rosette for horsemanship at the Bronxville Riding Club's junior horse show today.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The sharp rally in the dollar does not inspire any real confidence here. It is believed that President Roosevelt has become alarmed at the rapid fall of the dollar, but that he is as determined as ever to force it down. The feeling is that there has been a change of tactics, but not of policy.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- During this week another French Cabinet is expected to fall. Maybe it will be on Tuesday, but almost certainly by Thursday or Friday Premier Sarraut's ministry will be defeated. After that no one can predict what will happen.
Purchase of apartment houses for investment featured the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end:
Abolition of the tipping system in restaurants and other places was urged yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, New York City NRA Administrator.

ATLANTA, Nov. 19. -- To prove the practicability of theories that good newsprint could be made from Southern pine, nine leading daily newspapers of Georgia will issue their regular editions tomorrow on newsprint secretly made from this source.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- Gaining ground with almost every stride, Joe Mundy, unattached Philadelphia runner, won the national junior A.A.U. championship cross-country title today. He finished 300 yards ahead of Herb Trefferson, Meadowbrook Club harrier, who was second.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19. -- At the historic spot where Abraham Lincoln seventy years ago today delivered his Gettysburg address, the nation was called upon anew today to preserve a government "of the people, by the people and for the people."

The cotton market, which continued to be governed last week by monetary factors, reflected the advances in the dollar prices of foreign currencies by continuing its upward movement. Support was given also by continued strong Southern holding, strengthened by the announcement from Washington that the 2,400,000 bales of farmers' "option" cotton from the crops of former years would receive the 10-cent loan privilege.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Washington news is the dominating feature in the grain markets, with the price of gold, silver, British sterling and Canadian exchange the chief factors. Irregularity in prices of sterling, with speculation in gold and currencies in this and other leading countries, has created a lack of stability, extreme nervousness, sharp fluctuations in prices of speculative articles and a disposition toward ex treme caution such as have not been known in years.

Investments of approximately $340,000,000 in real estate, plant, equipment and rolling stock will have been made by the whisky and wine industries in the United States before Jan. 1. The figure, based on a recent survey, was announced yesterday by G.M. VanderBeek, managing director of the National Wine and Spirits Show to be held next month in the Hotel Astor.

Educational changes "almost revolutionary in character" have been set in motion in New York City high schools during the last ten years, according to the annual report of District Superintendent John L. Tildsley to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 19. -- Allan Clark and Sheridan Fahnestock were the leading skippers today in the frostbite dinghy races held on Manhasset Bay under the auspices of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Soviet Russia's first Ambassador to the United States will be Alexander Antonovich Troyanovsky, formerly its diplomatic representative at Tokyo and now vice chairman of the State Planning Commission.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 19. -- Aurelio J. Manrique and Antonio I. Villarreal, both prominent oppositionists to the National Revolutionary party, were arrested today at the conclusion of a meeting of a coalition of independent parties at Politeama Theatre this morning.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 18. -- Production of gold in Ontario in October amounted to $3,448,362, not taking the premium into account, which was a gain of about 580,000 over the figures for September, but the second lowest for the year to date.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 19. -- The meeting yesterday of the Palestine Arab Executive, attended by thirty-four representatives from all the districts, decided that every town should hold a demonstration against Jewish immigration, led by a representative of the Arab Executive, on the first day of the Bairam Feast, on Jan. 17.

Grete Stuckgold, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company whose recital of German lieder last season remains one of the most distinguished and thrilling performances of many years, again appeared at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon before a large and rapturously responsive audience.

DETROIT, Nov. 19. -- The Detroit Red Wings, backed by stellar work from their goalie, John Ross Roach, overwhelmed the champion New York Rangers by 4 to 1 tonight in an exciting National Hockey League match before about 12,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Although still undecided as to terms on which it will make advances to railroads for new equipment purchases, the Public Works Administration announced today that progress had been made on plans for lending, on security, to railroads for repairs to locomotives and freight cars.

Nearly 66 per cent of the mothers who died in childbirth in New York City in the years 1930, 1931 and 1932 could have been saved by the application of proper medical knowledge, and 61.1 per cent of these avoidable deaths must be directly charged to the medical profession, it is stated in a 290-page report on "Maternal Mortality in New York City," made public today by the New York Academy of Medicine.

In his address at Savannah on Saturday the President showed, perhaps for the first time publicly, that he is unpleasantly aware of the spreading criticism of his monetary policy. He spoke of the "doubting Thomases" who complain about the "great experimentation" undertaken lay the Government.
ISTANBUL, Nov. 6. -- A group of Christian mosaics, hidden for centuries in the Mosque of Santa Sofia, has at last been uncovered.
The Fifth Avenue Association opens a ten-day membership drive today -- its first in seven years -- to fill the gap in its ranks caused by the depression.

The Christless nations of the world are pressing closer on us each year and we will have to raise them to Christ through the work of foreign missions, or have them drag us down to their Christless level, Bishop Middleton S. Barnwell of Idaho declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the Mayor's committee on water supply, headed by Peter Grimm, asserts the belief that about 150,000,000 gallons of water are lost daily as a result of leaks in the house pipes and faucets. If we assume the population of this city to be 7,000,000 people, this would indicate a loss by leakage of about 21.5 gallons per capita.

Trading in commodity futures on Exchanges here last week was featured by violent movements in both directions, although on balance most staples gained for the week. The strong rally on Thursday, regarded as somewhat of a phenomenon because it accompanied a vigorous recovery in the dollar, was offset on Friday, when the dollar recovered further.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 19 (AP) --Al Jolson will end his motion picture career upon completion of his next film, now in production.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 72.1, which compares with 71.6 a week ago, 71.8 two weeks ago, 71-6 three weeks ago and 71.5 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When government becomes nurse it la not easy to wean its adopted children. They will not listen to the explanation that the government cannot, and should not, except for a very limited time, support them. They have been encouraged In the belief that government can create prosperity, a belief easy to inculcate and difficult to eradicate.
Although virtually devoid of major upsets, the past week-end's scholastic football activity produced several notable victories for teams in the metropolitan district.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- The best hogs in the market here were held at $4.50 to $4.60 a hundred pounds last week. Shippers' hogs and light hogs ended about $4.35 lower. Hogs averaging 195 to 265 pounds were $3.30 to $4.55, with 255 to 400 pound stock at $3.10 to $4.50, and 125 to 195 pounders at $3.75 to $4.60.

Set a musical comedy In a modiste's shop and, presto! you may indulge yourself in a fashion show. The fabricators of "Roberta," which opened at the New Amsterdam Saturday evening, have treated themselves to a particularly ravishing fashion show as the finale to the first act.
BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Professor William E. Dodd, United State Ambassador, discussed Martin Luther's oworks today at the Luther celebration in the American Church in Berlin.

Several bazaars arranged in behalf of various charitable under-takings will be held in the near future. The Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York will open a three-day bazaar, patterned along the lines of old English fairs, on Wednesday at the Biltmore after a luncheon.

Cardinal Hayes presided yesterday and delivered a congratulatory address at the diamond jubilee celebration of St. Boniface's German Church, Second Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. The Most Rev. Joseph F. Rummel, Bishop of Omaha, Neb., was the celebrant and delivered the sermon at a solemn pontifical mass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The intention of the administration to enlist unemployed teachers in the national war on illiteracy was announced tonight by Colonel Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to the President, in his weekly radio talk, over a National Broadcasting Company network.
BOSTON, Nov. 19. -- The burly Boston Redskins ruined the Green Bay Packers' famed passing attack today as they won a National Football League game by 20 -- 7 before a crowd of 16,500 at Fenway Park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to make an appeal in behalf of the pigeons in Central Park and in various other parts of the city. These tame and lovable birds are well fed by those who frequent the parks in Summer, but as soon as the cold weather sets in they are deserted by their former friends and many of them die of starvation.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,608,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The most difficult schedule ever undertaken by a Columbia football team has been arranged for the Blue and White in 1934. Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics, announced yesterday that the Lions again would play an eight-game schedule and six of the encounters will be classified as major combats.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- A comprehensive program of banking reform to eradicate the present admitted weaknesses of the system and to insure safety for depositors is recommended in a report made public today by the Association of Reserve City Bankers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The Hills made pretty much of a family party of the Larchmont Yacht Club's third Winter dinghy regatta which was sailed today. Dick Hill won half of the eight races held in Class B, and his wife, Mrs. Helen Hill, took three contests in Class A.

A resolution has been passed toy the Association, of Buying Offices, Inc., condemning "organized effort on the part of guilds, associations or groups arbitrarily to establish fixed prices, which do not recognize the economic advantages of volume business," it was announced here yesterday by H.T. Kleinhaus, executive secretary of the organization.

The plan and deposit agreement of the Consolidated Traction Company 5 per cent forty-eight-year gold bonds due on June 1 last has been declared operative as of today, owing to the deposit of more than 95 per cent of the $15,000,000 of bonds outstanding.

COLON, Panama, Nov. 19. -- Mr. LaGuardia and his wife were guests tonight of Exalted Ruler J. W. Dwyer and fifteen officers of the Cristobal (C.Z.) Lodge of Elks at a dinner dance in a Colon club. The LaGuardias plan to take off early tomorrow morning by plane en route to the United States.

From all accounts the three public hunting grounds in New Jersey which the State has thrown open this season for the first time are proving very popular. Sportsmen are finding the areas well stocked with game and easy of access.
MADRID, Nov. 19. -- Spain marched to the polls this morning to the tolling of church bells and voted for conversatism as opposed to continued revolution.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- The Brooklyn Dodgers today handed the Chicago Cardinals their eighth defeat of the season in the National Football League, winning by 3 to 0. With only two minutes of play remaining in the second period, Herman Hickman, Dodger guard, kicked a field goal from placement from the 25-yard line.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 19. -- President Roosevelt today requested Sumner Welles to retain his post as Ambassador to Cuba, following a five-hour conference on the reported critical situation there. However, he sent Mr. Welles on to Washington tonight to confer for several days with Acting Secretary of State Phillips.
Notes on Recognition. Senator BORAH, heartily endorsing recognition of Russia, appears in the very unusual role of agreeing with a considerable number of his countrymen.

SCARSDALE, N.Y. Nov. 19. -- Upsetting traditions, father's way of setting the dinner table has won first prize in the Scarsdale Woman's Club's latest competition for the best table arrangement, it was learned with surprise today by the club's 900 members.

Optimism toward improvement in trade was characterized as "silly" by the Rev. William G. Peck, rector of St. John the Baptist Anglican Church of Manchester, England, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A plan for reduction of the Federal tax on beer of 3.2 per cent alcoholic content by weight from $5 to $3 a barrel and imposition of a tax of $7 a barrel on beer of higher alcoholic content will be presented to the next Congress.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19. -- The first public toast to the health of President Roosevelt was drunk tonight at a dinner in celebration of recognition, given by the press department of the Foreign Office for American correspondents.

WOODBURY, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Two men escaped death narrowly today when the automobile in which they were riding crashed through a small railroad bridge on the Mantua-Sewell road near here and plunged 200 feet to the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, a Republican, announced yesterday that he would press for passage at the coming session of the Legislature a series of bills for revision of the New York City charter and for up-State county and township governmental reforms.

Speaking yesterday morning at the first service in the new Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman declared that "this is to be Christ's church in the City of New York, limited by no local, national nor denominational boundaries, seeking only to be a place where man may meet Christ."

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The gold exodus from Paris this week, indicated by the 730,000,000 francs loss by the Bank of France, was chiefly to London. Gold purchases for United States account were really insignificant. They have not aggregated more than a few tens of millions of francs, and amounted to only a few millions last week.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Giving a brilliant performance, Oronoke Seaview Mike today was selected as the winner of the open all-age stake which climaxed the two-day field trial meet of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club. Oronoke Seaview Mike, a liver and white pointer, is owned by Dr. C. H. Beere of Waterbury, Conn., whose Oronoke Paul was the winner yesterday in the Derby Stake.

Presenting a stanch defense that turned aside rival threats, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club triumphed over the St. Nicholas sextet, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 7,000 persons in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Like the poet who found sermons in stones, Dr. Herbert P. Whitlock, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has found murder in a geological specimen. The specimen is a small fragment of Vesuvianite, and for fifteen years Dr. Whitlock has used it, unaware of its significance, as a paperweight.

Ch. Han Chuan of Orchard Hill, a Pekingese owned by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lockhaven, Pa., took the best-in-show award last night in the toy dog exhibition held by the Progressive Dog Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania. This was the first show the club has staged, and thirteen breeds were represented.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 19. -- Demand for an 8 per cent return on its investment in place of the 6 2-3 per cent ordered by the State Railroad Commission in its recent gas rate reduction was made by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company in a petition for a rehearing filed today.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- As broadsilk manufacturers completed plans tonight for the reopening of mills tomorrow, union heads made arrangements "to resist in every way possible the attempt to break the broadsilk strike."

More than 100 athletes from twenty colleges will face the starter's gun in the thirty-fourth running of the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. cross-country championship today over the Van Cortlandt Park course. Manhattan College will defend its varsity and freshman team titles.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 19. -- President Roosevelt was urged today to intervene and avert the danger of mob violence tomorrow when seven of the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case are to be arraigned here in the Morgan County Court House.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler made public yesterday correspondence rejecting, as president of Columbia University, a request made to him by a students' club to cancel the Dec. 12 lecture of Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador.

The line-ups of the two all-star teams which will represent the New York Field Hockey Association in the Northeast tournament at Greenwich, Conn., on Friday were announced by the selection committee at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The greatest weakness of our election machinery is perhaps the constitution of the district election boards. Under the law this board is composed of four members called inspectors, two each appointed by the major political parties.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 19. -- Mexico today celebrated the twenty-third anniversary of her successful revolutionary movement with a parade along the principal avenues of 30,000 athletes, representing all Mexican sports. At the Presidential palace President Abelardo Rodriguez, surrounded by his Cabinet and foreign diplomats, made a patriotic speech.
Word from Panama that Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia contemplates building city-owned, non-profit beer gardens on the banks of the Harlem River was received here with mixed feelings.

Sponsored by the College Art Association and arranged as a benefit exhibition "for the purpose of establishing an immediate purchase fund for the relief of needy artists and for the continuation of the relief work of the association," a Salon of American Humorists will open Dec. 4 at 480 Park Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19. -- With half a dozen or more fist fights climaxing the game, St. Mary's Gaels and Santa Clara's Broncos battled to a 6-6 tie today in their annual football contest.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 19. -- Pilot James Wedell of Patterson, La., set a new airplane speed record of 5 hours, 1 minute and 39 2-5 seconds between New York and Miami when he landed his low-wing monoplane at the municipal airport here late today.
BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- There is great elation in Nazi circles that the biological aims of the Nazi program, designed to multiply and "purify" the German race, are beginning to show practical results.

PANAMA, Nov. 19. -- Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia, on the eve of his departure from the Canal Zone, revealed today his public works plans in an interview after he had communicated with his advisers in New York by telephone yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- A possibility that scientific enemies of society have, in some cases, succeeded in eliminating fingerprints caused speculation today in law enforcing circles.

Not in years have civil service reformers had so much cause for encouragement as in this city and State in the last few months. In one decision after another the courts have upheld and defended the merit system. Under one such recent decision little nests of privilege in the municipal courts here are about to be swept clean.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Evans Sperry will give a dinner dance Jan. 1 at the St. Regis for Mrs. Sperry's debutante daughter, Miss Georgia Buck. Miss Buck will be introduced formally at the first Monday german in Baltimore Dec. 4.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 19. -- The Rose Bowl football situation became slightly scrambled as a result of yesterday's games. Pour possible candidates for the New Year's Day game were defeated, and another was held to a tie.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Governor Albert C. Ritchie today suggested that circuit judges displace State's Attorney John B. Robins of Somerset County unless he arrests the nine men whom eyewitnesses have sworn had a part in the lynching at Princess Anne, Md., last month.

Contributions to the 1933 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies now total $2,312,873, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin J. Buttenwieser and Paul Adler, joint chairmen of the drive. Gifts last week amounted to nearly $400,000.

TOKYO, Nov. 19. -- Complaints that, despite the 60 per cent currency depreciation, farm products are cheap, the agricultural depression is as bad as ever and domestic consumption has not revived, were made today by Kisaburo Suzuki, president of the Seiyukai, at that party's opening meeting of the oratorical campaign preceding the legislative session.

Full support of the Citizens' Budget Commission's proposals for thorough reform of the city's pension systems was announced yesterday by the Merchants Association. Voicing its conviction that the city's general financial condition could not be properly adjusted until the various pension funds were placed on a sound actuarial basis, the association made known its intention to ask the 1934 Legislature to pass thirteen bills designed to accomplish that end.

MUNICH, Nov. 19. -- The opposition to Nazi rule that has been developing for some time in the Catholic Church, especially in Bavaria, was the subject of a speech at Neuberg on the Danube today by Premier Siebert of Bavaria, who taxed the Bavarian Catholic Bishops with being half-hearted in their loyalty to Chancellor Hitler.
In a diary kept by the mother of WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT this entry is made for Nov. 3, 1794:

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Former Judge T. Arthur Hendricks, Democratic State committeeman, who was permanent chairman of the Democratic State Convention which nominated Herbert H. Lehman for Governor, died suddenly at his home here this morning.

BOMBAY, Nov. 19. -- The depreciation of the dollar in terms of the pound sterling has caused great anxiety in cotton circles here, which see therein a menace to Indian cotton cultivation and cotton exports. It is reported that one Bombay mill already has placed orders for American cotton because of the favorable price.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Bituminous coal production increased to 7,210,000 tons the week ended Nov. 11.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Cold weather, scattered snowfalls earlier than the average stimulated general business in the Middle West last week and in a measure offset slight recessions in some lines. In all, the business done was reported to be materially in excess of that of the last few years at this time, in spite of the unsettled financial condition.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will address a meeting of brokers today in the building of the New York Stock Exchange in behalf of the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a fund of $4,000,000 for unemployment relief.

The Doubleday, Doran campaign for the new novel by Sinclair Lewis has just opened. The novel, which is to appear here on Jan. 24, will be published in many other countries and many languages, but the publishers say that it will not be brought out in Germany.

More New Yorkers joined the Red Cross in the first week of the 1933 roll-call campaign of the New York Chapter than during a similar period last year, Mrs. L.M. Fish, roll-call director for the chapter, announced yesterday at her head-quarters, 315 Madison Avenue.

Intolerance in religion has been largely caused by fear of the supernatural, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, declared in his sermon yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- The reduction in the suicide rate in New York State, which was first noted in February, continued during September.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 19. -- Trading in cotton contracts in this market was moderately active last week, although professional traders furnished most of the business as speculation by the public continued decidedly slack. The tendency of rices was upward, although the extreme spread between the high and low points was only slightly more than forty points.

WHEN Max Miller, author of "I Cover the Waterfront," came to New York from San Diego on very short notice to substitute for Heywood Broun in turning out a daily newspaper causerie, he was scared stiff. His knees quaked in the vicinity of the Woolworth Building; queer noises assailed his ears when he took the "L" in West Broadway.

The racketeer, if he has his way, will not be suppressed by the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, according to George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, who will end a three-year term of office tomorrow.

Martha Graham's first performance of the season at the Guild Theatre last night proved to be a large event in every sense of the word. An audience, including in its numbers many distinguished practitioners of the various arts, occupied all the seats and every available bit of standing room.
The ranks of the unbeaten and untied among the major football teams of the country were thinned further as a result of the games last Saturday.

Estimates for the first budget to be submitted to Congress by the Roosevelt Administration are now in the final stages of preparation. Some figures will be sent to the House Appropriations Committee at the end of the week. Others will follow in time to permit subcommittees to hold hearings early in December.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- The political aspect and the magnitude of the ceremonies today celebrating the 450th anniversary of Martin Luther's birth were eclipsed by the startling and unprecedented step made by the Roman Catholic Church in announcing virtual solidarity with non-Nazi Protestant pastors against the radical factions of the Nazi churchmen.
Faced with a two-goal deficit early in the third period, the New York Americans rallied to gain a 2 -- 2 overtime tie with the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Protestant insurgency against the Nazi church dictatorship and all that it implies reached a stage of open rebellion today when 3,000 Evangelical pastors from as many pulpits throughout Germany warned Chaplain Ludwig Mueller.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Considerable anxiety has been aroused in German and foreign church circles over a report that the units comprising the Free Church Council -- the German Protestant denominations outside the Evangelical Church -- are to be incorporated in the new Reich Church headed by Bishop Ludwig Mueller.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Summarizing the record of the National Labor Board, Senator Wagner said today that disputes disposed of since the board was organized had involved more than 300,000 workers.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 19. -- Champion My Own High Time scored another notable victory today to complete a unique record in the American cocker spaniel world. This remarkable red and white dog, owned by Herman E. Mellenthin and handled in the field by Elias C. Vail, both of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., captured the open all-age stake for cockers.
The American Council of Learned Societies announced yesterday the completion of the twelfth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES in reporting the Elmira meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs quotes Professor Jay B. Nash of the Department of Education, New York University, as demanding a revised system in the public schools "so there may be something of art, music or of literature aroused in the spirit to fill up the later empty hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, having assailed the administration's monetary policy in a demand for return to gold, plans to investigate the NRA program with a purpose of promoting radical changes.

Cincinnati is basking in the sun of national publicity. She has a City Manager, and a good one: C.A. DYKSTRA, successor to the popular Colonel SHERRILL. She has a City Council elected by the much-debated means of proportional representation, a device which Judge SEABURY would like to see introduced in New York.

GENEVA, Nov. 18. -- The disarmament conversations, which were broken off after Germany rejected the offer of Oct. 14 and quit the League of Nations conference, were rearmed here today for three hours at a tea given by Arthur Henderson, the president, and Foreign Minister Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, rapporteur of the conference.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 19. -- Loyola University's fleet backs dashed for long runs to give the Wolves a 26-7 victory over the University of North Dakota today. It also was a long run that brought the Ione Sioux touchdown, when Charbonneau sped 66 yards for the only local score against the Maroons this season.

FROM what happened in the Palmer Stadium, it is evident that Army can look to something more than a dress parade in the annual debate with the Navy, and, furthermore, the Yale-Princeton conference in the Bowl should be highly entertaining. Navy outplayed Princeton in the first half on Saturday and as late as the fourth period was still steaming along with apparently nothing worse than a scoreless tie on the murky horizon.

An important acreage deal in Northern Westchester County has just been closed in the purchase by A.I. Schweizer of Ossining of the Donaldson property in Bedford Centre, containing five acres with a large dwelling and outbuildings. It adjoins David's Brook and the properties of Nelson B. Williams and Holbrook Cushman.
