Sharp criticism of the Nazi regime in Germany and protest against attempts to spread its doctrines in this country were expressed yesterday in a resolution adopted by more than 1,000 delegates at the third annual convention of the North East Religious Union at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

American recognition of Soviet Russia was lauded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis, who recently expressed approval of the Soviet Government's attitude toward the Church in Russia. Dr. Davis, who is pastor of the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, West Fourth Street, near Washington Square, preached the sermon at the morning service there yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- It was remarked here this week that the United States was now faced with the following dilemma: Either to arrest the dollar decline and cause prices to fall or, by causing a further fall in the dollar, to shake public confidence in national credit and currency.

General Motors Corporation is replacing present type front axles and springs with an entirely new front wheel assembly, known as knee-action wheels, in all its 1934 models in connection with General Motors silver anniversary, it was announced here yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation.

Cold weather stimulated retail sales of ready-to-wear last week and, as a result, substantial orders came into the local markets for coats. Manufacturers' stocks were cut down and in many cases were not replenished. However, a few houses are producing new popular-price lines for three to four days' delivery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Optimism over the outlook for economic betterment under the Roosevelt program was voiced in an analysis of the present economic situation today by Charles A.R. Wardwell, Assistant Professor of Statistics and Finance at Northwestern University.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19. -- Striking success has attended Finance Minister Federico Pinedo's conversion of the entire internal debt into 5 per cent bonds. Holders of 72 per cent of the total circulation accepted new bonds at a lower interest rate.
Indications of improving realty conditions in Manhattan are seen in the steadily increasing demand for dwellings and apartment properties in the upper east and west side sections of the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Hearings of far-reaching importance to the petroleum industry and to the public will begin tomorrow morning when the problem of price-fixing will be taken up by the Petroleum Administrative Board for decision. The hearings, called by Secretary Ickes as administrator of the petroleum code, are expected to last several days.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19. -- The general tone of the steel market has improved distinctly in the last ten days, and producers are expecting a better year-ending than had been hoped for. References are made to the steady manner in which small consumers are buying steel, placing orders at regular intervals, and to customers appraising their wants for the future at higher levels than were formerly indicated.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The State Department is studying Russia's new political and economic organization preparatory to sending consuls to the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- Victory of the Hitlerites at the election at first had no visible effect on the markets. At the beginning of the week, while bonds were steady, stocks underwent a new decline. Business in the preceding weeks had anticipated the government's well-arranged success and for the first days after the election the market seemed to hesitate, awaiting reactions abroad.
For the second successive day the field goal was the instrument of victory at the Polo Grounds yesterday, proving that the kick is still in football.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP). -- Pressing the search for the body of Brooke Hart, 22-year-old victim of a kidnap plot to obtain $40,000, the authorities found his hat today on the mud flats on the Alameda County side of San Francisco Bay.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19. -- Ibero-American unity must be firmly established before Pan-Americanism can be usefully developed, said the Mexican Foreign Minister, Dr. Jose Miguel Puig Casauranc, upon his arrival here, en route to Montevideo as head of the Mexican delegation to the Pan-American Conference.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 19. -- A public holiday, with banks and shops closed, will be celebrated in Fukien Province tomorrow, when a declaration of independence is expected to be announced jointly by Foochow and Amoy. Parades by soldiers, trade unionists and school children are scheduled.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Frank E. Samuel of Indianapolis was re-elected national adjutant of the American Legion by the national executive committee today.

Activity in the listed bond market was sharply curtailed yesterday, compared with the brisk business done throughout last week. United States Government bonds dipped in sympathy with the weakness in the dollar, while leading foreign loans moved higher.

There may be rivalry among polar explorers, but there is also cooperation and friendly service when needed. LINCOLN ELLSWORTH'S response to Admiral BYRD'S request for help in getting the latter's big monoplane on to the Ross Sea Barrier, that "I will always go fifty-fifty with you," brings to mind AMUNDSEN'S cheerful assistance to Admiral BYRD at Spitsbergen when both of them were about to compete for polar honors in 1926.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday 6 to 9 points net higher.

The Grand Central Galleries are blowing all their golden trumpets this week. The Academy of Rome Fellows of 1933 bring forward samples of their three-year achievement, in the main galleries on the sixth floor of the Grand Central Terminal, where, next Thursday afternoon at 4 o'clock, the annual "Founders' Day" celebration will take place.

THE unofficial stenographer was unable to identify the speakers in the weekly football huddle. The report received leaves them simply voices in the night. One man's guess is as good' as another's in trying to solve the puzzle. The report is here with submitted for inspection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Speaker Henry T. Rainey told a radio audience tonight that the administration is battling against poverty and unemployment and would carry on until the last vestige of the old order was destroyed. The problem, of the Roosevelt administration, he asserted, was to combat the effects of twelve years of reactionary legislation which culminated in the distressing conditions of last March and April.

BARCELONA, Nov. 20 -- The latest reports tonight indicate an important advantage was gained in yesterday's election by the Conservative Lliga Catalana in opposition to Colonel Francesc Macia's party of the Left known as the Esquerra An outstanding feature of the balloting was that Colonel Macia's stronghold of Barcelona, capital of the region, probably was won by his chief enemy, the Lliga.

BELFAST, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Unionist Government of Northern Ireland won the general election contest today before the voting. Acclamations in the nominations for the fifty-two seats were sufficiently numerous to provide a Unionist majority over all other parties in Parliament.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater Now York filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday a protect against the efforts of railroads and truckmen to block the proposed store-door delivery and freight pick-up service which the Pennsylvania and Erie Railroads plan to put into operation on Dec. 1.

Hailed in England as a "publishing miracle," the new popular-priced fifteen-volume edition of "The Cambridge History of English Literature" is published here today by Macmillan. In England 4,000 sets of this new edition have been sold and 4,000 more have been printed for sale here, with advance orders already taken for 2,000 sets.

A delegation of professional men, led by Dr. Maximilian Cohen of Brooklyn, called at the office of the Department of Hospitals yesterday to press their demand, made on Nov. 4, for the dismissal of Dr. Ignaz T. Griebl from the city service.

With the government advancing its gold-buying price 10 cents an ounce after five days of unchanged quotations, the speculative markets displayed some enthusiasm yesterday and moved upward rather sharply. The dollar naturally had a setback in the foreign exchange market.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Princeton's varsity eleven was excused from practice today as the rest of the squad opened preparations for the Rutgers game on Saturday. The first-string team will start work tomorrow.

DUNEDIN, New Zealand, Nov. 20 (by wireless) -- The hold of the Wyatt Earp, expedition ship of the Lincoln Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition, is being stowed with New Zealand butter, cheese, biscuits, bacon and other commodities to make up sufficient supplies to last the expedition for eighteen months.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- All hopes of avoiding another civil war were abandoned last night when, after a day of hurried conferences, the Central Political Council, in session at Nanking, issued a statement denouncing the leaders of the Fukien Province independence movement and adding:

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 20 -- Momentum is being gained in the campaign to have banks sell preferred stock and capital notes to the RFC, to strengthen their capital structure, increase loaning facilities and aid banks in becoming eligible for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, according to Jesse H. Jones, RFC chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- What sounds like the dullest subject in the world -- the Federal budget -- is coming in for closest attention from the administration these days. By about Dec. 5 Director Douglas is supposed to have the government's housekeeping plans ready for the next year.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 20 -- The poise which has enabled President Roosevelt to create a new era of informality in the Presidential office failed today in the face of complications caused by a glass of soda water.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 20 -- The Navy squad today started special preparations for the Army game in Philadelphia Saturday, while its comrades began to decorate surrounding buildings with banners bearing the slogan, "Beat Army."

Beginning next Tuesday trolley car passengers to and from the St. George Ferry on Staten Island must walk about 800 feet between the ferry house and Richmond Terrace as the result if an Appellate Division ruling in Brooklyn yesterday.

It is understood definitely that there will be no change in the names of the two German steamship lines to be operated by a central operating company for the first two years in Bremen and then probably for a term in Hamburg. That means, it was pointed out yesterday, that the North German Lioyd will retain its house flag and title and the Hamburg-American will do the same.

Forty plans for the restoration of Bryant Park, including twenty-three prize-winning designs, submitted in the contest held by the Architects Emergency Committee, of which Julian Clarence Levis is chairman, were placed on exhibition under the auspices of the Sixth Avenue Association yesterday in the lounge of oew's Ziogfeld Theatre, Fifty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue.
To the Editor of The New York Times: While so much is being said, and so little will be done, to permanently put an end to Tammany Hall and its methods. I would like to make several suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- State Department officials are closely watching developments in connection with the Disarmament Conference, but are not prepared to indicate their course until some decision is made. Geneva dispatches stating that the conference might suspend occasioned much interest at the department today, but officials would not discuss such an outcome in advance.

Two years ago it was the municipal elections in Spain which gave an ominous sign of the unpopularity of the Government, and were quickly followed by the abdication of the King. Similar indications were thought to emerge from the same electoral contests this year, but the Government of the Republic made light of them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Preparing for Saturday's intersectlonal game at Stagg Field with Dartmouth, Coach Clark Shaughnessy gave the Chicago squad a light workout to day. Tomorrow Shaughnessy intends to bring a starter's gun to the practice to help correct the timing of the blockers, firing the gun at appropriate moments.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman from his sick bed in New York City today proclaimed the period from now until Thanksgiving Day a period for the "mobilization for human needs."

The Fifth Avenue Association is opening a membership drive to recoup the losses resulting from the depression. It seems strange in a way that there should ever have been any. Here is an organization dedicated to the maintenance of those standards and traditions which have mads the avenue famous, it is not too much to say.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the banker and the student of economics the Federal Reserve Bulletin, published monthly by the Federal Reserve Board, has always been held in high esteem as a source of facts. So far as it has interpreted business or economic trends it has always carefully given the obvious interpretation of statistical data.

Argument on a motion to set aside an accounting in the estate of Herman Sielcken, coffee merchant, filed in 1921, on the ground that the administrators were guilty of fraud and collusion, will be heard Friday morning by Surrogate James A. Foley.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 -- The undefeated gelding Chase Me made it five in a row today when he captured the featured Loch Haven Purse at a mile and a sixteenth. The son of Purchase and Mayanel, a 4-year-old, never raced at two and three.

Eleven members of the board of administrators of the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms were elected yesterday at a meeting in the offices of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, 42 Broadway. Five representatives were elected by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms of New York, five by other leading associations of brokers and one by brokers who do not hold memberships in any association.

The first drastic step by a government agency under the NRA to enforce the collective bargaining provision of the National Recovery Act was taken yesterday by the Regional Labor Board against two shipbuilding corporations and three of their subsidiaries in the New York area.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles Fearing Swan will give a luncheon for her debutante daughter, Miss Julia Post Swan, today at the headquarters of the Colonial Dames of America, 421 East Sixty-eighth Street.

The City Fusion party will make no drive to obtain political patronage from Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia, but will devote its energies to a permanent fight for clean government in the city, Maurice P. Davidson asserted last night at a meeting of the district chieftains of the City Fusion party in the Chanin Building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been asked by Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to expedite his reply to the request of the commitmittee for all the facts regarding RFC loans, totaling $4,250,000.
Football now enters that period of its season where past performances mean little. Games rich in tradition bring together teams which are keyed up to the highest pitch of the campaign.
The city's bankers, represented by J.P. Morgan Co. as agents, bought $70,000,000 of city relief bonds yesterday in the office of Controller George McAneny.

GENEVA, Nov. 20 -- The four powers secret meetings continued today under the chairmanship of Arthur Henderson, president of the disarmament conference. It was officially announced that these meetings would be concluded by a sitting of the disarmament conference bureau on Wednesday.

The hand of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, was seen yesterday in the appointment by District Attorney crain of three young lawyer to his staff. They took the places of three others dismissed last week, they contended, because they had left Tammany and joined the McKee Recovery party in the last Mayoralty campaign.

Increased enrolments in nine divisions, with many firms and individuals contributing who had not done so in the last four years, were reported yesterday in the annual Red Cross membership roll-call of the New York Chapter. Mrs. L. M. Fish, chapter roll-call director, announced that Victor Moore.

Time money quotations tightened, although the market remained nominal so far as volume business and sizable trades were concerned. From 90 days' forward rates rose 1/4, highest since August. Elsewhere, Stock Exchange call money, commercial paper and acceptances were quiet and rates unchanged.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday in trading on local commodity exchanges. Silver, rubber and hides closed with gains in the contract markets, while copper, sugar, coffee, cocoa and silk showed losses on the day. Trading was less active than last week. Cash prices were irregular.

SALEM, N.J., Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- A balloon in which Lieut. Commander T.G.W. Settle of the navy and Major Chester L. Fordney of the Marine Corps soared through the stratosphere yesterday was believed to be somewhere in Southern New Jersey early today.

The consolidated income account of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30 shows gross revenues of 551,966,752, comparing with $58,012,859 in the preceding year. Net earnings were $23,082,332, against $27,131,249, and total income was $23,725,252, against $28,404,768.

In yesterday's matches of the Class C tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association, the victors were the Yale Club, Harvard Club, Princeton Club, Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and City Athletic Club.

Tom Ottey, blond-haired 23-year-old junior from Michigan State, raced over the six-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday to win the individual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship.

Asserting that only by increases in dividends in prosperous times and a decrease in less favorable times can the safety of policy holders be preserved, John R. Hardin, president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday that the 1934 dividend rate for the company would be about 83 per cent of the present scale.

Religion and happiness in love are the best remedies for a would-be suicide, according to Dr. A.A. Brill, psychiatrist and author Dr. Brill addressed members of the National Save-a-Life League at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore, celebrating the twenty-seventh anniversary of the organization's founding.

Speaking as chairman of the Retail Code Authority, having jurisdiction over more than 50,000 retailers in the city, Grover A. Whalen declared in a radio address over Station WEAF last night that the buying public had an opportunity to cooperate effectively in the national recovery program by doing its Christmas shopping early.

By a roundabout process the American consumer is now subsidizing the export of wheat at lower prices than it brings at home. Washington dispatches yesterday reported the sale of 3,000,000 bushels in Latin America and the Orient by the North Pacific Emergency Export Association.

George P. Douglass, who remembers when Central Park West was "tickled to death" with its new horse-cars, attended a luncheon yesterday at which directors of the Central Park West Association expressed the hope of soon being able to do away with "the old-fashioned electric trolley."
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Dr. John Ferdinand Golden, surgeon, was killed today in a fall from big eighth floor apartment to the side walk below.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 20 -- Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia and his party flew 1,000 miles above the blue waters of the Caribbean today, landing here at sunset after nine and a half hours in the air. They took off in a Pan American Airways amphibian plane at 7 o'clock this morning from Colon, ending their Canal Zone vacation.

After fourteen years of control of street traffic by flashing lights, pedestrians will at last "get a break," if plans mapped out by Dr. John A. Harriss, who introduced the city's present system, are approved by Police Commissioner Bolan.

In preparing for the revenue from the sales tax on liquor in stores, restaurants, hotels and elsewhere, the State Department of Taxation and Finance announced yesterday a drive against speakeasy proprietors to force them to pay their share of the taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Conferences between Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, and American officials on the actual machinery for resumption of normal relations began at the State Department this morning and proceeded informally all through the day.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- A new nationwide propaganda agency to preach the necessity for large "Nordie" families was established today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Interior Minister. It is called the Reich Health Service Committee.

Directors of E.I. duPont de Nemours Co. voted yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock. This in addition to the regular quarterly payment of 50 cents a share, will be paid on Dec. 15 to stockholders of record Nov. 29.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- An undercurrent of nervousness was still evident on the Stock Exchange today, but prices in most departments held steady. British Government securities were firm and Brazilian and German bonds notably strong.
The text of former Governor Smith's address yesterday opening the Citizens Family Welfare Committee drive follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been a great deal of rather slighting editorial reference to Dr. George P. Warren of Cornell as a farmer or farm professor, and all that sort of thing. It happens that my home is in up-State New York where we have seen Dr. Warren in action for twenty-five years.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. Friday. For the best names. ........1 1/4% 1 1/4% Quotations are for three to four months paper.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Since the beginning of the year, foreigners have hoarded u73,160,570 of gold in London, according to an estimate based on official figures. The bulk of it is believed to be stored in vaults here for safekeeping.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, at a public hearing before the County Board of Supervisors this afternoon, criticized E.M. Allen, president of the County Taxpayers Association, for failing to appear to defend his attacks on recreation.

NRA Against Tips. Mr. WHALEN wants to abolish tipping in hotels and restaurants. As local head of the NRA he is in a peculiarly strong position, because the spirit of the NRA is opposed to the chief argument which one hears in defense of the tipping system.

More than three hundred postage-stamp enthusiasts, including dealers from many parts of the country, expert philatelists and average collectors, were present yesterday afternoon in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astorja Hotel at the opening of the five-day auction sale of the collection of United States stamps owned by the late Arthur Hind of Utica, N.Y.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The will of Mrs. Caroline McBain Johnson of Bernardsville, widow of James Wood Johnson, president of Johnson Johnson in New Brunswick, was admitted today to probate by Surrogate John Zulauf of Somerset County.

Tau Epsilon Phi, first ranking fraternity at Columbia College in scholarship in 1931-32, has maintained its position during the academic year 1932-33, it was announced yesterday by John Backes, '34, chairman of the Pamphratria Committee on Scholarship at the college.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Rose Cohen and Irving Kern gave to Pauline Cohen a mortgage for $6,200, payable Oct. 4, 1936. at 6 Per cent, with quarterly amortization, on the southeast corner of Lafayette and Bond Sts., subject to a first mortgage for $5,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued today. Advances in prices among "blue-chip" stocks reached 4 per cent in some instances. Bonds were led by industrial obligations, which gained beyond 2 per cent. Toward the close profit-taking by professional traders caused a drop from the best prices of the day, but the close was steady.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- An additional $48,000,000 will be distributed throughout the South by the Commodity Credit Corporation in loans of 4 cents a pound on the 2,400,000 bales of government-owned cotton covered by options growers have taken in the crop-reduction campaign.

Prohibition repeal showed continued stimulation of the metropolitan realty market in the business leases reported yesterday. In addition to rentals by wine and liquor dealers, various restaurateurs, furniture houses, garment firms and other commercial lines arranged for quarters.

The four-story tenement at 336 East Fifty-sixth Street, between First and Second Avenues, was purchased by the Condais Realty Company from Mrs. Anna Stanley. Douglas L. Elliman Co. acted as brokers. The house is on a lot 18 by 100.5 feet.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, the largest sportsgoverning body in the world, voted almost unanimously today to boycott the 1936 Olympic Games at Berlin unless there is a change in the attitude of the Hitler government toward Jews in sport.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A stenographic report of the radio conversation today between Rear Admiral Ernest J. King and Lieut. Commander Settle of the stratosphere balloon follows, in part:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today raised the price at which it will buy newly mined domestic gold to $33.66 an ounce, 10 cents above the quotation maintained since last Tuesday. No explanation for the action, which ran counter to the criticism by the United States Chamber of Commerce of the President's monetary policy, was obtainable in any official quarter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Maxim Litvinoff conferred today with William C. Bullitt, who is to be the first American Ambassador to Moscow, as well as other officials.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -- A new conception of the universe and its unthinkable dimensions, embracing a new genesis of the stars, the nebulae, the galaxies and the super-galaxies, was presented here today at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, before the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by the Abbe Georges Lemaitre, famous Belgian astronomer, and Professor Harlow Shapley of Harvard University.

All markets gave a confident response yesterday to the action of the government agency in raising its price for gold in the domestic market. At least, that was the incident that Wail Street cited in explaining the upward movement on the various exchanges after the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had resumed its "gold manipulation."

The gold medal of the New York Historical Society was presented last night to DeWitt McClellan Lockman, the artist, in recognition of his work in portraiture at exercises commemorating the 129th anniversary of the founding of the society, at its headquarters, 170 Ccnti'al Park West.
Pete Young of Bluefield College virtually has clinched the national football scoring honors for 1933.

Iowa has long teen one of the wealththiest and most important of agricultural States, although she has become a considerable manufacturing State. She has shared in the depressions of the Middle West and has usually had, perhaps, more than her fair proportion of political farmers.

Continuance of the 1 per cent gross income tax with amendments to allow personal exemptions and to establish it as an alternative levy for the small taxpayer, was recommended unanimously yesterday by the State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The investigation of recovery codes to be made by a committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will study the Gerard Swope plan looking to self-regulation of business, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Pennsylvania's 6-6 tie with Pernn State was not without its mishaps. Paul Stofko, sophomore guard, received a broken nose and may not be able to play against Cornell on Thanksgiving Day.

The Beethoven Association opened its season auspiciously last night in the Town Hall, with a program given by the Manhattan String Quartet, Greta Stuckgold, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Egon Petri, the pianist, and Fritz Reiner, the conductor, in the role of accompanist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- One of the first official orders issued by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau today, at a conference with the Treasury heads, is that henceforth they shall not give statistical or other information to the newspapers.

A modernistic tobacco and specialty shop was opened yesterday in the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Center by Alfred Dunhill of London. Although provision has been made for the retail sale of imported wines and liquors on the Fifth Avenue side of the second floor, John Dunhill, who runs the Paris branch of the business, was doubtful whether a license would be received.

PAULSBORO, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Sheldon A. Clark, 35 years old, son of Commodore Sheldon Clark of Chicago, wealthy sportsman and vice president of the Sinclair Refining Company, was shot and killed in the basement of his home here late this afternoon, following one of a series of arguments with his wife.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- "Just and fair provision for women" in the new civil works program was pledged toddy at a conference with Mrs. Roosevelt at the White House called by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator of Feaeral Relief and of Civil Works, and attended by more than forty representative women from all parts of the country.

We of America have been from the founding of Liberia most concerned of all peoples that the experiment there in self-government by Negroes should succeed. Those in authority have been men who have had contact either directly or through their forebsars of one or more generations with American institutions.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- United States Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland asked for and received today from Governor Moore assurance that everything possible was being done to solve the mystery surrounding the death at Princeton of Jay C. Towner 3d of Perryman, Md.

Argument in the suit by Victor Kosow, clothing salesman, to set aside the adoption of his daughter, Sylvia Sidney, film star, by Dr. Sigmund Sidney, a dentist, was adjourned yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel until Friday.
MADRID. Nov. 20 -- Leaders of the Spanish republic were striving tonight to find some way out of the predicament created by yesterday's election, in which conservatives won overwhelming victories.

Publication of the new book by Adolf Hitler, announced recently by the John Day Company, has been canceled. The book is too near "straight propaganda," Richard J. Walsh, president of the John Day Company, said in an interview last night.

A proposal to broaden the powers of the Triborough Bridge Authority and "place under its jurisdiction the planning, financing, construction and operation of all future interhorough bridges and vehicular tunnels which are to be made selfsustaining through the collection of toll."

The craze for roller skating among all persona old enough to skate, including many who do not know how, was analyzed by speakers last night at a dinner of the Lower East Side Community Council at the Bowery branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 8 East Third Street.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Former Premier Baron Reijiro Wakatsuki, the foremost Japanese defender of the London Naval Treaty, escaped injury today when two youthful "patriots" sought to assault him with daggers.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The 3,000 German Evangelical pastors who proclaimed yesterday their opposition to the program of Nazi extremists who want to "paganize the church" will meet their parishioners on Wednesday, when a renewed attack upon the Nazi church dictatorship may be looked for.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Senator Simeon D, Fess today said that he would urge an amendment to the National Industrial Recovery Act at the next Congressional session to lift newspapers "out of the category of trade and industry so far as freedom of expressing an opinion may go."

Announcement that "a small group of American business men and women, each of whom admits receiving the prescribed elementary public school education, have banded together to form a membership corporation to be known as the 'Association of American Tories,'" was made yesterday by Henry F. Holthusen, a member of tire law firm of House, Holthusen McCloskey, 25 Broadway.
ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Officials of four Georgia newspapers which printed several editions today on newsprint made from Georgia pine, commented favorably on the results obtained.

PRINCETON, N.J. Nov. 20 -- "When informed here this afternoon of the seizure of her property and her husband's in Germany, Frau Albert Einstein smiled and said: "We know it." She would make no further comment. Dr. Einstein was not available for a statement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- No time will be lost in conducting the actual transfer of American and Soviet representatives which, are the expression in fact of what is meant by the term "normal relations." This at once raises the question of how and where American diplomatic and other officials and their clerks and subordinates and their wives and families and their servants and chauffeurs are going to live in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Organized labor as represented by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and the spokesmen for 1,500,000 union mechanics, vigorously opposed the proposal of one master code for the construction industry today at a Hearing by Administrator Johnson and Deputy Administrator Malcolm Muir.

Following complaints from Thomas E. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney, that government witnesses had been intimidated, Waxey Gordon, New Jersey beer baron, was locked up last night at the Federal house of detention on order of Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman.

The city will immediately seek a review by the Court of Appeals of the recent Appellate Division ruling hat interest and amortization on Eighth Avenue subway bonds can no longer be paid out of tax funds, Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly announced yesterday.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 20 -- Seven Negroes who have been imprisoned since March, 1931, accused of attacking two white girls on a freight train near Scottsboro, sat in Morgan County Court today and heard their lawyers plead that they be sent to Birmingham for trial to thwart threatened mob vengeance here.

"Birthright," a play about life in Germany under the present Nazi regime by Richard Maibaum, will have its premiere this evening at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre. Sylvia Field, Montagu Love and Thais Lawton are in the cast.

The Parmelee System, controlling about 14 per cent of the taxicabs operating in the city, advocated yesterday the adoption of a uniform fare of 20 cents for the first quarter mile and 5 cents for each additional quarter mile, regardless of whether the city ordinance imposing a 5-cent tax on each taxicab fare is ultimately ruled invalid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The right of the University of Maryland to require its students to take military training was in effect, uphold today by the Supreme Court.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 20 -- The vagaries of the Nazi mentality have become more pronounced outside Germany than within the Reich, where the spotlight of world opinion had a certain restraining influence. To see now far Nazism is prepared to go in racial and social matters its development among Germany's neighbors is worth scrutiny.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 20 -- Announcement of plans for an aerial expedition into Central Africa to gather material for a book which they will write together was made tonight by Commander Fitzhugh Green, retired naval officer, and his bride, Mrs. Margery Durant Green, who are here on their wedding trip.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- Michael Kalinin, President of the Union, of Soviet Socialist Republics, greeted the people of the United States by radio today. His address, broadcast from Moscow in Russian, was repeated in English and expressed the hope that establishment of normal relations between his country and America will be of benefit to mankind and will strengthen the move for universal peace.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Johnny Sorrell, forward of the Detroit Red Wings, dominates the scoring in the National Hockey League race, according to the statistics issued tonight by President Prank Calder.

The salvation of the family, as the keystone upon which rested the government of the city, State and nation, was declared by Alfred E. Smith yesterday to be the reason behind the $4,000,000 fund-raising drive of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which he launched in the governors room of the New York Stock Exchange.

WILKESBORO, N.C., Nov. 20 (AP) -- A sentence of five years in the Atlanta penitentiary was imposed today upon John T. Lanier of VVinston Salem, who pleaded guilty in Federal court to an attempt to extort $10,000 from R.J. Reynolds under a threat of kidnapping Mrs. Reynolds.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Terming inflation "an enemy of mankind," Bernard M. Baruch, writing in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post, pleads with his fellow-Americans to "understand that a plan is advanced in their name which is certain to destroy their interest."

The annual December Ball for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House will take place on the night of Dec. 8 at the Ritz-Carlton. The proceeds will be devoted to the needs of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, 321 East Forty-ninth Street, one of the oldest welfare organizations in New York.

Speaking clearly, Lieut. Commander T.G.W. Settle and Major Chester L. Fordney, stratosphere adventurers, radioed back to earth yesterday that all was well at an elevation of nearly eleven miles. Radio listeners eavesdropped on the conversations, which were broadcast from coast to coast.
ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP AMERICAN LEGION, at Sea, Nov. 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today made the traditional bow to Neptune on crossing the Equator.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20 -- "Directly and indirectly the Recovery Act has been of great value," but business men's enthusiasm for it has been "materially lessened" in the last sixty days, Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared today.

Over-shooting is described as one of the chief reasons for the tremendous decrease in ducks in the last few years. Experts say seasons are too long, bag limits too large and the number of hunters too great for the supply of ducks.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- Following is the text of President Kalinin's radio address today:

Miss Lynn Curtis gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz -Tower. Her guests were Mrs. Frederick Hill Wood, Mrs. Richard C. Plater Jr., Mrs. J. Murray Mitchell, Mrs. Henry Townsend Ashmore, Mrs. Robert L. Major, Mrs. Ten Broeck Terhune, Mrs. Haliburton Fales, Mrs. Clark Kidder, Mrs. Frederick L. Lutz, Mrs. Emil J. Stehli and Miss Isabel Harkness.
Cardinal Hayes was praised last night at a birthday reception in his honor as a great leader of the Catholic Church and as a kindhearted, hard-working friend of man.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- A protest demonstration against the return of Ambassador Welles, said to have been organized by Communists and other anti-American groups, was broken up in the city of Matanzas today by soldiers when the demonstrators attempted to march on the United States Consulate there.

The plight of 30,000 homeless children, who will require special care and training apart from other relief measures provided by private and governmental sources, was emphasized yesterday by welfare leaders at an organization meeting of the women's division of the Crusade for Children at the Hotel Biltmore.

Jim Browning, giant Missourian, retained his world' s heavyweight wrestling title last night before a crowd of about 10,000 excited fans In Madison Square Garden by almost crushing the ribs of Gus Sonnenberg of Boston.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 -- In a national broadcast tonight Premier Bennett announced that at the next session of Parliament the government would introduce a bill for the establishment of a central bank in Canada.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Mayor Ellenstein received today a letter from Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announcing the Exchange's readiness to sign a lease for the New Jersey Stock Exchange in the Centre Market Building at a rental of $25,000 for six months from Sept. 25, 1933, if suits brought against the Exchange by tenants of the market, evicted when the Exchange planned to move here, were settled first.

Statements that Joseph W. Harriman, former chairman of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, is so closely guarded by police and hospital attendants in the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital that process servers are unable to reach him, were made in the Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Defending the administration's recovery program and assailing its critics, Secretary Roper declared tonight that the "next step in our experience will lead us into international studies, thus broadening our vision and enlarging our sympathies."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Completion of a newspaper code by the end of the week appeared tonight to be a possibility, depending on whether the code committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association finds acceptable the new labor provisions which have been submitted to it.

Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts told the New York State Economic Council last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria how in his opinion New York State could cut its budget by 13 per cent, as his State had done. He also gave his views on some of the provisions of the Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Holders of drainage and irrigation districts bonds which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has refinanced were said today by Chairman Jones to have taken an average loss of 50 per cent.

Plans for the creation of an art foundation to be charged with responsibility for the development and furtherance of American art have been completed by the national executive committee of the American Artists Professionsl League and the governing board of the National Commission to Advance American Art, according to announcement yesterday.

Nineteen ships will be added soon to the fleets of the American Scantic and American Export lines to handle the freight which is expected to be developed as a result of the recognition of Russia by the United States.

Pierre S. du Pont, Delaware industrialist and financier, who was active in the campaign against prohibition, predicted yesterday that liquor consumption in the United States would decrease after repeal to half of the 1914 figure.

Depreciation of the dollar in foreign countries has not yet stimulated sales of steel abroad by American producers, Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, said yesterday. Foreign consumers seemed disposed to buy the steel that was manufactured in their own countries, even if the price was higher than that of steel produced elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Because of strong opposition within and outside the oil industry against price-fixing and in the hope that the industry itself can work out a solution, the hearing on this problem which was set for today was postponed until Dec. 5 by Secretary Ickes, administrator of the oil code.

Nothing said here will convey much notion of the exuberance that roars out of "She Loves Me Not." Last evening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre the audience grew more and more helpless as this hairbrained comedy danced a leap-frog through imaginative absurdities.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Better understanding between Russia, Japan and the United States was seen by a Foreign Office spokesman today as likely to result from the appointment of Alexander Troyanovsky as Soviet Ambassador to Washington.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Final efforts to dislodge the metric system for track and field proved unavailing today and the international standard remains as the official A.A.U. measurement. Delegates to the forty-fifth annual convention of the A.A.U. voted by an overwhelming majority to reject the proposal to revert to the yardage basis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Yale's varsity squad was placed on the defensive more than an hour today against crimson-jerseyed scrubs. Developed by Ray Pond, and taught Harvard formations, the scrubs subjected the regulars to a foretaste of the attack expected in the stadium at Cambridge Saturday.
The final drive of the season for the Columbia football squad started yesterday at Baker Field as preparations began for the annual encounter with Syracuse here on Saturday.

The Serial Building Loan and Savings Institution of 195 Broadway has notified its members that its directors have decided not to waive the sixty days' notice required for the withdrawal of funds. "Under the Banking Law of New York State the rule applies to about $100,000 of Christmas Club funds which ordinarily would be payable around Dec. 15.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- Another extensive round-up of suspected Communists, alleged to be trying to resuscitate the Japanese Communist party, has resulted in the detention for examination of 1,696 persons, including 926 Korean laborers.

The 3,000 German Protestant pastors who protested Sunday against Nazi domination were stimulated by American Protestants, who have been cooperating with their German colleagues for months, according to a statement issued by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ yesterday.
VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- The twenty-first birthday of Archuduke Otto of Hapsburg today was celebrated by gatherings of monarchists in Austria and Hungary.

Reorganization of New York City's system of prosecution, by eliminating the five county district attorneys and consolidating their functions in a chief prosecutor selected by the Mayor for the entire city, was proposed yesterday by George Z. Medalie, retiring United States Attorney.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -- As the Harvard team today started its preparation for Saturday's Yale game, every member of the varsity squad was in trim with, two exceptions.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 20 -- The amateur record of 65 for the No. 2 course, set last year by George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur champion, was equaled today in the qualifying for the eighteenth annual Carolina tournament by Dick Wilson of Raleigh, N.C., former Georgetown star.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Nov. 15 shows decreases of 338,000,000 in loans and investments, $23,000,000 in time deposits and $30,000,000 in government, deposits and increases of $98,000,000 in net demand deposits and $47,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

The Musical Art Quartet, consisting of Sascha Jacobsen, Paul Bernard, Louis Kievman, a new violinist, and Marie Roemaet-Rosanoff, began its eighth New York concert series at the Town Hall last night. For the first of the season's four recitals the program was Haydn's Quartet in G, Op. 64, No. 4; Respighi's "Quartetto Dorico" and Beethoven's Quartet in E minor, Op. 59, No. 2.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- T.O.M. Sop-with helped ladle the lead into the mold when the keel of the Endeavour, his America's Cup challenger, was successfully cast at Camper Nicholson's yard at Gosport today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Intimations that an agreement of some sort had been reached between the American and Soviet Governments on the broad principles of out-standing questions such as debts and credits were furnished this afternoon following: a Treasury conference attended by Acting Secretary Morgenthau, Ambassador Bullitt, Commissar Litvinoff and Peter A. Bogdanoff, chairman of the Amtorg.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The so-called "Hitler confidence boom" on the Boerse which set in following the Nazi election victory began to show signs of exhaustion today. A firm opening was followed by extensive profit-taking which wiped out early gains ranging up to 4 per cent.

Bank clerks, hotel employes and accountants paraded in dull procession to the witness stand in Federal court yesterday at the second session of the trial of Waxey Gordon as the government began to depict the gangster's rise from East Side pickpocket to multi-millionaire with vast holdings in half a dozen States.

A program to effect closer cooperation in the adoption and administration of national and State revenues was discussed as a means of ending tax duplications yesterday at a meeting of the State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws, in the Bar Association Building.

MONTREAL, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Fluctuations of foreign exchange are hampering international trade and are "astonishing" in their scope, Sir Robert Borden said today at the annual meeting here of Barclays Bank (Canada), of which he is president.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- The first reaction to the Olympic boycott stand taken by the Amateur Athletic Union at its forty-fifth annual convention yesterday came today from Germany.

As an example of extremely facile expression, EMERSON quotes the report of a correspondent of the English Royal Society in which it was stated that a certain earthquake "had the honor to be noticed" by that society. The earthquake of day before yesterday seems to have enjoyed an exceptional honor, for it was noticed around the earth.

PAULSBORO, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The grand jury of Gloucester County will meet in special session Monday or Tuesday, it was anonunced here today, to hear evidence against Mrs. Audrey Smith Clark, former stage dancer, who said today from a hospital cot that she remembered nothing of the shooting of her husband and that she had no recollection of having had a pistol in her hand.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been asked by a former employer to remit a sum of money to cover the New York State 1 per cent emergency tax on non-resident incomes paid for services within the State. Were it not for the fact that I have only recently become employed, after a complete cessation of income for three months, I would likely give little thought to the situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave today the third of her series of departmental teas, entertaining for the women executives of the Departments of Justice, the Navy and the Interior. Earlier she received several guests "by apointment" and had a luncheon party for Miss Eva Le Gallienne, whose first performance here of "Alice in Wonderland" she attended tonight at the National Theatre.

Guila Bustabo was guest artist of the National Orchestral Association's first evening concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. A social audience filled every corner and included many of this most promising orchestra's sustaining patrons, some of them rarely able to hear its more customary matinees.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Prices of hogs here dropped 15 cents a hundredweight today and the average was $4, the lowest since Sept. 11. The top was 5 cents lower than yesterday at $4.20, the lowest since May 6, and late in the day it was hard to beat $4.10.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21. -- The 5-year-old mare Tambour made it two in a row at Bowie when she captured the White Marsh Handicap, six-furlong feature today. Bred, owned and trained by Preston M. Burch, the daughter of General Thatcher and Castanet gave further evidence that she is entitled to be called one of the best racing mares in training.

The New York State Affairs Committee of the Women's National Republican Club heard an attack yesterday morning on the costs of printing bills in the State Legislature. Mrs. H.A. Logan, assistant to Mrs. Preston Davie, finance chairman of the Republican State Committee, discussing "the functions of a watchful minority," said that "in 1932 it cost $1,700,000 just to print our bills, or $4.50 a page for each bill."
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21. -- Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia and his party arrived here by plane today from Kingston, Jamaica, after a vacation which, took him to the Canal Zone and Panama.
The new Ambassador to Russia, William C. Bullitt, wrote a novel some years ago called "It's Not Done," and Harcourt, Brace published it. The book is now out of stock, but it may be reissued.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Plans for an investigation of oil pipe lines were announced today by Secretary Ickes, oil administrator under the NRA petroleum code. Mr. Ickes also said there was a "fair chance" that the dispute over price-fixing in the oil industry would be adjusted without a public hearing.

ROME, Nov. 21. -- Joseph Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, arrived in Rome this evening and continued on to Naples, where he will place a wreath on the tomb of Senator Scialoja, long Italy's delegate to the League, tomorrow.
PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 21. -- Dick Wilson of Raleigh, the medalist, won his first match in the Carolina golf tournament today, defeating C.M. French of Seymour, Conn., by 9 and 8.

Frank C. Munson, president of the Munson Steamship Line, said yesterday that he had cleared Captain John J. Fallon, master of the liner Munargo, of responsibility for its collision with the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, which occurred last Friday night in the bay near Bedloes Island.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- The gateway to the human body through which the virus of infantile paralysis, and agents of other infectious and inflammatory diseases of the brain and the spinal cord enter the brain to do their work of destruction has been determined after many years of study at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, New York, to be the olfactory nerve, organ of smell.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Nov. 21. -- The Treasury Correspondents Association, composed of newspaper men assigned to that department, wired, a formal protest today to President Roosevelt at Warm Springs against the rule set up by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Acting Secretary, governing the issuance of news from the department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- It was obvious here tonight the administration fully realizes that the resignation of Professor O.M.W. Sprague is the opening gun in a public battle over the President's fiscal policy. Efforts have been made to postpone the resignation and, that failing, to induce Mr. Sprague to refrain from giving the forceful expression to his views which he gave in his letter of resignation.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- Alexander Antonovich Troyanovsky, the new Russian Ambassador to the United States, commented in an interview today on the question of propaganda.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 21. -- All elements of Palestine Jewry, ranging from the ultra-orthodox to the radically irreligious, were united in a delegation that called upon the High Commissioner, Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, today. They submitted to him a long memorandum concerning Jewish immigration and the Jewish labor scarcity in Palestine.
The public schools as a social agency in the city are discussed by Dr. John L. Tildsley, district superintendent of schools, in his annual report released in part yesterday at the Board of Education.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Princeton went through an easy practice session today, the varsity eleven concentrating on pass plays and running through a long signal drill.
Walter Merrill Hall of New York is slated to be the next president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- A compilation of estimates by State officials today placed at upward of 500,000 the number of unemployed who have gone back to work at tasks set by the Civil Works Administration.

New York City will ask the Federal Public Works Administration for loans totaling more than $95,000,000 to finance local projects, a statement made public in Mayor O'Brien's behalf disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- When the committee appointed by the government to investigate the German banking system rose from its first session this evening, its chairman, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, announced that it had unanimously declared against complete nationalization of the banks, especially the big banks.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 21. -- The organized distillers were reported today to have given informal notice to the administration that on the first day of repeal they would have on hand 100,000,000 quarts of whisky that could be sold at retail for $1.50 a quart, plus State taxes.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- Expression of faith in the future of technological development and a prediction that engineering will eventually be taught as a graduate course like medicine and law were contained in the annual report of Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology, published today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The duffer whose head has been swimming all these years as he has listened to professionals argue about the "only way" to learn and play golf, is going to get a uniform set of rules.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- England's most resplendent annual ceremony, the opening of Parliament by the King and the Queen wearing their crowns and royal robes in the House of Lords, was marred today when a radical member of the House of Commons hurled taunting questions about unemployment at King George and then, shouting at all the Lords and their ladies, called them collectively "a gang of lazy, idle parasites."
LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Newfoundland will lose her status as a self-governing dominion for a time under sweeping emergency measures which the government submitted to the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 18:...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 21. -- All the well-known symptoms of "Army game fever" are in evidence around the Naval Academy. Confidence is beginning to succeed hope, at least among the members of the regiment who will witness the football classic Saturday in Philadelphia.
LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Outstanding among Items In the report of the Exchequer tonight is the high net postoffice receipts, which are normally regarded as an index of trade activity.

BRESLAU, Germany, Nov. 21. -- The administrative head of the Jewish community of this city, former Judge Ernst Rechnitz, and Albert Rosenthal, joined with him as a co-defendant, were sentenced today by a special court for political offenses to fifteen months imprisonment each "for defaming the government and spreading atrocity stories."
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 21. -- Lee Tracy, the motion picture actor, flew to Ciudad Jaurez today after having been arrested on a charge of "insulting the Mexican Government" and "offending public morals."

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The veteran actor Cyril Maude, now 71, returned to the stage tonight in the role of the elderly village priest in the play "Cabbages and Kings," an adaptation from the Italian comedy by Forzano, Mussolini's collaborator on "Napoleon."

His face ruddy with health and wearing a broad smile, Lou Little strode into Chick Meehan's football salon Saturday night, and before he could relieve himself of the greatcoat that draped his massive shoulders he found himself surrounded and hailed as the man of the hour.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent articles appearing in your columns concerning maternity mortality, with editorial comment, cannot fail to have stirred all conscientious medical practitioners, and as one who has had considerable experience in obstetrics for over a third of a century perhaps I may be allowed some comment.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The sum of $100,000 was left by Columbus O'Donnell Iselin, financier, to be distributed by his executors to persons long in his employ, according to the will filed here today. Mr. Iselin died Nov. 10 at his estate on Davenport Neck, New Rochelle.
OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- A summary of the recommendations of the Royal Commission for the finane relief of Newfoundland follows:

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Two hungry and unshaven stratosphere explorers, who had slept, snug and unworried, under their balloon fabric while the nation fearfully awaited word of their fate, waded and swam out of a South Jersey swamp today after establishing what is believed to be an official world's altitude record.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The State Department announced today the formation of a new executive committee for commercial policy whose chairmanship is vested in the Department of State and which includes representatives from the leading government departments and the central agencies of the government which are shaping the new deal, such as the NRA, the triple A and the Federal Trade Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21. -- Perfection of new plays which will be used for the first time this season against Harvard occupied the attention of the Yale football men today. Coach Root and his aides sent the players through a long supervised scrimmage which lasted until after dark.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Mr. Dodge testified today that the bankers who financed the organization of General Theatres made more than $4,000,000 in actual and paper profits in its stock and debentures within a few months after it was created in July, 1929.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The struggle over small shipments of freight in the East came before the Interstate Commerce Commission today, with the Pennsylvania Railroad and a group of smaller lines arrayed on one side and several large railroads and truck operators on the other.

Railway stocks were strongest and the alcohol and miscellaneous industrials were weakest in yesterday's dull trading on the Stock Exchange. The market was mixed, various groups moving in opposite directions. The financial community watched the foreign exchanges interestedly; it did not derive any particular encouragement from the day's developments either in the action of the speculative or investment markets.

Salvador Dall is with us once more -- Salvador Dali, the arch-surrealiste -- and with a large one-man show of paintings, most of them new to this city. It opened yesterday at the Julien Levy Gallery, of course, where a season or two ago the memorable "Persistance de la memoire" leaped into fame over night.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 21. -- Leaving notes stating that she owas "not coming back," Mrs. Louise Turck Stanton, about 30 years old, a member of one of Jacksonville's most prominent families, borrowed a plane this morning, took enough gasoline to last four hours and headed east over the Atlantic Ocean.

Declines in prices of United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday contrasted with moderate gains in domestic corporation issues and in leading foreign loans. The market for government obligations was nervous most of the day, but quotations closed slightly above the day's lows.

One of the unusual events arranged in behalf of the Greenwich House Music School is an elaborate carnival, patterned after a Spanish fiesta, to be held after the performance of "Carmen" the night of Dec. 16 at the New York Hippodrome.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange over a range of 10 points ended yesterday in net gains of 2 to 4 points in light trading. Best quotations were recorded on the opening call, when active pre-notice day liquidation of December contracts halted the improvement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Allotment of $100,000,000 to the Federal Emergency Housing Corporation was announced today by Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator and president of the corporation. The money will be used for slum clearance and low-cost housing projects throughout the country.

Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy's two-year search for members of an alleged Brooklyn arson ring reached a climax yesterday with the arrest of a former member of his staff in the Fire Department. The man was Eugene J. Shields, 49 years old, well known in Brooklyn as a member of the firm of Wurzberg Shields, fire loss adjusters, of 66 Court Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- In an uproar so great that the police were called to restore order, the Senate subcommittee investigating the Overton-Broussard Senatorial primary wound up its session today with another burst of arm-swinging and table-pounding.

Defending the railroads against criticisms of obsolescence, M.J. Gormley, president of the American Railway Association, told the Traffic Club of New York, an organization of railway executives, at a luncheon in the Park Central Hotel yesterday, that improved equipment and methods of operation had benefited shippers to the extent of $535,050,000 in 1929.
BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- For the first time since Chancellor Hitler came into power the Nazi authorities announced today a sizable increase in unemployment in Germany.
HAMBURG. Nov. 21. -- The War-burg Library will be moved from Hamburg to London, it was said here today. It is expected that the final destination would be the United States.

Nazis Too Far Back. Germany's insurgent pastors accuse the Nazi extremists of wanting to go back to paganism. To meet this charge and other issues of a like nature, HITLER'S followers will ultimately have to soft-pedal the whole business of "going back" to the pure Teuton civilization of 2,000 years ago.

As a step in the modernization of national defense against aircraft, the engineers of the United States Army have awarded to the Sperry Gyroscope Company of Brooklyn a contract for 104 sixty-inch, high-intensity anti-aircraft searchlights, to cost $2,015,900, the War Department disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Nov. 14 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 11,250,851 running bales, counting 475,401 round bales as half bales, and including 3,313 bales of American-Egyptian.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me thank you for your clear summary of the pledge against Soviet propaganda given by Mr. Litvinoff to the President. I am quite sure that every one who has read the text of that pledge will agree with your editorial. In fact, it is almost identical with the following declaration made by Walter Duranty in his article in THE TIMES this morning:

Feted In regal fashion on the Continent and in the British Isles since September, the members of the women's United States field hockey team arrived yesterday after their long tour and received a warm greeting.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 21. -- Anti-Legitimist disorders in Budapest yesterday were protested in Parliament tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Harvard's football session today centred mainly on the preparations to perfect a defense against Yale's running plays and passes. The Yale formations were put on by the freshmen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The National Labor Board will hold a hearing on the strike of shipbuilders in the New York area on Friday at 3 P.M. Senator Wagner, chairman of the board, announced today.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The decision of the American Amateur Athletic Union to boycott the Olympic Games in Berlin in 1936 unless the German Government lifts its boycott against Jewish athletes in Germany, fell like a bomb among coordinated German sporting organizations today.

The New York Central Railroad has sold in the market the 50,000 shares of Lehigh Valley Railroad common stock that it had owned, it was disclosed yesterday. The shares had been held by the Securities Corporation of the New York Central.

Friends of Lawrence B. Dunham, who during the Mayoralty campaign was leader of the fusion forces in the Bronx and in that capacity was instrumental in winning a substantial victory in that strongly Democratic borough, are regarding him as especially fitted by experience and in other ways for the office of Police Commissioner in the Fusion administration.

GENEVA, Nov. 21. -- After all-day secret talks among Great Britain, France, Italy and the United States with Arthur Henderson and Dr. Edouard Benes, president and rapporteur of the disarmament conference, it was agreed tonight that Mr. Henderson would take responsibility for making three proposals to the bureau or steering committee tomorrow, with the support of the four.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 21. -- President Roosevelt departed from the usual form for Thanksgiving Day proclamations today in issuing the one for Nov. 30, incorporating a rebuke against "greed and selfishness."

Because the outgoing Tammany administration has proved its lack bf desire to economize it cannot be tounted on to make the drastic retrenchments needed to balance the 1934 budget, Samuel Untermyer, Special financial adviser to the Board of Estimate, declared yesterday at a budget hearing in the offices of Controller George McAneny.

Wilhelm A. Kurtz, president of the Soviet travel agency, Intourist, and a member of the Central Executive Committee of the U.S.S.K., arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to reorganize his bureaus here and make a study of American travel and hotel systems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The first four months of the current fiscal year was marked by an increase of nearly a third of a billion dollars in internal revenue over the corresponding period of 1932. Collections for the period from July 1 to Oct. 31 totaled $777,497,114, an increase of $329,449,153.

Net profit of the City Stores Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 was $95,922 after taxes, depreciation, reserve for contingencies, minority interest and other charges. This is equivalent after allowance for regular dividend requirements on the $3.50 Class A stock on which there are dividend accumulations, to 1 cent a share on 1,188,833 no-par common shares.
Applicants for liquor and wine licenses were warned yesterday by the State and City Alcoholic Bever-age Control Boards not to attempt to use political influence in obtaining licenses.

J.P. Morgan Co. led the list of contributors yesterday to the $4,000,000 campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee with a contribution of $50,000, it was announced by James G. Blaine, campaign chairman. Mr. Blaine announced also gifts of $5,000 each from Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Mrs. Charles B. Alexander, Mrs. William H. Moore and Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore, and a gift of $4,000 from Mr. and Mrs. Barklie Henry.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 21. -- The new independent Fukien Province regime is making a clean sweep of Nanking officials in the province, gradually seizing more and more government offices and property.

While decreases in game birds and game animals have been noted in almost every State, there are certain sections where depletion has been more severe than in others. As the country has been built up, game has been pushed back.

The biggest fighter in the United States, 260-pound Ray Impellittiere of Cold Spring, N.Y., will attempt to establish himself as a formidable challenger for the crown now held by another giant, Primo Carnera, when he faces Tommy Loughran tonight at the New York Coliseum.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Dr. Percy Williams Bridgman, Hollis Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy at Harvard University, received tonight the Comstock Prize, bestowed every five years by the National Academy of Sciences for outstanding scientific achievement.

Reflecting the recent increase in the Chesapeake Ohio Railway's dividend rate, the Chesapeake Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly payment of 63 cents on its capital stock, against 50 cents previously paid. Before July 1, 1932, the corporation's rate was 75 cents.

Waiter Neusel, young German heavyweight, hurdled his second United States ring obstacle last night at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, where he knocked out Stanley Poreda. Jersey Citv heavyweight, in the tenth round.
PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 21. -- The Phillies of the National League today announced the trade of Chuck Klein, hard-hitting outfielder, to the Chicago Cubs for three players and an unannounced sum in cash.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Thirteen hundred convicts, representing a large part of the Eastern penitentiary's population, joined this afternoon in the most serious riot in the history of the century-old "Cherry Hill."

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- What may be the ultimate scientific value of observations we have brought back from the stratosphere is still to be determined from an examination of our instruments and a study of the photographs that we made there-but we have returned from, as thrilling a trip as any human being has ever taken and we feel that we may rate it as eminently successful.

Forty years ago two nurses, directed by Miss Lillian D. Wald, started work as the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, which grew into a model for similar services here and abroad. This week the service, with twenty-one branches and 265 nurses, marks its fortieth anniversary with an educational campaign that got into full swing yesterday in preparation for the opening on Monday of a drive for a $300,000 emergency fund.

Former Mayor James J. Walker was invited yesterday to be the toastmaster at the forthcoming Lambs' Gambol, to be held at the Astor on Dec. 7, in celebration of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The invitation was cabled to Mr. Walker in Paris and was signed by Robert Hague of the executive committee, Frank Crumit, the Shepherd, and Gene Buck, head of the program committee.

Fluctuations in the prices of commodities on local exchanges were wide in many cases yesterday. Some of the markets moved upward early and turned weak in the afternoon. Trading volumes were moderate. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

THIS is very confusing. With optimists hoping that we were back on solid ground again, the distinguished Belgian astronomer, Abbe Georges Lemaitre, turned up at the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at Cambridge, Mass., with the interesting theory that the universe is just a bowl of bubbles after all.
Poignant souvenirs of fallen empire went to the highest bidders last night as books which had gladdened the hearts of the last imperial children of Russia were sold at auction here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A graphic story of how General Theatres Equipment, Inc., gained control of the Fox Film Company from William Fox by paying him $15,000,000 plus "other considerations" was related to Senate stock market investigators today by Murray W. Dodge, former vice president of the Chase Securities Corporation.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 21. -- Holding that the defense had failed to prove charges of local prejudice, Judge W.W. Callahan ruled today that the Scottsboro trials -- the South's cause celebre -- must be held here.
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 21. -- It was learned today that United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels had refused to ask that Lee Tracy be freed, holding that the actor should be punished if guilty.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The resignation of Dr. O.M.W. Sprague as economic adviser to the United States Treasury is treated here as news of first-class importance and it is likely to have considerable influence on the opinion of the British public, which knows Dr. Sprague well, toward President Roosevelt's experiment.

Stocks and commodities gave an indecisive and even indolent response yesterday to the further marking-up of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's gold price and to the resultant depreciation in dollar exchange. The dollar was moderately lower but transactions in foreign exchange were of small volume.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The purchase of Chuck Klein climaxed almost four years of persistent efforts on the part of the Cubs.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- The Boston Wool Trade Association, at its annual meeting here today, was told by Robert L. Turnbull, the retiring president, that the "soundness of the position of wool at this time is well assured, and its immediate future may be viewed with optimism."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Returning from Europe today aboard the He de France, Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City, State Senate President, not only announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor but immediately came to Trenton and issued a statement assailing President Roosevelt's monetary program.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Suspension of the charter of the New Mexico department was voted today by the national executive committee of the American Legion, following an investigation of charges that Legionaires of that State have permitted their organization to become involved in partisan politics.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 21.-- While remaining silent on the resignation of Professor O.M.W. Sprague as special adviser to the Secretary of the Treasury, President Roosevelt is known to feel that this was the only possible solution of an unpleasant situation which has existed since the London Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Two administration moves lately have put new life into the mimeograph machines in the offices of the Republican National Committee. One was the order from the secretary of the President's Executive Council -- privately known as "the Town Meeting" -- that henceforth no government agency could issue statistics without first submitting them to the Chief Interpreting Statistician in the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Still wearing the water-soaked and mud-covered clothes in which he had waded out of a New Jersey swamp, Lieut. Commander Thomas G.W. Settle landed without fanfare at the naval air station here at 3 o'clock this afternoon in a Coast Guard airplane and sped away to "a quiet nook" for a few hours.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,307,100 barrels, compared with 2,273,300 in the previous week, an increase of 33,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Increases of 24,200 barrels in Oklahoma and 16,000 in Kansas and a decrease of 15,400 barrels in California were the most important changes.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- Carnegie Tech's eleven today staged a hard practice session. Terbus, halfback, who has been, the Tartans' best runner this year and who has been suffering from an injury, returned to the team and probably will be in good physical condition for the N.Y.U. game.

The second day's sale of the Arthur Hind collection of postage stamps held yesterday in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel netted nearly $50,000 for the 400 lots, bringing the total for the two days to about $155,000.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman and three other New York men of prominence were recipients last night of the highest honor decoration of the Catholic Boys Brigade of Honor of the United States, a medal known as the Star "Pro Juventute," at a dinner given by the brigade at the Hotel Astor.

President ROOSEVELT'S chosen financial adviser to the Treasury, Professor SPRAGUE, has resigned in order, as he says, to make his personal contribution to an "aroused and organized public opinion" against what he perceives to be the Administration's "drift into unrestrained inflation."
"Scorpion," Bernard J. McOwen's comedy with Annette Margules, will open at the Biltmore Theatre next Monday evening.

EINSTEIN gave us a closed, cylindrical universe with matter so unstable that the mere lifting of an arm would have caused a collapse. Next came DE SITTER with a universe which was all space and no matter. The Abbe LEMAITRE decided that neither would do. He effected an ingenious compromise.
