The NRA was hailed as a success and a permanent feature of American life by leading figures in the retail dry goods trade last night at a dinner at the Waldorf given by the Uptown Retail Guild and attended by 500 department-store executives and others.

Alfred E. Smith, Edward P. Mulrooney and other speakers, who appeared yesterday before the New York Committee on the Use of Leisure Time, urged an intensive publicity campaign to inform the public of the recreational and educational facilities available to them.

Lord BALFOUR, who detested lawyers, abstracted the K.C. from the essential BIRRELL. He said that if he were going on a long journey, from all the men he knew he would choose BIRRELL as his companion. Much of that flavor of distinct personality, that wit, that unpedantic, mellow knowledge, that fantasy, irony and easy grace is felt in his books.

It is a sinking coincidence that on the day Governor MOORE of New Jersey assured Senator TYDINGS of Maryland that everything possible was being done to clear up the mystery of the death of JAY C. TOWNER 3d at Princeton, Dr. MARTLAND, chief medical examiner of Essex County, recommended that the coroner's office be abolished as cumbrous and inefficient.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The pastors of the German Evangelical Church who are opposing the radical ideas of the Nazi German Christians will issue a round-robin calling for a fight against the latter's "neo-Germanic heathendom" at church services tomorrow on the occasion of the "day of prayer and repentance," a State church holiday.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 21. -- The Indian Legislative Assembly today ratified the international agreement for the rehabilitation of silver, which was advanced at the World Economic Conference at London by Senator Pittman of the Americans-delegation.

The city's needy profited to the extent of $336.80 as a result of the last election, it was disclosed yesterday when the committee for the re-election of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook reported that it had turned that amount of surplus over to the Mayor's unemployment committee.

Efforts of the local compliance bureau of the Retail Code Authority to eliminate "clearance" and "liquidation" sales that are not genuine will receive the support and cooperation of the Fifth Avenue Association, William J. Pedrick, president of the association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Miss Anne Eustis, a grand-daughter of the late Levi P. Morton, vice president of the United States, and a descendant also of the late W.W. Corcoran, philanthropist and civic leader of this city, was presented to society this afternoon at a tea given by her mother, Mrs. William Corcoran Eustis, at their home in Rhode Island Avenue.

TOKYO, Nov. 21. -- Information collected by the police tends to show that the attempt on the life of former Premier Wakatsuki was not the work of another "blood brotherhood," but was that of unbalanced individuals.
Miss Doris Puke came of age last midnight and, on the last stroke of the clock, was automatically the richest girl in the world.

Corporation Counsel Arthur J. W. Hilly carried on the Tammany reprisal campaign yesterday by dismissing Matthew J. Troy, assistant Corporation Counsel heading the contract bureau, and appointing two supporters of the Democratic party as assistant Corporation Counsel at $4,000 a year.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- With the American gold price higher, dollars weakened today from the overnight rate of $5.32 to the pound sterling to $5.36 1/2. Gold here was lower at 127s an ounce. About L540,000 was taken by unnamed buyers.

Mrs. Angelina Burro, a Brooklyn housewife, attempted last night to prepare a live eel for the table. The eel, a 3-foot, 7-pound specimen, retaliated by clamping its jaws around Mrs. Burro's left index finger and, using the finger for leverage, curled itself firmly around her arm.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 21. -- South Orange, newcomer to the league, scored its third successive victory in defeating the Short Hills Club, 4-1, at South Orange, in the Class B division of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League today. Montclair, winning by the same score over Plainfield at Montclair, moved into second place.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The text of Professor Sprague's letter of resignation to President Roosevelt follows:

A 1-1 tie was the best the New York Rangers could get in their National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Although they were the first to score, the New Yorkers yielded a point to their fast-skating rivals from the North, and no amount of trying in the overtime session could help them break the deadlock.

The prediction that the National Industrial Recovery Act would "in all probability" be amended and modified, but that In general the act would remain an integral part of the nation's life, was made last night by A.D Whiteside, division administrator of the NRA, in an address before the monthly forum meeting of the New York Credit Men's Association at the Hotel Commodore.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Chancellor Hitler has granted to Fernand de Brinon his first interview with a French journalist. The interview, to be published by Le Matin tomorrow, quotes Herr Hitler as saying only the Saar question now divides France and Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Dr. O. M.W. Sprague, economic adviser to the Treasury, resigned today in protest against the Roosevelt monetary policies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Several NRA codes will be taken South Thursday by General Hugh S. Johnson for the President's signature.

Volunteer campaign workers in the annual membership roll call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross were warned yesterday against relaxing their efforts by Peter S. Duryee, roll call chairman of the chapter.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Shot in the back, Mrs. Rheta Wynekoop, 23 years old, was found dead tonight in the home of her mother-in-law, Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop. She was the wife of Earl Wynekoop, son of the woman doctor and the late Dr. Frank B. Wynekoop.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Little interest was shown in the grain markets today, trading being largely professional. Failure of Buenos Aires to show uneasiness over the report of striped rust in the southern sections of Argentina's wheat belt put a damper on that crop scare, although many operators feel that considerable damage may result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Earle Bailie of New York City, a partner in the firm of J. W. Seligman Co., was appointed today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Acting Secretary of the Treasury, special assistant to the Secretary in charge of fiscal affairs.

Thomas E. Dewey, who three years ago at the age of twenty-eight became chief assistant to George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, will be sworn into office this morning to succeed his chief, who retired yesterday on his fiftieth birthday.

Among the discretionary powers which Congress grave the President is authority to limit, to penalize or even to forbid entirely the importation of any articles of which the competition threatens the NRA. Recently the President prescribed a procedure for filing complaints in such questions.

The executive committee of the Federation of Hotel and Restaurant Guilds expressed its disappointment yesterday with the hotel code signed by President Roosevelt on Saturday. The committee agreed that the code, which will become effective Monday, will not increase the buying power of employes or lead to the employment of additional labor.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The British Olympic Association is seriously considering withdrawing from the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, following the lead of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States in boycotting the games because of Germany's discrimination against German Jewish athletes.

Another effort has been made to translate into dramatic form the fanaticism of Hitler's scourging of the German Jew. It is Richard Maibaum's "Birthright," which was acted at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre last evening. Two or three years ago Mr. Maibaum was represented in New York by an obscure and promising drama, entitled "The Tree."
Anticipating one of its most strenuous games of the year, when it opposes Syracuse on Saturday, the Columbia football team set about to build a defense against Oranges plays yesterday at Baker Field.

Buyers' Registrations Gain. The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday continued to show a slight gain over the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Edouard Harriot's return to his place in the Chamber of Deputies today in the middle of a debate on the government's financial proposals was the occasion for a tremendous out-burst of enthusiasm on the part of his followers of the Radical Socialist party, in which a good many members of other parties joined.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- A flood of invective unprecedented even in the unusually violent Nazi terminology is being poured by the coordinated German press upon the head of Mr. Wentworth, editor of The London Saturday Keview.

With the return yesterday of W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, from a tour of the western counties of the State it was reported that the continuance of Joseph A. McGinnies as Speaker of the Assembly was likely to become involved in a light now being launched by Mr. Macy.

AFTER reading Jack Conroy's American proletarian novel, "The Disinherited," it is a unique experience to pick up Valentine Kataev's brisk story of an aspect of the Russian Five-Year Plan, "Time, Forward!" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). The comparison bears out the truth that a novelist is bound, whether he likes it or not, to the existing social structure within his country.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 21. -- Joseph M. Schenck, president of the United Artists Company, visited President Roosevelt today, but no word concerning motion pictures intruded on a conversation that dealt exclusively with the Warm Springs Foundation and the President's experimental farm near here.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- The resignation of Senator Henry G. Schackno of the Twenty-first District, the Bronx, was received today by Charles Poletti, counsel for Governor Lehman, who sent it to William G. Reilly, secretary of Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray, Mr. Reilly filed it with the Secretary of State.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. H. Smith Richardson will give a dance on Dec. 26 at the River Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Grace Stuart Richardson.

After winning twenty successive bouts, Richard Librandi, Politan Athletic Club youngster, met his master in the amateur boxing bouts held under A.A.U. auspices at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 3,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Three trustees were named by the Federal Court today to take charge of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad pending a hearing on the bankruptcy petition, Dec. 28.

The Rooseveltian New Deal is based on the principles that brought about the development of social settlements, and it would have been impossible without their work, Professor A.A. Berle Jr., member of the original Roosevelt "brain trust," declared yesterday.

One of the first tasks of the new city administration will be to attempt a revision of the city's antiquated charter. Following the report of the Hofstadter committee, of which he was a member, Assemblyman MOFFAT submitted a new draft charter to the Legislature.

The Indian Legislative Assembly has ratified the silver agreement negotiated in London last Summer, due largely to the energy of Senator PITTMAN. It is an eight-Power pact, not yet ratified by the United States, which was greeted with enthusiasm at the time of its conclusion by those who believe it important to "do something for silver."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Circumstances surrounding the appointment of three of the eight government representatives on the National Bituminous Coal Industrial Board disclosed today a widening rift between organized labor and General Hugh S. Johnson, and a breach between the recovery administrator and Secretary Perkins.
What is apparently an entirely new system of creating the drive up forward so important to the success of any football team has been credited to Tiny Thornhill, the new coach of Stanford.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 22 -- President Roosevelt lashed back once more today at opponents of his policies as he prepared to spend part of the week-end in conferences on the monetary problem with the Acting Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Samuel Insull, now living in exile in Greece, will lose at the end of this year the $21,000 in pensions that he is receiving from the companies that he formerly headed. The directors of the four companies paying the annuities met today and voted to discontinue the payments on Dec. 31.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Albert R. Gates, once regarded as the dictator of American professional golf, today decided to give golfers legal advice instead of orders.

President Roosevelt's monetary policy was defended here yesterday by William H. Woodin, Secretary of the Treasury, now in New York on leave of absence, and by Professor James Harvey Rogers of Yale, one of the President's advisers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A prediction that the stratosphere would be penetrated for fifteen miles soon was made today by Lieut. Commander T.G.W. Settle, who, with Major Chester L. Fordney, reached about 59,000 feet in a balloon Monday.

REEDSVILLE, W. Va., Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, carrying on her expressed plan to help the "forgotten man," stood among the graves of 200 Colonial slaves on a wind-swept West Virginia hillside today and plotted a new freedom for destitute workers.

Etchings and engravings, including the collection of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, brought a total of $16,006 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., where the sale of Mr. Ryan's paintings, sculpture and other works of art will begin this afternoon.

Contributions of $338,474 as the result of the first week of solicitation, including fifteen special gifts totaling $280,000, were announced yesterday by the women's division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is conducting a campaign for a fund of $4,000,000 to be disbursed through accredited family welfare agencies for the relief of unemployed.

For the second day in a row the New York University football team concentrated on perfecting an aerial attack and a defense against forward passes. The aerial game has been a feature of Carnegie Tech's powerful attack this season, and the Violet is making every effort to meet its next opponent fully prepared.

Effective at 3:30 P.M. today, traffic signal timings in the area between Fifth and York Avenues will be changed in an effort to further improve the crosstown movement, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner James S. Bolan.

Men prominent in public life in this country and Canada will take part in the program of the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents on Dec. 7 and 8 in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Now, many hours removed from the peak of my flight with Major Fordney into the stratosphere, we find ourselves face to face with the one detail of several thousand for which we failed to provide in advance: the totally unforeseen public curiosity concerning our scientific observations and conclusions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In a comprehensive plan for ending technological unemployment, the NRA was asked today to require contributions from all cigar-making machines sufficient to pay $10 a week for each worker they displace until such time as the worker is absorbed elsewhere.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A plan to reorganize the German $1,000,000,000 steel and coal trust and give the government indirect control over it through bank holdings in the mother firm will be submitted at a stockholders' meeting in Essen next Wednesday.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Increasing nervousness, particularly abroad, about the future of the franc marked today's exchange market. The French newspapers are publishing editorials denouncing "the attack on the franc," citing, with the most emphasis, alarmist stories published in England and Germany.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with President Roosevelt's recent expression of impatience with so-called "Tories," it might be well to read the pamphlet "Fiat Money Inflation in France," by Andrew D. White, former president of Cornell University, Minister to Russia and Ambassador to France.

Except for a rather sharp decline in government bonds, the markets took calmly the latest onslaught against the administration's currency-management program. The rank and file of traders in Wall Street did not display any particular interest, except in their board-room debates.
The women's fencing season in New York opened last night at the Fencers Club and the Waverly Fencers Club was the victor in the first tournament, a junior interclub team competition.

Thomas E. Dewey, who at the age of 28 was appointed Chief Assistant United States Attorney under George Z. Medalie, took the oath of office yesterday in the presence of his former chief, who retired last Tuesday.

The New York Clearing House Association has been informed by the Controller of the Currency that national banks may not sell capital notes to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation but may sell only preferred stock to it, as he interprets the banking law.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back 8 to 10 points yesterday and closed at the bottom under heavy pre-notice day liquidation of December contracts.

Shipping men placed their suggestion for a code for the industry before W.H. Davis, deputy administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Administration, at three meetings in New York yesterday. The discussions supplemented hearings in Washington at which Mr. Davis had presided ten days ago.
TORONTO, Nov. 22 -- Ugly, ridden by Lieutenant C.W. Raguse of the United States Army, tonight won the $500 military jumping stake of the Royal Horse Show at the Royal Winter Fair.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia of New York arrived here late this afternoon for his first visit to the capital since the end of his successful campaign.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Secretary Ickes today allotted $12,309,230 for fifty-four non-Federal public works projects in twenty-seven States.

Lester Borden, 22-year-old star right end of the Fordham football team, unanimously was elected captain of the 1934 Maroon squad at a meeting of the twenty-three letter men yesterday. Borden, a resident of Everett, Mass., will succeed Ed Danowski as leader of the Rams.

Federated Textile Industries, Inc., will be the name of the successor organization to the Silk Association of America, it was learned here yesterday. Incorporation papers of the new organization have already been filed in Connecticut and steps are being taken to complete plans which, it is estimated, will require several weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The bureau of yards and docks of the Navy Department awarded contracts today for naval projects totaling $4,188,050. Over $8,000,000 more will be allotted before the end of the month.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- By foreign observers, as well as a growing body of responsible German opinion, Chancellor Hitler's interview, printed in Le Matin of Paris today, is taken as an earnest of his desire to initiate a direct exchange of views between France and Germany.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The British Cabinet is reported to have reached a decision today to retaliate against France if at the end of its month's notice, given Nov. 7, to withdraw from the tariff truce the French have failed to withdraw or modify their 15 per cent surtax and 6 per cent landing tax on British goods.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Substantial relaxation of the "censorship" rule which he had imposed on the Treasury Department was announced today by Acting Secretary Morgenthau.

An unused block of four of the rare 24-cent air-mail stamps, 1918 issue, with the centre of each stamp inverted, sold for $12,100 yesterday in the third day's session of the sale of the Arthur Hind collection of United States stamps at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Thirteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were offered by auctioneers at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Twelve of the parcels were bought in by plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Comment among members of Congress today on the resignation of Dr. O. M.W. Sprague as economic adviser to the Treasury varied greatly. Senator Reed, voicing the sentiment of the Eastern Republican, said that "the National Administration stands on the brink of the most dangerous experiment any government could undertake," an experiment that threatened ruin.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press) -- After losing five wickets for 142 runs, the touring Marylebone C.C. rallied today to score 431 runs for eight wickets as the match with the Viceroy's eleven continued. The Indian team was all out yesterday for 160 runs.

In an effort to determine the extent and source of the selling of United States Government bonds, which has disrupted the entire bond market during the last three weeks and has proved an embarrassment to the government in its monetary policy, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has started an investigation so searching that it is believed to be without precedent.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 22 -- A merger of the Union Trust Company of Boston and the Harris Forbes Trust Company, to become effective on Dec. 1, was announced here today. Business will be conducted under the name of the Union Trust Company of Boston, which will move from 11 Devonshire Street to 24 Federal Street, where are the banking rooms and safe deposit vaults of the Harris Forbes Trust Company.

The establishment of an eight-hour working day on inland vessels was recommended yesterday by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots. In a letter to Secretary of Commerce Roper it was pointed out that a twelve-hour day was in effect in New York and that the local steamboat inspectors had declined to reduce the hours on the ground that Congressional action was required.
PARIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The French eyed suspiciously today the olive branch which Chancellor Hitler was quoted in an interview as offering to France in return for equality for Germany.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- The latest model of a superspeed motion-picture camera, which takes up to 6,000 pictures a second, with exposures of about one-millionth of a second, was described here today before the closing sessions of the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

For the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 the Liquid Carbonic Corporation reported a net income after Federal taxes and all charges of $366,913, equal to $1 a share on 350,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. For the preceding fiscal year the company had a net loss of $440,529.

The prospect of more important ring engagements after their ten-round bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden confronts Kid Chocolate, world's featherweight champion, and Tony Canzoneri, former holder of the world's lightweight title.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Selma Lagerlof, Swedish author, who has been lauded in German Nazi publications as the "Nordic poetess," has fallen under a cloud because of reports that she is aiding "political refugees."

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The grain markets are so full of cross currents that the trade is far from certain of its position. Rapid developments in the monetary affairs in Washington have their counterpart in erratic fluctuations in grains.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- A drop of 25 to 35 cents a hundredweight in prices for hogs today equaled the sharpest recession of this year and carried the top down 30 cents to $3.90 and the average down an equal amount to $3.70. Arrivals were larger than had been expected, as a leading packing house shipped around 7,000 hogs from St. Paul to be killed here.

The International Paper and Power Company reports a consolidated net profit of $431,259 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, against a net loss of $3,001,567 in the same period last year, after charges, taxes, underlying dividends, accumulated unpaid subsidiary dividends, minority interests, depreciation and depletion.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess Christian of Hesse are arriving on the Europa and will join Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Rogers at Mayfair House.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association schedule was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell of Princeton, executive secretary. The program consists of thirty-six matches.

Governor Lehman issued a proclamation yesterday calling for a special election on Dec. 28 in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, in the Bronx, to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation on Tuesday of Senator Henry G. Schackno, who was elected a justice of the City Court for a term beginning on Jan. 1.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Governor Lehman issued his Thanksgiving proclamation today, as follows:

Finding a lack of effective leadership in the school boards of this city, Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, in a voluminous report yesterday, urges far-reaching changes which would place "full responsibility" on the Superintendent of Schools for both administrative and supervisory control of the system.

Paul Whiteman and an augmented orchestra of seventy-five players will present Mr. Whiteman's sixth "Experiment in Modern American Music" in a concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday evening, Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 -- The Navy football squad went through a long practice today, next to the last one on the home grounds. It is engaged in putting on the finishing touches for the game with Army in Philadelphia Saturday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 -- Attorney General William Lane Jr. has notified the three judges of the First Judicial Circuit and John B. Robins, State's attorney, that the arrest of nine persons as suspects in the Armwood lynching at Princess Anne can be made without warrants.

Columbia continued to work under pressure yesterday at Baker Field as its annual encounter with Syracuse loomed closer. The Lions had a three-hour session and there was not an idle minute as Coach Lou Little directed his squad in offensive and defensive tactics.
For the first time in the history of the sport a boxing referee was overruled in the ring last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- One of the biggest figures in American shipping, R. Stanley Dollar, was examined today by the Senate committee seeking to trace profits made by the Dollar Steamship Company with ships purchased from the government.
College education has proved largely unsuccessful in its major endeavor, that of making man the master of his environment, according to two speakers at a forum yesterday in the Women's City Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A proposal to establish and maintain Federal control over the distilling industry until Congress adopts a post-repeal policy was made today by the administration in a report by the President's special alcohol committee.

The Republic of Panama, which defaulted on May 15 on the payment of interest on its 5 per cent dollar bonds due on May 15, 1963, and outstanding here in an amount slightly less than $11,500,000, announced yesterday a plan of readjustment through Enrique A. Jiminez, Secretary of the Treasury of Panama.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- J.M. Holmes and Thomas H. Thurmond, who allegedly confessed they kidnapped and slew Brooke Hart, 22, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on seven charges using the mails in an attempt to extort.
Waxey Gordon, who remains with the missing Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer as the last of the powerful overlords of beer and liquor in the East, suffered heavy setbacks yesterday.

One of four men on trial for the hold-up of the Brooklyn Civic Club threw the Kings County Court into a turmoil yesterday by screaming invectives and bolting for the door when witnesses, recanting earlier testimony, identified him as the man who robbed them.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Dan Williams, veteran pro at Shackamaxon and tutor of champions, described as "absolutely impractical" tonight the P.G.A. announcement that a universal code of golf instruction would be sought.

Seven benefit performances of opera at the Hippodrome, as scheduled between now and Christmas, began last night with "Carmen," sung for the Women's Auxiliary of the Brownsville and East New York Hospital. Tomorrow's "Rigoletto" has likewise been sold in large part for the Cenacle Giuditta Guild of 610 West 140th Street, Manhattan.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The State Alcoholic Beverage Commission, created to recommend a plan for liquor control, submitted its report to the Legislature today. It became apparent immediately that the proposals would be changed materially before being enacted into law.
DOORN, Holland, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Former Kaiser Wilheim spends these long wintry nights studying ancient symbols and their meanings.

Will Irwin, just back from London, where he was the American delegate at a meeting of the executive committee of the International P.E.N. Club, is explaining why the German P.E.N. clubs have withdrawn from the international organization.

Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy and Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York, told the New York Committee on the Use of Leisure Time yesterday that the city needs many more parks, playgrounds and recreational facilities.
New Jersey hunters are finding plenty of game, according to many reports. This is true both of the wild waterfowl hunters and those who have confined their activities to upland shooting.
BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- There was no session of the Boerse today because of the Contrition Day holiday.

The money market was dull. Outside money on call dropped to 1/2, from 5/8, which had been ruling, while 3/4 remained the official rate on the Exchange. Offerings were in good volume, but demand was light. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

Quotations are for three to four months' paper. Convention Theme for Retailers. "The Retailer Plays His Part in National Recovery" was selected yesterday as the theme for the twenty-third annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by the executive council of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Faced with reports of ineffective enforcement of NRA code terms, General Johnson today increased the responsibility placed upon industry to secure compliance and designated a committee to help industrial self-government units get organized.

Health Commissioner Wynne announced yesterday that the Board of Health had amended Section 128 of the Sanitary Code so as to prohibit in New York City the manufacture, sale or use of eyebrow and eyelash dyes containing harmful ingredients.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A prediction that President Roosevelt would move to restore silver to monetary glory before Congress convened on Jan. 3 came today from Senator Pittman.

As the result of a two-year study of the causes and effects of slum neighborhoods in large cities, the Regional Plan Association of New York will submit to the division of housing of the Public Works Administration in "Washington today a "new formula" for the rebuilding of blighted areas at moderate rentals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The advisory council of the Federal Reserve Board, composed of leading bankers in each of the twelve Federal Reserve districts, has gone on record in favor of the re-establishment of the currency on a gold basis, coupled with safeguards to be agreed upon by international action.

Miss Doris Duke fled yesterday from her city home at 1 East Seventy-eighth Street after it had been besieged by a host of reporters, photographers and groups of the idly curious seeking a glimpse of "the richest girl in the world."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 20:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Treasury Department issued an order today instructing Treasury guards to "show respect for official superiors by standing at attention" when such officials approached or addressed them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- A "brain trust" for this city is indicated in the action of Mayor Loehr in summoning some of the best-known municipal experts of the country to help the city out of its financial difficulties.

The first seven railroads to report for October had a total net operating income of $10,089,000, compared with $11,774,000 in October, 1932, and with $11,548,000 in October, 1931, reductions of 14.3 and 12.6 per cent, respectively. Net operating income in September aggregated $9,135,000, a decrease of 2.9 per cent from the $9,417,000 reported for September, 1932.

At the suggestion of Sol A. Rosenblatt, deputy administrator in charge of the theatrical code, the name of the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, which enforces the provisions of the code, will be changed to the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority.

Jobs for 90,000 unemployed in New York City will be made available under the Federal civil works program recently announced by President Roosevelt, it was revealed yesterday by the State Temporary Relief Administration. About 50,000 unemployed, it is hoped, will be put to work at the prevailing rate of wages by Dec. 15.

The triple tie for first place in the Class A competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League was broken last night when the City A.C. was toppled by the undefeated New York A.C. team on the Winged Foot courts.

Albert Morris Bagby gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Princess Myriam Potenziani, who will return to Italy on Saturday with her father, Prince Potenziani. The other guests were the Hon. Mrs. Murrough O'Brien, Princess Karl Isenburg-Birstein, Mrs. Thomas Walsh, Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg, Mrs. Cooper Hewitt, Arthur Williams, Victor Morawetz, William Matheus Sullivan, Frederic Potts Moore and Charles E. Sampson.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Lee Tracy, film actor, was discharged from the employ of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Motion Picture Company tonight by Louis B. Mayer, studio executive, who described Tracy's behavior in Mexico City while he was watching a parade last Sunday as "deplorable."
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 22 -- A meeting of farmers of Meriwether, Pike and Upson Counties forwarded to the President today a resolution reading:

Word was received here yesterday from Somers, Conn., that the body of a man found stabbed, strangled and wrapped in a blanket there on Monday had been identified as that of Albert Silverman, ex-convict, bootlegger and gangster.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 22 -- The first upset in match play in the Carolina golf tournament happened today when Halbert J. Blue at Pittsburgh defeated Jack Ryerson, former Yale star, of Cooperstown, N.Y., by 3 and 2. Blue thus earned the chance to play Dick Wilson of Raleigh in the final.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 22 -- Seated in the living room of his small cottage, whose walls are paneled with the yellow pine of this region, President Roosevelt today held the seventy-first press conference of his administration.
Housing properties deals featured activity in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.

Inevitably the resignation of Professor O.M.W. Sprague as special financial adviser to the United States Treasury provoked a warm controversy yesterday and brought the administration's monetary policy into the spotlight to a greater extent than any other recent development.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 -- Without a whisper from any one the Disarmament Conference's bureau [steering committee] quickly approved today Arthur Henderson's proposal to postpone the general commission's Dec. 4 meeting "until a date during or immediately after" the January League Council, to be fixed by him.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Financial News, in an editorial today, accuses the British Government of discriminating unfairly against the United States holders of Newfoundland bonds.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Army today practically finished its preparations for the Navy game. The squad worked late, the call for supper halting the practice long after darkness had fallen. Tomorrow the drill will be light and the squad will leave for Philadelphia immediately afterward.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Cancellation of the 15 per cent increase in commuting passenger rates that became effective on the Erie railroad in January was requested of the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a complaint filed by the Metropolitan League of Erie Commuters.

A telegram has reached this office couched as follows: Stop sniping at the NRA. Support the President. The signer's name is of no consequence, nor is the telegram, in itself, but it does indicate a singular confusion of mind which seems to he prevalent.

Henry Goldman Jr., the member of the New York Stock Exchange who wrote last week a letter to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency suggesting sweeping changes in trading and the establishment of a government board to supervise the Exchange, has found himself faced with new competition on the floor of the Exchange this week.

A slight improvement in the demand for steel is reported by The Iron Age in its weekly review. This publication notes also that the "general market outlook has improved appreciably," with public works business "cutting a larger figure from a tonnage standpoint, rail buying actually getting under way and estimates of automobile production in December revised upward."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Chase National Bank and its investment affiliate, the Chase Securities Corporation, have written off as lost $69,572,180.44 out of a total of $89,330,047.10 of investments in and loans to the General Theatres Equipment, Inc., and the Fox Film Corporation, the Senate market investigators were informed today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the bank.

The Getty interests on the Pacific Coast have acquired in the last eighteen months slightly more than 1,100,000 shares of the common stock of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, or approximately 20 per cent of the 5,611,240 shares outstanding.
The importance of cancer prevention was emphasized in a statement yesterday by Dr. James Ewing, director of Memorial Hospital here.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Hugh MacMillan, Princeton's sophomore right halfback who played most of the Dartmouth and Navy games, sustained a shoulder injury in practice today which may keep him out of the last two games of the season, against Rutgers and Yale.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- The prize ship of Soviet aviation, the K-7, largest land airplane in the world, crashed at 3 P.M. yesterday near Kharkov, killing fourteen persons, including the chief pilot, Michael Snegeroff.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 22 -- Carefully chosen units of Nanking's army and naval air forces are being held in readiness near the Chekiang-Fukicn provincial border and along the Chekiang coast in order decisively to crush the Fukien rebellion on short notice, says an official announcement by General Lu Ti-ping, Governor of Chekiang.

BANGKOK, Siam, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Siamese Government lifted today the state of martial law proclaimed at the beginning of the October rebellion, which was not put down until after revolutionary forces had advanced within a few miles of the capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Virtual assurance of a grant of $22,500,000 to $25,000,000 by the Public Works Administration to New York City for completion of the Eighth Avenue subway was announced today by Senator Wagner.

Albert Naples hung by his finger tips to a fifth-floor window ledge at 666 St. Nicholas Avenue early yesterday morning. Below him was death and hurrying to save him was a patrolman who was later to arrest him for participating in a hold-up in which a man was seriously wounded.
BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Today was a legal holiday throughout Protestant Germany officially dedicated to contrite prayer, and the churches were thronged.
Housing properties in various towns and several commercial parcels were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The works of art in the Thomas Fortune Ryan collection go on public sale today at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries and the sale will continue tomorrow and Saturday. Leslie A. Hyam observes in his foreword to the catalogue that this collection "covers in one form or another almost the entire period of post-Hellenic creative art, from the Etruscan culture to the plastic works of Rodin."

Interest in trading on local commodity exchanges was relatively dull yesterday, and futures moved in a narrow range. Some commodities opened higher in the morning, but saw their gains reduced in later trading. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 22 -- With the hearing on defense motions in the Scottsboro cases in recess today, Circuit Judge W.W. Callahan let it be known that he hopes to try at least four of the seven Negroes before Christmas.

BUCHAREST, Nov. 22 -- The new Liberal Cabinet of Dr. Ion G. Duca decided tonight to deal severely with Fascist and other reactionary tendencies in Rumania. This intention will be strengthened by tonight's serious disorders in many parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The American Olympic Association unanimously adopted a resolution today expressing the hope that Germany would lift all restrictions on its Jewish athletes, "so that the athletes of the teams of the United States of America can and will be certified for competition under the Olympic standard."

With the double object of obtaining pensions and leaving their jobs to be filled before the LaGuardia administration comes in, about seventy-five Tammany jobholders applied for retirement on pension yesterday.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it had obtained new evidence to substantiate its charge that organized loaders of freight maintain a racket on the waterfront piers and force truckmen and consignees to use their services whether or not they are desired.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Already it is evident that the public battle over the administration's monetary policy, precipitated by Professor O.M.W. Sprague's letter of resignation, will be full of personalities and hard knocks. Comment offered in Washington today and Secretary Woodin's criticism of Mr. Sprague in New York definitely revealed this tone.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 22 -- The Dartmouth football team was out in full force today, and at the close of practice Captain Phil Glazer touched a match to a dummy, observing the traditional rite that football was over at Memorial Field for another season.

In approving the listing of 200,000 additional shares of $10 par value common stock of the Truscon Steel Company the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday full details of a transaction through which the company borrowed 65,000 shares of the stock from its president and other large stockholders and sold the shares for $615,000 several months ago to pay on bank loans, amounting to more than $1,000,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop, woman physician, and five members of her strange household were questioned by police tonight as an investigation progressed into the bizarre murder of Dr. Wynekoop's daughter-in-law, Mrs. Rheta Gardner Wynekoop.

At a recent dinner in this city Sir WILLIAM BEVERIDGE, a leader among British economic teachers, referred with some humor to the American attitude toward "economists." Public resentment against the profession seemed to him to be foreshadowed. As visitor and guest, he refrained diplomatically from saying what the trouble was; but most of us probably could guess.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Manifestation to prevent Ambassador Sumner Welles from landing on his return here Saturday is being organized by students in sympathy with the Grau San Martin government, according to the student newspaper Alma Mater.

The Junior League squash racquets team took undisputed possession of the lead in the metropolitan league play of the New York group yesterday. It defeated the Heights Casino in a close battle, 3 to 2.

Newfoundland Will Be Rehabilitated. Self-government in Newfoundland, usually spoken of as England's senior colony, is to go into temporary receivership. A commission of inquiry reports to the House of Commons that economic and political conditions in the island are desperate.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 22 -- Delegates numbering 350 from the twenty-seven active chapters of the Psi Upsilon fraternity met at Union College today in the first of the sessions which will mark the three-day centennial celebration of the founding of the organization at Union on Nov. 24, 1833.

When a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures was appointed to inquire into the election of JOHN H. OVERTON as Senator from Louisiana, its members, familiar with the little peculiarities of Kingfish HUEY, looked for trouble mainly from him and his aides in the enlightened government which he has been good enough to give a State whose unworthiness of it is sufficiently proved by the ingratitude of so many of its citizens.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- Immediate abandonment of President Roosevelt's gold-control monetary program and the establishment of an international gold standard, "improved and modernized," were advocated here tonignt by James P. Warburg, New York banker.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent will give a supper dance tomorrow night in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis for the benefit of the building fund of the college.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 -- When the District Court of Evangeline Parish issued an injunction against "dummy" candidates in the Overton-Broussard primary, Senator Huey P. Long advised the parish committee to burn the writ, "for it's not worth the paper it's written on," a witness testified today before the Senate committee investigating the election of Senator Overton last year.

Declining an invitation from Zurich, the executive committee of the Baptist World Alliance will hold its next meeting in Berlin next Aug. 4-10. Announcement of this decision was made yesterday at American Baptist headquarters, 152 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- With recognition of Russia won, but debts, credits and claims questions still unsettled, Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, paid a farewell call on Acting Secretary Phillips of the State Department this afternoon.

PAULSBORO, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Audrey Smith Clark, former stage dancer accused of firing the shot which killed her husband, Sheldon A. Clark Jr., after he had struck her with a billiard cue in their home here, had recovered sufficiently in Underwood Hospital today to describe the events leading up to the slaying.

Local societies for the prevention of cruelty to children are concerned over a new form of employment racket which involves the sending of young girls from neighboring States to New York as domestic servants.

A laboratory seven feet in diameter lifted into the air eleven and three-quarter miles -- such, in effect, was the balloon and its sealed car in which Commander SETTLE and Major FORDNEY rose into the stratosphere to measure the cosmic rays. Within three years no fewer than four similar ascents to unprecedented heights have been made.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 -- The Wheatley Stable's Propagandist, saddled by Harvey Fitzsimmons, son of the veteran James Fitzsimmons, captured the featured Long Green Purse today over a fast track and paid $7.80 for $2. The son of Chatterton had to be strongly ridden by Jimmy Hunter to win by a length from National Anthem, the favorite.

The demand for liquor license application forms slackened further yesterday, enabling the State and City Alcoholic Beverage Control Boards to concentrate their efforts on checking on the premises of prospective retail and wholesale liquor dealers.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Ambassador Bingham attended the tercentenary celebration today of the departure from Cowes, Isle of Wight, of the ships Ark and Dove in which the first British colonists embarked for Maryland. A commemorative bronze plaque, the gift of the Maryland Tercentenary Commission, was unveiled by Lord Fairfax.
Albert Comos, 51 years old, of 222 East Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a charge of sending annoying letters to Otto H. Kahn, the banker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- Running through its entire repertoire of offensive and defensive formations for two hours -- the final thirty minutes of the drill being staged under the flood lights of Anthony Thompson Field -- the Yale eleven's final long practice before the Harvard game was held today.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 22 -- Premier Goemboes was reproached in an interpellation by Deputy Buchinger, a Socialist, today with adopting too friendly an attitude toward Hitlerism and fascism.

Heavy selling of United States Government bonds with consequent losses of 6-32 to 28-32 point on the day, generally lower prices for domestic corporation issues and higher quotations for leading foreign loans characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Hans von Tschammer-Osten, Reich sports leader and supreme authority on all matters affecting athletics in Nazi Germany, issued a new order today regulating the admission of Jews to German athletic organizations.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The council of the British Empire producers' organization communicated to the government today an expression of grave concern over the continued depreciation of the dollar and its consequent effects on the prices of primary commodities produced within the empire.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Details of the combined views of the presidents of the University of Chicago and Northwestern University concerning the proposed merger of those institutions were disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The stratosphere ascension of Lieut. Commander Settle and Major Fordney to 61,237 feet probably set a new official world record, according to calibrations of the Bureau of Standards reported today to the National Aeronautic Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The resignation of General Thomas S. Hammond, executive director of the Blue Eagle division of NKA, is im- minent, it was reported today.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 24. -- One more French Cabinet went down to defeat at 2:30 o'clock this morning after every effort had been made to save it, and when success seemed to be just in sight. It fell on the same issue as Edouard Daladier's Ministry had fallen -- that of reducing civil service appropriations in an effort to balance the budget.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Having a short time ago regimented the edi- torial management of German newspapers and periodicals. Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the inde- fatigable Minister of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda, now also has taken charge of their advertising columns -- and the advertising trade in general.

The strictest economy in municipal expenditures would not be sufficient to meet the terms of the recent agreement between the bankers and the city, and new sources of revenue must be tapped. Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, said yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23. -- The Naval Academy football squad had its last home practice of 1933 today.

In addition to the Edward Hopper one-man show, the Museum of Modern Art offers to the public an exhibition of modern French paint- ing and graphic art, representing gifts and loans from the collection of Mrs. Sadie A. May of Baltimore. Mrs. May is a painter as well as a collector.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Yale's probable starting line-up for the Harvard game in Cambridge Saturday will include Harry Combs at left end, Vie Malin at centre and Tommy Curtin at quarterback.

A complete outfit of sports clothes for women, each model signed by Amelia Earhart, who has augmented her flying career by entering the dress-designing field, will make its appearance late in December, it was announced yesterday by R.H. Macy Co.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Wholesale prices in the week ended Nov. 18 reached, a new high in the trend which began nine months ago, and were at their best level since August, 1931, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of luabor Statistics, announced today.

An effort to raise the standard of radio programs was urgred yesterday at the opening session of the two-day biennial meeting and seventeenth convention of the National Council of Women in the Hotel Vanderbilt.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens pushed their way into first place in the international section of the National Hockey League tonight by earning a 1-0 triumph over the Ottawa Senators. The victory, the Canadiens' fourth of the campaign, grave them a total of 8 points against 7 for the idle Toronto Maple Leafs.

To the London correspondent of the Volkischer Beobachter, chief organ of the Hitlerites, its readers are indebted for a gratifying exposure of the myth that freedom of the press exists in England. The English press, which loves to view with alarm the muzzling of the German press, is itself amply muzzled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Certain banking houses in New York City have advised clients doing business in Great Britain to cover their sterling accounts with dollars. The advice was given yesterday, and it must mean that these bankers expect stabilization of the dollar by the administration in a reasonably short time.

The status of the proposed German Building enterprise in Rockefeller Centre was the subject of speculation among realty and business interests yesterday as excavation work neared completion on the site at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

A national campaign to mobilize consumers, particularly women, in support of the NRA garment label was launched yesterday at a luncheon of representatives of leading women's organizations under the auspices of the Coat and Suit Code Authority at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.

In the week ended on Wednesday, while government officials were, talking of pouring available Treasury funds into the government bond market to support it, the Federal Reserve System, until lately the largest buyer of government securities, sold $508,000 of its holdings.

Bruno Walter, present conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, has been reproached for programs that specialized in German music. Last night two short compositions of Arnold Bax, of the modern British school, were played in Carnegie Hall.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 23 -- Members of the Greenwich branch of the New York Junior League held a dinner at the Round Hill Club tonight. The proceeds will go toward the establishment of a recreation library in North Mianus, Greenwich.

Kid Chocolate, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's featherweight champion, will have an opportunity to square accounts with Tony Canzoneri, former holder of the world's lightweight title, when the pair collide in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23. -- In the presence of Howard Jackson, Mayor of Baltimore, and other officials, Cohort Miss annexed the featured Mayor Jackson Trophy race at Bowie today. Scoring easily by a lengtth over Chance Flight, Cohort Miss finished the mile and seventy yards in 1:46 2-5 over a fast track.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Members of the Army and Navy varsity football squads, who meet in their thirty-fourth football game at Franklin Field Saturday, are quartered on opposite sides of the Delaware River tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The intention of the British Government to establish a legislative council in Palestine without further consultation with the British Parliament was an- nounced tonight in the House of Commons by Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, Colonial Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Developments are expected here within a short time which will present a clear indication of the extent to which the President intends to proceed with his new monetary policy, and the future course of other phases of the administration's efforts to bring back normal economic conditions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Final decision as to whether the Coast Guard is to be made a part of the Navy rested tonight with President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- With the announcement of the United States Bureau of Standards this morning that our barograph shows us to have attained an altitude of 61,237 feet, or 18,665 meters, the story of our flight to the edge of the atmospheric envelope seems to be completed.

The Swiss Government formally announced yesterday its offer to exchange 4 per cent Swiss franc bonds, dated Dec. 15, 1933, and due on Dec. 15, 1953, for its 5 1/2 per cent dollar bonds due on April 1, 1946. The dollar bonds, outstanding in the amount of $30,000,000, are quoted at 162.

The joint facilities agreement of the Consolidated Gas Company and its affiliates was challenged yesterday by counsel for the city at a hearing into the rates of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company before Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Loans paid out by the Home Owners Loan Corporation had amounted to $26,859,105 on 9,199 individual properties by the close of business Nov. 17, the corporation announced today.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 23. -- President Roosevelt moved toward re-establishment of tranquillity in Cuba late tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The last few words of your editorial "Thomases Who Do Not Doubt" go to the heart of the President's monetary policy. You refer to the obscurity of the administration's purposes and say "It has greatly cheered the 'unscrupulous money changers.'"

At the annual founders' exhibition drawing yesterday at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue, first choice of a collection of paintings and sculptures contributed by artist members of the galleries fell to Mrs. Wooster Lambert of St. Louis and New York, who selected a painting of children at play by Jerome Myers, called "The Rest."

The North German Lloyd and Hamburg American steamship companies, which recently were fined $200,300 for accepting "blocked" marks last Spring in payment for transatlantic passage in violation of the rules of the Atlantic Passenger Conference, actually will be required to pay only $50,000 under an agreement reached by the conference member lines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Harvard's three football teams worked for only an hour and a quarter today. The teams ran through all of their plays and also watched the freshmen demonstrate Yale's attack for the last time.

Confronted by a defense that refused to wilt, the New York Americans were forced to accept another defeat last night. The Chicago Black Hawks, appearing at Madison Square Garden for the first time this season, kept the Simpson skaters from scoring their initial victory of the National Hockey League race, handing them a 2-to-0 defeat before a crowd of 8,000.

Sports leaders, in general, expressed themselves as satisfied yesterday with the more conciliatory tone of the resolution adopted by the American Olympic Association in Washington on Wednesday in preference to the strongly worded one which the A.A.U. had passed in Pittsburgh on Monday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A second city in Westchester County stood ready today to abandon wage payments to employes with, the announcement by City Manager John F. Donovan of New Rochelle, that the $50,000 police and fife payroll due Saturday would be indefinitely postponed.

The Harvard Club No. 1 team maintained its position at the head of the Class A Squash Racquets League by giving the strong Montclair A.C. quintet its first defeat of the season at the Harvard Club yesterday. Harvard No. 1 triumphed, 4 to 1 for its fourth straight victory, remaining unbeaten.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Criticism of President Roosevelt's currency policy was expressed here today at the opening session of the annual conference called by the New England Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Rapid progress in the examination of nonmember banks of the Federal Reserve System which have applied for membership in the temporary fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was reported today by Walter J. Cuminings, chairman of the organization.

For the period between formal repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment on Dec. 5 and the enactment by Congress of whatever regulatory legislation may succeed it, a Federal code has been proposed for the distilling industry. It is not an attempt to reimpose on the States a system of centralized control over the manner in which alcoholic beverages shall be sold and consumed.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Major Gen. George M. Cole, former Adjutant General in Connecticut for twenty-eight years, died today after a brief illness. He was 80 years old, and had retired on Dec. 31, 1929.

A book that may be called "Ger- many Prepares for War," in which a German professor outlines the mistakes of the last war and suggests the policies and strategies that may win another one, will be brought out early next year by Harcourt, Brace.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- France is about to begin a new customs regime, Laurent Eynac, Minister of Commerce, announced today.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- In view of Chancellor Hitler's recent interview in Le Matin of Paris, which has been hailed as signal evidence of the German Government's peacea- ble intentions and a desire for Franco-German understanding by the German press, the newspapers here are all the more stirred up and indignant over the continuing "propaganda revelations" in Le Petit Parisien.

Meows varying in pitch and in intensity formed a musical setting at the Hotel Taft yesterday as the combined show of the Empire Cat Club, the Solid Color Cat Society and the Siamese Cat Society of America got under way.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Despite some fluctuations and irregularity, the Boerse resumed its upward movement today. The star performer was Reichsbank, which soared for a 12 per cent gain on the day and dragged an otherwise hesitant stock market along with it.

Prohibition repeal continues to be a factor in the leasing of busines quarters in this city. Realty bro kers and managing agents of business buildings reported a large volume of new rentals yesterday. Included were contracts for floor and for many retail stores.
LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Londoners tonight saw the first performance anywhere of Robert Sherwood's "Acropolis," a play of Athens at the time of Pericles.

The bulk of yesterday's foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx involved housing properties. Fourteen properties were offered, all going to the plaintiffs. Savings banks took over several of the parcels.
The fourth day's sale of the Ar- thur Hind collection of postage stamps at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel netted about $15,000 yesterday, bringing the total amount thus far obtained to $207,000.
Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday citations for 150 members of the department for unusual service in the line of duty.

Four Brooklyn bandits who held up members of the Brooklyn Civic Club last year were convicted of first-degree robbery in the King's County Court yesterday, after one of them accused a Brooklyn Assistant District Attorney of accepting $300 for "fixing" the case.

Debate over the government's monetary policy continued yesterday to the accompaniment of a sharp advance in dollar exchange, a moderate decline in stocks, a lively recovery in high-grade bonds and pronounced weakness in the agricultural staples.

Jack Londin and Cy Alexander, national champions, last night were eliminated in the second round of the New York State A.A.U. one-wall handball doubles title tourney at Union Temple, Brooklyn. They lost to their clubmates, Dave Margolis and James D. Levinson of the Trinity Club. 14 -- 21, 21 -- 20, 21 -- 18.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil at the close of the week ended Nov. 18 amounted to 342,647,000 barrels, a decrease of 748,000 from the preceding week.

Murmurs of astonishment welled up in Federal court yesterday as the government began to sketch through its witnesses a portrait of Waxey Gordon, the beer runner, as the careful golfer, owner of a West End Avenue home that was so richly furnished that he insured the effects for $100,000, and holder of $298,000 in insurance policies.

PESTEHURST, N.C., Nov. 23 -- For the first time this week while playing in the annual Carolina golf tournament, Dick Wilson of Raleigh, N.C., went over par and it almost cost him his match today and the cup. Playing against Halbert J. Blue of Pittsburgh in the final round, the ex-Georgetown star managed to win only on the last green when he holed out in 5 while Blue took 6.

Eleven delegates to the Teachers Council were re-elected at the council's annual convention yesterday afternoon at the Haaren High School, Tenth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Timothy D. Poueher of the shop-work teachers, who is an instructor in Public School 51, the Bronx was defeated for member of the council by John E. Scher of Public School 44, Queens.
VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- "Mutiny" is said to have broken out among the fugitive leaders of the Austrian Nazis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Mayorelect F.H. LaGuardia discussed his public works program for New York City with Federal officials today and found that he saw "eye to eye" with them on the principles involved and the plan of procedure to be followed.

The regular membership of Bruce Malcom in the New York Curb Exchange was transferred yesterday to George La Sala, care of Levy Brothers, and that of John R. Ruggles to Harold Riley Colvin, care of Belden Co.

A proposal designed to give immediate stability to the bond market and greater security to bondholders than they thought they had in the "gold clause" is elaborated by Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank, in a memorandum prepared by him for the Committee for the Nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Senate committee investigators said today that they had evidence that the interests which bought out William Fox not only paid him $15,000,000, but paid $1,000,000 to Samuel Untermyer and $520,000 to the law firm of Charles Evans Hughes for legal services during Mr. Fox's conflict with the bankers.

The tentative plans of the Committee on Decentralization of Industry were announced here yesterday by W.A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States and chairman of the committee. It is one of social committees formed by the Business Advisory and Planning Council under Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce.

Contributions which brought the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee close to the $1,000,000 mark were announced yesterday at the first report luncheon of the committee's commerce and industry division at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BERNARD FAY is a Frenchman. Unlike most of his compatriots, he likes very much to travel. Indeed, it is a toss-up whether Paul Morand, Andre Maurois or himself has the best foreign mileage record among French authors. His intelligence, which is light, flexible and pervasive, will not settle down. One year will see M. Fay writing a biography of the first great bourgeois, Benjamin Franklin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Professor Roswell Magill of Columbia University will be the adviser on taxation to the Treasury Department instead of Harold M. Groves of the University of Wisconsin, as had previously been announced, Acting Secretary Morgenthau said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator of Civil Works and Emergency Relief, blocked today the first reported attempt to play politics in the apportionment of jobs under the civil works program.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 23 -- The mammoth volume which contains the names of those Jackson County citizens deemed qualified to serve as jurors was produced in court today, and it created a sensation in the Scottsboro case.

In few other games of the season have there been so many complexities for the would-be football seer to wrestle with as becloud the issue in the fifty-second meeting between Yale and Harvard at Cambridge tomorrow.

Weakness in other markets and active liquidation of December contracts preparatory to today's notices caused a slow but steady decline on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, prices ending 16 to 17 points lower for the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "After Recognition" you express great solicitude for the happiness of the Russian people. Would it be irrelevant to suggest that the happiness of the American people, in the shape of increased opportunities for employment, is not unaffected by the recognition of the Soviet Union?
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 23. -- The Dartmouth football squad, three teams strong, left today for Chicago and the final game of the year with the University of Chicago.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Before entering politics, M. Albert bad been a newspaper man, a professor, a lawyer and an author.
"Christopher Bean," based on Sidney Howard's stage comedy "The Late Christoper Bean," opens at the Capitol this morning. The cast includes Marie Dressier, Lionel Barrymore and Helen Mack.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 -- Kempster B. Miller, electrical engineer, who won distinction in the telephone field and designed the firealarm system of New York City, died last night at his home in Pasadena. His age was 63 years.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, with a strong defense and a pair of sniping forwards, routed the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 0, tonight in a National League hockey match.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Acting in his capacity of Oil Administrator under the petroleum code, Secretary Ickes today announced division of the country into refinery districts and allotment of inventories of gasoline, excluding natural gasoline but including stocks in storage.
PARIS, Friday, Nov. 24. -- The government of Premier Albert Sarraut was overthrown in a surprise vote early this morning on amendments to the Premier's financial plan.

The protective committee representing holders of mortgage bonds, participation certificates and real estate securities guaranteed by the National Surety Company has been advised by the Home Owners Loan Corporation of its willingness to exchange its bonds in the approximate amount of $15,000,000 for such underlying mortgages.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Packers were aggressive buyers of hogs today and the market recovered part of its recent decline, the top being up 10 cents at $4 a hundred weight, while the day's average was 15 cents higher than yesterday at $3.85. Decreased receipts are expected in the West as a result of the recent drastic decline in prices.

LEIPZIG, Nov. 23 -- Marinus van der Lubbe, the sphinx of the Reichstag fire trial, literally lifted the judges of the German Supreme Court and the entire court audience out of their seats today when in the midst of the proceedings he suddenly burst forth into speech and demanded the end of the trial with the acquittal of his four Communist co-defendants and his own consignment either to prison or to the executioner's block.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- A further hint that the British Government will yield to the demands of the big navy interests was given in the House of Commons today when the First Lord of the Admiralty said that the three cruisers recently announced would be built in private yards "because the government dock yards will have all the work they can do."

Musty, the Bronx Zoo's weasel, paid the last instalment on his Winter overcoat yesterday and blossomed out with a new ermine jacket. A few tufts of brown hair in one corner of his cage were all that remained of his last season's coat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The dally average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,574,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $365,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP), By Mail. -- "Something on the head o' nights" is the fashionable edict here. The coiffure which relied for its chic on a myriad of curls alone is a thing of the past. Most of the smart heads which appear at the Opera and in the most fashionable salons wear "something in the hair."
ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- A recommendation that the State's $100,000,000-a-year school aid be continued next year was made today by a subcommittee of Governor Lehman'a advisory budget committee.

Thursday, Nov. 23, 1933. An easy to firm market for street loans featured the money market. During the forenoon trades were done over the counter at 1/2, but this was later raised to 3/4, when the funds at the inside figure were all taken up.

In five years of crossing the Atlantic the Graf Zeppelin has proved the case of the dirigible airship as a reasonably safe means of transportation with a speed superior to that of any surface ship that could be built. It is estimated that the LZ-129, which will have her trials and perhaps be put in commission in 1934, will be able to make the east-bound North Atlantic passage in forty to forty-two hours.

Wheaton Bradish Kunhardt, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the Carpenter Steel Company of Reading, Pa., manufacturers of tool, alloy and stainless steel, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 100 Central Park South.

Estimates Local Xmas Volume. A total Christmas trade for the metropolitan area of $400,000,000 was estimated yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. This figure, covering the December sales of about 100,000 retailers in all lines, would represent a slight increase over a year ago, he said.

Speculative operators kept out of the share market to a large extent yesterday, possibly for the reason, as brokers surmised, that they were afraid of what may happen to the dollar in the present uncertain state of the foreign exchange market.

In preparation for a fight to the finish to "purge" the State Assembly of influence which he looks upon as a menace to progressive legislation which would be a credit to the party, W. Kingsland Macy chairman of the Republican State Committee, called yesterday a meeting of all the Republican county chairmen in the State on Dec. 8 at Utica.

George C. Austin, lawyer, former Assemblyman and a member for many years of the Union League Club and many other clubs in the metropolitan area, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the head.

The campaign to enlist the services of the more than 5,000 sportsmen's clubs in the United States in a plan to create wild waterfowl refuges is being renewed with greater effectiveness than at any time during the past two years. This was made known in a statement issued yesterday by Colonel Arthur F. Foran, president of the More Game Birds Foundation.
NEW YORK. Jacques Dupuy, son of Mme. Paul Dupuy of Paris, is with Prince and Princess Guy de Polignac at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. DOUGLAS, Director of the Budget, in his speech at Boston yesterday, stuck to his job. He did not discuss the Government's monetary policy, with which he officially has nothing to do. But he did dwell with great emphasis upon the need of preserving unimpaired the credit of the United States.
When Mayor-elect LaGuardia arrives at Floyd Bennett Field about 5:50 P.M. today by plane from Washington he will be greeted by a reception committee of aviation officials and Brooklyn residents.

Among the passengers on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, arriving today from Bremen and channel ports are Colonel Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia, Maxine Elliott, actress; John N. Willys, automobile manufacturer, and Mrs. Willys; Nelson Doubleday, publisher, with Mrs. Doubleday, and Ira Nelson Morris, Consul General of Rumania in Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- The Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York City, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, in a letter sent from the headquarters of the denomination here to its 10,000 pastors, declares that a great spiritual awakening throughout the church is the hope of its General Council.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- "Artists cannot be measured by the same yardstick that is applied to us ordinary mortals," according to Justice Frederick P. Close, whose ruling suspending an order of Oct. 12, 1931, to hold John W. Steel, prominent tenor, in contempt of court and to fine him $15,400 for non-payment of alimony was handed down today in Supreme Court here.

From the ruck and rush of Tammany officeholders seeking retirement on pensions before the new administration takes office, one figure stands out like a steeple in a flood. JOHN H. DELANEY, chairman of the Board of Transportation, evidently does not choose to wait to be legislated out of office again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Senate market inquiry took a sensational turn today, with William Fox, retired movie magnate, charging that bankers and others had formed a "conspiracy" to drive him out of business.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Still calling himself a good Socialist and a democrat, George Bernard Shaw sang praises of Chancellor Hitler and dictators generally in the annual Fabian lecture tonight.

The administrative system recommended by the State Commissioner of Education, Dr. GRAVES, is so sound in principle that the committee of experts must have been able to urge it without detailed inquiry. But the extensive data give firm foundation in fact for the specific recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The United States must either reverse its present commercial policy and begin to import much more than it exports, or be prepared to forego collection of debts owed to it by foreign countries, Secretary Wallace said today.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- For the eleventh successive week the Bank of France's statement, issued today, shows a loss of gold, amounting this time to 735,600,000 francs, which is slightly more than last week's loss.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals declared unconstitutional today the Mortgage Deficiency Law passed by the Legislature last Spring.

Traveling with the utmost secrecy, Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, who won Russian recognition from President Roosevelt, came to New York yesterday from Washington on the first stage of his return journey to Moscow.

In the Washington correspondence of The New Republic this week is to be found the common opinion at the capital regarding the appointment of Mr. MORGENTHAU as Acting Secretary of the Treasury. The President wanted a man who would "go along" with the Administration, whatever his personal views.

A brisk upturn in trading in Bronx properties formed the feature of realty activity in the metropolitan district yesterday. Several deals were reported for apartment houses, two of these being for buildings on University Avenue. In Manhattan a resale was reported for three flats on Columbus Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The resignation of Dr. O.W.M. Sprague sets the pace for the fast-riding opposition to President Roosevelt's financial policy and gives opposition a chance to express itself fundamentally.

Domestic bonds ruled steady to firm on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday under the leadership of United States Government loans, which just about wiped out the losses of the previous day by a rally of 3-32 to 24-32 point.
