Foreign obligations, however, dipped as the dollar firmed in the foreign exchange market.

ATLANTA, Nov. 23. -- Declaring that the country was 25 per cent out of the depression, General Hugh S. Johnson in a speech here tonight warned "partisan critics" of the recovery program to keep out of the way or "you might be trampled under."

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 23. -- To maintain the tariff against impairment by the discount on the United States dollar, the government tomorrow will announce the imposition of a dumping duty to keep the United States dollar at par for customs purposes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- General liquidation developed today in the grain and provisions markets on the Board of Trade and, while the selling was largely in small lots, it depressed prices because of lack of buying. Many local and Eastern operators went out of lines of long wheat and corn, and these grains closed near their lowest figures of the day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Presi- dent Roosevelt's special committee on control of alcoholic beverages announced a plan tonight to place liquor and wine importations under a quota system immediately.

About one-half of the city's 1,000,000 unemployed have been put back to work since the NRA began to function, Grover A. Whalen, local NRA chairman, declared last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

A three-hour drill yesterday concluded Columbia's heavy preparation at Baker Field for its annual encounter with Syracuse here tomorrow. Everything that a football team is supposed to do in the way of attack was rehearsed and the Lions revealed that they are at the peak of their season's form.

Purchases of coast resort estates featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday. One of the buyers was Benjamin Jacobson, member of the Stock Exchange, who acquired Mrs. Henrietta B. Kayser's four-acre estate, held at $50,000, in Deal.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, made the expected announcement in the House of Commons today that the British Government had warned France that if she did not abolish in the near future the special tariff of 15 per cent imposed on imports from Great Britain, the British Government would have to levy an equivalent duty on French goods received in this country.

The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday that at the request of the government resolutions had been adopted by the directors permitting steel producers to accept orders for rails and for products for use in public works projects that call for delivery beyond a single quarter.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several changes in memberships.

ROME, Nov. 23 (AP). -- The Italian Government's confidence that collaboration among the big powers can produce a world disarmament agreement was stated in an official communique today. The communique was issued to express the government's approval of the dis- armament conference's adjourn- ment at Geneva yesterday to leave further negotiations to direct dip- lomatic channels.

The local NRA compliance board, following a hearing yesterday at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway, ordered all independent film theatre operators, who have been working their employes fifty-two hours and more a week instead of the forty prescribed by the President's re-employment agreement, to establish the prescribed working schedule.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- The decision to adjourn the disarmament confer- ence until next January and Arthur Henderson's call to the big States to reach an understanding among themselves are considered here as a triumph for the view held by Italy since Germany's withdrawal.

Largely as a result of gains here, bank clearings throughout the country in the week ended on Wednesday made a sharp improvement over last year. In twenty-one leading cities the aggregate was 22.5 per cent larger than a year ago, and showed a gain over the preceding week, while a year ago a loss was reported.

TORONTO, Nov. 23. -- Tied with two others for first place in the military competition for international army officers at the Royal Horse Show tonight, Lieutenant Churchill Mann of the Canadian Army suffered a slight concussion and other injuries when his horse fell.

FIVE years in the wood and one night in the barrel. That's the record of Rosario Raimondo Impellittiere up to and including the recent boxing lesson he received at the hands of Professor Thomas Loughran at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary, and all his fellow officers of the Communist party, from members of the allpowerful Political Bureau down, will come up for re-election in the Seventeenth All-Union Congress of the party, summoned tonight to meet in Moscow next Jan. 25.
PONTA DELGADA, St. Michael Island, the Azores, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh plan to fly over the South Atlantic on the homeward leg of their five months' trip.

Samuel J. Wurzberg, Brooklyn fire loss adjuster and a well-known figure in minor Brooklyn politics, was held in $25,000 bail by County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of second-degree arson. He was arrested Thursday night -- the tenth man to be taken into custody in the inquiry into a Brooklyn arson ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Some Democratic Senators, who said they had talked to President Roosevelt by long-distance telephone, prophesied today that he will outline further measures in his monetary program in a statement to be issued before Congress meets.

Juvenile delinquency and the problems brought on by prohibition repeal were emphasized yesterday by Alfred E. Smith, Senator Royal S. Copeland and others at a hearing conducted by the Senate Subcommittee on Crime Control at the Bar Association Building.

"The Drums Begin," by Howard Irving Young, will have its premiere this evening at the Shubert Theatre. Judith Anderson is the star and Walter Abel, Robert Gleckler and Moffat Johnston are in the cast.

Most of Mrs. Rouverol's observations of youth appear to be authentic in "Growing Pains," which was acted at the Ambassador last evening. With the assistance of Junior Durkin in long pants and Jean Rouverol in high heels and a great many other adolescents, she has stitched together a ready-made comedy out of the heart-burnings of the young.

Declining 2.1 points during the week, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices fell to 102.8 on Tuesday, from 104.9 the Tuesday previous, and now stands at the lowest point since August. Lower prices for wheat, eggs, hogs and beef, and gasoline accounted for most of the loss.

Old Things Wanted. A bulletin from Science Service points out that not all the Ponce de Leons are in search of fountains of youth. In several lines of endeavor people are looking for fountains of old age, so to speak.
LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- A comprehensive plan that would take care of this city's financial needs for three years and set up a $24,000,000 revolving fund for the purpose was submitted today to the City Commission by representatives of the Citizens Advisory Finance Committee at a closed conference in the City Hall.
Organized protests against the depreciation of the dollar by the government multiplied here yesterday.

A spirited three-hour workout practically closed New York University's football preparations for tomorrow's battle with Carnegie Tech. The Practice, one of the longest of the season, was the final one at Ohio Field, the campus gridiron.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt turned poet last night and paraphrased a well-known couplet by Robert Louis Stevenson. Mr. Stevenson's rhyme was:

Speakeasies, de luxe and otherwise, that have prospered under prohibition will find it difficult to obtain liquor licenses, it was dis- closed yesterday by Louis Fischer, executive officer of the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, 2 Lafayette Street.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 23 -- The Fukien Province independence movement seems doomed to be short-lived, because thus far there are no signs of any support by other provincial elements or militarists supposedly dissatisfied and eager to rebel against Nanking.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop was taken in custody by police tonight following discovery of large quantities of chloroform in the organs of her slain daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York addressed to banks in the second district yesterday a communication from President Roosevelt urging all banks to cooperate with the Civil Works Administration by cashing promptly at par the checks to be received tomorrow by more than 1,000,000 employes of that organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Abandonment of 231.16 miles of branch, lines was proposed today by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad in applications filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The road has been in receivership for more than a year.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The Greenwich Country Club and the Bronxville Field Club scored victories in the Women's Westchester Interclub League squash racquets matches today.

EN GLAD GUTT, a dialogue film in Norwegian, with Tore Foss, Goerril Egede Nissen, Harald Stormoen, Hauk Aabel, Ragnhiid Hald and Eugen Schoeberg; directed by John Brunius; a National Tone-film production. At the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

Prices for commodity futures moved nervously yesterday in active trading on local exchanges. For the most part, the trend was definitely downward, reflecting the strength in the dollar. The trend in the cash markets was also to lower levels.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Yale and Princeton have agreed to terminate their football non-scouting agreement at the end of the present season, it was announced tonight. The agreement has been in force since 1926.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Evidence laid before the Senate Mail Investigating Committee today showed that the Admiral Oriental Company, one of the Dollar concerns, with a mail contract out of Seattle to Manila, was organized in 1922 with only $500 cash capital paid in and made profits of $1,055,647 up to 1925 while operating ships for the government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Before General Johnson, Recovery Administrator, left for Warm Springs today there was placed upon his desk a formal request of the NRA Labor Advisory Board that representatives of labor be placed on all code authorities.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 23. -- Despite the growing criticism of the administration's fiscal program, there appeared today to be no prospect of a change in the gold-buying policy.

ESSEN, Germany, Nov. 23. -- The suppression of two leagues working for the restoration of the Hohenzollerns was announced tonight by the National Zeitung, formerly the organ of Premier Goering of Prussia. The organizations are the Hohenzollern League and the Imperialist Front League for the Promotion of the Hohenzollern Idea.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, Inter nationally known suffragist and peace advocate, received last night the American Hebrew Medal for 1933 for the promotion of better understanding between Christians and Jews in the United States. The presentation was made in the Auditorium of City College, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Dr. John Pixley Munn, banker, philanthropist and chairman of the United States Life Insurance Company, who died Aug. 15, 1931, at the age of 83, left an estate appraised yesterday at $3,235,294 gross and $2,326,926 net, of which $2,624,107 was in securities.

DECATUR, Ala., Saturday, Nov. 25. -- In the midst of a last ditch fight to show that the jury rolls of Jackson County were forged and that the indictments against the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case should be voided, Samuel S. Leibowitz, chief counsel for the defense, received word early this morning that Ruby Bates was dying somewhere in the New York area.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The new book "Mary of Nazareth," by Mary Borden, which is to be published in the United States next week, has become the cause of a lawsuit here shortly after its publication in England.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The franc showed no sign of weakening today, demonstrating, it was held, that the financial markets had discounted the fall of the government. Besides, so many contrary factors worked upon the exchanges that the usual reaction to a political crisis here did not develop.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The city commission is expected to confer on Monday on acceptance of the finance plan offered to it yesterday by the Citizens Advisory Finance Committee to solve its financial problems for the next three years.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 24. -- Celebration with fireworks, gunfire, dynamite bombs, fist fights and stone-throwing last night and today marked the victory of the company union brotherhoods over the United Mine Workers in nine mines of the H.C. Frick Coke Company.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hartford of this city and Buena Vista Farms, Valhalla, N.Y., have sent out invitations for a dinner dance to be given at the Plaza on Dec. 22 for their debutante niece, Miss Louise Makepeace McKelvy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Graham McKelvy of Easton, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Reports that there had been an open break between the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department were emphatically denied today by Eugene R. Black, governor of the board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Miss Dorothea Whitehead will end her career as secretary to Representative Joseph A. Gavagan of New York City when she becomes his wife tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Liquidation in the grain markets apparently ran its course early today. Wheat on the Board of Trade dropped about 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish to the low levels reached early in the month, but a strong upturn came later, with corn in the lead, and the finish was around the best prices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The exchange situation is stimulating imports into Japan from the United States, the Commerce Department said today in its weekly report of foreign business conditions, based upon advices from commercial attaches abroad.

The first session of the sale of furniture and personal effects from the estate of Elisabeth Marbury attracted a large gathering at the Plaza Art Auction Galleries, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon. The total of the sale was $10,313,50.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The National Labor Board settled the seven-week strike in a group of New York shipyards today and arranged for more than 4,000 employes to return to work.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- State Senator John J. MeClure, leader of the Republican organization of Delaware County, was convicted in the Federal District Court here today with seventy co-defendants on charges of operating a liquor ring which had collected more than $2,000,000 in protection money in ten years.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The killing of his daughter, Mrs. Rheta Gardner Wynekoop, was described today by Burdine H. Gardner, Indianapolis wholesale flour and salt merchant, as a "murder of convenience."

They have bitten off an enormous mouthful in "The Drums Begin," which was staged at the Shubert last evening. In fact, they have bitten off more than they can chew. They have endeavored to sketch a rueful love affair against the febrile background of a war motion picture in the making, and at the same time they have tried to speak a few blunt words in the interests of peace.
LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh brought their hydroplane down on Gando Bay this afternoon after an 800-mile flight from Ponta Delgada, the Azores.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cost of free public education is such a large proportion of our nation's local and State budgets that it naturally attracts the attention of those trying to reduce expenses and to balance them.

The United States Intercoastal Conference, whose continued operation was threatened by the withdrawal of its member lines a week ago, will continue to function regardless of the effect of the proposed code for the shipping industry, it was announced yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Pingry School today practically clinched the Northern New Jersey Group Three Prep School championship by scoring a 6-to-0 victory over Montclair Academy in the renewal of a series which started in 1913.

WEIMAR, Germany, Nov. 24. -- In view of the critical state of German Protestantism, resolutions adopted today by the general meeting here of district leaders of the Nazi German Christian movement are remarkable chiefly for saying nothing whatever on the crucial issue between holding the gospel inviolate or Teutonizing it.
NICE, France, Nov. 24. -- Frank J. Gould's $5,000,000 Mediterranean Casino here was swept by fire today and tonight was only an empty shell.

Bridge and dance in aid of the seminary of the Christian Brothers in Barrytown, N.Y., will be held tonight at the clubhouse of the American Women's Association, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street. The party has been arranged by the Mothers' Club of the Cathedral Boys' High School, a Christian Brothers institution at 189 East Seventy-sixth Street.

Put your left hand down flat on the map of Westchester County and you will have a rough and ready guide to the developing highway system in the northeast quadrant of the metropolitan region. The little finger will lie parallel to the Hudson River, indicating the Albany Post Road.

The first sale by the government of liquor seized by Coast Guard vessels took place yesterday in the office of United States Marshal Fred S. Pulver, in Brooklyn. The bid of the Bernheim. Distilling Corporation of 52 William Street, Manhattan, was accepted for 24,624 cases, 116 demijohns and two fifty-gallon barrels of assorted liquors.

Brokers holding membership in the Association of Stock Exchange Firms have been asked by a special committee of the association to send to it suggestions for meeting "the current problems of the brokerage business." In effect, the committee is seeking the general opinion of the brokerage community to determine what steps should be taken to meet the legislative situation in Washington.

A total of $245,000 was realized during the five days' sessions of the auction sale of the Arthur Hind collection of United States postage stamps, which was completed yesterday-at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. For the final session, which included the choicest lot of Confederate States issues ever brought together in a single sale, nearly $35,000 was bid by dealers and private collectors.

The performance of "The Dark Tower" at the Morosco Theatre on Dec. 4 has been taken over by members of the Women's Auxiliary to the Tuberculosis Division of Bellevue Hospital to aid that institution. Arrangements for the benefit are under the direction of Mrs. James Alexander Miller and Mrs. Louis C. Hay.
The first of the large chain restaurant systems applied yesterday to the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board for licenses to sell liquor and wines on the premises.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club took the lead in Class B of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by beating the Princeton Club, 4 to 1, on the latter's courts last night. It was its second victory in two starts.

One of Mayor LAGUARDIA'S first tasks will be to make another attempt at unification of rapid transit facilities, not merely for its own sake, but for the sake of the sadly sundered budget. As it is now, there are three clusters of subway and elevated lines, all more or less competing with each other, and only one making any profit out of the venture: the Interborough, the B.M.T., and the city's Independent System.

Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, received the American Woman's Association Award for Eminent Attainment at the seventh friendship dinner of fifty women's clubs held last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. About 750 women attended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- In order to insure prompt action on the issue of import permits for intoxicating liquors after repeal, a special committee to make tentative allotments of the imports for the initial post-repeal trade was announced today.

Although the challenge for the America's Cup by the Royal Yacht Squadron on behalf of T.O.M. Sopwith's new yacht Endeavour was accepted by the New York Yacht Club on Nov. 8, no prospective defender has been ordered.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 24. -- The spirit of Notre Dame, crushed only two weeks ago after four successive shut-outs, rebounded tonight to probably the loftiest heights since Knute Rockne's heyday as the Ramblers awaited the invasion of Southern California's Trojans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Industrial production dropped in October, but factory employment, which had increased continuously for six months up to September, about held its own to mid-October, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued at the opening today, but professionals soon began to take profits and change their holdings into specialties, especially banks. As a result the market as a whole turned irregular and closed weak.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 24. -- Under the NRA 4,000,000 wage-earners have been taken off the breadline and put in the pay line, $2,000,000 more a day is being earned and spent, and sweatshops and child labor have been virtually abolished, Louis E. Kirstein, vice president of William Filene's Sons, told the New England Council today at its annual meeting.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Expert opinion on the Wynekoop murder case and its pathological implications was contributed tonight by Dr. Harry R. Hoffman, director of the Criminal Court Behavior Clinic, who obesrved Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop for six hours today and was present today when she signed her confession.

Prompt unification of all rapid transit lines without reference to the fare question, leaving that to be settled after unity has been achieved, was urged last night by the Citizens Budget Commission. Its position was stated by its counsel, Harold Riegelman, in an address delivered over radio station WEVD and later at a meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop confessed today that she shot her 23-year-old daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop as the girl lay in the operating room of the Wynekoop mansion Tuesday afternoon. But she did not admit that she killed the young woman.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 24. -- The Mexican press unanimously continues its attack on the Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer film, "Viva Villa," as derogatory to Mexico, going as far as to urge that diplomatic steps be taken to prevent the completion of the picture.

Various communities throughout the country will offer new bonds totaling $12,350,120 for award next week, including several issues that have been up for bids before. This week's revised total was $78,359,328, including $70,000,000 of New York City bonds which were purchased on behalf of commercial and savings banks and insurance companies for investment without recourse to public offering.

Holiday Shopping Fair So Far. While a fair volume of Christmas shopping developed during the week, comparative retail trade totals were affected to some extent by the recurrence of warmer weather and the lateness of Thanksgiving this year, it was reported here yesterday by retail executives.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in his capacity as chairman of the clergymen's committee of the Citizens' Family Welfare Committee, has sent a letter to pastors of all faiths in the city requesting Jewish congregations to observe next Saturday, and Catholics and Protestants the following Sunday, as "Family Welfare Day."

When Mr. SUMNER WELLES, then Assistant Secretary of State, was appointed Ambassador to Cuba last April, it was distinctly understood that his service there was to be temporary, and that when the highly complicated political situation there had been straightened out he would go back to Washington and be succeeded by Assistant Secretary of State CAFFERY.

Alfred E. Smith joined the growing opposition to the monetary operations of the Roosevelt administration yesterday with a public declaration that he was putting party regularity aside because the issue was one of government responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- More than 57,000 men were put to work today on six Federal projects, according to Harry L. Hopkins, administrator of the civil works program. Today's orders bring to 188,097 the total number of unemployed men assigned to Federal projects.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 24. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 18 amounted to 599,289 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 21,613 cars, or 3.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week and 26,666 cars, or 4.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 54.214 cars, or 8.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Publication of the vote taken last Wednesday by employes of the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company on the form of organization for collective bargaining revealed yesterday an overwhelming vote in favor of organizing outside the American Federation of Labor or any independent union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- A charge that Albert H. Wiggin, while head of the Chase National Bank, sent word to President Hoover in December, 1929, to "mind his own business" and "not interfere in what the bankers were doing down in New York" was made by William Fox today at the Senate banking inquiry.

The New York University football team will meet Carnegie Tech at the Yankee Stadium, starting at 2 P.M. today. The contest, the eighth between the institutions in a series which began in 1926, will bring the Violet's seven-game schedule to a close.

A 19-months old baby was saved from death last night after it had fallen more than forty feet from a window on the third floor of a dwelling at 1,688 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, during a fire. The child's mother, Mrs. Harry Vogel had jumped from the window with the baby in her arms, when her escape was cut off by fire mushrooming up the stairway.

The Prendergast, Davies Company, Ltd., Jerome C. Baum, president, has leased the five-story building at 25 Beekman Street for the handling and distribution of wines and liquors. Associated with Mr. Baum in the new enterprise is Allen M. Bernstein and Frank M. Rosenthal.
Tony Canzoneri knocked out Kid Chocolate last night in the most spectacular lightweight battle seen in a local ring since the night in the old Garden when Benny Leonard stopped Richie Mitchell.

Solution of the problem of providing a comprehensive bus system for Manhattan, including the substitu-weeks action on pending application of buses for surface cars on numerous important thoroughfares, will be left for the incoming Fusion administration, it was indicated yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24. -- President Roosevelt will not change his monetary policy or the gold purchase operations. Such was the authoritative confirmation here tonight of the reaction in administration circles to former Governor Smith's denunciation of "'baloney' dollars."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Princeton and Rutgers will meet in Palmer Stadium tomorrow starting at 2 o'clock in a renewal of the oldest football rivalry in the country. The undefeated and untied Princeton eleven is favored to win.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Fiscal officers of Westchester County and the cities of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Yonkers this afternoon discussed with bankers and State officials plans to overcome the financial difficulties of the areas.

Increased support by lawyers, dentists and other professional men in the Red Cross annual roll-call was reported yesterday at headquarters of the New York Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Aubrey D. Vibbert, chairman of the professional division, reported to Peter S. Duryee, roll-call chairman, that professional men who were not able to contribute during the last few years were joining on this roll-call.
A recodification of the rules of golf for the purpose of clarifying them was announced yesterday by A.M. Reid, secretary of the United States Golf Association.

Columbia and Syracuse will bring their football campaigns to a close today when they meet in their annual combat at Baker Field starting at 2 o'clock. A crowd of 25,000 is expected to attend, including several thousand students and alumni of the up-State institution.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24. -- Although hard urged for practically all of the mile and a sixteenth, J.F. Sweeney's Stroll Along today was strong enough to hold on and win the featured fifth race at Bowie by a length. Strongly handled throughout by Jimmy Hunter, the gelded son of Strolling Player returned $21.60 for $2, a price which surprised many in view of his previous winning race at this track.

The great question confronting the United States today, according to Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace, is to "find the courage and the tenacity that will be required to take and to stick to, either the international path, the national path, or to a planned path between the two, for long and perhaps trying years of readjustment."

A marble bust of Napoleon by Rodin brought $7,000 yesterday afternoon at the auction of the art collection of the late Thomas F. Ryan at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. Yesterday's session of the auction yielded $63,810, making the total for the sale to date $91,607.50.

Although no new official total was available, it was learned yesterday that contributions to the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, organized to help those thousands of unemployed who will not be reached by official government agencies, have' passed the $1,000,000 mark, with the campaign gaining momentum each day and speeding toward its final goal.

Fifty paintings by American artists have been placed on view at the Montross Gallery, where they will remain until Dec. 9. A few of the artists are to some extent known in the local art world, but for the most part this is work by newcomers.

Headed by a benefit double-header at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, and the New Rochelle-Davis High of Mount Vernon game to be played at New Rochelle, today's scholastic football program calls for forty contests in the metropolitan district. Eight of the encounters will take place on fields in New York City.

For the quarter ended on Sept. 30, the Ritter Dental Manufacturing Company, Inc. and subsidiaries reported a net profit of $65,594, after depreciation, taxes, interest and other charges, equal after preferred dividend requirements on 25,000 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock, which were outstanding on Dec. 31, 1932, to 13 cents a share on 160,000 no par common shares.

A new racket affecting more than 1,500 Italian bakeries in all parts of the city and extending even into the fish, fruit, ice, parber and boot-black trades has been uncovered after two months' investigation by the State Attorney General's office, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday the adoption, by a vote of 3 to 2, of an order directing an emergency reduction of 6 per cent, effective for one year from Sept. 1, 1933, of rates to be charged by electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system.

An agreement has been effected between the Public Works Administration and the Boulevard Gardens Housing Corporation on a low rent housing project for Woodside Queens, Robert B. Meyer of the corporation announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- At the first hearing today on the administration's substitute code for liquor manufacturers, representatives of the industry sought at every turn to render less direct the control which the government proposes to maintain over production, prices and the general conduct of the business after actual repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and pending legislation by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Filing of registration statements for the issuance of more than $3,500,000 in securities was announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The War Department released the following orders today:

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 24. -- As a result of two nights of fighting between Lafayette College and Lehigh University students, culminating in a free-for-all in front of the Lafayette chapel early this morning, fifty-six Lehigh students arrested in Easton and Bethlehem are under suspension.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 24. -- Food prices in the two weeks ending Nov. 7 resumed their climb, after a four weeks' decline from the high point reached Sept. 6, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, reported today.

"Commodity" bonds, parallel in principle to the "commodity" dollar, were advocated yesterday by Frank A. Vanderlip in the second of two statements prepared for the committee for the nation, as a means of ending the uncertainty regarding government securities.

A powerful finish in the last 400 yards carried Frank Maciewski of A.B. Davis High of Mount Vernon to a new meet record as he won the annual Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The signed statement of Dr. Alice Wynekoop regarding the killing of her daughter-in-law, Rheta, differing in some details from an earlier version of the statement as made public by the police, reads as follows:

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor gave a dinner with dancing for Miss Miriam Hall last night in the salon of the St. Regis Seaglade. The guests were seated at several small tables which were decorated win talisman roses and yellow snapdragons.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- In an editorial headed "Roosevelt Under Fire," The London Times suggests that America may be subjected to even more extreme experiments if President Roosevelt's present policy fails.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Miss Anne Blair Clark, daughter of Judge and Mrs. William G. Clark of Princeton, was presented to society yesterday afternoon at a large reception and tea given by her parents in their home on Library Place.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- For the second time within a month President Albert Lebrun faced the task today of trying to find some one who would take the responsibility of forming a government following upon the fall of Albert Sarraut's Cabinet early this morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 22:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -- The Harvard varsity soccer team won its fourth straight game by defeating Yale, 3 to 1 in an exciting contest on the Harvard Business School field today. In another game the freshman teams of Harvard and Yale played to a 1-to-1 tie, with darkness preventing any overtime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The Public Works Administration allotted $5,082,200 today for thirty-eight non-Federal projects in all parts of the country which officials said would provide 30,145 man-months of quick, direct employment.

Described as a sane but a very sick man, Joseph W. Harriman, indicted banker, was transferred yesterday afternoon from Bellevue Hospital to Doctors Hospital, where he will be under the care of private physicians.

Street funds on call remained firm at 5/8@3/4 but this was due more to paucity of supply than to any special demand. The Stock Exchange rate continued at 3/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and steady in quotation.

A further vigorous rally in United States Government bonds yesterday lifted prices of these issues 3-32 to 1 4-32 points and featured dealings in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation bonds displayed the best strength in many weeks as leading foreign loans slipped lower in response to the strength of ten dollar.

There is no need to dwell upon the importance of the attack upon the President's monetary policies released to the press by ex-Governor SMITH. Nominally issued as a statement to the Chamber of Commerce, it is really addressed to the whole country. Its vigorous and homely words will go echoing through the land.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The British note demanding suppression of customs surtaxes against British goods was received at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs this morning. While the French authorities refused to comment, it was learned they felt a serious situation had been treated, commercially speaking, and it is realized a definite decision cannot be delayed long.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -- Harvard's undefeated junior varsity football team closed its season with a sensational 31-to-0 victory over the Yale jayvees at Soldiers Field today.

Sixteen entries have been received for the Willie Price Challenge Cup and the Butwell Challenge Cup, both point-to-point races to be held today, under the auspices of the Meadow Brook Hunt on the Underhill and Burrill properties near Jericho, L.I. Eight have been named for each race.

With the States and the Federal Government bending their efforts to provide game and public game hunting areas throughout the country, it is not likely that the six million or more of American sportsmen will have to turn to semi-private or private game preserve shooting for their sport.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- An investigation of labor disputes on the Southern Pacific Lines in Texas and Louisiana was ordered today by President Roosevelt, thus halting a strike called for noon tomorrow.
The address by Maxim M. Litvinoff at a dinner given by the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce in cooperation with the American-Russian Institute at the Waldorf-Astoria last night follows:

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 25. -- The most serious fighting has broken out between the Fukien secessionist armies and Cantonese forces at three points, according to cables from Canton reaching Nanking late last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24. -- Four matches were played today as the Northeast Field Hockey Association opened a three-day tournament on the two hockey fields of the Greenwich Academy. The competition is under the auspices of the Stuyvesant Association.
Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia returned home last night, rested by his two weeks' tour of Latin-America and eager to take up the problems that will confront him in City Hall after Jan. 1.

Most of the commodities traded en the local exchanges recovered yesterday some of their losses of the preceding day. Trading was in fair volume and price movements were for the most part nervous. Cash prices were irregularly higher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- An announcement that Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State, will be sent to Cuba as the personal representative of President Roosevelt and not as Ambassador, was taken today to mean that the United States does not now contemplate recognition of the Grau San Martin government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Headed by the service Secretaries, Washington officialdom in large numbers will go to Philadelphia tomorrow for the Army-Navy football game.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James R. Sheffield will give a dinner on Dec. 12 at 45 East Sixty-seventh Street.
Circulation of notices for only 25,000 bales yesterday on the Cotton Exchange was followed by an improvement of a dollar a bale and a final gain in prices of 6 to 10 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Around her spare tall figure the frenzy of a city seethed and broke, but Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop's magnificent serenity endured. Hands rammed deep in the pockets of her loose green velour coat,. she tilted back in her chair against the wall of an anteroom at the Cook County Morgue, swinging her dusty black kid pumps and received interviewers with the unruffled poise of a social leader greeting friends.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Le Roi Williams and Thomas Marshall, lawyers, today were named by Federal Judge John P. Barnes as equity receivers for the Grigsby-Grunow Company, manufacturers of radios and electrical refrigerators, which recently had been seeking an RFC loan.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24. -- Speaking not as President of the United States, but as a founder of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight accepted for the foundation a new administration building financed by contributions from Georgians.

OTTAWA, Ill., Nov. 24. -- Two pilots and a stewardess were killed in the crash of a United Air Lines transport plane in a hay field seven miles north of this city this morning. The plane was being ferried, with its ten passenger seats and mail and express compartments empty, from Chicago to Kansas City when the crash occurred and it burst into flames.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 24. -- Motor freight carriers of Indiana were ordered by the State Public Service Commission today to charge mileage rates identical with those of railroads. The order is effective Dec. 30.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Senatorial investigation which is revealing to the public transactions of financiers which often show a lamentable disregard of high ethical standards of banking, makes pertinent reference to an address delivered by the late A. Barton Hepburn before the senior class of the Sheffield Scientific School, Yale University, in 1908.
Football moves to its climax today. Each day of play between now and the end of the season will bring games on which will be turned the eyes of all interested in the sport.

Miss Jean T. Proctor, daughter of A. Phimister Proctor, the sculptor, and Mrs. Proctor, will be married this afternoon at her father's studio, 39 West Sixty-seventh Street, to Robert F. Tack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Vincent Tack of 130 East Sixty-seventh Street and The Bars, Deerfield, Mass.

That stocks and commodities, as well as bonds, advanced yesterday simultaneously with the further broad recovery in dollar exchange excited little comment since this is becoming the fashion of the markets. Wall Street acclaimed the rise in prices as a sign of returning confidence.

VIENNA, Nov. 24. -- In an obvious attempt to silence the quarrel between Prince Ernst Rudiger von Starhemberg, the Heimwehr's commander-in-chief, and former Vice Chancellor Franz Winkler, who represent the most important allies of Chancellor Dollfuss, the Cabinet Council today proclaimed that no political meetings of any kind should be held from Dec. 1 to Jan. 15.

Holders of bonds of the Chicago Joint Stock Land Bank have been asked by a reorganization committee headed by Robert Stevenson to assent to a plan of organization of a new corporation to take over and liquidate the bank's assets. The plan, it is said, has been approved in principle by the Land Bank Commissioner.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Bronxville High School vanquished Scarsdale High, 18 to 12, today in their twelfth annual football game. In winning for the fourth straight year, Bronxville tallied its seventh victory in the series. Scarsdale has triumphed four times and one game was a tie.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Official modification of Acting Secretary Morgenthau's Treasury censorship was authorized in an order sent to division chiefs today. The action was decided on Wednesday.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The British Government's approval of Italian ideas on how the disarmament conference could be salvaged was announced today by Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon before the House of Commons.

A system of education, that will train citizens from childhood in a knowledge of their responsibility to government and in the fundamental principles on which governments are based was urged upon the Progressive Education Association last night by Colonel Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt.

New Stratosphere Record. It is now Soviet Russia's turn to experience the disadvantages of a policy of non-recognition. Commander SETTLE and Major FORDNEY'S stratosphere figure of 61,327 feet will in all probability be accepted as a world record in spite of the fact that the Russians in their recent flight went up 62,335 feet.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Charles Russell Cohen, 18 years old, son of Emanuel E. Cohen, a lawyer, of 839 Riverside Drive, New York, reported to the authorities here at 3 o'clock this afternoon that he had just been released by three men who kidnapped him late Wednesday afternoon from Cornell University, where he is a sophomore.

In voting yesterday to retire several important city officials on pension, the Board of Estimate expressed its wish that John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, and Daniel L. Ryan, one of its members, would reconsider their decision to leave city service before the end of the year.

The educational and economic advantages of the Federal Child Labor Amendment were emphasized by leaders in the social welfare activities of local and State organizations in an informal discussion held yesterday under the auspices of the National Child Labor Committee at a luncheon at the Hotel Gramercy Park.

Belief that some of the uncertainty that surrounds the government's monetary policy may soon be removed was expressed yesterday in Wall Street, where there was a further display of confidence. Business on the Stock Exchange increased only slightly, but trading in bonds and commodities was considerably more active than in the recent past.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The text of the conclusions of the RFC on reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company is as follows:

Improvement in trade was noted during the week, even though interest in the nation's monetary situation nearly crowded all other occurrences into the background, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -- Before a crowd expected to total 58,000, Harvard and Yale will come together tomorrow in their annual football game.

This is another of the words coined by the necessities of the times through which we are passing. It may be said that it is a relative of ARA, which helped men, women and children of other countries in their need following upon the war, and a companion of NRA in our own national recovery effort.

BASIL WOON has been a foreign correspondent in Paris, a press agent for Cuba and a ghost writer for Peggy Joyce. Yielding to an easy temptation, his publishers speak of sophistication often when they speak of Mr. Woon, and as a sophisticate he was much embarrassed, he makes it perhaps too plain, when it was necessary for him to tell a friend that he intended to summer in California.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24. -- On arriving here today for a two-day visit with President Roosevelt, General Hugh S. Johnson predicted an early settlement of the dispute between Henry Ford and the NRA.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Catholic University met South Dakota State tonight at Griffith Stadium and defeated the Westerners, 27-6.

Text of Mr. Litvinoff's address appears on Page 3. The combined voices of the American and Russian "giants" will make themselves heard and their joint efforts "will weight the scales in favor of peace." Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, predicted in an address here last night, the eve of his sailing for home after winning recognition of the Soviet Union by the United States.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- Premier Mussolini had an hour's conversation in Rome today with Joseph Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, during which current League problems were discussed. The. meeting is assumed to have been of particular importance in view of the approach of Dec. 5, when the Fascist Grand Council meets to decide whether Italy shall continue to be a member of the League.

A dispatch to THE TIMES yesterday from Ottawa reported that the Canadian Government intends to impose a "dumping" duty on American products. This is because our dollar has now fallen in terms of Canadian currency. The duty will be flexible, varying with the degree of depreciation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 23, unless otherwise specified:

Stock "touting" by operators of pools, through wash sales, the hiring of customers' men and publicity agents, or by any other means, was outlawed yesterday as fraudulent by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey.

Smaller factory units in the future were predicted yesterday by Walter Kidde, president of Walter Kidde Constructors, Inc., at a meeting of the Industrial Real Estate Brokers Association in the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street. Rapid changes in industrial methods, he expects, will force types of construction on which the cost can be written off quickly, before the structures become obsolete.

HAVANA, Nov. 24. -- Provisional President Ramon Grau San Martin, when asked to comment on President Roosevelt's statement last night concerning the policy of the United States in its relations with Cuba, limited himself to reiterating that his government was ruling with order and respect for all rights and indicating that he would continue his efforts to maintain the absolute sovereignty of the republic.
WAYNE, Pa., Nov. 24. -- Scoring in every period, Hun School of Princeton defeated the Valley Forge M.A. eleven by 31-6 today.

The State Civil Works Administration, acting on orders from Washington, sent a letter yesterday to the Board of Estimate calling upon the board to take certain specific steps necessary to complete the transfer of the 110,000 persons on the city's emergency work lists to Federal payrolls.

The framework of a program to mobilize the women of the United States in the cause of "social justice," embracing the cultural use of leisure and study of economic questions, was presented yesterday at the closing session of the biennial convention of the National Council of Women in the Hotel Vanderbilt by Mrs. Estelle M. Sternberger, first vice president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Declaring that a newspaper was the "proving ground for public policies and public opinion," Deal Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism, suggested today that newspapers, like educational institutions, be exempted from provisions of the NRA.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24. -- An exchange of farewell messages between President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Commissar for Foreign Affairs, was made public tonight at "the little White House."

Representatives of the Motion Picture Research Council, which compiled nine volumes indicating that motion pictures are harmful, especially to children, and of the motion-picture industry staged a verbal battle yesterday at the closing session here of the United States Senate subcommittee on crime control.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP). -- An announcement was made today that Katharine Hepburn will appear in a picture based on the historic story of Joan of Arc, which will go into production after she returns from the East, in about six months.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press). -- A move by the London Stock Exchange to force inclusion, in future municipal bond issues from the dominions, of guarantees that the principal and interest will be paid in sterling and the interest shall not be subject to domestic taxation, is under way.

With the exceptions of post-mortems and the Captain Blackjack incident, the second and last day of the cat show faded peacefully from the metropolitan scene. Along about 7 P.M. the three judges washed their hands -- in antiseptic solutions -- of the whole affair and abandoned the caterwauling entrants to the tender ministrations of their mistresses.

Threading their way through a forest of easels draped with charts and diagrams done on heroic scale, witnesses and government attorneys guided a jury in Federal court yesterday among the intricate financial transactions of Waxey Gordon's wide-flung beer business.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, made some comments on disarmament in the House of Commons today partly intended for Berlin readers and partly to pacify that large part of the British public which thinks its own Foreign Office is too lukewarm in the cause of peace.

PARIS, Nov. 18 (by mail). -- Costume jewelry is returning to vogue. Since the simple elongated line of the new code offers an effective background for accessories, new bracelets, clips and necklets have put the exclamation mark of chic on many a frock.

WARSAW, Nov. 24. -- The Teatr Polski in Warsaw, directed by Dr. Arnold Szyfman, has again been chosen by George Bernard Shaw for the first production of his new play, "On the Rocks." Four years ago "The Apple Cart" had its world premiere here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- An appeal for Pan-American unity, looking forward to reconstructed world business leadership and peace based upon a policy of the good neighbor, was issued by Secretary of State Hull in a statement today upon arriving in Rio de Janeiro, en route to the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo.

GENEVA, Nov. 24. -- An important move from Rome, designed to speed the diplomatic machinery that the great powers have promised to use for disarmament in the next few months and having the support of Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain, is expected soon by some important diplomatic quarters here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Consolidation of the properties of the St. Louis-San Francisco and tha Missouri - Kansas - Texas railroads, with estimated train-mile savings of almost 50 per cent from their unified operation, was suggested today in a report by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as the best way out of the Frisco's present difficulties.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Army, still undefeated, and Navy, with a light but fighting team, await the whistle that will send them into action in the thirty-fourth service game on Franklin Field tomorrow at 1:30 o'clock.

BUCKNELL vs. W. and J. -- The British Lawn Tennis Association now has a reserve fund of something more than $200,000 at the current rate of exchange. This includes the five or six pounds sterling known as the Davis Cup. One vote for Bucknell.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 24. -- About 1,000 of the 12,000 members of Psi Upsilon fraternity participated today in the centennial exercises at Union College in honor of the seven students who founded the national society.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 24. -- California's Bears and Stanford's Cardinals will meet in the Stanford Stadium tomorrow in a contest that may result in the winner being chosen the West's representative in the Rose Bowl game New Year's Day.

THE monstrous deaf-mute and Chinese super-criminal, Chu-Sheng, secreted in Panama, is plotting to destroy the Atlantic Battle Fleet as the ships are on the verge of attempting the transit of the canal in the unprecedented time of twenty-four hours.
DUBLIN, Nov. 23 -- The entry of Free State politicians into the arena of the Northern elections has been the most notable development of the week.

With commercial and savings banks throughout the country to begin operations under the Federal plan to guarantee deposits on the first of the year, leading figures in the building and loan business are seriously considering plans for a similar type of protection for participants in their associations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The controversy between the Roosevelt administration and Henry Ford over the latter's coldness to the NRA program flared up anew to- day when a local agent of the automobile manufacturer charged that specifications were being changed to rule him out of government contracts.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Professor George H. Barton, noted Harvard geologist and a veteran explorer, dropped dead today of a heart attack as he faced his geology class in the lecture room. He was 81 years old.

Many pastors will preach on Thanksgiving today. This evening there will be a number of Thanksgiving pageants, harvest cantatas and oratorios. Several military, patriotic and Masonic organizations will hold their annual services. All the 3,971 congregations which compose the United Lutheran Church in America, in celebration of its fifteenth anniversary, will be asked today to inaugurate an "every member visitation" to obtain church attendance and church support for 1934.

THERE is nothing dry or formal about this book, which is full of unexpected plums. One guesses that the author had a good time writing it. He was asked to do so by the State Agricultural Society, the Legislature and Governor Roosevelt having in 1931 authorized its preparation as a part of the centennial celebration of the society.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The Princeton University Triangle Club will present its 1933 musical production, "Fiesta," at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York on Dec. 19.

THERE is occasional lifelike characterization in this story of a luckless stock company's brief tenancy of a playhouse in a small Indiana city, but it is decidedly enfeebled by excessive preoccupation with purely amorous and irrelevant details.

HAVANA, Nov. 25 -- Five former army officers accused of crimes during the Machado regime, who were being transferred under military escort from Havana to Santa Clara to go on trial there, were seized and slain by a group of unidentified persons at daybreak today near Colon, Matanzas, Province.

As a result of lower commodity levels, consumer resistance to higher prices and misguided attempts to include every possible element in costs, manufacturers in several lines of industry have been forced to revise their ideas on Spring price lines, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

A condensed "Summary of the Welfare Services of New York City and Emergency Unemployment Relief Funds," showing the different agencies, with addresses and telephone numbers, to which variouus classes of distress cases should apply for relief, was made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

MAX MILLER has adopted the same technique for this autobiographical volume of boyhood memories as he used in his successful "I Cover the Waterfront." That is to say, it is a collection of fragmentary bits of memorabilia and brief "human interest stories," touched with wistfulness and gentle humor and nostalgia and simple pathos.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Profit-taking on the Boerse today interrupted the upward movement of the last few weeks and turned the market irregular and sluggish. Some specialties, especially among the electricals, remained strong, but most of the list either was dull or weak.

Plans are going forward for the annual Charity Ball -- the seventy-seventh -- to be held on Dec. 7 at the Ritz-Carlton. Usually an outstanding event in February, this will be the first time in its long history, that the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital has benefited from two balls in one year.

FOR more than one hundred years it has been the inevitable role of railroading to hold a pre-eminent place in industrial history. Yet its truly epic story is being written in this day. It is the story of the giant's comeback.

Golfers who have been clamoring for a more simple playing code at last have had their demands gratified, for when they take to the links next year they will be playing under a set of rules that have been completely overhauled by the two great ruling bodies.

Governors Island, headquarters of the United States Army's Second Corps Area, is undergoing sweeping changes as the result of a construction program which is being carried forward rapidly. Modern buildings have replaced a number of temporary structures erected during the World War; roads are being improved and extended, and utility services improved.

One of the largest conveyances of Manhattan real estate in recent years was put on record yesterday, when the Chase National Bank came into possession of two tall office buildings and an entire square block containing a score or more of smaller structures in the financial district.

PROBABLY every serious photographer in the city has ere this paid a visit to Knoedler's, where, on the third floor, are to be seen the daguerreotypes assembled by Miss M. Theresa Bonney from her own collection and from various American sources.

Twelve years is a long time to wait, but Inspector Lord is of the bulldog breed that never lets go. That is why he is waiting for Sprat Martin to come out of prison and lead him to the L60,000 stolen from the Lombard Street Branch of the London, Midland and Scottish Bank.

A GREAT store of platinum-blond liquid lies in the cellars of Champagne -- enough to provide for the imminent celebration and for the demands of many months to come. Fine wines, long in the making, have been accumulating and ripening in France during the years in which American cellars have run dry.

NIKOLAI SOKOLOFF and the New York Orchestra will begin a series of five symphonic concerts at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. The program, like those of the four concerts planned for later in the season, is of great interest.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 25 -- The Secessionist regime in Fukien Province, apprehensive of a blockade by Nanking's navy and fearing a naval attack, notified all steamship companies today that the entrances to the harbors at Foochow and Amoy were being mined, that incoming vessels must have authorized pilots and that the ports would be closed every night.

Jamaica High School's rifle team triumphed in the eighth annual New York Stock Exchange invitation meet at the Crescent AthleticHamilton Club, Brooklyn, yesterday. Nineteen schoolboy teams, comprising a field of 113 competitors, participated.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Lorne Chabot, the old Toronto goalie, came back tonight to Maple Leaf Gardens with the Canadiens of Montreal and in a remarkable exhibition of puck-stopping shut out the Leafs, 1-0. It was the first defeat of the season for the National Hockey League champions and increased the Canadiens's lead in the International group to three points.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- All the scoring and most of the thrills of the Army-Navy battle today were packed into the opening half.

R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners Association, suggested yesterday that the government "give some thought to the practicability of ocean liners as landing places for airplanes at sea." He said he thought this possibility should be studied before the government spent money on sea-dromes.

Growing appreciation on the part of the public of the advantages offered by the Air Express service of the Railway Express Agency for the expedited movement of shipments is plainly indicated in the remarkable increases in the volume of this traffic during the past two years, says The Express, organ of the agency.

Most retailers will welcome the investigation of prices which General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, has announced he will begin in Washing-- ton on Dec. 12 as a result of charges of profiteering under NRA codes and the Blue Eagle, it was said yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
READING, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Albright and Lebanon Valley, traditional rivals, battled to a 6-6 deadlock today in the twenty-fourth renewal of their series.

NANKING, Nov. 4 -- Chinese officialdom is staggered at the complexity of problems presented in a report made to the Central Government by a group of investigators who have just returned from an official tour of investigation to the distant provinces of Ching-hai, Sin-kiang and Kan-su.

It is good to see Law in its most amiable aspect, Cupid holding his own among austere and awful wigs. Justice pouring golden balm upon a wounded heart. Hear a tale of love and an action in contract. In December, 1931, an English nurse and an English engineer became engaged to be married.

PIERRE, S.D., Nov. 23 -- What depression in agriculture can do to an agricultural State of the Middle West is to be found these days in a case history of South Dakota, one of the truly representative farming empires of the country. The metamorphosis has been gradual until now most of the State's farms are being operated by renters rather than owners.

FOR December, Victor gives us two Wagner items differing considerably in size, subject matter and date of recording. First, on both sides of a single 12-inch disk (7680) is the Eva-Sachs duet from "Die Meistersinger," Act II, by Gota Ljungberg and Friedrich Schorr, and, more imposing, is Stokowski's "Gotterdammerung" excerpts by the Philadelphia Orchestra, on ten sides in Album M 188.

The checkered careers of the St. Louis-San Francisco and the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railways were subjected to further mutations last week, including a denial that the RFC had proposed to merge the Frisco with the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad.

JERICHO, L.I., Nov. 25 -- Sardon and Pinnace, aged veterans of the grueling sport of cross-country running, today triumphed in the challenge cup point-to-point races of the Meadow Brook Hounds over the winding and hilly course on the estates of Mrs. Middleton S. Burrill and Daniel Underhill.

Kind Friends, We fear you fear to see upon the stage A Moliere play in this impatient age When nothing's bearable unless it's new; Well, we are scared to death, the same as you. Yet, if solemnity's what you're afraid of, That isn't what this offering is made of.

The New York Football Giants will play the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, starting at 2:15, in a game which is one of the traditional contests on the National Football League schedule. The Giants have been unbeaten in five home games and must repeat their early season triupmh over the Packers to retain their Eastern divisional leadership.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Placing five men among the first ten finishers, the Passaic High cross-country team easily captured the annual Dana College run at Branch Brook Park today. Passaic amassed the remarkably low score of 19 points.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 25 -- A fighting Wolf Pack from North Carolina State College gave the undefeated Duke University Blue Devils the hardst fight of the season in the final State Conference game today. The Blue Devils were unable to push the ball across the goal line until late in the last quarter.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 25 -- Notre Dame's Ramblers of football stuffed twenty rabbits' feet in their moleskins for good luck today against Southern California's Trojans, but they couldn't catch the slippery "cottontail" from San Diego's hills and were crushed by 19 to 0.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Many wellknown figures in the American colony, as well as outstanding personalities in French society and official life, gathered at the recent showing of replicas of sculptures which Malvina Hoffman made originally for the famous Hall of Man of the Field Museum in Chicago and which are now being shown in Paris at the Trocadero.

VIENNA, Nov. 24. -- To every other capital Vienna is the sore spot of Europe and Nazi designs upon Austria the one immediate menace to the tranquil settlement of economic problems. But in Austria all is peace.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 -- St. Mary's exhibited too much early power and deception for the University of California at Los Angeles today and won the annual football game, 22 to 14.

THERE is mystery in the air at Skyetower, the home of Hester Prelton, widow of the late unlamented Carlyle Prelton, patent-medicine magnate and unscrupulous financier. Prelton died, five years before the story opens, by accident, according to the verdict of the deputy coroner, although there are those who question that decision and believe that somebody should be credited with a put-out or, at the very least, with an assist.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The Grand Jury today indicted twelve persons, including seven lawyers, in the Passaic County jury fixing investigation. Two indictments charging conspiracy to obstruct justice were handed up to Judge Joseph A. Delaney in Common Pleas Court.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25 -- A $3,225,000 bond issue for a municipal power distributing system was approved by voters today, and this will make Knoxville the first large city in the Tennessee Valley to be served by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Tyngsboro's Prejudice. New Yorkers must be a tolerant lot. One of the most interesting sights of a recent visit was a man who sat directly in front of me in a theatre. He wore earrings and apparently they attracted little or no attention, I presume this is because people from all over the world visit the great city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A nation-wide battle to vest liquor regulation entirely in the States instead of the Federal Government loomed today as the distillers grew more determined in their opposition to the proposed code embodying provisions for regulation under the NRA and the AAA of the manufacture and distribution of alcoholic beverages.

ANOTHER unit has been added to the plant of the Warm Springs Foundation. Last Friday President Roosevelt formally accepted on behalf of the foundation the new $100,000 memorial building, a gift to the centre from citizens of Georgia.

A NEW deal for the city school system and complete harmony between the opinions of the Mayor and those of the State education authorities would seem a logical forecast for 1934 in view of the report just made on the city school situation by the State Department of Education under Commissioner Frank P. Graves.

Women interested in the Wiawaka Holiday House for girls will give their annual card party tomorrow afternoon at the Sulgrave and at the homes of Mrs. R. Burnham Moffatt and Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre in the neighborhood of the hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- By a stroke of the pen Argentina has removed the United States from its predominating position in the Argentine market. That will be the effect of the import license decree, written by Finance Minister Pinedo and issued by President Justo.

Lewis Milestone, who directed the filming of "All Quiet on the Western Front," returned from Europe last week on the French liner Ile de France. He cut short a tour of Russia to return to Hollywood to direct filming of "Red Square" for Columbia Pictures.
PARIS, Nov. 14. -- A "decalogue for tourists," consisting of ten don'ts, has been compiled by the French tourist authorities. It gives some sane advice, and is as follows:

THE genealogist, following well-thumbed catalogues of historic families, was not taken unaware when President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in his recent Savannah speech, referred to the Bullochs of Georgia as kin to his wife and children.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Harvard's overhead game opened the way for its two first scores today. Bob Haley crossed in the first period and Fred Crocker scurried across for a second touchdown in the next session. After Bob Lassiter gave Yale a tally in the third period, Fergie Locke retaliated by uncorking a brilliant run of 90 yards for a touchdown, sealing the triumph for the Cantabs.

FREUD'S "Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis," presented to English readers in 1920, has been a stimulating book to psychologists, physicians, social workers and literary men. The present volume is a continuation consisting of seven lectures which discuss the new developments in psycho-analytic theory since the old were written and formulate authoritative statements of certain of Freud's views.

IT was a meeting unusually rich in important announcements that the National Academy held in Cambridge, Mass., last week. The universe expanded and collapsed in new and unexpected ways; light was thrown upon the manner in which infantile paralysis and so-called sleeping sickness (encephalitis) are contracted; a striking relation in the magnetic cycle of sunspots and our weather was brought to light, and new facts about the cosmic rays were presented.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- "I thought we played a great game, but we met a better team," said Reggie Root, Yale's coach, in the Eli dressing room after the game. "Of course, I'm sorry to be on the losing team, but I do get some measure of satisfaction in seeing Eddie Casey get a victory.

LONDON, Nov. 10 IVOR NOVELLO is the Duval of the London stage. He holds up good citizens at the pistol's point, levies (by means which they feel they ought to resent) a handsome tribute of laughter, and as he gallops away in triumph extorts from his victims a final tribute of unwilling admiration for his gay impudence.

BERLIN ALMA M. KARLIN, that curious globe-trotter of whom I told you recently, now has published the two final volumes of her trilogy, "Im Banne der Siidsee" and "Erlebte Welt. Das Schicksal einer Frau" (Wilhelm Kohler Verlag. Minden i.w., Leipzig, Berlin).

WASHINGTON PRETTY girls with Southern charm, sombreros from the Southwest, Harvard accents, foreign phrases, charts, radios, and "scavenger parties," economic argument and tea-table chatter, informality in the White House and tweeds at a diplomatic reception.

Having enlisted the aid of many younger members of society as committee workers, the executive committee of the County Fair Ball is now completing plans for that event, which is to be given Dec. 9 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Hospital social service work.

It is many years since Eliza Orne White began writing stories for children, and she has created a long line of very real little girls who are promptly taken to the hearts of sue cessive generations of little girl readers. That a story should be as absorbing to a 9-year-old of today as it was to a 9-year-old of twenty-five years ago is proof that it has truth and vitality.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Displaying its most powerful offensive drive of the year, Bucknell overcame Washington and Jefferson today by 38 to 6 in its final game of the season.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Representative Steagall of Alabama, chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, suggested today that Alfred E. Smith should accord to President Roosevelt "the same support and sympathy" which he gave former President Hoover.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Few people in England understand President Roosevelt's plans for economic recovery. Fewer still approve of them. Yet the American President is popular with the English. They admire him for the quality, which their own leaders today do not possess -- he is a man of courage.

PANAMA, Nov. 22 -- The Weston-Carr expedition, now exploring the Goajira Peninsula in Colombia, has made some interesting discoveries regarding the habits of the Indians who inhabit the vast cactus-covered plains of the Goajira.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 -- Sev- eral South American Governments regarded as a manoeuvre tonight the recent White House declaration that the United States could not discuss monetary and tariff problems at the Pan-American Conference in Montevideo.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the title "Commodity Benfits," Part II, Section 8 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act gives the Secretary of Agriculture power:

THE author of this charming little book of memories is quite sure that, although he is willing to admit that "there may be sweeter music in the world than the pealing of a dinner-bell atop the farmhouse," he has never heard it.

The development of an outlet for the adventurous spirit of youth which heretofore has found its expression in war was urged upon more than 1,500 teachers and parents yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 25 -- Following a three-day tournament on the field of the Greenwich Academy under the auspices of the Stuyvesant Field Hockey Association of New York, the All-Northeast first and reserve field hockey teams were announced at a dinner tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 25 -- The Boston hockey team scored another victory today in the Northeast Field Hockey Association tournament, defeating the Stuyvesant first eleven, 4 -- 3, at the Greenwich Academy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Crimson flares gleamed aloft in the dusk this evening and Soldiers Field was a bedlam of falling goal posts, singing, snake-dancing undergraduates and crashing cymbals as Harvard celebrated its first football victory over Yale in the three years of Eddie Casey's regime.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 25 -- Patchogue High School's football team continued undefeated in seven starts, which includes a tie, by blanking Amityville, 12-0, today in a contest between the Suffolk County rivals. Jack Hammond and Peter Nistad accounted for the winners' touchdowns.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- From distant Eastern stations, from remote foreign ports, soldiers and sailors traveled many segments of the globe to be among the thousands in the service family which saw Army and Navy clash on Franklin Field today.

AT the National Horse Show Association's golden jubilee, held recently in Madison Square Garden, 75,000 spectators (more than attended any former show) occupied the stands during exhibition week. Apparently a large section of the sporting public still remains horse-minded and to these the book under review should chiefly appeal.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25 -- The Montreal Maroons gained undisputed hold on third place in the international section of the National Hockey League tonight when they defeated the New York Rangers, world's champions, 1 to 0, before a crowd of 4,500 fans.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 25 -- Martin Conboy was appointed by President Roosevelt tonight as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Former Governor William E. Sweet of Colorado launched a counter-attack today against Alfred E. Smith for his criticisms of the monetary policy of President Roosevelt. He is a member of the National Speakers Bureau of the NRA.

BECAUSE "Arabia Felix," by the English explorer Bertram Thomas, preceded this account by H.St. J.B. Philby, let no one think that the sheen has in consequence worn off adventuring in Rub' al Khali, the great Arabian sand-waste which had remained as the last unknown quarter of the globe.

The postponement after a public hearing last week of the oil price-fixing schedule, originally planned to become effective on Dec. 1, is generally interpreted as meaning that this experiment will not be attempted. The consensus also is it indicates that the Federal Government through the NRA will lessen gradually its control of the industry, if more complete cooperation can be obtained within the petroleum industry on some of its major problems.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Criminal prosecution of persons responsible for destroying confidence in public securities was suggested by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, in a radio address tonight under auspices of the State Conference of Mayors.

Considering the violence of the controversy over the administration's monetary policy, most of the markets were surprisingly quiet yesterday. The usual Saturday dullness prevailed everywhere in spite of the fact that the currency debate appeared to be entering an advanced stage.

DETROIT. TO automobile manufacturing the diplomatic recognition of Soviet Russia brings a large future trade expansion opportunity, but it will take time and effort. This conclusion may be deduced from a statement by James D. Mooney, vice president of General Motors Corporation in charge of overseas operations, long a proponent of recognition.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 -- Cy Grant's 65-yard run for a touchdown and his placement kick for the extra point enabled the University of Georgia Bulldogs to defeat a hard-fighting Georgia Tech eleven, 7 to 6, today.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- No more reassuring news has reached Geneva in a long time than a dispatch from New York this week that also enjoyed great prominence in London.
