It reported that the United States Secretary of Commerce had asked the Secretary of the Interior to allot $1,500,000 to construct an experimental floating island as the first of five to link the United States and Spain.

PARIS BEFORE the midseason openings had got well under way, Parisiennes were clamoring to know whether the siren line would still be good for Spring. Consequently, Paris is letting down the bars and is again giving us a choice of silhouettes.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 23 -- Allegations that workers on the Federal relief payrolls were being coerced into giving $1 of their meager wages to buy a year's subscription to The Blue Valley Farmer again brings to public attention the publishing venture of Governor Alfalfa Bill Murray.

A majority of the commodity futures traded on exchanges here lost further ground in yesterday's quiet dealings. Only sugar, copper and cocoa rallied, while silver, rubber, coffee and hides closed lower. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

ON the day when Alan Prentice loses his job in the bank -- that institution closing down with the depositors holding the bag -- he also meets Judy, a young commercial artist, broke, friendless and stranded in the big city. He appoints himself her friend and platonic protector, the two forming a compact ruling out love and starting south in Alan's old car for Judy's former home in Pennsylvania.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- When the ponderous iron gate of the Cook County jail slid back today to admit Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop she left all that was dear to her outside -- but not her nerve.

The President Harding of the United States Lines arrived yesterday from the Channel ports thirtysix hours late, but that, the bo's'n said, was because she was heavily laden with a yarn about Bill, the ship's black cat.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 25 -- Playing without George Sauer, 195-pound triple-threat fullback, a courageous University of Nebraska football team today stamped a 7-to-6 defeat on Iowa's Hawkeyes.

WHEN Nelson Doubleday suggested to me that he would like to publish an omnibus volume containing seven of the most representative of my works, I stepped, for an instant, into eminent old age, and, smiling quaveringly across the years at irresponsible youngsters plowing through my musty old plays, I thanked God that the hurly burly was over.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Business leaders and "money manipulators" who are attacking the NRA and President Roosevelt's gold policy were scored today by Senator James Hamilton Lewis as conscious or unconscious enemies of progress.

WASHINGTON POLITICAL promises are always made and rarely kept. Campaign speeches are intended to capture votes and not to express serious policies. The political platform is usually something that is read at the convention and promptly forgotten when those who made the platform get into power.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Eddie Casey, head coach of the Harvard team, was happier tonight than he has been since that day in November, 1919, when, snatching a forward pass on this same gridiron, he raced nearly half a field length to help beat Yale, 10 to 3.

Defeating Textile, 19 -- 3, in their annual game at Thompson's Stadium yesterday before 6,000 persons, the unbeaten Curtis eleven recorded its seventh straight victory. By their triumph the winners gained the P.S.A.L. final, which will be played next Saturday at Ebbets Field.

Henry Morgenthau, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, and Mrs. Morgenthau, will be honored tonight by a special program of addresses and entertainment at Bronx House, 1,637 Washingon Avenue, the Bronx, a settlement which they founded in 1911, and of which both are directors.

BUFFALO THREE events conspire to make this, her forthcoming season the most important to Katharine Cornell that she has experienced. On Wednesday in the Erlanger Theatre in Buffalo, where she spent her childhood, Miss Cornell for the first time on any stage will appear in a Shakespearean role, Juliet in "Romeo and Juliet" to the Romeo of Basil Rathbone.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Nov. 22 -- The sudden shifting of 40,000 men and women from pauperism to employment at living wages has transformed the relief situation in Kansas. The Federal order came at the time hundreds of communities began the annual Red Cross and emergency relief drives with little enthusiasm because of unemployment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Miss Amelia Earhart's opinion that the armies of the future should include women is not new. Signer Mussolini declared years ago that in the next war Italian women should fight in the trenches. The good sense of this view will commend it to all shades of opinion.
The awarding of 111 degrees to City College students who had completed their undergraduate courses during the Summer session was announced yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 25 -- Mickey Vuchinich again proved his right to rate considerable respect in and around Champaign, Ill., today when his toe provided the winning point for Ohio State in a battle with Illinois. The score was 7 to 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ever since I read those sixteen articles in THE TIMES about inflation my head has been spinning. Nevertheless, the arguments put forth have convinced me that inflation would make the present depression seem like boom times.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Anthracite operators will fight for a higher tariff on coal from Russia as a result of the new threat to domestic markets because of Soviet recognition, Major W.W. Inglis, president of the Glen Alden Coal Company and spokesman for the industry, stated this afternoon.

AN exposition of automotive progress will be opened by the Ford Motor Company on Dec. 9 in the Port Authority Commerce Building. The display will symbolize Henry Ford's thirty years as an automobile manufacturer.

The disintegrating influence of the Far East upon the moral character of Europeans is a favorite theme with writers of stories about the Orient, but one may be permitted to doubt whether that influence is as great as the authors would have us believe.

THE evening before Jerry Cobb moved out of the old family house on Murray Hill to bachelor quarters in a Park Avenue penthouse, he announced his decision to the children, his wife Mil- dred being absent on a world cruise. Carol, Junior and the latter's wife Ruth accepted the news with equanimity.

EXTENSIVE reorganization in the system by which the schools of New York City are administered is recommended by the State Department of Education in a report by Commissioner Frank P. Graves transmitted to the city Board of Education and made public last week.
CAIRO, Nov. 24 -- Complicated political situations have arisen in the past few weeks in the Near East.

Resolutions prohibiting the use of manufacturers' models for retailers' style shows have been adopted by the Fashion Originators' Guild and will be sent out to 4,000 retailers within the next ten days, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild, which embraces 110 manufacturers of dresses, coats and sportswear.

Another advance has been registered by THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity. The number is 73.5 for the week ended Nov. 18, which compares with 72.9 for the previous week and 69.2 for the corresponding week of last year.

The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in October, lately issued in Washington, compares as follows with preceding months and years, with the average for the full year 1926 reckoned as 100. Comparisons are based on eighty-nine industries since the end of 1930 and on fifty-four for earlier dates.

TO draw is easy. To draw well is more than difficult. This may be the principal reason for the negligibility of the average drawing; but it fails to account for the special stimulus one gets from a drawing above the average.

Taxes that pertain generally to business enterprise, whether imposed upon income for income tax purposes or upon valuations placed on the privilege of exercising a corporate franchise for the franchise tax, are becoming more and more complex in their application.

Theodore A. Distler, director of student personnel at the New York University Heights Centre yesterday announced that 157 students have been pledged to the fourteen recognized fraternities at that division of the university.

Turkey -- the traditional piece de resistance of the Thanksgiving feast -- will be more plentiful and lower priced this year than in any other Thanksgiving season for several decades, chain stores and market experts predicted yesteray.

ONE of the most amiable of Hollywood's tricks of prestidigitation is that which reveals the cinema actors against Broadway and Times Square backgrounds when practically every one knows that the actors never left the studio.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Everywhere abroad one finds generally a totally wrong impression as to the real situation of Prussian-Germany toward Austria. This can easily be explained through the systematic faking of history originating in Berlin, with the object of glorifying Prussia and belittling Austria.

LONDON A JACKDAW has joined the British Army as a regimental mascot. Almost all of the regiments have mascots, but among them the jackdaw is probably unique. He is attached to the Border Regiment recruits, now stationed at Carlisle, Scotland.

SWIFT'S life is always interesting. Biographies about this strange figure in English literature have an inevitable fascination. The man's ruthlessness and tenderness, his violence and reasonableness are difficult to interpret.

Mayor-elect Fiorello LaGuardia will open tomorrow a Christmas bazaar in aid of Irvington House by making the first purchase of the many articles on sale, the handicraft of the little cardiac patients of the home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In the absence of a blue pigeon, a blue eagle may hover over the baseball diamond for the next world series.

PANAMA, R.P., Nov. 20 -- The relations between the church and State in Colombia were aired in the recent Congress and there are indications that it will be continued in the coming Presidential campaign, or in the Congress following, if the Conservatives carry out their threat not to take part in the elections.

THE crooked running of a palatial gambling house in a Midwest city afforded Squeegee Kemp a rich but perilous livelihood, his patrons numbering socially prominent men and women, leavened by the less lucrative attendance of those who dwelt near by.

Furniture and decorations from the New York apartment of Mr. and Mrs. George Arliss will be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. Furniture, art objects and decorations from other collections, including property of the estate of the late Mrs. James F. Sutton of Bedford Hills and the estate of the late Lulu G. Thomas, Norwalk, Conn., also will be offered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission announced today that open, competitive examinations to fill ninety-seven third class postmasterships in thirty States would be held at the request of Postmaster General Farley.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 25 -- Minnesota, unbeaten but tied four times in Western Conference competition, scored a slender 6-to-3 victory over a fighting Wisconsin eleven today in a football game played in driving rain and snow.

The forthcoming Thanksgiving holidays will bring the first in a long series of entertainments for debutantes of the season in New York. Some of the young women had large parties given for them in the country during the early part of September, and the parties in imminent prospect -- which include luncheons, afternoon receptions, dinners and dances -- will serve to introduce them formally to society.

LONDON GREAT interest has been aroused in literary circles by the announcement -- which came as a complete surprise -- that the King intends to offer every year a gold and a silver medal for poetry in English published in volume form within the empire by British citizens.

AN admirer, who subsequently underwent a change of heart, once called the author of the "Social Credit" theory the Einstein of economics, because it was said that only few could understand him. On reconsidering the matter, other followers of Major Douglas have proclaimed him the Darwin of modern economic thought.

CAMPBELL DODGSON, C.B. E., explains in his foreword to "Modern Drawings" that "the aim of this book is to illustrate by representative examples the character of modern drawing in many countries of the Western World."

Twenty of the larger universities in the United States provided honorary professorships for two years for as many scholars dismissed from their chairs in Germany at the opening of the Fall semester, Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, says in his annual report, made public last night.

Peter S. Duryee, roll call chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday that the membership campaign would be extended beyond the original closing date of Thanksgiving, because certain divisions of volunteer workers had notified him they would need more than the allotted time to complete their canvasses.

SOMEWHERE upon the broad and billowy bosom of the Atlantic Ocean this morning, bound east for the Channel ports, is the liner Ile de France, and resting comfortably -- we hope -- on board is Gilbert Miller, theatrical producer of the first magnitude and international shuttle in a class almost by himself.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Dr. Durant Drake, Professor of Philosophy at Vassar College, died of leucocythemia this morning at his home here. He is survived by his widow, Mrs. Anna White Drake; his father, James Drake, and sister, Miss Dorothy Drake, both of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Securities issues totaling more than $12,000,000, as filed for registration under the Securities Act, were announced by the Federal Trade Commission today. There were ten applications in the list, as follows:

MANHATTAN'S Bright-Young-Women need new laureates from time to time. The fundamentals of their themes may not altar vastly from one decade to another. These revolve with pretty reliable regularity about clothes and men and jobs and parties and dreams of luxurious ease and hearts forever convalescing.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 22 -- Relief for at least 70,000 of Kentucky's 190,000 needy appears to be in sight at last after long delay caused by failure of the United States and the Commonwealth to agree on how to administer aid and how to raise the funds.

SOMEWHAT "rarified," in certain quarters, the atmosphere hag been this week, what with Brancusi at Brummer's, Lehmbruck at the Museum of Modern Art, Derujinsky at Wildenstein's and Salvador Dali at Julien Levy's.

LONDON RECENT local elections in Great Britain have clearly indicated that the present coalition government -- which its friends call a "national" government -- had lost a good deal of prestige since it came into power two years ago.

PROFESSOR HANEY propounds his view of economics from a social standpoint, without in any way laying himself open to the suspicion that he sympathizes with the Socialists. As he sees it, a great deal of the difficulties confronting this nation is due largely to the spread of the philosophy of collectivism, which believes that the individual citizen exists for the welfare of the collective whole.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Police efforts to solve the slaying of Mrs. Rheta Gardner Wynekoop were marked tonight by bewildering developments.

LONDON, Nov. 11, 1933 IT was generally believed a few years ago that the day of the proverbial festival was over, that those gargantuan banquets where often a dozen programs are crammed into four days were not only artistically undesirable but impossible in the impoverished state of industry.

INFLUENCED so largely by the weather, retail trade in the week slackened somewhat under the warmer temperatures. Some Christmas buying started, but the volume was scarcely enough to give a clear idea of how the season will go or what types of goods will be particularly favored.

At the University of Minnesota, which has specialized this year in surprising tie games, the freshman football squad is handled a bit differently than is the case at the majority of colleges. Here no stress is laid on games against outside opposition.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The belief that international wheat export quotas set by leading producers last Summer are definitely fixed and will undergo no change at meetings next week of the World Wheat Advisory Committee, was expressed tonight in American delegation quarters.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 -- Canadians are discovering there are two sides to the exchange problem. There used to be much grumbling because the Dominion's dollar was at a discount as compared to its American brother. Now once more they are marching shoulder to shoulder and in some quarters a slight premium on the Canadian dollar is hailed joyously as a triumph for Canadian currency.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 25 -- Michigan again is football champion of the Western Conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Nov. 23:

European Financier. As a European who has followed with interest and concern the debate over the currency policy of the United States, I discover many features which are reminiscent of the European currency crises of the last decade.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 25 -- The Boilermakers from Purdue beat back the annual challenge of Indiana with a smashing second half attack today to smother the Hoosiers, 19 to 3, and hold custody of the old oaken bucket for another year.

HAVING completed his task as the Mock Turtle in the cinema version of "Alice in Wonderland" (a role, by the way, that originally was scheduled for Bing Crosby), Gary Grant is off for a visit to his native England, his first in five years.

THE latest considerable American bibliography concerns the writings of the first considerable American man of letters. The book, entitled "Washington Irving. A Bibliography Compiled by William R. Langfeld. With the Bibliographic Assistance of Philip C. Blackburn."

WALLPAPERS are becoming so decoratively important that greater care than ever is exercised in their selection. Old examples, carefully removed and preserved with a fabric backing, rival antique furniture in value and prestige, and less costly contemporary papers are chosen only after careful consideration of their agreement with other furnishings in the room.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 25 -- Middlebury College defeated the University of Vermont today on a snow-covered gridiron, 19 to 13, to tie for the Green Mountain conference title. Zawistowski, Boehm and Evans tallied for the Panthers and Andy Werner and Saba scored for Vermont.

IN 1890 when Romain Rolland was 24 years old he went to Rome, burdened with the conviction that he was a writer and not a school teacher. Against the advice of family and friends, he began to write, and the person who stood at his side as helper, counselor and inspiration was a little old lady of 74, Malwida von Meysenbug, a German expatriate.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 -- Drawing away easily when called upon, Mrs. John Bosley Jr.'s Chase Me won by a length from A.C. Bostwick's Mate in the $5,000 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap today to gain his sixth straight victory. He has yet to taste defeat.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 25 -- The Tufts football team today defeated Massachusetts State, 13 to 0, before 3,000 spectators. It was the thirty-first game between the teams and the sixteenth victory for Tufts.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 -- California is again girding on her belt of gold, discarded many years ago after the cream had been skimmed from her mines and panned from her running streams. Fallen from its royal estate to merely a substance from which wedding rings and an occasional tooth were made, this economic element is staging a comeback.

The board of administrators of the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms has sent to brokers a letter asking them to refer to it all questions concerning the code. The letter reads in part:

ON Dec. 15 the Darwin Memorial Expedition, under the direction of Dr. Victor von Hagen, will sail from San Francisco to parallel part of the voyage of the famous Beagle, which left England in December, 1831.

MODERN PALESTINE" is the third edition and the second revision of what appeared as a "Guide to Zionism" in 1916. A comparison of the contents of the 1916 edition with the present volume will give the reader a very fair idea of the amazing growth of Palestine and the Zionist ideology which built it.

If present plans materialize, Miss Sonja Henie, the holder of the women's Olympic and world's figure-skating crowns, will appear in an elaborate skating carnival which officials hope to stage in this country in March.

Members of the New York A.C. held their annual Thanksgiving turkey shoot over the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. J.H. Wantling and D.L. Taylor did the best work, each finishing with a card of 98 out of 100 targets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 29 an article discusses measures adopted by Denver business men to promote an economic entity of the Rocky Mountain group of States. It commences with the language, "Resigning themselves to the fact that Denver is not, and never can be, a city of national importance, Denver business men," c.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- The general level of activities showed little change from a week ago. Steel output held at a little less than 30 per cent of ingot capacity. Electricity output for the week ended Nov. 18 was 7.1 per cent above 1932, but about 2 per cent less than the week preceding.
CROTON, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The Croton and Highland Falls high school elevens played to a scoreless tie today. Croton remains in the ranks of the unbeaten Westchester teams.

The success of their entertainments last season has inspired a committee of young men representing several colleges and preparatory schools in the East to repeat a series of inter school and college dances at the Waldorf-Astoria during the Christmas and Easter holidays.
IN the circus arena a blond acrobat raised a silver ladder on a bar held in his teeth. A young boy climbed it nimbly and from the top began to juggle white plates. The acrobat's neck muscles swelled.

KWEIHUA, Suiyuan Province, Oct. 23 -- With her northeastern provinces lost to Japan, China is more and more turning her attention to her vast and unexploited northwest. Here at Kweihua, gateway to the rich but primitive northwestern territories, there are ample evidences of this reawakened interest in a region which has been long neglected.

The committee on American-owned blocked peso accounts in Argentina announced yesterday that, with complete reports now available from its subcommittee in Argentina, total subscriptions by American interests to Argentine dollar treasury bills under the agreement amounted to 60,395,862 pesos, or approximately $23,415,000.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- Answering criticisms of the way in which the restoration made possible by the Rockefeller gift to Versailles has been carried out in the picturesque rustic hamlet of Marie Antoinette, the architect and the government committees have declared that the restoration has faithfully followed the original plans.

The last-minute rush of applicants for licenses to dispense liquor and wine in restaurants, hotels and clubs in New York City swamped the offices of the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board yesterday.

ONE feels truly grateful to Mrs. Wilder for this book. Like her "Little House in the Big Woods." which appeared last year and promptly became a favorite with 9 to 10 year old readers. "Farmer Boy" is a genuine bit of American life, vividly and charmingly described and centring about a very real and natural small boy.

IT is gratifying to bear that the pictorial version of Louisa May Alcott's book "Little Women" during its first week has broken attendance records at the Radio City Music Hall, for it is a clear indication that a human, wholesome and intelligent narrative is what the cinemagoing public prefers.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 25 -- A crowd of 85,000 fans, including former President Herbert Hoover, sent cheers reverberating through the Stanford Stadium today as Stanford's Cardinals defeated California's Bears, 7 to 3, to earn a tie for the Pacific Coast conference championship.
ROME, Nov. 24 -- Italy's participation in the League of Nations again hangs in the balance, the Grand Council of Fascism having been convoked for Dec. 5 to consider the advisability of withdrawing.

A COUPLE of years ago the Green Bay Packers were the rulers of the professional gridiron. Now the "Wisconsin wanderers are down in the swamp. It was no wonder that Coach Curly Lambeau was playing the part of the Knight of the Rueful Countenance as he strolled down Broadway with a Green Bay trio as an escort.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- If the League of Nations is really dying, as many of its friends are beginning to believe, the British Government shows no sign of doing anything decisive to save it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Although not using its full strength at any time, Princeton's undefeated and untied football team conquered Rutgers by 26 to 6 today, but to the Scarlet went the distinction of being the first eleven to cross the Tiger goal line this Fall.

AN English Cathedral Close is still, in outward appearance at least, an oasis of settled custom and quietness in a changing country; but the insulated existence led by the Bishop, the Dean and Chapter, and their women people as pictured in "Uncharted Spaces" bears only an approximate and superficial resemblance to present-day actuality.

BOOTLEGGERS, corrupt police officials, bribery, political chicanery and prohibition are familiar ingredients of fiction. Unseasoned by anything in the way of novelty in viewpoint or skill in characterization, they are used once more in this story of that prosperity period which now seems so strange and so very far away.

LONDON It is within the recollection of far from the oldest inhabitant of this city by the Thames that the professional "boomsters" of British films have on several occasions within the last three or four years loudly proclaimed, "urbi et orbi," the defeat and dissolution of Hollywood and the triumph of Elstree in the cinematic world.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- The New York Americans went on a third-period scoring spree tonight to take a 3-to-2 decision from the fast-slipping Ottawa Senators. The victory lifted Joe Simpson's star-spangled outfit from the cellar in the International group of the National Hockey League a match a head of the Senators.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- Canada, it is now certain, is to have its financial machinery supplemented by a central bank. Its establishment has been recommended by a royal commission through a majority that included Lord MacMillan, noted British economist, who was its chairman.

Mayor-elect F. H. LaGuardia, in his first public address here since his campaign closed, declared himself in favor yesterday of the utmost speed in starting low rent and slum clearance projects in the city.

The protest against the government's present monetary policies, which became loud last week, has thus far been a matter principally of criticism of inflation as an economic panacea by prominent individuals or professional groups. The aroused sound money men have not yet, either as individuals or groups, advanced a monetary program of their own.

Whatever may be said of the anomalous position of RAMSAY MACDONALD as a Socialist who is virtual leader of the Conservative party in Great Britain, he uttered words of truth and soberness in his speech as Prime Minister at the Guildhall banquet. His views about disarmament and world peace may be idealistic, but about trade and employment he spoke with hard realism.

AMONG the excellent editorial efforts of the State Music Publishers Department of the U.S.S.R., Soviet Russia, is now to be numbered a complete reprinting of the piano compositions of Alexander Scriabin. The greater number of these are at hand.

THE Chinese student, perennial migrant in the field of international education, appears to be transferring his headquarters from the United States to Europe. Before the war Japan held first place for Chinese student migrants; after the war the United States commanded the largest number, and today Europe is the magnet.

With 332,561 families aided at a cost of $11,970,513, public relief rolls in New York State decreased 1 per cent in October, it was announced by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration yesterday in releasing its monthly report.

Wholesale market activity centred during the week on holiday gift items, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Practical gifts, such as handbags, jewelry, umbrellas, luggage, silverware, smokers' sets and toiletries, were ordered, with a decided trend toward better-type gift merchandise than in the past few seasons.

The bells of New York City churches will ring at noon Tuesday to signalize the opening of the crusade for children, during which welfare agencies will appeal for $400,000 for homeless and dependent children.

Retail trade was mixed last week, warmer weather arresting the purchase of Winter goods, while early holiday buying was increasingly a factor of improvement in many sections. Business on the whole appeared to be above a year ago, but it is estimated that in order to support the volume of costs and taxes not in effect a year ago, it should be substantially higher than at present.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Six Middletown residents were killed and eight persons were injured last night between here and Chester when a bus in turning sharply to avoid striking a farm wagon struck an auto in which the six killed were riding.

The highest price realized at an art auction in this country since the depression sent art prices tumbling was paid yesterday afternoon at the final session of the sale of the late Thomas F. Ryan's collection at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when Duveen Brothers bought for $102,500 a bust of a "Princess of Aragon," by the Italian fifteenth century sculptor Francesco Laurana.

THERE are striking differences 3 between radio broadcasting in Great Britain and in the United States. In Britain broadcasting was established by the government, although the government does not control the service. Operating revenue is derived not from advertising fees but from license fees paid by owners of radio sets.

No sports in the world are more encompassed with rules and regulations than hunting and fishing, as any one who has enjoyed either probably has found out to his amazement. Every year some new sections are added to the various State and Federal codes.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman left Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday afternoon, formally discharged as "completely cured." He left the city, accompanied by Mrs. Lehman, at 2 P.M. to rest for a week or ten days before resuming his official duties at Albany.

THIS is a challenging book. The author takes issue with some dearly beloved convictions concerning our early history that have long been cherished in American literature and belief, and with cogent presentation offers upsetting viewpoints and conclusions.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Stanford University's football team has accepted an invitation to represent the West in the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena on New Year's Day, Al Masters, general manager of the board of athletic control, announced late today.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The dollar rose sharply today to 16.08 as against 15.77 yesterday, thus crossing the 16-franc mark for the first time since Nov. 9. Washington's unchanged gold figure, rumors of approaching stabilization and news of growing opposition to President Roosevelt's monetary policies, particularly Alfred E. Smith's letter, all contributed to the dollar's strength.
Hitting a fast pace in the second half, City College opened its 1935-34 basketball schedule at the C.C. N.Y. gymnasium last night by overwhelming St. Francis College of Brooklyn, 39 -- 17.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Yesterday's firmness on the Stock Exchange was well maintained today, although the volume of business was small. British Government funds were quiet. The war loan was dull. German bonds continued firm.

THIS story, together with its illustrations, strives very hard to be satirically funny, and occasionally is One Robinson Lippingtree Mackintosh from Tristan Da Cunha is cast ashore on an astonishing island, where he spends several weeks investigating the mores of the inhabitants.

IVAN BUNIN, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature for 1933, was born in Russia of a noble family in 1870. Before he was 20 he was awarded the Pushkin Prize for poetry, and in 1909 he was elected an honorary member of the Academy of St. Petersburg,an honor which,up to that time had been tendered only to Chekhov and Maxim Gorky.

With the largest list of subscribers in its long history, the series of Junior Assemblies will begin for this season on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The occasion will mark the first important gathering of debutantes in New York this season.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- George Barnard Shaw's new play, "On the Rocks," was performed tonight at the Winter Garden Theatre. It has a continuous scene in the Cabinet room at 10 Downing Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A leveling off of productive activity following weeks of continuous decline and an upward movement of several important business indicators were reported today by the Department of Commerce in its survey of domestic business for the week ended on Nov. 18.

THERE was a time when a musician in error or a poor voice could hide behind the radio set. The machine was blamed, and because of electrical blemishes along the wires, the set could not dodge condemnation. But that does not hold today.
GILBERT MILLER (and these pages today seem to be dedicated to him) went back to London yesterday. Before departing, however, he conceded the following facts:

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Four persons were arrested here today in connection with the printing and passing of counterfeit "baby bonds" which had been disposed of as being the notes issued to city employes in lieu of salaries during the last nine months.

The Honest Ballot Association, still investigating hundreds of complaints of illegal voting in the recent election, has undertaken the further task of seeing to it that only qualified voters cast their ballots in the special election to be held in the Twenty-first Bronx Senatorial District on Dec. 28.
Protected by heavy police guard until the moment of departure, Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Commissar for Foreign Affairs, sailed on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday.

The soccer players of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club made it ten straight yesterday in the annual championship series of the Field Club Soccer League of New York and New Jersey. They defeated the team of the Staten Island F.C., 7 to 2, on the Crescent grounds at Bay Ridge.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Encouraging results with a new weight-reducing drug which enables fat persons to lose weight while eating an ordinary diet have been obtained by Prof. E.C. Dodds of the Courtauld Institute and Dr. J.D. Robertson of the Middlesex Hospital.

The first twenty-five railroads in the United States to report for October indicate in their returns that net operating income declined on an annual basis for the first month since April. This trend reflects a narrowing of the margin between traffic levels of 1933 and 1932 and increased expenditures for maintenance in October.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General and Democratic National Chairman, sailed yesterday for his first "real vacation" of many years. Mrs. Farley, happy and excited at the prospect of touring Europe and getting her husband away from politics, said in their suite on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia that it would be the first trip to Europe for either of them.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Albert Spaldlng, violinist, and Frank Sheridan, pianist, will appear in a concert tomorrow night in the Bronxville Theatre under the auspices of the music section of the Bronxville Women's Club, of which Mrs. Leon O. Bailey is chairman.

MANILA AFTER nearly a year of bitter political fighting in the Philippines, the question of independence is again being shifted to Washington. A new mission from Manila, headed by Manuel Quezon, is expected to arrive in the capital about Dec. 1, empowered by the insular Legislature to work for amendments to the Hawes Law or for other new legislation which "shall completely satisfy the aspirations of the Filipino people."

Isaac W. Cokefair, vice president and director of the International Silver Company, one of the world's leading manufacturers of silver and sliver-plated was and proprietor of the Derby Silver Company retail silverware store at 10 Maiden Lane, died on Wednesday night at his home, 329 West Eighty-second Street.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 22 -- Inauguration of the civil works employment program shared attention with the farm problem in the Corn Belt this week, although the latter continues the centre of interest and doubtless will continue to be so until more definite tangible progress has been made toward putting cash in the farmer's pocket.

FROM 3,000 Protestant clergymen of Germany has come the first sign of open revolt against the Hitler regime. Last Sunday, which was celebrated in Germany as the 450th anniversary of Martin Luther's birth, they read a manifesto declaring: "We preachers of the gospel do not want to draw upon ourselves the reproach of the Prophet Isaiah that we are 'all dumb dogs that cannot bark, sleeping, ing down, loving slumber.' "

ARCHY has written one of the outstanding biographies of the year. It was not easy for him; as half the world knows, each word that this sapient cockroach types out is accomplished only through grueling labor as he butts his head against the keys of Don Marquis's machine.

A request that $79,000,000 of public works funds be set aside immediately for the aircraft construction programs of the army and navy was telegraphed yesterday to President Roosevelt at Warm Springs, Ga., by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith's statement to the New York State Chamber of Commerce, in which he declared himself "for gold dollars as against baloney dollars," was protested yesterday by Joseph S. Byrne of Brooklyn in a letter to the chamber, of which he formerly was a member.

Following Friday's rally of $1 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday and ended with 1 loses of 2 to 6 points and a final quotation of 9.89 cents a pound for December, compared with 9.97 the week before and 9.82 two weeks ago.

It cost the Fusion campaign committee only $106,807 to achieve the substantial victory won by Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia and his running mates on the city-wide Fusion ticket. This appeared from a statement of campaign contributions and disbursements filed by the committee yesterday with the Secretary of State and the local Board of Elections.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Frank Koewing, former New York dress pattern manufacturer and style publisher, died today at his home here, 9 Koewing Place, after an illness of several years. He was in his seventy-ninth year.

MOST of us think we know that James Watt invented the steam engine and that George Stephenson made the first locomotive. Or if we have forgotten the exact circumstances and the precise names we recall them when some one else mentions them.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The midshipmen were a subdued lot in their dressing room after the game and many of them took their defeat a bit hard, even though they had nothing but praise for their Army rivals.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- "It was the hardest, toughest game we have played," said Major Ludson D. Worsham in the dressing room after the game.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 15. -- The Seventh Pan-American Conference, which will open here on Dec. 3, will receive European recognition for the first time. This will give it an international importance that may lift the Pan American Union out of its hitherto purely regional character.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- Dr. Robert Rieth, the German Minister to Vienna, called on Chancellor Dollfuss today and informed him of the re- suits of the official German investi- gation into the killing of a German soldier on the Austro-German border near Reith Friday by Austrian auxiliary policemen.
Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday the appointment of seventy-nine teachers to the faculty of New York University. They were:

An elderly spinster, of previously frugal habits, was depicted yesterday in the Brooklyn Surrogate's Court as having embarked on a reckless four-year spending spree before her death, with the result that her $100,000 bank account disappeared with almost nothing left to show for it.

A patrolman was shot and killed last night as his companion exchanged shots with three gunmen who had held up the policemen when they attempted to raid an apartment on the fourth floor of a brownstone building at 204 West Eighty-first Street, near Amsterdam Avenue.

A general alarm was sent from Police Headquarters yesterday for Robert Pearce Jr., 14 years old, who disappeared on Friday morning from his home, the Hotel Shelton, on Lexington Avenue at Fortyninth Street. He is the son of Robert Neil More Mclntyre Pearce, a prominent British underwriter, and Mrs. Ella H. Shumaker Pearce, formerly of Pittsburgh.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- Unexpected by any one either within the Nazi fold or among outsiders, the first real and substantial challenge to the authoritarian principle, on which the Nazi State rests, comes from among the Protestant ministers of Germany.

JACOB WASSERMANN wrote "My Life as German and Jew" twelve years ago out of a deep spiritual need, a compulsion to externalize an intense moral conflict that bad been plaguing him for years. It is, therefore, a highly personal book, and not, as its publication at this particular time might suggest, any general comment on the present situation in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A Board of Labor Review was appointed today by Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, to discuss and arbitrate all labor troubles arising on projects financed with public works funds. This board of three members, whose decision is final, will operate under the direction of Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board.

WHEN Martha Graham dashed into her new opening dance last Sunday evening, it was immediately evident that something was up. As the program went forward the conviction was strengthened until it reached its climax in the new cycle of "dances of possession," and then it was no longer possible to doubt that once again the dancer had entered upon a new phase of her art.
The Seward Park High School football team brought its season to a close yesterday by defeating Morris High, 19 to 0, at the George Washington High School Stadium.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 25 -- President Roosevelt today ordered William C. Bullitt, Ambassador-designate to Russia, to sail for his new post on Nov. 29, present his credentials, survey the housing situation and return as soon as practicable to report on the problem of re-establishing American officials in Russia.

The builders of commercial ships will follow more closely the example of the United States Navy in developing the safety features of ships of the future, in the opinion of Rear Admiral George H. Rock. Admiral Rock was elected president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers recently.

Legal action to place in competitive civil service about 200 positions in the courts of the city which are now in the exempt class will be taken by the Civil Service Reform Association, according to H. Eliot Kaplan, the secretary.

NEARLY every motorist who is not versed in automotive technicalities is wondering what may be involved in so-called "Independent wheel suspensions," which are promised on more than one make of car when the 1934 automobile show is held.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 25 -- One of the largest fields of the year came to the firing line at the Kassau Trapshooting Club today. The program called for a turkey shoot at both the regular 16-yard and the skeet trap.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- A sharp pronouncement against experiments with the currency, demands for which have been rising in Germany, has been issued by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank.
SANTOS, Brazil, Nov. 25 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull concluded his brief visit to Brazil tonight, rejoining the steamship American Legion here.

THREE exhibitions provide the Argent Gallery with diversity. Charles Goeller in his first one-man show is represented by both sculpture and paintings. His painting by itself has sufficient diversity to be startling. The still-lifes are outstanding both in color and in the remarkable fabric textures obtained.

A small pen rest, made of delicately carved jade, pink tourmaline and teakwood and valued at $800, was stolen about 4:30 P.M. yesterday from the $1,000,000 collection of Chinese jades on view in a store in the NEC Building, at Rockefeller Center Plaza and Fiftieth Street.

TO those who, in the award of the Nobel Prize for Literature, would wish to see not a polite gesture of encouragement toward this or that country or toward a social or political dogma which happens to be fashionable today, but the recognition and crowning of a high literary achievement, the choice which the Swedish Academy has made this year ought to be highly gratifying.

ALTHOUGH he is a commanding story-teller, Wassermann never gets out merely to tell a story. He is ever searching for the meaning of life, sometimes deciphering a human hieroglyphic, sometimes announcing his bewilderment in passionate accents.

The decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, construing the Rehabilitation Law for mortgage guarantee companies, which affects millions of dollars invested in mortgages, aroused great interest yesterday in real estate circles and among mortgage certificate holders of the State.
NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Rahway High registered a 19-0 triumph, over North Plainfield today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Treasury officials do not anticipate the use of greenbacks or any other inflationary device in arranging the $727,000,000 of refinancing of securities on Dec. 15. They are treating the refinancing as a matter of routine.

MANY seem to have taken for granted that work and leisure should be distinctly separated. From the stand-point of living, is that a good and wholesome process? If not desirable, is it at least inevitable? From an educational point of view the distinction is not clear, is very unfortunate and probably temporary.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- New Rochelle High School's eleven was held to a scoreless tie by A.B. Davis High School of Mount Vernon today, but despite the deadlock became the W.J.A.A. champion for the second consecutive year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 DURING the World's Fair period the legitimate stage of this city contented itself with the presentation of two shows -- "Dinner at Eight," in the New York interpretation, and "Take a Chance," with Olsen and Johnson as its leading wags.

With important football, soccer and cross-country contests scheduled, the 1933 Fall sports Campaign for New York City schoolboy athletes will reach its climax this week. Thanksgiving Day, with its traditional gridiron games and the national interscholastic cross-oountry run at Newark, will be the big day of the season's final week.

DURBAN, Natal, Oct. 23 -- With the rest of the world arming, rearming, co-arming and mis-arming, with other British dominions taking alarm at the so-called weakness of the British fleet, it is refreshing to find one part of the world which makes a practical gesture toward disarmament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- United States exports in October reached the highest point for any month since October, 1931, climbing $33,892,000 over those for September.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The Illinois General Assembly sat in regular session from Jan. 4 of this year until July 1, or 179 days. On Oct. 3 it convened in special session, with its main objective the passage of measure providing for unemployment relief.

WITHIN a few weeks William C. Bullitt will go as the first American Ambassador to the Soviet Union. He is in his forty-third year, a young man as Ambassadors go. The journey to Moscow will not be his first.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25 -- If Jack Spero loses in tomorrow's election of the chief of New York's League of Locality Mayors, his defeat will be due entirely to the wet issue.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 25 -- Circuit Judge W. W. Callahan denied a defense motion today to quash the indictments against the Scottsboro Negroes, holding that Samuel S. Leibowitz, their chief counsel, had failed to satisfy him that Jackson County officials had permitted tampering with the jury roll.

If Russia succeeds in its plan of raising the standard of living within its boundaries to the level of that in Western countries, it should be a large user of American cotton, according to a study prepared by the New York Cotton Exchange.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your argument from history in your Editorial, "President and Treasury," in which you by implication criticize President Roosevelt for the fact that the formulation of the government's financial policies have not been left to the Treasury Department, is burdened with such factual inaccuracies as to render it innocuous when the facts are clarified.

BUENOS AIRES THE New Deal has caused a pronounced change in the attitude of South Americans toward the United States, or toward North America, as they prefer to call it. Distrust, suspicion and ill-feeling toward the "colossus of the North" had become unanimous and intense by the beginning of this year.

DALLAS, Nov. 23 -- There is no revolt in Texas. Much is being said about opposition to the administration in the next Congress, but the spirit abroad here today would dictate that members of the Texas delegation uphold the hand of the President.

Among conductors and soloists who will appear with the Milan Symphony this Winter are Cordone, Elmendorff, Failoni, Monteux, Pizzetti, Reiter, Scherchen (conductors) and Gieseking, Menuhin, Prokofieff, Agosti, Backhaus, Bonicci, Borovski, Flesch and Edwin Fischer (soloists).

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22 -- A judge of a Virginia court, a man who holds office at the behest of the Democratic party and who is himself a Democrat, has ruled that his party cannot arbitrarily exclude qualified Negroes from its primaries, as now conducted.

IN this volume Mr. Lewisohn has compiled, as it were, a source-book to illustrate his findings in "Expression in America." That a man of his background and literary acumen should prepare an anthology of American literature is distinctly worth while in itself, but that he should do so with a strong sense of direction is even better.

THE gasoline bootlegger, who for years has preyed upon the gasoline and oil industries, taking millions of dollars annually paid by motorists as taxes intended for the State, is now due to be taken for a ride. Nine States of New England and the Middle Atlantic have banded together to accelerate this consummation, and tomorrow their representatives will meet in conference in New York to discuss means to that end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Rescinding a former ruling, the Interstate Commerce Commission today released the New York Central Railroad from its obligation of acquiring the Boyne City, Gaylord Alpena Railroad, required in the New York Central unification case several years ago.

GRETE STUECKGOLD, soprano, and Gustave Schutzendorf, baritone, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will sing with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra the excerpts from Hugo Wolf's "Der Corregidor," which Bruno Walter will conduct this afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

MILAN, Nov. 7, 1933 A WEEK after the publication of the Scala opera bill comes the official release of the program at the Rome Opera for the coming season. It is substantially as forecast in these columns in October.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Chancellor Hitler has taken the first step toward seeking a new accord with France replacing the imposed Treaty of Versailles. Yesterday morning he summoned Andre Francois-Poncet, French Ambassador, and in a two-hour interview laid before him his aims and desires.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- Now that the formalities of recognition of the Soviet Union by the United States are over there is a feeling in Moscow of "let's get down to business." The second Five-Year Plan is being outlined for approval by the All-Union Soviet Congress in January, and foreign trade is no small item in the plan.

The defeat of the swimmers of George Washington, only unbeaten team in the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond group, and a striking performance by Lee Rosenfeld of Thomas Jefferson, were outstanding features of yesterday's P.S. A.L. tank duels for senior high schools.

SUBSTANTIAL growth inthe volume of air express has marked the periodic statements of the two principal handlers of goods by air, the air division of the Railway Express Agency and-General Air Express, as well as of the country's airlines themselves, during the last year.

IN these days of abundance it is not unusual to serve up reminiscences like a banquet, in courses. This second volume of Mr. Lloyd George's memoirs, covering the years 1915-16, corresponds to an entree. Already he has told us how high-explosive shells shattered the Liberal government.

UNLIKE most writers who set out to describe the bitterness of the workingman's lot, Mr. Conroy has avoided the taint of propagandism. In "The Disinherited" there is no preaching about fundamental right or wrong, equality or justice; and there is no panacea -- legislative or revolutionary-propounded in its conclusion.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25 -- The way is believed to have been paved, at a conference between American and Brazilian officials, for an agreement satisfactory to both sides on the problems created by Brazil's decree fixing the rate for customs payments at eight paper milreis for one gold milreis.

IMPORTANT gains in efficiency for the anti-aircraft defense of the nation were marked last week by the placing of an order for 104 800,000,000-beam candle-power searchlights by the army engineers with the Sperry Gyroscope Company of Brooklyn.

More than 2,500 carpenters at the Star Casino, 107th Street and Park Avenue, heard speakers yesterday afternoon charge officials of the New York District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners with having been responsible for racketeering.

Some of the defenders of the Administration's efforts to depreciate the dollar have advanced a strange argument for it. They distrust the policy in itself, but maintain that it may be justified as a measure pf political expediency. The President sees, or thinks he sees, a rising and powerful demand for currency inflation.

UP-TO-DATE and authoritative is this latest addition to the excellent Appleton Popular Health Series, and also very important, since its subject is one that all conversant with the prevalence of eye troubles and defective vision agree should be increasingly brought to the attention of the public.

AS a little lad of 7 years, Kerry Young was badly tricked by Tod West, who stole his employer's payroll of some $2,000 while ostensibly helping the boy to save it from a forest fire. The loss ruined the old employer and he soon died.

There is some "pretty rough stuff" in James Joyce's novel "Ulysses," Federal Judge John M. Woolsey said yesterday, but he has not yet reached a decision as to whether the book is obscene. At a hearing on the book yesterday at the Bar Association Building, Judge Woolsey said that since he had become identified with the case he had received many letters about the book.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Six young women, their eyes dim with tears, carried to its last resting place today the body of Mrs. Rheta Gardner Wynekoop, Chicago murder victim.

UNKNOWN to whom? It can hardly be said that there is much of importance -- except in one matter, and the importance of that may be doubted -- disclosed in Mr. Schauffler's book that is not in its general purport familiar to those who have read considerably about Brahms in the sources that are open to everybody and have been open in increasing number since the composer's death in 1897.

BARCELONA, Nov. 10. -- The reconciliation between the new Andorran Council General and the coprinces, particularly the Bishop of Urgel, seems to be making excellent progress after the revolutionary events of last Summer. A few days ago the Bishop, Dr. Justin Guitart, visited Andorra for the first time in a number of years and received a warm and ceremonious welcome.

A RECENT tragedy in North Carolina, the slaying from ambush of a wealthy Northerner by a mountaineer, has served to revive the perennial tales that represent our Southern mountains as a land of feuds and feudists, of blood-hatred and vengeance.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- The principal occupation of this former Republican stronghold, following its second Democratic landslide within a comparatively short period, is in getting acquainted with its Democratic Mayor-elect, William N. McNair.

Marking the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Bide-a-Wee Home Association, Inc., a tea and fashion show will be held Tuesday afternoon in the ballroom of the Plaza to further the work of the association in its care and protection of friendless animals.
BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- The Civil Works Program is going over with a bang in New England.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Playing his last game of college football, Al (Red) Weiner of Irvington, N.J., Muhlenberg's star quarterback, blazed the path to the Cardinal and Gray's 7-to-0 victory today over Dickinson.

The petition of a large tobacco chain to work its store employes on a "split shift" has been denied by the local NRA Compliance Board, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, NRA Administrator for the City of New York.

NEWMAN LEVY'S "Opera Guyed" has cheered the dolorous hours of thousands of admirers. Its startling felicities of rhyme and unreason have been received with a pleasure that New Yorkers usually reserve for a Mayor's extempore remarks.

THE Fox Film edition of George White's "Scandals" is in that particular state of dynamic confusion which precedes its emergence before the cameras. Mr. White himself is on hand for the double purpose of supervising it and appearing in it.
SIX weeks ago broadcast listeners were invited to write to Federal Radio Commissioner James H. Haney, if they had any complaints because he believes "the people should rule radio."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Some- thing new in the way of a housing project is in process of development in the Tennessee Valley, where, not far from Knoxville, the Tennessee Valley Authority is building 250 houses, the like of which that region never knew until now.

The volume of sales in Fifth Avenue stores is already beginning to show that Christmas money will be more plentiful this year. Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, declared in a statement yesterday in connection with the membership drive being conducted by the association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In a barrage of comment today on the money question R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, lined up with the President, while Senator Fess, Republican, of Ohio, attacked the President's program.

This story follows the narrative of Garcilasso de Vega, son of a Spanish captain in Peru and of an Inca princess. When the story opens Garcilasso is a boy living in the midst of the unrest and civil war brought upon the country by the despotic Spanish Governor.

The Bartenders School, Inc., held its first commencement exercises yesterday afternoon in the Kings Tower Building, 276 West Forty-third Street. The thirty-five graduates, wearing clean white jackets, stood at attention while Jack FitzGerald, president of the school, urged them to "go forth and uphold the fine old traditions of bartending."

A GROUP of Jutlanders recently raised a memorial stone to Hamlet on a viking mound on Ammelhede Field, outside the Danish city of Randers. According to Denmark's first historian -- Saxo Grammaticus, who wrote in Latin and lived about the year 1200 -- Hamlet fell in battle on Ammelhede.

Flushing High School's powerful football team assured itself of a place in the P.S.A.L. championship final by eliminating a courageous Erasmus Hall eleven yesterday at Ebbets Field. A crowd, estimated at 20,000, saw the Red Devils register a 12 -- 6 victory in the feature game of a charity double-header, after Manual Training had conquered James Madison, 6 -- 0, in the opener.

PARIS, Nov. 24 - For the second time within a month a French Ministry has fallen because France cannot balance the budget. The reason is not that she lacks money but because a political habit has become demagogic.

In the belief that the subject of insurance of bank deposits is of vital concern to shareholders of a bank, the Bankers Trust Company sent yesterday to all its stockholders copies of the analysis of the plan recently published by the Association of Reserve City Bankers.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., NOV. 25 -- F. Joseph Budd of Newtown, nationally known as a breeder and exhibitor of thoroughbred horses and dogs, must pay $1,750 for striking Vincent Sullivan, a carpenter-contractor, according to a stipulated judgment filed in Superior Court today.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- Shareholders of Lake Shore Mines, Ltd., at the annual meeting had the unusual privilege of examining the plans of last year's developments, which, revealed hitherto virtually unknown ore from the 2,500-foot level to surface, with the usual mine values extending up to sixty feet in width.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The administration sought today to allay any fear in the minds of American liquor importers that the proposed quota restrictions on imports would be employed to make it difficult for them to meet the legitimate demand after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

YVONNE CARETTE'S name is familiar to American women because it is associated with styles that have no affectation and are extremely young. This does not mean that she caters only to the young, but she makes the kind of dress that older women can wear and feel young in.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., Nov. 1 -- Fear of Japanese aggression in these southern lands is again revealed by the additional defense plans newly announced by Prime Minister George W. Forbes to make New Zealand impregnable by air.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 25 -- Its early aerial attack failing to succeed, the University of Florida shifted to a frontal battle to topple the dangerous Auburn eleven, conqueror of Georgia, today by 14 to 7 before a home coming crowd of 14,000.

The average freshman at Barnard College this year is 17 years of age, is 5 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 120 pounds, according to tests given by the department of physical education and made public yesterday by Miss Agnes Wayman, department head.
The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association yesterday announced its nominations for next year. Russell B. Kingman of Orange, N.J., has been nominated as president, to succeed Holcombe Ward.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The Green football team from Dartmouth today had the great misfortune to get tangled up with a Maroon eleven that not only was inspired, but clicking. The score was 39 to 0 in favor of Chicago and the Maroon didn't really open up until the last eight minutes of play.

Additional opportunities for competition in the field will be offered fanciers of cocker and English springer spaniels if plans of enthusiastic followers of the sport materialize. At least three new meetings are being considered and it appears certain that two of these will be developed successfully.

A woman beer dealer, an official of a German singing society, a Pennsylvania brew dispenser, a handwriting expert and bank officials drifted on and off the stand in Federal court yesterday, the end of the first week of the trial of Waxey Gordon, the beer runner, for income tax evasion.

IN this vivid and pulsating story of Paris during the fateful year that was to see the triumph of Prussian arms in France and the fall of the empire Mr. Gorman has given us not only authenticated history and fiction of a high order, but a reasoned philosophy which comprehends, though it makes no attempt to resolve, the problems vexing the world today no less than in 1870 and 1871.

CHILD-WELFARE agencies in every part of the country are asking with much concern whether they will be enabled to continue for another year vital services for children for which they have been given, or, in the case of private agencies, have assumed community responsibility.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Camille Chautemps, Minister of the Interior in the last two French Ministries and once Premier for twenty-four hours, today accepted an invitation of President Lebrun to try to form a government which will have not only a program but a majority.

The legislative committee of the New York Credit Men's Association is launching a campaign to have the costs of unfair or unnecessary lawsuits borne entirely by those responsible for them, it was made known here yesterday by Alfred Rothschild, of the Weiss Klau Company.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Mamaroneck and Port Chester High Schools brought their W.I. A.A. campaigns to an end today, playing a 0-0 tie.

Bonds of all classifications moved higher yesterday on the Stock Exchange, United States Government long-term issues rising 3-32 to 16-32 point, domestic corporation bonds from fractions to 5 points and leading foreign loans from 1 to more than 6 points.

AMID the tumultuous debate of the past week over the program of the national administration, an event of wide economic significance occurred without attracting great attention. The iron and steel industry asked President Roosevelt for permission to continue under its code for six months longer.

Strong in and Deed. General HUGH JOHNSON'S high-powered vocabulary is one more reminder that the ancient contrast between men of words and men of action no longer holds. It would be a thesis hard to defend in the age of TROTSKY, MUSSOLINI and HITLER.

VERY quietly Mme. Anny Blatt has walked into our midst. Literally walked, for this creator of hand-knit sports goods, whose name did not appear in Paris fashion reports until about two years ago, is an enthusiastic pedestrian.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- West Virginia University's Mountaineers invaded Griffith Stadium today and defeated the Georgetown University eleven, 14 -- 12. Trailing, 12 -- 0, at the start of the last period, the visitors unleashed a brilliant aerial attack that resulted in two touchdowns.

EDDIE CANTOR once introduced a quack-quack noise on the air that many tried to imitate. Thousands wrote asking how he made the sound with his lips. It was almost a "trade name" for Cantor on the air. Suddenly he dropped it.
DETROIT, Nov. 25 -- The football season closed here today when the University of Detroit defeated Michigan State, 14 to 0, before 30,000 spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Captain Whitey Randour tore up the turf today and Villanova students carried off the goal posts as their team hammered out a 24-0 victory over Temple in the annual game at the Temple stadium. More than 25,000 persons, the biggest crowd in the history of the series, saw the battle.

The American Locomotive Company is prepared to manufacture stream-lined engines designed to put the railroads on a competitive basis with airplanes and omnibuses, the company has announced in outlining a plan called the first commercial application of the streamline principle to steam locomotion.

Maria Jeritza, a golden figure against the vivid glow of Madison Square Garden's giant orchestra sounding-board, sang to a gala audience in Manhattan's largest amphitheatre last night for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund. It was the second of Dr. Walter Damrosch's series of concerts for this cause, now in its third year.

HERE is a French novel, a very French one, that probably never should have been translated. This is not to quarrel with the translator, who has done a workmanlike job. But in the field of amour the French language has a deft way of handling subtleties which in blunt English are apt to sound awkward, flat or even funny.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 -- Geneva College was unequal to the task of stopping the strong Duquesne University eleven today and went down to defeat by the score of 26 to 0 on Forbes Field. Five thousand spectators saw the eleven coached by Elmer Leyden, former Notre Dame star, trample their opponents and score four touchdowns, two in the first quarter and two more in the third.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 25 -- Michigan won the 1933 Big Ten championship, according to the Dickinson football rating system, with Ohio State second and Minnesota third.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The Montclair State Teachers College eleven ran roughshod over the alumni in the annual homecoming game today by the score of 39 to 0. The graduates proved no match for the varsity, which scored in every quarter.

An appeal to the clergy of New York City to observe Family Welfare Sabbath next Sunday in connection with the Citizens Family Welfare Committee campaign for $4,000,000 was made yesterday by Dr. Charles Trexler, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- The German Protestant Church war tonight was heading straight for the long-threatened schism between those headed by the Rev. Dr. Friedrich von Bodelschwingh, former Reich Bishop, and the Nazi German Christians as a result of the enforced resignation today of the Rev. Dr. Simon Schoeffel, Bishop of Hamburg, from the Ecclesiastical Ministry, the executive governing board of the new Reich Evangelical Church.

Announcements last week of bonds to be retired before their dates of maturity were in number about the same as in the previous week, but the face value of the called bonds was smaller. They were mostly for future months, only a sprinkling of municipal bonds and warrants being listed for the remaining days of November.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Romping up and down the field with great abandon, the invading Lafayette Leopards today administered one of the severest setbacks that Lehigh has suffered in this gridiron rivalry which started in 1884.

A survey of New York City's resources for the use of leisure, containing more than 1,000 points of interest to be found in the metropolitan area, has been published by the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University.

More than 25,000 letters from people in all walks of life and from all sections of the country were received by Bloomingdale Brothers since the publication of their three advertisements dealing with support of the NRA, it was stated yesterday by Karl F. Egge, publicity director of the store.

The share market seemed yesterday to have been left to its own devices. Final quotations represented almost a stand-off, with the combined averages showing a trifling net gain. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange, involving 477,000 shares, was smaller by more than 100,000 shares than on the previous Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- British film interests have allowed Hollywood to get the better of them, in the obtaining by RKO Radio Pictures of the rights to produce a movie of his play, "The Devil's Disciple," George Bernard Shaw declared here today.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- No French Cabinet ever fell more foolishly than that of Albert Sarraut in the small hours of Friday morning. When the final test came, the Premier was guilty of a weakness which instantly brought punishment down on his head.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John T. Pratt will give a dinner tomorrow at her home, 7 East Sixty-first Street for her niece, Miss Barbara Pratt, whose marriage to David Richmond Wilmerding takes place Tuesday.

DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 23 -- The gold-buying policy of the United States and its consequent effect on quotations for foreign exchange is bringing material profit to the tobacco growers of Piedmont, Va., and North Carolina, where the bright leaf essential in cigarette making is produced.

DENVER, Nov. 23 -- The announcement from Washington that the newly created civil works division will spend $400,000,000 on public works without reference to the borrowing capacity of the region to be benefited has materially lightened the anxiety of some public officials here, who interpreted it as giving Colorado another chance at Federal funds.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Although the British Admiralty has had to restrict the number of cruisers laid down in 1933 to three under the limits imposed by the London treaty, that pact does not apply to cruisers laid down in 1934, so provisional arrangements are being made for a considerable increase.

The Community Craft Weavers, a vocational department of the Community Workers, which is an auxiliary of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, have opened a shop as a sales outlet at 47 East Fiftyseventh Street.

"No curtailment of essentials should be thought of in connection with schools over which Christ preaches as supreme teacher." Cardinal Hayes declares in a pastoral letter which will be read at all the masses today in the 454 churches of the Archdiocese of New York.

LONDON ONCE more the world is engrossed with the problem of the relations between the dollar and the pound -- between the newer economics, whose home is the White House in Washington, and the older economics whose most historic stronghold is a private bank in London with paintings in its parlors and a beadle on duty in every entrance lobby.

Marked consumer emphasis on medium to popular price merchandise, a dollar sales volume slightly in excess of a year ago and the probability that utility and repeal items will be outstanding shape up as likely features of a $4,000,000,000 Christmas trade this year, according to leading retail executives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Yesterday's buyers of grain started today to liquidate their holdings on the Board of Trade, and there was also selling by small longs in the December, who either were getting out of the market or transferring their lines into the deferred deliveries.

The Community Craft Weavers, a vocational department of the Community Workers, which is an auxiliary of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, have opened a shop as a sales outlet at 47 East Fiftyseventh Street.

"No curtailment of essentials should be thought of in connection with schools over which Christ preaches as supreme teacher." Cardinal Hayes declares in a pastoral letter which will be read at all the masses today in the 454 churches of the Archdiocese of New York.

LONDON ONCE more the world is engrossed with the problem of the relations between the dollar and the pound -- between the newer economics, whose home is the White House in Washington, and the older economics whose most historic stronghold is a private bank in London with paintings in its parlors and a beadle on duty in every entrance lobby.

Marked consumer emphasis on medium to popular price merchandise, a dollar sales volume slightly in excess of a year ago and the probability that utility and repeal items will be outstanding shape up as likely features of a $4,000,000,000 Christmas trade this year, according to leading retail executives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Yesterday's buyers of grain started today to liquidate their holdings on the Board of Trade, and there was also selling by small longs in the December, who either were getting out of the market or transferring their lines into the deferred deliveries.

Richard Slutzkin, 42 years old, of 1,352 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, described by the police as an exconvict and a former attorney, was accused yesterday of a racket to defraud property holders. He was held in $25,000 bail by Magistrate Smith in Morrisania court for a hearing Wednesday on a charge of petit larceny.

ANNIVERSARIES often stir reminiscences, and so it was with S.L. Rothafel, known by the unseen audience as "Roxy," on the day he celebrated his eleventh season on the air. He looked back across the years, recalling the big events that made radio history; but Roxy is more concerned with the human side of broadcasting.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 25 -- Two supper dances for members of the younger set will take place during the Christmas season.

HOLLYWOOD METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER is having an interesting if not tranquil time in Mexico filming "Viva Villa," according to reports which reached the studio this week. Stretched across a "battle front" some 600 miles long are three companies photographing many of the phases of the bandit leader's career.

ON BOARD ADMIRAL BYRD'S FLAGSHIP, en route to Little America, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd announced tonight plans for unique experiment in polar exploration on the rim of the South Polar Plateau.

New York University's football team came back to close its season in glory at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Entering the game with only one victory to its credit, the Violet upset Carnegie Tech, 7 to 0.

Recognition of Russia by the United States will open not only the vast Soviet market for American exports but also the hitherto closed markets in the Far East and the Balkans, Samuel C. Lamport, cotton goods exporter and long an advocate of normal relations with Russia, declared here yesterday.

IF there are, in these disillusioned days, any young girls left who believe that innocence will triumph over all difficulties and gain for them love, wealth and social position through marriage with their employer, they will adore "De-

The piano recital given by the 8-year-old pianist Ruth Slenczynski yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall confirmed the impression she had made on the New York public at her first recital of a few days previous. She is not, of course, and could not be, a matured musician, but she is phenomenally gifted and precocious in a way that connotes exceptionally great gifts and incipient virtuosity of a remarkable order.

Younger members of society are giving their active support to plans for the annual December ball to take place on Dec. 8 at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Miss Phyllis Brewster is chairman.
The six-day bicycle race returned to New York City last night. To the sound of a pistol shot by Rudy Vallee, a group of fifteen teams started the week-long ride to nowhere at Madison Square Garden.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Anxiety continues to be expressed by the Vatican over the religious situation in Germany, and it is feared there are forces in that country that are hostile to the cooperation of the German Catholics in the new political system.

The golden wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Morgenthau was observed last night at Bronx House, 1,637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, with a pageant, a presentation of a leather memorial book and dancing.

The cotton market here drifted downward last week, interrupting the long upward movement since the middle of October, influenced by lower dollar values for foreign currencies and by technical factors.
