On Friday, notice day for December delivery, the market gained strength from the easing of December liquidation and advanced moderately, but part of the gain was lost on Saturday as cotton again tended downward, following lower foreign currency quotations.

Perhaps twelve of the fifty children who technically were restored to the arms of their parents yesterday, when "Santa Claus" landed in a plane in Van Cortlandt Park, were genuinely lost and entitled to the pleasure of hearing their names called on the loud-speaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The National Labor Board made public today a ruling affirming contractors' rights to assign construction work held up by jurisdictional disputes between unions and ordered immediate resumption of construction on the Philadelphia postoffice.
Mrs. Josephine Corey, 36 years old, prematurely gray and the mother of two children, was arrested yesterday charged with having robbed a score or more of families in Brooklyn of their last few cents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- Four persons who had been celebrating a football victory of Stanford University over California were fatally hurt shortly before dawn today in a head-on collision on the Bay Shore highway, a half mile north of Broadway, Burlingame.

A charge that the pontifical mass celebrated at the Catholic Congress of the Protestant Episcopal Church before a congregation of 10,000 in the Municipal Auditorium, Philadelphia, on Oct. 24 was "for theatrical display" is made by the Evangelical Education Society in a postscript to its annual report to the House of Bishops.

Delay in the Federal construction program is affecting the building trades adversely, Myron L. Matthews says in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. Depression in the construction industry, Mr. Matthews finds, is bringing about an acute need for reconciliation of opposing factions and adoption of a master code for the industry.

The spiritual rewards for man's love in God, as emphasized by the saints in the New Testament, were declared preferable to "material rewards because of man's obedience to God," as promised by the philosophers and prophets in the Old Testament, by the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans in his sermon yesterday morning at the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

The Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters was asked last night by the State Police at Hawthorne, N.Y., for aid in establishing the identity of a man about 37 years old whose skeleton was found in the Hudson highlands.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Professor O. M.W. Sprague's letter resigning his post in Washington and the various manifestations by representative men against President Roosevelt's policy are unanimously approved here as expressing common sense and truth.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- The body of Brooke Hart, who was slain Nov. 9 by kidnappers, who then sought to collect ransom, was recovered today from San Francisco Bay in five feet of water about a mile west of the Alameda shore and half a mile south of the San Mateo-Hayward Bridge.

Eighteen ballet dancers walked out when a demand for payment of $163.75, which they declared was due them, did not produce the cash just before a performance of "Aida" at the Hippodrome yesterday afternoon. The girls, mostly graduates of the Metropolitan Opera House ballet school, it was said, had consulted their ballet mistress, Martha Henkel, who also leads the dances, and had laid their claims before two lawyers who were present in the theatre.

Germany is actively repatriating her long-term dollar bonds and is reducing her short-term external debt at a rapid rate because of the depreciation of dollar exchange, according to Robert S. Byfield of Willard Co., president of Foreign Bond Associates, Inc. Writing to his firm from Berlin, Mr. Byfield quoted a German banker as saying the slump of the dollar was giving Germany a bonus of $500,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Long hours of conference over the weekend between a committee of the liquor distilling industry and representatives of the government ended tonight in a new liquor code, less strict than the government's original formula, but still retaining iron-clad Federal control.

Mrs. ROOSEVELT, speaking as herself an experienced teacher to a large audience of teachers and parents last week, said that we cannot have progressive education, or education of any kind, if the school houses are not kept open and the teachers are not paid. One of the tragedies of depression is that schools in many States are open, if at all, for a shorter time.

Striking back at "disloyalty" during the recent Mayoralty campaign, Mayor John P. O'Brien said yesterday that despite his defeat he had gained "considerable satisfaction" from the campaign and that as far as he was concerned personally, he had "won" the election.
DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 26 -- Although a twice-told tale, the case of Heywood Patterson may still contain surprises, it was indicated here today on the eve of his third trial for his life.

Walter Hampden, one of the few remaining road stars, will start out on another of his periodic cross-country travels when he opens an extensive tour in Pittsburgh on Dec. 25. The opening bill there will be "Richelieu." Other plays in his repertory -- some of which he has not presented in recent years -- will be "Hamlet," "The Servant in the House" and "Macbeth."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Unemployed miners in Arizona may be put to work by the Federal Government on the cultivation of pyrethrum daisies if plans now under consideration are approved and funds are appropriated.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 26 -- The Tennessee Public Service Company, subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, which services Knoxville, has under consideration drastic rate reductions and, perhaps, total elimination of its street railway system to meet competition from a municipally owned electric system, according to an authoritative announcement tonight.
Inspired by the approach of Thanksgiving Day many clergymen voiced the hope for a new day in their sermons yesterday.

Sir Philip Gibbs, wno wrote of the depression in his last novel, dramatizes the problem of whether, another war between France and Germany can be avoided (at least until the ruin of the last one has been repaired) in his new novel, published last Monday in England.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 26 -- The newly selected Northeast first end second field hockey teams clashed today in the concluding match of the Northeast Field Hockey Association's three-day tournament, with the first eleven scoring a 2-0 victory.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Two country-wide manifestations against the existing economic order took place in France today when hundreds of thousands of farmers and about 30,000 coal miners converged on dozens of cities and towns in a common protest.

The two medieval stained-glass windows alleged by French authorities to have been stolen from an ancient church at Fecamp, Normandy, and sold in the United States to William Randolph Hearst, newspaper publisher, will be returned to France, it was indicated here yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Army's victorious football squad returned from Philadelphia by special train at 4 P.M. today.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Economists are speculating on the good fortune of three small unrelated countries that are enjoying real prosperity while the rest of the world is still painfully emerging from the depresion.
Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia has been asked by Samuel Untermyer to request the Board of Estimate to leave all pending bus franchise matters to be settled by the incoming Fusion administration.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Removal of the thyroid gland to relieve angina pectoris, the sixth operation of the kind in medical records, was believed a success today when Frank C. Lob, 54, an artist, returned to his home from the John B. Murphy Hospital.

It was said of the painter KNELLER that he felt he had mistaken his calling. Instead of being an artist he should have been a military man. He was sure that he would have been a great commander of an army because he did so like the smell of burnt gunpowder.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 26 -- President Roosevelt held long conferences today with three key men in the administration's recovery program. Silence cloaked the results.

When the Public Service Commission a few months ago ordered the local electric light companies to reduce their charges by 6 per cent -- Chairman MALTBIE would have preferred 10 per cent -- it took little or no cognizance of such recent developments as new Federal taxes, the effect of the NRA on payrolls, and the municipal ordinance increasing water rates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States Army is "below the danger line" in strength of personnel and materiel, General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff, reported to Secretary Dern today. The general attributed this condition to reductions in army appropriations and to the necessity for neglecting military training and schooling to organize the Civilian Conservation Corps and to superintend its camps.
Conference champions were established in several sectors on Saturday and hostilities were silenced for the season on most fronts, but still the caissons of Army, Princeton and Duke go rumbling along.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Commodore Egbert Moxham of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was the outstanding skipper in the dinghy races sailed today under the auspices of the Port Washington Yacht Club. He sailed his Class A boat, the Sandpiper, to four victories and a second place in five races.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- With the weather mild and springlike, the New Rochelle Yacht Club held its first Winter dinghy regatta today out on Echo Bay. Heavy frostbite garb was discarded by the sailors in eleven dinghies, but as ideal as the temperature was, there was no breeze.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 26 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.7, which compares with 72.1 a week ago, 71.6 two weeks ago, 71.8 three weeks ago and 71.6 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Stitch McCarthy was re-elected chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors here today, but not without incident. Charges of bribery, fraud, intimidation and breach of promise followed closely the announcement of the victory.

The body of a man who committed suicide on Nov. 14 by leaping from a window on the twelfth floor of the Hotel Taft has been identified as that of "Dan the Dude," race track follower and Broadway figure, who, in the palmy days before the depression was reputed to be worth half a million dollars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Robert L. Owen, former Democratic Senator from Oklahoma, joined supporters of the Presidential monetary program today, contending in a statement that "contractionists" of the currency, if their policy were followed, would intensify the depression and probably bring a "violent plunge into communism."

A youth identified later as Walter Costa, 17 years old, of 303 East 104th Street, was killed last night while leaving a fifth-floor apartment at 175 East 105th Street when he lost his foothold and fell to the bottom of an airshaft six stories below.

It is indispensable for a return to prosperity, that corporation executives be able to proceed with legitimate financing of their companies with assurance that, if they discharge their duties honestly and diligently, they will have no reason to fear penalties under the law, says The Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The chances of Soviet Russia's joining an international pact to boost the price of wheat were viewed optimistically by delegates here on the eve of the first meeting of the world wheat advisory committee.

Contained reports from Warm Springs that the President is resolved to stand firmly by his gold policy were only what was to be looked for. Even if he were contemplating modifications of it, he would not announce it. Moreover, his precise aim in Government buying of gold, or the goal which he has set for himself, he has never definitely stated.

Further disasters to the Jews in Germany are predicted in a report from what is described as "an authentic European source," made public yesterday by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the German relief fund being raised by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

Federal officials and representatives of eleven Northeastern States will meet today at the Waldorf-Astoria to devise plans to prevent evasion of gasoline taxes and the illegal sale of motor fuel and oil.

The recognition of Soviet Russia is the principal pictorial news item at the Embassy Newsreel Theatre this week. There are a newsreel review of Russian life under Soviet rule, excerpts from President Roosevelt's Georgia speech and camera interviews with Maxim Litvinoff and the first Ambassador to Soviet Russia, William C. Bullitt.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, A.F. MacNichol annexed the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The handicap trophy was taken by J.E. Getman, P. Sleppy winning the second cup.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The markets for hogs are getting back to normal conditions and the movement from the country is ample for all requirements. Packers and shippers were in the market here last week, but the week's average of $3.90 a hundredweight for all hogs was the lowest since Sept. 9.

Residential leasehold deals in various parts of Manhattan were reported over the week-end. The four buildings and a vacant lot at 305-313 West Twenty-second Street, adjoining the corner of Eighth Avenue, were leased for a term of years by Margaret V.C. MacNutt and the Mary M. Lagergren estate to Solomon Tarlow at a reported total gross rental of $73,100.

VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- Present indications are that the latest incident on the Austro-German frontier will become just one more in a long series of border troubles which at least add to the difficulties between the two nations. Whether it will become more depends on the Germans.

HERBERT GORMAN, the "old bookish browser," as Edmund Wilson has called him, has found some lush new pastures to tempt his always voracious appetite in "Jonathan Bishop" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). This "Jonathan Bishop" is a historical novel of the last days of the Second Empire and the episode of the Paris Commune. It cries aloud for swift translation into Hollywood symbolization.

Comparing communism in Russia with, the beliefs of the early Christians, John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, declared in his sermon at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday morning that communism was the only living religion in the world today.

Preliminary to an event to be called the Yankee Doodle Ball, which will be given Jan. 2 at the St. Regfis, a series of three tea dances will be given in the Egyptian Room of the hotel Dec. 9 and the two succeeding Saturdays for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanitarium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The clash of opinion between the Treasury Department and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation over the legal authority of the latter to purchase gold was revealed in detail today when the text of a Treasury memorandum became available contending that the procedure would be of "doubtful legality."

The trailers gained a bit on Winter, Davis and Elkins halfback, over the past week-end, but the leader still is far ahead in the race for Eastern individual scoring honors as the season moves toward the close. Winter has 91 points. His team-mate, Tinney, picked up one extra point as a result of his twenty-fifth conversion after touchdown to advance to 79 markers.

Ambushed as they were returning home along a quiet Brooklyn residential street last night, Aaron Scherwin, an attorney of 60 Wall Street, was shot four times and killed instantly, and his wife, Charlotte, was seriously wounded by an assailant who fired without warning.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 -- The cotton market here was active at times last week, but there also were periods of extreme quiet. Price fluctuations were rapid, but the spread between the high and low points reached only 34 points for March and 47 for December.

Among the entertainments to be given this week for various charitable enterprises will be a supper dance tomorrow night at the Biltmore for the benefit of St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Fort "Washington Avenue and 190th Street.
The Merchants Association announced yesterday that a memorandum expressing the views of the association on charter revision had been placed in the hands of Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia.

Fishermen who like to linger through the season as far as they can will find cod and haddock running in local waters, according to reports. In fact, if one can get a measure of real sport out of cod-fishing, there will be found no lack of fish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Unemployment rose in October to 10,076,000, an increase of about 11,000 over the previous month, according to the American Federation of Labor, but was 1,510,000 under October, 1932. The survey added that there was every evidence that the NRA program was keeping the situation under better control than was usual at this time of year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- With Treasury Department experts working on plans for refinancing maturities of about $727,000,000 falling due on Dec. 15, in such a manner as to avoid any step that would represent outright inflation, interest here in the monetary situation tonight was focused on what the RFC would offer tomorrow for gold.

Flushing's fine comeback against Erasmus Hall that toppled the latter from New York City's list of undefeated elevens was outstanding in schoolboy gridiron circles during the past week-end. By its 12-to-6 triumph, Flushing remained unbeaten along with two other public high School squads, Curtis and Manual Training, both of which won on Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- An unsuspected friendship between the Earl of Oxford and Asquith and the young widow of an army major will be revealed tomorrow with publication of a new book, "H.H.A. Letters From Lord Oxford to a Friend."

The radio and music trades division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies has passed its goal of $50,000 toward the $4,200,000 objective of the central organization. The division has raised $53,662, it was announced last night at the unit's annual $100 dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Harry Gannon, 36 years old, an amateur pilot, was killed yesterday when his plane fell in a spin into the Queens Meadows near Brookville Boulevard, about a mile from Valley Stream. His passenger, William Hentrich of 41-35 Forty-eighth Street, Woodside, was seriously injured.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Chancellor Hitler's official overtures to France through Ambassador Francois-Poncet have been greeted here with the expected reserve.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- In spite of the continued heavy loss of gold by the Bank of France there is less apprehension here concerning the future of the franc than existed recently.
Free College Professors. Little has been heard recently of the problem of academic freedom. It is the general impression that college professors now enjoy plenty of freedom of thought and speech.

A benefit supper dance will be given on Wednesday by the Alumnae Association of the Holy Child Convent in the roof garden of the St. Regis. The proceeds will augment the scholarship fund of Rosernont College, Rosemont, Pa., which is under the supervision of the Sisters of the Holy Child.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Real estate and building company plans for refinancing projects are embraced in five of sixteen registration statements for securities issues newly filed with the Federal Trade Commission. The sixteen issues, of which four are by New York concerns, total more than $8,600,000.

IN the official statistics of the recent Harvard-Yale debate one crucial play appears to have been completely overlooked. It came under the head of "yards gained by rushing" and the saving overland journey was made by a Harvard man wearing a brown felt hat and a long blue overcoat. He rushed "about four miles," or the long steeplechase distance on the turf.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- The steel trade has made an upward revision of its appraisal of the future, renouncing expectations of a further marked decrease in activity up to the year-end. It feels that it will hold all the business that it now has and may gain some.

LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh lifted their big seaplane from the harbor at 7:45 A.M., today, circled the city three times, and headed across 300 miles of ocean for Villa Cisneros.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Supplies of oats are liberal for the present but a shortage is predicted later in the season. One of the largest processors, who has been friendly to the buying side for months, suggests there will be a scarcity later but, with prices 16 to 19 cents above a year ago, part of the shortage has been discounted.

To protect the interests of holders of more than $1,000,000,000 in guaranteed mortgage certificates issued by the companies taken over for rehabilitation by the State Insurance Department, cooperative corporations are being organized and will begin to function soon, George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.

Two forward passes, neither of which reached its intended receiver, figured heavily in the convincing 17-6 victory scored by the New York Giants over the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The personnel of the Chicago Committee for the Defense of Human Rights Against Naziism, which will conduct a mass meeting next Sunday afternoon in the Chicago Stadium, was made public here today. The committee is composed mainly of Protestants and Catholics.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co., announced today that the company had sent the following telegram to all members of the New Jersey Legislature:
BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- The efforts for "Winter relief" are being pushed by the Nazi powers with equal appreciation of their material necessity and their publicity value.

To the financial watcher, last week had its interesting points. Official dollar manipulation halted; during the last four days of the week the Washington committee made no change. Public opposition to the government's operations was marked by greatly increased intensity; yet the markets reflected little but hesitation.

HARRISON, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Leonard Zaiss, 41 years old, an artist and sculptor, prominent resident of Purchase, near here, was found dead at his home early today with a bullet wound in his head. A .38 calibre pistol was beside the body.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Referring to Alfred E. Smith, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower, said in a radio talk today that an "outstanding Catholic citizen has loaned his illustrious name to a cause that is inconceivable."

The urgent need for an emergency fund of $300,000 to tide the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service over an impending financial crisis that would seriously cripple its work here next year was described by speakers at its fortieth anniversary celebration last night at the Guild Theatre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The first part of the long-awaited report by the State Commissioner of Education, Dr. Graves, states among other things that in the school system "there is a lack of effective creative leadership." The truth of this statement is amply borne out if we examine the comprehensive surveys and superintendents' reports from 1911 to 1932.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Three unions of stock yards workers today voted to start tomorrow a strike which their officials predicted would tie up Chicago's great meat-packing industry.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Replying to critics of the Roosevelt monetary policies, Raymond Moley, former Assistant Secretary of State in the President's Cabinet, asked this question today: "Some one has to fix the price of gold; why shouldn't it be the United States?"

Support for the annual campaign to raise money for the fifty-six voluntary hospitals associated in the United Hospital Fund, which opens today, was voiced by President Roosevelt in a letter to Henry J. Fisher, president of the fund, made public yesterday.

Trading in commodity futures on local exchanges produced last week a wide divergence of trends in the individual markets. Silver and silk were sharply lower; hides, copper, tin, coffee and cocoa lost ground and sugar and rubber gained ground. Trading was active.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There still seems to be a great deal of confusion about the possible effects of the new Bank Deposits Insurance Act, which goes into operation on Jan. 1.
The annual joint Thanksgiving service for New York patriotic societies was held at dusk yesterday it the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Business in leading lines in this territory is making a better showing than it did and its reports are the most cheerful for more than a month. More persons are being employed, Chicago alone having given work to more than 40,000 in the last week on roads and other projects and more are expected to be employed in the next few weeks, weather permitting.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Howard F. Chappell, her daughter, Mrs. Jeannette C. Hitchcock, and her sister, Miss Jeannette G. Campbell, are at the Drake for the Winter.

A private secretary and a school teacher-writer spelled down a university professor, an editor, a foreign correspondent and a dozen or more assorted writers at the annual spelling bee of the Town Hall Club last night.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The gloom which heavily enveloped the financial markets at the beginning of the week lifted considerably toward the week-end. Inasmuch as the depression was due to weakness in the dollar and franc, it follows that its partial dissipation was the result of the recovery in those currencies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Members of the women's United States field hockey team, who recently returned from a European tour, met with a surprising 3-1 defeat at the hands of the all-Southeast team on the Merion Cricket Club grounds today.

Ace of Aces Rebel concluded a gala day by being named best in show at the Boston Terrier Club of New York specialty exhibition last night. The victory was the highlight of the club's twenty-sixth annual show, which was held at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The golden jubilee of the Church of St. Benedict the Moor, the first Roman Catholic Church for Negroes north of the Mason and Dixon line, was celebrated yesterday, with Cardinal Hayes presiding at a solemn jubilee mass.

Bruno Walter conducted excerpts from an opera which is unknown in this country, Hugo Wolf's "Der Corregidor," at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, and thereby atoned for some uninspired program-making of recent weeks. For this music, judging by the pages heard yesterday, deserves a better fate than neglect; it is music of great tenderness, humor and passion.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles swept aside the Cincinnati Reds, 20 to 3, today in a National Football League game.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- While the insurgency in Protestant circles against the Nazi German Christian movement was spreading swiftly throughout the country today, Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller in Koenigsberg outlined a policy of drastic, unyielding adherence to Nazi principles and no quarter for the opposition.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 26 -- The Palestine Arab Executive today issued a proclamation appealing to all Arabs to strike tomorrow and Wednesday, the days set for the trials here and at Jaffa of Arab leaders who participated in Oct. 13's "illegal assembly, in which the whole Arab nation took part in person and spirit and in the peaceful demonstrations which were turned into human slaughter by police."

Playing at Ebbets Field for the first time in three weeks, the Brooklyn Dodgers entertained the crowd of 15,000 fans who turned out to welcome them home yesterday by beating the Boston Redskins 14 -- 0.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 -- Argentine grain prices reached new low levels last week, with wheat selling at the equivalent of 28 7/8 cents a bushel at Rosario on Thursday and 32 7/8 cents here. Corn was at the equivalent of 21 1/4 cents a bushel at Rosario and 22 5/8 cents here.

John Charles Thomas, baritone, filled the Town Hall yesterday afternoon for the third time in recent weeks and the last before joining the Metropolitan's coming opera season. In the interval since mid-October he also has opened three series of New York's social musical mornings or matinees and has appeared in Madison Square Garden.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 26 -- The confessed kidnapper-slayers of Brooke Hart, San Jose youth whose body was found today in San Francisco Bay, were lynched here tonight by a mob which broke into the county jail and seized the pair.

Revision of the basis of passenger rates on the three ships operated by the Panama Pacific Line in the intercoastal trade is asked in new tariffs submitted by the line to the Shipping Board bureau of regulation. Its proposal is attacked in statements also filed by its principal competitors in the passenger field, the Grace and Dollar steamship lines.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the Montreal Canadiens tonight, 4 -- 2, with a spirited fist fight thrown in as an added attraction in a keen National Hockey League match before some 8,500 spectators.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- The alibi which Earle Wynekoop tried to destroy last night by "confessing" the unaided murder of his wife, Rheta, was re-established today by two witnesses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An investigation of oil pipe lines and transportation practices to lay the groundwork for Federal regulation was announced today by Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- A 29-yard touchdown jaunt by Bronko Nagurski in the closing minutes of play today gave the Chicago Bears a l7-to-14 victory over the Ports-mouth Spartans and enabled them to cling to the Western division lead in the National Professional Football League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- Findings which may aid in conquest of one of the serious and common ailments of mankind, rheumatic fever, and the allied rheumatic heart disease, have been made by Drs. James F. Rinehart and Stacy R. Mettier of the University of California Medical School.
Howard Borok, home representative, won the first annual five-mile handicap road run conducted by the Sixty-ninth Regiment Athletic Association yesterday through the streets of lower Manhattan.

A contribution of $200,000 by the Rockefeller Foundation to the unemployment relief fund being raised by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee, which is raising a fund of $4,000,000 to be disbursed through accredited family welfare agencies.

Being a genuine collaboration, "The Dark Tower," which was acted at the Morosco Saturday evening, resists chemical analysis. How much of it is the work of Alexander Woollcott, wit? How much of it represents George S. Kaufman, wit?

The Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner cited the "Wiggin, Clark, Fox stories" last night as showing the "results when we worship gold." He preached at the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.
The Brookhattan eleven and the New York Americans battled to a 1-1 tie in their American Soccer League game at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 persons.

While retail trade proceeded at a satisfactory pace last week, the desire of stores to hold down inventories restricted the volume of reorders coming into the local wholesale markets. Purchases were mostly for fill-in purposes to keep stocks rounded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The repeal of about $20,000,000 of nuisance taxes probably will be urged on Congress by the administration, according to officials studying taxation in connection with repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

GENEVA, Nov. 26 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- Differences of opinion have arisen between James G. McDonald, League of Nations High Commissioner for German Refugees, and the British Government, it is learned.

A tract of 247 acres in Hampton Township, Sussex County, was sold by George Hendershot to Mrs. J. Lester Parsons of West Orange. The land, situated on the Paulins Kill, is half cleared for farming and contains several farm buildings and cattle barns. The sale was negotiated by the Frank Hughes Co. and A.N. Lockwood.

Grand opera broadcasts, beginning with the Metropolitan's preseason performance of "Hansel und Gretel" on Christmas afternoon and continuing to Easter Sunday, April 1, were announced yesterday by M.H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- Named to uphold the best traditions of Far Western football, Stanford's Cardinals scanned the nation's gridirons today in the search that will produce a worthy opponent from the sunrise side of the Rockies as a contender for Rose Bowl laurels New Year's Day in Pasadena.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Exhibiting to a high degree all of the points that are desirable in a finished Chesapeake Bay dog, Skipper Bob today was declared to be the winner of the open all-age stake at the second annual retriever trials of the American Chesapeake Club.
Martin V. Head announces the opening of a general real estate office at 736 Lexington Av.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell, of the New York Methodist area, and president of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Church, dedicated yesterday morning the new edifice of Christ Church at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

American humor from pre-Revolutionary times to the present, as expressed in cartoons and other satirical prints, will be put through all its paces in a big Salon of American Humorists which the College Art Association is now installing at 480 Park Avenue.

The Maganini Chamber Symphony gave its first New York concert last night at the Town Hall, replacing the New York Sinfonietta, which Quinto Maganini, organizer of the new ensemble, had directed for a number of years. Throughout a varied program the new ensemble showed itself distinctly superior to the old in accuracy of intonation, especially among the brasses and in the crispness of its attacks, the general finish of its performance.

With no intention of playing the part of the Curious Impertinent or poking an intrusive nose into high matters none of our business, we must confess a benevolent interest in the observations made by that accomplished young Republican, Assemblyman ABBOT Low MOFFAT, to his Republican brethren and sisters in the Fifteenth Assembly District.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- The forthcoming visit of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, is regarded here as of considerable importance. It is believed to have been arranged by Premier Mussolini to further those "still more useful" results which II Duce said he expected to derive from the Russo-Italian pact of friendship and non-aggression, signed in September.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 26 -- Six rioters were arrested, a score were beaten with clubs or trampled and police were pulled from their horses, scratched and pummelled tonight as 5,000 anti-Hitler demonstrators fought the police in the shadow of the State House after being driven from a meeting at Ford Hall.

Describing the increase in tax exemption in New York City as "alarming" and urging a revision of tax-exemption procedure, the City Affairs Committee made public yesterday a study of the problem, suggesting that no land acquired in the future should be added to tax-exempt rolls.

PARIS, Monday, Nov. 27 -- At 3 o'clock this morning, after eighteen hours of negotiations, Camille Chautemps announced the composition of the new French Government. It will be almost the same as Albert Sarraut's defeated government, although the names have been shuffled about slightly.

To Ontario many New York lawyers have looked with admiration and envy for its speedy and effective administration of criminal law. But our friends across the border are subject, like much of the rest of the world, to the methods of the Circumlocution Office, if a writer in The Sault Ste. Marie Star doesn't exaggerate.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,471,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Uncertainty as to the value of the new dollar and the future policy of the government has created the most unsettled feeling that the grain trade has experienced in years. With disagreement among the political leaders, there is a disposition in the trade to go slow.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A strongly worded resolution calling upon Governor Rolph to "retract or deny his reported favorable comment upon the action of the mob" was adopted by the Los Angeles Ministerial Association today.

It is an ingenious suggestion from a scientific source that MOHAMMED in offering to trade one of his two loaves "to get white hyacinths for his soul" may have been merely bidding an agricultural surplus in exchange for "goods incapable of saturating the market." He may have teen simply "an early agricultural economist," and perhaps he was not at once both "ascetic and esthetic."

DAKAR, Senegal, Africa, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The belief that Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh will soon attempt a South Atlantic homeward flight was strengthened today with their arrival at Porto Praia, Cape Verde Islands, a jumping-off place for Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- The growth of the Northern New York Utilities Company from 1913, when it had a fixed capital of $316,300, to 1931, when its fixed capital was $28,712,204, was described to the Federal Trade Commission today in its investigation of the company's affairs.

Two kidnappers and murderers were in jail. The country read with profound satisfaction of their arrest. A series of trials and convictions and severe sentences on other desperadoes in the same industry had demonstrated that law and justice were adequate to punish.

Dates for Race Week next Summer on Great South Bay were set last night at the annual meeting of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, which was held in the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street. Race Week will be from July 31 to Aug. 4, inclusive, with an invitation contest for small craft preceding on July 30 at Amityville.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Countess Grace de Benque, aged 58, was sentenced today to prison for two to four years for the theft of $5,000 from Miss Louise Maret, co-proprietor of a fashionable school for girls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad will be permitted to proceed with its plan to begin store door pick-up and delivery service throughout its system over the combined opposition of other Eastern carriers, under a ruling today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- There was virtually no early trading in livestock here early today as around 8,000 drivers, feeders and weighers at the Stock Yards struck. Late in the day, however, the three big packing companies, which are not affected, agreed to clean up the market.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP AMERICAN LEGION AT SEA, Nov. 27 -- Argentine trade questions occupied the attention of the United States delegation to the Pan-American conference on its last day at sea before landing at Montevideo.

Germany's desire for power and the fear in neighboring countries that she might reach that objective will lead to another European war sooner than the world expects such a conflict, in the opinion of Henry Morgenthau Sr., former Ambassador to Turkey.

The recent decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in the guaranteed mortgage certificates litigation is in accord with the program of the State Insurance Department to help creditors of the title and mortgage companies in rehabilitation, State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick declared last night in a statement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The distilling industry has informed President Roosevelt by telegraph that it will cooperate "to the fullest extent" in the code signed tonight at Warm Springs, pending final action by Congress this Winter.

The plan announced by State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick to protect the interests of holders of more than a billion dollars in guaranteed mortgage certificates by organizing cooperative corporations composed of the owners of the certificates, was praised by some realty interests as a solution of the problem and criticized by others and certificate holders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Eight thousand workmen in the Union Stock Yards were on strike tonight for higher wages and a shorter work week. The movement was reported to be spreading after a day of confusion in the world's largest livestock exchange.

Joseph Palma, Borough President-elect of Richmond, said on his return from a West Indies cruise on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus yesterday that one of his major interests in office would be the development of Staten Island as a port.
MONTREAL, Nov. 27 -- Scoring honors in the National Hockey League still remain with Johnny Sorrell of Detroit, in particular, and the American division in general.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Nov. 27 -- Deerfield Academy concluded its football season today by defeating Governor Dummer, 7 to 0. Deerfield outplayed the hard-fighting Governors in every department, but missed two opportunities to score.

Net profit of the Holland Furnace Company for the six months ended on Sept. 30 was $142,701 after depreciation, taxes, interest and other charges. This was equivalent, after 7 per cent preferred dividend requirements, to 25 cents a share on 426,397 no-par common shares.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 -- The Happy Argro colt Happy Go, which races for J.R. Buchanan, was an easy winner in the featured race at Bowie today. At the end of the six furlongs he was two lengths before Zipalong, while Boy Valet, held at more than 50 to 1, was a fast going third.
Sixty-five exiled Cuban, leaders representing three political parties united yesterday in a demand for the end of the present "humiliating and dolorous" spectacle in their nation.

John A. Brown, president of the General Petroleum Corporation, the Pacific Coast subsidiary of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, was elected yesterday chairman of the newly created executive committee of the parent company. The primary responsibility of the company's management has been lodged in this board, which is composed of Mr. Brown, Harold F. Sheets, G. V. Holton, F. S. Fales and A. F. Corwin.

The absence of the State's principal witness, Arthur J. Smith, National Commander of the Khaki Shirts of America, caused Judge Thomas C. Kadien of the Queens County Court to postpone yesterday for two weeks the trial of Athos Terzani.

Baffled in their efforts to find a motive for the killing of Aaron Scherwin, an attorney, and the wounding of his wife by an assassin in a Brooklyn street late Sunday night, the police centred then investigation yesterday on a young woman with whom Scherwin had been friendly before his marriage.

DUNEDIN, N.Z., Nov. 27 (By Wireless). -- Looking superbly fit after nearly three months of mountain climbing and sea beach walks, Lincoln Ellsworth, leader of the transantarctic flight expedition bearing his name, returned to Dunedin today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 27 -- A ceremonious state funeral attended by many military and civil dignitaries, headed by Chancellor Hitler himself, was accorded here today to Philipp Schumacher, the German soldier who won public attention by his death at the hand of an Austrian frontier guard.

The shock of a terrific explosion in the kitchen broom closet of her apartment last night caused the death of Mrs. Mary Collie, 45 years old, a trained nurse, of 1,931 Madison Avenue, which is across the street from the Hospital for Joint Diseases at 124th Street.

A move on the part of a committee from the National Association of the Legitimate Theatre to obtain permission from the Actors Equity Association for regular performances of legitimate theatrical attractions on Sunday evening, Dec. 31-- New Year's Eve -- died yesterday when Frank Gillmore, president of Equity, informed it that such permission could only be granted by the assent of Equity members.

Henri W. Shields, a Negro lawyer of 208 West 141st Street and a former member of the Assembly and of the Board of Aldermen, is being considered for United States Collector of Internal Revenue in the Third district to succeed Charles W. Anderson, also a Negro, who is a Republican and has held the office for several years. Mr. Shields is a Democrat.

At the outset small amounts were done at 1/2 followed by 5/3. The Exchange rate remained at 3/4. In time money ninety days loaned at 3/4 but there was little interest in the other maturities. Commercial paper and acceptance markets were quiet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A revival of the Ford-Johnson controversy over Henry Ford's failure to sign the NRA automobile code tonight put before J.R. McCarl, the Controller General, the question of whether a car contract must be awarded to the low bidder, regardless of the recovery program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The National Labor Board ruled today that a building contractor has the right to assign work to any craft he may select.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- China as a political organization is traveling fast toward ruin and destruction, said Dr. Yutaro Sugimura, former Assistant Secretary General of the League of Nations, when he was interviewed today for the newspaper Asahi after a lengthy tour of China.

Plans for a preliminary football game to the P.S.A.L. championship Flushing-Curtis meeting at Ebbets Field on Saturday were dropped yesterday. The proposed contest between James Monroe and Manual Training could not be arranged, as the latter team has a regularly scheduled game with New Utrecht on Thanksgiving Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The price at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy newly mined gold was kept at the same level today, as the administration conducted an appraisal of the situation before determining the future course of its monetary program.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- The main bulwark that man has erected against tyranny -- a free and independent judiciary to which the ruled may appeal against arbitrary acts of the rulers -- will be abolished in Germany if the Nazis carry out their present plans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- In view of the September price slump and recent recessions in the bond market, it may not be generally understood why the administration still feels that the recovery march is upward. The explanation is that the President and his important aides are dealing with prices and unemployment on a relative basis and for a long pull.

Legislation to prevent non-Celtic persons from assuming Celtic family names was urged yesterday at a meeting of the Celtic Society of Columbia University in the Horace Mann Auditorium of Teachers College, Broadway and 120th Street.

Seven freight ships operated by the Leyland Line, a subsidiary of the Roosevelt-International Mercantile Marine Company, have been sold to the Harrison Line of Liverpool, a competitor, it was announced yesterday. The sale will be followed by the sale of fifteen ships remaining in the Leyland fleet as soon as possible, according to P. A.S. Franklin, president of the company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Liquidation in wheat developed today on the Board of Trade, and while reports that the Federal relief agency had resumed buying carlots of country-run wheat in leading markets brought about a rally of 2 1/2 cents a bushel from the early low point, the upturn was not maintained and the close was 5/8 to 3/4 cent net lower.

Following the action, of New York, Wisconsin, New Jersey and several other States, Connecticut yesterday announced more liberal regulations covering pheasant shooting. However, the new plan was not adopted until last Friday, and it cannot be put into general use until next year.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Dartmouth's bedraggled football forces returned today from defeat at Chicago in time to note the opening move in Dartmouth's campaign to force the resignation of Head Coach Jackson Cannell.

F.H. LaGuardia's successful campaign for Mayor cost less than the campaigns of his two leading opponents, the Board of Elections disclosed yesterday when the time for filing campaign expenses expired.

Price movements In local commodity markets were governed yesterday almost entirely by the action of the foreign exchange markets and resulted in losses for most staples. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices, likewise, were lower.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- The Russian Arctlo freighter Chelyuskin is being carried westward in the Bering Sea by a strong wind.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- In the last minute of his speech in the House of Commons tonight closing debate on a Labor amendment to the speech from the throne, Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, suddenly turned from domestic affairs to make the clearest statement that has come so far from the British Government on the critical European situation.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Trading on the Boerse opened the week in a generally confident mood despite some irregularity caused by profit-taking. The majority of the list was able to score gains, heavy industrials, cables and electrics rising as much as two points, in individual cases even higher.

Plans for liquidating the National Exchange Bank and Trust Company of Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Henry R. Lathrop, president, in a letter to stockholders, who are to vote on the matter on Dec. 27 on recommendation of the directors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27 -- The NRA is an instrument for creating a consumptive power to balance the productivity of industry, Secretary Perkins told an audience of 3,000 tonight in Woolsey Hall at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Numerous bills providing for remonetization of silver are certain to be among the early measures presented to Congress in January, it was indicated today. Separate measures are being studied in the Senate and the result will probably be identical bills introduced simultaneously in both houses.

Reorders Fair Here Yesterday. Mail orders in the wholesale markets here yesterday were fair, with holiday items representing the bulk of the goods purchased. While some reports indicated brisk early Christmas shopping at the week end, retailers are tending to bold reorders to quick moving merchandise.

MARY OF SCOTLAND, a play in three acts, by Maxwell Anderson. Staged by Theresa Helburn; settings and costumes designed by Robert Edmond Jones; presented by the Theatre Guild as the third offering of its sixteenth subscription season: production committee: Lawrence Langner and Philip Moeller.

Turkeys -- carload upon carload -- are piling into the New York market for Thanksgiving Day tables. With the price the lowest it has been in years and quality of the best, dealers are expecting heavy sales today and tomorrow, when the peak of the retail market will be reached.
Excerpts from the addresses at the mass meeting at Carnegie Hall last night in opposition to President Roosevelt's monetary policies, as furnished to the press in advance of delivery, follows:

Charter reform to elminate useless city offices, abolish county lines and county government and generally to simplify the machinery of government was advocated last night by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in a speech to the Columbia Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Joel Sibner, 3 1/2-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sibner, was accidentally strangled, to death by a telephone cord yesterday morning while playing alone in his home at 317 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn. The child's mother was out shopping in the neighborhood.
The City A.C. players maintained their position as pace-setters in the Class C Metropolitan Squash Tennis League championship race last night by scoring their fifth consecutive victory.
NEW YORK. Lord Donegal will arrive today on the Berengaria and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Rev. Dr. Howard B. Grose of Mount Vernon, N.Y., editor emeritus of Missions, a magazine published by the Northern Baptist Convention, was entertained at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Wolcott on the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination to the Baptist ministry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- When Santa Claus climbs down the White House chimney Christmas Eve he will find President Roosevelt's stocking hanging over the fireplace in his bedroom, along with those of the rest of the family.

Mrs. Madeline Force Astor Dick and Enzo Fiermonte, Italian middleweight pugilist, were married at 5:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Mrs. Dick's room at the Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street. Mrs. Dick is 40 years old; Mr. Fiermonte, 26.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27 -- Economies of $1,124,982.66 were effected in the operating expenses of Harvard University for the year ending June 1, 1933, in comparison with the previous fiscal year, according to the report of Henry L. Shattuck, treasurer, made public today.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

The Peerless Corporation announced yesterday through its attorney, Max D. Steuer, that it had started an action in the Federal court here to force Redmond Co., bankers, of 48 Wall Street, to comply with the terms of an underwriting agreement.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Unqualified support of President Roosevelt's monetary policies was voiced tonight by Senator Robinson, Arkansas Democrat, the majority leader in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Resentment at an interruption of the Senate market inquiry by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, caused Senator Couzens to assert today that the Banking and Currency Committee would investigate in its own way and not be "dictated to" by "Mr. Aldrich or anybody else."
Three coaching figures have dominated football in the past decade -- the late Knute Rockne at Notre Dame, Glenn Warner, formerly of Stanford, and Howard Jones of Southern California.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Federal Power Commission today dealt what authorities said was a significant blow to the holding-company system in public utility enterprises, and in so doing urged the necessity of Federal authority for dealing with this "dynasty," with its spread of "sovereignty over far flung dominions in many States."

With the price of gold set by the RFC unchanged for the sixth successive day, the dollar recovered sharply in the world markets and gained 1.23 cents in gold value on the foreign exchange market here yesterday. The dollar closed at 64.56 cents based on local quotations for the French franc, after reaching 65.24, the highest level since Nov. 1.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Following a blackboard session in the gymnasium today, Army's football squad went out on at windswept and frozen gridiron to begin final preparations for the Notre Dame game.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Teachers in the State have contributed in money and in added service to the reduction during the past year of about $20,000,000 in the cost of public education, according to the Fact Finding Committee of the State Teachers Association, announced today by President W. Howard Pillsbury.

"Strange Orchestra," a play by Rodney Ackland, which was presented in London a year ago, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Playhouse. Cecilia Loftus and Edith Barrett are costarred in the cast.

Defeating Miss Ann Jones in the fence-off, Miss Muriel Guggolz, a member of the American Olympic team in 1932, won the first women's Individual fencing competition of the season last night at the Salle d'Armes Vince. After each, had won two bouts and lost one to finish in a tie in the final. Miss Guggolz triumphed over Miss Jones, 5 -- 2.

Lucrezia Bori, the Spanish soprano, whose appeals from the local stage and over the radio in last Spring's campaign for a fund to "save Metropolitan Opera" have made her known to millions of Americans, is to be honored in SanFrancisco tonight at a special performance of "La Boheme."

One of the most important public exhibitions of illuminated manuscripts ever held in this country will open today at the New York Public Library. The main exhibition room on the first floor has been arranged with cases containing 150 treasures of the Pierpont Morgan Library, which owns the largest and most important collection of illuminated manuscripts in this country.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The brilliant riding of Lieutenant Marshal Gleland and the stamina of his eight-year-old black mare Margot tonight gave Canada its second victory in the international army officers' jumping events at the Royal Horse Show.

The busy riders participating in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden completed their first twenty-four hours last night. Showing no inclination to slacken the fast pace that they have maintained since the grind got under way, the sturdy pedalers fought grimly for favored positions and thrilled a crowd of 10,000 with their continual bursts of speed.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than a dollar a bale yesterday and ended at the bottom, with losses of 20 to 25 points.

Richard H. Brown, former president of the Manhattan Electrical Supply Company, who is on trial with Charles H. McCarthy, stock promoter, charged with mail fraud, collapsed in Federal court yesterday after hearing the government outline its case against him before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey and a jury.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Members of the Republican joint conference committee tentatively decided tonight to recommend to the Legislature enactment of a bill providing for State liquor control by a single commissioner and a threemember advisory board.

PRINCETON, N. J.. Nov. 27 -- Chick Kaufman and John Weller, Princeton's sophomore halfback and guard respectively, probably will not be able to play against Yale on Saturday, it was announced, by Head Coach Crlsler today.

Spelling Bee Flourishes. It would be startling to find the following letter in the morning's mail: "Mr. Evander Z. Jones, 999\ Palm Avenue, New York, N.Y. Dear Sir: Yours of the 16th inst. at hand and we shall be happy to book your order for six necrophaguses, three opiophagists and a dozen each of the following items: cachinnation, hosanna, desuetude and mnemonics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Relief Administration purchased a large quantity of cash wheat today through the Agricultural Credit Administration. While the exact amount was withheld Administrator Hopkins said it was less than 1,000,000 bushels.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Frank approval from Governor Rolph and other State officials for giving "a fine lesson to the wholes nation" eased the taut nerves of this normally peaceful town today, scene of the lynching last night of John. M. Holmes and Thomas H. Thurmond, confessed kidnapperslayers of Brooke Hart.

LLOYD GEORGE takes his revenge in his own good time. He has been savagely criticized for wobbling in his aims, notably by John Maynard Keynes, the political economist, whose "Economic Consequences of the Peace" riddled the economic pretensions of Lloyd George and the rest of the "Big Four" at Versailles long before the world depression justified the Keynesian prophecy.

Increased expenditures on maintenance were reflected in reports on railway operations for October. Of the first fifty-nine companies to report, only nineteen showed increases in net operating income in comparison with their receipts the year before, although, twenty-three had larger gross revenues.

Pity the poor electric light and power industry, more familiarly known as the Power Trust! Once it flourished like a banyan tree, sending down new roots from every branch. Investors watered it, the twin suns of the Business Cycle and the Price Level shone down upon it, courts and commissions saw to it that it was properly fertilized with favorable rates.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop, in her cell in the Cook County jail today, repudiated her "confession" that she shot her daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop, according to Frank Tyrrell, attorney for the Wynekoop family.

Demanding the end of President Roosevelt's gold-purchase policy to prevent world-wide economic warfare, thirty-eight educators of Columbia University issued a joint statement yesterday urging an "expeditious" return to the gold standard.

A warning by the State Board of Pharmacy to patrons of "cut-rate" and other stores selling cosmetics, drugs and miscellaneous products was issued yesterday through George W. Mather, secretary of the board, following the presentation of a report showing that almost 44 per cent of brands of four articles commonly sold by the stores were of substandard quality.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia made public yesterday a letter he had written to George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, requesting that the hoard refrain from filling the post of Superintendent of Schools until Dr. Ryan had conferred with him.

The plan to conduct a campaign throughout the country to raise $50,000 to enable the United Synagogue of America to carry out the program adopted at its recent National Recovery Assembly was announced yesterday by Israel Silberman, treasurer of the organization, whose headquarters are at Broadway and 122d Street.

One of the smallest vessels ever to brave the seas in any season will start out this morning from Pier 6, East River, on a cruise around the world. The boat is the 35-foot Cimba, and in her cockpit at 5 A.M., if the weather is propitious, will be Richard H. Maury, marine painter and illustrator, of Darien, Conn., and his friend, Russell Dickerson, a former officer on a New York steamship line.

Isidor J. Kresel, who was counsel and a director of the Bank of United States, which failed in December, 1930, with about $443,000,000 of the depositors' money involved, was sentenced yesterday to a term of from eighteen months to two and a half years in Sing Sing.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The fact that the RFC again today failed to increase the price of gold "was interpreted in the Paris exchange market as at least a momentary victory for the anti-inflationists in the United States.

A mass meeting for the declared purpose of "staving off" inflation was held last night at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Crusaders, a national organization, which accumulated a million and a half members in a four-year fight against prohibition.

Father Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit's radio crusading priest, continued his campaign in support of President Roosevelt's monetary policy here last night before a crowd of nearly 7,000 that packed the Hippodrome.
BARCELONA, Nov. 27 -- Little Andorra, which so recently wound up a popular rebellion against the authority of the country's Spanish and French co-princes, was faced today with an anarchist movement.

If one could credit the dire predictions, contradictory as they are, about the future of this country, he would feel like the colored man of the story that nothing was left but to "take to the woods." Ex-Senator OWEN of Oklahoma warns all opponents of inflation that if they persist in criticizing the Administration's monetary policy they will surely start a great wave of Communism sweeping across this fair land.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Army will consider an invitation to play Stanford in the Rose Bowl intersectional football game, New Year's Day, if and when the cadets are fortunate enough to round out an undefeated season with a triumph over Notre Dame.

The scheduled finish bout between Joe Savoldi, famed Notre Dame football star, and George Zarynoff of Ukrainia, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night ended in dramatic fashion; when both men were counted out The end of the bout came in 27:41., It was called a draw.

The 365th musical morning in the series founded by Albert Morris Bagby took place yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria being the first of this season. The artists were Mme. Ninon Vallin, soprano; John Charles Thomas, baritone, and Alberto Salvi, harpist.

In the current issue of The Yachting World, the English publication, Major B. Heckstall-Smith, who was one of the British representatives in the rearrangement of the racing rules covering the America's Cup size yachts, takes up the deed of gift of the cup, and makes a novel suggestion.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Faced with an even greater glut of wheat than was feared last Summer, members of the International Advisory Commission on Wheat met today to review the working of the wheat agreement, which twenty-one nations signed at London three months ago.

With Samuel Untermyer and former United States Attorney George Z. Medalie as the principal witnesses, the committee of the Federal Bar Association, that is investigating the possible methods of regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages continued its work yesterday with a session at the Bar Association Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. --A new organization, designated the NDA, the initials being taken from, the name Nach der Arbeit (After Work), which is to systematize the recreation of the German people under Nazi auspices, was founded today.

New opera subscribers had their first innings at Thirty-ninth Street and Broadway yesterday, when the Metropolitan offered to the general public all seats remaining over from the annual renewals by former opera patrons, some of whom have held their places in the Golden Horseshoe during the greater part of its fifty years.

The Southern Women's Educational Alliance has changed the plans for its forthcoming entertainment, which will serve the double purpose of raising funds for the work of the alliance and celebrating the tenth anniversary of the founding of the organization by Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Having failed to make a Left concentration Cabinet with representatives of the group ousted by the Socialist party and the group led by Pierre-Etienne Flandin, Premier Camille Chautemps faces an early defeat by the combined votes of the extreme Left and the extreme Right.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Nov. 1 shows the following principal changes in October. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:

Moves in Gold Situation. The Crusaders, in alliance with the American Federation of Labor and the American Legion, held a rally at Carnegie Hall to "stave off" inflation. Matthew Woll demanded that the President give a clear statement on his policy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The Princeton basketball team will play twenty-one games and the hockey sextet nineteen, according to the schedules in the two major Winter sports announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Dissatisfaction of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration with the more important provisions of the proposed Grain Exchange code became evident today at a formal hearing on a tentative draft submitted by the grain committee on national affairs, representing the exchanges.

A concerted campaign to stamp out gasoline bootlegging and tax evasion, a racket which defrauds the States of millions of dollars annulally, was started by eleven States of New England and the Middle Atlantic at a conference in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While I am just as much a sound money man as the next one and am thoroughly in accord with its underlying principles, nevertheless, I can see where the President in his position may find it both expedient and necessary to continue a middle course.

A children's entertainment will be given under the auspices of the city visiting committee of the State Aid Association on Friday afternoon at Sherry's to raise money for the handicapped children of Bellevue Hospital. The program will include a showing of Remo Bufano's marionettes and Julius Caesar's circus.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- The significance attached abroad to Chancellor Hitler's conversation with Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador, last week appears to be getting on the nerves of the Berlin government.

Running over the frozen turf of the intercollegiate six-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park for the first time, Bernard (Barney) Oldfield of Alfred University sped to the crosscountry championship of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate A.A. yesterday afternoon.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 27 -- Before a jury of middle-aged farmers chosen today to try Heywood Patterson for his life, Victoria Price repeated her charge that he attacked her, but about the details she was hazy and alternately apologetic and defiant.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 27 -- Martial law prevails in the Chinese area of Greater Shanghai between 6 P.M. and 6 A.M. nightly while troop trains from Nanking arrive at the Junction, in the city's outskirts and are shunted onto the line for Hangchow.

United States Government bonds shot 4-32 to 25-32 point higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday in anticipation of the setting of the stage for the Treasury financing on Dec. 15. Domestic corporation issues finished moderately higher, while foreign loans, except most German issues, were lower as the dollar mounted in the foreign exchange market.

VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- General Julius Goemboes, a soldier who in the stress of post-war exigencies took to politics and has become Hungary's Premier and leading statesman, came to Vienna today to pay a friendly visit to his colleague, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria, and to discuss with him matters of mutual concern.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 27 (AP). -- Notre Dame's regulars rested today while Coach Hunk Anderson searched through his reserves for replacements to use against the Army Saturday.

With the government again assigning a value of $33.76 an ounce for domestic gold, the speculative markets yesterday broke away from the influences that had restrained them. The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's gold-buying price remained unchanged for the sixth successive business day, which was taken to indicate that possibly the administration was listening to the rising chorus of complaint against the present monetary policy.

While no official statement had been issued, well-informed shipping circles in Liverpool expect that the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Neville Chamberlain, will make an announcement in Parliament within a few days about the merger of the White Star and Cunard steamship lines, according to reports received here yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27-- If the request of New York State for $5,000,000 from the State Civil Works Administration is granted, half of it will be used on construction of farm-to-market roads, Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, chief of the Department of Public Works, announced today.

Officials of the United Hospital Fund, which is conducting its annual campaign to raise money for the care of the sick poor in its fifty-six affiliated institutions, estimated yesterday that during the current year the net operating deficits in fifty of its allied hospitals would total $4,553,995.

Two of Waxey Gordon's brewmasters -- one Falstaffian in girth and with a bulging neck, the other thin as a rail and with no voice -- brewed some potent testimony in Federal court yesterday at the beginning of the second week of the beer gangster's trial for income tax evasion in 1930 and 1931.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt today promulgated the industrial code for the motion picture industry and then brought the liquor industry under virtual government control when he signed its special temporary code to be administered by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

In terms of dollars, American exports in October reached the highest point for any month in two full years. The figure reported by the Department of Commerce is $194,000,000, compared with $153,000,000 for the same month last year. But dollars no longer command the same value on foreign exchange that they had a year ago.

The New York University Council elected Laurence G. Payson, president of the New York Stock Clearing Corporation, to membership yesterday, it was announced by Dr. Fred I. Kent, president. The council also confirmed the election of Malcolm D. Simpson of J.P. Morgan Co., which was announced some time ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- General John J. Pershing spoke today in behalf of the Crusade for Children in New York City, which is seeking to raise a fund of $400,000 for aiding destitute children. He appealed to radio listeners, "in the name of some child you love, in the hope of the future of our country, to give what you can, as much as you can."

In yesterday's dull trading the Stock Exchange proved to be an unsatisfactory barometer. The day's business was slightly above the recent average, but the price movement was somewhat disturbing to speculative operators. There was a decline of well over 4 points in the industrial averages, the widest in a month.

With repeal going into effect next Tuesday afternoon, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, yesterday warned those holding beer licenses against attempts to violate any of the rules governing the sale of liquor and wine.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- The ninth annual Associated Press All-Pacific Coast football team, presented today as the consensus of leading coaches, sports writers and officials, embraces a light, speedy back field, a 200-pound line and an all around collection of stars that makes the 1933 mythical varsity as versatile as any ever named.

BALTIMORE, Tuesday, Nov. 28. -- Proceeding under the orders of Governor Albert C. Ritchie, a provisional battalion of Maryland National Guardsmen early today left Baltimore for Somerset County to assist State policemen in the arrest of nine men, alleged to have taken part in last month's lynching of a Negro at Princess Anne.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- R.L. Jarnagin, chief of the appeals division and chairman of the Board of Appeals of the Veterans Administration, was appointed today as vice chairman of the Board of Veterans' Appeals.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27 (AP). -- City Manager W.W. Mynatt announced today that he would present a formal application immediately to the State Public Works Board for a $3,225,000 Federal loan and grant to finance a municipal power distributing system served by Muscle Shoals power.

Charles Blumberg, 31 years old, youngest of six sons of Mayer Blumberg, died with a bullet wound over his heart last night defending his father's wholesale tobacco and candy store at 1,834 Third Avenue against three hold-up men.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Nov. 22 shows a decrease of $49,000,000 in loans, $13,000,000 in investments, $27,000,000 in time deposits and $45,000,000 in government deposits and increases of $47,000,000 in net demand deposits and $40,000,000 in reserve balances with the Federal Reserve Banks.

Continued operation of the Roxy Theatre on Seventh Avenue under the present management and policies is recommended in a report filed yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, receiver, with Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 24:

ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- After the charter of the proposed Recovery Credit Corporation had been amended to restrict it to the handling of RFC funds, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. approved its incorporation under the stock corporation law today.

Additional contributions from life members, heavy enrolment in private schools and gains by volunteers working in restaurants were reported yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross in its annual membership roll-call.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Thousands of Protestants attended three Berlin meetings tonight to denounce inteference with the Evangelical Church by the Nazi German Christians. They adopted a resolution calling for defense of the Luther Bible and the traditional articles of faith.

NIGHT had fallen over Baker Field. The Columbia squad had finished its final practice session of the year and had trotted off through the darkness to the rambling low building that housed the lockers and the showers. There was an air of tenseness pervading the whole place. Cliff Montgomery and Red Matal would be playing their last game for Columbia the next day.

Governor Rolph of California was charged yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union with "being a party" to the lynching of the two kidnappers in San Jose because of the attitude he bad taken on the action of the mob which seized the two men in jail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a concerted work to increase our nation's armament. Immense appropriations have already been made directly for arming. Unemployment has been used as an occasion indirectly to increase our war strength. Still further, there will be presented to Congress a larger and longer plan to make our already towering armament tower higher still.

The estate of Mrs. Katherine H. Brown, who died Dec. 11, 1931, was appraised yesterday at $1,365,778 gross and $1,171,886 net. Half of the estate will go ultimately to the Children's Hospital Association of Denver. Her daughter, Marion Brown Elliott of Rye, N.Y., received $250,000 outright, $265,767 in trust and the income from the residue, $619,328, which goes on her death to her children, and then to the hospital.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is agent for extension of the maturity of the Northwest Louisiana Gas Company 6 1/3 per cent sinking fund bonds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Until a formal invitation is received from Stanford, the possibility of unbeaten Princeton representing the East on New Year's Day in the Rose Bowl will not be considered, Asa Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, said today.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia issued an appeal to the people of the city yesterday to support the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a fund of $4,000,000 to help family welfare agencies take care of those thousands of unemployed who cannot be reached by government relief agencies.

ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini all but abolished the employment of women in public offices in an order Issued today, demanding that the number of women workers in many State offices be limited to 5 per cent of the total workers.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The San Jose lynchings and Governor Rolph's attitude toward them provided a majority of British newspapers with main items of news and comment tonight.

Louis C. Wills, chairman of the Brooklyn NRA committee, who appeared before the Regional Labor Board last Thursday as counsel for New York Dugan Brothers, Inc., a Brooklyn bakery concern at which a strike was called last week, offered to resign from the NRA rather than abandon his clients, he announced yesterday in a letter to Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, vice chairman of the board.
To the Editor of The New York Times: General Johnson likens the citizens who object to Rooseveltian policies to rabbits desirous of becoming public characters by striking at a lion already great.
