PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Seven of the twelve men indicted Friday on charges of obstruction of justice in the Passaic County jury-fixing investigation appeared this afternoon before Judge Joseph A. Delaney and were released under $2,000 bail each pending trial.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A fear that the administration's goldbuying policy will be ineffective or may result in harmful consequences was expressed today in a joint statement by Harold L. Reed and six other professors and assistant professors of the economics department of the College of Arts and Sciences of Cornell University.
ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The construction of two new Italian cruisers, the Garibaldi and Duca degli Abruzzi, each, of 7,500 tons, has started, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Acting "in the public interest," the Treasury today rejected all bids for the New York City postofflce annex.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Not unlike a carnival crowd was the throng of several thousand persons who jammed St. James Park here last night to witness the lynching of Thomas H. Thurmond and John M. Holmes, confessed kidnapper-slayers of Brooke L. Hart.

The American Institute of Graphic Arts has opened its fourth exhibition of American book illustration on the thirty-first floor of the Squibb Building. The period covered is 1831-33. The institute sent out its call for American books illustrated by American artists or by artists living in this country; books printed in the United States and published since January, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- On petition of Canon William Sheafe Chase, Justice F.D. Letts of the District of Columbia Supreme Court granted a rule today directing Acting Secretary Phillips of the State Department to show cause why he should not be restrained from proclaiming repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

A denial that he had given preferential treatment either to banks or affiliates of the Paramount-Publix Corporation in his fourteen-month term as head of the finance committee of that organization was entered yesterday by John Hertz of Chicago at the hearing before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at his offices at 140 Nassau Street.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 -- Mack Sennett, Inc., Hollywood motionpicture corporation, today was adjudicated a bankrupt automatically by the Federal District Court here. The motion was taken after the corporation failed to respond to subpoena service in a creditor's plea for bankruptcy proceedings.

More than 15,000 unemployed seeking jobs under the new Civil Works Administration swamped the administration's re-employment offices in the various boroughs yesterday. While every effort was made to handle the crowds with the limited facilities available, most of the applicants had to be turned away pending the opening of twelve additional registration places this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The dollar, which fluctuated today between the extremes $5.041/2 and $5.25 1/2, closing at $5.12 against $5.20 Saturday, was, in the opinion of the financial editor of The London Times, "dominated by speculative influences, which he considers roust persist until the fate of the dollar is decided.

NEWARK, N.J. Nov. 28. -- The New Jersey section of the Professional Golfers' Association of America announced today unanimous approval of the plan projected by the national body for standardized instruction by all golf teachers holding membership in the P.G.A.

Richy Craig Jr., young vaudeville headliner who was master of ceremonies and a monologist in the musical show, "Hey, Nonny, Nonny," at the Shubert Theatre last Spring, died yesterday in the New York Hospital of heart disease. Just a week previously he had been obliged because of illness to leave the bill at the Palace Theatre in the middle of his week's engagement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Notice of Senate opposition, to confirmation of Martin Conboy, President Roosevelt's selection for District Attorney for Southern New York, was served today by Senator Couzens, Republican, of Michigan.

Robert E. Christie Jr., president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, announced yesterday the formation of a committee to draft fair-practice regulations for the investment banking business, now that the investment bankers' code has been approved and signed by President Roosevelt.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Montreal's Maroons defeated their local rivals, the Canadiens tonight, 4 to 1, in the second intra-city clash of the National Hockey League season. The result reduced the Habitants' lead in the International Division to a single point over Toronto.

Returns to date indicate that net operating income for October for all railroads in the United States not only declined on an annual basis for the first month since April, but that it moved contrary to the usual seasonal trend and below the September level.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28. -- George D. Widener's Chicstraw, a home-bred son of Chicle from Last Straw, won his third race in succession when he captured the featured $2,500 added Endurance Handicap at Bowie today. The dark bay colt was a 3-to-5 favorite and won by a length in 1:453-5 for the mile and seventy yards.
LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The problems confronting the wheat advisory committee were too much for it today, and the delegates adjourned after an inconclusive two-day meeting.

At a meeting last night at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, the council of the Fine Arts Federation of New York nominated three artists and three laymen whose names will be submitted to the Mayor as candidates for the two vacancies that will occur on Jan. 1 in the Municipal Art Commission.

Four hundred representatives of forty educational organizations, meeting last night in the Horace Mann Auditorium of Teachers College, Columbia University, adopted a resolution asserting that "the very existence of the American public school system is at stake" and urging Federal appropriation of "at least $1,000,000,000" to remedy the situation.
The incoming Fusion administration will have by Jan. 1 a complete program for employment of 200,000 under the Federal Civil Works Administration, Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia said yesterday.

Sales of department stores in the New York Federal Reserve district in October were 2 per cent less than last year, the Dec. 1 Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions by the Federal Reserve Agent at New York will say. The survey, as prepared, reads in part:

Alertness on the part of supervisors in the public schools and the maintenance of high standards of teachings are urged by Dr. William J. O'Shea in his forthcoming and final annual report as Superintendent of Schools, a part of which was made public yesterday.

Football arrives tomorrow at what used to be its traditional peak. Thanksgiving Day, in the past, was marked by a long list of games. However, in recent years, the holiday has been omitted on the majority of schedules, so that there remain only a few outstanding contests in the nation.

Soon or late most of us have to go to the hospital. If some manage to get on without its ministries, we have yet the comforting assurance that they are at hand for instant use whatever the malady or injury. The need of hospitals grows normally with the apartment and tenement mode of urban life.

New Yorkers are preparing to celebrate Thanksgiving tomorrow. Those to whom the city is home are planning to partake of the traditional feast here; those to whom New York is a place to earn a living are crowding planes, trains and other transportation to be at the spot they call home for their Thanksgiving turkey.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Dr. Alice Wynekoop's illness took a turn for the worse today as Charles S. Dougherty, Assistant State's Attorney, went ahead with plans to go before the Cook County grand jury tomorrow morning and ask for an indictment charging her with the murder of her daughter-in-law, Rheta.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 28. -- The New Jersey team won the triangular tournament in the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Greenwich Country Club this afternoon by defeating the New York representatives, 5 -- 2.

In October a Maryland Negro, accused of assault on an aged woman, was dragged out of jail by a mob and hanged. The county authorities, reflecting the diseased temperament of their public, took no real pains to bring any participants in the murder to justice.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Nov. 28. -- Lloyd Warner, a 19-year-old Negro, who confessed an attack on a white girl, was hanged to a tree on the court house lawn tonight by a mob which seized him in the county jail.

The need for supporting organizations which foster programs for profitable use of leisure time in this age of reduction in working hours was stressed by Gerard Swope, president of Greenwich House, in his annual report made public at a dinner of present and past residents of the institution last night at 27 Barrow Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The first legislation for the control of the liquor traffic in New Jersey was passed tonight by the House of Assembly by a vote of 50 to 2 (two Democrats, Assemblymen John V. Burke of Middlesex and Theron McCampbell of Monmouth, voting against the bill).

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Through former Judge Harry V. Osborne, his counsel, Julius J. Newmark today refused to accept a position offered to him by the State Highway Commission on the ground that it was not comparable to the one he held before dismissal last August and that the proposed salary was only about one-half that he previously received.

About 100 children of pre-school age contributed yesterday to the campaign of the women's division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee. Although they gave nothing material toward the $4,000,000 for the aid of established welfare organizations, they demonstrated the need for at least a part of this fund.

Army's undefeated cadets contributed three men, the husky arrays of Fordham and Pittsburgh two each, and unbeaten Princeton, Holy Cross, Duquesne and Columbia one man apiece to the all-Eastern football team selected yearly for The Associated Press by the men in the press box.

Doubling or tripling the Federal public works appropriation of $3,300,000,000 may be necessary to insure a large business pick-up, in the opinion of L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F.W. Dodge Corporation. Should the appropriation be increased, housing and other building work would figure more largely in the total, Mr. Schnitman believes.

Chancellor J.O. Wolcott of the Court of Chancery in Wilmington, Del., has directed the receivers of tha Electric Public Utilities Company to sell there on Feb. 1, 1934, at public sale to the highest bidder all assets of the company other than cash.

Nathan Burkan, attorney and Tammany district leader, was appointed chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority by Mayor O'Brien yesterday after George Gordon Battle had resigned from that post a few hours earlier.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 28. -- Called to the witness stand today to corroborate the charge of Victoria Price that a band of Negroes attacked her on a Southern Railway freight train nearly three years ago, Orville Gilley, a roving young minstrel of the South, added new contradictions to the Scottsboro case.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- In this series of ten articles I am going to discuss ways and means of extricating the country from depression.
Apartment houses in Jersey City, Hoboken, Bayonne, West New York and Union City were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

On the ground of alleged violation of the President's Re-employment Agreement, a suit for $1,000,000 damages and an injunction were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Harry Sherman, as president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators, against 150 independent theatre owners and corporations operating 420 neighborhood theatres in this area.

The objection of shipping men in thirty ports, represented by the Propeller Club of the United States, to the proposed merger of the Coast Guard Service with the Navy Department was expressed yesterday in messages to President Roosevelt, Secretary of Navy Swanson and members of Congress, including Senators Copeland and Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Virtually complete Federal control of the liquor traffic, at least until Congress meets and determines a policy of its own, became an official fact today, a week before the Eighteenth Amendment is to be dropped from the Constitution.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Stanley M. Bruce, Australian High Commissioner to London, in addressing the Empire Industries Association today urged a strong, resolute policy of British imperial cooperation independent of world trade.

Without lapsing entirely into inactivity, the stock market yesterday practically stood still. The twenty-five industrial stocks in THE NEW YORK TIMES index advanced .30 point, while the twenty-five rails moved exactly the same distance in the opposite direction.

Jim Londos, formerly recognized as world's champion, made his first start in this country since returning from Greece against Paul Boesch of Brooklyn in the feature finish wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night. After 33:02 of an exciting struggle Londos pinned his rival's shoulders to the mat with a crotch and body hold.
BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Eddie Shore's flukey goal in the last four minutes of play enabled the Boston Bruins to top the Ottawa Senators, 2 -- 1, in a well-played game tonight.

Announcement of the President's nomination of Mr. MARTIN CONBOY to be Federal Attorney for the Southern-District of New York was warmly greeted by the press, the public and the legal profession. His demonstrated ability, political independence and integrity of character made it seem a wonderful piece of luck to get him for such an office.
TORONTO, Nov. 28. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs overpowered New York's battling Americans tonight, 7 to 3, in a free-scoring game that kept a small crowd of 5,000 interested all the way.

All departments of the money market were quiet. Business was at a minimum, although funds were in good supply. On the Stock Exchange, 3/4 ruled for call loans, outside trades at 1/2@3/8. Time money ranged 3/4@1 1/4 for the near and distant maturities.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 28. -- Roger Touhy, Chicago gang leader, and three of his associates were acquitted by a Federal court jury here this afternoon of kidnapping William Hamm Jr., St. Paul brewer for $100,000 ransom. They were held in the county jail tonight while preparations were being made to transfer them to Chicago where they will face charges as the abductors of John (Jake the Barber) Factor, nationally known speculator.

The sites of three Indian settlements, undisturbed for 300 years or more, have been discovered in Palisades Interstate Park, only fifty miles from New York City, it was announced yesterday by William H. Carr, chief naturalist of the park, and assistant curator of the Department of Public Education of the American Museum of Natural History.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith denounced as "absolutely false" last night the story told here by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit priest, that Mr. Smith, accompanied by two Bishops, had visited the offices of J.P. Morgan Co. to arrange an "immense loan for the Empire State Building."

THE message was "On vous verra avec plaisir" (You must come over), and so, between the dark and the daylight (entre chien et loup), a call was made on a former resident of Amiens (Department de la Somme), who is spending the week at Madison Square Garden.
Eighty awards for intercollegiate athletic competition at Columbia University were announced yesterday by Robert F. Moore, assistant director of athletics.
NEW YORK. Lord Astor, who arrived on the Berengaria, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Bishop William T. Manning in a statement yesterday denounced the stand taken by Governor Rolph on the San Jose lynchings as a betrayal of trust and an affront to the people of the nation.

E.J. Kenney of Chicago paid the top price of $6,800 during the first day of the thirty-ninth annual Old Glory Sale of light harness horses, which opened yesterday morning in the Squadron A Armory at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- With Federal regulation in prospect, representatives of the grain Exchanges left Washington tonight after telling the government, in effect, that they would not be responsible for the administration of any code other than the one they submitted.

The engagement of Miss Veronica Balfe, who is known in talking pictures as Sandra Shaw, to Gary Cooper, the screen actor, was formally announced last night by Miss Balfe's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Shields, at a supper dance they gave for Miss Balfe and Mr. Cooper at their residence, 778 Park Avenue.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- For the second year in succession Mrs. J.H. Whitney of New York and Upperville, Va., won the International Challenge Cup for hunters when The Grey Knight, a 6-year-old gelding, outjumped a field of thirty horses at the Royal Horse Show tonight.
"Peace on Earth," by George Sklar and Albert Maltz, will open tonight at the Civic Repertory Theatre.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 28 (AP). -- A recurrence of the fullback trouble which marked the close of Notre Dame's great 1930 season was threatening today as Notre Dame went into serious drill for the finale with Army in New York Saturday.

ROUND HILL, Mass., Nov. 28. -- A steady, direct current lightning bolt of 7,000,000 volts, the most powerful man-made thunderbolt of its kind produced so far, was hurled here today from a man-made Olympus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The negotiations which led to the sale of the Leviathan and other vessels of the defunct United States Lines were described by R. Stanley Dollar today before the Senate committee investigating ocean mail contracts.

The Vanishing Stain. As between Governor ROLPH and the civilized instincts of the American people, the chances are still good that civilization will win. In the first five years of the present century, just a generation ago, lynch, law took an average of more than ninety persons a year.
A ghostly parade of the names of dead North Jersey beer runners added a macabre touch in Federal Court yesterday at the trial of Waxey Gordon for income tax evasion.
The death-knell of drinking practices -- and prices -- of the prohibition era was rung yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Society of Restaurateurs held at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.
VIENNA, Nov. 28. -- In the strange three-cornered fight now being wagred here for Austrian independence all is not going well.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Instead of clarifying the situation Chancellor Hitler's conversation with French Ambassador Andre Francois - Poncet last Friday in some ways confused it still further. For the Chancellor, it is believed, insisted primarily on one thing that France holds it is not within her power to grant -- settlement of the Saar situation.

Number of Buyers Down. Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a slight drop in comparison with the figures for the previous week. The total, however, remained well above the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago due to the Thanksgiving holiday falling a week earlier.

A committee of prominent New Yorkers headed by Mrs. Vincent Astor discovered yesterday that, at prices about three times as high as usually charged at Carnegie Hall, they had succeeded in selling only one-third of the seats for "The President's Concert," to be given there on Dec. 8 for the benefit of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation.

The eighth annual national interscholastic cross-country champion-ship run to be held at Branch Brook Park in Newark tomorrow morning has attracted 252 entries, according to Harry A. Coates, director of the event, which will be conducted under the auspices of Newark Prep.

A tea, with a fashion show, to further the work of the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals, was held yesterday in the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel, in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the home by Mrs. Harry Ulysses Kibbe.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- Creation of a State corporation which would have sole authority to sell liquor was proposed by the Mastick Tax Commission today. Under the plan the system of licensing retail dealers would be abandoned.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28. -- While Yale's opening line-up against Princeton next Saturday is expected to be the same as that which started the Harvard game, Captain Bob Lassiter and Bill Keesling, halfbacks, did not practice today because of leg bruises received at Cambridge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28. -- The financial report of the Harvard Athletic Association for the twelve months ending June 30, 1933, was announced today by Henry L. Shattuck, treasurer of Harvard College. It showed a decrease in gross receipts of $324,456.65, as compared with the previous year and a deficit of $57,064.78.

A spokesman for the beleaguered burlesque interests confessed yesterday to License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine that "not one new burlesque skit had been written in the last twenty years." The admission was made during a departmental hearing on performances at the New Gotham Theatre, which are under fire as indecent.

A good deal was said during the last campaign about Major LAGUARDIA'S "radical" leanings. In one sense the word means "that which goes to the root of a matter." It is fine to see the Mayor-elect manifesting, in one of his first interviews here since his return from the South, a tendency toward that kind of radicalism in the vital matter of city-planning.

Pursuing the new Harvard policy of league competition against natural rivals instituted last Spring, the Crimson yesterday entered its basketball team in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. Announcement of the move was made by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer of the circuit.

With the New York Orchestra, recruited from the ranks of unemployed musicians and throughly drilled through last Summer and the early part of this Summer, Nicolai Sokoloff gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra, which has excellent material, gave highly creditable performances.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Army righted its goal posts, which were blown down by the heavy gales of yesterday, pulled the tarpaulins off the frozen practice field and resumed its preparations for the Not re Dame game in a long workout on the plains today.

The estate of George Ehret, who came here from Germany in 1857 to found the brewery bearing his name, was appraised yesterday at $39,801,569 gross and $38,220,790 net. He owned 181 parcels of realty, including many valuable corners acquired originally for the liquor business, valued at $27,004,432.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 28. -- A record turn-out of seventy-five candidates reported for the opening practice of the Harvard varsity hockey squad in Boston Garden today. Practice lasted two hours.

ESSAYISTS, these days, are being quoted at a discount, but that may be the fault of the world, not the fault of the essayists. At any rate, both G.K. Chesterton and Christopher Morley keep up a steady flutter of feuilletons for the casual reader. Mr. Morley is represented in the book stores today with "Internal Revenue" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50).

U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York. General Conditions. Supplies of most classes were below normal. Trading, though not active, continued to improve and the market was steady to higher. The slaughter of cattle, vealers, calves and lambs was barely normal, and today's kill will be the last until Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Evidence of large initial profits to bankers who financed construction of the Detroit-Canada tunnel, on which investors lost more than $15,000,000, was presented to the committee.

Approval of the bout between Tony Canzoneri, former world's lightweight champion, and Acleto Locatelli, European titleholder, scheduled to take place in Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15, was given yesterday by the State Athletic Commission.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Alfred C. Read Jr., Oakland broker, whose former wife won a $75,000 judgment from Claire Windsor, blonde stage and screen actress, was convicted tonight by a municipal court jury on a charge of stealing $11 from the actress's purse on Oct. 14.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. is no better. His condition is about the same as it was a week ago, and whether or not he will spend the Winter in Florida is in the balance. He is in no danger.

Myron C. Taylor will retire as chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation on Jan. 1 and will be succeeded in that position by William J. Filbert, now vice chairman of the committee, it was announced yesterday.

Following is a list of new offices to be opened at 9 A.M. today and of offices already being operated by the National Re-employment Service in conjunction with the State Employment Service for registration of unemployed seeking jobs under the Civil Works Administration:

More than 400 persons ate last light a fifteen-cent dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the Golden Rule Foundation. The dinner was a prelude to the nationwide celebration of Golden Rule Week, Dec. 10 to Dec. 17, during which all who believe in the Golden Rule will be asked to live in their homes on special economy budgets and contribute the savings thus obtained to those who are less fortunate.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 28. -- Italy has offered to pay $1,000,000 on the $2,133,905 instalment of her debt due Dec. 15, it was announced at the State Department today. While indications pointed to acceptance of the offer, the proposal must be submitted to President Roosevelt at Warm Springs.

Additional official canvass figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections showed two changes in the voting results as reported election night. They showed that a Democrat instead of a Republican was victorious in the Fifty-third Aldermanic District, Brooklyn, and that a Republican instead of a Democrat won in the Nineteenth Assembly District of the same borough.
BUCHAREST, Nov. 28. -- Anti-Semitic disorders in Jassy increased in violence last night, forcing the military commander of the district to use his cavalry to end attacks on Jews.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Bishop Joachim Hossenfelder, militant leader of the Nazi German Christians and chief instigator of the crisis that has brought German Protestantism to the brink of religious civil war, resigned today as a member of the ecclesiastical ministry of the Reich Evangelical Church.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Liquidation was continued today by holders of December grain contracts on the Board of Trade, and while there was a sharp upturn early, the bulge caused renewed selling. Wheat prices closed well toward the inside levels of the day, although net gains were 1/2 to 5/8 cent.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 28. Mrs. James B. Given Jr., the medalist in the women's Carolina tournament, eliminated Mrs. Oscar Seeley of Mercer, Pa., by 6 and 5, in the first round today. The winner returned a 90, two better than, her qualifying score.

Dale Robinson of the Greco Fencing Academy defeated E.H. McLendon of the New York A.C. in a fence-off to win the novice foils fencing tourney conducted by the Amateur Fencers League of America at the New York A.C. last night.

Even before Congress meets, it is evident that the American people are going to discuss every phase of the money question. They will do it in mass meeting's and on the street corners. They will write letters to the newspapers-already they are sending them in floods-and will harangue each other in offices and clubs and on trains and steamships.
Former Judge Samuel Seabury is sailing today with Mrs. Seabury for Europe on the Cunarder Berengaria. Others sailing are:

The fourteen teams left in the six-day bicycle race continued to go through their paces at Madison Square Garden last night, showing no inclination to slacken the gruelling rate of speed that has characterized the grind since Sunday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- With twenty-five persons known to have died of amebic dysentery in the United States and Canada and 368 other cases reported in 118 American and Canadian cities, the medical profession is marshaling its forces to halt an epidemic.

Contributions to the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $4,000,000 now total 51,401,909, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, general chairman, at a report meeting of the commerce and industry division at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Under the heading "The Scarlet Letter," The Harvard Crimson today demanded a change in the method of awarding the major H for Harvard athletes, especially in those sports which do not readily permit last-minute substitutions.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- With the members of the Republican majority not in complete accord and the Democrats willing to let them take full responsibility for any errors of judgment that may be made, the Legislature met again tonight in an attempt to enact a liquor control code.

After an early firmness stimulated by the rise in the domestic gold price to $33.85 an ounce, a new high record, stocks drifted within a narrow range yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Government bonds, which had been advancing in the four previous sessions, declined and wiped out the previous day's grains.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The Nazi Government moved today for dissolution of the German labor unions which a year ago had 7,000,000 members and property worth hundreds of millions of marks. The unions were the strongest and richest in the world.

Engelberg Roell. treasurer of the Friends of New Germany, was committed to the Federal House of Detention yesterday to serve one day for contempt of court growing out of his refusal to produce the organization's membership list for the Federal grand jury.

Viscount Astor, publisher of The London Observer and husband of Lady Astor, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard liner Berengaria for a month's business visit. Five seats in the House of Commons are held by members of his immediate family, the last one to be elected to Parliament being Willoughby De Eresby, the Viscount's son-in-law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Newspaper readers, especially radical readers, have a right to complain of the current newspaper idiom which calls increased inflation a "swing to the Left." It is nothing of the sort; it bears no relation to any radical program of collectivism or a rational redistribution of wealth.

Liquid assets of the Bank of Montreal increased $50,000,000 in the year ended on Oct. 31 to 71.15 per cent of the bank's total liabilities to the public, the annual report shows. Total assets amounted to $768,535,908, virtually unchanged from a year before.

A young bride and bridegroom of Lawrence, Mass., who came to New York for their honeymoon, lost each other in the subway rush to Brooklyn late yesterday, and were reunited in a Brooklyn police station after more than three hours of anguish.

Frederick Brown, operator, reported yesterday that he had bought the four-story business building at 308 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-first and Thirty-second Streets, from Martha Krakeur. The parcel, including a plot 24.8 by 100 feet, is assessed at $185,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A bid of the Chevrolet Motor Company today of $629.19 per unit for 700 one-and-one-half-ton dump trucks for use in the Civilian Conservation Corps camps was $41.91 lower than one submitted by the Northwest Motor Company, a Ford dealer, of Bethesda, Md.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28. -- Yale's registration for the current school year was announced today as 5,475. The enrolment represented every State of the Union and twenty-nine foreign countries. Last year the registration was 5,631.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Princeton's varsity eleven went through a short offensive scrimmage against the scrubs today as Coach Fritz Crisler continued the drive for the Yale game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A promise that the United States will deal with other countries in the utmost frankness was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as he and his party arrived today at Montevideo to attend the Pan-American Conference.

An indictment charging violations of two sections of the election law was handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday against Pasquale Caffre, chairman of an election board in the public school at Elizabeth and Bayard Streets in the last elections.

The Society of American Etchers, Inc. (formerly the Brooklyn Society of Etchers) opened its eighteenth annual exhibition with a private view last evening at the National Arts Club. The exhibition will be open to the public beginning today and it remains through Christmas.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Thomas W. Lament united yesterday in a plea for public support of the campaign by which welfare agencies plan to raise $400,000 for the care of homeless children.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The Princeton football team was removed from the Hat of possible contestants in the annual Tournament of Roses game in Pasadena New Year's Day by action taken tonight by the board of control of the Princeton University Athletic Association.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- An agreement proposed by the NRA Regional Labor Board for ending the strike of 8,000 workmen in the Union Stock Yards was refused tonight by the strikers. They voted to remain on strike until the wage agreement satisfactory to them has been signed.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated in the House of Commons today that the British Government's attitude as to the American dollar's relation to the British pound was still one of watchful waiting.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Attorney General William Preston Lane Jr. tonight welcomed habeas corpus proceedings against any of the four alleged lynchers, arrested in Somerset County by troops this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The country has in operation a network of 2,400 Federal employment offices to place workers on jobs in private industry and on public and civil works projects, Secretary Perkins said today.

The Board of Estimate fell Into line yesterday with the new Federal program of unemployment relief under the Civil Works Administration by making appropriations which will assure the expenditure of 317,500,000 a month for relief until Feb. 15 and will give employment to scores of thousands of men and women in addition to the 110,000 persons now on emergency work lists in the city.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The British Admiralty has issued a report on an experiment in convoy protection in the Mediterranean last June, when a new system known as "evasive routing" was tried, apparently without success.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Security issues totaling about $4,600,000 are proposed in eight registrations under the Securities Act filed with the Federal Trade Commission and made public today.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $2,149,263 for the year ended on Oct. 31 after all deductions. Annual requirements for preferred dividends are $2,323,500. In the preceding year the company and its subsidiaries earned $4,554,292.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The first formal dance of the college year at New Jersey College for Women was held here tonight by the sophomore class. A Mardi Gras motif was followed in the decorations in the Science Building, where about 200 sophomores and their escorts danced.

A man and a woman were held on charges of arson last night after an investigation of a fire Monday night in an apartment on the fourth floor of a new eighteen-story apartment house at 235 East Twenty-second Street. Paintings and etchings insured for $10,000, according to the police, had been strewn on the floor of the apartment and fires started in a couch and a bed in an adjoining room.

Faith in the future of the railroads was expressed yesterday by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, at a luncheon of the Bond Club. He instanced improvements made by his company to show how the railroads should cope with changing conditions in transportation.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The Boerse had several fluctuations today but turned firm at the end and closed with gains ranging up to 4 per cent. The fluctuations were attributed to the month-end settlement, and the firmness was ascribed to continued optimistic reports from heavy industries and brighter export prospects, due to recovery of the dollar, which was quoted at 2.725 marks.

The United Hospital Fund announced yesterday that more than fifty business, trade and professional auxiliary committees had been formed to assist the fund in its annual campaign now in progress. The fund is seeking money for the care of needy patients in fifty-six voluntary hospitals.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 28. -- The Andrea Art Guild, a new association of Catholic priests and laymen, is sponsoring an advance showing of a collection of American contemporary art here. The new guild hall opened for the first time today.

Reacting to the increased gold price of the RFC and the consequent dip of the dollar in foreign exchange markets, prices for commodity futures moved higher yesterday in local markets. The major exception was sugar, which had advanced on Monday as other staples were declining.

Walter S. Franklin, vice president in charge of traffic of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was authorized yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission to serve also as president and a director of the Wabash Railway. He recently resigned as receiver for the Wabash and was succeeded by N.B. Pitcairn, formerly an official of the Pennsylvania.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 28. -- San Jose was returning to normal conditions today after the excitement attending the lynching of the kidnappers and slayers of Brooke Hart.
VIENNA, Nov. 28. -- Former Vice Chancellor Franz Winkler's statement that his Farmers party had been invited to join the Cabinet is denied by his successor, Vice Chancellor Emil Fey.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 28. -- Jackson L. Cannell tendered his resignation as head coach of the Dartmouth football team today In a one-sentence letter to Harry R. Heneagre, director of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission hinted today it might recommend the establishment of a definite rule for public utilities companies to follow in carrying on their books the assessments against them for benefits under New York State's river-regulating plan.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- J.B. Priestley, the novelist, who scored a success with his first play, "Dangerous Corner," is the author of a second play, "Laburnum Grove," which was produced in London at the Duchess Theatre tonight. Mr. Priestley has written a third play, "The Roundabout," which as yet has been produced in the provinces only.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Despite the political crisis, the still unbalanced budget, the treasury's lack of funds and speculation against the French currency which has been fostering rumors abroad, France has no intention and is under no necessity of abandoning the gold standard.

According to plain printing in the program, the title of the incident exhibited at the Playhouse last evening is "Strange Orchestra." "Potty Band" would fit it more exactly. Pardner, it don't make sense. Even if it were good it would require a syllabus before it could be translated into the mother tongue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Administration today fixed the price at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy newly mined gold at $33.85, nine cents above yesterday's quotation. Apparently the purpose was to check the rapid strengthening of the dollar in foreign exchange and head off further declines in commodity values.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The time seems to have arrived to provide for newspaper readers a key to the abbreviations and a glossary of the phrases of the administration and its critics. So swiftly and in such variety have the new government agencies come into being, and so long are their names, that most of them go by initials.
Fire swept the three-story frame clubhouse of the Atlantic Yacht Club on Poplar Avenue between Highland and Sea Gate Avenues in the Sea Gate section of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,253,750 barrels, compared with 2,307,100 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 53,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 24,700 barrels in the average output of Oklahoma, 16,900 barrels in that of California and 10,500 barrels in Texas were the most important changes for the week.
The doughboys have no bananas; the officers have no olives; tapioca is taboo and Japanese shrimp is not suited for a soldier's palate, the War Department has ruled.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28. -- Senator Huey P. Long stormed into the Senatorial investigation of the Broussard-Overton primary today to answer the charge that he had demanded, $5,000 from an oil and gas producer under the threat of sending the oil man to the penitentiary.

Dividend payments by the companies of the old Standard Oil group for the fourth quarter of this year are estimated at $42,457,920 by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. That is more than double the $19,546,576 disbursed in the preceding quarter and compares with $44,112,501 paid out in the final quarter of 1932.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 29. -- If the United States and British Governments are willing, Foreign Minister Hirota is prepared, to Initiate preliminary negotiations among the chief naval powers in preparation for the 1935 naval conference.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria has expressed to the German Minister in Vienna his formal regrets for the shooting on the Austro-German frontier of Philipp Schumacher, a German soldier, by Austrian border guards, it was announced here tonight.

SALISBURY, Md., Nov. 28. -- Mob terrorism unleashed its fury here today, causing 300 armed militiamen to beat a strategic retreat to Baltimore with four civilians whom the soldiers had routed out of bed long before daybreak and arrested in connection with the lynching of a Negro at Princess Anne on Oct. 18.

A decline of 60 points, or $3 a bale, from recent high levels reduced offerings from producing sections yesterday and sent prices on the Cotton Exchange a dollar a bale higher at one time. Strength in several other markets, an advance in the gold quotation and an increased demand from spinners steadied quotations, so that the list ended with net gains of 7 to 14 points.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28. -- Brown ended its preparation for the Colgate game with a comprehensive review of all departments of the game today. Coach McLaughry put his men through offensive and defensive scrimmage, with pass offense and defense figuring prominently in the afternoon's work.

"By and large, the American press is today more informative, better displayed and less irregular in its mannerisms than, say, the British press, which in its new phase is seemingly trying to find itself," R.D. Blumenfeld writes in "The Press in My Time," just published in London by Rich Cowen.

The Endicott Hotel, one of the landmarks of the upper West Side, was offered at voluntary auction in the Vesey Street salesroom yesterday and was struck down to the Endicott Securities Corporation, Diederich A. Christoffers, president, on a bid of $10,000 above a mortgage of $500,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 28. -- After deliberating two hours and five minutes, a jury in Union County Court tonight acquitted Nicholas Delmore, former Republican leader of Berkeley Heights, and Martin Podolsky of Newark, who were on trial charged with the murder of John G. Finiello, Federal prohibition agent.

TOKYO, Nov. 28. -- The newspapers report that the directors of the Tokyo Electric Light Company, Ltd., have decided to cancel the provision in debentures allowing holders cash in dollars or sterling at the former gold exchange rate. Since the fall of the dollar many American holders have been sending their coupons to London.

The farmer-sportsman cooperative hunting plant, inaugurated in New Jersey at the start of the present upland game bird season, rapidly is gaining wide public approval, according to Commissioner Benjamin W. Cooper of Moorestown, a member of the State's Fish and Game Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Albert H. Wiggin, former head of the Chase National Bank, admitted at the Senate stock market inquiry today that the Shermar Corporation, a Wiggin family institution, lost $2,079,355.44 in 1930 as a result of pool transactions in stock of General Theatres Equipment, Inc.

United States Government bonds led the decline in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday under the impetus of the increase in the administration's domestic gold-buying price and the consequent weakness of the dollar. The government issues dropped back 6-32 to 30-32 point for the active issues, aside from the called fourth Liberty 4 1/4s, which lost only 1-32 point, thus more than wiping out the advance of the previous day.

WINES and liqueurs cannot be used as legal aids to degustation this Thanksgiving, but it will be quite another matter next year, for which one may be thankful in advance. And one may prepare for the event by reading George Saintsbury's "Notes on a Cellar-Book," which Macmillan is reissuing for $2.50 with a foreword by Owen Wister.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 29 -- Secretary of State Hull held a half-hour conversation today with President Terra, but its scope was not announced.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- After asserting he was the illegitimate son of the Duke of Clarence, King George's elder brother, who died in 1892, Clarence Guy Gordon Haddon, 43 years old, a consulting engineer, was remanded in custody today after a hearing at Bow Street police court.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 29 -- In an impromptu talk with the members of a Civilian Conservation Corps camp on a hillside near here today President Roosevelt announced his intention to ask Congress for funds with which to continue the camps for another year.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sturges and Dr. Victor Corse Thorne jointly gave a dinner dance last night at the Ritz-Carlton for their respective daughters, Miss Catharine Armit Sturges and Miss Victoria Corse Thorne.

Camp Thomas Paine faced another Thanksgiving Day yesterday, in a truly thankful mood. Its choice river frontage, its admirable view of the sunsets, and its new oven in which turkey can be roasted instead of parboiled as it was last year, had combined to lift the spirits of Commander John B. Clark, and to tinge the faces of his men with some of the rosiness of the setting sun.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- A nude body discovered yesterday in a ditch outside the city limits was identified today as that of Verne C. Miller, 37 years old, who was said to have handled a machine gun that mowed down five men in the Kansas City Union Station massacre on June 17.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The two most controversial sections of the motion picture code -- the antiraiding clause and the salary curtailment provision -- were made inoperative by an Executive order issued when President Roosevelt signed the charter.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- With the first hunger marchers only two days' distance from the capital, unrest all over the country, alarm among the moneyed classes and complete disunion in Parliament both as to measures of financial reform and the policy to be adopted in regard to Germany, the chances of the Chautemps Cabinet's surviving even one week are considered today to be very small.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The "dead voter" appeared very much alive before the Senate committee investigating Senator John H. Overton's election today and testified he was "alive now and also was alive on election day."

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The Boerse saw considerable liquidation today, which depressed prices generally between 2 and 3 per cent and in individual cases even more. The drop was attributed in part to the month-end settlements, but in greater degree to profit-taking following the upward movement of the last three weeks.
Prices advanced 4 to 7 points yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, but the trading was the smallest since last Spring.

Sales of wholesale firms in the New York Federal Reserve district in October jumped 18 per cent ahead of those in the corresponding month last year, while chain-store sales generally were unchanged, says the December issue of the Monthly Review of Credit and Business by the Federal Reserve Agent at New York.

The tendency among prominent families toward frequent change of residence, with many families remaining in their country homes for the Winter, is shown by the New York Socal Register for 1934, which is being distributed to its subscribers.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Running through its entire repertoire of offensive and defensive formations, Army practically concluded its home preparations for the Notre Dame game today. Fine weather prevailed as the squad took its two hours of practice.

Net profit of the American Safety Razor Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was $485,936 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, equal to $2.43 a share on 200,000 no-par shares outstanding. This compares with $472,663, or $2.36 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The second big horse-racing meet in Texas since betting became legal three months ago will open tomorrow at the new Epsom Downs track near Houston.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- A coast-to-coast investigation by Department of Justice agents and postal officials was started here tonight after Miss Helen Jacobs, women's national tennis champion, had turned over to Francis J. W. Ford, United States Attorney, a number of objectionable letters she received while visiting friends at 25 Pilgrim Road, Melrose.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- An increase of eight cents in the price which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will pay for newly mined domestic gold was made by the administration today as rumors multiplied in the capital as to further steps which will be taken in carrying out the new monetary policy.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has awarded a contract to Stone Webster, New York engineers, to design an experimental fertilizer plant at Muscle Shoals, Ala.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Conservative anxiety over a charge that Britain had fallen to fifth place as an air power forced a debate in both houses of Parliament tonight when resolutions were adopted condemning its inadequacy.
WARM SPRINGS, Nov. 29 -- Joseph H. Choate Jr. of New York City was designated virtual "liquor czar" by President Roosevelt today.

GLASGOW, Nov. 29 -- A crack eleven from Austria today held the best team Scotland could produce to a 2-2 draw, in an international soccer classic that attracted a crowd of 62,000 despite dull weather conditions. The grounds were dry, however.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The lynching at San Jose, Calif., of Thomas H. Thurmond and Jack Holmes, self-confessed kidnappers, brings into striking relief a few phases of social justice and criminal law. It seems to me that hardly any one will doubt the self-confessed kidnappers received a punishment which fits the crime.

COATESVILLE, Pa., Nov. 29 -- In a shallow grave in a Chester County cornfield the bodies of two young women were found today. They had been slain because of their knowledge of the shooting of two gangsters near Camden, N.J., on Nov. 1.

Contributions totaling $213,443 to the fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced yesterday at the second report luncheon of the women's division of the committee at the Waldorf-Astoria, bringing the total raised by the division to $576,819.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Nov. 29 -- In a small court room charged with the emotions of hundreds of grim looking sympathizers, the four men arrested early yesterday by National Guardsmen in connection with the lynching of a Negro here last month were discharged late this afternoon.

Officials of the National Recovery Administratibn in New York and Washington took drastic action yesterday for the first time against a large employer for violation of the President's re-employment agreement. The action was taken against Loft, Inc., a concern operating a large chain of candy stores and restaurants through the country.
A Federal anti-lynching bill will be introduced in the United States Senate in January, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Penn- , sylvania and Cornell, both striving to redeem an otherwise erratic season, will meet in their fortieth annual football game on Franklin Field tomorrow.

The jurisdiction of the Jockey Club over the State of West Virginia, an authority which dated back to the nineteenth century, when racing in the United States was divided into three areas, was withdrawn at a meeting of the stewards yesterday.

Immediate application for loans of $39,122,643 from the Public Works Administration will be made to provide for a number of important city improvements. Mayor O'Brien said yesterday after signing the applications.

James Brown, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, which has played an important part in the movement for a return to the gold standard, issued a warning yesterday directed equally against Congressional decision of monetary policy and against "the inflammatory exhortations of demagogues."

All security and commodity markets throughout the country, as well as all banks, will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. The markets will reopen as usual tomorrow. Attention will be directed today to the fluctuations of the dollar in foreign countries and to the movements of securities abroad.

Germany's Church Battle. From the Protestant churches has come the sharpest challenge to the Hitler doctrine of "coordination." The Nazi zealots mean by coordination that 70,000,000 Germans, their beliefs, practices, traditions, instincts are so much clay in the hands of the potter, for HITLER to do with absolutely as he pleased.

While 15,000 additional unemployed registered yesterday in government re-employment offices throughout the city for jobs under the Civil Works Administration, the first batch of pay checks under the Federal civil works program was distributed here.

Metropolitan fans who like their football with their turkey will need to be up early and on their way this morning, for the nearest college attraction at hand is the Penn-Cornell classic starting at 2 o'clock at Franklin Field, Philadelphia.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Miss Adelaide H. Childs Frick was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Childs Frick, at Clayton, their country home here. The guests were members of the younger set of New York and the North Shore colonies, many of whom arrived home today from college with house guests.
Numerous apartment rentals on the West Side of Manhattan were reported yesterday, in addition to scattered leasing on the East Side. Among the lessees were the following:

Jerome Blum of Chicago and the wide world, is exhibiting at the Delphic Studios. This is his first one-man show in New York since the Winter of 1929, when his work was on view at the old Anderson Galleries.

The Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York has addressed to President Roosevelt a letter protesting against the refusal of the Interstate Commerce Commission to suspend the "store-door" tariffs of the Pennsylvania, Erie and Grand Trunk Railroads for less-than-carload freight, as requested by seventeen competing railroads, terminal companies and trucking interests.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The $260,000 Mousquetaire, largest yacht in the Great South Bay, has been purchased by the Point o' Woods Ferry Corporation, it was announced yesterday, and will be commissioned in the regular ferry service between Bay Shore and Point o' Woods next season.
New York State's hunting and fishing regulations are among the most liberal and most wisely formulated in the country, in the opinion of leading conservation authorities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- An indictment charging Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop with the unaided murder of her daughter-in-law, Rheta, was returned by the Cook County grand jury today before Chief Justice Philip L. Sullivan in the Criminal Court.

Radoye Yankovich, Yugoslav Consul General in this city, acted as arresting officer last night in District Attorney Crain's office when he took into custody Darlton M. Costick, 44 years old, an insurance broker of 72 Seaman Avenue, on a grand larceny charge.

Mrs. Leila Roosevelt Denis and her companion and mechanic, Miss Edna Olmstead, have completed more than two-thirds of their 10,000-mile overland automobile trip from Antwerp to Singapore, according to word, received here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- An unexpected announcement that the Argentine Government would pay minimum levels for wheat, corn and flax to farmers confused the grain trade today, both here and abroad. General buying developed, causing sharply higher prices.

The nation-wide sale of Christmas seals by more than 2,000 organizations affiliated with the National Tuberculosis Association will be opened today and continue until Christmas Day. In New York City three associations will conduct drives.

It would take a stubborn optimist to deny that clouds hang over this Thanksgiving Day. Yet Americans still have their invincible habit of pointing to where "cheerfulness breaks through." They will seek to find compensation even for the outbursts of primitive savagery in California and Maryland and Missouri on the very eve of the day set apart for the nation to "consider its mercies."

Claims that Charles P. Doelger, vice president of Peter Doelger, Inc., a real estate concern, was not a bankrupt and that "he was being crucified by one creditor" were made yesterday by Owen S.M. Tierney, attorney for Mr. Doelger, at a bankruptcy hearing before Referee Irwin Kurtz at his office, 15 Park Row.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 29 -- Eugene R. Black, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, came here today to assure President Roosevelt of the cooperation of the Federal Reserve System with the Treasury Department in the administration's monetary policy.

Accusations of simple assault were made against Ed Wynn, comedian; Fred Zweifel, his manager, and Albert Baron, Wynn's secretary, in Yorkville Court yesterday by Morris Newman, a process server. Newman said that when he went to Wynn's apartment at the Berkshire Hotel, 21 East Fifty-second Street, to serve certain legal notices the three men attacked him.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 29 -- Anti-Semitic students scored a victory over their Jewish colleagues at the Technical College here today when they forced them, in accordance with a demand formulated at a meeting of Nationalist students last night, to occupy only the two left-hand seats in each row of benches in the classrooms.

BERLIN, Thursday, Nov. 30 -- The crisis in the German Evangelical Church created by the triple split of the more moderate Nazi German Christians, their extremist Teutonizing wing and the old-line Protestants reached an acute stage last night with the resignation of the ecclesiastical Ministry or Cabinet of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller.
Two more riders made a strong bid for the lead and the favor of the crowd at the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden last night.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Nov. 29 -- A State investigation ordered by Governor Park was begun here today into the lynching last night of Lloyd Warner, 19-year-old Negro accused of attacking a white girl.

WOODBURY, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Mrs. Audrey Smith Clark of Paulsboro was freed today after being under arrest in the Underwood Hospital here since the fatal shooting of her husband, Sheldon A. Clark Jr., on Nov. 20. An impounded report of the Gloucester County grand jury, which failed to return a true bill against the former musical comedy dancer, was made public at noon and the news was conveyed to Mrs. Clark by her attorney.
Because of a $760,000 deficit in the police pension funds, regular monthly pension checks were not available yesterday to beneficiaries who applied for them at police headquarters.

Denying a new trial to James Cahill, a dismissed policeman now serving a twenty to forty year term in Sing Sing for a hold-up, General Sessions Judge Collins ordered yesterday an investigation of an alleged attempt to intimidate a material witness.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- The New Jersey Liquor Control Bill was passed by the Legislature shortly before 7 o'clock this morning despite the informal opinion of Attorney General Stevens that one of the major provisions of the measure was unconstitutional.
Many annual Thanksgiving Day rivalries will be renewed among the feature games on today's card of fifty schoolboy football contests listed for fields in the metropolitan district.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- It is a fact that Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, author of the monetary amendment, and most of those government experts who consent to give a curbstone opinion believe that nothing in the amendment authorizes the President to stabilize the dollar on a commodity price basis.

WOODMERE, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick gave a dinner and later a supper dance this evening at the Rockaway Hunting Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Louisa B. Herrick.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Nov. 27:

A two-weeks lay-off of their companies instead of the usual one-week recess before the Christmas holidays will be permitted legitimate theatrical managers this year by the Actors Equity Association. This action was taken by the Equity Council because of economic condiions in the theatre today, according to Frank Gillmore, president if Equity.

Two armed and masked bandits held up and robbed James H. McGraw, 73-year-old publisher, in a washroom adjoining his office in his company's building in West Forty-second Street yesterday afternoon. Mr. McGraw, chairman of the board of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Co., Inc., did not give up without a struggle in spite of the two pistols, one of which was pointed at his head, the other at his heart.

At the risk of appearing to go over the heads of the present city administration, and freely admitting a lack of official powers, Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia stepped in yesterday and virtually took charge of the project to put 200,000 of the city's needy to work with funds to be furnished by the Federal Civil Works Administration.

The Louisville Hydro-Electric Company is planning to ask a rehearing on its case before the Federal Power Commission, which announced its decision disallowing certain items of cost on Monday, according to John J. O'Brien, president of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Byllesby Engineering and Management Corporation.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 29 -- The United States touring field hockey team, composed of eleven young women from the East, today avenged the setback it suffered last Sunday by defeating the Southeast eleven, 5 to 2, in the opening of the national tournament at Dyche Stadium.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- The Princeton football squad went through a hard three-hour practice today in the last contact session in preparation for the Yale game at New Haven Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Responsible officials of the administration today disclosed that the government intended to use its authority over liquor importations as an instrument with which to open more markets for American exports.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 29 -- Brown and Colgate, both at top strength, will play their annual Thanksgiving Day game tomorrow morning.

The central question raised by the Mastick report is whether a State monopoly in the sale of alcoholic spirits is preferable to licensing. When liquor returns legally to New York next Tuesday it will be on the latter basis. The Mulrooney commission, which has authority to prescribe temporary regulations, has favored this method and is now issuing licenses to distillers, wholesalers and retailers for "off premises" and for "on premises" consumption.

The estate of Mrs. Sarah J. Brooks, widow of James Brooks, was appraised yesterday at $1,416,427 gross and $1,322,543 net, of which $253,715 was in securities and $831,014 in real estate, comprising thirty-two parcels. The most valuable was 369-71 West Fifty-sixth Street, appraised at $120,750.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Former President Hoover was among those who signed a statement issued here today deploring the San Jose lynching of Thomas H. Thurmond and John M. Holmes and "the laudation of the deed" by Governor Rolph.

Not Waxey Gordon, but two men now dead were the kingpins of the beer industry in the golden era between 1929 and 1931, Gordon will testify when he takes the stand today at his trial for income tax evasion. Defense counsel revealed this last night just after the government rested its case.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The indignation of the British over Japanese underselling of Manchester in manufactured cotton goods throughout the world's markets came to a climax today in the House of Commons with the assurance from Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, that the government would defend British industry against Japan.

Contributions and pledges totaling $90,669 to date were announced yesterday by the United Hospital Fund of New York. A letter from Governor Lehman supporting the fund's annual drive was made public by Henry J. Fisher, president of the fund. It follows:

Expect Xmas Spurt Next Week. A sharp pick-up in Christmas trade is expected next week, affording the first real test of the probable trend of consumer holiday buying, retail executives here said yesterday. While efforts were made this week and last to develop early gift shopping, the results have indicated quite strong adherence on the part of the many of the public to the notion that such shopping should be done after Thanksgiving.

William C. Bullitt, first United States Ambassador to the Soviet Republic, sailed yesterday on the President Harding of the United States Lines on his way to Moscow to take up his new post. He was accompanied by his 9-year-old daughter, Anne, and Keith Merrill, who is in charge of building and housing for the State Department.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- That France is ready to negotiate tariffs with the United States in exchange for a big wine quota was indicated today in government quarters. The wine group in the Chamber of Deputies already has asked the government to use France's unfavorable trade balance with America to bargain for a special quota of French wines.

HAVANA, Nov. 29 -- Ambassador Sumner Welles, after an absence of twelve days, returned to Havana this morning by airplane and was met by a cheering throng. An expected demonstration by students supporting the Grau San Martin government, who had threatened to prevent his landing, failed to take place.

In churches, homes, restaurants and welfare agencies New York's millions will gather today to celebrate Thanksgiving. Turkey -- at the lowest price in years -- cranberry sauce and "all the trimmings" will weight the holiday board.

ATLANTA. Nov. 29 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent fifteen minutes walking across railroad tracks in the Terminal Station here late today because an excited trainmaster could not find the train to Warm Springs.

Seven faculty members of Columbia University issued an appeal yesterday to their colleagues in the university to protest against the appearance of Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, on the Morningside Heights campus.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29 -- The fleet sprinter Miss Merriment, owned by the Dorwood Stable, gained a nose decision in the Galena Purse, feature at Bowie today. The hustling ride of Hank Mills did much to decide the issue, for he threw all his power into the finish and just got the daughter of High Time across the line a winner at $7.40 for $2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United Mine Workers of America requested the National Labor Board today to consider charges against the H.C. Frick Coke Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, which is accused of violating the National Recovery Act.

A verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree in the shooting of Patrolman George L. Gerhard in a hold-up Dec. 14 was returned by a jury in Judge Rosalsky's part of General Sessions yesterday against William G. Vogel, 25 years old, who gave his address as 109 West 103d Street.

Steamship piers are piling up with gifts and table delicacies, arriving from all parts of the world, and ships are heading for New York laden with all kinds of rare seasonal articles for Christmas, according to operators in a variety of trades.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 29 -- The court-martial war resumed at Surabaya, Java, of the second group of mutineers from the Dutch battleship DeZeven Provincien, all of whom are Europeans.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The nationwide recruiting campaign to enlist every German "Aryan" worker with "fist and brow" in the German Labor Front was started today by the National Socialist shop cell organization, known as the NSBO, which governs the Labor Front and labor unions.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, defender of President Roosevelt's monetary policies, made a second attack tonight on Alfred E. Smith for his opposition to those policies, declaring that Mr. Smith "has written his own obituary notice in lining up with the philosophy of the Morgans."

The domestic price of gold was advanced again yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the new rate posted being $33.93 an ounce, a gain of 8 cents over the previous day. Foreign exchange rates moved higher, but later declined.
BUFFALO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Katherine Cornell played her first Shakespearean role here tonight, that of Juliet in a "Romeo and Juliet" staged in Forty-second Street Tempo. Basil Rathbone was Romeo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- "Political and financial" ramifications of the Eighth Avenue subway line in New York City are holding up allotment by the Public Works Administration of $22,500,000 to $25,000,000 for completion of the line, Secretary Ickes said today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29 -- Two of Yale's injured stars, Earl Nikkel and Captain Lassiter, reported for practice today on Anthony Thompson Field, but only Nikkel took part in the drill. Bill Keesling, the other injured member of Yale's regular back field, was not in uniform.

In the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday United States Government bonds followed the dollar downward during the forenoon, reflecting the mark-up of 8 cents in the domestic gold-buying rate, and domestic corporation issues followed the government bonds into lower grounds.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Westchester County was enabled today to avoid a default on its obligations when four banks in New York City and thirty in this county consented to make the loans that were needed after officials had obtained maximum credits from every other possible source.

An encouraging sign in the real estate market yesterday was an announcement by Phillips Co. of the resale of 30 West Ninetieth Street by Daniel Brener, an operator, after he had held it only about a week.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Argentina's national economic restoration plan received an impetus today with the institution of minimum prices for wheat, corn and flax and the partial removal of exchange control.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A cotton reduction contract providing for Federal rental payments of from slightly less than $3 an acre to a maximum of $18 was offered today to Southern growers by the Farm Administration.

PARIS, Nov. 21 (By Mail) -- A note suggestive of the Middle Ages has been launched by Lanvin in midwinter evening styles. Rich velvets worked with golden embroidery and regal furs fashion trailing robes and wraps reminiscent of those worn by the chatelaines of medieval castles.

Price movements for commodities traded on local exchanges were narrow yesterday in most cases, but the trend was generally higher. The volume of trading in most of the markets was smaller than had been customary of late. Most cash prices were quoted at higher levels.

Propaganda plays like "Peace on Earth," which was staged at the Civic Repertory last evening, raise questions that have never been answered satisfactorily. The current incitement in the interests of peace is based on a hypothetical incident; it is hysterically written and crudely presented and it is not likely to convince any one who stands in need of conviction.

The first important modification in the new liquor control rules was announced yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, a ruling that may possibly double the number of licensed retail liquor stores.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Nila Cram Cook, who fled Mahatma Gandhi's seminary in search of thrills, has had an offer of a movie contract.

A yearling filly was bought for $3,000 yesterday "sight unseen" at the Old Glory sale of light harness horses in the Squadron A Armory. The yearling in this most unusual transaction was the bay filly Lyric, by Peter Volo out of Zombelle, she by Guy Axworthy.

Directors of the International Silver Company, after adopting a resolution to aid recovery, voted yesterday to resume dividend payments on the $7 cumulative preferred stock. A dividend of $1 a share, payable Jan. 1 to stock of record Dec. 13, was voted.

Captain R.C. Winchester, United States military attache at Warsaw, and Mrs. Winchester are arriving today from the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Others aboard will be Mrs. Harry Whitney Brown, E.A. Baldwin, Mrs. Dennis King, Colonel D. John Markey, David Darrah, Mr. and Mrs. Roy Durstine, Brig. Gen. Wallace Wright, Mrs. Wilson Cross and Miss Alethia Serpell.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Purcell Mellon will give a dinner dance tonight in the Georgian Room of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Churchill Mellon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Following is the text of the statement by W.W. Aldrich before the Senate subcommittee today:

SACRAMENTO, Nov. 29 -- Kidnappings, murder, gangsterism and racketeering have grown up in this country to terrible proportions. There is no security of property. There is no security of life. Mothers even fear to permit their children long out of their sight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- General Johnson received a new defeat today in his attempt to prevent Henry Ford from receiving contracts from the government.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported no change yesterday in its rediscount rate from the 2 per cent level which has prevailed since Oct. 20, last. Because today is a holiday, the usual Thursday meeting of the directors was held yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- More than 5,000 music lovers last night were guests of the city and the San Francisco Opera Association at an elaborate remote-control electric reproduction in the municipal auditorium of the complete performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" as it was given only one block away in the War Memorial Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- In disclosing at the liquor importers' code hearing today the government's intention to bargain with foreign liquor exporting countries for lowering their trade barriers against American products, Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to Secretary Wallace, testified that France, Germany and Italy were the largest wine-exporting nations and that these nations had imposed more restrictions against American farm products than most countries.

A further advance by the RFC of 8 cents in the price of gold yesterday was attended by a renewed decline in the dollar, but it did not persist and a sharp rally in later dealings resulted in a 53 point gain in the gold value of the dollar for the day.

Reflecting moderate releases on specifications, steel mill operations are again running somewhat ahead of the weekly schedules as announced by the American Iron and Steel Institute, and are averaging close to 28 per cent of capacity, compared with 27 1/2 per cent a week ago, according to The Iron Age.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The dollar's downward trend, resumed yesterday afternoon when news of the advance in the RFC's gold price reached here, continued today. Complete disbelief replaced hopes here that the dollar would be stabilized, and the United States currency quickly slid to an official closing of 16.11 francs, against 16.67 francs yesterday.
One policeman was seriously wounded in a dance hall brawl at 2,310 Ryder Street, Brooklyn, early this morning and a detective sergeant was held for questioning in connection with the shooting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A drastic new deal in American banking was advocated today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board and president of the Chase National Bank, in a formal proposal for remedial legislation, made to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Seventeen institutions receive legacies in the will of Moe J. Fisher, cloak and suit merchant, who was killed in a fall from a window of his apartment at 280 Riverside Drive on Oct. 27, it was disclosed yesterday when his testament was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Out of probably the closest race for individual honors in a decade, the outstanding aces of Michigan, Iowa, Purdue, Minnesota and Ohio State won berths on the 1933 all-star Big Ten football team as selected by The Associated Press.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The threat of a default by this city on its tax notes held by banks in New York has been lifted as a result of willingness of the City Commission to accept the conditions of the three-year financing plan offered by the Citizens' Advisory Finance Committee, Reginald Parnell, director of revenue and finance, announced today.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 29 -- An issue which has plagued the State of Alabama for nearly three years was argrued again today before a Morgan County jury which tomorrow will be asked to decide whether Heywood Patterson, a Negro, shall live or die.
Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald ordered yesterday the routine quarterly shift of magistrates' court attendants and assistant clerks, affecting fifty-seven persons.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- European countries, in particular Germany and England, have imported thousands of barrels of apples from the Hudson River Valley this Fall.

Judge and Mrs. Edward Ridley Finch gave a dance last night at their home, 21 East Eighty-fourth Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Noelle Finch. Earlier this month, Judge and Mrs. Finch had given three afternoon receptions for their daughter.

Reclamation of the Democratic party in the city and support meanwhile of the LaGuardia administration were urged yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., recent Recovery party candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen.

Herbert German, whose new novel, "Jonathan Bishop," has just been published by Farrar Rinehart, is now abroad finishing his biography of James Joyce, "The Man From Dublin," and preparing to start on a new novel.
