A woman was burned to death and seven persons were injured, two of them seriously, last night when a fire broke out in the fifth-floor apartment of Miss Rose Mason at 296 West Tenth Street during a Thanksgiving Eve party.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Ex-Judge Henry Nichols Blake, oldest surviving graduate of the Harvard Law School and first Chief Justice of Montana after Statehood was granted, died here today at the age of 95 after a fortnight's illness. He was a Civil War veteran.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Philip H. Johnson, architect and widely known yachtsman, died of a heart ailment today in the Taylor Hospital at Ridley Park. He was 65 years old.

Isidor J. Kresel, noted lawyer, who had been in the Tombs since he was sentenced on Monday to from one and a half to two years and a half in Sing Sing for aiding and abetting in the misapplication of $2,914,000 belonging to the Municipal Safe Deposit Company, an affiliate of the Bank of United States, was released last night in $10,000 bail.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Activities in the Union Stock Yards, which were crippled during the two-day strike of about 8,000 workmen, returned to normal today as the men went back to their jobs under a truce arranged by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, chairman of the NRA Regional Labor Board.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Digging deep in his frayed trick bag for some scheme to beat the Army, Coach Hunk Anderson today came up with John (Red) Tobin and decided to make him a fullback for the last stand against the untamed West Point Mule.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Eighty-three per cent of the non-member banks of the Federal Reserve System which have made application for admission to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have received the approval of supervising examiners.

Plans for the most ambitious schedule ever attempted in Tight harness horse racing are under way in the Grand Circuit for 1934 with a tentative program calling for race meetings throughout the South and Southwest, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Normal trading operations in the market for hogs here were resumed today. The best hogs sold at $3.90 a hundred-weight, or 10 cents under the scattered lots that were sold late yesterday, and the general market was about in line with most of trade of the previous day.

The death of JAMES LAURENCE LAUGHLIN at 83 ends a notable career not only of economic teaching but of aggressive leadership in defending the principles of sound money. With a knowledge of economic theory and history possibly unequaled among American teachers, he was for half a century a continuous and unsparing fighter against the recurrent popular mania for greenback inflation, free-silver coinage, or depreciation of the money standard.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn gave a supper dance tonight at their country home here to introduce their second daughter, Miss Katharyn Steele Milburn. The guests included the debutante set of the North Shore and many students home from school and college for the holiday as well as the hosts' house guests.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The broad silk strike, which for fourteen weeks paralyzed the industry here, was settled today when organized silk workers formally approved peace terms. The agreement will be signed Friday and the workers will return to the mills Monday morning.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 29 -- The $3,300,000,000 public works fund, of which only about $150,000,000 remains unallocated or not earmarked, will be completely disposed of within three weeks, it was announced at the "Winter White House" today.

Five new three-year deacons, four three-year trustees, one two-year trustee and a church clerk were elected last night at the annual corporate meeting of the congregation of the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive.
Residential properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Urging support for W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, in his fight to prevent re-election of Fred W. Hammond as clerk of the Assembly, William Ziegler Jr., State Treasurer, sent a letter to county chairmen through the State denouncing present Assembly control as being dominated by the public utility interests.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 -- The International Army Officers Team Challenge Trophy, donated by the Hon. G. Howard Ferguson, Canadian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom, was won by the Irish Free State officers at the Royal Horse Show tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- The forty-five day meeting at Jefferson, Park will get under way tomorrow with the $1,200 added Thanksgiving Handicap featuring a seven-race program. Eleven have been entered for the main event.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- Thanksgiving Day was the same as any other day for the Yale football eleven, as Coach Reggie Root put his charges through a long drill today.
The Green Bay Packers routed the Stapleton eleven, 21 to 0, in an exhibition game before 4,000 spectators at Thompson's Stadium on Staten Island yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Official and resident society was well represented tonight at the navy relief ball. This dance, for more than a quarter of a century the finale of Thanksgiving Day at the capital, proved a colorful event. Family dinners and debutante teas preceding the ball made up a crowded day for the younger set.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Ambassador Robert W. Bingham came to the defense of President Roosevelt's monetary policies tonight in a hard-hitting speech which stirred the American Society in London to enthusiasm.

Coast Guardsmen were searching the waters of Long Island Sound off Northport, while State troopers were combing the shore last night for two men who had failed to return from duck hunting on the Sound. They had left early yesterday morning in a rowboat from Crab Meadow Beach, about half a mile from Northport.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Farm Administration today revised its corn processing tax regulations so as to continue the present five cents a bushel tax instead of increasing the rate to 20 cents at midnight tonight as originally provided.
The United States lifter Manhattan, commanded by Captain A.B. Rand all, commodore of the company's fleet, arrived yesterday with 498 passengers, one owl and one turkey.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- Following a conference today with W. Preston Lane Jr., Attorney General, and other advisers, Governor Ritchie announced that the Executive and State law departments would take no further steps to bring to trial the lynchers of George Armwood, Negro, and that the entire case is now in the hands of the three judges of the First judicial district.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 30. -- Members of the United States delegation to the Pan-American Conference received today with keenest interest news from Buenos Aires that Argentina had launched a national recovery plan very similar to President Roosevelt's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- President Roosevelt was urged today in a telegram sent by the Public Affairs Committee of the Socialist party and signed by Norman Thomas and Louis Waldman, chairman of the committee, "to make a public appeal against lawlessness and mob lynching in an effort to stem the lynching wave."
Politics, economics, science and the freedom of the press were among the topics on which were based the Thanksgiving Day sermons preached in New York City churches yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Alice L. Wynekoop looked up from her Bible in the county jail today and told her jailers she would not live to go on trial for murdering her daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 30. -- A greatly superior Tennessee team today defeated Kentucky, 27 to 0, before 15,000 persons. Most of the play was in the Wildcats' territory, and they never seriously threatened to score on the Volunteers. The victors rolled up thirteen first downs to three for Kentucky.

ROME, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The feeling that American cotton might form the basis of an Italo-Soviet agreement when Premier Mussolini and Maxim Litvinoff meet shortly was current in business circles here tonight. The Russian Commissar of Foreign Affairs will arrive in Italy Dec. 2 from his recent visit to the United States.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Confronted with the biggest crisis that the German Protestant Church has faced since its birth during the Reformation, Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, Chancellor Hitler's own confidant in church affairs, began a difficult struggle today to save his own authority from the present wreck of his program of coordination of the church with the Nazi State.

Dr. James T. Shotwell of Columbia University, who is head of the Division of Economics and History of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, discussed several outstanding qualities of Sir Arthur Currie last evening at his office in this city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Organized labor in the building trades is drawing up objections to the newly proposed code in the construction industry.

"Sitting Pretty," with a cast including Jack Oakie, Ginger Rogers and Jack Haley, opens at the Paramount this morning. Gary Cooper, Raquel Torres and Sari Maritza will appear together on the stage in a travesty on "Design for Living," in which Mr. Cooper is featured on the screen of the Criterion.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The Princeton football squad staged its last practice of the year on University Field this morning in a spirited two-hour workout in preparation for the Yale game at New Haven Saturday.

John Biedrzycki, 14 years old, left the tenement house at 311 Seventh Street, Jersey City, where he and his family occupy a small flat, yesterday noon to gather firewood for the heating and cooking stoves. He started out with a short-handled axe, not intending to be gone long, since his mother, Lottie, was waiting for the fuel to cook the Thanks-giving dinner.

Lion Feuchtwanger is one of the most skilful of historical novelists; Maurice Schwartz is one of the most assiduous adapters of novels, and often historical novels, for the stage. Last night at the Yiddish Art Theatre the latter presented his version of Mr. Feuchtwanger's latest work, "Josephus," and it must be reported that the novel's' still the thing.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Army Eats at Home. The War Department Was come to the defense of the home market. Orders have gone out that the army must "eat American." The interdict on foreign foods does not spare even the humble and universal banana -- unless human ingenuity should discover a way of doing something to the foreign-grown banana after its arrival on American soil.

October wages were slightly higher on an average than in July and hours of work were lower, but the cost of living rose more than the wage level, according to the monthly report of the National Industrial Conference Board. Industrial recovery was pronounced after March, but since the peak in July the indices of production show some recession, the report asserts.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 30. -- Driving their little cockle-shell of a boat, Feather, through squalls that capsized two other craft and kept some skippers ashore, Sheridan and Bruce Fahnestock took the honors in the North Hempstead Yacht Club's dinghy regatta on Manhasset Bay today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Pennsylvania is ready to enter the liquor business under a control system which Governor Pinchot describes as the "best in America." He signed yesterday the McClure Bill creating a State liquor monopoly and designating the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board as the only agency through which citizens may obtain their alconolic supplies after Jan. 1.
FARIS, Nov. 30. -- The French will start removing the 15 per cent surtax against British goods on Dec. 6, it was reported today.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 30. -- Smashing his way sixty yards on eleven consecutive power plays, Eck Alien scored a touchdown that gave West Virginia's eleven a 7-to-2 victory today in its traditional game with Washington and Jefferson.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- New York State cities are granting more nearly adequate public relief on a more intelligent basis, but perfection has not yet been attained, according to a report made by Hugh R. Jackson after a survey under the joint auspices of the Bureau of Training and Research of the State Conference of Mayors and the School of Citizenship of Syracuse University.

ONE Army rooter remarked coolly yesterday that Coach Gar Davidson's troop was going after Notre Dame "with sword and Buckler." That's almost as bad as the fellow who said some time ago that Drake's offense had quacked under the strain in the Illinois game. There ought to be a law!

Mayor-elect LaGuardia is slowly Founding up the Cabinet with which he will run the city for the four years beginning Jan. 1. There is considerable foundation for the belief that it will be a "personal" Cabinet, that is, that the group composing it will be men whom the Mayor-elect knows and admires, regardless of their political affiliations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Investigation of expenditures under the Agricultural Relief and Public Works Administrations, and a move to test the constitutionality of the Recovery and other acts giving the President wide powers, will be the policy of the Republicans in the next Congress if the conservative group prevails in the party councils.

It may surprise some readers of Professor SPRAGUE's articles, the second of which appears elsewhere on this page today, to see him lay so much stress on housing. Yet even rival economists are agreed that the construction industry occupies a pivotal position.

Several rentals in East Side cooperative houses were among the apartment leases reported yesterday. The larger volume of leases was on the west side, with the Gramercy Park section a centre of activity on the east side. The tenants included the following:

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Eleven members of the faculty of Swarthmore College have signed a statement urging President Roosevelt to abandon his present monetary policy because, they said, they are convinced that "the government is moving rapidly in the direction of an inflation of alarming proportions."

Deputy Police Commissioner John A. Leach ordered yesterday the suspension of Detective Sergeant Stephen Downey, in charge of detectives at the Vanderveer Park police station in Brooklyn, and two patrolmen involved with him in a shooting affray earlier in the day in the Harms Casino, a dance hall and restaurant at 2,370 Ryder Street, Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. S. Fullerton Weaver and their son, Spencer Weaver, gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane for many of their friends. The room was decorated to resemble a sunken garden in which were evergreen trees and flowering plants.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 30. -- North Carolina scored two touchdowns in the final period and won its traditional Thanksgiving game from Virginia by 14 -- 0 today. A crowd of 20,000 saw the game.

NEW YORK. The first Junior Assembly, a subscription dance for debutantes of this season, will be held tonight in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The dance will be preceded by numerous dinners.
Led by Gulliver the Gullible, a troupe of weird rubber, papier onache and weirdly clad human figures marched down Broadway yesterday in Macy's annual Thanks-giving parade.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 30. -- A steady rise of power, like the swelling of a flood tide, carried Colgate to victory over Brown in their traditional Thanksgiving Day game today, 25 to 0.
WARSAW, Nov. 30. -- An order for two new 14,000-ton transatlantic liners has been placed with an Italian shipyard at Monfalcone in Trieste by the State-owned Polish-American Line.
Clinton added the sixth consecutive victory to its string of football triumphs over the High School of Commerce eleven at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Following the ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment next Tuesday, legal liquor will begin to flow next Tuesday or soon afterward in twenty-four of the forty-eight States.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 30. -- President Roosevelt carved a turkey this evening for his larger "family" here who have made Thanksgiving Day also Founder's Day in his honor.

Determined that no resident of the city and State shall be deprived of an opportunity to drink legal liquor or wine on Tuesday when repeal becomes effective, the State Alcoholic Beverage Board and its staff spent Thanksgiving Day at work.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 30. -- Unable to reach a verdict in the first three hours of their deliberations, a Morgan County jury which is weighing the fate of Heywood Patterson was told by Judge W. W. Callahan at 6 o'clock this evening to give it up for the night and try again tomorrow.

Revision of the methods of financing municipal waterfront developments and of the formula by which rentals for city piers are arranged is recommended by John McKenzie, Commissioner of Docks, in his annual report to Mayor O'Brien, published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The administration is expected by advisers to pursue a more aggressive gold-buying policy in foreign markets as the result of the conferences which President Roosevelt held this week with Acting Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury and Eugene R. Black, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

Continuing his attacks on the policies of President Roosevelt, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declares in the current issue of the New Outlook, published today, that the Federal civil works program, as devised and being put into effect under the Civil Works Administration, is merely an attempt to cover up the breakdown of the Public Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Remonetization of silver, particularly for the millions in the Far East and elsewhere who have long used it, was urged by Senator Borah today as a practical plan to relieve the present monetary situation.

Mount St. Michael's High School football team closed its season as the only undefeated and untied schoolboy eleven in New York City by vanquishing All Hallows Institute, 29 to 6, yesterday before more than 6,000 fans at Mount St., Michael's Field.

New securities offered to the public here in November, as in the previous month, were few, the number being about equally divided between stocks and bonds. The offerings of the latter type of security were the smallest since March, while stock offerings exceeded the totals for October and for November a year ago.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- Judge James Arnold Lowell of the United States District Court at Boston died this morning at his home in Chestnut Hill. He became ill with erysipelas on Nov. 19. Pneumonia developed two days before his death. He was born sixty-four years ago in the house where he died.
Thanksgiving was celebrated throughout the nation yesterday in the tradition established by the Pilgrim Fathers.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 30. -- A surprise has been caused in trade circles here by the news that Argentina had suddenly broken off negotiations with Belgium for a trade convention.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- During the week ending Nov. 24, the Bank of France lost 1,460,000,000 francs in gold, according to its weekly statement published today. This brings the loss of gold to about 4,000,000,000 francs between Oct. 20 and Nov. 24, leaving a total reserve of 77,822,000,000 francs, which gives a currency coverage of 79.14 per cent, against 79.95 per cent last week.

For the first time since the depression cut down travel on rapid transit lines in the city, the comparative monthly figures have shown an increase in trafifc, the Transit Commission announced yesterday. From June, 1930, until last October, traffic figures had shown an uninterrupted decline.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- Sharp retorts were exchanged today between former President Hoover and Governor Rolph, over the latter's approval of the San Jose lynching.

The Book Survey, the official name for the "catholic "white list" of books selected quarterly by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, is made public today. Dr. Blanche Mary Kelly is the editor. The complete selection for this quarter follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Aided by an improvised seventy-five-piece band using every conceivable kitchen utensil for instruments, with a few penny horns thrown in, the Army Goats, the low-ranking students in the Military Academy, defeated the more scholarly engineers in the annual Thanksgiving Day game today, 7-0.
Mozart performances given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, Bruno Walter conductor, and Albert Spalding, violinist, made brilliant features of the concert last night in Carnegie Hall.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The Newman School eleven defeated Priory School of Portsmouth, R.I., today, 20 to 0, as a feature of alumni day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Not since the days between April 6, 1917, and the signing of the armistice has the atmosphere of politics been so absent from the capital as for the last few months. This week it has entered, briefly but effectively, as a Thanksgiving present to Mr. Ropsevelt from the people of the Third Congressional District of West Virginia.

HAVANA, Nov. 30. -- The strike of employes of the Cuban Telephone Company, affiliated with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, ended at 9 o'clock this morning. A settlement was reached through the intervention of government authorities.
SAINT-MARTIN-DE-RE, France, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Another shipload of convicts will sail from this island penitentiary tomorrow for the prison colony of French Guiana, where 673 were taken two months ago.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 30. -- Latin-American debts to United States investors are casting a shadow of discord over the outwardly harmonious feeling of the delegations arriving for the opening of the Pan-American Conference Sunday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 30. -- The long-expected "National Union" Cabinet of Bolivia was formed yesterday after Congress had approved a law creating the Ministry of National Defense, to continue in existence as long as the war with Paraguay lasts.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 30. -- In the first of these articles I insisted that in order to overcome the depression it wag necessary that an enlarged demand for labor and materials be induced by a reduction in relative prices of those goods and services for which a large increase in demand might reasonably be anticipated.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- The trend on financial markets here today was irregularly lower in a dull, inactive session on the Bourse. Month-end liquidations were accomplished easily, although the rediscount rate rose to 1 1/4 per cent, compared with seven-eighths of 1 per cent on Nov. 15.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 30. -- Before a small but enthusiastic group of spectators the second day's play in the four-day national field hockey tournament was completed at Dyche Stadium today. Three more games were played In the round-robin tourney wnich is being used as a means of selection of the United States team of 1934.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- Although it is absurd to think France is imperialistic it is just as foolish to believe her defenceless and unprepared, Minister of War Daladier said tonight in addressing military journalists as a banquet here. The former Premier said France was ready for any emergency and had never been better prepared.

Improved earnings of corporations were tangibly reflected in the dividends declared in the last month for shareholders, the aggregate of the dividends coming close to that of a year ago. Many companies resumed payments, while others increased them by either ordering extras or raising the quarterly rates.

A sweeping reduction in passenger fares, which will be put into effect today by the Western railroads, will leave the East and New England as the only regions in which no reductions in these rates have been made below the standard charge of 3.6 cents a mile, established in 1920.

Addressing the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun at the 108th Thanksgiving service held yesterday in the temple at 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, General Charles H. Sherrill, former Ambassador to Turkey, explained his opposition to the proposed plan to refuse to send an American team to the next Olympic Games in Berlin.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Purcell Mellon gave a dinner last night at the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Churchill Mellon, for whom they gave a reception on the afternoon of Nov. 16 at their home, 1,030 Fifth Avenue.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Army is finished with its preparations for the Notre Dame game. The Cadets had the lightest kind of a practice today, then departed by bus for the Knollwood Country Club in Westchester County where they will remain until time to go to the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

Finishing with a burst of speed that left the rest of the field far in the rear, Peter Patrikakos, Greek-American-Hermes A.C. entrant, won the twenty-third annual City Hall-to-Coney Island walk yesterday. Patrikakos, a novice, had a 22-minute allowance.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30. -- The Cleveland Plain Dealer today published the following letter on its 'ditorial page, signed "U.S. Citizen" and written by Robert D. Wilkin, a New Philadelphia (Ohio) attorney, as a Thanksgiving Day response to President Roosevelt from the great average citizen:

BOWIE. Md., Nov. 30. -- A.C. Bostwick's Mate, sixth among the money winning thoroughbreds of the world, drove his earnings to $297,660 by a decisive victory in the $2,500 added Thanksgiving Day Handicap, closing-day feature at Bowls today.

Exports of gold here in November showed a sharp decline from the previous month's total and made the smallest monthly figure since January. Three small consignments, two lots to France and the other to Great Britain, comprised the month's exports.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 30. -- A crowd estimated at 30,000 celebrated the return of horse racing to South Texas today by attending the inaugural program at Epsom Downs, a new $500,000 race track a few miles from Houston.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 30. -- The Latin flair for quixotic gestures reached a new zenith today when Salvador Mendoza, husband of a prominent feminist attached to the Mexican delegation, registered the pair at a hotel as:

A capacity crowd of 16,000 persons, including Governor Moore of New Jersey and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, saw unbeaten St. Peter's Prep and Dickinson High battle to a 7-7 tie at the Jersey City baseball park yesterday morning in the twenty-fifth renewal of a football series which began in 1898.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 30. -- Following a report that yesterday's meeting of the Ford Motor Company of Holland had decided to pay back 40 per cent of the capital stock, the quotations for Ford shares here jumped 20 points to 185 in today's stock market.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- For the first time since 1894, a team from Hamill House won the interhouse championship at Lawrenceville School today.

The commodity and security markets will reopen today after yesterday's nation-wide observance of Thanksgiving. Financial centres were at a standstill in this country, and observers were compelled to look abroad for the day's developments in money and securities.

The field In the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden has dwindled to twelve teams. Yesterday afternoon Franco Georgetti, one of the most popular of modern pedalers, withdrew suddenly, and last night Alfredo Binda of Italy decided to quit the grind.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Al Mingucci excelled in Barringer High School's 7-to-6 victory over East Orange in their thirty-seventh annual Thanksgiving game today. More than 8,000 spectators saw Phil Caruso toss the ball twenty yards to Mingucci, who ran ten yards for a touchdown in the third period.

Hates for call loans on both Stock Exchanges here in November were unchanged from those of October, but time funds were fractionally higher. Quotations for call loans have been stationary since Aug. 30. On the New York Stock Exchange, where the rate remained at 3/4 of 1 per cent, it was 1 per cent in November a year ago and 2 1/2 per cent in the corresponding month in 1931.

John J. Raskob, former Democratic National Chairman, came to the defense of former Governor Alfred E. Smith last night in the controversy over the financing of the Empire State Building, with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- A survey conducted by the Public Works Administration of the projects for which its non-Federal allotments have been made was announced today by Secretary Ickes, who said it showed that "the taxpayers' dollars are being spent on useful and socially beneficial public works in every State."

A reception with dancing was given yesterday afternoon in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis by Mr. and Mrs. W. Ruloff Kip to introduce their daughter, Miss Betty Kip. Mrs. Kip and the debutante received in a bower of palms and ferns interspersed with clusters of chrysanthemums. Standards of these Autumn flowers were arranged around the room.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30. -- Pittsburgh downed Carnegie Tech for the city football title, 16 to 0, in the Pitt Stadium before 45,000 holiday fans today. The contest was staged in ideal weather, with the sun warming the huge bowl throughout the game.
And ARTHUR yet had done no deed of arms, But heard the call and came.
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Franklin and Marshall ran roughshod over Gettysburg today in their forty-first annual football game, 21 to 7.
Banks closed for holiday; money unquoted. Wednesday's final prices: Call loans 3/4 of 1 per cent, 60 to 90 days' time loans 3/4 of 1 per cent. prime three-months' commercial paper 1 1/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Chicago Bears administered their customary Thanksgiving Day defeat to their fellow-townsmen, the Chicago Cardinals, in a National Football League contest today, triumphing by 22 to 6.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- George Connors, veteran trainer of Yale football teams and track coach until last season, will retire after the Yale-Princeton game, the Athletic Association announced tonight. He will make his home in San Diego, Calif.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- For several hundred thousand children and grown-ups of Newark and the Oranges the feature of Thanksgiving Day was the annual Bamberger Co. parade of Tony Sarg grotesques.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Many recommendations for improving the government weather service were made today by a special committee of the Weather Bureau of the Science Advisory Board. The two most important were:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Encouraging developments in industry during November were reported today in the monthly survey of business issued by the American Federation of Labor.

All financial and commodity exchanges in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving Day. With the banks also closed, no quotations were available for money or foreign exchange. No action was taken in Washington on the price of gold, because of the holiday.

With regard to her inferiority in the air Great Britain is in the embarrassing position of a leader in the cause of disarmament who cannot propose expansion of air power without exciting suspicion of her good faith. Mr. BALDWIN pointed this out in a debate in the House of Commons on Wednesday.

In the first stages of our Government's gold-buying policy, Europeans spoke of it as a riddle, a puzzle, a mystery. Then they began to divine an intention to raise prices by depreciating the dollar. It was just one more bubble breaking on the surface of "the American stew."

Retirement of bonds before their due dates was less in November than in the previous month and a year ago. Industrial and foreign bonds, in the order named, accounted for the most of the refundings. The total of $13,170,000 compared with $23,781,000 in October and $29,967,500 in November a year ago.
Dwelling conveyances made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

Newspapers of Tuesday, Dec. 11, 1883, their front pages given over largely to the closing of the Manufacturers Bank at Amsterdam, N. Y., the resignation of W.H. Peckham as District Attorney of New York and the French policy in China, made no mention of Frank Roehrig.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- St. John's of Annapolis defeated Johns Hopkins University, 13 to 0, in their annual Thanksgiving Day football game today. It was their fifty-first meeting.

For more than six hours yesterday Waxey Gordon squirmed in the witness chair in Federal court in an attempt to defend himself against the government's charge of income tax evasion. After he left the stand, both sides rested. They will sum up today.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Years of controversy over the amateur status in golf ended tonight when the Royal and Ancient Club of St. Andrews, after consultation with the United State Golf Association, issued a new rule, under which, it is claimed, there can be no misunderstanding.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 30 (AP). -- The open revolt against the attempt of Governor O.K. Allen and Senator Huey P. Long to "elect" their Sixth District Congressional candidate by eliminating the primary election spread quickly today as five parishes in the district announced that they would not pay officers to serve in the "general election."
Three Broadway attractions will give speical matinees today. They are "As Thousands Cheer," "Sailor, Reware!" and "Ah, Wilderness!"

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November was slightly slower than in the preceding month. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 33,645,736 shares, compared with 39,379,082 in October and 23,037,683 shares in the same month a year ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30. -- Professor O. M. W. Sprague, who resigned as special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, will return to the Harvard Business School to resume his teaching there after a leave of absence of nearly four years from his chair of Converse Professor of Banking, most of which time was spent as economic adviser to the Bank of England.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 1. -- The Cabinet meets today for a final effort to decide on the budget.

DUBLIN, Nov. 30. -- Extensive police raids were made in Irish cities today on the homes of prominent leaders of the Blue Shirt United Ireland party. In Dublin the police were especially active, making a simultaneous swoop on the residences of General Owen O'Duffy, Ernest Blythe, who was Minister of Finance in the Cosgrave government, and Commandant E.J. Cronin and on Blue Shirt headquarters on St. Stephen's Green.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Miss Deborah Black, daughter of Mrs. Robert Clifford Black, was introduced to society this afternoon at a reception with dancing given at her mother's home here.

Two men were wounded, one seriously, last night when one of three hold-up men wantonly opened fire upon them after his companions had rifled their pockets and looted a safe in Herman Brinn's watch repair shop at 1,645 Madison Avenue. Brinn, shot in the abdomen, slumped to the floor crying:

Mrs. Douglass Bomeisler of 620 Park Avenue and Cobble Court, Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Douglas, to Edward Rotan, son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Rotan of Houston, Texas.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- The undefeated Central High School football team of Washington, D.C., brought its season to a successful close today by defeating White Plains High, 20 to 0. A crowd of 10,000 fans saw the intersectional contest this morning in Parker Stadium.

Total savings deposits in savings accounts and certificates of deposit in banks and trust companies throughout the country stood at $21,424,226,000 on June 30, according to the annual report of the savings division of the American Bankers Association.

High winds were responsible for low scores in the Thanksgiving Day shoot of the New York Athletic Club over the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. The best work was done by S.B. Masten, who took the High Scratch Cup with 91 out of 100 targets.

An appeal by Mrs. Leonard Wood, widow of Major General Wood, for a Thanksgiving offering of Red Cross membership contributions brought to a close last night the intensive campaigning for the annual roll call of the New York Chapter.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Just four and a half centuries after a boy King and a boy Prince were murdered in the Tower of London in one of the most famous crimes of all times, the guilt has been definitely fixed upon the man first suspected -- King Richard III.
DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 30. -- The text of Judge W.W. Callahan's charge to the jury in the Scottsboro case was as follows:
The bleak November weather that usually is associated with turkey, pumpkin pie and all the other Thanksgiving trimmings gave place yesterday to something akin to Spring.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 30. -- The white helmet of George Henry Sauer and those of a pair of substitute halfbacks, Jerry Lanoue and Bobbie Benson, bobbed all over Memorial Stadium today as Nebraska overcame the strong Oregon State eleven by 22 to 0 before 25,000 fans.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 30. -- Orthodox Jewish leaders, gathered here for the opening of the annual national convention of the Mizrachi Zionist Organization of America, today heard their national president warn that the Mizrachi stands at the parting of the ways in relation to the Zionist movement as a whole and to the procedure adopted in recent years in the upbuilding of their homeland.

A woman believed to be Miss Gene La Vigne, whose address has not been learned by the police, is thought to have jumped to her death from the south footwalk of the George Washington Bridge early last night. A small felt hat and a tan polo coat containing 80 cents and a note addressed "to whom it may concern" were found about 500 feet west of the New York tower.
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 30. -- The Supreme Court has rendered a decision which is regarded as a blow to the divorce industry of several Mexican States.
Sales by banks and development purchases were included In the city and suburban realty trading reported yesterday.

Certain New Yorkers, whose childhood antedated the stock market crash of 1929, bank holidays, government by abbreviation and the emergence of the crooner-including many who played punchball in Harlem or Washington Heights long before Sarajevo, liberty loans and "Over There" -- must have agreed yesterday that Thanks-giving, in at least one respect, was not what it used to be.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, has forbidden the indiscrimiate dismissal of women officials, especially school teachers. In an order addressed to local authorities he referred to the numerous complaints he had received, and then said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Hope of a relaxation of the restrictions on liquor imports after repeal was expressed tonight by Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, after conferences last night between the importers' committee of which he is chairman, and the government's inter-departmental liquor committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Registering his seventeenth straight major victory in two seasons, Steven Szumachowski concluded his cross-country running career at Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady by retaining the national interscholastic title over the Branch Brook Park course this morning.

Two important exhibitions will open today in out-of-town museums. At the Worcester Art Museum the director, Francis Henry Taylor, has assembled an exhibition of contemporary American paintings, and Jere Abbott, director of the Smith College Museum of Art at Northampton, Mass., has arranged a Degas show, to celebrate that museum's new acquisition, Degas's early canvas, "La Fille de Jephte."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 30 (AP). -- War in the Gran Chaco between Bolivia and Paraguay, a two-year-old skeleton in the South American closet, was brought into discussions preliminary to the Pan-American Conference today by Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc, Mexican Foreign Minister.
BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Robert Rankine of Preston, Ont., won the twenty-fourth annual Berwick modified marathon today over the mountainous country here.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 30. -- Governor Murray sent his oft-used troops to the University of Oklahoma campus today to check the gate receipts of the annual football game between the university and Oklahoma A. and M. College. Fifty-five National Guardsmen sent here from Chickasha took charge of the ticket booths and gates at the university stadium.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The text of Ambassador Bingham's Thanksgiving Day address today follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- President Roosevelt heads a list of speakers who will "address a two-day celebration here Wednesday and Thursday, marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of organized church cooperation as represented in the Fedaral Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- In a spectacular, wide-open game filled with forward and lateral passing, Cornell defeated Pennsylvania in their fortieth Thanksgiving Day meeting on Franklin Field today, 20 to 12.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30. -- Under a cool, gray sky a holiday crowd of approximately 7,500 racing fans today saw Contraband win the Thanksgiving Day Handicap, feature of the opening card at the Jefferson Park track.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 30. -- Taking advantage of what he said he regarded as the observance of the most national of American holidays, Jose Padin, Commissioner of Education, gave an interpretation of American citizenship and what it means to a native son of Puerto Rico in an address at the Thanks-giving observance at St. John's Episcopal Church today.

Intensification of the drive among wage-earners by campaign workers of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking a fund of $4,000,000 for relief of the unemployed, will mark the remaining period of the campaign, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, general chairman.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The stock markets were irregular today, but there was some increase in activity. British Government funds were better. International stocks were neglected because of the holiday in the United States. Aviations featured the industrials, on the prospect of increased defenses, and motors also were strong.

Large brush and grass fires were reported yesterday in several parts of New Jersey. The dry season and the fresh winds made the flames difficult to control, but the damage to buildings was slight. Motorists parked their automobiles for hours along main highways to watch the fire fighting, thus causing much traffic congestion.

SOMEWHERE in his life of Herman Melville, we believe, Lewis Mumford has remarked upon the division between sacred and profane classics. The sacred classics, if we remember the Mumford definition, include those works of art (such as "The Brothers Karamazoff" or "Moby Dick") which convey to us both a profound thinker's allegory of good and evil in the heart of man and a basic spiritual attitude toward the universe.

The H. Herrmann Furniture Company has leased for wholesale show-rooms the Store and second floor in 462-78 Fourth Avenue, to be known as the feerrmann Building. An option for additional space is included in the lease, which was arranged by J.G. White Co.

Support of the annual fund-raising campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York was urged in a letter from Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, made public yesterday by the fund. A statement was issued also by Edwin P. Maynard, vice president of the fund and chairman of the board of the Brooklyn Trust Company, urging further support because of the great need of the fifty-six institutions.

With the repeal of national prohibition next Tuesday, four Federal taxes will quickly cease to be effective. They are the 5 per cent tax on excess profits of corporations and the similar tax on dividends; the additional half-cent-a-gallon levied last June on gasoline, and the tax of $1 per $1,000 on capital stock.

Raymond Moley, former close adviser to the Roosevelt administration, forecast yesterday an early steadying of the RFC gold price, followed by a period of inflation through issuance of public works bonds and renewed open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- "This is the happiest Thanksgiving I have ever had," John D. Rockefeller Sr. remarked today to his son.

A three-act comedy, "Polly With a Past," will be given tonight by the Business Girls' Club of the Central Branch Y.M.C.A. at its head-quarters. Fifty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. All the roles will be assumed by members of the club.
In a statement issued on Wednesday Governor ROLPH said:

The approach of the end of prohibition brings to steamship operators in foreign and domestic trade problems of management and service, many of which probably will remain unsolved until the lines have had a chance to study the reaction of the public to the new conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- Climaxing its most successful football season in many years, the University of Oregon, co-champions of the Pacific Coast Conference, defeated St. Mary's Gaels, 13 -- 7, today before a crowd of 20,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- In a statement replying to Alfred E. Smith's criticism of the public works fund, Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, said today: "It is impossible to satisfy any man who is nourishing a grudge as the result of disappointed ambitions."

The Brooklyn Dodgers were enmeshed in a net of forward passes at Ebbets Field yesterday and lost to the Giants, 10-0, before a crowd of 28,000. The New Yorkers thus advanced to within a step of clinching the professional football crown for the Eastern Division and the right to enter the national championship playoff.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 30. -- Alabama strengthened its claim to the championship of the year-old Southeastern Intercollegiate Football Conference by defeating Vanderbilt, 7 to 0, in the last game off the season for both teams. More than 15,000 fans watched the battle.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30. -- Mike Frankovich pulled down a pass against Washington State today, to give the University of California at Los Angeles its first Pacific Coast Conference victory in the final football game of the season.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- D. FredericK Burnett, State Commissioner under the new alcoholic beverage control law, marshaled his associates and office force today in an effort to make applications for retail liquor licenses available so that repeal would find the sale of liquor under control.

Twelve hundred or more children welcomed Mozart's "Bastien and Bastienne" and Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel," with which the Charlotte Lund Opera Company opened its seventh season at the Town Hall yesterday morning. The early classic pleased by its novelty to many hearers, with Louis Sherman and Lilli Barr in its title roles and Alberto Bimboni leading the several players grouped tin the pit.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 1 -- There is a distinct swing toward an optimistic outlook in expectancy of concrete beneficial results as the date approaches for the opening of the seventh Pan-American conference here. This is in sharp contrast to the air of pessimism and doubt which hung over the conference arrangements as recently as two weeks ago.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Clarence Fisher's 75 won the William H. Bright Memorial Trophy, the medalist prize, in the qualifying round of the eleventh annual Eastern States Thanksgiving tournament at the Wildwood Golf Club today. Willard Goeckler of Cedar Brook and John Edwards of Ocean City tied at 78 for runner-up honors.
In a terrific battle of ballots and ballyhoo, for the fifth successive year the balance of All-America power in college football ranks has been captured by the Middle West.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Denouncing Governor James Rolph for his attitude in the San Jose lynching controversy, the Rev. Leslie C. Kelley, a San Francisco minister, resigned today from the State Athletic Commission and bitterly arraigned the State administration.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutneran Council, and the Rev. Dr. Liars W. Boe, president of St. Olaf Lutheran College, Northfield, Minn., will be guests of honor Tuesday evening at a dinner in the Town Hall Club.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 1 -- The Duke Blue Devils and Georgia Tech will clash tomorrow in the closing game of the local collegiate gridiron season. Unbeaten and untied, Duke will be bidding for a claim to the Dixie Championship and for consideration as an opponent for Stanford in the annual Rose Bowl battle.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 1 -- Paying only enough attention to national affairs to laugh at new reports of changes in the administration's monetary policy, President Roosevelt devoted today to the Warm Springs Foundation and the near-by village of the same name.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- By raising the RFC price of gold by 8 cents while Treasury specialists were at work on details of the Dec. 15 program of refinancing $727,000,000 in maturing government securities, the administration today gave notice to its critics that it felt free to chart the course of its new monetary policy as it desires.
Richard and His Nephews. It will be news to the average person that HENRY VII of England has ever been suspected of being the murderer of the two poor little Princes in the Tower just 450 years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Dr. Frank J. Loesch, president of the Crime Commission of Chicago and creator of that city's list of public enemies, in an address here today urged college men to enter police forces in an effort to correct the "low moral tone" now prevalent in some of the forces.

Daniel Kennedy, 31 years old, reported to be a son of a police official of Glens Falls, N. Y., was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter by a jury in General Sessions yesterday in the automobile killing of 16-year-old Dorothy Goodman, a high school student, on June 9, 1932.

MONTREAL., Dec. 1 (Canadian Press) -- An unofficial guard, composed of a sergeant and four other ranks from the McGill University contingent, Canadian Officers Training Corps, maintained watch tonight over the body of Sir Arthur Currie, which reposes in the privacy of the Currie home, on the fringe of the McGill campus.

WOODBURY, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Audrey Smith Clark of Paulsboro will receive until her death or remarriage the interest from an estate of "$50,000 and upward." left by her husband, Sheldon A. Clark Jr., who was shot and killed following a dispute in their home on Nov. 20.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors today modified the law with respect to the impounding of tax collections of municipalities which had not paid their county taxes, thus clearing the way for the completion of the transactions with banks in New York and Westchester that prevented the county from defaulting on more than $3,500,000 in obligations.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 -- Long shots captured the two featured races at Jefferson Park today when Dark Ayr scored in the fourth event and Fitkin, 65-to-1 shot, won the fifth. The latter returned $132.40 for $2 and Dark Ayr $57.60 for $2.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 1 -- Negotiations over the purchase of power are in progress between the Tennessee Valley Authority and private utility companies, according to David E. Lilienthal, Authority member in charge of power development.

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, is preparing to fight to a finish for the elimination of "outside" reactionary influences from the 1934 Assembly. He is determined that there shall be no compromise and is willing, according to his friends, to stake his present position as titular leader of his party in this State on the outcome.

Inflation was condemned as "legalized confiscation" by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippine Islands, who supported the attack an President Roosevelt's monetary policies, in an address before the League for Political Education last evening at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Although informed by cable that the new amateur definition adopted by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews was being forwarded here, officials of the United States Golf Association stated yesterday that it had not yet arrived.

Joseph H. Choate Jr., chosen by President Roosevelt to head the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, made known yesterday in his first interview since appointment that he hoped to set up a minimum of regulation.

DUBLIN, Dec. 1 -- General Owen O'Duffy, leader of the Blue Shirts, dramatically replied today to the government's offensive against his organization by appearing at the head of a parade of thousands of his followers at Kenmare, County Kerry, where he made an address.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The dollar declined today to 16.10 francs at the official closing, as against 16.38 yesterday. This drop took place before the 8-cent increase in the United States gold price was known and was due to President Roosevelt's reiteration of an intention to depreciate the dollar.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 1 -- The first major race meeting in West Virginia will start tomorrow when the new plant of the Shenandoah Valley Jockey Club Inaugurates its twenty-day session. A seven-race program will be presented, with the five-furlong Inaugural Purse for 2-year-olds heading the list.

Thousands of miles of streams once considered excellent for fishing but long since rendered unfit will be reclaimed through the work of the Civilian Conservation Corps, according to the reports of a number of State Fish and Game Commissions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Five hundred refunding operations on small urban homes are being completed dally by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, it was announced today by the corporation.
WARM SPRINGS, Dec. 1 -- A plea for the aid of unemployed women was sounded by Mrs. Roosevelt in her talk before the clubwomen.

With nearly 50,000 unemployed registered for civil works jobs at the close of registration here yesterday, new civil works were approved by the State Civil Works Administration for cities and counties. This was the first group of new projects to be approved by the State administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Two big American industries dominated by single interests, the telephone and aluminum businesses, may receive NRA codes limited to mere regulations of hours and wages, with no provision for control of business practices.

Belief that the future regulation and development of American banking can be worked out best within the structure of the banking code under the NRA rather than by resort to further legislative changes is expressed in a statement by William K. Payne, chairman of the National Bank of Auburn, Auburn, N.Y., and chairman of the Bankers NRA Committee of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Compensating taxes on jute yarn and fabric and paper for specified uses were proclaimed today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration on a finding by Secretary Wallace that processing taxes on cotton are causing "excessive shifts in consumption" to the former products.

Although superb pitching was the Giants' chief stock in trade last season. Bill Terry, manager of the world's champions, apparently is not of a mind to neglect an opportunity for still further strengthening himself in this vital department.

The listed bond market moved yesterday contrary to the generally accepted trends on a day when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had posted an increase in its domestic gold-buying price. United States Government bonds opened slightly lower, reflecting the 8-cent increase in the gold quotation, but soon steadied.

Tabloid if true is "Little Giants," the domestic comedy drama by H. Kalmanowitz presented at the Second Avenue Theatre last night. Papa is a drunkard, a liar, a gambler and a thwarted artist into the bargain; and he wrecks a couple of families.

There will be plenty of wines and whiskies available in New York warehouses for delivery when repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is ratified next Tuesday afternoon. Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, said yesterday.

Only one of the 367 mutual savings banks in the five New England States has so far signified an intention of applying for insurance in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. This group constitutes substantially more than one-half the 567 institutions of that type in the country.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 1 -- The Rev. Dr. Minot Canfield Morgan, former co-pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York, was installed tonight as minister of the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich. His distinguished career, during which he was moderator of the New YorkPresbytery, was reviewed and hewas welcomed to his new pastorate by clergymen of the community.

The Treasury will close its books today on the offering of new twelve-year bonds in exchange for outstanding Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s. About $1,875,000,000 of the latter have been called for redemption on April 15. Mr. MORGENTHAU announced last Tuesday that some $890,000,000 had been turned in tor exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Wholesale commodity prices suffered a reaction during the past week, according to figures issued today by Isidor Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics. The upward trend which had been in progress since the middle of October was halted, and prices went down to the level of nearly a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Holding companies as well as their active subsidiaries will be expected to come under NRA codes, General Johnson said in response to questions at a press conference from reporters seeking to clarify the relations between the NRA and the A.T. and T.

Following a slight reaction at the previous month-end, the forward movement in the stock market, which started abruptly in October, was resumed in November, prices reaching a level corresponding with that of the high point in the previous month.

The first prosecution for violation of the provisions of the NRA resuited in a victory for the government yesterday after a corporation and two persons pleaded guilty yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn to a charge of failing to meet the requirements of the petroleum code.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 1 -- George M. Estabrook, conservator of the First National Bank of this village, which has been operating in a limited manner since March, announced tonight that waivers for a sufficient amount had been signed to meet the Federal requirements to reopen the bank.

Scholastic football will come to the end of the 1933 trail this afternoon at Ebbets Field when the undefeated Curtis and Flushing High School elevens meet in the benefit final arranged by the P.S.A.L.

Football comes to the end of its trail today in the East and throughout the country, save for scattered post-season and special games. The long weeks of practice are over and another season drops off into the discussion of all-star squads and mythical championships.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- The University of Georgia, here for a football game with Southern California tomorrow, was told in two words today by unofficial scouts just the right system to employ in the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to what is apparently an error in the comparative figures I used in my article on public utilities last Sunday. I compared the Tennessee Valley Authority rate with the average rates charged by the private companies.

GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- Joseph Chamberlain, Professor of Public Law at Columbia University, arrived here today to attend as the American member, the first meetings of the governing body of the High Commission for Refugees From Germany.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- Analytical reading of newspapers by school children was advocated as an interesting aid in the study of English by Charles R. Gaston of the Theodore Roosevelt School of New York in an address before 1,000 delegates to the annual convention of the National Council of Teachers of English here today.

Adhering to the government's gold policy, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation yesterday increased the price for newly mined domestic gold 8 cents an ounce to $34.01, resulting in a slight decline for the dollar in the foreign exchange markets.
The general tempo of trade was slower this week, and an element of caution appears to be tempering both commercial and industrial operations, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Yale College and Sheffield Scientific School societies and clubs tonight began a series of dances, luncheons and dinners in connection with the annual Princeton-Yale football game, which takes place tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The fining of the operators of the Hercules gasoline filling stations in Brooklyn for violation of the provisions of the petroleum-code was termed ''most gratifying" by Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator, today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- Speaking on "The New Democracy" before the Democratic Luncheon Club today, Professor Raymond T. Moley, former adviser of President Roosevelt, made a plea to the Democrats to aid Senator Johnson, Progressive Republican, who comes up for reelection next year.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Ambassador Robert W. Bingham's mention of an American "exchange equalization fund" in last night's speech to the American Society referred merely to the administration's goldbuying operations, it was stated today in his behalf.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York, and Count and Countess Guillaume d'Ornano are among the passengers sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Champlain. Others booked for the ship include:
Army plays Notre Dame today and, as usual, there are hardly enough seats in the Yankee Stadium to accommodate the demand.

Among the few hundred Indians who dwell on the mountain-rimmed Crow reservation in Southeastern Montana there may still be a score who know the story of their fellow tribesman, Henry Russell, and the secret of the great bird.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Leading throughout, the Princeton junior varsity eleven today defeated the Yale jayvees, 15 to 6, in a game played in a gale. On one occasion a Princeton punter lost 15 yards by kicking against the wind.

Prices of commodities futures moved irregularly higher yesterday in dealings on local exchanges. The advance in the RFC purchasing price for gold, coupled with the relative strength of the dollar in the afternoon, were the principal factors in the day's movements.

BARCELONA, Dec. 1 -- Six persons were injured late tonight by the explosion of a bomb in a congested part of this city. The bomb had been placed inside the base of an iron post supporting street car cables. Fragments of iron were hurled in all directions, injuring passers-by and penetrating the walls and windows of neighboring buildings.

Reports of the broadcast speech in which Sir HERBERT SAMUEL declared the intention, fulfilled on Tuesday, of his little Spartan band, the Liberal parliamentary party, to sit no more on the Government benches but "cross the floor of the House" into Opposition, show him replete with solemnity and at times magniloquent in a way that tempts the scoffer:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Establishment by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad of store-door pickup and delivery service as provided in Pennsylvania Railroad tariffs that became effective today was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Friday, Dec. 1, 1933. Bankers' bills, thirty and ninety day maturities, were raised 1/3 in yield, the only change of interest in the day's money market. The advance was interpreted as ushering in a firm month for money, with the Dec. 15 government finaning and year-end commitments in sight.

Two lower East Side residents became supernumerary street cleaners yesterday near their homes in Henry and Pike Streets. With knots of children looking on, the amateurs worked at layers of dirt and refuse under the professional eye of a Sanitation Department inspector.

THE choice today is between visiting the Bronx to watch Army tackle Notre Dame or touring to New Haven to view the traditional gridiron debate involving the Princeton Tiger and the Yale Bulldog. Either way a man can't go wrong.
Tax collections up to Nov. 30, when the time for payment without penalty expired, fell short by $160,525,858 of the year's tax levy, Controller George McAneny disclosed yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Dr. William T. Hornaday, zoologist and wild-life conservationist, was 79 years old today.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Having finished the month-end settlements, the Boerse resumed its upward movement today. Some stocks showed gains up to 4 points and South German Sugar advanced 5 points. Confidence that the Winter will pass quietly and continued optimistic business reports were cited as explanation of the buoyancy.

Retention of the Blue Eagle by Loft, Inc., operating a chain of 150 candy stores and restaurants in this city, was made contingent yesterday by the local compliance board, of the NRA upon the company's "promise to abide by the provisions of the President's Re-employment Agreement and rectification of abuses charged against the company.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Purchase of all properties and assets of United Artists Corporation, Ltd., by Twentieth Century Pictures, headed by Joseph Schenck and Samuel Goldwyn, was announced today by the purchasers. They declined to disclose the amount paid.

A mass meeting sponsored by leaders of the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths, to protest against the recent lynchings in San Jose, Calif., and Governor Rolph's declared approval of them, will be held at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

Samuel Untermyer is prepared to step into the somewhat tangled legal battles involving S.W. Straus Co. in the interest of holders of bonds sold through the company, if certain conditions laid down by him are accepted, it was disclosed yesterday.

A protest against the alleged attempts of shippers and railroads to break down the rate structure on freight moving on the State Barge Canal and on railroads competing with the barge route was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday by the Canal Carriers Association, 70 Pine Street.

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season, held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, brought out a large gathering of debutantes of the season and a limited number of girls who were formally introduced last year.

Bank clearings compared with those of a year ago give a somewhat distorted result because of the Thanksgiving holiday, according to the weekly report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The return for the week ended on Wednesday covers six days, while only five business days were included in the corresponding week in 1932.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 2 -- The Cabinet reached an agreement on the budget this morning, ending a deadlock that had threatened to plunge the nation into unwanted and inconvenient political change. The agreement came when the Finance Minister, Viscount Korekiyo Takahashi, consented to the appropriation of an additional 15,000,000 yen demanded by the Navy Minister, Admiral Mineo Osumi.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is more than, fifty years since, listening with awe and respect to my college professor, I was informed by him that "money is merely a medium of exchange" and even gold and silver, except for their utility in the arts, had no intrinsic value; that their adoption as a standard was a matter of convenience to facilitate intercourse and commercial exchange between nations.

Of the $49,006,813 of new State and municipal bonds scheduled for award next week through competitive sealed bidding, chief interest will centre in the issue of $25,000,000 Commonwealth of Pennsylvania relief bonds on Tuesday. At least two major syndicates are considering bidding for the bonds, which are to be sold as not exceeding 4 1/2 s.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 1 -- Charles R. Weeks, counsel for the township of North Hempstead in its suit to eject Wesley Harper, Horatio Harper and Mrs. Mabel A.H. Gow from an eight-acre strip of waterfront land on Sands Point, L.I., announced today that he would move early next week before Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey Jr. to set aside the adverse verdict returned by a jury before Justice McCooey last Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As president of the House of St. Giles the Cripple and of St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, two of the fifty-six hospitals affiliated with the United Hospital Fund, I am deeply concerned over the financial difficulties which face these New York voluntary hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,584,000,000, an increase of $10,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $380,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Willie Sharkey, called a "strong-arm man" for the Touhy gang by the government and an innocent person who became insane by his counsel, committed suicide in a jail cell today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- In keeping with provisions of the Reed amendment of March 3, 1917, Acting Postmaster General Joseph C. O'Mahoney today signed a Postoffice bulletin listing States which forbid the mailing of any advertisement or solicitation of any order for intoxicating liquors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- In a reply to Alfred E. Smith's attack on the Civil Works Administration, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, announced today that 1,183,267 persons had been employed under the Civil Works program by Nov. 25, the end of the first week of operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interest aroused by the announcement that the Metropolitan Museum is about to open two branch museums is indicative of the growing appreciation of the importance of museums as institutions of popular education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Robert Jackson, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, gave a ball tonight at the Sulgrave Club to present to society his daughter. Miss Hope Jackson. All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented in the company, which numbered about 1,000 and included guests from New York, Philadelphia and the hunting section of Virginia, where many house parties were entertained over Thanksgiving.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 1 -- The first-purchase prize and $500 in cash were awarded to Nicholal Cikovsky for the painting "Girl Before the Mirror" in the exhibition of contemporary American paintings, which opened at the Worcester Art Museum last night.
Heading toward Federal prison, Gordon still remains an example of what the golden opportunities of the prohibition era could do for a man without scruples and anxious to get ahead.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 1 -- A new kind of mercury lamp, which is said to give light more closely approximating sunlight than those now existing, was shown publicly for the first time by scientists of the University of Cincinnati at a meeting today of the American Physical Society and American Mathematical Society.

Matthew C. Brush has retired from the presidency of the American International Corporation and has been elected to the long-vacant position of chairman of the board. His withdrawal from the daily routine of active direction of the large Stock Exchange investment trust was prompted by his desire to rebuild his health.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 -- In the belief that his body "will serve a useful purpose to the cause of science," Major Daniel O'Connell Lively, who had given up an opportunity to make a fortune to devote his life to relief work, bequeathed his body to the New York Post Graduate Medical School and Hospital for post-mortem examination.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia announced yesterday that he planned to go to Washington next week to confer with Secretary of the Interior Ickes on the $25,000,000 loan, for the completion of links of the city's independent subway system.
Seven Manhattan properties and six Bronx parcels offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bid in by the respective plaintiffs. One Manhattan sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

Government control of business, which had "forgot its responsibility to the people," and Federal cooperation, in home financing were hailed yesterday by speakers at a special meeting of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

T.S. Stribling, whose novel, "The Store," won the Pulitzer Prize last Spring, has finished a new novel which, after considerable indecision, he has decided to call "Unfinished Cathedral." It concerns the building of a large church in a small community and is the third novel of his trilogy, which started with "The Forge" and was continued with "The Store."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was exonerated today of charges that he had been interested in loans made by the corporation to three Texas mortgage companies.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- A lottery with more than 49,000 prizes, each a ninety-day job paying from $15 to as high as $36 a week, will be held in Chicago next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 25 amounted to 581,347 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 17,942 cars, or 3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 88,029 cars, or 17.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 22,549 cars, or 5.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Final plans were announced yesterday for the annual celebration of German Day, which Mayor O'Brien refused to allow in the armory of the 165th Regiment on Oct. 29, on the ground that it was to be made the occasion for undemocratic Nazi propaganda and might result in disorder. The event will take place on Wednesday.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- For the fourth time since Edouard Herriot was defeated last December on the issue of the war debt to the United States a French Radical Socialist Cabinet will present itself before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow, this time under the leadership of Camille Chautemps, and ask for support.

Retail Trade Showing Spurt. Both Christmas buying and response to clearance events struck a good stride here yesterday. Gift buying opened up much better than was the case prior to Thanksgiving and gave warrant of being exceptionally heavy today.

Waxey Gordon, last but one of the Eastern beer nabobs, was sentenced last night by Federal Judge Coleman to serve ten years in prison, to pay $20,000 fine and to pay $60,000 to defray the cost of his prosecution for evasion of income tax.

A reception with dancing was given yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Plaza by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Le Roy McMillen to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary McMillen. The debutante and her mother received near the entrance to the ballroom in a bower of cybotium ferns and smilax flanked with vases of lavender, yellow and bronze chrysanthemums.

Christmas shows are getting under way in good season this year. Many of the galleries are arranging special displays of art priced low enough to tempt the gift-buying public. Among these exhibitions is one that opened this week at the Barbizon-Plaza, headquarters of An American Group.

The large reduction in the French bank's gold reserve reflects a peculiar situation. Since the beginning of September the Bank of France has lost, in American values, $174,600,000 gold; $56,200,000 went out last week, and the movement has naturally occasioned rumors that France will presently be"forced off the gold standard."

Banks throughout the country continue to be well supplied with reserve funds and in the New York money market the supply has remained "moderately large" despite considerable fluctuations, according to the review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering November.

Contributions of $449,348 have been made to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee by firms and corporations in the financial district, it was announced yesterday by Oscar Cooper, chairman of the finance division of the committee's finance and Industry division.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.

Stabilization of the dollar would do much to increase credit and stimulate the velocity of bank deposits, C.T. Revere of Munds, Winslow Potter asserts. He predicts that the administration's monetary plan will soon be completed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Within the first two months after repeal, the Federal Government will allow between 4,000,000 and 5,000,000 gallons of liquor to be imported from abroad, it was announced today by the Federal Alcohol Control Administration.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A threat by Fascists to tar and feather John McGovern, Laborite, for his outburst after the King's speech opening Parliament has been received by the police.

DECATUR, Ala., Dec. 1 -- Another Alabama jury found Heywood Patterson guilty today and condemned him to death. The third trial of this 20-year-old Negro defendant in the Scottsboro case ended as had his first and second.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A tribute to THE NEW YORK TIMES appears on the editorial page of The Daily Telegraph today in a signed article by Lord Camrose, proprietor of The Telegraph.
One of two aged sisters was burned fatally and the other seriously yesterday forenoon in a fire in the living room of their threeroom flat on the second floor of 617 Ninth Avenue.
Our dollar is now altogether too greatly influenced by the accidents of international trade, by the internal policies of other nations and by political disturbances in other continents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The marketing agreement for importers of liquor, as signed tonight by Secretary Wallace, is as follows:

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Another step toward converting Germany into a supposedly classless "State of estates" was taken today when the industrial employers' associations announced their voluntary dissolution.
NEW YORK. J.T. Johnston Mali, Belgian Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Mali will give a dinner for Paul May, the Belgian Ambassador, and Mme. May, at 11 East Eighty-sixth Street on Dec. 9.

After an advance of 8 cents an ounce in Washington's gold-buying quotation had stimulated buying sufficient to improve prices 10 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, trading dwindled and much of the gain was lost, making the close 3 to 9 points higher than on Wednesday.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Mr. Post, whose offices were at 1,440 Broadway, New York, had occupied his Summer home here for about twenty years. He and Mrs. Post left Sea Girt about a week ago for their Winter residence in Miami which they purchased last year.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 1 -- Citizens of West Feliciana Parish today seized and burned ballots for the special Congressional election without a primary, scheduled for Tuesday.

As the six-day bicycle race swept into its closing stages at Madison Square Garden, last night, the twelve teams remaining in the grind continued to make a merry chase of it.
