Although there was one time when as many as eight laps seprated the leaders from the tall-enders, not one pair showed any inclination, to abandon the ad pace that has characterized the event all week long.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reports for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net profit of $2,397,060 after interest, taxes, depreciation and other charges, which is equal to $5.13 a share on the 466,902 shares of the Series A cumulative preferred stock.

The annual P.S.A.L. hockey season got under way at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday with six of the seven teams competing and the defending titleholders, Brooklyn Tech, drawing a bye. The winners were Erasmus Hall, Jamaica and New Utrecht.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 1 -- Five favorites romped home at the new Epsom Downs track today, with Kievex scoring at odds-on in the Fairfield Purse, feature event.

Preparatory to the hearings in Washington next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday on the real estate codes, including those for office and loft buildings, apartments and brokers, the Real Estate Board of New York held an open meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore for the purpose of receiving suggestions from realty owners and others for use by the board's representatives at the hearings.

DUNEDIN, N.Z., Dec. 1 (By Wireless) -- The Wyatt Earp, motor ship of the expedition, is almost completely loaded. The crew, after a three weeks' spell ashore, is aching to feel the swell of the ocean once more, and I have given orders for the ship to be ready to sail early Tuesday morning.

Net earnings of the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 were $530,630 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, equivalent, after dividend requirements on 6 per cent preferred stock, to 43 cents a share on 700,000 no par common shares outstanding at the close of the period.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 2 -- According to The Dally Express, a storm of indignation has arisen among Roman Catholics following the announcement yesterday that a Protestant burial service was read over the exhumed bodies of King Edward V and Richard, Duke of York, when reinterred in Westminster Abbey last June.

The resumption of activities in the stock markets after the holiday was marked by a continuation of the quiet, persistent strength that was noticeable on Tuesday and Wednesday. Public participation is at a low point, and the pools are neither many nor aggressive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Attorney General Cummings said today that the Department of Justice "will take further action to protect law-abiding citizens from the menace" of the Chicago gangsters acquitted in St. Paul of kidnapping William Hamm Jr.

Harry I. Arrow, an attorney of 51 Chambers Street and a former vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on the charge that in 1930 and 1931 he misapplied $142,000 of the bank's funds.

Reflecting the nation-wide demands on the banking machinery in connection with the month-end and the Thanksgiving holiday trade and the sizable withdrawals of funds by the Treasury from its depositories, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped to approximately $750,000,000, according to the system's weekly statement of condition as of Wednesday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Ice which has embedded the Soviet icebreaker Cheliuskin in the Bast Siberian Sea for two months started to break up today and the ninety persons aboard had hopes of an early return to safety and civilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- State Department officials said today that war debts and other international considerations had no influence on the action taken toward limiting liquor imports. It was suggested, however, that a rule might be adopted that countries entering trade agreements with the United States after the initial quotas would receive three times as much business as those unwilling to do so.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Yale and Princeton, principals in the longest football series in the United States, will play their fiftyseventh game in the Bowl tomorrow before about 40,000 spectators.

BAGHDAD, Dec. 1 -- Princess Aliyah, who was married by proxy to King Ghazi of Iraq last September, arrived here today from Istanbul to meet her husband for the first time and to become Queen. She was accompanied by her mother, Queen Nagia, a brother and her sisters.

In his standard work on the Philippines JOHN FOREMAN says that from the earliest period of the Spanish occupation of the islands "attention has been given to gold-seeking." The village of Mambulao, in the Province of Camarlnes, "long enjoyed fame for the gold washings in its vicinity."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Eva Le Gallienne and Ethel Barrymore took turns rebuking a Philadelphia Lecture Assembly audience today. Miss Le Gallienne told her hearers she was "disappointed" in them, but Miss Barrymore went further and characterized them as "moronic," adding that both actresses did them an honor in being present.

The record made in fighting diphtheria in the Bellevue-Yorkville district gives fresh hope that this disease may be practically eliminated. There was not a death from diphtheria between March 7, 1932, and Nov. 28, 1933. An intensive three-year campaign ending in January of 1932 was made by the Health Department with the aid of a special committee of citizens under the chairmanship of Mr. THOMAS W. LAMONT.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 1 -- A human being can live to be 150 to 180 years old, says the Russian academician Lazarev.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, Dec. 1 -- Harry Da Windt is survived by his widow, Mrs. Charlotte Elizabeth Ihle De Windt.

A general conference of the electrie power and light industry will be held in St. Louis, Mo., on next Tuesday and Wednesday, when the operating heads of several hundred power companies will gather to discuss a permanent code for the industry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to commend you for the consistent and bold stand which you have maintained in your editorial columns with regard to the monetary problem during this crisis. Experience is a dear teacher, yet it seems that the administration is determined not to profit by the experiences of other countries with inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- New York, Connecticut and New Jersey figured largely in the list of seventy-one non-Federal allotments of Public Works Administration funds announced today. The list, which is the longest single one issued to date, totals $26,543,053.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Malcolm G. Buchanan, vice chancellor, today ordered Colonel William H. Kelly, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, to turn over to the receiver for the Liberty Surety Bond Company of Trenton bonds aggregating in value $100,000 claimed by the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company.

Ed Wynn, comedian, and Fred Zweifel, his manager, were found not guilty yesterday in Yorkville Court of assaulting Morris Newman, a process server, last Wednesday at the door of Wynn's apartment in the Hotel Berkshire, 21 West Fifty-second Street.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 1 --The United States touring field hockey team, which represented this country so ably in Europe this year, closed its performance in the national tournament at Dyche Stadium today with a 5-to-0 victory over the Midwest team, composed largely of North Shore players.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's brown shirt army became an official organ of the German Reich today when President von Hindenburg appointed Colonel Ernst Roehm, commanderin-chief of the Storm, troops, and Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the National Socialist party, to membership int he Cabinet as Ministers without portfolios.

That interest rates are dropping fast and that banks and loaning institutions are beginning to realize that cooperation between the borrower and the lender is the most practical solution of the critical mortgage situation is further demonstrated by transactions just filed in the Recorder's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The controversy between Henry Ford and General Johnson as to the former's right to obtain contracts from the government because of what the latter held was non-compliance with NRA rules reached practically its finish tonight.

MADRID, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh were said tonight to be planning visits to Bissau and Bolama, in Portuguese Guinea, and perhaps to other ports in West Africa, after which they will fly to London to board a steamer for New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Big Ten football teams, their chests already expanded after a great campaign this year, will really step out after competition next Fall with eleven and probably twelve important intersectional encounters and three games against Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Federal Emergency Relief Administration will make available $50,000,000 worth of anthracite and bituminous coal to the needy unemployed, it was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Civil Works Administrator and president of the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation.
The name of former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade, who resigned under fire in the Seabury investigation, appeared yesterday among those of the 105 who have applied for retirement on city pensions.

THERE once was a time when the nervous theatrical producer, prowling about on the fringe of his first-night audience, kept his eyes and ears sharp for whatever reactions might be revealed by the professional critics. On the smiles or frowns of the latter gentlemen he mentally computed his future box-office receipts and the success or failure of his show.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29 -- On the very day the Southern Commission on the Study of Lynching issued its report relating to the notorious Tuscaloosa lynching, the Governor of California praised the hanging of two prisoners by a San Jose mob. In one utterance, Rolph has set back for years the efforts of the South to prevent lynchings.

The suit of Victor Kosow, clothing salesman, to set aside the adoption of his daughter, Sylvia Sidney, film star, by Dr. Sigmund Sidney, dentist, was discontinued without costs yesterday in a stipulation filed in the Supreme Court. The agreement was signed by Mr. Kosow and the defendants, Miss Sidney, her mother, Mrs. Beatrice Sidney, who married the dentist after divorcing Mr. Kosow in 1919, and by Dr. Sidney.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 2. -- The National Industrial Recovery Act, so far as it attempts to control local industry, was held unconstitutional by Federal District Judge Alexander Akerman today in refusing to issue an injunction requiring a cleaning and dyeing operator to keep his prices up to those fixed by the code for this territory.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- The shocked lecture audience which heard Ethel Barrymore say its members "don't know anything," found voice today and in no uncer- tain terms turned on the Queen of America's "royal family" of drama.

One of the oldest-established musicales in the interests of philanthropy -- the annual concert for the benefit of the work conducted by the New York Diet Kitchen Association -- will take place on Tuesday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 30. -- Economic importance of Puerto Rico's population problem is stressed by Former Governor James R. Beverley in his annual report for the fiscal year ended last June 30, when he retired to be succeeded by Robert H. Gore, and for the first time direct reference is made to birth control in the annual accounting rendered by the island's chief executive to the Secretary of War.

Chronic diseases disable about 1 per cent of the population, it was estimated yesterday by the United Hospital Fund, which credited them with being the greatest single cause of disability and death. While the usual number of vacancies exist in voluntary general hospitals for acute diseases, hospitals for chronic diseases are crowded, it was declared.

Mrs. Rosa F. Huyler Cooke of 1 West Seventy-second Street, who was the wife of William Wilbur James Cooke and formerly the widow of John S. Huyler, candy manufacturer, who died on Nov. 25, left most of her estate to her husband and two sons, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogates' Court.

Preparations for handling a heavy volume of American-Russian trade were under way here last week among both exporters and importers. Although the export trade is awaiting word from Washington of a possible plan of governmental backing on credits extended to the Soviet before closing sales of merchandise, their salesmen have been actively soliciting orders both here and broad since the announcement of recognition.

Production plans shaped by major industries for the coining year assure a vigorous gain in industrial activity for 1934, according to views expressed by business men in leading manufacturing centres visited in the last two weeks by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Thomas E. Dewey, 31-year-old United States Attorney, who obtained the conviction on Friday of Waxey Gordon, first of the prohibition era beer barons to be tried here for violation of the income-tax law, paid a tribute yesterday to the government agents who helped him build up his case.

THROUGHOUT the empire of filmdom, on which the sun never sets, countless millions watch with unceasing wonder the stately solemnities that surround the King of England when he opens Parliament. They hear the strains of the national anthem, played by mounted bands, the sharp clatter of horse-hoofs on the pavements, and the outbursts of cheering along a crowded route.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The price of gold remained unchanged at $34.01 today, as the Treasury studied figures for the first five months of the fiscal year and closed its books on exchange subscriptions of called Fourth Liberty loan bonds for the new ten to twelve year Treasury issue with what it regarded as a favorable reaction to that program.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2. -- Frank D. Seremba's Zekiel scored a half-length victory in the featured Frank J. Reyes Handicap at Jefferson Park today. Mrs. J. Grossman's Merrily On was second in the six-furlong dash and Mrs. S.F. Murphy's Modesto third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Advocates of a larger army air service, noting the administration's reported plan to separate the Coast Guard from the Treasury Department, are expected to make a drive this Winter toward consolidation of the Army Air Corps and the Coast Guard.

Four young Communists, one of them a woman, were arrested last night on disorderly conduct charges after they had handcuffed themselves together around a trafficlight pole at Broadway and Fortyseventh Street to protest against the Scottsboro trials.

LARRIKIN" is a good novel and a good story. It marks a departure from the few Australian novels that have heretofore reached an American audience. It is a step in the hoped-for emergence of Australia into the republic of letters.

CLARK GABLE, who is Joan Crawford's consort in "The Dancing Lady," at the Capitol, forced himself upon the consciousness of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer officials by his impersonation of Killer Hears in the Los Angeles production of "The Last Mile."

A COLLECTION of autographs and memoirs of famous musicians, assembled by Dr. William Mason, uncle of Daniel Gregory Mason. Professor of Music at Columbia University, is now on exhibition at the University in Avery Hall.

The attack on the American Federation of Labor by Father Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit radio priest, at a mass meeting at the Hippodrome last Monday, was endorsed yesterday by James L. Ryan, president of the Amalgamated Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental, Iron and Bronze Erectors and Affiliated Trades of America, 222 East Thirty-first Street.

Family Welfare Sunday in support of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee campaign to raise $4,000,000 to aid private family welfare agencies of New York in meeting the extraordinary demands this Winter will be observed in many churches throughout New York City today.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 18 -- With the State lottery for the University of Iceland now under way, the "smallest university of the North" looks forward to the time when the work on the new building can be started.

Approval of the women's re-employment program of the New York City women's division of the NRA has been given by Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia in a letter to the division in which he promised that reemployment for women would be "one of the serious concerns" of his administration.

SAN SIMEON, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP). -- William Randolph Hearst said tonight that President Roosevelt "is striving to get the country away from the blood money of the Shylocks, away from the hard money of hard men," and asserted that Alfred E. Smith is "all wet" in his criticism of the President's policy.

THIS, which is believed to be the first illustrated edition of Dostoevsky's great novel ever published, is a volume to be prized by every lover of good book-making as well as by those who concede to Dostoevsky his place among the giants of creative literature.

SINCE a ballet forma the entire second act of "The School for Husbands" as produced by the Theatre Guild, and since it and the several other incidental dances are choreographed and actually performed by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, the production becomes automatically a subject for the attention of the dance department.

TO thirty-four route miles of the Independent, or Eighth Avenue, subway system now in operation will be added another eighteen miles, if the Public Works Administration grants loan of from $22,500,000 to $25,000,000 to New York City.

ATHENS, Nov. 18 -- The back-to-the-land movement in Greece, under way since 1922, when 1,500,000 refugees were received into the mother country after the exchange of population with Turkey, has been so much accelerated by the depression and restrictive immigration throughout the world that the American Farm School, located on an arm of Salonica Bay facing Mount Olympos, has this year an over-capacity total of 169 Greek boys studying American dry farming and industrial methods.

IN "Stand Clear of Thunder" Hager Wilde has written a crisp and civilized novel. The title, which is borrowed from Swinburne's "Light loves stand clear of thunder. And safe from winds at sea," serves aptly enough to point the moral of the piece.

TORONTO, Nov. 30 -- Work is proceeding vigorously on the David Dunlap Observatory of the University of Toronto, which is being erected by Mrs. D.A. Dunlap as a memorial to her husband, who died in 1924. He was connected with the mining industry in Northern Ontario and was well known for his support of philanthropic enterprises.

Support of the "sound money" program of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has been expressed by eleven industrialists throughout the country, James Brown, president of the chamber, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A remarkable reversal of opinion concerning Japan has occurred in Great Briltain. Parliament itself, with, the government's restrained sympathy has in the last week manifested a hostility to the empire of the Far East that could hardly be matched in Canada, Australia or California.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James T. Johnstone will give a reception this afternoon at their home in Flushing for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Louise Johnstone, who will be formally introduced at a dinner dance Dec. 23 at the St. Begis.

Teachers were urged to unite in opposition to curtailment of public school facilities yesterday afternon by Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, vice president of the American Federation of Teachers. He addressed 300 members of the High School Teachers Association at the Astor.

FARGO, N.D., Nov. 30 -- Once more the so-called biological balance of nature seems due for adjustment, and Central North America, including Canada, faces the task of waging the most intensive war on grasshoppers in the history of agriculture.

REPORTS of fundamental changes in next year's cars are confirmed by the Detroit correspondent of the North American Newspaper Alliance, who specifies in particular that the 1934 Chevrolet will embody "radical styling and engineering changes," and that the De Soto has been "completely re-designed from the ground up."

JOHN McCORMACK, the Irish tenor, believes that microphone technique is more or less a flight of fancy; words concocted by those who would perhaps like to make broadcasting more formidable than it is in reality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Thirty-three national banks with frozen deposits of $36,644,000 and unrestricted deposits of $3,265,000 obtained charters to open for business in the final twenty days of November, the Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor, announced today.

HOLLYWOOD. THE return of former feminine stars to calm and prosperous days is difficult. Two obstacles hinder them: first, their lack of appreciation of their current box-office value, and, second, their disinclination to play mature roles.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- The Princeton football squad was a happy group tonight. While the Pririceton band and a large crowd of friends waited for the players outside the dressing room. Coach Fritz Crisler was bestowing his praise individually on members of the victorious team.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Two seniors having the highest scholastic standing in their class at New Jersey College for Women will be the yule-log bearers at a traditional Christmas ceremony Dec. 19, on the eve of the Christmas recess, it was announced today by Acting Dean Albert E. Meder.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 2 -- With only two college week-ends remaining, the Wellesley dormitories, societies and clubs are crowding the evenings with presentations of their traditional seasonal observances.

LUCREZIA BORI is turning eastward tonight from San Francisco, with but three weeks to spare before she opens New York's opera. Swinging round the circle of many States, the Spanish prima donna has found the high spot of a triumphal concert tour in San Francisco's "longest opera season," which ends this evening.

BELFAST, Dec. 2 (AP). -- A sentence of a month's imprisonment was given to Eamonn Donnelly, member of the Free State Dail and leader of the Fianna Fail party, today for violating an order prohibiting him from entering Ulster.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 2 -- A continental dinner at the Greenwich Country Club tonight attracted about 250 members and guests. Many were hosts at parties.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Admiralty's change in the 1933 program is a little startling in view of its formerly expressed preference for smaller ships and more of them. It almost appears that "bigger and fewer ships" is now to be the slogan.

FOUR one-man shows have opened at the Macbeth Galleries, filling the three rooms of the old quarters and overflowing into the annex. Ralph Rowntree, a Texan, confesses pre-occupation with the textures and shifting colors of Oriental still-life.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, reached Naples this morning and Rome this evening. He will remain here for conversations with Premier Mussolini until Tuesday. The two officials will meet at noon tomorrow.

BERLIN. THE German film industry has received proper instruction what to feed its public. It must provide heroes of sterling worth, heroes that at all times shine in untarnished splendor, beacons of human prowess.

THE art of printing books from wood blocks, technically known as xylography, died hard. After the invention of printing from movable metal types the blockbook continued to struggle along despite the rapid spread of its rival, and not until about the middle of the sixteenth century did it finally peter out and disappear.

The Chicago Black Hawks, rated by many hockey fans as one of the strongest defensive teams in the National League, will make their second appearance of the season on the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight, when they oppose the New York Rangers.

HERE is a book that is unique in its dramatic presentation of the history of the Atlantic in an unbroken chain of events from the voyages of the Viking Dragon ships to General Balbo's twenty seaplanes flying from Italy to Chicago by way of Greenland.
Documentary evidence of widespread German academic opposition to Adolf Hitler's anti-Semitic policy has been revealed by Dr. Raymond C. Knox, Chaplain of Columbia University.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Princeton's Orange flag rippled placidly over the east stands in the evening breeze at the Yale Bowl this evening. Despite the swarm of Princetonians dancing behind their band on the turf, the field down below looked strangely bare, for it had been stripped of its goal posts.

A review in The London Times Literary Supplement of the reissued and corrected Oxford English Dictionary, whose own Supplement records many treasures of American slang, quotes the old and too sweeping dictum of Dr. HOLMES:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- There wag little noticeable change in the rate of industrial production in the week ended on Nov. 25, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions on the basis of fragmentary statistics.

SINCE the days of ancient Rome when victorious generals returned from the provinces to court the favor of the populace with sumptuous festivals and pageants there has been nothing to compare with the ingenuity of Nazi statecraft in present-day Germany.

Two debutantes, Miss Jean Stirling Martin and Miss Alice Dunning, were formally presented to society last night at a supper-dance at the River Club, given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clifford Martin and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wheeler Lowe.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Houston police made a riot call on the German freighter S.A. Nedenfels today to quiet an outbreak in the crew after Captain Oetmanns, the master, declined to authorize a Nazi parade in downtown Houston.

IS this crisis which has afflicted us for four years a crisis in the system or of the system? This is a serious question. I answer: The crisis has so deeply penetrated the system that it has become a crisis of the system. It is no longer an ailment; it is a constitutional disease.

DUBLIN, Dec. 1 -- One of the most significant acts of the economic revolution slowly being effected in the Irish Free State occurred at the beginning of this week when President de Valera cut the first sod at the sites on which two new sugarbeet factories will be erected at Tuam and Thurles.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- The mission of intermediary among the great powers which Europe has virtually entrusted to Premier Mussolini has only just begun and has not yet had time to bear the fruits that every one in Italy confidently expects.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 29 -- Notwithstanding recent evidence of a contrary mood the Corn Belt generally is sensible of ample reason for thanksgiving. It is measurably better off than it was at this time a year ago and it faces the future with a large degree of public confidence in the prospect for further material improvement.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Stanislav V. Kossior, a member of the Communist Political Bureau, in a speech before the plenary session of the Ukrainian Communist party, revealed a separatist movement in the Ukraine. M. Kossior linked the strong nationalist movement that has been present in the Ukraine for several years with international events.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 2 -- South Carolina's Gamecocks, undefeated in the Southern Conference, conquered Auburn by 16 to 14 today at Legion Field.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 -- Economy was stressed as the most pressing need of the State Government in a speech made today at the convention of the New York Conservation Association by the Acting Governor, William H. Bray. Mr. Bray, the State's Lieutenant Governor, is filling the Governor's place during the latter's illness.

Trading in stocks was almost at a standstill yesterday, and with fluctuations limited to fractions in the most prominent issues, interest in the session on the Stock Exchange was at a low point. Many issues failed to appear on the tape. The market was the narrowest since Saturday, March 25, when 364 issues were dealt in, compared with 435 yesterday.

THE prediction may err on the side of optimism, but is probably true, that the Metropolitan Opera Company passed the worst crisis in its history last Spring. A guarantee fund of $300,000 was needed, and was finally forthcoming.
Alderman Murray W. Stand of Manhattan will succeed Dennis J. Mahon as vice chairman of the Board of Aldermen when Mr. Mahon resigns, it was reported yesterday at City Hall.

SINCLAIR LEWIS'S forthcoming novel, "Work of Art," is about a hotel-keeper who tried to run a perfect hotel. It is to be published early in January by Doubleday, Doran Co. in this country and by Jonathan Cape in England.

Early reports indicate that most retailers had November sales figures equal to those of a year ago and that many will probably show conservative increases, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

Plans for a children's performance to be held for the benefit of the Junior Auxiliary of School Nature League at the Plaza Theatre, Fifty-eighth Street near Madison Avenue, on Dec. 28, were announced yesterday by Mrs. Lothair S. Kohnstamm, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Tentative approval of Home Owners Loan Corporation loans in New York State since Nov. 24 numbered 2,733, totaling $14,954,981, the corporation announced today. The average loan was therefore $5,540. Operations of the new recovery activity started last month.

THE rise of Fifth Avenue in twenty-six years to its position today as the nation's greatest business thoroughfare presents a revealing chapter in the story of New York. The avenue's status as a "quality street" was not achieved without sustained and organized efforts against odds.

BRUNO WALTER is usually unheard by radio listeners. His task is to direct, but the other day he stepped out of his role as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to discuss on the air what he calls the "dangerous easiness" with which the broadcast listener approaches the sanctuary of music.

Thwarted in an attempt to hold up a butcher shop in the East Tremont section of the Bronx last night, three boys, all believed to be less than 12 years old and armed with an automatic air rifle, robbed a laundry proprietor a few minutes later and escaped into Crotona Park.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The present burden of real estate taxes imposed by local units of government can not be lightened or relieved by any source of revenue which local units have power to apply or control, State Tax Commissioner John J. Merrill declared tonight in an address over station WGY.

The first week of an exhibition of religious paintings by C. Bosseron Chambers -- opening Tuesday afternoon at the John Levy Galleries, will be sponsored by the Order of the Good Shepherd in this city, which is endeavoring to establish a Good Shepherd House of Reception in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- General Johnson today approved the recommendation of the Cotton Textile Institute, which is the Code Authority for the cotton textile industry, that machine hours of operation be cut during December to 75 per cent of the hours allowed under the code.

A SPECIAL concert of Viennese music with Friedrich Schorr, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, is announced by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for Wednesday night. Bruno Walter "will accompany Mr. Schorr in groups of Schubert and Wolf songs.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The constitutional transformation of Germany into a one-party State and the formal conversion of Chancellor Hitler's brown-shirt army into a duly ordained organ of the Reich were accepted by the German people today with the calm born or a certain stunned fascination at the breathtaking speed and sweep of the National Socialist revolution.

Mrs. Edgar Dennison, matron of Lincoln Hospital, died late Friday night of a stroke of paralysis. She was active in the affairs of the hospital up to an hour before her death, which came as a shock to the medical and nursing staff of the institution and to the old women patients whom she had made her especial charge.

Miss Jean Flagler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Harkness Flagler. will give a tea on Tuesday at the home of her parents, 32 Park Avenue, for many of those activily interested in plans for an entertainment now being arranged for the joint benefit of the Third Street Music School Settlement and the Manhattanville Day Nursery Association.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 2 -- The Chaco warfare was a centre of interest among the larger delegations to the Pan-American Conference today, following Secretary of State Cordell Hull's initiative in calling for individual unofficial efforts to end the hostilities between Bolivia and Paraguay.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- "Yale lost to a well-drilled and well-coached team, one of Princeton's finest in every detail," said Reginald D. Root, Yale head coach, after the game. "It had greater man power than Yale and it applied its power most effectively.
The New York Giants will have an opportunity of clinching the championship of the Eastern Division of the National Football League today when they meet the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds.

NOW that the football din is dying away, some attention may be paid to other matters. Some weeks ago there came a story from chicago that the White Sox ball park there was being remodeled according to plans and specification's provided by Architect Aloysius Szemanski, better known as Al Simmons, the Powerful Pole.

Nearly 500,000 additional workers will be given employment and approximately $4,000,000,000 will be spent over retail counters this month, according to an estimate issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The prevailing feeling among tradesmen that "Paris is not buying" has led to unusual appeals to the purchasing public.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 2 -- L. Hunt did some excellent shooting in the registered event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He triumphed by breaking 99 out of 100 targets, then continued on for a string of 121 straight. He was forced to halt with an unfinished run because of darkness.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 2 -- The temporary machinery for Federal control of liquor, pending the enactment of legislation by Congress, was completed today, when President Roosevelt signed the code for fair competition for the alcohol beverage importing industry.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- In an office of the Bell Telephone Company here, Bertil Hjalmar Clason sat nervously consulting his watch at 9 o'clock this morning like any bridegroom on his wedding day. In fact, it was his wedding day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- President Roosevelt has notified leaders of Congress that he expects early passage of legislation providing for stricter Federal supervision of banking and modification of the Securities Act so as to encourage the movement of capital into legitimate enterprise.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Grove E. Warner, formerly vice president and a director of the Warner Sugar Corporation founded by his father the late Charles M. Warner, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home here on Old Church Road, after five days' of illness.

A series of Wednesday night entertainments in the Seaglade of the St. Regis has been arranged in aid of various charitable undertakings. The first two, those of next Wednesday and Dec. 13, will be in behalf it the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

On the principle of the survival of the fittest, the Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, EDOUARD BENES, must be reckoned among the leading statesmen in Europe. He has maintained himself in power and influence longer than most of his compeers in other countries.

The first of this season's Knickerbocker Assemblies -- a series of subscription dances arranged for debutantes of a New years ago -- took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, which was decorated with palms, smilax and Autumn foliage.

A total of 658,745 garments have been distributed free to needy veterans of New York City and their families in the first year of the clothing distribution service of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, it was reported yesterday at the end of the year's work.

GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- Germany's notification of withdrawal from the League of Nations in 1935 has eased the position considerably for an American rapprochement with Geneva, according to non-League quarters specializing in a study of Washington's relations with the League.

Enlargement of the arbitration system, limitation of jury trial in small cases involving less than $100 to eliminate delays, and organization of a central courthouse for important cases were urged as reforms in the Municipal Court yesterday by Justice William Chilvers.

TORONTO, Deo. 2 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs made it two straight over the Maroons tonight with a crushing 8-to-3 victory after a 1-0 triumph at Montreal Thursday and maintained their one-point lead in the National Hockey League's international group. A crowd of about 9,000 saw the Leafs run up the highest score made so far this season.

Tracy H. Lewis and B.M. Higginson tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished the regular competition with a card of 96 out of 100 targets. The gunners again deadlocked with 24 each in the first shoot-off, Lewis scoring 24 -- 23, in the next test.

In the smoldering ashes of the most disastrous season in Notre Dame history was kindled the spark of a great football team at the Yankee Stadium yesterday to end Army's dream of national gridiron dominion, fifteen minutes short of the end of the campaign.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 2 -- Duke's dream of a Southern championship was shattered today and its hopes for a bid to the Rose Bowl were dimmed by a hard-fighting Georgia Tech eleven, 6 to 0. A crowd of 16,000 saw the battle.

Indications are apparent, points out A.J. Swenson, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board, that in view of the expected large income from liquor licenses, effort will be made in the forthcoming Legislature to abolish the State sales tax.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 2 -- As his last official act on his fortnight's visit to Warm Springs, President Roosevelt today extended executive clemency to a prisoner whom he saved from a death sentence fifteen years ago while Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
After a setback of almost ten points from week-end realizing and a few selling orders from the South, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed with losses of one to three points.

The Seventh Pan-American Conference opens today at Montevideo. The United States is represented by a delegation with Secretary HULL as chairman. Delegates of the twenty other member nations of the Pan American Union will be present. The conference is the first to be held since 1928.

AMONG radicals in India it is constantly stated that one or another has "given an undertaking," an expression indicating that a solemn compact has been made to achieve some special enterprise connected with the Nationalist movement.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 2 -- Tulane and Louisiana State, arch rivals for many years, battled to a 7-7 tie in their thirty-first contest today. The Greenies tallied just a few minutes after the start of the game and the Bengals rallied to knot the count with but two minutes of the first half remaining.

The "secret" appointment of former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade to the city's law department so that he might obtain a pension was cited yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, as an illustration of the need for revising the pension systems.

As a result of the successful retriever trials held recently on Long Island it is proposed to follow them with an all-breed retriever meeting to be held early in the Winter. While no details have been worked out, it is suggested that the meeting be held on the North Shore of Long Island before the holidays if it is possible to complete arrangements.

The "stagger" lease plan, by which expiration dates are spread out over the year instead of being confined to the usual Fall and Spring dates, should be extended to business and loft leasing, in the opinion of E.R. Munn, head of E.R. Munn Co.

THE centennial of a long sea voyage which did much to revolutionize man's conception of natural history will be observed next March when a small band of scientists will erect on Chatham Island, in the Galapagos group off the coast of Ecuador, a monument to the memory of Charles Darwin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The public debt of the United States stood at $23,534,115,771 at the end of November, the highest point since 1921, when it was $23,977,450,000, and within about $3,000,000,000 of the all-time, war-loan peak of $26,596,701,648 on Aug. 31, 1919.

Eva Le Gallienne, actress and founder of the Civic Repertory Theatre, declared yesterday that the rebuke which she and Ethel Barrymore had administered to the Lecture Assembly audience in Philadelphia on Friday had been the result of a "misunderstanding'' and "not artistic temperament."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 29 -- Within forty-eight hours after a mob in San Jose, Calif., had lynched two confessed kidnappers and murderers, a mob of 7,000 battered down the doors of the jail at St. Joseph, Mo., hauled Lloyd Warren, 19-year-old Negro who had admitted attacking a white girl, to a tree in the public square and hanged his body at the end of a rope.

Guiomar Novaes, Brazilian pianist, gave her first recital of the season yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall before a large and en- thusiastic audience. Her program comprised the Bach chromatic fantasie and fugue. Scarlatti's sonatas in G major and C major; Liszt's sonata in B minor; Vianna's "Suite of Four Miniatures on Brazilian Songs; Guarnieri's "The Little Horse With the Broken Leg"; Albeniz's "Navarra" and his "Triana."
