WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Eugene L. Vidal, Director of Aeronautics in the Commerce Department, was appointed to the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics today by President Roosevelt to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Dr. William F. Durand.

IN "Mary of Nazareth" Mary Borden has taken the biblical narrative of the life and passion of Jesus and endeavored throughout to see in the colossal drama of the story not the religious significance it was so enormously to acquire but the simple figure of a mother on one hand torn from her ancestral religious moorings by her son's preaching, on the other stanchly loyal in her maternal affection to that son.

WHEN Camille Chautemps became Premier of France last week it was as the head of the thirtieth government to rule in that country since the World War. During that period France has known fifteen different Premiers, some of them serving two or three times and some reconstructing their Cabinets before going down in defeat.

WASHINGTON ONE of the problems of the NRA -- not a major but an annoying problem -- are the chiselers, the persons or corporations which, through subterfuge, seek to evade the responsibilities that go with the Blue Eagle and at the same time make it appear that they are loyally living up to the obligations assumed in the signing of the President's Agreement.

Notre Dame's countless admirers and supporters, found wherever football is played, swarmed by thousands on the gridiron at the Yankee Stadium yesterday after the victory over Army, uprooting goal posts, knocking down fences, and smashing through yardage markers.

THIS book contains a series of short sketches of the major and minor prophets of Israel, including the precursors of the literary prophets, Moses and Elijah, and the heroes of the later writings, Jonah and Daniel. The essential features of the message of each prophet is placed in the setting of Israel's history and expounded in terms of their eternal validity.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- With the end of United States prohibition a few days off, Americans in Paris are wondering what is going to happen to the colony's most famous wine cellar -- that in the American Embassy residence.

While the RFC is buying newly mined gold at $34.01 a line ounce, and is paying the same price for gold bought abroad, gold is being bought and sold in New York at a buying price of $21.60 and a selling price of $25.50 in the open transactions of the jewelry trade, according to The American Banker.

SOME years ago one of the favorite jokes with which, veteran stagehands made sport of a gullible novice consisted in the rather harmless business of sending the gawking tyro to fetch what was called "a box of shouts." Thailand "the key to the curtain" were two fantastic inventions which many a budding stagehand diligently sought in vain while the more experienced practical jokers watched his confusion with sly winks and guarded guffaws.

Five hundred and fifty scientific models, all the work of children under 18 years old, were judged last night at the American Museum of Natural History by 100 scientists, educators and laymen. Ten thousand New York school children participated in their construction.

UPLIFT for those walking human advertisements -- sandwich-board men and women -- may come under the pinions of the Blue Eagle. Hitherto the sandwich men have had no status, but lately a drive against them has raised questions and they may acquire new standing.

Complete realization of the ideals embodied in the objectives of New York City's high schools would make human wastage in the city almost negligible, according to Dr. John L. Tildsley, district superintendent. In his forthcoming ten-year report to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, he outlines fifteen attributes which the high schools seek to develop in the pupils.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 2 -- C. Leroy King's Pari-Mutuel led home a field of six handicap stars in the $1,500-added Houston Handicap at Epsom Downs today. He won by a head from the Three D's Quatre Bras II to account for his first victory in Texas.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- Canada has a deep and natural concern in the affairs of Newfoundland, her nearest British neighbor, rooted largely in the sentiment of their common origin, and would do almost anything for the island's welfare except take it into the Dominion.

Pending an announcement of formal organization of the American Foreign Bondholders Protective Committee, which is expected in a few days, American holders of more than $1,000,000,000 of South American dollar bonds now in default are watching the Pan American Conference in Montevideo to ascertain if the debt question is to be discussed.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia pledged a "house-cleaning" when the Fusion city administration takes office, in an address last night at a dinner tendered to Ambrose B. Acker, Queens chairman of the city Fusion party, at the Hotel Astor.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Contrary to most people's expectations, the Chautemps Cabinet received a much stronger vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies today than was given to Albert Sarraut on his first appearance.

HERE comes still another vigorous person in his seventies to point out that it is not necessary to grow old just because of the passage of years. There are so many of these people already and their number increases so interestingly that the current census of young men and women of anywhere from sixty to a hundred, if it could be taken, would reveal one of the most striking phenomena of the time.

SEVERAL unusual features are incorporated in the plans for a stone and shingle residence for John Howard Laeri on Victory Boulevard, New Rochelle, on which work was started last week. The dwelling was designed by E. Dean Parmelee, architect.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Statewide confusion resulting from last-minute preparations to meet the provisions of the new Liquor Control Law was partly dispelled tonight by the establishment of six districts where wholesalers could obtain licenses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the recent death notices of Edward N. Hurley mention was made of past honors and achievements, but nothing said concerning his "key commodities" peace plan of 1929.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Reichsbank statement as of Nov. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Advice by the Detroit Housing Commis- sion to Detroit property owners to "cash in" on Public Works Administration funds brought a sharp rebuke today from Secretary Ickes.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Portents of far-reaching changes in the French economic and political systems are seen by some in the events of this week-end. While the Chautemps government fought desperately yesterday to save the franc, the vanguard of hunger marchers from the mining areas of the North invaded the capital, harbingers of a vast unrest that is sweeping the industrial areas of the country.

PROFESSOR COLE, to whose efforts the inquisitive student must be thankful for a great deal of intelligent guidance in the study of social and economic questions pressing for solution in the world today, has added to his, estimable record by planning, editing and contributing to the present outline of monetary problems.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Seven persons, including Carl W. McKeen, president of the largest bank in Topeka, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for participation in the million dollar Kansas bond forgery case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- More than 100 alleged "chiselers" under the cleaners and dyers code have been summoned to Washington by Recovery Administrator Johnson to explain alleged violations of the code. The explanations will be made at public hearings on Dec. 11.

Harry Weinberger, a New York attorney with offices at 70 West Fortieth Street, was misidentified in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday as Harry H. Weinberger, an attorney of Passaic, N.J. The Harry H. Weinberger who is under indictment in New Jersey with eleven others for alleged jury-fixing, was not counsel to Emma Goldman and is not the lawyer of Eugene O'Neill, playwright.

"Family Welfare Sunday" will be observed in many of the city's churches today in compliance with the request of the clergymen's committee of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, headed by the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday to its members its annual warning governing the distribution of Christmas gifts to employes of the Exchange or to employes of other members.

LAUNCHING of apparel clearance sales and the starting of the traditional holiday shopping period brought a sharp pickup in retail trade toward the close of the week. Before Thanksgiving business was not very active, the warm weather again holding down volume.

Statements of earnings of Fred F. French Operators, Inc., and sixteen subsidiary and affiliated companies were issued yesterday. Most of them were for 1932, and the others were for fiscal years not coinciding with the calendar year.

MONTEVIDEO FOR the third time within a year the ideal of international cooperation is on trial. At London during the Economic Conference and at Geneva during the disarmament discussion, it suffered staggering blows.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A powerful fighting navy to back up her extensive Rhineland defenses is being built by France in reply to German rearmament.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- Descendants of John Nicholas Emerick, who is averred to have furnished capital to enable John Jacob Astor to enter the fur trade and amass the Astor fortune, made another court move today in seeking a share of the fortune.

THE breadline scene was the one that pleased Luis Trenker most. It was filmed in the evening under the Brooklyn Bridge. The flares which illuminated it licked fitfully across the faces of hungry men, stabbed at the spidery criss-cross of the cables that were black against a purple sky, and crawled toward the silhouette of skyscrapers across the river.

BARCELONA, Nov. 18 -- The existence of Nazi espionage and other activity in Spain, with headquarters in Barcelona, seems to have been pretty well established by a series of recent events, the latest of which was a Nazi raid on a printing plant and the seizure of the entire edition of 10,000 copies of the anti-Nazi newspaper El Antifascista, which is printed half in English and half in German.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Yale's entertainment of its guests today in connection with the Princeton football game included dances and dinners at the fraternity houses and the New Haven Lawn Club. There were many parties of house quests.

Progress, not perfection, is all one can ask of the New Deal, Dr. Willard Thorp, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, declared last night in a radio discussion with Felix Morley of Brookings Institution over Station WJZ.

MANILA, Oct. 28 -- Governor General Frank Murphy has opened up a sociological program for the Philippines on a larger scale than has hitherto been remotely hinted. He has outlined a course of action which will embrace almost every field of humanitarian activity which comes under the government, and will take several years to bring to completion.

An enterprising reporter on the staff of The London Graphic in England became curious yesterday about the probable effect of prohibition repeal next Tuesday, crime in America in general, particularly with regard to lynchings, and what the people of this country thought of Governor Rolph of California.

Piecing together threads of information out of the secrecy surrounding the new America's Cup yachts, the conclusion was reached yesterday by yachtsmen that the greatest variance in them may be in their booms. The stringent new rules have restricted hulls and sails to a large measure.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 30 -- Michigan Republicans are gleefully watching from the sidelines the series of family squabbles the Democratic administration is having. The discord that has developed between leading State officials of that party has become so bitter that destruction of the party's chances to continue in power is threatened in the 1934 election.
CHICAGO MORE than any other commodity market, the Chicago Board of Trade is in the limelight as the administration in Washington continues its efforts to raise agricultural prices to higher levels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial entitled "Old Fallacies With New Faces" you pay a well-deserved homage to Andrew D. White. All praise to him, as he was indeed a very great man, but may I take the liberty of raising an eyebrow at the phrase, "virtual founder of Cornell University"?

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- "Hay Fever," by Noel Coward, was presented tonight by the drama section of the Manor Club, under the direction of Mrs. Bradley Randall. Among those who played principal roles were:

TORONTO, Dec. 2 -- An order for extradition of Martin J. Insull was granted today by Justice A.C. Kingstone of the Ontario Supreme Court on the appeal of Cook Countl, Ill., for his return to Chicago to stand trial on charges in connection with the failure of the Insull utilities system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the NRA, said tonight that apparently Judge Akerman had denied an injunction in an alleged NRA code violation primarily on the technical ground that the petition for the injunction was not brought by the Federal District Attorney.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The fourth season of grand opera, at the Westchester County Centre was opened tonight with the presentation of Gounod's "Faust" by the San Carlo Grand Opera Company. About 2,000 attended.

ISTANBUL, Nov. 18 -- Girl students in a high school in Istanbul recently came forward with the startling proposal that Turkish women should be as liable as men to compulsory service with the nation's fighting forces and expressed willingness themselves to enlist forthwith.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Arsenal, league champion, strengthened its hold on first place in the first division of the English Football League today by beating Liverpool, 2 to 1, while the Tottenham Hotspurs were absorbing a 2-to-0 defeat at Manchester City.
The New York group team of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association will face the New Jersey players on Tuesday at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club, Princeton, N.J.

A plan to rehabilitate unemployed workers in the theatre through the operation of "recovery" theatres, has been formulated by Gustav Blum, Broadway producer, who is seeking the support of the National Recovery and Civil Works Administrations.

Fighting off every bid made by their closest pursuers all through the final hour, the Red Devil team of Alfred Letourner and William (Torchy) Peden rode through to victory in the six-day bicycle race which ended at Madison Square Garden at midnight.

With only slight publicity, perhaps because she is a small country with a population of only about 7,000,000 at home and 8,000,000 in her colonies, Portugal has proceeded to establish a corporative State, somewhat similar to those aimed at by Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler, and regulated more closely than even the United States under the NRA.

DESIGNERS are beginning to think very definitely about large, load-carrying autogiros. While Cierva continues to improve the flying characteristics of his latest wingless model in England, attention is being given here, at least on paper, to the possibilities of this type of craft for transport use.

WITH a few rare exceptions, such as Plato, Schopenhauer and Bergson. philosophers, like scientists, have been notoriously careless of style in their writings. The thought or substance for most of them is enough, leaving the form to take care of itself.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 THESE are the days in which Bostonians "point with pride" to their city as a "good theatre town" -- the best in the country, next to New York. During the six days between Nov. 20 and 25, it poured into the box offices of four "legitimate" playhouses as much as $50,000 -- to say nothing of the receipts at the picture theatres simultaneously flourishing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The "iron man" eleven from the University of Kansas scored its second triumph in three days at Griffith Stadium today, turning back the George Washington University team, 7 to 0. A crowd of 18,000 attended.

BUFFALO, Dec. 1 -- The Thanksgiving holiday for 1933 found the people in this community ready enough to conform with the President's injunction to "recall the courage of those who settled a wilderness, the vision of those who founded the nation, the steadfastness of those who in every succeeding generation have fought to keep pure the ideal of equality of opportunity and hold clear the goal or mutual help."

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $9,826,970, after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interests for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31.

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., Dec. 2 -- Apparently no interest will be paid on Newfoundland bonds on Jan. 1. Government officials so interpret financial resolutions passed by the Assembly as the final measure before surrendering the parliamentary Constitution.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- From her cot in the Cook County jail infirmary, the invalid Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop issued a statement today containing further puzzling reflections on the murder case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A time has come when the United States "can no longer afford to lead in disarmament by example," Secretary Swanson declared in his annual report to President Roosevelt, made public today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- A fast and rugged Villanova team defeated Rutgers, 18-13, today. Seven thousand persons, the largest home crowd of the season, saw the Scarlet, outplayed for the first three periods, come back in the last six minutes of the final quarter to score two touchdowns.

To introduce their daughter, Miss Christina Whitehouse Boardman, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boardman gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. Mrs. Boardman and her daughter received at the head of the stairway leading to the garden, against a background of Southern smilax and palms.

Suggestions that the mass production of homes may be the industry that will lift this country back to prosperity, as outlined by Professor Oliver M.W. Sprague in THE NEW YORK TIMES, have reawakened the interest of the financial commimity in several projects of this nature which have been announced or discussed in the course of the depression.

Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt will serve as honorary chairman for the benefit performance of "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera on the afternoon of Dec. 28. The performance has been taken over in the interests of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's relief and medical work among the fishermen of Labrador and Northern Newfoundland.

Sportsmen made a record kill of deer in New York State this year, according to a report announced last night by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne. The hunters accounted for 8,500 bucks. The number may be augmented somewhat, for not all of the reports have been received to date.
VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- A new story is told here nearly every day about the diminutive Austrian Chancellor who has made himself virtual dictator of the country.

PANAMA, R.P., Nov. 29 -- A telegram sent by Jose R. Castro of El Liberal Progresista, Guatemala City daily, to directors of newspapers in other Central American countries, proposing a press conference for greater harmony and unity of action, has started a newspaper war with the battlefront extending from Mexico to Panama.

TWO sturdy hollow columns feet high and 6 feet in diameter, a polished aluminum sphere 15 feet in diameter supported by each, terrific electrical flashes leaping between the spheres with the crack of a fieldpiece -- the paradox-loving G.K. Chesterton might derive considerable amusement from the contemplation of this enormous apparatus to smash something so small that it cannot even be seen.

With Wall Street's ear keenly attentive to the views of legislators and jurists on stock market practices, interest was aroused a week ago by the ruling of "caveat vendor," or "let the seller beware," enunciated by Federal Judge Woolsey for pool operators. For a time, many brokers believed the ruling would establish a new standard for pool operators that would strictly limit their activities in the future.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- General Hugh S. Johnson told a mass meeting of organized labor in the Mastbaum Theatre here tonight that, while "the right to strike is inviolate, like the law of self-defense," the day had arrived when it was "neither faithful nor fair to strike until the means provided under the law have been pursued."

To prefect investors from loss through inflation and to spur activity in the capital goods industries, the broader use of convertible bonds was advocated here yesterday by Warren M. Persons, consulting economist. Failure to encourage the lending of money, through some protective instrument is the one gap in the Roosevelt recovery program, Mr. Persons said, and the one factor most likely to retard it.

DECEMBER nights afford excellent opportunity to test the tuning ability of any broadcast receiver. Long-distance stations are plentiful from one end of the dial to the other. It is interesting to begin at the top and slowly pass down the scale, counting the number of stations handling the same program.

CAIRO, Dec. 2 -- Bert Fish, new United States Minister to Egypt, visited the royal palace today to present his credentials to King Fuad. Riding in the emblazoned palace coach and surrounded by picked horsemen of the King's bodyguard, Mr. Fish was the first Democrat and the second American Minister to be received with such ceremony.

Tradition will vie with modernity at the seventy-seventh Charity Ball to be held Thursday night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. In a week offering no less than six large dances arranged in the interests of philanthropy, the time-honored Charity Ball holds the distinction of being probably the oldest charity entertainment in the history of New York society.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Richard Lee of the Community Service Commission team of Yonkers led the pack home today in the intermediate division three-mile race, the feature test of the eighth annual Westchester cross-country championships.

The State Tax Commission completed yesterday the task of setting up its machinery for the collection of the new excise taxes on beer, wine and liquor, througn which it hopes to receive more than $4,000,000 from the time of repeal to April 1, 1934.

NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Boston College closed its best football season since 1927 with a brilliant 13-to-9 victory over a heavy and powerful Holy Cross team, before a close-to-capacity crowd of 24,000 at Alumni Field today.
Manhattan's basketball team defeated St. Peter's, 32 to 16, in a hard-fought game at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

HAVANA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The possibility of a compromise settlement of Cuba's political ills held the attention of all factions tonight as Fernandez Medina, Uruguayan Minister, continued to press for acceptance of his "formula for cordiality."

Stating that the project to create a great housing centre in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn clearly demonstrates the need of a city planning commission to properly coordinate the city's development, Howard Gregory of the industrial department of the Chauncey Real Estate Company, Brooklyn, says that he does not believe the apartments as proposed to be built in Red Hook would relieve the conditions in parts of Wllliamsburg and Brownsville.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- Southern California unleashed too much power for the lighter University of Georgia, football team today, and defeated the Bulldogs from Athens, 31 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- Five Morris Foundation Fellowships in Botany, each of which carry a stipend of $1,200, have been awarded for the current academic year by the committee on administration of the Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania, Dr. Rodney H. True, director, announced tonight.

Aided by a suitable financial structure, the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway should attain strength "second to that of no carrier west of the Mississippi," according to a report by Hilton M. Moore, examiner, and J.Y. Barriger, chief examiner, of the railroad division of the RFC.

Licensed restaurants, clubs and hotels throughout the city are completing their preparations to celebrate repeal on Tuesday and, in the case of some on Wednesday. Bands and entertiners have been rehearsed in drinking songs. The assorted glasses required for highballs, cocktails, apertifs, wines and liqueurs, have been purchased.

Out of the many obscurities surrounding the financial situation, the experienced observer recognizes two visible facts. On the one hand, the upturn in the "business cycle" has begun, as it usually does at about this stage of economic readjustment. On the other, business confidence is still impaired by the currency experiments and the resultant flight of capital.

The Manhattan of the United States Lines, which will sail next Wednesday for the Channel ports, will be the first American flag ship to carry real beer, ale and stout for sale to the passengers eastbound since the Prohibition Law came into force in 1920.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 2 -- Headed by Miss Anne Townsend, captain for the eleventh consecutive year, the all-America field hockey team defeated a reserve all-America eleven 3 to 2 today in the final of the rational women's tournament at Dyche Stadium.

A VETERAN of the German Air Corps in the World War, in which he acted the part of an observer and photographer rather than a fighting pilot. Mr. Supf has had almost twenty years of training to write this book. He is concerned neither with the technical problems of flight nor with the achievements of noted pilots.

Retail trade attained substantial proportions last week, the volume of business done following the Thanksgiving Day holiday having more than offset the closing of stores for one day of the week. The demand for luxury goods, partly representing early Christmas shopping, was regarded as a significant change in the character of buying.

In settings suggestive of a semitropical Winter resort, the Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and supper dance will be held on Friday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many features of entertainment have been arranged for the party, which is being given in the interests of the social service committee of the New York Cancer Institute.
BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- While the 86-year-old President von Hindenburg lives and is willing to continue to serve he will continue to head Germany with the title of Reich President.

Coach Heartly (Hunk) Andersen and members of the victorious Notre Dame football team were the guests of honor at a dinner tendered by the Notre Dame Club of New York at the Hotel McAlpin last night. About 500 persons were present.

SOME 34,788,000 children and adults now go to school in Soviet Russia, according to advices recently received by the United States Office of Education. That is 4,000,000 more in the aggregate than our school enrolment here, though it does not yet include quite so large a proportion of the population: 22 per cent in Russia as against 25 per cent in the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Excitement over the lynching in San Jose this week of two men who admitted kidnapping and killing Brooke Hart still prevails undiminished. It appears now that the affair was not entirely unexpected.

WHEN the Earl of Cottenham ventured to pick a few historical flaws in "The Private Life of Henry VIII," George Grossmith replied to him through the columns of the British press. This was the Earl's answer, as published in The London Daily Telegraph:
PARIS. AS in every year, the approach of the prize season brings forth the best novels of the young writers. This year the quality of the new talents thus revealed seems to me especially remarkable.

Dean Dorothy McSparran McArnold of the New York University Washington Square College announced yesterday that fifty-three girls were pledged to sororities at four branches of the university this semester. Dean Arnold, who is faculty adviser to the Pan-Hellenic Congress, said that fifteen sororities at the School of Education, College of Fine Arts, Washington Square College and School of Commerce were represented.

MILAN, Nov. 15, 1933 THE Third International Music Festival, to be held in Venice next Fall as a part of the Biennial Art Exposition long established there, promises an interest surpassing those of 1930 and 1932, which attracted prominent musicians from far and wide.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The controversy over Governor Rolph's official stand in the San Jose lynching took a new line today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In many respects the "new" economics of the past few months seems to represent lack of knowledge of the "old" economics, which is now so blithely and at the same time so contemptuously kicked aside.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 -- A theory that the shapes of animals could be prophesied mathematically, just as the shape of inanimate matter results from certain laws, was advanced today by Dr. N. Rashevsky of Pittsburgh before the final session of the American Physical Society here.

TODAY young New Yorkers will show their calibre as scientists. The annual Children's Science Fair will open at the American Museum of Natural History and more than 500 exhibits, chosen competitively from the work of members of Junior Science Clubs all over the city, will be on view.

ONCE again December has come to woo the land with snow and repeal, and with holly, holidays, reindeer and mistletoe. These pages, being blandly indifferent to most of December's attributes, look forward into the dark glass of the theatre.

The theft of a specially designed automobile valued by its owner at $25,000 was charged in Harlem Court yesterday to Bartholomew Circoleo, 45 years old, a baker, of 416 East Ninth Street. Magistrate George Deluca held him in $3,000 bail for the grang jury despite the fact that he was able to produce what appeared to be a bill of sale for the car, showing he had bought it from a man named Anderson.

The County Fair Ball, to be held Saturday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, has drawn such a large advance subscription from members of society that the committee has estimated the event will have an attendance of nearly 2,000.

WITH the crash of the great Russian plane, K-7, less than two weeks ago, the apparent oblivion of the Do-X after its spectacular transatlantic career and the concentration of airline operators in this country on the medium-sized fast transport, the "big plane" seems to have lost favor for the time being.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Almost at the same instant that the gun barked in New York to end Notre Dame's victorious football battle with Army, the student body set up a mighty yell.

OF business, as of all other forms of human endeavor, it is difficult to say whether a change in the way of looking at things precedes or follows a change in the things we are looking at. Whether we change our minds because conditions have been altered, or conditions are altered because we have changed our minds, is one of those questions which offer occasion for endless and, perhaps, futile argument.

OMAHA, Dec. 2 -- The greatest era of railroad equipment building the transportation world has ever experienced is seen for the near future by Omaha railroad men as the result of the new 110-mile-an-hour streamline trains which the Union Pacific, Burlington and other railroads are building.

WHEN one finds that "AE" (George Russell) has contributed a foreword to a book of poetry one may as well understand that it is a signal to stop, look and listen. For "AE" is himself one of the foremost poets of this century.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 2 -- Senior stars off All-Southeastern Conference football teams will be seen in action in a charity game here New Year's Day. Announcement of the game was made today by C. L. Foster, chairman of a local charity football committee.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The ministerial crisis in the Reich Evangelical Church was temporarily ended today with the appointment by Reich Bishop Mueller of a new ecclesiastical cabinet comprising the following delegates from several Protestant denominations:

IT may seem a far cry from "Uncle Tom's Cabin" to "Her Master's Voice," but the connection is not as far-fetched as might be imagined. Clare Kummer, the author of the comedy at the Plymouth, was born Clare Rodman Beecher.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 -- The question of Samuel Insull's status when his residence permit expires Dec. 31 rested tonight in the hands of Foreign Minister Maximos, who was expected to make a final decision as to how long the former Chicago utilities operator may remain in Greece.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Commander T.G.W. Settle's twelve-mile ascent into the stratosphere Nov. 20 began to bear momentous scientific results in the laboratories of the California Institute of Technology today.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- For a third of a century or longer the industrial primacy once readily conceded to New England has been challenged increasingly by other sections. Such competition of late years has made New England more eager than ever to ascertain, the exact facts and to abandon all guesswork in the handling of industrial conditions.

The Russky Golos of 64 East Seventh Street, a pro-Soviet newspaper and the leading Russian language daily in this country, announced yesterday that it was owned collectively and equally by its editorial, business and printing staff, with every member receiving an equal share of the profits in lieu of the former graded salaries.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2 -- The Canadiens held their position in second place in the International group of the National Hockey League, one point behind the Toronto Maple Leafs, when they defeated the New York Americans, 3 -- 1, before a crowd of 4,500 tonight.

John Taylor Terry gave a large supper dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre for his two debutante granddaughters, the Misses Elizabeth Terry Savage and Josephine Taylor Terry. Miss Savage is the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Theodore Fiske Savage of this city and Huntington, L.I., and Miss Terry is the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Terry Jr. of this city and Tahawus, N.Y.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Disregarding yesterday's increase in the price of gold by the RFC, the dollar improved to 16.32 francs to the dollar today against 16.10 yesterday. This rise came before it was known that the American gold price was unchange today, so had the market remained open the dollar could have been expected to rise even higher.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Roosevelt, responding to a plea by President Stenio Vincent of Haiti, has replied that unescapable treaty obligations prevent immediate withdrawal of the United States financial administration front Haiti, unless a refunding arrangement can be evolved satisfactory to the holders of $12,600,000 of Haitian bonds.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The Florida University Gators ended their season today with a smashing 19-to-0 victory over the Old Liners of the University of Maryland. A crowd of 10,000 witnessed the hard-fought battle.

THAT European drama, barring of course the drama of Greece and Rome, took its rise in religious presentations of the medieval church, and that many of these church plays, with their derivatives the miracle play and the interlude, held well down to the time of Shakespeare, are facts that were once almost solely known by scholars, though of late years they have become common knowledge.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The American Legion's opposition to reduced Federal appropriations for the care of disabled war veterans was reiterated here tonight by its national commander, Edward A. Hayes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Some members of the Hollywood colony rose up in defense of the tongue-lashing which Ethel Barrymore and Eva Le Gallienne administered to the Philadelphia Lecture Assembly last night, but there were others who did not agree with the actresses.

BUCHAREST, Dec. 1 -- Behind the outbursts of anti-Semitic excesses that reached their culmination in brutalities and destruction in Jassy this week lies a story of German Nazi intrigues that goes deeper than a mere desire to beat Jewish shopkeepers.

The debate on use of leisure time is gathering force throughout the country as a result of the shorter work-week of NRA codes. The question is here discussed by a member of the staff of the National Recreation Association, who recently completed an extensive study of what the public schools are doing to provide leisure-time activities for pupils and adults.

MADRID, Dec. 2 (AP) -- On the eve of national elections in sixteen provinces the Cabinet terminated a long session tonight by declaring a "state of prevention" in Catalonia to curb unsettled conditions resulting from strikes and political unrest.

Dates have been approved for a Harmsworth Trophy series next year, Sept. 1, 2 and 3 having been assigned, although no challenge has been received. The International Motor Yachting Union sent out word that the reservation of dates had been made for another international match at Detroit over Labor Day.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The American request for temporary trade concessions in the British market in exchange for larger imports of Scotch whisky arrived today and received the immediate attention of officials of the Board of Trade and the Ministry of Agriculture.

CEZANNE'S water-colors, says Meier-Graefe, seem breathed upon the paper. And that is no exaggeration, but it is a very small fragment of what may be said of Cezanne's water-colors. With a light touch and a discreet reticence in application one can without too great difficulty approximate the breathing of water-color upon paper.

LONDON. TO the list of curious monuments and memorials there has just been added a statue of the famous White Rabbit in "Alice in Wonderland." It was unveiled as a memorial to Lewis Carroll at Llandudno, Wales.

Many excellent opportunities exist at the present time for very advantageous real estate purchases, points out Benjamin M. Phillips of the firm of L.J. Phillips Co. These facilities, he states, will be found in improved properties throughout the West Side.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 2 -- Collaboration of the authorities of many countries, including the United States, with the Finnish political police has solved an espionage mystery which had worried the nation since October. The police then seized an American citizen, Arvid Jacobson of Detroit, and his wife and an alleged Canadian, Mrs. Mary Louise Martin, and twenty-three Finnish citizens suspected of belonging to Mrs. Martin's espionage organization.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- It is just possible that Illinois may surprise itself by obtaining liquor control legislation on or about the date when repeal goes into effect. Such prompt action was not expected, but the legislators have shown such impatience to complete their task as stimulates hope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Italy will lead all other countries in import quotas for liquor entering this country after prohibition is repealed, R.C. Miller of the Department of Agriculture predicted tonight. He is a member of the special committee making allotments.

Notice has been given to counsel for Mrs. Joseph Force Crater, wife of the missing former Supreme Court Justice, that her husband's aged parents will seek in Surrogate's Court to obtain an allowance from his estate to avert foreclosure on their home, it became known yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Grayarno, graceful black gelding, belonging to the Wynfromere Farm Stables of Westport, Conn., won the championship hunter stake, feature event at the Westchester Indoor Horse Show tonight.

With the official gold price unchanged at $34.01 an ounce, the dollar strengthened slightly in the foreign exchange markets yesterday. Shares on the New York Stock Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range, closing firm and quiet. Wheat and cotton were a little easier.

MOSCOW. IN a side street off the Strasnoy Boulevard in Moscow is located a little theatre which calls its own a little known collection of paintings -- six pictures by Marc Chagall, who was born in the little Russian town of Witebsk and is now living in Paris.

In San Jose, one of the larger cities or California, with the safeguards a city is supposed to provide, a mob stormed the Jail and hanged in a near-by park the two men who had confessed guilt of the kidnapping and brutal murder of Brooke L. Hart.

WARSAW, Dec. 1 -- For the first time in her history the reborn Poland is justified in feeling safe, according to the government press. On the east and west peace and good relations seem firmly established, both with Soviet Russia and with Nazi Germany, Poland's two powerful neighbors.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- Except for some specialties, stocks suffered today under the week-end profit-taking on the Boerse, losses ranging up to 5 points. Heavy industrial and potash issues lost most. Electric shares, on the other hand, won up to 2 3/4 points and cables up to 4 1/2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Revision of the curriculum of the Yale Law School to train students to cope with the intricate problems which have arisen with Federal regulation of business was announced today by Dean Charles E. Clark in his annual report to President Angell.

(Sonny) Fraser of Seaview, 17-year-old high school student, will battle it out tomorrow in the upper half of the semi-final round of the Eleventh Annual Eastern States Thanksgiving tournament over the Wildwood Golf Club course.

Moderate gains were made yesterday in all sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange. United States Government long-term issues closed generally higher, up 8-32 to down 2-32, and many domestic corporation issues gained a point or two.

Appointment of Travis H. Whitney, formerly Public Service Commissioner, as Civil Works Administrator for New York City was announced yesterday by Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the State Civil Works Administration, 124 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Construction of berthing basins in the Hudson River for small boats and the organization of a bureau to combat the propaganda of rival ports directed against the traffic of New York are reconmended by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie in a statement to Mayor O'Brien.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 2 -- President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay will inaugurate the seventh Pan-American Conference at 6 P.M. tomorrow with all the pomp and solemnity with which it is possible to surround such a ceremony under a democratic form of government.

During the year ended Sept. 30, 1933, the Salvation Army here furnished a total of 1,281,723 lodgings to homeless men, women and children and served 5,148,838 free meals according to its annual report, soon to be issued. Jobs were found for 10,530 persons, and 37,761 garments and 7,892 pairs of shoes were given out.

Reorganization of mortgage guarantee companies for the protection of purchasers of participation certificates as the class that can least afford losses was suggested yesterday at the closing session of a two-day meeting of the New York League of Savings and Loan Associations in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- A house cleaning in the legal profession was demanded last night by Earle W. Evans, president of the American Bar Association. He urged ethical lawyers to rise up and drive the "crooks" from the profession as money changers were driven from the Temple.

An alert Flushing High School football team that tallied two touchdowns within three minutes conquered Curtis, 13 to 7, yesterday at Ebbets Field in the post-season benefit final arranged by the P.S. A.L. Sharing with the P.S.A.L. in the net proceeds will be the Board of Education's School Relief Fund and the New York American Christmas Fund.

LONDON. THE champion eater of the English town of Middlesbrough, George W. Leader, a paper merchant, has just died at the age of 59. A joke and a bet with a friend are said to have revealed his enormous capacity for food.

Know You the Land? Where is the pleasant land of Amenia which ALBERT JAY NOCK holds up for our envy in the current number of The Atlantic Monthly? It is "one of the smallest countries of Europe" and "little visited," but Mr. NOCK reports that its inhabitants are happier than in any other country he can think of.

FREDRIC MARCH'S first picture under his newly signed contract with Twentieth Century Pictures will be Victor Hugo's celebrated novel "Lea Miaerables." Mr. March, who is valiantly filling Noel Coward's shoes in the cinema version of "Design for Living" at the moment, will appear in the Jean Valjean role.
TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- A gesture by War Minister Araki for which the Navy Minister thanked him in the Cabinet meeting today has produced a budget settlement by compromise.

A LONG-SMOLDERING controversy over money has flared into open discord. On one side are stanch supporters of a managed currency who believe that the government's present plan will lift prices, correct an injustice to debtors and revive profitable markets for the exchange of goods.

Paintings by Rubens and Van Dyck and other old masters are included in the furnishings of the residence of the late Mrs. Jacob H. Schiff, 965 Fifth Avenue, which will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening and on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Bernard K. Marcus, former president of the defunct Bank of United States, and Alexander J. Whynman, the special Deputy Attorney General who defrauded its depositors while investigating the bank's collapse, are prominent figures in this year's "Sing Sing Revue."

THE second Five-Year Plan is to bring light literature once more into Soviet children's lives, as it is to bring the products of light industry into the laps of adults. Fairy tales are to be readmitted -- with qualifications. Goldilocks and Alice are to be granted entrance visas and the small Soviet child can once more squeal with delight when the Prince finds Cinderella's shoe or the little bear discovers his bed occupied.

Trading on local commodity exchanges yesterday was the smallest for many weeks. Price movements were irregular, The apathy of traders was attributed largely to the absence of any significant monetary or foreign exchange developments.

The growth of the collectivist principle in economic and political affairs will make marked changes in the entire field of medicine, Dean William C. Rappleye of the Columbia School of Medicine predicted yesterday in his annual report to Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Mathematical experiments have shown gambling as a money-making enterprise to be futile, Dr. James S. Taylor of the University of Pittsburgh told a group of his colleagues attending the forty-seventh annual convention of the Middle States Association of College and Secondary Schools here today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- The Yale Bulldog was first to score today on the Tiger eleven that had its goal line crossed only once previously this season. A safety by Kilcullen in the opening period gave Yale a 2-0 lead.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Belief that Newfoundland is entering an "era of prosperity" by relinquishing her rights to the status of a dominion until she becomes self-supporting again was expressed in the speech from the throne today when the Legislature was prorogued after approving the Amulree report.

An immediate hearing on the city's application for a loan of $25,500,000 for completion of its independent subway system was asked of the Federal Public Works Administration yesterday by Herbert L. Carpenter, chairman of the City Committee on Subway Completion.

THE man with a used car to trade in came under a new system last Friday which sets the maximum allowance that automobile dealers may make on his vehicle. SYOSSET, L.I., Dec. 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Chalmers Wood gave a tea this afternoon at Little Ipswich, their country home here, for their debutante niece, Miss Louise Williams, daughter of Mrs. Henry Cimino and the late Walker Williams of Jasper County, Ga.

Statements urging prayer and vigilance for temperance and self-control after the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment were issued yesterday through the Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal Churches throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- NRA officials said today that they were not disturbed by the opinion handed down by Judge Alexander Akerman in the Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla., yesterday, that the Constitution does not permit enforcement of NRA code terms on local industries.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment tomorrow will find twenty-four States prepared to sanction in one form or another purchase of distilled spirits. This number will soon be increased. It does not include Minnesota, Florida, Kentucky and various other States which voted for repeal of the national law and are expected soon to authorize changes in local legislation which now forbids traffic in intoxicating beverages.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The Chicago Cardinals and the Boston Redskins concluded their National League schedules today by playing a scoreless tie at Wrigley Field before a ladies' day crowd of 7,000.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Out of the many influences which are at work affecting the dollar, which receives no support whatever from the British exchange fund, it is impossible to determine the part played by the flight of capital from America to England.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Motives for the policy of Washington concerning the fixing of the domestic price of gold are not well understood here. It is thought that perhaps President Roosevelt intended, by maintaining the same price for one week, to demonstrate to opponents of his policy that commodity prices would fall when the dollar ceased declining.

Unless efforts to reach a compromise prevail, the Tammany organization in the Bronx, it was learned yesterday, will nominate its own candidate for State Senator in the Twenty-first District and seek to have the Board of Elections declare him the regular Democratic candidate entitled to the use of the star, the party emblem.

Indistinct squeaking noises in the dark cage of the female vampire bat caught the sharp ear of Peter Toomey late Saturday afternoon as he walked through the reptile house in the Bronx Zoo. They seemed weaker than the usual call of the bat -- a new note.

SHERBROOKE, Quebec, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Establishment of a central bank in Canada to exert a stabilizing influence on currency values will be provided for in legislation at the next session of Parliament, Premier R.B. Bennett said in a week-end address here.

Miss Margaret Boise Robinson and Miss Georgia G. Buck, New York debutantes with Southern, affiliations, will tie introduced tonight in Baltimore at the first of the Bachelors' Cotillions, the outstanding event of the season in that city. Before the dance Miss Robinson will be the guest of honor at a dinner to be given by her aunt, Mrs. John E. Semmes.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Forty-one men took part in the first of a series of eight qualifying snow-bird golf tournaments today at Siwanoy. Robert Cook turned in the best performance with a low gross of 79.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- New cash advances by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounting to $309,151,216 during November brought the disbursements by that agency since its establishment in February, 1932, to $3,543,913,394, according to a monthly summary of its operations.

Members of society are showing much interest in the scheduled opening of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe the night of Dec. 22 at the St. James Theatre. It will be the first appearance in this country of the Russian ballet for sixteen years. Already two performances of the ballet, those on the nights of Dec. 23 and Dec. 26, have been taken over in behalf of philanthropic undertakings.

Proclamations declaring: this week to be Family Welfare Week were issued yesterday by the presidents of the five boroughs of the city through the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking $4,000,000 to be devoted to relief of unemployed through accredited welfare agencies.

Companionship is a dominating factor in personal progress, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, recently of the First Presbyterian Church at Ann Arbor, Mich., said yesterday in a sermon at the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street, cast of Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- William Harryman Rapley, theatre owner, died tonight of heart disease. His age was 76.

Except for official resumption of dollar depreciation, after a four-day pause, no visible indication of the trend of things appeared on last week's markets. Even the course of "dollar valuation" was contradictory. The Washington committee marked it down half a cent further; the open international market raised it nearly half a cent.

The cotton market registered little change last week, reflecting holiday influences and uncertainty regarding the future of the domestic monetary policy. At the first of the week prices moved downward, but later they strengthened with higher quotations for foreign currencies as a result of the increases in the price of gold made by the RFC.

BARCELONA, Dec. 3 -- Constitutional guarantees were partly suspended in Barcelona today by the proclamation of a "state of prevention" because of increasing violence in the transportation strike, which entered its third week yesterday.

Lunn, Public Service Commissioner, of Schenectady Lodge 480, B.P.O.E., declared last night at the annual memorial service of New York Lodge 1, at the Elk lodge rooms, 108 West Forty-third Street.

Football, to the end, provided upsets in a topsy-turvy campaign. On the last day of the season's regular schedule, with only a few post-season affairs left to be settled, the purposeful, businesslike Princeton team remained the only major undefeated and untied squad in the country.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 3. -- Playing the game brand of steady golf that won the British open crown for him last Summer, Denny Shute, lanky Philadelphia pro, today scored a 2-up victory over Johnny Goodman. ARNOLD ZWEIG is one of the novelists writing today who gives philosophical overtones to his fiction. His "The Case of Sergeant Grischa" was more than a psychological study of men under the stress of war; it was also called a philosophical inquiry into the nature of justice. Some have called it a greater novel of the war than the more vivid and direct "All Quiet on the Western Front."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Scoring all of its points in the second period, the Stapleton Football Club defeated the New Rochelle Bulldogs. 10-0, in an exhibition game before 6,000 persons today at the City Park (Hunk) Anderson, Notre Dame coach, was among the spectators.

New uniform systems of accounts in preparation nearly a year and a half, have been promulgated by the Public Service Commission for use in this State by privately owned omnibus and water works corporations for which no systems had previously been prescribed, and for use by gas, electric and steam corporations which have had systems in force several years that are radically revised by the new systems.

Protestants, Catholics and Jews, clergy and laymen alike, joined here yesterday in demanding the end of lynching in the United States and in condemning Governor Rolph of California at a mass meeting in the Great Hall of City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 3 -- The keynote speech by President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay, opening the Pan-American Conference here today, appeared to impress the United States delegates as a fair measure of the principal objectives they expect to attain.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Further steps in the administration's gold purchase program await the return to Washington tomorow of President Roosevelt, Acting Secretary Morgenthau and other officials.

Representatives of Eastern railroads, commenting yesterday on Omaha dispatches predicting the widespread adoption of streamlined, high-speed passenger trains, showed less enthusiasm for the idea than was attributed to their Western colleagues.

Realty interests of the metropolitan district are awaiting with interest the results of the hearings starting today in Washington on NRA codes for real estate brokerage, management and allied professions.
The twenty-second annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases, launched yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was greeted with fortyseven opening contributions totaling $7,409.27.

A 69-year-old woman, the victim of an automobile accident last night in which she was seriously but not critically injured, unfolded to police of the Sixty-seventh Street station a version of her experience which left them baffled.
MADRID, Dec. 3 -- The proclamation throughout Spain tonight of a "state of prevention;" which is a mild form of martial law, followed elections in which Right parties added to their recent gains.

Three gunners tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, Tracy H. Lewis, S.B. Masten and H. Thoens each breaking 98 out of 100 targets. In the first shoot-off, Lewis and Masten each had 25 straight, Thoens carding 23.

Employment for about 3,000 men will be provided on grade crossing eliminations under its jurisdiction in 1934, the Transit Commission announced yesterday. The elimination projects form part of the comprehensive program adopted by the commission in 1930.

The operating expenses of the fifty-six voluntary hospitals affiliated with the United Hospital Fund, which is making its annual appeal for money to provide free care, aggregate more than $25,000,000 yearly, it was said yesterday by Henry J. Fisher, president of the fund.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The situation in the United States continues to dominate financial London and also to a very large extent commercial business. The feeling of greater confidence which followed the sharp rise in the dollar early in the week was dispelled almost immediately by resumption of the upward movement of the American price of gold.
Increasingly in recent years, friends of the Hundred Neediest Cases have arranged to aid the unfortunate, even after they themselves have gone on, by setting up trust funds under their wills.
IT was last down and one up, the one up being Princeton, the only "big team" from coast to coast to go through this astonishing gridiron season with a clear record from kick-off to the final whistle.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, played yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall Cesar Franck's symphony in D minor, Wagner's "Siegfried Idyll" and Respighi's "Church Windows," the last repeated from last week's programs.

Dr. Raymond Moley, Professor of Public Law at Columbia University and editor of the political weekly Today, declared yesterday his belief that nine out of ten bankers were in agreement that an immediate return to the gold standard would be damaging to the United States.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S TRAIN, En Route to Washington, Dec. 3 -- Ending a fortnight's visit in Georgia, President Roosevelt left Warm Springs in a special train at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon with the expectation of returning to his desk tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers uncorked a brilliant, aerial attack today to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 10 to 0, in a National League football game.

Sale of a modern apartment house in Harlem and the leasing of a building in West Forty-second Street constituted two of the important features of real estate trading reported in the metropolitan district yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 3 (AP) -- Church cooperation during the last twenty-five years was said today by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, to have introduced a new epoch into American Christianity.

Recommendations for further reductions in the 1934 budget and for new revenue sources will be submitted to the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen today by the joint committee headed by Controller George McAneny. The budget, now calling for the appropriation of about $554,000,000, is in the hands of the Aldermen, who have until midnight to act upon it.

Presenting a tight defense in the crisis and an offense which capitalized every scoring opportunity, the New York A. C. triumphed over the North Cambridge Hockey Club of Boston, 3 to 1, in an amateur game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3. -- The Thanksgiving holiday, the unsettled state of foreign exchange and the general uneasiness as to financial developments in Washington contributed last week to make a quiet cotton market here. Lack of buying support, due to absence of speculative activity and the slump in sterling and francs, gave prices a downward tendency, and values declined about $2 a bale.

"Greed-cankered foes from within and treacherous friends from without" are hampering President Roosevelt in the administration of the New Deal, the Rev. John D. McCarthy declared yesterday in the first of a series of Advent sermons on social justice at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- With actual repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment less than two days away, the executive arm of the government is working night and day in an effort to complete arrangements for liquor control.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 3 -- The Clark brothers and the Moxhams, father and son, made a clean sweep in today's Manhasset Bay dinghy racing in which sixteen craft competed. Light, variable airs, which sometimes disappeared altogether, made sailing a wearisome business.

Members of the auxiliary to the tuberculosis division of Bellevue Hospital have taken over the performance of "The Dark Tower" tonight at the Morosco Theatre to raise funds for the relief of needy patients suffering from tuberculosis.

Football started a nine months' leave of absence from the scholastic sports world late Saturday afternoon after Flushing High School's alert unbeaten eleven had conquered Curtis, 13 to 7, in the P.S.A.L.'s benefit final that proved a fitting climax to the 1933 campaign.
The Irish-Americans of Newark yesterday defeated Brooklyn, 3 to 0, in their American Soccer League fixture at Commercial Field, Broolyn. The Jerseymen led by 1-0 at half time.

Predicting that seasonal influences in the nation's trade and industry will not be favorable to general recovery until after the turn of the year, the National City Bank, in its monthly review of economic conditions and finance, declares that, with the Christmas trade at hand to accellerate the movement of goods over retail counters, there is reason for hope that the period of contraction is drawing to a else.

Summary arrests will be made for the illegal sale of wine and liquor after repeal is ushered in tomorrow afternoon, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, announced yesterday.

Three Davis and Elkins halfbacks finished in the top three places as the race for Eastern individual honors came to a close with the end of the football season on Saturday. Winter gained first position with fifteen touchdowns and one extra point for 91 tallies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- While the administration was perfecting its liquor-control plans today the Anti-Saloon League began to form its lines for a new battle in announcing the program for its annual convention, to be held here from Jan. 7 to 10, inclusive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Dean A A Potter of Purdue University has been added to the committee on railway research of the Science Advisory Board, it was announced today by Karl T. Compton, chairman.

Alfred Letourner, popular littie French rider, and William (Torehy) Peden, the red-haired giant from Vancouver, B. C. who won the New York six-day bicycle race which finished Saturday night in Madison Square Garden, were feted at a dinner at the Unione Sportiva Italiana, New York's largest Italian-American athletic club, last night.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,903,202,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-in-interest-bearing discount bills."
The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, recanted yesterday his approval of the stand taken by Governor Rolph of California in support of the San Jose lynching.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Fresh defiance was hurled at Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller today when the pastors of the insurgent Emergency Federation refused to carry out his orders for a uniform Protestant Church service throughout Germany.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A mass meeting of 15,000 persons in the Chicago Stadium this afternoon adopted a resolution condemning Chancellor Hitler and the Nazi government and calling for a boycott of German-made goods and services "until the stigma and curse of Naziism are weeded out of the German government."

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 3 (AP) -- With two men in custody, officers today were investigating "tips" which they said may lead to additional arrests of possible leaders of the mob that lynched Lloyd Warner, 19, Negro, last Tuesday.

The change in women's drinking habits in the last few years was largely responsible for an application by the management of the Martha Washington Hotel, 29 East Twenty-ninth Street, for a license to dispense wine, the granting of which was announced yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 3 -- The Ramblers won't be bringing back a national championship this time, but Notre Dame and South Bend tonight were preparing a huge welcome for the football team which conquered Army yesterday.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, announced yesterday the formation of a department within his organization to advise film producers on motion picture advertising and exploitation, with a view to eliminating the objectionable features in all types of motion picture advertising.

There is great reason for satisfaction at the conviction and severe punishment of the man known as WAXEY GORDON. A self-confessed criminal of long standing, he had escaped detection and punishment until the long arm of the Federal Government reached out and arraigned him for cheating the Treasury.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- While frantic eleventh-hour efforts were being made to prepare for repeal on Tuesday, D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, announced tonight a few of the rigid restrictions that would apply to liquor license applicants and to consumers.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 3. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.4, which compares with 71.7 a week ago, 72.1 two weeks ago, 71.6 three weeks ago and 71.8 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

Persistence won for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Opposing the defensively powerful Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League battle, the New York skaters charged their rivals recklessly for three full periods only to find themselves deadlocked at 0-0, at the end of the regulation sixty minutes.
MADRID, Dec. 3 -- A "state of prevention" throughout Spain was declared at a special Cabinet session late today in the face of increasing reports of disorders scheduled for tonight or tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Rusteaten relics of Captain John Smith's 1607 Virginia colony on Jamestown Island, the first permanent English-speaking settlement in tha New World, are included in a collection received by the Smithsonian Institution, the gift of Martin L. Ehmann of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- As the House Ways and Means Committee prepared to consider tax legislation tomorrow at a meeting with a special subcommittee, Representative Bacharach of New Jersey, a Republican member, expressed the opinion that if government expenditures were kept within reason, there would be no need for further tax increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- About , 3.00.0,000 men have been returned to employment directly and indirectly on public works, according to a statement issued today by Harold L.Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Public Works Administrator.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not surprising that "Dr. O'Shea finds marked difference in the result of school work. He attributes this largely to differences in the quality of supervision." I believe there is another reason for lowered standards in discipline and work.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Walter Cantley, Lulu Temple Country Club, Philadelphia, won the eleventh annual Eastern States Thanksgiving golf tournament today by downing Clarence Fisher, local champion, 1 up, in a close final match.
The predatory nature of man was discussed yesterday morning by the Rev. Reinhold Niebuhr, professor at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

The Christmas bazaar, under the auspices ou the Pen and Brush Club, will be held on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the clubhouse of the organization, 16 East Tenth Street, to raise funds for carrying on various charitable enterprises. The interior of the clubhouse will be transformed into a French mart, decorated with Christmas greens and bright-colored booths, where a variety of articles suitable for holiday gifts will be offered for sale.

BATHURST, Gambia, British West Africa, Dec. 3 -- Balked by lack Of wind in two attempts to take off for Brazil, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh announced late today that he and his wife would start at 4 A.M. tomorrow, local time [11:45 last night, Eastern Standard Time].

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The two winners of the 1933 Schubert Memorial Award will be presented at symphony concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra in this city and New York, it has been announced by the board of directors of the orchestra association.
One man was burned to death and eight persons were injured early yesterday morning when fire spread through a three-story brownstone rooming house at 359 West Fiftieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Government officials under whose authority liquor will be imported after repeal were discussing today a plan for blanket licensing and permit systems for importers as a means of expediting importations to meet the demand during December and January.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 3 -- George Griswold entertained several guests with a buffet supper at his home in Rock Ridge tonight in honor of Mrs. Griswold's birthday, which is tomorrow. Among those present were:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Topics of The Times this morning "Some Things Forgotten" lauds the period before 1929. I do wish it could be given more publicity. Certainly the principles of our Constitution have brought happiness and prosperity to a greater number of people than any form of government heretofore tried.

An increase in State aid for education in accordance with statutory provisions for such funds is recommended in a report to be submitted to Governor Lehman today by a committee he appointed last July to study public education costs.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Conditions in Europe are still giving us a great deal of anxiety and seem to be poising for a leap off the cliff.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 -- A sensational 98-yard run through the entire Brooklyn team helped give the Cincinnati Reds a 10-to-0 victory today over the Dodgers in the final National League football game of the season here.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Eleven dinghies had a difficult time going through four races today at the Larchmont Yacht Glub as they drifted around the course in light airs. Drake Sparkman managed to guide his boat Cough Drop home first in three Class A events and Sam Wetherill triumphed once with Fifi.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 3. -- With the football season over, Navy will concentrate on basketball starting this week, when the squad will work out for the opener against Western Maryland on Jan. 6. The game with Army features this season's schedule.

Hoboken, the "oasis across the Hudson" of the prohibition era where the open clam broth house took the place of the speakeasy of other localities, will not change its ways after tomorrow in the face of legality and perhaps smaller profits for the barmen.

Sales Inducement by giving away free merchandise with the purchase of another article has been banned as illegal by the New York Retail Code Authority, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the authority, in making known some decisions affecting enforcement of the code as it applies to more than 50,000 retailers here.

DUBLIN, Dec. 3 -- Events are fast moving toward a crisis in AngloIrish relations and leaders of all political parties are awaiting with extraordinary interest the statement by Dominions Secretary J.H. Thomas in the House of Commons on Tuesday.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 3 -- The Chaco conflict and reciprocal tariff agreements formed the keynote of President Gabriel Terra's address inaugurating the seventh Pan American conference this afternoon.

The reverence for love which Christ brought into the world is a primary factor in social advancement, the Rev. Dr. Finis S. Idleman said yesterday in his sermon at the Central Church of Disciples of Christ. 142 West Eighty-first Street.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 3 -- Burgoo King, a white and lemon Kentuckybred foxhound, was awarded the title of best in show at the foxhound bench exhibition of the Babylon Hunt Club, held on the club's grounds today. This typical American foxhound is owned by J. Vincent O'Shea of Babylon.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 3 -- While Suffolk County hotels, restaurants and clubs are ready to celebrate the repeal of prohibition, very little hope for the issuances of licenses before Tuesday is expected by the Alcohol Beverage Control Board. No hard-liquor licenses have been received, and none will be before Tuesday at the earliest, is the belief.

Buyers were active in the wholesale markets here last week, their purchases covering a variety of holiday merchandise ranging from apparel to home wares. Although most of the interest was on Christmas goods, staple merchandise and early Spring apparel came in for a substantial share of attention.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 -- Developments last week gave the steel trade further assurance as to activity in the remainder of this year and the early part of the new year. The general tone of the market improved more and orders flowed steadily, although no new buyers appeared and no purchasers showed any material increase in requirements.

In the second half of "Blackbirds of 1933-1934," which opened at the Apollo Saturday evening, Bill Robinson makes two appearances. That is fortunate. In the midst of a floundering Negro revue he is the one master of style. Without wasting energy or time or directing attention to anything except his virtuoso feet he devotes himself to tap dancing, which is a form of physical exercise he has translated into magic.

Fighting for Last Place? It is reported that the proud Commonwealth of Utah has its heart set on being the thirty-sixth State to ratify the repeal amendment. At the risk of being belied by tomorrow afternoon's facts we venture to suggest that there must be a few men, women and children in Utah who are not all agog over the distinction.

Christians should regard death with love and trust rather than fear, the. Rev. Dr. Granville Mercer Williams, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin. 139 West Forty-sixth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Prizes were announced yesterday for the successful contestants at the Children's Science Fair, held under the auspices of the American Institute at the American Museum of Natural History. Exhibits at the fair, all the work of children under 18 years of age, were judged on the basis of original conception and application of scientific principles in an endless number of fields.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- A retreat by the Senate from its hitherto uncompromising stand against the licensing of taverns set the stage today for possible passage of a liquor control act by the Legislature tomorrow in time to provide for legal sale in Massachusetts with repeal Tuesday.

A formula for motor vehicle taxation is recommended by the Bureau of Railway Economics in a publication, "Economic Survey of Motor Vehicle Transportation in the United States" to be made public today. The bureau repeats several recommendations made by the Association of Railway Executives to the National Transportation Committee a year ago.

James P. Warburg, vice chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, and opponent of the Roosevelt administration's monetary policy, made public yesterday a letter written on Dec. 1 to Senator Borah, replying to the latter's criticism of Mr. Warburg's stand.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past four years and until quite recently this country was on a so-called gold basis, and during that period deflation ran its destructive course. Our banks, industries and labor suffered almost irreparable losses, and millions of men, women and children felt the pangs of hunger and want.

HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 3 (AP) -- From a three-mile height aboard an interisland land plane looking down through the clouds of steam that rose from the ring of hot lava pouring from the Mauna Loa volcano, the island of Hawaii today resembled a land of seething fire.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges were irregular last week, with trends somewhat higher in most cases. Trading was spasmodic, with fair activity early in the week and little business just before and after the holiday. Cash prices also were irregular.

GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- Germany cannot tear up the Versailles treaty without thereby resorting to precisely the same kind of methods of dictation that Chancellor Hitler has denounced so often as the root of the ills of Germany and Europe as a whole.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The cessation of the rise in the Reichsbank's reserves after a big increase during the four months following the June moratorium declaration is explicable only in the light of the impending conference with foreign bondholders.

The efforts of five Polish seamen to keep a German fishing vessel afloat during a storm in the North Sea in the hope of winning her for the Polish merchant marine were described yesterday as arrangements were announced for a testimonial dinner to be given tomorrow night to Captain Eustazy Borkowski of the Gdynia America liner Kosciuszko.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Securities issues involved in a program for the readjustment of the finances of Atlantic City and Atlantic County, N.J., were among those filed with the Federal Trade Commission during the last week.

A preview of the "Salon of American Humorists," a collection at 400 cartoons and caricatures by American artists from pre-Revolutionary days to the present, was held last night. The exhibition, at 480 Park Avenue, will be open to the general public today and for the rest of the month.
Industrial properties and housing were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported over the week-end.
