The Committee of Forty-four, under the chairmanship of Mr. C.C. BURLINGHAM, appointed last July by Governor LEHMAN to study the costs of education is all but unanimous in urging that there should be no diminution in the State's grant for 1934-35. The "considerable" majority goes further and recommends that the State return to the "full statutory provision," which would mean a substantial increase.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Under the impetus of recent satisfactory performances by streamlined, lightweight self-propelled railway coaches capable of a speed of ninety miles an hour, a move toward a "revolution" in railroad building is said here to be gaining headway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt has accomplished many excellent things. He has given hope to the hopeless; courage to the weak, and work and pay for the unemployed. These figures are greatly to his credit and must not be forgotten when criticizing other of his policies.

Contributions amounting to $51,429 were pledged last night to the 'Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at a dinner of the Bronx Division, honoring Abraham Krasne, held in the Hotel Commodore.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Asserting that it is either "Roosevelt or ruin," Father Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower, in a speech today renewed his defense of the administration's monetary policies. The address was broadcast over an independent book-up of radio stations.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Joseph C. Stancook of the class of 1935 was elected captain of the Army football eleven for the 1934 season as the team returned from New York today following is game with Notre Dame.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Elevator interests which had millions of bushels of corn sold for December delivery have bought it in and resold it for May to get carrying charges Of 6 1/2 to 7 cents a bushel, which is unusually profitable. The open interest in corn on the Board of Trade here yesterday was 4,501,000 bushels, while a week ago it was 26,425,000 bushels.
Two important changes in the rules of the game were adopted yesterday as the United States Inter-collegiate Lacrosse Association concluded its fifty-first annual convention at the Hotel Paramount.

It has been historically true that champions of inflated currency grow shrill and violent whenever their ideas are questioned. That familiar stage has been reached today. All bankers are robbers. Every financial expert who speaks for sound money is either in the pay of Great Britain or hired by the wicked money-changers of Wall Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Many traders in grains and commodities express the belief that the government's inflationary plans have failed thus far to accomplish what they were expected to do in the way of advancing prices. The grain markets have fallen into a rut where there is no incentive for trade leaders to take more than a scalping interest and where prices on the whole mean nothing.

The present busy week in the art world includes among the outstanding events, the Whitney Museum's first biennial exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, watercolors and prints, with a private view today and opening to the public tomorrow.
SOUTH CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 3 (AP). -- Richard Henry Warren, formerly a prominent New York organist and musician, died today at his home here at the age of 74.
DECATUR, Ala., Dec. 3 -- Testimony given by Ruby Bates from a hospital bed in New York will be presented here tomorrow to the jury of fanners before whom Clarence Morris is being tried for his life.

Dr. Charles G. Pease, vegetarian, teetotaler and president of the Non-Smokers Protective League, will observe his seventy-ninth birthday anniversary today. He will abstain from all the things most persons usually indulge in when they celebrate. Tea, coffee, cocoa and even chocolates are frowned upon by the doctor.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 4 -- Japan's second supplementary naval building plan, funds for which are now provided, comprises two B class cruisers of 8,500 tons each and carrying 6-inch guns; two aircraft carriers of 10,000 tons each, fourteen destroyers and four submarines.

With three minutes left to play in the third period, the New York Giants professional football team trailed Pittsburgh, 3 -- 0, yesterday and apparently was headed for its first defeat at the Polo Grounds in seven games.

The steadily increasing activity of shipping moving to and from the Port of New York in the last three months has nearly overcome the losses sustained in the first six months of the year, according to a survey by the Shipping Register.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- Thomas Cadwalader, an attorney and member of a prominent old Philadelphia family, shot and killed himself today in his home, "Stonedge," at Fort Washington. The act was caused by ill-health, according to the coroner, R. Ronald Dettre, of Montgomery County.

Important programs of game conservation will be put forth this Winter at Washington and in the State capitals where Legislatures are meeting. It is so each year, although it would seem at first glance that additional laws are unnecessary.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Thomas Webster Edgar will give a luncheon Wednesday at the Embassy Club for Miss Mary KingSmith, whose engagement to Robert Woodward Prosser 2d was announced recently.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 3. -- W. Murdock, E. McGrath and P. J. Collins tied for the high handicap cup in the regular shoot over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. Each finished with a full card of 45. G. Schwalb was the high scratch gunner, with 42.

Gerritsen Beach at 9 A.M. yesterday was very much like any other waterfront settlement on a dull Sunday. The long rows of cottages looked out on almost empty streets. The few inhabitants who were abroad moved with a certain Sabbath decorum.

President ROOSEVELT has more than once expressed the hope that Federal aid will not dry up local charity. He is deeply impressed with the importance of keeping charitable agencies alive and efficient. Under this definition the Neediest Cases Fund has full right to press its special appeal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Crude oil stocks at refineries declined 1,521,000 barrels in October, according to the United States Bureau of Mines, which reported today that total October receipts at refineries were 74,355,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,399,000.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Selection of an Eastern team to meet Stanford University in the Rose Bowl football game at Pasadena New Year's Day was believed tonight by observers to have narrowed down to a choice among Pittsburgh, Princeton and Columbia Universities.

Trade Gains Need Adjustment. Figures available yesterday indicated many stores made heavy gains in trade last Friday and Saturday over the corresponding days a year ago. The combination of clearance sales and Christmas buying last Friday resulted in increases over the corresponding day last year of 50 per cent or more.

Since it is based on a novel, "Tobacco Road," which was acted at the Masque last evening, is not an organic play. Although Jack Kirkland has turned it into three acts, it is still Erskine Caldwell's novel at heart, which is to say that it is more like a soliloquy with variations than a dramatic character sketch.

Thomas F. Dougherty, assistant chief of the New York Fire Department, will retire today after forty-six years' service. Chief Dougherty, besides being a veteran of hundreds of fires, has contributed to the science of fire-fighting by his writings and mechanical inventions, which he gave to the department without royalties.

In the Long Room of Fraunces Tavern, at Broad and Pearl Streets, where Washington bade farewell to his military aides 150 years ago, the State chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution held their fiftieth annual meeting yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Twelve men and three woman, elected on a State-wide ballot last month, will assemble at Harrisburg at noon tomorrow and by unanimous vote put Pennsylvania on record for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Ways and Means Committee will receive tomorrow a draft of general tax legislation tentatively designed to bring in between $235,000,000 and $270,000,000, and to embody modification of income taxes which would effect deductions to offset capital gains and tighten the loopholes through which great amounts in taxes have been legally evaded in the past few years.

Partial settlement of the dispute involving compliance with its Blue Eagle obligations by Loft, Inc., operating a chain of candy stores and restaurants, was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, New York NRA administrator and chairman of the local compliance board, following the completion of an investigation of the case and a report to the National Compliance Board in Washington.

The Democratic split in the Bronx between the party organization headed by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn and the Tammany faction headed by Park Commissioner Thomas J. Dolen will come to a head today, when the Dolen group will present a petition to the Board of Elections for the removal of the Democratic election inspectors in the Twenty-first Senatorial District on the ground of party disloyalty.

The Interborough's first "noise proof" train, with six of its ten cars equipped with special devices for interior ventilation and the exclusion of the ordinary din of high speed subway operation, went into service yesterday on the Broadway line between Van Cortlandt Park and New Lots Avenue.
The price of drinks will be brought down today by repeal to almost half the recent bootleg and speakeasy level.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- The first shots were fired tonight in the revolt of the Sixth Congressional District against the holding of an election without a primary tomorrow. This followed by a few hours the hanging and burning in effigy of Huey P. Long, senior Senator and "Kingfish" of Louisiana.

Four institutions share equally in the residuary estate of Miss Ella S. Clock, daughter of the late Eliphalet and Phoebe Clock of Islip, L.I., it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court. Miss Clock died at her home, 380 Riverside Drive, on Nov. 25, leaving an estate declared formally at "more than $20,000."
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A high official said today that the British Government regarded with "benevolent interest" any negotiations that would open the door of the United States to more British liquor.

Loans on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange and carried in New York increased $13,047,506 in November to $789,229,539, according to a compilation by the Exhange. At the end of October total loans were $776,182,033, compared with $896,595,531 at the close of September.

Mr. J.H. THOMAS, Secretary of State for the Dominions, is expected to make a statement in the House of Commons in regard to the Government's attitude in respect of the Irish " crisis," which he has done much to provoke and in regard to which he seems innocently to have played into DE VALERA'S hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Inclusion of airport construction in the new Civil Works program and the allocation to State agencies of representatives of the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce to assist in the approval of all airports to be developed as civil works projects, was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Administrator of Emergency Relief and Civil Works.

It was a "bird in flight" that caused the downfall Sunday night of the cultured young man in the raccoon coat, who carried two heavy, expensive handbags. For the bird, being only a chromiumplated automobile radiator cap, failed to fly fast enough and the man who gave it to a taxicab driver as a tip found himself locked up, accused of grand larceny.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- The Busy American gelding, Flying Cadet, broke a sequence of losing favorites when he got home first at even money in the fifth race at Jefferson Park today. The result enabled him to turn the tables on Malimou, which last Friday had beaten Flying Cadet by a head.
Although the sale of alcoholic beverages becomes legal tonight, wines and whiskies will be available only in the 1,000 restaurants, clubs and hotels that have licenses.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 4 -- A move to broaden the outlook of the Pan American Conference by admitting observers from Spain and Portugal and a Mexican proposal for inter-American systems of banking and currency were made at the first plenary session of the conference today.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Warren Bynner Nash will give a small reception this afternoon at 410 Park Avenue, at which she will introduce her daughter, Miss Kathleen Whately Jackson.
New York will have imported liquors today, but the stock will come from warehouses and not "right off the boat," shipping men predicted.

Henry J. Fisher, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced yesterday that to date contributions and pledges totaling $145,785 had been received in the campaign for support of free service in its fifty-six hospitals. Mr. Fisher made his announcement to the fund's executive committee at a luncheon at the Bankers Club.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4 -- What is believed to be the first lawsuit against the "one-year rule" of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board was started here today, when James M. O'Connell, attorney for the Nassau County Liquor Dealers Association, obtained an order directing the board to show why a permit should not be issued to one of his clients, a member of the association.
PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Dec. 4 -- The strange death of a 20-year-old girl stirred Princess Anne, the scene of October's lynching and more recently the focal point of troops sent to arrest lynch suspects.

PEIPING, Tuesday, Dec. 5 -- Reports of the capture of Tihwa (Urumchi), political centre of Chinese Turkestan, by the 24-year-old Mohammedan General Ma Hungying are reviving hopes for restoration of peace and order in that vast disordered territory.

Moccasin snake venom is being successfully used to decrease bleeding in hospital patients, it was disclosed yesterday at the ninth annual December dental meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Dr. Nathan Rosenthal, hematologist, or blood expert, at Mount Sinai Hospital, revealed the use of the venom in a casual reference during a discussion of bleeding gums.

Mrs. F. Ritter Shumway gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for the Baron and Baroness Traverso of Florence, Italy. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Sykes, Mr. and Mrs. H. Bertram Legg, Mr. and Mrs. George W. Welch, Mrs. Marion M. McMillin, Charles Fletcher, Warren Brown, William Bradley, Dr. William Bishop and J. Stewart Brown.

After a survey of the Republican county leaders of the State, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the State Committee, expressed a conviction yesterday that Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies had not received a sufficient number of pledges from Republican members of the 1934 Assembly to insure his re-election for the Speakership by Republican votes.

Benefits accruing to the shoe manufacturing industry under its two-months-old NRA code were outlined yesterday at the thirtieth annual convention and style conference of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- General Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, capitulated in "principle" today to the demand by organized labor that labor be represented on code authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A jobless man who claims kinship with the King of England wrote his sovereign that he was forced to wash his own dirty linen in a backroom "and that of the royal family in public for a living."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- The Board of Supervisors of West Chester County at its meeting today officially levied assessments for tax delinquencies against communities that have failed to pay their 1933 taxes in full. While these delinquencies amount with, interest to $4,564,284, the county has sold only $3,060,000 in tax-delinquency certificates against the defaulting communities.

Five more city officials filed applications with the New York Employes Retirement System for retirement on pensions yesterday, making 110 such requests which are to be passed upon by the Board of Estimate on Friday, the largest number at any one time in the city's history.

The removal of the trustees in bankruptcy of the Paramount Publix Corporation was sought yesterday in an appeal before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals by Samuel Zirn, attorney for creditors of the bankrupt corporation. The motion also included the petition to reopen the first meeting for the election of the trustees.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The Lufthansa says the refueling ship Westfalen has been instructed to aid Colonel Lindbergh in any way possible, but says he has not applied for facilities and is not expected to land at the ship in the South Atlantic, as it is now near the Brazilian shore.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- With official count revealing more colonists now occupying their villas than were present on Jan. 1 last year, indications are strong for the earliest and most brilliant season since 1928.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asked tonight that liquor control regulations be so framed that those who buy liquor may ''do so in an open, direct and commonplace way."

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- On the eve of making his anxiously awaited pronouncement on Anglo-Irish relations tomorrow, J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, told the House of Commons today that Britain had "no intention of imposing any hardship on the Free State."
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Trial on indictments handed up in connection with the Passaic County jury-fixing investigation will begin next Monday.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- A call to German Protestants to make common cause with Catholics in defense of Christianity against pagan and racial teachings by Nazis was issued from the pulpit of St. Michael's Church in Munich by Cardinal Faulhaber yesterday.

Two different groups of people will greet the end of national prohibition today. One of them will be thinking of the large and public aspects of repeal. The day is surely a fit occasion for dwelling upon the strange and almost inscrutable ways of a great democracy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Not less than 74 per cent of all traders in wheat and corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last June 30 were classified as speculators in a report today by the Grain Futures Administration, on the results of its investigation into the collapse of the grain markets in July.
Ninety extra patrolmen and nine sergeants will make certain tonight that Times Square crowds keep their hilarity within reasonable bounds while celebrating the death of prohibition.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 (AP) Utah is ready to drive home the thirty-sixth and final nail in the coffin of Federal prohibition, but will do it with such ceremony that the nation will not get a legal drink of "hard" liquor until late tomorrow afternoon or early evening.
One of the four murals painted for Rockefeller Center by Frank Brangwyn, British artist, was placed in position yesterday in the main corridor of the RCA Building.

Creditors of Francois Coty, French perfumer, politician and newspaper proprietor, are seeking property belonging to him in this country after taking legal steps abroad, it was revealed yesterday. His former wife, Mme. Yvonne Alexandrine Le Baron, through her attorney, Francis L. Kohlman, filed a default judgment for $5,760,622 in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

George Brothers, Salem-Crescent A.C. light heavyweight, outpointed Raymond Miller of Essex Prep in the special intercity bout which featured the amateur boxing program at the New York A.C. last night.

The first strike of workers under the Civil "Works Administration occurred yesterday when 2,700 men employed on work projects at Bear Mountain and vicinity refused to go to their jobs unless their demands affecting wages and hours of employment were granted.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Declaring that Father Charles E. Coughlin is "on the side of the angels" in his advocacy of the Roosevelt recovery program, the Right Rev. Mgr. John A. Ryan of Washington told the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems today that Father Coughlin is "enlisting the masses" to fight for the recovery cause.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 4 -- Striking with speed and precision, a gang of five bank bandits robbed the Wollaston branch of the Quincy Trust Company of more than $20,000 in five minutes today and escaped after beating a customer and terrorizing employes.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Governor A. Harry Moore indicated tonight in an interview with reporters that he would veto the Liquor Control Bill tomorrow.

Formation of an association of investment banking houses to supervise the licensing of new security offerings in order to permit the bankers to regulate their own business was advocated yesterday by Henry F. Holthusen of the law firm of House, Holthusen McCloskey.

A hearing will be held before Chancellor Wolcott in Wilmington, Del., on Dec. 20 on a plan for reorganization of the Central States Edison Company submitted by F.J. Young and Ivan Culbertson, receivers.

WE haven't read all of the 5,000-odd books published this year, but if Ralph Roeder's "The Man of the Renaissance" (Viking, $3,50) isn't the best book which these twelve months have seen then the publishers have been very remiss in bringing some overlooked candidate to our attention. Mr. Roeder has pretty nearly everything.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Supreme Court today granted the City of New York until July 1, 1934, to complete its incinerator system and to cease dumping garbage at sea off the New Jersey coast.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 4 -- In the destruction by fire yesterday of the seventy-year-old Law Courts Building here virtually all the judicial archives of Turkey until 1923, when the capital was moved to Angora, were lost.

Money market was quiet and steady all day. Except that a little Street money was done at 5/8, while the Exchange rate remained at 3/4, there were no variations in other sections of the market. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all unchanged in quotation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Yale athletic officials were urged today by The Yale Daily News to allow a longer period of training prior to the opening of the football season.

In his debut recital in the Town Hall last night, Franklyn Baur, tenor, revealed unusual gifts of sensitivity and musicianship. Debussy is a perilous test of a singer's taste and command of bis instrument. He must not only encompass difficult phrasing and intervals, but project Debussey's unique combination of cool, liquid detachment and a volupte that is more of air and water than of the human heart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- National prohibition will pass into history as an unsuccessful experiment late tomorrow afternoon or evening -- thirteen years, ten months, eighteen days and a few hours after it was declared in effect.

There is no longer any doubt that we are "far more than half over the road leading out of the depression," Grover Whalen, local NRA head, told women of the city yesterday at a convention at the Hotel Biltmore called by the local women's division of the NRA, of which Miss Emma Dot Partridge is chairman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Farmers are estimated to have seeded around 40,000,000 acres for next year's harvest of Winter wheat, or virtually the same as a year ago. The plan of the Department of Agriculture called for a reduction of 15 per cent from the 1931-33 average, which, if followed, would have resulted in about 36,200,000 acres being seeded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The "H. H. Rogers" named as one of the seventeen subparticipants with Harry F. Sinclair in a purchasing syndicate which dealt in Sinclair Consolidated Oil stock in 1928-29, and who was mentioned in an exhibit submitted to the Senate Stock Exchange Investigating Committee on Dec. 11, was not identified except that, at the time, he probably was connected with an Oklahoma bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The remainder of the $90,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, of which former Vice President Dawes became chairman of the board several weeks before the advance was made, has been overdue almost a year and never renewed.
Wall Street Variations. Wall Street's attitude toward President ROOSEVELT may be briefly described as that of a sullen and defeated bully who goes along 90 per cent of the way with his policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A policy of moderation was continued today in the administration's monetary activities, as officials studied commodity price trends, tax proposals, plans for the Dec. 15 Treasury financing, and other features of the President's recovery program.

Trading was quiet yesterday in the listed bond market. Under the impetus of the stronger dollar in the foreign exchange market, United States Government bonds and domestic corporation issues of all classification made moderate gains in the forenoon, but later, when the dollar reacted slightly from its highest point, the government list turned weaker, closing 12-32 point lower to 4-32 higher.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 4 -- Renewed conferences on Stock Exchange regulation which brought the leading officials of the New York Stock Exchange to Washington today coincident with White House talks on that topic greatly strengthened a common understanding that such regulation is imminent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- One American group which, tomorrow night, will be celebrating the end of prohibition can be definitely acquitted of the charge by some drys that the jubilation is all founded on the wish to consume liquor freely and takes no thought of the morrow.

The 'stock markets' movements became increasingly lethargic yesterday. Not only was the turnover on the Stock Exchange smaller than usual -- 671,000 shares, compared with 813,000 shares on Friday -- but the fluctuations were narrower than in many weeks.
In the inauguration of play in Group 1 of the Class B Metropolitan League squash racquets matches last night, the Harvard, Yale and Princeton clubs proved victorious.

Harry F. Sinclair and other officers of the former Sinclair Oil Company, now the Consolidated Oil Corporation, were sued in the Supreme Court yesterday by a stockholder for an accounting of $12,000,000 profits alleged to have been made in 1928 in a pool of 1,300,000 shares of Sinclair stock.

In the first day's mail received yesterday from those who read the Hundred Neediest Cases in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday were 105 contributions of varying amounts, compared with 136 contributions on the corresponding day last year. Yesterday's gifts totaled $11,468,21.

Pending the return of W. Arthur Cunningham, Controller-elect, to the city shortly, Mayor-elect LaGuardia began a series of preliminary conferences yesterday with the men who are to serve with him in the Board of Estimate after Jan. 1.

The Tennessee Valley Authority will finance further experiments with the huge 10,000,000 -- volt electrostatic generator developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology because of its possibilities in connection with power transmission.

Reorganization of guaranteed mortgage certificate issues in New York on a scale described by some realty interests as "broader than any heretofore attempted" has been started by the certificate holders themselves after many months of delay and uncertainty arising from other proposals for rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The constitutional validity of much of the drastic legislation enacted by States and by the Federal Government to meet the economic emergency was believed at stake when the Supreme Court took up for consideration the New York milk case.

An unchanged price of $34.01 anounce for newly mined domestic gold, the third successive day at the same level, sent the dollar higher yesterday on the foreign exchanges. A scarcity of offerings resulted in a reaction at the close. Government bonds, also higher at the opening of trading, ended the day much easier.

Extra police protection was provided yesterday for Christmas shoppers and all the main shopping districts in the city. At the same time, Commissioner of Buildings Fassler sent to all department stores a list of fifteen recommendations to guard against fire, Commissioner Fassler also announced that representatives of his department would make daily inspections to make sure the building laws are being obeyed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Judge Joseph B. David gave orders today for the trial of "Dr. Alice Lindway Wynekoop to begin a month from today and clamped down, meanwhile, on further public statements by State and defense attorneys on the operating room murder case.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 4 -- Mrs. E.I. Shewbridge's 3-year-old filly Washout raced excellently over the five-furlong route at the new Charles Town track today to win the featured event by a length. The Middleburg Stable's Glorify was second and W.I. Newmarch's Vacillate third, another length behind Glorify.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Harry H. Freeman, municipal finance and research expert of Buffalo, N.Y., arrived here tonight to become the first city manager under the form of government becoming effective at noon tomorrow. The selection of Mr. Freeman was announced after a meeting attended by Councilmen-elect Sidney L. Henry, Louis P, Groce, James J. Digney and Sherman O Dennis.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Spectacular scoring feats of the Maple Leafs in the past week of the National Hockey League campaign were reflected in the scoring statistics issued today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Plans were under way today for an attack on the New Jersey liquor regulations by the State Grange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Applications for admission into the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by banks not members of the Federal Reserve System numbered 6,748 up to noon today, according to Walter J. Cummings, chairman.

Pearl S. Buck's new novel "The Mother" will be published on Jan. 10 by the John Day Company, with a first printing of 50,000 copies. The first announcement by the publishers says that so far American book-sellers have received more than $875,000 from the sale of books by Mrs. Buck.
DUNEDIN, N.Z., Tuesday, Dec. 5 -- The motor ship Wyatt Earp, carrying Lincoln Ellsworth and his Antarctic expedition, left Dunedin at 1 P.M. today.

The fight to reorganize Tammanny by trying to oust John F. Curry as leader, which was inaugurated by the unsuccessful candidacy of Joseph V. McKee for Mayor on the Recovery party ticket, will be continued for years, if necessary, it appeared yesterday when the newly formed Charles F. Murphy Association leased the entire building at 353 Second Avenue as permanent headquarters.

A personal minority report by Dean Clark, consulting engineer and member of Governor Lehman's committee on public education costs, made public yesterday, lists nine points of disagreement with the majority report which recommended an increase in State aid for education.

There should be close to 1,000 restaurants, hotels and clubs ready to serve wines and liquors when repeal becomes effective this evening, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board said yesterday, and before the end of the week there will be at least another thousand licenses for such, places in the mails.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- Art connoisseurs and museums of many lands, especially the United States, were represented here today at the auction of part of the Guelph Treasure, unique and internationally famous art collection founded 100 years ago by Prince Karl Anton of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 4 -- A Mexican move to enlarge the agenda of the Pan-American Conference materialized today. Dr. Jose M. Puig Casauranc, the Mexican Foreign Minister, asked the steering committee to add a chapter of fifteen items, including governmental debts.

The bondholders' protective committee for Electric Public Service Company secured 6s, Series A and B, due in 1941, and first-lien 5 1/2s due in 1942, is mailing to bondholders a plan of reorganization which was submitted to the Chancellor of the State of Delaware for approval on Nov. 29.

With three challenges by British yachtsmen for international events including the America's Cup, already in hand and as many matches being arranged for next Summer a fourth inquiry was received yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The long-awaited hearing to be conducted by Secretary Ickes as Oil Administrator under the petroleum code was again postponed today after conferences between the Secretary and proponents and opponents of price-fixing.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 4 -- The defense committee of the Estonian Parliament today approved appropriation for two submarines and four torpedo boats as the first part of a new naval program. Finland recently completed two cruisers and three submarines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Dec. 1:

The first Biennial Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Watercolors and Prints opens to the public today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, to remain until Jan. 11. The museum has two biennials, held in alternate years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Although the RFC loan to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company went into technical "default" Dec. 23, 1932, this step was taken advisedly at the suggestion of the RFC, according to information here.

The machinery designed for operation of the Federal Government's civil works program in this city will begin full work this morning when Travis Whitney, newly appointed local Civil Works Administrator, assumes his duties at the CWA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, Sixteenth Street and Eighth Avenue.

The Columbia University football team will play in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., on New Year's Day against Stanford. This was announced yesterday following several hours of conference among the athletic officials of the local institution.

DECATUR, Ala., Dec. 4 -- The second of the Scottsboro cases went to the jury tonight after a dramatic scene in which Judge W.W. Callanan, at the insistence of Samuel S. Leibowitz, chief of defense counsel, amended and emended the charge he had just delivered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that John (Jake the Barber) Factor must go to England to face charges of participatng in an $8,000,000 swindle.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4 -- Nassau County's celebration of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment tomorrow will be a dry one, officially at any rate. No permits have been received from the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board for the county, according to William Curley, deputy in charge of the county organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Mrs. Roosevelt returned today from her Thanksgiving holiday at Warm Springs and plunged without an hour's delay into the problem of the placement of women under the civil works program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Under the caption "Tories, Chiselers, Dead Cats, Witch Doctors, Bank Wreckers, Traitors" the Republican National Committee resumed its campaign against the Roosevelt recovery program tonight.

The ranks of women owners engaged in racing horses will be increased further next season, it was learned yesterday, when the colors of the Manhasset Stable are carried for the first time. The Manhasset Stable will be conducted by Mrs. Charles S. Payson, daughter of Mrs. Payne Whitney, and Mrs. Thomas I. Laughlin, the former Louise Bailey.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- On the eve of the conference between Germany's creditors and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, which begins tomorrow and is to decide whether the German transfer moratorium is to be prolonged in its present discriminatory form, both sides observed today the silence of poker players.
Spirits, forbidden by the nation for thirteen years, may legally be sold this afternoon in at least sixteen States.

A rise in dollar exchange and a decline in sterling to the lowest figure in more than three weeks, together with the lowest wheat quotations since the gold-buying policy was started on Oct. 23, depressed prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

Contributions to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is raising $4,000,000 for unemployment relief, approached the $2,000,000 mark yesterday with the announcement by James G. Blaine, campaign chairman, of gifts totaling $1,801,377.

HAVANA, Dec. 4 -- Two hundred armed men seized the postoffice and custom house at Hanzanillo, Oriente Province, today to keep an inspector sent from Havana from taking over these departments. Rural guards attacked the raiders and after a short battle dispersed them.

Charles H. (Chuck) Klein, star outfielder who recently was traded by the Phillies to the Chicago Cubs, won the batting championship of the National League with a mark of 368 for the 1932 season, according to the official averages released for publication today.

Walter Oertly of the New York A.C. and R.C. Aikenhead Jr. of the Columbia University Club were forced to extra games to win as the National Class C Fall squash tennis tournament got under way yesterday at the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Nov. 29 shows increases for the week of $53,000,000 in loans and investments and $75,000,000 in net demand deposits, and decreases of $35,000,000 in time deposits, $98,000,000 in government deposits and $101,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Preparations for repeal proceeded yesterday in nearly a thousand establishments licensed for consumption on the premises throughout the city -- and in ten times as many speakeasies -- on the assumption that every one who has ever taken a drink will want one today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 4 -- Notre Dame's Ramblers, who found themselves in their final game of an otherwise dismal season to beat the Army, received a tumultuous welcome today as they came back home.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 5 -- Nanking having completed distribution of more than 80,000 reinforcements along the Southern Chekiang Province border, a government spokesman characterizes its attitude as "waiting for war to come."

The Fourteenth Biennial Exposition of Chemical Industries opened yesterday afternoon at Grand Central Palace with hundreds of exhibits illustrating the advances made in chemical industry and engineering during the last two years. It will be open daily throughout the week from noon until 10:30 P. M., with the exception of Saturday, when it will close at 6 P.M.

In police stations throughout the city at 9:30 o'clock last night the alarm warning bells on the teletype machines clanged and the police radio announcer boomed to squad cars on patrol. Code Signal 8, all cars: Code Signal 8, all cars."

A marked improvement in leasing activity directly due to the surety of prohibition repeal has been a bright feature in the realty market during the last few weeks, William B. Falconer, executive vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, reports.

A group of wholesalers of liquors and wines was endeavoring yesterday to obtain from Washington a ruling that would permit removals from government warehouses last night and this morning without the formalities of prohibition department permits.
Several flats and a variety of dwellings made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday:
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Princeton's first undefeated and untied football season since 1922 was celebrated tonight.
The Eastern coach, with all his staff, Was standing in the hall. The Rose Bowl bid was in, and they Were waiting for the call. The faculty was huddling and The Dean still held the ball.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Two hundred police officials, sheriffs and district attorneys promised full cooperation in enforcing the rules of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board today.
Deals by operators and banks in Manhattan and the Bronx, including further activity by Frederick Brown, featured the local realty transactions reported yesterday.

A sample specimen of labradorite, which is to be the base of George Grey Barnard's rainbow arch war memorial, was taken by vandals from the front of the fullsized model of the arch, now on public exhibition in the former power house at 216th Street and the Harlem River.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Governor Moore signed today the bill of Assemblyman Thomas M. Muir of Union County, making the owner liable if a dog bites a person who is lawfully on the premises where the attack occurs. The measure had been opposed by Emerson L. Richards, president of the Senate, on the ground it made the owner responsible even if all reasonable precautions had been taken.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The new Japanese naval construction program will, if ratified by the Japanese Diet, bring that navy up to maximum London treaty strength. The previous program, which is superseded by the new one, called for one aircraft carrier of 10,000 tons displacement, two light cruisers of 8,500 tons each, seven destroyers of 1,300 to 1,400 tons each and six submarines of an undisclosed tonnage.

William C. Dodge, District Attorney-elect of New York County, announced yesterday that he would "force" the newspapers to recognize him "as an honest and competent prosecutor" and promised some "surprises" during his first few weeks in office.

BATHURST, Gambia, Dec. 4 -- Their big red monoplane held in the Gambia River by an almost dead calm, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh waited tonight for the first fresh wind to lift them on a flight to South America.
"All Good Americans," by Laura and S.J. Perelman, opens tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre. The cast includes Hope Williams and Fred Keating.

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements for December, issued tonight, shows its position on Nov. 30 was virtually the same as on Oct. 31, its funds totaling roughly $130,000,000 gold, a decline of about $1,000,000.
"All Good Americans," by Laura and S.J. Perelman, opens tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre. The cast includes Hope Williams and Fred Keating.

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements for December, issued tonight, shows its position on Nov. 30 was virtually the same as on Oct. 31, its funds totaling roughly $130,000,000 gold, a decline of about $1,000,000.

Ignoring all last-minute pleas for drastic economies to fit the city's impaired financial position the Board of Aldermen adopted, at 1 o'clock this morning, a 1934 budget aggregating $551,004,248, after cutting a scant $3,604,264.74 from the tentative figure of $554,608,512 set by the Board of Estimate on Oct. 31.

A campaign to oust John F. Curry from leadership of the Democratic party was announced by a group of young men who fought off the attempts of a Tammany group to gain control of the New York Young Democratic Club at its annual meeting last night at the Hotel Taft.

Commodities traded on local exchanges opened weak, on the unchanged gold-purchase price. In later dealings, however, there was a moderate recovery in most markets. Trading was in relatively small volume. Cash prices were mainly lower.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- New Jersey, which voted overwhelmingly in favor of repeal, faced the possibility tonight of being officially bone dry, even as regards 3.2 beer, for a time after the Eighteenth Amendment gives way to the Twenty-first.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 -- Seventy-one debutantes, including eight from New York, made their formal entrance into society tonight at the first Bachelors Cotillion at the Lyric. There was a larger number of debutantes from out of town than usual.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- I am in hearty accord with Senator Thomas, Professor Warren, and, indeed, with all the world in desiring an early general rise of prices from the present low level.
Two youths were met by a fusillade of shots last night in front of 5 Prince Street, about 100 feet from the Bowery. One was killed and the second was taken to Bellevue Hospital critically wounded.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The Boerse opened the week with a sagging price trend, attributed in the main to foreign, chiefly Russian, sales of I.G. Farben and Siemens Halske, which lost around 2 points each. The opening of the creditors' conference on prolongation of the moratorium on bonds likewise advised caution.

A group of young women, headed by Countess Eleanora Colloredo-Mannsfeld, are aiding in arrangements for a bundle reception and tea for the benefit of the new Generosity Thrift Shop to be held Dec. 12 in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle.

The National Industrial Traffic League warned against parity of Federal regulation as between the railroads and competitive forms of transportation as "not practical at the present time," in a statement yesterday to Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator of transportation.

Announcement yesterday by the New York Public Service Commission of prescriptions for establishment of uniform systems of accounts for public utilities in this State aroused much concern in gas and electric company circles, but no comments will be made until the commission's orders have been received and analyzed.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 4 -- The steering committee of the Pan American Conference today unanimously approved a resolution presented by Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina, proposing the creation of a preparatory committee for a Pan American economic and commercial conference.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Another act in the drama of national prohibition repeal will be staged here tomorrow as Ohio formally ratifies the Twenty-first Amendment.

With seven colleges as affiliates, the New York City Intercollegiate Chess League was organized yesterday at the headquarters of the N.Y.U. Chess Club, South Hall, Washington Square. The meeting was attended by representatives of N.Y.U., City College, Columbia, Brooklyn College, Seth Low, St. John's and Yeshiva.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Cards began falling today in first-round matches for championships of the American Bridge League.

Secretary ICKES has replied to criticism of the Public Works Administration with a broadside of figures. They show that in the last week of November 608,000 men were directly employed on Federal and local projects financed in whole or in part with funds placed at the disposal of the PWA by Congress.

When earthquake, fire or pestilence overwhelms a community, the shock of disaster and the ineradicable heroism of man in disaster combine, to rally amazing forces of reconstruction. It is one of the characteristics of the Neediest among all the thousands of needy this year that they do not give up hope.

The Rev. Dr. Harold S. Laird, pastor of the First and Central Presbyterian Church, Wilmington, Del., unanimously was nominated yesterday afternoon as the candidate of the Fundamentalist group in that denomination for the next Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 4 -- The East answered the Rose Bowl call today for the tenth time in the eighteen years of the annual New Year's Day classic, when Columbia announced to Stanford's representative here, Al Masters, graduate manager, that it had accepted the Rose tournament football bid.

Jim Browning, world's heavyweight wrestling champion, successfully defended his title last night in Madison Square Garden when he threw Sammy Stein in 25:03. A crowd of 8,000 spectators witnessed the bout.

Some of the best deer hunting in the United States is enjoyed in the most thickly populated regions of the country, as the opening of the season in Massachusetts yesterday may have reminded sportsmen.

The Yorkville dinner dances in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association will be resumed this season. The first dance in the series will take place next Tuesday and the second on Jan. 23. Both will be held at Sherry's.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- Francis Clare Curtin of North Abington, Mass., was elected captain of the 1934 Yale football team tonight. The election was unanimous, twenty-seven members of the Eli squad voting.

The sale of a tall loft building in West Twenty-ninth Street and the leasing of several other structures in Manhattan, including one on upper Broadway and another on Columbus Avenue, formed the chief features of realty trading yesterday.

Encouraged by the success of the Young Republicans in bringing down Mr. KOENIG, the Young Democrats of the New York Young Democratic Club are pursuing or trying to pursue Mr. CURRY and dislodge him from Ms lair. This club called in vain last Spring for AL SMITH to lead the chase.

HAVANA, Dec. 5. -- Employes of the Compania Cubana Electricidad the largest American corporation in Cuba and an affiliate of the Electric Bond and Share Company today presented forty-one demands to officials of the company. The workers threatened to walk out un less their demands were accepted Within forty-eight hours.

The National City Bank of New York announced yesterday plans for a sweeping revision of its capital structure involving the sale to the RFC of $50,000,000 of preferred stock and a reduction of $56,500,000 in the present capital funds for the purpose of writing down all known losses.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- Rejoicing at repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, H.L. Mencken, long its foe, today took occasion to toss a barb at the politicians and the "political parsons," and paid tribute to Captain William H. Stayton, organizer of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment.

A small centrifuge motor about the size of a teacup, capable of sending its tiny steel rotor at a speed of 1,200,000 revolutions a minute, and developing a centrifugal force 7,600,000 times greater than the force of gravity, was placed on exhibition yesterday at the fourteenth biennial exposition of chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 5. -- The Fukien Province rebellion, which was proclaimed a fortnight ago, is proving one of the strangest in the twenty-two-year history of the Chinese Republic.

The Bronx Democratic organization headed by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn and the Tammany faction each will nominate a candidate for State Senator in the Twenty-first district to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Henry G. Schackno, City Court Justice-elect, at the special election on Dec. 28.

The words "Prohibition Division," painted years ago in gilt letters on the main entrance of a suite of rooms on the fifth floor of the Federal Building, were all that remained yesterday in the United States Attorney's office as a reminder of the dry era.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Mark Twain received today belated credit for the authorship of the expression, "the New Deal," the slogan of the Roosevelt administration.

Sales of the first seven chain-store organizations to report for November amounted to $43,742,034, or 5.2 per cent more than in the same month last year. No company reported sales smaller than the year before. In October the sales of twenty representative chain-store systems were 4.8 per cent larger than in the corresponding period of 1932.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings slightly improved their position at the top of the American group of the National Hockey League by tying with the Montreal Maroons, 1 -- 1, in an over-time game tonight. The tie added 1 point to Detroit's total and left the Red Wings 2 points ahead of the second-place Chicago Black Hawks.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 5. -- Mrs. W.T. Anderson's Lebam won her second victory of the current meeting at Epsom Downs today when she scored by a nose over Mrs. A. R. Smith's Out Bound in a six-furlong dash, which held the feature position on the program.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- America's "historic hour," represented by the abolition of prohibition, was welcomed in Germany as marking the return to sanity. Newspapers devote large banner headlines and long columns to reports of the event.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5. -- Invoking what he termed the American tradition and ideal of fair play, George B. Cortelyou, president of the Edison Electric Institute and former Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday demanded that the Federal Government refrain from financing publicly owned utility plants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- John S. Hurly, deputy chief of the Department of Justice's Bureau of Investigation, in charge of prohibition enforcement, said today that the present force of 1,300 would remain as now deployed in the dry and wet States until the Treasury set up its machinery of internal revenue agents for enforcement of the revenue laws.
Several important matters are expected to be aired at the first fortnightly meeting of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 5. -- The Pan American Conference devoted its activities today to organizing its committees. Then its members attended a state dinner tonight given by President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay at the Legislative Palace.
Wild ducks are beginning to leave this sector, according to the latest reports from sportsmen and guides.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The Boerse opened today with a continuation of the sagging trend of yesterday, losses ranging beyond 3 points. A slight recovery set in toward the close, but was able to wipe out only a small fraction of the losses. The weakness again was ascribed to sales by Russians who are alleged to be using the proceeds to pay off their bills.

(Rose Bowl Soliloquy in Blue and White.) Tell me not in mournful numerals that I must tote the ball And, be picked up crushed and breathless underneath that Stanford wall. Life is tough (and this is earnest) and it's hard to reach the goal With a guard like Corbus waiting where there isn't any hole!

Holiday Cut Buyers' Total. Due to the holiday, the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Hugo Castello, 19-year-old son of Julio Castello, fencing coach at N.Y.U., won the junior foils tourney for the Hammond Prize at the New York A.C. last night. Castello, represerting the University Fencers Club, defeated Arthur Fregosi of the New York A.C., 5 touches to 4, in a fence-off after each had won two matches in the final round.

Because it is a plan of social and economic order, "the NRA is here to stay," Grover A. Whalen, head of the local retail code authority, told members of the newly formed Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Senate committee investigating ocean and air mail contracts disclosed today that the government has paid in a little less than five years $1,587,444 to a single line for the transportation of mail from New Orleans and other Gulf ports to the West Indies which, had it been paid for on the poundage basis, would have cost the government only $1,903.

Action by the National Compliance Board to compel Loft, Inc., to pay its 4,500 employes in this city back wages held to be due under the provisions of the President's Re-employment Agreement was recommended yesterday by the local compliance board of the NBA.

Although the wine was said to be flowing freely last evening, it seemed to this department that the audience assembled at Henry Miller's Theatre was unnecessarily cool toward "All Good Americans." In this portrait of the loose habits of Americans living in Paris Mr. and Mrs. Perelman have written a second-rate Barry comedy with a trying scene of whimsical pantomime toward the end.

Charging that the Board of Aldermen had again "demonstrated its own uselessness" by adopting a 1934 budget $33,000,000 greater than the current budget, the Citizens Budget Commission counseled property owners yesterday to resist any new taxes until real economies had been made.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,195,050 barrels, compared with 2,253,750 in the preceding week, a decrease of 58,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The decrease brought production 14,950 barrels below the Federal allowance of 2,210,000 barrels, effective on Dec. 1.

Class I railroads in the United States reported in October their first decrease in gross revenues for any month since May, when the first monthly increase since 1929 was shown, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. A decrease of 0.3 per cent in October gross and an increase of 3.4 per cent in expenses resulted in a drop of 8.8 per cent in net operating income, the first in many months.

The efforts of many persons to make of President Franklin D. Roosevelt a messiah is pathetic and pitiful, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. McGregor, the new executive secretary of the department of religious education of the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared in an address to more than 1,000 women yesterday afternoon In Synod Hall of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Heat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Somers Roche were hosts tonight at a small dinner at their home, taking the party Later to the weekly prizefights in the American Legion arena. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld and Mrs. William McGregor Paxton.

Although in favor of national prohibition repeal, the people of North Carolina voted against it in the last election because the wets there wanted repeal of State liquor restrictions as well, former Governor O. Max Gardner of North Carolina declared in an interview here yesterday.

After uncertain openings, largely because the gold purchase price remained unchanged, quotations for futures on the commodity exchanges here yesterday became firm and rallied. In most cases the closings were at advances, with trading in fair volume.

New York, somewhat unexpectedly, celebrated repeal with legal liquor last night, after it bad been announced that available supplies of post-prohibition bottled goods would remain locked in bonded warehouses until this morning.

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly today issued a statement to Republican county chairmen and vice chairmen which was interpreted as indirectly accusing W. Kingsland Macy of jeopardizing the party's chances for victory in the next Gubernatorial election.

The entire police force of the city was mobilized yesterday to guard the return of John Legal Barleycorn to a respectable status, and to protect him from disreputable relatives who had usurped his place during his absence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, signed the proclamation repealing the Eighteenth Amendment at 49 and one-half minutes after 5 o'clock this afternoon, thus ending a brief but colorful ceremony.

Four plans for rapid-transit tunnels under the Narrows between Brooklyn and Staten Island were filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The estimated costs of the projects ranged from $38,076,000 to $47,902,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Close finishes marked the racing at Jefferson Park today, six of the seven events being decided by margins of less than half a length. In the feature, the Ponchartrain purse, Blue Day lasted to win by a neck at $19.60 for $2.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh were flying across the South Atlantic from Africa to Brazil this morning, reporting their progress by radio every fifteen minutes and their location every half hour.
At the annual meeting of the National Trotting Association, held yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel, officers were re-elected as follows:

A suicide attempt by an elderly dress manufacturer in his home at 272 Beaumont Street, Brooklyn, ended last night not only in death for himself but in painful injuries for his wife and one of his daughters when they entered the gas-filled cellar by the light of a match, according to the police.

Copyright, 1933. Australian and New Zealand Rights Reserved. STEAMSHIP JACOB RUPPERT, AT SEA (Via Mackay Radio), Dec. 5. -- After bucking a fifty-mile gale the flagship of the Byrd Antarctic expedition, the Jacob Ruppert, at 10 o'clock tonight was nosing into the harbor of Wellington, N.Z.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Inability of New York City to furnish security satisfactory to the Public Works Administration has caused the latter to abandon the allotment of $25,000,000 for completion of the Eighth Avenue subway.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The conference with representatives of Germany's foreign creditors called by the Reichsbank to discuss the terms of Germany's transfer moratorium after the present arrangement expires on Dec. 31 began today under the chairmanship of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Jonnston will give a small dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Jane Brooks Jobnston, on Dee. 19 at the Pierre.

Hailed by the wets as the "dawn of a new era," the advent of repeal yesterday was a source of chagrin to the drys. Their leaders saw no cause for rejoicing. On the contrary, they voiced the direst prophecies and declared their determination to stick to the task of saving the country from the "liquor evil."
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 6. -- India's reply, received yesterday evening, to Japan's "final" trade proposals suggests further modifications of details.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The latest phase of the critical relationship between Great Britain and Ireland reached a stalemate this afternoon when the British Government refused to answer President de Valera's challenging question as to whether it would consider secession of the Free State a cause for war.

It would be platitudinous to dilate upon the fact that the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was an occasion rich in color, brilliancy and Stokowskian eloquence. The orchestra seemed never a more superb instrument, sensitive in nuance, shimmering or blazing with color.

Trading in all major markets Showed increasing signs of activity yesterday. The dollar declined in the foreign-exchange markets as the government price for domestic gold remained unchanged at $34.01 an ounce. Government bonds were irregular; stocks developed strength with the industrial group leading the rise, while commodities advanced on the day.

Pointing to "many significant improvements" in the New York State penal system, the latest Handbook of American Prisons and Reformatories, made public yesterday by the Osborne Association, Inc., also finds fault with, some features of the system.

Following light business for a week, trading on the Cotton Exchange picked up yesterday, influenced by brisk upturns in stocks and grains and a sharp decline in dollar exchange. After the market had absorbed a moderate quantity of hedges at a slight rise in prices, professional operators were encouraged by more activity in commission-house quarters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The text of the proclamation by William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, certifying to the adoption of the Twenty-first Amendment repealing prohibition, follows:

New York City's private clubs served little liquor or wines last night and of a list of twenty or more of the larger and more exclusive ones the majority delayed repeal celebrations until tomorrow or when licenses are granted.

Of interest to many in society here and in Boston will be the appearance of Mise Helen Warren, daughter of Mrs. Samuel D. Warren of Boston, at the seventy-seventh Charity Ball to be given tomorrow at the Ritz-Carlton. Miss Warren will make her public debut here as a singer in a program of light Continental music to be presented in the Oval Restaurant during the supper hour.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- News reached here today of the arrest of Mrs. Melida Moissant Hockwald in San Salvador, charged with the fatal shooting of Bertin Moissant, who killed her husband, Luis N. Hockwald, last July on the 10,000-acre Santa Emilia sugar plantation in Salvador.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While Mr. LaGuardia's request to President Byan that the Board of Education defer the election of a successor to Dr. O'Shea until Mr. Ryan has conferred with the Mayor-elect is indeed an unusual one, yet in the present case the request is horn of the deep distrust of the Tammany Board of Education.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 5. -- This little Shenandoah Valley town was talking tonight of the speed of Zombro, a 3-year-old gelding which captured the second race at the recently constructed course today at odds of 294 to 1.
DUBLIN, Dec. 5. -- The political crisis that threatened in the Free State apparently has been averted for the time being. following publication of the de Valera and Thomas notes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The RFC price of gold remained unchanged at $34.01 today, and indications accumulated that the administration's immediate purpose would be to keep the British pound at about $5 in dollar exchange while the effect on commodity prices was tested.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was celebrated by the national directors of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment at a victory dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night at which a resolution to disband was tabled pending action this morning.
A recapitulation of the football season yesterday showed the strong men of the Far West again the leaders in intersectional warfare.

When the President appointed the Science Advisory Board to act under the jurisdiction of the National Academy of Sciences and the National Research Council he took a step which may prove to be of historic importance. Meteorologists will think so after reading that the board's special committee on the Weather Bureau has recommended the European method of analyzing air masses in forecasting the weather.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight for a large company, including several house gudsts from New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- New York State's Milk Control Law, up for a test before the Supreme Court, was assailed today as a statute which compels consumers to pay high prices "in a State overflowing with good milk."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Sentiment in the grain markets underwent a decided change today, buyers showing more confidence than for some time. Speculative buying, which was larger in volume than recently, with offerings light, advanced wheat and corn about 3 cents from Monday's finish, the greater part of the upturn being maintained at the last.

Prior to their departure for home tomorrow the members of the Swedish Army horse show team will be guests at a luncheon today at the Hotel McAlpin. The winners of the International Military Trophy at the recent National Horse Show will be guests of the Kiwanis Club and the Sportsmanship Brotherhood.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 (Wednesday). -- The New Jersey House of Assembly passed shortly after 1 o'clock this morning a measure for State liquor control, more than four hours after it had been vetoed by Governor A. Harry Moore on the ground that it was unconstitutional.

The executive members of the New York County Republican Committee at a meeting held late yesterday failed to adopt a resolution instructing Chase Mellen Jr., the new county chairman, to support Chairman W. Kingsland Macy of the Republican State Committee at the conference of county chairmen to be held at Utica on Friday to discuss organization of the 1934 Assembly.

Governor James Rolph Jr. of California has been expelled as a member of the National Advisory Board of the National War Veterans Association, on motion of D. George Paston, past national commander, who appointed Mr. Rolph. The expulsion, because of Governor Rolph's "actions and statements in connection with the San Jose lynching," occurred at a meeting of the national executive committee at the Pennsylvania Hotel Monday night.

The Lindberghs left New York to start their exploration flight on July 9. Adventure attended their from the very beginning. Their first landing was scheduled for North Haven, Me. Instead of reaching their destination, they were forced to alight, because of fog, several miles from North Haven and they spent the night as guests of a stranger at South Warren, Me.

An "engineerocracy," a form or social control in which the engineer would take a leading part not only in the production of wealth but in its equitable distribution as well, was pictured last night before the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building by Dean A.A. Potter of the Purdue University Schools of Engineering, outgoing president of the society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Administration support for the projected Greenville-Bay Ridge tunnel under New York Bay, which would provide all parts of New York Harbor with all-rail service to and from the West, was sought at a conference held today with representatives of the Coordinator of Transportation by representatives of the Port of New York Authority and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

At a ceremony in the dining saloon of the Gdynia-America liner Kosciuszko last night a silver trophy cup was presented to Captain Eustazy Borkowski, master of the liner, in commemoration of his rescue of the crew of the German fishing steamer Horst Wessel last month.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 5. -- Fifty minutes after convention delegates assembled in the Senate Chamber here at noon today, Pennsylvania became the thirty-fourth State to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

The conflicting feelings and viewpoints of two outstanding leaders in the long fight for and against repeal, as repeal becomes effective, are presented herewith: By MRS. COURTLANDT NICOLL, First National Vice Chairman, Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.
Conveyance of several Bayonne properties featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

Contributions for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases were received yesterday from 238 men, women and children. They totaled $10,123.79 and carried the amount given thus far in this year's effort to $29,001.27.

The prohibition lid, clamped on New York hotels and restaurants for fourteen years, came off last night, but not with the fizz that was generally expected. It was lifted gently because liquor was scarce.

As the most effective means of opposition to the Tugwell bills, for revision of the Federal Food and Drugs Act, members of the Drug Institute, meeting yesterday, decided to frame substitute legislation which will remove from the proposed measures those provisions which they consider unjust.

UNION CITY, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Officials of Union City, Weehawken, West New York, Guttenberg, North Bergen and Secaucus drew up a set of uniform liquor regulations for their localities today. License fees for sales on the premises would be $350, and for retail shops $200.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- A hard-hitting guard from Houghton, Mich. -- Herman Gundlach Jr. -- today was elected captain of the Harvard varsity football team to succeed John H. Dean of Cohasset, Mass.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The British public was watching tonight with keen interest to see how Americans behave under what was heralded here as their "greatest whoopee party," while distillers wondered whether Scotch and Irish whiskies would appeal to their taste after nearly fourteen years of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Legal liquor today was returned to the United States, with President Roosevelt calling on the people to see that "this return of individual freedom shall not be accompanied by the repugnant conditions that obtained prior to the adoption of the Eighteenth Amendment and those that have existed since its adoption."
Repeal came to the sidewalks of New York last night, and East Side, West Side -- all around the town -- the metropolis welcomed the end of the dry era calmly.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5. -- Ohio became the thirty-fifth State to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment at 2:45 o'clock this afternoon.

A three-month quest for Gerard Simonson, 20 years old, Tombs fugitive, ended early yesterday with his arerst with two other youths and two girls in an apartment at 1,895 Madison Avenue. One of the girls, Marie Lambert, 18, said that Simonson forced her to rent the apartment so he could hide there, although she had no connection with his escape from the Tombs.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The texts of the notes exchanged between the Irish Free State and the British Government were as follows:

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The dollar closed officially at 16.45 francs today, against 16.53 francs yesterday and an unofficial high of 16.80 francs last night Today's quotation still represents a premium of nearly a franc over the theoretical gold parity, and Washington's unwillingness to take advantage of it is leading many short speculators to cover.

The Supreme Court has a way of keeping its iron hand in a velvet glove, but stripping it off occasionally. In the Chicago drainage case it met confirmed non-compliance with unbending insistence. In the dispute between New York and New Jersey over the nuisance of continued dumping of this city's garbage off the New Jersey beaches it has hitherto been lenient toward the offender, even though intolerant of the offense.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Formation of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, consisting of seven teams in four States, was announced tonight at a meeting in the Penn Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- On one or two occasions the Department of Justice, acting with Presidential approval, has discreetly but effectively let it be known that it would not enforce the technical provisions of a Federal statute. It has taken this position when such enforcement meant injustice, or socially or industrially destructive results.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not customary for a visitor making a short stay to make any comment upon affairs of the country of which he is a guest. It is possible, however, that in the present circumstances an exception may be made.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The stock markets generally were firm today, with a confident feeling and less attention to the unsettled foreign exchanges, while reduction in unemployment was a favorable factor. British funds were quiet but firm. The war loan hardened.

"Basic values" in books for children and contrasts with those of the past were discussed by leaders in this field at a conference held yesterday under the auspices of the Child Study Association of America at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Louis Camps of the Unionport A. C., former metropolitan 118-pound champion, scored two impressive victories in the monthly amateur boxing show at the Downtown A.C. last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Broad tax reforms designed to increase the Federal revenue $237,000,000 a year and prevent "the avoidance and evasion of the internal revenue laws" were recommended today in a report submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee by a subcommittee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As THE NEW YORK TIMES opens its twenty-second annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases want to offer you my expression of good-will and hopes for complete success.

Two seeded players were among the twelve men who advanced to the second round in the National Class C Fall squash tennis tournament yesterday at the New York Athletic Club. They are E.P. Field of the Short Hills Club and Charles Fechheimer Jr. of the City A.C.

TORONTO, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- At special meetings of members today the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Standard Stock and Mining Exchange decided unanimously to merge into one organization, to be known as the Toronto Stock Exchange.

SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 5. -- Bertin Moissant, member of a wealthy San Francisco family, was shot and killed here last night, allegedly by his cousin, Mrs. Melida Hockwald, whose husband Moissant killed last July.

ATHENS, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Greek Government will request Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities operator, to leave Greece at the expiration of his police permit Dec. 31, it was learned reliably tonight.
Several properties in the business districts of Manhattan and the Bronx were included in the list of twenty-two parcels in these two boroughs which figured in foreclosure auction sales yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- The Benjamin Franklin Memorial and Franklin Institute Museum, this city's new $5,000,000 contribution to scientific and industrial education, was opened today for inspection by the 11,000 donors who made it possible.
Columbia will resume its football practice this afternoon at Baker Field, after a ten-day lay-off, in preparation for its New Year Day's encounter with Stanford in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif.

Representatives of foreign creditors who have loaned several billion dollars on long term are again meeting in Berlin to discuss the troublesome question of German debts. Last June the German Government declared a partial moratorium for a period of six months ending Dec. 31.

A farewell reception was given Diego Rivera, noted Mexican mural artist, last night at the New Yorkers' School, 51 West Fourteenth Street, in the room with walls he had decorated with a series of twenty-one panels in fresco as his gift to the working men of this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Dr. Albert Levitt at first acknowledges his error in computations which were included in his article published on Nov. 26, and then proceeds to refute this acknowledgment by repeating in substantially the same form his previous incorrect claims.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Nippon Yusen Kaisha, the largest shipping company in Japan and one of the greatest in the world, has passed its dividend for the seventh consecutive time. This announcement was made by the line's president, Kenkichi Kagami, at the shareholders' general meeting in Tokyo.
PARIS, Dec. 5. -- France's difficulties in maintaining the abnormally high internal price of wheat kept the Chamber of Deputies in heated debate throughout today and late into a night session.

The Finch School, one of the oldest private schools for girls in New York, and the Lenox School, were thrown into receivership yesterday when a mortgage foreclosure suit was brought against the Lenox School, Inc., which operates both. Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel appointed Arthur J. O'Leary and Herman Hoffman, lawyers, as receivers and directed them to give a bond for $60,000.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5. -- Sixty thousand persons have fled from Germany since Adolf Hitler came into power, James G. McDonald, as the League of Nations' High Commissioner for Refugees from Germany, told his governing board in more diplomatic terms at its first meeting in the university here this morning.

Showing little pity for their weakened adversaries, the Toronto Maple Leafs went on a scoring spree last night to defeat the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, former world's pocket billiard champion, won his opening match in the 1933 tournament today by the slim margin of one point, 125 to 124, from William Mosconi of Philadelphia.
