Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia swamped George Kelly, a third Philadelphian, 125 to 47, in the first afternoon match.

Peggy Fears, who is producing "Divine Moment," by Robert Hare Powel, will appear herself in that play. Miss Fears, who is the wife of A.C. Blumenthal and has had other productions presented under her own name, formerly was on the musical comedy stage.

ROME, Wednesday, Dec. 6. -- At the end of a long sitting lasting far into the night, the Fascist Grand Council, which had been convoked to decide on Italy's relations with the League of Nations, passed a suspended sentence on Geneva.

After several days of leisure and comparative inactivity Wall Street again became a busy and cheerful place yesterday as a new buying movement carried the stock market to the highest level since Sept. 23. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was the largest in nearly three weeks.

DECATUR, Ala., Dec. 5. -- A fagged-out jury which had spent eleven hours and ten minutes wrestling with the evidence for and against Clarence Norris, one of the Scottsboro case defendants, was sent to bed at 9:31 o'clock tonight by Judge W.W. Callahan after it had failed to reach a verdict.

Senator GLASS explained the "savage humor" in which he appeared at the Senate hearing yesterday as due to the fact that he had risen from a sick-bed In order to he present But he has not been in the habit of sparing his opponents even when he was in full vigor of health.

After an all-day turbulent discusion in which nearly 100 civic workers strove vainly to defeat the project, the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate reported out favorably the Wood Harmon plan for the construction of a centre for Brooklyn College.

The Federal Government has no legal authority to regulate the rates and operations of contract and private motor carriers, the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce declares in a brief filed with Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator of transportation, and made public yesterday.

Slowly gathering momentum from the time when the news began to spread just at nightfall that national prohibition was no more, the public rejoicing at the end of the long dry reign was carried on last night with restraint and absence of undue hilarity.

In sharp contrast with the gloomy outlook generally pictured for the United States in the 1934 Davis Cup campaign, Bernon S. Prentice, chairman of the American Davis Cup Committee, takes a strongly optimistic view of this country's chances in the international team matches next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Although prohibition has been formally repealed, the government temporarily at least proposes to continue boarding ships at sea to ascertain whether they are trying to bring in liquor in violation of the quota and licensing systems.

The American printmakers are having their season's heyday, with three big group exhibitions simultaneously in progress in New York and a larger section in the biennial at the Whitney Museum. The eighteenth annual show of the Society of American Etchers, at the National Arts Club, has already been reviewed.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Thirteen of the thirty-five members of the Princeton football squad who took part in the final game against Yale on Saturday have joined practice for Winter sports teams.

The "convention values" at which insurance companies may value heir holdings of securities in their annual statements this year were established yesterday by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners, in session in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

In accordance with a program of decentralization, the United States Steel Corporation is planning to recast its subsidiaries along geographical lines, abandoning the present division, which is on the basis of products.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Amid the smoke of burned ballot boxes and a defiant show of arms by protesting citizens, State administration forces under the direction of Senator Huey P. Long succeeded today in holding a Congressional election in three-fourths of the Sixth Louisiana District.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- Judging from front pages or French papers, the biggest news today is the end of prohibition in the United States. Long dispatches from New York and many editorials attest the French interest and satisfaction at the final disappearance of the "noble experiment."

The suit of Governor Murray in behalf of the State of Oklahoma against the Prudential Insurance Company appeared to have arisen out of a refusal of the company to accept bonds of the Home Owners Loan Corporation in the case of a $3,000 foreclosure, Edward D. Duffield, president of Prudential, said yesterday.

Domestic corporation bonds were bid up briskly on the Stock Exchange yesterday despite the fact that United States Government issues turned weaker on the decline to the dollar. Many of the corporation issues climbed 1 to 4 points and a few even higher, with the rails and industrials leading the advance.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 5. -- As a result of conversations begun on shipboard en route to Montevideo, progress has been made toward a settlement of the United States' problems with Haiti. It became known today that the situation had reached the stage where two unofficial proposals had been laid before President Roosevelt after informal talks between the United States delegates here and the Haitian representatives, headed by Justin Barau.

Copyright, 1933. by NANA. Inc., and The New York Times Company. ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 5 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp, bearing the members of the Ellsworth Transantarotic Flight Expedition on their great polar adventure, sailed from Dunedin, N.Z., at 1 o'clock, Tuesday afternoon (8 P.M., Monday, Eastern standard time).

Hughie Critz, the nimble-footed infielder whose striking comeback was one of the strong contributory factors in the pennant and world's series successes of the Giants the past year, turned in the best fielding average among the regular second basemen in the National League for 1933, according to the official figures released for publication today.

Creation of the "Advisory Committee to the Treasury on Fine Arts," to help in formulating and executing a program for work in beautifying Federal buildings, is incidentally giving employment to a group whose skill is their only capital. It has been asked:
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Under his own management, Richard Bird appeared tonight in Ernest Truex's role in the American gangster comedy, "Whistling in the Dark," at the Comedy Theatre.

Saint Gets Eagle. General JOHNSON has let it be known that the restrictions of the new codes do not apply to Santa Claus. This is all the more surprising because Kriss Kringle's traditional trade practices are not at all in accord with the spirit of the NRA.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The Eigheenth Amendment died with no obsequies other than the usual week-day gatherings in Westchester's clubs, hotels and eating places. Those who did celebrate the legal return of wines and spirits had to content themselves with wassail of questionable origin.

VIENNA, Dec. 5. -- Alfred Frauenfeld, leader of the Austrian Nazis, was committed to the city jail today to await trial on a charge of high treason. It was officially stated that he was arrested because the words "by order of the district leader" were on printed illegal Nazi leaflets recently seized.

Despite a decrease of $199,693 in gross operating revenue in October compared with a year ago, the Interborough Rapid Transit Company reported a net income of $157,812 before rentals on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee shares, the Best result since March, when the net income was $201,411.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 5 -- The Eighteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States passed out of existence officially at 3:32 1/2 o'clock this afternoon, Mountain standard time (5:32 1/2 New York time) with the ratification of repeal by the convention of Utab, the thirty-sixth required State.
The State Alcoholic Control Board issued 800 licenses yesterday, of which about 200 were for retail stores in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- President Roosevelt's proclamation of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was as follows:

Approximately 60,000 men out of jobs have thus far registered for work under the Civil Works Administration in this city, it was estimated yesterday at the office of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, 124 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Hard liquor was legally dispensed at New York bars last night for the first time in more than thirteen years. But the bars were service bars -- phenomena which in the opinion of many who recalled the drinking counters of pre-prohibition days were doomed to disappear soon after the public settled down to the new era.

Appealing for support of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee's campaign for a fund of $4,000,000 for unemployment relief, Owen D. Young urged yesterday that the emotion now being shown in the discussion of the highly involved money question be transferred to that of relief where, he said, it would do much more good.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 5. -- The steering committee of the Pan-American Conference spent a stormy two-hour session today discussing the proposal of Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Puig-Casauranc of Mexico to include government debts in the conference agenda.
The Fordham University basketball team will launch its 1933-34 campaign tonight when the Maroon lines up against the alumni quintet in the Fordham gymnasium at 9 o'clock.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Bill Conklin of the Chippewa Club scored a knockout victory over Fred Kohrs, a clubmate, in the 175-pound novice final, one of the feature bouts of the Yonkers amateur boxing championships held tonight at the Catholic Boys Club.

ROME, Dec. 5. -- Speaking to representatives of the international press prior to his departure from Rome today, Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, indicated that some misapprehension existed as to supposed religious concessions he had made to President Roosevelt as the price of United States recognition of the Soviet.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, had a talk today with Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister, concerning the future of disarmament negotiations. Mr. Henderson was M. Paul-Boncour's guest at a luncheon attended by Premier Chautemps and other political leaders.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Football teaches three significant things to the boys who play it: dependability, real sportsmanship and an infectious enthusiasm and spirit, declared James Crowley, Fordham football coach, in the principal address tonight at the dinner of the Schenectady alumni of Union College.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Supplies of hogs were somewhat larger today despite a threatened strike of cutters and butchers in packing plants. All interests were in the market and absorbed offerings at prices 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The American League not only is anxious for a uniform baseball among the two majors, but heartily favors a standardized ball for every league of every classification, President Will Harridge said today.

J. Stewart Baiter, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, gave yesterday to the bank's shareholders at their annual meeting the most complete statement of details of the bank's investments, the salaries and pensions paid to employes and the status of Us employe stock-purchase plan that ever has been known in Wall Street.

PINEHURST. N.C., Dec. 5. -- Combahee Lion, white pointer owned and handled by Charles L. Lawrance of East Islip, L.I., today won the members' all-age stake, opening event of the Continental Field Trial Club's meet. Twenty-one competed, nineteen pointers and two setters.
Robert E. Sherwood, author of the play "Acropolis," and Marc Connelly, producer, returned yesterday after staging it in London.
BATHURST, Gambia, Wednesday, Dec. 6. -- With bright moonlight turning the waters around the little island of St. Mary, on which

Net profit of Montgomery Ward Co. for the nine months ended on Oct. 31 was $570,795 after taxes, depreciation and other charges, including a special appropriation of $1,000,000 against possible declines in the market value of their inventory.

An indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary was imposed by Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday on Edward E. Jochen, 52 years old, who swindled many persons of hundreds of thousands of dollars through a spurious Mexican silver bullion project.

There is no more reason to change the value of the dollar than there is to change the yardstick, the bushel measure or the standard of weights, according to Percy H. Johnston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

Mrs. Henry S. Jackson gave, a luncheon in the terraced restaurant of the Plaza yesterday for Princess Christian of Hesse. The other guests were Mrs. Frederic W. Nellson, Mrs. Rollin Pierson Grant, Mrs. Robert Lincoln Lee, Mrs. James Harihan, Mrs. Henry Jeffries, Mrs. Howard Eager, Mrs. Orville Davies, Mrs. George C. Smith, Mrs. Robert Owen and Mrs. Leslie Cheek of Nashville, Tenn.

MADRID, Dec. 5. -- Spain is busy rumor-mongering after the second day of the "state of prevention," which is the first stage of martial law according to the new law of public order, but thus far the anarchist plot foreseen by the government has not materialized.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Westchester women's squash racquets team captured the honors today in the second of a series of three triangular matches with New York and New Jersey at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club.

General Joseph Haller, commander-in-chief of the Polish Army on the allied fronts during the World War and later h o of the defense of Warsaw against the Bolshevists, arrived yesterday on the Gdynia-America liner Kosciuszko.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 5. -- Pleas for Puerto Rican independence appearing in insular party platforms hereafter will be taken seriously by Senator Tydings of Maryland, chairman of the United States Senate Insular Possessions Committee, he announced today at a Rotary club luncheon.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 5. -- Felipe Barreda Laos, Peruvian delegate to the Pan-American Conference, today presented to the steering committee a project for the establishment of an international American bank with headquarters at Buenos Aires.

Virtually none of the retail stores licensed throughout the city to sell wines and liquors to take home had anything to sell yesterday when prohibition ended. Customers looked through the clear windows prescribed by the law and saw only bare shelves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Senator Glass charged at the Senate banking inquiry today that a "lobby" of New York and other bankers led the opposition which resulted ii the twenty-one-day filibuster of Senator Long against the Glass Steagall Banking Act of 1933.
The New York Athletic Club squash tennis team continued its winning streak in the metropolitan Class A league by winning a close match from the Harvard Club team on the Harvard courts last night.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- A new program which would radically reorganize the League of Nations in the hope it may attract within its doors the United States and other world powers has been launched, The Associated Press learned today. The movement is under discussion in several European capitals, it was divulged.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The sagging tendency on the Boerse continued today, but business was dull and changes stayed within narrow bounds. Steadiness in I.G. Farben, the bellwether of the Stock Exchange, enabled the list to show resistance to liquidation by professionals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The City Council passed an ordinance today providing for the refunding of the city bonds due Jan. 1. The terms of the ordinance, by comparison with the refunding deal a year ago, showed a substantial improvement in city credit.

LAUSANNE, Dec. 6 -- Jewish and other delegations gave today to the governing board of James G. McDonald, the League's high commissioner for German refugees, their views and pledged their support. The board decided to establish a council of the organizations to advise Mr. McDonald.

Celia Kelly, 3 years old, is in Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn today in a critical condition with second-degree burns of her entire body. She is the only link the police have in the story of an unusually pathetic chain of events.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie are giving a dinner dance at the Pierre tomorrow night to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Eileen Gillespie. The guests will include some of the married friends of the family as well as the young friends of the debutante.

Repeal has come, and as a timely gesture George Biddle has brought to the Rehn Gallery a group of paintings, water-colors and drawings that bears the comprehensive title "Speakeasies." His one-man show will be on until Dec. 30.

Debentures of all series of the Associated Gas and Electric Company to the amount of about $80,000,000 have been deposited by more than 40,000 holders under the company's plan of rearrangement of capital, according to a letter mailed yesterday to holders of its 4 per cent debentures due in 1983.

BISMARCK, N.D., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Governor William S. Langer, who has made repeated efforts to raise farm prices and bring to general attention the plight of farmers, today declared an embargo on out-State shipments of beef cattle "intended to be processed into human food."

BUDAPEST, Dec. 6 -- The bitterness of Hungarian politics was well illustrated today in a challenge to a duel issued by Deputy Dinich of the Small Farmers' party to Minister of the Interior Franz Keresztes-Fisher following a heated debate yesterday in which legitimists, antilegitimists and liberate united in attacking the Goemboes government.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 6 -- A motherly, soft-spoken woman past middle age, who never made a public speech in her life, threw consternation into Louisiana politics today by offering to cancel her disputed victory in yesterday's Sixth District Congressional election and run again in a primary in which all aspirants for the post would obtain an equal footing on the ticket.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt challenged the "pagan ethics" of "our boasted modern civilization" tonight before the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- A declaration protesting prospective inflation of United States currency has been signed by ten Princeton University professors and instructors, headed by Professor Edwin W. Kemmerer, Walker Professor of International Finance.

An orderly and carefully thought through program for a return to the gold standard was urged last night by Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, who spoke at a dinner in his honor at the Women's National Republican Club, 8 East Thirty-seventh Street.
Changed drinking habits resulting from years of schooling in the speakeasies became evident yesterday as throngs flocked to high-class restaurants and hotel cafes when liquor was being served.

Twenty-one charity organizations in New York and Germany receive legacies totaling $75,000 under the will of Henry Ollesheimer, vice president of the Chase National Bank, who died in Paris Nov. 6, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Thirty-one more changes in the proposed new revenue measure now under consideration by the House Ways and Means Committee were recommended today by a subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Roosevelt administration is holding up the delivery of transoceanic vessels sold in the closing weeks of the Hoover administration to Gulf Steamship interests, and no deliveries will be made until thorough investigation of the whole shipping situation, now under way, is concluded.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The text of the address delivered by President Roosevelt tonight before the special meeting of the federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America was as follows:

HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- The Compania Cubana de Electricidad, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company, was ordered in a Presidential decree signed at 2 o'clock this morning to reduce its gas and electric rates an average of 45 per cent throughout Cuba.

The unloading of ten freight cars of California wine, valued at $100,000, was stopped by authorities in Jersey City yesterday in the first proceeding begun by New Jersey officials under the State liquor-control law that was passed early yesterday morning.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- An angry attack on the American shipping policy was delivered today by the Hon. Alexander Shaw, chairman of the powerful Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, at the annual shareholders' meeting.

More than 20,000 men and women assembled last night in Madison Square Garden for the celebration of German Day, which Mayor O'Brien refused to allow in the armory of the 165th Regiment on Oct. 29 on the ground that it was to be made an occasion for undemocratic Nazi propaganda and might result in disorder.

The NRA and scientific development of new educational uses for playthings were cited yesterday as major factors in the estimated $200,000,000 retail volume of toy sales this year, representing a 10 per cent increase in dollar volume and 15 per cent in units, by W.C. Lehman, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., in his report at the seventeenth annual convention of the organization at the Hotel McAlpin.

The special concert of the Phil-harmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the benefit of its Pension Fund -- a concert devoted to Viennese music and invoking the welcome presence of Friedrich Schorr, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, as soloist, took place last night in Carnegie Hall before a large and very responsive audience.

Prices reacted yesterday on local commodity exchanges, losing some of the gains of the preceding day. The trend was in sympathy with that in outside markets and was attributed to the general apathy of the investing and speculating public, coupled with the unchanged gold purchase price of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

A new testing machine for oil, the first of its kind, which determines in advance in the laboratory how an oil will behave as a lubricant under conditions of extreme heat or cold, was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building.

Theodore Wexler, oldest child of Waxey Gordon, was killed near Chester, Pa., before daybreak yesterday. His sedan went off the road as he raced northward through a fog to appear before Federal Judge Coleman and United States Attorney Thomas Dewey to plead for reduction of his father's sentence.

Production of steel for the first eleven months this year totaled 21,057,319, against 12,461,799 tons in the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. In the eleven months the industry operated at an average of 33.29 per cent of capacity, comparing with 20.15 per cent in the same period of 1932.
Manhattan apartment rentals reported yesterday were divided about equally between the East and West sides. The bulk of the leasing was in the midtown section. The tenants included the following:

Joseph. A. McGinnies, Speaker of the Assembly, came here yesterday and conferred with the five Republican county chairmen in New York City on city legislation to come before the next session of the Legislature. His trip was on the eve of the Utica conference tomorrow at which W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, will meet the sixty-two Republican county chairmen and their women co-leaders to discuss organization of the 1934 Assembly.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 6 (AP) -- A warrant charging first-degree murder was issued here tonight for John Zook, a former St. Joseph policeman, arrested last night in connection with the lynching of Lloyd Warner, a Negro.

Staging a spirited second-half rally which yielded twenty-five points, Fordham's varsity basketball team opened the season with a 29-to-13 triumph over an alumni five last night. A crowd of 1,000 spectators attended in the Fordham gymnasium.

James Joyce's "Ulysses," a novel which has been banned from the United States by customs censors on the ground that it might cause American, readers to harbor "impure and lustful thoughts," found a champion yesterday in the United States District Court.
The New York Giants and the Chicago Bears will meet Sunday, Dec. 17, in the play-off game for the championship of the National Football League, it was announced yesterday by Joe Carr, president.

NANKING, Dec. 6. -- Acknowledging that Japan would not tolerate return of control of North China to Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang on his return from Europe, a Nanking authority envisages removal of his armies from Hopei to control and develop a practically independent area in Northwest Shansi Province.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- A rush by applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses kept licensing officials busy all day today, both at the State Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control and at the City Hall.

"No More Ladies," the new comedy by A.E. Thomas, will begin an out-of-town engagement in Philadelphia on Dec. 25 and is scheduled to come to Broadway two weeks later. Additions to the cast are Bradley Cass, John Bramall and Mrs. Fitzwilliams Sargent.
A sterling performance by Peter Fick, formerly of Philadelphia, now a member of the New York A.C., featured the opening water carnival of the season in the 25-yard Winged Foot pool last night.

Broadway, one of the world's most famous and traveled avenues, will have only nineteen retail wine and liquor stores on its fifteen miles from Bowling Green to the Yonkers city line. The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board so decided yesterday in issuing licenses for that number.

Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, has written to George B Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York urging that utility companies stand firmly for "fair play" from the government "unless many millions of utility bonds which have been issued and sold to investors in good faith and with the approval of State commissions are now to be destroyed."

A special spirit of fraternity and good will seems to mark recent publishing announcements. The firm of Doubleday, Doran speaks highly of Gene Fowler's "Timber Line," published by Covici, Friede, in its latest pre-publication announcement of Sinclair Lewis's "Work of Art."

Following Tuesday's brief burst of activity, trading on the Cotton Exchange diminished yesterday and final prices showed losses of 6 to 10 points. An advance in the London gold price lowered the foreign gold value of the dollar for the second successive day, but other markets furnished no stimulation either to commission house or professional buying of cotton, and some reselling wiped out about half the recent improvement.

Stocks drifted aimlessly yesterday, to the disappointment of brokers who had interpreted Tuesday's strong and active session as the beginning of a broad upward movement. Profit-taking by professional traders, coupled with the failure of the speculating public to buy on the rise, dampened the enthusiasm of the bulls.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Maurice Maschke, former Cleveland political leader, and G.W. Parratt, also of Cleveland, won the last auction pair championship of the American Bridge League today in a session that ended in a cloud of protests.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6. -- The holders of all of golf's major titles were enlisted in the brigade of more than 150 players preparing to storm the Miami Biltmore Country Club course in the fourth annual Miami Biltmore $10,000 open, starting Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently we have been trying to make the dollar look cheap. The trouble with our medium of exchange, so we were told, was that its gold content got too dear. What it needed was to be taken down a peg or two, perhaps have its gold content cut in half, in order that prices might increase and happy days return once more.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- German women, already relegated by the Nazis to the three K's -- "Kuche, Kinder, Kirche" [cooking, children, church] -- will also lose the right to vote in the Third Reich if the plans for the constitutional reorganization of Germany now being discussed in Nazi circles are carried out.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Christine Conniff Lee of this city and Hollywood will be married to Ricardo Cortez, film star, shortly after the Christmas holidays, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Conniff of New Street, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In a bold stroke to keep George N. Peek at the head of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and at the same time remove the principal source of dissension between him and Secretary Wallace, President Roosevelt tonight stripped the AAA of its authority over many of the important codes of fair competition with which it had been entrusted.

A proceeding brought in the hope of clarifying the defaulted guarantee mortgage certificate situation was started yesterday with the signing by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler of an order directing George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to show cause why a commission of five persons should not be appointed to examine the various salvage plans of quasi-official and independent organizations and report to the court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The application of Miss Margaret Mayo, playwright, of Croton-onHudson for a writ of mandamus directing the Corporation Counsel of New York to apply for the appointment of a condemnation commission to determine the damage to Miss Mayo's property caused by the diversion of water by the city from the Croton River, was granted late this afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Morschauser.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Arthur Krock's article of Nov. 30 it is assumed that if the commodity dollar be adopted it will be necessary to make changes in its gold content in accordance with the change in the commodity index. This, I believe, is a plan which has been proposed by certain advocates of the commodity dollar.

An application for the appointment of a receiver to conserve the assets of the Lehrenkrauss Corporation of 359 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and four subsidiary companies, was made in a suit in equity filed against the corporation in the Federal Court in the borough yesterday.
Beer stepped up into the higher alcoholic brackets yesterday, the 3.2 per cent limit giving way to something like the pre-prohibitior brew.

New Tork City is facing a Winter in which the danger to its boys and girls is comparable with the peril faced by European children during the World War, it was said in a radio address over Station WINS yesterday by George Barr Baker, a trustee of the American Child Health Association.

Announces Spring Silk Hues. Colors of the Orient and tropic tints are special fashion features of the Spring (1934) color card for silks, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association. The Oriental hues are twelve in number, comprising brilliant tones, as well as several softer blues, suggestive of Chinese pottery.

The National Recovery Administration will lead the United States into either a sort of American fascism or a strong super-Cabinet governmental control of industry and labor, Ordway Tead, editor of economic books and a lecturer at Columbia University, told the members of the Taylor Society last night.

NATAL, Brazil, Dec. 6. -- At 2:50 P.M. today a keen-eyed watcher here caught the first-glimpse of the great red monoplane of the Lindberghs as it headed in from the Atlantic. Launch whistles blared, and from the waiting crowd arose a mighty roar of "Viva!"

Mr. and Mrs. William Vanderbilt are to arrive today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex. Others aboard include Arthur Cunningham, Controller-elect, and Mrs. Cunningham, Miss Rosemarie Phelps Dodge, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jardine, Charles Rogers, Count Maxence de Polignac, Albert Ives Ely, Henry Dater, Russell Firestone and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Esterbrook.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Joseph P. and, prominent Chicago financier and brother-in-law of Charles E. Mitchell, former head of the National City Bank of New York, filed suit for $1,300,000 in the United States District Court today, naming the National City Company, a subsidiary in the financial set-up dominated by his brother-in-law.

Yankee, the Boston syndicate yacht brought out for the America's Cup defense competition of 1930, again may be under canvas for a try at international representation in the match with T.O.M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour next September.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 100,000 units of National Beer and Wine Importers, Inc.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- This city, which has been expecting to have its financial troubles solved for the next three years by an agreement with a lending syndicate under a plan submitted by the Citizens Advisory Finance Committee, was faced today with continuance of its recent difficulties as a result of the defeat in the Legislature of a bill authorizing the proposed agreement.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 6 -- William Ziegler Jr.'s Zipalong took the featured Llangollen Purse over a slow track today. The son of Whiskalong and Lucy Jackson made every post a winning one in the six-and-a-half furlong dash to score by four lengths over Mrs. J. H. Whitney's Blue Foam.

At the last session of Congress a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee was instructed to consider simplification of existing tax laws and to propose ways of preventing such methods of tax avoidance as were revealed by the Senate hearings. Its report, now complete, recommends various administrative changes and hazards the opinion that as much as $237,000,000 annually will be added to the Government's receipts if they are made.
A 26-year-old military prisoner who was serving a term for larceny in the army's disciplinary barracks on Governors Island was shot and mortally wounded by an armed sentry yesterday afternoon.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith expressed surprise yesterday on his return to his office in the Empire State Building after lunch. At the office door he saw sound-picture apparatus and a group of waiting newsreel photographers explained that he was supposed to pose while receiving a gift case of champagne.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Treasury Department announced today as its December financing program, an offering of $950,000,000 of one-year certificates of indebtedness, carrying 2 1/4 per cent interest. Thus the administration put to rest rumors that an issue of greenbacks or other inflationary methods would be employed to meet $727,692,500 of maturities which must be refinanced on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Besides the $727,692,000 in maturing Treasury certificates, interest payments on the public debt totaling $114,000,000 will be due Dec. 15. By floating a total new issue of $950,000,000, the Treasury will increase its working capital by some $82,000,000.

Several of the more famous night clubs and speakeasies were transformed into legitimate restaurants yesterday and did a capacity business in food and legalized liquor. Newly framed licenses adorned the walls, bars were either torn out or used as service counters, all the illicit supplies of liquor, made during the prohibition era, were out-lawed, and trucks hummed through the streets bringing fresh supplies to assuage the thirst of the customers who filled the tables.

What local NRA officials characterized as a "showdown" in the case of Loft, Inc., operating a chain of 150 candy stores and restaurants in this city, will be sought in Washington today by representatives of the local compliance board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The Federal Relief Agency re-entered the hog market as a buyer today, working through several packers in order to bolster up prices and at the same time obtain supplies for general distribution through its organization.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Opening this morning at 83.10 to the pound, the franc fluctuated up and down, actually touching 82.90 at one time and closing officially at 83.025, against 84.02 yesterday. Thus the value of the pound dropped a whole franc in one day.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Among the many colonists who are expected to arrive this week is Alexander C. Yarnall of Devon, Pa., who will bring with him on Saturday to Nautilus cottage a party of six. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall, are expected early in January.

Angna Enters made her first local appearance of the season at the Town Hall last night as the second attraction in the Town Hall Endowment Fund series. The audience, a large one, gave every evidence of enjoying itself, especially when Miss Enters indulged in her devastating burlesques.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Another Ministerial warning to Japan was given in the House of Commons late tonight when Dr. Burging, parliamentary secretary of the Board of Trade, on examining expert copies of some British pottery, declared that unfair competition in regard to imitation of styles and trade-marks ought to be severely dealt with.

That the future seasons of the Metropolitan Opera are not to be left in doubt as they have been in the last two years was indicated yesterday in an announcement from the opera association. An executive committee has been appointed from among the members of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was disclosed, and this new group has already discussed plans for future seasons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Ralph Greenleaf of New York, world's pocket billiard champion, was defeated tonight for the first time in three years of championship play by George Kelly of Philadelphia, 125 to 85 in 25 innings. Kelly had a high run of 30 to 51 for the champion.

With instructions to investigate and report upon the possibility of beautifying Bedloe's Island and freeing the base of the Statue of Liberty from the somewhat bedraggled buildings that now surround it, two officials of the Department of the Interior visited the Island yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Before the Legislature recessed at dawn today until Jan. 9, the Senate confirmed Governor Moore's appointment of Harry Hackney of Atlantic City, William F. Burke of Jersey City and William H. Cane Of Hohokus to the newly created State Racing Commission.

Forging ahead steadily, the Citizens Family Welfare Committee yesterday went well over the halfway mark in its campaign for $4,000,000 to aid family welfare agencies in the city in meeting the extraordinary demands for their services this year.
GENOA, Italy, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Primo Camera, world's heavyweight boxing champion, today sailed unexpectedly for New York on the Conte di Savoia.

By passing their Liquor Control Bill over the veto of Governor MOORE, the Republican majority in the New Jersey Legislature made itself responsible for the flaws he pointed out in his veto message. The new law will give the Republicans considerable patronage. There will be elections for Governor and United States Senator next November, and Governor MOORE cannot be a candidate to succeed himself.

Commissioner Bolan submitted a list of fifty-two arrests yesterday to proye that he was determined to wipe out the bootlegger and the speakeasy in New York City. All the arrests were for sales of liquor without State licenses. They were made within twelve hours after repeal was ratified.

German Refugees Numbered. JAMES G. MCDONALD, as League of Nations commissioner for German ref"gees, has made the first authoritative estimate of the size of the problem. It would appear that the Hitler government has made progress in settling the Jewish question.

Despite increased participation by high school and sand-lot players deaths from football in the season just closed showed a decline from the high marks of 1931 and 1932 it a survey made yesterday by The Associated Press.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- By a decision today of the Austrian Bishops conference, under the presidency of Cardinal Innitzer, the Catholic priests of Austria were forbidden to retain their seats in Parliament, in the provincial diets or in municipal or county councils after Dec. 15, "in view of the delicate political situation."

A meeting of theatrical managers and producers in New York to discuss the "indiscriminate use of passes" which has grown up of late was called for tomorrow afternoon by the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority at its regular meeting yesterday.

Among the 221 contributors who added $6,441.70 yesterday to the Fund for the Neediest Cases were two who, though in hard straits themselves, could not pass the Neediest by, so they sent $1 each. One wrote as follows:

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Despite denials from officials of the league and of the clubs involved, rumors persisted tonight that the Senators and the Americans will merge before the new year.

Based on figures gathered by The Associated Press from all parts of the country and tabulated yesterday, college football attendance for 1933 increased 13 per cent, ap compared with the previous season, and appears to have recovered approximately half the business lost at the turnstiles during the 1931-32 decline.

The first section of the new Eastern State Parkway, a stretch of 5.3 miles running north from the Westchester County line into Putnam County as far as the Peekskill Hollow Road, was officially opened to motorists yesterday by the Taconic State Park Commission.
International competition between England and the United States in men's squash racquets will be renewed in this country in January.

The Board of Education, through its president, George J. Ryan, is distinctly cool to Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia's request that the selection of a new Superintendent of Schools be delayed until he and the beard members confer, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The bank deposit insurance provision of the Glass-Steagall Banking Act and the unlimited liability plan of the new Securities Act were criticized today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, head of the Chase National Bank, in testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the sixth consecutive trading period as the dollar swung Higher, but United States Government bonds were generally weak, closing unchanged to 20-32 point lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Federal Alcohol Control Administration was planning today to turn the spotlight of publicity on liquor costs to cut the high retail prices, quoted in many localities the first day after repeal of prohibition.
TOTTENHAM, England, Dec. 6. -- An aggressive French soccer team was defeated, 4 to 1, by England today in the first meeting between the two countries since 1921.

The directors of the Humble Oil and Refining Company are considering a readjustment of the company's financial structure, with a view to transferring a large part of its surplus to capital account. At the close of 1932 the surplus was $117,589,682, while the outstanding capital stock was $74,366,125.
Columbia took its football equipment out of storage yesterday at Baker Field and started preparation for its game with Stanford in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., on New Year's Day.
In about 100,000 homes throughout the city bottles of legal wine and liquor were uncorked last night and repeal reached the family stage.

To the Blue Eagle comes or promises to come something of the pride and ample pinion that the Theban eagle bears. Under the auspices of the Poet Laureate League, Inc., whose home is rightly in Washington, the seat of knowledge, wisdom and burlesque and original poetry for use in the Congressional Record, a poet laureat is to be appointed for each State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade acted early today as if they wanted to advance, and wheat at one time was about 1 cent a bushel above yesterday's final price. The buying, however, was not followed up. Many of those who had bought yesterday and early today became sellers and found only fair support.

Minimizing the danger of unlimited currency inflation as a straw man raised by the orthodox, and declaring that bankers are not necessarily monetary experts, Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank, urged yesterday stabilization based on a modernized gold standard.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 6 -- Dartmouth's varsity hockey team, under the direction of its new ooach, Herbert Gill, will launch its 1933-34 campaign next Wednesday. The Green sextet will oppose the St. Johnsbury team at home in the first of a ten-game schedule, which includes meetings with Yale, Harvard and Princeton. Each of the Big Three will be met twice.

Money market was firm in tone, but quiet so far as turnover was concerned. Money on call, on the Exchange and in the counter market, ruled at 3/4 Sixty-day acceptances were marked up 1/8, in yield, this on top of an advance in the 120-day bill on Tuesday.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 6 -- A potassium photoelectric eye has disclosed things about distant island universes to which photography with the world's largest telescope was blind.

The deer hunting season in Pennsylvania opened on Dec. 1 and since that time more than 150,000 gunners have searched the woods in quest of game. When the season ends next Wednesday it is likely that a record bag for that State will have been recorded.
Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx and stanch supporter of the Roosevelt-Farley faction of the Democratic party of the State, broke openly with Tammany Hall last night.

The Manhattan College basketball team met an unexpected defeat at the hands of a fast Long Island University quintet, 32-23, in a keenly contested game before a near capacity crowd of 1,200 in the Jasper Gymnasium last night.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Two trainmen were killed and five others and several passengers slightly injured early this morning when a passenger train northbound on the Richmond, Fredericksburg Potomac tracks crashed into the wreckage of a southbound freight train which had been derailed an instant before by a landslide.
ABOARD THE WYATT EARP, Dec. 6 (By Wireless) -- Cruising leisurely at a steady speed of six knots, the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition is heading southward.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 6 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull took a definite stand today to preserve the regional aspect of Pan Americanism as a cooperative relationship of the American republics and to prevent its assuming world-wide in terlocking relationships.

About 225,000 men throughout the State are already employed on civil works projects, it was announced yesterday by Frederick I. Daniels, executive director of the State Civil Works Administration. Mr. Daniels said 350,000 would be employed by Dec. 15.

RENO, Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Marion B. Warburg today received a decree of divorce from Gerald F. Warburg, son of Felix M. Warburg, the New York banker. Suit was brought on the ground of extreme crulety. Agreement as to the custody, educcation and support of two children and a property settlement was reached.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The farmers of the United States will be the principal beneficiaries of the estate of Alexander Legge, president of the International Harvester Company, and former chairman of the Federal Farm Board, who died Sunday.

EDMONTON, Alta., Dec. 6 -- Out of the frozen North, where blizzards have been sweeping up the Mackenzie River basin for two days and temperatures are down to 40 below, Pilot C.H. (Punch) Dickins of Canadian Airways flew his ski-equipped plane today on a "mercy flight," bringing Fred Shagory, fur trader, to the hospital here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The last hope for allotment of Public Works funds for the completion of the Eighth Avenue subway in New York faded today when President Roosevelt indicated that the administration felt it did not have enough Public Works money to finance the subway loan and a proposed sewer-age loan.

If the Eighteenth Amendment had not been repealed, "the government of the United States as we know it would have been completely revolutionized in a generation," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said last night at a dinner of the Association of Foreign Correspondents in the Hotel Lafayette.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Nearly 61 per cent of all national banks in the country which were unlicensed on March 16, following the bank holiday, had been licensed, chartered, absorbed or placed in receivership by Dec. 1. J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, said today.

DECATUR, Ala., Dec. 6 -- Another trial in the Scottsboro case ended today v. th a conviction and a sentence of death after prolonged deliberation by the jury had aroused defense hopes of a disagreement. Thus another chapter of the South's cause celebre came to a close, with the next one to be written in the Supreme Court of Alabama.

With the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's price for newly mined domestic gold unchanged at $34.01 an ounce for the fifth successive day, the dollar was consistently strong yesterday in the foreign exchange markets. The brisk upward movement in the stock market was stemmed, while government bonds were weaker.

After several weeks of recession, the adjusted index of electric power production has advanced, moving to 90.4 from 89.8 in the previous week. For the week ended Dec. 3, 1932, the number was 83.8. This rise in the index is due to a gain in the daily average, as both actual output was lower and the seasonal trend was upward.

A Rome dispatch intimates that the Italian Government will soon propose rewriting the Covenant of the League of Nations. This is put forward as an alternative to the recent report that Italy may soon withdraw from the League. It would be in line with the recent statement by Sir JOHN SIMON, British Foreign Secretary, that the Italian Government had proposed negotiations looking to disarmament agreements independent of the League.

WHAT they ought to do in hockey circles is to make those Toronto Maple Leafs skate on one foot until the other teams catch up. Either that or remove their skates entirely and make them play barefoot until late January.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 -- The 4-year-old daughter of Epinard, Foreign Play, making her third start of the year, was a surprise winner of the featured fourth race at Jefferson Park today. Leading from start to finish, the 16-to-1 shot was first by length at the end of six furlongs.

One of the unusual factors of the flight of Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh across the South Atlantic was the constant radio connection maintained by the filers with an anxious world. Mrs. Lindbergh sent position reports every half hour and progress reports every fifteen minutes to stations of Pan American Airways, whose engineers installed the radio apparatus in the Lindberghs' plane.

Ten persons, one of them a bedridden woman of 70, were carried down ladders to safety last night by firemen summoned on a second alarm after flames had spread from a vacant ground floor apartment at 817 East 179th Street, the Bronx, up the stairways to the fifth floor, cutting off exit.

The collective bargaining and licensing provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act are opposed by about 98 per cent of the manufacturers of the country, it was declared in reports read yesterday at a meeting of the National Industrial Council at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Cabinet met today, but did not consider it necessary to discuss the statement by the Fascist grand council that Italy would leave the League of Nations unless that organization radically reforms itself soon.
Three tobacco companies voted extra dividends yesterday. In all, six major companies took action toward the payment of new or enlarged dividends.

Coming out of a long retirement, Jose R. Capablanca, Cuban master and former world champion, took part in a rapid-transit tournament with nine rivals at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. The ex-champion, who always has been rated one of the fastest players alive, made a clean sweep.

Although steel operations fell in the last week one-half point to 27 1/2 per cent of capacity against 28 per cent the week before, the slight decrease "is apparently not a significant one, since declines in some centres were matched by gains in others," according to The Iron Age.
Apartment house deals in the Bronx and Brooklyn featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.
Warning of an impending crisis in both the private and public hospital systems of the city was voiced yesterday by Dr. John A. Hartwell, president of the New York Academy of Medicine.
The New York Evening Post, New York City's oldest newspaper, was reported sold yesterday, but the report was officially unconfirmed and the identity of the purchaser was not disclosed.

Gross revenue of the country's railways in October, as compiled from their monthly statements, fall slightly below 1932. The decrease was unimportant; it attracted comment only because railway receipts have run far beyond last year in every other month since April.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 6 -- Jockey Jack Westrope flashed his best riding form at Epsom Downs today, climaxing a triple by bringing home W. Graham's Cambridgeshire in the featured Chamber of Commerce Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Unless the job given Frank C. Walker by the President today evaporates -- as other big ones have -- in a confusion of unrelated effort, it is in many respects the most important office that has been created under the legislation of the New Deal. As executive director of the bewildering and multiple forms of Federal relief, Mr. Walker's task will be to coordinate the coordinators.

The market value of the 1,211 stock issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $2,424,622,470 in November, according to a compilation announced yesterday by the Stock Exchange. At the close of November these issues had a market value of $32,542,456,452, compared with $30,117,833,982 at the end of October.

ROME, Dec. 6. -- Italian officials revealed today that the Fascist Grand Council's call for reform of the League of Nations was intended to bring in the United States and Soviet Russia and to cause the return of Germany and Japan.
Thirteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were sold at auction yesterday, the parcels in each case being bid in by the plaintiffs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Changes in the Federal Securities Act which would weaken the protection it gives the public are opposed by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Four allotments for New York State and one for Connecticut were included in a list of sixty-six non-Federal allocations of public works funds made public today. The list totals $9,182,378, and brings the amount allotted to date to non-Federal projects to about $520,000,000, and the number of projects to nearly 1,000.
Carl Hubbell, star southpaw of the New York Giants, Was the National League's leading pitcher for the 1933 campaign, according to the official averages released for publication today.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- More powerful, faster, and priced slightly higher than current 1933 models, the 1934 Ford models were shown to newspaper men at a pre-view today. On Saturday the new cars will be put on display by more than 7,000 Ford dealers throughout the country.

A total of $385,000 in customs duties on foreign wines and liquors yesterday brought the customs collections for the first day of repeal well above the recent average at the New York Custom House. Still wines constituted most of the imported products on which duties were collected, according to Henry C. Stuart, assistant collector of customs.

The first in a series of entertainments in aid of various philanthropic enterprises throughout the city was held last night in the Sea-glade of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. There were divertissements by Sarita, Spanish dancer; Romero's Orchestra, Gregory Ratoff, Rodney McClelland, and Caperton and Biddle.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt superimposed upon the Federal relief and recovery structure today a new coordinating organization to be known as the National Emergency Council.
All utility reports are consolidated returns, including subsidiaries unless otherwise specified.

The Tale Club and the Princeton Club in Group I and the Princeton Club No. 2 team, the Squash Club and the Columbia University Club in Group 2 of the New York Division of the Metropolitan. Class C Squash Racquets League won their matches last evening.

A national statistical bureau to analyze the investments of insurance companies for the guidance of State insurance commissioners was proposed yesterday at the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners in the Hotel Pennsylvania. After a long discussion, the proposal sponsored by Colonel Howard P. Dunham, Insurance Commissioner of Connecticut, was referred to the executive committee for study.

The Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, who for the last nine years has been pastor of the First Presbyterian Church at Ann Arbor, Mich., was installed last evening as pastor of the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street, east of Broadway.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed at Natal today at 3 P.M. (1 P.M. in New York), sixteen hours after taking off from Bathurst, Gambia, on the West African coast.

New Yorkers turned to legalized drinking yesterday with a gusto tempered somewhat by a scarcity of supplies. The celebration of the end of the dry era went on all day and far into the night, but with few exceptions a spirit of calm satisfaction, rather than reckless hilarity, seemed to prevail.
SHANGHAI, Friday. Dec. 8. -- The possibilities of ending the Fukien rebellion without firing a shot are increasing as all factions are showing signs of yielding to political pressure.

In the belief that Tuesday's temporarily overbought condition on the Stock Exchange had been corrected, traders and investors were again predominantly on the buying side yesterday. The advance amounted to a little more than a half point in the stock averages, but the gains did not reflect the extent to which a long-range optimistic viewpoint is crystallizing in Wall Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks overcame a one-goal lead tonight to defeat the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 1, and move into a tie with Detroit for the leadership of the National Hockey League's American division.

A score unwisely neglected by conductors in this city was offered by Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at the concert last night in Carnegie Hall -- a score as gorgeous as a peacock's wing. It is the symphonic piece "La Peri" which Paul Dukas composed in 1910 in Paris for the dancer, Mme. Trouhanovna.

Allan M. Pope, president of the First of Boston Corporation, was elected president of the American Acceptance Council at the annual meeting of that organization yesterday. Robert H. Bean, secretary, presided at the meeting, which was held in the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 7. -- Restoration of State police to full strength of 280 troopers, refilling the sixty places vacated by economy cuts, and a guarantee of schooling to every child were asked by the New Jersey State Grange as it closed its sixty-first annual meeting here tonight.

A high mark in the rising tide of increased dividend disbursements was reached yesterday, when extras, resumptions, increases or accumulations were voted on eighteen more issues. Only two companies voted reductions, while three announced deferment of action until after the first of the year, when, the dividend tax is to be dropped.

Continuing their drive to wipe out the speakeasies, cordial shops and other establishments selling liquor without a State license, the police made thirty raids between early Wednesday morning and 8 A.M. yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The growing feeling here that stabilization of the dollar is not far off reached a point today where it began to play an important role in financial transactions connected with the Paris exchange market.

Paintings from the residence of the late Mrs. Jacob H. Schiff, 965 Fifth Avenue, brought $63,785 last night at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The collection of slightly more than 100 paintings by artists of many schools had been on exhibition at the galleries since last Saturday, together with furniture and decorations, which will be sold this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon.

The December nail in behalf of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House will take place tonight in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. A midnight entertainment will be given in the oval restaurant during the supper hour by Olga Baclanova, Paul Gerrits and Micky Blatz of the cast of "Murder at the Vanities."

The seasonal expansion of credit and currency requirements which forced member banks to seek accommodation at the Federal Reserve Banks was reflected in the report of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday, which was issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- President Roosevelt late today ordered the books closed on the $950,000,000 issue of one-year 2 1/4 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness which was offered this morning. Reports from the Federal Reserve Banks indicated a heavy oversubscription.

After more than five months of activity, the local NRA organization, headed by Grover A. Whalen, began to make preparations yesterday to wind up its activities on Dec. 31, the date set for the expiration of the President's Re-employment Agreement.

MOORHEAD, Minn., Dec. 7 (AP). -- President Lotus D. Coffman of the University of Minnesota termed the Rose Bowl football game played annually at Pasadena, Calif., "a Roman holiday staged for the commercial interests of Los Angeles," in a talk last night.
The trend of bank clearings as compared with last year was again made confusing, because of the Thanksgiving holiday last week. The holiday came a week earlier last year than this year.

The Taylor Society yesterday held a memorial for Frederick Winslow Taylor, for whom the organization was named, on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of his graduation from the Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken. He was praised as the man who had "discovered and set down certain fundamental lawa of management," which could be applied today in an economic situation he had not foreseen.

To the accompaniment of increasingly heavy trading, bonds listed on the Stock Exchange moved generally higher yesterday with the exception of United States Government bonds, which closed unchanged to 27-32 point lower. The rise in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic corporation bonds marked the seventh consecutive trading day on which the movement was upward.

Play started last night in the fourteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament of the Princeton Club. One of the strongest fields of recent years, including twenty-four Class A players and three others who have been of Class A ranking, but were inactive last year, are entered.

In the belief that present regulations governing the issuance of stock options by corporations may have become out of date, the New York Stock Exchange is studying the advisability of drafting more stringent rules covering such operations.

The restrictive effect of the depression upon the usual activities of foundations is the basis of the report of Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Foundation of New York, on the year's work of that organization. Half of the appropriations for new projects in the United States during the year were for emergency purposes, $992,750 being spent in this way.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Dec. 7. -- The personal estate of Z. Smith Reynolds is valued at about, $200,000, the final report of his uncles and guardians, W.N. Reynolds and R.E. Lasater, showed today. This does not include his share of the tobacco fortune of his father, the late R.J. Reynolds, valued in the millions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Public Works Administration will continue to allot properly secured funds for municipal power projects in spite of objections being raised by public utility interests, Secretary Ickes said today.
A nation-wide movement for a complete revision of criminal law and procedure was sought yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County at the Astor.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Sir Thomas Inskip, the Attorney General, has been called to account for his remarks in the House of Commons on Nov. 28, which some hearers took to be a Ministerial criticism of President Roosevelt's policy.

A plea to the medical profession to reconcile itself to the inevitability of socialization in all walks of life, including itself, and to recognize as an indisputable fact that we are living in an era in which a new collectivism is constantly supplanting individualism, was made last night by. Joseph V. McKee, former Acting Mayor, before the eighty-seventh anniversary meeting of the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Passage of the administration's Pure Food and Drug Bill as a substitute for the 1906 measure, which was described as inadequate at present to protect the public from dangerous food and drug concoctions, was urged by Secretary Wallace today before a Senate Commerce subcommittee when it began hearings on the measure.
Major W. Arthur Cunningham, Controller-elect of New York, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after a month's vacation in Europe. He was accompanied by Mrs. Cunningham.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Western Conference sports leaders -- athletic directors, football coaches and faculty committee members -- will rally in Chicago tomorrow for their annual Winter meeting.
Resale of a Bronx apartment house by an operator was reported yesterday, in addition to several Manhattan leasehold deals and housing transactions in Brooklyn and Nassau County.

There are two current one-man shows of water-colors that no gallery visitor should miss. At Kraushaar's you will find work in this medium by Gifford Beal and at Milch's, more than two dozen examples by Emil Holzhauer. The techniques employed are widely dissimilar, yet both artists arrive at admirable results.

There were shots and spills in profusion at Madison Square Garden last night but no goals. The New York Rangers and the Canadiens of Montreal, meeting in a National Hockey League game for the first time this season, waged a bitter, exciting battle, but when the whistle sounded the end of the overtime session, they had to be content with a scoreless tie.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff of Soviet Russia turned a cold shoulder today on the editorial wooing of the Nazi press and departed for Moscow at 6:40 P.M. without seeing either Chancellor Hitler or Foreign Minister von Neurath.

Des Moines, Iowa. Offering will be made today of a new issue of $500,000 city of Des Moines (Iowa) 5 per cent improvement bonds due on Dec. 1, 1935 to 1953, by BIyth Co., Inc. The bonds will be priced to yield 4.40 to 4.60.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Coarse grains are attracting much more attention now than wheat from operators on the Board of Trade. Reports that farmers over a large part of the leading surplus-producing sections of the country were making plans for loans so as to hold back corn on farms, combined with a strong statistical position, started buying today that lifted corn and oats 5/8 to 1 1/2 cent a bushel for the day.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 7. -- Steps for the immediate arrest of leaders of the mob which lynched the kidnapper-slayers of Brooke L. Hart will be taken here Tuesday.

It is now judicially decided that the "Ulysses" of JAMES JOYCE is not an obscene or pornographic book. That will prevail, at least so far as permitting the work to be imported into the United States. In the carefully prepared opinion of Judge WOOLSEY, certain general principles are laid down.

President Roosevelt's present financial policy is "perhaps the strongest weapon in his hands to fight uncontrolled inflation," Dr. Edwin R. Seligman, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy in Residence at Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon. He spoke before more than 200 members of the Columbia Graduate Economic Club at a meeting held in Philosophy Hall, Columbia University.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 8. -- A change in the naval administration announced in this morning's government gazette creates "three new defense squadrons" -- at Yokosuka, Kure and Sasebo.

Borough President Samuel Levy told the members of the Central Mercantile Association, at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Empire City Club, that, during his next four-year term, he would make an effort to obtain a reduction in real estate taxes.

Former Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby, who has dealt with a myriad of perplexities in his long career as lawyer and diplomat, has had his first encounter with a clock, and yesterday apparently had won a decisive victory.

"The Charming Deceiver," with Constance Cummings and Frank Lawton, will be offered at the Seventh Avenue Roxy this morning. Ernest Truex is appearing on the same program in a two-reel comedy entitled "Mr. Adam."

DEAD cats may encumber the landscape, bankers may object to the New Securities Act, "Tories" may denounce Roosevelt as a Socialist and Socialists may accuse him of being a Mussolini in false-face, but through all the hubbub Charles A. Beard keeps his head. He knows that history is a "movement of ideas" which, in turn, are "umbilical to earth"; he knows that men do what they have to do.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- In accord with the Public Works Administration's policy of transferring men from relief rolls to pay rolls to increase purchasing power. Secretary Ickes announced today loans totaling $5,500,000 to the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Lehigh Valley Railroad Companies which will enable them to employ 2,700 more men in their shops to repair and rebuild cars and other equipment.

QUERETARO, Mexico, Dec. 7. -- General Lazaro Cardenas, candidate of the National Revolutionary party for the Presidency of Mexico, received a tremendous ovation on his arrival here this afternoon to accept the nomination.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- A difference between D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, and the city of Newark over interpretation of the Liquor Control Law came to a head today when Mr. Burnett wrote to City Clerk Harry S. Reichenstein that his action in taking applications for retail licenses, accompanied by a two months' fee, "notwithstanding instructions under Bulletin No. 2," was contrary to law.

If only for one paragraph in his address to the Federal Council of Churches, President ROOSEVELT would be entitled to unfeigned thanks. He spoke out energetically against "that "vile form of collective murder -- lynch "law." Identifying himself with the attitude of "the new generation," he declared: "We do not excuse those in "high places or in low who condone" "lynch law."

Trading in the various stock and commodity exchanges was moderately active yesterday, with a firm undertone as the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, for the sixth successive day, held at $34.01 an ounce the price of newly mined domestic gold.

It is not the leaders and followers of the Recovery party who failed to observe party loyalty but the leadres of the Tammany machine, because of their disregard for the fundamental principles of civic decency, Nathan Straus Jr., Recovery candidate for Aldermanic President, said last night at a dinner of the Recovery party of the Ninth Assembly District in the Park Central Hotel.

The magnitude of operations involved in financing the public deficit is illustrated by yesterday's announcement of the Treasury's quarterly plans. No less a sum than $950,000,000, in the shape of one-year loan certificates, is offered for subscription. This amount is by no means unprecedented for a singie offering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The government's attack on the problems growing out of repeal advanced on two fronts today as the President's Interdepartmental Alcohol Control Committee completed its report on liquor taxation, and Attorney General Cummings announced a policy of "extreme leniency" toward minor offenders against the Prohibition Act.

The AAA, or Agricultural Adjustment Administration, has its Right Wing and its Left. On some points they disagree -- most immediately on the question of codes dealing with products manufactured from farm commodities. The Right, represented by Mr. PEEK, is described as favoring a minimum of regulation, particularly with respect to profits.

While England and France are experimenting to develop more powerful pursuit and bombing planes, progress in the United States Army Air Corps is being seriously retarded by the present policy of national economy, said Major C. W. Howard of the Army Air Corps at the annual meeting yesterday of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7. -- Professor Benjamin H. Beckhart of Columbia University attacked the monetary policies of the national administration, and Professor Irving Fisher of Yale University defended them at a Yale meeting tonight held under the auspices of the Connecticut Chapter of the American Statistical Association, the Yale Economics Club and the New Haven Chamber of Commerce.

A suit to restrain the City of New York from granting a pension to former City Magistrate Francis X. McQuade and to enjoin Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly from continuing Mr. McQuade's employment as an Assistant Corporation Counsel under an appointment which made his application for a pension possible, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Construction throughout the country continues to make substantial progress.
The Playhouse has been announced for the opening of Paul Osborn's new comedy, tentatively entitled "Perhaps We Are," on Monday evening, Jan. 8. Dwight Deere Wiman is the producer.

Special relief projects for women and white-collar workers will be mapped out for New York City and financed by the Federal Relief Administration under a specia Service Works Administration created yesterday. Walter W. Pettit, former director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, was appointed chief of the new agency.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 8. -- It is reliably learned that the Curtiss-Wright Aircraft Corporation has reached an agreement with the Nanking Government under which it will erect at Hangchow, 110 miles southwest of Shanghai, an airplane factory, involving an investment of $5,000,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 7. -- After a day of inquiry, Harvard College authorities tonight made known definitely for the first time their policy on consumption of wines and liquors in the Harvard dining halls. The result is a prohibition of such drinking.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- In an opinion written by Justice Perskie, the Court of Errors and Appeals sustained today taxes, assessed by the State on the Central Railroad of New Jersey for 1931. The court held that the proof offered to show alleged excessive valuation of property and a higher than warranted tax was "unconvincing" and lacked "persuasion."

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- British shipowners, after years of conferences, have decided upon concerted action in seeking government help to defend themselves against the competition of subsidized foreign rivals. The council of the British Chamber of Shipping decided today to make two recommendations to this effect.

Four employes of the fifteen-story apartment house at 145 West Fifty-fifth Street dropped from the fourteenth floor to the basement in an elevator at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon when something went wrong with the mechanism.

J.O. Hobson of the New York A.C. beat Joseph V. Gallagher of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the national Fall Class C squash tennis tournament at the New York A.C. yesterday to advance into the quarter-finals. The scores were 15 -- 12, 15 -- 9.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Louis F. Timmerman will give a luncheon Dec. 19 at the Pierre for her debutante sister, Miss Barbara Belmont.

A novel experiment in art has been tried by F. Luis Mora in his exhibition opened to the public yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The Harvard Club No. 1 team gained undisputed possession of first place in the Class A Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association tournament yesterday by defeating the Harvard Club No. 2 team, 4 -- 1. The victory enabled the Harvard No. 1 outfit to maintain its unbeaten record.

Mrs. Culver McWilliam of the Apawamis Club in Rye was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the annual meeting held at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday. Mrs. McWilliam succeeds Mrs. F.B. Ryan of the Baltusrol Golf Club at Short Hills, N.J.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- Franco-German direct conversations upon two important questions affecting the relations of the two countries have reached an impasse and temporarily have ceased. Whether the deadlock will be broken depends on the course the French Cabinet may decide to take in the next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Governors of the six New England States today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to require divestment by the Pennsylvania Railroad of its direct or indirect holdings in the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Boston Maine Railroads.

The Polish Minister of Education said last Summer in Warsaw that citizens of Poland had to choose where they would spend the small amount of money they had. "For armaments we "had to spend. For roads we should "have spent. Our roads are regrettable. "But we have educated our children.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- An act of grace that is to get more than 5,000 political prisoners out of the concentration camps y Christmas was announced today by Premier Goering of Prussia in his capacity as chief of the secret State police.

An unconventional party as far as costumes are concerned will be the County Fair Ball, which is being given tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-As-toria for the benefit of the New York Hospital social service work. Guests have been requested to wear "ginghams, calicoes and overalls" and the ballroom, will feature various carnival games and sideshows similar to the old-time county fair.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Criticism of the League of Nations in such official quarters as the Fascist General Council obviously has struck a responsive chord in German officialdom and in the press. The press, perhaps by request, comments with a certain reserve on the Italian rebuke, and the official response likewise reflects an attempt at restraint.
A great deal of conservation work in this State and many others has been curtailed because of the lack of funds and the need for restricting expenditures until normal conditions are at hand.

ATLANTA, Dec. 7 -- John Stephens, 32 years old, late today was exonerated by a coroner's jury of the "mercy slaying" of his aunt, Miss Allie Stephens, 60 years old, a mission board worker. The jury found that death was due to natural causes created by her hopeless illness.
