On Track 17. The Federal Coordinator of Transportation is planning many improvements in railroad travel. Among other things, says a dispatch which almost taxes belief, is the colition of unintelligible train and place announcers.
The following resolution, recently adopted by the general council of the Charity Organization Society, was forwarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday by Stanley P. Davies, general director :
DUBLIN, Dec. 7. -- Eamon de Valera spoke in the Free State Senate tonight regarding his exchange of notes with Dominions Secretary Thomas.
Borough President Henry Hesterberg of Brooklyn will be named by Mayor O'Brien as a member of the Board of Water Supply after he resigns his present office, it was disclosed at City Hall yesterday.

Maintenance of the gold standard and prompt stabilization of the currency were advocated in a resolution adopted by executives of fifty-seven United States life insurance companies at an executive session at the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 7. -- The most important spot in the seventh Pan American Conference is the room in Uruguay's legislative palace where the steering committee sits.

Announcement of the sale of The New York Evening Post, the city's oldest newspaper, to J. David Stern, editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Record and The Camden (N.J.) Courier and Post, was made last night.

LAUSANNE, Dec. 7. -- iscount Cecil of Chelwood agreed today to accept the permanent presidency of the governing board named by James G. McDonald, High Commissioner for German Refugees. He will also head its executive committee, which will include French, Uruguayan, Swiss and Dutch representatives.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 7. -- T.C. Worden's consistent 6-year-old gelding Labor accounted for his second Houston victory at Epsom Downs when he managed to win by a neck from Buck and West's Royal Treasure in the featured Waco Purse today.
IT was a bantamweight who started the discussion. Drawing himself up to his full height of 5 feet 5 inches, he thrust out his chest and remarked:

Returning for the first time since he yielded his crown at Forest Hills in September, Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, national tennis champion in 1931 and 1932 and the latest recruit to the professional ranks, will arrive in New York this morning from Pawtucket, R.I.

Mayor-elect F. H. LaGuardia appealed yesterday to the people of the city to give their support to the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is raising a fund of $4,000,000 for relief of the unemployed. The money is to be expended through accredited welfare agencies in behalf of those unemployed who will not be reached through government relief organizations.

The policies of the present coalition government in Great Britain were defended as "the only way out" by Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald in a radio address from London yesterday afternoon. He said there was no chance of progress in any direction except through common action.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 7. -- With the troublesome Mexican economic program shelved, the Pan American can Conference divided its attention today between economics and peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- After working out a standard form of deposit agreement, under which bonds of the Federal Home Loan Banks will be issued, executives of the twelve regional institutions adjourned a two-day session here today.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The women's squash racquets team of the Greenwich Country Club scored its fourth successive triumph in the interclub league today. Greenwich won by 4 to 1 over the Racquet and Swimming Club of Ardsley at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

The text of the speech delivered by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, last night before the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria follows; You have asked me to come before you and tell you what the NRA is all about.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The rapid depreciation in value of Shipping Board ships was strikingly shown today by the Senate committee investigating ocean and airmail contracts, when evidence involving the purchase of fifty-two ships by the Lykes interests of New York, New Orleans and Texas disclosed that in 1930 this company made three proposals to buy these ships, the first at $22 a ton, the second at $11 and a third at 55 a ton.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 7. -- One hundred and eighty-six awards for participation in Fall sports were announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association. The list included members of the varsity, junior varsity and freshman football and soccer squads, varsity and cub cross-country groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Nine statements filed under the Securities Act calling for issues aggregating more than $1,600,000 and including two from New York were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. The list follows:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The New York Conference of Mayors meeting in special session here today, adopted a proposal of Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse for a 2 per cent State sales tax, expected to yield about $130,000,000 a year, to be collected by the State and turned back to the municipalities for real-estate tax relief.

Two companies which for many years have been familiar to railway travelers in this city will disappear from their service on Jan. 1 as a result of the decision of the railroads to provide baggage delivery through their own agency. On that date the New York Transfer Company and the Westcott Express Company will be replaced by the Railway Express Agency, a railroad-owned organization.
General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, struck out vigorously here last night at critics of the NRA and of the President and his monetary policies.

W.F. Roeber, general manager of the National Council of Compensation Insurance, has issued his annual report to members. He says the features of the year were substitution of classification inspection for schedule rating and the increase of 2.5 per cent in the country-wide rate level.

None of the dietary schools of thought, neither "the cod-liver oil, the tomato class, nor the A, B, C or D vitamins" school can deny the truth of the old adage -- "a clean tooth will not decay," Dr. Thaddeus P. Hyatt declared yesterday.

The Hamburg-American liner Albert Rallin will sail tonight for Channel ports and Hamburg. Those booked include J.F. Schoellkopf, Buffalo banker; Dr. Wilbur K. Thomas, executive secretary of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, Philadelphia, and Nicholaus Kiep, director of the Vulcan Shipyards in Hamburg.

A survey of the liquor distribution system revealed yesterday that about two weeks must elapse before legal wines and liquors will be available to a widespread public in the retail stores and public drinking places to be licensed throughout this city.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday, Wednesday. For the beat names..........l 1/4% 1 1/4% The quotations are for three-four months' paper. * * * Liquor Sales Aid Xmas Figures. Liquor sales are providing a welcome addition to the holiday sales volume of five leading stores here and are likely to prove an important factor in putting sales figures on a favorable comparison basis with a year ago.
PARIS, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

About 1,400 liquor licenses have been approved or issued to date to hotels, retail stores and restaurants in New York City, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, said yesterday.
Contributions to the Neediest Cases amounting to $7,894.84 were received yesterday from 219 donors. They brought the total for the year thus far to $43,337.81.
Mayor-elect LaGuardia discovered yesterday morning that 9:45 o'clock is much too early to make social or even business calls at City Hall.

Appreciation of the services of the Salvation Army has increased throughout the world in recent years, said Evangeline Booth, Commander-in-Chief of that organization, in an address to the members of the Rotary Club of New York at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The Ottawa Senators sprang the biggest surprise of the National Hockey League season tonight as they checked the Toronto Maple Leafs' high scoring array, 4 to 1, in a brisk battle featured by sensational goal-tending by Billy Beveridge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- If one of Premier Mussolini's major objectives in demanding reforms in the structure of the League of Nations is to open the way to United States membership, his effort has made no impression here thus far. Discussion in official and Congressional quarters today of the moves of the Fascist Grand Council developed a unanimity of opinion that nothing can now tempt the United States to join.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday marked time pending today's annual crop estimate from Washington, and, after fluctuating within an unusually narrow range, prices ended unchanged to 3 points higher than on Wednesday.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- First-class fares on express liners probably will be reduced substantially as a result of an agreement reached today by the North Atlantic shipping conference.

Copyright, 1933, by The Associated Press. Eamon de Valera, President of the Council of the Irish Free State, declared in a cable to The Associated Press yesterday that Great Britain was keeping Ireland within the British Commonwealth by threatening to employ force of arms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to railroads resulting in the payment of $10,300,000 to the Chase National Bank in 1932 at a time when Harvey C. Couch, an RFC director, owed money to the bank on a joint loan still unpaid, were revealed today at the Senate market inquiry.
Copyright. 1933, by NANA, Inc. KANSAS CITY, Dec. 7. -- One of the great art galleries of the world will be opened here next Monday. It is the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- President Roosevelt's condemnation of lynching as "collective murder" was unanimously acclaimed, but his part in prohibition repeal was deplored by several delegates at the concluding session here today of the anniversary meeting of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- In a Statement as of Nov. 23 William H. Kelly, State Banking Commissioner, reported to Governor Moore today that eight banks under the jurisdiction of his department had been reopened, nine had been released from restrictions of the Altman Act and twenty were being liquidated.

Cardinal Hayes, two Bishops, a Bishop-elect, many monsignori and Mayor John P. O'Brien participated yesterday in the sixth annual pontifical mission service of the Catholic Students' Mission League in the Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and 131st Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Dec. 5:

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Selections for a 1933 All-America football team made by twenty college newspapers, including The Daily Princetonian, were published in the Princeton undergraduate daily today.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The House of Commons took the first step today toward rescuing Newfoundland from bankruptcy, even though the process will cost British taxpayers u2,500,000 [$12,825,000 at yesterday's exchange] and possibly more.
The Lambs turned out last night to celebrate the passing of prohibition with a Repeal Gambol attended by more than 1,200 persons, in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

A decline in the number of foreclosures in the country was reported last night by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation and of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Mr. Fahey spoke here at a dinner of the Union League Club arranged by the Home Mortgage Advisory Board, of which Frank A. Vanderlip is chairman.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 7. -- Fielding H. Yost, grand old man of Michigan football and member of the national rules committee, turns a deaf ear toward suggestions that the defense now has most of the advantage on the gridiron.

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- The real estate outlook is the brightest it has been for several years, Joseph W. Catharine of Brooklyn, who was installed as president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, Inc., told a group of realty men at a luncheon here today.

Representatives of about forty steamship lines operating cargo and passenger ships in foreign commerce to and from the ports of the United States and Canada organized the Foreign Trades Shipping Association at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the first state reception of their administration, entertaining in honor of the diplomatic corps. Between 9 and 10:20 o'clock they shook hands with 1,000 guests, and then, having exchanged greetings with the last arrival, President Roosevelt withdrew to his private apartments.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Warner Pyne, receiver of the Pelham National Bank, whose removal was asked last night at a meeting of 500 depositors, filed suit today in Supreme Court against eleven officers and directors of the bank for $750,000 damages, alleging that they had been negligent and thus damaged the institution to that amount.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 7 (AP). -- Dr. Robert E. Blackwell, president of Randolph-Macon College at Ashland, Va., told the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools today that "the best that we can do is simply admit that athletic ability is a skill to be sold and let it go at that."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 7. -- The League of Nations commission seeking to end the war between Bolivia and Paraguay has arrived in La Paz after a thousand-mile journey from the frontier that resembled a triumphal march.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Three players went into first place, deadlocking the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight, when young James Caras of Wilmington, Del., last year's runner-up to the defending champion, Ralph Greenleaf, defeated the veteran Bennie Alien of Kansas City, Mo., 125 to 71 in 14 innings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- George N. Peek was preparing tonight to submit his resignation to President Roosevelt as Agricultural Adjustment Administrator following the President's refusal to support him in his dispute with Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, and Jerome Frank, counsel for the Adjustment Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The prestige of the National Labor Board, appointed by President Roosevelt to mediate in industrial disputes, was threatened today when it was defied at two successive hearings.

EDWAKD J. FLYNN, who pontificates in the Bronx, must speak with authority on all matters relating to bridges. So long as he occupies his throne he won't let the Tammany Tiger cross "the Harlem River bridges." Politically considered, these are to be one-way structures.

Ed Danowski of Riverhead, L.I., 1933 captain of the Fordham University football eleven, will play at halfback on the All-East eleven that will clash with a selected squad representing the Western colleges in the annual East-West charity football game in San Francisco on New Year's Day.
Manhattan Prep's basketball team rallied in the secand half to defeat Xavier High, 21 to 15, in the Xavier gymnasium yesterday. At half time, Xavier led, 9 to 8.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Harold Butler, director of the International Labor Office at Geneva, addressing the Industrial Copartnership Association today on his return from a study of the new industrial conditions in the United States, urged that Britons follow the American experiments very closely, with sympathy and without trying to form any final judgment yet, in the realization that an amount of confidence had already been restored.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Describing Congress as ready to adopt almost any kind of inflation, Senator David A. Reed today promised whole-hearted support to President Roosevelt in a move to stabilize the dollar.

Real estate experts value the property owned and used by the New Haven Railroad for its right of way between Woodlawn Station, in the Bronx, and the Connecticut line at $9,979,250.74, it was shown by documents put in evidence yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- An agreement on the question of price-fixing under the petroleum code, reached today by opposing factions of the industry, may result in an indefinite postponement of the whole price-fixing problem, Secretary Ickes, the Oil Administrator, revealed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The daily average volume of federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,603,000,000, an increase of $19,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $394,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7. -- Brustigert, owned by the Devereux Brothers and the favorite in a field of nine in the featured race at Jefferson Park today, won by three lengths. The winner is a gelded son of Donnacona from Poke Bonnet and carried 118 pounds six furlongs in 1:13 4-5.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Guns blazed at two points along the Texas-Mexico border today as officers surprised smugglers attempting to run liquor into Texas, which is still dry, and the toll was counted tonight at three known dead and one wounded.

TRENTON, Dec. 7. -- The Civil Service Commission reported today to Governor Moore a reduction in the last fiscal year of $9,351,299 in payrolls of State and municipal personnel under its jurisdiction.
The members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York pledged themselves yesterday to promote moderation and tolerance under repeal.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Justice Taylor in Supreme Court here approved today rehabilitation of a $195,000 first mortgage on the Embassy Golf and Tennis Club at Armonk and of a $161,000 first mortgage on an apartment house at 1,080 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today that authorizations have been made by his corporation for purchases of preferred stock or capital notes totaling $425,000,000 in 1,293 banks throughout the country, in the campaign to expand credit facilities in the recovery drive and prepare the institutions for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

The seventy-seventh annual Chai ity Ball, held last night in the RitzCarlton, brought out an unusually large gathering of members of society, ranking officers of the army and navy and distinguished foreign vistors. Incidentally, it will add a goodly sum to the treasury of the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital, the beneficiary.

NORTH SYDNEY, N.S., Dec. 7. -- Wireless messages flashed to ships throughout the North Atlantic today warning them to watch for a speedy boat whose crew turned the tables on the Coast Guard by kidnapping four Guards-men and speeding out to sea in their seized vessel.

NATAL, Brazil, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Colonel Lindbergh tonight had prepared his transatlantic monoplane for a return to the United States. Mrs. Lindbergh said she was anxious to get back home, and their departure tomorrow was expected.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- The Boerse was somewhat firmer today. Harpener gained 2 1/4 points and other mining stocks were slightly stronger on reports of a further increase in the number of miners employed in Ruhr coal mines.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The steadiness of the dollar, which closed today at $5.10 1/4 after a fluctuating range of only 3 cents, was the subject of considerable comment in financial quarters here.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Republican leaders from every section of the State flocked to this city tonight for a conference tomorrow which some political experts say may cause a wide split in the State organization unless counsels of peace prevail.

DETROIT, Dec. 7. -- Henry Ford, addressing his automobile dealers over a nation-wide telephone network today, predicted that 1934 will be a good year for everybody who works, and urged work as the way to help President Roosevelt "pull the country out of the hole."

Trading on local commodity exchanges was the dullest yesterday in several weeks. Price movements were narrow, with quotations permitted to drift to lower levels without attracting much buying interest. Cash prices, on the other hand, were higher.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- The conference between Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, and the committee of Germany's foreign creditors called to discuss new terms for Germany's partial transfer moratorium ended today without any definite agreements being reached.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The Cleveland pair of E.J. Babin and O.S. Emrich swept into the lead tonight in the national open contract pair bridge tournament of the American Bridge League.

Action was postponed after a spirited discussion last night on the advisability of endorsing the provisions of the Warsaw Conference regulating liability on air traffic at a joint meeting of the aeronautical committees of the New York State Bar Association and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

James G. McDonald was elected recipient of a medal awarded annually by the Town Hall Club to a member who in the last year has brought credit to the organization by "an accomplishment of lasting merit," at a meeting last night in the Town Hall Auditorium.

Routine questions and requests sent to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, will be referred by her hereafter to the heads of appropriate government departments, Mrs. Roosevelt announced yesterday. She explained that a constantly growing volume of correspondence had made such a step necessary.

The linemen of the Columbia football squad ran into an unexpected heavy workout yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions continued their preparation for their New Year's Day encounter with Stanford in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Wholesale prices last week continued the downward movement of the previous week, according to a report today by Isidor Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- In the preceding article of this series I called attention to the slight immediate influence which the supply of money at times exerts upon the level of prices. This point is convincingly illustrated in recent experience.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The formal attitude of the British Government toward the question of reform of the League of Nations raised by the Italian Fascist Grand Council is that no proposal has been made by Italy in a manner that calls for diplomatic negotiations or international discussions.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7. -- The greatest field that ever competed in a golf tournament below the Mason-Dixon line was primed tonight for the $10,000 Biltmore open. The tourney begins tomorrow over a seventy-two-hole route and a new champion may be crowned before sundown on Sunday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Over 22 per cent of the members of Princeton varsity sports squads this Fall are honor students, a survey of the 150 players engaged in football, soccer and cross-country reveals.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- Neither Premier Mussolini's attack on the League of Nations nor the rumored preparation by Chancellor Hitler of a five-point plan for Franco-German friendship had succeeded tonight in shaking France's faith in the League and her determination to protect her rights.

GENEVA, Dec. 7. -- The higher League of Nations quarters, apparently unperturbed by the adverse attitude of Italy's Fascist Grand Council, await Rome's decision on withdrawal with skepticism as to there developing any general talk of rewriting the covenant.

Action by the New York Retail Code Authority to stop the sale of books at or below cost to save from bankruptcy more than 1,500 retail book stores in the city employing some 6,000 persons was demanded yesterday by a delegation of the American Book Sellers Association when it appeared before the code authority at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway.

A radical change in the leadership of the Anti-Saloon League is threatened as a result of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, it was disclosed last night, and the fight will be brought to a head when the board of directors of the organization holds its biennial meeting in Washington on Jan. 3.

The Republican County Committee of the Twenty-first Senatorial District of the Bronx last night nominated Jacob Weil, former Alder-man and a Republican, for State Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Henry G. Schackno, City Court Justice-elect.

Despite the improved outlook for business, stocks drifted slightly lower under profit-taking by speculators yesterday. The losses, however, were slight, and several specialties continued to forge ahead. Most brokers are still inclined to expect little from the market until the latter half of the month, but the consensus is highly optimistic in view of the favorable reports from trade.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- William W. Farley, former Democratic State Chairman, has asked United States Attorney General Homer Cummings and State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to take steps to revoke the charter of the Crusaders on the ground that this organization has exceeded its authority by opposing the monetary policies of President Roosevelt.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc... and The New York Times Company. ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 8 (By Wireless) -- We have had a remarkably smooth trip so far, and today finds us about half way to the pack ice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- President Roosevelt studied with interest today preliminary reports on surveys of a North Atlantic aerial route prepared by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.
Sales of several homes in Brooklyn, mostly in the Flatbush section, were reported by Allyn S. Crumm, brokers, as follows:
MADRID, Dec. 8. -- The second Parliament in Spain's young republic opened this evening.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.
ON and around the gridiron, the following propositions are considered self-evident:

Gottesman Co., Inc., distributers of woodpulp, paper and paper-makers' chemicals, and the Central National Corporation, investment; securities, are to move to 22 East Fortieth Street from 1,440 Broadway, it was announced yesterday. D. S. Gottesman heads both companies.

MUNICH, Dec. 8. -- The friction that is known to exist between the extremist and moderate elements among the Bavarian rulers was indicated today by the removal from office of Georg Luber, State Secretary of Agriculture for Bavaria.

The St. Joseph Grand Island Railway, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Railroad, declared yesterday a $5 dividend on its first preferred and a $4 dividend on second preferred stock. This was the first dividend on the first preferred shares since 1902 and the initial disbursement on the second preferred.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The London debut of the German actress Elizabeth Bergner tonight in C. B. Cochran's production "Escape Me Not," by Margaret Kennedy, author of "The Constant Nymph," caused the greatest stir among the critics since the late Anny Ahlers of Germany appeared in "The DuBarry."

Denial that be had any particular influence with the Republican leaders of the Legislature was made yesterday by former Speaker H. Edmund Machold, following the attack upon him by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, in a speech at Utica.

A legal interpretation from the NRA on certain clauses in the legitimate theatre code relating to the distribution of free passes and the "throw-away" ticket system will be sought by the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the Code Authority specially convened to deal with the current "pass-tax" system of admissions.

Captain Ivy Wambolt, who has spent most of her twenty-two years following the sea, as did her father and brothers, stood yesterday on the fore-deck of the 432-ton auxiliary schooner E. P. Theriault at Newark and supervised the unloading of a lumber cargo from Newfoundland.

Handicraft work of widows and dependent children, particularly from the Near East Industries in Greece, are on sale at a Christmas bazaar of the Near East Foundation, 151 Fifth Avenue, with a group of prominent women acting as sponsors.

LAUSANNE, Dec. 8. -- The governing board named by James G. McDonald, League of Nations High Commissioner for German Refugees, closed its first session here today in an inconclusive argument indicating only that countries having a few of these refugees want no more and those having many want to lighten their burden.

Over the opposition of the Citizens Budget Commission and other groups the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to retire 120 city employes on pension, including Mayor O'Brien, and to continue in service 362 others who have passed the retirement age of 70.
NATAL, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh took off for the north in their big red monoplane this morning at 6:07 o'clock, Eastern standard time.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer and one of the most powerful figures in the British Cabinet made a short but pointed reference to President Roosevelt's currency experiment tonight which lines him up alongside Walter Runciman and other critics of the President's policy.

Another phase of the underlying firmness in money was revealed in the paucity of offerings of time money, the market virtually going over to the bid side alone with a fractional advance in quotations by borrowers. Money on call on the Stock Exchange was 1 per cent all day, which also ruled in the counter trading, although a little 3/4 money was done in the Street in the afternoon.

A concert took place at Carnegie Hall last night for a cause that is near to the heart of President Roosevelt. The Georgia Warm Springs Foundation was the beneficiary, and the entire proceeds, some $20,000, will be presented to the President as a Christmas gift to the institution which he founded.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- Supreme Court Justice Staley today reserved decision in the action brought by the Third Avenue Railway Company and thirteen affiliates to restrain Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commisioner, from enforcing an order revoking permission to the company to act as a self-insurer under the Workmen's Compensation Law.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8. -- Mary Pickford filed suit in the Superior Court here today to divorce Douglas Fairbanks, thus bringing to a close the fifteen-year-old romance of the "royal family of the motion-picture world."

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Ralph Greenleaf of New York, the defending champion, lost his second straight game in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight. He bowed to Bennie Alien of Kansas City, Mo. The score was 125 to 58 in twenty-three innings.

The national recovery program and President Roosevelt's monetary policy were upheld, though not without reservations, yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers at the final session of its convention in the Waldorf-Astoria.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Brilliance and color as of pre-war days marked the annual Assembly Ball, held here tonight, with 1,000 guests, many from other cities, in attendance.

Sales of passenger and commercial cars of the General Motors Corporation to consumers in the United States in November made a total of 35,417, or nearly three times the total in the same month of last year, when 12,780 cars were sold.

When one bartender was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday and another was acquitted in the first cases under the new State Liquor License Law, the question arose as to whether policemen, to obtain the necessary evidence, must drink the concoctions they order in unlicensed places.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The German Christians, the Nazi church party that attempted to seize the Protestant Church in Germany and make it a unit of the National Socialist State, struck their flag today and announced their dissolution as a party.

To the Editor at The New York Times: Possibly the nicest Christimas present the people of the United States could receive would be for President Roosevelt to announce in unmistakable language that he is against inflation and in favor of sound money.

Twenty leading Western cattle producers arrived here yesterday, set up a base of operations in the Hotel New Yorker and attempted to discover for themselves why a pound of beef, for which they received 2 1/2 cents, should cost the New York consumer between 40 and 45 cents.
DENVER, Dec. 8. -- Defeated in two earlier attempts officially to revise the Rocky Mountain Athletic Conference, the eight larger schools of the circuit tonight voted to secede.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 8. -- The Personal Finance Company, with principal offices at 30 South Broadway, Yonkers, has been authorized by the State Banking Department to transact business as a licensed lender at 226 East Fordham Road, New York, and at South Grove Street and Sunrise Highway, Freeport, L. I. Each office is to have $25,000 in liquid assets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Senator Fletcher, chairman or the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which through a subcommittee has been investigating stock market practices, said informally today that Federal supervision of stock exchanges may be necessary.

Charles (Chuck) Klein, the hard-thumping Philadelphia outfielder who will appear in uniform for the Chicago Cubs next year, compiled the highest slugging percentage in the National League for the 1933 season, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

The volnme of new municipal financing scheduled to be done next week will amount to only $4,490,101, compared with $49,206,813 this week, and the weekly average for the year thus far of $15,506,694. On next week's calendar are included several issues not expected to draw bids from New York dealers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- RFC directors today authorized the purchase of preferred stock and capital notes totaling $22,900,000 in 112 banks of the Northwest Bancorporation. They also authorized a loan of $3,000,000 to the Union Investment Company, a subsidiary of the Northwest Bancorporation.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 8. -- Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas of Argentina was the day's hero at the Pan-American Conference. He received a tremendous ovation when he finished reading his anti-war pact into the record. It was the only thrilling incident in a day devoted to committee meetings, handling routine matters.

A lawyer's war record saved him yesterday from punishment more severe than censure when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upheld the report of Frederick Spiegelberg, official referee, in proceedings by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York against James J. Britt.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Recovery of a man whose stomach was removed in an operation performed on Nov. 2 by Dr. Karl A. Meyer, chief surgeon of the Cook County Hospital, was announced today at the hospital. The small intestine is performing the functions of a stomach and the patient is leading a normal healthy life.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- The bull movement in coarse grains that was started yesterday on the Board of Trade collapsed today. Weakness in wheat impelled some of yesterday's buyers to sell, and the result was that corn closed 1/4 to 7/8 cent lower and oats 5/8 to 3/4 cent off.

NEW ORUSANS, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Senator Huey p. Long said today that Charles S. McCain, chairman of the Chase National Bank, "didn't tell the whole story" to a Senate committee about their breakfast together at which the Senator ordered oysters, sirloin steak, French-fried potatoes and vanila ice cream.

Not only within the personnel of his Administration tout outside it President ROOSEVELT has to deal with, conflicting political,views. There are those who assert that in his policies he has gone too far. Others at the same time declare that he has not gone far enough.

A young Brooklyn school teacher's dreams of high finance collapsed yesterday as District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn investigated scores of alleged thefts ranging from dollar loans from pupils to an $90,000 larceny from a now destitute Brooklyn widow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Samuel J. Sonderling of Scarsdale, a certified public accountant associated with Lehman Brothers, New York banking house, who died Nov. 30, left $25,000 outright to New York philanthropic organizations, and larger sums to charity contingent upon the death of relatives, according to his will filed here today.

The New York Ethical Culture Society of the American Ethical Union "held a memorial meeting yesterday afternoon for Dr. Felix Adler, who founded the society fifty years ago. The meeting at the society's headquarters, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, opened the annual gathering of the American Ethical Union which will continue through tomorrow.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 8. -- After a four-hour discussion not paralleled for bitterness in recent Republican annals and bound to leave deep scars, the Republican county chairmen of the State and their feminine co-leaders at a conference held here adopted today by unanimous vote a resolution expressing confidence in the Republican members and leadership of the Legislature.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 8. -- A preview of the 1934 Buick models given to newspaper men today revealed that changes from current models were numerous, the major one being the so-called "knee action" front wheels, with independent wheel suspension. There are nineteen different models.

"Hold Your Horses," the Joe Cook show that has been running at the Winter Garden for the last eleven weeks, will close its New York engagement after tonight's performance. It then goes on a road tour, opening in Newark on Monday of next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- In what was regarded as its most important test to date, the NRA today forced the Loft Stores,' Inc., operating a chain of candy shops and restaurants in twenty-seven cities, including New York and Washington, to pay as arrears the difference between wages agreed upon in the blanket code and those actually paid, even though formal protest bad been lodged by the company against the code as finally drafted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Preliminary scientific findings indicating that science stands to enhance greatly its knowledge of the cosmic rays through the recent ascension into the stratosphere by two Americans were announced today by Dr. Arthur H. Compton, University of Chicago physicist.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- A plan for making New York State a fisherman's paradise -- with State-controlled trout streams and State-built ponds and lakes -- is being formulated by the Conservation Department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The following are the full texts of the agreements submitted to Secretary Ickes by the joint committee representing opponents and proponents of petroleum price control:

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- Unemployment figures for the week ending Dec. 2 show a rise of 6,626 to a total of 257,836. This exceeds the figure for the corresponding week in 1932 by 1,261. The total, however, still remains well below the six-year peak of 331,816 recorded in the first week in March.

VIENNA, Dec. 8. -- The reactions toward the Italian "ultimatum" to the League of Nations now make it clear that Premier Mussolini has thrown a bomb into the camp of the Little Entente and France which has aroused in Hungary hopes of a destructive effect on Hungary's enemies.

The passenger traffic departments of transatlantic steamship lines were at work yesterday on reports from London advising of the change of passenger rates which was voted by the Transatlantic Conference at its meeting on Thursday.

Billy Sunday, for many years known as "the baseball evangelist," will return to New York City after an absence of sixteen years and conduct a revival campaign. Services will begin Sunday, Jan. 7, and continue every afternoon and evening for two weeks except Mondays.

Supporters of Mayor-elect LaGuardia will seek to obtain legislation to abolish the City Magistrates' Courts and the Court of Special Sessions and to substitute for them a new court, it was learned yesterday. A study of the situation is now being made, with a view to drafting a bill for presentation to the State Legislature.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 8. -- Important changes in the new Federal Securities Law were suggested by Arthur A. Ballantine of New York, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, in an address before 300 lawyers, who attended the first legal clinic ever held by the Wisconsin Bar Association here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- But for the mail subsidy the American West African Steamship Line, operating between New York and New Orleans and West African ports would have lost nearly $1,100,000 in the past five years. This was disclosed today before the Senate committee investigating ocean and air-mail contracts.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- After a stormy discussion the Chamber of Deputies debate on budget reform was interrupted tonight when the Socialist group, led by Deputy Vincent Auriol, walked out in a body. This action caused considerable excitement in political circles tonight because it signified the definite withdrawal of Socialist support from the Radical Socialists, whose power since 1932 has depended upon the Socialists.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8. -- A dispute between city and State officials over the issuance of liquor licenses in this city will be taken to court tomorrow. Frank A. Boettner. city corporation counsel, said he would apply to Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker for a review of an order by D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcohol Beverage Control, requiring the prorating of license fees to June 30, 1934.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to dismiss the complaint in a suit by Mrs. Clara Isenberg SielckenSchwarz, in behalf of herself and mother, Mrs. Paul Isenberg, both American citizens, for $6,352,540 damages against American Factors, Ltd., created during the war by the alien property custodian to take over the property of Hawaiian sugar companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- After forty witnesses had moved across the rostra in a session that lasted for almost nine hours today, Senator Copeland, chairman of the subcommittee studying the administration Pure Food and Drug Bill, concluded hearings on the proposal early this evening.

Thirty-one New York University students were inducted last night into two honorary societies at the university. Sixteen became members of Alpha Delta Sigma, national advertising fraternity, at a dinner in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and fifteen joined the Washington Square Economics Society at a dinner at Ann Holloway's, 25 West Eighth Street.

HAVANA, Dec. 8. -- The threatened island-wide strike of employes of the Compania Cubana de Electricidad, an affiliate of the Electric Bond and Share Company, holding a virtual monopoly over electric power on the island, caused military authorities to take extraordinary precautions today to prevent the disorders and general looting anticipated if the island is thrown into darkness.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- The world's middleweight championship remained the property of Vince Dundee of Newark, N. J., when he out-pointed Andy Callahan of Lawrence, Mass., in a 15-round contest before 11,000 spectators in the Boston Garden tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 8. -- The first person Postmaster General James A. Farley wanted to see after his arrival in Paris from Rome this morning was James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Thomas have arrived from New York at Villa Marcheta, where they are guests of Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff. Others in the house party there include Miss Shirley Skiff Janotta of New York and Harry W. Eulass of Short Hills, N. J. Mrs. Skiff will give a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Thomas next Friday.

The constitutionality of the emergency legislation passed for the rehabilitation of insurance companies was upheld yesterday for the first time in an appeals court, when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed an order of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler for the reorganization of the National Surety Company.

Criticising the government's policy in attempting to raise domestic agricultural prices irrespective of world prices, Roy A. Roberts, managing editor of The Kansas City Star, told the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, in session yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, that the farmer was in no mood for revolution.

With an unchanged price for domestic gold at $34.01 an ounce for the seventh successive day, the dollar in foreign exchange markets yesterday was slightly"" lower. Stocks drifted back and forth and, as a result of the weakness in the commodity markets, closed irregularly lower.

The administration of the National Recovery Act by compliance boards was denounced as absurd and as providing many means for inciting complaints, but few for settling them, yesterday by Wilson Compton of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association.

Heavy engineering contracts reported for the last two weeks indicate a slowing up of the pace set in October and early November, with the total of awards for the week ended Dec. 4 set at $23,256,000, according to figures compiled by Engineering News-Record.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 8. Four kidnapped members of a Royal Canadian Mounted Police boat were liberated and their captors, members of the crew of the Kromhout, were arrested by French authorities at St. Pierre, Miquelon, last night, it was announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Southeastern Conference football coaches tonight recommended abolishment of the rule prohibiting substitute players from being rushed into the game at a critical moment with instructions from the coach.
Hunting on Long Island this year has not been a huge success, judging from several reports which have come in within recent days. The quail and pheasant shooting has been below par.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 8 (AP). -- George K. Arthur, a comedian in the days of the silent film, announced his return to the screen today. He has signed for a role in Norma Shearer's new starring vehicle. Since he left the screen, Arthur has been operating a Hollywood playhouse.

Steps to create jobs for additional thousands of unemployed under the Civil Works Administration were taken yesterday by Travis H. Whitney, local Civil Works Administrator, with the appointment of a committee to survey the 269 parks in the city and recommend useful projects.
Sale of a Jersey City apartment house corner by an estate was the outstanding item in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: On a side street off the Bowery I watched a crowd of shabby men buying and selling and trading things -- hats. watches, pipes, overcoats, pants and shoes. A policeman moved them on, and when I asked him why, he said: "Because most of that stuff is stolen goods.

So little change was made yesterday in the government's final estimate of the cotton crop from figures of the previous month that prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to move narrowly under the lightest trading attending any annual report in many years.

BARCELONA, Saturday, Dec. 9. -- Anarchists began their scheduled uprising shortly before midnight by bombing churches and other buildings in several parts of the city and opening battles with troops and the police in the city and in the suburbs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- A warning that the liquor codes might plunge the Federal Government into the liquor business "to a far greater extent than it ever has been before" was sounded here tonight by Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment.

The Fund for the Neediest Cases was greatly helped yesterday by s. contribution of $1,000 from Miss Caroline L. Morgan, a regular giver for years. Her contribution and 205 others of all sizes made a total for the day of $5,365.17 and brought the amount received thus far this year to $48,702.98.

A new magic "mirror" for gazing into the wonderland of primeval matter, through which science may for the first time behold the "dance of the molecules," and "tag" the specific atoms composing them, was described last night before the New York section of the American Chemical Society.

Two large collections of textiles have been presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art recently and have been arranged in a special exhibition to be opened this morning n Gallery H15. The exhibition will continue through next June 9.

Twelve pounds heavier than when he lost his national amateur tennis crown at Forest Hills in September and more rested and carefree than he has been on any previous trip to this city, Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena paid a flying trip to New York yesterday.

A tropical festival was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, drawing an attendance of nearly 1,500 persons. Designated the Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and Supper Dance, the event presented a lavish fashion exhibit and a program of divertissement in a setting characteristic of a Florida Winter resort.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Clarence Click, 27 years old, who was pictured by his attorneys as the unwilling tool of leaders of the gang who kidnapped Miss Mary McElroy last May and held her for $30,000 ransom, was convicted here today by a jury which fixed the penalty at eight years in prison.

GENEVA, Dec. 8. -- A report that Secretary of State Cordell Hull had made a move at Montevideo for closer cooperation between the League of Nations and the Pan American Union was carried today in dispatches from that city to Continental newspapers.

Mayor O'Brien and the Board of Estimate approved yesterday applications for Federal loans totaling $33,697,420, which, if granted, will be largely devoted to school construction. The total of city applications for all purposes to the Federal Government is now above $110,000,000.

Tears streamed down Waxey Gordon's cheeks yesterday as he stood in the sunlight by the grave of his son, Theodore, in Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing and recited the kadish, the Jewish prayer for the dead. Mourning beside him stood Leah Wexler, his wife, and near by their children, Paul, 15 years old, and Beatrice, who is 11.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would be a distinct loss to the taxpayers of the State and to the genuine welfare of our educational program if the significance is lost of the minority report of the Governor's committee on cost of education.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -- Football's noted pigskin, jugglers, the gridiron troupers of Southern Methodist University, will match their aerial mano uvrings against the stoned-wall line and crushing ground offense of St. Mary's Gaels tomorrow in the season's outstanding intersectional clash in this sector.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 8. -- Elmer Layden, fullback of the famous "Four Horsemen of Notre Dame" of a decade ago, will attempt to pull Notre Dame back to the football crest.

Though the financial crisis of last February-March now lies nine months behind us, there are communities which still have inadequate banking facilities and in some cases none at all. Fortunately, the situation in this respect is constantly improving. On March 15 there were 1,446 national banks which had not received licenses to reopen.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 9. -- Fears of concerted international action against Japanese goods have been aroused by the recent remark of Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, in the House of Commons that Japanese competition concerned all Europe, coupled with reports that Premier Mussolini and Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, had discussed restriction of Japanese imports.

The London Times has got hold of the memoranda of THOMAS HAMMERSLEY for the years 1798 to 1808. Hammersley Co. opened their private bank, ultimately absorbed by the more famous Coutts Co., in 1796. As usual, the good old days of banking were sighed for:

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour affirmed France's fidelity to the League of Nations today and expressed the intention of his government not to permit the least diminution of the League, "which remains and will remain the basis of French policy."
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Behind the scenes in four capitals energetic steps were being taken today to end the disarmament deadlock.

Service Not Official. The late FRANK L. BABBOTT was sometimes called The First Citizen of Brookyn. Yet he never sought or held public office, except membership in the Board of Education. It Was enough for him to lay upon his spirit the lowliest duties, at the same time that he gave time and strength and money to the institutions which stand for the highest aims in art and music and education.
The first round was completed in the fourteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club last night. Five players reached the third round.

The coaching situation at Yale was to have been aired at a meeting at the Yale Club yesterday, but the session did not materialize when Cupid Black, captain of the Eli's 1916 team, gave information purporting to come from Malcolm Farmer, director of athletics.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 8. -- The sudden departure of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh from Natal for the north today disappointed the inhabitants of Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- An estimated cotton production of 13,177,000 bales was announced today by the Department of Agriculture as this year's crop. That compares with 13,100,000 bales indicated a month ago and 13,002,000 bales ginned from the 1932 crop.

The Bayside Tennis Club's squash tennis team gained undisputed possession of first place in the metropolitan Class B league last night by blanking the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club quintet on the latters' courts, 5 to 0.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8. -- One of the largest fortunes accumulated in Pittsburgh's history was disposed of this afternoon when the will of Richard B. Mellon, banker and industrialist, was filed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- President Roosevelt listened for more than an hour late today to complaints of motion-picture producers against the code promulgated for their industry which were presented by Will H. Hays, president of the Motion-Picture Producers and Distributers, Inc.

A temporary injunction and showcause order, served on the individual members of the Board of Estimate just before noon, yesterday, blocked action by the city in approving the Wood Harmon plan for the construction of a centre for Brooklyn College.

ST. JOHN, Que., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Two men were held by customs officials today as members of a ring which in the last six months is reputed to have smuggled gold to the value of $1,000,000 into Canada from the United States.

Upton Sinclair's dream for the future, "I, Governor of Californa, and How I Ended Poverty," is to be published next week by Farrar Rinehart. The well-known Sociallst is attempting to win the Democratic nomination for the Governorship of California, and in this volume offers his "Two-Year Plan to make over a State."

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 8. -- A plenary session of the Inter-American Commission of Women adopted today recommendations for presentation to the Pan-American Conference. The commission will ask the conference members to sign a convention granting equal nationality status to men and women and a treaty guaranteeing to women equal civic and political rights with men throughout the Americas.

Last week's radio triologue on "Pruning the City Budget" showed again how Mr. GRIMM, Chairman of our Citizens Budget Commission, has increased in wisdom and stature. He was once the accredited spokesman for real estate interests. Now he has left his more querulous and timid brethren so far behind that some of them may no longer recognize him.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In his radio address of Nov. 5 on "The Restoration of Silver," subsequently published, Father Coughlin said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 2 amounted to 495,425 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 85.922 cars, or 14.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, because of observance of the Thanksgiving holiday.

The advisability of allowing "certain simple buildings, inoffensive in shape and design," to remain standing at the base of the Statue of Liberty, thereby enabling a comparison to impress observers with, the tremendous scale of the statue, was pointed out yesterday by Electus D. Litchfield, president of the Municipal Art Society.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 8. -- In two stubbornly contested meets the Yale varsity defeated the alumni, 34-28, and the freshmen shaded the junior varsity, 39-36, tonight as the Yale swimming season opened in the Bayne Whitney gymnasium pool.

Bank exchanges at the leading clearing houses in the country in November totaled $19,823,804,941, a drop of 6.1 per cent from the turnover in October, but 9.6 per cent larger than that in November, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- About 2,500,000 employes on Federal, State and local civil works projects will receive pay checks tomorrow, and 4,000,000 will be at work by Dec 15, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal administrator, announced today.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down yesterday a decision, for which it said there was no specific authority, removing the possibility that the Bankers Trust Company and the National City Bank might be called on to pay $3,761,431 twice as a result of litigation in both the State and Federal courts over stock deposited by the International Match Company as security for a loan.

The ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton was the scene last night of the annual December ball, given for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House. The event drew a large attendance of members of society, the majority of whom had come from dinners.

The annual invitation concert for contributing members of the Third Street Music School Settlement was given last night at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Harkness Flagler, 32 Park Avenue. Talented young musicians presented the program after a reception in which the guests were received by Mrs. Thomas T. Mackie, president of the settlement's board of directors, and Miss Jean Flagler, a member of the board.
UTIGA, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Following is the text of the address by Chairman Macy at the meeting of Republican County Chairmen here today:

Members of the Yale Club of Montclair tonight will introduce a resolution proposing that Army be dropped from the Yale football schedule, and that an Eastern Intercollegiate Football Conference be formed, according to a statement last night by Kick Roberts, president of the club.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie grave a large dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their elder daughter, Miss Eileen Gillespie. It was one of the most notable debutante parties of the season in New York, and brought together many of the Summer residents of Newport, R. I., with which Mr. and Mrs. Gillespie and the debutante's grandmother, Mrs. Watts Sherman, for many years have been associated.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 8. -- Elmer Layden, who will take up the coaching reins at Notre Dame, is credited with having been the finest of all Notre Dame fullbacks.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 8 (AP). -- The 14-year-old French peasant girl whose visions of the Virgin in 1858 were responsible for the world-famous Grotto of Lourdes was canonized today by Pope Pius.

The prospect of continuation of the restricted payment of interest on German dollar bonds for six months was indicated in a cable dispatch received yesterday by bankers who originally sponsored the issuance of the bonds, from John Foster Dulles of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, who attended the debt conference which has just adjourned in Berlin.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Dec. 8. -- Memories of Civil War days, when commerce of the world plied the Rio Grande up to this city, carrying out the cotton of the Confederacy, were recalled this afternoon when Brownsville people celebrated victory in a twenty-five-year fight to make this a seaport.

Despite optimistic reports that wine and liquor prices were coming down as more licensed places opened up yesterday, retailers in general were found selling the same goods at the same prices as on previous days. Distillers in control of the whisky situation and wholesalers engaged in distributing a full line of wines and other drinkables declared that no reduction could be expected before Christmas.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 8. -- Yale's basketball team romped to a 52-25 victory over the alumni quintet tonight in opening its season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Bristling with new ideas and voting for them almost to the man, the Big Ten football coaches, today asked for the return of the training table on a modified basis within their own conference and recommended three drastic changes in the playing rules to the national football rules committee.

Reorder Main Floor Gift Items. The sudden rush of orders and reorders for accessories during the week indicated the major role which these main floor items are currently playing in holiday retail trade. The call for handbags, particularly for evening wear styles, showed, a considerable increase over the business of the two preceding weeks.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The Boerse was decidedly weak today, the losses ranging beyond three points. The reaction was considered natural in view of the sharp upward movement since early in Nevember and was forecast in recent fluctuations. Heavy industrials and electricals suffered most.

The first award for chemical engineering achievement to be given to a company rather than to an individual was presented last night at the Chemists' Club, 52 East Forty-first Street, to the Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation, a unit of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, at a dinner attended by many noted chemical engineers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Secretary of the Interior lakes, Oil Administrator, made public tonight without comment two proposals of the petroleum industry as substitutes for price-fixing. They provide for removing excess stocks at gasoline from the market and for guaranteeing profit margins to distributers.

The invasion of England by American horses and American horsemen, with the British distance classics, the steeplechasing season and the Liverpool Grand National in view, is on with more emphasis than for several years past, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Secretary of the Interior lakes, Oil Administrator, made public tonight without comment two proposals of the petroleum industry as substitutes for price-fixing. They provide for removing excess stocks at gasoline from the market and for guaranteeing profit margins to distributers.

The invasion of England by American horses and American horsemen, with the British distance classics, the steeplechasing season and the Liverpool Grand National in view, is on with more emphasis than for several years past, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- President Roosevelt has asked George N. Peek to relinquish his post as Agricultural Adjustment Administrator and to head a new division in the State Department that would have for its purpose the opening of new markets for United States farm and industrial products abroad on the basis of the American demand for imported wines and liquors.

Prices in the local commodity futures markets slumped again yesterday, although in most cases, the losses were moderate. Trading continued in reduced proportions. In the cash markets, most quotations were lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Upon detailed reports from Federal Reserve Banks, the Treasury Department announced today that $2,714,000,000, or nearly three times the $950,000,000 requested, was subscribed to its offering yesterday of 2 1/4 per cent one-year government certificates.

The regulations to which national banks must suscribe in connection with the sale of preferred stock to the RFC were revealed for the first time yesterday in a letter sent to stockholders of the National City Bank notifying them of the meeting called for Jan. 9 to ratify the program of recapitalization announced on last Tuesday by James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of directors.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The House of Commons decided today to wipe out the worst absurdity of the British liquor licensing regulations, which have been the butt of ceaseless complaints and ridicule ever since the World War.
Purchase of a block of flats on the upper West Side featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday. The Hotel White, bid in at a foreclosure sale, was the outstanding auction item.

The campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is raising a fund of $4,000,000 for unemployment relief, was approaching the $3,000,000 mark yesterday as all divisions and groups were redoubling their efforts to attain the final goal by Dec. 16, the date set for conclusion of the drive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Dec. 1 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 12,108,292 running bales, including 533,620 round bales, counted as half bales, and 4,679 bales of American Egyptian, but excluding linters.

At Natal the reception of Colonel and Mrs. LINDBERGH resembled in enthusiasm the welcome given aim at Le Bourget when he dropped from the skies at the end of his lonely flight from Long Island. Passage of the South Atlantic had often been made, and by celebrated airmen, but this case was different.

As a result of a split between the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency and the Twentieth Century Fund, these bodies will conduct independent surveys of stock market practices. Their investigations, however, will be along sub stantially the same lines.
The start of Christmas buying in earnest and heavy buying of liquors throughout the country featured trade developments during the week, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- A basic liquor tax of $2.60 a gallon on distilled spirits to supplant the present rate of $1.10 is suggested in the report of the President's Interdepartmental Committee on Alcoholic Control, copies of which have been transmitted to chairmen of tax committees in the House and Senate.
BERLIN, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Mrs. Maria Griebl, who was questioned during the Nazi investigation In New York, is in Berlin, It was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Formal approval of the first big grant of public works money to Illinois was announced today by Secretary Ickes in the form of a loan of $33,948,000 to the Sanitary District of Chicago.

An appeal for application of the NRA to the railroads was sent yesterday to President Roosevelt by the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau as part of a protest against collection and delivery service started by the Pennsylvania, Erie and Grand Trunk Railroads and approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8. -- The filly Betty Farrell, by North Star III from Sweep Park, made it four in a row when she captured the featured fourth race at Jefferson Park today in a driving finish. The former E. R. Bradley colorbearer now has won six of her last seven starts and apparently has reached the best form of her career.

DUBLIN, Dec. 8. -- President de Valera's government decided tonight to suppress the Irish Fascist, or Blue Shirt, movement and issued a proclamation banning the Young Ireland Association, the Blue Shirt section of the United Ireland party.

Commerce Hall in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, opened yesterday with the Ford Exposition of Progress. The hall was dedicated last night in ceremonies presided over by General George R. Dyer, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

With diphtheria cases reduced by almost half from last year, and only seventy-seven deaths this year as compared with 200 for the first eleven months of last year, a new low record has been, set for diphtheria in the city, Health Commissioner Wynne announced yesterday.

MADRID, Dec. 8 (AP). -- A long-expected revolutionary movement was apparently under way in Spain tonight with attempts to cripple international communications and with open outbreaks in Barcelona. Extremist action expected since last month's general elections, which turned the government sharply to the Right, were scheduled to begin with the slashing of communication lines.
NEW YORK. Paul May, the Belgian Ambassador, and Mme. May are at the Ambassador.

Columbia athletic authorities studied weather maps and charts yesterday as they amassed data on possible routes and stop-over places for the Blue and White football squad on its trip to Pasadena, Calif., to meet Stanford on Jan. 1.

The Paramount film version of "Alice in Wonderland" will be presented simultaneously on Dec. 22 in 120 cities in the United States, twelve in Canada and fifty in Europe and Asia. Charlotte Henry, 19-year-old Brooklyn girl who plays the title role, will arrive in New York tomorrow morning from Philadelphia in the course of a 10,000-mile tour of the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Money circulation during November rose $106,000,000 from the October amount to a total of $5,740,774,218, the largest November increase in several years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- A decision on an allotment of $25,500,000 to complete the Eighth Avenue subway in New York City was promised for early next week by Secretary Ickes, the Public Works Administrator, after a conference with President Roosevelt today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Prosecution of railroads which interfere in union affairs was threatened today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads. Railroads which have violated the labor provisions of the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act must "keep their hands off so far as labor organizations are concerned."

The bo market on the Stock Exchange was regular yesterday in the absence of any important change in the value of the dollar against leading foreign exchange rates. United States Government bonds closed irregularly lower, 22-32 point down to 3-32 point up, as leading foreign loans pointed higher.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Deposits in banks under jurisdiction of the State Banking Department amounted to $1,066,903,709 on Oct. 25, a decline of $25,438,560 in the four months' period, and $85,238, 630 from the total on Sept. 30, 1932.

TRENTON, Dec. 8. -- Shortages in the accounts of the Motor Vehicle Department, Board of Shell Fisheries and Department of Commerce and Navigation were reported to Governor Moore today by State Auditor Walter R. Darby.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 8. -- Leading from start to finish in the six and a half furlongs of the Hagerstown Purse, Martin Finn's aged campaigner, Silverdale, won by a length and a half from T.H. Somerville's March Step today. Vacillate was third.

Encouraged by the success of past efforts, the G.R.D. Studio, now at 818 Madison Avenue, is putting on its fifth annual Christmas Show, presenting the work of young artists who have exhibited at the studio in recent years. Small oils and water-colors, drawings, etchings and Christmas cards have been assembled.

ESCANABA, Mich., Dec. 6 -- No tax -- not even the State retail sales tax -- has created so much furor as the $2 head tax which the State of Michigan intends to collect soon to finance the old age pension plan, enacted into law by the State Legislature at its last session.

IN the first three volumes of this monumental work on Spanish painting, which were published in 1930 and reviewed in THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW Nov. 9 of that year, Professor Post developed his theme through the earlier phases and carried it into the fifteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A delegation of four New York relief workers, claiming to represent the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration Employes Association, called at the Federal Emergency Relief Administration today to protest the failure of the New York authorities to transfer "white collar" workers from the relief rolls to the regular Civil Works Administration payrolls.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A 17-year-old girl who can open her mouth only a fraction of an inch murmured her gratitude today when a surgeon promised he would try to check the affliction fast locking her jaws.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A move to increase naval enlisted personnel by 5,000 to man new warships to be put into commission in 1934 is planned in the coming Congress by Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 -- Jacob H. Frank, a founder of Frank Seder, department store owners, died suddenly late today at his home here.

DEVEVELOPMENTS which this department has often predicted as likely to take place in the field of radio music are now rapidly assuming form. This refers above all to the quality of the musical programs sent over the air.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- Information collected and issued by the International Labor Office shows how seriously farm working conditions have been affected by the depression in many countries, especially the United States. In nearly every country, it says, the two chief consequences have been a "considerable fall" in farm wage rates and unemployment reaching the proportions of "a most serious problem."

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- On his way back to London from his sadly diminished disarmament conference at Geneva, Arthur Henderson, its president, stopped two days in Paris to talk things over with Joseph Paul-Boncour, the Foreign Minister, and others.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- If there is a secret leak by which the gold price might be given out to foreign speculators in advance of the Washington announcement, it is well covered.

THE first of the annual series of Children's Concerts will be given Saturday morning by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Ernest Schelling conducting. An all-Mozart program will be presented, with Guila Bustabo as violin soloist. Saturday also marks the final appearance this season of Bruno Walter as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9. Foreign Minister Mello Franco has given a gloomy summary of the probable achievements of the Pan-American Conference to the Journal do Brasil.

FREDERICK KEPPEL has in his annual report for the Carnegie Corporation presented not only a detailed statement of its activities but an interesting review of foundations in general during the lean years. The outstanding fact is that they have been willing to interrupt, or forego entirely, enterprises for which their past experience particularly qualified them and to enter fields which appeared to present "genuine emergency conditions."

SARNIA, Ont., Dec. 9 -- Coming from behind to defeat the Sarnia Imperials by 4 to 3 on a very icy field today, the Toronto Argonauts, champions of the Canadian Senior Football League, retained their title. The battle was a distinct thriller packed with action, triple lateral passes and excellent punting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The leading figures of the Roosevelt administration and the operation of the principal policies of the New Deal were satirized in song and skit as the Gridiron Club gave its annual Winter dinner tonight to its 400 guests chosen from the leaders of American official, political, professional and journalistic life.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Despite falling revenues not one public school in New Jersey was closed during the 1933-1933 school year, Charles H. Elliott, Education Commissioner, declared today in his annual report to the State Board of Education.

CHARLOTTETOWN, P.E.I., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Charles Dalton, Lieutenant Governor of Prince Edward Island, died here today from pleuropneumonia, which developed after he fractured a hip last month in a fall. He was 83 years old.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood today denied Alphonse (Scarface Al) Capone's second plea for his freedom from the Atlanta Penitentiary on a writ of habeas corpus based on the statute of limitations.

THE catalogues of the Scribner Book Store (597 Fifth Avenue. New York) will bear watching. Among American booksellers they have lately assumed the leadership in exploiting the special subject field. Only a month or so ago they published such a list, devoted to "Classics of Discovery and Exploration, 1773-1933."

SYRACUSE, Dec. 9 -- Children's courts were declared instruments "through which the rights of the child may be safeguarded and fostered, and where social justice may be secured for him," in an address by Irving I. Goldsmith of Saratoga, former Supreme Court Justice, before the conference of State juvenile court judges here today.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 8. -- When the Commonwealth Government signed the international agreement to restrict the export of wheat It was obvious it would have to give further financial assistance to the wheat growers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Points in issue involving the administration of the moving picture industry code of fair competition were finally ironed out early tonight and agreement was reached, which, it was stated, is satisfactory to both the NRA and the industry.

IT is something like a century and a half since the German Winckelmann amazed the dilettanti of his age by demonstrating the fact, which nowadays appears so obvious, that the vast majority of all known "Greek" sculptures were in reality no more than copies hastily executed in late Roman imperial times.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- New York's hopes of reclaiming the Lockett Trophy were dealt a severe blow today when its squash racquets team fell before Boston, 4 to 3, as the annual intercity matches started at the Philadelphia Country Club.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Marcel Rochas's fluted and quilted patent leather revers and cuffs are original understudies for fur trimmings on early Spring costumes.

FURTHER highly successful tests last week with the blind landing facilities developed by the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce and installed at Newark Airport have served to emphasize a new the vital part which radio communication plays in the modern air transport system.

The selection of the 1933 All-America field hockey team again gives the greater number of places to Philadelphia players. Six posts in all have been won by the Pennsylvanians, Boston has three, Baltimore one and Washington the other.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 9 -- Dome Mines in November produced bullion to the value of $358,700, an increase of $7,894 over the $350,906 reported for October. For the eleven months ending with November production amounted to $4,171,500, gold figured at $20.67 an ounce, from 501,660 tons milled averaging $8.40 a ton.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 10 -- Statements made by army and navy spokesmen at press conferences today are interpreted as efforts to interdict free discussion of the military and naval budgets at the forth-coming Diet session.

A warning against political wirepulling in the placing of men in new jobs was sounded yesterday by Travis H.
