Whitney, New York City Administrator of the Civil Works Administration, after reports had reached him that district leaders were trying to influence some of his agents to grant favors to their followers.

WITH the Twenty-first Amendment only five days in force, it has already become apparent that the passing of prohibition has left the liquor problem still unsettled, with many puzzling questions no nearer an answer than they were thirteen years ago, and with bitter controversies already springing up.

ROME, Sunday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A new corporative law under which Italy's economic life will be brought under the jurisdiction of the National Council of Corporations, invested with law-making powers, was approved early today during an all-night session of the Grand Council of Fascism.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The purpose and functions of the Nazi storm divisions, popularly referred to as the S.A. [Sturmabteilung], were elucidated with considerable detail and frankness by Captain Ernst Rochm, their chief of staff to large gathering of newspaper men and diplomats a few nights ago.

LONDON. FOR several days past large crowds have visited Sunderland House to inspect one of the most remarkable book exhibitions ever seen in London. It has been organized by The Sunday Times, which has persuaded over forty publishers to display the best of their recent productions.

ADEQUATE protection of the taxpayer's dollars which are to be expended for public education is a matter of graveconcern. In 1931 the annual expenditures for public education in the United States amounted to approximately two and a half billions of dollars -- 25 per cent of the taxes collected for all public purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Lower liquor taxes to hold down the price of the legal beverage were demanded on Capitol Hill today at about the same time that the Federal Government was virtually clinching its control of the liquor industry.
The New Harmony. "And now that we have seen the Capitol and the White House and the Washington Monument," said Alice, "don't you think we might look at some of the Government Departments?"

ONE of the particularly bright spots in the lists recently received from abroad seems to us to be the Ernest Bloch quintet for piano and strings, played by Alfredo Casella and the Pro Arte Quartet, which is now to be had on four H.M.V. disks (DB 1882/5).

The National Consumers League, at 156 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had submitted a program of suggested improvements of labor provisions in NRA codes to Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, and other high NRA officials.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Before adjourning for the Christmas rccess Parliament will have placed on the legislative program for the Winter session one or more bills for the reform of the House of Lords.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- The Princeton University Triangle Club production, "Fiesta," which will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York on Dec. 19, will open on Friday in the McCarter Theatre here.
PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The Pelham Country Club was the scene tonight of a repeal celebration which included a supper, dance and Monte Carlo party.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9 -- Elmer Layden, one of the famed "Four Horsemen" of Notre Dame, will assume his new duties as athletic director and head coach of the Rambler football team on Feb. 1. The resignation of Jesse Harper and Heartly (Hunk) Anderson, are effective at once.

The NRA program with its shorter working hours and increased leisure offers educational institutions throughout the country a chance to "dignify" adult education, originally concerned with the Americanizatior of foreigners, by elevating it to the same level as full-time collegiate study.

A RECENT occurrence in a Brooklyn court illustrated the collusion that goes on in many divorce cases. A lawyer more naive than most of his profession handed to the astonished judge a document setting forth the terms of a bargain regarding a divorce.

MAYOR-ELECT LAGUARDIA announced the other day that on assuming office he would attend strictly to executive business and let the social activities take care of themselves. A more cautious temperament might have qualified it, as did the little girl who said she was going to get married when she grew up -- "At least I will if I can, and I think I can."

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most disheartening signs of the times is the apparent indifference of the people to encroachments upon their liberties by our legislative and executive authorities. It is, perhaps, because we have enjoyed our liberties so long that we take them for granted.
Using three complete teams Fordham defeated Cooper Union at basketball in the Fordham gymnasium last night, 37 to 9.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: In his review of G.D.H. and Margaret Cole's "The Intelligent Man's Review of Europe Today." William MacDonald quotes. "* * * if they (the trade unions) are to retain power, they will have to organize in future far more in such a way as to bring together in one closely knit organization the whole mass of workers, skilled and unskilled, employed in a particular industry."

HARTFORD, Dec. 7 -- What constitutes a proper system of liquor regulation is still being debated in Connecticut just as warmly as if the Legislature had not last April, after its greatest battle in a generation, adopted a control law recommended by its sponsors as perfection, not only to control 3.2 beer but to control anything that could be offered after the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- General Smedley D. Butler of the marines, retired, directed sharp criticisms at the American Legion leadership and called for payment of the soldiers' bonus in a speech before a meeting of the New Orleans Veterans of Foreign Wars here last night.

WILL ROGERS told his London music-hall audiences in 1926 that he had watched the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and then had rushed over to Paris to watch another daily spectacle -- the changing of the French Cabinet.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The effort of Judge Alfred O. Erickson of Chicago to prevent extradition of James A. Larue to Florida as an escaped convict drew from Governor Dave Snoltz tonight a telegraphed message that "if you want to keep him * * * that's your privilege."
PARIS, Dec. 9. -- Premier Camille Chautemps's Cabinet cleared today the hurdle of civil servants' pay cuts when the Chamber of Deputies gave two votes of confidence in adopting the measure.

Steamship operators hail the end of the prohibition era as business men from the standpoint of safety of their property as well as the conveniences of passengers. Although the short cruise business was developed a few years ago as a result of prohibition and has greatly increased the income of the operators, the losses traced to the liquor situation are said by shipping men to overbalance this.

WHAT is the National Recovery Administration trying to do for American business? What does self-government of industry mean? Are we moving toward government control of industry or industrial control of government?

ONCE upon a time, now a long time, this reviewer caught a shark. To be more accurate, he caught one-third of the shark, as it took the combined power of three pairs of arms to lift the creature over the high counter of the barkentine aboard which he was at the time becalmed off Hatteras.

HISTORY is to be defined as life transference by literature from one period to another. Mr. Russell belongs to the twentieth century, and it has been his task to enable the eleventh century to be itself again.

DENVER, Dec. 7 -- Shaken from their usual apathy 28,500 Denver taxpayers went to the polls on Nov. 28 and the school board's proposal that it be allowed to issue refunding bonds to care for obligations maturing in 1934 and 1935 was defeated.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Camille Chautemps' new Cabinet had a remarkable success in the Chamber of Deputies today when its provisional plan for reductions in civil service salaries was upheld by an imposing majority of 345 to 150. Such plans had been rejected twice before by the Chamber, causing the defeat of the Cabinets of Edouard Daladier and Albert Sarraut.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A serious difference of opinion has manifested itself recently regarding currency management. The view seems to be, in many quarters, that currency management is not justified. The question from my point of view is, rather, "Is present 'management' in any way consistent with the requirements of the situation?"

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Eleven persons were killed in automobile accidents in New England today as a light snow turned highways into icy paths. Four were Civilian Conservation Corps members who lost their lives at Center Ossipee, N.H., when a camp truck was side-swiped by another truck which went on without stopping.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9. -- Yale outscored the St. Nicholas Club sextet by 7 to 3 in opening its hockey season in the New Haven Arena tonight.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- No tidal wave of intoxicating liquor has inundated New England as a result of repeal. All the celebrations have been relatively mild. Conditions differ enormously, however, among these six States. Vermont is bone dry.
BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The official stand of the government -- which is synonymous with the Nazi party -- is and always has been that it does not conduct any political propaganda abroad.

Steamship lines and shippers are pleased with service provided by the union inland terminal which was built a year ago by the Port of New York Authority at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. Savings in time and trucking charges have been effected, shipments expedited and motor trucks diverted from the waterfront piers of the railroad lines, a survey of its first year of operation shows.

A reception will be given by the president and members of the board of directors of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association tomorrow afternoon at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, for Mrs. Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, and her son and daughter-in-law, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, and Mrs. Roosevelt.

After an uninspired opening the stock market turned strong and active soon after 11 o'clock yesterday to close the week in a burst of rising quotations. Representative issues rose 1 to 6 points and closed at or near the best prices for the day.

OMAHA, Dec. 7 -- To the corn and cow States between the Mississippi and the mountains formal repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was just a date rather than an event. It came unaccompanied by any of those outward evidences of recognition which show that people are sensible of an important change affecting their lives.

SINCE there have been at least four Danas named Richard Henry, it is essential that genealogy be exactly set down. The subject of this biography by Bliss Perry was the son of the author of "Two Years Before the Mast," who was in turn Richard Henry Jr.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The sales tax as a medium for obtaining revenue is minimized in a survey just completed for the American Legislators" Association by Joseph G. Riddle and discussed in a report by Rodney L. Mott, research consultant, issued here today.

HITLER'S Brown Shirt army, or storm detachments, recently made an official arm of the German Reich, has climbed rapidly in numbers and power. A few years ago it was merely one of several "private armies" in Germany. Absorbing other groups, and growing from within, it has become the most powerful in the land.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Definite announcement that preparations were being made for a flight of six giant navy, seaplanes of PT-10 Squadron from California to Hawaii early next year was made today by Rear Admiral A.W. Johnson, commander of the aircraft base force.

Several young women, headed by Countess Eleanora Colloredo Mannsfeld, are aiding in the arrangements for the bundle reception and tea which will be held Tuesday in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle, in behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop.

Running up a 25-8 lead at the intermission and then coasting through the second half, three complete City College basketball teams collaborated in defeating the University of Baltimore, 41-21, at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night.

PARA, Brazil, Dec. 9 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh decided today that the next lap of their long Odyssey would be a flight over jungle wilderness to Manaos, about 1,000 miles inland up the great Amazon River.

The downward trend of prices on local commodity exchanges was checked yesterday and the markets for most staples closed with gains. Trading generally was featureless, the markets taking their cue from the trends of outside exchanges. Cash prices were higher.
A suggested Jiquor t creed for young men will be circulated this week through the city branches of the Y.M.C.A.

LA FIGLIA DEL DRAGONE ROSSO ("The Red Dragon's Daughter"), a dramatic spectacle in sixteen scenes, by Clemente Giglio. Produced by his company at the Teatro Venezia, with music directed by Giuseppe de Luca.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Mr. Baseball Fan, who annually cocks his ear in expectation toward the major league conclave, probably will be rewarded by hearing a good bit of news from Philadelphia diamond magnates at this year's conference in Chicago next week.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 THE classical drama has always brought out the best that is in the German theatre. On reviewing its activities of the past dozen years or so the greater number of its High points were reached through the medium of the already approved dramatic works.
New Yorkers proved again last night that, as far as liquor is concerned, they could take it or leave it alone.
MADRID, Dec. 9. -- In the full blaze of the political limelight as Parliament opaned this week was the figure of Jose Maria Gil Robles.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Sixty years after the death of Eugene Magevney, an Irish immigrant, the Tennessee Supreme Court today disposed of his $3,500,000 estate by awarding the bulk of it to an adopted granddaughter, who years ago was taken from a New York orphanage.

FOR one who, for more than a quarter of a century, has devoted his whole working life to the development of the electric power industry it is impossible to read, without amazement and protest, the article by Albert Levitt entitled "Utilities Under the New Deal."

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 9 -- Mississippi Dan, a white and liver pointer owned by Robert Huntley of Buffalo, N.Y., today was adjudged winner of the members' Derby Stake in the Pointer Club of America's field trials.
Although declarations of dividends reached a high mark last week, a group of managements deferred declarations until the new year because of tax considerations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Encouragement of local study and promotion of low-cost housing continues to be the policy of the Public Works Administration, Secretary Ickes said today in a formal statement redefining the policy of the housing division.

John Romeo of Abraham Lincoln High captured the P.S.A.L. individual rifle shooting championship as three groups of scholastic teams competed in the preliminary round for the team title yesterday over different ranges in the city.

AFTER excellent business over the Thanksgiving (and Army-Notre Dame) week-end, the theatre drifted into a slight sigh of despond. In fact, the first two nights of last week were saved by theatre parties, six of them on Monday and eight on Tuesday.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 6 -- No one seriously thinks that in any of the Mountain States either the bootlegger or the moonshiner will disappear, at least for the present. Passing of the Eighteenth Amendment is of purely academic interest. For practical purposes, drinking habits are likely to remain as at present.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Ch is sometimes hard before a, as in chaos and Michael. But in the proposed form Chaikovski, the ch is not before a, but before ai; and in that collocation it is normally not hard -- for instance, chain, chair.

If one happens to be lazy, one may be excused for having left unread, perhaps having formed a resolution never to read, that protracted novel whose rating among the best sellers is AA. To such a faineant such a task looks as difficult as shinning up Mount Everest. It is easier for him to adopt the comparative method and escape.

There has been no evidence of widespread profiteering in retailing, according to views expressed by a number of leading manufacturers to the National Retail Dry Goods Association and issued yesterday by that organization.

Lady Armstrong, wife of Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, until two years ago British Consul General here, called upon the Catholic women of New York yesterday to carry not only their own burden in the present crisis, but to play an active part in meeting national and international problems.

DUBLIN, Dec. 8. -- All the political furor occasioned by the exchange of notes between Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council, and J.H. Thomas, British Secretary for the Dominions, has subsided.

DECEMBER, 1932 . . . the shadow of separation hanging over a home . . . a devoted father and mother, fearing for their two children . . . both parents prostrated by illness and at the end of their resources . . . and Anne, 15, and Robert, 7, too young to take up the task of bread-winning.

Fred G. Clark, Commander-in-Chief of The Crusaders, denied yesterday that the organization was opposing the monetary policy of President Roosevelt. He denied, also, that The Crusaders, in their stand on monetary policies, had exceeded the authority of their charter, as was charged on Friday by W.W. Farley, former Democratic State Chairman and a member of The Crusaders, in a statement in Albany.

Tammany is facing an insurrection in the Board of Aldermen, which it has dominated for years, as a result of a "trick" played on the Bronx members of the board by the New York County organization, in the cutting down of the city budget.

AFTER a protracted and bitter debate with, the British Government, President de Valera of the Irish Free State last week raised the issue of secession. In a formal communication he asked the British Government for "a direct and unequivocal statement" in answer to the question whether it will "treat as a cause of war or other aggressive action a decision of the Irish people to sever their connection" with the British Commonwealth of Nations.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 9 -- The University of Richmond, football team ended the hopes of Emory and Henry College for the State championship by pushing across third and fourth period touchdowns to win, 13 to 0.

NEW YORK. Prince and Princess de Caraman Chimay gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre for Mrs. Orme Wilson, Mrs. Cooper Hewitt, Mrs. R. Horace Gallatin, General Charles H. Sherrill and Benjamin Welles.

THIS beautifully printed limited edition of the poems of Charles Churchill, with its brilliantly written Introduction and complete footnotes, will be highly prized by scholars and students of the eighteenth century. For Churchill, although not a great poet, addressed himself directly, in his satires, to the important men of his day.

The ruling of D. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey Liquor Commissioner, that liquor licenses issued by municipalities must be on a seven months' basis, was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker in Newark. Justice Parker denied an appeal by the City Commissioners of Newark, through Corporation Counsel Frank Boettner, for a writ seeking to review the ruling of Commissioner Burnett.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The National Industrial Recovery Act was praised by Wilson Compton, manager of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association and Special Industrial Adviser of the NRA, in an address before the Taylor Society in New York last night.

HTLER'S Germany, the United States under the NRA, these would have driven Lauro de Bosis to passionate rebellion. He did not live to see them. Rugged individualist, he died in defense of a liberty which he declared Mussolini's dictatorship imperiled.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9. -- A simple electrical device which can reproduce exactly the simple forms of behavior of a child, and may lead to wholly new fields of study in psychology, was shown today by a senior at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

NOW that prohibition is officially dead, we are told that its brief inglorious reign did more to popularize the domestic practice of wine-making -- and wine-drinking -- in these United States than three centuries before were able to accomplish.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Enthusiastic over the prospects of winning permission to establish a modified training table and for moving up the start of organized Fall gridiron practice five days, Big Ten football coaches and athletic directors cleared up various odds and ends of their meeting today and then talked shop.

IN this illuminating volume G. Wilson Knight has out himself loose from all textual criticism, from all criticism based on historical or social interpretation, and "voyaging through strange seas of thought alone" (to use Wordsworth's arresting phrase), has come upon meanings and relationships the implications of which must give every thoughtful reader pause, even though in the last analysis he may not at every point agree with Professor Knight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Legislation to tax the income from government securities, now tax exempt, is being prepared by Senator Ashurst, Democrat, of Arizona, for consideration by Congress.

WILL ROGERS renewed an old acquaintance on the set of "Mr. Skitch" when he encountered Big Heart, a University-trained Osage Indian. It stirred in him memories of his early days in Oklahoma at the time when the Osage nation was receiving so much money from oil rights that every buck and squaw owned at least one Rolls-Royce.

UNION CITY, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Unwilling to submit further to the "abuse" by charity patients, Dr. Morris Green, town physician, tendered his resignation today to the Union City Commission. His $500 annual salary represented "ten cents a call," he declared.

THE nearer the season of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe which opens Dec. 22, the more staggering becomes the extent of its repertoire. To the originally announced twelve ballets there have now been added ten more.

PARIS. PARIS couturiers are showing an exceptional number of new evening gowns for this time of year, when they usually concentrate on sports and daytime frocks. This must mean something! It may indicate at least two things: First, that a strong effort is being made to prolong the rediscovered formality of the town season into Summer resort evenings: and second that the couturiers are going in more and more for timely creations.

Coming back strongly in the second half, the James Monroe High School soccer team retained the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship by defeating Thomas Jefferson High of Brooklyn, 2 to 1, yesterday morning on Monroe's field in the Bronx.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 7 -- Tuesday's passing of the Eighteenth Amendment meant less than nothing in Puerto Rico. The island is still legally dry. Prices of imported liquors probably are at the lowest point. Stocks are not as large as at some times in past years, but the assortment is considered quite adequate.

WHITCHURCH, Hampshire, England, Dec. 9 -- A sudden fire roared through the country home of Leander J. McCormick, prominent Chicagoan, and Mrs. McCormick early today, cast tragedy over a week-end house party by causing the death of a French nobleman and a British army Captain and left the mansion virtually in ruins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Following complaints that the American purchasing price for newly mined gold in the domestic market had been available in London four to eight minutes before the daily announcement by the United States, an inquiry to hunt out any "leaks" has been begun by Acting Secretary Morgenthau.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Joe Bach, Elmer Laydens's assistant at Duquesne and the man responsible for the development of the Dukes' powerful lines, is believed to have the inside track for the football coaching job, and Bach admits he'd like to have it.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Application for a temporary injunction against enforcement of Rule 8 of the State Board of Regents respecting advertising by dentists has been denied by Judge John To Loughran of the Supreme Court The matter was argued here last month.

AN engine that may exert important influence on the future of aircraft design and operation is flying in Great Britain. For seven years the experimental staff of the Bristol company worked on the many difficult problems involved in securing troublefree, efficient running of a single-cylinder sleeve-valved unit.

THE book of Roman Dyboski, Professor of English Literature at the University of Cracow, is an encyclopedic work, covering in the main Poland's history, her problems of national minorities, of economy, education and research, and her most important creations in literature and art.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 7 -- Terrapin dealers hereabout say Yankees are ordering more diamond backs to be made into soup than they have in the last few Winters. Savannah has several diamond back terrapin dealers, and they have been receiving very few orders for their products since the stock market began to misbehave.

THIS is the record of five weeks' observation of the social and solitary wasps and stingless bees of Barro Colorado Island, Gatun Lake. C.Z. Panama, where the Institute for Research in Tropical America maintains a jungle laboratory under the auspices of the National Research Council.

THESE papers, chiefly on the great Germans of the past, bear down on the modern situation -- and not only in Germany -- with startling force and pertinency; we doubt if any other writer could, through a few commemorative speeches and.

Foreign criticism of the American merchant marine brought a vigorous reply yesterday from American ship interests. These attacks upon the American shipping policy were made by Alexander Shaw, chairman of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of London, followed by the British Chamber of Shipping and lastly fay Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who indicated that his government was preparing to enact immediate measures for the defense of British shipping.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9. -- A decree issued today and signed by President Mikbail Kalinin. Premier Molotoff and A.S. Yenukidze, secretary of the Soviet Central Executive Committee, places responsibility for the poor quality of goods and inefficiency in factories on managers and other executives.

AN appeal has been made to Eugene L. Vidal, director of aeronautics, for government consideration of the future of seaplanes. About ten days ago it was announced in Washington that under the Civil Works Administration $10,000,000 had been allotted to the building of better airport facilities at something like 2,000 cities in the United States This work is designed to increase the efficiency of air transport and to provide jobs.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 10 -- While Nanking's four peace delegates are sailing toward Hongkong upon a mission on which Sun Fo, head of the Legislative Council, says the preservation of China's integrity depends, Canton has completed the massing of 50,000 soldiers along Fukien Province's southern border.
PARIS, Dec. 1. -- The once obscure and now world-famous little Norman town of Lisieux is giving more and more work to the French postoffice authorities, thanks to Ste. Therese.

A sale of European and American paintings from various collections and estates will take place at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening. Eighteenth, and nineteenth century works predominate in this auction, which will include lots from the collections of Alexander M. Hudnut, Mrs. James B. Wilbur Jr., Kiliaen Van Rensselaer, and the estate of Margaretta B. Webb.

Orders for Christmas gift items, particularly for main-floor selling, poured into the market during the week, with immediate delivery requested, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

AN imposing array of machines and materials which illustrate the development of our industrial era and go far in explaining the mechanical age is now being shown at the Ford Exposition of Progress in the newly decorated Commerce Hall of the huge Port Authority Building at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are told that there are 48,000,000 laborers in this country, of whom 8,000,000 are farmers, and that these farmers will profit by the depreciation of the dollar. The other 40,000,000 will go to the wall. We will leave them there for the present.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 7 -- Kentucky, thirty-third State to ratify repeal despite having a constitutional amendment and an enforcement act patterned after the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead Act of the United States, virtually has returned to the status of pre-prohibition local option.

WHENEVER we speculate on life after a social revolution -- and some form of social revolution seems to us more imminent today than it did five years ago -- we are inclined to worry about the fate of the artist in the new state.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The celebration of the new "wet age" among Americans in London was somewhat curbed today by receipt in the afternoon's mail of demands for payment of an instalment on their British income tax.

The French have a saying, "il nous faut un traitre" -- we must have a traitor. The search for a scapegoat is one of the commonest of human weaknesses. It may be a husband or an ancestor or a witch or a banker or a politician. It is never any fault in ourselves. Many tribes of men are held responsible for the depression, among the most popular proscriptions being those issued against bankers and statesmen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Parties and policies were satirized tonight within the walls of the White House no less pointedly and before as "official"a company as at the Gridiron dinner where President Roosevelt, members of his Cabinet and others, were the guests of honor.

THE Christmas shopper who includes art in his list will find an unusual opportunity in the galleries this year. Among the gallery exhibitions especially arranged and priced with a view to holiday gifts are several designed to help young and deserving artists as well as to attract the shopper.

IN new tap rooms and restaurants that repeal has brought upon the scene, decorative inspiration from famous taverns of the past shares honors with gay original contemporary motifs. Important in helping to create a convivial atmosphere in some of these hostelries are murals of appropriate subjects.

When the delegates to the American Kennel Club gather at head quarters on Tuesday for their December meeting they will receive official announcement that the governing body of the kennel world will remain in its present location.

The new Ford cars for 1934 were demonstrated publicly for the first time yesterday at the opening of the Ford Exposition of Progress in the Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

COINCIDENT with the broad-casting in this country on Wednesday of the first radio program from Bombay, comes word from London that efforts are being made for the organization of broadcasting in India as a means of educating its backward races.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The tax lien law put into effect here last year to force payment of delinquent taxes will stay on the local statute books for at least six months, it was decided last night by the city council. The lien law, a rigid measure, was an issue in the recent election.

Although Thomas J. Dolen, leader of the Tammany faction in the Bronx, declared recently that the Tammany group would name a candate for State Senator in the Twenty-first district, it appeared yesterday that this plan had been abandoned and that Tammany would make no attempt to defeat Deputy Attorney General Lazarus Joseph, the nominee of the Democratic county organization headed by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State.
To the Music Editor: The Sunday Times of Oct. 22 carried an article entitled "Music in the Preparatory Schools," in which the following statement was made:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Detectives were stationed today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Claude D. Young of Drexel Park, after their daughter, Alice, 14 years old, had been, threatened with kidnapping unless $10,000 was paid for her safety.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- Japan is preparing to join the rest of the world in the flight from the nineteenth century economics of the open market.

DALLAS, Dec. 7 -- Unjust reflections are being cast on the credit of Texas while the State is in grave danger of fast becoming in bad odor with the Federal Government. This is due to the actions of a small ring of political-minded and selfishly ambitious public officials in handling the State relief bonds, the first issue of which is still begging for a buyer.

The United States Steel Corporation reports shipments of finished steel in November of 430,358 tons, compared with 572,897 in October, a decrease of 142,539 tons. This is the second monthly statement on shipments of finished steel, the corporation having abandoned its monthly report on unfilled orders with its September estimate.

IF proof were needed that in "Ola," published last year. Mr. and Mrs. D'Aulaire created a thoroughly convincing and lovable child character, it would be found in the attitude of boys and girls toward "Ola and Blakken," which they seem to regard not as a new picture and story book but as another glimpse of a tried and true friend.

Accidents Guaranteed. IN a statement issued last week, Owen B. Augspurger, president of the Automobile Club of New York, says that nine out of ten automobiles involved in accidents are in good mechanical condition before suffering the fractures and contusions into which their operators drive them.
THE solid citizen with the brief case all but knelt on the sidewalk to peer appraisingly at the stucco doll-house in the toy-shop window. Impulsively he addressed the stranger beside him.

Editor. The New York Times Book Review: In your issue of Sept. 10 I read a very able review of a book entitled "Cecil Rhodes" by Sarah Gertrude Millin. The book appears to be very interestingly and truthfully written, with the exception of the empire maker's end.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 9 -- Thirty-five students from New York and nineteen from New Jersey will be among the 115 members of the Mount Holypke Glee Club which next Saturday evening will give its ninth annual Christmas Carol Concert at The Town Hall, New York.

Rachmaninoff occupies a lonely position among contemporary pianists, partly because of his unique gifts as virtuoso and composer, partly because his personality grips the public imagination and permeates all he plays. Yesterday's concert at Carnegie Hall, his first of the season, potently illustrated this fact.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES recent articles describing the new Warwick Training School for Boys, and outlining its up-to-date methods, must have been read with, appreciation and satisfaction by all well-wishers of erring youth.

BERLIN. BEFORE mention of the new books, let us give some moments to the memory of the poet-philosopher Albert von Trentini, who died on Oct. 18. His mode of writing, the rich ideological content of his beautifully written works, the profound and religious ethical sense that filled him -- all these combined to drive him into solitude.

TOKYO. YOUNG Mr. and Mrs. Japan last year raised the world record for babies. The number born was 2,182,743; deaths (at all ages) numbered 1,174,875 during the same period. The net increase of population due to an excess of births was 1,007,868.

MADRID, Sunday, Dec. 10. -- Derailed by Extremist revolters, a fast express train plunged over a 100 foot embankment near Puzol, Valencia Province, early today. Six bodies were hauled from the wreckage.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Frankford won the Philadelphia Public High School football championship by beating the Simon Gratz eleven on Franklin Field today, 7 to 0, before a crowd of 7,500 chilled spectators. The field was covered with snow.

George Bernard Shaw analyzed the strong points of dictatorships and once again emphasized the weaknesses of a parliamentary system in a recent lecture before the Fabian Society in London. The following article is made up of excerpts from the stenographic report of his lecture, which Mr. Shaw called "The Politics of Unpolitical Animals.''
Miss Eleanor Hale Mullally was introduced to society yesterday at a tea dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mandeville Mullally, in the grand ballroom of the Pierre.

In addition to the expected and usual difficulties attendant on a marked change in atmosphere, the long trip and strange surroundings, the football players of Columbia will face a tremendous physical barrier in the Stanford team itself when the pair come together in the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena on Jan. 1.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP). -- A committee report denouncing liquor, lynching, divorce, gambling (including bridge playing) and social injustices was adopted here today by a rising vote of the Florida conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Three codes covering the wholesale food and grocery industry, the retail food and grocery industry, and the grocery manufacturing industry, all passed on to the NRA from the AAA by Executive order of President Roosevelt, have received NRA approval.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Luke Lea, who became a United States Senator at 32 and a few years later, a colonel in the A.E. F. who led an unofficial expedition that tried to kidnap the former German Kaiser from his Holland refuge, lost another legal battle today and turned to the United States Supreme Court in a final effort to sidestep a North Carolina prison cell.

TEHERAN, Nov. 25. -- Two main issues have called the attention of the outside world to Persia during past years -- the recurrent controversies betwaen the Persian Government and the Anglo-Persian Oil Company and the growth of nationalism. The oil industry is likely to be the more permanent object of interest, as it is based on something substantial and on support from abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Kenneth Hashagen of Staten Island starred in Pennsylvania's basketball victory over St. Joseph's College at the Palestra tonight, 38 to 26, before a crowd of 3,000 persons, It was the opening game for the Red and Blue.

A plaque of Dr. Virgil P. Gibney, done by Miss Nell Van Hook, painter and sculptor, whose life, when she was a 4-year-old girl, was saved by the surgeon's skill, was presented last night to the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University by the class of '98, one of Dr. Gibney's classes.

SAARBRUECKEN. IN this border district of the Saar, where the population is almost entirely German, the economic regime French and the government international, there has begun a vigorous political offensive which is likely to increase in intensity and bitterness as the date of the plebiscite to decide the future of the Saar approaches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The national award of $200 offered by the American Forestry Association for "the most beautiful photograph of trees in America" will be given to T.O. Sheckell of East Orange, N.J., for his original photograph of trees in the Utah landscape.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 9. -- Greenwich society is expected to attend in large numbers the annual Christmas concert of the Wednesday Singing Club at the Greenwich Country Club on Monday evening. More than 400 invitations have been issued for the concert by the committee, which consists of Mrs. Frank M. Carson, chairman; Mrs. Edgar T. Mead, Mrs. F. H. Filley, Mrs. William E. Hall and Mrs. Walter C. Douglas.

Last June the House or Representatives adopted a resolution authorizing the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee to appoint a subcommittee to make a study of Income taxes. The report of the subcommittee, the publication of which was urged in this column last Sunday, was made public during the past week.

MR. SPAETH finds that there is no book covering the whole subject of music in such a way that "the totally inexperienced listener can immediately understand it." Can there be such a book ? Is it still true that "art is long"?

Swinging higher during yesterday's abbreviated session, prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed at the best levels of the day as the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's price for newly mined domestic gold continued unchanged at $34.01 an ounce.

GUAYAQUIL, Dec. 4 -- The elections on Dec. 14 and 15 to fill the post of the ousted President Martinex Mera promise a close contest between Colon Eloy Alfaro, Left Wing Liberal, and Velasco Ibarra, Liberal, with considerable Conservative, following.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 9 -- Windber High School played brilliant football today to defeat John Harris High of Harrisburg to give a western team its second championship in the Central Pennsylvania Interscholastic Football Conference.

LAST year Stanley Baldwin bluntly told the British House of Commons that the world is preparing for another war in which there will be "wholesale slaughter of non-combatants." This year H.G. Wells forecasts the war as beginning in 1940.

William Armour Thayer, well known organist, professor of music at Adelphi College for the last twenty-five years, died yesterday at his home, 464 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, of a heart attack which occurred last Sunday. He was 59 years old, a native of Brooklyn.

IN Philadelphia, at the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, a quite remarkable sequence of Renoir's paintings has been assembled for the "Manet-Renoir" exhibition, which is to last until Jan. 1. Following the brilliant showing in the Manet-Renoir Gallery at the Century of Progress exhibition, it will focus attention in this part of the country upon these two artists as leaders in modern art.

Dollar sales of leading chainstore systems and mail-order houses throughout the country in November went further ahead of the preceding year than in any month for several years, reports made public to date indicate.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -- Southern California came from behind today to defeat Washington, 13 to 7, and go into a tie with Stanford and Oregon for the football championship of the Pacific Coast Conference.

HATS are like the first birds that fly north ahead of the Spring. They are the messengers of things to come; in their brims and crowns they seem to bear news of oncoming seasons. You are apt to get your Autumn hat before you do your tweed suit, and a straw long in advance of your cotton or linen dress, or even ahead of your crepe ensemble.
The Hunter College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa has elected nineteen students to the society. Their names were announced at the Phi Beta Kappa chapel by Miss Margartha Brohmer, secretary. They are:

THE fate of a radio singer feats in the sensitive fingers of the studio engineer who manipulates the controls, according to Richard Crooks, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, who is now on the air in a series of broadcast recitals. He declares that the man in the glass cage at the edge of the studio can do more tricks with a singer's voice than a magician with a silk hat.

Professor A.A. Berle Jr. of President Roosevelt's "brain trust" said yesterday that the government might have to go considerably further in the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, the NBA and the credit machinery, "particularly in protecting and taking care of the groups who are not able to navigate through the perpetual and violent readjustments of an industrial scheme."

IN its vitality, its drama and splendor, in its achievement in the arts, there is no age to match the Italian Renaissance. Nor can one easily find its equal for complexity. The reader is not to be misled by Mr. Roeder's title, with its seeming simplification, nor does the author intend that he should be.

BELLMORE, L.I., Dec. 9 -- Two soldiers attached to Mitchel Field were arraigned here today before Police Justice George S. Johnson on charges of grand larceny in connection with a series of thefts of typewriters from schools in Nassau County during the last few months.
The repeal of prohibition enriched the State Treasury by $1,200,000 in certain license fees collected in and around New York City alone up to Friday night, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A concerted move to keep liquor taxes at a low rate in the interest of reasonable prices to the consumer was taking form in Congressional circles today, following the recommendation of the President's Interdepartmental Committee on Alcoholic Control for a levy of 52.60 a gallon.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 -- They sing a different tune west of the Mississippi. If the war was won on the cricket fields of England, then this depression is being beaten on the football fields of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Hallett Johnson of South Orange, N.J., an experienced career officer in the foreign service, who has been counselor of the legation at The Hague, has been named counselor of the embassy at Madrid. Hugh Mi Hard of Omaha, who has been second secretary at Madrid, will become second secretary at the embassy in London.
A Columbia quintet that trailed for the greater part of the game staged a stirring rally in the final ten minutes to upset St. Francis, 28 to 27, in the Lion gymnasium last night.

The Creston and Frederick Douglass quintets will meet next Saturday at Stuyvesant High School for the city P.S.A.L. junior high school basketball championship as a result of winning their respective sectional semi-final games in the annual competition yesterday.

ONLY the other evening a Gotham bluestocking was saying: "I thought 'Her Master's Voice' was about the worst play I ever saw, but I loved it." That is the sort of remark that leaves one speechless and that makes going out in the evening a perilous occupation.
Francis X. Shields of New York again heads the ranking of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, announced yesterday by Chairman William M. Fischer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- In this week's encounter of men and theories at the Department of Agriculture the real "winnah and new champion," as Joe Humphreys would say, is Rexford Guy Tugwell, erstwhile Professor of Economics at Columbia University. By a skillful mixture of discernment and tactics he finally manoeuvred the blunt administrator of the AAA, George N. Peek, into a position where the President had to choose between him and Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

Breaking 95 out of 100 targets, T. H. Lawrence took the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the spot for the High Handicap Cup, the trophy went to H.E. Dickerman, with second going to A.L. Cornwell.

SHANGHAI, China, Nov. 24 -- By far the most pessimistic summary of the financial plight of the Nanking Government has appeared here in The Morning Post, a Chinese-language newspaper which is conceded to be General Chiang Kaishek's personal journal.

An enormous audience covered the vast spaces of Madison Square Garden and listened last night to the third festival concert of the Musicians Emergency Fund, conducted by Walter Damrosch, when Wagner's "Rienzi" was revived in condensed concert form.

In a book of consolation and counsel written seven centuries ago the writer gave a bit of advice which is now repeated in many languages but which in plain English reads: "What good thing you can do, do not defer it." And it is counsel that will be needed so long as there are some in need and some who have that which can minister to it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia took undisputed possession of first place in the world's championship pocket billiard tournament today by defeating Bennie Allen of Kansas City, 125 to 50 in eight innings.

BARCELONA, Dec. 9. -- Eight men were killed and at least twenty were wounded in Barcelona and its suburbs in the anarchist uprising which began last night. Two civil guards were killed and four were wounded.
QUERETARO, Mexico, Dec. 9 -- Socialist education for Mexico has been clamorously approved as one of the provisions of the Six-Year Plan of the National Revolutionary party, in session here.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The exchange market today concluded its first

Backed by another court decision, William Hausler, painter, of Hicksville, L.I., moved yesterday to acquire possession of his 7-year-old daughter, who has been brought up by foster parents as a Catholic and now is to become a Lutheran.

It was inevitable, as well as entirely fitting, that the President in his address to the Federal Council'' of Churches should speak of the place which religion holds in the modern world. Differing from many despondent observers of the trend today, Mr. ROOSEVELT holds that the Churches are still " the greatest influence in this "world of ours to overcome the present tendency toward greed."

IN spite of several days of unfavorable weather, retail trade jumped ahead for the week as a whole, with holiday business getting into its stride and liquor sales helping out totals. Merchandise demand was found to centre upon useful gifts and the mainfloor departments were particularly busy.

IF the producers of "The House on 56th Street," a film now at the Hollywood, had tossed some of the melodramatic ideas overboard and concentrated on the interesting thought regarding what might happen in twenty-five years to a Manhattan dwelling -- in the East Fifties -- which had been the home of a family of the Four Hundred, they might have made a far more absorbing offering.

A one-day open-air international horse show is being planned for next October. It will be held in the vicinity of New York City and the principal competitors will be members of the teams of army officers who meet each Autumn in this city to prepare for the events of the National Horse Show and other important exhibitions here and in Canada.

The spirit as well as many of the material requisites of the time-honored county fair were brought to the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the County Fair Ball, one of the largest and most ingeniously conducted parties of the current season.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 7 -- In some States the calling out of the National Guard is a major event, occurring only in times of great emotion. Time was when Oklahoma viewed with alarm the superseding of civil authority by armed men in khaki, but that was before the reign of Alfalfa Bill Murray as Governor.

Increased appropriations for the Naval Reserve were predicted yesterday by Captain John Downes, assistant chief of the Bureau of Navigation in Washington. He addressed a morning meeting of the fifteenth annual convention of the United States Naval Reserve Officers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ATLANTA, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A conviction that the way to solution of many of the world's economic ills lay in a commodity standard of values was expressed here tonight by George Foster Peabody, retired banker.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Party tickets as composites representative of nationalistic groups are familiar features in the politics of cosmopolitan Chicago. The supposed practical necessity for such balancing of candidates for office is generally acknowledged to be a nuisance to the politicians and a detriment to good government.

THIS is another of the slender volumes in which Mr. Simonds every now and then speaks to American readers, ex cathedra, on international affairs. Two of its recent predecessors have been, "Can Europe Keep the Peace?" and "Can America Stay at Home?"

The appeal for New York's Neediest Cases is renewed today in Part 1. Section 10, of THE NEW YORK TIMES by the republication of typical cases among the first hundred, together with a selection from a second hundred whose stories have not previously been told.

LIMA. ALL roads, during the weekend, lead to the market in Huancayo, the new capital of the Department of Junin. (Huancayo is the terminus of the Central Railway of Peru, the loftiest broad-guage railroad in the world, and lies about 200 miles inland.)

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- West Point's horse show team No. 1 captured the military team jumping competition which featured the tenth annual military horse show held tonight by Troop F of the 102d Cavalry in the Roseville Avenue Armory.

PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 7 -- Here in agrarian South Dakota the case of the taxpayer versus the general tax system has Just been tried. The result is a clear indictment of the ad valorem tax in a noteworthy decision handed down by the South Dakota Supreme Court, which has sustained the State's new gross income tax measure and simultaneously interpolated a significant new chapter into the whole book of the nation's problems.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Arthur Krock. in THE NEW York TIMES, gives the Roosevelt administration's interpretation of the result of the special Congressional election in the Third West Virginia District "as a Thanksgiving present to Mr. Roosevelt" and as evidence "that the people of the country want to give him an even larger opportunity to work out his policies of recovery, monetary and otherwise."

The Junior League Players, the amateur theatrical company of members of the New York Junior League, will begin, their season with performances of "Toad of Toad Hill" on Saturday morning and afternoon at the Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street.

LONDON, Nov. 24. ROBERT SHERWOOD'S "Acropolis" was performed for the first time last night at the Lyric Theatre under the direction of Marc Connelly, with Raymond Massey as Cleon, Gladys Cooper as Aspasia and Ian Hunter as Phidias, now engaged in the building of the Parthenon.

A NEW Ford V-8, incorporating improvements and refinements, while retaining the appearance and other characteristics of the previous model, was introduced last week by the Ford Motor Company. It was placed on display in dealers' showrooms throughout the country and was also on view at the Ford Exposition of Progress being held in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

THE two most interesting characters in this-story are Lord Rayle, the more than half-mad master of Bowstring Castle, and his son, Francis, who secretly fears that he has inherited his father's madness. The gloomy old castle itself provides a fitting background for a series of mysterious events, beginning with the discovery of Lord Rayle's body in the vast hall where his collection of medieval armor is housed.

BRUNO WALTER will conclude his present season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this week. This afternoon Ossip Gabrilowitsch will play Mozart's piano concerto in D minor and the Weber "Concertstuck" as part of a Mozart-Weber program.

SIMULTANEOUSLY with the publication of Henry Wysham Lanier's "A.B. Frost: the American Sportsman's Artist," an exhibition of paintings, water-colors and drawings by Frost has opened at the Harlow, McDonald Galleries. Besides the familiar shooting scenes, which served to make this artist's name known to three generations of sportsmen, there are some glowing still-lifes and poetic landscapes.

With low hanging clouds and a drizzling rain that caused the cancellation of passenger schedules out of Newark Airport last week, blind landings were practiced successfully with a new instrument which is expected to go far to increase the safety and regularity of air travel.

SHOULD the school try to help steer the nation toward a better social order, or should it be merely a trailer? The National Education Association has apparently not only adopted the former as its faith but has now added works.

ANY ONE who enjoys cowboy songs and yarns will enjoy this new book of ballads by Powder River Jack H. Lee. They are not, of course, folk ballads. But they are the ballads of a man acquainted with the people and the country be describes, familiar with vernacular expressions, completely understanding the kind of tale a cowboy likes.

PEIPING, Nov. 8 -- Remarkable development has occurred during recent months in the relations between China and Japan. Although the Nanking Government has not yet chosen to risk public displeasure by entering into formal diplomatic negotiations with Japan for the settlement of the Manchurian and related issues, Japanese diplomacy has made important gains through informal dealings with the North China political faction headed by General Huang Fu.

MR. TOWNSEND has written one of those "truth about China" books which excite the resentment of the kind of people who do not want to see publicity given to the kind of statement it contains, and which only convince people who are convinced already.

A SECOND book by Don Antonio de Fierro Blanco, author of "The Journey of the Flame," is announced for publication next Spring by Houghton Mifflin Company under the title of "Rico, Bandit and Dictator."

The Greenwich House Music School will benefit by a performance of "Carmen" Saturday night at the New York Hippodrome in conjunction with a fiesta arranged by members of the board of directors of the school. A program of unusual entertainment will be presented during the three intermissions of the opera.
ROME, Dec. 9 -- The presence in Home of Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, has given rise to a new crop of rumors of Russo Vatican negotiations for a means of contact.

Last week's calls of bonds for payment in December before their dates of maturity were few and consisted mostly of parts of municipal loans. Calls for next year, too, were for small amounts. They included bonds of three companies and parts of several industrial, public utility and municipal issues.

The General Foods Corporation has participated in the widespread movement among large industrial units toward decentralization of control, it was announced yesterday by C.M. Chester, president of the company.

A conclusive victory over Seth Low of Brooklyn enabled the Henry P. O'Neil swimmers to retain their city P.S.A.L. junior high dual meet championship in the George Washington High pool yesterday. The score was 53 to 8.

About twenty carloads of butter have been distributed free to State emergency relief administrations in this area by the local branch of the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation, since its establishment on Nov. 11, it was announced last week.

PARIS. WITH the season in full swing there is almost an avalanche of new film descending upon Paris. For the first time this year the proportion of French pictures is exceeding that of foreign films, and it is possible now to get a good idea of what the French industry as a whole has been producing.

ALL students who are willing can learn although at different rates of speed, and the problem of dealing with the poo. student is largely one of teaching hin good methods of study. Such are the conclusions reached by the Bureau of Personnel Research of the University of Buffalo after several years of intensive work with substandard freshmen.

For the first time in three years the normal seasonal movement of money in circulation, uninfluenced by hoarding, appears to be taking effect. One result of the movement as revealed last week, was a gradual hardening of money-marks rates, including those for bankers bills, call money and Stock Exchange time loans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- St. Mary's giant Gaels overpowered Southern Methodist's Mustangs by 18 to 6 today in a thrill-filled intersectional gridiron skirmish that completed the 1933 schedule for the two teams.

While the date for the twentieth session of the American Game Conference to be held in this city is more than a month away, delegates already are preparing to attend, as it is felt that the meeting of game officials, sportsmen, conservationists and scientists will be one of the most important held in recent years.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 9 -- The University of Michigan football team, champions of the Big Ten for the fourth successive year, tonight was announced as the winner of the Knute K. Rockne national intercollegiate football trophy.

Every priest of the Archdiocese of New York has received an invitation to the consecration to the episcopate of the Right Rev. Bernard John Kevenhoerster, Prefect Apostolic of the Bahama Islands, which will take place in St. Patrick's Cathedral Dec. 21 at 10 A.M.

RECENT discoveries in the chsmistry of nutrition empnasize strongly the importance of a wise choice of food. With proper food supplies the deficiency diseases are prevented. And, as will be explained below, this rewer knowledge of nutrition has also a more positivie or constructive aspect by virtue of which the consumer's choice and use of food become an important factor in the attainment of better-than-average health, with resulting postponement of old age.

SENSATIONAL climaxes in the evolution of radio have been numerous but none compares in magnitude with the triumphant scene staged by a young-Italian standing on the edge of the North American Continent on Dec. 12, 1901-thirty-two years ago this week.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- Closing fast after racing among the laggards in the early part, John J. Robinson's Eva B. won by two lengths from Frank Seremba's Zekiel in the featured Baton Rouge Handicap at Jefferson Park today. She returned $8.20 for $2.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9. -- Aroused by the continued failure of Soviet industry to improve the quality of its products, particularly in those branches producing the means for "the defense of the country," the Soviet Central Executive Committee decreed today criminal prosecution for officials and employes found guilty of turning out inferior materials.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Three hundred Yale alumni gathered tonight for the Yale barn party, staged each year at the end of the football campaign.

Holiday trade got into full swing last week in all sections of the country, and early results indicated that buying was substantial in volume. The ending of prohibition brought a large turnover in alcoholic beverages, but, in contrast with the low price policy adopted by merchants in other lines, price scales were regarded as abnormally high due to the large "novelty" demand anticipated upon the return of legal liquor.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 8. -- This week's strife in Parliament, culminating in the challenging of Minister of the Interior Franz Keresztes-Fischer to a duel by Deputy Dinich of the Small Landholders' party, is only one of several signs that the Hungarian political pot is again simmering.

Officials of the New York State American Legion, meeting yesterday at the Kings County American Legion headquarters, 160 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, denied recent reports that the Legion, jointly with the Crusaders and the American Federation of Labor, had protested President Roosevelt's monetary policies.

BERLIN, Nov. 26, 1933. ONE of the most poignant but uplifting by-products of Nazi anti-Semitism is the "Kulturbund deutscher Juden," the "Cultural League of German Jews." This organization, though, a development of only the past few months, can already claim a membership of between thirty and forty thousand.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8. -- Soviet trains are running from two to twenty-five hours late and transport again has became an all-union problem, demanding concentration of efforts to keep the roads open and avoid complete jamming.
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 -- Spectacular goal tending by Andy Aitken head enabled the New York Rangers, world's hockey champions, to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 8,000 tonight.

A meeting of about 2,000 union painters to protest the action of their district council in levying a daily work tax of 50 cents ended abruptly yesterday when the chairman decided it would be impossible to maintain order. The meeting, at the Central Opera House, 207 East Sixty-seventh Street, was heckled throughout by a group of about 100 painters supporting the policies of the council leaders.

Playing one of the best games of his career, Leonard S. Green, City Athletic Club squash tennis star, produced an upset in the annual Princeton Club invitation tournament yesterday by denting FranK R. Hanson of the Columbia Club. The scores were 15 -- 6, 9 -- 15, 15 -- 10.

THE eginning and ending of the world -- Broadway in 1940! Within seven years, I dare say, neither you nor I will know the street to which I used to send my regards. The gyps, the pips and the snips will have vanished as completely as the synthetic fronts, the synthetic drama and the synthetic shell games that made a mining camp out of the most beloved thoroughfare I ever knew.

Gifts of $25,000 by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and $12,000 by the News Syndicate Company, Inc., to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee fund of $4,000,000 for the support of welfare agencies in relieving families in distress this Winter were announced yesterday by the committee, of which James G. Blaine is chairman.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- With Ken Willis, diminutive sophomore wing, scoring three times, the Princeton hockey team opened its season in Baker Rink today with an impressive 8-3 victory over M.I.T.
Tucson, Arizona, will be the general training headquarters for the Columbia football squad on its trip to Pasadena, Calif., where it will oppose Stanford in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 -- High winds played havoc today with the low-scoring hopes of many golf stars as two Middle Westerners came from behind to take the lead at the half-way mark in the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open tournament.

The Florence Crittenton League, Inc., will benefit from a special matinee performance of "Manon" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Jan. 11 This organization, which works in connection with the courts, for many years has maintained a shelter for young women at 427 West Twenty-first Street, where first offenders awaiting trial or sentence, girl witnesses and wandering or runaway girls are cared for temporarily, without regard to race or creed.

To the Drama Editor: The theatre, like every other form of human expression in the arts, has to keep trying and trying-always apparently to lift itself by its bootstraps. It can be done. There is an old lesson to be learned over and over.

Michael Laby, an specter at the polls in November, 1932, who has been a fugitive since being indicted almost a year ago for intimidating voters in the Seventeenth Assembly District and failing to make a proper count of ballots, was trapped yesterday.
A sparkling performance by Lee Rosenfeld of Thomas Jefferson High featured yesterday's competition for the senior high school dual meet swimming championship of the Public Schools Athletic League.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 9. -- President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay has begun direct personal conversations with the chiefs of the Bolivian and Paraguayan delegations to the Pan-American conference in an effort to establish immediate peace in the Chaco.

The value of the government reforestation camps as agencies for character building was emphasized yesterday by Dr. John L. Elliott, service leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, at the annual meeting of the American Ethical Union, held at 2 West Sixtyfourth Street.

THE lapse of time since this book was written has been less than a year, yet so much alcohol has flowed under the bridge during that period that many of Mr. Woon's pages have a distinctly historical flavor. This fact he himself acknowledges in a last-minute chapter of "Addenda and Errata" in which he points out that repeal alters "the entire entertainment map of the United States."

Developments yesterday in football's post-season activities made it appear possible that a new season will find only Harvard and Army adhering to the old custom of graduate coaching which has been in force at the majority of large Eastern colleges during most of the past.

The quinquennial report of the Bureau of Census on the electrical industries for 1932, completed recently, shows that municipal electric light plants get more for their power than privately owned plants, the average price received for each unit by the former being 3.1 cents compared with 2.7 cents received a kilowatt-hour by the private electric companies.

MORE often than not, when one turns to a collection of critical essays, one does not find the illumination of a consistent underlying philosophy; one discovers, ordinarily, that the author expresses convictions or prejudices on a variety of topics, but does not look at his subject-matter from the perspective of any deeprooted or significant system of thought.

Two men who described themselves as Edward Clare, 20 years old, of 26 Ludlow Street, and Savio Albano, 21, of 64 Linden Street, Wyandanch, L.I., were locked up in the Fifth Street police station yesterday charged with assault and robbery, following a hold-up at 169 Avenue in which one man was wounded.

Two hockey games to be played at Madison Square Garden in the near future are being sponsored by two philanthropic organizations as a means of raising funds to support their work. The first, on the night of Dec. 30, will bring together the teams of Princeton and McGill Universities.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Edward Potterton, minister for more than thirty years of the Universalist Church of Our Father, 415 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, died suddenly on Friday night of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Due to its crops of strawberries, valued at $2,805,611, Tangipahoa Parish, La., led the entire country in the value of small fruits harvested in the United States, according to the list of fifty leading counties compiled in the census of 1930 and announced by the Department of Commerce here today.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- The downward trend which set in on the Boerse yesterday continued today. The losses ranged up to 5 points. Selling was attributed to raising of funds for tax payments due on Monday. The entire list was weak. Bonds likewise were soft, losing up to 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States today informed its members that a "growing confidence, inspired by favorable signs of business recovery, characterizes the official attitude in Washington."

ON that sufficiently well publicized day of last week which will take its place in American history as Repeal Tuesday, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. stood by a window above the Radio City Music Hall and stared down Fiftieth Street toward Broadway.

Because today is recognized as annual "Universal Bible Sunday" virtually every pastor of a Protestant Church will preach a sermon setting fourth the responsibility for supporting the American Bible Society and the New York Bible Society, which today observes its 124th birthday.

IN the late Spring the American Foundation announced the appointment of a committee on Russian-American relations, with Curtis Bok as chairman. Its task was to get the relevant facts about that relationship, with particular reference to the issue of recognition.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, in sympathy with other markets, were more steady than on Friday, prices ending 8 to 10 points higher on the day.

Shippers in all parts of the country went on record last week as opposed to the extension of Federal regulation of the domestic waterways and control of water transportation lines by the railroads. The opposition was expressed in a statement by the National Industrial Traffic League to Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of railroad transportation.

The rise in the prices of domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange last week was the largest of any week sice April 29, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES averages. The average gain of forty issues was 2.13 points, the rails leading with 2.66, with public utilities up 1.71 and industrials up 1.48.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8. ONCE again that cradle of dramatic art, the Pasadena Community Playhouse, will have the distinction of presenting for the first time on an American stage a notable foreign work.

Persons interested in the work of the Turtle Bay Music School have taken over the performance of "The Lake," on the night of Dec. 28 at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the school. Several young women of society headed by Miss Nancy Low are active in the sale of boxes and seats for the benefit, many of which have already been purchased.
MADRID, Dec. 9. -- The fourth attempt of the minute but active Iberian Anarchist Confederation to overthrow the Spanish republic was crushed throughout the nation today.

ACHMED ABDULLAH is one of those figures about whom legend and myth would long ago have begun to cluster and build were this not a prosaic age. Born of a Russian father and an Afghan mother (incidentally, she poisoned her second husband because she didn't care much for him), Achmed Abdullah was not likely to grow up dull-witted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Only minor changes in the volume of industrial production occurred in the week, ended on Dec. 2, according to the weekly survey of business made public today by the Department of Commerce.

RECEIPT is acknowledged of a flock of letters on the selection of Columbia to represent the East in the Rose Bowl. They vary in tone between attempting to prove that (a) Columbia is the most logical selection, since Princeton declared itself out and (b) Columbia is the most illogical selection since, roses first grew in California.

Debutantes of this season and last, as well as several girls who will be introduced to society next year, comprise a large junior committee assisting with plans for the Interschool and College Dance to be held on the night of Dec. 30 in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Max D. Steuer applied to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday for permission to sue to strip George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, of control of fourteen mortgage guaranty corporations, now in rehabilitation and which have many millions of dollars of mortgage issues in default.

The local NRA Compliance Board will make an intensive drive to eliminate "chiselers" in the seventeen days remaining before it relinquishes its functions to another agency, it was announced by Grover A. Whalen, NRA administrator for this city.

TELAVIV, Palestine, Dec. 9 -- Sixteen British and Jewish policemen and three civilians were injured in a demonstration here today when a revisionist mass meeting attempted a demonstration against the Palestine Government's immigration policy and so-called "tourist hunting."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Forty-seven civilian conservation corps camps in New York State have been approved for the 1933-34 Winter period by Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work.

INTO this volume of 632 pages Mr. Nevins has put that part of the material used by him in writing the "Life of Grover Cleveland" which consists of letters. Many of them have been published or epitomized before. This is especially true of what Mr. Cleveland wrote about public and political questions.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 -- The Carolinas voted against repeal a month ago, and today their thousands of moonshiners are functioning more freely than ever before. North Carolina, long regarded by Federal prohibition officials as the premier, moonshining State of the Union, is virtually without enforcement of any kind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Reports of improved conditions today caused Speaker Rainey to predict the coming session of Congress would be comparatively short and that harmony would prevail in the huge Democratic Congressional majority.

A disturbance in the city penitentiary on Welfare Island, in which protesting prisoners had barricaded themselves and others in a dormitory for forty-eight hours, obtaining food from a kitchen attached to the dormitory, was revealed yesterday. The situation with its menace of riot yielded to the pleas on Thursday night of Joseph F. Fishman, Deputy Commissioner of Correction, it became known.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- One hundred and forty-seven Westchester County residents are prepared to purchase $700 "fool-proof" airplanes, should planes of this price and type be placed on the market, the Westchester Air Pilots' Association, which recently sent out a questionnaire in connection with the development of a county airport, revealed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Many persons, who could not be described as animated by dry prejudices, believe that in Illinois and Wisconsin there must be radical revision of proposals for liquor regulation, if the President's earnest injunction against return of the saloon is to be respected.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 9 -- The Nanking Government has an army of 50,000 men on its hands in the far North and does not know what to do with it. In fact, the mere continued existence of this army is a constant threat of a new civil war, and is the cause of a daily and continuing defiance of the orders of the central government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- As a new step to provide employment for railroad workers, among the hardest hit by the depression, and to add new rolling stock, Secretary Ickes announced today a loan of $36,307,500 by the Public Works Administration to four railroads with which to construct 12,755 freight cars, 167 passenger coaches and 30 locomotives.

VIENNA, Dec. 9 -- Much space is devoted in the Vienna press today to the wave of executions of political opponents of the Nazis in Germany who have been condemned on charges of murder arising from the period of armed conflict between the Nazis and the Communists before the Hitlerites came into power.

The Poly Prep basketball team, which started practice during the past week, expects to make a strong bid to retain its Eastern Private Schools Basketball League championship, won last season by the Blue and Gray quintet during the league's first year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Farmers in 359 of the 1,460 counties participating in the wheat acreage reduction program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration have received 77,021 checks totaling $4,388,434 to date.

Active buying of domestic corporation issues sent prices higher yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Gains of a point or more were numerous in a substantial section of the corporation list, and comparatively few issues received setbacks of consequence.

The Assembly district leaders of the Fusion campaign group in Brooklyn met yesterday at the Hotel Pierrepont and decided to form, an independent and autonomous organization to be known as the Kings County Fusion Organization, not a part of the City Fusion party, but willing to cooperate with it.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement, as of Dec. 7, shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

IT was learned at Flint, Mich., recently that the 1934 Buicks will be introduced to the public about the middle of this month, and that they will be the first cars to show the independent front wheel suspension, termed "knee-action," which General Motors has announced for all the automotive members of its family.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Cheltenham scored an upset in the second round of the competition for the association football cup today by defeating Carlisle United of the third division of the English League, 2 to 1, at Carlisle.
