ACQUISITION of broadcast studios that accommodate a large visible audience seems to be encouraging performers to act more for the studio assemblage than for the unseen audience. For example, Eddie Cantor in tights bedecked with leaves and later in a nightshirt and derby won the laughter of the crowd; but the invisible gathering was not "in on the joke."
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 7 -- The juice of the grape has emerged from a fourteen-year eclipse and moved into the California king row, there to battle the orange for supremacy.

"A wide number of wage increases and an insignificant number of decreases" for the month ending Sept. 15 were reported yesterday by the Labor Bureau, Inc., in the December issue of its monthly review, Facts for Workers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Governor Pinchot is elated, and with good reason, over the activities of his special legislative session on the liquor question. Facing a General Assembly whose hostility to him had become traditional, he saw enacted into law all of the fundamental features of his liquor-control program.

More than 500 persons, including educators, philanthropists and financiers, paid final tribute to Frank Lusk Babbott, patron of the arts, at funeral services yesterday in the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- New York's and the nation's "New Deal" met today when Mayor-elect LaGuardia and President Roosevelt conferred for half an hour. The meeting, however, failed to produce any information as to the allotment of Public Works funds for the New York Eighth Avenue suhway or other projects.

An investigation to determine whether criminal acts were committed in transactions engaged in by the Lehrenkrauss companies in Brooklyn will begin tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn after a conference with Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

PRIZES for the contest of American poets for an international hymn to the first sixteen bars of the "Ode to Joy" of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony will be awarded tomorrow by the League of Nations Association, Inc., which sponsored the contest.

Open house will be held Tuesday afternoon and night at Christadora House, 147 Avenue B. The various enterprises of the settlement, including handicraft, musical activities, recreational work, sessions of boys and girls clubs, health and dental clinics in operation, will be exhibited to the guests.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9 -- A dinner in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton of New York and East Hampton, L.I., who are at Brazilian Court, was given by Mrs. Alfred D. Bell tonight at La Chaumiere. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kro- ger, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West and Mr. and Mrs. George C. White.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 9. -- Louisiana State University today smashed through the University of Tennessee eleven for a 7-0 victory to end its second season of no defeats in the Southeastern Conference and bolster its claim to the 1933 conference title.

WHEAT growers were assembled In small groups in 3,000 country school houses, churches and town halls. Everywhere the scene, were identical -- of farmer audience being urged by government representatives to sign up for acreage reduction.

GET ready for the new day that is dawning!" is the slogan that has inspired this useful and practical book. Mrs. Reis in her foreword makes a closely and convincingly reasoned presentation of the very general need of both adults and children of advice and counsel and information on how to use to best advantage the increasing leisure the changing times are throwing into their laps.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Playing before 3,500, one of the smallest Boston crowds in years, the Boston Bruins tonight turned back the New York Americans by a 4 -- 2 margin.

Postmaster General Adam Hamilton of New Zealand bade farewell last night to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and the members of the Second Byrd Antarctic Expedition in an international radio broadcast from Wellington, N.Z., heard in this country over a nation-wide Columbia network.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Deets Pickett, research secretary of the Board of Temperance of the Methodist Episcopal Church, said in a statement tonight that the promulgation of a Federal liquor code was "sufficient guarantee that the whisky situation will not get out of hand until it can be dealt with by legislation."

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- It is with great uncertainty and some uneasiness that Paris is awaiting the outcome of the intense diplomatic conversations going on in London, and also undoubtedly between London, Berlin and Rome. For with regard both to Germany and to the future tof the League, it is on London's decision that everything depends.

IT is not because he takes a diabolic pleasure in catastrophes that Dr. T.A. Jaggar is rubbing his hands in glee at the spectacle of three lava fountains spouting from Mauna Loa in Hawaii and of colossal cauliflowers of blue-brown smoke vanishing in a milky cirrus that hangs for hours and even days, above the normal clouds.
LONDON. BRIAND, on one of his numerous visits to London, is said to have ordered beer and kippers for breakfast under the surprising impression that he was conforming to the custom of the country.

EVERY automobile accident in New York City in which some one is killed or seriously injured brings a flash into Police Headquarters, and within a few minutes special investigators motor detectives, they have been called -- appear on the scene.

MILAN, Dec. 1. -- The recent speech of Benito Mussolini to the Assembly of the National Council of Corporations has aroused interest abroad chiefly for its references to the international situation Leagne of Nations and disarms merit.

ONE always approaches a group showing of contemporary American sculpture in a mood of hopeful suspense. Miracles do sometimes happen; but sculpture has ever been a slowmoving art, and it is an act of precautionary wisdom not to expect too much.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7 -- Dr. Carlos C. Alden, dean of the University of Buffalo Law School, thinks that a long time will elapse before the damage done by prohibition is repaired. The task of restoring the same degree of respect for law as existed before the Eighteenth Amendment appears to the dean to be formidable.

THAT part of the American public which does not read agricultural bulletins has recently learned with some surprise that a good many things besides eggs have been hatched on that upper section of the Cornell University campus which is devoted to agriculture and kindred subjects.

An appeal for public support of the Crusade for Children, a joint effort by seven child welfare organizations to raise $400,000 to care for juvenile victims of the depression, was made yesterday over the radio by A.E. Thomas, playwright.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Princeton University, according to its president, Harold Willis Dodds, is not a "rich man's college." Forty per cent of its students are working their way through, he said.

Due to higher farm prices, cropreduction allowances and NRA benefits, the agricultural and industrial areas of the country bid fair to make the best comparative showing in Christmas retail trade this year, according to analyses made during the week in retail circles here.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 9. -- Undeterred by the ill fate of its economic program, the Mexican delegation today subroitte'd the most comprehensive peace code yet offered to the Pan. American Conference. The plan was ordered printed for consideration Monday by a subcommittee of the committee on organization of peace.

The Brooklyn College basketball team handed the Manhattan College quintet its second straight defeat in winning by 26 to 17 in a hotly contested game at the Jasper gymnasium before 1,000 spectators last night.

FRANCIS HENRY TAYLOR, director of the Worcester Art Museum, detects "a new and vital feeling abroad in American painting of today -- a 'deflation,' if you will, of the fatuousness of imported post-war culture." He perceives in the best of our contemporary production "a definite spiritual and intellectual growth."
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Princeton University, according to its president, Harold Willis Dodds, is not a "rich man's college." Forty per cent of its students are working their way through, he said.

ED WYNN, who still would have something to do with a fire, is considering various trifling matters theatric. He has his thoughts, his nebulous plans, his possibilities. To state them in chronological order: Perhaps on Jan. 8, he will lurch out into the South with a touring company of "The Laugh Parade" (New York version was back in 1931) and tempt the one-two-three nighters.

THE fragile and misty Lillian Gish, whose alliance with the cinema goes all the way back to "The Birth of a Nation" and "Orphans of the Storm," will reach the Paramount's screen on Friday as the star of "His Double Life."

HOLLYWOOD. THE film centre has reached the age when It has anniversaries. This week Hal Roach rounded out his twenty years as a producer and celebrated the event with fitting splendor. Cecil B. De Mille, who complained that Mr. Roach's asking price of $5 a day for horse, costume and services was too much for any cowboy when he gave him a job in 1913, was there.

IN Mexico City the students and professors of the oldest university in North America, the National University of Mexico, have achieved self-rule along strictly democratic lines. They now elect their own university council and, most important of all, the rector, or president, of the institution.

Due to higher farm prices, cropreduction allowances and NRA benefits, the agricultural and industrial areas of the country bid fair to make the best comparative showing in Christmas retail trade this year, according to analyses made during the week in retail circles here.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 9. -- Undeterred by the ill fate of its economic program, the Mexican delegation today subroitte'd the most comprehensive peace code yet offered to the Pan. American Conference. The plan was ordered printed for consideration Monday by a subcommittee of the committee on organization of peace.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- One of the reasons for the calm with which France has faced the recent events in Europe is that she feels that the main entrance is well barred. A solid system of fortifications that is near completion guards the Rhine and the main corridor of invasion from the north and east across Lorraine.

Tributes were paid to Dr. William R. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, at a testimonial luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt to eommemorate the fifteenth anniversary of the high school and Dr. Hayward's service there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The United States has reminded European debt defaulting nations, including France and other countries which have adopted her policy, that $107,000,000 is due as their share of Dec. 15 payments.

Testimony heard by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee last week stirred Wall Street by reason of the light that it threw on the fortunes of the Seaboard Air Line Railway when that company was encountering the onset of the depression.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Deep-seated differences within their party organization in this State which, with a Gubernatorial, Senatorial, Congressional and legislative election to be held next year, should give the Republicans pause, were revealed by yesterday's conference here between Chairman W. Kingsland Macy and county chairmen.

AFEW days ago a letter was delivered at the main office of the Stage Relief Fund. It contained a dime and a penny. It was written, on scalloped, pale-blue paper of miniature size, and was obviously in a child's handwriting.

The Brooklyn College basketball team handed the Manhattan College quintet its second straight defeat in winning by 26 to 17 in a hotly contested game at the Jasper gymnasium before 1,000 spectators last night.

FRANCIS HENRY TAYLOR, director of the Worcester Art Museum, detects "a new and vital feeling abroad in American painting of today -- a 'deflation,' if you will, of the fatuousness of imported post-war culture." He perceives in the best of our contemporary production "a definite spiritual and intellectual growth."

The board of administrators of the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms issued yesterday a pamphlet of interpretations of the code, made with the advice of the board's counsel and with the approval of the National Recovery Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- George N. Peek, it is understood, has decided to accept President Roosevelt's offer that he relinquish his post as farm administrator to head a new State Department division. This would be devoted to creating new outlets for American farm products abroad on the basis of enlarged import quotas for foreign wines and liquors.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Artificial pneumothorax has been used successfully at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in the treatment of acute lobar pneumonia.

A distinguished audience is expected at the Paul Whiteman concert on Friday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House, according to the large list of members of society who already have subscribed to it. The net proceeds from the event will be given to the Church Mission of Help, a social casework agency conducted under the auspices of the Episcopal Church for the relief of unfortunate girls.

Columbia and New York University, meeting yesterday in the first round of the newly organized New York City Intercollegiate Chess League at the rooms of the latter in the South Building on Washington Square, failed to reach a decision, owing to the adjournment of the game at the first table.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 9. -- The first week of the seventh Pan-American Conference terminated today without the appearance of any definite move toward the customary grouping of South and Central American republics against the United States. This has been emphasized by the surprising manner in which Argentina and the United States are working together, in sharp contrast to Argentina's antagonistic attitude toward the United States at previous Pan-American conferences, especially at Havana in 1928.
The upland game bird season in New Jersey will come to an end on Friday, but sportsmen will have only a short interlude in their activities, since the deer-hunting season will begin on Sunday.

Miss Susan Robertson of the Women's Swimming Association, the national long-distance champion, was vanquished by her team-mate, Miss Catherine Goetz, in the feature 300-yard handicap test at the meet in their home pool yesterday. A large gallery attended.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Recovery of at least some of the German colonies lost under the Treaty of Versailles at the end of the war is being pursued with increasing energy by the Nazi regime, under whose auspices a large mass meeting was held today for various public bodies.

Opponents of lynch law should not stop with mere protests, but should see to it that constructive steps are taken to ensure speed in trials and certain punishment for crimes, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday morning in his sermon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The Metchnikoff Institute of Moscow announced today it had succeeded in cultivating the typhus germ after thirty-five years of experiments, and expected it to result in elimination of the typhus menace in Russia and other eastern countries.

It is difficult to understand the reluctance of the Federal authorities to loan the City of New York the $25,000,000 it needs to complete the Eighth Avenue subway. No one could blame Secretary ICKES for wanting to be assured that the project is a desirable one, and that the city has ample security to offer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Under the impetus of increasing public works activity, construction contract awards in November reached their highest figure since October, 1931, the Public Works Administration said today.

Creditors of the bankrupt Paramount Publix Corporation received notification yesterday that a special meeting of the creditors would be held on Dec. 18 at 2 P.M. in the office of Henry K. Davis, Federal referee in bankruptcy, 140 Nassau Street, to consider applications for allowances made by receivers and attorneys in the equity proceedings which began on Jan. 3 and preceded the voluntary petition in bankruptcy of March 14.

Dr. William J. O'Shea, in his forthcoming and final annual report as Superintendent of Schools, will criticize severely those who seek large "slashes" in school appropriations, it was made known yesterday by release of a section of the document.

Mr. ARTHUR BALFOUR, who retained his philosophic view of public life to the end of his long career, once said that, while he was more or less happy when praised, and not very uncomfortable when he was abused, he felt most uneasy when he was "being explained." This last is an annoyance which President ROOSEVELT must occasionally feel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- With reports before them of a business Upturn In various sections of the country, administration leaders believe the likelihood of an outbreak of hostility in Congress to the President's recovery program has decreased.

Asserting that under the bankers' code there had been set up "the machinery to bring about the desired condition of cooperative sound banking on a nation-wide scale," Ronald Ransom of Atlanta, Ga., chairman of the banking code committee which represents the American Bankers Association, said here yesterday that with the progress made thus far the banking situation was being rapidly strengthened.

To the Editor of The New Torts Times: There are only two methods of getting the dollar volume of business into balance with debts: deflation and inflation. We are now trying the latter method at the command of the American people.

Escaping four bullets when a bandit suspect who had surrendered his revolver drew a second weapon and fire pointblank at him, Patrolman John Sheehy of Traffic I chased down the suspect in Pacific Street, Brooklyn, last night and dropped him with two bullets in the knee from the surrendered weapon.

Morris Fleischer of the Greek-American-Hermes A.C. annexed he first metropolitan A.A.U. championship 25,000-meter walk yesterday. The event was sponsored by the German-American A.C. and he course took the field of thirty-three around Central Park two and a half times.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- Tom MeCabe, noted collegiate football official and for fifteen years an outstanding authority on New England schoolboy sports while scholastic editor of The Boston Herald, today was named athletic director at Holy Cross by the Rev. Francis J. Dolan, S.J., president of the Worcester educational institution.
ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The government's economy program as it affects veterans was criticized here today by Smedley D. Butler, retired Major General of the marines.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Dec. 10. -- Arthur Williams gave a luncheon today at Brook Corners, his country home here, which he is keeping open until the holidays. Mrs. John North Wyllys was hostess for Mr. Williams. Luncheon was served by a blazing log fire.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 10. -- For the first time this Winter the polar bear burgee of the Frostbite Yacht Club waved today in an appropriate setting. It was at the sailing dinghy regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, where defiance of the cold weather under canvas originated.

BELGRADE, Dec. 10. -- For the first time in more than twenty years the national anthem of Bulgaria was heard and her national colors were flown today in the capital of Yugoslavia to welcome King Boris and Queen Giovanna of Bulgaria on their arrival for a four-day visit to King Alexander and Queen Marie of Yugoslavia.
MADRID, Dec. 10. -- Anarchists renewed their revolt in numerous cities and villages throughout Spain today, but met such strong opposition that the government is confident they have been crushed.

The Rev. Jonas I. Corrigan of Boston College, preaching yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at Eighty-fourth Street, branded "modern marriage a travesty, a caricature, a mockery of the true ideal."
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The fourth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship for women will begin on the Haddon Hall Tower courts tomorrow and continue Tuesday and Wednesday.

A check for $83,000, representing the amount raised so far by the clothing, woolens and allied trades for the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, was presented last night by Charles D. Jaffee, president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange and chairman of the publicity committee of the Clothing Code Authority.

Reduction of the 1934 city budget by at least $50,000,000 was advocated yesterday by the Mechants Association, which said that at least that amount could be saved by elimination of useless city jobs and by placing the city subway system on a self-sustaining basis.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 10. -- Condemning as a "bold attempt to secede from the body politic of Georgia" the City Council's action to license liquor here in the face of the State dry laws, a mass meeting of Augusta citizens urged today that the move be reconsidered.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 11. -- Japan's proposals for naval limitation, presented to Geneva recently, will be abandoned at the 1935 naval conference and replaced by a demand for parity, the newspaper Asahi reports.

A nation-wide investigation of the work of all government employes. Federal, State and local, to be carried out with the approval of President Roosevelt and financed by the Spelman Fund, one of the Rockefeller endowments, was announced yesterday by the Social Science Research Council.

Breaking 95 out or 100 targets, S. B. Hasten captured the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The score was excellent, as cold weather and a high wind made shooting conditions difficult. The high handicap prize went to H.K. Curtis, with A. Wendroth-Sielcken taking the second cup.

A dinner dance in behalf of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be held next Saturday night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Later in the evening an entertainment will be presented by stars of the stage and radio.
Gifts, large and small, from 114 men, women and children, added $3,580 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and brought the total amount contributed thus far this year to $57,282.98.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia, in a letter to President George J. Ryan of the Board of Education, made public yesterday, said that he would be glad to see Dr. Ryan and other members of the board at City Hall on Jan. 1 to discuss the appointment of a Superintendent of Schools to succeed William J. O'Shea.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Andrew Ponzi, veteran Philadelphian, improved his hold on the leadership in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight by defeating William Mosconi, another Philadelphian, 125 to 17, in eighteen innings for his fourth straight victory.

Registration of white-collar workers seeking jobs under the Civil Works Administration will begin on Wednesday at the headquarters of the administration in the New York Port Authority Building, Sixteenth Street and Eighth Avenue.
DEL MONTE, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The red, white and blue ribbon of the National Association for Ad vancement of the Fine Art of Drinking has been won by Samue J. Blythe with a cocktail recipe.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP). -- New York State is faced with "unavoidable" increases in its 1934 budget which will require additional appropriation of about $43,000,000, it was revealed tonight as Governor Lehman's budget advisory committee started an investigation into the departmental requests preparatory to submission of its report to the Executive.

Work for 14,000 men, of whom about 4,000 will be professional engineers, will be provided by the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, it was revealed yesterday. About 500 of the engineers will be hired in New York City.

With a substantial increase in retail sales last week, the volume of orders coming into the local wholesale markets picked up sharply Main floor gift merchandise was principally in demand. Coat sales were surprisingly good for this time of the year.

Steel operations gained fractionally last week to just above 29 per sent of capacity, but are scheduled to ease moderately this week, according to the magazine Steel. Contrary to the usual trend and barring unforeseen abrupt curtailment before Christmas, the publication expects the December output of steel to approximate that of November.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Assailing what he said was a gold-standard capitalism's grip on industry, Father Charles E. Coughlin charged today that the effort to maintain the gold standard was responsible for the depression beginning in 1929.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Prompt action to prosecute managers and technicians of Soviet industry who allow deterioration of the quality of output was taken today by Ivan Akuloff, Soviet Prosecutor.

VIENNA, Dec. 10. -- It was announced tonight that Prince Bernhard of Saxe-Meiningen, the German aristocrat who was recently sentenced to six weeks' imprisonment for conducting Nazi propaganda in Carinthia, had abused the good faith of the Austrian Government by fleeing from his castle of Pitzelstetten to Italy with his wife, Princess Margot.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Four Cincinnati players became the national open contract team-of-four bridge champions in the early hours of this morning by playing a system whose chief injunction they described as "Don't bid on 'lousy' hands when sitting third or fourth."

CHAPEL, HILL, N.C., Dec. 10 (AP). -- A clean sweep of the varsity football coaching staff was made by the University of North Carolina athletic council today In answer to the complaints of the alumni at the Tar Heels' lack of success on the gridiron.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- The Chicago Bears clinched the right to meet the New York Giants here next Sunday in the play-off game for the National Football League championship by defeating the Green Bay Packers, 7 to 6, today.

A pledge to cooperate with Mayor-elect LaGuardia and to play no politics was made yesterday by William C. Dodge, who was elected District Attorney of New York County on the Tammany ticket. He and Police Commissioner Bolan spoke in a radio symposium on "Fighting Crime" yesterday afternoon over Station WOR.

A large subscription indicates lively interest in the entertainment in behalf of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance which will take place tomorrow night at the St. Regis. The occasion will mark the tenth anniversary of the founding of the organization.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, arrived here today for a four-day visit that may kelp clarify Great Britain's attitude toward Premier Mussolini's proposals for reform of the League.

Frederick J. Werner, former Brooklyn school teacher whose adventures in high finance have brought him six indictments and the accusation of having swindled fifty persons of $150,000, was brought back to Brooklyn last night from Miami, Fla.

Doubtless because he knew that he would be on the high seas before his crime was discovered, Mr. JAMES STEPHENS left with the reporters before sailing on Saturday a reprehensible pun. He declared that in Ireland they think now of three eras-the pagan era, the Christian era and the DE VALERA.

Five men were arrested yesterday following a $23 hold-up in the Knickerbocker Tower Beer Garden at 127 Gold Street, Brooklyn, in which an habitue of the place was shot and killed. A sixth man, who is alleged by the police to have done the shooting, still is being sought.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10.-- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, will be among the guests at a football dinner to be given at the Princeton Inn tomorrow night by Edward D. Duffield of Newark, chairman of the board of Trustees, and Colonel Franklin D'Olier of Morristown, first Commander of the American Legion.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia, who has already announced his intention of pushing transit unification, is being urged by friends and advisers to waste no time in starting the necessary negotiations with the transit companies.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 10. -- Trading in the cotton contract market here last week was exceedingly slack, due in part to the approach of the final government crop estimate of the season, which was issue'd on Friday. Interests on both sides of the account had been thoroughly liquidated in advance.

The necessity for stripping religion of the "wrappings" and discovering the real jewel within was discussed yesterday morning by Dr. Charles W. Gilkey, dean of the chapel of the University of Chicago, at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Administration spokesmen disclaimed today any official sponsorship for the proposal of the President's special Interdepartmental Committee for a $2.60 a gallon spirits tax as the basic rate for a new schedule of liquor levies.

More than $1,000,000 was contributed to the unemployment relief fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee during the official "Family Welfare Week" designated as such by the presidents of the respective boroughs and completed Saturday, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Financial circles here regard the inconclusive termination of the Berlin conference on German foreign bond service as a new success for Dr. Sehacht's traditional policy, which consists in presenting the Reichsbank's reserves and prospect of future export surpluses in their most unfavorable light.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- It is becoming increasingly difficult here to comprehend Washington's policy on fixing the price of gold, and it is held particularly incomprehensible why the price varies for a fewdays running and then remains stationary.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10. -- House guests of Hugh Dillman at Sandy Loam Farm are his mother, Mrs. James B. McGaughey of Columbus, Ohio, who arrived yesterday to remain for the season; his aunts, the Misses Charlotte and Clara McGaughey, also of Columbus, and Mrs. George H. Nicolai of Great Neck, L.I., who will return north in ten days.

Five arrests for arson made in Brooklyn late Saturday night may be an important step in the District Attorney's campaign to end incendiary fires, according to an announcement yesterday by Ralph K. Jacobs, assistant district attorney.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- Sharp employment declines in the clothing and millinery, textile, fur, leather and rubber goods, and food and tobacco groups were mainly responsible for a 3 per cent fall in factory employment from mid-October to mid-November, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced today.

Philip Townsend Case, a retired Major of the United States Marine Corps, was run down by a hit-and-run driver early yesterday at Sixty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, suffering injuries from which he died at 9:25 last night in Flower Hospital.

Jay E. Rice, Republican Assemblyman-elect from the Fourth Assembly District, Queens, announced yesterday that at the first meeting of the Legislature he would introduce a bill to permit drinking at bars and the licensing of restaurants open less than a year before filing application for a license.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Army's 1934 football schedule was announced today by Major L.D. Worsham, graduate manager, of athletics at the Military Academy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System increased to 2,026 thrift and home-financing institutions today following approval of the applications of twenty-nine additional organizations. Chairman John H. Fahey called attention to the fact that the system has been in operation only fourteen months and that on Jan. 1, 1933, there were but 116 members.

Interest amounting to $22,254,627 has been remitted in the last four months to certificate and mortgage holders of the fourteen title an mortgage companies being rehabilitated by the State Insurance Department, according to a report submitted yesterday to Governor Lehman by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- After a survey of Socialist sentiment throughout the country, Norman Thomas and Louis Waldman of the public affairs committee of the Socialist party made public a statement here today opposing inflation as a policy.

The three-day conference of the American Ethical Union closed yesterday with addresses by James Weldon Johnson, Negro writer; Robert D. Kohn, chairman of the housing division of the Public Works Administration, and Professor Nathaniel Schmidt, formerly of Cornell University.

A rally on Saturday of substantial proportions reduced the extent of losses in local commodity markets last week, but most staples never-theless closed lower for the period. The period was marked by a shrinkage in the volume of trading and a tendency to watch general trends in view of the persistently unchanged RFC gold purchase price.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10. -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.7, which compares with 71.4 a week ago, 71.7 two weeks ago, 72.1 three weeks ago and 71.6 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

Arrested Saturday night in a penthouse at 1,070 Park Avenue, on warrants issued by the Litchfield (Conn.) authorities, Walter Halliwell, said to be the heir of Charles E. Halliwell, a vice president of the American Tobacco Company, and Mrs. Helen Cox Williams, a former show girl, were arraigned yesterday in Harlem Court.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers, 13 to 0, in a charity exhibition football game today. A crowd of 3,000 braved the cold and snow to see the first major professional gridiron contest here in many years.

Sales and leases of desirable properties in Manhattan and the Bronx continue to show steady improvement and all indications point to the real estate year closing in a more satisfactory condition than was the case at the close of 1932.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10. -- Just 100 years after Alfred Nobel was born, King Gustaf of Sweden presented the annual Nobel Prizes in Literature, Physics and Medicine today in the presence of eleven Princes, the entire diplomatic corps and a brilliant audience.

The Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York has voted awards to three officers and five seamen of the French liner De Grasse for their "humanity and able seamanship" in effecting the rescue of the captain and three men of a Canadian schooner more than a year ago, it was announced yesterday by Herbert L. Satterlee, president of the association.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- Notwithstanding the French political confusion Paris just now is the diplomatic sentre of Europe -- the hilltop from which one looks upon a changing world, for the world is changing East. Europe itself is politically a different continent from what it was only two short months ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Government buying of hogs weighing 160 to 220 pounds was on in eight markets late last week, and 53.40 to $3.60 a hundredweight was being paid here, with the same range in other markets. It is understood that the government will be in the market for some time, but no statement has been made as to how many hogs are to be bought.

MANAOS, Brazil, Dec. 10. -- Completing a 932-mile flight from Para, part of the way in a tropical rain, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed here at 2:32 P.M. today. They left Para, near the coast, at 6:55 A.M., completing the trip in 7 hours 37 minutes.

WHITCHURCH, Hampshire, England, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Mrs. J.H.V. Rodney, widow of Captain Rodney of London, who was killed in a fire at the country home of Mr. and Mrs. Leander J. McCormick of | Chicago, was informed tonight of her husband's death.

Supporters of Postmaster General James A. Farley and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn will make a definite attempt soon after Jan. 1 to oust John H. McCooey as Democratic leader of Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The annual pre-Christmas walking trip of the James K. Hand Walking Association, the members of which are prominent New York, Westchester and Connecticut business and professional men, will be held next Sunday, it was announced today.
INGEBORG. Comedy in three acts by Curt Goetz. Presented in Italian by the Teatro d'Arte under the direction of Commendatore Giuseppe Sternl. At the Little Theatre.

BARCELONA, Dec. 10. -- The anarchist revolt which began Friday night was resumed tonight when terrorism began simultaneously in Coll Blanch, Torassa and Hospitalet, suburbs of Barcelona, where working men live.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- For the second successive year Philadelphia won the Lockett Trophy today as Beekman Pool, the national squash racquets champion from New York, succumbed to the dazzling drop shots of Neil Sullivan.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James Brown Potter is expected this week on the Statendam and will be at tha St. Regis before going to Richmond, Va., for the holidays.

Sale by the North River Terminal Company, James L. Houghteling, president, of the former holdings of the Lord Realty Company and the Lord Dry Dock Company on the west shore of the Hudson River in North Bergen featured the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end.

A special service in celebration of the forty-fifth anniversary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States was held yesterday morning in the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- The latest monthly government return contains an official prediction that export surpluses are likely to decline, but the majority of the new reports of branch industrial associations, including iron, steel, machinery, textiles and electricals, speak of an increase in exports, or at least of an increase in foreign inquiries about German goods.

A nation-wide appeal by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce; Nathan Straus Jr. and Dr. John H. Pinley marked the eleventh annual observance yesterday of Golden Rule Sunday and the beginning of Golden Rule Week. The speakers, heard over an NEC network, urged that savings made this week be devoted to those who are hungry.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- Increased sales yielding a larger margin of profit have been the NRA program's effect on representative metropolitan business firms, according to a survey reported in the current issue of Boston Business, the organ of the Boston Chamber of Commerce.
Columbia's football team will settle down to a week of intensive practice starting today, in the preparation for the New Year's Day encounter with Stanford in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif.

JAY, Okla., Dec. 10. -- Climaxing a hunt of more than two weeks, Jack Wisdom, young cowhand, was arrested today on a charge of kidnapping Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pritchard of Wichita, and the body of Mrs. Pritchard was found soon afterward in a highway culvert.

If Congress will reduce the present tax on beer, the beverage soon will become available to the public at five cents a glass, Julius Lieban, president of the New York State Brewers Association, announced yesterday.

Plans for its benefit ball were announced by A.J. Weber, president, of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its December meeting in the Hotel Astor yesterday morning. The proceeds of the entertainment, which will be held on Sunday night, Feb. 11, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, will be devoted to relief for needy members of the organization.

HAVANA, Dec. 10. -- The latest effort at conciliation between the Grau San Martin government and its enemies is destined to fail, political observers believe. The plan is said to call for President Grau's resignation in favor of a political leader who would be acceptable to the government and the Opposition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- A production adjustment program designed to limit the 1934 burley tobacco crop to about 250,000,000 pounds and improve prices to growers was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The Official News Bureau reissued today a report published in the Saarbruecken. Zeitung purporting to reveal plans of former German Socialist leaders, now political refugees in adjacent lands, for an armed revolt against the Hitler regime.

Worshipers going to mass in Holy Trinity Church at 9 o'clock yesterday morning saw policemen capture three men who had taken $78 at pistol point from a United Cigar Store at Broadway and 137th Street.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 10. -- Dr. Guerdon N. Messer, 46 years old, director of athletics of Williams College, was found dead, slumped over the gas stove in the kitchen of his home early tonight All six jets were turned on.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 10. -- The United States delegation prepared tonight to bring into the Pan-American Conference its own program for the solution of what a member of the delegation described as the two most important questions facing the parley.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 10. -- Art critics and curators from various parts of the United States and Europe were among the guests today at a preview of the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art and Atkins Museum, which is to open to the public tomorrow.

The Montreal Victorias skated to an 8-to-3 triumph over the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey sextet at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon in a hard-fought contest marked by heavy checking.

Scientists May Disagree Two lively controversies now under way help to remind us of the enormous range of scientific inquiry. One quarrel is between the new school of dental physiology, which says that healthy teeth are entirely a matter of diet, and the old school, which stands for the toothbrush and the mouth wash.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Encouraging business developed last week in this territory, suggesting steady gains in leading lines for the remainder of the year and possibly longer. Opinions expressed by many trade leaders indicated that they were working more in unison.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Actual cash payments of $115,032,938 have been made to farmers during the first seven months' operation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

The new plan for price stabilization proposed by twenty-four large oil companies is an excellent example of the cooperative enterprise which the NRA was intended to encourage. The oil industry has suffered chronically from unstable prices. Overproduction has stimulated "price wars" which have had as their objective the unloading of sorplus stocks.
In a telegram to William Randolph Hearst, L.T. Russell, publisher of The Newark (N.J.) Ledger, said:

HAMPDEN, Me., Dec. 10 (AP). -- At least three marathon dancers were burned to death, and many others were injured in a fire which destroyed the Paradise Dance Hall here tonight at the height of a fierce northeast blizzard.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The international flow of gold has reached such proportions that it would be possible for one country to affect seriously another's monetary standing by acquiring sufficient bullion, according to Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP). -- The might of wicked Queen Jezebel, she who painted her face, as told in the Old Testament, is verified by announcement from Harvard University of a massive granite tower in her capital city, Samaria.

The executive committee for the Beaux Arts Ball, composed of leading architects, painters and sculptors, will be assisted in planning for the event on Jan. 19 by a woman's committee headed by Mrs. Tuckerman Draper.

Chairman MACY'S speech at his Utica conference of county chairmen was an extraordinary philippic against the conduct of the Republicans in the Legislature for the last eight years. Either as dupes or accomplices those statesmen have served that "invisible government" so highly visible to Mr. MACY.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: General Johnson makes a wonderful devil's advocate. Not only is his language picturesque, but it is constructively adding to the English language, and his vigor must delight not only those for whom he is speaking but all lovers of good fighting.

A new biography of Alfred de Vigny, poet, soldier, aristocrat, has just been written by Arnold Whitridge and published by Oxford University Press. The Paris of 100 years ago, with his enthusiastic literary evenings, noisy theatrical first-nights and fiery politics, is the background.

"The bankers and the business men are not to blame for the depression, for they were not taught to see the close connection between their business and the Sermon on the Mount," the Rev. Nellie M. Wagar, director of Christian Education of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, declared yesterday morning in a symposium at the morning service.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The unusual steadiness of the dollar is exciting considerable comment. This week there has been less movement than at any time since President Roosevelt inaugurated his gold-buying policy on Oct. 25. Moreover, since then the dollar-sterling rate has been as high as $5.53 and now it is down to $5.12.
Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the American-Jewish committee, presented the organization's twenty-seventh annual report yesterday to delegates from thirteen States gathered at the Hotel Astor.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10. -- A brilliant sub-par round of 70 today enabled Willie Macfarlane to win the $10,000 Miami Biltmore 72-hole open golf tournament with a total of 288. He captured first money of $2,500.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Ready foR everything from a battle over the question of a uniform ball to the customary discussion of radio broadcasts, representatives of sixteen major league clubs began drifting into Chicago tonight for the annual baseball meetings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Sprague in his opening paragraph today says: "I am in hearty accord with Senator Thomas, Professor Warren, and, indeed, with all the world in desiring an early general rise of prices from the present low level."

UVALDE, Texas, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Fit as a fiddle, for all of his 65 years, Vice President John N. Garner returned today from a weekend hunting trip, bringing in a deer and several quail. He evinced his usual calmness over the fact that a new Congress will convene in less than a month.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and the Bronxville Field Club gained victories in Section 1 of the Westchester Division in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C play yesterday. The former team conquered the Racquet and Swimming Club of Ardsley-on-Hudson, 4 -- 1, while Bronxville won by default over West Point.
PARIS, Monday, Dec. 11. -- The Chautemps Government has gotten its budgetary project through the Chamber of Deputies after a session lasting through yesterday and until dawn this morning.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10. -- Successful transplantation of parts of human organs from one person to another was reported at a joint meeting of the Interurban and Cosmopolitan Medical Clubs at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, The Baltimore Sun says today in a copyrighted article.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- Automobile liability and workmen's compensation insurance led in the volume of business in casualty and miscellaneous insurance lines in 1932, George S. Van Scfaick, superintendent of insurance, will show in his report to the Legislature.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The first all-Nazi Reichstag elected in Germany will be called to order by its president, General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, in the Kroll Opera House Tuesday. Brown will be its predominating color; 659 of its 661 Deputies will appear in brown shirts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Treasury officials devised new methods tonight, for plugging any possible leak by which the daily domestic gold price may have been Teaching financial centres in Europe before its announcement here.

KINGFISHER, Okla., Dec. 10 -- Jack Wisdom, young murder and kidnapping suspect, was rushed to a secret destination late tonight after the finding of the body of Mrs. Harry Pritchard and an unsuccessful search for that of her husband, a Wichita (Kan.) merchant.

H.P. Borer, passenger traffic manager of the Cunard Line, said yesterday that the cancellation of two cruises to the West Indies, announced last week, had been due to the overtonnaging of the service rather than to a change of attitude on the part of passengers resulting from the repeal of the prohibition amendment.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 11. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, assuming a newly belligerent attitude toward the Fukien rebels, said he would not resign, regardless of the pressure brought upon him, until he had successfully concluded his anti-Communist drive.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 10. -- Mrs. Albion Fellows Bacon, well-known writer and worker for better housing conditions and child welfare, died early this morning at her home here after an illness of several weeks of a heart ailment attributed to overwork.
Brookhattan defeated Hispano, 4 to 1, at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday before 1,100 persons in an American Soccer League game.

Eight companies producing 25 per cent of the alcohol in the United States made public yesterday copies of telegrams sent to President Roosevelt and other administration officials protesting the marketing agreement for the distilled-spirits industry approved by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 10. -- Delegates to the Pan American Conference today lolled on the sands of Montevideo's famous beaches or went to the horse races run in their honor at Maronas Hippo-drome. With four committees and twelve subcommittees meeting tomorrow, they face an intensive program of routine work during the next few days.
Intense cold, which sent the mercury here down to 11 degrees at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning, was held responsible for two deaths that occurred in the hours just before daybreak.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Grain and live stock markets are regarded by the trade in general as having been well liquidated, the low point being reached last week. None but the corn and oats farmers can be helped much by higher prices, for most of the wheat, rye and barley has been marketed to a large extent, and corn is the only grain that can bring farmers a great deal of money.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,928,258,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Estimates for ordinary and extraordinary government expenditures in the next fiscal year will be decided upon by President Roosevelt this week in meetings with Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, and departmental heads.

Mozart and Weber are composers for whom Bruno "Walter has not only affection but a positive affinity. He devoted to them yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic-Symphony program at Carnegie Hall and, aided by the self-effacing solo playing of Ossip Gabrilowitsch, gave them memorable interpretations.

In order to bring over the members of the London company appearing in "Nymph Errant," one of the current musical hits there, the engagement will be curtailed, it was said last night by Arch Selwyn under whose auspices the show will be seen here.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- Elvin (Kink) Richards wheeled in from the sideline toward the centre of the gridiron, speared a perfect 20-yard pass from Harry Newman and raced forty yards more for the touchdown that gave the New York Giants a 20-14 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in snow-covered Baker Bowl today.

GENEVA, Dec. 10. -- The inside story of what led to the Fascist Grand Council's demand for radical revision of the League of Nations covenant has been assembled from private information received here from sources that have been considered trustworthy for years.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10. -- Sentiment in the steel trade has improved continuously for a month. Contacts with customers have increased appraisals of prospective steel requirements while there has been a slight increase in actual buying.
Scoring twice in the first chapter and three times in the second, the Ottawa Senators turned back the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 5 to 2.

DUBLIN, Dec. 10. -- An attempt was made this afternoon to ambush an automobile in which William T. Cosgrave, former President of the Free State Executive Council, was riding near Killybegs, County Donegal.

Cardinal Hayes told more than 700 members of the Carroll Club at a reception in his honor yesterday at the clubhouse, 120 Madison Avenue, that he feared for them because of the "almost diabolical Influence" on young women of the present day of books, movies and the stage.

DETROIT, Dec. 10. -- Detroit's flying Red Wings took undisputed leadership of the American Division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 1, in a wild, rough game marked by fighting between players and fans.

If the New English Singers, who grave their first recital of the sea-son yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, should cease to visit our shores at this time of year, many of us would feel that one of the more succulent plums of the Christmas musical season had been withdrawn from the pudding.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec, 10. -- Short Hills defeated Plainfield, 3 -- 2, today in a Class C, New Jersey Division, Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association match. With the score tied at 2-all, Vance Lauderdale wor the match for Short Hills by defeating J.W. Zerga, 17 -- 14, 15 -- 12, 13 -- 15, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 13.

Mrs. Alfred Ettlinger of Cary, Ill., lost a $70,000 pearl necklace yesterday afternoon somewhere between the apartment of her father John Hertz, at 450 East Fifty-second Street, and the reservoir in Central Park. The necklace was insured.

Cardinal Hayes told more than 700 members of the Carroll Club at a reception in his honor yesterday at the clubhouse, 120 Madison Avenue, that he feared for them because of the "almost diabolical Influence" on young women of the present day of books, movies and the stage.

DETROIT, Dec. 10. -- Detroit's flying Red Wings took undisputed leadership of the American Division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 1, in a wild, rough game marked by fighting between players and fans.

If the New English Singers, who grave their first recital of the sea-son yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, should cease to visit our shores at this time of year, many of us would feel that one of the more succulent plums of the Christmas musical season had been withdrawn from the pudding.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec, 10. -- Short Hills defeated Plainfield, 3 -- 2, today in a Class C, New Jersey Division, Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association match. With the score tied at 2-all, Vance Lauderdale wor the match for Short Hills by defeating J.W. Zerga, 17 -- 14, 15 -- 12, 13 -- 15, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 13.

Mrs. Alfred Ettlinger of Cary, Ill., lost a $70,000 pearl necklace yesterday afternoon somewhere between the apartment of her father John Hertz, at 450 East Fifty-second Street, and the reservoir in Central Park. The necklace was insured.

Sophia Delza gave her first New York dance recital in two seasons at the Civic Repertory Theatre last night under the auspices of the Theatre Union. That she has obviously been busy in the interim was evidenced by the presence of nine new compositions on her program, running through a wide range of styles.

Suave, cheerful and completely confident that everything "can be straightened out," Frederick J. Werner, former Brooklyn teacher, freely admitted yesterday to District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn that he had swindled scores of victims out of sums aggregating $200,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- Dr. Kurt Schmitt, Minister of Economics, in a speech before the foreign and domestic press today, presented a bright picture of the German business situation, which in his mind warranted profound confidence in Germany's economic recuperation.
Mayor-elect LaGuardia has filled all but one or two of the cabinet posts that he regards as important, according to reliable information yesterday. There are about a dozen such posts.

Mortality from heart disease is twice that of cancer and three times that of tuberculosis, Frederick H. Ecker, President of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon, of the Irvington House Advisory Board at the City Midday Club, 25 Broad Street.

The application by Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions for the reopening of the voting machines for an inspection of the ballots cast for General Sessions judge at the last election, in which Owen W. Bohan, Tammany candidate, was declared winner over Justice Kernochan, Fusion, by 2,767 votes, was granted in part yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The monetary policies that have been adopted by the Roosevelt administration up to the present time have been directed toward bringing about a rise of prices primarily through such influence as may be exerted by the depreciation of the dollar.

The New York Central Railroad is devising plans to use an RFC loan in meeting the maturity of $48,000,000 of New York Central Hudson River Railroad 4 per cent mortgage bonds on May 1. The plan contemplates the retirement of these securities partly with cash and partly with a new issue in a proportion to be reached after consultation with the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Elwood McGlenn (Mose) Kalbaugh of Bellaire, Ohio, today was elected captain of the 1934 Princeton football team by unanimous vote of the thirty-six members of the squad who played against Tale.

Mrs. William Seward Webb Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., and New York, the daughter of the late Mayor William J. Gaynor, made a profit of $72,000 on a marginal stock account opened for her in 1919 by the late Harry Payne Whitney, it was revealed yesterday in a decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Reed Brown Jr., who recently appeared in "The World Waits," has been engaged for "Jezebel," which will begin a preliminary engagement in New Haven on Thursday night. Mr. Brown will take over the role formerly assigned to Robert Wallsten.

The Dime Savings Bank, holder of a mortgage on the old home of the Brooklyn Lodge of Elks at 150 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, expects to aid the lodge to regain its home, Albert Hutton of Hutton Holahan, attorneys, said yesterday. The lodge has been homeless since its clubhouse in Livingston Street, Brooklyn was bid in earlier this year by the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee under a mortgage.
NEW YORK. Mrs. George Edwin Holmes will give a dinner dance on Dec. 27 in the roof garden of the St. Regis to introduce her daughter, Miss Jane Harrison Holmes.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Jack Wisdom, 26, a cowboy, signed a statement this afternoon. Assistant County Attorney Eli Eubanks announced, that he kidnapped and killed Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fritchard of Wichita.

The New York Evening Post, founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton, entered a new phase of its existence yesterday by returning to the standard eight-column size which it gave up almost three months ago for the tabloid five-column format.

HAVANA, Dec. 11 -- President Ramon Grau San Martin abruptly broke off the conciliation negotiations here tonight, declaring he had no intention of resigning and would make no further effort to bring about an agreement between his government and the opposing factions.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
BUFFALO, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Protection of newspaper confidences by State law was the principal subject for discussion of newspaper editors of New York State here today.
GREENWICH, Conn , Dec. 11. -- Baron Jacques de la Motte Fouque was placed in the Greenwich jail this morning after he had tried to give a policeman the slip.

Glenn Cunningham, Bill Bonthron and Gene Venzke, the three outstanding milers in the United States, were invited yesterday to compete in the 800-meter special which will be one of the features of the eighth annual Columbus Council, K. of C. meet at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn on Jan. 6.
Several small flats and business structures were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- The Cuban Government will issue $3,000,000 in silver coinage and $17,000,000 in silver certificates, according to a Presidential decree which became law when it was published in the official gazette issued today.
The City A.C. defeated the Princeton Club, 5-0, last night to tighten its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Class C squash tennis tournament. The victory was the sixth straight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The fourth annual Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship got under way on the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall courts today, with the seeded stars encountering little difficulty in their early matches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The average of retail food prices rose .1 per cent in the two weeks ending Nov. 21, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, reported today.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The government will have a convenient opportunity on Wednesday to take the plunge into shipping subsidies.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The rose-colored beach mansion of Mae Murray, film actress and former wife of Prince David Mdivani, was auctioned off for $11,000 on the steps of the Hall of Justice today by a Sheriff's deputy. It cost $100,000.

PORTAGE, Pa., Dec. 11 -- Weighted down with ice as they battled through a heavy storm in the Alleghanies, Pennsylvania's "graveyard of the skies," two monoplanes crashed on the mountainsides today within fifty miles of each other. The pilots "bailed out" and descended safely with parachutes.

The Civil Works Service Bureau of the Civil Works Administration announced yesterday that registration of "white collar" workers for civil works service jobs would begin tomorrow at 9 A.M. at the Fourteenth Street armory, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

Fifty owners and amateur crew members of the Long Island Sound interclub class of racing sloops attended the dinner of the class, held last night on board the Furness Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda, at the foot of West Fifty-fifth Street.

Members of the Columbia University Social Problems Club and other clubs of educational institutions of the city are expected to stage a demonstration protesting the appearance of Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, on the Columbia campus tonight.

Mutual charges of responsibility for the high cost of drinking were exchanged here yesterday among distillers, wholesalers and retailers, together with threats that Congress would be asked to investigate the entire liquor distribution system.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Hundreds of Londoners were watching the colorful ceremony of guard mount at Buckingham Palace today when they saw an airplane almost dash into the roof of the King's residence.

The way for a Fusion nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, the Bronx, was opened last night when Jacob Weil, former Alderman, filed his declination of the Republican nomination with the Board of Elections.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in opinions written by Judges Martin T. Manton and Harrie B. Chase affirmed yesterday a decision of the District Court which last April declined to sign an order restraining the Irving Trust Company from acting as a standing receiver in bankruptcy cases.

Henri Barbusse, internationally known French pacifist and author, who wrote "Under Fire," went back to France recently with an advance from Macmillan on his projected biography of Stalin. Mr. Barbusse went to Russia last Winter, put up at a hotel and sent a note to Stalin that he would like to write a book about him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The NRA gave a last chance tonight to more than 100 violators of dry cleaning price regulations, but only three agreed to comply and the names of most of the rest were turned over to the Federal Trade Commission for punitive action.

Mr. Garner Brings Cheer. Vice President GARNER has just made one of his rare, brief and useful unofficial appearances in the news. This time he has brought back from the open a deer and a brace of quail.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 11. -- Dispatches from the South that report the arrival in Hongkong of Nanking's peace delegation also recount several small skirmishes between Nanking and Fukienese rebel troops along the Chekiang-Fukien provincial borders, but there are not yet any large-scale general engagements.

Aleksandr Helmann, young Russian pianist, gave his third recital last night in the Town Hall. His program comprised Bach's English suite in E minor, Brahms's F major sonata, Op. 5, Schumann's "Carnaval," Debussy's "Reflets dans l'eau" and the "Liebestod" from "Tristan und Isolde" in piano transcription.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Two Cabinet luncheons, several teas, a morning and afternoon concert and a State dinner are among the social activities on this week's program announced by Mrs. Roosevelt at her press conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Competitive bids for the leasing of Piers 3 and 4 at Brooklyn, N.Y., for the period from March 1, 1934, to Dec. 31, 1936, will be received by the Merchant Fleet Corporation on Dec. 22.

A large exhibition of paintings and sculpture from sixteen American cities will open at the Museum of Modern Art today with a private view for members of the museum and their friends. Beginning tomorrow, it may be visited by the public.

THE baseball meetings are about to burst into flower in Chicago and it is a grave matter to interrupt the regular order of business at such momentous gatherings. There are definite and important matters already on the crowded schedule.

George S. Messersmith, United States Consul General in Berlin, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington from Hamburg and advised the people of this country to follow with the closest interest what is taking place among the inhabitants in Germany.

The 108th Old Guard Ball, which will be held on Jan. 26 at the Hotel Commodore, promises to be more impressive than ever. Many old-time commands from the various States will attend in their colorful uniforms.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 11 (AP). -- In a stern denunciation of lynch law, Circuit Judge J.V. Gaddy told a special grand jury today that every person who was active in the mob that lynched Lloyd Warner, Negro youth, the night of Nov. 28 "is guilty of murder in the first degree."

Miss Josephine Windle, energetic president of the Women's Long Island Golf Association, was re-elected head of that organization yesterday at the annual meeting at the city residence of Mrs. Howard F, Whitney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The age-old legal rule that a wife may not testify at the trial of her husband was reversed today by the Supreme Court, which held that the wife of a defendant in a criminal case in a Federal court is a competent witness in behalf of the husband.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Amendments tightening restrictions on transfers and to make more certain that academic standards are maintained were adopted today by the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association in its annual meeting.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Baseball's trade winds whipped into a veritable gale tonight as major league club owners and their pilots, all of them out to get their men, sailed into Chicago for their annual Winter meetings and shopping tour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Federal Reserve Bank's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Dec. 6 shows decreases for the week of $72,000,000 in loans and investments, $98,000,000 in net demand deposits, $43,000,000 in time deposits and $40,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 11. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, gave Germany's creditors a choice between "interest or dividend" in a speech with that title here tonight. He reaffirmed Germany's views in a way that many took as a final warning that the Reich, which is now transferring half its coupons, would do less when the next six-months period ends in June unless more is meanwhile done to give its exports openings.
Columbia's football forces worked indoors yesterday, as snow and cold weather practically put an end to any hope of outdoor practice for the rest of the week.

BARCELONA, Dec. 11. -- More bomb explosions and the killing of a factory watchman marked the anarchists' attempt today to support their revolt by a general strike. They succeeded in c sing many textile factories by bombing factories and otherwise threatening workers.

The cost of remodeling projects started in Manhattan during November far exceeds the estimated value of new building work, according to a report yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, on plans filed last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- George N. Peek, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator thus far, was commissioned by President Roosevelt today to organize a new government agency for developing American foreign trade in agricultural products through reciprocal tariffs, barter and other internatUmal agreements.

Although they finished in the second division in the pennant race the Brooklyn Dodgers jumped ahead of the other two metropolitan clubs yesterday by announcing their Spring training schedule, prepared by General Manager Bob Quinn before he headed for the major league meetings in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- President Roosevelt is seriously considering restoring at least part of the 15 per cent reductions in Federal salaries, probably at the beginning of the new calendar year, if was learned today.

BELFAST, Dec. 11. -- Sir William Whitla, well-known physician, died today at the age of 82. He was formerly Professor of Materia Medica and Thereaputics at Queens University in Belfast. Sir William's "Dictionary of Treatment," one of the best sellers among medical publications, was circulated widely and reached its sixth edition in Chinese.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Wool dealers' representatives of wool-producing centres of the country met here today and took steps to form the National Wool Trade Association.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 11. -- Jack Westrope, America's leading jockey, completed his third consecutive triple at Epsom Downs today to bring his total for the year to the impressive figure of 287 winners.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- T. Darrington Semple, Treasurer of Westchester County, today asked the Board of Supervisors for $375,000 out of $636,000 of State refunds on gasoline and other automobile tax money to prevent the county from defaulting on payrolls due on Dec. 15 and 31.

An unemployment insurance bill under which employers, workers and the State would contribute to a central fund -- the "pool plan"-- was approved last night at a meeting of the New York Permanent Conference on Social Security at the Russell Sage Foundation.

With stock transactions almost doubling those of the last five-hour day of the week before, Wall Street allowed its hopes to rise yesterday in several directions. Some of the conservative brokerage houses professed to see evidence of a reawakened public interest, although they continued to caution against overextension of commitments.
BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- The downward price tendency which set in on the Boerse last week continued today.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Eddie Casey has been reappointed head coach of the Harvard varsity football team. This was announced by William J. Binm, athletic director, at the victory dinnsr given to the members of the Harvard varsity, junior varsity and freshman football teams at the Harvard Club of Boston tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning of the fact that the British rejected recently two suggestions made by George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to the Bank of England that the monetary situation be canvassed with a view to the stabilization of the dollar and pound sterling, attracted widespread interest here in official and diplomatic circles.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Several deaths from exposure were reported from various districts today as Winter kept a firm grip on all sections of the country. The Thames was completely frozen over at Kingston for the first time in forty years.

KOSICE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 11. -- Eduard Benes, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, and Nicolas Titulesou, Foreign Minister of Rumania, who have been conferring here on the attitude of the Little Entente toward reform of the League of Nations and the Hungarian campaign for revision of the peace treaties, emphasized in speeches and interviews today the solidarity of the Little Entente.

THE relish for Americana has increased during recent years, as is shown by the vogue for the scrapbooks of Mark Sullivan, the popularity of Frederick Lewis Allen's "Only Yesterday," and the resurrection by Harry Peters of the dusty treasure trove of the Currier Ives lithographs. But the eager explorer in the mausoleum of time has overlooked one excellent bet, and that is the American magazine of the Eighties and the Nineties.

HAVANA, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Fernandez de Medina, the Uruguayan Minister to Cuba, explained tonight why he blamed United States Ambassador Sumner Welles for the failure of the conciliation conference between government officials and Opposition leaders.

The annual championship boxing tournament of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union got under way at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 4,000 persons was on hand to see the medal-chasers perform in preliminary eliminations.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 11. -- S. T. Greenfield's Don Guzman led home a field of seven 3 year-olds in the featured Charles Town Purse, run over the mile and a sixteenth route today. Chatterfol was second, beaten a length, and Lough Port landed third.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- An American offer of lower import taxes on French wines and liquors in return for lower tariffs on American farm products, made in Washington today to Andre de Labouiaye, the French Ambassador, will get the closest consideration in France.

Sharp improvement was noted in the statement of earnings of the Cleveland Tractor Company and subsidiaries, which reported for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net loss of $243,171 after depreciation, inventory adjustments, taxes and other charges, compared with a net loss of $1,548,305 in the preceding fiscal year.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11. -- Flying Don, running his fifth race since the first of the month, emerged victorious in the feature at Jefferson Park today. Driving hard at the end of the six furlongs the gelded son of Master Charlie and Sue Donovan won by" half a length and paid $7.40 for $2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The emergency conference of consumers organizations formulated a program today calling for the creation of a Department of the Consumer in the Cabinet to protect the lower income classes under the recovery plan.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 11 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today abandoned his effort to force the Pan-American Conference to decide its future relations with the League of Nations and other nonregional organizations. At a secret session lasting nearly three hours of the steering committee's subcommittee, Mr. Hull asked that his project to establish a permanent policy committee be deferred until the next conference.

The orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Association began rehearsals yesterday in preparation for the coming season, which opens on Tuesday evening, Dec. 26, with "Peter Ibbetson." Artur Bodanzky and Tullio Serafin both conducted the ensemble in passages from the two most important new productions: Richard Strauss's "Salome" and the "Merry Mount" of Howard Hanson and Richard Stokes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ralph Greenleaf of New York, the defending champion, regained his best form today to score his second victory in the world's pocket billiard title tournament, 125 to 84, in ten innings, over Pasquale Natalie of Chicago.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 11. -- The report from Asuncion of a Paraguayan victory, with the capture of many Bolivian prisoners, was received calmly here. The public was inclined to wait for confirmation from Bolivian headquarters. It is expected, however, that more reservists will be called to the colors in a day or so.

The decorative charm of eighteenth-century French art is exemplified in the current exhibition of drawings, water-colors and gouaches at the galleries of McMillen, Inc., 148 East Fifty-fifth Street. There is one Hubert Rqibert drawing; there are delightful gouaches by Moreau, Mandevare, Lallemand, Bellanger and Gadbois two romantic Water-colors, "Ruines," by Genin; also drawings by Boueher, Desrais, Massard, Oudry and others.

Reports of contracts awarded last month in the building industry make good news. One estimate places the total for thirty-seven States at $162,000,000. This is a gain of no less than 54 per cent over the same month last year and the highest figure reported for any month since October, 1931.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11. -- A.C. Blumenthal of New York, theatrical promoter, was today named president of the Poll-New England Theatres, the new corporation formed to direct the chain of houses which are controlled by Sylvester Z. Poll of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Department store sales in November were 2 per cent higher than for the same month last year, but for the first eleven months of the year showed a decline of 6 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Robert Henry Smith, Professor Emeritus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and for forty-seven years a member of the staff of the Department of Mechanical Engineering, died at his home in Watertown, early today at the age of 71.

Malvina Hoffman, American sculptor, who has nearly completed an ethnological exhibit for the Hall of Man in the Chicago Field Museum, returned yesterday on the Washington of the United States Lines. She said she expected to finish the work this Winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Fully 2,500 artists, including mural painters, sculptors and other craftsmen, will be employed in decorating Federal and other public buildings as a result of plans approved today by Harry L. Hopkins, Civil Works Administrator.

Money market was quiet, but firm. Stock Exchange call money ruled at 1 per cent, and that charge also prevailed in the counter trading. Funds were freely offered in both places, but demand was exceedingly light. In time money, a small amount of ninety days' was done at 1 1/4 per cent, and there was an advance of 1/4 in maturities running from four to six months to 1 1/4@1 1/2 per cent.

Prices of United States Government bonds and of domestic corporation issues were sharply higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday in response to the news over the weekend of discussions regarding the dollar-pound stability.
