The government issues rose 1-32 to 22-32 point with the exception of the uncalled Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s, which held unchanged.

Except for an acceleration of the trading pace, which, was encouraging to commission-house brokers, the behavior of the share market yesterday was not much different from that of the previous week. The gold-buying price of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation remained at $34.01 an ounce, where it has been anchored since Dec. 1.
ROME, Dec. 11 -- A nation-wide and simultaneous reduction in salaries and the cost of living is being worked out by Premier Mussolini and experts of the corporative State.

For six years there has been a rising tide of protest against the cost of German scientific periodicals, especially those devoted to medicine. Although $195 for Roux's Archiv and $135 for VIRCHOW'S were exceptional prices even in 1929, a subscription for a medical journal may cost from $15 to $50 annually.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- For the first time since 1918 the United States flag floated in Moscow today over the Hotel National, which will be the residence of Ambassador Bullitt, who arrived this morning. He had a rather unusual reception.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The nation's sixth city has gone to the State Legislature with a financial headache. Mayor Harry L. Davis, who took office Nov. 13, said Cleveland, as a municipal corporation, is "bankrupt." With a burst of civic pride, the Chamber of Commerce replied that the city "is by no means bankrupt."

Only 1,928 of the city's speak easies have survived the death of prohibition a week ago, according to a survey announqed yesterday by Police Commissioner Bolan. Suspected places in the midtown district have dwindled to 273, the check-up showed.
Contributions and pledges to the United Hospital Fund reached a total of $215,775 yesterday.

A comprehensive program for the improvement of the service performed by the City Home Relief Bureau designed to place the bureau on a more humane and scientific basis, was outlined yesterday by Homer Folks, chairman of the executive committee of the Welfare Council at a joint meeting of the council's board of directors and its coordinating committee on unemployment at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Charging that prices have been increased from 100 to 200 per cent under the NRA dry-cleaning code, an attack on the constitutionality of the National Recovery Act was filed in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday. The suit was brought by the Kent Stores, operators of eighteen drycleaning and dyeing establishments in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau.

The Yale, Harvard and Princeton Clubs all triumphed last night in the second round of play in Group 1 of the Class B Squash Racquets League campaign, remaining in a tie for first place. The Squash Club was a winner for the second time in Group 2, holding first place alone in that division.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- The Gates plan for de-emphasis of intercollegiate athletics was compared today by Lud Wray, former University of Pennsylvania football coach, to prohibition, in that it needs "modification or repeal."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- John Stehman Pennypacker, star left end, was tonight elected captain of the University of Pennsylvania varsity football team for next season at the first annual dinner of the football club, held at the Bellevue-Stratford.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The City Commission decided today not to appeal the decision of Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker, upholding the ruling of D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, that in issuing temporary retail liquor licenses, municipalities must collect fees prorated to June 30, 1934.
ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- Proposed budget increases amounting to $43,027,000 were approved by the State Budget Advisory Committee at its meeting today with Budget Director Abraham S. Weber.

For more than forty years M. LEON DAUDET has been writing books. For twenty-five he has been "hurling" specimens of his inexhaustible vocabulary at Marianne and most of her Ministers. He has delivered innumerable lectures, speeches, comminations. His editorial acreage is immense.

A request for a ruling on the addition of a percentage to cover labor costs to the wholesale price of merchandise, as provided in the retail code, has been made to NRA officials by the National Retail Code Authority, it was announced yesterday by Lew Hahn, chairman of the code authority.

A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried May contracts to 10.38 cents a pound, the highest quotations since Nov. 24 and $2 a bale above recent low figures. The advance in near months to above 10 cents, however, increased Southern hedging, and the resulting setback left the list 3 to 6 points higher than on Saturday.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Union, announced yesterday that he had protested to the National Recovery Administration against tactics of Pacific Coast ship lines, which he said had attempted to break up the association in favor of company unions through offers of favorable wages.

George McAneny, City Controller, announced yesterday that the city's bankers had extended $58,500,000 of corporate stock notes due yesterday, for nine months at 5 per cent interest, against the former rate of 5 3/4 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The passage by the Chamber of Deputies early this morning of the long-debated bill for raising by taxation and economy the 6,000,000,000 francs necessary to balance the budget has solved France's immediate problems. But it is admitted, even by those who have been their warmest supporters, that the proposals provide no far-reaching cure for the budgetary situation.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 11 -- It was learned today that at least two proposals for reorganizing the Pan American Union will be submitted to the Pan American conference in the next few days.

The executive council of the United Textile Workers of America, with a membership of about 75,000, yesterday called upon the American Federation of Labor to call a special convention of all its affiliated unions to consider the advisability of a general strike to enforce adoption of a universal thirty-hour week in American industry.

Postmaster General Farley was criticized by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church at the annual meeting of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States yesterday, in the parish house of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- A message from President Roosevelt expressing optimism over farm recovery was read today at the opening session of the American Farm Bureau Federation convention here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- In many sections of the country home owners are being duped by agencies which claim to have special influence with the Federal Home Loan Banks, Chairman John H. Fahey, of the Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 -- The election of officers, executive committee and board of governors has been held by the Everglades Club. The formal opening, according to tradition, will be marked by a dinner dance on New Year's Eve.

The cold and snow, bringing suffering to the poor but reminding the more fortunate that the Christmas season of giving is here, brought a welcome increase to the fund for the Neediest Cases yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Earl Roche, left-winger, prominent in the Ottawa Senators' drive to third place in the international group of the National Hockey League, has reached the top in the weekly scoring statistics. He is tied with Johnny Sorrell of the Detroit Red Wings, who, for the first time this season, is compelled to share the leadership he has held since the campaign opened.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the league of Nations, was the guest at luncheon today of Sir Austen Chamberlain at the House of Commons and afterward addressed a private meeting to which members of both houses and of all parties were invited.

More than 400 guests attended the reception for Mrs. Roosevelt, widow of former President Theodore Roosevelt, and her son and daughter-in-law, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, and Mrs. Roosevelt, at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Upon the compilation of detailed reports from the Federal Reserve Banks, Acting Secretary Morgenthau announced today that subscriptions to the recent $950,000,000 offering of one-year 2 1/4 per cent certificates of indebtedness had totaled $2,800,000,000, or about three times the amount asked.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- The State Municipal Finance Commission received creditors' claims today against Fort Lee and Manville as a preliminary to advancement of rehabilitation plans.

More than 500 employes of Fulton Fish Market, the block of three-story frame buildings on the East River at Beekman Street, fled into the icy waterfront breeze shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday as dense smoke billowed from the top floor at the south end of the block.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The United States should open its trade doors to the rest of the world for those branches of production which she is not qualified to enter or can renounce without great loss or sacrifice, Herbert Feis, economic adviser under President Roosevelt to the Department of State at Washington, told a service club today.
MADRID, Dec. 11. -- Anarchists were unsuccessful today in their attempts to revive their crushed rebellion by a general strike, although there was considerable disorder.

The Due de Richelieu, Countess Pierrefeu and Mrs. Dora Delano Forbes, aunt of President Roosevelt, will arrive tonight on the French liner Iie de France. Others arriving on the ship from Havre via Plymouth include Alfred Hoen, painter; Mme. Ganna Walska, Martin Beck, theatrical producer; Paul Lukas and Dennis King, actors; Afrem Kurtz, conductor of the Monte Carlo Russian Ballet, and:

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 11 -- About 400 members of Greenwich society attended the annual Christmas concert of the Wednesday Singing Club, of which Channing Lefebvre of New York is conductor, in the ballroom of the Greenwich Country Club tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 11 -- The Paraguayan delegation to the Pan-American Conference received communiques from Asuncion today confirming reports of the surrender of thirteen Bolivian regiments, with a personnel of 700 officers and 10,000 men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Out in Moline, Ill., they will be surprised to read tomorrow, that George N. Peek agreed to change one government job for another, and a lesser one, when circumstances forced him to resign the first. His associates in the old War Industries Board, who foregather annually for dinner with Bernard M. Baruch in New York, will probably be surprised also.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The number of authorizations for purchases of preferred stock or capital notes of banks by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the campaign to strengthen their capital structures has reached 1,512, involving an outlay by the government of about $440,000,000, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of tbe corporation, said today.

A second cold wave within twenty-four hours was sweeping eastward last night from the region of Lake Superior and was expected to send the mercury to record low temperatures here and throughout the Northeastern States early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Charges of violation of the collective bargraining provision of the NRA by the Weirton Steel Company will be placed before Attorney General Cummings for prosecution as soon as the legal staff of the National Labor Board gathers a complete record of the case, it was indicated today at the offices of the board.

The estate of Mrs. Eleanor Whitney Fosburgh, widow of James B. A. Fosburgh, partner in Grayson M-P Murphy Co., was appraised yesterday at $1,523,777 gross and 11,432,547 net, of which $1,321,376 was in securities. Mrs. Fosburgh, who died on April 24, and who lived at 14 Kast Eightieth Street, left her estate to her family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt today called Congressional leaders on tax legislation to the White House to admonish them to make revenue a secondary consideration in determining the new liquor levies. He believes that the imposition of high taxes at this time would be the surest contribution that could be made to a continuation of bootlegging.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 11 (By Wireless) -- Through terrific winds and lumpy seas the Wyatt Earp, bearing Dr. Lincoln Ellsworth and the Sixteen members of his transantarctic flight expedition, has beaten her way amid white-capped waves almost 1,000 miles toward the Antarctic pack ice since leaving Dunedin, N.Z., Dec. 5.

HAMBURG, Dec. 11. -- Two Americans and four Germans were killed and four other passengers were seriously injured when the Lufthansa's regular Berlin-Hamburg plane crashed when landing at Fuhlsbuettel Airdrome this afternoon.

Sale of sixty lots at Baldwin, L. I., to builders who expect to start construction of a group of brick-and-stone residences shortly, and leasing of two manufacturing plants in Brooklyn were included in the list of realty transactions reported yesterday by brokers in the metropolitan district.

Frank B. Kellogg, justice of the World Court and former Secretary of State, returned yesterday from Europe on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines. He said the thing most needed to stimulate business and restore public confidence was stabilization of the dollar.

Several hundred members and guests of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York attended a reception and tea in honor of the women of the members' families and their friends yesterday in the building of the organization at 65 Liberty Street.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the Weirton Steel Company, defied the National Labor Board today, refusing to abide by rules it had announced to guide an election of employes' representatives for collective bargaining.

Harry F. Wolf, national squash tennis champion, made his initial appearance in the Princeton Club's invitation tourney yesterday and scored a decisive third-round triumph. He gained the bracketron a default.

A program of education rather than coercion for the elimination of recruiting and subsidizing of athletes throughout its member colleges is favored by the executive committee of the National Collegiate A.A., it was revealed yesterday in The News Bulletin of the association.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 11 -- The fight for women's rights brought into the light today sharp differences of opinion during a stormy debate in the Pan-American Conference subcommittee appointed to study the report of the Inter-American Commission of Women.

The four receivers appointed last week to take over the business of the Lehrenkrauss banking, travel, insurance and real estate organizations in Brooklyn have stated that the companies will continue to function normally despite the bankruptcy proceedings pending in the Federal court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- With only about $300,000,000 of the total $3,300,000,000 still to be allocated by the Public Works Administration, only $131,185,100 has been granted directly to the City and State of New York in Federal and non-Federal loans, it was learned today.

Sixty colored balloons, fifteen of them bearing tags that will entitle the finder to free tickets to "Little Women" at the Roxy Theatre, were released from the observation tower of the RCA Building yesterday afternoon by members of Mrs. F. Trubee Davison's Junior committee for the crusade for children.

Models of historic New York buildings are included in the exhibition of the Architects Emergency Committee which will be opened to the public today on the sixth floor of the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Center.

Because the election of the new Cortes in Spain revealed a strong revulsion against radical parties and extreme policies, it was natural that the Socialists and the defeated politicians should he keenly disappointed and raise cries of fraud and ecclesiastical interference. But they did not resort to open violence.

Contributions of $227,700 by twenty-two New York banks and trust companies have been made as corporate gifts to the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking to raise $4,000,000 for unemployment relief for disbursement through accredited family welfare agencies.

The City of Detroit Bondholders Refunding Committee, headed by B. A. Tompkins, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, announced yesterday that it expected to distribute by next Friday the full two-thirds of the interest matured since July 1 on all bonds and notes of the city deposited under the refunding plan.

MANAOS, Brazil, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, safe at this point, 900 miles up the Amazon River, planned to take off early tomorrow toward Trinidad, 900 miles away. The start was set for 5 A.M., Eastern Standard Time.

Appearances are nowhere more deceptive than in taxation. Judging from the bald figures, Chicago is about the most heavily taxed city in the country. Its rate today is $73.50 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, as compared with $24.30 for New York and $14.50 for Lancaster.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- American women have been buying fewer silk hose during the last five months, it developed today when a two months' curtailment of hosiery production was requested in a hearing on the code of the hosiery industry before deputy NRA Administrator B.H. Gitchell.

Holiday Reorders Numerous. Reorders on gift merchandise continued numerous in this market yesterday. The business was mostly of a fill-in nature on main floor items, with medium to popular-price goods stressed. Reports agreed that retail sales volume at the week-end was the best of the holiday season so far.

The main office of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles at 155 Worth Street was a beehive yesterday, with about 3,000 car owners filing applications for the registration of their vehicles for 1934. Thousands of application blanks were made available also at the other offices of the bureau in the city and at police stations, while automobile clubs sent many hundreds out to their members.

Seven speakeasy bartenders were sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to serve thirty days in the Workhouse for failing to pay fines of $200 each. They were the first to plead guilty to violations of the; new State Liquor License Law.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Willard F. Smith, retired president and treasurer of the Smith Paper Company of Lee, with which he was identified for thirty years, died suddenly in New York this afternoon. He was 58 years of age. Burial will take place, at Lee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade started today as if they would continue the strong upturn of Saturday, but after wheat had advanced, slightly more than 1 cent a bushel and corn about 7/8 cent, profit-taking developed and disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

The first proceeding for the removal of a judge in the Brooklyn district since the Civil War was begun yesterday when the Appellate Division heard testimony in an action to remove City Judge J. Charles Zimmerman of Long Beach.

At the invitation of the committee on quotations and commissions of the New York Stock Exchange Frank R. Hope, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, has been attending meetings of the committee at which problems involving customers' men have been discussed.

Commodity futures moved within a narrow range yesterday on local exchanges and closed irregular. The strength in the dollar and the unchanged gold price caused traders to prefer the side-lines for the time being, with the result that trading was light.

Any benefit to the consumers in the near future through the recent 6 per cent rate cut ordered for the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas System by the Public Service Commission became doubtful yesterday when the matter was thrown into the courts.

Sing F. Lee, manager of the Chinese restaurant at 104 West Forty-fourth Street, is going to the police today to see about installing a holdup alarm system. Mr. Lee would like an alarm connecting directly with police headquarters.

The New York Giants and the Chicago Bears, who will clash for the national professional football championship at Chicago on Sunday, demonstrated during the past season that they are the outstanding offensive teams in the National Football League.

Those accustomed to pass through the terminal stations see frequently something to stir both their pity and their pride. It is pity for the travelers, often mothers with children, sometimes a whole family of alien appearance, sometimes a lone child, stranded in the great strange city; pride in the kind, intelligent service that enables them to find their way to their destinations.

Mischa Elman celebrated last night in Carnegie Hall the twenty-fifth anniversary of the night that he first played in America. He is now a man of 42, a musician, a consummate virtuoso, in the full flood of his powers. Like so many great violinists, he showed a phenomenal talent at an early age.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- This was "Roosevelt Night" at the first of three cotillions given annually by the Washington bachelors at the Mayflower Hotel.

With Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne leading the fight and Governor Lehman lending his support, an effort will be made at the next session of the Legislature to enact into permanent form the Conservation Fund Law.

An unprecedented increase in labor turnover under the NRA was reported yesterday in a survey by the American Economic Institute. According to the survey, twice as many industrial workers in the United States voluntarily quit their jobs in July, August and September of this year as in the previous quarter, and almost three times more than in the first quarter of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's economic proposal before the Seventh International Conference of the American States at Montevideo, as given out by the State Department, follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Miss Cicely Fenwick of England the lone foreign representative among a galaxy of American stars in the women's fourth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship, eliminated two more opponents on the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall courts today to move a step nearer the title.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12 (AP). -- A new plan for meeting the State's bonded and accrued debt of $155,374,180 was placed before Governor Futrell's Bond Refunding Committee today by a subcommittee, which will recommend an immediate special legislative session if the program is accepted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- In furtherance of the government's effort to force down the price of retail liquor, officials have decided to permit the immediate importation of 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 gallons of old rye and bourbon whiskies from Canada for blending and resale.

Some eighty pieces of jewelry belonging to the former Mrs. Jesse L. Livermore, now Mrs. J. Walter Longcope, will be sold at auction this afternoon and on other afternoons this week at 664 Fifth Avenue, where their exhibition attracted several visitors yesterday.

For several days the so-called "stabilization of the dollar" has figured in endless dispatches and cablegrams. Hints and rumors, assertions and denials, have flashed back and forth between Washington and London and Paris. Nothing positive has come out of it all.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The re-appearance of Harvard as a football rival of Princeton is the outstanding feature of the Tigers' schedule for next year. Harvard will be played at Cambridge in the first game since 1926, when relations were severed.

Members of the Bar Association of the City of New York adopted a resolution last night condemning Governor Rolph of California for condoning the San Jose lynchings. The resolution was put before the members at the regular meeting of the association in its assembly room at 42 West Forty-second Street.

In the heart of South America, Paraguay and Bolivia have been waging a war in a wilderness for a year and a half. The battleground has been in the almost trackless jungle of the Gran Chaco Boreal, a disputed territory of about 100,000 square miles, lying in the angle formed by the junction of the Pilcomayo and Paraguay Rivers.

BUCHAREST, Dec. 12 -- The Rumanian election campaign is now in full swing. General Cantacuzenu, head of one of the greatest aristocratic families in the country, threatened today to shoot Premier Duca on sight and applied to King Carol for an audience to explain the threat.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Mickey Cochrane, whose appointment as manager of the Detroit Tigers was announced tonight in Chicago, becomes the tenth pilot the Bengals have had since 1900, and of that number Detroit fans are hopeful he will emulate the late Hughey Jennings.

When Connie Mack bought his famous southpaw, Robert Moses Grove, from the Baltimore Orioles, of the International League late in 1924, agreeing to pay $100,600, the baseball traders of that day shook their heads. They couldn't "see" that value in a left-handed pitcher, for southpaws are admittedly the most unreliable of assets to a baseball club.
The receivership of the Roxy Theatre on Seventh Avenue under Howard S. Cullman was extended for another six months by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel denied yesterday an application by Lucius Wilmerding Jr., a member of the City Budget Commission, suing as a taxpayer, to restrain the Controller and City Collector from canceling an assessment for $882,437 on 2,000 pieces of property which benefited from the widening of Forsyth and Chrystie Streets.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 12 -- The war in the Chaco jungle that has cost Bolivia and Paraguay 100,000 dead and wounded in the last year and a half, appeared tonight to be near its end.

A vigorous controversy between Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, and the Medical Society of the County of New York developed yesterday with the release for publication of an editorial from the society's official organ, The New York Medical Week, severely criticizing the administration of the Health Department.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Kenesaw Mountain Land is tonight was voted another seven-year contract as baseball commissioner by American and National League club owners. It is his third contract of that length.

Influential groups of conservative artists here, feeling that they had been slighted by the Federal Government to the advantage of the so-called modern art group, made a concerted attack yesterday on the Public Works Art Project, under which, it is estimated, some 2,500 artists, sculptors and craftsmen will be employed in decorating public buildings.

Twenty-three major letters are included among the 109 awards voted by the City College Athletic Association to athletes who took part in Fall sports, according to the announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, manager of athletics.
The University Fencers Club won the national junior foils team championship in the competition held last night at the Fencers Club, defeating the Salle d'Armes Vince team, 5 -- 0, in the final round.

There was a general display of weakness in foreign loans on the Stock Exchange yesterday, particularly those issues which had gained considerable ground of late. Strength of the dollar in the foreign exchange market sent the foreign issues lower early in the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Platt amendment, which gives the United States power to intervene in Cuba, may be abrogated as a means toward solving the troubled Cuban situation, it was intimated today in official circles. While it was denied that President Roosevelt or the State Department had officially directed such a program, it was understood that Ambassador Welles had made advances looking to such a proposal.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 -- Indictments charging two of the three "marrying Mdivanis," Princes David and Serge, with fourteen counts of grand theft in connection with their operations of the Pacific Shore Oil Company were returned today by the county grand jury.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., the national amateur squash tennis champion, met with one of the hardest battles he has faced in a long while last night when he was carried to 18 -- 15, 15 -- 11 by Leonard Green of the City A.C. in the invitation tournament of the Princeton Club.

Members of the Board of Estimate balked yestetday at the request of the Civil Works Authority that its relief-job program be slowed down until after Jan. 1, with the prospect that most of the jobs would be filled during the LaGuardia administration.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 12 (A.P.) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in introducing his economic proposals at the Pan-American Conference today, spoke as follows:

Departing from what Wall Street has been speaking of for several days as a "true bull market pattern," stocks reflected yesterday a tendency on the part of traders to wait and watch. The fact that the government's price for gold was permitted to remain at $34.01 an ounce when there had been predictions of a resumption of the advance, may have discouraged speculators for the rise in stocks and commodities.

The opening date for "Divine Moment," the Robert Hare Powel play which Peggy Fears will produce, has been set for Monday evening, Jan. 1, at the Vanderbilt Theatre. A try-out engagement in Philadelphia will begin on Dec. 23. Allen Kearns is an addition to the cast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A sharp increase in the volume of refunding of urban home mortgages was reported today by the Home Owners Loan Corporation for the week ended on Dec. 6. Loans were closed by the corporation during the week at the rate of more than $2,100,000 a day, with a total of $12,655,065 for the week.

Plans for a repair and service base near New York for planes to be used in a transatlantic service were revealed here yesterday when it was learned that the Marine Airport Corporation had taken an option on the big seaplane plant near Port Washington, L.I.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- Shadows of an expected struggle for mastery of the Pacific are etched each day more sharply in the columns of the Soviet press.

After flooring his opponent twice for a count of nine with a withering body attack, Billy Petrolle, Fargo (N.D.) welterweight, gained a technical knockout over Stanislaus Loayza of Chile in the sixth round of the main ten-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove S.C. last night.

Booth Tarkington, whose impaired eyesight makes "everything El Greco now -- a little too long and a little lopsided," was in town yesterday telling stories about Maine, explaining his new methods of work and making nostalgic comment on the New York that he liked best.

A terrific explosion on the site of the new postoffice at West Broadway and Barclay Street resounded distinctly as high as the observation tower on the fifty-fourth floor of the Woolworth Building, two blocks away, and throughout a large part of the lower western tip of Manhattan at 2:10 P.M. yesterday.

TORONTO, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press) -- A merger of the Standard Stock and Mining Exchange with the Toronto Stock Exchange was authorized finally today, when members of the Mining Exchange unanimously ratified the terms of the merger.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Sir Walter Layton, editor of The Economist, declared today that currency stabilization by Great Britain is not likely so long as the dollar is "artificially undervalued."

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,317,750 barrels, compared with 2,195,050 in the previous week, a rise of 122,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Mary Pickford arrived in New York yesterday without any fanfare except that created by dozens of flappers and interviewers. At the late milkman's hour when most New Yorkers were either commuting or getting extra minutes of sleep, the first lady of the films slipped out of the train which brought her from Chicago, into a taxicab at the Pennsylvania Station.

The Russian influence on style was the outstanding feature of the Spring fashion revue of the Associated Model Houses of America, held last night in the Hotel Astor. More than 500 persons, including retail buyers, stylists and dress manufacturers, attended the exhibition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Fifty violators of the Dry Cleaning Code prices yielded under NRA's persuasion and the threat of prosecution, but a hundred remained, unshaken and tonight faced prosecution as a two-day hearing into charges against them was brought to its close.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Chancellor Hitler and all other leaders of the Nazi Government are among those absent from the 1934 edition of the British "Who's Who" just published here.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 12. -- The regulation and stabilization of commodity prices by varying the gold content of the dollar la a practical as well as theoretical and technical impossibilty, according to Benjamin M. Anderaon Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Security issues aggregating about $31,000,000 are contemplated in ten registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today. The list follows:
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- A strong and steady revival in Britain's foreign trade is revealed by Board of Trade returns for November, published today.

Although speculators undoubtedly made the most of their limited trading opportunities, yesterday's domestic markets lacked the energy and enthusiasm shown on the day before. Price movements were mixed and more or less hesitant, with no special significance.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- A strong and steady revival in Britain's foreign trade is revealed by Board of Trade returns for November, published today.

The rule prohibiting drinking at bars would not be modified, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Control Board, said yesterday. Liquor dealers and disappointed applicants for licenses were responsible for the criticism of the board and its regulations, he declared.

Although speculators undoubtedly made the most of their limited trading opportunities, yesterday's domestic markets lacked the energy and enthusiasm shown on the day before. Price movements were mixed and more or less hesitant, with no special significance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The issuance of emergency import permits was ended today by the special committee assigned to this task, and the list of importers, together with their quotas, will be given out tomorrow.

William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council of New York City and a member of the State CWA, was reported last night to have been picked by Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia for Commissioner of Public Welfare to succeed Frank J. Taylor.

Maurice Colbourne and Barry Jones will arrive in New York on Dec. 21, along with tse company of "Women Kind," lately shown in London. They will present the play -- which is by Lewis Galantiere and John Houseman -- in Montreal on New Year's Day, and later in Toronto and New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Members of the Romany chorus were guests tonight of Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne at Casa Beata. The chorus presented a program of music especially prepared as a surprise to John Charles Thomas, who, with Mrs. Thomas, John Shepard Jr. and Hugh Dillman, members of the board, were also guests.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Little interest was taken today by speculators in grains on the Broad of Trade, while the December deliveries of wheat and oats showed independent strength, the distant futures were easy.

Headed by Raymond G. Wardell, president, a delegation of the American Artists Equity, an organization of commercial artists, called on Grover A. Whalen, administrator, at the NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway, yesterday, and asked his help in obtaining approval of a code to end what the delegation termed "the worst chaos that has ever existed in art."
A general sampling of the whisky being sold in this city was promised yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, to find out what kind of liquor is being provided under repeal.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 12 -- In the first teat vote on women's rights at the Pan-American Conference, a subcommittee today rejected, three to two, the treaty on equal civil and political rights. The treaty on equal nationality rights, however, was unanimously approved.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- Buying orders and the speeches of Dr. Schmitt, Dr. Schacht and Arthur Henderson encouraged the Boerse today. Trading was livelier and the general tone firmer. Some gains were recorded by the most active stocks. Reichsbank shares rose 3 points and mining, chemical, machinery and automobile shares were stronger.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 12 -- Because of lack of funds, 2,500 men at present employed on the parks on Long Island under the Civil "Works Administration will be discharged next Saturday, Robert L. Moses, chairman of the Long Island State Park Commission, announced here today. He said the administration had failed to furnish funds for the purchase of materials and equipment.

Prospects of further outdoor practice in New York for Columbia's football team vanished yesterday when the Lions established headquarters in the 105th Field Artillery Armory, Franklin Avenue and 166th Street, the Bronx.
Bronx members of the Board of Aldermen failed yesterday in their attempt to breathe life into thirty-four Bronx jobs dropped from the 1934 budget without their knowledge.

LEFTY GROVE. Born in Lonacoming, Md., March 6, 1900; 6 feet 2 1/2 inches tall, weighs 175 pounds. Made his professional debut with Martinsburg of the Blue Ridge League in 1920. Has been rated the major league's greatest left-handed pitcher for several years.

The private life of the only "immortal" piece of living tissue in existence, which has been kept artificially alive in a glass case for twenty-one years at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, will be revealed for the first time to the public Saturday night in a microscopic motion picture recently made with a specially designed camera.

The first of the season's Yorkville dinner dances in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association took place last night at Sherry's. The proceeds from the entertainments will aid the beneficiary in its work at 1,639 York Avenue and at a camp, a gymnasium and clubs for children and adults.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- The speech at Basle yesterday by Dr. Hjalmer Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, was accepted in German quarters today as a definite announcement that Germany would reduce her interest payments under the partial transfer moratorium after Jan. 1.

Salt-water fishermen in almost every section of the United States enjoy a privilege which they are not compelled to pay for, namely, the privilege of angling without having to pay for a fishing license.

Julius H. Barnes, former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Carl Sherman, former Attorney General of New York State, were among the defendants named in suits filed in Supreme Court yesterday by stockholders of the Insuranshares Corporation and the North and South American Corporation.

An exhibition called "The Dance in Modern Art," containing 100 examples in various mediums, has opened at the Reinhardt Galleries, where it will remain until Dec. 24. This is one of the traveling exhibitions assembled by the College Art Association, which also is responsible for the big and extremely interesting "Salon of American Humorists," now in progress at 480 Park Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Where does one buy one's alcohol these times? I visited several licensed liquor dealers yesterday, but could not buy a five-gallon can of alcohol. They had plenty of ready-made gin at $1.50 a fifth.

Politicians will find excellent bedtime reading in LOUISE OVERACKER'S article in The American Political Science Review on." Campaign Funds in a Depression Year." The author is Associate Professor of Political Science at Wellesley; also the author of "Money in Elections."

Russian members of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe, sailing from Plymouth today on the Lafayette, will begin their first American engagement here at the St. James Theatre on Dec. 22. According to S. Hurok, the manager, this is the largest company of European dancers to visit this country since the Diaghilev Ballet in 1916.

Authority to inspect payrolls and greater action by labor to strengthen enforcement of NRA codes were recommended yesterday at the second national conference on labor standards of the National Consumers League. The meeting was held in the Allerton House, 132 East Fifty-second Street.

Tammany should have learned by now that they who take the sword will perish by it. Ever since the beginning of the city campaign the organization has been ruthless in striking down its foes wherever it could reach them, turning faithful public employes out on the streets for so much as daring to support the opposition candidate.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Bolivia has been defeated in the war for possession of the Gran Chaco Boreal, in the opinion of Victor Rojas, Paraguay's Defense Minister. In a statement today he said:

A fantastic story unfolded to him by Frederick J. Werner, the former Brooklyn school teacher, who is said to have confessed to swindles totaling $200,000, led District Attornew Geoghan of Brooklyn to announce yesterday that he was seeking another man for questioning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The resignation of Walter J. Cummings of Chicago, chairman of the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, is expected within a few weeks. He declined comment today, but it is understood that President Roosevelt has been advised of his desire to resign.

HAVANA, Dec. 12 -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, will leave Havana tomorrow afternoon by airplane for Washington, where he will immediately take over his duties as Assistant Secretary of State. He said Jefferson Caffery would arrive in Havana in four or five days as a special representative of President Roosevelt.

Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, had just begun a plea for disarmament and less criticism of Germany last night before the Institute of Arts and Sciences at Columbia University, when a young woman in the auditorium of Horace Mann School broke in with a loud yell.

A demand mortgage for $6,000 was given by Grace Lo Gerfo to Guglielmo Glannone on the four-story building at 326 E. 21st St., subject to a first mortgage for $12,000. The second mortgage is to secure payment of a note given to the mortgagee by the Magic Beverage Co., Inc., and John Lo Gerfo.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Connie MacK, veteran leader of the Philadelphia Athletics, who startled baseball way back in 1914 by breaking up his famous "$100,000 infield," tonight went even further in player transactions.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- A preliminary law governing the administration of the Protestant Church in Germany was issued today by the clerical cabinet of Reichsbishop Mueller. Its publication made it effective immediately.

Welcome both for itself and for the reasoning on which it rests is the decision of the Supreme Court that in a criminal trial in a Federal court the defendant's wife is competent to testify in his behalf. Thus another of the old exclusions of the common law is removed.

Good Republicans who wanted badges to flash when they were in traffic difficulties received appointments here as $1-a-year special investigators for the immigration bureau of the Department of Labor, according to testimony given yesterday by Ervin F. Brown, former chief of the local bureau.

State of California. California plans to offer a new issue of $6,000,000 of relief bonds for award on Feb. 1, bankers were advised here yesterday. The issue will mature $2,000,000 annually from 1941 to 1943, with interest rate to be named by the bidders not to exceed 4 1/2 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last evening I heard Senator McKellar of Tennessee broadcast a speech in support of the President's financial policy. Extracts from this speech published in THE TIMES omitted the more violent expressions.

A sweeping injunction against the Shoe and Leather Workers' Industrial Union, restraining its members from performing virtually any overt act of protest against twelve shoe manufacturers, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Mayor-elect LaGuardia of New York scored a personal triumph today when Secretary Ickes announced a loan and grant totaling $23,160,000 to New York City, to be employed on the Eighth Avenue subway project and put some 6,700 men to work for twenty-two months.

The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom announced plans yesterday for a nation-wide campaign to seek a Congressional investigation, of the munitions industry and to prevent any further increase in armament expenditures. The first step in the campaign will be taken this afternoon when a delegation from the league, headed by Mrs. Gerard Swope, calls on Senator Copeland at the Hotel Astor.

GLASGOW, Dec. 12 -- Thousands of Clydebank riveters and engineers, unemployed for two Winters, were in high spirits tonight for word had come privately from London that work was to be restarted forthwith on the "big boat."
More than 500 alumni honored the Columbia football team at a testimonial dinner at the Columbia University Club last night.

The National Orchestral Association of young players who gain symphonic experience and preparation for professional work under the baton of Leon Barzin gave a program of unusual interest yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. This was called a "young soloist concert," but the contents of the program were more interesting than a concert devoted principally to the interests of young soloists might imply.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Denials from Washington regarding moves for stabilization of the dollar served to cool the exchange market's enthusiasm today, and, while the dollar and the British pound improved a little, the market remained calm. The dollar closed at 16.33 francs, against 16.17; the pound at 83.45 francs, against 83.20. The gold currencies continued slightly weaker against the franc, which continues to benefit from passage of the budget by the Chamber of Deputies.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Unemployment relief through business expansion, "promoted by private enterprise and financed with sound money," was termed America's greatest need by Colonel Leonard P. Ayres. vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company and economist, in his annual business prediction, before the Chamber of Commerce today.

Retail establishments in Manhattan alone increased their payrolls by about $38,000,000 a year and added 32,000 employes to their staffs between Aug. 1 and Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, NRA Administrator for New York City.
Twenty properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One sale scheduled was postponed until next month.

TWICKENHAM, England, Dec. 12. -- Before a crowd of 40,000 Oxford defeated Cambridge, 5 -- 3, today in their annual rugger classic. The record in the 58 matches played since 1871 now stands at 27 victories for Oxford, 21 for the Light Blues and 10 drawn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- While the inflation debate continued to absorb statesmen and economists, Federal Reserve figures disclosed today that the system had sufficient gold resources to increase the money in circulation by more than 50 per cent without resorting to any inflationary measure.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12 -- Fortified with an opinion from the Attorney General's Department that an act of the Legislature presumably is valid until set aside by the courts, the Board Appeals created by the new State Liquor Control Law was organized here today.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Dec. 12 -- Acceptance of the presidency of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching was announced tonight by President Walter A. Jessup of the University of Iowa.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12 -- Professor Albert Einstein was moved to tears today during a private recital of the Westminster Choir School of Princeton. The recital was arranged by Albert Morini, impressario of Venice and Paris, who is booking the coming European tour of the choir, and was hem in the practice rooms of the First Presbyterian Church of Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- General Johnson indicated today that he would make a thorough investigation of Charges by representatives of the American Federation of Labor that the Ford Motor Company was violating the labor sections of the Recovery Act, as soon as such charges were formally filed with him.

George Merry, 26 years old, who said he had been unemployed for more than three years and was driven desperate by hunger and cold, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to rob the Brownsville branch of the East New York Savings Bank in Brooklyn by vaulting a six-foot grill surrounding a teller's booth.

Despite criticism from members of the New York Stock Exchange of certain regulations governing the employment of customers' men, no changes in the rules are probable soon, it was said yesterday at the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Senator Borah declared today that the proposed oil equalization agreement would put the whole industry in the hands of a few large concerns which could then "wipe out every independent oil man in the country."

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Foreign Minister Joseph Faul-Boncour laid before the Cabinet today for the first time an account of the conversations that took place last month between Chancellor Hitler and the French Ambassador to Berlin, Andre Francois-Poncet, and of the supplementary conversation of yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Comments on the successful flotation of the $950,000,000 of government certificates, it seems to me, are not altogether held in the proper key. The fact in itself is gratifying, but it carries no special significance. The money being there, what were the banks to do?
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 12 -- General Jose Lanza, who was a member of the military junta that governed Bolivia after the overthrow of President Siles, was appointed chief of staff today.

The cold weather will continue its grip on New York City today, according to the Weather Bureau, which forecast not much change in temperatures. It will be followed by snow tomorrow, according to the forecast.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 12 -- Nicholas F. Brady, public utility financier, left a gross estate of $14,729,O16.06 and a net of $9,742,955.09, much of it in power and motor stocks, according to a State transfer tax appraisal filed here today. His stocks and bonds we're appraised at more than $12,196,000.

The trend of prices of commodity futures was irregularly lower yesterday in continued relatively quiet trading in the markets here. Cash prices also turned downward after having advanced several days.

After Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN had made some rather indiscreet remarks about the United States going in for a dictator, Professor FELIX FRANK-FURTER of the Harvard Law School, now lecturing at Oxford, took up the question in a recent address at Rhodes House.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The rise of "Father" Divine, 4-foot 6-inch Negro, from a lowly status in Sayville, L.I., five years ago to the prosperous leadrrship of a cult which includes "kingdoms" in New York, Newark, Baltimore, Washington, Bridgeport and other cities, and whose followers worship him as God, is traced in a report submitted today to Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The War Department released the following orders today:

A code of ethics for water transportation lines operating between North Atlantic ports of the United States and ports on the Great Lakes, canals or other river ports via the New York State Barge Canal and the St. Lawrence River, has been filed with the National Recovery Administration, it was announced yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States today called on the nations of the Western Hemisphere to lower their tariffs and to invite the rest of the world, through the London Economic Conference, to follow their example.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Frank Taberski of Schenectady, N.Y., tonight just about ruined Ralph Greenleaf's chance of winning his fifth consecutive world's pocket billiard title by defeating the New York star, 125 to 98, in eighteen innings.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Discussing the new measures for financial reform, which were laid before the Senate today. Senator Francois Milan, president of the administrative council of the Caisse d'Amortissement, declared:
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade's figures for November:

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Postmaster General James A. Farley spoke reassuring words today about the Roosevelt "experiment" to members of the American Club of Paris, whom their chairman, Theodore" Rousseau, described at a luncheon today as "a representative group of forgotten men, trying to get along on depreciated dollars."

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Discussion of a merger of the University of Chicago and Northwestern University are in such a preliminary stage at present that consolidation is neither imminent nor assured, Robert M. Hutchins, president of the midway institution, told 2,000 students and faculty members today.

A bundle reception and tea in behalf of the recently opened Generosity Shop was held yesterday in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle. Countess Eleanor ColloredoMannsfeld headed the group of young women who assisted during the afternoon.

The Horace Mann School for Boys opened its basketball campaign with an impressive 52-24 triumph over the Fanwood School yesterday on the winners' court. Coach Tewhill used the entire Horace Mann varsity squad of thirteen players. The victors were ahead at the intermission, 31 -- 7.

MUNICH, Dec. 12 -- Cardinal Faulhaber, the Catholic Archbishop of Munich, delivered "the second of a series of Advent sermons on "Judaism and Christianity" yesterday. He dealt mainly with the moral values of the Old Testament, which he vigorously defended against the attacks by the Nazi German Christian and anti-Semitic schools of theologians, repudiating recent criticism of prominent figures of the Old Testament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 --Civil Works Administration officials appeared unperturbed today as reports of dissatisfaction among conservative New York artists over the selection of representatives of the modernists on the New York Regional Committee.

Although the New York Stock Exchange and other security markets here decided to stay in this city after the city administration last September dropped its plan to impose special taxes on the brokerage business, a survey yesterday showed that trading in low-priced unlisted issues is drifting steadily to New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The administration can produce figures to sustain its thesis that the dollar is the steadiest and soundest of world currencies today, while the pound and franc are gyrating in their dollar value. This contention was the basis on which unofficial administration representatives approached the Bank of England twice recently with a proposal that an immediate survey be made with a view to joint stabilization of the dollar and the pound.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States Code, Title 31, Money and Finance, Section 314, provides:

Our Flag in Russia. With the arrival of Ambassador BULLITT in Moscow our flag has been raised for the first time in that city since 1918. Less formally, one imagines, the American flag must have occasionally been seen in Soviet Russia later than that.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Secretary Wallace and George N. Peek, Federal chieftains for agriculture, who were principals in a row over farm recovery policies in Washington last week, united forces on a platform here today to defend the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and President Roosevelt's administration against critics.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess Christian of Hesse have returned from Buffalo to Mayfair House.

Bonds of public utility companies to the amount of $906,217,150 were in default on Nov. 1, according to compilations made by Dow, Jones Co. It is the highest figure on record and compares with S794,658,040 on Nov. 1, 1932. In the twelve months $160,731,800 was lifted by foreclosure, reorganization or extension, so that the net increase amounted to $272,290,910.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 12 -- The homeward trail of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh took them today on a 1,100-mile flight from Manaos, Brazil, to this old capital city of Trinidad.

Jacob Elkin of 1,791 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, a member of the law firm of Brauer Klein, 225 Broadway, was picked last night as the Republican candidate for State Senator in the Twenty-first District. Mr. Klein will be substituted for Jacob Weil who declined the nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced tonight that it would open for public use on Friday morning the main waiting room and concourse of its new station on the west bank of the Schuylkill River.

A decision outlining the right of holders of an interest in a mortgage to bring foreclosure proceedings was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in upholding a ruling vacating the appointment of receivers for the property at 273-277 Madison Avenue and 24-26 East Fortieth Street.

Business in the money market was small and quotations for all classifications unchanged from those which prevailed on Monday. On the Stock Exchange call loans were arranged at 1 per cent, but small amounts of outside funds were done at 3/4@7/8.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- The 5-year-old gelding Jaz Age, noted for years as a smart sprinter, led practically from start to finish to win the featured race at Jefferson Park today. The son of Great Jaz and Elga scored toy two lengths at even money.
BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- Germany's new all-Nazi Reichstag met, organized and adjourned in seven and a half minutes today when speeded up by General Hermann Goering, its president.

Surprising even their most ardent admirers with their fire and aggressiveness, the New York Americans battered their way to a 3-to-0 triumph over the New York Rangers in a torrid National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Pacific Fruit Express Company, jointly and equally owned by the Southern Pacific and Union Pacific Railroads, has declared total dividends of 47 per cent in the first eleven months of this year, against 70 per cent in 1932. Payments in both years included amounts drawn from surplus.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday, Monday. For the best names........ 1 1/4% 1 2% The quotations are for three-four months paper.
Two sales on the east side of Manhattan, one on Third Avenue near Seventy-fifth Street and the other in Fifteenth Street, claimed the attention of real estate interests yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- At today's hearing on suggested liquor taxes before the Finance Committees of Congress Representative Crowther of New York suggested that the $170,000,000, estimated as revenue from a tax of $2 a gallon, would not replace the sum lost with the automatic repeal of some of the recovery taxes.

A strong, organized movement for country-wide adoption of the Rockefeller plan of liquor control became known, yesterday, when a committee of the National Municipal League with former Governor Frank O. Lowden of Illinois presiding, met at the Hotel New Yorker.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board has issued liquor licenses to twenty-eight clubs and hotels in Westchester County, it was disclosed here today when a list of the first group of licenses issued was made public. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Alcohol Control Administration tonight announced that pending issuance of permits for the wholesaling industry, authority for engaging in that branch of the liquor business would not be required.

Despite the vote of confidence and "affection" by which the Republican county chairman at the conference in Utica last Friday upheld the present leadership and personnel of the Republican Assembly, Chairman W. Kingsland Macy of the Republican State Committee will continue his fight to oust Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse as clerk of the Assembly.
The growing realization of the misery confronting many of the Neediest Cases this Winter unles help is given brought an increase yesterday in the number contributing to the fund.
Petitions Filed -- Against NORTH AMERICAN MILLINERY CORP., electrical equipment, 392 5th Av. -- By Gafmor Hats, Inc., for 5120; Ben Fuchs, Inc., $13; Samuels, Inc., $500.

The second concert of the New York Orchestra under Nicolai Sokoloff took place last night in Carnegie Hall before a good sized and very responsive audience. Again Mr. Sokoloff's program revealed a welcome freshness of material and reminded the audience that the symphonic repertoire is not necessarily bounded by Tchaikovsky, Beethoven, Schubert and Mozart.
BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team opened its season tonight with a 4-to-1 victory over the Massachusetts Institute of Technology sextet in the Boston Arena.

Members of the New York branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance held a large reception and entertainment last night in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization. The occasion marked the tenth anniversary of the founding of the New York branch of the alliance by Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, who is now its honorary president.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- The American dollar is the best money in the world and its stability is not open to question, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said in an address at the annual banquet of the Illinois Manufacturers Association here tonight.

Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, is at work on her first book. The John Day Company, which published President Roosevelt's book, "Looking Forward," last Spring, will bring it out, probably in May. The tentative title is "The New Age of Labor."

There is nothing necessarily irreconcilable in the points of disagreement as to President Roosevelt's monetary policy, Frank M. Law, president of the American Bankers Association and of the First National Bank of Houston, Texas, declared here in an address last night.

Likening the need for alteration of the repressive features of the racing law to prohibition repeal, William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, announced yesterday that a bill would be introduced at the coming session of the Legislature designed to give the State a tax and to avoid further losses to the five New York racing associations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Strengthening of the Securities Act rather than weakening was favored today by J.M. Landis, Federal Trade Commissioner, and Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, which is investigating stock market practices through a sub-committee.

President ROOSEVELT did not claim too much when he told the Farm Bureau convention that the outlook for agriculture has greatly changed in recent months. The index of farm purchasingpower compiled by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics -- that is, the ratio of farm prices to those of goods the farmer buys-stood at 49 when the new Administration came into office.

THERE is a moldy tradition that book reviewers, the callous brutes, give away for Christmas all the dull and insipid volumes which have come their way through the Fall publishing season. They are commonly reported as saying to their wives, "Oh, that piece of tripe, will do for Aunt Meg," or "Give that sappy novel to grandma; she likes such junk."

The Queens District Attorney's office "will be glad to hear any evidence" on certain activities of Art J. Smith, national commander of the Khaki Shirts of America, an organization with Fascist tendencies, according to Assistant District Attorney Harry I. Huber.

In the absence of any official Statement regarding the progress of formal organization of the American Foreign Bondholders Protective Committee pursuant to the White House statement of Oct. 20, American holders of foreign bonds now in default are faced with the prospect of Federal legislation to halt all trading in these issues.

Net profit earned by and accruing to the Greyhound Corporation from its own operations and those of subsidiary and affiliated companies, applicable to the common stock of the corporation, amounted to $1,385,634 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to a preliminary statement issued by C.E. Wickman, president.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The British attitude toward the new European situation created by Germany's withdrawal from the Disarmament Conference and the League of Nations has now crystallized. Direct exchanges between Paris and Berlin, Paris and London and London and Berlin have produced this effect.
The Rockefeller Center Corporation obtained tentative approval yesterday from the Board of Estimate for its plans to provide additional access to its buildings through seven subsurface tunnels.

Dr. Walter Albert Jessup, president of the State University of Iowa, was named yesterday to the presidency of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, which was founded in 1905 to give aid to college teachers and to study educational problems.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee is approaching its goal of $4,000,000 in its campaign for an unemployment relief fund to be disbursed through accredited family welfare agencies, James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

The New York Telephone Company served yesterday the Public Service Commission, the Attorney General and the Corporation Counsel with its statement of jurisdiction of the United States Supreme Court, to which it has appealed in its rate case.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Although many people are talking about the necessity of reforming the League of Nations no precise plan of reform has yet been presented by Italy or by any one else.
LON ANGELES, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Frank X. Shields of New York was listed as the top ranking amateur tennis player of the United States today by Lester Stoefen, national men's doubles champion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- An increase in rates on coal from Colona and Conway, Pa., when it is transported partly by water to Youngatown, Ohio, and from river transport points on the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway to Canton, Massillon, Cleveland and Lorain and South Lorain, Ohio, was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 13. -- Delegates to the Pan American Conference broke out in open rebellion against secrecy this morning and grave the conference its first really thrilling dramatic session.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- Governor Lehman returned to Albany tonight. As the Governor stepped into the waiting room of the station he was greeted by Mayor Thacher, who headed a group gathered to extend him a welcome.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13. -- Those Yale alumni who have been clamoring for a winning football team had an indirect assurance tonight from Malcolm Farmer, chairman of athletics, that there will be a new Yale football advisory committee.

The Yale Club gained another victory in the metropolitan league Class C squash racquets matches last night by defeating the Heights Casino team, 4 to 1, on the loser's court for its third victory thus far in Group 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The necessity for further large public works appropriations was being studied today as President Roosevelt again conferred with aids on the problem of reaching a balance of expenditures and income for the fiscal year 1935.

About 12,000 white-collar workers seeking jobs under the Civil Works Administration were registered at twenty-eight offices of the National Re-employment Service here yesterday. Many had waited all night. Many more flocked to the offices but were unable to register.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- As the session of Congress nears, the policy-makers of the New Deal are hopeful that they may have one more year's grace in which to work out the philosophy of NRA, AAA and the other recovery agencies. If they can have that, many of them feel certain they can erect in the United States an entirely reformed profit system.

After taking a toll of 52 lives in various sections of the United States and Canada, the cold wave that set in last Saturday appeared to have broken last night. The Weather Man promised milder temperature today, possibly with snow or rain.

Mario Chamlee, tenor, who was formerly a member of the Metropolitan and Ravinia Opera Companies, made his New York recital debut at the Town Hall last night. His program comprised songs in Italian, German, Spanish, French and English by Peri, A. Scarlatti, Schumann, DeFalla, Kochlin, Duparc, Levade, Myron Jacobson, Hardon Church and Blanche Hennion-Robinson.

H.O. King, Deputy Administrator of the NRA in charge of copper, held meetings yesterday with the representatives of the copper fabricating units. At the meeting in the morning, the independent fabricators assured Mr. King they were willing to buy as much copper as they could in order to help out the situation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The administration will ask Congress for appropriations of at least $5,375,000,000 at the coming session of Congress and the ultimate figure may be $6,000,000,000 or more.
Francis Warren Fershing, son of General John J. Pershing, will become a partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Weicker Co. on Jan. 2, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Two farmer boys and their mother, from Franklin, Idaho, arrived in Chicago today on their way to spend Christmas as the guests of Owen D. Young in New York.

Members of the entertainment committee interested in the performance of "Carmen" next Saturday night at the Hippodrome, which has been taken over in behalf of the Greenwich House Music School, met yesterday to complete plans for the benefit.

The tariff plan submitted by our delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo looks to the future. Secretary HULL himself says that it "calls for no treaties, conventions or legal commitments" at the present time. The United States is not in a position to participate immediately in any general reduction of " the existing high trade barriers " which the plan proposes ultimately to abolish.

Pleasurably excited, albeit slightly bewildered, little Catherine Hauslet, 7 years old, was restored to the arms of her father yesterday, to become a Lutheran again, after having been baptized into the Catholic faith by foster parents. Without grasping all of the legal and moral issues involved, Catherine, quite simply, was glad to be back with her father, William Hausler of Hicksville, L.I., and her two sisters, Gertrude, 16, and Jeanette, 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Clarification of the Securities Act by Congress to dispel confusion regarding certain sections is deemed necessary by President Roosevelt, but he opposes any weakening of the law.
Princess Djordjadze and Lady Orr-Lewis, who are sailing tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia, gave a dinner dance last night in the Louis XVI Suite of the St. Regis.

Support by the States of the National Recovery Act not only for its immediate emergency purposes but with a view to making provisions of the act permanent was urged yesterday by John G. Winant, Republican Governor of New Hampshire.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Players eligible to compete in the National Football League championship play-off between the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears Sunday at Chicago were announced today by Joe F. Carr, president of the league.

Paul Whiteman's conceit for the Church Mission of Help has sold out boxes and parquet at the Metropolitan for tomorrow night, but the committee still has cheaper seats available from fifty-cent gallery to $2.50 orchestra circle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- President Roosevelt, although anxious for world-wide tariff adjustments, believes that the immediate method is through bilateral treaties such as Secretary Hull advocated before the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo yesterday.

The granting of extraordinary powers to the President is "more ominous in some ways" than the acceptance of autafcratic government by Russia. Italy and Germany, Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, writes in the January issue of Foreign Affairs, published today.

With the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a fund of $4,000,000 for unemployment relief approaching its conclusion, the women's division of the committee yesterday surpassed its quota of $1,000,000.

Federal authorities moved swiftly yesterday against would be kidnappers and extortionists. Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, sitting in United States District Court in Manhattan, sentenced two youths who had sent threatening letters to Dr. Willard P. Beach, 1,789 Patterson Avenue, the Bronx, to five years in jail.

The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission yesterday issued regulations for the deer hunting season which will begin in that State on Monday. The season actually dates from Sunday but under New Jersey codes it is illegal to hunt on that day, hence the season will last only four days, until Dec. 21.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Delegates to the American Farm Bureau Federation's annual convention here today voted approval of the Roosevelt recovery measures for agriculture, including his stand on monetary changes. It wound up the convention by scoring the "profiteering" going on under the NRA and, urging the Farm Adjustment Administration to speed up increased income for farmers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Miss Cecily Fenwick, of England, the only foreign representative in the fourth annual women's Atlantic coast squash racquets championship, met defeat in a sensational upset in the final round today.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Dealings in German marks in the foreign exchange market here came to a standstill at one time today following the issuing by the Reichsbank of new regulations designed to check international speculation in the German currency.
BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The conflict between the Reich and the Vatican over the interpretation of certain articles of the concordat concluded last July has reached a stubborn impasse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The fears expressed by conservative New York artists that discrimination in favor of the modernists might be shown by the regional committees appointed to carry out the Civil Works, Art project, on which 2,500 artists are to be employed, are not shared by members of the advisory committee appointed to assist Assistant Secretary Robert of the Treasury and Forbes Watson, project director.

The New York Board of Trade deferred action yesterday on a proposed declaration of gold policy after an address by Frank A. Vanderlip in which the former head of tie National City Bank reiterated his confidence in the present monetary course of President Roosevelt.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Ambassador Sir Eric Phipps was urgently summoned to London from Berlin tonight, and until he arrives tomorrow afternoon the Cabinet has decided it can reach no positive conclusions regarding its next step in the conversations on disarmament that have been taking place between the British Foreign Office and several other capitals in Europe.

Prices continued easy yesterday in local commodity markets, although for the most part the range was narrow. Trading volumes continued on a reduced scale, with many operators preferring the sidelines. Cash prices again, were lower.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday in a range of 10 points, but ended at the top at gains of 3 to 8 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- As a result of defiance of the authority of the National Labor Board by large corporations and in order to strengthen the structure of the board, Senator Wagner will offer legislation in the next Congress giving it distinct legislative status.
VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- Austrian newspapers were completely gagged in the matter of political demonstrations and outrages by an order issued by Chancellor Dollfuss's department today.
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- The Boerse generally was firm today, particularly in the case of some specialties, such as cables, construction shares and a few public utilities.

Baseball's Pioneer Code. KENESAW MOUNTAIN LANDIS has been named for a third successive seven-year term as baseball czar by the National and American League members. Among those who hasten to congratulate the picturesque arbiter of the national game, will there be any spokesmen for the NRA idea?

Throttled with five feet of an insulated electric light cord ripped from a floor lamp, the body of an attractive 25-year-old brunette was discovered yesterday afternoon in the bedroom of her apartment at 255 West Ninety-third Street. She had been dead forty-eight hours.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Frank Patrick, managing director of the National Hockey League, took quick action tonight in an effort to reduce the growing demonstration of fisticuffs at professional hockey games.
Led "by Harry F. Wolf, the national champion, the New York A. C. Class A squash tennis team won its fifth successive match of the season last night to increase Its lead in the Metropolitan League.

Some sections of the money market developed a moderately easier tone, contrasted with the recent firmness. Outside call loans dropped to 3/4@7/8, but the official rate on the Exchange remained at 1 per cent. Offerings were heavy. In time money, the short dates, 60-90 days, yielded 1/4, business in these maturities going at 1 and 1 1/4.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- Beacuse Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck declined to rule immediately on the constitutionality of a rate reduction order of the Public Service Commission, Chairman Milo R. Maltbie today agreed to defer proposed cuts in gas and electric charges for New York City.

OSSINING, N. Y., Dec. 13. -- After permitting doctors to remove him from the death house to an operating table in the prison hospital, Ross Caccamise, 24 years old, who is awaiting execution for murder, today refused to give his consent to an emergency operation for acute appendicitis.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Warren Hildreth will give a dinner dance on Dec. 21 in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss Hope Hildreth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Legislation creating a Federal communications commission, with jurisdiction over all interstate and foreign communications by wire or radio, will be sought by the administration at the coming session of Congress.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 13. -- The Paraguayan delegation to the Pan-American Conference here announced today the capture of Fort Samaklay (also called Agua Rica), between Nanawa (Ayala) and Saavedra, indicating a Paraguayan drive on Fort Saavedra before the Bolivians tiave time to reorganize their defeated armies.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, has added to his English distinctions by being elected to membership in the Reform Club by the political committee of that old Liberal body.
