WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Federal Alcohol Control Administration today announced the allocation of 5,595,137 gallons of assorted liquors for immediate importation into the United States to help meet the overwhelming demand which has sent prices so high as to menace the new system of alcohol control.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13. -- Something new in diplomatic procedure -- at least as far as Soviet relations with other countries are concerned -- happened today when William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, presented his credentials to President Mikhail Kaliniu at noon in the Kremlin.

After deliberating more than six hours a jury in Federal court reported last night at 11 o'clock that it was "hopelessly divided" and could arrive at no verdict on the guilt or innocence of Ervin F. Brown, nephew of the late William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor under President Hoover.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the four-month period, Aug. 1 to Nov. 30, was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 1,979,302 tons, compared with 2.106,840 tons in the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills Nov. 30 totaled 1,342,640 tons, compared with 1,442,585 tons a year ago.

Many young women of society are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "The Lake" on the night of Dec. 27 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement to raise funds for that organization.
Fordham's basketball Quintet registered a decisive 52-to-20 triumph over a fighting St. Peter's College team last night before 1,000 spectators in the Ram gymnasium.

Articles of jewelry owned by Mrs. J. Walter Longcope, the former Mrs. Jesse L. Livermore, brought less than a fifth of their reputed cost when placed on the auction block at a forced sale yesterday to satisfy her creditors. The auction was held at 664 Fifth Avenue and will continue through Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A wave of strikes in hotels and restaurants in several parts of the country was threatened today on the eve of the NRA's new proposal for a restaurant code.

If necessary, Commissioner Bolan will put a policeman on every truck carrying legal liquor in order to prevent hijacking. He made the statement yesterday following the seizure of legal liquor valued at $20,000, the first hijacking since the repeal of prohibition.

The opera department of the Juilliard School of Music presented last night at the school a version of Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" in English wherein, during the four acts, spoken dialogue was frequently employed. While this is permissible enough and warranted by tradition, the effect last night was curiously to set off and separate the solos and concerted numbers.

Testimony that she had pawned a diamond ring for $3,000 with which to pay counsel fees for her father, Charles P. Doelger, was given yesterday by Miss Elaine L. Doelger, daughter of the vice president of Peter Doelger, Inc., a real estate company, at a bankruptcy hearing before Referee Irwin Kurtz at 15 Park Row.

Brooklyn Tech, defending champion in the P.S.A.L. hockey tournament, went into a three-cornered tie for first place yesterday with Erasmus Hall and Jamaica as a result of its triumph over Manual Training, 4-0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

Plans for "the greatest birthday party in American history" were announced yesterday by the National Committee for the Birthday Ball for the President. The newly formed committee opened a nation-wide movement to honor President Roosevelt on hia fifty-second blrthday, Jan. 30, by raising a permanent endowment fund for the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation for Infantile Paralysis at Presidential Birthday Balls "to be held in every community of the nation."

Negotiations were entered into yesterday between the Metropolitan Opera Association, the American Tobacco Company and the National Broadcasting Company on plans to broadcast the Metropolitan Opera productions this season under the commercial sponsorship of the cigarette manufacturer.

Debates in the House of Commons, like those in our own Congress, are often as dull as ditch water. But it seems probable that flashes of humor light up the darkness at Westminster Hall more frequently than they do at the Capitol at Washington. One of the recognized utterers of irreverent speech in the former place is WINSTON CHURCHILL.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- A weak technical position was disclosed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and selling by recent buyers caused an easy undertone from the start. Wheat never went above yesterday's final level and the close was 1 1/2 to 2 cents a bushel lower, the December showing the most decline.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13. -- The United States Government has taken precautionary measures to insure the maintenance of newsprint prices as set forth in the industry's NRA code and to protect against dumping.

The National Society of Mural Painters and John Sloan, president of the Society of Independent Artists, came to the defense yesterday of Federal Government's handling of the new Public Works Art Project, a national measure for the relief of artists.

The Tammany group in the Bronx, made up of supporters of Mayor John P. O'Brien in the recent election, are unwilling to stand up and be counted at the special election called for Dec. 28 to fill a vacancy caused by the retirement of State Senator Henry G. Schackno in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, who has been elected a City Court justice.
The Westchester County Golf Association announced yesterday that the amateur championship for 1934 had been awarded to the Bonnie Briar Club at Larchmont. The dates have not been decided on.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- The improvement in the French financial situation which followed the adoption of the budgetary proposals Sunday night by the Chamber of Deputies has assumed important proportions Based upon the supposition that the government will pursue the thorny path of financial readjustment to an ultimately satisfactory goal, the betterment, even if it be considered only temporary, gives striking evidence of the recuperative powers of the French financial structure.

"Wild Justice," the play by James Dale, a member of the cast in "The Green Bay Tree," has been acquired by Raymond Moore and is scheduled for Broadway presentation following Mr. Moore's production of "Whatever Possessed Her?" "Wild Justice," a melodrama set in an English village, had a successful run in London last season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- A brisk rally in which he collected 96 points in three innings today helped Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia to score his fifth straight victory in the world's pocket billiard title tournament. The triumph enabled him to stay in first place.

A vigorous rally in United States Government bonds featured yesterday an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange. In the domestic corporation list, utility issues showed better strength than did railroad and industrial obligations, while in the foreign loans German issues were especially weak.

Postal inspectors and the Brooklyn police united yesterday in efforts to solve an early morning robbery of stamps, money orders and blank postal savings certificates from the safe of the Gravesend post-office at Avenue U and West Fourth Street, Brooklyn.

A suit against the Bank of the Manhattan Company as the principal stockholder of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, aimed at forcing the bank to pay about $20,000,000 for the benefit of holders of mortgage certificates guaranteed by the title firm was filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Packers were aggressive buyers of hog's today and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight, closing at the top in one of the liveliest sessions in many weeks. There was less discrimination against light weights, and buyers in many instances took droves as they ran without sorting out the light kinds.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- The National Research Council listened yesterday to a report on cosmic rays by a scientific mission headed by Professor Bruno Rossi which had been sent some months ago to Asmara in the Italian colony of Erytrea in Africa.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 13. -- In one of the most exciting basketball games ever witnessed in this city, the C.C.N.Y. quintet defeated St. Thomas College of Scranton tonight. 40-35, before a large crowd in the Colonel Watres Armory.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 3 -- Robert A. Russell's Decorate showed marked improvement over his last race when he won by two lengths from W.G. Merion's Happy Message in the featured Berkeley Springs Purse at Charles Town tolay. Monastic was third.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Seven robbers carrying cold chisels and sledge hammers as well as pistols and shotguns invaded the safety deposit vaults in the old Unity Trust and Savings Bank at 3,909 West North Avenue, this afternoon, took five men prisoners and after working for more than three hours fled with the contents of 96 of the 335 boxes which they had smashed.

Jean Lureat, the French modernist, is having two one-man shows at the moment in New York. He is exhibiting oils at the Valentine Gallery and gouaches at the gallery of Pierre Matisse. All of this appears to be recent work.

An outline of suggested municipal recreation projects described as both needed and practical was presented yesterday to the City Federation of Women's Clubs at a forum meeting at the Hotel Astor. James V. Mulholland, supervisor of recreation of the Manhattan Park Department, stressed the need for increased facilities and put forward a series of developments for meeting recreation needs.
Athos Terzani, 31 years old, of 329 East Sixteenth Street, Manhattan, was acquitted in Queens County Court, yesterday of second degree murder.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: As one who favored repeal, may I voice my disgust at the ruthless way the liquor interests are grabbing for the profits of the bootleggers and cheating the consumer.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York refused to uphold a special committee in its recommendation that domestic water lines be operated free of Federal government regulation, precipitating a warm discussion of the rights of ships as opposed to motor truck and rail lines, at its monthly meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of the Merchants Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been much comment lately -- most of it adverse -- relative to large numbers of city employes asking for retirement on pension. The public has become aroused in the matter, but in its lack of information fails to get a true picture of the state of affairs.

Opera in four languages will make up the first week's programs of the Metropolitan Opera this season for the first time in the opera's history here, General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza announced yesterday. There will be presentations in English, German, Italian and French in the opening week that begins on Tuesday evening, Dec. 26, with "Peter Ibbetson."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Members of the Congressional tax-framing committees were described tonight as leaning definitely toward a distilled spirits tax of between $1.75 and $2 a gallon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Albert Bates, life termer, must stay in solitary confinement until he surrenders the fortune he collected in the kidnapping of Charles Urschel, Oklahoma oil man, Assistant Attorney General Joseph B. Keenan said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13. -- Harvard's varsity basketball team started its season auspiciously tonight as it defeated Boston University, 33 to 24, in the athletic building.
Columbia's football team received an indication yesterday of what type of offense Stanford will use when the teams clash in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., on New Tear's Day.

Harry Smythe, left-handed pitcher, has been purchased by the New York Yankees from the Baltimore Club of the International League and will report to Manager Joe McCarthy at St. Petersburg this Spring. The deal calls for the Orioles to receive an unnamed amount of cash and one player from the Yankees on option.

HAVANA, Dec. 13. -- Terminating a seven months' stay in Cuba as Ambassador of the United States, Sumner Welles left Havana by plane this afternoon for Miami. A huge crowd, composed of Cubans and Americans, gathered at the docks and gave him a tremendous ovation when he prepared to embark.
GLASGOW, Dec. 13. -- Jubilation spread through thousands of poverty-stricKen homes" along the Clyde today at the news that work on the Cunard liner 534 would be resumed.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 13 -- James A. Reed, outspoken Missourian in the United States Senate from 1911 to 1929, was married at a surprise wedding here tonight to Mrs. Nell Q. Donnelly, for whom he directed the search as her attorney at the time of her sensational kidnapping in 1931.

Football men, past and present, met at the Downtown A.C. last night to organize the Touchdown Club of New York, designed to bring together well-informed gridiron figures who will lend their influence and knowledge to the game. About 150 were present.

CHICAGO, Dee. 13. -- Hope for final settlement of the controversy over the reorganization of Armour Co. was seen here tonight following reports from New York that Frederick H. Prince of Boston had made a substantial investment in the common and preferred stocks of the packing concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- To hasten the employment of about 1,200 architects on the Historic American Buildings Survey in which he is interested, Secretary Ickes appointed a national advisory committee today to cooperate in formulating the plans and directing the project, which will be carried out under the Civil Works program.

PAUL WINDELS. Paul Windels, a life-long resident of Brooklyn, is 48 years old. He is a graduate of Columbia University and Brooklyn Law School. He was a delegate to the Republican National Conventions in 1920, 1924 and 1928.

Another in the series of entertainments in behalf of various philanthropic enterprises throughout the city was held last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. It was called Pomp and Circumstance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Baseball's trade winds, unleashed yesterday with history-making fury as Connie Mack broke up his once unbeatable Athletics combination, blew more noted stars helter skelter today.

The troubled process of installing a supply of wine and liquor in this city under legal supervision was attended yesterday by an investigation of alleged license graft and an announced intention of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to reconsider the one-year rule of previous operations by all applicants who wished to sell drinks for consumption on the premises.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Two directors were elected to the board of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Ltd., at a meeting of the board here today. They are D.W. Fraser, vice president of the American Locomotive Works, New York, and Colonel A. N. Jones, Halifax.

The Board of Education took steps yesterday to change the administrative and supervisory control of the city's public schools as recommended in the recent report of Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education.

LEIPZIG, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Five tired defendants in the Reichstag arson trial listened for ten hours today to a thundering prosecutor's summing up of the case against them and were led back to their jail cells without a hint of the punishment to be demanded for them.

New York's current crop of amateur boxers continued their quest for the Metropolitan Association's championships at Madison Square Garden last night. The second round of preliminaries and some quarter-finals were conducted. The stage thus was set for the semifinal and final battles that will conclude the tournament next Wednesday.

The monetary difficulties of the post-war period were not due to any intrinsic imperfection in gold as a standard, but rather to the mistakes that were made in re-establishing the gold standard after the war, according to Charles Rist, a leading French economist associated with the Bank of France, who discusses "Gold and the End of the Depression" in the current issue of Foreign Affairs.

Most of the domestic speculative markets pointed down yesterday, but for the most part the declines were small and operations were conducted largely by professional traders. On the Stock Exchange, where the volume was even lighter than on the day before, the net losses in representative issues averaged a little less than a point.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Voluntary revision of the Ottawa agreements is understood to be the purport of the private conversations which Walter Elliot, Minister of Agriculture, is now holding with representatives of the dominions In London. According to The Daily Mail, the main object of the talks is a further restriction of importations of empire beef and dairy products.
Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia announced yesterday his selections for six important cabinet posts.

Results of a seven-year fact-finding study of productive work, based on data of twelve billion man-hours in every major industry all over the country, the greatest amount of man-hour data so far compiled were presented last night at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the Society of Industrial Englneers at 22 East Thirty-eighth Street by Dr. L.P. Alford, consulting engineer, and Joshua E. Hannum, editor of "The Engineering Index Service."
Mayor O'Brien has paid into the city pension fund only $28,000 of the $144,000 reserve set aside to provide for his annual pension of $14,933, examination of the pension records disclosed yesterday.
A new wrinkle was introduced in lawn tennis yesterday when the Professional Lawn Tennis Association came out with two national rankings of the players under its jurisdiction.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr. has resigned as vice president of the General Motors Corporation to become vice chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, effective on April 1, 1934, it was announced yesterday. He will fill the vacancy caused by the recent advancement of William J. Filbert to chairmanship of the finance committee, effective on Jan. 1.

The award of the Edison Medal for 1933 to Dr. Arthur E. Kennelly, Professor Emeritus of Electrical Engineering at Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. Dr. Kennelly was Thomas A. Edison's chief electrical assistant from 1887 to 1894.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Senator Thomas of Oklahoma was informed today by James H. Rand Jr., chairman of the Committee for the Nation, that the administration was negotiating with the Bank of England and the Bank of France for stabilization of the dollar at about 62 cents.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Colqnel Charles A. Lindbergh announced tonight he would lift his big red-and-black monoplane ficom Port of Spain Harbor between. 6 and 7 o'clock tomorrow morning and start for Puerto Rico.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 13. -- The Fan-American Conference appeared headed tonight in the general direction taken by the London conference. On economic subjects there seemed to be a hopeless disagreement among the delegations.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The merger of the Cunard and White Star Lines is so nearly achieved that the British Government today pledged itself to help complete Cunard's 73,000-ton superliner 534, now half finished on the stocks at Clydebank, Scotland.

In the January number of Foreign Affairs ex-President LOWELL of Harvard has a judicious and thoughtful article on "The Present Crisis in Democracy." Anything written on so vast a subject " must be fragmentary and superficial," he modestly says. He will touch on only a few obvious points, but his remarks are full of suggestion and, to our mind, of encouragement.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 13. -- Including on their list about twenty members of the younger set, Mr. and Mrs. A. Kinnaird Tod entertained today with a tea at their residence, the Bandbox.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 -- The longest and shortest prices of the meeting were paid at Jefferson Park today, when Gold Ridge won the sixth race at $201.80 for $2, and Zekiel captured the fifth at 3 to 10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Austrian Government has taken advantage of its debt pact with the United States to postpone a payment of $460,093 due Jan. 1 until Jan. 1, 1944, Acting Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

FORT WORTH, Dec. 13 (AP) -- E.J. Cox, one-time spectacular oil promoter, and V.T. Bolin pleaded guilty to a mail-fraud charge in Federal court here today in the promotion of a mining scheme in Mexico.

Ninety-six awards have been made to members of five Manhattan College Fall sports units, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. The varsity, freshman and 150-pound football teams, and the varsity and cub cross-country squads were honored.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Warm commendation of the manner in which the State's program for rehabilitation of mortgage companies is being carried on by George S. Van Schaick was expressed today by Governor Lehman.

The State Civil Works Administration granted the Long Island State Park Commission $135,000 for purchase of materials and equipment ten days ago, it was learned yesterday following announcement by Robert Moses, president of the commission, that 2,500 workers would have to be discharged Saturday because of lack of funds for this purpose.

Through a slight miscalculation the 290,000th copy of Hervey Allens four-pound novel, "Anthony Adverse," came from the presses yesterday while the specially bound 275,000th volume was being "christened." The "christening party" was held at the printing plant of the H. Wolff Estate, 508 West Twenty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Wholesale commodity prices began rising again last week, increasing about three tenths of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Speaker Rainey and Representative Byrns. House Democratic leaders, predicted today that while Congress probably faces a critical session when it convenes on Jan. 3, President Roosevelt would retain his legislative control.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13. -- The Yale hockey team conquered the Boston University sextet in the Arena tonight by 3 to 1, all the goals coming in the final period of play. Robinson, of the victors, was the first to net the puck. Mills and Colby also counted for the Elis, while Lax made the losers' goal.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 13 -- Clarence L. Marks Jr., Dartmouth senior, who has been missing since Sunday, was sought today by his parents, college authorities and police.

More than 4,000,000 of the nation's unemployed have, been returned to work and more than 4,000,000 others are now being employed on public projects, Grover A. Whalen, local NRA Administrator, said last night at a dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- Declaring American retailing now faced two needs, a new deal and a brain trust, I.A. Hirschmann, New York advertising man, called today for a "whole-hearted revision of attitude, a whole-hearted housecleaning of ancient ideas and antiquated practices" in stores.

Charges, that the local union of the American Federation of Musicians was illegally Interfering with his business were made in the Supreme Court yesterday by Michael Saks, owner of the Second Avenue Theatre. Saks obtained an order directing Local 802, Louis Welshman, a member of its governing board, and S. Mendelson, a drummer, to show cause today why they should not be restrained from interfering with him in discharging Mendelson for incompetence.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The firm of Ratsey Lapthorne of New York and Gosport, England, has begun to make the sails for Tom Sop-with's America's Cup challenger, the Endeavour. The same company made the sails for the Shamrock V, the late Sir Thomas Lipton's last challenger for the historic trophy.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 13 -- Zoltan Mesko and Count Alexander Festetis, leaders of rival Hungarian Nazi sections, attacked Premier Goemboes in Parliament today for an anti-Nazi statement in a speech yesterday at a meeting of the Governmental party.

The property at the northeast corner of Broadway and 174th Street, known as 4,120-24 Broadway and running through to Wadsworth Avenue, was purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Bank of United States, in liquidation.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 13 -- Jockey Jack Westrope brought home two winners at Epsom Downs today to run his total for the year to 292. It was the ninth consecutive day in which Westrope has ridden at least two triumphant mounts.

The Fund for the Neediest Cases still lags far behind the amount given by this time last year. But a stiffening of the determination to bring it up so that it will care for the greatest possible number of the distressed in this year of unprecedented need was evident in the contributions received yesterday.

Frank J. Fulton, 58 years old, former cotton broker and oil and shipping company executive, jumped from a window of his apartment on the sixth floor of 30 Beekman Place early yesterday and was killed. His body, clad in pajamas, was found in the rear courtyard.

WESTFORT, Conn., Dec. 13. -- Charged with sending blackmail and threatening letters to Gustavus Pfeiffer of Easton, owner of Hudnut Perfumery Company of New York City, Ernest Schnack, 28, of Stratford, was arrested last night by State police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Woodrow Wilson and Mrs. William Howard Taft attended today the first of the season's musicales given by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Security issues totaling more than $21,500,000, of which more than $12,000,000 pertains to new capital, are provided for in ten registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Shares of stock of certain mortgage-loan companies, which are obtaining loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in order to relend the proceeds to local industries and mercantile businesses, are exempt from registration under the Securities Act, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

The New York Stock Exchange incorporated a new section on stock options in the final printing of the application of the National Distillers Products Corporation for the listing of its new no-par value stock, it was announced yesterday. Under this section, corporations are being asked whether they know of any options on either unissued or issued shares in their own hands or in those of brokers or others.

Sales Now Xmas Trade Factor. Major retail interest yesterday centred on the extent to which clearances and special sales of gift items may be a factor during the nine shopping days remaining until Christmas. Many stores, both here and out-of-town, have adhered to the view that clearances should he held off to as late a date as possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Woodrow Wilson and Mrs. William Howard Taft attended today the first of the season's musicales given by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Security issues totaling more than $21,500,000, of which more than $12,000,000 pertains to new capital, are provided for in ten registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Shares of stock of certain mortgage-loan companies, which are obtaining loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in order to relend the proceeds to local industries and mercantile businesses, are exempt from registration under the Securities Act, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

The New York Stock Exchange incorporated a new section on stock options in the final printing of the application of the National Distillers Products Corporation for the listing of its new no-par value stock, it was announced yesterday. Under this section, corporations are being asked whether they know of any options on either unissued or issued shares in their own hands or in those of brokers or others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Applications for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by 7,260 banks not affiliated with the Federal Reserve System had been made up to noon yesterday, Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the corporation, announced today.

Sales Now Xmas Trade Factor. Major retail interest yesterday centred on the extent to which clearances and special sales of gift items may be a factor during the nine shopping days remaining until Christmas. Many stores, both here and out-of-town, have adhered to the view that clearances should he held off to as late a date as possible.

A suit against Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, sculptor, and Mrs. Juliana R. Force, for many years her art secretary, for a balance of $25,466 alleged to be due in connection with a contract for a statue of Eleonora Duae, Italian actress, to be designed by Mrs. Whitney, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court here.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 4. -- Secretary Hull's announcement of a change in the United States tariff policy and of President Roosevelt's disavowal of international bankers was declared today at the Pan-American Conference to be the most important development of the gathering.

In the early days of "wireless," skeptics were arguing that the striking success of a certain young MARCONI in sending telegraphic messages through space had its limitations. Never would it be possible to send signals across the Atlantic. These wireless rays were a form of invisible light, and light always travels in straight lines.

The Union League Club adopted a resolution last night at a meeting at 250 members charging the Democratic party with a betrayal of trust because of President Roosevelt's gold policy and demanding an immediate return to the gold standard.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Eastern holders of wheat started to liquidate relatively small lines today on the B of Trade and found the market poorly supported, an early bulge of about 1 cent weakening the technical position. The close was at net losses of 1 1/2 cents a bushel for the December and 3/8 to 5/8 cent for the distant futures.

Three officers of the Belfair Cleaners, Tailors, Furriers, Inc., the main office of which is said to be at 3,548 Park Avenue, were held in $2,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Greenspan in Morrisania Court. They were charged with grand larceny and will have a hearing on Dec. 26.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Declaring a belief that the Weirton Steel Company was "about to commit a deliberate violation of Federal laws," General Johnson tonight warned the company's head that his defiance of the National Labor Board was endangering his right to the Blue Eagle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Directors of the International Harvester Company elected today as president Addis E. McKinstry to succeed Alexander Legge, who died a week ago. For two years Mr. McKinstry had been first vice president and next in command to Mr. Legge.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Herb Pennock, veteran New York Yankee pitcher, received with a philosophical attitude today the news of his unconditional release, but at the same time he expressed the belief he is not "through" with baseball.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange coincided with changes in other markets yesterday and after frequent rallies quotations ended with losses of 3 to 5 points.

After having been locked up all night in the Hotel McAlpin in spite of repeated assertions that it was unable to agree, a jury in Federal court yesterday convinced Judge Grover M. Moscowitz of Brooklyn, sitting temporarily in this district, that it could not arrive at a verdict.

CANTON, Dec. 14. -- After two days of conferences, Nanking's delegation has received no assurances from the Cantonese leaders that they will come to Nanking, but only a promise "to think over the request after the delegation leaves."

The North German Lloyd Company, which borrowed $20,000,000 here in 1927 through the sale of 6 per cent bonds, due in 1947, to build the steamers Bremen and Europa, announced to bondholders yesterday a plan whereby it will reduce the coupon rate to 4 per cent.

J. Lehrenkrauss Sons of 359 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, against which a petition in bankruptcy was filed last week, built a $55,000 Garden City home for Charles Lehrenkrauss, member of the banking house, Mr. Lehrenkrauss testified yesterday at an inquiry into the company's affairs before Louis R. Bick, special commissioner, in Brooklyn Federal Building.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Miss Sarah Morgan Gardner, daughter of Mrs. Henry B. Gardner of Princeton, was formally presented to society this evening at a reception and dance given for her by her grandmother, Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan, in her home, Constitution Hill.

Stockholders of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation approved yesterday the sale of the company's marketing outlets in the Far East and adjoining areas to the new Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, whose stock is owned equally by Socony-Vacuum and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- The major leagues today voted to adopt a uniform ball as a climax to one of the most important series of meetings in baseball history.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to Berlin, returned to London today for a consultation with Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, concerning the diplomatic conversations now proceeding in various capitals on the disarmament situation.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- A scathing attack on General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister and Prussian Premier, for his utterances during the Reichstag fire trial was delivered editorially by The London Times today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Rejecting a compromise settlement, the Federal Government has set out to collect tax claims against Charles E. Mitchell, former head of the National City Bank of New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Mayor Jasper McLevy, Socialist, announced at City Hall today that he would appear in Superior Court on Dec. 22 to protest the $20,000 fee asked by George S. Foster of this city as receiver for the closed American Bank and Trust Company and the Commercial Bank and Trust of Bridgeport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Time stood still and even briefly turned backward for several of the 300 men and women who attended the opening of the two-day sale at auction of the household effects of Admiral and Mrs. George Dewey this afternoon.

Champions of yesterday and today in sports and notables in other fields of endeavor assembled at the Hotel Astor last night for the all-America sports dinner staged by John Hay (Jock) Whitney for the benefit of a coal fund for the needy.

The $250,000 jewelry collection of Mrs. J. Walter Longcope, the former Mrs. Jesse L. Livermore, continued to trickle away under the auctioneer's hammer during the second day of the forced sale being held at 664 Fifth Avenue.
The fund for the Neediest Cases held its own yesterday as old and new contributors rallied to check the drop in this year's giving.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- The Princeton hockey team scored its second successive victory of the season in Baker Rink tonight, downing the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York, 2-1, in a fast, hard-played game.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- In his first public address since going to Washington as monetary adviser to the President, Professor James Harvey Rogers emphasized tonight the possible vast stimulus to recovery resulting from the "gold profit" to be made from devaluation.

The American Radio Telegraphers Association, comprising virtually all radio operators on American ships, last night voted a strike against the American Merchant Line, a subsidiary of the International Mercantile Marine. The vote was unanimous and followed efforts by the wireless men to obtain restoration of a 25 per cent wage cut on ships of this line.

A mid-city consolidation of various welfare organizations is to take place next March 1 in Rockefeller Center, where two floors of the RCA Building have been leased by the National Health Council, together with fifteen constituent and allied units in medical and other welfare work.

The Protestant Episcopal Church is faced by a deficit at least 5300,000 for the year 1933, it was said yesterday at a meeting of the National Council of the church in the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue.

DANNEMORA, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP). -- An escaped inmate of Dannemora State Hospital for Insane Criminals, stumbling through a night of zero weather after shooting a pursuer, sought refuge in a farmhouse early today and was captured there by State police.

Wall Street brokers found a simple and innocent explanation yesterday for the mystery surrounding the "leak" which is alleged to have enabled London each day to obtain the RFC's purchasing price for newly mined gold several minutes before the Treasury Department's official announcement readied England.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Charles Minot Amory gave a beach luncheon today for members of his house party including Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld, Captain Richard Cooper of London, who arrived from New York this morning, and Prince George of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil at the close of the week ended Dec. 9 amounted to 342,847,000 barrels, a decrease of 687,000 barrels under the total of 343,534,000 reported for the preceding week, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Administrator of the Code of Fair Competition for the Petroleum industry, announced today.

The American Highway Freight Association has protested to the American Iron and Steel Institute against alleged discrimination by the steel producers against motor truck operators and in favor of railroads. Directors of the institute are studying the protest, but have not reached a decision, it was said yesterday.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 11. -- L. Haymaker's Slipper King just got up to win by a nose from the Argosy Stable's Bongo in the six and a half furlongs of the featured Front Royal Purse at Charles Town today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14. -- Expressing "surprise" at the telegram from General Johnson, Mr. Weir announced tonight that he had talked with the recovery chief a few minutes before the administrator's telegram reached him this afternoon.

W.H. Davis, Deputy Administrator of the NRA, announced last night that a code of ethics for the water transportation industry would be ready by Jan. 1. It will be sufficiently flexible to permit adjustments to suit actual conditions in the industry, he said.

The twelve-story apartment building at 817 West End Avenue, at the southwest corner of 100th Street, and the Hotel Montague in Brooklyn were two of the chief properties figuring in auction sales yesterday.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday. United States Government bonds closed 9-32 point lower to 2-32 point higher, easing slightly as a whole in sympathy with the weakness in the dollar. All groups of domestic corporation issues averaged moderately higher on the day.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- The Bank of France's statement today for the week ended Dec. 8 showing that the loss of gold dropped to 293,000,000 francs reinforced a growing conviction among Frenchmen that the latest "Battle of the Franc" has been won.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 14. -- From the avalanche of proposals poured into the seventh Pan-American Conference by its ninety-four delegates from twenty countries, several projects are gradually assuming concrete form in subcommittees, and some of them may emerge as definite accomplishments at this conference.

The movement for social insurance as a solution for the problem of the high cost of medical care is gaining headway in "the United States, it was said in an interview at the Hotel Chatham yesterday by Dr. Alexander Bruno, director of the "Saranac Village Sanatorium of the French Alps," at 4 Chamonix, France, and founder of the American Medical Centre of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained tonight, in honor of the Chief Justice and the Associate Justices of the Supreme Court, with the second of the State dinners on their official program. Associate Justice and Mrs. Brandeis were the only absentees.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia won his sixth straight game and increased his lead in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight when he defeated Ralph Greenleaf of New York, defending champion, 125 to 30, in 10 innings.

A thorough house cleaning in the city Department of Hospitals as well as other departments, and an attack on the problem of over-crowded city hospitals, were pledged yesterday for the new city administration by Paul Blanshard, named to be Commissioner of Accounts by Mayor-elect LaGuardia.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- Governor Lehman, back at his desk today after an absence of two months, during which he recovered from an operation for appendicitis, found his office filled with flowers, the gift of his office staff. During the day State officials came in to welcome him back to Albany.

A more liberal policy on the part of the New York Stock Exchange in respect to public relations was described yesterday as taking shape as a result of meetings between the board of governors and a committee representing the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities operator, must leave Greece by Jan. 1, it was stated on behalf of the government tonight.

After all these syncopated years the heart of America is going to begin beating again in temperate, three-quarters time, if the ninety-six dancing masters of the New York State Division of the National Institute of Social Dancing can possibly arrange it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- In this article I shall consider the influence on prices that we can expect to be exerted by the depreciating dollar.

Ivan Bunin, this year's winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, has a 12,000-word story in the January issue of Story, his first new work published here since he won the $40,000 prize. Harrison Smith and Robert Haas are to publish a volume of his short stories, using more than a dozen that were sent here to Whit Burnett, editor of Story, some months ago.

Professor Raymond Moley, former Assistant Secretary of State, told an audience at Columbia University last night that the internationalist views of his erstwhile chief, Cordell Hull, were out of harmony with the national economy of the "New Deal."

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Lord Rutherford and other outstanding figures of British science suggested tonight that the new name "diplogen" be given to the heavy hydrogen recently discovered in the United States, and that another new name, "diplon," be given to its nuclear unit.

A somewhat different picture of an old Yale Blue looking over the perplexing football situation at New Haven is presented by Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, an end of more than two decades ago, bracketed in the memory of veterans with Yale's immortals, Frank Hinkey and Tom Shevlln.

The Annalist's index of business activity declined 3.2 points for November, the preliminary index being 69.2, against 72.4 for October, 89.5 for August, the high for the year, and 64.7 for November, 1932. The decline since July has now canceled 20.3 points of the March-July rise, the November index showing 10.7 points net above the low of March.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes has placed the name of Richard A. Bonnell Jr., former salesman for a Chicago engineering firm, as the second on the list of those persona non grata to the Public Works Administration.

Music teachers who encourage pupils with little talent were attacked yesterday by Edward Johnson, Metropolitan Opera tenor, in an address at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street. He spoke at a meeting of the committee in charge of the performance of "Carmen," to be given tomorrow night at the Hippodrome for the benefit of the school.

The merchant shipping policies of the United States were defended yesterday by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, in reply to British critics who have addressed private and public groups in the last ten days, hinting that Great Britain would undertake "retaliatory" measures to win trade to British ships.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 14. -- By swift attacks and marches the victorious Paraguayans in the Chaco had brought themselves tonight to the chief base of the Bolivian Army there.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Warden Lawes of Sing Sing prison said today the law allows prison authorities to perform a vitally important operation on a convict against the patient's wishes, but that such action would not be taken against Ross Caccamise, 24 years old, of Rochester, N.Y., who refused to permit surgeons to remove his appendix yesterday.

Settlement of 195 specific complaints against retailers was announced yesterday by the New York Retail Code Authority following a meeting at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway. Grover A. Whalen, local NRA administrator and chairman of the Retail Code Authority, presided.

The American Federation of Arts announces the near realization of a projected series of weekly radio broadcasts on the arts in America over a nation-wide network. This announcement appears in the December issue of The American Magazine of Art, just out.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Nazi zealots who sought to restrain "non-Ayran" shops from decorating their holiday show windows and business quarters with such "Christian symbols'' as stars, angels and Christmas trees have been severely frowned on by the Reich Ministry of Economics.
OTTAWA, Dec. 14. -- Flashing the form that won them the Stanley Cup last season the New York Rangers defeated the Ottawa Senators tonight, 4 to 3, in a fast National Hockey League game.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 (AP). -- George M. Humphrey, director and chairman of the executive committee of the National Steel Company, which owns the Weirton Steel Company, issued the following statement today on the controversy:

For a time yesterday the share market seemed about to fulfill the rosy forecasts which have been appearing of late with increasing frequency. Stocks of every description advanced sharply, even buoyantly, in the forenoon. But something went wrong around mid-day and the market began to give up its gains.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- Completing the circle of diplomatic conversations that are being busily pursued in Europe, Dr. Eduard Benes, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, arrived in Paris today on an official visit.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 14 (By Wireless). -- The icebergs we have sighted, which appeared to be more than a quarter of a mile long, with rugged surfaces, are my first contact with the Antarctic, and I am thrilled.

The fight in which Primo Carnera won the world's heavyweight championship netted the Italian boxer exactly $360, according to a statement made by Max Rockmore, one of his counsel, yesterday in a bankruptcy hearing before Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. at 19 Rector Street.

Dry Goods Jobbers More Active. Dry goods wholesalers showed a little more interest in the primary markets during the week and picked up a few fair-sized quantities, they reported yesterday. Prices, in general, showed more strength and there was less tendency on the part of mills to dump goods before year-end inventory taking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- John Hamilton, one of the gang of killer bandits who escaped on Sept. 26 from the Indiana penitentiary at Michigan City, today shot and killed Sergeant William T. Shanley, veteran detective squad leader.

Francis X. McQuade, who resigned in 1930 as a city magistrate, and was appointed an Assistant Corporation Counsel last month, had a right to apply for a retirement allowance of $6,000 a year six days later, it was decided yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Authorizations and advances by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation shot up in October to $643,118,403, as compared with only $95,009,511 in the previous month, as that organization expanded its help in financing the administration's recovery program.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14. -- There were three odds-on choices at Jefferson Park today. Two won, but Kyso, 7-to-10 chance in the featured race, was beaten by a length at the end of six furlongs. Tony Pascuma had the leg up on the favorite, which races for J.J. Robinson, but could not hold him together long enough to save the day.

HONOLULU, Dec. 14 (AP). -- A supplement entitled "Dream of War Between the United States and Japan" which was inserted in a Japanese magazine caused the seizure within the past week of 5,000 copies of the publication imported from Japan, it was announced today by Walter Doyle, Collector of Customs.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reports a consolidated net income of $403,088 for the third quarter of 1933, contrasting with a deficit of $1,125,275 for the same part of 1932. Net income of $211,940 was reported for the second quarter of 1933, following a net loss of $854,251 for the first quarter.

An unusually large and distinguished audience is expected at the Paul Whiteman concert tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House, for all of the boxes and large blocks of seats have been sold to members of society. The net proceeds will be given to the Church Mission of Help, an Episcopalian agency for the relief of unfortunate girls.

The Harvard Club's No. 1 team maintained a perfect score in the Metropolitan Class A squash racquets tournament as the result of a 4-to-1 victory over the Princeton No. 1 team yesterday on the Harvard court. The team now has won six matches and lost none.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- The French Government has assessed American companies in France nearly 2,000,000,000 francs ($122,650,000 at the current rate) covering taxes due under the double taxation law, despite the signature of an agreement abolishing this form of taxation by the United States Ambassador and Premier Tardieu in the Spring of 1932.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- State Finance Commissioner John Colt of Princeton, who is serving without pay as director of emergency relief, recommended to Governor Moore today that when the Emergency Relief Act expires Jan. 31 provision be made for a full-time salaried director, with a non-salaried administrative council of seven members.

Frederick J. Werner, former Brooklyn school teacher, will contend that he was insane when he embarked on a reckless series of swindles that caused fifty victims losses of $200,000. This was indicated yesterday when his counsel asked County Judge McLaughlin in Brooklyn to permit Werner to change his plea on six indictments charging grand larceny from "not guilty" to "not guilty on grounds of insanity."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- If the liquor-taxation sentiments of members of the Ways and Means Committee can be taken as a criterion, representative from the dry sections of the United States will be in the forefront of the movement to put into the hands of citizens aged whisky at no more than $1.50 a quart.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT (En Route to the Antarctic), Dec. 14. -- The thick fog which encircled the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition yesterday began to lift today and by afternoon had thinned into a haze.
The appointment of substitute day high school teachers to fill regular teaching positions, of which there are 1,576 vacancies, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14. -- The quota of 5,580,590 gallons of liquor which has been allotted to Canada for export to the United States for four months represents about 13 1/2 per cent of the supply available for export. At present about 40,000,000 gallons of matured liquor are held by Canadian distilleries, but this is not all of the American type.

Frederick H. Prince of Boston confirmed yesterday reports that he had acquired a substantial stock interest in Armour Co. of Illinois and that he would in a day or two go to confer with the management in Chicago with a view of working out a constructive program to insure the company a full share of the general improvement in business, which he believes is under way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Gold purchases by the United States will continue indefinitely, Stephen T. Early, assistant secretary to the President, announced today on behalf of Mr. Roosevelt, following an extended White House conference participated in by four of the President's chief fiscal advisers.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- Irvin (Ace) Bailey, dangerously injured Toronto hockey player, came through a long and delicate trepanning operation on his fractured skull in encouraging condition tonight in the neuro-surgical ward of the Boston City Hospital.
"He walked right in, and turned around, and walked right out again."

Bruno Walter met his Thursday night audience for the last time this season at Carnegie Hall last night as he began his eleventh week With the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra rose for him as he entered and the applause was warm and prolonged throughout the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The Federal Alcohol Control Administration intimated today that permission might be granted to import the entire quantity of American types of rye and bourbon whiskies stored in Canada, totaling 20,000,000 to 25,000,000 gallons, if this was needed to lower liquor prices in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Millions of sportsmen and sportswomen throughout the world will be cheered by the news that the Marylebone Cricket Club received a cablegram tonight from Australia indicating that the malcontents on the cricket board of control there have capitulated in the bodyline bowling controversy.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 14. -- A special economic committee of the Pan-American Conference resumed debate late today on the tariff declaration of Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, for a downward revision. His proposal has been altered so that it is believed all delegations may sign it.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14. -- The deep gratification of the Soviet Government and public for Ambassador William C. Bullitt's speech yesterday to President Kalinin was expressed today in an editorial in the Izvestia, which is the official organ of the Soviet Government.
Police Commissioner Bolan put a ban yesterday on radio-equipped taxicabs.

Objections to an accounting by the Empire Trust Company as substitute trustee in the $10,000,000 estate of Matthew Byrnes have been filed by Ida Von Claussen, through her attorney, Robert H. Law Jr. of 7 East Forty-second Street, it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 14. -- As usual, the youthful apprentice Jack Westrope stole the spotlight at Epsom Downs, where he scored another triple today. Although he shared riding honors with Earl Porter, who also accounted for a triple, Westrope ran his victories for the year to 295.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Lieut. Col. Walter Buller, bridge critic, made a vigorous attack today upon the quality of the game in the United States and upon Ely Culbertson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,667,000,000, an increase of $64,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $473,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

The national skate-sailing championship will be determined at three regattas in February, according to the schedule released yesterday by W. Van B. Claussen, secretary of the Skate-Sailing Association of America. Clarence W. Capes of Brooklyn, national champion for six years, will defend his title.

For the second time this year monthly production of new life insurance has run ahead of 1932, according to figures sent to the Department of Commerce yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents for November. The only other month this year that has run ahead of 1932 was August.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia indicated yesterday that he would announce his choice for Police Commissioner tomorrow. Intimates of the Mayor-elect understood that he had selected Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan for the post.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- The Boerse continued today the sagging trend which marked yesterday's closing, but the changes mostly were fractional, and in no case went beyond 2 points. Confident business reports and steadiness in the dollar and the pound sterling provided some resistance, and the turnover was very small.

Criticism of the national recovery program on the grounds that it is not sufficiently internationalistic in its aims and that it does not go far enough in correcting economic maladjustments, was voiced yesterday at a conference on the religious implications of the program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks gained two points on Detroit tonight in the struggle for the leadership of the National Hockey League's American Division, conquering the Wings, 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank of New York, conferred today with Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, in regard to the sale of preferred stock by his bank to the corporation.

New York welfare agencies are caring for many more homeless children this Winter than three years ago with incomes that have been reduced about two-thirds, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared yesterday in a radio appeal for contributions to the Crusade for Children.

CRESCENT CITY, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Ten children were killed and thirty were injured when a freight train crashed into a school bus at a grade crossing about six miles south of this place this morning. Four of the children fatally hurt were from a single family, that of Mrs. Bennie Smith, a widow.

The New York Association for the Blind spent more than $120,000 to assist and train the sightless and to carry on its preventive work in the year ended on Oct. 31. The report was made at the association's annual meeting yesterday afternooon at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

J. Edd Weir of Jamesport, L.I., member of the Timber Point Golf Club, was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association for 1934 at the annual meeting held at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club last night. He succeeds W. Neal Fulkerson Jr. of Cherry Valley, who has headed the Long Island body for the last two years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Reorganization of the fighting forces of the marine corps so as to put them directly under the commander-in-chief of the fleet was announced today at the Navy Department.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14. -- The discovery that the oxygen content of the air in the stratosphere at about 60,000 feet is about the same as that at earth level was reported today by Dr. Goltzman, a member of the Leningrad Academy of Science.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Criminal cases arising under the Volstead Act and left pending in Far Western States when the Eighteenth Amendment was repealed were invalidated today by a decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Securities issues aggregating $5,000,000, of which $3,000,000 relate to new capital enterprises, are provided for in registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today.

New York City renewed revenue bills yesterday to the amount of $195,562,000, offering the bondholders three-year renewal notes bearing an interest rate of 4 per cent, which represents a reduction from the older rates of 4 3/4, 5 and 5 3/4 per cent.

A flight such as Admiral Byrd is contemplating from the pack ice to the Ross ice shelf at Little America has never been attempted in that sector of the Antarctic, although numerous flights have been made from outside the pack to other parts of Antarctica.
The Board of Estimate will act today on additional, pension applications brought by John J. Dietz, Water Supply Commissioner, and other city employes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Westchester County's government will cost the taxpayers $6,501,950 in 1934, including $320,123 in State taxes, according to the budget for next year, which was submitted this afternoon to the Board of Supervisors. The total is an increase of $167,530 over the budget for 1933.

SOUTH CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 14. -- Bearing a grunshot wound in the right side and abdomen, the body of Richard J. (Rich) Glendon, coach of the Columbia crew, was found today in a bleak, snow-covered spot near an old ice house not far from the beach.

Idlewild Farm, 850-acre Connecticut estate of the late Jack Dunston, who was proprietor of the well-known Jack's Restaurant in New York, has been purchased by Titus S. Hose of New York, a dealer in old land royalties.

The annual report of the Secretary of Agriculture is anything but a routine document. It covers a period during which the Government's policies of farm relief have radically changed. Under the AAA, efforts are being made to restrict the production of wheat, cotton, corn, tobacco and other important crops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Six out of eleven European nations will pay the United States $8,898,123 tomorrow on a total December debt instalment of $152,952,637.

While all the figures have not been compiled as yet and probably will not be until after the first of the year, it is safe to say that fully as many persons procured hunting and fishing, licenses in New York State in 1933 as was the case in 1932, when the number went beyond 494,000.
Tony Canzoneri will meet Cleto Locatelli, European lightweight champion, in the main ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The match will mark the American debut of Locatelli.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Spencer Turner will give a dinner at the St. Regis on Dec. 22 for Miss Emily K. Du Moulin, daughter of Mrs. Prentice Strong.

Lucrezia Bori, the Metropolitan opera soprano, who headed the successful campaign for $300,000 to save the opera last Spring, returned to New York yesterday after a tour of 10,000 miles that became virtually a triumphal procession. Miss Bori was greeted by capacity houses and almost everywhere she was asked to speak about her work for the Metropolitan.

Assistant coaches, third-stringers, two players from Manhattan College and a former Georgetown star combined to give the Columbia football team a strenuous workout yesterday in the 105th Field Artillery Armory. Coach Lou Little plans to give the Lions a great deal of heavy work before they leave on Tuesday to meet Stanford on New Year's Day in Pasadena, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- President Roosevelt's gold-buying policy might not affect the price of some raw materials for "a year or even several years," Secretary Wallace warned today, in urging the farmer to place his main reliance in proper adjustment of supply to demand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- One of the biggest air shows ever staged will be put on here Saturday afternoon by the army, navy and marine air services, in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the Wright brothers' first flight in a heavier-than-air machine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Coming from behind in the second half, after its rival had assumed a 26-to-18 lead, the Catholic University quintet defeated Duke tonight, 33 to 31. Jim Thompson scored 20 points for Duke.

The New York Americans had a lead of 3 to 1 over the Boston Bruins last night, but could not win. The charging Boston aggregation, fighting desperately when things looked most discouraging, sent a ceaseless bombardment into the Simpson skaters' zone.

More than 6,500 persons -- about 2,900 of them widows -- drawing upon police pension funds will not receive their regular semi-monthly allowance due today, it was said yesterday at police headquarters. The next scheduled payments are due after Christmas.

Mayor-elect LAGUARDIA'S first Cabinet appointments are an earnest of good things to come. They are all men of an independent type, accustomed to do their own acting as well as their own thinking, like their chief. If Mr. BLANSHARD has at times seemed to let his crusading zeal run ahead of his judgment, officeholding should sober him without diminishing one Whit his unquestioned abilities as an inquisitor.

Henry R. Kinsey, president of the New York State Savings Bank Association, praised the Roosevelt administration yesterday for improving the banking situation since March 4, but declared the deposit insurance measure which will become effective on Jan. 1 was "basically wrong" from the savings bank standpoint.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- George R. Dale, militant Mayor-editor, of Muncie, Ind., whose many legal and political battles have attracted attention, has received an unconditional pardon on a liquor conspiracy conviction.

HARDY souls who make up the ranks of the Chicago Bears and the New York Giants, professional football teams which have come to the point of deciding between themselves the national championship, will mingle in the game that decides that title on Sunday in Chicago. There is sure to be, as there has been all season where these teams are concerned, exciting competition.
Tristate champions for 1933 among pistol and rifle experts of the National Guard 'and Officers' Reserve Corps will be honored at military ceremonies to be held on Governors Island today at 11 A.M.

Senator HIRAM JOHNSON is in Washington, doubtfully contemplating a "realignment" of parties. A "social realignment" is now going on -- Mr. ROOSEVELT'S "human leveling program," which Mr. JOHNSON will follow "without yielding his independence." He observes, with perfect correctness, that the President "is in a singularly fortunate position."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman, disclosed today that the Reconstruction Corporation holds $51,780,500 of railroad loans which are classed as being in default.

With additional thousands registering for white collar jobs under the civil works administration and with the list of those already registered for civil works approaching 100,000, Travis H. Whitney, local civil works administrator, announced yesterday that his staff was working "night and day" to speed up the placement of unemployed in jobs.

FRANKLIN, Pa., Dec. 14. -- The body of Clark N. Witherup, 50-year-old Venango County oil operator, who was kidnapped from his Kennerdell oil lease on Saturday, was found last night in Clarion County, twenty miles from the lease.

A Moreland investigation of the State Insurance Department's administration of mortgage guarantee companies was ordered by Governor Lehman in Albany yesterday immediately after it had been requested by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, in a letter to the Governor.
BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler today assumed personal charge of Germany's preparations for the Olympic Game scheduled to take place in Berlin in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed in November was reported today by the Census Bureau at 475,368 bales of lint and 59,111 bales of linters, compared with 503,873 and 66,838 in October, and 502,434 and 56,963 in November, 1932.

The upward trend which real estate in general has shown during the past thirty days was very evident yesterday, when brokers were heartened by the sale of three large apartment houses and a high-class private dwelling. The sales involved many hundreds of thousands of dollars.

The dollar fell sharply in foreign exchange yesterday, losing nearly all the gains made earlier in the week on talk of stabilization. The currency was weak throughout the day, and closed at 62.36 per cent of par, the lowest point reached during trading, down 1.41 cents from Wednesday's final value at 63.77 per cent of par.

LEESBURG, Va., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Testimony that George Crawford, Negro, on trial for the murder of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley and her maid in January, 1932, boasted during an argument in Boston that he had killed two white women in Virginia, was given today in Loudoun County Circuit Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Continuation of the Civil Works Administration until such time as the 4,000,000 persons now employed thereby can find private employment, solution of the municipal default problem through Congressional action, an increase in the PWA fund of $2,000,000,000 and extension of credit to public bodies upon sound collateral, were urged today by the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors.

Although sugar and hides declined with the principal staples, all of the other commodities traded in futures markets here moved to higher levels yesterday, making the first general advance in several days. Trading was on a larger scale than it had been recently.

Further large purchases of bankers' bills in connection with the seasonal demands upon the money market were revealed in the Federal Reserve System's report for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday. The system's purchases this week amounted to $55,000,000, on top of purchases of $37,000,000 last week.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking to raise a fund of $4,000,000 for unemployment relief, will hold its final report meeting today at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The committee's campaign is scheduled to close tomorrow.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 14. -- Admiral Byrd is expected to beat Lincoln Ellsworth to the Antarctic by flying from his ship to Little America. When his expedition left port the Admiral said: "There will be no race, but we will get there first."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (AP). -- An "Independent Democratic ticket" composed of leaders pledged to "the elimination of Huey P. Long from Louisiana politics and the tyranny under which we live," was announced today for the January Mayoralty election.

Richard J. Glendon was, like his father before him, a New Englander and a man of the water, at the beginning of his life and at its close. Born in Boston in 1897, where his father, Richard A. Glendon, had come ashore after years spent at sea with mackerel fishing schooners, the younger Glendon, most often called "Young Dick" to distinguish him from his father, was in an atmosphere of rowing almost from birth.
A shortage of clothing for the destitute was reported yesterday among various private relief organizations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Reduction of rates and the prevention of speculative management and "watering of stocks" are among the chief reasons for government supervision and regulation of all communication services cited in the report to President Roosevelt by the Interdepartmental Communications Committee.

Two underworld figures, one wanted in another killing, were being sought last night by detectives investigating the murder of Mrs. Mary Pilasky Crishock, who was found strangled Wednesday in her apartment at 255 West Ninety-third Street.

The opening of the "Ziegfeld Follies," which was scheduled for the Winter Garden on Christmas night, has been postponed for at least a week. Instead, it will be shown at the Shubert Theatre in Newark during Christmas week. At present it is playing in Pittsburgh.

Resumption of the decline in dollar exchange was accompanied yesterday by conflicting movements in the domestic markets. Stocks advanced confidently for two or three hours in trading that was slightly more active than on the previous day, domestic corporation bonds moved upward as United States Government issues fell back, and the agricultural commodities worked irregularly lower.
Skyscrapers are good to throw things from. Elevator buttons a good to play with. Presidential suites have lots of matches. Paper knives make good daggers.

Sponsored in catalogue forewords by Thomas Craven and Sherwood Anderson, Valenti Angelo is presented to the New York art world through the current showing of his work at the Ferargil Galleries. Mr. Craven perceives a relationship between the work of this artist and that of Blake, Ryder and the Italian primitives.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Yale today announced the award of 115 athletic insignia, including 37 major Y's.

Dr. John F. Fitzgerald and Dr. F. F. Russell of thp Rockefeller Foundation are leaving tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa on their way to India. Arthur S. Vernay also is leaving for India on the ship to go tiger hunting in Nepal with Donald Stewart, Indian Forestry Officer.

The Eastern presidents conference will consider today a proposal made by W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, that the managements and labor unite on a national legislative program. If Mr. Atterbury's suggestions are accepted, the presidents will appoint a committee to confer on the subject with a like body appointed by the Railway Labor Executives Association.

LEIPZIG, Dec. 14. -- After summarizing the case for two whole days the prosecution in the Reichstag fire trial demanded today the death penalty for Ernst Torgler, former Communist floor leader of the Reichstag, and Marinus Van der Lubbe, the young Dutchman caught in the burning building on the night of Feb. 27.

Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne, who had been the subject of widespread and confused reports during the day which credited him with local embargoes on whisky and warnings against buying any blended or compounded whiskies, explained the situation last night authoritatively.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Official announcement that Malcolm Farmer, director of Yale athletics, will appoint a committe of alumni of the university to frame recommendations for next year's football program, including a coaching staff, was made tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Coming from behind in the last two minutes of play, the Providence College basketball team triumphed over the Yale quintet tonight, 35 to 32. The score was tied several times during the close and exciting battle.

A Double Ovation. Of the departure of Mr. SUMNER WELLES from Havana it might be said, as it was in a supposed flowery compliment to a Governor of South Carolina, "he took office with little opposition, and left it with absolutely none."
Health department agents shifted their operations yesterday to public drinking places and took samples of the bar whiskies to be tested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Support by the United States delegation to the Montevideo conference of the women equality in nationality treaty now pending before it was expressed today to Secretary Hull by Senators Wagner and Lonergan, Representatives Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts and Kahn of California, and by Dr. James Brown Scott, president of the American Institute of International, Law and of the American Society of International Law.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 15 -- A goal by Harry Hart, New York boy, early in the overtime period tonight enabled Brown University's hockey team to down Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 3 -- 2. The game opened the season for Brown.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee exceeded yesterday its goal of $4,000,000 which the committee had sought to raise for unemployment relief in this city, to be distributed through accredited welfare agencies. Actual contributions totaled $4,147,034.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 -- E.E. Crozat's 3-year-old gelding Done For just lasted to win by a head in the mile and seventy yard contest that held the feature position on the card at Jefferson Park today. The fast-closing Sister Zoe was second and Athol third.

ASBURY PARK. N.J., Dec. 15 -- John J. Berry, retiring president of the New Jersey State Association of Real Estate Boards, recommended to the seventeenth annual conven tion today at the Berkeley Carteret Hotel that radical changes be made in the government set-up of New Jersey to bring about improved conditions for the real estate business and the ownership of property.

Since Oct. 24, when it began operation, the Regional Labor Board has disposed of 171 industrial disputes, involving 21,087 workers, George W. Alger, chairman of the board, announced yesterday. Included in the settlements were 143 strikes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- General trade activity of encouraging volume in some sections of Canada was reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee were described today as being strongly inclined toward giving the President broad powers to enter bilateral trade agreements with liquor-importing countries but barring such agreements with nations delinquent in war debt payments.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's declaration on tariff policy was unanimously adopted today by the committee on new economic matters of the Pan-American Conference. It is the first major business to progress thus far.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Entrance of Frederick H. Prince of Boston into the affairs of Armour Co. is expected to begin a new era for the great packing house, which dates back to a family partnership started in 1863. He is known as a man who impresses himself on any enterprise of which he takes hold.
Several more companies announced yesterday plans for the resumption of dividends between the present time and the first week in January.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Now that the bodyline bowling dispute, which threatened to disrupt the historic cricket relations between England and Australia, has been settled officially, it remains to be seen whether it will crop out again during the forthcoming Aussies' tour of England, when they will seek to recover the mythical "ashes."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary Ickes today announced public works loans totaling $6,000,000 to two more railroads.

It is painful to read of further sharp differences among the professors who are advising the President. While he preserves an "open mind," they seem all the time on the point of breaking out into open warfare. The main difficulty seems to be that they are not content to consume their own smoke. In writings, in newspaper interviews, in speeches, over the radio, they are suffering, we respectfully submit, from too much publicity.

Investment bankers and brokers who wish to remain after Jan. 1 as directors of banks that are members of the Federal Reserve System must fill out comprehensive questionnaires covering every point where the compatibility of the two positions might be in doubt.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, revealed tonight in Halifax that Britain's budget was balanced and that at the end of the financial year next March there would be "a substantial surplus." He gave no hint to taxpayers as to what he was thinking of doing with the surplus.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The stories of possible flat-money inflation in the United States which reach us in Germany make us wonder if Americans know the terrible consequences of such a course. No one who went through inflation, here ten years ago can contemplate the prospect for America without dread and pity.

BARCELONA, Dec. 15 -- Whether American passports will in the future admit United States citizens to Majorca or any other of the Balearic isles is a question being studied by the American Consulate General today in view of the drastic decree just issued by the government with the authority of the President of the republic.
