The City's Independent Subway System carried 13,681,018 passengers in November, or 416,235 more than in October, according to a report made yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The November traffic exceeded that of the same month in 1932, when only the Eighth Avenue line was in operation, by 8,068,144 riders.
The American Bar Association launched yesterday a nation-wide drive for the solution of the crime problem.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 15 -- The family of Marinus Van der Lubbe, on learning of the death sentence, demanded, for him in the Reichstag fire trial, announced today that it planned to present a petition for mercy should the death penalty be imposed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Radical legislation in Washington, with continued inflationary threats, is undermining confidence and thus holding back business recovery, Edwin W. Kemmerer, Walker Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, asserted today before the Bond Men's Club.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- The Rev. Carl W. Bothe, who resigned a year ago as priest-incharge of Christ Episcopal Church here, disclosed today that he had been received into the Roman Catholic faith last Wednesday at the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, 465 West 142d Street, Manhattan, where he was baptized and received his first communion as a Catholic.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Miss Anne Tooker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman B. Tooker of Princeton, was presented to society last evening at a dance given by her parents at the Present Day Club.

Recommendations for making more stringent the system of legal education and bar admissions in this State were presented yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the Joint Conference on Legal Education in the State of New York, held at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, is preparing a "bill of particulars" to bear out his recent charges that the Republicans in ''the Assembly under its present leadership have been unduly influenced by power and public utility interests, it was learned last night.

Dr. Alexander Bruno, director of the American Medical Centre in Paris, is sailing today for Europe on the French liner Ile de France with Mrs. Bruno. Others sailing on the ship for Havre, via Plymouth, are:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 9 amounted to 537,503 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 42,078 cars, or 8.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week, when loadings were reduced by the Thanksgiving holiday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The first of the United States' new commercial treaties, the reciprocal trade agreement with Colombia, was signed today by Acting Secretary of State William Phillips and Dr. Fabio Lozano, the Colombian Minister.

Renewed assertions that the administration does not intend to abandon its gold-buying campaign and that currency stabilization has no part in the present monetary program were received somewhat skeptically yesterday by the foreign exchange and domestic speculative markets.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- An enthusiastic audience in the McCarter Theatre tonight greeted the opening performance of "Fiesta," the annual production of the Triangle Club of Princeton University.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The text of Secretary Hull's speech today before the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo follows:

LEIPZIG, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Five German Supreme Court judges will go into retirement after tomorrow's final pleadings to determine the fate of a German, a Dutchman and three Bulgarians accused of burning the Reichstag building and committing high treason.

Parke H. Davis, nationally recognized football historian, announced his annual compilation of outstanding plays of the season yesterday. For the second straight year, the statistics record a scoring play which carried more than the length of the field.

The American Merchant Line refused yesterday to cancel a 25 per cent reduction of wages of wireless operators despite the announcement of the American Radio Telegraphers Association that it had called a strike on all ships of the line.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad today placed in public use its entire new station here, one of the features of its $100,000,000 New York-Washington electrification project.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The Paris exchange market became convinced today that denials from "Washington of stabilization of the dollar were valid, hence the dollar dropped sharply to 16.21 francs, against 16.43 francs yesterday. All of last week's reports about the imminent stabilization of the dollar and the pound seem to have evaporated, and the French again feel that the dollar will be directed downward.
MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 15 -- The Pan-American Conference today took two important steps toward insuring immediate and lasting peace in the Western Hemisphere

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The National Labor Board speeded up its machinery today for an early test of the alleged violation of the Recovery Act in the "company union" election held in the Weirton plants.

Skill in the use of offensive weapons and the value of combat experience were stressed yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, at a military ceremony on Governors Island honoring Tri-State champions of 1933 among pistol and rifle experts of the National Guard and Officers Reserve Corps.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- In an address at the annual convention of the American Mining Congress today, Donald B. Gillies, president of the Corrigan, McKinney Steel Company, stated that the industry was "tremendously satisfied" with its code of fair competition.

If the ordinary citizen has been bewildered by the experiments with, the money standard, the day-to-day reports from Washington bid fair to create absolute mental confusion. This is only setting the stage for next month's Congressional oratory, now scarcely three weeks away.

A.C. Bostwick, a member of the Jockey Club, and his horse Mate, sixth largest money winner in the world, boarded the Cunard liner Berengaria for England yesterday. Also aboard was the steeplechaser Cahirciveen, owned by Mrs. R.V. McKim, Mr. Bostwick's sister.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In considering the matter of education costs in New York State, as recently studied by Governor Lehman's committee on the cost of education, I believe that New York could profit from the experience of Fall River, Mass. Fall River has reduced its school expenditures per pupil in two years from $107.28 to $74.59.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15 -- Fifteen Yale University professors united today in a protest against the government's monetary policy, asserting that existing conditions were untimely for experimenting along the lines of raising price levels by manipulating the currency.
Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner since 1928, announced yesterday that he intended to retire on his $7,500 pension Dec. 31.

Carrying with them the good wishes of the President of the United States, members of the Morristown School ice-hockey team boarded the Cunard liner Berengaria yesterday to sail for a series of games with picked French and Swiss teams.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Although the stock markets again were irregular, there was a firm undertone in most sections today. British funds were the brightest feature, on reinvestment orders following large disbursements. Internationals were still quiet, as were industrials.

A large sum of money had been appropriated by the Musicians' Emergency Fund, Inc., to finance a thousand concerts of the best music in the public high schools of this city, Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, director of the fund, announced yesterday.

The Christmas buying season has advanced sufficiently to indicate that retail sales volume will be above that of last year and in many districts will be the largest since 1930, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., Medium and low price merchandise is selling most readily, with sales of the so-called luxury items and novelties running fully 10 per cent larger than last season.

BOMBAY, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The all-India cricket team made a good start today in the first official test match against England ever played in India. When play was called for the day, India had compiled 212 runs for the loss of nine wickets, against the bowling of some of England's best trundlers.

Carrying with them the good wishes of the President of the United States, members of the Morristown School ice-hockey team boarded the Cunard liner Berengaria yesterday to sail for a series of games with picked French and Swiss teams.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Although the stock markets again were irregular, there was a firm undertone in most sections today. British funds were the brightest feature, on reinvestment orders following large disbursements. Internationals were still quiet, as were industrials.

A large sum of money had been appropriated by the Musicians' Emergency Fund, Inc., to finance a thousand concerts of the best music in the public high schools of this city, Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, director of the fund, announced yesterday.

The Christmas buying season has advanced sufficiently to indicate that retail sales volume will be above that of last year and in many districts will be the largest since 1930, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., Medium and low price merchandise is selling most readily, with sales of the so-called luxury items and novelties running fully 10 per cent larger than last season.

BOMBAY, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The all-India cricket team made a good start today in the first official test match against England ever played in India. When play was called for the day, India had compiled 212 runs for the loss of nine wickets, against the bowling of some of England's best trundlers.

TOD UEBER SCHANGHAI, a German dialogue picture, with Theodor Loos, Else Elster, Robert Eckert, Gerda Maurus, Peter Voss and Georg John; directed by Rolff Randolf; a Siegel-Monopol production. At the seventy-ninth Street Theatre.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 15 -- The Argosy Stable's Chatterfol, a 3-year-old son of Chatterton, won the featured fifth race at the Charles Town track today when he scored by a length and a half over C.C. Smithson's Miss Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt ordered the Navy Department today to give full cooperation to the Coast Guard in a warfare on liquor smuggling as the result of a request by owners of liquor now aboard a British vessel hovering off the lower California coast to be permitted to bring in the cargo under the import quota terms.

Tomorrow Grace Church celebrates the 125th anniversary of the consecration of the original church -- the actual date being Dec. 21, 1808. Daughter of Trinity, and resident for many years within two blocks of the mother church (at 71 Broadway, on the site of the building now occupied by the United States Steel Corporation), Grace Church has its own memories of the pioneer days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- With the approval of President Roosevelt, Chester C. Davis today became Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, succeeding George N. Peek, who relinquished the post to become Mr. Roosevelt's special adviser on commercial policy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- It became evident today that Henry Ford has not yet won his battle against the NRA.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, issued yesterday a denial of a published statement that the Exchange had approved an extensive program of publicity and advertising to enlist public support against Federal regulation of the Exchange.

Futures prices for commodities traded on local exchanges worked to higher levels yesterday in dull dealings. In most cases price movements were restricted to narrow ranges. Cash prices also were higher.

Doubting that recognition of Russia would stop the dissemination of Soviet political doctrines here, Mrs. Rheta Childe Dorr suggested yesterday the establishment of a special agency to detect communistic propaganda in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The only defensive policy which the British Government has in view for selfprotection against excessive depreciation of the dollar is entirely within the zone of tariff activity. It includes no plan whatever for deliberately depreciating the pound or adopting other currency devices as weapons in the battle of the exchanges.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday remained under the influence of January liquidation, but the resistance to a decline helped to lift prices 3 to 6 points after limited fluctuations. The best figures were at the opening after which profit-taking for income-tax purposes and scattered hedging caused a setback of 8 points, only to have a scarcity of contracts disclosed in late covering.

Tony Canzoneri, former lightweight champion of the world, advanced another step in his comeback campaign last night by defeating Cleto Locatelli, ruler of his class in Europe, in the main bout of ten rounds in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- A break in the cold wave reduced today the demand for fresh pork and prices of hogs dropped 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight here, most sales being 5 to 10 cents below yesterday's. Leading packers bought on the decline, and the heavy carryover from the previous day was readily absorbed.
MONTREAL, Dec. 15 -- McGill University's unbeaten Crimson sextet defeated Yale tonight in the first international college hockey game of the season, 5 -- 1, before a crowd of 7,000.
The "Supreme Court of the United States" declined last night to decide the constitutionality of the National Industrial Recovery Act on the ground that "only God knows that."

Indictments charging 120 persons with fraudulent voting in the general elections last month were handed up yesterday by the grand Jury to Judge Corrigan in General Sessions. The names of those accused in the bills were withheld, but bench warrants were issued to the police for service.

The right of labor to organize and bargain collectively without interference from employers or the law, and the complete abolition or drastic limitation of injunctions in labor disputes, were asked in a brief submitted yesterday by Louis Waldman, on behalf of the State Committee of the Socialist party, to the Legislative Commission on the Administration of Justice, at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Dec. 15 -- The honesty of Mrs. Rose Volz of 10 Beachurst Street in returning to its owner a $70,000 pearl necklace she found in Central Park, New York City, has indirectly cost her her job as a nursemaid for a family living on Park Avenue, New York.

All groups of bonds moved irregularly yesterday on the Stock Exchange, United States Government issues closing generally higher, up 5-32 to down the same fraction in response to the slight improvement of the dollar in the foreign exchange market.

Several year-end reorganizations of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange were announced yeeterday. There will be six new firms. Five of these represent reconstitution of existing firms, and three of them will retain their present names.

Dr. Willard L. Thorp, director of the Federal Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, in an address at a joint dinner last night of the American Manufacturers Export Association and the Export Managers Club of New York, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, declared that the problem of economic nationalism and internationalism was one of adjusting them, not of choosing one or the other.

A chime of twelve bells, the hanging of which in the tower has just been completed, will be dedicated tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street. The dedication ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, the rector.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- It was officially announced today that Germany's export surplus for November slumped to 42,900,000 marks currently about $16,066,0001, which is less than half the 98,400,000-mark surplus rolled up during the preceding month and considerably below the average for the year.

A statement urging all Jewish congregations and their leaders in the United States to avail themselves of the opportunity offered by the NKA for the rehabilitation of the Jewish Sabbath was issued yesterday by the Synagogue Council of America.

La Salle Academy defeated Manhattan Prep, 23 to 16, yesterday in the Manhattan College gymnasium in the opening game of the New York division C.H.S.A.A. championship competition. The victors led, 12 to 7, at half-time.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 15 -- France's failure to pay her December war debt instalment of $22,200,927 was explained by the French Government today as based on its conviction that the Lausanne agreement and the Hoover moratorium justified new arrangements 'regarding war debts.

CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 15 -- Mrs. Richard J. Glendon today told authorities investigating the death of her husband that she and her husband had become reconciled several weeks ago after a period of estrangement. She said that it was their plan to return to New York shortly and make their home there with their three children.

WARSAW, Dec. 15 -- The President of the Polish Republic will be a most powerful ruler under the new Polish Constitution, the principles of which at last were officially announced at a meeting of the Government party after several years' preparatory work.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Miss Frances Perkins, Dr. Mary E. Woolley, Mme. Louise Homer and others are patrons of the Mount Holyoke Glee Club's annual concert to be held at the Town Hall tonight.

The old subscribers have been resuming their places on the Metropolitan Opera's books and they are conducting among themselves a quiet but intensive campaign to bring back to the opera audiences those who were forced to cancel subscriptions in the past two seasons.

All the cable and radio companies announced yesterday several adjustments in rates and regulations relating to messages sent from this country, effective on Jan. 1, under amendments to the international telegraph and radio regulations adopted by the Madrid conference several months ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt opposes changes in the Bank-Deposit Insurance Law at the coming session of Congress, it was learned today after he had conferred with officers of the American Banking Association.
The speedy pace that Coach Low Little has put into effect for his Columbia football squad was maintained yesterday as the Lions went through a two-hour drill at the 105th Field Artillery Armory.
Capturing four of the seven individual first places, the City College swimming team opened its season, by subduing Fordham, 40 to 31, last night in the Lavender pool.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Wheat fluctuated erratically today on the Board of Trade, advancing fractionally early, only to break later and then rally sharply when scattered buying appeared. The early upturn was short-lived, and just before the close a selling movement sent the May down to 83 3/4 cents, the lowest mark since the Reconstruction Finance Corporation started to buy gold.

The Jamaica High School sextet gained first place in the P.S.A.L. championship hockey race by scoring a 2-to-0 triumph over Erasmus Hall at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Both goals were registered in the second period.

A ten-point plan under which newspaper publishers would supply news bulletins through the press associations to radio broadcasting Chains, thus ending a long controversy, was made public yesterday by a committee of publishers and representatives of press associations, radio chains and broadcasting associations.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The House of Lords in its high legal capacity upheld in a test case today the disputed "gold clause" in an agreement affecting British holders of certain Belgian bonds. As a result the British holders will receive capital and interest in gold pounds, not in paper pounds which are depreciated in terms of Belgian currency.

Estimates that the Pennsylvania Railroad would earn enough this year to cover a $1 dividend were confirmed yesterday when the company disclosed a net income in the first ten months of the year equal to $1.15 a share on its $50-par stock. The company declared a dividend of 50 cents in March, with the notation that further disbursements would depend on earnings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Chairman Copeland of the Senate Commerce subcommittee which recently concluded hearings on the administration's pure food and drugs measure, drafted by Assistant Secretary Tugwell of the Agriculture Department, began a study today of the transcript of the hearings with a view to making suggested changes in the measure.
Recognizing a need for monetary stabilization, Sir Norman Angell, British economist, in an interview at the Hotel Commodore yesterday suggested a return to a gold standard of a new ratio.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to refer the question of former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade's city pension to the incoming Fusion administration by laying the matter over until Jan. 26.

The Marjorie Post Hutton free food station, operated by the Salvation Army at 455 Tenth Avenue, celebrated its second anniversary last evening. The birthday festivities included half an hour of music by the Salvation Army staff band and songs and Christmas carols by a large group of children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Four million, men are at work on civil works projects, and the goal fixed by President Roosevelt in his announcement of the plan to transfer the unemployed from relief to payrolls has been achieved, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal administrator, stated today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The American Newspaper Guild, formed to "preserve the vocational interests" of newspaper editorial and reportorial workers, "and to improve the conditions under which they work by collective bargaining," was organized here today, following an all-day session of delegates from thirty newspapers.

On an application made by John Harlan Amen, Special Assistant to the United States Attorney General, Federal Judge John C. Knox signed yesterday an injunction restraining the Film Securities Corporation from delivering securities of Loew's, Inc., to any purchaser.
TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Nelson Alien on a charge of distributing unsolicited advertising circulars to a private residence in Jersey City.

Taxicab owners and operator have a right to keep the $60,000 collected as a city tax at 5 cents a ride before the levy was declared invalid. This ruling was made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in dismissing a suit by Jacob Kramer and others for a judgment that the fund should be devoted to charitable purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Three committees representing groups of the petroleum industry called at the Department of the Interior today to make objections to the oil marketing agreement signed by twenty-four leading companies and many others.

A strong move by the stewards of the Jockey Club to put New York racing on a better basis of competition with the commercialized sport in some other States became known yesterday when Algernon Daingerfield, an official of the club, announced that there would be an alteration of the rule governing handicaps.

GENEVA, Dec. 15 -- Figures for the first world-wide limitation of anything in history were published today by the League of Nations. They give down to the last gram the amount of every dangerous narcotic drug -- fifteen in all-allowed for medicine for 1934 in every inhabited area of the earth, including a total of 188 regions and not forgetting either the Fiji or Falkland Islands.

Although a total of $8,796,222 of new State and municipal bonds has been posted for award next week through competitive bidding, only a small percentage is expected to attract bids from New York bankers. This week new bonds in the amount of $5,548,101 were up for bids, but only one comparatively small issue reached investors.

Helen Keller, the famous blind and deaf scholar and writer, is living in seclusion in Rosshire, Scotland, so that she can nurse her lifelong friend and teacher, Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy, and coach her on the Braille system, whereby the blind can read.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 -- Balloting for collective bargaining representatives at the Weirton Steel Company plants "exceeded all expectations," with 9,317 employes casting votes, John Larkin, chairman of the rules committee handling the election announced today.

Several persons have written to Viking Press pointing out that the plot of the motion picture "Only Yesterday" is similar to the plot of Stefan Zweig's novelette, "Letter From an Unknown Woman." These similarities were bought and paid for by Universal Pictures.

With nearly 120,000 men already at world on civil works jobs, the local Civil Works Administration announced yesterday that 7,000 more men would be added to the payrolls immediately and the entire program speeded up so as to employ the entire quota of 200,000 jobless allotted to New York City by the Federal Civil Works Administration.

Prizes ranging from $2 to $40 were awarded to 208 students in public and parochial schools by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in its annual essay contest yesterday. About 375,000 children competed, writing essays on the subject: "How can I assist in keeping the streets, parks and playgrounds of my city clean and wholesome?"
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Soviet patience is growing rather thin about the continued arrests of Soviet citizens in Manchukuo.

After speculators had swallowed their early disappointment that the government did not resume its advance in the posted price of gold the share market had little support or encouragement yesterday. Those traders who have stubbornly clung to the theory that all domestic speculative markets must rise or fall as the administration gives the signal by its gold operations retired quickly when the unchanged gold price was announced.

The Bayside Tennis Club team continued to lead the league in the metropolitan Class B squash tennis tournament last night as a result of its third, successive victory in as many starts. Bayside turned back the New York A.C. by 5 to 0 at the Winged Foot courts.

To the Editor of The New York Times. I call your attention to Article III of the proposed liquor creed of the Young Men's Christian Association: "We will refrain from encouraging young women to drink."
ROME, Dec. 15 -- The Vatican denies that any negotiations are in progress with the German Government concerning the status and treatment of Catholics of Jewish blood.
Ten properties were sold at auctions in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. The list included three upper Fifth Avenue parcels, which were bid in by the plaintiffs. The list follows:

NO words sound more clumsy and studied, ugly and obtrusive, than old slang lost from speech but found moldering in a book with all vitality gone. There are many such black bits -- mixed with good lively words that even in their old age have a trick in them -- in the historical parts of Eric Partridge's "Slang Today and Yesterday" (Macmillan, $4).

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 -- Senator Huey P. Long today requested the withdrawal of his name from the Washington Social Register because, he said, Washington society never learned to dunk corn pone properly in potlikker and had otherwise disappointed him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt continued conferences with advisers on monetary questions today, but it was intimated that the conversations represented merely a check-up and that too much significance should not be attached to them in connection with future moves under the gold policy.

The fund for the relief of New York's Neediest lost a little ground yesterday in comparison with last year -- but only a little. The determined resistance of givers to the decline, which was so alarming a week ago, is still strongly in evidence.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Discontent over the wine importation concessions made to France by Washington was expressed by American business circles here today.

IT may be that one ancient sport is extending, unconsciously, a helping hand to another. Lawn tennis can boast of almost as great an antiquity as polo. Tennis first was played, according to some histories, in monasteries of monks and the courtyards of ancient nobles and kings. The start of polo is lost somewhere in the first recorded pages of history.

The National Council of American Shipbuilders filed protest yesterday with President Roosevelt against the terms of contracts for the construction of nine new Coast Guard vessels, which, it alleges, would put privately owned shipbuilding yards under a handicap in competing against navy yards for the work.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Ben Coltrin, professional of the Lake Mercer Country Club, San Francisco, displayed spectacular putting and approaching to take a two-stroke lead in the California open golf championship over the rugged Lakewood Country Club course today.

Dr. Oliver M.W. Sprague, Professor of Banking and Finance at Harvard Business School, told the Harvard Business Club of New York last night that recovery from the depression demands more "guts" on the part of the business community.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A new type of armored and unsinkable speedboat of revolutionary design, it was learned today, is being built by Hubert Scott-Paine for open-sea bombing experiments by the Royal Air Force.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Eduard Benes, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, today continued his conversations with Joseph Faul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister, and with other French political leaders. He paid an official visit to President Albert Lebrun and had a long conversation with Henry Berenger, President of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- As the hum and the roar of the baseball mart died down and the club owners scattered back to their ball parks, a recheck today disclosed that forty-five major league players had been shuffled about to new scenes in the trading and selling spree since the close of the 1933 season.
The United Real Estate Owners Association, Stewart Browne, president, will hold its annual meeting next Monday at 8:30 P.M. in the Hotel Biltmore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The decision of the Federal Government to permit the immediate importation of 5,000,000 gallons of Canadian whisky is evidence of an enlightened governing body's interest in the correction of evils arising as a result of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Loft, Inc., reports for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $41,884, after charging off $365,893 of depreciation and amortization. This was equal to 4 cents a share on 1,073,259 capital shares. It compared with $58,383, or 5 cents a share, in the same period last year.

COLUMBIA, Tenn., Dec. 15 -- The body of Cord Cheek, a 20-year-old Negro, whom the grand jury had refused to indict after his arrest for an attempted attack on an 11-year-old girl, was found hanging from the limb of a cedar tree near here tonight.

Issues Spring Hosiery Card. Nine new shades designated as gray, beige and sun tones, feature the Spring color card for hosiery issued yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association. The grays comprise "nudawn," a light neutral hue; mouette, a medium gray of beige cast and taupesan, a high-style taupe.

The largest and most important real estate transaction in the Times Square section for many months was closed yesterday when Louis Adler, builder and operator, bough from the Trinity Church Corporation the fee to the northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue and took a long-term lease on the southwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue from the same corporation.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia scored the city's past condemnation proceedings last night and suggested to a large meeting in the Richmond Hill High School in Queens that the people of that borough unite in forming a systematized program of planning for the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Organization of more than 3,000 consumers' councils throughout the United States, whose activities would range from hearing price complaints to promoting symphony orchestras, was outlined here today as an objective of the Consumers' Advisory Board of the Recovery Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Serious consideration is being given by some of President Roosevelt's advisers on liquor control to a proposal for a general amnesty for bootleggers and other holders of illicit liquor by which under immunity from arrest and prosecution they would turn over their stocks to legal dealers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Noting a "distinctly better tone to business," The Chicago Daily News, in a frontpage editorial today, calls upon "all patriotic Americans" to support President Roosevelt in his exploration of "the possibilities of a stabilization agreement between Great Britain and the United States."

Charges against two unnamed ticket brokers accused of violating the ticket sale regulations were upheld yesterday by a specially convened quorum of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority. The evidence against the brokers was ordered sent to the National Recovery Administration in Washington for review.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Finding themselves in a minority of two against nearly 200, Senators Joseph Caillaux and Marcel Regnier have abandoned their attempt to transform the Chautemps government's financial proposals into a real act of deflation.

Mrs. F.H. LaGuardia, wife of the Mayor-elect, gave out yesterday the first of more than 5,000 baskets of food distributed to the poor and needy of Brownsville at a store at 1,478 Pitkin Avenue, corner of Grafton Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The framework for a world-wide minimum scale of wheat prices was completed tonight after an exhaustive four-day survey of present conditions and past trends by the international wheat marketing committee.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- Trading stayed within narrow limits on the Boerse today, but the general tone was firm and remained so until the close, despite the unfavorable foreign trade balance for November. Siemens Halske rose 5 points on a rumor that the dividend for the year ended on Sept. 30 would be higher than that of the year before, but there was no confirmation and half of the gain was lost.

Affidavits by George S. Van. Schaick, defending his acts as rehabilitator of guaranteed mortgage companies, were submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in answer to the application by Max D. Steuer in behalf of Joseph Nemerov, counsel for the Mortgage Bond Protectorate, for permission to sue to remove him.

The group of economists who, on Nov. 24, attacked the Roosevelt monetary policies and urged a return to the gold standard took steps yesterday to enlarge their organization and to, increase their activities against inflation.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 -- After a conference lasting more than eighteen hours, employes of the Cuban Electric Company, who met officials of the company, decided to postpone for thirty days a strike scheduled for today that would have thrown the island into darkness.

Paul Whiteman and his orchestra presented their "Sixth Experiment in Modern American Music" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The concert was for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help, Diocese of New York, and there was a distinguished and friendly on hand.

The Eastern railroad presidents' conference appointed a committee yesterday to investigate a proposal by W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, that the managements and labor unite on a national legislative program. The committee was not empowered to meet labor at this time, but, as a result of the committee's deliberations, it, or a succeeding group, may assume the task.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation agreed today to advance funds for relief of distress against the security of guaranteed mortgage certificates and guaranteed mortgages under a plan advanced by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Following is the text of Acting Secretary Morgenthau's statement on the preliminary report of a subcommittee of the Committee on Ways and Means relating to methods of preventing the avoidance and evasion of the Internal Revenue Laws:

The money market was dull and quotations unchanged for all classifications. Stock Exchange call loans held at 1 per cent, while a small amount of counter funds traded at 7/8. Maturity money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

The special and vital place that the fund for the Neediest Cases has in the welfare work of New York is emphasized in a memorandum adopted by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and forwarded yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to Berlin, who returned yesterday for a consultation on the disarmament negotiations, attended a meeting of the Cabinet's disarmament committee today. He gave the Ministers reports of his recent interviews with Chancellor Hitler and Foreign Minister von Neurath and received instructions concerning the line to take on disarmament when he returns to Germany.

New York's blanket of snow was transformed into an ice coating yesterday by sleet, which began falling at about 7 A.M. in a temperature of 19 degrees above zero and continued intermittently throughout the day.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann will give a tea dance today in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Katharine Schuyler Cammann.
Long Island University's basketball team scored its seventh triumph of the season by turning back Brooklyn Polytechnic, 37 to 12, last night at Odd Fellows Hall, Brooklyn.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Completion of the Michelson speed of light measurements was announced today. The instruments showed an almost unbelievable record of speed fluctuations.

Very Popular Art. Mickey Mouse has been admitted, to full citizenship in the domain of art. With others of WALT DISNEY'S cartoons, to the number of 100, Mickey has just been hung on the walls of the Chicago Art Institute.

The art collection of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick of Chicago, daughter of John D. Rockefeller Sr., is to be sold at auction here at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on the afternoons of' Jan. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6, by order of the Chicago Title and Trust Company, executor.
BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Doctors literally held their breath today and hoped for the recovery of Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto hockey player, who underwent a major operation yesterday.
After spending several hours yesterday with the "social revolution" this reviewer is satisfied that the "revolution" won't get very far in America if it has to depend on the efforts of its artists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The sale of the remaining household effects of Admiral and Mrs. George Dewey ended today.

The Baltimore Orioles strengthened their hold on first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League at the New York Coliseum last night by defeating the Bronx Hockey Club, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 1,500. In a closely fought contest, the Orioles came through with a savage assault in the final period to win.

The second of the season's Friday Assemblies, for young married couples and debutantes of a few years ago, took place last night in the Crystal Room of the RitzCarlton. The guests were received by Mrs. Elisha Dyer and Miss Virginia Cowperthwaite, members of the dance committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Desiring, as he said, to correct misapprehensions arising from a statement that some of the State's emergency taxes will be repealed, G. William Magly, chairman of the State budget advisory committee said today that these taxes will have to be collected during the rest of the fiscal year "in order to pay off the accumulated deficit."
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Completion of the Michelson speed of light measurements was announced today. The instruments showed an almost unbelievable record of speed fluctuations.

Very Popular Art. Mickey Mouse has been admitted, to full citizenship in the domain of art. With others of WALT DISNEY'S cartoons, to the number of 100, Mickey has just been hung on the walls of the Chicago Art Institute.

The art collection of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick of Chicago, daughter of John D. Rockefeller Sr., is to be sold at auction here at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on the afternoons of' Jan. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6, by order of the Chicago Title and Trust Company, executor.
BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Doctors literally held their breath today and hoped for the recovery of Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto hockey player, who underwent a major operation yesterday.
After spending several hours yesterday with the "social revolution" this reviewer is satisfied that the "revolution" won't get very far in America if it has to depend on the efforts of its artists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The sale of the remaining household effects of Admiral and Mrs. George Dewey ended today.

The Baltimore Orioles strengthened their hold on first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League at the New York Coliseum last night by defeating the Bronx Hockey Club, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 1,500. In a closely fought contest, the Orioles came through with a savage assault in the final period to win.

The second of the season's Friday Assemblies, for young married couples and debutantes of a few years ago, took place last night in the Crystal Room of the RitzCarlton. The guests were received by Mrs. Elisha Dyer and Miss Virginia Cowperthwaite, members of the dance committee.
Coming from behind in the last few minutes, the St. Francis College basketball team defeated Manhattan, 27 to 23, in a hard-fought contest at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

BELGRADE, the capital of Yugoslavia, flew the national colors of Bulgaria and heard the national Bulgarian anthem for the first time in more than two decades last week, when King Boris and Queen Giovanna arrived from Sofia for a visit with King Alexander and Queen Marie.

WILLIAM TATEM TILDEN 2d, once of Germantown, Pa., now of almost any city in the world which can boast a halfway decent lawn tennis court, is planning a bit of rewriting on present-day volume of non-fiction. Though Tilden has concerned himself in the past with the art of writing, to his own amusement and the consternation of tennis officials, he is confining himself in the present instance to a revision of a title.

CLOSE to 6,000 persons on many a Summer night sat or stood in the New York Hippodrome to hear opera by young voices this year at prices from 25 to 99 cents. The big theatre's 5,200 seats continued to be filled nightly during torrid weeks that out attendance at the open-air Stadium and artificially refrigerated movies.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The next big art show at Burlington House, to open in January, will be an exhibition of British art throughout the centuries.

HIDDEN away in back courts or tucked between newer, higher buildings on side streets, more than 800 old wooden houses are still to be found in different parts of Manhattan. Today these survivals of a modest era appear out of place and slightly wistful in a city boasting lofty skyscrapers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Subscriptions to the Treasury's Dec. 15 offering of 2 1/4 per cent one-year certificates amounted to $2,806,779,500, of which $992,496,500 was allocated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would it not be well to change the status of our Vice President? If anything should happen to President Roosevelt what of Vice President Garner, our seemingly "forgotten man"?

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15. THAT flaming symbol of male rebellion and genius, Charles Strickland, made his first appearance before an American audience on Tuesday night when the Pasadena Community Theatre presented Edith Ellis's dramatization of "The Moon and Sixpence," with Ian Keith as the smoldering Strickland.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- The Nazi campaign against the world's best seller has suffered a decisive setback through the elimination of the German Christians as a political factor in the German Protestant church conflict.

THE old educational assumption that a student should do well in a course whether be liked it or not is being disproved by findings of the Adjustment Service of New York City, a public vocational and avocational testing and counseling bureau.

The record of Grace Church and its influence for more than a century on old and modern New York were commemorated yesterday by Episcopal leaders at the 125th anniversary luncheon in the WaldorfAstoria.

Bernon S. Prentice, chairman of the Davis Cup Committee, has accepted the chairmanship of a Sports Participation Committee, which has been organized to help in the $4,000,000 Citizens Family Welfare campaign, according to an announcement from James G. Blaine.
TOKYO, Dec. 16. -- Premier Saito this afternoon obtained imperial sanction for the appointment of Hiroshi Saito as Ambassador to Washington subject to the United States Government's agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Pointing to "grave danger of armed conflict with Europe," R. D. Blumenfeld, American-reared English editor, yesterday called upon President Roosevelt to use dictatorial powers "to bring the world to its senses."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- A desire to force the world gold price up a point nearer the figure fixed by the Treasury for newly-mined domestic gold was given today as one reason for the recent big increase in administration purchases of the metal abroad.

Scores of brokers and investment bankers here are busy filling out the applications required if they wish to continue after Jan. 1 as directors of member banks of the Federal Reserve System. Indications are that, in spite of the rigorous examination they must undergo, only a small minority will voluntarily resign from bank boards without first asking the Federal Reserve Board in Washington for permission to remain.

HE who takes his movies seriously, the hard-bitten fan who stands in the queue night after night -- to him we would not dare suggest "Albert Goes Through," for to him this bold and delicious satire by J.B. Priestley might seem sacrilege.
Grants aggregating $622,050 were made to various public administration enterprises during 1932 by the Spelman Fund of New York, according to the report for that year made public yesterday.
Members of the New York Branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance have taken over the performance of "Die Meistersinger von Nunrberg" for the afternoon of Jan. 18 at the Metropolitan Opera.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- The Boerse closed the week with a somewhat irregular but generally buoyant trend. The turnover was small, but optimistic business reports, the new Dutch - German trade agreement and the friendly tone of the Swiss President's remarks regarding the new bond interest transfer regulations contributed to the market's confidence.

A variation of the European system of police surveillance which would require out-of-town visitors who have been convicted of crimes to register at Police Headquarters on their arrival in New York received the approval yesterday of Police Commissioner James S. Bolan.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16. -- While many foreheads are wrinkled over the outcome of Ernest T. Weir's defiance of the National Labor Board, he is quietly reading "David Copperfield" for the 101st time.

HOLLYWOOD. RATHER elaborate preparations are under way at MGM for Irving Thalberg's production of "The Merry Widow," which, the studio believes, will be its most important contribution to next year's screen list.

Four of the players who probably will be in the line-up when Mount St. Michael's High School opens its basketball season on Tuesday against St. Simon Stock School were among the leading members of the undefeated and untied Mount St. Michael's football squad during the recently concluded campaign.

DANCE themes in modern art have been assembled by the College Art Association and constitute an exhibition that is current in the Reinhardt Galleries. Many artists, both American and European, are listed, represented by oils, water-colors, drawings, prints and sculpture -- a hundred items in all.

Assets involving more than $6,100,000,000 and plant worth in excess of $5,200,000,000 would be affected by proposed legislation to create a Federal Communications Commission with full jurisdiction over all interstate and foreign communications, and embodying features that will permit mergers between domestic telegraph companies handling foreign record communications of every sort.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The American Iron and Steel Institute reported to the NRA today a substantial increase in payrolls in the face of a 4 per cent decline in ingot production.

To the Drama Editor: "Peace on Earth" cannot be dismissed with complaints that it is old stuff and not very well produced. It is the first play of the season which has moral content and sticks to its subject.

THE author of this book confesses that once in his early youth he contemplated writing a school composition on girls' garters, but something told him that he had better not. One shudders to think what might have happened had he written that composition and handed it to his teacher.

Swift Co. report for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28 a consolidated net income of $5,882,582 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and reserve of $4,267,000 for declines in inventory prices. This is equal to $1 a share on the 5,895,527 shares of capital stock held by the public.

AT this moment the thermometer may register far below freezing point, yet some of us are thinking of those climes in which the mercury is rising to the other end of the shaft. You are going cruising -- perhaps -- into lands where the warm sun beckons.

NORMAN, Okla. A PIONEER, effort in educational cooperation with the NRA is the directed leisure program now being tried by University of Oklahoma. Convinced that the problem of utilizing the free time of the American people as a result of shorter working weeks is second in importance only to that of putting the unemployed back to work, President William Eennett.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The New York Giants, led by Harry Newman, Michigan's all-America quarterback in 1932, will battle the Chicago Bears for the national professional football championship at Wrigley Field tomorrow. A crowd of more than 20,000 is expected to see the opening kick-off at 1:45 P.M. (Central standard time).

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 16. -- Despite all denials, conferences concerning the sales of Boliden mine shares are said to have been held between the Consolidated Gold Fields of South Africa and representatives of the estate of the late Ivar Kreuger and of the Kreuger Toll Company.
THE new Lincoln models for 1934, introduced to the public yesterday, are presented in two series, both with the same V-type twelve-cylinder engine of 150 horsepower.

THE most fundamental question for human progress is, "Who are being born?" If, for example, the children born during the next seventy-five years all had intelligence as low as 10 per cent of them will, most of civilization would vanish.

JUSSERAND had apparently not written, by the time of his death in July. 1932, all that he intended to say about his experiences as French Ambassador at Washington during the administrations of Theodore Roosevelt and Taft, and his reminiscences break off somewhat abruptly with comnents upon the personality of the first of those Presidents.
ATHENS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Greek lawyers for Samuel Insull, deposed Chicago utilities king, began a search today for new means to save their client from the United States authorities.

IN cities, villages and country districts in many parts of the country those phases of education calculated to prepare children for life in the modern world have been curtailed or wiped out! These facts are brought out sharply in recent records of the Office of Education and the National Education Association.

THE long-deferred hope that the City of New York will have a master plan to guide its development is again renewed. Mayor-elect Fiorello H. LaGuardia has expressed his interest in the project; possibly one of the first acts of the incoming administration will be the revival of a department of city planning.
Director Survey of School Finance of the U.S. Office of Education.

THIS very short story -- it is really little more than a sketch -- displays a simple-minded and rather middle-aged sense of humor which does not disdain jokes about mothers-in-law and husbands who are too addicted to fishing; nothing could be further removed from the more sparkling kind of wit now generally fashionable.

Mary Pickford yesterday announced that she had signed a contract with Adolph Zukor, president of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, for a stage appearance at the Paramount Theatre during Christmas week. The announcement was made in Miss Pickford's suite at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel following a luncheon with Mr. Zukor, who sponsored the screen actress's first feature-length pictures.

THIS is by all odds the most distinguished-looking book we have had from The Printing House of Leo Hart in Rochester, a recent entry in the field of fine bookmaking. More than that, this new edition of the immortal Travels, which Mr. Komroff calls "the one unique record in all travel literature," is one of the handsomest books of the year.

DUBLIN, Dec. 15 -- Irish industry for the Irish is a new slogan raised by graduates of the National University of Ireland at a convocation meeting this week at which alarm was expressed that Irish University graduates are not finding scope for their training in employment in any of the important industries being established here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Friends of free public education in Illinois are determined to make their cause a major issue at a third special session of the General Assembly, which is expected to convene early in the new year. The Governor, who restricted the pending session to liquor control, has a long list of matters upon which various, groups of citizens are clamoring for action.

NOTWITHSTANDING the thousands of sermons Harry Emerson Fosdick has preached during the thirty years of his ministry, this is the first collection of sermons he has ever put between book covers. He has published in that time a dozen volumes and many magazine articles and pamphlets, but his sermons heretofore have not appeared in print for general circulation.

Plans for the formation of the Federated Textile Industries, Inc., are rapidly being completed and the organization will represent "a new and forward step in trade association leadership," according to James A. Goldsmith, president of the Silk Association of America.

Permanent business stabilization in the United States hinges upon the assumption of two functions by the government that of forcing the constant circulation of money through non-debt accumulating expenditures, and that of acting as general stabilizer for the economic system by greater control over concentrated industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Even if the lost export market for agricultural products could be quickly revived by tariff revision, trade agreements or international debt readjustments, the farm problem cannot be solved without drastic curtailment of production in obedience to the "remorseless" law of supply and demand.

WHY is it that the spirit of peoples today, reflected in the policy of governments, seems bent on national isolation rather than on international cooperation? A serious world -- and certainly we have a serious one just now -- must ask itself this question and try to answer it. Why it is that financial interchange is more difficult, not easier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Broad revisions of many fluid milk marketing agreements approved or pending before the Agricultural Adjustment Administration were foreshadowed tonight with the resignation of Clyde L. King as chief of the AAA dairy section.

A QUIET province of Austria came into the news again recently with the escape to Italy of Prince Bernard of Saxe-Meiningen and his wife, Princess Margot. German Nazis, from the Castle Pitzelstaetten, in Carinthia. They had been held there in custody of the Austrian political police for flaunting the swastika on their car and helping to organize Austrian Carinthians in behalf of Hitlerism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The last paragraph from the letter of Benedict Wise read as follows: "So far as the so-called flight of capital is concerned, the taxing power of the nation should be ruthlessly exercised by taking a large percentage of the income derived from such investments."

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 16. -- General Johnson took a rap today at those who assert that the NRA is failing. He stated that out of about 3,000,000 employers under the Blue Eagle only forty-eight had had their insignias taken away.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 15. -- If the latent Cabinet crisis in Hungary soon develops, as seems probable, the real reason will be Admiral Horthy's resentment at being treated as a "Hungarian Hindenburg" by his Premier, General Goemboes.

THE New English Singers, the People's Chorus, the Dessoff Choirs, the Wiener Sangerknaben, and various glee clubs will contribute to the pre-holiday week of Christmas music. On Thursday evening, Hans Lange will begin his period as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony pending the arrival of Toscanini.

THOUGH it is contrary to the policy of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe to have any stars, it is inevitable that certain personalities should emerge above their fellows. After this ballet's season opens on Friday night at the St. James Theatre, several personalities may be outstanding, but in advance of that date there is one that looms head and shoulders higher than all the rest.

In support of the annual appeal for the Neediest, THE TIMES is pleased to he able to publish elsewhere in this issue striking testimony to the practical value of the Fund. Representatives of several of the charitable organizations which have direct knowledge of the various "cases," and are conversant with the way in which the money for relief is applied, write of the indispensable place which this charity has come to have in New York.

Joseph Nemerov, counsel for the Mortgage Bond Protectorate, on whose behalf Max D. Steuer is suing to remove George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, as rehabilitator of guaranteed mortgage companies, announced yesterday that he would apply in the Federal court tomorrow for the appointment of trustees to look after the interest of certificate holders.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- France, which is justly proud of the originality and devotion of its scientists, has adopted a program by which it is hoped to insure that they will have competent successors and to en- courage those who are fitted, to dedicate themselves to scientific re- search.

BANKERS' hoars are coming to industry -- hours of bank ex-ecutives, I mean, not those of bank clerks -- and coming rapidly. Fifty years ago we were trying to reduce a twelve-hour day to ten, with a six-day week. Now our objective is the six-hour day and the five-day week.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 16. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh returned to the United States today after a five-month aerial survey that took them across the North and South Atlantic. They alighted here at 1:21 P.M. after an 800-mile flight from San Pedro de Macoris, Dominican Republic.

THE elimination of the outside marking on third-class carriages of the Great Western Railway in England, thus indicating a trend toward one-class travel in the United Kingdom, emphasizes the difference between railroad accommodations in the United States and those in Europe.

NOT only is Mr. Hilalre Belloc French in blood and French in upbringing -- the last and the greatest of the musketeers. He is the three musketeers rolled regally into one. There is the huge bulk of Porthos, hurling facts that are mountains with the ease of a Goliath.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Tumbling exercises helped eliminate football injuries at Princeton during the past two seasons, according to Dr. J.E. Raycroft of the health and physical education department at that university.
GENEVA, Dec. 15. -- By the process of self-elimination, the League of Nations seems to have been gradually becoming during the past year a league of democratic nations.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. THE Autumn season tapers to an end. At beginning the Winter season promises not too well. In a fourth and final week at the Shubert, Conrad Nagel and "The First Apple" are wearing out what for a while seemed an inexhaustible vogue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The New York Central Railroad Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue and reissue from time to time not exceeding $75,000,000 of short-term promissory notes. As collateral security the commission authorized the road to pledge and repledge all or any part of $175,000,000 of its refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, Series C.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- So popular is the national lottery that it is still difficult to obtain tickets for the future drawing's. Every one is not enthusiastic, however. Barkeepers, theatre managers, taxi chauffeurs and sports promoters are complaining that the lottery is cutting into their receipts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 . -- The United States held aloof tonight from any formal agreement with France on liquor quotas until it had learned the extent of concessions reported to have been made by the French. Government in its announced purpose to raise the import licenses on United States products, an increase in the importation of which was proposed as the basis for an advance in the amount of French wines coming to America.

A decision construing provisions of the recent deficiency judgment law in mortgage foreclosures and suggesting a means of working out the statute in fairness both to mortgagee and mortgagor, has been handed down by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins in a suit by the City Bank-Farmers Trust Company against the Combined Real Estate Interests as owner of three five-story apartments at 112 to 124 East Eightyfirst Street.

SOCIAL service, new style, today more than ever challenges the imagination and capabilities of women, and it demands, according to Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, who has long been identified with this field of endeavor, an almost professional training and status on the part of the worker.
JASCHA HEIFETZ, when he brings his violin to the microphone this evening, does not anticipate the same "terrific ordeal" he encountered at his broadcast debut several years ago.

A hearing was held yesterday into the assertion that between 130 and 150 depositors of the defunct Berardini State Bank in Mulberry Street, through misrepresentation or misunderstanding, had employed a lawyer to recover some of their money under an objectionable 5 per cent lien agreement.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. Editors of trade publications throughout the United States, spokesmen for the businesses and industries that their journals represent, have reported substantial gains made in the year now ending and are highly optimistic for 1934.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec., 13. -- Out of the row over hospitals resulting from the application of Charity Hospita for a Public Works loan of approximately $10,000,000, has come the announcement that hospital care at the cost of $9 yearly is to be available for the thousands of Orleanians who need it most.
